title: Judge Reaffirms Housing Pact With Yonkers
description: The Federal judge in the Yonkers desegregation case yesterday refused to release City Council members from their commitment not to appeal his ruling requiring the city to build public housing in white neighborhoods.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Pre-Hippie Standards

title: Greenspan Wary of Bill on Markets
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board gave Congress a message today that some legislators wanted to hear and some did not: do not rush to pass legislation to avert another market crash.

title: Books of The Times; Uncertain Absence Under the Nose
description: The Mustache By Emmanuel Carrere Translated by Lanie Goodman. 146 pages. Charles Scribner's Sons (hard cover), $17.95. Collier Books (paperback), $7.95.

title: American National Petroleum CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Japan and U.S. Still at Odds Over Beef and Citrus Trade
description: As a four-year-old trade agreement expired today, negotiators from the United States and Japan were unable to settle differences over the amount of beef and citrus products that American farmers would be allowed to export to Japan.

title: Sports of The Times; 'My Nephew Says 'Boom' ''
description: JUST call her Sally Yukon. Her real name doesn't matter. All you need to know is that she roots for the Boston Red Sox in the summer and the University of Connecticut in the winter, and suffers.

title: Wyandotte Journal; Where the Muskrat Is a Delicacy for Lent
description: Muskrats are the moral equivalent of fish for otherwise observant Roman Catholics in this blue-collar town just south of Detroit. Every Friday in Lent, when church rules call for abstinence from meat, these Catholics gather in family kitchens, fraternal halls and a few restaurants for meals featuring the little swamp rodent as the main dish.

title: Fair Chance in Chinatown
description: The Asian children who attend the Garment Industry Day Care Center in New York's Chinatown are outside the American mainstream in two ways. Their immigrant parents are very poor; and nobody in the family knows much English. By the time they're 5 years old, though, those kids have taken a crash course in America. Not only can they speak English (the more precocious read and write it, too), but they are at home with American holidays and habits, ''Jimmy Crack Corn'' and the fine art of finger painting.

title: Eastern and Texas Air Sued by Machinists
description: The machinists' union of Eastern Air Lines Inc. yesterday sued Eastern; its parent, the Texas Air Corporation, and 14 other defendants. The union contends that the two companies are engaged in a ''systematic, ongoing campaign'' to dismantle Eastern, in violation of Federal labor and securities laws.

title: Swiss Businessman Declines To Testify on Pipeline Project
description: Bruce Rappaport, the Swiss businessman who was active in the proposal to build an oil pipeline from Iraq to Jordan, has changed his mind and decided not to give a deposition to the special prosecutor investigating Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, The Washington Post reported in its Friday's issue.

title: Dynamic Homes INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $112,900 related to writedowns in the carrying value of several company-owned lots, a loss on the sale of an idle plant and an increase in allowance for bad debt. c-Net income and share earnings equals less than one cent a share.

title: Review/Art; Setting Free the Images In Big Beams of Wood
description: Ursula von Rydingsvard was born in 1942 in a village in north central Germany. Her father was a Polish peasant farmer with a feeling for wood who had been brought to Germany to labor on a collective farm. After the war, the parents and their seven children spent seven years in German refugee camps for Poles as they inched their way north to the port city of Bremerhaven, from where they sailed for the United States. The barracks in which they lived were made of wood. When Ms. von Rydingsvard became a sculptor in the mid-1970's, wood was her material. Her subject is memory.

title: U.S. Says Qatar Has Stinger, Raising Fear of Missile Spread
description: The Persian Gulf state of Qatar has illegally obtained an American-made anti-aircraft weapon, the Stinger missile, that is only rarely sold in the region, the State Department said today.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY JAPANESE COMEDY

title: Walton Says Both Jet Lines Need Help
description: In a candid assessment of the Jets' chances for a season still more than five months away, Coach Joe Walton said today that his club's problems remained with the lines: the need for bigger, better offensive lineman and a continuing search for a pass-rushing defensive lineman.

title: Kimmins Environmental reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Art; Ninth-Century Views Of the Constellations
description: Readers who have rushed to have their horoscopes read at some moment of crisis in their lives should proceed forthwith to see the Aratea manuscript that has been lent by the University of Leiden, in the Netherlands, to the Pierpont Morgan Library. Though it is from the layman's point of view primarily a picture-book of the constellations, together with the mythological images that are associated with them, it also has a zodiacal interest. Names like Leo and Aquarius, and many others besides, will henceforth have a new echo for every visitor.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Sugar Ray Leonard was named an adviser to the United States Olympic boxing staff by Don Hull, president of the U. S.A. Amateur Boxing Federation. Leonard, winner of three world professional titles, won a gold medal in the 1976 Olympics in Montreal. . . . One day after meeting with officials trying to fill the basketball coaching job at Texas, Lon Kruger has decided to remain at Kansas State. He accepted a new contract, extending by a year his four-year contract. Kruger finished his second season at Kansas State with a 25-9 record after losing to Kansas in the Midwest Regional final last Sunday. . . . Joseph Faraldo, the harness trainer suspended after one of his horses competed at Roosevelt Raceway Nov. 4, 1985 while under the illegal drug prednisolone, will have to serve his 60-day suspension beginning April 11, the New York State Racing and Wagering Board ruled.

title: Quick & Reilly Group INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
P & F Industries INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest year share earnings is after payment of $450,000, or 16 cents a share, in preferred stock dividends.

title: Kaufman & Broad Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Frisch's Restaurants INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 6
description: Share earnings are restated to reflect a stock dividend issued in January 1988.

title: Conrail Engineer Is Charged With Lying in Crash Inquiry
description: The man sentenced to prison on state charges in an Amtrak crash that killed 16 people was indicted today on Federal charges that he lied to Government officials about taking drugs the day of the accident.

title: Potvin Is Honored; Capitals Are Routed
description: Denis Potvin spoke wistfully of the sacrifices made by his compatriots on the four Islander Stanley Cup teams. Then, knowing that he will never play another regular-season game here, he said that he thought this Islander team could win another championship before it marched on without him.

title: Saturday Morning Fever: S.A.T. Class
description: On Saturday mornings, Luz Velazquez, a junior at the Manhattan Center for Math and Science in East Harlem, resists the temptation to sleep late or watch television. Instead, she and 19 of her high school classmates return to school for an intense coaching course aimed at raising their scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Test.

title: Haitian Rock
description: Coupe Cloue will play Haitian rock tonight at Sounds of Brazil, 204 Varick Street (243-4940). Sets begin at 11 P.M., and 1 and 2:30 A.M.; there is a $16 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Trucking Lines Reach Contract With Teamsters
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the trucking industry reached tentative agreement today on a three-year national freight contract covering 200,000 drivers and warehouse workers.

title: Market Place; Cautious Outlook On AIDS Drugs
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS of progress in research on drugs and vaccines to combat AIDS have come thick and fast, sometimes generating dramatic gains in the stocks of small companies. But many gains have been followed by equally steep setbacks, and experts who follow drug and biotechnology stocks caution that payoffs are unlikely before the 1990's.

title: Review/Dance; Movement Ideas by Brazilian Troupe
description: Fernando Bujones, Yoko Morishita and Brazil's Cisne Negro (Black Swan) dance company from Sao Paulo all did considerably better the second time around than on opening night.

title: Bill Staines to Perform
description: Bill Staines, a songwriter and singer, will perform tonight at Speakeasy, 107 Macdougal Street (598-9670). Sets are at 8:30 and 11 P.M.; admission is $8 with a two-drink minimum.

title: For Fresh Diplomacy Toward Moscow
description: LEAD: The United States badly needs a major review of its diplomatic approaches to the Soviet Union. Mikhail S. Gorbachev's much advertised ''new thinking'' on foreign policy is merely one factor making such a review overdue.

title: Standard Brands Paint CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,041,000 on early extinguishment of debt for the quarter and year, and losses from discontinued operations of $1,910,000 and $2,315,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income d-Included losses from discontinued operations of $300,000 for the quarter and $1,329,000 for the year.

title: Florafax International INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a profit of $204,000 from continuing operations, which was offset by $277,000 in reserves for discontinued operations. c-Net income

title: Review/Opera; 'Jenufa' in Concert: Death, Pain and Love
description: The most exciting operatic event of this waning season took place on Wednesday evening, but it was not in an opera house. Carnegie Hall was the scene of a concert performance of Janacek's ''Jenufa'' in which Leonie Rysanek's hair-raising portrayal of the murderous Kostelnicka aroused the audience to the kind of thunderous enthusiasm that is seldom heard in opera houses nowadays, and even less often warranted.

title: A Huston Tribute
description: A film tribute to the Huston family will begin on Sunday with a double-bill of ''The Maltese Falcon'' and ''The African Queen'' on Sunday at the Biograph Cinema, 225 West 57th Street. About 35 films that feature the work of the Hustons - Walter, John, Anjelica and Tony - will be shown in two groups of screenings; the first will run through April 20 and the second is planned for May 9 to May 28. Admission for each screening is $6; there is also a series ticket of $25 for five screenings. Information: 582-4582.

title: Florida Employers Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Sports People; King Issues Denial
description: Don King denied yesterday that he had attempted to persuade Mike Tyson to bolt from his manager, Bill Cayton, and sign with him instead. Reports began to circulate after the death last week of Tyson's co-manager, Jim Jacobs. ''It's idiotic and insane to say I'll take Mike Tyson from two honorable men,'' said King. King said that to do what he has been accused of would be self-destructive.'' King said that he had spoken to Cayton yesterday, and that Cayton told him he had heard the same rumors.

title: For a Top Official at Justice, Torment Amid the Turmoil
description: Next to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, the man on the spot in the current turmoil at the Justice Department is Solicitor General Charles Fried.

title: Communications & Cable INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a non-cash charge of $523,000 from depreciation and amortization and deferred taxes. The company said results for periods prior to Jan. 31, 1987 are not comparable as a result of a restructuring of the business and assets of the company.

title: KEY RATES
Transport Chief Warns Against F.A.A. Shift
description: Transportation Secretary Jim Burnley sought today to head off any recommendation by a Presidential panel to remove regulation of the nation's flights from his department's oversight.

title: Review/Film; A Tale of the Dark Side: 'Bright Lights, Big City'
description: The hero of Jay McInerney's book ''Bright Lights, Big City'' didn't have a name, but he certainly had a voice. On the other hand, the film version calls its leading character Jamie Conway and allows him no real equivalent of the novel's astute, dry, nicely self-mocking second-person narration. ''You are a republic of voices tonight,'' Mr. McInerney's hero tells himself at one juncture. ''Unfortunately, that republic is Italy.'' Who could invent a visual or even conversational equivalent for that?

title: Sports People; Tippett Offer Reported
description: Two weeks after Wilber Marshall, the free-agent linebacker for the Chicago Bears, was signed by the Washington Redskins, Andre Tippett, free-agent linebacker for the New England Patriots, is being lured away by the San Francisco 49ers with a multiyear, multimillion-dollar offer sheet, according to a report yesterday in The Boston Herald. The paper said the 49er proposal called for a six-year deal worth a minimum of $5.5 million, including a $1 million cash signing bonus worth. The Boston Globe reported that the deal was for five years. The Patriots would have seven days after San Francisco makes the offer to match it or lose Tippett, a four-time all-Pro. If Tippett goes to the 49ers, the Patriots would receive the 49ers' first-round draft choices in 1988 and 1989 as compensation.

title: Winners of Pulitzer Prizes in Journalism, Letters and the Arts
description: PUBLIC SERVICE The Charlotte Observer

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Famous Unknown
description: He is unknown here, but Friedrich Nowottny, the man coming to dinner in the Washington offices of ARD German Television on Thursday, is perhaps the most popular journalist in Central Europe today.

title: Toni Morrison's Novel 'Beloved' Wins the Pulitzer Prize in Fiction
description: ''Beloved,'' a novel by Toni Morrison about the agonizing remembrances of a former slave in post-Civil War Ohio, was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for fiction yesterday.

title: Sons Follow Fathers' Moves to Glory
description: Last spring, when dollar signs were jumping in front of Danny Manning's eyes and working to gain his attention, the junior at the University of Kansas had to decide whether to become a senior. As a state full of people waited for his decision, Manning turned to a person whose priorities had long ago been made clear.

title: Western Tele-Communicaions reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a $328,000 loss from discontinued operations. c-After net from discontinued operations of $581,000. The company said it recorded a $3,740,000 provision in the latest period.

title: MONEY FUND ASSETS OFF
description: Assets of the nation's 420 money market mutual funds decreased $548.4 million, to $278.23 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 112 institutional funds decreased $552.7 million, to $78.33 billion. Assets of the 210 general-purpose funds were up $624.5 million, to $82.86 billion. The 98 broker-dealer funds decreased $620.2 million, to $117.04 billion.

title: U.S. and Italy Join in Breaking a Vast Drug Ring
description: In the biggest joint drug case ever mounted by the United States and Italy, officials yesterday announced charges against 233 suspected members of a Sicilian Mafia drug ring. More than 100 suspects were arrested in early morning raids.

title: G.E. in Deal To Acquire Roper
description: The General Electric Company and the Whirlpool Corporation agreed last night that G.E. could proceed unopposed with its tender offer for the Roper Corporation. The deal between the two giant appliance makers ends a bitter takeover battle for Roper, a manufacturer of stoves and other appliances.

title: Option Cost Rise Sought
description: In response to increased volatility experienced during the October market collapse, the Chicago Board Options Exchange said today that it had proposed raising margins on its equity and index options.

title: Organ Recital
description: E. Davis Wortman 2d is to give an organ recital featuring Bach's Toccata and Fugue in D minor, Delius's ''On Hearing the First Cuckoo in Spring'' and Franck's ''Grande Piece Symphonique'' on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 7 West 55th Street. Admission is free. Information: 247-0490.

title: American Midland CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes extraordinary income of $755,000.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Asko Deutsche Kaufhaus A.G., Frankfurt, a retailer, said its acquisition of Safeway Stores Inc.'s El Paso unit had been approved by United States authorities.

title: Writer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter and year losses included a $13 million writedown on commercial property.

title: Leetch of Rangers Is on Nonstop Trip
description: Flights out of O'Hare Airport were overbooked, as usual. Airlines bumped customers who had reservations, and passengers elbowed one another. Those lucky enough not to have lost their way were generally in the process of losing their temper. Amid it all, Brian Leetch, who had squeezed into a seat and between the headphones of his Walkman, sat unfazed, smiling brightly.

title: Hollywood, Tattered and Troubled, Seeks Revival With a New Costume
description: A Hollywood revival is under way and it has nothing to do with old films. It is old Hollywood itself, the now-tattered urban remains of the once-glamorous movie capital, coming back to life in a new costume.

title: Laidlaw Transport Looking for Buyer
description: Laidlaw Transportation Ltd., the largest school bus operator in North America, said it is looking for a buyer. Michael G. DeGroote, chairman of the company, which is also in the waste-management business, said he would sell his 50.5 percent controlling stake ''at the right price and with the right terms.'' Mr. DeGroote said he had decided to sell to put his estate in order and to provide for an orderly succession.

title: New York Shifts Drug-Case Strategy
description: In a new strategy prompted by the assassination of a rookie police officer, New York City law-enforcement officials will be singling out repeat narcotics offenders, seeking higher bails and severely limiting plea bargaining, officials announced yesterday.

title: Congress Begins to Correct Mistakes in New Tax Laws
description: Congressional tax writers introduced legislation today to make hundreds of ''technical corrections'' and other changes in the Tax Reform Act of 1986 and the Revenue Act of 1987.

title: Closings Today
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be closed today in observance of Good Friday. Most foreign stock exchanges will also be closed.

title: Review/Film; A Robbery, Focusing on the Robbers
description: Bank heist stories ordinarily concentrate on the details and take a businesslike tone, but the British film ''Bellman and True'' could not be a greater departure from that. Though it catalogues the particulars of an elaborate theft, Richard Loncraine's dark, riveting, offbeat new gangster film is less about a robbery than about a man and boy who are unwittingly caught up in its machinations, and the ways in which this unlikely crisis binds them together.

title: Hei Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: b-Includes tax credits of $41,500 and $81,500 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: U.S. Plans Tax Diversions As a Way to Press Noriega
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it was working on a plan to divert Panamanian tax payments by American companies to a fund outside the control of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the military leader.

title: A Heritage Imperiled
description: Bull Run is a creek that meanders through Virginia so near Washington that members of Congress and ladies of fashion could take horse and buggy out to witness the first battle of the Civil War, fought along the creek banks near Manassas Junction on July 21, 1861.

title: Knicks Respond To Pitino Warning
description: Coach Rick Pitino threw a challenge at the Knicks and they met it by defeating the Milwaukee Bucks, 113-103, tonight, in what Trent Tucker called ''our biggest victory of the season.''

title: Strawbridge & Clothier reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Soviet Asks Inspection Of All Space Programs
description: The Soviet Union said today that it would open up its space program to full international inspection if other nations did the same and acted to bar the deployment of weapons in space.

title: PEC Israel Economic Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Prosecutor Seeks Jail Term For an Unrepentant Nofziger
description: Lyn Nofziger should be imprisoned for illegally lobbying the White House because he flouted the law and compared his offense to ''running a stop sign,'' a prosecutor said today in court papers.

title: As Dust Settles From U.S.-Soviet Flurry, The Main Choices for the Russians Emerge
description: After eight years of war, six years of negotiations and several months of tantalizingly high hopes, the Soviet Union is faced with four possible routes out of Afghanistan, each one passing through a dense political thicket.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the crossword puzzle in some copies yesterday was a reprint of Wednesday's. Readers wishing to obtain the correct Thursday puzzle may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N... 10036.

title: Ethiopia's President Admits the Rebels Are Forcing 'Grim Battles'
description: In a rare acknowledgment of the growing threat posed by rebels, President Mengistu Haile Mariam of Ethiopia said today that Government forces were fighting ''grim battles'' against insurgents in the northern provinces of Eritrea and Tigre, Radio Ethiopia reported.

title: Empire Blue Cross Wins Rate Rise
description: An average rate increase of 16.6 percent for 2.4 million individual and small group subscribers to Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield in the New York City area was approved yesterday by the State Department of Insurance.

title: Rabbit Software reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the results reflected the consolidation of Micro Plus, acquired in 1987, into Rabbit Software, certain one-time year-end balance sheet writeoffs, lower than anticipated revenue because of the timing of certain contracts and costs associated with establishing a larger sales distribution organization.

title: How Macy Kept Takeover Bid Alive
description: A higher bid and a dramatic plea made by Edward S. Finkelstein, the chairman of R. H. Macy & Company, kept Macy in the bidding for Federated Department Stores Inc., after Macy thought it had lost to the Campeau Corporation.

title: Family Dollar Stores INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Business People column yesterday misstated the plans of Richard M. Furlaud, chairman and chief executive of the Squibb Corporation. Squibb has no mandatory retirement age, and Mr. Furlaud, 64 years old, has announced no plans to retire.

title: The Law; Nurse as Lawyer: A Foot in Two Worlds
description: It began in the 1970's: people with established careers setting them aside to go to law school. As medical and legal issues became more complex and intertwined, nurses who became lawyers found themselves moving into law practices connected to their previous profession and started calling themselves nurse attorneys.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on March 21 about the Armenian community in Glendale, Calif., incorrectly described the Soviet city of Yerevan in some copies. It is the capital of Soviet Armenia, not of the Nagorno-Karabakh autonomous region.

title: Advertising; New York Post Sets Big Drive
description: The venerable New York Post, now under new ownership, will salute its founder, Alexander Hamilton, and also promise more meaty news coverage in a $500,000 ad campaign that breaks Monday.

title: Virginia Beach Federal Savings LOAN reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Joan Sutherland Recital
description: The soprano Joan Sutherland is to sing the aria ''Casta Diva'' from Bellini's ''Norma'' and the ''mad scenes'' from Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor,'' Thomas's ''Hamlet'' and Bellini's ''Puritani'' in a recital at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday at 7:30 P.M. Richard Bonynge will conduct the Orchestra of St. Luke's, which will offer overtures from Donizetti's ''Don Pasquale,'' Herold's ''Zampa'' and Maillart's ''Dragons de Villars.'' Tickets are $35 to $50. Information: 874-6770.

title: Environmental Diagnostics reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Review/Film; The World in Very Big Trouble
description: ''The Omen'' isn't exactly one of the 10,000 best movies of all time, but it still towers above ''The Seventh Sign,'' which also claims as its inspiration Revelation, the New Testament's apocalyptic, final book, written, according to the Columbia Encyclopedia, by ''one John'' in A.D. 95.

title: New Swaggart Meeting Set
description: The Louisiana District of the Assemblies of God Church, which recommended barring the Rev. Jimmy Swaggart from preaching for only three months, will meet Friday to discuss harsher penalties demanded by the church's national leaders, a member said today. The television evangelist said through his lawyer Wednesday that he would defy the national leadership's order that he step down for a year.

title: New Afghan Province: A Toehold for Moscow?
description: A decision by the Government of Afghanistan to create a new northern province has aroused speculation among diplomats that Moscow may be planning to retain a military zone in the north if the stalled Geneva peace talks break down.

title: JUSTICE AIDES SAY SOLICITOR GENERAL TOLD MEESE TO QUIT
description: Solicitor General Charles Fried, the Justice Department's fourth-ranking official, urged Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to resign but was rebuffed, department officials said today.

title: California Group for Cuomo Is Set Back in Petition Drive
description: Governor Cuomo's supporters here have failed to gather enough signatures to put the New Yorker's name on the ballot for California's Democratic Presidential primary June 7.

title: Fritz H. Landshoff, 86, Executive In Publishing for Over 60 Years
description: Fritz H. Landshoff, a former publishing executive with Harry N. Abrams Inc., died of heart failure Wednesday in the Netherlands. He was 86 years old.

title: Bond-Fund Gains Are Continuing
description: Investors continued to favor money market and bond funds over equity mutual funds in February, a trend that began late last spring and accelerated after October's stock market plunge.

title: Woman Dies at 112
description: Orpha Nusbaum, listed in the Guinness Book of World Records to be the world's oldest person, died Wednesday at the age of 112.

title: Outbreak by Cuban Inmates
description: Extra officers were called to the Talladega Federal Correctional Institute Wednesday to quell an hour-long disturbance involving Cuban prisoners, a spokeswoman, Karen Stephens, said today. She said it was unclear what prompted the disturbance. The prison holds 167 Cuban detainees.

title: Rebels' Rank and File Backs Truce
description: Guerrillas operating in northern Nicaragua said today that they were ready to stop fighting and resume civilian life if their leaders directed them to do so.

title: Plea Bargaining May Be Sought In Queens Trial
description: The judge in the Howard Beach attack case is encouraging the defense and prosecution to settle through plea bargains the cases of six of the seven remaining defendants, according to people close to the situation.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Curlew Downtown

title: Art That Strikes Up Conversations With Viewers
description: THE 1980's have been a time when art has talked back to its audience with unusual directness, and meaning has gained equal footing with form. This is as true of Neo-Expressionism as it is of the best Neo-Geo - to use two ubiquitous handles - and it is also true of much art that does not readily conform to these or any other labels.

title: Results Plus
description: N.H.L.

title: Rays and Fumes in the Air and in the News; Expand Ethanol Use
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Kornhauser Will Keep Key Pet Food Account
description: When an agency's client is acquired, there follows many anxious hours while the new bosses decide whether to keep the old agency.

title: Turner Broadcasting System INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest fourth quarter included a charge of $13.1 million to reduce the carrying value of certain internally-produced programming to its estimated net realizable value. The quarter also included a credit of about $10 million from the recognition of copyright fee income which had been the subject of litigation. The second quarter of 1986 included a charge of $25.7 million related to the 1986 Goodwill Games.

title: Review/Film; Homage to Max Linder, Early French Film Comic
description: Cinema students who missed ''The Man in the Silk Hat'' when it was shown on Channel 13 a year ago can catch up with it at the Public Theater, where it opens today.

title: Clark Will Miss First Home Stand
description: Jack Clark accepted the news without much emotion. In a way, he had been expecting it, and now it was official: the Yankees' new $3 million designated hitter would not be available for the team's six-game season-opening home stand that was to start next week.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Super Complicated?
description: Hoping for relief in calculating your income tax with the new Internal Revenue Service from the new generation of super computers? Forget it. Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi, himself a certified public accountant, was visiting the Houston Area Research Center to inspect an advanced computer model that is touted as being capable of performing one billion operations per second. The Scarsdale Republican asked whether it could handle the 1987 tax returns?

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; 'Education President'
description: In a now-famous exchange, Dan Rather, the CBS News anchor, tried to pin down Vice President Bush on just how closely involved he was in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Venture for Perkins And Detroit Diesel
description: The Detroit Diesel Corporation and the Perkins Engines Group said they would market each other's diesel engines in North America as the first step in a collaborative effort to gain leadership in world markets. A spokesman for Detroit Diesel said the marketing arrangement might lead to a merger of the companies' North American distribution networks, which have 4,000 outlets, and that further steps could include joint research, purchasing and manufacturing.

title: An Ex-Prosecutor Charged
description: A former Federal prosecutor was charged yesterday with failing to file tax returns and pay income taxes for three years.

title: Hartmarx Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
For Morrison, Prize Silences Gossip
description: Responding to the first call yesterday afternoon informing her that she had won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction, Toni Morrison caught her breath, asked for a few minutes to form her thoughts, then said:

title: Review/Theater; Sandra Bernhard, a One-Woman Band
description: You may remember Sandra Bernhard from ''The King of Comedy,'' Martin Scorsese's 1983 movie, in which she came on frenetically as a far-out fan of Jerry Lewis. Finding herself between movies for most of the years since, she has put together a one-woman, four-musician show that opened last night at the Orpheum Theater. ''Without You I'm Nothing'' is 90 minutes of monologue and song, sometimes in her own style, sometimes in kidding imitation of superstars in the rock firmament.

title: Singers and Dancers Shake and Sway to a Brazilian Beat
description: WHAT is Brazilian culture? Is it the samba and the bossa nova, or Villa-Lobos? Is it Carmen Miranda, the ''Brazilian Bombshell'' of Hollywood movies in the 1940's and 50's, or Cecilia Meireles, the poet? New Yorkers will have a chance to explore Brazilian arts this weekend, when an unusual variety of Brazilian cultural events will take place.

title: Arnie Zane, 39, Choreographer and Dancer, Dies
description: Arnie Zane, a choreographer, dancer and co-artistic director of Bill T. Jones-Arnie Zane and Company, a leading postmodernist dance troupe, died of AIDS-related lymphoma on Wednesday night at his home in Valley Cottage, N.Y. He was 39 years old.

title: An Empty Gesture for Veterans
description: Like it or not, the nation seems about to get its 14th cabinet department, the Department of Veterans Affairs. It won't help the country, and the veterans don't need it. What they really need is something they're unlikely to get: the right to challenge Government decisions on their benefit claims.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, APRIL 1, 1988
description: THE ECONOMY House and Senate conferees imposed stiff curbs on Toshiba, in retaliation for its subsidiary's sale of sensitive technology to Moscow. The sanctions, part of a sweeping trade bill, were a compromise reached after President Reagan threatened to veto the bill if it contained more severe Senate restrictions on Toshiba. On other issues, the conferees significantly relaxed the controls on technology exports but failed to settle the most contentious issue they face: a proposal to require disclosure of foreign investment in the United States. Mr. Reagan has threatened to veto the trade bill if the disclosure provision is adopted. [ Page A1. ] Alan Greenspan said the Fed's governors had concluded that legislative proposals to reconfigure the regulatory structure of the financial markets ''appear premature.'' The Federal Reserve chairman specifically declined to support a bill introduced by Senator Proxmire that would create a regulatory coordinating committee to handle intermarket issues. [ D1. ] Congressional tax writers introduced an 800-page bill to make hundreds of ''technical corrections'' in previous legislation. [ D9. ] COMPANIES G.E. and Whirlpool struck a deal on Roper. G.E. will proceed unopposed with its $507 million tender offer. Whirlpool will acquire the Roper brand name. [ D1. ] Federated's board postponed until today its decision on whether to reaffirm a merger accord with Macy or to accept Campeau's bid. There were strong signs that during the last 24 hours the board had flip-flopped in sentiment from Macy to Campeau and then back to Macy, which sweetened its bid to $6.7 billion. [ D1. ] Along with Macy's higher bid, a dramatic plea by the retailer's chairman helped keep it in the bidding. [ D3. ] First Republicbank expects a ''significant net loss'' for the first quarter and continued losses through the year, it said in an S.E.C. filing. One official said the Comptroller of the Currency would soon finish an analysis of the banking company's problems. [ D2. ] The machinists' union sued Eastern and Texas Air, contending the two companies have tried to dismantle Eastern in violation of Federal labor and securities laws. [ D3. ] Irvin L. Jacobs plans to take Minstar private for $29 a share, or about $369 million, in cash and stock. [ D3. ] MARKETS Wall Street was far more favorable for corporate financing in the first quarter than in the months right after October's stock market collapse. Underwriting volume jumped 58 percent from the final three months of 1987. [ D1. ] Stock prices ended moderately higher in light pre-holiday trading. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.94 points, to 1,988.06, and ended the shortened week with a gain of 9.11 points. For the first quarter of the year, the Dow lost 27.19 points, or 1.3 percent. [ D6. ] Bond prices inched up slightly in light, listless trading, as market participants closed their books on the first quarter and prepared for the holiday weekend. [ D12. ] Investors continued to favor money market and bond funds over equity mutual funds in February, a trend that began late last spring and accelerated after October's stock market plunge. [ D2. ] The dollar headed lower in subdued pre-holiday dealings. In New York, gold dropped $2.25, to $454 an ounce. [ D13. ] The contract for June delivery of hogs plunged the 150-point limit for daily trading on the Chicago Merc. [ D13. ] INTERNATIONAL U.S.-Japan talks continued on beef and citrus quotas, but no agreement was reached as a four-year-old pact expired. The U.S. said it would press its case at GATT next month in Geneva. [ D4. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS What steps must the U.S. take to avoid losing its place as the world's strongest economy? Both a bipartisan study group and Harvard's president argue that a major priority is upgrading the nation's education system. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Payoffs on stocks of companies fighting AIDS are unlikely before the 1990's in most cases, according to experts who follow drug and biotechnology stocks. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: Holiday Weekend
description: Today is Good Friday, tomorrow is the first day of Passover and Sunday is Easter. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parade: Fifth Avenue will be closed Sunday between 44th and 57th Streets for the Easter Promenade, which begins at 11 A.M. and ends at 2:30 P.M. Government offices: Open today. Post Offices: Normal schedule. Banks: Open today. Schools: New York City schools closed today; New York state schools have the option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended today and tomorrow. Sanitation: Regular collections. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on regular schedules. Libraries: New York Public Library, Brooklyn and Queens libraries open today and tomorrow, closed Sunday. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal offices are open today; state and local offices are closed. Post Offices: Normal schedule. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Option to close. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular schedules. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal offices are open today; state and local offices are closed. Post Offices: Normal schedule. Banks: Closed today. Schools: Closed today. Transportation: New Haven line on regular weekday and weekend schedules.

title: Brendle's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Mega-Broker Is Named To No. 2 Post at Gordon
description: To those in the real estate business, it came as no surprise this week when the Edward S. Gordon Company, a leading New York real estate concern, named Martin Turchin as vice chairman.

title: Fugitive Is Tied to a Drug Theft From the Police
description: Federal authorities said yesterday that a fugitive arrested in Florida had been identified as a former associate of the man suspected of masterminding the unsolved theft of the ''French Connection'' drugs from the New York City Police Headquarters.

title: British Flights to China
description: China gave delayed approval to British Airways today to add a second flight a week to Beijing, temporarily averting a dispute. A British Airways plane had been scheduled to fly to Beijing Wednesday with 150 passengers, but China unexpectedly withheld permission for the flight.

title: Hachette Adds To Grolier Bid
description: Hachette S.A., the French multimedia giant, said yesterday that it had raised its offer for Grolier Inc. to $24 a share, or nearly $475 million, from $21, after a week of re-examining Grolier's books.

title: House Panel Votes to Extend Time for Aliens to Seek Legal Status
description: The House Judiciary Committee today approved a bill that would extend until Nov. 30 the period for illegal aliens to apply for legal status.

title: Corrections
description: A calendar of tours, crafts and landscaping classes in The Home Section yesterday misstated the site of a course on penthouse and terrace gardening. The three-session course, which starts April 14, will be at the Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street, (212) 757-0915, not at the Bartlett Arboretum Association in Stamford, Conn.

title: Wicks Is Voted An All-American
description: Sue Wicks of Rutgers, the Naismith Award winner as the top player in women's college basketball, was named today to the Kodak women's all-America team for the third straight year.

title: Spencer-Devlin Takes Lead
description: A severe north wind charged down over the San Bernardino mountains today, through the Banning Pass and into the desert resort area from Palm Springs to LaQuinta.

title: Bridge; A Deal From Prague Shows How a Fifth-Best Lead Can Help the Declarer
description: Every bid and play designed to give information to your partner also gives information to the opposition.

title: Kelley Oil & Gas Partners reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Infodata Systems INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $390,573 gain from securities transactions.

title: Olympics; Fencer Outlines Long-Range Goals
description: As a youngster growing up in Orange, N.J., Bob Cottingham probably knew as much about fencing as any other kid in the neighborhood. ''I guess I once saw half a 'Three Musketeers' movie,'' he recalled. ''That's about it.''

title: 2 Slain and 1 Wounded By Brooklyn Gunmen
description: Two people were killed and another person was injured yesterday when two gunmen burst into a Brooklyn beauty salon and opened fire on the staff with handguns, the police said.

title: Advertising; New Officer at Cahners
description: Peter A. Derow, the 47-year-old former chairman and president of Newsweek Inc., and former president of the CBS publishing group, is joining Cahners Publishing. a subsidiary of Reed Publishing of Britain, as senior vice president. Cahners is based in Boston, where Mr. Derow grew up.

title: Mr Gasket Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an $828,000 gain from a change in accounting for income taxes. c-Net loss and the year included a special charge of $3,470,000 to adjust the carrying value of certain assets and to provide for the relocation of certain facilities. The company said its results for the first three quarters of 1987 have been restated to reflect the change in accounting for income taxes and to adjust previously reported results to reflect more accurate inventory values and cost of sales.

title: Burke Lifts Devils' Hopes
description: Sean Burke, the rookie goaltender for the Devils, was the protagonist again tonight in a 7-2 triumph over the Penguins, who were shut out by Burke two nights earlier in New Jersey.

title: William McMahon, 80, Ex-Australia Chief
description: Sir William McMahon, a former Prime Minister of Australia, died of cancer today. He was 80 years old.

title: Community Psychiatric Ceners INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Sports People; Ban for Next Season
description: The National Hockey League season has not even ended, and already Gord Donnelly of the Quebec Nordiques has been suspended for the first six games of next season. It came about after Donnelly was suspended for the third time this season when Brian O'Neill, the N.H.L.'s executive vice president, issued a 10-game ban yesterday for a stick-swinging incident last Sunday against Pittsburgh. The suspension included one game that Donnelly missed while awaiting the verdict. Because the Nordiques, who failed to qualify for the playoffs, have only three games to play, six games of the suspension will carry over to next season. Donnelly had served two five-game suspensions this season.

title: Inquiry in Pit Bull Shootings
description: Police Chief Walter Adams Said Today that he had ordered an investigation into why police officers shot two pit bulls that were mauling a third dog, rather than trying to tranquilize or restrain them. He said officers killed the 2-year-old pit bulls and the third dog, a husky, with shotgun blasts Wednesday. The police said they shot the husky because it appeared near death.

title: New Centel Chairman Faces a Test of Wills
description: When John P. Frazee Jr., the president and chief executive of the Centel Corporation, takes on the additional role of chairman today, his most pressing concern will be to defend the company from a possible takeover attempt.

title: Meaning of '67 Israel Resolution Disputed; Deliberately Ambiguous
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Television; The Halls of Britain vs. the Streets of New York
description: British royalty squares off with an Italian peasant woman this Sunday in prime time. ''The Woman He Loved,'' on CBS at 9 P.M., offers still another television treatment of Edward VIII and Wallis Simpson, this time portrayed by Anthony Andrews and Jane Seymour. ''The Fortunate Pilgrim,'' written by Mario Puzo, on NBC at 9 o'clock, gives us Lucia, a woman from Calabria who comes to America dreaming of raising a family and someday having a home on Long Island. Lucia is played by Sophia Loren. On balance, stick with the Italians.

title: Brooke Partners Sets 2 Offerings
description: Brooke Partners L.P. is offering $160 million in 13 1/2 percent senior subordinated reset notes due in 1997 at par through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: The Law; Crime Victims Getting a Day, and a Say, in Court
description: In increasing numbers, local judges and prosecutors around the country have formally begun to involve victims and their families in the sentencing of criminals.

title: Review/Opera; Kraus and von Stade in Metropolitan's 'Werther'
description: Three arias well understood and one scene precisely enacted were the highlights of Wednesday night's ''Werther'' at the Metropolitan Opera. They could not by themselves take a very good performance into the realm of the memorable, but a very good performance with memorable moments is a lot, and the company deserves congratulations for this revival, which will have five more performances before the end of the season next month.

title: The Law; Abrams Suit Challenges Jersey's Milk Price Law
description: Reopening a year-old battle over milk price policies, New York today accused New Jersey of discriminating against out-of-state dairies and violating Federal antitrust laws.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Italian Passover

title: E-Z-Em reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
More Infants Showing Signs Of Narcotics
description: Reports of infants born in New York City with symptoms of drug withdrawal nearly doubled in the 1987 fiscal year and continued to climb sharply during the first four months of this fiscal year, the city's Human Resources Administration said yesterday.

title: Sierra Health Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $38,000 for the quarter and $74,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: National Medical Enterprises INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,707,000 for the quarter and $3,897,000 for the 9 months.

title: Auctions
description: A Massachusetts collector who paid $15 on Feb. 29 for a first edition of Edgar Allan Poe's ''Tamerlane'' found this rarity while browsing among fertilizer catalogues and pamphlets in a New Hampshire antiques store. He took the tattered and stained copy of Poe's first book to the Boston office of Sotheby's, where he was told it could bring $200,000 to $300,000 at auction.

title: Avery International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
No More Sears Lawn Darts
description: Sears, Roebuck and Company has agreed to stop selling within a week the outdoor game of lawn darts, settling a Federal complaint about inadequate warning labels and about stocking the darts near toy items, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Wednesday. In the game, large pointed darts are tossed at targets on the ground. Three deaths have been reported in the last 18 years, with annual injuries estimated at 670, the safety agency said.

title: Economic Scene; Proposals to Keep The U.S. on Top
description: IS the United States losing its place as possessor of the world's strongest economy? And, if so, what can it do to check its declining economic and political power?

title: Dow Up 9.94 in Light Pre-Holiday Trading
description: Stock prices ended moderately higher yesterday in light pre-holiday trading.

title: First Republicbank Sees A String of Big Losses
description: The First Republicbank Corporation disclosed in a filing with the Government Wednesday that it expects to report a ''significant net loss'' for the first quarter and that losses would continue through the year.

title: Restaurants Again Face Inspections
description: Yellow posters were plastered on the windows of the B & H Dairy, a 12-stool lunch counter claiming to serve the best soup in New York City. The posters proclaimed: ''This establishment closed by order of the Board of Health.''

title: INSIDE
description: Senate Passes Contra Aid

title: Landmark Land CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title:
About Real Estate;
Lower East Side Buildings Rehabilitated
description: LEAD: The rehabilitation of vacant residential and commercial properties is bringing new vitality to an area of Manhattan's Lower East Side where derelict buildings, empty storefronts and crime problems have long prevailed.

title: On Stage
description: Fit for an Opening

title: Le Peep Restaurants reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Contracts for G.E.
description: The General Electric Company has been awarded $1.68 billion in military contracts, including $945.1 million for a new submarine combat system, the Pentagon said. The corporate giant, which ranked as the nation's third-largest military contractor in the 1987 fiscal year, received eight military contracts as the first half of the 1988 fiscal year came to a close. The biggest award was for the Navy's AN/BSY-2 submarine combat system, which G.E. is developing for the SSN-21, the nation's newest proposed class of attack subs.

title: Our Towns; A Crack Pipe Is a Triumph In the AIDS War
description: Yesterday morning, while Federal agents were busy cracking another international heroin ring, the Jersey City AIDS van pulled into the Montgomery Gardens housing project. ''Nice weather,'' said Adrienne Hall, stepping from the van with her AIDS pamphlets. ''Very nice,'' said Dr. Natale Graziano. What they meant was, nice weather for finding heroin addicts. ''Our numbers go up when it's nice out,'' Mrs. Hall said cheerfully. She walked between the 10-story buildings, handing out pamphlets. Another AIDS worker, Ron Austin, explained that their methadone clinic, Spectrum, was giving out free 21-day coupons to intravenous drug users. ''Free!'' said a man. ''They're free!'' And he followed Mr. Austin into the van, where Dr. Graziano asked questions and filled out forms.

title: Jewelcor Discloses 2 Buyout Offers
description: Jewelcor Inc., the jewelry company, said it had received bids from two management groups. One group, led by its chairman and chief operating officer, Frank P. Cuscela, and affiliated with Bear, Stearns & Company, is offering $18 a share, or $58.6 million, to acquire the company.

title: Transit Talks Adjourn; Workers Stay on Job
description: Negotiations between the Transit Authority and the Transit Authority and the city's 35,000 bus and subway workers broke off at 1:30 A.M today without agreement on a new contract, officials said.

title: New Khmer Rouge Drive Feared As Buildup of Weapons Goes On
description: The procession begins at sundown, when international relief workers have left some of the lonely border camps that shelter more than a quarter of a million displaced Cambodian civilians along the Thai border.

title: Sports People; Valvano to U.C.L.A.?
description: Whenever a prominent basketball team dismisses its coach, the name of Jim Valvano pops up prominently among the possible successors. That happened again yesterday when Valvano, the North Carolina State coach and athletic director, was reported to be in the running to replace Walt Hazzard as coach at U.C.L.A. According to a report in The Los Angeles Herald Examiner yesterday, Valvano has been offered a five-year, $2.5 million contract to become the Bruins' sixth coach since John Wooden retired 13 years ago. The newspaper said that sources reported that Valvano was 90 percent certain to accept the offer and was to fly to Los Angeles today to meet with school officials on details. Valvano, who was in Kansas City, Mo., said: ''This was not an appropriate time'' to comment.'' Officials at U.C.L.A. would neither confirm nor deny the planned visit.

title: Communism's Conscientious Objectors
description: Communist states boast of their devotion to peace, but won't recognize the right to refuse military service. Hundreds are jailed for the crime of conscience, denied alternative service like caring for the old and sick. This is the message of a bold letter on behalf of conscientious objectors signed by 400 Soviet and East European dissidents. It is addressed to a Vienna conference reviewing compliance with human rights promises made by Moscow and its allies in the 1975 Helsinki accords.

title: Meese Proves Master Of the Specific Reply Special to The New York Times
description: At a news confernce today, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d again demonstrated his talent for answering only the questions that is asked him.

title: Sharper Image Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Corrections
description: A headline yesterday on an article about cargo fees for the space shuttle misidentified the agency considering an increase. It is the Senior Interagency Group for space, an umbrella government organization that includes the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, and not NASA alone.

title: European Plea to Japan
description: A visiting member of the European Parliament, Bernhard Salzer, urged Japan today to open its construction market to Europeans as it has promised to do for American contractors in an accord reached this week.

description: b-Net loss

title: Rock Double Bill
description: Tall Lonesome Pines and World Famous Blue Jays will play a rock double bill tonight at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077), with sets at 9:30 and midnight. There is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Mobile Communication CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Mobile said it incurred start-up expenses of about $5 million in 1987, from the introduction of its National Satellite Paging operations. The company also said 1986 net included a non- recurring after-tax gain of $18 million from the sale of a 50 percent interest in its cellular telephone operations to Bellsouth Corp. in December 1986. The net in 1986 also reflected non- recurring charges of $8.4 million.

title: New Brunswick Scientific CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said adjustments related primarily to inventory writeoffs and other adjustments reduced the latest fourth quarter and year pre-tax operating results by $2.7 million. The prior year results are restated for the effects of an understatement of cost of sales and a related overstatement of inventories of a foreign subsidiary. The restatement reduced the 1986 fourth quarter and year by $502,000, or 14 cents a share.

title: DUKAKIS ATTEMPTS TO ANSWER CRITICS
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis tried today to answer the critics who charge that his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination lacks vision and fire.

title: Hofstra Hires van Breda Kolff
description: Butch van Breda Kolff, who said ''I threw only one chair last year, a good chair,'' brought one of college basketball's finest coaching records back to Hofstra today.

title: Election Panel Gives Candidates $2.6 Million
description: The Federal Election Commission has given $2.6 million more to the Presidential candidates, bringing the total dispensed for the 1988 campaign to $48.1 million.

description: b-Net loss
