Detroit Will Spare Cemetery In an Airport Expansion Plan
description: The city of Detroit said today it would spare a cemetery next to its City Airport in a planned expansion.

title: Growth Called Threat to Delhi's Grace
description: There is no other Asian capital with the grandeur and grace of this city on India's windswept northern plain. This was intentional.

title: Cocoa Prices Weaken
description: Cocoa prices reacted to prospects of a world surplus by falling today to their lowest levels in nearly six years. Cocoa beans for May delivery fell by $30, to $1,692 a metric ton. Gill & Duffus, international merchants, today forecast 1987-88 world production of 2.1 million tons, up 6 percent from 1986-87, with record crops expected in the Ivory Coast, Brazil and Malaysia.

title: For Wisconsin's Liberals, a Choice
description: Senator Bob Dole's announcement on Tuesday that he was abandoning the Presidential race gave Wisconsin Republicans an opportunity for mischief and Wisconsin Democrats an opportunity for righteous outrage. Neither rose above the temptation. After Mr. Dole's news conference, the state's Republican Governor, Tommy G. Thompson, called The Milwaukee Sentinel to offer his comments. He volunteered a denial that he had ever encouraged Republicans to cross over and vote in the Democratic primary next Tuesday, now that the Bush-Dole race was over. Republicans, he said, should stay in their own party and vote for Vice President Bush. Democrats Suspect a Plot

title: Rome Journal; Arranging Political Marriages Not Made in Heaven
description: Atop the highest of this city's seven hills sits a palace guarded by soldiers in plumed helmets. There, hidden from public view, a shy professor of constitutional law is secretly practicing the old Roman art of political marriage brokering.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Review/Film; 'Sorceress,' A Medieval Parable
description: Like Bertrand Tavernier's recent ''Beatrice,'' Suzanne Schiffman's ''Sorceress'' is set in France in the Middle Ages, but its spirit is in the Enlightenment. It is a parable about the clash between a dedicated healer and a dedicated pursuer of heretics, over whether God prefers to tend man's body or scourge his soul. The characters assume allegorical roles, and the resolution is meant to edify. The somewhat obvious yet intriguing movie, Miss Schiffman's debut as a director, opens today at the 68th Street Playhouse.

title: Former Wedtech Official Recounts U.S. Investigations of Competitors
description: A former Wedtech executive testified yesterday that the South Bronx company had used its influence with the Reagan Administration to have the Justice Department investigate its competitors.

title: Review/Film; Clash of Cultures, in 'Playing Away'
description: ''Playing Away'' was shown as part of last year's New Directors/New Films festival. These are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times March 13, 1987. The film opens today at the Cinema Studio 2, Broadway and 66th Street.

title: Mets Pick Teufel As Regular at 2d
description: In a series of sweeping moves that shaped the Mets for 1988, Dave Johnson named Tim Teufel his No. 1 second baseman today, demoted Wally Backman to No. 2 and sent four promising young players to the minor leagues, including Keith Miller, the super sub at three positions.

title: Rays and Fumes in the Air and in the News
description: To the Editor:

title: Sematech's Weary Hunt for a Chief
description: Sematech, the ambitious industry research consortium designed to restore the ability of the American semiconductor industry to compete with the Japanese, is having difficulties finding a chief executive.

title: Women's Final Four; Louisiana Tech Has Incentive
description: The four teams that led the nation in scoring, three from the South and one from the West, are poised for the N.C.A.A. Division I women's basketball Final Four.

title: Dining Out Guide: Easter Brunch
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAFE LUXEMBOURG, 200 West 70th Street (873-7411) - ** (May 9, 1986) Brunch is prepared with patience and care here, where an essentially American menu is offered in a stylish but casual Art Deco bistro setting. Brunch starters include fruit in season and delightfully lumpy Irish oatmeal with brown sugar and cinnamon. Among the entrees are grilled chicken salad on mixed greens with deep-fried eggs, crusty corned-beef hash, blintzes with chevre and pear compote. Homemade biscuits accompany the meal. Dense chocolate torte and a lighter lemon tart are favored desserts. Sunday brunch: 11 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. Appetizers $4 to $6, entrees $6 to $10. LOLA, 30 West 22d Street (675-6700) - * (Dec. 20, 1985) The ambiance is elegant cafe, with pastel tints and soft lighting. The noise level can be less than soft during peak serving hours, however. This Easter, and every Sunday at brunch, rousing gospel songs are performed with piano accompaniment. The kitchen offers such choices as shrimp and chicken curry with wild rice waffles, ricotta pancakes with blueberries, and potato and shrimp fritters; there are egg dishes as well. To end brunch on a sweet note, one might order the frozen raspberry charlotte. Sunday brunch: noon to 4 P.M. Prices: $11 to $16. THE VILLAGE GREEN, 531 Hudson Street (255-1650) - ** (Sept. 25, 1987) An 1827 row house is the frame for this romantic neighborhood restaurant serving imaginative American food. The prix fixe brunch menu includes entrees of smoked chicken and Italian greens on fried cappellini, duck hash served with fried eggs in peppered sauce, and poached salmon with green mayonnaise. French toast made from hallah, and scrambled eggs with sevruga caviar are also available. Hazelnut mocha mousse torte is a recommended dessert. Sunday brunch: noon to 3:30 P.M. Prix fixe at $19.95. THE WATER CLUB, on the East River at 30th Street (683-3333) - * (July 19, 1985) Treat yourself to a dose of tourism at Sunday brunch, taking in panoramic waterside views at this restaurant on a barge. Asparagus with herb vinaigrette or three-seafood salad are two of the appetizers on the brunch menu. Crab cakes (some of the best in town) are served as an entree, as are eggs Benedict with smoked Irish salmon, the grilled fish special or waffles. The warm apple tart and berries with sabayon have won acclaim. Sunday brunch: 11 A.M. to 1:30 P.M. Appetizers $4.25 to $9.75, entrees $11.50 to $22. VOULEZ-VOUS, 1462 First Avenue, at 76th Street (249-1776) - ** (Feb. 12, 1988) A French bistro of contemporary design, glass-fronted and comfortably appointed. The standard brunch menu will be supplemented on Easter with additions of roast leg of lamb, prime ribs and spinach-stuffed salmon with shallots and vermouth. Or choose French croissant toast topped with raspberry sauce, egg dishes, pizzas, cheese souffle or first-rate steak tartare, all regular brunch items. For a special Easter Sunday dessert, the chef will prepare oeufs a la neige. Sunday brunch: 11:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. Prix fixe at $10.50, extras at $2 to $4 per item.

title: Meaning of '67 Israel Resolution Disputed
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants
description: IT might seem that midtown Manhattan needs another $250-a-day hotel about as much as it needs another T-shirt shop, yet here is the lavishly renovated former Gotham Hotel, a dignified turn-of-the-century landmark on Fifth Avenue, newly rechristened Hotel Maxim's de Paris. The $100 million face lift includes two restaurants that feature intriguing Mediterranean-style fare, one called Bistro d'Adrienne, the other a more formal setting called simply Adrienne, and it is the subject of this review.

title: JMB Realty Trust CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
HIGH FINANCE
description: Following are 1988 salaries for major leaguers who, with a few exeptions, will be on opening day rosters next week or on the disabled list. Some players listed will be returned to the minor leagues before opening day. Some of those players will have lower salaries in the minors than those listed here. Figures, obtained from management and player sources, include base salary, prorated share of signing bonus and other guaranteed money, but not incentive bonuses that could be earned during the season. In some cases, parts of salaries that are deferred without interest are discounted to reflect present-day value. Ten players have salaries of $2 million or more and 73 are at $1 million or more. On opening day last season, those totals were 5 and 57.

title: Harold E. Pickett, Publisher, 41
description: Harold E. Pickett, publisher of The New York City News, died Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York from complications of AIDS. He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Brazil's Cuisine: An Ethnic Mosaic
description: Brazilian cuisine has never caught fire in New York the way, say, Mexican food has, in part because there have never been more than a half-dozen Brazilian restaurants around town, most of them humble and homey. For those who want to try this gutsy maritime fare, though, ample opportunities exist.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Historians will look back and view the vote that cut off military and humanitarian aid to the contras as a low point in United States history.'' - Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona. [ A5:5. ]

title: Macmillan Broadens Barry Lippman's Role
description: Barry Lippman has been named president and publisher of Macmillan Inc.'s five adult trade-book imprints - Atheneum Publishers, Charles Scribner's Sons, Rawson Associates, Collier Books and the Macmillan Publishing Company.

title: Albany Budget Negotiations Go Astray
description: Negotiations over the state budget broke down tonight as Senate Republicans from Long Island demanded more money for the Island's schools. The collapse meant the budget would not be in place by midnight, the start of the new fiscal year.

title: Beard Co reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $2,355,000 from an accounting change. c-Net loss The company said the latest year includes gains of $10.3 million on sale of stock in USPCI Inc., compared with $2 million in 1986.

title: SHAMIR PROMISES TO CRUSH RIOTERS
description: As Israel prepared to lift a three-day blockade of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir warned today that rioters would be crushed ''like grasshoppers.''

title: Senate Upholds Mecham Vote
description: After hours of backroom negotiations today, the State Senate let stand its dismissal of the third and strongest impeachment charge against Gov. Evan Mecham.

title: Cullinet Founder Back As Chairman and Chief
description: John J. Cullinane, 53, the founder and vice chairman of Cullinet Software Inc. of Westwood, Mass., returned as chairman and chief executive yesterday after an absence of almost two years, following the unexpected resignation of David L. Chapman.

title: Review/Music; A 5-Hour Feldman Trio
description: Toward the end of his life, when he began writing works of mammoth proportions, the composer Morton Feldman noted that ''up to an hour, you think about form, but after an hour and a half, it's scale.

title: Ad on New York City Co-ops Understates Warehousing Figures
description: To the Editor:

title: Volatile Sounds Of 3 Bands
description: Standing in front of his big band at the Village Vanguard the other day, the saxophonist Illinois Jacquet, hands in the air, waved on his saxophone section as if he were a third-base coach sending a runner to home plate. The section responded with a golden, urbane, welling of sound, only to be answered by the trumpet section, rudely rapping like an impatient bill collector knocking at a door. The trombones, soft and round, rushed in to mediate the fight. All three sections decided to join together, and the massed sound of the orchestra, building tension by the second, filled every dusty crack in the room with a joyous noise.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Datamarine International Inc., Pocasset, Mass., a maker of marine navigation systems, appointed Dean Straw senior vice president of its Datamarine business unit.

title: A Buffeted First Boston Regroups
description: After a lengthy strategy review and stormy internecine feuding, Peter T. Buchanan, First Boston's chief executive, announced on Jan. 21, ''There will be no fundamental change in First Boston's strategic direction.''

title: Medical Technology Products reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
American Nursery Products reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: News Summary
description: International A2-7 Toshiba faces stiff import curbs, under a House-Senate accord, because a subsidiary sold sensitive technology to Moscow. But trade bill conferees reached no compromise on disclosing foreign investments in the United States. Page A1 News analysis: An Afghan pullout by Moscow involves four possible but difficult routes - a gentlemen's agreement, an American concession, a separate accord with Pakistan or a unilateral withdrawal. A1 New Afghan province: Toehold for Moscow? A6 A $47.9 million contra aid package was speedily approved by the Senate a day after it won approval in the House. The Nicaraguan rebels will soon start receiving food, clothing, medicine and shelter assistance. A5 A cease-fire seems to be holding throughout Nicaragua. One week after the truce accord was signed, a Sandinista Government spokesman said no significant combat with the contras was being reported. A5 A Soviet library fire was disastrous, officials acknowledged, saying 400,000 books were destroyed and 3.6 million were damaged by water. The Feb. 14-15 blaze did major damage to the national science library in Leningrad. A1 A new Khmer Rouge drive against the Vietnamese occupiers is feared in Cambodia as a buildup of weapons for Pol Pot, the fugitive leader, goes on. The weapons carriers are burdened like pack animals. A1 The Seoul opposition is in disarray after forcing the Government to carry out sweeping reforms last year. The coalition has dissolved in bitterness and confusion just before legislative elections. A4 Panama's shops reopen, without cash A3 Ethiopia admits rebels are forcing 'grim battles' A4 Rome journal: Political marriages not made in heaven A4 National A8-16, A21 Demands rose for the resignation of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d. Officials said Solicitor General Charles Fried had urged Mr. Meese to leave on the ground his legal problems were creating turmoil. A1 The Solicitor General is the highest-ranking department official other than Mr. Meese who has not resigned. Friends say he has been agonizing since Monday over whether he should leave. A1 Wedtech had the Justice Department investigate its competitors for any possible 'skeletons in the closet,' Mario Moreno, a former executive of the Bronx contractor, testified. A13 A major U.S.-Italy drug crackdown resulted in charges filed against 233 suspected members of a Sicilian Mafia trafficking ring and the arrests of 62 of the suspects in Italy and 40 in American cities. A1 Toni Morrison won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction for a novel, ''Beloved,'' about the agonizing remembrances of a former slave. She said the book had begun to take on ''an extra-literary responsibility it was never designed for.'' A1 and B5 The Pulitzer drama award was won by Alfred Uhry for ''Driving Miss Daisy'' and the music award went to William Bolcom for ''12 New Etudes for Piano.'' The Public Service award went to The Charlotte Observer for the Bakker fund disclosures. A1 A tentative teamster-trucking pact covering 200,000 employees was reached before a midnight deadline. Details of the accord, which must be ratified by union members, were not made public. A8 Where muskrat is a Lenten delicacy A8 Hollywood making comeback, but in new role A8 Senate votes aid to uranium industry A16 Study finds drug curbs high blood pressure toll A21 Politics A14 Jesse Jackson is running nearly even in the Democratic Presidential preference polls with Michael S. Dukakis in Wisconsin, a state that is 4 percent black but a center of progressivism for more than 80 years. A14 Candidates gets $2.6 million more in U.S. funds A14 Washington Talk A16 Uproar over pipeline shakes up a quiet agency Regional B1-7 Infants showing drug withdrawal in New York City are increasing. The number born with the symptoms nearly doubled in the 1987 fiscal year and continued to soar in the first four months of this fiscal year, officials said. B1 The 'French connection' drug theft at New York City Police Headquarters remains unsolved, but officials say an arrested fugitive was a former associate of the man suspected of masterminding the famous theft. B3 A racketeering trial witness has said she saw a man being abducted shortly before he was murdered. The witness, Babette J. Questel, completed her second day of testimony in a trial involving the Gambino organized-crime family. B3 Talks over a state budget broke down as Senate Republicans from Long Island demanded more money for schools. As a result, the budget will not be completed today, the start of New York's new fiscal year. B2 News analysis: Political donations by real-estate developers and big businesses in New York are very generous. The main reason, not mentioned in recent testimony, is the most plausible - they give to get. B1 A feast of Brazilian cultural events will be laid out this weekend in New York City. They include ballet and modern dance, a light-hearted revue, a Carmen Miranda TV festival, art and samba music. C1 Restaurant inspections resume in New York City B1 Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield rates to rise B2 Home-Care aides reach contract B2 Repeat drug offenders to be singled out using computer list B3 Abrams challenges New Jersey milk law B7

title: Prosecutor in Killing of Indian
description: A special prosecutor was appointed Wednesday to investigate the death of Julian Pierce, an Indian running for a judgeship in a county with a long history of racial tension.

title: Bush to Press for Minorities' Backing
description: Vice President Bush is preparing to press for the support of black and Hispanic voters as part of a still evolving strategy for the Presidential campaign this fall.

title: Thatcher Is Challenged On Gibraltar Shootings
description: Amnesty International has demanded additional details from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on the shooting of three unarmed Irish terrorist suspects in Gibraltar by the British Army.

title: Health-Care Rationing Punishes the Old
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Says That It Will Replace Ambassador to Saudi Arabia
description: The United States will replace its Ambassador to Saudi Arabia, Hume A. Horan, the State Department said last night.

title: Universal Medical Buildings LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding are in units.

title: New Face/Stephanie Roth; Starting at the Top, With the Classics
description: It has been less than a year since Stephanie Roth graduated from Juilliard, but she has already won the kind of opportunities an actress might pine after for a lifetime. Her first job was on Broadway with the Royal Shakespeare Company, understudying a major part in ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses.'' Then there was a stint as Olivia in a regional theater staging of ''Twelfth Night,'' after which Ms. Roth returned to New York to do Chekhov for one of the most famous directors in the world.

title: Shanker Asks Greater Autonomy For Teachers and School Special to The New York Times
description: Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, called today for expanding an approach to education that would allow groups of teachers to create automomous programs within their own schools.

title: Covington Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $791,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income and includes an extraordinary gain of $888,000 from a tax benefit and a loss from discontinued operations of $73,000. The company said the 1987 results include a $600,000 charge related to an insurance settlement on discontinued operations. The company also said that in the latest fourth quarter, it reduced the carrying value on certain slower-moving projects to their revised net realizable values. It said the effect of the adjustment was about $2 million.

title: Mary B. Duryee, 92; Poet and Civic Leader
description: Mary Ballard Duryee, a poet, died Sunday at her home at the Medford Leas Retirement Community in Medford, N.J., after suffering a stroke. She was 92 years old Mrs. Duryee's books of collected poems included ''Songs and Sonnets'' (1914); ''Avenue of Song'' (1926); ''No Special Pleading'' (1940); ''Free Enterprise'' (1943), and ''Signs and Wonders'' (1972). She was also a contributor to The New Yorker and Voices.

title: Jacobs Offers To Buy Minstar
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, the chairman and chief executive of Minstar Inc., has made good on earlier hints that he would take the company private by offering $29 a share, or about $369 million.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; One-Day Stampede Of Derby Hopefuls
description: Tomorrow is the busiest day so far this year for Kentucky Derby prep races, with 44 3-year-olds entered for four races in Arkansas, Florida, Kentucky and New Jersey. All but 8 of those 44 horses have been nominated for the Derby on May 7, and about half of them are being seriously considered for the race.

title: The Law; Law School Applications Up Sharply
description: Applications to law schools have risen dramatically this year while the grades and test scores of applicants have also risen, admissions officials say. Although no one is sure what is causing the numbers to go up, one consequence is clear: getting into a good school will be tougher than in recent years.

title: Avatar Holdings INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $180,000 for the latest year and $1,405,000 for the year-earlier period, from tax loss carryforwards and the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Library Lost 400,000 Books In Soviet Fire
description: The fire started about 8 P.M. By dawn the library of the National Academy of Sciences, founded by Peter the Great in 1714, was an inferno of burning books and newspapers.

title: Jazz Messengers
description: Art Blakey, a drummer, will lead the Jazz Messengers tonight and tomorrow at Mikell's (760 Columbus Avenue, at 97th Street, 864-8832) at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. and at 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $7 minimum.

title: Southern Co reports earnings for 12mo Feb 29
description: The latest 12 months reflected an accounting change and the associated writeoffs after tax of about $229 million related to costs in excess of the retail rate-making Cap for Georgia Power Co.'s Vogtle Nuclear Project.

title: No. 1 Maine Upset In N.C.A.A. Hockey
description: Lake Superior State, a college of 2,500 students in Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., lacks the usual tournament accouterments, such as a marching band and cheerleaders.

title: At The Movies
description: Production Prep

title: New World Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter included $8.7 million in realized and unrealized losses in the company's marketable securities portfolio because of the October stock market crash. The 1987 results included film cost inventory writedowns of about $6 million.

title: Washington Talk: Overseas Investment; Uproar on Oil Pipeline Shakes Up a Quiet Agency
description: A little-known Government agency has suddenly found itself under an unwanted spotlight because of the legal troubles of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d.

title: Aid for the Contras Clears Congress
description: The Senate today swiftly approved and sent to President Reagan the $47.9 million Nicaraguan aid package adopted by the House on Wednesday.

title: The Law; At the Bar
description: Clustered around the bench of Federal District Judge H. Lee Sarokin, the nine defense lawyers looked prosperous and formidable, a modern version of the Rembrandt reproduced on the Dutch Masters box. What concerns them, though, aren't cigars but cigarettes, specifically the roughly 370,000 that Rose Cipollone smoked.

title: Bond Prices Turn Slightly Higher
description: Bond prices inched up slightly in light, listless trading yesterday, as market participants closed their books on the first quarter and prepared for the start of a long holiday weekend.

title: Medical Graphics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Yanks Firm on Winfield Deal
description: The trade was still hot and still a hot topic today. The Yankees remained convinced that they could deal Dave Winfield despite the player's veto power and they continued talks with the Baltimore Orioles on a trade that could bring Fred Lynn to New York. Such a trade could also bring a challenge to the basic agreement between players and owners.

title: TRADE CONFEREES IN CONGRESS AGREE ON TOSHIBA CURBS
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed today to impose stiff import curbs against the Toshiba Corporation because a subsidary of the company had sold sensitive technology to the Soviet Union.

title: Groff Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
CUC International reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $156,000 from reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and a tax credit of $1,041,000 for the year.

title: New U.S.-Pakistan Afghan Stance Reported
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States and Pakistan had devised a new negotiating strategy on a Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan.

title: Panama Shops Open, Without Cash
description: Last week, in the heady first days of an ''indefinite'' general strike against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the streets of this normally bustling capital were best described in a refrain by exasperated cab drivers. ''Todas estan muertos,'' they would mutter as they sped past block after block of shuttered storefronts. ''Everything is dead.'' Today, as businessmen and other opposition figures assessed their nine-day protest, the byword seemed to be, ''Ya abrimos'' - ''We're Open'' - as expressed on one flapping white banner, above a Burger King shop.

title: Senate Votes to Aid Uranium Industry
description: The Senate has approved a bill intended to revitalize the American uranium industry by charging fees to utilities that use more than a specified amount of foreign uranium.

title: Human-Powered Craft Makes Test Flights in Mythic Quest
description: A lightweight human-powered aircraft made a successful series of test flights today in preparation for a world-record distance attempt that also will recreate the mythical flight of Daedalus.

title: Charles C. Barry, 76, Early TV Programmer
description: Charles C. Barry, a pioneer in television programming who also served as executive vice president in charge of television and radio for Young & Rubicam, the advertising agency, died of a heart attack last Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76 years old.

title: How to Push Noriega
description: The staying power of Panama's strongman, Gen. Manuel Noriega, exceeds his opponents' expectations. Washington's application of economic pressure is nevertheless the most constructive course. Even though his regime keeps finding day-to-day financial expedients, the pressure keeps building, and should finally prevail.

title: Dionics Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said 1986 share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective Dec. 31, 1987.

title: Why Takeovers Are Taking Off Again
description: LEAD: Confounding the predictions of many analysts, 1988 has witnessed an amazing resurgence of takeover activity. Less than six months after the Oct. 19 market crash, takeover activity is higher than at any time before the crash. So far this year, more than $72 billion in takeover bids have been announced, twice that of this time last year.

title: Review/Theater; Friel Adapts a Turgenev Classic
description: It was V. S. Pritchett who observed that Turgenev's ''Fathers and Sons'' was ''carefully planned in playlike fashion,'' telling us in intimate detail about an irreconcilable conflict between generations and philosophies. Despite that fact, it would be exceedingly difficult to encompass all aspects of the novel on stage. In apparent recognition of the limits of the art of adaptation, Brian Friel declares that his dramatization is ''after'' Turgenev.

title: Jackson Bids Meese Resign
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson called for the resignation of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today, saying: ''It is not a question of guilt or innocence. He simply cannot fulfill the requirements of the job.''

title: Advertising; People
description: * Gregory W. Dunn, Frank J. Colonno, Steven B. Levinson and Linda Cohenhave been promoted at Family Media publications, which named Mr. Dunn executive vice president/publishing director, Mr. Colonno group publisher, Mr. Levinson executive publisher of Homeowner magazine and Ms. Cohen publisher of Model magazine.

title: Children's Book Day
description: An array of events celebrating International Children's Book Day and the 183d aniversary of the birth of Hans Christian Andersen will be held tomorrow, beginning at 12:30 P.M., at the Model Boat Pond in Central Park, reachable from Fifth Avenue and 72d Street. The day will include model-boat racing, storytelling, games, puppet shows and readings from stories by Beatrix Potter and E. B. White. Information: 360-8157.

title: Home-Care Aides Reach Contract With Raise of 42% Over 3 Years
description: Union officials representing 60,000 home health-care workers last night announced what they called a ''breakthrough'' raise of 42 percent over three years that should help ease staff shortages.

title: Advertising; An Update on Changes Among the Magazines
description: And now, for a potpourri on publications.

title: Advertising; Uproar Over The Whittle Proposal
description: CHRISTOPHER WHITTLE, whose plans to dominate the reading material in the waiting rooms of doctors' offices has other magazine publishers in an uproar, predicted yesterday that the debut of his six magazines in late September would be ''the most successful magazine launch in history.''

title: Mortgage Bonds Linked to Ships
description: Midland Enterprises is offering $50 million in 9.90 percent first-preferred ship mortgage bonds due 2008 at 97.35 to yield 10.21 percent through the First Boston Corporation. The financing is secured by mortgages on ships.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Schisms Crumble Korea's Opposition
description: This nation's opposition coalition, the diverse group that forced the Government to carry out sweeping democratic changes last year, has dissolved in bitterness and confusion, unable to overcome personal antagonisms in time for the legislative elections next month.

title: Campaign Contributors: Seeking to Give or to Receive?
description: Why do they do it? Why do real-estate developers and other big business interests in New York contribute to political campaigns, contribute so generously that their largess can still stun the uninitiated? (And sometimes the initiated.) The question is as fundamental as such matters get in politics. The answers are, as recent hearings before a state panel demonstrated, not so simple.

title: Barrier Science & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Pontiac Refunds
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would refund the full price of Pontiac Grand Am cars sold to California residents and returned, for any reason, within 30 days. The refund would have to be applied to the purchase of another Pontiac from the same dealer. The program begins on April 1 and ends in September, at the close of the model year. G.M. said the program, intended to attract more people to dealers' showrooms, might eventually be extended to cover other models and other parts of the country.

title: Wildcats Put Their School on the Map
description: Clint Pitman pointed his van down a stretch of highway just outside the city limits and concentrated on the question his passenger had asked: What had been the most enjoyable aspect of Arizona's fantastic basketball success this season?

title: Medicore Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $95,090. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $641,001.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; U.S.-Soviet Hookup
description: Another innovation in Soviet-American relations is in the making: a live radio call-in show linking Washington and Moscow.

title: Charter Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $21,502,000 and $20,809,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary gains mainly from tax credits of $12,272,000 for the quarter and $31,047,000 for the year. c-After net from discontinued operations of $28,502,000 for the quarter and $33,207,000 for the year, and extraordinary gains mainly from settlement of claims of $90,500,000 and $114,780,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Metro-North Delays Closing Of a Bronx Commuter Station
description: At the request of Bronx officials, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad has decided to delay the closing of the Melrose station for 90 days.

title: Avalon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $830,000 and $3,303,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a tax charge of $533,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $433,000 for the year. c-Includes a loss of $435,000 for the quarter and income of $2,046,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and tax credits of $298,000 and $1,421,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The 1986 year results reflect a change in accounting for oil and gas operations.

title: Handel Program
description: The organist Anthony Newman and the New York Trumpet Ensemble are to perform Handel's ''Water Music'' and ''Royal Fireworks Music'' at Holy Trinity Church, 316 East 88th Street, on Sunday at 5 P.M. Tickets are $7. Information: 289-4100.

title: Copley Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports People; Action on Fighting
description: ''The college game is too great to allow it to be ruined by fisticuffs,'' said Edward Steitz, the athletic director at Springfield (Mass.) College, who has been secretary-editor of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball rules committee for 21 years. Steitz was leaving for the committee's meetings in Kansas City, Mo., where he said he expected the body to enact at least a one-game suspension for fighting. But he said he would push for a two-game suspension, and would urge conferences and college presidents to tack on even stronger penalties. ''Depending on the seriousness of the altercation, I can see suspensions of up to a season,'' he said. ''We're the guardians of the game and we can't kick this under the rug. We've got to move quickly and forcefully. The ugly fight scenes we've seen this season have no place in an educational setting.''

title: Abduction of Man in '75 Recounted by Witness
description: A witness in a racketeering trial has testified that she saw a man being abducted shortly before he was murdered.

title: Both Sides Raise Bids For Federated
description: After receiving improved, competing takeover offers that are within $1 a share of each other, the directors of Federated Department Stores Inc. postponed until today a decision either to reaffirm their merger agreement with R. H. Macy & Company or to accept the Campeau Corporation's latest bid.

title: Alexandra Bloch Wed To Lawrence A. Jeydel
description: The marriage of Alexandra Bloch, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Bloch of New York and Southbury, Conn., to Lawrence Alan Jeydel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Jeydel of Fair Haven, N.J., took place yesterday at the University Club in New York. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony.

title: Techdyne Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $159,280. c-Net loss

title: Club Med INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the year-ago share earnings is restated for 382,949 common shares issued Oct. 30, 1987, for the acquisition of the Caravelle Village, accounted for as if the shares were oustanding for the entire year.

title: Amount of New Issues Rises By 58% From Crash Period
description: Corporations found Wall Street a greater source of new money in the first three months of this year than during the shell-shocked climate after the stock market collapse in October. The amount for stock and bond underwriting jumped 58 percent in the first quarter, to $67.9 billion, from $43.1 billion in the previous quarter. That compares with growth of only 6 percent over the same two quarters a year ago.

title: Reebok, Patriots Agree
description: Billy Sullivan, the original owner of the New England Patriots when they were formed in 1959, has reached a tentative agreement to sell the debt-ridden team to the owner of Reebok International, a club spokesman said today.

title: Inside the Van
description: The detective who drove the surveillance van was warm in manner, quick of mind, experienced in undercover work and looked a lot like Liza Minnelli.

title: Interfund Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $2,400 for the quarter and $7,500 for the year.

title:
Patents;
Device Films People Who Fire at Road Signs
description: LEAD: An inventor in Anchorage has devised an apparatus to photograph people when they fire guns at traffic signs. John C. A. Bierman, a retired state highway employee, was awarded patent 4,734,725 this week. The patent says that traffic signs are frequently damaged by vandals who use them for target practice.

title: AW Computer Systems Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Albany's Housing Embarrassment
description: Governor Cuomo tripped over a verb in his January budget message: he asserted that New York State had ''produced'' 145,000 dwelling units since he took office, when in fact it was directly responsible for fewer than 25,000. At best, the state ''assisted'' in the production of the larger figure.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT: The Biggest States
description: Civilian unemployment in February and March. Figures are seasonally adjusted.

title: Soviet Paper's April Fooling
description: A Soviet newspaper reported today that the Argentine soccer star Diego Maradona might be talking about joining a Moscow team, but an editor said later that the story was a joke.

title: At a Ripe 25, 'Hospital' Is Healthy
description: ''General Hospital,'' an ABC soap opera nearly canceled a decade ago, celebrated its 25th anniversary today, showing no signs of ill health in the Nielsen ratings, a recovery that began when it went on location and added such contemporary anti-heroes as Luke and Laura.

title: Construction Spending Down 0.3% in February
description: Construction spending fell three-tenths of 1 percent in February, a third consecutive monthly drop, which reflected weakness in housing.

title: Who Owns Mickey Mouse?
description: Mihail Chemiakin, a Soviet artist, was forced out of his country for refusing to paint the party line. Now a resident of the United States, he is filled with enthusiasm for American culture. Recently Mr. Chemiakin painted an homage to his dual heritage: a picture of Mickey Mouse giving a Campbell's soup can to a heroic Russian count. He invited Michael Eisner, chairman of the Walt Disney Company, to view the painting at a Beverly Hills gallery.

title: District Accedes To Year Penalty For Evangelist
description: The Assemblies of God district council that wanted the Rev. Jimmy Swaggart barred from preaching for three months said today that it would go along with the one-year suspension demanded by the church's national leaders.

title: Mexico City Journal Marilyn and Virgin: Art or Sacrilege?
description: Throughout this country, no figure is more venerated than the Virgin of Guadalupe. And during this Easter Week, no person may be more despised than Rolando de la Rosa, a renegade artist who has dared to tinker with - or profane, many here say - the image of the Patroness of Mexico.

title: Angola Rebels Claim Gains
description: Angola's pro-Western rebels said today that they had killed 51 Government soldiers and shot down a helicopter in separate incidents. A statement distributed here by the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or Unita, said the soldiers were killed on Monday near Bembe in the northern province of Uige.

title: Albany Notes; Capitol Mirages: Budget, a Surplus and School Aid
description: Like parched explorers crawling toward a mirage, state legislators spent this week inching toward a budget agreement that always seemed to vanish just as they reached it.

title: Jobless Rate for New York, At 3.8%, Is Under Jersey's
description: New York State's unemployment rate dropped below New Jersey's in March for the first time in four and a half years, according to data released yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Kleinert's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary gain of $147,000.

title: Campaign Trail
description: Warning From Koch

title: Markets Closed
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets were closed yesterday in observance of Good Friday. Most foreign markets were also closed yesterday, and many European markets will remain inactive on Monday.

title: Why an $873 Flight Can Also Cost $124
description: If you find air fares baffling, you're not alone.

title: Toy Maker Has Financing Pact
description: Worlds of Wonder Inc., the once high-flying toy maker now in bankruptcy proceedings, said today that its chairman would resign as part of a financing agreement with its banks and creditors.

title: Seal and Deliver The Genocide Pact
description: LEAD: Finally, after nearly 40 years the Congress appears to be moving toward the crucial action required for ratification of the historic genocide treaty - the enactment of implementing legislation. With hearings in both houses recently completed, the target date set by Congressional proponents of the pact is April 14, Holocaust Day.

title: Macy to Get I. Magnin, Bullock's
description: In bowing out of the battle for Federated Department Stores Inc., R. H. Macy & Company has again failed in a takeover attempt, but it has gained a long-wanted stake in Southern California, one of the nation's most affluent residential markets.

title: Sizing Up Survivors' Resources
description: When 291 Divison I basketball teams began practice last October, they all had aspirations of reaching the Final Four, but only a handful had a realistic shot at getting there.

title: Holiday Weekend
description: Today is the first day of Passover and tomorrow is Easter. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parade: Fifth Avenue will be closed tomorrow between 44th and 57th Streets for the Easter Promenade, which begins at 11 A.M. and ends at 2:30 P.M. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Post Offices: Normal schedule. Transportation: Subways and buses, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on regular weekend schedules. NEW JERSEY Post Offices: Normal schedule. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular weekend schedules. CONNECTICUT Post Offices: Normal schedule. Transportation: New Haven line on regular weekend schedules.

title: Army Resuming Drug Tests
description: Taking advantage of an appeals court ruling this week, the Army today ordered a resumption of random drug testing of civilian employees in some jobs.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the On Stage column of Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect title for a play by Lonne Elder 3d that begins on April 15 at the American Place Theater. It is ''Splendid Mummer.''

title: For a New Priest, a Very Special Easter
description: The Rosary Society has taken care of the flowers, azaleas and lilies that are banked on the altar. The chasubles, white for Easter season, hang pressed and ready in the sacristy.

title: Prosecutor's Statement
description: Following is the text of the statement issued today by the office of James C. McKay, the independent prosecutor investigating Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d since last May:

title: Fed Voted to Push Rates a Bit Lower
description: Top policy makers at the Federal Reserve, faced with a weakening economy, decided to push interest rates slightly lower in late January and early February, according to minutes of their February meeting released today.

title: Lyphomed's Net Expected to Suffer
description: Lyphomed Inc., which makes injectable drugs for patients with AIDS, cancer and other critical illnesses, said that its 1988 earnings would suffer because of quality-control problems at one of its plants. In recent months, the company, based in Rosemont, Ill., has repeatedly been warned by the Food and Drug Administration about quality control problems at the plant and had been urged to correct them. The company has recalled drugs several times for quality-control reasons.

title:
Patents;
Assisting Students In Language Study
description: LEAD: A device for helping students to learn a foreign language has been invented by Helene Kaisha, a language specialist in North Haven, Conn.

title: Nicaraguans Begin Pact's 60-Day Cease-Fire
description: After more than six years of fighting, Nicaragua's warring armies today began observing a 60-day cease-fire that leaders on both sides hope will lead to permanent peace.

title: Ceradyne Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title:
Patents;
G.E. Led In Licenses Granted in '87
description: LEAD: The General Electric Company and its subsidiary, the RCA Corporation, received 1,283 patents last year, more than any other company in the world. Some Japanese companies, however, like Canon, which received 847 patents; Hitachi Ltd., with 845, and the Toshiba Corporation, with 823, also scored high, according to a study by Intellectual Property Owners Inc., a private organization of holders of patents, trademarks and copyrights.

title: Maurice Lucas Retiring
description: When Maurice Lucas signed his contract with the Portland Trail Blazers last fall he hinted that this might be his last season. The 6-foot-9-inch power forward confirmed yesterday that he was calling it quits after 14 years as a pro, 12 of them in the National Basketball Association. ''When you say that's it, that's it,'' said Lucas, who has been averaging 16.7 minutes, 6.2 points and 4.3 rebounds a game this season. The former Marquette star began his career in the 1974-75 seasons with the Spirits of St. Louis in the American Basketball Association, and played the following year for St. Louis and the Kentucky Colonels. He was acquired by the Blazers in the A.B.A. dispersal draft in August 1976, and started on the 1976-77 National Basketball Association championship team, going on to spend time with the Nets, the Knicks, Phoenix, the Los Angeles Lakers and Seattle last season before returning to Portland.(AP)

title: Advice To the Lorn
description: Let's answer the mail:

title: Kafka's Kafkaesque Love Letters

title: U.S. WILL INCREASE ITS PANAMA FORCE BY 1,300 SOLDIERS
description: The United States will send 1,300 more troops to Panama next week to improve the security of American bases and citizens there, the Defense Department announced today.

title: Careamerica Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company is a development- stage company whose operations began in September 1986. It had no revenue from continuing operations for 1986. The company said its 1987 revenue was derived from sales by its American Microelectronics Inc. unit, an Austin, Texas-based contract manufacturer of printed circuit boards, which it acquired last November.

title: A P Green Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a writedown of about $5.6 million for both the quarter and year. The company has no share earnings for the latest periods because it went public in February of this year.

title: Sequa Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,167,000 for the quarter and $3,653,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After net from discontinued operations of $3,596,000 for the quarter and $12,854,000 for the year, and a gain of $124,176,000 on disposal of the company's graphic arts business for the both periods; the year also included a charge of $4,943,000 from equity in the net loss of Chromalloy American Corp.'s discontinued operations. The latest periods included net after-tax portfolio losses of $23.8 million for the quarter and $13.2 million for the year. The year-ago fourth quarter net also included a charge of $2,274,000 for equity in Chromalloy's losses from discontinued operations.

title: Albany Assailed Over Cut In Building Inquiry Money
description: By refusing to finance a special investigation in the Manhattan District Attorney's office, the Legislature is ''sending a signal that the state government is not committed to rooting out racketeering in the construction industry,'' the head of a civic anticrime group said yesterday.

title: QUARTERLY GAINERS AND LOSERS ON THE AMEX
description: Common stocks listed on the American Stock Exchange that showed the largest percentage gains and losses in the first quarter of 1988. Prices are adjusted for splits. Listings exclude stocks trading fewer than 1,000 shares or for less than $2 a share.

title: Still a Bad Trade Bill
description: Negotiations on the foreign trade bill have stripped away page after page of crippling protectionism from the original House and Senate legislation, but there's still too much. President Reagan has at least a half-dozen good reasons for a veto.

title: Integrated Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,871,000 from early extinguishment of debt. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $10,395,000 and an extraordinary charge of $10,510,000 from early extinguishment of debt. The company said in the prior year, preferred dividend requirements exceeded final net income.

title: Review/Rock; A SOUL CONCERT BY TERENCE TRENT D'ARBY
description: Terence Trent D'Arby, a singer who has been enjoying a full-tilt record-business hype (including a live performance on the Grammy Awards telecast), has at the moment about two-thirds of what it will take to make him a star. He writes catchy songs with a smart, enigmatic tinge, and his voice can rasp, croon, slide or float into falsetto as if the whole pantheon of soul singers were in his throat. He's photogenic, with doe eyes and flaring cheekbones, and he can dance like James Brown or Prince -not continuously, but in what television producers might call dance-bites.

title: Hampton Healthcare reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ALCOTT POSTS 66 FOR ONE-SHOT LEAD
description: Laura Davies, the English golfer with thunder in her drives, today became the fourth woman in the 17-year history of the Nabisco Dinah Shore tournament to reach the island green of the 487-yard, par-5 18th hole at Mission Hills in two shots.

title: Somebody's Idea of a Joke
description: When you got the message yesterday to call Mr. Fox, did you dial what turned out to be the number for the Bronx Zoo?

title: Sisters Under the Fur
description: LEAD: It's the beginning of April - time to put my fur coat into storage. I'll be sorry to part with the sleek brown beaver that has kept me warm all winter. The end of the season has made me think about the past winter, my first as a fur owner, and some unusual experiences.

title:
Your Money;
Pension Benefits Need Close Study
description: LEAD: People who are counting on their corporate pensions to pay for their retirements may be disappointed, benefits experts say. As a result of changes in company benefits policies, some workers will have to rely less on the pensions paid by their employers, and take on more of the burden of financing their own retirements.

title: Computer Devices Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a tax credit of $35,000.

title: Backing Set For C.D. Plan
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank of Dallas announced a new plan this week to lower the high cost of funds at Southwest savings institutions through certificates of deposit backed by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

title: JOHN P. COHALAN, 80, EX-JUSTICE AND SUFFOLK COUNTY OFFICIAL, DIES
description: John P. Cohalan Jr., a retired justice of the New York State Supreme Court and an associate justice of the court's Appellate Division, died on Wednesday at his home in Sayville, L.I. He was 80 years old.

title: Cadema Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
J. Hunter Walton, Dairy Merchant, 71
description: J. Hunter Walton, chairman emeritus of Hunter Walton & Company, a dairy merchant in New York, died of an aneurysm Thursday at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 72 years old.

title: Spoleto in Brooklyn
description: Chamber music by Mozart, Brahms and Kodaly is to be offered as part of the Spoleto Comes to BAM series at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, at 8 o'clock tonight. The performers are to be Joshua Bell, violinist; Carter Brey, cellist; Jeffrey Kahane, pianist, and Scott Nickrenz, violist. Tickets are $8.50 to $12. Information: (718) 636-4100.

title: Seoul Apologizes for a 'Tragic Incident'
description: The Government apologized today for its long silence over the 1980 killings of hundreds of protesters in the city of Kwangju.

title: Japan's Surplus Shows a Drop
description: Japan announced today that its current-account surplus for the month of February fell to $6.85 billion from $7.63 billion a year earlier.

title: American City Business Jourals reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Include a restructuring charge of $9 million for both the quarter and year.

title:
Patents;
Reactor Control Rod
description: LEAD: A temperature-responsive nuclear reactor shutdown control rod was patented this week for the Department of Energy. Konstantin Bilibin of North Hollywood, Calif., was granted patent 4,734,252. Objects of the invention are described as offering sufficient compactness for contemporary reactors and the opportunity for an operator to reset the device when the coolant is at or below normal temperature.

title: Assault of a Woman Prompts Charges Against 11 in Texas
description: Eleven men were charged after a 19-year-old woman told the police she was raped repeatedly by a group of men who urged onlookers to join in, the authorities said Thursday.

title: F.C.C.'s Phone Rate Plan Is Under Attack in Congress
description: Opposition is growing to a sweeping regulatory proposal that would give the American Telephone and Telegraph Company more freedom over what it charges for long-distance calls - and that could possibly end the trend of declining phone rates.

title: Horizon Healthcare Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: This was Horizon's third quarter as a public company.

title: Bedrosian Is Out At Least a Month
description: Steve Bedrosian, who is suffering from pneumonia, will probably be unavailable to the Philadelphia Phillies at least until the end of April.

title: Cardinal Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Kodak-Fuqua Tie
description: A Supreme Court justice stepped out of a legal dispute over the merger of the photofinishing operations of the Eastman Kodak Company and Fuqua Industries - one he had entered a day before. Justice Byron R. White set aside an emergency order he had issued Thursday on the request of the Phototron Corporation, ruling that the request had been made too late. Justice White on Thursday had set aside a Federal appeals court decision that cleared the way for the merger despite a pending antitrust challenge by Phototron, but in today's superseding order, Justice White said that the merger had actually occurred before he issued the order. He noted today that he was ''not advised of the closing'' of the merger when he issued Thursday's order. The deal between Kodak and Fuqua created the nation's largest wholesale photofinishing operation.

title: Whiting Petroleum reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Trade Bill Vulnerable To a Veto
description: In completing most of the sweeping trade bill that has been in the works for nearly three years, House and Senate conferees have retained several provisions that President Reagan finds objectionable.

title: Orient-Express Hotels Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $17 million.

title: Oklahoma, Arizona May Be Top Teams
description: Arizona and Oklahoma deny that they have chips on their shoulders. No, Arizona said, that muck about coming from the ''weak'' Pac-10 conference with plenty to prove is now worn, tiresome. No, Oklahoma said, that talk about being a bully and running up scores doesn't provide extra fuel.

title: On the Numbers of AIDS-Infected Heterosexuals
description: To the Editor:

title: Good Friday in Israel: Holy Rites and 2 More Deaths
description: Along the Via Dolorosa, Christian pilgrims walked the Stations of the Cross today on what was to all appearances a sunny and peaceful Good Friday. But there was a brief clash outside a mosque elsewhere in Jerusalem and two more Palestinians were killed near Hebron after firebombs were reportedly hurled at Israeli troops.

title: Gandhi Urged to Order Emergency In Punjab After 89 Die in a Week
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi is under growing pressure to declare a state of emergency in Punjab State, where 89 people have been killed this week in an offensive by Sikh extremists.

title: Man, 68, Surrenders In Theft of House
description: A 68-year-old retired construction worker gave himself up yesterday for moving a two-bedroom beach house from a lot in Shirley, police said.

title: THE LEADERS ARE FOCUS OF DUKE-KANSAS
description: They have been brought together, on and off, since not long after birth. Two Dannys, Danny Ferry of Duke, Danny Manning of Kansas, grew up in an atmosphere of professional basketball that had to do more with survival than glamour.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 42.

title: Calvin's Old City Carps About U.N.
description: Revolutionaries have always appreciated Geneva's calm. Calvin, Voltaire, Rousseau and Lenin all lived here. But their ideas were exported, to rock the thrones of kings and bishops in other parts of Europe.

title: Piano-Vibraharp Duets
description: Chick Corea on piano and Gary Burton on vibraharp are playing duets tonight and tomorrow at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. with a 1:30 A.M. show tonight; there is a $20 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $15 charge at the bar.

title: Pluralists Take It on the Chin - Deservedly
description: LEAD: The 80's have been bad years for pluralists like me - deservedly.

title: Leftover Eggs, In the Shell or Out
description: After Easter and Passover, eggs in the shell and out are likely to be among the leftovers to be stored.

title: FAKE FOLK
description: Recently, a New Yorker with a modest knowledge of folk art bought a small Shaker rug from a street peddler. At least the peddler said it was an authentic Shaker, and the purchaser was only too willing to take him at his word. Who, she asked herself, would bother to fake a Shaker rug?

title: International Seaway Trading Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary gain of $315,000.

title: Southwest Realty LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included writedowns of $3,980,000 for the quarter and $1,123,000 for the year, of note receivables.

title: DEATHS REPORTED IN BULGARIA IN TURKISH PROTESTS IN '84-85
description: Contradicting three years of official denials, a Bulgarian journalist has said that about 40 people died in clashes between militiamen and the country's ethnic Turkish minority.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-6 More U.S. troops will go to Panama to improve security for American bases and citizens. The Reagan Administration said it was sending an additional 1,300 troops as a response to unrest, including the storming of a hotel. Page 1 A new Iraqi chemical weapon attack killed 75 people and disabled at least 100 in late March, Iran said. The Teheran radio warned that further Iraqi attacks with mustard gas and nerve gas on major Iranian cities were likely. 1 Aid for Afghan refugees is often applied in contradiction to stated principles of the donors that prohibit help for armed forces. Relief workers say it is difficult to limit services to refugees who are not fighting. 2 The U.S. envoy to Saudi Arabia, Hume A. Horan, has been recalled because of differences between the Ambasssador and senior Saudi leaders, State Department officials said. 6 Sikh violence in India's Punjab State has increased pressure on Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi to declare a state of emergency. Sikh extremists killed 89 people this week in a violent offensive. 1 South Korea sought to ease passions over the killing of hundreds of protestors in Kwangju in 1980. A Government statement expressed regret for the pain victims suffered but did not apologize for the killings. 3 Curbs on the Toshiba Corporation that U.S. Congressional negotiators want to include in a trade bill were denounced by Japanese Government and business leaders, who said the act violated Japanese sovereignty. 29 A cease-fire in Nicaragua began as the country's warring armies started a 60-day cease-fire that both sides hope will lead to a permanent peace. The Defense Ministry said the truce was being observed across the country. 4 Basque separatist violence in Spain is on the rise. Bombings and an assassination have ended hopes that the Government offer of a truce would end violence and allow economic recovery in the Basque region. 6 Calvin's old city carps about U.N. 3 Police say 3 large drug groups joined forces in Italian ring 3 Mexico City Journal: Marilyn and Virgin - art or sacrilege? 4 NATIONAL 7-10, 24 No indictment for Edwin Meese 3d is contemplated, based on the evidence so far, a special prosecutor said. The prosecutor, James C. McKay, said his investigation involving the Attorney General would continue through April. 1 A surplus in Government accounts could result when, as is expected, Social Security payroll taxes greatly exceed the benefits paid out. Some wonder whether debates over surpluses will be stormier than debates over deficits. 1 The Federated Stores takeover battle has been won by the Campeau Corporation of Canada for $6.6 billion. R. H. Macy & Co., which had also bid for Federated, the nation's largest department store chain, received the right to buy two of Federated's California divisions. 1 Jobs increased in March, and the unemployment rate dropped to 5.5 percent, the lowest level since 1979. The growth of 262,000 jobs was higher than expected and suggested continued moderate expansion of the economy. 1 Study of non-European cultures will be included in a required Western culture course for freshmen at Stanford University. The faculty approved the proposal with limited opposition. 7 A project to save the red wolf, a particularly endangered species, is returning them to the wild. Four wolves on a Federal wildlife refuge in North Carolina are among the 80 remaining in captivity. 7 Gay student groups won equal access to facilities and financing at Georgetown University. Under a settlement reached Tuesday, the Roman Catholic university does not have to recognize or endorse the groups. 7 Unpainting the White House 7 District Accedes To Year Penalty For Evangelist 7 Army to resume drug tests 10 U.S. Says Big Meatpacker Cheated Workers 10 Pipe inspections ordered at nuclear plants 24 POLITICS 9 News analysis: Michael Dukakis campaigned at Milwaukee's Serb Hall, where Democratic Presidential candidates in past races stirred enthusiasm among blue-collar voters. There was applause for Mr. Dukakis, but no cheers. 9 Jesse Jackson must court whites as he campaigns for the Democratic Presidential nomination in Wisconsin, a state that is only 3 percent black. White voters have greeted Mr. Jackson enthusiastically at campaign stops. 9 REGIONAL 25-27 Lists of unsanitary restaurants with possible inaccuracies were issued for over a year to protect an undercover operation into corruption among inspectors, New York City's Health Commissioner said. 25 Store vacancies on Madison Avenue have hit a record for recent times in the prime blocks between 60th and 80th Street, though the prestigious street remains commercially healthy. About 20 street-level shops are empty. 25 Agreement on New York's budget seemed to vanish just as state legislators thought they had reached one. Until negotiations broke down, most thought it would be easy to reach by yesterday's deadline. 25 Long Island's demand for electricity can be met even if the the Shoreham nuclear power plant does not open, Lilco said. The State Public Service Commission ordered Lilco to prepare an energy plan without the nuclear plant. 26 Apartments built with city subsidies on the Lower East Side can be sold as co-operatives or condominiums after 20 years, according to an agreement between the Koch administration and the developer Samuel J. LeFrak. 27 A newspaper charged censorship when it lost its lease at Co-op City. City News criticized management at the giant Bronx complex. But officials said they evicted the weekly only for business considerations. 27 New York State's unemployment rate drops below New Jersey's 8 For a young priest, it's a special Easter 25 Cut in building inquiry money is assailed 26 Jersey jail guard shoots 2 dead and kills himself 26

title: Marketing Gives Corning a Boost
description: A catchy television commercial showing a transparent cooking pot being used to melt an aluminum saucepan has helped spawn a resurgence of cookware at the Corning Glass Works, which had been in decline because of strong foreign competition.

France Rejects Concessions On Hostages Despite Election
description: Defense Minister Andre Giraud said today that France wanted to free French hostages in Lebanon, but warned that the kidnappers should not expect concessions to coincide with presidential elections.

title: Corning Withdraws Its Bid For International Clinical
description: Corning Glass Works said yesterday that it had ended its $35-a-share offer for control of International Clinical Laboratories Inc., after a three-week struggle with the SmithKline Beckman Corporation.

As a result, comparisons with the year-ago periods are not meaningful.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The instability of the current situation in Panama, the heavy-handed tactics of Noriega in dealing with the situation, and the potential for increased threats to U.S. citizens and interests in Panama make this deployment essential at this time to insure the continued safety of U.S. personnel and facilities.'' - The Pentagon. [ 1:3. ]

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, APRIL 2, 1988
description: Companies

title: ST. LAWRENCE REACHES FINAL
description: Peter Lappin, the scrappy center for St. Lawrence, has been known for hanging around the opponent's goal, waiting, watching and ready.

title: Jobless Rate Drops To 5.5% as Payrolls Expand Vigorously
description: Job growth surged in March and the unemployment rate edged down to 5.5 percent, the lowest level since 1979, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Rent Increases Forcing Stores Off Madison Ave.
description: A ''Lost Our Lease'' sign stretches across the plate glass window at L'Elegance Paris Rome on Madison Avenue near 78th Street, announcing a going-out-of-business sale -adding yet another site to the glut of shuttered storefronts and for-rent signs along the prestigious avenue.

title: Stanford Alters Western Culture Course
description: With little final opposition, Stanford University's faculty has voted to replace the required Western culture course for first-year undergraduates with one that includes the study of non-European cultures and works by women, blacks, Hispanic people, Asians and American Indians.

title: New Issue on Budget Horizon: What to Do About Surpluses
description: It may be hard to believe in this era of enormous Federal budget deficits, but the Government could soon be showing surpluses, even decades of large and growing surpluses.

title: GMI Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After pretax provisions of $47,000 and $474,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, for losses on sale of the company's investment in a federal securities fund. c-Net income

title: Texas Intl Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $515,000. c-After extraordinary gains of $247,000 for the quarter and $809,000 for the year.

title: Frances Denney Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest year results were restated.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about the New York City Board of Estimate gave an incorrect list of board members who voted for a development project favored by a campaign contributor. Although the developer and his lawyer contributed to David N. Dinkins, Mr. Dinkins had not yet been elected Manhattan Borough President and did not participate in the votes on that project.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Ted Nance, the executive director of the Bluebonnet Bowl, said the bowl may soon cease to exist. ''If we don't get a title sponsor, I think it would be difficult to continue to have the game as we've done in the past,'' he said. The bowl still owes about $100,000 to Pittsburgh and Texas for this year's game and must come up with the final payments before the National Collegiate Athletic Association postseason committee meets on April 14 or face decertification. . . . The Baltimore Orioles signed Dickie Noles, a pitcher, and Dale Berra, an infielder, to contracts with their minor league teams. . . . Representatives from Montreal and the Tour de France participated in talks that ended yesterday, but no agreement was reached in the negotiations to stage part of the 1992 Tour de France in Montreal to coincide with the 350th anniversary of that city and the 500th anniversary of the discovery of North America. . . . Coach Jim Valvano of North Carolina State, and his wife, Pamela, visited Los Angeles yesterday to discuss the vacant U.C.L.A. basketball coaching job, according to school officials.

title: Suit Challenges Immigration Rules
description: The State and City of New York as well as individual plaintiffs filed a class action suit against the Immigration and Naturalization Service yesterday, challenging ''unlawfully restrictive regulations'' that may deny legal status to aliens with children receiving public assistance.

title: Dyansen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $44,000 from cumulative effect of an accounting change for both the quarter and year.

title: Rural Wisconsin Town Turns Out for Jackson
description: The size of the crowd that turned out for the Rev. Jesse Jackson today at Bu-Fay Farms in northwestern Wisconsin was bigger than even the turnout for the annual Farm-City Day in this depressed farming community.

title: Article 951388 -- No Title
description: The Federal Aviation Administration ordered a $632,200 civil fine today for numerous safety violations against Orion Air, the cargo airline that is being sought out to fly passengers in case of a strike at Eastern Airlines.

title: P.I.P. Accepts New Buyout Offer
description: Postal Instant Press, a franchiser of short-term printing and copying centers, said it had agreed to a sweetened buyout proposal of $17.41 a share, or $69.3 million, from an investor group consisting of management and Golder Thoma & Cressey, a Chicago leveraged buyout concern. In February, the group made an initial bid of $17. Just as the offer was to expire earlier this month, the company said it had received a bid of $17.50 a share from an unidentified third party.

title: Japanese Protest Curbs On Toshiba
description: Japanese Government and business leaders today denounced an agreement by United States Congressional negotiators to include stringent curbs on the Toshiba Corporation in an omnibus trade bill.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Campbell Soup Co., Camden, N.J., said it had sold its Pietro's chain of 65 pizzerias in the Northwest to a company formed by Dimeling, Schriber & Daglish of Philadelphia. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Canadian Bidder Beats Macy In Fight for Federated Stores
description: Ending a tangled, often bitter two-month takeover battle, Federated Department Stores Inc., the owner of Bloomingdale's, Filene's and Abraham & Straus, accepted a $6.6 billion cash takeover bid from the Campeau Corporation yesterday.

title: U.S. Replacing Its Envoy to Saudis
description: State Department officials said today that Hume A. Horan had been recalled from his post as Ambassador to Saudi Arabia, largely because of personal differences between the envoy and senior Saudi leaders.

description: The catalytic weekend for this season in the children's mercantile trade, Passover-Easter (isn't it a wonder no merchandiser came up with a brainstorm to annoy everyone, something like Passeaster or Eastover?), was bearing down hard, and outside a shoe store for diminutive feet on the Lower East Side there was a perambulator jam.

description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it would propose to reduce the extra deposit insurance premium it has imposed on the savings and loan industry since 1985, beginning later this year.

description: The company said 1986 net included $2,718,613 premium income earned since March 1986 by a unit.

title: RANGERS UNABLE TO HOLD OFF JETS
description: There were myriad plot twists, wild swings of emotion and goals both frequent and freakish. Their heads spinning and their fingers crossed, the Rangers emerged barely clinging to the path to the playoffs.

title: Iran Reports New Iraqi Gas Raids; And Says Cities May be Hit Next
description: Iran said today that 75 people had been killed and at least 100 injured in new Iraqi attacks with mustard gas and nerve gas, and the Teheran radio warned that widespread Iraqi chemical attacks on major Iranian cities are likely.

title: Compuchem Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Basque Attacks Shatter Hope for End to Strife
description: A truce that prompted hope for an end to the war between Basque separatists and the rest of Spain has been shattered by renewed violence.

title: Constructive Chaos at a Big-Power Arts Feast
description: ''Making Music Together,'' Boston's sprawling and ambitious Soviet-American arts festival, concludes Saturday night after three crowded and often chaotic weeks. The festival threw together nearly 600 Soviet and American musicians, dancers, singers, composers, conductors, actors, poets and technicians to produce roughly 100 events in six different theaters and 21 local schools. In the process, it has had more than its share of onstage triumphs and backstage troubles.

title: V.A. Loan Rate Raised to 10%
description: The Veterans Administration said today that it would raise its maximum interest rate for federally backed home mortgages by half a percentage point, to 10 percent.

title: Transmark Buys 10% of Air Wis
description: Transmark USA Inc. and its president, Mark C. Sanford, have purchased the equivalent of a 10 percent stake in Air Wis Services Inc. and said it might seek control of the airline holding company, based in Appleton, Wis. Air Wis, the parent of the nation's largest regional air carrier, said recently that it was not for sale after receiving an unsolicited $14-a-share cash and note offer from a group led by its senior management. The management bid was the second unsolicited offer for the airline holding company in the last four months.

title: Central Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29

title:
Patents;
Compounds for Ending Muscle Paralysis
description: LEAD: Compounds patented this week are capable of reversing the muscle paralysis that may follow surgery. Dr. Francis F. Foldes and Iraj Lalezari, who were granted patent 4,734,275 for the anti-curare agents, did their research at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx.

title: GIBBONS TRADED TO DODGERS
description: John Gibbons, once billed as the catcher of the future on the Mets, finally escaped the shadow of Gary Carter today when the Mets traded him to the Los Angeles Dodgers for Craig Shipley, a minor-league shortstop who was born in Australia.

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page map caption in some editions yesterday incorrectly described the Thai camp at which some Cambodian refugees told of having carried supplies into Cambodia for the Khmer Rouge. The refugees fled to the camp, Site 2, a non-Communist settlement, after being used as Khmer Rouge porters; their treks into Cambodia were made from other camps.

title: Red Wolf, Nearly Extinct, Being Trained to Survive in the Wild
description: Deep in the Alligator River National Wildlife Refuge, four red wolves are isolated in pens as part of an ambitious project to restore one of the continent's most endangered species to the wild.

description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,911,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net income and after net from discontinued operations of $45,571,000 and $53,607,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary gains of $10,906,000 for the quarter and $13,459,000 for the year. The latest quarter and year losses from continuing operations both include writedowns of $9,110,000 for impairment in value of certain of the company's equity investments. The year-earlier quarter and year losses from continuing operations include gains from the sale of investments in Enron Corp. of $14,000,000 and in associated companies of $4,189,000, less writedowns of investments in National Intergroup Inc. of $11,805,000 and Brae Corp. of $15,607,000.
