description: Questions appear on page 10.

title: Dukakis and Jackson Differ in Appeal To Wisconsin's Working-Class Voters
description: The American Serb Memorial Hall on Milwaukee's South Side is one of the landmarks on the Presidential campaign trail. For 30 years and more, Democratic White House hopefuls have spoken there, hoping to stir the enthusiasm of working-class ethnic voters in this historically pivotal primary state.

title: Reflections On 'Beloved Country'
description: Alan Paton believes it is for others to judge whether ''Cry, the Beloved Country,'' his classic novel of racial hatred, despair and reconciliation, has stood the test of time.

title: A RETAIL BATTLE OF TITANS ENDS
description: Following are the highlights of the battle for Federated Stores waged between Macy and Campeau. Jan. 25, 1988: Campeau Corporation of Canada begins a $4.2 billion, $47-a-share takeover bid for Federated Department Stores Inc. Jan. 26: Federated files suit in Columbus, Ohio, seeking to block the Campeau tender offer. Feb. 3: Campeau increases its bid to $5.2 billion, or $61 a share. Feb. 5: Federated says its board has unanimously rejected the $47-a-share cash tender offer. Feb. 15: Federated announces that it is holding talks with Campeau and several other parties. Feb. 16: Campeau again sweetens its bid, adding another $5 a share, to $66 a share, or a total of $5.7 billion. Feb. 29: In a surprise bid, R. H. Macy & Company offers more than $6.1 billion, or $73.80 a share, in cash and stock. March 2: Federated agrees to a Macy offer of $6.2 billion. Hours later, Campeau revises its bid. March 8: Macy files a lawsuit against Campeau, seeking to postpone the expiration of the competing offer. March 14: Macy increases the cash front end of its offer by $200 million, to $77.35 a share for 80 percent of Federated's stock. March 16: Campeau says that it is ready to pay $68 a share for all of Federated's stock. March 18: Federated's poison pill defense is upheld in Federal court, a setback for Campeau. March 22: Campeau sweetens its offer to $6.6 billion, or $73 a share. March 23: The Federated board meets to discuss the sweetened bid from Campeau. March 24: Federated says that it has begun talks with Macy on a possible higher offer after receiving the new Campeau bid. March 29: Federated gives guidelines for final offers to the two bidders, leaving its poison pill plan in place. March 31: After two days of meetings of Federated's board, Macy revises its tiered bid and says the new offer is worth $75.14 a share, or $6.7 billion. Campeau proposed $74 a share in cash. April 1: Campeau wins Federated, in a $73.50-a-share, or $6.6 billion, deal that allows Macy to buy two Federated divisions.

title: Cannon's Results To Be Delayed
description: Cannon Group Inc. said it expected to report substantially higher operating losses for 1987. It said the release of its financial results would be delayed because of recent transactions with European investors. The film company also said it had settled two class-action lawsuits brought by shareholders and bondholders for $20 million, although the pacts still need court approval.

title: Oxford Crew Is Favored
description: With its heaviest crew in the history of the event and six members back from last year's winning crew, Oxford University will go into its annual rowing race with Cambridge on Saturday as a firm favorite to post its 12th victory in the last 13 years.

title: Pact for Schlichter
description: The Ottawa Rough Riders, who have gone through 30 quarterbacks in the 1980's, including four starters last season when they managed only three victories in 18 games, will give Art Schlichter a chance at making the Canadian Football League team. The Rough Riders signed the former Ohio State star, who has been plagued with problems related to gambling since he was picked on the first round by the Colts in the 1982 National Football League draft. The Rough Riders signed him to a one-year contract for a reported $125,000 and a $25,000 bonus on Thursday. Schlichter, with income of $3,800 last year and nearly $1 million in debt, filed for protection in United States Bankruptcy Court in Columbus, Ohio, this week. He was suspended for the 1983 season for gambling. He joined the Buffalo Bills in 1986, then made the Indianapolis Colts as a backup last season. His contract was not accepted because of another gambling incident.(AP)

title: Streaking Devils Can Catch the Stumbling Flyers
description: The Devils are playing so effectively right now that they could win the Stanley Cup. The only trouble is that they are still in danger of not making the playoffs.

title: Lilco Offers Plan to Meet Energy Needs Without Shoreham
description: The Long Island Lighting Company said today that it could meet the energy needs of Long Island even if the Shoreham nuclear power plant never opens.

title: A Weapons Program That Works!
description: Among the usual array of foul-ups in the Defense Department's strategic weapons systems, the House Armed Services Committee has uncovered a surprise: a well-managed, technically successful program that's on time and within cost. Its success contains useful lessons for Pentagon management.

title: Co-op City Ends Lease Of Hard-Hitting Paper
description: Amid accusations of censorship, the management of Co-op City has terminated the lease of a weekly community newspaper that regularly criticizes the way the giant housing complex in the northeast Bronx is governed.

LeFrak's Offer Allows Chance For Conversions
description: In an agreement not previously disclosed by the Koch administration, the developer Samuel J. LeFrak will be allowed after 20 years to sell as cooperatives or condominiums the 800 moderate- and middle-income rental apartments that he has offered to build with city subsidies on the Lower East Side.

title: Review/Jazz; Old Sense of Play Lives On In the Music of Clark Terry
description: Of all the many changes inflicted on jazz by the 1960's, perhaps the worst was the loss of a sense of play. The flugelhornist and trumpeter Clark Terry, who began his career in 1945, has that sense of play, and hearing him Wednesday at Carlos One was like walking into a different world, where rhythms, melodies and words are all used in service of the sort of creativity that revels in itself and becomes an act of self-affirmation.

title: PHL Corp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $332,000 for the quarter and $2,036,000 for the year. The latest year included losses of $3,641,000 from the restructuring of its College Life Insurance Co. of America unit's investment portfolio and a $9.5 million provision for restructuring costs applicable to the trading stamp segment. Comparative results are not available; the company emerged from Chapter 11 reorganization proceedings on Nov. 13, 1986.

title: Review/Jazz; Chamber Music Is Duo's Muse
description: Chick Corea and Gary Burton belong to the wing of jazz that finds as much inspiration in European chamber music as in the African-American tradition that sprang from New Orleans. When working together, the pianist and vibraharpist, who opened a six-night engagement at the Blue Note (131 West Third Street) on Tuesday, become frisky impressionists playing off the sonorities of their instruments against one another in effervescent duets that reveal their mastery of a refined Europe-oriented chromaticism.

title: Candidate Declares Victory
description: A judgeship candidate whose rival was slain last weekend asked Gov. James G. Martin today not to call a special legislative session that would allow a candidate from a minority group to enter the primary race. In his meeting with the Governor, District Attorney Joe Freeman Britt, a white, declared himself the rightful Democratic nominee for Superior Court judge in racially troubled Robeson County. His rival, Julian Pierce, a Lumbee Indian, was shot to death last week in what apparently was a domestic dispute. There is no Republican candidate for the judgeship.

title: CORRECTION
description: A biographical sketch yesterday about James B. Stewart of The Wall Street Journal, who won a Pulitzer Prize for explanatory journalism, misidentified the college he attended.

description: Over-the-counter common stocks that showed the largest percentage gains and losses in the first quarter of 1988. Prices are adjusted for splits. Listings exclude stocks trading fewer than 1,000 shares or for less than $2 a share.

description: A dramatic three-hour showdown Thursday night between Edward S. Finkelstein and Robert Campeau at Mr. Finkelstein's Manhattan town house led to the $6.6 billion merger agreement reached yesterday morning between Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Campeau Corporation.

title: LOUISIANA TECH TO PLAY AUBURN FINAL
description: Louisiana Tech clamped down on top-rated Tennessee to earn a 68-59 victory tonight and advance to the final round of the Women's Division I National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

description: The United States announced today that beginning July 1 it would eliminate duty-free imports on products worth $1.1 billion in 1987, shipped here from 140 third world countries.

description: To protect an undercover corruption investigation, New York City's top health official allowed possibly inaccurate lists of unsanitary restaurants to be issued for more than a year.

title: Ex-Packer Sentenced
description: John Brockington, a former star running back for the Green Bay Packers, was apologetic when he was sentenced to three years' probation for tax evasion stemming from his role with the J. David & Company investment firm. ''I'm very sorry for what happened,'' Brockington told United States District Court Judge Earl Gilliam in San Diego on Thurday, after the judge suspended a two-year Federal prison term and ordered Brockington to cooperate with the Internal Revenue Service on repayment of $7,992 in taxes not paid for 1982. J. David Dominelli, the founder of the company, is serving 20 years in prison for mail and bankruptcy fraud.(AP)

title: Jim Jordan, Radio's Fibber McGee, Is Dead at 91
description: Jim Jordan, who delighted audiences for two decades as the well-meaning but bumbling Fibber McGee in the classic radio show ''Fibber McGee and Molly,'' died today at the Beverly Hills Medical Center. He was 91 years old.

title: A New Police Unit Starts Special Patrols
description: A special Police Department unit created to patrol Bridgeport's downtown started work yesterday with orders to target vagrants and prostitutes.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Hawks 105, 76ers 93: Dominique Wilkins scored 28 points, including 6 late in the game, as visiting Atlanta clinched a playoff berth last night. The victory was the fourth straight for the Hawks although they made only 12 free throws compared to 28 for Philadelphia. Atlanta had 15 free-throw attemptes and the 76ers 45. Atlanta led, 85-73, on a jumper by John Battle with 9 minutes 24 seconds to play, but Philadelphia rallied to cut the deficit to 92-89 with 4:28 left. Wilkins then scored 6 points during an 8-1 Atlanta spurt, and his two free throws with 2:13 remaining gave Atlanta a 100-90 advantage. For the Hawks, Glenn Rivers added 19 points and 10 assists. Charles Barkley had 26 points and 10 rebounds and Mike Gminski scored 19 points for Philadelphia, whose three-game winning streak was broken.(AP) Bullets 118, Mavericks 103: Moses Malone scored 13 of his 27 points in the fourth quarter, and Bernard King added 18 to lead Washington at home. The victory moved the Bullets to within a half-game of Philadelphia in the race for the final Eastern Conference playoff berth. Jeff Malone scored 13 of his 23 points in the first half as the Bullets built a 56-45 lead. He added 10 more in the third period helping Washington hold off a Dallas comeback that closed the margin to 86-81 after three quarters. Jeff Malone left holding his hip late in the third period, and did not play in the final quarter. Dallas narrowed the gap to 90-88, on Detlef Schrempf's free throw with 9:35 remaining in the game. Then, with Washington leading, 92-90, the Bullets scored 9 consecutive points, including 7 from King. Mark Aguirre, who scored 21 in the first half, finished with 38 points to lead the Mavericks. Rolando Blackman added 21 for Dallas.(AP) N.H.L. Red Wings 7, Maple Leafs 3: Shawn Burr scored two goals last night to lead Detroit at home and extend Toronto's losing streak to eight games. The Maple Leafs are 1-14 in their last 15 games and have lost 11 straight on the road. Burr opened the scoring for Detroit 21 seconds into the game, picking up the puck behind the Toronto net and banging a shot off the stick and through the skates of Ken Wregget, the Toronto goaltender. After Gerard Gallant scored his 34th goal to give Detroit a 2-0 lead, Burr got his second of the game and 17th of the season, again picking up the puck along the boards and skating uncontested in front of the net before bouncing a shot off Wregget.(AP) Golf Record Performance by Sluman: Jeff Sluman set course and tournament records for 36 holes yesterday and established a two-shot lead at the halfway point of the $1 million Greater Greensboro Open. The bogey-free seven-under-par round, combined with an opening 64, left Sluman at 15-under-par 129 after two rounds at the Forest Oaks Country Club. That score broke the course record of 132, set by Sandy Lyle of Scotland in 1985, and the tournament record of 131, set by George Archer at Sedgefield in 1967. Sluman's 36-hole score also matched the low on the PGA Tour this year. But even those heroics were not enough to shake his old nemesis, Lyle, a former winner of this title. He put together a 63, one lower than the course record set by Tom Purtzer in 1980 and tied by Lyle in 1986. It left Lyle at 131.(AP) Tennis Sanchez Is Winner: Unseeded Arantxa Sanchez of Spain continued a string of upsets yesterday at the $200,000 Eckerd Open in Largo, Fla., by eliminating fifth-seeded Katerina Maleeva, 6-2, 6-2, in a quarterfinal match. The straight-set victory advanced the 16-year-old Sanchez into the semifinals, where she will face another unseeded player, Patricia Tarabini of Argentina. Sanchez, 45th in the world, used a steady baseline game to beat the 12th-ranked Maleeva of Bulgaria.(AP) Horse Racing Cadillacing Wins by 2 Lengths: Cadillacing swept wide into the stretch to take the lead and went on to a two-length victory yesterday in the Distaff Handicap for fillies and mares at Aqueduct. Cagey Exuberance was second in the field of five. The victory was the fifth in seven career starts and the second straight stakes victory for Cadillacing, who won the Davona Dale Stakes at Gulfstream in her last start, March 5. Cadillacing, a 4-year-old daughter of Alydar and Relaxing, earned $84,450 for his owner, Ogden Phipps, after covering the seven furlongs on the fast track in 1:22:3. Cadillacing paid $3.60 for $2 to win as the favorite. Track Brooklyn Runners Sweep: Brooklyn high school runners swept the 440 and 880 events yesterday at the Kearny Relays at Kearny (N.J.) High School. Warren Nurse of Prospect Heights won the boys' 440 in 49.7 seconds and his teammate, Greg St. Ulmer, was first in the 880 in 1 minute 57.2 seconds. In the girls' division, Kyron Agard of Tilden was the winner of the 440-yard run in 56.2 seconds and her teammate, Renee Ray, finished first in the 880 in 2:17.

Mr. Carlucci began a three-day visit here that was to include tours of Moroccan military bases. On Sunday, he will fly to India and then visit Pakistan and Tunisia.

title: U.C.L.A. Gets Gay Fraternity
description: Delta Lambda Phi, an 11-member fraternity organized by homosexual men, has been approved by the University of California at Los Angeles, which last month approved a lesbian sorority. Official recognition means the fraternity can use the school's name, meet on campus and apply for student activities funds, said Chris Fishburn, U.C.L.A.'s director of fraternity and sorority relations. The fraternity is barred from discriminating against heterosexuals, should any apply.

description: Excitement over takeovers, a switch by investors to smaller stocks and an abiding fear of a reoccurrence of October's crash were the key features of the stock market in the year's opening quarter.

title: Unpainting White House
description: Paint that has built up on the outside of the White House since 1797 is being removed as part of a project to spruce up the Presidential residence for its bicentennial in 1992.

description: The police shut down part of the Schuylkill Expressway outside Philadelphia for nearly an hour today in an effort to find a man who stabbed to death two women and wounded a couple working on an archeological dig.

description: All three of Italy's major underworld organizations have worked together in the trans-Atlantic drug trade, indicating that the New York Mafia families had more extensive contacts here than previously thought, senior Italian police officials said today.

title: Review/Dance; From Jazz Tap Ensemble, A Happy-Go-Lucky Style
description: The Jazz Tap Ensemble can certainly put on a good-natured show. But, as the Los Angeles-based company revealed Wednesday night in the second program of its engagement at the Joyce Theater, its presentations can also be so innocuous as to be lacking in oomph.

title: Choosing Film
description: As spring takes hold, cameras are coming out of storage, and snapshooters who haven't taken pictures since Christmas are buying film. The wide variety of film names can seem bewildering, and many are new. Basically, color films come in two types: negative film, for prints, and transparency film, for slides. Negative films, whose names end in ''color,'' are the most popular. Choose a film according to its speed, or sensitivity to light, depending on what you will shoot. High-speed films are usually more expensive. Prices are lowest at camera and discount stores; check the expiration date to be sure the film is fresh. Lighting Film speed Suggested films Bright sun 100 Kodacolor Gold (VRG) 100 Fujicolor Super HR 100 General outdoor use; 200 Kodacolor Gold (VRG) 200 flash portraits Fujicolor Super HR 200 Dusk; large groups 400 and up Fujicolor Super HR 400 with flash Konica SR-V 3200

title: Bessie Gambrill, 105, Professor of Education
description: Dr. Bessie Lee Gambrill, a specialist in elementary education who served on the faculty of Yale University for three decades, died yesterday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. She was 105 years old and lived at Whitney Center, a retirement home in Hamden, Conn.

title: Trade Chief Replaced In Canadian Shuffle
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney has shuffled his Cabinet with major changes in the trade and immigration portfolios.

description: The Campeau Corporation's acquisition of Federated Department Stores Inc. - the biggest takeover in retailing history - has implications for two very different businesses: It may lead to a restructuring of the retail industry and, on Wall Street, it is the deal that put the fledging firm of Wasserstein, Perella & Company on the map.

title: AT&E Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Jersey Jail Guard Shoots 2 Dead and Kills Himself
description: A county jail guard fatally shot his former companion and a 19-year-old man as they slept this morning, critically wounded the woman's mother and then went home and killed himself, the police said.

title: A Gay Rights Victory at Georgetown
description: An eight-year legal battle that pitted gay students against the nation's oldest Roman Catholic university ended this week as lawyers for Georgetown University in Washington agreed to give homosexual student groups the same privileges as other student groups.

title: Rondo Dance Theater Performing Three Modern Landmarks
description: ARTISTIC directors in search of thematic connections can be depended upon to come up with a catchy, linking alliterative phrase - like ''Fantasies, Fables and Foibles.'' Elizabeth Rockwell, founder and director of the Bedford-based Rondo Dance Theater, is using this collective title for the program to be seen Friday and Saturday at 8 P.M. and next Sunday at 3 P.M. at the State University of New York at Purchase in Theater C. The program will include four dance pieces: ''Fables for Our Time'' (with words by James Thurber), ''A Time of Crickets'' (inspired by T. S. Eliot's ''Four Quartets'') and ''Time on the Road,'' subtitled ''A Trip Through Jazz Styles,'' being performed in its entirety for the first time with the Rondo company. ''Bach Suite,'' one of the company's staples, is also on the bill. (For ticket information, the telephone number is 253-5900.) Although three of the pieces are Rondo firsts, they are landmarks of modern dance, conforming to the company's credo of perpetuating the classics of the genre.

title: Jody Silverbush to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Silverbush of North Providence, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jody Lynn Silverbush to Dr. Todd William Auerbach, a son of Leonard Auerbach of Bayside, Queens, and the late Audrey Auerbach. Miss Silverbush, a special-education teacher in the New York City school system, graduated from Syracuse University and received a master's degree in special education from the College of New Rochelle. Her fiance, a dentist, graduated from the University of California at Los Angeles and the Washington University School of Dental Medicine.

title: PARENTS MUST INSTILL THE WORK ETHIC
description: Re: ''Debate Grows on Working Teen-Agers,'' March 6:

title: POSTING: Historic Markers Benefit; City Flags of Whimsy Up for Auction
description: Forty artists, architects and designers tried their hands at creating an updated flag for New York City. While no new Betsy Ross emerged, their whimsical efforts will be auctioned on Wednesday evening, April 13, to raise funds for a historic-marker program.

title: How Republicans View Bush: Some Faults, but 'a Class Act'
description: Emma Lewis doesn't hear bells and banjos when she looks at George Bush. She just gets a nice safe feeling inside.

title: Retirement Life With the Amenities
description: LEAD: THE image of adult-home residents idly rocking on the front porch from dawn to dusk is hardly what one would expect to find at the recently opened Huntington Lodge, where active elderly people continue to drive, shop and participate in off-site activities.

title: BLIND LAWYER'S ARREST ON PLANE SPURS DISPUTE
description: Advocates of rights for the blind, angered by what they contend is the Government's failure to enforce an anti-discrimination law, said they will make a test case out of the arrest of a blind lawyer who was forcibly removed from an airplane when she refused to change seats.

title: NONFICTION
description: PARIS FASHION: A Cultural History. By Valerie Steele. (Oxford University, $35.) In her first book, ''Fashion and Eroticism'' (1985), Valerie Steele put forth the notion that changes in fashion primarily reflect changes in sexual curiosity. Since then, Ms. Steele has reconsidered: ''I still believe that this is an important factor in fashion change,'' she says, ''but I now recognize that (as usual) the situation is more complex.'' Perhaps to avoid such oversimplification here, Ms. Steele is reluctant to offer much analysis at all, giving us instead an exhaustive chronicle of Paris fashion from the 14th century to the present. We meet milliners, designers, seamstresses, tailors and fashion illustrators. Quirky details abound (for example, a woman in trousers would have been arrested in 19th-century Paris unless she had a permit), but they do not add up to anything more than mere details. Ms. Steele is out to debunk historians who assert that major social upheavals - the French Revolution, say, or World War I - caused radical changes in styles. There were seeds of change before every such event, she says, and her evidence seems persuasive. But the questions remain - why did skirts rise above the ankle, for instance? Ms. Steele tells us that the ''cult of chiffon'' coincided ''with an increasing emphasis on sexual happiness within marriage.'' But that is the first and last we hear of the influence of marriage on fashion, and it is too bad. ''The real motive for fashion change originates in people's changing identities,'' she writes near the end of ''Paris Fashion.'' More about those changing identities might have transformed this book from an impressive compendium of information into an impressive work of history.

title: Dangerous Obsessions
description: THE AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF ROY COHN By Sidney Zion. Illustrated. 284 pp. Secaucus, N.J.: Lyle Stuart. $18.95. CITIZEN COHN By Nicholas von Hoffman. Illustrated. 483 pp. New York: Doubleday. $19.95.

title: Amy Einsidler Fiancee Of Keith Martin Lewis
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Roy Einsidler of Lawrence, L.I., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Einsidler, to Keith Martin Lewis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan L. Lewis of Rochester. An August wedding is planned.

title: DATA UPDATE: April 3, 1988

THE VIEW FROM: THE VIDEO ARCHIVE FOR HOLOCAUST TESTIMONIES AT YALE UNIVERSITY;
Preserving Memories of the Holocaust
description: LEAD: FROM the attic of her family's home during World War II, Renee G. could hear the entire town crying.

title: Her Magazine Images Brought the World Home
description: Margaret Bourke-White's photographs, and her career, seem tailor-made for today's new breed of socially conscious, context-oriented art historians. From the 1930's through the 50's she observed and recorded the thick of her times, first as an industrial photographer for Fortune and, beginning in 1936, as a photojournalist for Life.

title: Man in Bronx Kills a Robber
description: A 65-year-old man who was being robbed in the elevator of his Bronx housing project wrested the knife from his assailant and fatally stabbed him yesterday, the police said.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE STEEP increase in garbage-disposal costs for most counties in northern New Jersey has inspired several legislative and regulatory proposals to ease the rate shock.

title: A Gracious Image of Vienna in Waltz Time
description: On his way to Vienna to see the Biedermeier exhibition that will be on view in the Kunstlerhaus through June 12, this critic pondered the recent ups and downs of the status of Austria, and more particularly of Vienna, in worldwide esteem.

title: NOMINATING THE SCALLOP AS THE STATE SHELL
description: It has been thoughtfully proposed that the New York State bay scallop (Argopecten irradians) be designated by New York State as its official state shell.

title: Mental Patients Transferred to L.I.
description: STATE hospitals on Long Island are becoming involved in New York City's efforts to deal with its mentally ill homeless population.

title: POWER AMPLIFIERS PROVE THEIR MERIT
description: By plotting a sensi-ble path between the commonplace and the extravagant, quite a few American audio manufacturers have recently been able to establish themselves quite firmly in a grimly competitive international market. Our sampling of their wares - begun in last week's column - continues to examine outstanding power amplifiers. Unlike the popular all-in-one stereo receivers, which combine amplification with control functions and a radio, power amplifiers perform only one task. They boost signal power - usually to a higher wattage than is commonly attained by receivers.

title: Searching for Ways to Muscle Out the Competition
description: WHEN the interstate moving industry was deregulated in 1980, analysts predicted that thousands of new carriers would enter the business. After all, an industry that had been tightly controlled by the Interstate Commerce Commission was now open to anyone with a truck and the nominal license fee.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
A Mexican Master's Whimsy in Wood
description: LEAD: WHAT do you take home?

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: So you're a dear friend of Al King, Mel Kahane and Johnny Marion. Known them for years, you say. In fact, you were schmoozing with Al the other night and he was so funny you were doubled up with laughter.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE LAST CRUSADE: The War on Consumption, 1862-1954. By Mark Caldwell. (Atheneum, $22.50.) It has been said that history is too important to be left to the professional historians, but this book illustrates the dangers of popular history written by a nonhistorian. In his cultural study of tuberculosis, Mark Caldwell (who teaches English at Fordham University) exhibits only a superficial knowledge of the traditions of 19th-century therapeutics and the social history of health movements.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article March 30 about electrocardiogram screening for high school athletes misidentified the Long Island community in which a young player died suddenly on a football field in 1983. It is Glen Head, not Glen Cove. In addition, a picture caption misidentified a nurse administering an electrocardiogram. She is Ilene Gottesfeld.

title: POSTING: 'Neath Liberty's Torch; New Arcade
description: If the trivia question is: where is the other Statue of Liberty?, the correct answer is: atop Burton Handelsman's eight-story warehouse at 43 West 64th Street in Manhattan.

title: Linda Freitag to Wed Dr. Henry Ilian in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Freitag of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Linda Joan Freitag to Dr. Henry Robert Ilian, the son of Sara Ilian of New York and the late Simon Ilian. The couple plan to marry in October.

title: The Uncertain Legacy of the Crash
description: NEARLY six months after Oct. 19, it is remarkably difficult to gauge the impact of the stock market crash. The nation's economy survives and grows. The terrible recession that collapsing stock prices seemed to promise has not materialized. And the riveting fears of late October have dissipated.

title: Woosnam Out to Prove He Belongs in Masters
description: The English highway patrolman couldn't quite believe what had just whizzed past him shortly after midnight last Sept. 29. His digital radar numbers were among the highest he'd ever seen - 122 miles per hour in a 70-mile zone heading west along M-6.

title: BAD NEWS FOR THE NICE AND WELL-MEANING
description: THE FIFTH CHILD By Doris Lessing. 133 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Review/Piano; URUGUAY'S ALBERTO REYES
description: What made Alberto Reyes's piano recital at the 92d Street Y on Thursday evening so exciting was the Uruguayan pianist's way of capturing each work's essence - the quality of its nervous energy, its musical fingerprint - and his ability to transform it into something like a living organism. His technique, while estimable, is by no means flawless, and fleeting as his slips were, they were jarring. But in light of what was happening in the music, they hardly mattered.

title: IT'S NOT OVER TILL SHARMA SINGS
description: LEAD: O PARADISO By Conrad L. Osborne. 349 pp. New York: Arbor House/ William Morrow & Company.

title: Tracing A Young Dancer's Odyssey
description: Partly to cope with the demands that 21 world premieres will make on the New York City Ballet's dancers during the American Music Festival that starts this month, 10 corps members were added to the company's roster last fall.

title: Playing a Tasty Italian Tune
description: PICCOLO is a marvelous mixture. This new restaurant in the space formerly occupied by the Great Dane Restaurant in Huntington's Southdown Shopping Center is more than a neighborhood Italian restaurant without the expense of a special-occasions spot.

title: FROM PARIS, SENSIBLE SHOES
description: The walking shoe is making a comeback. Shoes are part of the movement towards serious fashion in Paris. Last season when the thigh-high skirt and a flighty mood dominated the runways, models tottered along on spike heel sandals or pumps. In the recent fall and winter openings, designers offered clothes that would appeal to grown-ups and sensible shoes dominated, especially for day. Models skimmed along on low heel pumps and even laced-up oxfords, especially when the hemlines reached mid-calf or longer. Trousers, which have been shown recently with high heels, are now presented with more appropriate flats.

title: Faster Than Sound Romps
description: Faster Than Sound derailed King's Swan's bid to carry an extraordinary 133 pounds to victory yesterday by scoring a front-running 8 1/2-length victory in the $180,000 Westchester Handicap at Aqueduct. King's Swan rallied late to finish third, a nose behind Ron Stevens and a nose in front of Mocito Fogoso, the 6-5 favorite.

title: Navy Strays, U.C.L.A. Wins
description: U.C.L.A. won the featured Copley Cup for men's heavyweight eight-oared crews today, but a collision that disqualified the Navy crew marred the race as the 15th annual San Diego Crew Classic ended today on wind-swept Mission Bay.

title: 'Burden-Sharing,' Jolted
description: LEAD: ''Burden sharing'' means little to most Americans who live beyond that charmless circle, the Washington Beltway. But, according to a just released national survey of voter attitudes on national security, it could be a major issue in the Presidential campaign.

title: The Book Sleuth of Stockbridge
description: FROM the shelves that line three walls come titles out of yesterday, bridging the years back to the comfort of the nursery or to long summer afternoons spent reading Nancy Drew on the back porch.

title: Why Hysteria on a Mideast Parley?
description: Proposals for international conferences to discuss the Middle East were always accepted by Israeli Governments in the past. Why not now?

title: Lacking 'Official' Documents, Aliens Use Alternatives to Gain Citizenship
description: George Montoya has been a compulsive pack rat all his life, hanging onto almost every scrap of paper he got. Now, that collection of paper may help Mr. Montoya, an illegal alien from Colombia, become a United States citizen.

title: THE WORLD: Promises of Amnesty; Sorting Out the Prisoners in Managua
description: UNTIL last month, the future looked bleak for the thousands of anti-Sandinista prisoners in Nicaraguan jails. Though the Government had loosened controls on dissent in an effort to comply with a Central American peace plan, it had shown no signs of budging in its resistance to an amnesty for political prisoners, particularly for those who served in the National Guard during the rule of the Somoza family.

title: Fanfare to Accompany Legislators' Move
description: WHEN the first Connecticut General Assembly met in the 1700's, its 14 members borrowed a meetinghouse, since they had no building of their own and no money to build one.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Lake Superior St. Earns Hockey Title
description: A goal during a scramble in front of the St. Lawrence net in the fifth minute of a sudden-death overtime period gave Lake Superior State the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I hockey championship tonight.

title: In Search of the Place Where the Mountains Claimed a Son
description: WE WERE driving south on the two-lane blacktop road. I was at the wheel.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: The Constitution Team

title: Review/Rock; Robyn Hitchcock's Songs
description: Robyn Hitchcock's songs could stand on their lyrics alone - deadpan, off-the-wall, funny-strange phantasmagorias of protoplasm and its discontents, where ordinary life offers no refuge from organic processes or disruptive visions. In ''Globe of Frogs,'' the title song of his latest album, a disembodied soul, searching for reincarnation, settles on a lonely old woman whose children have been ''certified insane'' -hardly a standard pop-song scenario. Sometimes, Mr. Hitchcock couches his lyrics in bouncy, straightforward, 1960's-style pop or folk-rock; more often, he does with pop-song structures what his lyrics do with the laws of physics, casually warping and dissolving them.

title: Glimpse of Victorian Middle-Class Dining
description: LEAD: IN 1873, ''The New Cyclopaedia of Domestic Economy and Practical Housekeeper,'' a book ''adapated to all classes of society,'' recommended that a household's inventory of table linen should include three dozen napkins, two-and-a-half-dozen tablecloths of various sizes, six servants' tablecloths, three dozen towels, six round towels, two dozen napkins ''for fish, vegetables and fruit,'' six pudding cloths, two dozen damask ''d'oylies'' and one dozen Berlin wool ''d'oylies.

title: Prost and Piquet Are Favored
description: Formula One auto racing is a sport in transition, with new rules forcing a technical revolution in the world's premier form of motorsport. Although the deck has been thoroughly shuffled over the winter, when the new game starts today with the season-opening Brazilian Grand Prix (ESPN, 11:50 A.M.), the strongest hands should be held by a familiar pair of drivers, Alain Prost and Nelson Piquet.

title: State Planners Seek to Defuse Opposition
description: LEAD: THE FRAMERS of the preliminary draft of the State Development and Redevelopment Plan are counting on state agencies down to the level gf municipalities for consensus-building to defuse opposition by home builders and advocates of home rule.

title: ; Manning Just Too Much For Blue Devils to Handle
description: Half an hour or so after Kansas stunned Duke tonight, Robert Brickey, the Blue Devils' 6-foot-5-inch, 205-pound sophomore forward, was asked about guarding Danny Manning, the Jayhawks' 6-10 senior forward.

title: Michelle Horowitz to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Horowitz of East Northport, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Michelle Lyn Horowitz, to Michael Landsman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Landsman of the Bronx. Miss Horowitz, a commercial leasing representative with Dakota Realty in New York, graduated from Stern College of Yeshiva University. Her fiance, who graduated from Syracuse University, is an accountant in the New York office of Laventhol & Horwath.

title: Substitute Teachers In Short Supply
description: LEAD: TO FIND enough substitutes to cover the classes of absent teachers, the Union County community of Roselle advertises in newspapers and on cable television. Adjoining Linden uses permanent substitutes and New Brunswick counts on Rutgers students.

title: Low Wages and Drug Tests Make Drivers Scarce
description: AS if intense competition, deep discounts and a possible downturn in the economy aren't enough to contend with, moving industry executives are bracing for a severe shortage of qualified drivers that may begin as early as this summer, according to Mr. Harrison of the Household Goods Carriers' Bureau.

title: An Uncompromising Look at a Hard World
description: Resolutely, mournfully, with a quaver that might be a choked-back sob or wordless rage, Tracy Chapman sings, ''Last night I heard the screaming/ Loud voices behind the wall/ Another sleepless night for me/ It won't do no good to call/ The police/ Always come late/ If they come at all.'' The unaccompanied melody suggests a mountain ballad transferred to a tenement; there are no instruments to cushion the voice or distract from the story. The police, who show up only to ''say they can't interfere/ With domestic affairs,'' arrive again later in the song - this time to disperse a crowd that gathers when an ambulance arrives for the battered wife.

title: Construction Of Apartments In Manhattan Falls Sharply
description: NO one expected them to last forever, those buoyant days when it seemed there was a construction crane on every corner of Manhattan and apartment buildings were rising as fast as land could be cleared.

title: FICTION
description: SPIRIT OF THE HILLS. By Dan O'Brien. (Crown, $17.95.) You might say the central character of this wonderfully accomplished first novel is a large gray wolf. At least that's what the ranchers around Medicine Springs, S.D., would have you believe. Something huge and stealthy has been killing their sheep and cattle in the night, and it surely isn't a coyote. But wait: the very last wolf in the Great Plains was trapped in the 1920's, and now they're extinct. So what is the nervous, harassed chief forest ranger to do? Why find Bill Egan, the only man alive who's ever seen and trapped a wolf, and bring him to Medicine Springs. Meanwhile, as the ancient hunter makes his way west to locate the still-unsighted wolf, a Vietnam veteran named Tom McVay is also heading toward Medicine Springs, but for a very different reason: revenge. His younger brother has been killed in a drug deal, and this small town at the foot of the Black Hills is where McVay has been told he can find the killer. You might think that in trying to merge such vastly different plots (there's even a third highly charged story line about an Indian sit-in at nearby Mount Rushmore), Dan O'Brien has bitten off more than he can chew. But if he has, you wouldn't know it. He writes with great confidence, and his story, no matter how twisty or lurid it becomes, is always credible. Mr. O'Brien obviously knows and loves the land he writes about and clearly feels the same way about his characters. This gives his prose a special quality, as if John Ford had collaborated with Conan Doyle. You find yourself avidly turning the pages as the older and younger men's obsessions - with everything they mean about the old West and the new - inevitably intertwine. ''The Spirit of the Hills'' is an exciting, absorbing and extremely well-written book.

title: John Paul Asks Us to Look Into Our Economic Heart; Who Said It?
description: To the Editor:

title: How Will The Mets And Yanks Do in '88?
description: Frank Cashen has put together the best baseball team in the past 50 years. Pitching is 90 percent of the game and with Gooden, Darling, Ojeda, Aguilera, and Cone as starters, and McDowell, Myers, Leach and Fernandez as relievers the Mets should win by 25 games.

title: Meese and Reagan: The Anatomy of a Friendship
description: Once again it was apparent that Edwin Meese 3d's political longevity has rested on his relationship with Ronald Reagan. For more than 20 years Mr. Meese has shared emotions and experiences with his chief and hero, performing the role of the ''perfect servant bureaucrat,'' as a mutual friend put it.

title: Sarah Elliott Lindsley Plans to Wed John B. Mattes, Editor, in September
description: The Rev. and Mrs. James Elliott Lindsley of Germantown, N.Y., and Castine, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Elliott Lindsley to John Baxter Mattes, a son of Mrs. Edward Charles Mattes of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and the late Mr. Mattes. A September wedding is planned.

title: How Will The Mets And Yanks Do in '88?
description: The Yankees trade Jack Clark and Lee Guetterman for Ozzie Smith. Willie Randolph smiles. Jose Cruz bats .388 as a designated hitter, and the Yankees beatthe Mets in six. PEGGY CRITZ West Islip, L.I.

title: Correction
description: An article by The Associated Press on March 27 about a protest in Bratislava, the Slovak capital, located the city incorrectly. It is in central Czechoslovakia, on the southern border.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Mountainside
description: LEAD: THE business district of Mountainside straddles busy Route 22. But down a series of wooded back roads in this Union County borough lies another world, a rustic preserve of homes terraced on the Watchung mountains.

title: Is Price Too High?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
HEALTH AND SHELTER OPTIONS FOR THE ELDERLY;
Rising Need for Post-Hospital Care
description: LEAD: A NEW statewide reimbursement system, designed to control health costs by giving hospitals financial incentives to discharge patients sooner, is leading to a greater demand for post-hospital care, such as nursing-home and home-health services. These are already in short supply in Nassau and Suffolk

title: Dukakis Voices His Support For Israel and '78 Accords
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today sketched his views on the perils and possibilities for peace in the Middle East in a speech characterized by sharp criticism of Arab leaders and strong support for Israel.

title: A Gospel Show Marches to a Different Beat
description: Unifying classic Greek tragedy and American gospel music, ''The Gospel at Colonus'' was the revelation of the 1983 Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. This improbable blending of apparent opposites was the invention of Lee Breuer (as author, co-lyricist and director) and Bob Telson (as composer). After a national and world tour and a television presentation on PBS's Great Performances, the lavish concert musical has arrived on Broadway, where it is something of an anomaly. It is a gospel show whose emotional sweep enhances its intellectual premise.

title: Offer to Buy Lilco: Only the Beginning
description: THE unanimous decision last week by the Long Island Power Authority to offer to buy Lilco for $7.45 billion was a stunning finale to more than 13 months of deliberations. But the end, surprising as it was, could only be seen as the beginning.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My 65-year-old house has a red brick chimney running up through the center of the house. About five or six of the bricks in the bottom of this chimney (in the basement) seem to be eroding along their entire length and height, leaving red brick powder on the floor. Bricks on either side are not affected. I cannot imagine any bugs feasting on brick dust. What is your guess?

title: Correction
description: An article on March 13 about marketing black colleges gave an incorrect figure for the number of applications to the School of Veterinary Medicine at Tuskegee University. For the class entering in the fall of 1987, the school had 259 applications for 60 available seats.

title: IN SEARCH OF GEORGE BUSH
description: Mr. Rothenberg speaks of George Bush's ''innate moderation.'' Nevertheless, Rothenberg reports the following about Bush's entry into Texas Republican politics: Centrists believe ''he too readily accommodates extremists''; when he won the chairmanship of the Harris County Republican Party, he drew in both ''establishment Republicans and the more militant members of the John Birch Society . . . identifying with one or the other as the occasion warranted,'' and he ''opposed . . . much of the Civil Rights Act.''

title: Headliners; Trickling Up
description: As South Korea prospered in recent years, there was increasing suspicion that members of the family of President Chun Doo Hwan were taking a share off the top. Last week, barely a month after Mr. Chun's seven-year Government ended, the former President's younger brother, Chun Kyung Hwan, was arrested on charges of embezzlement, influence peddling and tax evasion, among other things. Prosecutors charged that Mr. Chun stole at least $10.4 million in six years as head of a semi-official national development agency, a post to which his brother appointed him. When Mr. Chun reported to the prosecutor's office, angry crowds chanted, ''Kill him!''

title:
LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: THOMAS A. DOHERTY;
Banker Sees Prosperity, Complexity, Consolidation
description: LEAD: ''DON'T do indirectly what you cannot or should not do directly'' is the creed of Thomas A. Doherty, the chairman, president and chief executive officer of the Norstar Bank of Long Island.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: LECTURE BY SCALIA Associate Justice Antonin Scalia of the United States Supreme Court will lecture on ''The Constitution and the Law'' at 8 P.M. Wednesday in the Sports Building of the College of New Rochelle. In an era when nominations to the Court were being challenged by Congress with unprecedented frequency, Justice Scalia's nomination by President Reagan was received with unanimous approval by the Senate, and a 98-0 vote by a partly filled House.

title: Where Bad Teaching Is Being Taught
description: To the Editor:

title: Dukakis-Jackson Bid Beats Bush, Poll Says
description: A Democratic ticket led by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts with the Rev. Jesse Jackson as his running mate would defeat Vice President Bush in a general election, a poll made public today showed.

title: Carter Leads Off the Field
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Physician In the New Age Of Health Care
description: THE next time you are a patient in the hospital, take pity on your doctor. Never mind that you are a diagostic enigma or therapeutic dilemma. Forget about all the blood tests that are drawn and the myriad of X-rays with all those unpleasant ''cleanouts.''And ignore the insipid food, the inconveniences and your loss of dignity. Instead, have sympathy for your doctor.

title: Power Meets Power in Women's Final
description: Two teams with strong inside games that stress defense and rebounding will contend Sunday for the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I women's basketball championship.

title: FISCAL PANEL SET IN SUFFOLK COUNTY
description: The Suffolk County Executive appointed a panel this week to recommend ways the county can avoid budget deficits that he predicted would total nearly $124 million by 1989.

title: Review/Theater; Psychological Terror, in 'Mr. Universe'
description: If you can be satisfied only by neat plot resolutions and perfect exposition, Jim Grimsley's ''Mr. Universe'' at the New Federal Theater will annoy you - for a long time, because once this play gets its hooks into you, it won't let go. Mr. Grimsley has things to learn about storytelling, but his theatrical imagination is strange and captivating. And under the direction of Steven Kent, this production moves with such energy that the play's structural and narrative flaws become irksome only in retrospect.

title: An Exhibition With Many Directions
description: THE AURORA, a gallery that will be celebrating its second anniversary next month, has the potential of attracting artists from the ''other side of the border,'' as well as from New Jersey. And so it may be a sign of things to come that the best-known exhibitor in the present show is Alan Gussow, a resident of Rockland County, N.Y.

title: WOMEN LAWYERS
description: Your article on women lawyers presumes that female professionals embrace the traditional male definition of success. You highlight three women who have achieved a modicum of success measured by that same tiresome standard.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Cache of Gold Coins Will Be Sold at Auction
description: LEAD: THE Federal Drug Enforcement Administration has seized a large cache of United States gold coins from a group of drug dealers and consigned them for sale at public auction to be held later this year. It is claimed to be the largest public sale of confiscated collectibles ever arranged by the agency.

title: Fighting to Spur C.P.A. Rivalry
description: IT IS against the law in Florida for a certified public accountant to solicit clients by quoting fees for audits. That is why Richard Rampell, a C.P.A. in West Palm Beach, Fla., found himself accused of ''stealing.''

title: Cambodia Conscripting Border Labor
description: SITE 2, Thailand, March 29 -

title: Common Men At Prayer
description: THE FIRST TIME I ever heard a man who wasn't a minister, priest or rabbi pray out loud, I felt so embarrassed and nervous I literally hid under the covers. I was attending a high-school journalism convention, and my roommate, a friendly rival sports columnist on my paper, The Shortridge (Indianapolis) Daily Echo, asked if I would like to join him in prayer.

title: Gloria Signorelli Plans To Wed Eliot W. Berry
description: Gloria Susanne Signorelli and Eliot Ward Berry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rynn Berry of New York and Oyster Bay, L.I., plan to marry May 21, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. John V. Signorelli of Newton, N.J., have announced.

title: CINDERELLA OF THE TENEMENTS
description: ANZIA YEZIERSKA A Writer's Life. By Louise Levitas Henriksen with Jo Ann Boydston. Illustrated. 327 pp. New Brunswick, N.J.: Rutgers University Press. $20.95.

title: Union Organizers' Task Is Uphill at Nissan Plant
description: Clearly he has a bias, but Jerry Benefield, president of Nissan Motor Company's manufacturing plant here, offers this rough calculation of the prospects that the United Automobile Workers will be able to bring his company's 3,200 employees into the union fold: slim and none.

title: Prospects Remain Clouded for Afghanistan Talks
description: The latest round of Afghan peace talks enters its fifth week Monday with no encouraging omens for ending the eight-year-old civil war, which has cost a million lives, left five million homeless and drawn the Soviet Union into a foreign military adventure.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article last Sunday about a New York State program to buy parkland misattributed a statement. It was Paul Sabatino 2d, not Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin, who said he thought that the formula for allocation of funds from an extension of a quarter-penny sales tax in Suffolk County could change only if it were to be approved in a new referendum.

title: On the Road, 1988: New Dangers and Decline in Hitchhiking
description: ''Somewhere along the line I knew there'd be girls, visions, everything,'' Jack Kerouac wrote in ''On the Road,'' his classic 1950's paean to thumbing his way across America, and to lowlife joys of the road. ''Somewhere along the line the pearl would be handed to me.''

title:
HEALTH AND SHELTER OPTIONS FOR THE ELDERLY;
Trying New Ideas for Living Arrangements
description: LEAD: THE need for housing has become a critical issue for most of Long Island's aging population. While those in the upper classes who are 65 and older manage to live independently or retire to warmer climates, large numbers of lower- and middle-class older people are seeking alternative living arrangements to meet changing personal and financial situations.

title: Installing an Outlet For Outdoor Electricity
description: THE most recent revision of the National Electric Code, upon which many local electrical codes are based, requires that all new homes be equipped with at least one outdoor electric outlet. This doesn't mean that if your home is not so equipped, you can expect a visit from the authorities. But it does recognize a growing need: As more household activities move outdoors, a safe means of supplying electricity to accompany them is also necessary.

title: Panel Backs Proposal To Curb Pesticide Use
description: THE Environment Committee of the General Assembly has recommended a bill that could reduce pesticide use in the state by at least a third.

title: Georgia Will Begin Testing of Kindergartners
description: Over the opposition of some parents and educators, the 93,000 kindergarten pupils in Georgia will begin taking standardized tests next week to help determine whether they should enter first grade in the fall.

title: Help Wanted: Pitchers of All Kinds
description: In the year after 4,458 home runs were hit in the big leagues, Sandy Koufax walked to the mound in Florida the other night and pitched batting practice for the Los Angeles Dodgers. He was the ghost of summers past, and the symbol of glories past.

title: Top New York Court Refuses to Overturn A Man's Extradition
description: A black man facing murder charges in Mississippi lost his yearlong battle to remain free when New York's top court refused this week to block his extradition. But one member of the court said he remained unconvinced that the man would receive a fair trial.

title: Easter Choirs Sing Their Joy
description: EASTER Sunday is the high point of the Christian liturgical calendar, and the joyous music associated with it makes it the day of days for church choirs.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Livingston $220,000 433 South Livingston Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 16-year-old split level; rec room, 2-car garage; taxes $3,446. Millburn $205,000 899 Ridgewood Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 2 half-bath, 48-year-old colonial; fireplace, oak floors, 1-car garage; taxes $2,722. North Brunswick $149,500 300 Constitution Circle 3-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 4-year-old town-house condominium; fireplace, family room, dining room; monthly charges, $150; taxes $1,966.
