Rutherford $250,000 210 Hollister Avenue 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 59-year-old colonial; finished basement, family room, fireplace; taxes $2,954. OTHER AREAS Westport, Conn. $471,500 42 Colony Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 19-year-old colonial; greenhouse, underground sprinkler, 1 acre; taxes $3,399. White Plains, N.Y. $220,000 37 Valley Road 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 78-year-old stucco colonial; eat-in kitchen, deck, walk to station; taxes $989. Mineola, L.I. $190,000 457 Wilson Boulevard 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 37-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,000.

title: Sketching the Early Years of Eugene O'Neill
description: LEAD: With his neatly trimmed Vandyke, softly impassioned baritone and high-minded manner, Calvin Skaggs seems more an artistic impresario than a film executive. In fact, he is both. Producer of the acclaimed ''American Short Story'' series (shown on public television between 1976 and 1979), as well as a televised biography of Katherine Anne Porter, he has now produced and directed ''Eugene O'Neill: Journey Into Genius'' (to be shown on ''American Playhouse'' over PBS -including Channel 13 - on

title: NONFICTION
description: THE GLOBAL MARKETPLACE: 102 of the Most Influential Companies Outside America. By Milton Moskowitz. (Macmillan, $24.95.) From Nestle and Nissan to Philips and Fiat, this hefty volume offers a glimpse of many giant corporations around the globe. The flood of foreign investment into the United States - the result, in large part, of a weak dollar - makes the book a timely one. Although it focuses mainly on the heavyweights, a few smaller concerns, most notably Club Mediterranee and the Hard Rock Cafe, are thrown in for spice. Milton Moskowitz, a veteran business writer and co-author of ''The 100 Best Companies to Work For in America,'' devotes about six pages to each profile, telling how the company got its start, what businesses it is in today and who is in charge. The sketches are highly accessible, written with little jargon, and Mr. Moskowitz has done a credible job of putting each company in the proper context. Writing about Saatchi & Saatchi, the multinational advertising empire based in London, for example, he discusses the growth in global advertising and also the problems in holding on to competing clients when their ad agencies become sister subsidiaries. Also of interest are the author's comments on companies' social policies. On the minus side: there is no real overview of what makes one company different from another, or what makes each one remarkable. For the general reader, however, ''The Global Marketplace'' should prove a useful introduction to the companies behind so many of the products we buy - and whose presence here is growing daily.

title: FICTION
description: MAGNOLIA GARDENS. By Caroline Bridgwood. (St. Martin's, $17.95.) London at the turn of the century has often provided a fertile setting for fiction. And in the hands of Caroline Bridgwood, a best-selling British novelist who is making her American debut with this book, the respectable London suburb of Magnolia Gardens is nothing less than a Peyton Place of intrigue, infidelity, and murder. Narrated in turn by six central characters, the story begins by introducing the first generation of three families whose paths will intersect when they become neighbors. This promising start is brought abruptly to a close, however, and the subsequent segments of ''Magnolia Gardens'' focus on the children of these first narrators. Thus the time frame lurches forward as the discursive preamble's many seeds come to fruition in the rest of the book. Unfortunately, readers may well feel cheated when the voices of Frank Finzel, an ambitious plumber of humble origins, Magdalena Stark, a mysterious woman who has survived an ugly past, and Robert Clifford, a pompous barrister with more prosperous forebears, are allowed to recede. For while many of its details work well and its backdrop of British history from Edwardian England to the eve of World War II is convincingly real, Caroline Bridgwood's clamorous, cliche-ridden book ultimately yields neither a compelling narrative nor convincing characters.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Sign Here - and Watch the Paws

title: STREETSCAPES: The Knickerbocker Field Club; Fire-Damaged Flatbush Landmark May Be Razed
description: THE Landmarks Preservation Commission has before it a knotty problem involving the Knickerbocker Field Club, a charming clapboard clubhouse built in 1893 that was heavily damaged - but not destroyed - by fire last January.

title: Catering to Easter and Passover Needs
description: LEAD: DARLENE FOUR is serving Easter dinner for 20 in her White Plains apartment this evening. The menu: asparagus soup with creme fraiche and chives, rack of lamb with pink peppercorn sauce, sauteed spinach and creamed onions, herbed potato fritters, soft rolls with rosemary butter, and rhubarb and strawberry cobbler with vanilla praline ice cream.

title: A Postal Card for The Increased Rate
description: THE colorful new postal card ''America the Beautiful'' was issued last Monday to meet the 15 cent rate that goes into effect today. It offers a prairie view and is the first in a new series that will feature regional scenes.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: VISIONS AND VOICES. By Jonathan Cott. (Dolphin/Doubleday, $17.95.) Scratch any artist, any therapist, any writer, and one finds a brooding visionary just waiting to hold forth on life and death, angels and devils. That, it seems, would be the message conveyed by ''Visions and Voices,'' in which the journalist Jonathan Cott presents 10 interviews (most of them have been published before); each is preceded by a brief introductory essay by the author.

title: Review/Opera; DEMBSKA'S 'JUNIPER TREE'
description: Depending on your definition of things operatic, Anna Dembska's ''Juniper Tree'' at the Henry Street Settlement last Sunday night was or was not what it said it was - an opera. This retelling of the Grimm tale could also be called a dramatic monologue - or a one-woman show with minimal props. With Carol Emanuel playing the harp and Tim Moran doubling on the flute and saxophone, Miss Dembska's storytelling narrates and illustrates, with choreographed gestures acting out both overt action and inner turmoil.

title: 'Personals' Goes Public in Metuchen
description: ON FIRST thought, the notion of a musical revue based on personal classified advertisements seems self-limiting. But, then, the ever-proliferating number of such ''lonely hearts'' solicitations is a phenomenon of the 1980's, and a certain reverse chic has gone a long way to diminish the embarrassment and alleviate the stigma of those sensitive souls with post-office-box numbers who declare, in anonymity, that they are looking to share langorous afternoons and fun-filled evenings with prospective soul mates.

title: Catherine A. Mazza To Wed S. A. Christie
description: Catherine Andrea Mazza and Stuart Andrew Christie are planning to be married in June, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Mazza of Stamford, Conn., have announced.

title: Is There Life After Rampal?
description: In his memoir ''I really should Be Practicing,'' the pianist Gary Graffman recalls his struggling years in the 1950's, when European pianists dominated the field. Mr. Graffman and his colleagues Leon Fleisher and Eugene Istomin were described so often as ''outstanding young American pianists'' - a phrase that brought much honor but few bookings - that they wryly referred to themselves as the OYAP's.

title: Safeguarding Blood Supply
description: The American Red Cross says it is starting a program of staff training and other steps to reduce the chances that its blood centers could accidentally distribute contaminated blood or blood products. Last month the Red Cross acknowledged that it had distributed 24 pints of blood that had failed testing for AIDS contamination or hepatitis B antigens, but it said none of the blood was used and none had the AIDS virus.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Smoking Club Takes Wing In Texas

title: Video Cameras: Unwelcome Onlookers
description: IF one more person holds a video camera in front of my face and says ''smile'' while a party is in progress, I shall grab the nearest plate of crab puffs and grind it into the lens.

title: Ewing Outduels Olajuwon as Knicks Hang On
description: The losses and injuries he suffered during his first two seasons are a memory now. The record may not be great, but the Knicks are in contention for a playoff berth for the first time since Patrick Ewing became their center, and it is bringing out the best in him. Playing his best game of the season, Ewing scored a season-high 36 points, leading the Knicks to a 104-98 victory against the Houston Rockets last night.

title:
GARDENING;
Flowers for the Damp Garden
description: LEAD: JUST as there are numerous trees and shrubs that are tolerant of moist planting sites, there are even more herbaceous perennials that will thrive under such conditions.

title: Panel Backs Restitution To Home Repair Victims
description: LEAD: LAWMAKERS are considering a bill that would create a trust fund for homeowners who have lost money on improvement projects that went sour.

title: Richardson Joins the Call
description: Former Attorney General Elliot Richardson added his voice today to those calling for Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to step down. Mr. Richardson said on Cable News Network's ''Newsmaker Saturday'' program that Mr. Meese ''has forfeited confidence'' and should resign. ''Too many questions'' have been raised, he said, and Mr. Meese ''was too close to too many questionable dealings'' that are being investigated by an independent counsel.

title: Maple-Syrup Producers Hope for a Better Season
description: A wisp of white smoke curled above the roof of the sap house here the other day, a telltale sign that the 1988 maple-syrup season had arrived.

title: The Talk of People's Park
description: SHANGHAI IS A BIG brown riverside city with the look of Brooklyn, and the Chinese - who are comforted by crowds - like it for its mobs and its street life. It has a reputation for city slickers and stylishness. Most of China's successful fashion designers work in Shanghai, and if you say the words Yifu Sheng Luolang the Shanghainese will know you are referring to Yves Saint-Laurent.

title: Debuts; A Cellist and 2 Pianists Give Their First Recitals
description: David Eggar

title: Miss Mahdaviani to Wed Eric Jay Goldstone in Fall
description: The engagement of Miriam Mahdaviani to Eric Jay Goldstone, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sheldon B. Goldstone of Scranton, Pa., and Naples, Fla., has been announced by the mother of the future bride, Roberta Balsam Mahdaviani of Forest Hills, Queens. An October wedding is planned.

title: SO, WHAT'S BEHIND THE MESS AT NEW YORK'S PENN STATION?
description: RUSH hour at Pennsylvania Station, New York, the busiest train station in America: Tens of thousands of commuters. Corridors of plywood. Filthy restrooms peopled by pushy panhandlers. Armies of the homeless - some polite, some demanding, some staring straight ahead.

title: Panama Appears Unruffled by U.S. Buildup
description: The Pentagon's announcement Friday that 1,300 more American soldiers and 26 helicopters will be dispatched here did little outwardly to shake the military Government or distract Panamanians from their traditional Easter holiday weekend.

title: Despite Fuss Over Winfield, Martin Has High Hopes
description: They were five weeks of tranquillity.

title: 4 for Lemieux, as Penguins Hang On
description: Mario Lemieux scored his fourth goal of the game with 58 seconds left in overtime as the Pittsburgh Penguins stayed alive in the Patrick Division playoff race with a 7-6 victory over the Washington Capitals tonight. With the Capital loss, the Islanders clinched the division title.

title: NONFICTION
description: BAD GUYS DON'T HAVE BIRTHDAYS: Fantasy Play at Four. By Vivian Gussin Paley. (University of Chicago, $12.95.) Though her career spans 30 years of teaching (and, with this latest addition, five books), Vivian Gussin Paley enters the preschool classroom as an inveterate learner, an intramural anthropologist equipped with a tape recorder and an open mind. Whereas the average observer might perceive ordinary children engaged in nonsensical shenanigans, she finds them to be ''submerged in philosophical position papers, a virtual recapitulation of life's enigmas.'' Birth, death, the nature of power and evil - her small charges tackle the eternal mysteries daily. Through imaginative play and a bewildering array of hastily improvised rules, they not only come to terms with their own destructive impulses but bring order to apparent chaos and, ultimately, reinvent the world. The carefully transcribed dialogue seems at times more native to Bellevue than to ''Sesame Street'': these dramatist-players ''change identities and burrow into hidden places; they speak in code and flee from invisible foes.'' However, in respecting the children's level of logic and looking for their underlying concerns (not easy in the case of an inventive but intolerable game called ''doll-corner smashie''), Mrs. Paley guides them gently toward integration and growth. ''There is no small talk,'' she says of the prevailing pandemonium; indeed, a certain poetry hums just beneath the ruckus. Among the rules that the children concoct is the assertion that ''magic always needs a place to hide.'' Evidently, one need look no further than the nursery.

title: Words and Music, Without Opera
description: Opera stars of the magnitude of Montserrat Caballe, Luciano Pavarotti and Kiri Te Kanawa supplement their fame and fortune with orchestral concerts and song recitals. And the same audiences that thrill to their performances at the Metropolitan Opera House flock to their recitals at Carnegie Hall, Avery Fisher Hall or even -in Mr. Pavarotti's case - Madison Square Garden.

title: Ukrainian Eggs Nest in Handmade Cages in Exhibit
description: LEAD: ALONG with rites of spring and lauding of the egg for Easter and Passover is the exhibition ''Eggs in Cages'' at the Brookfield/SoNo Craft Complex in South Norwalk.

title: Warmth on Opening Day
description: Shortly after dawn Friday, dozens of anglers were wading in the 43-degree waters of the upper East Branch of the Croton River under lowering skies from which a cold, intermittent rain soon began to fall.

title: French Visas
description: To the Editor: I wasn't sure whether to be saddened or amused by the article on French visa problems (''Your Visas Have Expired'' by Guy Henle, Travel, Feb. 7).

title: Jane Austen's Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: A Net to Catch Playwrights BefCre They Fall Away
description: The American theater does not lack for playwrights. It has playwrights, plenty of them, mostly young ones. They are all over the place, and when I say playwrights I mean that they have not only written plays, they have had at least one produced professionally and they have stood there and watched it succeed. They have, in short, proved to the public, and proved to themselves, that they are able to write entirely workable plays.

title: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER
description: BUSINESSES are finding it increasingly important to transfer high volumes of data from one computer to another rapidly and accurately.

title:
GARDENING;
Flowers for the Damp Garden
description: LEAD: JUST as there are numerous trees and shrubs that are tolerant of moist planting sites, there are even more herbaceous perennials that will thrive under such conditions.

title: How Will The Mets And Yanks Do in '88?
description: Yankees 99-63, Mets 97-65, both good for division flags. Mets over Reds, 4-1. Yanks over Royals, 4-2. Mets over Yanks, 4-2. JEFF MARINER New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: Salvation Army Bins
description: Those colossal bins with the cheerful red and white ''Salvation Army'' logo on their sides have been attracting the wrong kind of attention in Westchester lately. Some people throw their garbage in them and others steal from them or even sleep in them.

title: Two Reminders: ... And Add 3/
description: Postal rates increase today, to 25 cents for a one-ounce, first-class letter (20 cents for each additional ounce) and 15 cents for a post card. The E stamp, worth 25 cents, can be used on domestic mail but not on international mail, for which rates also rose. Page 19.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
21 Housing Units for the Poor in Camden
description: LEAD: CAMDEN, once a thriving industrial city that has suffered decades of neglect, economic decline and false starts, is slowly reviving.

title: A Need to Be Stirred
description: A Greek journalist asked the other day whether the rise of Jesse Jackson meant U.S. politics was swinging ''to the left again.'' It was a reminder of how far the old vocabulary has lagged behind the developing issues of government and politics. This has been much reinforced by developments in major Communist countries, though little noticed yet.

title: ARAB RAGE INSIDE ISRAEL
description: ON PEACE DAY IN JAFFA, VICTOR Tayar learned something about his neighbors. ''It was a Monday afternoon, about 3 o'clock,'' said the burly Tayar, sipping coffee in the restaurant he owns and recalling the general strike staged by Israel's Arab citizens on Dec. 21, 1987. ''I heard that the Arabs were holding a demonstration and I was curious. I mean, the Arabs of Jaffa have never been very political.'' Tayar, a Jew, walked over to Yefet Street, not far from the Ottoman clocktower that is the chief landmark of Tel Aviv's decaying twin city. ''I couldn't believe my eyes,'' he said. ''There must have been 1,500 people out there. And they were angry.''

title: Ellen Remsen Engaged To John Lorne Waxlax
description: Mrs. Charles G. Miller Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Frederick D. Remsen of Mount Kisco, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ellen Jebb Remsen to John Lorne Waxlax, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lorne R. Waxlax of Brookline, Mass.

title: The One Who Made It; After 36 Ballots - Garfield!
description: James A. Garfield, the only Representative ever elected President, presents a somewhat slender precedent.

title: Johnson Glowing Over the Depth of Mets Pitching Staff
description: The Mets, primed after the best spring in the history of the franchise, turn into their 27th season in the National League tomorrow convinced they will reach the peaks of potential that they approached in 1986 but missed in 1987.

title: WAHT PLACE FOR A CREATOR?
description: A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME From the Big Bang to Black Holes. By Stephen W. Hawking. Illustrated by Ron Miller. 198 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $18.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My 65-year-old house has a red brick chimney running up through the center of the house. About five or six of the bricks in the bottom of this chimney (in the basement) seem to be eroding along their entire length and height, leaving red brick powder on the floor. Bricks on either side are not affected. I cannot imagine any bugs feasting on brick dust. What is your guess?

title: Correction
description: An article in Sports Pages yesterday about the Final Four basketball matchups incorrectly identified the former assistant coach at Maryland who recently became head coach at Radford University. He is Oliver Purnell.

title: No Headline
description: There should be nothing better than seeing a structure by the architect Frank Gehry inside the great hall of the National Building Museum. After all, Mr. Gehry's buildings are extraordinary pieces of sculptural form, and surely stand among our age's most compelling works of architecture. And the National Building Museum, at Fourth and G Streets, N.W., possesses what must be the most exhilarating interior in Washington, a columned central space, 159 feet high, 316 feet long. Grand as it is, this hall seems often to cry out for something within it.

title: Margery Trimble, a Teacher, To Marry R. B. Kennelly Jr.
description: The engagement of Margery Mills Trimble to Richard Bayard Kennelly Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William Cattell Trimble Jr. of Owings Mills, Md., and Northeast Harbor, Me., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. Kennelly of Claremont, Calif., and Mrs. Tevita Puloka of Nukualofa, Tonga, and Arlington, Mass. An October wedding is planned.

title: THE POET IS A PRIVATE EYE
description: SILVER LININGS By Charles Cohen. 279 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $17.95.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Metrotech; Lease Gives Impetus to Brooklyn Project
description: THE milestones along the route to a construction start in what might be called the megaventures in New York City real-estate development usually pass with barely any public notice, despite their significance. So it was last month when the 4.2 million-square-foot Metrotech office project in downtown Brooklyn took a crucial step toward its groundbreaking - a lease-signing by the Securities Industry Automation Corporation.

title: A FAILURE THAT CHANGED THE WORLD
description: THE YEAR OF THE BARRICADES A Journey Through 1968. By David Caute. Illustrated. 514 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $24.95. CHICAGO '68 By David Farber. Illustrated. 304 pp. Illinois: University of Chicago Press. $19.95.

title: Henry S. White, TV Executive, Dies at 80
description: Henry S. White, a longtime television and film executive, died of a heart attack Thursday at New York University Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan and Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: The Right Hand Man Starring Rupert Everett, Hugo Weaving, Arthur Dignam, Jennifer Claire, Catherine McClements, Ralph Cotterill, Adam Cockburn, Tim Eliott. Directed by Di Drew. 1987. New World Video. 99 minutes. $79.95. Rated R.

title: Mustard Adds a Special Zing to the Flavor of Many Foods
description: NOTHING wakes the palate and perks up the flavor in food like a touch of mustard. But more often we think of it as something to be spread on a hot dog or added to a salad dressing than to be used for cooking. I like to mix mustard with oil and brush it lightly over fish fillets before broiling them. I also add it to a marinade for lamb or pork chops or mix it in with cream sauces, which it helps to thicken. It is excellent with rather bland meats such as rabbit or chicken, and particularly good with the delicate taste of veal kidneys.

title: Spring, in the Greenhouse
description: Easter commemorates resurrection, Passover deliverance. With ancient roots in the spring equinox, both rites serve to mark the renewal of nature's cycle. As is becoming slowly evident, that cycle is too easy to take for granted.

title: The Nickel Sting
description: After losing $15 million since he started the Chicago Sting soccer franchise 14 years ago, Lee Stern was more distraught than usual after a loss by his Major Indoor Soccer League team last week. ''I've lost enough,'' he said. ''Anybody who wants to buy this team can have it for a nickel.''

title: Resort Units Face Removal
description: LEAD: IN many areas on Long Island, developers say it is difficult enough winning approval from municipalities to build projects, yet in the Town of East Hampton a development company is faced with the prospect of tearing down a portion of a project it has already built. Whether this step will be taken will be debated at a public hearing that the town's Planning Board has scheduled for this

title: A Persistent Group of Elderly Get a Haven of Their Own
description: MANY of them have known one another for much of their lives, and they are in their 70's and 80's, blessed with good health, sound minds and a degree of affluence. They number more than 200, and they are selling their homes and getting ready to move in together. Forever.

title: BEST SELLERS: APRIL 3, 1988
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 4 THE ICARUS AGENDA, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) A congressman's secret dealings with terrorists may bring him the Presidency - or death. 2 2 22 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 3 3 4 HOT MONEY, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) Which member of a gold arbitrageur's family was responsible for the murder of his fifth wife? 4 4 3 TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) title: Soviet Union's Ethnic Minorities Find Little Room at Top
description: SOMETIME in the next few months, Mikhail S. Gorbachev will convene a plenary meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee to deal with the bedeviling discontents of ethnic minorities. Arrayed alongside him on the dais in the circular hall of the Kremlin's Council of Ministers building will be an embarrassing symbol of his problem: The top leadership in this country of more than 100 non-Russian minorities resembles a Slavic brotherhood.

title: Susan Tamara Keon to Wed
description: Joseph J. Keon Jr. of Los Angeles and Margaret Lumpkin Keon of Belvedere, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Tamara Keon to Richard A. DeWyngaert, a son of Mrs. Robert A. DeWyngaert of Westfield, N.J., and the late Mr. DeWyngaert. The couple, who graduated from Georgetown University, plan to marry in July. Ms. Keon is a registered nurse. Her fiance is gallery director of the Fine Arts Company, a Philadelphia auction house.

title: ON BEING WRONG: CONVICTED MINIMALIST SPILLS BEANS
description: With all the talk in these and other pages about the new, faulty literature, about things left out and whole tenses turning up bum, not to mention indictments for excessive reticence, moral snorkeling and too much time in the grocery store, a writer hardly has time to put a new word up on the easel, let alone paint it, before somebody's deciding it's the wrong word. A couple of reactions come to me: the ''Hey, Mom, more dumb stuff in the newspaper'' reaction, which isn't very useful, and this: my own self-lighting, burns-in-colors! artificial log tossed into the fiery debate.

title: In Washington: A Mistake Corrected
description: CONGRESS conceded a bad call on Union Station, and it agreed to pay the price. Finally, the grand Beaux Arts terminal here, closed since it slouched into disrepute as a ''national visitors' center,'' is to open again in September.

title: 'Nixon' Opens a New Chapter for Opera
description: We are accustomed to contemporary opera's being either dense and harsh, or, if ''accessibility'' is attempted, forlorn and derivative. It can also, of late, be Minimalist, but the long works of Philip Glass seem more like pageants than operas to many people, and many find them numbingly repetitive.

title: British Board Presses Effort To Find Nazis
description: Government investigators have been sifting through more than 50 letters that have arrived in response to an unusual advertisement headlined ''War Criminals, Evidence Wanted,'' which appeared in British newspapers last weekend.

title: The Grip of Tennis
description: I CAN'T begin to count all the years I have played tennis indoors, or how many different players I have been with. Of course, there have been changes; the years have brought not only new personalities but new artificial turfs, better lighting, more heat. When I finally, reluctantly, have to leave, what will be my legacy to my tennis friends?

title: Gandhi Promises Measures To Crush Violence in Punjab
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi said today that his Government would use emergency laws in Punjab State to combat rising terrorism ''as and when necessary.''

description: WHEN Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Representative Jack F. Kemp of New York departed from Presidential competition last month, they underscored one of the capital's political axioms: House members do not make successful Presidential candidates.

title: New Product Is Offered To Reduce Lyme Disease

Attackers are coming from all directions brandishing a variety of weapons - lawsuits, competitive products and imitations of Intel's product - all after the jewel of the kingdom that is hidden inside.

title: Miss Fullmer Plans to Wed
description: Mrs. James C. Fullmer of Toms River, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Jennifer Elizabeth Fullmer, to Robert Dalton Constable, a son of Elinor Greer Constable, the United States Ambassador to Kenya, and Peter Dalton Constable, the Director General of the Multinational Force and Observers in the Sinai Peninsula. The couple plan to marry in June.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: ANOTHER 'MELTDOWN MONDAY'?;
The Question Is Not If, but When
description: LEAD: NOT much has changed in the nearly six months since the biggest stock market crash of the century. The United States and the world economy appear to be back on their pre-crash track. The economy's resistance to the market collapse has been a suprise and a relief to most. But familiar and disturbing patterns remain in the financial markets - a weak dollar and a market- induced trend to higher interest rates - signs that the lessons of the crash have not yet been learned.

title: TEEN-AGERS, EGGS AND HOME ECONOMICS
description: Though the article ''Suffolk Teen-Agers Find Responsibility Begins With an Egg'' on Feb. 14 characterized Alice King as a teacher of child psychology, many of her colleagues on Long Island regard her as a well-respected teacher of home economics. It is regrettable that the home economics connection was not reported.

title: Review/Jazz; Sun Ra, And Work By Mingus
description: The Jazz Triple-Header, part of the Composers' Showcase series at Lincoln Center, opened on Thursday with the Mingus Dynasty Band performing a piece by the bassist Charles Mingus. The work, ''Sketch III,'' a premiere, was composed by Mingus while he lay dying of Lou Gehrig's disease; he sang it into a tape recorder. Mr. Knepper, the trombonist who has been leading the band, transcribed it, giving the weaving melody some pastel harmonies and making it sound much like Mr. Knepper's own orchestrations.

title: A Time and Place for Radios

I was at a branch bank and wanted to open an account. Then I heard the strains of soft rock. The song ended, and I heard a car commercial. A bank officer was supposed to be at work, and he had a radio on.

title: Special Education: Readers Respond
description: HOW sad and disturbing it is to read a lengthy, articulate letter to the Long Island editor concerning special education for children with disabilities (Jane Goldlatt, March 6), which, while full of facts and figures, seems totally absent in appreciation and understanding of the human values that underlie special education services - or, for that matter, the cost benefits to society.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Lyle Takes Lead: Sandy Lyle surged past Jeff Sluman and took a three-stroke lead yesterday after three rounds of the $1 million K-Mart Greater Greensboro Open tournament. Lyle, a Scot who won this title in 1986, came from two shots off the pace with a four-under-par 68 and tied the tournament scoring record for 54 holes at 199, 17 under par. Sluman, who led through the first two rounds, slipped to a 73. He takes a 202 total into today's final round of the chase for a $180,000 first prize. ''I didn't play bad,'' said Sluman who has yet to win in five seasons of PGA Tour activity. ''It was just a day when the putts lipped out and the drives trickled into the rough in funny places.'' (AP) Auto Racing Senna Wins Pole Spot: Ayrton Senna of Brazil won the pole position yesterday for today's 61-lap Brazilian Grand Prix in Rio de Janeiro, the first Formula One race of the 1988 season. Senna, in a McLaren-Honda turbo, set a fast lap time of 1 minute 28.096 seconds at the Nelson Piquet race track on Rio's outskirts. His average speed was 127.5 miles per hour around the 3.126-mile course. The surprise of the day was England's Nigel Mansell, who took second with a 1:28.632 in a Williams-Judd, the only non-turbo car to finish in the top six. Third was former world champion Alain Prost of France in the second McLaren-Honda, followed by Austria's Gerhard Berger in fourth with a Ferrari turbo.(AP) Bowling Top-Seeded Wagner Wins: Top-seeded Lisa Wagner of Palmetto, Fla., defeated Lorrie Nichols, of Algonquin, Ill., yesterday to win the $40,000 first prize in the $200,000 Seagram's Coolers United States Open professional tournament in Winston-Salem, N.C. Wagner, twice a runner-up in the United States Open, won her 18th career title, 226 to 218, when Nichols failed to strike on her second ball in the 10th frame.(AP) Bellinger Takes Final: Jeff Bellinger, the only player who could reach 200, won four matches to capture the $200,000 Professional Bowlers Association Miller Lite Championship in Milwaukee. Bellinger collected $39,000 and his second P.B.A. victory by beating Steve Cook, 204-183, in the finals.(AP) Soccer Liverpool Loses Again: Nottingham Forest became only the second team to beat Liverpool this season in English League play by edging the First Division leaders, 2-1, yesterday in London. Forest will face Liverpool again in the semifinals of the Football Association Cup next week. Liverpool's previous loss came at the hands of Everton. Brian McClair scored three goals as Manchester United, the runner-up, beat Derby County by 4-1.(AP) Boxing Lockridge Retains Title: Rocky Lockridge retained his International Boxing Federation junior lightweight boxing title yesterday by outmuscling the top-ranked contender Harold Knight to win a unanimous 15-round decision in Atlantic City. Lockridge is 43-5 with 35 knockouts. Knight is 19-1 with 15 knockouts. Judge Frank Cairo scored the fight 145-140; Richard Murray scored it 145-139, and Tom Kracmarek scored it 145-139. It was the second title defense for the 29-year-old Lockridge, who captured the I.B.F. title in August by knocking out Barry Michael in Windsor, England.(AP) Steeplechase Rio Claro Triumphs: Rio Claro took the lead after the 12th of 13 jumps to capture the 56th Carolina Cup steeplechase yesterday at the Springdale Race Course in Camden, S.C. Rio Claro won by 2 1/2 lengths in 4:13.2. A record crowd of 42,000 watched the jockey Gregg Morris ride his second consecutive winner in the race. He was aboard Gogong in 1987.(AP) Track and Field Schmidt Third in Comeback: Wolfgang Schmidt, a former world-record holder in the discus, placed third in the competition yesterday at the Miami Track and Field Grand Prix, his first international event since he was imprisoned for trying to defect from East Germany. Schmidt, a former captain of the East German track and field team, began serving a 16-month prison term in August 1982 for forging visa documents but was barred from competition on his release. He resumed training after he was allowed to emigrate to West Germany last November.

title: 'Unruly Dragon': An Excursion In Need of a Guide
description: ''The Unruly Dragon'' flows along like its subject, the Yellow River in China. It's long and it's muddy, but it has lots of bright flashes of color. The Yellow River, or Huang Ho, starts in the Tibetan highlands and empties out in Bo Hai Bay off southeast China after twisting and turning 3,300 miles. Some 120 million Chinese, Tibetans, Mongols and Moslems live along its banks, a great many of them, one thinks, worried about disaster. In the last 50 years, ''The Unruly Dragon'' reports almost casually, floods, crop failure and starvation have taken the lives of more than 4 million. The figure of 4 million is hard to comprehend; we can't imagine misery that vast. The problem is, ''The Unruly Dragon'' can't quite imagine it, either.

title: Miss Rothstein Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Nancy Ellen Rothstein and Eric Paul Chwatt, graduates of the University of Maryland, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Rothstein of Lawrence, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Edward A. Chwatt of New York and Mrs. John W. Landy of Great Neck, L.I. Miss Rothstein is with Harry Macklowe Real Estate in New York. Mr. Chwatt is secretary-treasurer of the JEM Capital Corporation, also in New York.

title: FICTION
description: IMAGIO. By James McClure. (Penzler, $16.95.) Here's a warning for novelists and novel readers alike. Beware of paragraphs, such as the one on page 9 of James McClure's ''Imago,'' that talk about the ordinariness of facing a midlife crisis - because in all probability they signal an author's unsuccessful attempt at reweaving a threadbare theme. James McClure, who normally writes mysteries set in his native South Africa, has ignored the signal in this change-of-pace novel. His protagonist, Tom Lockhart, is a London radiologist who is lurching through his troublesome middle years, and it shouldn't be thought that either his surname or the fact that he's continually performing angiograms - looking clinically at the human heart - is an insignificant clue to his emotional aneurysms. Neither is his developing friendship with Felicity (for happiness), a cardiac surgeon. Lockhart has fallen out of love with his wife, Sylvia, and has fallen in love, or so he thinks, with the teen-age daughter of friends. It is Lockhart's conniving pursuit of this girl that forms the plot of ''Imago.'' After much persistent, clumsy and mendacious finagling, Lockhart finally realizes that middle age is the time when fantasies ought to be exchanged for romantic realities, a discovery with which many men - and women too - might well identify. But it would take someone much more intriguing and amusing than the oafish Lockhart to entice most readers to go along with this twice-told - no, twice-told is a great underestimation - tale.
