Cards show probable opening-day lineups; slashes represent a platooned position.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: RECHENKA'S EGGS Written and illustrated by Patricia Polacco. Unpaged. New York: Philomel Books.

title: From Behind a Brother's Shadow
description: LEAD: EVERYTHING is relative; for Shepard Alonzo Mount, perhaps, more so.

title: A Second-String Day at the Races
description: Second-stringers dominated an afternoon of Kentucky Derby preps yesterday that was filled with upsets and ironies.

title: Contras Seek to Change Timetable for Peace Talks
description: Contra guerrilla leaders will not arrive in Managua Wednesday to begin peace talks as was agreed in last week's cease-fire accord, contra officials said today.

title: Vietnam Echoes: 'We Are All Afraid to Die'
description: Reality, the novelist Philip Roth suggested in the early 1960's, was growing so surreal as to render fiction almost obsolete.

title: Alcott Leads by Four In Shore Tournament
description: Amy Alcott, whose 12-year streak was ended when she did not gain a victory in 1987, was approaching her first triumph in nearly 20 months as she moved to a four-shot lead today after three rounds of the Nabisco Dinah Shore tournament.

title: Meese and the Presumption of Innocence
description: To the Editor:

title: 'The Phone Rings All the Time'
description: PAUL KENNEDY, the Dilworth Professor of History at Yale University, has become an instant celebrity. No one is more surprised than Dr. Kennedy.

title: Economic Shifts: How Contrctors and Their Towns Are Adjusting
description: THE Grumman Corporation's military contracting business is becoming ''more demanding and unforgiving,'' according to the company's president. The same could be said for the Bath Shipyards in Bath, Me., the helicopter and jet engine divisions of the United Technologies Corporation in Connecticut, the airframe builders in southern California and many other companies, as military suppliers adapt to flat or declining Pentagon budgets.

title: Freighter Runs Aground
description: For the second time in as many days, a freighter has broken anchor in rough seas and run aground just off the beach, the Coast Guard said today. The 128-foot Honduran freighter Brac Express was reported mired 30 yards offshore.

title: The Palestinian Leadership: Diffuse and Decentralized
description: AS the wave of protests the Palestinians are calling the intifadeh, or uprising, approaches its fifth month, life in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip is settling into a grueling struggle.

title: A LA LAIQUE
description: Etched dragonflies, bubble patterns and mica flecks, scenes such as a glass polar bear ambling across an arctic-blue lamp shade - these we find in Victor Arwas's magnificently illustrated GLASS: Art Nouveau to Art Deco (Abrams, $65), a breathtaking ode to man's creativity. ''Glass,'' Mr. Arwas writes, ''is the end product of the fusion of a siliceous matter, such as powdered flint or fine sand, with an alkali, salt or metallic oxide.'' In the late 19th century, it was also the stuff from which dreamlike forms - what the glassmaker Emile Galle aptly called ''vitrified poems'' -were made. This book, which has been written for collectors but is accessible enough for any curious reader, presents a kaleidoscopic look at some 130 glassmakers. Included are the histories and works of Louis Comfort Tiffany and Rene Lalique, the Daum brothers, Maurice Marinot, John Northwood, Johann Loetz-Witwe and others. The book lingers over the most memorable, particularly Galle, who was so enamored of flowers, insects, lily pads, banana leaves and other natural forms that he turned this love into glass. Mr. Arwas, the author of ''Art Deco,'' does his scholarly duty and provides a good bibliography and glossary as well as descriptions of techniques; there are also sections of special interest to collectors, notably signature identification guides and remarks on the detection of forgeries. But the real strength of this volume is the revelatory beauty of the glass itself. Many of these works reflect flashes of extraordinary brilliance - we'll never see their like again.

title: 25/ Is Mightier Than the Word
description: A CRUDE intruder one day invaded the tranquil airwaves of our blissful domocile.

title: Uneasy Alliance
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Reminders: Add One Hour ...
description: Daylight saving time resumed at 2 A.M. today. Clocks were set forward one hour.

title: Why Don Mattingly Is Baseball's Best Hitter
description: ON A DAY IN MARCH, three members of the Kansas City Royals' starting pitching rotation are in the team's spring-training clubhouse discussing Don Mattingly, the New York Yankees' first baseman. Talking about Mattingly, they agree, is infinitely more amusing than pitching to him.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: DIANA BLAIR;
New Executive Director of Federated Conservationists
description: LEAD: AFTER months of searching, the Federated Conservationists of Westchester County, a coalition of more than 300 people and 60 organizations dedicated to protecting the county's natural and historic resources, has hired a new executive director.

title: Driver Shortage Is Seen Idling Taxis
description: Despite a fare increase last year, New York taxicab companies continue to face a shortage of drivers that is idling from 4 to 20 percent of fleet-owned cabs every day, city and taxi industry officials say.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Hallowell, Me.; Rebounding From a Flood
description: WITHIN several hours a year ago, a flood devastated storefronts in downtown Hallowell that had been renovated with painstaking attention to historic detail.

title: BUCKS TOP NETS, 125-111
description: Terry Cummings scored 34 points and a reserve, Larry Krystkowiak, added a season-high 22 as the Milwaukee Bucks defeated the New Jersey Nets, 125-111, tonight. It was the Nets' fifth consecutive setback.

title: Contras' Future: Crippled as Warriors
description: The 60-day Nicaragua cease-fire that went into effect on Friday leaves the rebels in a vulnerable military position and makes it highly unlikely they could resume effective military operations if peace negotiations with the Sandinistas broke down, according to American military specialists.

title: Women Energize The Man's World Of Paul Taylor
description: Deep within an anony-mously industrial building on lower Broadway, the Paul Taylor Dance Company is preparing for its monthlong City Center season, which begins Tuesday. To a visitor, the contrast between the impersonal bustle on the street and the focused intensity within suits Mr. Taylor's choreography - that kind of joking, jarring scramble of what's real and what's not has made his 34-year-old ensemble perhaps the most consistently popular in American modern dance.

title: Sports of The Times; Johnson and Martin: The Subdued Couple
description: Fashion note: Both Dave Johnson and Billy Martin shaved off their mustaches before spring training. The desperado look is out. Patience and humility are in.

title: Corporate 'War' At Columbia
description: STUDENTS and administrators at Columbia University agree that Asher B. Edelman conducts an unusual course in the Graduate School of Business: ''Corporate Raiding -The Art of War.''

title: Mets Win, Prepare to Move
description: The Mets ended their first spring training on Florida's Atlantic Coast today, their best anywhere, with a seven-run first inning against Joaquin Andujar, four home runs and an 11-5 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: AIDS Symptoms Found Slowed In Teen-Agers
description: AIDS experts who have recently begun to focus on teen-agers have discovered, to their surprise, that that age group may be more resistant to the disease than either infants or adults.

title: Higher Rates for Mail To Take Effect Today
description: Letters, postcards and packages cost more to mail starting today. A first-class letter now costs 25 cents to mail, up 3 cents. The second ounce of first-class mail costs 20 cents, also up 3 cents.

title: Louise Nicholson, A Lawyer, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. James J. Nicholson of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Chatham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Louise Ellen Nicholson to Mark Peter Howe, a son of Chester M. Howe of Winchester and Osterville, Mass., and the late Geraldine J. Howe.

title: SHUTTLE MEMORIAL IS MOVING AHEAD
description: More than two years after the space shuttle Challenger exploded, momentum is growing for the building of space science centers in memory of astronauts who died in the accident.

title: TILDEN GIRLS EXCEL
description: Tilden High School of Brooklyn was the big winner in the girls' division at the Kearny Relays today while Prospect Heights of Brooklyn excelled in the boys' division.

title: A Stern Manila Hunts Mutineer, Again
description: The Government mobilized as if for a national emergency today after the leader of a coup attempt escaped from a prison ship along with his sympathetic jailers.

title: The Patterns That Repeat
description: I WAS sitting at the kitchen table planning the garden and watching the finches at the feeder.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: HOLLYWOOD DOESN'T LIVE HERE ANYMORE. By Robert Parrish. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) Hollywood memoirs can be a double letdown when the great old star or director turns out to be a bland writer without a story to tell. Robert Parrish is not a great director - ''Cry Danger,'' ''Fire Down Below'' and ''In the French Style'' are probably his best films - but he is a most engaging autobiographer and raconteur.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My 65-year-old house has a red brick chimney running up through the center of the house. About five or six of the bricks in the bottom of this chimney (in the basement) seem to be eroding along their entire length and height, leaving red brick powder on the floor. Bricks on either side are not affected. I cannot imagine any bugs feasting on brick dust. What is your guess?

title: ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS IN BREAST CANCER
description: In regard to your update about the disturbingly high incidence of breast cancer on Long Island [ ''Breast Cancer Rate: Puzzle for L.I.,'' March 13 ] , and specifically Nassau County, it is important for women to realize that, now more than ever, they must take this issue into their own hands.

title: THE NATION: THE PENTAGON IS LEARNING TO LIVE WITH LESS;
description: THIS year's annual report to Congress from Secretary of Defense Frank C. Carlucci 3d bore a startling notation over a chart projecting the Navy's shipbuilding plans for 1990 and beyond: ''Subject to further review,'' it said.

title: Turnpike Spur Undergoing Repair
description: LEAD: MOTORISTS using the western spur of the New Jersey Turnpike, which feeds traffic to and from the George Washington Bridge, will find the roadway in both directions reduced by one lane for 11 weeks starting after the rush hour Friday evening.

title:
GARDENING;
A Selection of Bulbs to Plant for Summer Bloom
description: LEAD: BULBS conjure images of spring: crocus, tulips and daffodils. But these early season gems are not the full story.

title: POSTING: A Mt. Laurel Obligation; A First for Affordability in New Jersey
description: Three years ago, New Jersey enacted the Fair Housing Act allowing one municipality to pay another to take on half of its obligation to provide affordable housing. By the end of this year, the first new buildings to result from that law, which stemmed from the Mount Laurel court decisions, will replace a bus garage in New Brunswick. The 44-unit project, called Delavan Court, will consist of three structures designed by Quincy Johnson at Sanford and Delavan Streets.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
A Workshop for the First-Time Buyer
description: LEAD: ON a recent Sunday afternoon, Ron and Regina Connors decided to forgo house-hunting to attend a workshop for first-time home buyers at the Bank of New York in Garden City.

title: 'Made in Japan' or Not? That Is the Question
description: It seemed a sure-fire marketing plan: sell consumer electronics goods branded with a Japanese name, a ''rising sun'' symbol and a catchy motto, ''Japanese Technology Made Perfect.''

title: Denise Mersereau to Wed
description: Paul E. Mersereau of Avon, Conn., and Carol Mersereau of New Britain, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Denise Mersereau to Galan G. Daukas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Daukas of Watch Hill, R.I. Miss Mersereau, a municipal credit analyst with the Connecticut National Bank in Hartford, graduated from Ithaca College. Her fiance, who graduated from Dartmouth College, is an associate in the Investment Partnership at Drexel Burnham Lambert in Hartford.

title: Smoking Curbs to Begin Wednesday
description: New York City's new anti-smoking law will take effect Wednesday, beginning a social experiment on a grand scale that will pit increasingly militant nonsmokers against more than a million smokers, some of whom view lighting up not only as a pleasure but as a civil right.

title: Vienna
description: To the Editor: We read the chart ''What Your Dollar Will Buy in 18 Cities Around the World'' (Travel, March 6) with dismay, for it might cause grave misunderstandings as far as Vienna is concerned.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: STREGA, by Andrew Vachss. (Signet/New American Library, $4.50.) A temptress named Strega (the Italian word for ''witch'') hires a private investigator to find a photograph taken by a ring of child pornographers. The search through New York's seamy underworld makes ''Mickey Spillane's exploits read like the minutes of a Harvard alumni meeting, class of 1920,'' Newgate Callendar said here last year. The novel is ''unbelievable and slick, but fun.'' RECKLESS DISREGARD: Westmoreland v. CBS et al.; Sharon v. Time, by Renata Adler. (Vintage, $6.95.) Beginning in late 1984, two libel cases went to trial, more or less simultaneously, on the first and third floors of the Federal District Court in Manhattan. As a journalist, novelist and graduate of Yale Law School, Renata Adler took advantage of the coincidence. In her examination of the cases of Gen. William Westmoreland v. CBS and Gen. Ariel Sharon v. Time, she criticizes journalists she believes were less interested in truth than in whatever legal technicalities would get them off the hook. ''The quality throughout of intense thought - the perception of the nonobvious connections and the attention to history, to social context and to the competing values at stake - conveys the sure sense of a challenging mind at work,'' Marvin E. Frankel said here in 1986. THE TWO FACES OF JANUARY, by Patricia Highsmith. (Atlantic Monthly, $7.95.) A young American poet living in Athens tries to help a swindler who has accidentally killed a policeman elude justice; in the process he falls in love with the man's wife. ''It's an offbeat, provocative and absorbing suspense novel,'' Anthony Boucher said here in 1964. The same publisher has reissued Patricia Highsmith's book A GAME FOR THE LIVING ($7.95), which was published in 1958. The plot of this mystery also centers on a triangle, involving a German, a Mexican national and the woman they love. WIND AND SAND: The Story of the Wright Brothers at Kitty Hawk, by Lynanne Wescott and Paula Degen. (Eastern Acorn/Abrams, $19.95.) Drawing on Orville and Wilbur Wright's own writings and the glass-plate photographs they took, the authors re-create the years in North Carolina when the two young bicycle mechanics were developing the first airplane. ''The combination achieves an uncanny evocation of what it must have been like,'' Richard Witkin said in The Book Review in 1984. ''The Wrights' brilliance, humor, tenacity and courage, intellectual and physical, are highlighted on page after page.'' FORREST GUMP, by Winston Groom. (Berkley, $3.95.) With an I.Q. near 70, Forrest Gump is not only a war hero, a football star and an astronaut (among many other things) but an idiot as well. In 1986, our reviewer, Jonathan Baumbach, said this ''picaresque novel is a kind of defanged 'Candide,' an unabrasive satire of the idiocy of life in our time. [ It ] has many pleasures to offer.'' THE JAGUAR SMILE: A Nicaraguan Journey, by Salman Rushdie. (Penguin, $6.95.) The Indian novelist Salman Rushdie spent three weeks among the Sandinistas, emerging with ''political musings [ that ] tend to sound superficial - and sometimes naive,'' Michiko Kakutani said in The Times in 1987. Still, she found his account ''stirring and original. . . . It gives us an impressionistic picture of the country in bright, patchwork colors unavailable in your usual journalistic dispatches.'' ALL WE NEED OF HELL, by Harry Crews. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.95.) Duffy Deeter, a health-crazed lawyer, is so obsessed with his body that he almost destroys the rest of his life. Last year, our reviewer, Russell Banks, called Harry Crews ''a comic moralist, Swiftian at times in his ferocity and wit. . . . There is in [ his ] work the sheer pleasure of reading a man who is not embarrassed by his own sense of moral outrage.'' BEYOND OUR MEANS: How Reckless Borrowing Now Threatens to Overwhelm Us, by Alfred L. Malabre Jr. (Vintage, $6.95.) An editor of The Wall Street Journal argues that America's mounting debt and spendthrift ways could lead to a Government-controlled economy. Last year, Adam Smith (a k a George J. W. Goodman) said here that the book is ''scarier than anything by Stephen King. It may be the scariest tract since Jonathan Edwards.'' IN THE CITY, by Joan Silber. (Penguin, $6.95.) When Pauline, the teen-age daughter of Russian immigrants, leaves Newark for Greenwich Village in 1925, in search of ''a circle of people who did artistic and outrageous things,'' she finds friends reminiscent of the coolly detached characters in a Tama Janowitz story. In 1987, our reviewer, Joyce Johnson, said she doubted that life in the 20's and the 80's was really so similar, but she admired the novel's ''deft, elegant, wryly economical dissections of Pauline's elastic nature.'' CLOSE PURSUIT, by Carsten Stroud. (Bantam, $4.50.) In this book about a week in the life of a homicide detective, a Canadian journalist finds that New York City policemen are often professional and cooperative but sometimes sexist and racist. Last year, Dorothy Uhnak said here that while ''Close Pursuit'' contains too many ''unexamined opinions,'' it ''provides a strong, clear and admirable picture'' of a big-city detective. MOLECULES OF THE MIND, by Jon Franklin. (Laurel/Dell, $8.95.) Since mind, like life, is rooted in the interaction of molecules, psychology might ultimately be reduced to chemistry. In 1987, Barry L. Jacobs said here that this book about molecular psychology is sometimes glib and overstated but, for the most part, an ''exciting and thought-provoking'' account of a science and its moral and philosophical implications.

title: Question of the Week: Next Week; Does Steinbrenner Help or Hurt The Yanks?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Not Much Movement In the Winfield Market
description: Another day went by and there was still no trade involving Dave Winfield. There might never be one.

title: Yale Students' 'Tempest' Set for Kennedy Center
description: ''THIS is the year of Yale on the road,'' said David Chambers, the director of the Yale Drama School's production of ''The Tempest.''

title: Barcelona Style
description: To the Editor: We really enjoyed Shopper's World on design in Barcelona by S. Irene Virbila (Travel, March 6). In conjunction with the shop Bd Ediciones de Diseno, she mentioned Bar Boadas off Las Ramblas. It is surely one of the most delightful little bars anywhere - a 1930's time-warp, pulsating with life.

title: Officials Seek Ways to Stop A Strike in Armenian Enclave
description: Communist Party leaders in the disputed Armenian enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh in the Azerbaijan Republic met today to decide how to stop strikes disrupting the region's industry, a party spokeswoman said.

title: Review/Music; Berg Violin Concerto
description: Patches of empty seats dotted the orchestra section of Avery Fisher Hall at the New York Philharmonic's all-Romantic matinee Friday afternoon; perhaps subscribers noted the names of Berg and Webern on the bill and feared something forbidding. The former's Violin Concerto and the latter's Passacaglia for Orchestra were not played quite as romantically as they might have been - both tended to move bar-by-bar, not in poetic, airborne spans - but their harmonic and timbral richness would surely not prove alienating to such a large part of the orchestra's regular audience.

title: Warsaw Bids a Big Benvenuto to Italian TV
description: The notion of spaghetti westerns along Poland's Vistula River may become a reality when Italy's principal state-owned network begins direct transmission of its full television program to Poland later this year.

title:
DINING OUT;
Chinese Cuisine in New Rochelle
description: LEAD: THERE is no doubt that Szechuan Empire has in the past been an asset to the community, bringing to Wykagyl solid as well as attractive preparations of classic Chinese cuisine. Included and welcome were the goodly number of Sichuan dishes, with their sour, sweet and spicy components in skillful balance.

title: LILCO'S TOP CLIENT SHIFTS TO A RIVAL
description: The Long Island Lighting Company's biggest customer, the Grumman Corporation, helped break ground here this week on a $63 million power plant that will make the sprawling aircraft factory largely independent of the troubled utility and insulate it from increasing questions about the price and reliability of Lilco's electricity.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: THE OBSERVATION TOWER
description: LEAD: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S passion for putting a ''For Sale'' sign on the United States Government and turning everything over to the private sector has stirred within me a secret desire. I am confident Governor Kean will offer me his complete support.

title: Headliners; Buying Up
description: Peter Kalikow, one of New York City's best-known landlords, now aspires to move up to media baron. Mr. Kalikow recently purchased the New York Post from Rupert Murdoch after Federal legislation forced Mr. Murdoch to sell the Post in order to keep his New York television station, WNYW-TV. Last week, a Federal appeals court ruled that the Congress had unconstitutionally singled out Mr. Murdoch. The ruling did not affect the sale of the Post; nor did it overturn the Federal ban on cross ownership of a newspaper and television station in the same market. But it did seem to give Mr. Kalikow ideas. After the ruling, he said through a spokesman that he had ''always had the desire'' to own a radio or television station and now intended to acquire one in New York City.

title: John Paul Asks Us to Look Into Our Economic Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Anti-Smoking Experiment

title: John P. Colligan And Lacey Hall Plan to Be Wed
description: The engagement of Ruth Lacey Hall to John Patrick Colligan, a son of Mrs. George A. Colligan of Hanover, N.H., and the late Dr. Colligan, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Barbara Bradley Hall of Essex, Conn., and William R. Hall of Bensalem, Pa. A September wedding is planned.

title: French Visas
description: To the Editor: Last year we planned a trip to Yugoslavia and Greece and, as we were flying via Luxembourg, thought we would also visit France, the first country we've ever needed a visa for. We got our passports stamped and left for Luxembourg. At the airport we rented a car; France was our first entry. After having our passports dutifully stamped by Luxembourg officials, tension mounted. My wife asked, Was I sure that the visas were in proper order? Approaching the customs checkpoint, I slowed down. With one fell swoop of the guard's arm, I was suddenly atuned to the crowd at Mudville when ''the mighty Casey has struck out.''

title: Arts and Crafts Put on Airs At the Cooper-Hewitt
description: The most ambitious exhibition ever organized of Arts and Crafts material is also the most controversial, presenting the turn-of-the-century movement as a philosophy, not a style. The show, comprising far more than the robust oak furniture, leaded-glass lamps, colorfully glazed ceramics and woodblock typography usually associated with Arts and Crafts, opens Tuesday at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CELEBRATING POPE Alexander Pope, England's esteemed 18th-century poet, is the subject of a dual exhibition in New Haven. The Center for British Art and the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library at Yale are celebrating the tricentennial of the writer's birth.

title: Genial Setting and Modest Prices
description: INDULGE is a cozy little restaurant in Craft Village at Bittersweet Farms in Branford that is making a whole-hearted effort to serve fresh food in imaginative ways and at modest prices.

title:
MUSIC;
Princeton Offering Piano-Cello Duo
description: LEAD: THE award-winning cello and piano duo of Julia Lichten and Jennifer Tao will give its only New Jersey performance of the season Saturday evening, two days before leaving on a month-long European tour.

title: MOTHER'S 'UNCONTROLLABLE SWARNING'
description: WE DREAM OF HONOUR John Berryman's Letters to His Mother. Edited by Richard J. Kelly. Illustrated. 405 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $22.50.

title: Hill Risks Title In Fight Today
description: Virgil Hill defends his World Boxing Association light-heavyweight title for the second time Sunday afternoon against Jean-Marie Emebe.

title: Dukakis Leads Jackson in Wisconsin Poll
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis leads The Rev. Jesse Jackson in support for Tuesday's Wisconsin primary, according to the latest Milwaukee Journal Poll.

title: Rhetta M. Arter; Researcher, 79
description: Dr. Rhetta M. Arter, a social and cultural researcher and former director of field studies for the Center for Human Relations Studies at New York University, died of breast cancer in New York Hospital last Sunday. She was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: WHY NEW YORK HAS A SOUND ALL ITS OWN
description: Watching terminally cheerful television weather forecasters, with their satellite radar maps and brightly colored graphs and diagrams, is to contemplate a daily metaphor for the nature-defying power of New York City. Fearsome-looking cold fronts sweep down from the Arctic, dumping snow or rivers of rain on the reeling Midwest. Closer and closer they march, terrorizing helpless New Jersey and chilling upstate New York. But as they approach New York City, they falter. Snow becomes rain, temperatures jump 10 degrees, dire predictions turn to smiling, apologetic shrugs.

title: A Moody Retreat Under Italy's Alps
description: LAKE COMO, where I spent some weeks last spring finishing a novel, is temperamental. In 10 minutes it can change from the rippling transparency of ginger ale to a simmering olive-green witch's broth beneath which you can almost glimpse the heaving and churning of the aquatic monsters some locals claim to have sighted on dark, misty mornings.

title: After Settling On Size of Pie, Albany Fights Over Slices
description: GOVERNOR CUOMO often speaks of New York as a ''family.'' Last week, as state budget talks broke down, it might have been called a bad case of sibling rivalry. For what separated the various sides, it seemed, was not so much ideological differences as geographical ones - questions as to how much of the $28 billion pie each region would get.

title: A Sentence the Offender Takes Home
description: On an end table in Ronnie's modest living room sits an unassuming little box that keeps him sober, working and out of jail.

title: Garden State Ballet Giving Newark a Dazzling 'Thank You'
description: LEAD: THE Garden State Ballet, which has assumed a dazzling new polish this season, will celebrate its 27-year tenure in Newark this week with four free performances at the New Jersey Institute of Technology.

title: LEARNING THE ART OF BRINGING UP BABY
description: Twenty-three-year-old Pam Thomas is the mother of three children, 5 years old, 4 years old and 4 months old. Her fiance is in counseling to learn to control his anger. Pam, her fiance and the children share a trailer with her father-in-law, who suffers from cirrhosis of the liver.

title: Who's Entitled?
description: To the Editor:

title: Learning How to Fish From the Masters
description: LEAD: LIKE soldiers lining up for target practice, 26 children formed 4 columns in the gymnasium of the Tri Beach Center in Milford, waiting to try their luck with a spincast fishing rod. The rods, capable of throwing out up to 30 yards of line at the flip of a wrist, were armed at the business end with nothing more lethal than a yellow plastic weight.

title: Rampal One Week, Pianos the Next
description: LAST week, Isaac Stern played the Palace, the one in Stamford, and tomorrow night, another of the world's most famous musicians, Jean-Pierre Rampal, pays Connecticut a call.

title: Quest for the True Meaning of Blue Zero
description: WHAT does the term Blue Zero mean to you?

title: In the Other Wisconsin, Too, Jackson Has Appeal
description: What happens in the Wisconsin primary is often determined in places like this, far from the fiery liberal precincts of Madison and the working-class wards of Milwaukee or Kenosha.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
911 Automation
description: LEAD: The New Rochelle Police Department's average response time to medical emergencies has been cut to 3.7 seconds from 4.3 seconds since the installation of an enhanced 911 system three months ago, according to Kevin Spillane, the city's Director of Emergency Services.

title: When Team Spirit Is the Star
description: Under her Louise Brooks hairdo and serene demeanor, this freckle-faced heroine is as tenacious as Columbo and as relentless as Eliot Ness. But her quarry is not stylish murderers or gangsters hiding gallons of bathtub gin. Instead, she single-mindedly pursues Japanese citizens engaged in a national pastime: tax evasion.

title: George, Do as You Say
description: In another Yankee crisis, in another Yankee era, Reggie Jackson talked about how he, not Thurman Munson, was ''the straw that stirs the drink.'' And in a fond foreword to the new book, ''Catfish,'' published by McGraw-Hill, another Yankee remembers how the book's author, Jim (Catfish) Hunter, reacted in 1977 to ''the straw that stirs the drink'' controversy.

title: Keeping A Delicate Balance
description: It has been nearly a quarter of a century since I played in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament, but the memory of the Final Four remains fresh in my mind. Each year as the tournament comes to a close, I think about my days as a college player and about the important role basketball has played in my life.

title: P.L.O. Seeks to Restore Its Presence in Beirut
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization is pressing for a reopening of its office in Beirut, which was closed in the aftermath of Israel's invasion of Lebanon six years ago.

title: Peril in Trading Rooms: $1,000,000 Cigar Break
description: In dozens of trading rooms at banks and securities companies around the city, the puffing of cigars and cigarettes starts with breakfast when early arrivals check the London markets.

title:
ART;
Roles on the Dance Stage
description: LEAD: ADELPHI'S University Center Gallery is small, just a fraction of the size of a theater stage, yet ''The Artist and the Choreographer: Sets and Studies for the Dance'' succeeds in creating an awareness of the manner in which contemporary artists have been collaborating with performance companies.

title: FRONT-PAGE RELIGION
description: SPIRITUAL POLITICS Religion and America Since World War II. By Mark Silk. 206 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Where Maharajahs Once Played
description: THERE comes a time in Indian travels - after the Britishness of New Delhi, the disbelieving wonder of the Taj Mahal, the delight of peacocks and emeralds in Jaipur, the majestic rock sculpture of Aurangabad's caves, the flashiness and despair of Bombay and the frustration and decayed beauty that is Calcutta - when a gentle respite is in order. Consider Puri, one of the four holiest Hindu centers in India, situated on the Bay of Bengal and with one of the most beautiful beaches in the world.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: How Will The Mets And Yanks Do in '88?
description: The Mets will finish in first in the National League East by a 21 games, whip the Reds in five games in the National League playoffs, and breeze past the Blue Jays in five games to win another World Series. The Yankees, on the other hand, will finish a disappointing third as Jack Clark is plagued by his nagging ankle. MARK MILLER New York

title: Miss Aldrich Plans to Wed S. S. Murray
description: Mrs. Charles Duane Aldrich of Cambridge, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter Sarah Elizabeth Aldrich to Stephen Sheals Murray, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan J. Murray of Morristown, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass. The couple, who graduated in 1981 from Phillips Exeter Academy, plan to marry in July.

title: Making Slam With A Backward Finesse
description: AN ambitious international experiment at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals in Buffalo last month showed considerable promise but will have to overcome some bugs.

title: The Seder and Its Message of Freedom
description: I WAS there when it was truly morning in America. I watched my newly naturalized father pledge allegiance for the first time, to the flag of the country that had adopted him. He was not an emotional man, but his eyes glistened with joy. I was 6 years old at the time, but the moment lives in my memory.

title: Melissa Salten to Wed R. A. Rothman
description: David G. Salten of Old Westbury, L.I., and Frances C. Salten of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Melissa Gail Salten to Richard Allen Rothman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Rothman of New York and Greenwich, Conn. The wedding is to be next month.

title: NO SEX PLEASE - WE'RE HOLLYWOOD
description: THE CENSORSHIP PAPERS Movie Censorship Letters From the Hays Office, 1934 to 1968. By Gerald Gardner. 226 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $18.95.

title: Mindy Gildin, Lawyer, Engaged to Marc Utay
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert I. Gildin of Lloyd Neck, L.I., have announced the enagement of their daughter, Mindy Ann Gildin, to Marc Alan Utay, a son of Florence Utay and Edwin Utay, both of Chicago. The couple plan a September wedding.

title: Turmoil in Justice Dept. Saps Drive for Conservative Agenda
description: Senior Justice Department aides say that while disarray has subsided after one of the more tumultuous weeks in the department's history, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d appears to have lost virtually all momentum in pursuing his politically conservative legal and legislative agenda.

title: Wimps Sweeten The Screen
description: Presidential politics isn't the only realm in which the wimp factor plays a role. It's also a consideration in film, for works like ''The Milagro Beanfield War,'' in which a group of nice New Mexico townsfolk band together to outsmart a crass developer; ''A New Life,'' the Alan Alda divorce comedy that pretends to have a cutting edge but is, in fact, colored by boundless optimism; ''Dominick and Eugene,'' about a handsome young doctor making huge sacrifices to take care of his mentally deficient twin, and ''Stand and Deliver,'' about a dedicated teacher who cares more about his students' math test scores than anything else in the world.

title: Montclair Museum: Ethnic Textiles
description: ETHNIC textiles are the focus of two programs at the Montclair Art Museum this month.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on March 20 about the Indonesian province of East Timor omitted a sentence in a passage on the release of political prisoners. It should have read: ''The prison on Atauro Island, 20 miles offshore from the East Timorese capital of Dili, has been closed, although about 200 former prisoners elected to stay there or around Dili.

title: Robert Joffrey and His Great American Dream
description: In many ways, Robert Joffrey embodied the American dream. The son of an Italian mother and an Afghan restaurant owner, he was typically American. Others might want a home with a picket fence; the child who grew up in Seattle as Abdullah Jaffa Anver Bey Khan dreamed of founding his own ballet troupe. In a nation of immigrants with no state-supported ballet company, he knew this dream company would have to be built with his own bare hands.

title: The Bull Market in Cash Equivalents
description: LAST October's stock market collapse sent investors scurrying for safety. Six months later, fear still reigns over greed. Investors want truly ''secure'' securities - even though the payoff will be modest - and cash has become king.

title:
DINING OUT;
An Italian Fixture in Bloomfield
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH Italian restaurants abound in New Jersey, there are several areas where they predominate, one of which is the northeastern part of the state. Here, although there are restaurants of every hue imaginable, those serving Italian food are still in the majority.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We debate various possible options. I never comment on speculative newspaper articles.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz, on possible U.S. action in Panama. [ 16:3. ]

title: On Film Processing
description: HAVE you ever wondered who is responsible for processing your precious film? If you frequent one of the ubiquitous one-hour film labs, the answer is simple: the film-developing and print-processing machines are usually in plain sight. But if you prefer a more leisurely pace, which usually costs less, the question is more complicated.

title: Opening Japan's Markets
description: Last week, Japan agreed to open its construction market to American companies. Initially, there are 14 projects worth about $15 billion covered by the agreement. But there are no guarantees that American companies will produce winning bids. How will American companies do in the Japanese market? CLYDE V. PRESTOWITZ Former counselor to the Secretary of Commerce and senior associate of the Carnegie Endowment.

title: 'The Founding Fortunes'
description: To the Editor:

title: This Way To the Dark, Satanic Mills
description: AT every turn, Britain pays homage to its rich past. No shortage of castles, cathedrals, stately homes or museums here. And the spoils of Britain's flights of imperial adventure are handsomely housed. Yet despite this reverence for the past, there are few major landmarks to note that this country launched the Industrial Revolution, which along with parliamentary democracy is often deemed Britain's most distinctive contribution to world history.

title: 'Story of My Wife'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Vanishing Lieder Ritual
description: Every concert audience plays a part in a ceremony whose roots lie buried in the primeval ooze, one with sacred rituals ruled over by gifted celebrants who manipulate mass emotions and give dramatic expression to communally held values. People who grow up attending such events do not so much learn their roles as absorb them unconsciously, by a kind of social osmosis. Consider only the strange ritual of the disappearing maestro at symphony concerts: the audience takes it calmly when the conductor abruptly leaves the stage at the end of the piece. We know, somehow, that we have not seen the last of him.

title: Lawyer Engaged To Tara Purohit
description: The engagement of Tara Purohit to John S. Wojak Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wojak of Manhasset Hills, L.I., has been annnounced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Surendra N. Purohit of Port Washington, L.I. The couple plan to marry in the fall.

title: What Austria Can't Buy for $416
description: Austria has seemed unable to get anything right about its past since Kurt Waldheim acknowledged two years ago that he served Hitler in the Balkans. But that, he explained, was long ago. He was a youth doing his duty and besides, he knew little about the killings of Jews, hostages and British prisoners. An Austrian majority rewarded his defective memory by electing him President. Now, as in some bitter play by Durrenmatt, the majority is turning against him and strives to exorcise the ghosts he has conjured up.

title: Workplace for Homeless Needs Home
description: There was a time when Regis Moore made $25 an hour printing brightly colored labels on aluminum cans at the Reynolds Corporation plant in Woodbridge, N.J.

title: THROWAWAY SOCIETY NEEDS NEW MATERIALS
description: As a throwaway society we have steadily built up the enormous mountains of refuse and garbage that are now posing such a threat to our air, soil and water, and inevitably to ourselves [ ''Running Out of Time and Landfills,'' Feb. 28 ] But why in all the discussion is the focus only on the disposal of all our waste, and not on the cause of so much trash? The wrappings and containers that are forced upon us, the consumers. I say forced because we have little or no input into what is wrapped around our purchases.

title: Meese's Friend Missed Potential Impropriety
description: E. Robert Wallach, a friend of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, says he should have been more sensitive to an appearance of impropriety in helping Mr. Meese set up a financial partnership with an investment manager who wound up on the board of the Wedtech Corporation.

title: Bush Wraps It Up, as Democrats Struggle On
description: FOR both political parties, it was a week of some turmoil and apprehension, but the reasons for the unease were very different.

title: FICTION
description: RICE WINE. By Barry Came. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $17.95.) Barry Came, a journalist who covered the Philippines for Newsweek, has set this colorful suspense novel in the northern Luzon highlands in the concluding years of the Marcos era. It is loosely based on the bloody struggle over ancestral lands that took place in the Chico River valley, where President Marcos and his cronies planned a huge hydroelectric project - and the Communist New Peoples' Army clashed with Government forces on behalf of the impoverished farmers who would be displaced as a result. In Mr. Came's version of this story, popular resistance to the dam project has scared away potential investors, and the United States Government has decided to intervene on the side of its client, President Marcos. Unaccountably, through a quasi-official banking agency, Mr. Came's hero, Paul Stenmark, is sent to assess the political situation. Stenmark, the sort of young professional who would be indicted if he worked on Wall Street, is plunked down in a mountain hamlet, where he comes under the protection of a number of people who fear that his ignorance and ambition may get them all into trouble. These include Alfredo Dantog, a revered chieftain who leads the faction opposed to the dam; Harry Quayle, a cynical Australian engineer; Father Frank Enright, a priest who has lost his faith; and Liz Buenaventura, a tireless country doctor. Despite their differing opinions on what's good for the uplanders, the members of this varied group have somehow learned to cooperate. All is not chummy, however, because two other outsiders - a guerrilla commander and an army lieutenant - are bent on using the situation to further their own ends. And when the inevitable battle erupts, everyone is engulfed. Alas, while ''Rice Wine'' has plenty of action, Paul Stenmark thinks and acts so slowly that he impedes a good deal of it. He also dims the luster of several more promising characters, whose points of view often seem more interesting and challenging to the author - but are only fleetingly presented to his readers.

title: PLOTS AGAINST HER VIRTUE
description: THE ADVENTURES OF ROBINA, BY HERSELF Being the Memoirs of a Debutante at the Court of Queen Elizabeth II. By Emma Tennant. 165 pp. New York: Persea Books. $14.95.

title: Bedtime Story
description: THE PRINCESS BRIDE Starring Robin Wright, Cary Elwes, Chris Sarandon, Mandy Patinkin (in photo, center), Wallace Shawn (in photo, left), Andre the Giant (in photo, right), Christopher Guest, Fred Savage, Peter Falk, Peter Cook, Carol Kane, Billy Crystal, Mel Smith. Directed by Rob Reiner. 1987. Nelson Entertainment. 98 minutes. $89.98. Rated PG. Some minor violence, a few rude moments.

title: THEY ONLY COME OUT AT NIGHT
description: I HAVE BEEN ONE acquainted with the night,'' wrote Robert Frost. Acquainted, sure. But you aren't really on intimate terms until you've commuted by night. For five years, I awoke at 3

title: Rapid Growth Founders in Maine's Largest City
description: Just a few years ago, everything seemed possible in this city on Casco Bay.

title: How Will The Mets And Yanks Do in '88?
description: Billy Martin's old sidekick, Art Fowler, will probably ruin the Yankees' already shaky pitching. At least two starters will be out of action by the All-Star Game break; and despite a strong offense, the Yanks are headed for fourth place. RICHARD SCHUCKMAN New York

title: OTHER STATIONS ON THE LINE ARE ELEGANT ONCE AGAIN
description: TWO hours and 17 minutes from the Spartan claustrophobia of New York's Penn Station, there is another Pennsylvania Station, graceful and grand. This one is bathed in a gentle aqueous light that filters through the silver-green panels of a triple-domed stained-glass ceiling and reflects off celery-green Rookwood tiles.

title: Think Thin, Thin, Thin . . .
description: THE THIN MAN Starring William Powell and Myrna Loy (in photo), Maureen O'Sullivan, Cesar Romero. 1934. AFTER THE THIN MAN William Powell, Myrna Loy, James Stewart, Sam Levene. 1936. ANOTHER THIN MAN William Powell, Myrna Loy, C. Aubrey Smith, Virginia Gray, Sheldon Leonard. 1939. SHADOW OF THE THIN MAN William Powell, Myrna Loy, Donna Reed, Barry Nelson, Louise Beavers. 1941. THE THIN MAN GOES HOME William Powell, Myrna Loy, Gloria DeHaven, Donald Meek. 1945. SONG OF THE THIN MAN William Powell, Myrna Loy, Keenan Wynn, Dean Stockwell, Jayne Meadows. 1947. MGM/UA Home Video. $24.95 each.

title: A Few Pointers for the Season
description: NOW is the time to seed hardy crops in the garden, especially spinach, lettuce, cabbage, roquette, mache, radicchio and others used for salads. Also, plant onion sets or seed, peas, beets and chard. Allow crocus, galanthus and aconite foliage to remain and renew bulbs for next spring. Prune summer-flowering hydrangeas and rose of Sharon. Indoors last call to sow seed of tomatoes, peppers, cucumbers, melons and eggplants. Transplant seedlings of annuals that have their second pair of true leaves; keep them moist and once a week use a water-soluble fertilizer diluted to half the recommended rate. The Greensward

title: Miss Dentzer Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. William T. Dentzer Jr. of Larchmont, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter Susan Grace Dentzer to Charles Clark Alston, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Alston of Greensboro, N.C. The couple plan to marry in September.

title: Warehousing
description: To the Editor:

title: Fanfare to Accompany Legislators' Move
description: LEAD: MORE stringent regulations on when wetlands can be destroyed and replaced artificially have been recommended by the state's Council on Environmental Quality.

title:
GARDENING;
Flowers for the Damp Garden
description: LEAD: JUST as there are numerous trees and shrubs that are tolerant of moist planting sites, there are even more herbaceous perennials that will thrive under such conditions.

title: Parties Maneuver to Replace 2 Representatives
description: WITH the death of Representative James J. Howard nine days ago and the announced retirement of Representative Peter W. Rodino, New Jersey has lost its two most powerful Congressmen.

title: Foes Take Off Gloves Over Name for Library in Bucks County
description: Mention the new Bucks County library, a $5 million, 50,000 square-foot building that looks like a miniature shopping mall, to the librarians cataloguing books in their current cramped quarters across the street from the courthouse and everyone smiles.

title: Report Warns on Efforts to Reduce Class Size
description: A report by the Department of Education says that any major attempt to reduce class sizes in public schools would be very expensive and probably ''a waste of money and effort.''

title: TALKING: Delinquents; Strategies On Late Payments
description: THE news last month that John Z. De Lorean, the former car manufacturer, had fallen many months behind with maintenance payments at his Fifth Avenue cooperative raises an issue of continual concern to officers and managers.

title: HOW SWEET IT IS
description: THIS MAY BE THE AGE of running shoes, diet books and food taboos, but there is one part of our lives still outside of calorie-counting. That is the field of glorious desserts, be it a hefty scoop of vanilla ice cream or an insidiously good afternoon fix of a chocolate truffle. Even after a prudent meal of grilled fish and vegetables, most diners in American restaurants greedily dive into the richest dessert on the menu.

title: The Editorial Notebook; A Sure Thing in the Casino
description: The charter bus pulled up to 86th Street and Second Avenue on Manhattan's Upper East Side. It was 8:30 A.M., first stop on the run to the Atlantic City casinos, and most of the passengers were in their 70's, or older. ''Sometimes I feel like I'm in charge of a mobile nursing home,'' the driver said as he collected the $18 round-trip fares. The passengers greeted him warmly; many also seemed to know fellow regulars, who make the trip every week or so.

title: How Will The Mets And Yanks Do in '88?
description: Mattingly will field a slow-bouncing Mookie Wilson grounder cleanly, and the Yanks will take the Series 4 games to 2. ROGER HENNEFELD New York

title: Jesus Died -- And Then What Happened
description: ''IF Christ has not been raised, then our preaching is in vain, and your faith is in vain.'' Wherever members of the clergy prepare their Easter sermons, those words from St. Paul's letter to the Corinthians almost certainly echo in their minds.

title: Valvano to Remain At N. Carolina St.
description: Jim Valvano, the North Carolina State basketball coach, withdrew his name today from consideration for the coaching job at U.C.L.A., saying it was in the best interests of his family.

title: Kluszewski Farewell
description: He slugged his way into the hearts of Cincinnati players and fans, and both groups turned out in force yesterday to bid farewell to Ted Kluszewski, the power-hitting ''gentle giant,'' who died of a heart attack last week at the age of 63. He was the Reds' first baseman from 1947 to 1957 and served as the team's batting coach during the Big Red Machine days of the 1970's.

title: Rangers Fall Out of the Driver's Seat as Playoff Push Stalls
description: The Rangers, like awkward congregants at a wake, sat in the silent locker room and tried to look busy. Those that didn't have their heads in their hands clutched cigarettes and bottles of beer, fumbled with ice packs and uncooperative neckties. Finally, they picked up their bags and left, weighed down by what they had let slip: control of their immediate future and a hold on 11 years of history.

title: BECKER CAPTURES FIRST W.C.T. TITLE
description: Boris Becker earned his first World Championship Tennis Finals title today with a four-set victory over top-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden.

title: Rev. Constance Jordan Married to David Haas
description: The Rev. Constance Mary Jordan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Jordan Jr. of Bethlehem, Pa., was married at the First Presbyterian Church there yesterday to David Stewart Haas, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Dennis W. Haas of Grinnell, Iowa. The bridegroom's father performed the ceremony.

title: Another Ferry? Yes, We Need It
description: BECAUSE of increasing roadway congestion between Long Island and New England and the New York State Department of Transportation's projected shortfall of $3.5 billion in funds to bring Long Island's roads to capacity by the year 2000, the L.I. Midsuffolk Business Action group has begun a campaign for tractor-trailer ferry service the 20 miles between the end of the William Floyd Parkway and New Haven.

title: Peter S. Clark 2d And Stacy West To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard West of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Stacy Ellen West to Peter Stratton Clark 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Garland Clark Jr. of Mount Lebanon, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

title: POSTCARDS, ELEGIES AND GHOSTS
description: APRIL GALLEONS By John Ashbery. 97 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $15.95. DISBELIEF By John Ash. 127 pp. New York: Carcanet. Paper, $9.95. SELECTED POEMS II Poems Selected & New 1976-1986. By Margaret Atwood. 147 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: A Farmer Believes Government Should Get Out of the Barnyard
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; Elisa King's Angels and Alter Egos
description: Elisa King's ''Epode'' is a dark and powerful dance. And it is all the more interesting for the fact that Ms. King appears to be most at home creating gently lyrical dances. Or so it seemed in a concert presented by Elisa King and Dancers on Thursday at Playhouse 46 of St. Clement's Church (423 West 46th Street).

title: Review/Jazz; Piano and Songs, by O'Brien and Nakasian
description: When Hod O'Brien was first heard playing piano in New York in the 1950's, he was a product of the be-bop era, with a style that drew on the playing of Bud Powell. In recent years Mr. O'Brien has been working as a duo with the singer Stephanie Nakasian, primarily in New Jersey, and the rumbling, swaggering lines of Dave McKenna have replaced the fleet, be-bop virtuosity of Powell as Mr. O'Brien's stylistic stimulus.

title: GANGSTERS AND PRANKSTERS
description: THE MYSTERIES OF PITTSBURGH By Michael Chabon. 297 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $16.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My 65-year-old house has a red brick chimney running up through the center of the house. About five or six of the bricks in the bottom of this chimney (in the basement) seem to be eroding along their entire length and height, leaving red brick powder on the floor. Bricks on either side are not affected. I cannot imagine any bugs feasting on brick dust. What is your guess?

title: SASSY PUBLISHER: Sandra Yates; The Ms. on the Masthead Wants the Magazine
description: SANDRA YATES still remembers her first encounter with male chauvinism. She was 26 years old and had just bought a copy of ''The Female Eunuch,'' Germaine Greer's feminist book. ''Someone, I suspect one of my brothers, ripped the cover off,'' Ms. Yates recalled. ''It was my first hint that anyone would resent the idea that men and women are equal.''

title: Ellen Miskovsky Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Milan C. Miskovsky of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter Ellen Barry Miskovsky to Andrew W. Kentz, a son of Judge and Mrs. Frederick C. Kentz Jr. of New Vernon, N.J., and John's Island, Vero Beach, Fla. A September wedding is planned.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''We have dodged the bullet from the stock market decline. The economy seems to be getting its second wind.'' - Robert Dederick, executive vice president, Northern Trust Company.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Laurel, Md.;
A Compromise On Wetlands
description: LEAD: A 619-ACRE tract midway between Baltimore and Washington, without utilities and including 150 acres of marshy wetlands and a lake, is about to go into development after four years of work and negotiations with the local Anne Arundel County government.

title: April Showers
description: Following is a listing for 20 places around the world of average April rainfall and the number of days in which there is measurable precipitation. Rainfall Rainy (in inches) Days Death Valley, Calif. 0.1 1 Reykjavik 2.2 18 Seattle 2.3 13 Paris 1.7 13 Brussels 2.4 18 Portland, Ore. 2.8 14 Miami 3.2 7 New York 3.2 11 Vancouver 3.3 14 San Juan 4.1 14 New Orleans 4.8 7 Tokyo 5.3 10 Sydney 5.3 14 Hong Kong 5.4 8 Bogota 5.8 20 Singapore 7.4 15 Nairobi 8.3 16 Dar es Salaam 11.4 19 Kuala Lumpur 11.5 20 Cherrapunji, India 26.2 16 Source: The World Weather Guide (Times Books, 1984)

title: Singer-Songwriters Spin Their Tales
description: Gradually and with little fanfare, the singer-songwriter, the musical animal that threatened to overrun pop in the early 1970's, has regained a foothold in music following a prolonged and severe reaction.

title: How Will The Mets And Yanks Do in '88?
description: In October, take the 7 from Willets Point-Shea Stadium in Queens to 42d Street-Grand Central in Manhattan, where you transfer to the uptown 4. Stay on until you reach 161st Street-Yankee Stadium, the Bronx. Then back again. JOHN KISSEL Staten Island

title: A Girl Who Cast Herself Into a Man's World
description: I first thought about fishing at the end of a summer evening's excursion on Greenwood Lake, N.J., in the early 1930's. Dad was the fisherman and mom was rowing the boat.

title: Nearly $1 Billion in Missile Contracts Canceled
description: The Air Force has rewritten its contracts covering development of the new Midgetman mobile nuclear missile, canceling almost $1 billion worth of work planned by six contractors.

title: Oklahoma Pressure Foils Arizona, 86-78
description: Oklahoma flustered Arizona tonight in a way no team has this season. The Sooners wrecked the Wildcats' calm, cool order by flapping hands in their faces, by shoving hips into their sides and by riding a numbing defense to an 86-78 semifinal victory here in Kemper Arena.

title: Social Events; Parties, Landmarks, Jazz
description: Preview in SoHo

title:
BODY AND MIND;
The Wolf Inside
description: LEAD: FOUR WEEKS BEFORE SHE DIED OF A COMPLICATION of lupus erythematosus, Flannery O'Connor wrote: ''The wolf, I'm afraid, is inside tearing up the place. I've been in the hospital 50 days already this year.'' By the time of her next recorded letter, three days later, she had received the rite of Extreme Unction.

title: Comings and Goings
description: They've been together in the NBC broadcast booth for five years, and now Vin Scully and Joe Garagiola are about to make it six. The two have been named to continue as the network's announcers for the ''Saturday Game of the Week.'' . . . Ed Eyestone, who won the collegiate championships in the 5,000 and the 10,000 meters in 1985, has been named to the United States team in the Asics Cup America's Ekiden, a five-leg, 50-kilometer relay through the streets of Manhattan next Saturday. . . . Vernon (Lefty) Gomez, the 79-year-old Hall of Fame former Yankee pitcher who was admitted to a hospital in Greenbrae, Calif., after complaining of chest pains, is doing well, doctors said, but will remain in the coronary unit for several days.(AP)

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: East Hampton, Conn. $130,000 24 South Main Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 29-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 0.75 acre; taxes $1,317. Westport, Conn. $471,500 42 Colony Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 19-year-old colonial; greenhouse, underground sprinkler, 1 acre; taxes $3,399. Wilton, Conn. $449,000 2 Twin Ponds Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 28-year-old colonial; cul-de-sac, spacious country kitchen, newly painted interior, 1.8 acres; taxes, $4,327. Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $518,000 2 Doxbury Circle 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 3-year-old contemporary; eat-in kitchen, deck, patio, 0.51 acre; taxes $7,199. Bronxville, N.Y. $381,000 3 Dusenberry Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old brick ranch; dropped living room, walk to station; taxes $8,064. White Plains, N.Y. $220,000 37 Valley Road 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 78-year-old stucco colonial; eat-in kitchen, deck, walk to station; taxes $989. OTHER AREAS Mineola, L.I. $190,000 457 Wilson Boulevard 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 37-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,000. Livingston, N.J. $220,000 433 South Livingston Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 16-year-old split level; rec room, 2-car attached garage; taxes $3,446. Millburn, N.J. $205,000 899 Ridgewood Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 2 half-bath, 48-year-old colonial; fireplace, oak floors, 1-car garage; taxes $2,722.

title: 'No Regrets'
description: Long after Jean Herman's holdout is forgotten, passersby will wonder why a four-story brownstone protrudes from the side of a 31-story office tower on East 60th Street near Lexington Avenue. Though it will be a memorial of an epic battle in New York City's real estate wars, the jarring juxtaposition of brick-and-brownstone and granite-and-glass may be the best resolution of a bad situation.

title: Drink Deep and Let the Stars Shine In
description: GROWING up in Queens, I had an intense interest in astronomy. I was given a telescope and learned the constellations. Older, I moved to the East End of Long Island, along a belt of woodland where the lights of scattered neighbors were far fewer than the stars above. Far from the light pollution of Queens, I could now see the night sky in all its glory (there is no other way to put it).

title: Political Notes; Primary Scenes: Koch's Vote, Shadow Candidates and Wooing Dukakis
description: Mayor Koch, who has consistently beat the drums for Governor Cuomo for President, seemed to be flirting with an endorsement of Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee last week. The Mayor was unusually strong in his praise of the Senator, and two top Koch advisers, David Garth and Lawrence Mandelker, are playing key roles in the Gore campaign.

title: Demolition Dumping Costs Are Soaring
description: THE high price of construction in New York City is being pushed even higher by rising costs for demolition and the disposal of rubble.

title: Susan Heller Anderson Weds Lawyer
description: Susan Heller Anderson, a reporter for The New York Times, and Robert B. von Mehren, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton, were married yesterday. Judge James L. Oakes of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Manhattan.

title: Back to School For Older Drivers
description: LAST month, the New York State Motor Vehicle Department sent me a card saying I could reduce my auto liability and collision insurance cost if I took an approved six- or eight-hour course, which did not involve a test. It seemed like the best offer of the day, so I looked into it.

title: New York Fall Flashes
description: WHAT A SHAME IT WILL BE IF the fall season disintegrates into a shambles of controversy over hemlines! Manhattan-based designers begin presenting their autumn collections this week, and, like their counterparts in Paris, Milan and London, they are highlighting hemlines as a focal point for change. But it is not the only one. There is also news in the way the whole silhouette is shaping up, from the narrrowing-in and rounding of shoulders to the cuts and use of fabrics that mold body coverings in diverse shapes. Some are loose but controlled; others elongate the figure in a sophisticated manner; still others continue to exaggerate curves. Given the design diversity, hemlines look good at various lengths: a bit above the knee, somewhere below the knee, sometimes longer still.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-17

title: Signs of Strength Keep Cropping Up
description: More signs of strength in the economy emerged. The unemployment rate in March fell to 5.5 percent, the lowest in a decade. The decline of one-tenth of a percentage point means that 6.8 million people are unemployed, 137,000 fewer than in February. The leading indicators' index climbed nine-tenths of 1 percent in February, after posting declines in three of the four preceding months. Sales of new homes were up sharply in February, rising 20.3 percent over the depressed January figure. Mortgage interest rates that fell below 10 percent were given credit for that.

title: Specialized Storage for Oenophiles and Others
description: WITH the moving side of the moving and storage industry tightening, many carriers are discovering that storage can provide new sources of profit. With a little fixing, dusty old warehouses can be turned into specialized storage areas that command premium rates.

title:
GARDENING;
Flowers for the Damp Garden
description: LEAD: JUST as there are numerous trees and shrubs that are tolerant of moist planting sites, there are even more herbaceous perennials that will thrive under such conditions.

title: This Spring's Hot Movie Underlines The Uneasy Link Between Art And Advertising
description: The hottest French film in Paris today is titled, with droll irony, ''Life Is a Long, Quiet River.'' It is a chuckle-inducing comedy about two archetypal French families, one grubby and proletarian and the other well-to-do and piously Roman Catholic, that are disruptively intermingled when it is revealed that their son and daughter were switched in swaddling at birth by a spiteful hospital nurse. The belated discovery of the hospital swap sets off bedlam in the uptight, haute bourgeoise Le Quesnoy family.

title: Slinging Muddle
description: ALBERT GORE'S analysis of the Democratic race has become received wisdom,'' wrote Michael Kramer in U.S. News & World Report early in the primary campaigning. ''Iowa and New Hampshire have produced a 'muddle.' ''

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: LIGHTNING. By Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $18.95.) Just when you think a cliche hasn't a bit of energy left in it, along comes some writer to surprise you. That's the case here with the stock horror story opening ''It was a dark and stormy night,'' as Dean Koontz takes each of its lightning bolts and thunderclaps out of the realm of meteorology and into that of horrific fantasy.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: EASTER PARADE The Easter Sunday fun begins at 1 P.M. today in Garden City, as the annual Antique Car Parade and informal fashion walk-by wend their way along Franklin Avenue. Because it's no use donning finery with no place to go, both cars and humans eventually will end up across from Village Hall on Stewart Avenue: the cars to collect their trophies and plaques and be on display for the public to see at closer range, the spectators to give the young among them the chance to explore the Easter egg tree, meet the costumed bunnies and sample the lollipops. Everything is free. NEW BEGINNINGS This is also the week that several gardens and museums open their grounds and doors for the new season. Today, Old Westbury Gardens is waiting for people to stroll its pathways from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. on a pre-season spring walk. The first of four weekend walks through April 30, when the gardens open officially, today's jaunt affords a look at the first signs of spring in the formal gardens and the surrounding woodlands. Visitors in need of a more educational pursuit can join in the guided garden tours at 1 and 2 P.M. The gardens are at 71 Old Westbury Road. For admission information call 333-0048.

title: VERIFICATION IS ABOUT TO BECOME EVEN HARDER
description: THE Reagan Administration has said proudly that the agreement recently signed with Moscow banning medium- and shorter-range missiles contains measures for on-site inspection that are both unprecedented and effective. But if the two superpowers are able to work out a new treaty reducing long-range arms, it will have to include even more far-reaching ways to verify that each side is abiding by the treaty.

title: Laura Kurjan Engaged To Robert M. Goldman
description: The engagement of Laura Michelle Kurjan to Robert M. Goldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Goldman of Rochester, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Marvin A. Kurjan of Woodmere, L.I. A November wedding is planned.

title: NEW NAME TAGS
description: CELEBRATED INTERIOR designers such as Mark Hampton and Juan Montoya will be the newsmakers at this spring's Southern Furniture Market. Other well-known names in the design world, including Pierre Deux, the shops synonymous with antique French country furniture and fabrics, will also be newcomers to the mass-market industry. The twice-yearly furniture fair, which opens in High Point, N.C., on April 14 and runs through the 22d, is the largest in the United States. It is here that store buyers and merchandise managers shop in hundreds of wholesale showrooms, selecting furniture and accessories that will fill stores in the coming months.

title: SPLIT IS REPORTED IN ADMINISTRATION ON PANAMA POLICY
description: American officials said today that the Reagan Administration was deeply divided over what further steps it should take to force the ouster of Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Hard Times for a Discounter
description: CHARLES SCHWAB & COMPANY, the nation's largest discount broker, advertises that its low-cost commissions can help investors save money when they buy and sell stock. But investors who bought stock in Schwab at its initial offering last September have only lost money. The villain of course, is the Oct. 19 stock market crash. Schwab, which went public at $16.50 a share, rose to only $17 before plunging to $5.75. The stock was trading around $7.38 last week.

title: Paolo Milano, 83, Dies; Italian Literary Critic
description: Paolo Milano, a professor and literary critic, died of Parkinson's disease yesterday in Rome. He was 83 years old and lived in Rome.

title: Tippett a Patriot
description: There's nothing like a little new blood and a lot of new money to lead a team to change its mind about how much it needs a high-priced free agent. That appeared to be the case Friday night when the New England Patriots signed the All-Pro Andre Tippett to a six-year contract that presumably rivals the $4.5 million, five-year deal the free-agent linebacker had reportedly been offered by the San Francisco 49ers.

title: The Future of Israel
description: They are like grasshoppers compared to us. - Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, speaking in the West Bank on March 31.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MAC By John MacLean. 175 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin.

title: Can the Team With the Talent (the Mets) Be Beaten?
description: The following reports on the American and National Leagues were prepared and written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in the order of predicted finish, with the Yankees and Mets picked to finish first in their divisions. Cards show probable opening-day lineups; slashes represent a platooned position.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Melbourne
description: It is typical of Melbourne to regard Australia's Bicentennial celebration as belonging more to Sydney than itself. Melbourne began not with the convict settlers at Sydney Cove in 1788 but in 1835 with sheep and cattle men who drove southward in search of pasture and water. For Melbourne, which has its own celebrations like the Spoleto Festival of Three Worlds in September, the Bicentennial seems a bit premature.

title: Suzanne B. Ducat Engaged
description: Suzanne B. Ducat, a producer of national news and public affairs programming at WETA-TV, a public station in Washington, and Stanley M. Cohen, the regulations quality officer for the Education Department in Washington, plan to marry in June.

title: Q and A
description: The Use of a Deck

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: FINAL PERFORMANCE. By James Brown. (Morrow, $18.95.) With its allusions to Nelson Algren and Jack London, ''Final Performance,'' James Brown's third novel, clearly aspires to place domestic strife in a larger social context. The time is the Vietnam War era. The story involves immigrants' children who marry, settle in northern California and begin raising two sons to the American Dream.

title: THE REGION -- Pro & Con: Wicks Law; Is Inefficiency Built Into Public Construction?
description: Responding to complaints by the Citizens Budget Commission last month that New York City takes a long time over construction projects, Deputy Mayor Robert Esnard and Budget Director Paul Dickstein said that 41 months on the average was ''not too long'' for design and completion ''given the constraints of the system government is required to work under.''

title: Animal Testing
description: To the Editor:

title: Starving Deer Found At Overpopulated Park
description: BLUFF POINT STATE PARK in Groton has been an ideal deer preserve for years, with dense hardwood forests and no hunting permitted. Now, conservation officials say, it seems the deer have thrived there too well.

title: Kansas and Oklahoma Are the Final Two; Jayhawks' Defense Stops Duke by 66-59
description: Near the end of a season that had once seemed lost, the Kansas Jayhawks used an overwhelming defensive presence to build an early lead, then overcame exhaustion and a Duke comeback tonight to defeat the Blue Devils, 66-59. With the victory, they advanced to the championship game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

title: IN SEARCH OF GEORGE BUSH
description: According to Randall Rothenberg (''In Search of George Bush,'' March 6), a former White House official says that Vice President Bush ''is a fiend for writing personal notes.'' I can tell you of one note from Mr. Bush that is not so much personal as it is indicative of his temperament. It was found recently by my niece, Patricia Haesly Worthington, who was sorting out the papers of her late father, Gerson Haesly, a businessman, of Tyler, Tex. On Nov. 20, 1970, shortly after Mr. Bush lost his campaign for a United States Senate seat, Mr. Haesly, a vigorous opponent of desegregation, wrote this letter to Representative Bush:

title: WOMEN LAWYERS
description: Jill Abramson's article (''For Women Lawyers, an Uphill Struggle,'' March 6) was excellent as far as it went, but it offered little perspective on how difficult it was for women lawyers to break into law in the first place.

title:
INVESTING;
A Strong Rebound for Hospital Stocks
description: LEAD: AFTER a miserable 1987, hospital management stocks have been outperforming the market by a huge margin this year. Analysts are revising earnings estimates upward and portfolio managers are once again buying shares of the major companies.

title: Report on Boy Returned to Africa
description: FOR two months, 9-year-old Terrence Karamba was scared to return home to Zimbabwe, New York City welfare officials said. When he finally made the trip a month ago, he was accompanied by a Zimbabwean social worker and a psychiatrist assigned by the United States State Department in Washington.

title: 3 Unlikely Shows in Ridgefield
description: LESTER JOHNSON, Varujan Boghosian and James Grashow: a more improbable cross-section of contemporaries is hard to imagine. Yet, there the three are with a show apiece at the Aldrich Museum in Ridgefield, and surprisingly, since there is no grand curatorial design behind the juxtaposition, they turn out to have something in common: obsessiveness.

title: SPRING, AND EVERYONE'S FANCY TURN LIGHTLY
description: NOW is the time to keep a weather eye open while keeping fashion in focus, too. Spring clothes, always unpredictable and surprising, are even more so this year, as if going along with the now-they're-up, now-they're-down temperatures.

title: Headliners; Stepping Up
description: Faced with disciplinary action by the national leaders of his church, the Rev. Jimmy Swaggart first decided to answer to a lower authority and then, apparently, to none. Mr. Swaggart stepped down from his television pulpit Feb. 21 after reports that he had paid a prostitute to pose naked for him. Leaders of the Assemblies of God in Louisiana, Mr. Swaggart's base, recommended suspending him for three months. But the church's national leaders in Springfield, Mo., last week ordered him to cease preaching for a year. The next day, Mr. Swaggart said through a spokesman that he would accept only the punishment ordered in Louisiana, and would resume preaching May 22. When Louisianians subsequently changed their minds and backed a one-year suspension, Mr. Swaggart he would return to the pulpit in May anyway.

title: Devils Closing In; Islanders Win Title
description: The Devils are one victory away from making the playoffs for the first time in their history. Their 5-2 triumph over the Islanders this afternoon put them into a fourth-place tie with the Rangers, and both teams have one game left.

title: How Will The Mets And Yanks Do in '88?
description: Mets: 103-59, first in the National League East. The only thing that can stop the Mets this year is the Mets.

title: Low Prices Won't Induce Customers to Move
description: ''ON the New Jersey Turnpike no one can hear you scream.'' This slogan, from an advertisement for ''Moving,'' the recent Richard Pryor comedy about ''one family's experience with the 'M' word,'' typifies a problem that has plagued the moving and storage industry for years: a poor reputation.

title: Catherine Kerr, Dancer, Wed to Dr. J. R. Ginsberg
description: Catherine Anne Kerr and Dr. Joshua Ross Ginsberg were married yesterday in Yonkers at the home of the bride's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Kerr. Judge Jose A. Cabranes of the Federal District Court in New Haven officiated.

title: Carol Beam to Marry in June
description: The engagement of Carol Scott Beam and Richard Lyon Bowditch 3d has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Elza Beam of Beaverdam, Va. Mr. Bowditch is the son of Phebe A. Bowditch of New York and the late Mr. Bowditch Jr. Miss Beam, the Manhattan sales representative for Rushford Kasel Associates, and her fiance, a photographer, plan to marry in June.

title: The Smallest Church In England
description: CLIMBING beneath the delicate green fretwork of an English wood, I could sometimes glimpse the sea far below through a break in the foliage. Luxuriant ferns grew on the steep hillside along which the path was carved. Pausing to catch my breath, I leaned gratefully against a cushion of emerald moss. Except for a rustle of leaves and a whisper of wind blown up from the sea, I walked in total silence, wholly removed from the world below. That silence was fitting, for I was on a brief pilgrimage to Culbone Church. At first I didn't want to call it a pilgrimage; that sounded penitential rather than pleasurable. But when, vacationing in nearby Lynmouth, a seaside village on the edge of Exmoor, I read about Culbone, the smallest complete church in England, I knew I had to go there.

title: The Tip of the Volcano
description: AT 11 DEGREES NORTH LATITUDE and 104 degrees west longitude, about 1,200 miles west of Managua, Nicaragua, there is a 3,350-foot-high active volcano that no one has ever seen.
