It's underwater, the summit 7,460 feet below the surface of the Pacific, a depth to which surface light does not penetrate. Until recently, scientists were without an accurate picture of such land formations on the ocean floor. The available technology (sound waves, basically) yielded maps that showed changes in elevation (top left) and the texture of the terrain (right) in shapes determined by the paths of the sonar-equipped ships.

title: He Who Wins First Often Wins All
description: IN six out of the seven preliminary matches for world championship candidates in Saint John, New Brunswick, the player who scored the first victory went on to win.

title: 13 Hit, One Killed, by Los Angeles Gang's Gunfire
description: A carload of gang members fired on pedestrians Friday night as they drove by, killing one and wounding 12 others, the authorities said.

title: DATA BANK: April 3, 1988
IN SEARCH OF GEORGE BUSH
description: Randall Rothenberg has come to the conclusion that George Bush knew nothing of the Iran-contra details, but rather was ''ill-served'' by his ''lackluster'' staff who kept him in the dark.

title: LOOK QUICKLY, IT'S BIPARTISAN POLICY
description: CAPITOL Hill seemed unusually blessed last week with the appearance, if not the true spirit, of that most elusive of legislative achievements - bipartisan foreign policy.

title: On Illegal Aliens
description: 'The word is just beginning to get out now to some isolated groups of immigrants, such as Haitians, Asians and Europeans. In this program, the best advertisement is a freshly minted temporary resident card in the hands of a relative or neighbor. ' - Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, after a committee vote to give illegal aliens another six months to apply for legal status. from the library's budget.

title: Where You Can Light Up Under New York's New Law
description: New York City's new anti-smoking law will restrict smoking in most enclosed public spaces, from restaurants to hotel lobbies to offices. Here are the basic provisions of the law: Places of Employment

title: Finding a Substitute Can Prove Frustrating
description: LEAD: FIVE DAYS a week - from 6 to 8:30 A.M. and again from 8 to 11 P.M. - Doris Suitt makes telephone calls to insure that the New Brunswick school system has as many substitute teachers as it needs.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Chasing the Anti-Drug Puck
description: LEAD: THREE years ago, when Governor Kean and President Reagan announced they were coiled for attack on the beast, drug addiction, I was visiting Atlantic City.

title: Giant Lobster Gets Reprieve
description: A 25-pound lobster that nearly became somebody's dinner will be flown by jet plane to Maine on Monday to live out its old age in the Atlantic Ocean. Publicity forced a seafood company owner, a seafood lover, an animal-rights group and the Maine Department of Marine Resources into an unlikely alliance to save the lobster, whose age is estimated in the range of 40 to 125 years.

title: BYGONE HAIRCUTS AND OTHER STORIES
description: MOURNER AT THE DOOR By Gordon Lish. 162 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: Sacha Jonckheer Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Willem August Jonckheer Jr. of Larkspur, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alexandra Louise Jonckheer to James Herbert MacNaughton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Robert MacNaughton of Bethesda, Md. A September wedding is planned.

title: Elizabeth Medlin To Wed a Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. John G. Medlin Jr. of Winston-Salem, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Warfield Medlin to Frank Sheffield Hale, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradley Hale of Atlanta. A June wedding is planned.

title: Let the State Pay for Its Mandates
description: WHEN the Legislature enacted its much-heralded ''caps'' law in 1976, it meant to harness runaway spending at the local level of government, which had contributed to the highest property-tax rates in the nation.

title: Sandra Kunhardt Planning to Marry Francis Basile Jr.
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Philip B. Kunhardt Jr. of Chappaqua, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Sandra Kunhardt to Francis X. Basile Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Basile of Pelham, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in June. Miss Kunhardt is a writer and an associate producer with Kunhardt Productions, a New York television and video production company operated by her brother Peter Kunhardt. She graduated from Middlebury College. Her father is an author and a former managing editor of Life magazine. Her grandmother the late Dorothy Meserve Kunhardt was an author of children's books.

title: Abigail L. Jones To Marry in June
description: Abigail Lispenard Jones and Andrew Michael Feder, 1985 graduates of Vassar College, plan to marry in June. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Sprague Jones of New York, who have announced her engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Feder of New York.

title: Judith Bernstein Plans May Wedding
description: Judith Ellen Bernstein and William Garretson Atkinson 3d plan to be married next month. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Ben Bernstein of Minneapolis, parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Martha Atkinson of Norwich, Conn., and Mr. Atkinson Jr. of Gales Ferry, Conn.

title: GOVERNMENT CRISIS LOOMS IN LEBANON
description: The candidates for the Lebanese presidency agree that without a Christian-Moslem consensus on political changes and a compromise candidate, a power vacuum may be inevitable when President Amin Gemayel's term expires in September.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Shifting the Weight While Milan Kundera wrote a novel called ''The Unbearable Lightness of Being,'' Italo Calvino was a champion of lightness in literature. This is from his ''Six Memos for the Next Millennium'' (Harvard University).

title: The Worlds of Lake Constance
description: LIKE the nearby Black Forest and the equally close Allgau mountains of Bavaria, Lake Constance is one of those idyllic spots first romanticized by peripatetic 18th-century poets, thinkers and artists, then discovered as ideal for summer chateaus by the nobility, made fashionable by the new moneyed industrial elite of the 19th century and finally conquered by just plain tourists.

title: Plastics Bill Aims At Landfill Content
description: LEAD: AFTER the Suffolk County Legislature vote last week to bar stores and fast-food restaurants from sending customers out the door carrying food in plastic bags or containers, the county seems ready to try to control the content of landfills and incinerators.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Meadville, Pa.; Conversions Bring Hope
description: THE rehabilitation of a huge manufacturing plant outside this city of 15,500 in northwest Pennsylvania is the centerpiece of an effort to attract businesses to the area, which has been hit hard by plant closings and layoffs.

title: Top Players Seek New Chess Image
description: Waiters moved through the throng with fluted glasses of sparkling wine. Live doves in a wicker cage picked the order of play. The chess players from the Soviet Union and the United States and points between, all among the best 25 in the world, talked in clusters of a new day in their sport.

title: As Holidays End, Pace Picks Up
description: THE Easter-Passover holidays have brought a lull to the concert scene in Westchester, but by next weekend, everything will be back in full swing.

title: Review/Dance; A Guy Named Samson
description: There was this guy named Samson (Sam, for short). Unlike the biblical Samson, this guy never amounted to much. Yet, like his biblical namesake, he exerted considerable power.

title: Plisetskaya to Dance In Tour of 12 U.S. Cities
description: Maya Plisetskaya and 14 members of the Bolshoi Ballet who have taken part in Boston's Making Music Together festival will open a 12-city tour on Tuesday in Cincinnati.

title: April Dance Performance Schedule
description: LEAD: Following is a calendar of April dance performances

title: Ada L. Pollock to Wed Dr. Alan G. Rosmarin
description: Ada Lynn Pollock and Dr. Alan Glen Rosmarin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Rosmarin of Edison, N.J., plan to marry June 26, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Pollock of Cranford, N.J., have announced.

title: A Brazil State Tries to Civilize Its Bull Spree
description: The fishermen from the Azores who migrated to the southern Brazilian state of Santa Catarina in the late 18th century brought with them a bizarre Easter Week ritual in which a bull representing Judas Iscariot was tied up and taunted.

title: Istanbul Film Festival In Censorship Dispute
description: A dispute over censorship may force the withdrawal of 5 of 160 films that are to be screened at Istanbul's seventh annual film festival next week, organizers said today.

title: New York Has Long Known Plan for a Refuse I.
description: To the Editor:

title: Within the Turbulence, Currents and Undertows
description: When the Justice Department plunged into crisis last week, the scenes played out on television screens, in news conferences and blandly ambiguous official statements, sketched only the dim outlines of a far more complex drama.

title: Kidnappers Are Said to Seek Ransom in Talks With French
description: Security officials said today that Lebanese Moslem extremists holding three French hostages have asked for a ransom in negotiations with the French Government.

title: Russian Jewish Composers
description: Early 20th-century music by such Russian Jewish composers as Joel Engel, Jacob Weinberg, Julian Krein and Joseph Achron will be presented at 7 P.M. tomorrow at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street. Appearing in the concert will be a mezzo-soprano, Kimball Wheeler, replacing Katherine Ciesinski, who was originally scheduled, and Daniel Blumenthal, a pianist. Tickets are $10 ($8 for students and the elderly.) Information: 860-1863.

title: Jackson Wins in Virgin Islands
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson overwhelmed Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in the Democratic Party caucuses here Saturday to win three of the Virgin Islands' four votes at the national convention this summer.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, APRIL 4, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Sports World Specials
description: Mountie on the Mound

title: As for Ex-Presidents
description: Former Presidents and former Presidents' widows have received $9.5 million from the Government in pensions and services in the last decade, according to a study by the General Accounting Office. That does not count the $102 million spent on Secret Service protection. (Such protection for former President Richard M. Nixon ended in 1985, at his request.) Of the $9.5 million, $3.5 million went to Gerald R. Ford, $3.3 million to Mr. Nixon, $2.1 million to Jimmy Carter, $220,000 to Lady Bird Johnson, $120,000 to Bess Truman and $62,000 to Mamie Eisenhower. In addition to $94,838 annual pensions, former Presidents receive Federal funds for office rent, transportation, telephones, office supplies and equipment. Additional funds were spent for renting the house at 716 Jackson Place, which faces Lafayette Park north of the White House and is available for use by former Presidents.

title: Carry On, Clouseau
description: Police officers here patiently watched a stolen motorcycle around the clock for 17 days in hopes of catching a burglar linked to nearly 200 break-ins. Then one officer took a two-minute restroom break and the bike disappeared, The Gainsville Sun reported in Saturday's issue. Two Alachua County sheriff's investigators involved in the failed surveillance were placed on six months' probation.

title: Purchasers Report Dip in Growth Rate
description: The economy continued to expand in March but the rate of growth slowed for the third month in a row, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in a monthly report scheduled for release today.

title: Wendy Foster Fiancee Of Roy S. Wasserman
description: Wendy Paula Foster, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Foster of Manhattan, and Roy Seth Wasserman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Wasserman of Bridgeton, N.J., were married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan by Rabbi David M. Posner.

title: The Text of Resolution 242 of November 1967
description: Following is the text of United Nations Resolution 242, which was approved by the Security Council on Nov. 22, 1967:

title: At Sea World, Stress Tests Whale and Man
description: If killer whales could communicate with humans, as some experts believe they may someday, four whales here might give answers to some profound questions:

title: First Brendan Gill Prize
description: The recipient of the first Brendan Gill Prize, given for an artistic contribution to New York City, will be announced this month by the Muncipal Art Society. About 50 people from the worlds of art, literature and theater have been nominated for the award, which consists of a $5,000 cash prize. The presentation will be made on May 4.

title: Japan Begins Savings Tax, Tapping Pool of $2.4 Trillion
description: The Japanese investment world is scrambling after an enormous pool of wealth - $2.4 trillion in individual savings looking for a better way to grow.

title: Amazing Rents
description: It can cost as much as $2,400 a month to house New York City welfare families in hotels that are second rate or worse. But if that sounds extreme, consider that the luxurious Plaza Hotel on Central Park has rooms for only a fraction as much. The monthly rent for one of them is about $300.

title: 11 Squatters Arrested in Protest for Homes
description: The police arrested 11 protesters who moved into vacant apartments at a public housing project Saturday, but they did not arrest demonstrators who set up a tent city nearby.

title: Dude Vs. Duke
description: The best crack I've heard about this mystifying Presidential election came from Phil Dunne of California, son of the late Finley Peter Dunne: ''The skim milk is rising to the top.''

title: EXPANSION AWAITS FEDERATED STORES
description: The Campeau Corporation plans a huge expansion of Federated Department Stores Inc. - the owner of Bloomingdale's, Filene's and Abraham & Straus - following the completion of its recently accepted takeover offer, according to Robert Campeau, the company's chairman.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON NEW AND RENEWABLE SOURCES OF ENERGY - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Secret Chinese-Israeli Arms Deal Reported
description: Israel has signed a secret deal to supply advanced missile technology to China after sending an arms delegation to Beijing, The Sunday Times reported.

title: Transit Worker Dies After 18-Story Fall
description: An elevator operator at a Manhattan subway station fell 18 stories to his death yesterday when he stepped into an open shaft, the police said.

title: Rangers Win, but It's in Vain
description: The television screen flickered darkly and then slowly faded to black, all of a sudden reflecting perfectly the nearly two dozen faces that had spent the last 45 minutes staring at it.

title: Business and the Law; Antitrust Actions Against Insurers
description: WHEN government officials take on an entire industry by filing major legal actions, two things often follow: private parties bring suits resembling the state claims against the same defendants and legislators call for changes in the industry.

title: I.B.M. Still Bolsters Apartheid
description: LEAD: Two years ago, the International Business Machines Corporation decided to sell its South Africa subsidiary and ''depart'' from that country until apartheid had ended. Although that sale, to an independent company called Information Services Management Ltd., was made final in 1987, it is now clear that I.B.M.

title: Will Milk Be Served?
description: ''A cat may looke on a King,'' as John Heywood observed in his Proverbes in 1546, and it now appears that a cat may look on a President.

title: Golf; Alcott Sets Mark in Victory
description: Five years to the day after she won the Dinah Shore tournament on a very windy April 3 in 1983, Amy Alcott completed a record score of 14-under 274 for 72 holes to win her second Nabisco Dinah Shore title by two shots over Colleen Walker.

title: Key U.S. Bond Dips in Tokyo
description: Because of speculative selling, the key 30-year United States Treasury bond fell 1 1/4 points at the market's opening here from its close on Friday, brokers said. Five minutes after the opening, the 8 7/8 percent bond was trading at 99.24-30, compared with a Friday close of 101.02-05.

title: Review/Cabaret; Theatrical Self-Portrait With Song and Dance
description: Nicky Paraiso is no stranger to risky excess. For years, the diminutive actor and musician has been an important featured player in the psychodramas of the downtown performer Jeff Weiss, singing the popular standards that punctuate Mr. Weiss's semi-autobiographical marathons with a maniacal exuberance. It's no surprise that in his own cabaret act, ''20th-Century Blues,'' which he brought to La Mama from last Thursday through yesterday, Mr. Paraiso should echo Mr. Weiss's ferocious, sweaty energy.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the primary in Wisconsin incorrectly characterized what could happen to Jesse Jackson's campaign if he loses, describing such a result as ''devastating.''The original passage said: ''Just a month ago, Mr. Jackson could have lost in Wisconsin but come out with such a strong white vote that everyone would have noticed. Now, expectations have gone so high, so fast, that a defeat, still very possible, would be a defeat.''

title: Review/Music; Lush, Poetic Meditation For Pop-Jazz Ensemble
description: Although the ''new age'' musical movement has been a largely instrumental phenomenon, it has also left its mark on songwriters and performers. One of the most talented is David Sylvian, the English singer, composer and arranger who uses his foggy folk-jazz crooner's voice as a mood-music instrument in extended original tone poems.

title: Heroin as Painkiller
description: To the Editor:

title: Homing Device to Aid Search for Lost Climbers
description: FOR three awful days in May 1986, an army of volunteers searched the snow-covered slopes of Mount Hood for a lost party of teen-aged climbers. Meanwhile, the youths' families paced and huddled and cried inside this historic ski lodge that faces the 11,235-foot peak. When the search was over, only two of the students had survived. For seven others and two teachers, time ran out before searchers could find the snow cave where they had hidden from a sudden storm.

title: Animal Rights Group 'Liberates' Chickens
description: The Animal Liberation Front tool responsibility Saturday for raiding a chicken hatchery in what it called an ''Easter liberation for life'' for at least 28 hens.

title: Review/Rock; Flashy 60's Extremism
description: The 1960's came back like a fever at Drums on Thursday night. Ball, which opened the show, is one of several groups revolving on the axis built by the increasingly important Shimmy Disc record label. The group has not played much live, and this showed in its enthusiastic looseness and spontaneity.

title: U.S. Must Do More to End Cambodian Conflict; Save Angkor Temples
description: To the Editor:

title: Mine Kills a South African
description: A white South African Army officer was killed on the Namibian border when his vehicle set off a mine, a military spokesman said today. He refused to say whether the explosion that killed Lieut. Jacobus Diederichs occurred inside South African-controlled Namibia, also known as South-West Africa, or across the border in Angola, where South African forces are fighting guerrillas of the South-West Africa People's Organization.

title: Review/Rock; Flesh for LuLu: Pretty Melodies And Rebellion
description: Flesh for Lulu, a five-man English group dressed in regulation leather and makeup, came out at the Ritz Saturday evening and played a regulation set. In front of an appreciative clean-cut crowd the band did what it was supposed to: posture a bit of rebellion (it uses some biker imagery), play loud, sing some pretty melodies, and give people a beat to dance to.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9 New Israeli-Arab peace negotiations must be based on the exhange of occupied territory for peace found in U.N. Resolution 242, Secretary of State George Shultz said. Israel contends it has fulfilled the requirements. Page A1

title: And These Little Piggies Went to Hollywood
description: On the movie screen they are dramatic stars - Louise lurching around France sniffing out cocaine, Lupita stealing scenes directed by Robert Redford, Mephisto ever elegant in his formal bow ties. They might be household names, if only they weren't such pigs.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Jordan Scores 59 Points: Michael Jordan scored a season-high 59 points, including two free throws with four seconds left in the game to snap a tie and give the Chicago Bulls a 112-110 victory over the Detroit Pistons yesterday at Pontiac, Mich. The loss was Detroit's fourth in a row. Chicago has won 12 of its last 16 games. Jordan set up the game-winning free throws when he stole the ball near midcourt and was fouled by Bill Laimbeer. Jordan set the Silverdome record with 61 points on March 4, 1987. (AP) Hawks 102, Pacers 100: Cliff Levingston stole the ball and fed Dominique Wilkins for an uncontested layup with 49 seconds to go to give the Atlanta a victory over Indiana yesterday at Indianpolis. Wilkins finished with 35 points as the Hawks won their fifth straight game and pulled within one game of Detroit in their battle for the Central Division lead.(AP) Celtics 110, Mavericks 101: Larry Bird sank seven 3-point shots and scored 32 points to lead Boston over Dallas yesterday at Boston. Bird fell one short of the league record of eight 3-pointers in a game set by Rick Barry on Feb. 9, 1980, and tied by John Roche on Jan. 9, 1982. (AP) Tennis Evert Outlasts 16-Year-Old: Facing her toughest challenge of the week, top-seeded Chris Evert fought off Arantxa Sanchez, an unseeded 16-year-old, 7-6, 6-4, yesterday in Largo, Fla., to win her second consecutive Eckerd Open. Sanchez, from Barcelona, Spain, won a spot in the final by defeating unseeded Patricia Tarabini of Argentina, 6-2, 6-2, in a semifinal match rained out Saturday and resumed yesterday morning. In the final set for the championship, Evert jumped to a 5-2 lead before Sanchez made one last charge, holding serve then and breaking Evert to close to 5-4. Evert stayed firm, breaking Sanchez in the final game.(AP) Boxing Hill Knocks Out Emebe: Virgil Hill stopped Jean-Marie Emebe at 1 minute 29 seconds of the 11th round yesterday to retain his World Boxing Association light-heavyweight boxing title in Bismarck, N.D. Hill knocked Emebe down early in the deciding round of the scheduled 12-rounder. Emebe got up quickly and backed Hill into a corner, but Hill reversed himself and put Emebe in the same corner, throwing combinations that Emebe failed to answer. Referee Roberto Ramirez of Puerto Rico then stopped the bout. (AP) Golf Lyle Beats Green in Playoff: Sandy Lyle, given second life when Ken Green three-putted the 72d hole, won the Greater Greensboro Open in North Carolina yesterday with a 10-foot birdie putt on the first playoff hole. The victory was Lyle's second on the PGA Tour this season and made him the first Scot in history to lead the American money-winning list. Lyle's fourth American triumph in three seasons was worth $180,000 from the total purse of $1 million and gave him a leading total of $408,021 for the season. Lyle, three shots clear of the field when the day's play started, was one shot back when he and Green went to the last hole of regulation play. (AP) Auto Racing Prost Takes Brazil Grand Prix: Alain Prost of France, driving a McLaren-Honda Turbo, won the Brazilian Formula One Grand Prix yesterday for a record fifth time in Rio de Janeiro. Prost completed the 60 laps of the 187-mile race in 1 hour 36 minutes 6.857 seconds. His average speed for the first race of the Formula One season was 117 miles an hour. It was the 29th career victory for the Frenchman, who has won more Grand Prix races than any other driver. Gerhard Berger of Austria finished second in a Ferrari Turbo in 1:36:16, and the defending world champion, Nelson Piquet, of Brazil was third. (AP)

title: Iraq Says Its Planes Hit Iranian Oil Refineries
description: Iraq said its warplanes raided two Iranian refineries today, but Iran said the bombs had hit residential areas, killing 10 civilians and wounding 50 others.

title: Sale Planned By Fremont
description: The Fremont General Corporation agreed to sell all of its property and casualty insurance operations to a management-led group for $82 million in cash, notes and stock warrants. Upon completion of the deal, Fremont General will remain a financial services concern with commercial and life insurance operations, a real estate finance unit and half ownership of a workers' compensation insurance firm. It is also awaiting regulatory approval to acquire the Malibu Savings and Loan Association.

title: Rumanians Choose Life in Hungary
description: A 37-year-old textile worker from Salonta said he fled Rumania because things were getting ''worse and worse.''

title: Shootings Leave Seven Dead In N. Carolina and California
description: A man apparently angry over a land dispute involving his former in-laws opened fire on mourners gathering for a funeral here today, killing three and wounding three, including his former wife, the authorities said.

title: Mecham Impeachment Trial Entering Final Phase Today
description: The last phase of Gov. Evan Mecham's impeachment trial begins Monday with final arguments on the charges of obstruction of justice and misuse of state funds.

title: Books of The Times; What Reagan Has Wrought, as Moynihan Sees It
description: Came the Revolution By Daniel Patrick Moynihan 344 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich

title: Many With AIDS Said to Live In Shelters in New York City
description: Despite a longstanding New York City policy to provide housing other than shelters for homeless AIDS patients, hundreds of people suffering with symptoms of AIDS are living in such shelters, according to the city's top health official and doctors and social workers in the shelters.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Has any pitcher come close to matching Bob Feller's feat of throwing a no-hitter on Opening Day?

title: Title Game Is a Neighborhood Affair
description: On the eve of college basketball's most prestigious game, the atmosphere here is charged with an excitement that has made fans a little crazy.

title: U.S. Envoy Is Reported Chased in Panama
description: A chaffeured car carrying the United States Ambassador, Arthur H. Davis, was chased a half-mile today by a Panamanian military vehicle that had turned on its sirens and flashers, an American Embassy spokesman said tonight. The spokesman, Terrence Kneebone, called the incident ''serious.''

title: Advertising; The Doctor's Office: Target Of Time Inc.
description: If nothing else, Christopher Whittle's bold and brazen move to stake out doctors' offices as a private turf for his advertiser clients has made the rest of the publishing industry aware of the potential of patient waiting rooms as a marketplace.

title: Gore Assails Dukakis Over Jackson
description: In his jet the other day, Senator Albert Gore Jr. pointed with a grin to a newspaper article in which Gov. Michael S. Dukakis refused to explain why he would make a better President than the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: Shevardnadze Flies to Kabul To Pursue an Afghan Peace
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, flew to Afghanistan today, saying that he planned to discuss what steps to take if the peace talks in Geneva fail, the Soviet press agency Tass reported tonight.

title: Police Watch Over Churchgoers After Los Angeles Gang Shooting
description: Police officers watched over Easter services today in the poor neighborhoods of south-central Los Angeles, trying to reassure churchgoers shocked by a street gang shooting on Friday that ranked among the city's worst.

title: Birgit Nilsson Master Class
description: Birgit Nilsson will conduct an open master class at the Manhattan School of Music on April 13, in the John C. Borden Auditorium. Tickets are $25; proceeds are to go to the Birgit Nilsson Scholarship Fund, established three years ago to help young voice students at the school. Tickets may be reserved by telephone (279-4200, from 1 to 8 P.M.,) or by sending a check to Nilsson Class, Manhattan School of Music, 120 Claremont Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10027. Information: 749-2802. The school entrance is at 122d Street and Broadway.

title: In Times Sq., Easter Prayers at Sunrise
description: Embraced by the stillness of New York City before dawn, a small group of worshipers made their way to a spot just off Times Square yesterday for an unusual Easter service.

title: Raising Minimum Wage Leads to Inflation
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Blame Workers For Stress on the Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 3, 1988: MONDAY Carolina Freight Oxford Industries Cummins Engine TUESDAY Ohio Mattress Weis Markets Travelers Corp WEDNESDAY American Water Works Phillips-Van Heusen Houston Industries Southwestern Energy Murphy Oil Corp THURSDAY General Pub Utilities Puget Sound Pwr & Lt Orange & Rockland Util Sun Co FRIDAY First Chicago Corp NY St Elec & Gas Flowers Indus Sterling Drug Mercantile Stores

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on March 3 discussed a New York State highway contract worth $57.6 million with a company under indictment on Federal charges of bid rigging. The Times reported that the office of Robert Abrams, the state Attorney General, had decided to reconsider its approval of the contract after learning of confidential provisions negotiated between the company and the State Transportation Department. The article quoted ''a senior aide to Mr. Abrams'' who said officials in the Attorney General's office were ''shocked by these secret protocols.''

title: 1916 Irish Rebellion: It Is Not Over Yet
description: In this troubled land, where Christianity, conflict and killing have long been inextricably linked, it somehow seems fitting that Catholic nationalists spend Easter morning celebrating the resurrection and Easter afternoon marking the insurrection.

title: Global-Market Notion Is Dispelled in Quarter
description: The first quarter of 1988, if nothing else, dispelled the popular notion that there is one synchronized, global market. ''It's a joke,'' said Maureen White, an international equity strategist at First Boston & Company.

title: House Panel Report Assails Cuts In U.S. Programs for Mentally Ill
description: The Government is spending billions of dollars a year on mental health services that often are fragmented, inappropriate, ineffective or desperately lacking, a House committee says in a report made public today.

title: Man Said to Have Set Fire to Woman's Bed
description: A Long Island man was arrested today and accused of setting fire to his girlfriend's bed while she was lying on it, the police said.

title: Advertising; History Magazines Add Vietnam, a Quarterly
description: Although neither Adam Landis nor Carl Gnam have ever been in the military, they are keenly interested in recent wars as history. They have been publishing magazines on the subject since 1984.

title: Illinois Project Gives Families a New Way To Aid Disabled Kin
description: Danny and Fay Moore have lived with anxiety since the births of their daughter and their son, both mentally retarded as a result of the genetic disorder Down's syndrome. The Moores shape their family life around providing special schooling and counseling for Stacey, 7 years old, and Aaron, 4, who are growing into adventurous, fun-loving children.

title: Abrams Predicts Sandinistas Will Violate Accord and Consolidate Power
description: Elliott Abrams, the combative custodian of American policy on Central America, expresses grave reservations about the new cease-fire in Nicaragua. He fears the Sandinistas will violate its terms and use it to consolidate their power.

title: Vernon W. Thomson Dies at 82; Was Governor and Congressman
description: Vernon W. Thomson, a former Governor of Wisconsin, member of Congress for 14 years and Federal Election Commission chairman, died Saturday at the George Washington University Hospital, a spokeswoman said. He was 82 years old.

title: Advertising; WPP Acquires Henley, British Marketing Firm
description: Undaunted by the commotion in the Colonies, Britain's WPP Group has bought the Henley Center, a London specialist in strategic marketing analysis. The purchase price could be as much as $34.9 million, depending on earnings until August 1992.

title: 9-Year-Old Pilot Sets Cross-Country Mark
description: A 9-year-old California boy landed his father's twin-engine plane in this Boston suburb Saturday, becoming the youngest pilot to complete a transcontinental journey.

title: I.B.M.'s Akers Got 18% Raise
description: The International Business Machines Corporation increased the pay of its chairman, John F. Akers, by 18 percent last year, to $840,896, according to a proxy statement released this week.

title: Metro Matters; Housing Agency Looks to Its Past For Its Future
description: Twenty years ago this week, New Yorkers witnessed how sheer willpower accomplished one of the most stunning flip-flops in legislative history.

title: New York Still Lags In Screening Its Contracts
description: Five years after New York City's Department of Investigation called for a computer system to screen for fraud and mismanagement the $5 billion in municipal contracts that are let each year , there is no such system.

title: Worlds of Wonder Loses Its Chairman
description: Donald D. Kingsborough, who founded Worlds of Wonder Inc., a toy company that went into bankruptcy proceedings after two years of fast growth, has left the company.

title: Orator of the IRT
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite Defects, Javits Center Becomes Boon to New York
description: After two years of management turmoil and harsh criticism from its exhibitors, the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center is coming of age as a troubled but powerful player in the New York City economy.

title: Democrats Insisting That Meese Quit
description: Congressional Democrats today continued to press for the resignation of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, even though an independent prosecutor has said that the evidence to date does not warrant an indictment.

title: Administration Backs Endangered Species Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Crises Weathered, San Francisco Opera Dares to Hope Anew
description: After a winter of painful crises, the San Francisco Opera, long regarded as second among American companies only to the Metropolitan Opera in prestige and grandeur, is facing the future with a new general director and a growing but cautious sense of optimism.

title: Tougher Antitrust Stance Expected
description: Enforcement of Federal antitrust laws is likely to become significantly more aggressive, particularly regarding mergers, no matter which party wins the White House in November, many lawyers and members of Congress believe.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the sanctions approved by the House and the Senate against the Toshiba Corporation misstated the duration of the penalty. If the bill becomes law, the Federal Government will not buy any Toshiba products for three years.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Review/Television; Charisma on Film In a Grant Profile
description: Dapper and debonair, romantic and yet a ''regular guy'' with a goofy sense of humor, on screen Cary Grant had everything, or at least enough to keep him a star of the first magnitude for some 30 years. Abundant proof is available in ''Cary Grant: The Leading Man,'' which is having its debut on Cinemax tonight at 8. The profile is part of a ''Crazy About the Movies'' series on the pay-cable service. This one provides a genuine touch of class.

title: INSIDE
description: It's Opening Day The baseball season gets under way today with nine games scheduled. The Mets visit the Montreal Expos. SportsMonday, pages C2, C3. 'Steve Canyon' Creator Dies Milton A. Caniff, the cartoonist who created the comic strips ''Terry and the Pirates'' and ''Steve Canyon,'' died in Manhattan. Page B10.

title: Oh, I Miss the Revolution
description: I have a pretty nice house. It's not that big, but it's bright and cheerful, with a small pool. My cars are pretty good, too: a Toyota and an Acura, and my wife even has a Mercedes. We have a lovely son, and the sun shines here almost every day. So far, we can pay our bills and life is all right, except for an occasional lawsuit. But there's something I miss so badly it cuts like a paper burn across my heart every night: It's the Revolution.

title: Bicycle Shifting Becomes Automatic
description: Learning to shift gears on a bicycle takes practice. Competitive cyclists develop a fluid movement over time, shifting as often as the terrain requires. Recreational bikers are apt to shift less, sometimes only when forced to. But a newly developed automatic transmission may change that.

title: Town's Marshal Is Accused Of Making Up Kidnap Story
description: A town marshal who said he had been kidnapped by burglars faked his highly publicized disappearance last week, a Mississippi Highway Patrol investigator said.

title: Japan Land Prices Soar
description: Land prices skyrocketed in Japan in 1987, the Government reported, with residential real estate rising 68.9 percent in Tokyo, nearly twice the previous high of 35.9 percent in 1973 and almost triple the 1986 increase of 23.8 percent. The National Land Agency, a Government office, released the 1987 statistics Thursday, the last day of the fiscal year in Japan.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., a retail insurance brokerage that also does consulting in risk management and human resource management, named Michael K. White chairman and chief executive.

title: Review/Books; Family Tree Nearly a Millennium Old
description: Ancestors By Frank Ching Illustrated. 672 pages. William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: Northeast Now Least Populated Area
description: The Northeast has become the least populated region in the United States, falling behind the West for the first time, the Census Bureau says.

title: Bid for Lilco: Serious Offer or Ploy?
description: The question of motive - whether the Long Island Power Authority would actually try to carry out its mandate to take over the Long Island Lighting Company and close the Shoreham nuclear power plant - has afflicted the public authority since its inception.

title: Kansas Transforms a Madhouse Into a Mansion
description: Their sense of purpose was strengthened by stressful times. Their willingness to adjust to unfamiliar positions was made necessary by an alarming attrition rate.

title: South Africa Divestitures
description: Four foreign companies, including the Newmont Mining Corporation, announced plans last week to pull out of South Africa.

title: Yanks Look for Stolen Bases
description: On the final day of spring training, all was quiet. The Yankees played their final game before the opener Tuesday and finished their best exhibition season in more than 25 years, and Billy Martin made some pronouncements. One of them was that Rickey Henderson will steal 100 bases this season, the other was his opening-day lineup.

title: Of Meese And Men
description: Eight years ago this month, in my first and last interview with Ronald Reagan, I asked the candidate where he stood on the status of Jerusalem. Some Carter people were talking about the internationalization of Israel's capital (a position Jesse Jackson holds to this day). Mr. Reagan's glance flicked to Ed Meese, the only aide with him. Mr. Meese almost imperceptibly shook his head.

title: Olympic Notebook; Boycott Weighed By African Nations
description: FOR now, the Seoul Olympics promise to bring more countries together than ever before, 161 of the 167 invited. Yet two developments in Britain are causing African nations grave concern and could lead to a boycott of the Games, similar to the one in 1976 by 22 nations, many of them African.

title: Martin Puts the Ball Squarely in the Hand of Rhoden
description: In the middle of spring, almost without warning, Billy Martin said it. And he said it with such firmness and certainty that it sounded like some kind of announcement, as if it should have been printed and mailed to every hitter in the American League.

title: Crown Jewel of a Retailing Empire
description: Behind the Art Deco facade on 59th Street and Lexington Avenue, there is a fantasy land that is at once a museum, a nightclub, an amusement park - and a department store.

title: London Journal; In Eye of Belfast's Storm: Optimism or Bravado?
description: Tom King is a hawk-faced, bespectacled man whose stocky body betrays his past as a schoolboy cricketer.

title:
SCOUTING REPORTS;
Routes to Top Rung Differ
description: LEAD: The game tonight between Oklahoma and Kansas is a classic confrontation between two teams who have reached the same step on the ladder by different routes. Oklahoma is a talented, well-balanced club, one that is overpowering defensively and offensively. Kansas, on the other hand, is a team featuring a superstar leading four good players.

title: Bridge
description: There were two surprises for the six student teams that arrived in Buffalo last month for the final of the 1987-88 Collegiate Championships. For most of the players it was a first encounter with bidding boxes, and they adapted happily to the idea of replacing a verbal announcement with a special colored card.

title: Changing Presidents
description: Long before the light at the end of the campaign tunnel comes into view, a group of national security pundits is trying to smooth the way for the transition from one Administration to the next.

title: SHULTZ, IN ISRAEL, ASKS AN EXCHANGE OF LAND FOR PEACE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that new negotiations between Israel and its Arab neighbors must be based on the formula of exchanging territory for peace found in United Nations Resolution 242. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel contends that Israel fulfilled the requirements of the resolution when it returned the Sinai peninsula to Egypt.

title: Baseball's Middle Age
description: The 1988 baseball season opens today and that means, among other things, an outbreak of lyrical prose about the rhythm of the seasons and the continuity of a game that evokes a sense of pastoral stability, even of the renewal of life itself. Baseball may be all that. But it is also a cultural eccentricity capable of surviving even its silliest mistakes. Durability is the key word, not continuity. Starting in the 60's, the sport has absorbed one revolutionary jolt after another, not least a relentless commercialism that made the franchise shifts of the Dodgers and Giants in the 50's seem quaint. The pace of change challenges even the most ardent fan's fidelity.

title: Barbs of a Polish Comedian Bring Cheers in Brooklyn
description: ''I'm going to talk, and you're going to listen,'' declared Jan Pietrzak as he took the stage at the crowded Brooklyn meeting hall.

title: Outcast Who Maimed Girl to Be on His Own Soon
description: Lawrence Singleton, who was convicted of raping a teen-ager and chopping off her arms, has lived a hermitlike existence in a trailer at the state prison here since he was paroled last spring and barred by town after town.

title: Islanders Fall to Bruins
description: They didn't go out in high style, but ended the season in a shower of popcorn in the losing locker room. Still, the loss in Boston left nobody on the Patrick Division's top team discouraged.

title: 6 Seized in Clash at Harlem Fire
description: Six people were arrested yesterday after a confrontation between bystanders and police officers outside a burning Harlem apartment tower, at Schomburg Plaza.

title: Market Place; Do Airline Stocks Look Too Good?
description: RARELY have all the fundamentals looked so good for the airline industry. Traffic is strong, fuel prices look stable and fares are going up by huge amounts in most markets.

title: Review/Television; 'Japan,' A Look In 4 Parts
description: ''Japan'' is a good-looking series: shrines, mountains, mists and energetic, courteous people. It's enough to make us want to visit, and it may be that ''Japan,'' which begins on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, wants us to feel that way. The principal underwriter for the four-part public television series is United Airlines, and each episode begins with a reminder about flying ''the friendly skies to Asia and the South Pacific.''

title: Women's N.C.A.A.; La. Tech Rallies to Win Title
description: Louisiana Tech stormed back from a 14-point halftime deficit today to score a last-second 56-54 victory over Auburn and capture the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I women's basketball championship.

title: Vanishing Oil Slick
description: A diesel oil spill disappeared today from the Ohio River as mysteriously as it had appeared, the Coast Guard said. A team conducted a land search along a 50-mile stretch of the river from Louisville to Madison, Ind., where the slick was spotted Saturday, said Lieut. Eric Mosher. He said the oil was light and tends to evaporate.

title: Some Powdered Drink Mixes May Be Tainted, F.D.A. Says
description: The Food and Drug Administration is warning consumers not to use Nutrien and Vitalite powdered drink mixes because they may be contaminated with Salmonella bacteria.

title: Bullets Defeat Nets, 105-103
description: The Washington Bullets have been playing in streaks since Wes Unseld took over as coach in January. Unfortunately, for the Nets and the Knicks, the Bullets are currently on a roll.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: The Oldest Consulate
description: When new budgetary restraints take effect in October, the State Department will have to close perhaps eight of its overseas consulates. State's administrators say that no decisions have been made yet, and that the severity of the cuts depends on exchange rates and inflation.

title: Review/Dance; 'Seagull' and Finale End U.S.-Soviet Festival
description: Maya Plisetskaya held a dove in her hands, faced the audience from the stage and released the small gray-white bird, which fluttered its wings impatiently as it headed toward the ceiling of an old vaudeville theater turned opera house.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Tuesday about the naming of Bernard Kalb to be host of the ''Global Rivals'' series next fall on the Pubic Broadcasting Service gave an incorrect title, supplied by Channel 13, for a participant, Prof. Seweryn Bialer of Columbia University. He is the Robert and Renee Belfer Professor of Social Sciences and International Relations at the university's School of International and Public Affairs.

title: Knick Receives A New Reaction
description: Mr. Bill. It's short for Bill Cartwright, the Knick center. And it's a nickname that fits easily into a newspaper headline.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Treasury financings will be limited to the bill market this week, and the regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills is set for today. The size of the auction is $12.8 billion, the same as a week ago.

title: Oakland Journal; Drug-Related Violence Erodes a Neighborhood
description: When Michael Burdick arrives for work at his automobile repair shop here, dirty drug syringes, spent bullets and empty cartridges often litter the driveway. He tries to sweep it before his first customers arrive.

title: U.S. Must Do More to End Cambodian Conflict
description: To the Editor:

title: Devils' Playoff Blight Ends
description: John MacLean scored his second goal of the game 2 minutes 21 seconds into overtime as the Devils defeated the Chicago Blackhawks, 4-3, tonight and advanced to the playoffs for the first time since the franchise moved to New Jersey six years ago. MacLean's first goal had tied the game at 3-3 with 8:03 left in regulation to set up the overtime.

title: Woman and Son Die In a Fire in Building
description: A woman was killed and her son injured yesterday morning when a fire began in a three-story apartment building in Brooklyn, the authorities said.

title: Innings
description: LEAD: Time flows in many ways, but two modes stand out both for their prominence in nature and their symbolic role in making our lives intelligible.

title: I.B.M. Offering Chips to Rivals Outside Japan
description: For more than two years the International Business Machines Corporation has secretly supplied some competitors with state-of-the-art computer chips, apparently seeking to stay ahead of Japanese microelectronics advances.

title: Critic's Notebook; How Men Shape History, and How History Shapes Men
description: After seeing ''A Walk in the Woods'' and reading ''The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers,'' I attended a performance of ''Julius Caesar.'' Lee Blessing's Broadway play concentrates United States-Soviet relations in a couple of good-guy negotiators, Paul Kennedy's history traces the destinies of nations to impersonal forces and Shakespeare delivers a momentous period through a clutch of world-class heroes. Their convergence naturally incites thoughts about the part individuals play in struggles for global power, and the approach of a summit meeting with the Russians gives the matter a certain topicality.

title: Jackson Success Brings Scrutiny Of Themes That Defy Rival Views
description: Day after day, in rhymes, metaphors and other oratorical flourishes that captivate his campaign audiences, the Rev. Jesse Jackson talks in general terms of fighting the menace of drugs, ending ''economic violence'' against the poor, improving health care and education, expanding jobs at home and markets abroad and bringing peace to the Middle East, Latin America and South Africa.

title: New and Ancient Music Planned for U.S. Spoleto
description: The 17-day Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S.C., scheduled to run from May 20 to June 5, is to include two modern multimedia works by Martha Clarke and Bob Telson, together with two older but less-performed operas. New chamber music is also planned, including pieces by Lowell Liebermann, Ken Frazelle and Leon Kirchner. A new piece for Spoleto's dance festival, composed by Kent Stowell, is scheduled as well.

title: As Others Hunt Eggs, Simon Looks for Votes
description: The quest for votes in this state's Democratic Presidential primary on Tuesday took Senator Paul Simon of Illinois to the bunny trail at a local park today.

title: Jackson Draws Crowds in Colorado On Eve of Showdown With Dukakis
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson preached politics and faith to thousands at Easter services today on the eve of precinct caucuses that place him and Michael S. Dukakis in a close race for the support of Colorado's Hispanic voters.

title: James F. Skinner, Chemistry Professor, 47
description: Prof. James F. Skinner, chairman of the Williams College chemistry department, died March 19 at his home in Williamstown, Mass., after a short illness. He was 47 years old. He was born in Saint John, New Brunswick, earned degrees at Williams and Yale University and was a research fellow at Oxford University before joining the Williams faculty in 1966.

title: No Headline
description: ''This is the time and the season to move decisively toward peace.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz. [ A1:6. ]

title: Fitness; Target Heart Rate: Is It Important, Or Overrated?
description: DISPLAYED on the walls of most health clubs are posters that depict the ''target'' heart rates that someone should achieve while exercising. People who exercise regularly soon learn to figure this rate: Subtract your age from 220, and calculate 85 percent of that value for the top of the zone and 65 percent for the bottom.

title:
On Your Own: Golf;
The Pros' Secrets: Follow at Your Own Risk
description: LEAD: GOLF is a game of secrets. Good players make it look so easy, they must know something that we don't know.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions of Business Day on Friday about an agreement between the General Electric Company and the Whirlpool Corporation misidentified the senior vice president in charge of G.E.'s appliance business. He is Roger W. Schipke.

title: New Rise In Interest Rates Seen
description: Interest rates, which have been inching higher during the last month, are almost certain to rise further, credit market analysts say.

title: Sports of The Times; The State Of Suspension
description: WHILE viewing tonight what has rarely failed to be delicious entertainment, the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's basketball final - this year, in case you've been locked in a closet, it's between the universities of Kansas and Oklahoma - one may sit back, or, as things heat up, move to the edge of his seat.

title: Praxis Founder Is Back After Board Room Fight
description: Dr. David H. Smith, fresh from a board room victory, is once again chief executive of the company he helped to found, Praxis Biologics Inc., based in Rochester.

title: Schell Reading Albers
description: The actor Maximilian Schell is to read from the poetry of Josef Albers on April 26 at 5:30 P.M. as part of a retrospective of the artist's work at the Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue and 89th Street. Tickets are $6 ($4 for students). ''Josef Albers: a Retrospective'' runs through May 29 and includes about 250 paintings, glass works, photographs, collages and other works. Information: 360-3503.

title: Former Pilot Says Waldheim Saved Him From Nazi Killers
description: A former British fighter pilot was quoted today as saying that Kurt Waldheim, now President of Austria, saved his life and those of other Allied prisoners during World War II by keeping them from Nazi executioners.

title: On an Easter In Jerusalem, Forlorn Rites
description: At first light of dawn, the Roman Catholic Patriarch of Jerusalem walked through the cobblestone streets of the Old City to the Church of the Holy Sepulcher to begin the Easter celebration.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; The Ad Man Who Mastered Market Segments
description: Long, long ago, in the Dark Ages of Demographics, there lived an ad man named Martin Puris. It was the early 1970's, and, to everyone else, ''market segments'' referred to disconnected brackets: women 18-35, household incomes over $25,000, black males who lived east of the Rockies.

title: Advertising; Children's ad Position Filled
description: Helen Boehm, a former City University of New York faculty member, is joining the Council of Better Business Bureaus as head of the Children's Advertising Unit. It is part of the National Advertising Division, the investigative arm of the ad industry's self-policing operation.

title: The Final Two, by the Numbers
description: Oklahoma FGM FGA Pct FTM FTA Pct Reb PF-D A Pts King 330 607 54.4 192 286 67.1 8.6 100-1 1.1 22.4 Grant 344 626 55.0 111 152 73.0 9.5 97-3 1.4 21.1 Blaylock 235 510 46.1 78 113 69.0 4.1 87-1 6.0 16.4 Grace 195 426 45.8 64 94 68.1 3.5 113-3 7.4 14.4 Sieger 141 309 45.6 42 62 67.7 4.9 119-3 3.4 10.6 Jones 53 119 44.5 28 37 75.7 1.8 39-0 1.5 6.3 Wiley 66 124 53.2 49 66 74.2 3.4 47-3 0.3 6.0 Mullins l48 112 42.9 21 32 65.6 1.4 68-1 1.2 3.8 Martin 51 111 46.9 30 37 81.1 2.7 72-1 0.5 3.7 Pollard 18 41 43.9 4 8 50.0 0.7 13-0 0.2 2.5 Bell 19 29 65.5 11 19 57.9 1.2 22-0 0.1 2.1 Skurcenski 3 10 30.0 3 4 75.0 0.4 3-0 0.4 0.6 Totals 1503 3024 49.7 638 917 69.6 42.8 781-16 22.2 103 .5 Opponents 1173 2580 45.5 597 851 70.2 43.4 787-26 13.9 80.9 Kansas FGM FGA Pct FTM FTA Pct Reb PF-D A Pts Manning 368 629 58.5 166 226 73.5 8.8 111-5 2.0 24.6 Newton 160 293 54.6 43 76 56.6 5.0 79-2 1.7 11.5 Pritchard 138 289 47.8 88 119 73.9 2.6 99-5 3.0 10.6 Marshall 45 90 50.0 9 16 56.3 4.0 24-0 1.4 8.8 Branch 38 78 48.7 41 59 69.5 6.1 34-2 0.9 8.4 Piper 62 117 53.0 43 61 70.5 3.7 76-3 1.7 5.1 Minor 71 168 42.3 16 25 64.0 1.4 46-1 1.9 4.8 Gueldner 45 107 42.1 32 47 68.1 2.0 55-1 1.8 3.9 Barry 31 63 49.2 52 63 82.5 1.4 49-0 2.0 3.4 Harris 31 70 44.3 19 30 63.3 2.6 30-0 0.8 3.1 Livingston 26 40 65.0 19 31 61.3 1.4 51-1 2.7 2.6 Maddox 27 51 52.9 8 17 47.1 1.5 27-0 0.3 2.5 Masucci 22 51 43.1 7 15 46.7 1.5 40-0 0.4 2.1 Mattox 1 4 25.0 0 1 0.0 0.8 0-0 0.0 0.3 Totals 1076 2079 51.8 553 799 69.2 35.5 747-20 17.6 75. 1 Opponents 882 2145 41.1 586 830 70.6 33.6 764-28 12.8 67.6$ X The Rosters Oklahoma No. Player Pos.
