title: New Obstacles Bog Down Nicaragua Peace Effort
description: Less than two weeks after contra guerrilla leaders agreed to a cease-fire with the Sandinista Government, new obstacles threatened to slow the Nicaraguan peace process.

title: Washington Enjoys a Slugfest
description: The Mets ended their best exhibition season today by outslugging the Baltimore Orioles, 10-7, at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium in a 24-hit game witnessed by a crowd consisting heavily of baseball-starved onetime New Yorkers.

title: Milton Caniff, 81, Creator of 'Steve Canyon,' Dies
description: Milton A. Caniff, the creator of the comic strips ''Terry and the Pirates'' and ''Steve Canyon,'' died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.

title: Fight Over WPP Defections Excites and Annoys Britain
description: The Sunday Times of London has dubbed it the ''Lord Geller Saga,'' while The Independent, the newest national newspaper in Britain, labeled the defecting advertising executives ''the gang of six.'' Madison Avenue's leading drama - the walkout last month by top executives from Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein and the suit filed against them by a unit of the agency's British owner, WPP Group - has attracted an attentive audience in London as well.

title: Deposed Panamanian President Opposes Further U.S. Sanctions
description: Eric Arturo Delvalle, the President deposed by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega five weeks ago, has said that new economic sanctions against Panama will only make it more difficult to oust the tenacious military strongman.

title: Advertising; Account
description: * Zantac by Glaxo, Hong Kong, to Barnum Communications for promotion of the ulcer treatment product.

title: The Ensemble Studio Gets a Country Home
description: Faced with strained budgets and the skittishness of contributors still reeling from the October Wall Street crisis, the Ensemble Studio Theater has bought a place in the country.

title: After 2 Months, Yonkers Lacks Housing Solution
description: Two months after agreement was reached on a plan to build low-income housing in Yonkers to satisfy a court desegregation order, the city is uncertain about the location, style and cost of the housing and is parting company with its Manhattan law firm.

title: Sooners Are Prepared to 'Steal' the Title
description: Whether it's called 12-Z or 12 Special, 50-Z or 200 Special, Oklahoma defenses all emphasize thievery.

title: Advertising; 'People Meter' Faulted On Counting Children
description: Steven Sternberg, a vice president who heads broadcast research at Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, thinks that the old diary method of counting how many 11-year-old and younger kids watch Saturday morning TV reported too high and that the new ''people meter'' system is reporting too low.

title: Developer Buys Marine Lab But Says He Wants to Save it
description: A developer has agreed to buy a marine laboratory in the Florida Keys from Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, and he says he plans to preserve it while building a resort there.

title: Advertising; Hill, Holliday Selected By United Jersey Banks
description: Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos of New York has been tapped to do advertising for United Jersey Banks, which has assets of more than $10 billion and 250 offices in New Jersey and Pennsylvania. The agency says the budget is about $7 million. The former agency was Trout & Reis.

title: Unlike '87, Gooden Will Open Season
description: The Mets followed the Yankees into town at full strength today to complete the baseball extravaganza billed in Canada as ''New York, New York,'' and to open their pursuit of the pennant that eluded them last year.

title: New Finding Disputes Theory on Earthquakes
description: A drilling project that was suspended after penetrating 11,420 feet into rock near the San Andreas Fault has confirmed a surprising discovery about stresses in the fault, undermining a long-held theory about earthquakes.

title: Tobacco Industry Assails Release of Smoking Data
description: The blanket release of previously confidential tobacco industry documents provoked industry protests at a civil trial in Federal District Court in Newark last week.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Michael S. Leeds is replacing his father, Gerard G. Leeds, as president and chief executive of CMP Publishing, Manhasset, L.I.

title: Holding Back on Construction Crime
description: In his State of the State address in January, New York's Governor Cuomo announced a $3.5 million strike force to prosecute corruption in the construction industry. Now, for inappropriate reasons, the Legislature appears ready to cripple this urgent initiative by cutting its funding in half.

title: Outdoors: Improving Your Casting
description: IN less than six weeks, bluefish will be moving against the beaches as far north as Cape Cod, making this a good time to begin getting your surf-fishing gear in order.

title: Neighborhood Networks
description: ''Networking'' is a yuppie term but not a yuppie invention. It has been a fact of life for decades in working-class neighborhoods, helping the young make the passage from school to work force. It explains why certain ethnic neighborhoods are populated by several generations of police officers, firefighters or members of the building trades.

title: CHINA POLICY SHIFT ON STUDY OVERSEAS
description: Chinese students in the United States have obtained a copy of a Chinese Government document confirming that Beijing has set new limits on the number of years students will be allowed to attend college abroad and has also established central control over who will be allowed to apply for foreign study.

title: Palestinian's Poem Unnerves Israelis
description: A poem by a leading Palestinian writer has set off a furor in Israel, touching on a primal fear shared by almost all Israelis.

title: Skinny Needles Help Ease Diagnosis
description: THE spot that showed up on the chest X-ray was the size of a quarter. Doctors thought it was lung cancer, but standard tests did not confirm the diagnosis.

title: They Were Wrong About Television
description: LEAD: Everyone knows that television is the most important - maybe the only important - factor in a Presidential campaign. The candidates know it; that's why they turn themselves into a collection of walking sound bites for the evening news.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, APRIL 5, 1988
description: COMPANIES Dart Group has expressed interest in F. W. Woolworth. The disclosure pushed Woolworth's stock up $8.875, to $54.125. Woolworth responded by adopting a ''poison pill,'' giving existing shareholders the right to buy additional shares at half price. The Dart Group in the last three years has bid unsuccessfully for Beatrice, May Department Stores, Jack Eckerd, Safeway, Federated Department Stores, Supermarkets General, Dayton Hudson and Stop and Shop. But they have often walked away with substantial profits on their investments. [ Page D1. ] Wall Street will have one of its biggest paydays ever as a result of the battle for control of Federated Department Stores. Investment banks and law firms expect to collect at least $200 million for their work on Campeau's $6.6 billion takeover. [ D1. ] Transco Energy will pass along to customers $675 million that it expects to spend settling contract disputes with natural gas producers. Transco is a major supplier of gas to the New York area, and gas bills are expected to rise about 2 percent in the area. In exchange for the permission to pass along the charges, Transco is accepting the Federal designation of open access transporter, the equivalent of a common carrier. [ D5. ] Irving Bank forecast higher earnings in an attempt to persuade stockholders that Bank of New York's $63-a-share offer is too low. Irving Bank forecast net income of $234 million, or $11.78 a share, based on its performance in the first two months of 1988. [ D2. ] The first step toward cloning I.B.M.'s PS/2 personal computers has been taken by two computer makers. Canon and a Taiwanese computer manufacturer will need other licenses to proceed. [ D6. ] Kansas City Southern has repurchased 11.3 percent of its stock from an investment group led by Howard Kaskel, a New York real estate developer. The company paid $60 a share, or $72 million, well above the market price of $49.75 yesterday. [ D5. ] MGM/UA Communications has received several inquiries about a possible takeover. [ D5. ] MARKETS Prices of Treasury notes and bonds tumbled by a point or more as bond traders reacted to Friday's unexpectedly strong employment figures by selling fixed-income securities. Much of the downward move occurred in overnight trading in Tokyo, the first market with a chance to react to the data. Traders said few retail customers showed much interest. [ D1. ] Stocks moved broadly lower with the cheer generated by the strong employment figures released Friday offset by fears of inflation caused by that strength. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 7.46 points, to 1,980.60. [ D10. ] The dollar finished mixed against foreign currencies after opening in Asia at a three-month low against the Japanese yen. Gold rose $1.85 an ounce in New York, to $455.85. [ D20. ] Prices of precious metals futures rose and soybean prices surged to four-year highs, fanning new fears of inflation. [ D20. ] INTERNATIONAL An appeals judge in India ordered Union Carbide to pay $195 million in immediate compensation for victims of the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster, apparently ruling that the company's liability had been adequately established without a trial. The ruling is certain to be appealed by Union Carbide to the Supreme Court of India and possibly to courts in the United States. Experts said the decision could speed negotiations to settle the case. [ D1. ] A proposal to require disclosure of foreign investment has proved as contentious as anything in the trade bill. And when the House and Senate conferees recessed last week, the disclosure amendment remained unresolved. [ D2. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Containing health-care costs took the upper hand over medical priorities in the Administration's refusal to authorize extra reimbursement for TPA, the anticlotting drug for heart attack survivors. But the battle continues. Business and Health. [ D2. ] Property-casualty insurance companies enjoyed rising profits in 1987, but analysts generally believe industry prospects for the next several years have turned uncertain. Market Place. [ D10. ]

title: PATTERNS
description: Men's Wear Sets a Pace The clothes horse is galloping these days through unfamiliar terrain: the men's department.

title: India Judge Tells Carbide To Pay Relief
description: An Indian appeals judge today ordered the Union Carbide Corporation to pay $195 million in immediate compensation for victims of the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster, apparently ruling that the company's liability had been adequately established without a trial.

title: Regal Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bonds Tumble on Strong Jobs Data
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds tumbled by a point or more yesterday as bond traders reacted to last Friday's unexpectedly strong employment figures by selling fixed-income securities.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The poem returns us to the true demons. It speaks truth; poems do not lie.'' - Haim Guri, the Israeli writer, on a new poem by Mahmoud Darwish,a Palestinian. [ A8:5. ]

title: Reichhold Executive Named to 2 Top Jobs
description: Reichhold Chemicals Inc., which was purchased last year by Dainippon Ink and Chemicals Inc., announced yesterday that Thomas R. Mitchell had been named president and chief executive.

title: Laserland Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sooners Confident Until Last Second
description: Before the tip, Oklahoma was certain it was the better team. The records said so. Oklahoma had already beaten Kansas twice this season, and with the Sooners' hurry-up, knock-'em-down style, time was on their side.

title: Triangle Home Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; Berenter, Greenhouse Chosen By Paddington
description: Berenter, Greenhouse & Webster has been tapped by the Paddington Corporation of Fort Lee, N.J., to handle the advertising for Baileys Irish Cream liqueur, which has a budget of about $8 million.

title: AEL Industries reports earnings for 13wks to Feb 26
Pan Atlantic Re reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment losses of $9,000 for the quarter and $849,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After realized investment losses of $13,000 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $1,047,000 for the year; the year also included a tax credit of $919,000.

title: 17 Stormy Months
description: Nov. 4, 1986: Evan Mecham is elected Arizona's first Republican Governor since 1974, succeeding Bruce Babbitt. Jan. 5, 1987: Mr. Mecham is sworn in as Arizona's 17th Governor and rescinds Mr. Babbitt's decision to make Dr. Martin Luther King's birthday a state holiday. July 6: Mecham opponents open drive for a recall election. Oct. 21: The local press reports that the State Attorney General is looking into the Governor's failure to disclose a $350,000 loan he received before his election. Jan. 8, 1988: Mr. Mecham is indicted by state grand jury on six felony counts, including perjury, fraud and concealing the loan. Jan. 20: A committee of the Arizona House of Representatives opens impeachment hearings. Jan. 25: State officials certify more than 300,000 signatures on recall petitions. Mr. Mecham is given five days to resign or run in a recall election. Jan. 30: Mr. Mecham says he will not resign and will run in the recall election on May 17. Feb. 5: House votes to impeach. Secretary of State Rose Mofford becomes Acting Governor. March 2: Mr. Mecham's former security chief testifies that he told Mr. Mecham he considered a reported death threat against a former aide who became a grand jury witness a potential felony. March 8: The state's top police official, Col. Ralph Milstead, testifies that Mr. Mecham ordered him not to cooperate in the investigation of the purported death threat. March 16: Mr. Mecham takes the stand in his own defense, starting with a denial of assertions that he had sold state jobs to successful fund-raisers. March 18: Six candidates make the deadline for filing petitions to oppose Mr. Mecham in the recall election. March 30: The Senate drops the strongest of three impeachment issues: the cover-up of the $350,000 campaign loan. April 4: Senate convicts Mr. Mecham on the two other counts and removes him from office.

title: Mozambican in Nicaragua
description: The leaders of Nicaragua and Mozambique, whose Governments are besieged by guerrillas, met here today.The Mozambican President, Joaquim Chissano, arrived for a four-day visit and was welcomed at the airport by his Nicaraguan counterpart, Daniel Ortega Saavedra. Before arriving here, Mr. Chissano visited Cuba and Argentina. He is to return home Thursday.

title: Opening to Cheers And Echoes of Past
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers and the San Francisco Giants, who 11 days short of 30 years ago faced each other in the first major league baseball game played in California, opened the 1988 season today at Dodger Stadium amid appropriate festivities before a sellout crowd of 50,813.

title: Moore McCormack Talks to Suitors
description: Moore McCormack Resources Inc., the cement maker that has been trying to elude a takeover attempt by its rival, Southdown Inc., said it had been talking with potential friendly suitors. It said its board is scheduled to meet Tuesday to consider Southdown's most recent sweetened offer, plus any other proposals.

title: A News Dispute Opens the Trial Of Ferraro's Son
description: The drug trial of John A. Zaccaro Jr. began here today with a dispute over reporters' access to jury selection.

title: Miltope Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest year included an aggregate charge of about $2.5 million to recognize continuing cost over-runs and anticipated future losses, and provisions for reserves of about $2.4 million in the fourth quarter for obsolete and slow-moving inventories. The company also said the latest year was negatively impacted by design and development costs of about $1 million associated with its decision to bid as a prime contractor on a significant multi-year defense contract and the expenditure of about $1 million of deferred costs in the fourth quarter to discontinue manufacturing multi-layer chip capacitors.

title: Trial on Cuomo's Law Fees Starts With Stormy Moves
description: After eight years of maneuvering, a trial involving Governor Cuomo and a dispute over more than $4 million in law fees began yesterday on a stormy note in Brooklyn. The attorney for the two lawyers opposing Mr. Cuomo withdrew abruptly, there were charges that procedures were being violated and opposing lawyers quarreled over who was delaying the trial.

title: Dyncorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $2,926,000 and $6,305,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary charges of $990,000 for the quarter and $4,500 for the year from fines and other costs associated with antitrust matters of the company's Dynalectric Co. unit. c-Net income d-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2,805,000 for the quarter and $5,006,000 for the year. The company said the loss in the latest quarter and the decline in the full- year results were mainly due to the company's restructuring and expenses associated with its leveraged buyout.

title: Article 626188 -- No Title
description: The 11-week battle for control of Federated Department Stores Inc. will produce one of the biggest paydays Wall Street has ever seen. Investment banks and law firms expect to collect at least $200 million.

title: U.S. Moves to Ban Nicaraguan Coffee
description: While the Nicaraguan Government and the contras are negotiating a peace settlement, the Reagan Administration is considering ways to tighten the trade embargo that it imposed on Nicaragua three years ago, Administration and Congressional officials say.

title: Computer Power reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Alpine Journal; Small-Town Newspaper For Wide-Ranging Beat
description: Like most small-town newspaper editors, Bob Dillard has to worry about minutiae of rural life ranging from ribbon cuttings to soporific chamber of commerce meetings.

title: Salem Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $305,000 for the quarter and $395,000 for the year. c-Net loss and included a $1.1 million writedown of assets for the quarter and year. The latest periods' nets from operations included gains from the termination of pension plans of $4,005,000 for the quarter and $4,950,000 for the year.

title: Jesse Gray, 64, Leader Of Harlem Rent Strikes
description: Jesse Gray, a former New York State Assemblyman and a leader of rent strikes in Harlem in the 1960's, died Jan. 2 at the Beth Abraham Home in the Bronx, where he had been in a coma for several years. He was 64 years old.

title: Japan Studies Beef Dispute
description: Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita said Japan would decide its position on the beef and citrus dispute with the United States by May 4, a report by the Kyodo News Service said today.

title: Our Towns; Nimby Views On People With AIDS
description: With Easter on their minds, residents and leaders of this suburb gathered Good Friday to stop the state from moving 120 AIDS patients to a nursing home here. Children on vacation protested, too. Carin Olson, 8 years old, handed out fliers titled ''Keep AIDS Out of Wanaque.'' Her father, Ed, a carpenter, was up all night making signs: ''Don't Bring the City to the Suburbs'' ''We Need State Aid, Not AIDS From the State.''

title: Oxoco Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $3,887,405, a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $9,020,565 and a $98,657,162 gain from the early retirement of debt.

title: Afghan Talks Are Strain to All
description: As the deadlocked Afghan peace talks enter their fifth week here, the negotiators show signs of strain and are expressing doubts about the outcome.

title: Venezuelan's Japan Trip
description: Venezuela's President, Jaime Lusinchi, is going to Japan in search of fresh credits and investment. Mr. Lusinchi's trip is the first official visit ever to Japan by a Venezuelan president. He will also go to Indonesia. The President, in meetings with Japanese officials on Tuesday, will seek more than $400 million in fresh credit and discuss further trade and investment increases.

title: Electrosound Group reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a $139,000 loss from the reversal of tax loss carryforwards for the quarter and a tax credit of $113,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-Includes a $13,000 loss from the reversal of tax loss carryforwards for the quarter and a tax credit of $258,000 for the 9 months. The company said the latest quarter results include a $226,000 loss representing its pro-rata share of pro-rata start-up expenses of Memory-Tech, a 40 percent-owned joint venture with Mitsubishi Corp.

title: New I.B.M. PC May Be Cloned
description: Two Asian computer makers have taken the first legal steps toward cloning the International Business Machines Corporation's new PS/2 personal computers.

title: Malling Over The Past
description: The Campeau Corporation of Canada, having just swallowed Federated Department Stores Inc., has agreed with the Edward J. DeBartolo Company to spread a new rash of shopping malls across an American countryside that's already in danger of being paved over.

title: Eyeless in Gaza and the West Bank
description: Claiming the need to maintain ''public safety and public order,'' Israel has closed down for six months the Arab-owned Palestine News Service. This follows wider closures last week: the entire West Bank and Gaza were sealed from press scrutiny for three days, in the apparent belief that a 15-week uprising has been staged principally for the benefit of reporters and cameras. The theory is dubious and the remedy ominous.

title: Italy's Socialists Are Tough in Coalition Talks
description: ''We have been uncovering our cards slowly, one at a time, and our whole hand will not be showing until all the bets are on the table,'' said a senior strategist for the Socialist Party, likening Italy's latest political crisis to a poker game with very high stakes.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Another Tax Deduction
description: The BAC, or baby action committee, may be joining the PAC, the political action committee, in Washington's array of tax-deductible corporate philanthropy organizations.

title: Johnstown-Consolidated Realty Trust reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,375,000 on sale of Ginnie Maes.

title: Transco Energy Customers To Get Settlement Charges
description: The Transco Energy Company, the major supplier of natural gas to the New York area, announced yesterday that it would be allowed to pass along to customers $675 million, or three-quarters of what it expects to spend in settling contract disputes with natural gas producers.

title: Wisconsin Picks Delegates Today
description: Today's Wisconsin primary, with 81 Democratic delegates at stake, is an apparently tight contest between Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, with Senator Al Gore Jr. of Tennessee behind them. It pits not only the candidates who lead in delegates, but also offers voters choices among very different styles of leadership and very different campaign themes. Page B8.

title: Takeover Talk At MGM/UA
description: MGM/UA Communications Inc., the film maker controlled by the financier Kirk Kerkorian, has received several inquiries about being acquired, the company said today. It said a special committee of directors would be created to study offers. The announcement sent

title: First Medical Devices reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Books of The Times; Fable of Man as a River-Borne Creator-Destroyer
description: The Day of Creation By J. G. Ballard 254 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: Calton Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The company said it realized $4 million of revenue from the sale of land in the latest quarter. There were no land sales in the first quarter of the prior year.

title: Medicare Fee Revision For Doctors Is Proposed
description: A congressional commission recommended today that Medicare payments to physicians be based on a fee schedule that reflected the ''relative value'' of various specialties and medical procedures.

title: A BROOKLYN RAPIST GETS 18-YEAR TERM
description: A 27-year-old Brooklyn man, known as the ''Spiderman Rapist,'' was sentenced to 18 years to life in prison yesterday for a series of rapes, robberies and burglaries in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Mailers and The Times Agree on a 6-Year Pact
description: The New York Times and leaders of its mailers' union have tentatively agreed on a six-year contract that includes a lifetime job guarantee for current employees, union officials said yesterday.

title: Silver State Mining Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bendel's: Seeking a New Image for a Fashion Icon
description: Henri Bendel isn't what it used to be. Since the Limited bought the temple of high fashion at 10 West 57th Street in October 1985, the look of the store, the clothes it carries and the customer who shops there have all changed.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Paris Journal; Iranian's House is Chilly and His Exile Feels Icy
description: Sitting on an oversized sofa inside a dark, austere house he half-jokingly calls ''the ice palace,'' Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, once President of Iran and now a leading opponent of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, can only dream of better days.

title: Mesa Authorizes Buyback of Units
description: Mesa Limited Partnership said its general partner, T. Boone Pickens, had authorized the natural gas partnership to buy back up to $100 million worth of Mesa's 69.6 million outstanding common units.

title: Irving Seeks to Show Offer Is Not Sufficient
description: The Irving Bank Corporation, which is fending off an unwanted takeover bid from the Bank of New York Company, issued an earnings forecast yesterday for 1988 that was intended to persuade its shareholders that the Bank of New York's $63-a-share bid is too low.

title: Continental Air
description: Continental Airlines, a unit of the Texas Air Corporation, said it would freeze fares between Seattle and Tokyo for five years if it were granted authority to fly that route and were prohibited by the Japanese Government from reducing fares. The Allegis Corporation's United Airlines now flies the route. The AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, is also seeking the route and has also said it would not raise fares.

title: Bridge
description: The vast majority of duplicate players throughout North America do their playing largely or entirely in small local clubs rather than in tournaments. In the past four years the American Contract Bridge League has recognized this obvious fact by naming the most successful club player in various categories.

title: Simon, Head High, Refusing to Quit
description: It was too beautiful a day to be depressed. The air had the balm of June in it, the sky shone travel-poster blue and Paul Simon refused to hang his head like a loser.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the stock markets misstated the performance of the Dow Jones industrial average in the first quarter of 1988. The average gained 49.23 points, or 2.5 percent.

title: Sports People; Woes for Krzyzewski
description: When Coach Mike Krzyzewski of Duke walked off the court at Kemper Arena in Kansas City, Mo., on Saturday after a sobering 66-59 semifinal-round loss to Kansas that eliminated the Blue Devils from the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, he got some more bad news.

title: Ply-Gem Stake
description: Esfinco Inc., a private investment company based in Madrid, has bought a 6.1 percent stake in Ply-Gem Industries for $7.6 million and said it might seek a seat on the company's board. Ply-Gem is a building materials concern based in New York. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Esfinco said it had bought its stake for an average price of $11.67. Ply-Gem's stock rose 62.5 cents a share today, to $14.50, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: A Plan to Ease Japan Mergers
description: An advisory panel for Japan's Justice Ministry will propose simplified procedures to speed approval of corporate mergers and acquisitions, a ministry official said today.

title: William Sweeney, 89, Ex-Research Director
description: Dr. William J. Sweeney, a chemical engineer who retired as corporate research director of the Standard Oil Company (N.J.) in 1963 after 34 years with the concern, which is now the Exxon Corporation, died Wednesday at a nursing home in North Andover, Mass. He was 89 years old and lived in Summit, N.J.

title: Resorts Rejects Griffin's Offer
description: Directors of Resorts International Inc. spurned a revised takeover offer by the entertainer Merv Griffin. But they also formed a special committee to talk with Mr. Griffin to determine ''whether an acceptable offer would be made.'' Meanwhile, Resorts' chairman, Donald J. Trump, who holds 88 percent of the company's voting power, also renewed his pledge not to sell his stock to Mr. Griffin.

title: Amfac to Sell Lamb-Weston
description: Amfac Inc. said it had agreed to sell its Lamb-Weston potato products processing division to a joint venture of Conagra Inc. and Golden Valley Microwave Foods Inc. for about $276 million. Lamb-Weston, based in Portland, Ore., had 1987 revenues of $409 million.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * A.L. Laboratories, Inc., Fort Lee, N.J., which makes pharmaceuticals, animal health products and nutritional beverages, appointed Charles A. Baker to the newly created post of executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Philip Crosby Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MBS Textbook Exchange reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Wisconsin Chooses Delegates Today
description: In the most dramatic showdown yet in this year's Democratic Presidential campaign, Michael S. Dukakis and the Rev. Jesse Jackson meet Tuesday in a contest for Wisconsin's 81 delegates that offers voters a choice between two starkly different styles of leadership.

title: Belzbergs Pay $400,000 Fine
description: A holding company controlled by the Belzberg family of Canada has agreed to pay a $400,000 fine to settle a lawsuit charging that its 1986 purchase of stock in the Ashland Oil Company violated Federal law. The settlement between the

title: Pfister Sale May Bring Chairman $62 Million
description: Peter S. Gold owes his fortune to a chance meeting at a trade show 32 years ago. While working as a shower door salesman, Mr. Gold met a top executive of Price Pfister Inc., a plumbing fixture company he eventually acquired with two colleagues.

title: INSIDE
description: Tests Check Talent for Life To remedy the defiencies of standard I.Q. tests, researchers are developing ways to measure psychological factors that lead to success in everyday life. Science Times, page C1. Another Anti-Smoking Bill Legislation to curb smoking in New York State was introduced into the Senate with the support of Republican leaders, making some kind of a ban on smoking in public places likely to become law this year. Page B2. Unhappy Home for the Poor A motel in Mamaroneck, N.Y., has become a makeshift way station for Westchester's homeless population, stigmatizing them and frightening community residents. Page B1.

title: Phillips-Van Heusen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss of $227,000 for the quarter and a gain of $8,691,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations; after LIFO charges of $1,315,000 for the quarter and $4,973,000 for the year, and the quarter included a provision of $2.6 million for restructuring activities. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $633,000 for the quarter and $2,923,000 for the year; included LIFO credits of $2,050,000 for the quarter and $2,071,000 for the year; the year also included a gain of $5,879,000 from the settlement of certain pension plans. The latest fourth quarter and year included the results of G.H. Bass & Co. from its date of purchase, Aug. 21, 1987. The latest fourth quarter's share earnings were not given because of preferred dividend requirements.

title: Islanders Wary of the Devils' Emotion
description: The Islanders are not as exuberant and youthful a team as the Devils, their first-round playoff opponents, but they are young enough to be learning about themselves. The latest lesson was provided by the Devils on Saturday afternoon.

title: By Design; Grim Days for the Grand Old Brolly
description: Like many another elegant fashion flourish that was once de rigueur - say, short white cotton gloves for summer - the long-stemmed umbrella is fast becoming an anachronism. As handsome as an umbrella can be, especially if it has a swanlike handle and a thin, silky skin, the fold-up, tuck-'em-away version has it beat by far.

title: Dart Shows Interest in Woolworth
description: In the latest chapter of its three-year series of bids for major retail chains, the Dart Group Corporation has expressed interest in the F. W. Woolworth Company.

title: VMS Mortgage Investors LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hong Kong Helps U.S. In Drug-Money Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: Rise Technology reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Dairy Mart Convenience Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Parisian Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Jackson Urges Noriega to Quit; Letters Traded
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, again injecting himself into an international conflict, made today what he described as a ''very strong public appeal'' for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama to resign.

title: Frederick's of Hollywood reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
Teeco Properties reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The share earnings are in units. The results of operations between the two years are not comparable since the partnership's principle objective is to sell or otherwise dispose of its assets and distribute the proceeds to its unit holders.

title: Press Secretary for Jackson Now Consultant in Campaign
description: Elizabeth Colton resigned today as the Rev. Jesse Jackson's campaign press secretary.

title: Arizona's Senate Ousts Governor, Voting Him Guilty of Misconduct
description: The Arizona Senate today convicted Evan Mecham of two charges of misconduct, removing him from office, in the first impeachment trial of a governor in almost 60 years.

title: Topics of The Times; Dear Suzy,
description: I swore, really swore, that I was going to stay out of this. I wasn't going to join the Gannett Chain, The Washington Post, ABC News, Newsday, CNN, Good Morning America, USA Today, The Wall Street Journal, NBC's Live at Five and Heaven knows how many other people who are talking about The Problem. The only thing is, I can't help it. The Problem, as I understand it, is that you, Suzy, a ''star . . . the best and the brightest'' of gossip columnists (only quoting you, Suze), and James Revson, ''a jerk . . . a know nothing . . . a liar . . . malicious . . . sneaky, ugly-mean,'' are on the outs. ''Rat Revson'' (still quoting, Suze), a newcomer to the chat biz, said that in describing a party, you named some guests who weren't there at all. Then he said he'd like to have a job like yours because working from press releases sure beats pounding the parquet. You, able to describe yourself as a ''Mount Rushmore'' among journalists, said, in effect, lots of luck.

title: On the Trailing Edge
description: APRIL Fool's Day has passed, and with it the first anniversaries of Apple's Macintosh II, I.B.M.'s PS/2 family of computers and the OS/2 operating system. Soon, perhaps as early as next week, there will be an announcement of a second generation of PS/2 machines from I.B.M. These machines and the new operating system represent the cutting edge of personal computer technology.

title: Designatronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Bearing Maker Files Trade Petition
description: The Torrington Company has filed petitions with the Federal Government charging that foreign manufacturers are selling antifriction bearings in the United States at below market prices and hurting domestic manufacturers.

title: Manning Lifts His Whole Family to No. 1 Status
description: The parents were about 10 feet from the basket, on the right side of the foul lane. Their son, supported by a ladder and helped by a pair of scissors, was cutting down the remaining net to celebrate a national championship.

title: Iran Says Iraqi Missile Killed 15 in Holy City
description: Fifteen civilians were killed when an Iraqi missile hit the Iranian holy city of Qum early today, according to the Iranian news agency.

title: Record Inflation in Peru
description: Peru registered a record monthly inflation rate of 22.6 percent in March, but Economy Minister Gustavo Saberbein predicted the rate would drop in coming months. The National Statistics Institute said the inflation rate was up from 11.8 percent in February and stood at 180 percent for the latest 12 months. Mr. Saberbein said the March figure was caused by rising fuel prices and utility charges, together with increased sales taxes.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; CBS Is Ordered to Pay $3 Million Libel Award
description: The Supreme Court today let stand a $3,050,000 libel award against CBS and an anchor at its Chicago television station for a 1981 broadcast found by lower Federal courts to contain deliberate falsehoods about a tobacco company's advertising.

title: Amerihealth Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $247,000 from reversal of tax loss carryforwards. c-Net income and after tax credits of $170,000 and $321,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a gain of $190,000 from termination of a pension plan for both the quarter and year. Latest fourth quarter results include a $223,000 writeoff of deferred development costs associated with the termination of a purchase agreement with Hospital Corp. of America for purchase of a hospital in Hunington, W. Va., and a $74,000 writeoff of certain deferred costs relating to terminated financing activities. The company said share earnings for the prior year and for the first 9 months of 1987 reflect preferred dividend requirements paid on its series B preferred stock.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-12 First steps for a Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan appear to have been taken, officials said. Intelligence reports showed the Soviet Union was moving some units to make them less vulnerable to attack if other forces leave. A1 Frustrations over an Afghan peace are straining negotiators in Geneva. A peace treaty is almost ready to sign, but talks are stalled over a U.S.-Soviet dispute on continued military aid to the combatants. A8 Drug trafficking by Panama's leader was ignored by the Reagan Administration in 1986 because it believed Gen. Manuel Noriega was supporting the Nicaraguan rebels, a former State Department official told a Senate hearing. A1 Panama rejected a U.S. complaint that a police vehicle had tried to stop a car carrying the United States Ambassador to Panama, Arthur Davis. Panama said the police were trying to protect him from 3 cars of men with guns. A6 New trade restrictions on Nicaragua are being considered by the Reagan Administration to tighten an embargo it imposed in May 1985. One product, Nicaraguan coffee, still enters the U.S. legally through third countries. A6 The Dalai Lama could live in Tibet if he abandons calls for Tibetan independence, China said. Beijing had previously invited the spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism to return from exile but said he must live in Beijing. A1 Mike Mansfield is back in Tokyo at his post as Ambassador to Japan after 4 months away for surgery. Mr. Mansfield, 85, has served longer than any U.S. envoy there, but this may be his last year after 11 years on the job. A3 Secretary of State George Shultz did not get a positive response from Israeli leaders after pressing his proposal for Arab-Israeli peace in talks with them. Violence in the occupied territories continued. A8 A poem urging Israelis to ''get out'' has set off a furor in Israel, where the poet, Mahmoud Darwish, was regarded as a moderate Palestinian. The poem has raised doubts that Palestinians will settle only for their own homeland. A8 Union Carbide must pay $195 million in immediate compensation to the victims of the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster, an Indian appeals judge ordered. The company is expected to appeal the ruling. D1 Somalia and Ethiopia resume relations A3 Paris Journal: Iranian's house is chilly and his exile feels icy A4 National A14-17, B7-8 A Justice Department nominee with-drew from consideration. James Knapp had been Attorney General Edwin Meese's choice to head the criminal division. The choice for Deputy Attorney General also indicated reluctance to accept. A1 Gov. Evan Mecham was convicted by the Arizona Senate in the first impeachment trial of a governor in almost 60 years. The vote, 21-9, ended more than a year of controversy. A1 An espionage conviction was upheld by a Federal apeals court in the case of a former intellignce analyst who gave pictures of a Soviet ship to a magazine. The case pits protection of national security against freedom of speech. A1 Traffic in California's urban areas is so congested that the economic prosperity of the state is threatened, according to a study, which said that long commuting times have reduced worker productivity. A14 New tests of practical intelligence are being devised to measure psychological factors that lead to success in everyday life. They complement I.Q. tests, which remain excellent predictors of academic performance. C1 Smalltown beacon in vast reaches of West Texas A14 Zaccaro drug trial opens A14 High court upholds $3 million CBS libel award A17 Politics A1, B7-8 Many middle class blacks in Queens, whose votes are important to the Demoratic Party, support Jesse Jackson but fear the party will work to deny him the Democratic Presidential nomination. A1 Wisconsin's Democratic Primary has contrasted the styles of Jesse Jackson and Michael Dukakis. Mr. Jackson has drawn large, enthusiastic crowds. But Mr. Dukakis led in the final pols. B8 Simon head high as trail's end seems to near B8 Washington Talk A16 Moynihan wants U.S. to develop a floating train Regional B1-6 Changes in the Board of Estimate in New York City will be suspended, pending a ruling by the Supreme Court on the constitutionality of the board. The board was challenged on the way votes were allocated to members. A1 A Westchester motel housing homeless has aroused community fears after drug arrests there. Moreover, the motel's residents say thereputation it gained as the ''crack motel'' after the arrests stigmatizes them. B1 Expansion of health care services in New York State is needed to correct shortages but even if it can be achieved, some sick people may still be without proper care, health experts warn. B1 Governor Cuomo's claim to fees of more than $4 million is being disputed in a trial that began in Brooklyn amid quarrels and charges that procedures were violated after years of maneuvering. B2 A chief witness modified testimony about how Representative Mario Biaggi obtained stock in the Wedtech Corporation. The witness, Mario Mareno, also described Wedtech's unsuccessful attempts to sell arms to Iran. B3 Troubled Paterson schools face budget defeat B1 State anti-smoking bill gains support in Albany B2 Green names deputy B3 A new spot for Mama Leone's B3

title: Q&A
description: Q.What happens to records over time? Is there some component of the LP that deteriorates, even with proper storage?

title: Russians Have Had Income Taxes Since the Czars; Not Meant to Equalize
description: To the Editor:

title: Worldcorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $4,357,000 for the quarter and a loss of $13,726,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,820,000 for the quarter and $85,519,000 for the year. There were no share earnings in the year-ago quarter after preferred stock dividends.

title: Market Place; Analysts Wary On Insurer Stocks
description: ALTHOUGH most property-casualty insurance companies enjoyed rising profits in 1987, Wall Street analysts generally believe that industry prospects for the next several years have turned uncertain.

title: For Jackson Voters in Queens, Pride and a Bit of Trepidation
description: Henry Smith, a retired postal worker, is very proud of Jesse Jackson's race for President. But he is also sure the powers that be are prepared to steal the nomination from him.

title: Ports of Call Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Business and Health; Cost Cutters Gain In TPA Debate
description: THE Reagan Administration's refusal to authorize extra reimbursement for TPA, the new genetically engineered anticlotting drug for elderly heart attack survivors, is a powerful salvo in a long-running conflict between containing rising health care costs and providing the best possible medical care.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's approval of a treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces misidentified Senator Larry Pressler's home state. He is from South Dakota.

title: A Warning From Moscow
description: The Soviet Union has suddenly made a steely new move in its brilliantly executed plan to salvage political power from its military defeat in Afghanistan. The target is Pakistan and the threat is that country's political dismemberment.

title: Medical Imaging Centers of America reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Revenue represents revenue under management, but the total revenue was $5,995,396 for 1987 and $2,262,854 for 1986.

title: Sports People; Orioles in Accord
description: Edward Bennett Williams, the owner of the Baltimore Orioles, said yesterday that his team and the Maryland Stadium Authority have tentatively agreed to a 15-year lease on a new stadium for which the issuance of revenue bonds has been authorized by state voters.

title: New Scales of Intelligence Rank Talent for Living
description: IN an effort to make up for some of the glaring limitations of I.Q. tests, researchers have begun to develop new ways to measure the kinds of emotional factors and psychological attitudes that lead to success in everyday life.

title: Shelter Components reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Software for Oldtimers
description: DIEHARD fans of CP/M, the operating system of the older generation of Kaypro, Osborne and other computers, will like the spring catalogue from Spite Software. Although Spite is increasingly switching over to MS-DOS, the operating system of the I.B.M. PC line and clones, it still carries many products of interest to CP/M users.

title: Sierra Spring Water reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Batus May Raise Bid for Farmers
description: Batus Inc. told stockholders of Farmers Group Inc. that it would consider raising its bid of $63 a share for the insurer in a ''friendly transaction supported by the board of Farmers Group.'' But the Los Angeles company has resisted takeover offers by Batus, the American subsidiary of the London-based B.A.T. Industries.

title: Soviet and U.S. Scientists Join in Quest to Select Sites for Mars Landing
description: WITH the Soviet Union poised for a major drive to explore Mars, scientists are trying to identify the most rewarding places to visit on the red planet. In an expanding experiment in cooperation, Americans are joining Russians for comprehensive study of the many possible sites where spacecraft could land on Mars, beginning in 1994.

title: Olympic Broadcasting reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Intercontinental Life Insurance Co reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a capital loss of $63,000. c-Includes a capital gain of $994,000. The company said the increased revenue and earnings reflect the acquisition of Standard Life Insurance Co., of Jackson, Miss., in November 1986.

title: Blasius Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $1,330,000 and $1,674,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the repurchase of 12 3/4 percent subordinated notes. c-Net income

title: Sports of The Times; Nouvelle Doc on Opening Day
description: HOW much of last year's opener did you see? ''Not much,'' said Doc Gooden. ''I caught only about 15 minutes of it, in between meetings and lectures.''

title: VMS Short Term Income Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: A music review on Friday about a concert performance of Janacek's opera ''Jenufa'' misstated the national origin of Gabriela Benackova, the soprano. She is Czechoslovak.

title: Cervantes Lecture Series
description: A free lecture series on Cervantes continues with the topic ''The Cult of Fame in Cervantes and Unamuno,'' tomorrow at 4:30 P.M. on the Lincoln Center campus of Fordham University, 113 West 60th Street. Prof. Geoffrey W. Ribbans, the William R. Kenan Jr. University Professor of Hispanic Studies at Brown University, will give the lecture, which is in English and open to the public. Information: 579-2666 or 841-5373.

title: Carlucci in New Delhi For Talks on Defense
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci arrived today for talks with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and other officials on steps to upgrade military cooperation between the United States and India.

title: California Now Sees Cars as a Threat
description: Economists and business leaders say urban areas in California are facing such serious traffic congestion that the state's economic vitality is in jeopardy.

title: Swaggart Speaks Out in Church Appearance
description: The Rev. Jimmy Swaggart took the microphone at a service here Sunday night and gave his most emotional speech since stepping down from the pulpit Feb. 21.

title: Colombia Gunmen in Hoods Kill 34 at an Easter Festival
description: Gunmen opened fire on about 500 peasants at an Easter festival in a village in northern Colombia, killing 34, the police and witnesses said today.

title: Gemco National Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $135,000 from discontinued operations for both the quarter and year, and tax credits of $137,000 for the quarter and $323,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $104,000 for the quarter and a loss of $3,430,000 for the year, and tax credits of $17,000 and $515,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: The Big Squeeze Facing Digital
description: With an average annual growth of 20 percent in the last four years, the Digital Equipment Corporation has been forcing the computer industry's leader, the International Business Machines Corporation, to look over its shoulder constantly.

title: Cetus and Amgen Settle Disputes
description: The Cetus Corporation and Amgen Inc., both biotechnology companies, said they had settled all disputes between them about certain United States and foreign patents covering genetically engineered interleukin-2. Under the settlement, Amgen will assign all of its patent rights to Cetus, and each company will have the right to develop, manufacture and market its own form of interleukin-2.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Conservation Spirit
description: The Civilian Conservation Corps, that child of the Depression responsible for the greening of large parts of the United States, has not been around since 1942. But the spirit of the C.C.C.'s hard work and dedication lives on in Christina Sprott of Brooklyn; Don Hunt of L'Anse, Mich.; Rita M. Gardere of Oakland, Calif.; and April Wells of Kittanning, Pa.

title: Review/Television; For 'Heat Of Night,' A New Life
description: Two names out of television's recent past have joined forces on a new series that has been giving ''Moonlighting'' some spirited competition. One is Fred Silverman, former programming guru at all three networks and now head of his own producing company, specializing in new ''concepts'' for veteran stars (Andy Griffith in ''Matlock,'' William Conrad in ''Jake and the Fatman''). The other is Carroll O'Connor, best known to the world at large as Archie Bunker. That's the problem. Mr. O'Connor has been trying to shake the Archie image for several years in assorted stage and television projects. He may finally have found the right vehicle with ''In the Heat of the Night,'' currently on NBC on Tuesdays at 9 P.M.

title: Kansas City Southern Buys Group's Stake
description: Kansas City Southern Industries announced today that with the help of another Kansas City, Mo., company it had bought back 11.3 percent of its stock from an investment group led by Howard Kaskel, a New York real estate developer.

title: In a Colorado Precinct, Edge to Jackson After Debate
description: In an urban precinct that straddles a working-class black neighborhood and a middle-class white area, 67 Democrats gathered tonight to debate the electability of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis versus the emotional draw of the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: Budget Woes in Troubled Paterson Schools
description: If Paterson needed a symbol to dramatize the plight of its troubled schools, it could hardly have found a more potent one than Joe Clark, the principal of Eastside High School.

title: Del-Val Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Texas A&M Accused of Violations
description: Investigators of the National Collegiate Athletic Association have accused the Texas A&M football program of 31 rules infractions and 7 procedural violations in a letter released today by the school.

title: Manufacturers' Profits Dip
description: American manufacturers' after-tax profits in the fourth quarter of 1987 totaled $26.4 billion, or 4.3 cents per dollar of sales, which was lower than the previous quarter but higher than a year earlier, the Commerce Department said today.

title: CVN Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter and 6 months include the full operating results of Cable Value Network, which became wholly owned by CVN Cos. on Aug. 31, 1987. Prior to full ownership, financial results included only the company's 50 percent equity interest in the joint venture.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Haitian Inquiry on Massacre Absolves Duvalier and Army
description: A Government-appointed commission has absolved the military and supporters of former President Jean-Claude Duvalier of any blame for last November's electoral violence that left 34 dead and nearly 70 injured.

title: N.C.A.A. Championship; Manning Is Magnificent as Kansas Wins Title
description: In a season distinguished by unusual twists and turns, Kansas, an unlikely candidate to be a champion after early season problems, upset Oklahoma tonight, 83-79, to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball title.

title: Careers; Middle-Level Staff Seen as Expendable
description: PITY the poor middle manager in this here-today, gone-tomorrow job market.

title: U.S. Challenges Posner's Sentence
description: A sentence requiring the industrialist Victor Posner to make a $3 million contribution to the homeless is illegal and shows that ''the rich can trade money for liberty while the poor cannot,'' a Federal prosecutor said today in challenging the sentence.

title: VMS Strategic Land Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company began its initial public offering in October 1986.

title: VMS Mortgage Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Three Youths Shot on Subway Train in Brooklyn
description: Three 15-year-old boys were shot on a subway train in Brooklyn early yesterday, the police said, when they were confronted by a group of youths, one of whom tried to rob them.

title: Edelman Bids For Datapoint
description: In a revived effort to take the company private, the Datapoint Corporation announced yesterday that it had received a leveraged buyout offer of $6 a share, or about $60 million, from a management group led by Asher B. Edelman, the New York financier who gained control of Datapoint in 1985.

title: Sharpton Arrested in Brawley Case Protest
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton and 13 other people were arrested today outside state buildings in a protest against the state's handling of the Tawana Brawley case.

title: Rig Count Up in Week
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States rose by six last week, to 941, Baker Hughes Inc. announced today. A year ago, the count stood at 752. The rig count, a widely watched industry index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil, not the number producing oil.

title: Healthcare Compare reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $60,000.

title: Defense Seeks To Bar Tapes In Homicide
description: Lawyers for three of the four men charged with murdering a rookie police officer in Queens say they will argue that the prosecution should not be allowed to use their clients' statements because the police obtained them illegally.

title: Queen Bees' Cachet
description: QUEEN honeybees produce a glandular substance called HQMC - honey bee queen mandibular complex - that has powerful effects on the entire colony, telling the workers who's boss and how they should all behave.

title: VMS Hotel Investment Fund reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KEY RATES
Seahawk Oil International Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Cerone and Royster Let Go
description: The scenes were familiar for the day before opening day. Players sorted their belongings in the Yankee clubhouse. Painters applied finishing touches to the hallways underneath the Stadium. And outside, while it drizzled, Rick Rhoden, the starting pitcher today at 1 o'clock against the Minnesota Twins, made some minor adjustments to the mound with the help of the grounds crew.

title: Review/Books; The Gonzaga: A Family And an Oligarchy
description: A Renaissance Tapestry The Gonzaga of Mantua By Kate Simon Illustrated. 309 pages. Harper & Row. $22.50.

title: Phone Link Simplifies Defibrillation
description: DOCTORS in Northern Ireland have tested a new approach to home treatment for one of the most common natural causes of sudden death, abrupt disturbances of heart rhythm called ventricular fibrillation.

title: Trade Plea From Japan
description: A Japanese trade association yesterday tried to rebut charges that growing international competition in the plastic-molding machinery industry threatens United States security by endangering American manufacturers in the field.

title: Tinker Hoping Hits Are Still There
description: Grant Tinker was in his Hollywood uniform - open collar, sweater casually draped over his shoulders - as he strolled across his new domain, a 30-acre studio in Culver City. Out front, his blue Mercedes baked in the Southern California sun. Out back, his production teams were bringing to life the shows Mr. Tinker will produce for next fall's television season.

title: Baseball; Bell, as D.H., Belts Record 3 Homers
description: George Bell became the first player to hit three home runs on opening day, leading the Toronto Blue Jays past the Kansas City Royals, 5-3, today.

title: PANAMA DISMISSES U.S. ACCUSATIONS
description: Panama today dismissed an American complaint that a police vehicle had tried to halt a car carrying the United States Ambassador. It said the police had actually been trying to protect the envoy from what they thought were three menacing carloads of armed men.

title: Japan Air Tells Boeing of Defects
description: Japan Air Lines has told the Boeing Company that it found defects in two types of Boeing aircraft, airline officials said. In a letter, J.A.L.'s president, Susumu Yamaji, told Boeing's chairman, Frank A. Shrontz, that engine heat detectors had been incorrectly installed in Boeing 747's and the wrong wiring had been discovered in fire extinguishers in the cargo hold of 767's.

title: Stronger 76er Front Line to Face Knicks
description: Jim O'Brien, one of the Knicks' three assistant coaches, found a new look in the Philadelphia 76ers last Wednesday night when he watched them overwhelm the Milwaukee Bucks, 134-109.

title: Fur Vault Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $96,000 for the quarter and $386,000 for the 9 months.

title: Outlook Dim For Expanding Health Care
description: Leading health experts are calling for major expansions to address New York's critical health-care shortages, but they warn that even if the efforts could be achieved some sick people would be left without proper medical care.

title: Walker Telecommunications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $308,385 for the quarter and $205,930 for the year, and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $1,893,982 for the both periods.

title: Washington Talk: Transportation; Championing the Idea of a Train That Floats
description: To hear some politicians tell it, the history of public policy is a catalogue of progressive ideas boldly enacted as legislation. The reality is that great ideas have often been ignored in Washington while silly ideas have frequently been embraced.

title: Lexington Group reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $51,000 from the early retirement of debt. The results for all periods are restated to include the operations of Harris & Co., which merged with a unit of Lexington Group in November 1987.

title: LEADING CANDIDATE FOR JUSTICE POST WITHDRAWS NAME
description: In what Justice Department officials described as another serious embarrassment for Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, the leading candidate to head the department's criminal division has withdrawn from consideration and Mr. Meese's choice as Deputy Attorney General has indicated a strong reluctance to accept the post.

title: Consolidated Capital Income Trust reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After gains of $366,000 and $2,008 for the latest year and year-earlier period, respectively, on sale of investments and property.

title: Soviet Believed To Be Preparing Afghan Pullout
description: The Soviet Union appears to have taken some steps in preparation for withdrawing its troops from Afghanistan, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Mansfield, 85, Back in Tokyo For the Finale
description: His long frame, always spare, borders on gaunt these days. The mouth is a bit pinched, an unmistakable sign that here is a man of years.

title: In a Change-of-Pace Production, Merchant and Ivory Film on Mott St.
description: Hanging in the wardrobe room are two neon-bright apple-green tutus -one for a woman walking her dog, the other for the dog. Together these characters will prance down Mott Street in the opening shot of ''Slaves of New York,'' setting the tone for the Merchant-Ivory film of Tama Janowitz's story collection, which began shooting yesterday.

title: Imports Tested for CFC's
description: Federal tests of imported aerosol cosmetics have found 43 percent of them to contain chlorofluorocarbons, in violation of United States law, the Customs Service said today.

title: Sports People; Lemieux Takes Honors
description: The reign of Wayne Gretzky as the scoring champion of the National Hockey League for seven consecutive seasons came to an end Sunday as Mario Lemieux of the Pittsburgh Penguins finished with 70 goals and 98 assists for 168 points.

title: USR Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Congress vs. Andrew Johnson on Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics of The times; Art Over Politics
description: When international relations heat up, cultural exchange gets frozen out. A vivid illustration of why art shouldn't be held hostage to politics is the Metropolitan Museum's current exhibit of Dutch and Flemish painting from the Hermitage, the Soviet Union's premier palace of art.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about Wendy Paula Foster and Roy Seth Wasserman described their celebration incorrectly. As the article reported, it was a marriage, not an engagement.

title: Witness in Biaggi Trial Alters Payment Account
description: A chief Government witness in the corruption trial of Representative Mario Biaggi and six others modified his account today about how the Congressman obtained Wedtech stock.

title: Rightist Party in El Salvador Challenges Election Results
description: The right-wing Nationalist Republican Alliance challenged today the result of last month's elections, saying it was being cheated of a majority in the Legislative Assembly by manipulation of the vote in eastern provinces.

title: Impasse Persists on Investment by Foreigners
description: Little in the trade bill that has been in the works for three years has proved as contentious as a House proposal to require disclosure of foreign investment in the United States. When the House and Senate conferees ended work last week and left for a 10-day recess, the disclosure amendment remained unresolved.

title: Comic Sees Politicians As Good for Nothing Except His Jokes
description: Surveying the 1988 Presidential campaign, Will Durst has tart words for all the contenders.

title: Taking Advantage of 'Mr. Market'
description: Few corporate annual reports are as eagerly awaited as that of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the Omaha-based holding company whose chairman, Warren E. Buffett, matches the wisdom of his investments with the wit of his message to shareholders. In this year's report, mailed in late March, Mr. Buffett harks back to a lesson learned from his Columbia University mentor, Prof. Benjamin Graham, a giant in the field of securities analysis:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about calls for the resignation of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d misidentified the chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. He is Senator John F. Kerry of Massachusetts, not Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine.

title: In Suburb, Poor People In Despair At a Motel
description: It had not been unusual for one or two welfare families to stay at the Larchmont Motel. The Town Supervisor, Dolores Battalia, recalled: ''A caseworker would call and say she had placed a family at the motel. We usually made sure they got into our recreation programs. And then the family would be gone.''

title: Paul Wollstadt, 77, Oil Industry Consultant
description: Paul Wollstadt, a retired petroleum industry consultant and former senior vice president of the Mobil Oil Corporation, died Saturday at the Lawnwood Regional Medical Center in Fort Pierce, Fla., after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J., before moving to Fort Pierce four years ago.

title: Scientists Decipher Code That Governs Life and Death of Cells
description: SCIENTISTS are learning to decipher a chemical language that governs how cells in the human body grow and interact in health and illness, life and death.

title: SAI Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $786,000 on the sale of assets of a subsidiary and a charge of $175,000 for the repurchase of reinsurance rights. c-Net loss and included a pre-tax charge of $100,000 for the purchase of stock options from a former officer and after a loss of $450,000 from discontinued operations, both for the quarter and year.

title: Critic's Notebook; Going Beyond Music for Choreographic Inspiration
description: Ballets inspired by the structure and moods of symphonic music continue to preoccupy American choreographers and dominate the programs of the nation's dance companies. But this may be a weakness as well as a strength of contemporary ballet.

title: PC Quote Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
HIGH COURT TAKES APPEAL OVER FATE OF ESTIMATE BOARD
description: In a move that effectively preserves New York City's Board of Estimate for at least a year, the United States Supreme Court agreed yesterday to rule on the constitutionality of that powerful governing body.

title: Advatex Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and year-ago fourth quarter figures are not available because the company was not public. The company said on a pro forma basis, the latest year's net income would be $583,000. Pro forma net income is determined by deducting from historical net income, tax liabilities which would have accrued during the first six months of 1987 had the company not had S Corporation status.

title: State Anti-Smoking Bill Gains Support in Albany
description: Republican leaders in the State Senate, who have blocked anti-smoking legislation in previous years, proposed their own set of restrictions today, making it likely that some kind of ban on smoking in many public places would become law this year.

title: Brougher Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized net losses on investments of $112,157 for the quarter and $78,105 for the year, and the year also includes a gain on stock sale by a subsidiary of $320,025. c-Net income d-Includes realized net losses on investments of $3,929 for the quarter and realized net gains on investments of $80,088 for the year.

title: China, in Shift, Says Dalai Lama Can Return to His Home in Tibet
description: China said today that the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism, would be permitted to live in Tibet if he abandoned calls for independence.

title: Koppers Blocks Beazer Bid
description: The Koppers Company won a preliminary injunction yesterday in Federal District Court in Los Angeles, halting the $1.85 billion takeover bid of Beazer P.L.C. of Britain.

title: Banking Shift Urged in China
description: Delegates to China's parliament have called for an independent central bank, which they say is vital to end four years of excessive money supply and to control inflation, the No. 1 economic problem.

title: Ethel Grant, 63, Dies; Headed a U.N. Forum
description: Ethel Henck Grant, a social worker, died of a heart attack Friday while traveling in Agra, India, a representative of the United Nations Children's Fund said yesterday. She was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Soybeans at 4-Year High And Precious Metals Gain
description: Prices of precious metals futures rose yesterday as soybean prices surged to a four-year high, fanning new fears of inflation.

title: They Misled The Voters On Jackson
description: LEAD: In the wake of the frenzy after the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Michigan victory, we should all calm down as the normal process of the candidates' competition for votes goes forward. That process is unduly beset by the intervention of a host of other players - political pundits in and out of the media, and pollsters - who are scurrying around analyzing this, interpreting that, projecting, assuming and concluding all over the place.

title: Reagan's Nightmare in El Salvador
description: LEAD: The El Salvador elections have brought to pass the Reagan Administration's second worst nightmare: a triumph of the extreme right in the National Assembly and mayoral contests. This makes more likely the first nightmare: the growing polarization and radicalization of Salvadoran society, leading to the eventual triumph of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front and the Democratic Revolutionary

title: Russians Have Had Income Taxes Since the Czars
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Royal Crown Ads With No Black Actors
description: IT'S hard to believe in this day and age that an ad agency could produce three 30-second television commercials for a major soft drink and not include any black actors.

title: Helene Curtis Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Fed May Limit Check Fees
description: The Federal Reserve Board agreed today to consider barring banks from charging a fee for honoring checks on the same day they are presented for payment.

title: A New Spot for Mamma Leone's: Mangia!
description: After a six-month hiatus, Bertha Farfana, 86 years old, will be back at her post near the door of Mamma Leone's tonight, signing autographs for tourists who think she's the original matriarch and can't possibly be sent home disappointed.

title: Champion of Highway Safety Will Be Missed
description: To the Editor:

title: Beard Accepts Bid By Union Pacific
description: The Beard Company said it had agreed to be acquired by the Union Pacific Corporation in a deal worth nearly $100 million. Union Pacific, based in New York, will also acquire the almost 3.6 million shares of Uspci Inc. that Beard owned. Union Pacific is the majority owner of Uspci, a waste-management company.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: U.S. Court Backs Conviction In Spy Satellite Photos Case
description: In a case pitting protection of national security against freedom of speech, a Federal appeals court today upheld the conviction of a former Navy intelligence analyst who gave photographs of a Soviet ship to a British military journal.

title: U.S. SAID TO IGNORE NORIEGA DRUG ROLE
description: A former State Department official testified today that the Reagan Administration passed up an opportunity in 1986 to foster opposition to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian military leader.

title: Shultz Finds Shamir Still Opposed to Peace Plan
description: As Palestinians staged a general strike in the occupied territories to protest his visit, Secretary of State George P. Shultz pressed his proposal for Arab-Israeli peace talks today with Israeli leaders. He came away without the endorsement he says he is urgently seeking, but an American official said there was ''a sense of some movement'' in the official Israeli position.

title: Restoration of Environment Emerges as a Major Goal
description: USING backhoes, bulldozers and biology, environmental scientists are developing new techniques to repair landscapes damaged by industrial development and pollution.

title: A 'Smart Start' for Poor Children
description: What's the best way to give disadvantaged children a fair chance to succeed? Focusing on early childhood education can save futures, and money. Committing the Federal Government to such early intervention is the aim of an unusually welcome bill about to be introduced by Senator Edward Kennedy.

title: Merc March Volume Up
description: March volume at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange increased six-tenths of 1 percent from March 1987, but volume for the first quarter fell 4 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier, the exchange said today. March volume in the Merc's Standard & Poor's 500-stock index futures declined 36.1 percent, to 1,137,037 contracts, from 1,780,538 contracts a year ago, the exchange said.

title: Joyful Night in Lawrence
description: Shouting ''We're No. 1!'' amid the crackle of fireworks and the blast of car horns, thousands of fans swarmed over the University of Kansas campus tonight in celebration of the Jayhawks' national basketball championship.

title: North Atlantic Industries Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $2,720,000 from discontinued operations and a provision for loss on disposal of operations of $3,571,000. c-Net income and after a loss of $1,124,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Devils Fulfill Primary Goal
description: After the frustration of so many losing seasons, so much scorn and ridicule from their peers, the Devils have finally been rewarded for their patience and their relentless refusal to concede.

title: Indonesian Oil for Japan
description: Pertamina, Indonesia's state-owned oil company, and Japanese buyers have agreed in principle to a new one-year contract for sales of crude oil, a spokesman for Pertamina, Kusmadi Endin, said today. He gave no details. Japan imports half of Indonesia's oil.

title: Elliott S. Barker Is Dead at 101; A Conservationist and an Author
description: Elliott S. Barker, a conservationist and author who helped make Smokey Bear part of American lore, died Sunday at a nursing home here. He was 101 years old.

title: Synergetics International reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the 1987 loss included fourth-quarter adjustments alone of $738,000.

title: Advertising; Laurence, Charles Wins A McDonald's Account
description: Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson has won the Philadelphia area McDonald Operators Association account, billing about $9 million.

title: Mets Open Season With a Big Bang: 6 Home Runs
description: Darryl Strawberry hit two titanic home runs today as the Mets opened the season with a record-breaking barrage of six home runs that buried the Montreal Expos, 10-6, and awed a sellout crowd of 55,413 fans in Olympic Stadium.

title: Selective Microscope
description: Three physicists at the University of Southern California have invented a microscope that allows a user to single out moving microbes for observation by blanking out all non-moving details in the background scene.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * BIS Group Ltd. and Nynex Information Solutions Group Inc. announced the acquisition of CAP International Inc., a marketing research company. The price was not disclosed.

title: Households Exceed 90 Million
description: The United States has more than 90 million households for the first time, but each contains fewer people on average than ever, the Census Bureau said today.

title: Green Appoints Fund Executive As His Deputy
description: Schools Chancellor Richard R. Green named a newcomer to the New York City school system as his deputy yesterday.

title: Aca Joe's Stock
description: Aca Joe Inc., a men's clothing retailer, said its common stock had been deleted from the Nasdaq over-the-counter trading system effective April 1 because of the company's failure to meet Nasdaq's capital and surplus requirements. Aca Joe had previously been granted a temporary exception from the requirements while it sought to obtain financing, but the exception expired March 31.

title: Graphic Packaging reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are not available because the company became publicly owned in May 1987.

The company said the latest quarter and year include gains from a change in accounting for pensions of $19,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $74,000, or 3 cents a share, for the year.
