title: Somalia and Ethiopia Resume Relations
description: Somalia and Ethiopia have agreed to restore diplomatic relations, 11 years after their border dispute over the Ogaden region erupted into war, the Ethiopian press agency reported today.

title: Chess
description: Six players tied for first place in the National Open Tournament at the Holiday Inn O'Hare in Chicago.

title: Pinnacle Petroleum Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls, who scored a season-high 59 points against the Detroit Pistons on Sunday, has been named National Basketball Association player of the week for the period ending Sunday. . . . Sean Burke, the rookie goalie of the Devils, and Luc Robitaille, a left wing for the Los Angeles Kings, have been named players of the week for the final week of the regular season ending Sunday by the N.H.L.

title: Leisure Concepts reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Administration Says It Plans To Sell 75 F-16's to Israelis
description: The Reagan Administration told Congress today that it intended to sell Israel 75 advanced F-16 C/D fighter planes for $2 billion as a way to help bolster Israeli security.

title: Review/Concert; Joan Sutherland, Building On Details, With Bonynge
description: Some performers begin with the spirit, which then sprinkles down over musical detail and infuses it with life. Joan Sutherland's singing builds from a different direction -with a precisely directed attention to every phrase and every breath. Miss Sutherland may be 61 years old, but her recital at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday night said loudly that if this great soprano is considering retirement, it will be out of choice, not because she has to.

title: Dow Drops 7.46 Points on Fears of Inflation
description: Stocks moved broadly lower yesterday, as the cheer generated by the strong employment figures released Friday was offset by fears of inflation caused by that strength.

title: Review/Theater; Orpheus Myth in a Whirl Of Song, Dance and Decor
description: More than most of his peers in the world of performance art, John Kelly defies categorization. His new performance piece, ''Find My Way Home,'' is both a drama without dialogue and a chamber musical that merges grand opera with show tunes. The play is filled with movement, only some of which could accurately be described as dance, and a few of the most dramatic moments are directly connected with the decor. Combining film and kinetic action, ''Find My Way Home'' (at Dance Theater Workshop) draws its essential character from its landscape and from the presence on stage of Mr. Kelly.

title: New York's Blind Deserve a Real Library
description: To the Editor:

title: Tumult in the Political Laboratory
description: It hadn't even registered on most people yet, but one of the nation's premier experiments in political science - the complete transformation of New York City's government - was already well under way. Then suddenly, word came from the Supreme Court yesterday that the change, if any, would take a while longer.

description: Japanese auto makers have fallen short of their Government's 2.3 million quota on car exports to the United States for the fiscal year ended March 31, an auto industry trade journal reported today. The report by Automotive

title: Science and Technology: The Gap Is Shrinking Fast
description: INVENTORS are dramatically increasing their reliance on basic scientific research to compete in the international race for commercial innovations. Indeed, new studies show the trend is so powerful that in places science and technology are starting to merge.

title: No Budget Bill Accord But Printing Proceeds
description: In an unusual move that could portend an extended delay in passing a state budget, State Senate aides said today that they were preparing to print the entire budget bill even though it had not yet been agreed to by the Assembly and the Governor.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Small-Scale Reminder
description: For the last week, some of the 5,000 members of Roots, the American Palestinian Youth Organization, have gathered near the Embassy of Israel to protest the Israeli presence in the occupied territories of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

title: What Might Underlie Contribution Disclosure
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Bemoan Their Missed Chances for a Playoff Berth
description: ''The greatest reverses of fortune,'' a philosopher once remarked for both comfort and posterity, ''are the most easily borne from a sort of dignity belonging to them.''

title: For a Chef, Baking Is Still Spellbinding
description: LEAD: AT the Cakery in Dumont, N.J., Alex Miles had just finished going over his basement stock: 700 pounds of chocolate; 5 gallons of blueberries imported from France; barrels of hazelnuts, walnuts and almonds, and 100-pound sacks of flour and sugar. He has a chest freezer, a double-door freezer, and a walk-in refrigerator that holds dozens of fresh eggs, tubs of butter and quarts of heavy cream.

title: Quarex Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
Real Estate; A Municipal Complex for New Haven
description: NEARLY eight years after a tightening of municipal purse strings halted construction of a new city hall in New Haven, the ambitious project has resumed.

title: Eastern Withdraws Plan to Sell Its Shuttle
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. bowed to a Federal judge's order yesterday and said that it would no longer take any steps to sell its shuttle to another subsidiary of its parent, the Texas Air Corporation.

description: The executive who will shape Federated Department Stores Inc. for its new owner, the Campeau Corporation, will be Robert H. Morosky, the president of Allied Stores Inc.

title: Potvin Redirects His Chase
description: He is 34 years old. His knuckles and his knees are scarred. His lower lip is freshly split, and after he makes one last, inspired dash for a fifth Stanley Cup this spring, he would like to go off and become as good a businessman as he has been a hockey player.

title: Critic's Notebook; Jackson and TV Reporters in a Cautious Dance
description: It is fashionable to say issues have died and people are apathetic, but it may be more accurate to say they turn numb. Candidates' voices blur and blend, and turn into background din. On television, only the Rev. Jesse Jackson shows quicksilver flash; he is warm and friendly and a master of stylish locutions. Correspondents said almost unanimously last week that he might be the Democratic front-runner for the Presidential nomination.

title: Education; Math Centers Stress Tough Training
description: Keiko Kikekawa shook her head in horror as she recalled talking to her daughter's teacher about how much homework , the teacher was assigning - or, rather, how little.

description: A $1.5 billion reorganization plan is crucial to the survival of the First City Bancorporation of Texas, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

description: Citicorp yesterday began offering $250 million of 9 percent notes due in 1993 at a price of 99.60, to yield 9.10 percent, through a group of underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

description: b-Net income and includes extraordinary items of $755,000, or 14 cents a share. All 1986 share earnings have been restated to give effect for the 1-for-10 reverse stock split.

The company noted that this was its first earnings report since the $1.5 billion acquisition of Taft Broadcasting Co. in October 1987.

title: A Campaign to Change The Coin of the Realm
description: Eleven years ago, faced with growing Government deficits, the Carter Administration took an unusual step aimed at reducing the Treasury Department's budget by $50 million a year. It introduced the Susan B. Anthony dollar coin to complement the George Washington dollar bill.

title: Shifting French Landscape
description: With three weeks to go before the first round of French presidential elections, five weeks before the final vote, a watershed looms after a ho-hum campaign.

title: Mixing Law and Kosher Salami for the Cambridge Crowd
description: A FEW nice Jewish boys from the Harvard Square neighborhood will make their mothers very happy when their kosher delicatessen opens here.

title: U.S. Aide Offers Plan to Cut Arms at Sea
description: Reagan Administration officials are considering an unusual suggestion to eliminate several types of nuclear weapons from the American and Soviet navies, Administration officials say.

title: Alexander's Stake Raised by Trump
description: Interstate Properties, a New Jersey developer, and the developer Donald J. Trump have increased their combined stake in Alexander's Inc. to 48.3 percent from 43 percent.

title: Air Force Is Facing Critical Gap in Combat Readiness
description: The Air Force, saying it has had to make worldwide cuts in training, maintenance and routine operations because of budget cuts, is trying to reallocate money to fill critical gaps in combat readiness this year, according to senior officials and internal documents.

title: Dukakis Wins in Colorado; Jackson Faults Tally Delay
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts won a narrow victory over the Rev. Jesse Jackson in the first round of the Colorado caucuses Monday night. Mr. Jackson, who made a strong showing in a mostly white state, accused the state Democratic Party of slowing the count to make Mr. Dukakis appear stronger going into the Wisconsin primary today.

title: SHULTZ INITIATIVE GETS NO SUPPORT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today after talks in Jordan and Syria that he had failed to get any agreement in the latest American peace initiative for the Middle East.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: A FEW days before Passover, Stella Isaacs was on a downtown subway, on her way from her home on the Upper West Side to B. Altman's. She spotted an abandoned newspaper on the seat beside her. Mrs. Isaacs picked it up and began thumbing through, scanning the advertisements, searching for headlines of interest. What she settled down to read was . . . well, why not listen to Mrs. Isaacs herself.

title: 17 Tied to Embassy Attack
description: The 17 pro-Iranian prisoners whose release was demanded in the hijacking of a Kuwaiti airliner yesterday are members of Al Daawa, or The Call, an underground Shiite group that arranged truck-bombings on Dec. 12, 1983, that killed 4 people and wounded 87 at the French and American Embassies in Kuwait.

title: Education; Youths Leave Foster Care For Campus
description: In his first semester at Langston University in Oklahoma last year Peter Blackwell, a criminal justice major, struggled to a 2.4 grade point average, on a scale of 4. He raised his average to 2.7 in the second semester and to 3.5 last fall. Now he says with quiet confidence, ''I'm ready to really do well this semester.''

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: SKATE is a delectable fish that has recently become popular in many American kitchens.

title: EATING WELL
description: AFTER lunch do you usually want to take a nap? When the lights are turned out at work for a slide presentation, is that your signal to close your eyes and catch 40 winks?

title: Economic Scene; Minimum Wage: A Tangled Puzzle
description: WOULD the House Labor Committee's plan to increase the Federal minimum wage in stages, to $5.05 an hour from $3.35, lift the living standards of the working poor? Or, as opponents contend, would it push marginally qualified workers onto welfare?

title: FLOW OF REFUGEES IS SAID TO DECLINE
description: The violence that marked the enforcement of a Thai policy of turning back Vietnamese arriving by boat was limited to a few weeks in February, diplomats and refugee officials say. They say the violence has been substantially reduced or eliminated as the number of Vietnamese in Thai waters drops sharply.

title: Yank Eye-Openers: Rookie and Veteran
description: The three hits, Roberto Kelly said, that is what he will remember most.

title: Title Fuels Talk About Brown
description: Perhaps Larry Brown will never be truly content as a basketball coach. Part of the problem, by his admission, is his pursuit of perfection.

title: A New Family Of Intel Chips
description: The Intel Corporation today introduced a family of microprocessors aimed at expanding the company's sales outside the personal computer market.

title: Review/Television; O'Neill as a Young Man Of Calculated Theatrics
description: Grappling with the glum, monumental figure of Eugene Gladstone O'Neill can be treacherous. Calvin Skaggs tries mightily in ''Journey Into Genius,'' an hourlong drama he has directed and produced for public television's ''American Playhouse.'' The teleplay is by Lanie Robertson (''Lady Day at Emerson's Bar and Grill''). It can be seen on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: Dollars, Not Dresses
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; The Sturges Wit in 'A Cup of Coffee'
description: When Preston Sturges was directing ''Unfaithfully Yours,'' he would stuff a handkerchief in his mouth to keep from laughing out loud while shooting. This sense of hilarity was shared by audiences watching that movie and such other Sturges films as ''Sullivan's Travels'' and ''The Palm Beach Story.'' Deservedly, Sturges came to be regarded as a master of sophisticated, satiric comedy.

title: Soaking the Rich?
description: Are the rich getting soaked more under the Reagan Administration? A quick look at a new Treasury Department report suggests that this might be so, showing that high-income taxpayers have been paying an increasing share of Federal income taxes.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Basix Corp., an operating systems and energy company, appointed P. David Searles president and chief operating officer.

title: Corning Net Off 17.4%
description: Corning Glass Works said today that its profit had fallen 17.4 percent in the first quarter from a year ago, when it had a one-time gain stemming from an accounting change. For the quarter ended March 27, Corning reported a profit of $37.1 million, or 83 cents a share, compared with $44.9 million, or 97 cents a share, a year ago, when it had a $14.2 million accounting gain.

title: But Where Are the Bees of Yesteryear?
description: To the Editor:

title: Moore McCormack Considering Offer
description: Barred from pursuing a recapitalization plan intended to prevent a hostile takeover, directors of Moore McCormack Resources met to consider a $512 million offer from the Southdown Corporation. The proposal would pay common shareholders $40 a share. Moore McCormack previously rejected two lower bids from Southdown, of $31 a common share and $35. Southdown's offer expires at 6 P.M. Wednesday.

title: Former Head of Bar Picked for No. 2 Justice Post
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today recommended the nomination of John C. Shepherd, a former president of the American Bar Association, to replace Deputy Attorney General Arnold I. Burns, who resigned last week in an apparent protest over Mr. Meese's leadership of the Justice Department.

title: On-Time Air Flights Gain
description: Airlines in the United States improved their on-time record in February, but one of every four flights was late as weather conditions played a major role in how close the airlines were in having their planes arrive on schedule.

title: Centrust Savings Sets Note Offering
description: Centrust Savings Bank is offering $100 million of floating-rate notes due in 1991 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Webster Clothes reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Six Shot, One Fatally, On a Brooklyn Street
description: A man was shot to death and five other people, including a 13-year-old girl, were wounded by three gunmen in the East New York section of Brooklyn last night, the police said.

title: A Fisherman Finds $5 Million
description: It wasn't much to look at, just a modest blue bag floating in Jamaica Bay. But it was the big one that didn't get away.

title: MacLean Peaking for Devils
description: The goal had sent his New Jersey teammates streaming deliriously over the boards and their season spilling further into spring. John MacLean, his arms raised simply and tiredly over his head, just turned his back to his bench and the bedlam, and skated away.

title: Kuwaiti Jet Is Hijacked to Iranian City
description: A Kuwaiti airliner with more than 110 people aboard was hijacked today on a flight from Bangkok to Kuwait and forced to land in Iran.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-15 Obstacles to an Afghan peace treaty may have been removed at talks in Geneva. The United States and the Soviet Union may be moving toward an understanding on military supplies Afghanistan after a treaty is signed. Page A1

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
St. Paul
description: LEAD: MORGAN'S Mexican and Lebanese Foods offers one of the more unlikely ethnic combinations of ingredients to be found in this city, with its large Scandinavian and German populations.

title: OFFICIAL SAYS U.S. SEEKS PANAMA RIFT
description: A senior United States official suggested today that the Reagan Administration was seeking to destabilize the Government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega by fomenting discord within the Panama Defense Forces.

title: ARMS AID REPORTED FADING AS BLOCK TO AFGHAN PEACE
description: There were signs at the Afghan peace talks today that the United States and the Soviet Union had removed major obstacles and were moving toward an understanding on military supplies for Afghanistan after a peace treaty is signed.

title: Fannie Mae Offer
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is offering $1.4 billion of three- and 10-year debentures at a price of par, through various securities dealers. A $800 million issue of three-year debentures due in 1991 is priced to yield 8 percent, or about 20 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity, while the $600 million companion issue of debentures due in 1998 yields 9.15 percent, or about 47 basis points more than Treasuries.

title: Iran and Iraq Step Up Raids on Urban Areas
description: Iran and Iraq stepped up their ''war of the cities'' today, reportedly killing dozens of civilians in missile, air and artillery attacks.

title: Dalai Lama Dismisses China's Offer to Return
description: The Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism, today dismissed China's offer to allow him to return to Tibet if he abandoned his campaign for independence. He said there was nothing new in the offer, which was made Monday, and indicated that he would not accept the restrictions.

title: Ralph W. Schreiber Is Dead at 45; Bird Expert Was Museum Curator
description: Dr. Ralph W. Schreiber, an ornithologist and curator of birds and mammals at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, died March 29 of pancreatic and liver cancer at his Los Angeles home. He was 45 years old.

title: Cocoa Falls in London
description: Cocoa prices fell to the lowest level in nearly six years today amid a world glut and weak demand. Cocoa for July shipment sank to $:895, or $1,683, a metric ton in London, down from the Thursday close (before a long Easter weekend) of $:920, or $1,730.

title: Sports People; Brown Honored
description: Within hours after his Jayhawks captured the N.C.A.A. basketball championship, Larry Brown of Kansas was named winner of the Naismith Coach of the Year award. Brown will receive the award at a dinner of the Atlanta Tipoff Club tomorrow. Leon Barmore, coach of Louisiana Tech, the N.C.A.A. women's DIvision I champion, was named coach of the year for women's teams. (AP)

title: Britain Forms Fraud Agency
description: Britain is creating a new specialist agency to tackle cases of serious fraud, hoping to raise confidence in the integrity of London as a world financial center.

title: White House Can't Disregard Law on P.L.O.; No Free Speech Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Deadline on Skin Cream Ads
description: The Food and Drug Administration has given cosmetics companies 30 days to stop maintaining that their over-the-counter creams can reverse or retard aging of the skin.

title: Ballesteros Suggests New Plan
description: The men with the best record in the last eight Masters tournaments are Seve Ballesteros and Tom Watson, with the Spaniard having an edge over the Kansan because he has two victories in that time, two ties for second and one for third. Watson has one victory and six top-10 finishes.

title: About New York; A Radio Nomad Enjoys a Pause In Life on the Air
description: Four years ago Monday, Roy Fox and Mary DeRoss were married on the radio in Pittsburgh. Mr. Fox had a show there on KDKA, a talk program called ''The Fox's Den.'' This week, on their anniversary, they were living in Brooklyn, looking for work from the Foxes' kitchen.

title: Enscor Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a special gain of $250,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: New Glarus, Wis.
description: EACH Thursday, Omer Reese drives 500 miles to the dairy farms of southwestern Wisconsin, gathering cheeses to sell in Country Connection, his shop in Evanston, Ill., or to distribute in the Chicago area.

title: Marble Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $157,000 from termination of a pension plan.

title: Intelligent Bus Commun reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary tax benefit of $190,000. Shares outstanding reflects the effect of the exercise of 4,210,709 rights to purchase the company's common stock in a rights offering completed in July 1987.

title: A.T.&T. Planning 2 New Services
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would offer for the first time on a public network two services that would allow large business customers to transmit and receive information in a faster and more sophisticated fashion.

title: For Restaurants, It's D-Day on Smoking
description: Today is the moment of truth for New York City's restaurants: the city's new smoking law goes into effect. Some restaurateurs are tearing their hair out, while others are almost totally oblivious.

title: Deadly Contagion Over Teheran
description: Half of Teheran's six million inhabitants have evacuated the city to escape Iraq's indiscriminate missile attacks. Fearing Iraq may next fit its missiles with poison gas warheads, the other three million are preparing for one of the most abhorrent acts of warfare conceivable - attacking civilians with chemical weapons. Warfare in the Middle East has attained a new depth of savagery, for which outside powers as well as the belligerents are to blame. It's time to contain the furious escalation of terror before it flies beyond all control.

title: Knicks Win a 'Crucial' Game
description: Rick Pitino, the Knicks' coach, was more innovative than usual in his game plan tonight. After terming the game ''crucial'' to the Knick playoff hopes, Pitino showed the Philadelphia 76ers a different look in each quarter, and they all worked as the Knicks coasted to a 136-119 victory at the Spectrum.

title: A Red Letter Day
description: While the eyes of Muscovites are on military hardware in the May Day parade, officials of the United States Postal Service might consider a modest celebration of their own as Express Mail service is extended to the Soviet Union.

title: Bus Terminal Adding Police As Crime Rises
description: Responding to a steep rise in drug-related crime at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown Manhattan and to the growing ranks of homeless people living there, the Port Authority police have increased the size of the force there by more than 20 percent.

title: Philippines Renegade Hints at New Coup Try
description: The fugitive leader of an attempted coup hinted strongly today that he would try again.

title: Victims of Gulf War Treated at Queens Hospital
description: Five Kurds who were wounded in what Iran says was an Iraqi chemical attack on their town last month have been flown to a hospital in Queens.

title: Cigarette Maker Cuts Off Agency That Made Smoking-Ban TV Ads
description: RJR Nabisco Inc., the giant producer of tobacco and food products and the nation's fourth-largest advertiser, has taken all United States assignments away from one of its longtime advertising agencies, apparently because the agency created a television commercial announcing Northwest Airlines' new smoking ban.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Executive Changes column of Business Day on Monday about Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. described the promotion of Michael K. White incorrectly. He has been named chairman and chief executive of the company's largest division, Alexander & Alexander Inc.

title: A Researcher's Serendipity 50 Years Ago Brought Forth Teflon
description: Fifty years ago today, in the aftermath of a failed experiment on refrigerator gases, Roy Plunkett, a Du Pont researcher, discovered a white powder that had to be handled like a metal. Polytetrafluoroethylene came to be known as Teflon. It helped build the atom bomb and introduced the world to no-stick frying. Eventually, in the 1980's, journalists borrowed the name to describe President Reagan's ability to slough off criticism.

title: Wisconsin Sees a Warmer Dukakis
description: Something finally clicked. Ten days after an embarrassing defeat in Michigan's caucuses, a defeat that touched off widespread questions about Michael S. Dukakis's ability as a campaigner, the Massachusetts Governor turned back a determined challenge from the Rev. Jesse Jackson in the primary yesterday in Wisconsin, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll of voters.

title: The Pop Life
description: 'Fast Car' From Boston ''You got a fast car/I want a ticket anywhere,'' begins ''Fast Car,'' the first single from the debut album of Tracy Chapman, a 24-year-old singer and songwriter from Boston.

title: White House Can't Disregard Law on P.L.O.
description: To the Editor:

title: In These Reckless Times
description: I have an old friend who still smokes. She refuses to give it up, or cannot give it up. She doesn't know which. She hasn't many friends left, and, of course, doesn't deserve any at all, as I remind her when I visit.

title: Sensormatic Electronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
A Tough Choice on Health Care Costs
description: LEAD: Daniel Callahan, an ethicist and author of the book ''Setting Limits,'' has stirred sharp debate over his proposal for slowing the rise in health care costs by eliminating life-extending care for most people over the age of 75.

title: Initio Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Suspect in Murder of Drug Agent Is Seized in U.S. Trap in Honduras
description: Springing a trap at dawn in Honduras, the United States today arranged the capture and arrest of a key suspect in the murder of an American drug agent in Mexico, law enforcement officials said tonight.

title: Children's Discovery Centers of America reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The 1987 figures reflect a non-recurring change in the fourth quarter of $6.0 million as a result of the company's previously announced intention of disposing of 18 of its day care centers , excess office space, and other assets.

title: Oklahoma Officials at Odds Over Flying Confederate Flag
description: Gov. Henry Bellmon signed a resolution today requiring that the Confederate flag be flown over the state Capitol. But he said the flag pole would remain empty until he knows which of the three flags used by the Confederacy from 1861 to 1865 should be flown.

title: G.O.P. No Longer a Joke For Chicago Democrats
description: Several years ago, a Republican running for Mayor here was a clown, a professional prankster. The joke was his candidacy in a city so heavily Democratic.

title: The Burden-Sharing Numbers Racket
description: The confusion generated by statistics on our allies' contributions to defense is nothing short of amazing. Nobody wants to set the record straight because the record is embarrassing.

title: As Crowding in Jails Eases, New York City May Not Need Barge
description: With New York City jails less crowded than expected, the additional space provided by the prison barge docked on the East River will most likely not be needed, Correction Commissioner Richard J. Koehler said yesterday.

title: The Rest of the World Does Business by Payoff
description: To the Editor:

title: Eric A. Havelock, 84, Professor of Classics
description: Prof. Eric A. Havelock, a scholar of Greek philosophy and politics, died Monday at his home in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 84 years old.

title: Tacoma Journal; On Good Days, the Smell Can Hardly Be Noticed
description: Mayor Doug Sutherland has a standard way of dealing with all questions about the odd ''aroma of Tacoma,'' a tag this tough, industrial city of 158,000 has had for almost a century.

title: The Shanghai Cure
description: Tired of city crowds? Sick of being shoved on the sidewalk or jostled in the subway? As the weather gets warmer, the density seems ever more oppressive. New Yorkers who think they know density should only walk the streets of Shanghai.

title: Coals to Paris? A New Cooking School
description: SOME spice was added to the competition among Paris's cooking schools when the glass doors at 38 rue Cambon opened Tuesday. The new entry, the Ecole de Gastronomie Francaise Ritz-Escoffier, is in a newly excavated basement under the Hotel Ritz.

title: Crownamerica Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: b-Includes a gain of $500,000 from an accounting change for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Education; Challenge in Women's Course Roils U. of Washington Campus
description: When Pete Schaub could not get into a crowded business course at the University of Washington last quarter, he signed up for an introductory class on women's studies, thinking he might learn something about feminism.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Atlanta
description: LEAD: WHEN Jim Watterson wheels 14 to 15 loaded carts into a supermarket checkout line, people take note. Mr. Watterson is a professional food shopper, and his carts are typically filled with $1,200 in groceries. Under the name Market Express (404-998-SHOP, or for the mnemonically disinclined, 7467), he buys and delivers groceries to customers once a week.

title: Maker Gives Free Heart Medicine to Needy
description: A leading pharmaceutical company announced yesterday that it would give all its heart drugs free to patients who cannot afford them. The manufacturer, G. D. Searle & Company of Chicago, called on other drug companies to follow its lead.

title: Federated's Buyer Plans Divestitures
description: Just a few days after winning the battle for Federated Department Stores Inc., Robert Campeau, chairman of the Campeau Corporation, said yesterday that he would sell $4.4 billion of Federated's store assets to help pay for the merger.

title: Corrections
description: A report in Science Times yesterday about tests that measure success in everyday life misstated the affiliation of George O. Klemp, Jr. a psychologist. He is with Charles River Consulting Inc., in Boston. The concern has no connection to Charles River Associates, also of Boston.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Hawks 121, Bucks 110: Dominique Wilkins scored 34 of his 39 points in the first half last night, and Kevin Willis added 25 points to lead the Hawks at home. The victory was the sixth straight for the Hawks. Wilkins helped Atlanta open leads as large as 19 points in the first half. But John Lucas hit two 3-pointers as Milwaukee came back from a 17-point deficit in the fourth quarter to get within 5 with 1 minute 18 seconds to play. Glenn Rivers then sank a 3-pointer, his only field goal of the game, to put the Hawks up by 8, and the Bucks could get no closer. Ricky Pierce led Milwaukee with 21 points.(AP) Bullets 105, Bulls 94: John Williams scored 23 points to lead Washington to the victory in Chicago. The Bulls' loss ended a three-game winning streak. Moses Malone added 21 points for the Bullets, whose front-line players outscored the Bulls', 70-30. The victory was the third straight for the Bullets, who moved into eighth place in the Eastern Conference, a half-game behind seventh-place Cleveland, a half-game ahead of the Knicks and a full game ahead of Philadelphia. The Bulls' Michael Jordan led all scorers with 29 points. Chicago clinched a playoff spot earlier in the night when the Knicks beat the 76ers.(AP) Pacers 106, Cavaliers 105: Steve Stipanovich sank two free throws with two seconds remaining to give Indiana the victory in Indianapolis. The victory moved Indiana into sixth place in the Eastern Conference, half a game ahead of the Cavaliers. Wayman Tisdale led the Pacers with 27 points. Cleveland was led by Mike Sanders with 20 points. (AP) Nuggets 110, Rockets 97: Lafayette Lever grabbed a career-high 21 rebounds and scored 22 points to lead Denver to their ninth consecutive victory. The Nuggets pulled within four percentage points of first-place Dallas in the Midwest Division. Joe Barry Carroll scored 25 points for Houston.(AP) Tennis Phelps to Play Navratilova: Unseeded Terry Phelps advanced yesterday to the second round where she will meet top-seeded Martina Navratilova in the $300,000 Family Circle Magazine tournament at Hilton Head Island, S.C. Phelps of Larchmont, N.Y., defeated Dianne Van Rensburg of Zimbabwe by 6-2, 6-1 in continued first-round play. Opening play was suspended Monday because of rain. Phelps won the first game of both sets. She dominated most of the match with a fast-paced, two-handed backhand and precise passing shots. Phelps said she was glad her match against Navratilova is on clay. ''Her serve is really hard - I can't play tentative at all,'' she said. In other matches completed yesterday, Federica Bonsignori of Italy defeated Gisele Miro of Brazil, 3-6, 7-6, 7-5; Patricia Tarabini of Argentina defeated Katrina Adams of Chicago, 7-5, 6-3, and Karen Schimper of South Africa defeated Stacy Martin of Largo, Md., 6-3, 6-2.(AP) Grabb Beats Anger: Jim Grabb took advantage of his strong serve-and-volley game to beat Matt Anger, 7-6, 6-3, in an opening-round match of the $315,000 Volvo-Chicago championships.(AP)

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: REFRIGERATORS often yield a little of this and that: a few carrots left from the bunch bought to make stew or half an onion left from goodness knows what. To clean it all out, try making soups for quick eating and warm or cold comfort.

title: Review/Television; Church As Threat To State
description: The fundamentalists will get you if you don't watch out. ''Thy Kingdom Come . . . Thy Will be Done,'' a 90-minute public television special, says they're trying to impose a theocracy; good citizens must be warned. The program, on many public-television stations tonight, including Channel 13 at 10:30, is very solemn.

title: Helm Resources Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $457,000 from reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and a tax credit of $823,000 for the year, and the year also includes a $2,202,000 gain from common stock offering of Bamberger Polymers Inc. and a gain of $1,618,000 from a public offering by Bamberger Polymers. c-Net loss d-Includes an extraordinary loss of $38,000 for the quarter and a gain of $162,000 from debenture exchanges.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Cliff Branch, 39 years old, a National Football League wide receiver for 14 seasons, headed a list of 12 players named yesterday as territorial and at-large free-agent picks by the Los Angeles Cobras of the Arena Football League. . . . Virgil Hill of Grand Forks, N.D., the World Boxing Assocation light heavyweight champion, will defend his title on June 6 at the Las Vegas Hilton against Ramzi Hassan of San Diego, who has a 25-3 record.(AP)

title: Beeba's Creations reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income

title: Bank of Redlands reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Education; Lessons
description: It is safe to say that the earliest model of education in America was Indian and likely highly analytic.

title: Official Sees Problems on Contra Aid
description: The head of the Agency for International Development said today that he foresaw ''enormous logistical problems'' in delivering food, clothing and medical supplies to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Government Notables Urge Mild Sentence for Nofziger
description: Two Cabinet members and four members of Congress have written letters of support for Lyn Nofziger to the judge who will sentence the former Presidential aide for illegal lobbying.

title: Icahn Files Appeal On Texaco Plan
description: Texaco Inc.'s largest shareholder, Carl C. Icahn, has appealed a Federal bankruptcy court's approval of Texaco's reorganization plan, restating objections already rejected by the judge. Mr. Icahn's lawyer had said last month that an appeal was likely, and the plan will still take effect on schedule Thursday unless Mr. Icahn persuades the judge to halt the process, which will include $5.6 billion in payments to Texaco's creditors.

title: 2 Airlines Cut Certain Fares
description: Continental Airlines and Eastern Airlines initiated some very low but highly restrictive discount fares yesterday in a bid to stimulate leisure travel during the lull before summer.

title: Campaign Trail
description: Bush and Debating

title: DUKAKIS DEFEATS JACKSON HANDILY IN WISCONSIN VOTE
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts overwhelmed the Rev. Jesse Jackson in the Wisconsin Democratic primary today, giving his Presidential candidacy an important push forward and seriously impairing Mr. Jackson's momentum.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bankers Trust Co., a subsidiary of Bankers Trust New York Corp., said its international private bank unit had acquired Wells Fargo Bank's international private banking business. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Advances; Increasing the Speed of Film: Kodak's New Development
description: KEVIN HIGLEY is among the many people in upstate New York with vivid memories of the October evening in 1986 when East Rochester High School's football team upset Canandaigua High School, ending a winning streak that had lasted more than three years. Unlike the others, however, Mr. Higley remembers the dramatic game as a secret test of a new high-speed black and white film that the Eastman Kodak Company introduced this week.

title: American Festival Preserving Black Dance
description: The American Dance Festival has announced the creation of ''The Black Tradition in American Modern Dance,'' a three-year program to celebrate and preserve the contributions of black choreographers to American modern dance.

title: Jersey Clammers Ask Who Will Police Them
description: The commercial fishermen who rake hard clams from New Jersey's coastal rivers and bays are being forced into opposing camps by a dispute over who should police their activities.

title: Corning Glass Works reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $300,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $1.2 million and a gain of $14.2 million from an accounting change.

title: New Sun Models Blur Computer Distinctions
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., the fast-growing maker of engineering work stations, will move a step closer to the personal computer market Wednesday when it introduces a family of machines based on a microprocessor used in some advanced personal computers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I never did that before.'' - Rafael Santana, of the Yankees, after grounding into a triple play. [ B11:6. ]

title: KEY RATES
A Somnolent Spring
description: The cherry blossoms are visible, and the tourists are here in droves. But the Government seems to have departed the capital. The Congress is on Easter recess. President Reagan is at his ranch near Santa Barbara. Secretary of State George P. Shultz is in the Middle East. Secretary of Defense Frank C. Carlucci is in India. And Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d is about to take off for Latin America. At the White House, a secretary in the West Wing was asked who was running the Government. ''I am,'' she said, without missing a beat.

title: Trump to Pay $750,000 Fine
description: Donald J. Trump, the New York real estate developer, has agreed to pay a $750,000 fine to settle a lawsuit charging that his 1986 acquisition of stock in the Holiday Corporation and the Bally Manufacturing Corporation violated Federal disclosure rules. The settlement between the

title: Review/Music; Trying Out Textures And Solos
description: Ushio Torikai, a young Japanese composer now living in New York, offered an evening of her recent music Monday night at the Dance Theater Workshop, repeated last night, under the rather giddy title ''Ohhhh New Yorrrk!!!'' Miss Torikai has a wide-ranging musical imagination, and she is a most appealing performer on her various instruments, her face screwed up to a level of concentration wherein every emotion seems revealed. Her music on Monday had many felicitous moments, and one piece was very good. But most if it sounded more like ideas for music more than music itself.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON NEW AND RENEWABLE SOURCES OF ENERGY - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. COUNCIL FOR NAMIBIA - 3 P.M.

title: Boxing Notebook; Tyson Inner Circle Is Feeling a Strain
description: Since the death of Jim Jacobs, co-manager of Mike Tyson, the prime speculations of boxing men concern rumors of conflict and unrest in Tyson's inner circle.

title: Air Ball Comes to Olympic Stadium In Montreal
description: Prof. Bob Moore of the Physics Department of McGill University calculated today that Darryl Strawberry's skyrocket home run on opening day would have carried about 525 feet if it hadn't struck the rim of lights just below the roof in Olympic Stadium.

title: CSX Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after a $294 million loss from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes. The company said the latest quarter results principally reflect lower realty and energy operating income which more than offset stronger transportation results.

title: U.S. Effort to Remove Noriega Begins to Irk Latins
description: Latin American leaders who were initially quiet about the Reagan Administration's efforts to force a change in Panama's leadership are now expressing reservations about the policy, according to diplomats and analysts.

title: For Jackson, Good Will, But Not Enough Votes
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson earned an enormous amount of good will among white voters in Wisconsin, persuading tens of thousands to take him seriously as a candidate. But when Primary Day finally arrived, the positive feelings of many of them did not translate into votes for Mr. Jackson in Wisconsin's Presidential primary.

title: U.N. Attributes 170 Deaths To Thai Refusals of Refugees
description: United Nations refugee officials say at least 170 Vietnamese boat people have died off the Thai coast since the end of January after their boats were pushed off or intentionally rammed by Thai police, navy or fishing vessels.

title: Review/Film; Exotic Old Shots Show World Being Conquered
description: To watch ''From the Pole to the Equator'' is to feel that one has seen a ghost - many ghosts, human and animal, from places all over the globe. The spectral quality of this documentary is overwhelming. Two Italian film makers, Yervant Gianikian and Angela Ricci Lucchi, have drawn upon turn-of-the-century film from regions that were then fabulously exotic - the Arctic, India, Africa and less remote but equally striking settings in the Dolomites and the Caucasus - and assembled it at a sleepwalker's pace, with changeable color tints and a humming electronic score. The result offers haunting glimpses of a world in the process of being conquered.

title: Geneve Capital Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment losses of $2,512,374 and realized investment gains of $1,242,399 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a tax credit of $1,261,360 for both the quarter and year. c-Net income d-Includes realized investment gains of $1,502,151 for the quarter and $11,113,718 for the year.

title: Sports People; Robinson in Tourney
description: David Robinson, the all-America center who played at Navy, will play for the United States Armed Forces All-Stars in the Amateur Basketball Association's national tournament from April 14-17 in Colorado Springs.

title: Oakland, Calif.
description: RESTAURANT patrons are being treated to some artistic fare these days, not all of it edible. On April 20, for example, the Early Music Society will play its baroque flutes and virginals at the Bay Wolf restaurant in Oakland for its sixth annual fund-raising dinner.

title: New Principal Calms a Troubled High School
description: In just two months, Park West High School in the Clinton section of Manhattan has been transformed from a center of violence and fear to a place of learning and calm.

title: Advertising; Model Magazine Goes To Favara, Skahan
description: Favara, Skahan, Tabaczyk, in business for about four months, has picked up its second piece of business, Model magazine. The budget for advertising and promotion will be just over $2 million.

title: Books of The Times; Garcia Marquez Novel Covers Love and Time
description: Love in the Time of Cholera By Gabriel Garcia Marquez Translated by Edith Grossman 348 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Oh, to Dine in Saugus, Mass.
description: A 68-FOOT-HIGH neon cactus towers over the suburban prairie along Route 1 north of Boston, a commercial badlands of mini-malls, muffler shops and markdown liquor marts. This startlingly garish landmark beckons hungry passers-by to the Hilltop Steak House in Saugus, Mass., America's largest restaurant, both in number of customers served and sales volume.

title: Debut for an East Side Arts Center With a Definite Tilt to the French
description: Concert life on New York's East Side has pretty much been confined to isolated outposts. Now a new one is joining the 92d Street Y on Lexington Avenue and the Metropolitan Museum a few blocks away: the Florence Gould Hall, a compact and carefully designed center for concerts, dance, lectures and film built by the French Institute/Alliance Francaise at 55 East 59th Street.

title: Market Place; Profit Surprise Gives ARCO Lift
description: THERE is nothing like a pleasant earnings surprise - for example, management telling analysts that profits will be better than expected - to help the price of a stock in an uncertain market.

title: ONE SOVIET PAPER REBUKES ANOTHER
description: Pravda rebuked another Soviet newspaper today for publishing what it called a ''manifesto'' by Mikhail S. Gorbachev's ideological opponents.

title: US Shelter Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; Cable TV Ad Bureau Calls U.S. 'Cable Ready'
description: The Cable Television Advertising Bureau, which believes its medium has truly come of age, is prepared to begin a print and cable TV ad campaign Monday. The theme line will be ''America is cable ready,'' with the word ''cable'' always printed in red.

title: The Rescue of a U.S. Chip Company
description: A year ago the demise of Micron Technology seemed imminent. One of the country's few manufacturers of the most commonly used memory chips, Micron was a victim of competitive pricing by Japanese semiconductor manufacturers and a market glut.

title: Quality Food Centers reports earnings for Qtr to March 19
Albany Legislators Decide to Pass Parts of Budget
description: After a day of political maneuvering that would have made Machiavelli proud, New York legislative leaders said tonight that they would pass portions of the state's $28.4 billion budget to avert a shutdown of the bureaucracy. But they failed to resolve crucial issues that have already delayed passage of the budget four days beyond the legal deadline.

title: Hewlett-Packard Sets 7 New Models
description: Expanding its product line at both the high and low ends, the Hewlett-Packard Company introduced seven new computers in its Spectrum series, based on a common architecture using reduced instruction set computing, or RISC. The company also introduced two entry-level business computers using its traditional design, as well as a high-speed disk drive interface using fiber-optic technology.

title: Winfield Rejects Trade
description: He was in their opening-day lineup yesterday, but the Yankees apparently remain intent on trying to trade Dave Winfield. A deal with the Baltimore Orioles fell through, and now one with the Houston Astros didn't get past the talking stage this week because the right fielder rejected it.

title: Hanoi Is Seeking Talks On Political Prisoners
description: Vietnam today invited the Reagan Administration to open negotiations on the resettlement in the United States of several thousand recently released political prisoners.

title: Review/Theater; 'Like Them That Dream,' About Racial Injustice
description: Lanyard A. Williams comes on lightly and likably as Sparrow, street artist and sidewalk philosopher, in ''Like Them That Dream,'' Edgar White's new play at the Negro Ensemble Company. This blithe spirit, who is determined ''to paint our race, to paint our dreams,'' seems to have flown airily from Johannesburg to ''New York, city of miracles,'' indifferent to bad weather and the slingshots of life. If a sparrow can be footloose, he's the one. It's a pleasure to hear him sweet-talk a cute woman (''Your eyes are the difference between the way the world works and the way it really is'') into bed. ''We passed like them that dream,'' he tells Sharon. ''Now we're coming together again.''

title: Bridge; An Improvised Partnership Found Temporary Success at the Spring Nationals
description: When the Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League began in Buffalo last month there was a surprising demand for substitutes who would play a few deals.

title: INSIDE
description: Doubts on Panama Policy

title: Let the People's Nickels Pay for Recycling
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Finds Bias in Zoning In L.I. Town
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the Town of Huntington, L.I., ''perpetuated segregation'' through a zoning ordinance that confined the construction of apartments to an area populated predominantly by minority-group residents.

title: Baseball; Cubs Win in 13; 7 Homers Tie Mark
description: Manny Trillo's 13th-inning sacrifice fly gave the Chicago Cubs a 10-9 victory over Atlanta tonight in an opener that included a controversial interference call on the Braves and a record-tying seven home runs by both clubs.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Traveling Chefs

title: Judging the Hiring Upswing Baseball's Minority Hiring: Judging the Upswing
description: One year ago tonight, the words that shook baseball were spoken on national television.

title: Advertising; World Style Magazine Sets Debut
description: WORLD STYLE is the name of a new quarterly women's fashion magazine scheduled to make its debut on Aug. 28, with an anticipated circulation of 3.3 million in the top 25 markets.

title: Treasury Issues End Up Slightly
description: After a late flurry of bargain hunting, most prices of Treasury notes and bonds ended slightly higher yesterday despite the Federal Reserve's continued tolerance of tighter credit and rising short-term rates.

title: Sports of The Times; Cheers and Candy For an Author
description: ALONG the first-base line during the introductions, Dave Winfield glowed in the longest and loudest public ovation in the history of American literature. But then Ernest Hemingway and William Faulkner never wore a Yankee uniform.

title: Planters Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports People; Horford Seeks Draft
description: Tito Horford, the University of Miami's sophomore center, said yesterday he was making himself eligible for this year's National Basketball Association draft. ''I just want to play in the N.B.A.,'' said the 7-foot-1-inch, 245-pound Horford. ''I believe in myself a lot. I think I can be a good one.'' The 22-year-old Horford, a native of the Dominican Republic, averaged 14.2 points and 9 rebounds last year for the Hurricanes. Coach Bill Foster said he was surprised by Horford's decision. Horford said he has had no contact with agents or anyone connected with the N.B.A.(AP)

title: Millicom Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a pretax gain of $13.5 million on the sale of marketable securities. c-Net income and includes a pretax gain of $145.1 million on the sale of cellular interests, principally the company's equity interest in Racal-Millicom Ltd.

title: Review/Film; British Satire Takes On Capitalism and Takeovers
description: ''Mr. Farris,'' says an apprehensive Felicity Stubbs, who's the entire quality-control department at Chumley's Chocolates (est. 1887), ''this new batch of chocolates has no nutritional value whatsoever.''

title: Investors May Seek Control of Damon
description: An investment group led by the American Magnetics Corporation and Ballantrae Partners L.P. has purchased a 10 percent stake in the Damon Corporation and said it might seek control of the laboratory instrument maker based in Needham Heights, Mass.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Listening to the Consumer Again
description: What do such classic products as the Pyrex measuring cup and the Samsonite garment bag have in common?

title: United Stationers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Koppers Bid Extension
description: Beazer P.L.C. of Britain is expected to extend the deadline of its tender offer in its hostile takeover attempt of the Koppers Company, people familiar with the deal said last night. The $1.85 billion tender offer is scheduled to expire tomorrow.

title: ISRAELIS PREVENT GUERRILLA ATTACK
description: Israeli soldiers prevented two guerrilla bands from entering Israeli-held territory early today, killing two armed men who tried to cross the northern border, an army spokesman said.

title: For Pieds-Noirs, the Anger Endures
description: In the mosaic of French electoral politics, minorities count and are cultivated. There are the loyalist citizens of France's overseas territories like Reunion and Guadeloupe, who tend to vote conservative. There are disaffected minority peoples like the Bretons, Basques and Corsicans.

title: Review/Music; Soprano With Eight Cellos and Harp
description: Lucy Shelton is a singer with a spelunker's profound curiosity and daring. The soprano loves to go adventuring in rarely explored caverns of the song literature, old and new. When, for example, did you last hear an entire program for soprano, harp and one to eight cellos? Miss Shelton offered just that on Monday evening in the second of her three recitals this season at Town Hall, where she threw light in crannies occupied by obscure 18th- and 17th-century composers (Joseph Hector Fiocco, Domenico Gabrieli and Bernardo Gaffi). Leaping across the 19th century directly into our own, she also investigated songs of Ravel, Warren Benson, Henze and Villa-Lobos, each with her characteristic mixture of intelligence, good taste and vocal purity.

title: Celina Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an investment loss of $21,500 for the quarter and an investment gain of $154,801 for the year. c-Net income d-Includes a gain of $1,676,527 from a pension fund termination for both the quarter and year, and an investment gain of $96,157 and an investment loss of $202,787 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: At Bloomingdale's, a Tap Water Toast
description: At Bloomingdale's annual spring party last night, there were klieg lights on Lexington Avenue, movie stars, fashion designers and social types.

title: Sports People; Byrnes Is Named
description: Robert J. Byrnes, a 1968 graduate of Manhattan College who for the last 13 years served as director of labor relations for a construction and engineering firm in Cleveland, yesterday was named as the athletic director at his alma mater. Byrnes, a former club-football player for the Jaspers and a high school athletic director and football coach at Queen of Peace High School in North Arlington, N.J., before joining the Morrison-Knudsen Company in 1975, replaced Jack Powers. After 10 years as athletic director, Powers will become the executive director of the National Invitation Tournament, succeeding Peter Carlesimo, who is retiring from that post. Byrnes will be concerned with returning Manhattan, an N.C.A.A. Division I school with strong academic standards, to levels of athletic achievement it has known in the past. Last year, Manhattan finished seventh in the eight-team Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference in a combined rating of all varsity sports for the Commissioner's Cup.

title: Sports People; Sherrill Responds
description: Jackie Sherrill, the athletic director and football coach at Texas A&M, said yesterday the Aggies hope to answer quickly the National Collegiate Athletic Association's allegations of 31 rules violations and 7 procedural infractions that were announced last Monday. ''We've gone through the process before,'' said Sherrill after releasing the letter, in which the N.C.A.A. charges were outlined. ''We have an outside firm that will go out and interview people.'' Sherrill said that the school has until the end of June to prepare its answer, but that he did not believe it would take that long ro respond. Sherrill said that the procedural violations were not major and that no academic violations were cited in the 38-point letter. (AP)

title: DOC Optics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Sales represent systemwide sales.

title: Cintas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Bangor Hydro-Electric Co reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $1,233,661 from the writedown of investments in Seabrook Nuclear units.

title: Rhoden and Yankees Sparkle in Opening Game
description: The sun broke through early and never left. It was bright and warm and soothing, and when Rick Rhoden threw the pitch that opened the Yankees' 86th season yesterday, it seemed to put all the turmoil behind.

title: Executive at Ticor Gets Expanded Duties
description: Ticor, the Los Angeles-based insurance holding company, said yesterday that it had named William T. Seitz president of its nationwide title-insurance operation.

title: Advertising; D.M.B.&B. Wins Denny's Restaurants
description: The Los Angeles office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles has won the $20 million Denny's restaurant account, which had been handled for 10 years by Foote, Cone & Belding, Los Angeles.

title: Better Bedfellows in Albany
description: New York State's lieutenant governor earns $85,000 a year for a job with little responsibility. With no disrespect to the incumbent, Stan Lundine, good government would hardly suffer if the post were abolished. The secretary of state or a leader of the State Legislature could be designated to fill a sudden gubernatorial vacancy, as is done in several other states.

title: ARIZONA IS FACING A LEGAL QUESTION
description: The conviction and removal of Evan Mecham from office in the first gubernatorial impeachment trial in almost 60 years has put state officials in a legal maze.

title: Sports People; Nelson to Coach Again
description: Don Nelson, who was twice honored as the National Basketball Association's coach of the year during an 11-year career with the Milwaukee Bucks, will return to coaching next season. Nelson, who resigned his Milwaukee post last May 27 to become the executive vice president and general manager of the Golden State Warriors, was named yesterday to succeed George Karl as the Warrior coach. Nelson will retain his front-office positions. Karl resigned last March 23 when the team's 16-48 record was the second worst in the league. Ed Gregory will be the interim coach for the remainder of the season. Nelson, who is 47 years old and who played 14 seasons in the N.B.A., had a record of 540 victories and 344 losses as coach of the Bucks, who reached the playoffs nine times with him. He was named the league's top coach in 1983 and 1985. The Warriors made the playoffs under Karl last season, but have been near the bottom of the Pacific Division for most of this season.(AP)

title: Los Angeles Times Names Executive Editor
description: C. Shelby Coffey 3d, who spent most of his career at The Washington Post, will become executive editor of The Los Angeles Times next Monday.

title: List of CUNY Events
description: Hundreds of events at colleges in the City University system, many of them free, are listed in a free calendar published by the City University of New York. The listing covers this month and next. To obtain a copy, write to the Office of Community Relations, City University of New York, 535 East 80th Street, New York, N.Y. 10021.

title: Ida Sturz, Travel Consultant, 87
description: Ida Sturz, a retired travel consultant, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 87 years old.

title: Education; Is There an Optimum Class Size for Teaching?
description: Some teachers can stand before 100 juvenile delinquents and command such attention that the scratch of a pen would draw stares of reproach. Other teachers are overwhelmed by a handful of honor students.

title: Hosposable Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: 5 Springsteen Dates At Madison Sq. Garden
description: Tentative dates have been announced for five shows by Bruce Springsteen at Madison Square Garden. Columbia Records, the company for which Mr. Springsteen records, announced yesterday through a spokesman, Steve Peckman, that Mr. Springsteen and the E Street Band would perform at the arena on May 16, 18, 19, 22 and 23, as part of the ''Tunnel of Love'' tour. Beth Nicholson of the Madison Square Garden booking office said that the dates were tentative and that ''no contract has been signed,'' so no date has been set for ticket sales.

title: On Dusty Africa Hill, Easter Draws Multitude
description: Jonathan Chauke gestured toward the mass of more than a million people sprawling on a dusty hillside.

title: Graying of America Prompts New Highway Safety Efforts
description: At the center for the elderly in suburban Berwyn, Ill., Philip Grosshenrich was dispensing safety tips this week to a class of older drivers: Plan your trips for daylight hours. Be aware that arthritis medication can cause drowsiness. Remember that driving too slowly can be as dangerous as driving too fast.

title: Corrections
description: A dog-show listing in some editions of SportsMonday this week for results of the Riverhead Kennel Club at Uniondale, L.I., misidentified the winner. The best in show was Ch. Willow Wind Pardon Me Boys, a terrier owned by Maggie Rodenbach and David Ramsey.

title: Amid Artworks, Refuge for Smokers
description: As New York City's anti-smoking law takes effect today, a glass-enclosed, tree-shaded oasis for smokers continues to exist in the heart of Manhattan.

title: Spain Gives a U.S. Photographer 6 Years in Drug Trafficking Case
description: An American freelance photographer was convicted today of drug trafficking and was sentenced to six years and one day in prison despite a personal plea on his behalf by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d.

title: Anyang Journal; In Korean Factory, a Dream Is Reduced to Ashes
description: Past the rows of charred sewing machines, amid the smoke-blackened piles of timber and cinder blocks, lie the keepsakes of the women who worked and died here. These were among the remains of the Green Hill Textile Company: a snapshot of a young girl smiling in a field of red flowers, a magazine clipping of a singer, a letter from a young man in the army.

title: Berkeley Alumni: A Gang's All Here
description: LEAD: BY day, and most nights, they seem like any other young New York professionals: smart, competitive, in love with the city and its energy, watchful of both the stock market and, on crowded streets, their wallets.

title: Big Board Offers Rule Aimed at Curbing Front-Running
description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday proposed a rule aimed at curtailing a form of trading between the exchange and futures markets known as front-running.

title: Morton Pepper, Lawyer In Manhattan, 81, Dies
description: Morton Pepper, a Manhattan lawyer for more than half a century and former president of the Jewish Guild for the Blind, died of a heart attack Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: WINE TALK
description: THERE is an old saw in the literary game that goes like this: ''I'm sorry to have written so much, but I didn't have time to make it short.'' The same adage could be frequently and most profitably applied to the composition of wine lists.

title: Minding Appearances
description: It seemed as if the Reagan Administration was instituting a dress code last month, at least for the purposes of identification passes, when a 17-year employee of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms was dismissed because he refused to don a necktie for his I.D..

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 6, 1988
description: Companies

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Pistons Wake Up And Beat the Nets
description: For the Detroit Pistons, it was a good time to play the Nets. After four losses in a row, Detroit was happy to make the trip to New Jersey.

title: RTE Stock Soars On Mark IV Offer
description: Mark IV Industries has offered $236 million for the RTE Corporation, an electrical equipment manufacturer in Brookfield, Wis. After the cash tender offer was made in a newspaper advertisement today, RTE's stock jumped $5.875 a share, to $37.375, on the New York Stock Exchange, where its 18.7 percent gain was the largest of the day. RTE told Reuters tonight that it was urging its shareholders to take no action.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Panel Suggests A Leaner Look For U.S. Meat
description: In an effort to improve health by reducing the amount of fat, cholesterol and calories in the American diet, the National Academy of Sciences today called for substantial changes in the way cattle and other livestock are raised and graded.

title: First Commercial Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Optelecom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Heilig-Meyers Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Calmat To Sell 2 Businesses
description: In a restructuring to avert a takeover by a New Zealand investment firm, the Calmat Company said today that it intended to sell its cement and real estate operations and distribute the estimated $800 million in proceeds to shareholders.

title: Sports People; Driesell Returns
description: Lefty Driesell, the former basketball coach at Maryland, will reportedly be named today as the coach at James Madison. Driesell, whose pending appointment was reported in today's issue of The Daily-News Record of Harrisonburg, Va., would become the Dukes' fourth full-time coach since the Virginia school began its men's program in 1969. He would succeed John Thurston, who resigned during the 1987-88 season.

title: Advertising; 40,000 Free Magazines From Business Traveler
description: Business Traveler International, a new magazine, has mailed out 40,000 copies to likely subscribers and hopes to develop a circulation of that size that is half paid.

title: Penny Wise on Rikers Island
description: A recent inmate uprising made clear that New York City's jail complex on Rikers Island remains vulnerable to riot. Even though the crowding that has troubled the system may be abating, jail management remains hostage to a complex of tormenting legal, political and financial factors. Rikers managers still need all the help they can get. If the Koch administration went along with a modest budget increase, the jail could gain much from an administrative practice called unit management.

title: Good Riddance to Governor Mecham
description: ''Well, they don't like my politics,'' Evan Mecham said after the Arizona Senate convicted him of misconduct Monday and removed him as Governor. ''So we've finished a political trial.''

title: Devils-Islanders Matchups
description: Hockey people like to say the playoffs are different from the regular season. Certainly, the intangibles gained from playoff experience can be important, and the Devils know that. But the Devils, who play the Islanders in the opening round of the playoffs starting tonight, also say that their last few regular-season games gave them something like playoff experience.

title: Advertising; People
description: John Ferries has been promoted to executive vice president at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles/International Division, effective June 30.

title: White House Can't Disregard Law on P.L.O.; Status of Nonstates
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Advances by 16.91 Points, to 1,997.51
description: After an opening rally lost momentum, stocks rallied late yesterday to close higher in light trading, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 16.91 points, to 1,997.51.

title: Armed Guards Protect Drug-Plagued Building
description: For 19 months New York City has been paying a private armed security service to guard a city-owned, five-story walk-up on the Upper West Side to ward off drug traffic and crime by screening all visitors.

title: Opening Is Postponed For the Musical 'Carrie'
description: The opening of ''Carrie,'' a musical based on the Stephen King novel, has been changed from May 4 to May 12, a spokesman for the show, Jim Baldassare, said yesterday. Previews of the Royal Shakespeare Company-Friedrich Kurz production are now to begin April 28 at the Virginia Theater.

title: Lord and Einstein Ordered Not to Recruit Old Clients
description: The chairman and the president of the Lord, Einstein, O'Neill & Partners advertising agency were barred yesterday from pursuing clients or employees of Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, the agency they quit last month.

title: Waiting in Line for Life
description: When the issue is a subway token or a movie ticket, having to stand in line is only a bore, and the person who jumps the line is only a nuisance. For the thousands of Americans waiting months, even years, for organ transplants, the wait is a nightmare and line-jumping is a matter of life and death.

title: Inching Toward a 'Middle Way' on Tibet
description: Abruptly, China has shifted back toward conciliation in its approach to the continuing national grievances of Tibet. This week it invited the Dalai Lama, whom it has blamed for recent bloody unrest, to return to live in Tibet if he ceases to call for independence.

title: Summagraphics reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After tax loss carryforwards of $489,518 for the quarter and $979,402 for the 9 months. c-After tax loss carryforwards of $214,000 for the quarter and $355,592 for the 9 months.

title: U.S. Clears Vital Gyroscope for Indian Jet Fighter
description: In a major step reflecting increased military cooperation with India, Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci announced clearance today for New Delhi to purchase a highly advanced American gyroscope for use in production of a new jet fighter plane.

title: Bell Goes 5 for 5 as Blue Jays Beat Royals
description: George Bell went 5 for 5, and Pat Borders had three hits and drove in five runs in his first major league game as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Kansas City Royals tonight, 11-4.

title: Hijackers Free 32 Hostages From Kuwaiti Plane
description: The hijackers of a Kuwait Airlines jetliner released 32 more passengers in Iran early today, but warned that those remaining would be in danger if Kuwait failed to meet the hijackers' demands, Iran's official press agency reported.

title: Day Care Is Subject Of P.B.S. Programs
description: NEXT week, public television stations will extend their programming beyond the airwaves and into communities with a multifaceted look at day care.

title: Salaries Now Top $300 Million
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers spent lavishly and uncharacteristically during the winter in overhauling their disappointing team, but they still fell short of the Yankees in the opening-day payroll standing.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: State Panel Censures A Judge in Queens For Ethical Abuses
description: One of New York City's more powerful judges, Surrogate Louis D. Laurino of Queens, was censured yesterday for ethical misconduct by a state agency that investigates the judiciary.

title: Crescott Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $1,300,000 and a gain of $6,253,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and after a gain of $1,175,000 from discontinued operations. In the latest year there was a $2,934,000 loss from continuing operations which included an $811,000 loss related to the disposal in 1987 of certain unprofitable divisions. In 1986 there was a loss of $7,436,000 from continuing operations, which included the writedown of vending divisions which resulted in a net charge of $2,500,000. The 1986 results have been restated to reflect certain operations as discontinued operations.

title: U.S. Said to Weigh International Drug Force
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States was considering creation of a multinational police force to restore order in Latin American nations where government operations are threatened by narcotics trafficking.

title: National Community Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The company said the year-ago figures were restated to reflect the adoption of FASB No. 91 and the 4-for-1 stock split in May 1987.

title: Chandler Criticized
description: Some University of Kentucky students, upset over a racial epithet by A. B. (Happy) Chandler, a former baseball commissioner, have called for him to apologize for the remark or resign from the board of trustees. Chandler, a two-time Kentucky Governor and United States Senator who was commissioner in 1947 when Jackie Robinson broke baseball's color barrier, said Tuesday during a committee's discussion of the university's 1985 decision to dispose of its investments in South Africa, ''You know Zimbabwe's all nigger now. There aren't any whites.'' Chandler, 89 years old, said he did not plan to apologize unless asked to do so by the university president, David Roselle, or Gov. Wallace Wilkinson. About 40 students representing six organizations marched to the administration building to meet with Roselle, who told the group that the school ''completely and totally repudiates'' what Chandler said. Wilkinson, who appointed Chandler to a voting position on the university governing board, said that he would recommend to Chandler that he apologize and explain the remark.(AP)

title: Cabinet Approves Effort to Widen Trade With Soviet in 5 Categories
description: On the eve of a visit to Moscow, Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. has won Cabinet approval of an initiative to stimulate trade with the Soviet Union, Administration officials said today.

title: Dukakis Now Front-Runner After Triumph in Wisconsin
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's triumph in the Wisconsin primary gave the Democratic Party a widely acknowledged front-runner today for the first time in the contorted 1988 Democratic Presidential campaign.

title: The Husband of a Smoker Testifies On Her Death From Lung Cancer
description: His voice breaking with emotion, Antonio Cipollone told a jury in Federal court today how his wife died in his arms in 1984 after an excruciating bout with cancer that followed 40 years of heavy cigarette smoking.

title: Diagonal Data reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said results for 1987 include two companies acquired in June 1987.

title: Refusal by Robins
description: The A. H. Robins Company said it was not obligated to pay $34 million in breakup fees to the Rorer Group Inc. as a result of Robins's decision to merge with the American Home Products Corporation instead of Rorer. Rorer, based in Fort Washington, Pa., contends that, under its earlier merger pact with Robins, the Richmond pharmaceutical company agreed to pay it a $25 million breakup fee if their merger fell through. Rorer says Robins also owes it slightly more than $9 million for out-of-pocket expenses stemming from the talks.

title: A Social Responsibility
description: To The Home Section:

title: Automated Language Proessing Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Maryland Gives New Life to Radar Detectors
description: Ronald James said he drove with a radar detector in his car for years without an accident. His insurance company canceled his policy anyway, citing its rule against underwriting drivers who own the devices.

title: Bee Quarantine Is Set To Contain Killer Mite
description: The Federal Government has quarantined bees in 13 states to help prevent the spread of a tiny killer mite that threatens the nation's bee industry, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Review/Concert; 3 Youth Ensembles at Carnegie Hall
description: Midamerica Productions is an enterprising concern that brings young choruses and orchestras from around the country to New York for concerts showcasing their accomplishments. Often, the performances involve collaborations with young soloists -some fairly established, some winners of Midamerica's competitions. And at times, the visiting ensembles join forces with a New York pickup orchestra, conducted by Midamerica's director, Peter Tiboris. At the concert offered Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall, however, the three visiting ensembles were on their own, with their own conductors taking turns on the podium.

title: General Instrument Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $5,721,000 and $9,261,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and losses on disposal of discontinued operations of $91,556,000 for the quarter and $89,600,000 for the year.

title: Pressure of Playoff Rattles Schoenfeld
description: Jim Schoenfeld had never coached in the Stanley Cup playoffs, and he felt the pressure late in the second period tonight of his and the Devils' postseason debut.

title: Knights of Malta (and U.S.) Picking New Chief
description: Princes, barons and some mere master knights are gathering here for a sacred conclave that will elect the next leader of an organization that is medieval in origin but increasingly American in membership.

title: Protect Every Lunette, Every Curlicue?
description: Actors and preservationists won a major fight recently when New York City's Board of Estimate landmarked 27 Broadway theaters. Unless a sensible compromise is reached on the designation and restoration of all interior surface decorations, however, the victory could turn out to be hollow.

title: Events: Texas Tapestries and Finnish Art
