description: Needlepoint Tapestries, New School for Social Research, fourth floor gallery, 66 West 12th Street; 212-741-5687.

title: The Architect's-Eye View of New York
description: AS much as Chamber of Commerce commissioners, mayors and real-estate moguls, architects tend to be loquacious boosters of their cities. After all, they design them. Architects can often be identified on city streets by their craned necks, looking corniceward. They are known to marvel at architectural minutiae: the fact that the cast-iron facades of SoHo, for instance, are made of ''the same material as a frying pan,'' in the words of Alta Indelman, an architect with Davis, Brody & Associates.

title: China Is Said to Arrest 203 for Panda Poaching
description: China has arrested 203 people for illegally hunting the endangered giant panda and recovered 146 pelts, representing about one in seven of all pandas alive at the last count, the World Wildlife Fund said today.

title: Wicker Old and New
description: ELEVEN years ago, Pamela Scurry had an idea whose time had come: buying old wicker furniture, fixing it up and selling it. So in what was then considered the upper reaches of Madison Avenue, she opened Pamela Scurry's Wicker Garden.

title: GORBACHEV PARLEY WITH AFGHAN CHIEF HINTED BY SOVIET
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev flew to Soviet Central Asia today, apparently for a meeting with the Afghan President, as signs persisted that an agreement was near on the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan.

title: Advertising; RJR Flap Not the First In Cigarette Ad History
description: The news that RJR Nabisco had stripped business from an agency for being involved in a television commercial against smoking caused at least one former adman to remember a similar incident in his own past.

title: Power Failure Delays Rail Service in Jersey
description: A power failure on the Amtrak railway lines between Philadelphia and New York disrupted service for almost 30,000 passengers on Amtrak, N.J. Transit and PATH yesterday morning. The manager of public affairs at Amtrak, R. Clifford Black, said the problem had apparently been caused at 7:39 A.M. when a metal chain or strap on a freight train came in contact with a power feeder cable on a railway bridge over the Delaware River near Philadelphia, tripping protective circuits at electric substations nearly 70 miles to the north. Full power was not restored until sometime after 8:20 A.M., he said.

title: Personal Health
description: ''A merry heart doeth good like a medicine,'' it says in Proverbs, 17:22. Similarly, Reader's Digest reminds us monthly, ''Laughter is the best medicine.''

title: Thomas Shearman, 94; Newspaper Publisher
description: Thomas B. Shearman, a newspaper publisher who crusaded against gambling in the 1950's, died after a long illness Monday at his home here. He was 94 years old.

title: Scientific Technologies reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $334,000.

title: Life in the 30's
description: THIS is a story about Clown. (''A whole story about Clown?'' asked his owner, age 4, sounding just like Christopher Robin in the Winnie-the-Pooh books.

title: Redgrave-Orchestra Case Heard by Full Appeals Panel
description: Vanessa Redgrave's lawyer told a Federal appeals court today that the actress deserved damages from the Boston Symphony Orchestra because her civil rights were violated when it canceled her performances after receiving threats of anti-Redgrave protests.

title: LaRouche Lawyers Seek North's Notebooks
description: Lawyers for Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. have subpoenaed the personal notebooks of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the former White House aide who Mr. LaRouche says directed a Government plot to ruin him.

title: Vornado Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $1,890,000.

title: Review/Dance; Joel Hall's Personal, Eclectic Style
description: The Joel Hall Dancers, who opened a week's engagement at the Joyce Theater Tuesday, are an engaging company. The men are standout dancers. And Mr. Hall's attractively personal style raises questions that are intriguing, though occasionally a little daunting.

title: Accused Killers Suspected in Robbery
description: Three of the four men charged with murdering a rookie police officer in Queens in February are suspected of having been the armed robbers who stole $7,000 in cash from a Queens warehouse last October, law-enforcement authorities said yesterday.

title: Talking Deals; Developer Plays A Waiting Game
description: LARRY SILVERSTEIN, the New York City real estate investor whose 7 World Trade Center skyscraper in lower Manhattan remains 86 percent empty, seems almost unwilling to rent out his building - except on his terms.

title: Exit Card for Afghan Officials
description: A card that appears to provide for the evacuation of Afghan officials in the event of a Soviet military withdrawal has been obtained by Freedom House, a New York-based organization monitoring political and human rights.

title: Hamdija Pozderac Yugoslav Official, 64
description: Hamdija Pozderac, who resigned as Vice President of Yugoslavia last September in a major financial scandal, died of a stroke today, the state press agency Tanyug said. He was 64 years old.

title: Study Finds Children Know Computer's Parts, Not Whole
description: Most American students have used computers and like doing it but cannot answer questions about computer programming, a study says.

title: Santo Domingo Journal; At 80, the Master Builder Is Busy (and Boastful)
description: In his first three elected terms as President, Joaquin Balaguer went on a building spree that forever changed the face of this country. He laid down roads and bridges, schools and housing projects, libraries, museums, theaters, parks and sports complexes.

title: International Lease Finance Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a $3,731,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Accord on Aid In Albany Effort To Pass Budget
description: Senate Republicans said late tonight that they had agreed to a proposal to increase school aid by helping districts with their asbestos removal costs, a move that was expected to clear the way for an agreement on the state's full $28.4 billion budget.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs; Flyers Recover to Top Capitals in Opener
description: Dave Poulin snapped a 2-2 tie with a power-play goal midway through the third period tonight and the Philadelphia Flyers defeated the Washington Capitals, 4-2, in a Patrick Division first-round playoff opener.

title: Iran Reports Iraqi Attacks Kil 37 Civilians
description: Iraq fired four missiles into Teheran today and said that it bombed eight other Iranian cities. Iran said that at least 37 civilians were killed and that it fired two missiles into Baghdad in retaliation.

title: Fairchild Stock Up
description: Fairchild Industries' shares jumped $1.625, to $11, on the New York Stock Exchange after the company said it expects 1988 pretax earnings from continuing operations of $20 million to $23 million, up sharply from $6.1 million in 1987. The stock's 17.3 percent gain was the largest on the Big Board. The projections are based on increased growth in space and military electronics, aerospace fasteners, and industrial and communications services, as well as the effects of a restructuring announced last July.

title: Ten Days That Shook the Campaign
description: It took the Wisconsin primary to put Jesse Jackson's progress back into perspective.

title: Currents; Enfolding Light
description: The Japanese are clearly the masters of origami, the art of folding paper, but they are not alone. Lucasz Bogucki has folded paper, and now fiberglass, into lamp shades.

title: Political Memo; On Hustings in New York: Buckle Up, Ignore Bumps
description: To: Messrs. Dukakis, Jackson, Gore, Simon.

title: U.S. Denies Japan Plea On Fishing
description: President Reagan today denied a Japanese request to catch small quantities of certain kinds of fish in American waters, saying Japan had violated an international moratorium on whaling.

title: Washington Talk: Congressional Aides; A Rare Long Run in Era of Quick Capitol Careers
description: They don't make them like Neal J. Houston on Capitol Hill anymore, a man who has worked behind the scenes of Congress for nearly three decades, serving a single member, first in the House, then in the Senate.

title: Appeals Court Suspends Logging Among Sequoias
description: A Federal appeals court here has ordered tree cutting halted on hundreds of acres in the Sequoia National Forest until a study of environmental consequences of the logging is completed.

title: Where Swedish Crystal Will Capture the Light
description: Swedish crystal sculpture, vases and bottles will line the walkways on the sixth floor at Bloomingdale's from next Thursday to May 11 with bright colors and light.

title: 250,000 Glimpses of 18th-Century New York
description: A New York gripped by furor over imported tea; a New York gripped by terror over miasmas believed to cause yellow fever - those dramatic visions have emerged from more than 250,000 archeological artifacts that were given yesterday to the South Street Seaport Museum.

title: Pace Medical reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
The European Pillar
description: Last month, NATO held its last meeting. The Brussels session wasn't officially the final meeting - its joint communique was poignantly labeled ''A Time for Reaffirmation'' - but future confabulations cannot hide the fact that NATO is now a paper alliance.

title: KEY RATES
Consolidated Imaging reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Troops in Panama Use Tear Gas to Break Up Demonstration
description: Panamanian troops and plainclothesmen firing birdshot and tear gas scattered several hundred anti-Government demonstrators in the capital today.

title: C. Willard Heckel, 74, Ex-Law Dean, Dies
description: C. Willard Heckel, former dean of the Rutgers University Law School and a top official of the United Presbyterian Church, died of advanced diabetes and pneumonia yesterday at the Marcus Ward Homestead in Maplewood, N.J., where he had lived for the last three years. He was 74 years old.

title: N.C.A.A. Acts on Fights
description: College basketball players who repeatedly fight during games next season will risk losing their eligibility for the rest of the season under tough measures announced today.

title: Vietnam, Going Hungry, Seeks U.S. Aid
description: Vietnam said today that it faced serious malnutrition because of falling food production and rising population, and it said it would welcome emergency food aid from the United States.

title: A Judge Halts Bid by Beazer
description: A Federal district judge today temporarily halted Beazer P.L.C.'s hostile $1.69 billion bid for the Koppers Company. It was the second courtroom victory for Koppers this week.

title: Young Trainer Is Seeking the Roses
description: Claude R. McGaughey 3d was wearing his heart on his head yesterday morning: a white baseball cap with ''Kentucky Derby'' stitched on the bill in golden thread.

title: General Energy Development reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results for the latest fourth quarter and year include a $1 million credit from the reduction in the carrying basis of the company's Geothermal property and gains of $649,000 from the sale of properties. Prior year includes $10,400,000 credit from a reduction in the carrying basis of the Geothermal property and a $2,030,000 writedown of the company's oil and gas properties.

title: 21 Students Seek to Feed The Hungry
description: At the Syracuse Rescue Mission, which feeds the hungry and houses the homeless, students from the Cornell University School of Hotel Administration are figuring out how to cut the cost of each meal from 64 to 50 cents.

title: Super Valu Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: b-Included a pre-tax charge of $6.5 million from the settlement of litigation.

title: Pro-Guerrilla Senator Urges President to Reject Afghan Pact
description: A United States Senator who is a leading supporter of the Afghan guerrillas called on President Reagan today to reject the emerging peace agreement.

title: Lead Paint Forces Move for a School
description: It was the first day of school all over again today, with hugs from the teachers and noisy greetings, as about 470 kindergarten and elementary pupils filed into the Toquam School.

title: Soviet Scientists in U.S. for Tests on Verification
description: A group of scientists from the Soviet Union have arrived in Washington to join a private environmental group in field experiments to test ways of enforcing potential limits on underground nuclear explosions.

title: Currents; Swedish Design, Budapest-Bound
description: FOR IKEA, the Swedish home-furnishings chain, with 76 stores in 18 countries, there can never be enough customers. In 1990, the company will open a store in Budapest, its first in an Eastern European country.

title: Northwest Ties Air Fare to Age
description: Northwest Airlines has announced a two-month discount fare that will give older people a percentage off the regular fare that matches their age. A 65-year-old passenger would receive a 65 percent discount, for instance, and a 100-year-old passenger would fly free, the airline said Tuesday.

title: Chief Tax Judge Resigns
description: Samuel B. Sterrett, chief judge of the United States Tax Court, announced today that he will resign in June to return to private law practice. Judge Sterrett, who has served on the court since 1968, became chief judge in 1985.

title: CAUCUS RESULTS IN COLORADO
description: Unofficial tally from Monday's caucus, with 82% of the precintcs reporting. DEMOCRATS Dukakis 4,852 (45%) Jackson 3,720 (35%) Gore 307 (3%) Simon 14 (0%) Others 1,867 (17%) Source: Associated Press

title: American Greetings Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Delaware Ostego reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
'The Nerd' to Close Sunday
description: ''The Nerd,'' a comedy by Larry Shue about a house guest who disrupts the life of his host, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Helen Hayes Theater. Directed by Charles Nelson Reilly, the play will have run for 441 regular performances and 15 previews.

title: Possis Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Cocoa Glut: Good News and Bad
description: It is a chocolate lover's dream and a cocoa-producing country's nightmare: Thousands of tons of cocoa, much more than can be consumed, are piling up in warehouses around the world.

title: Metro-North Engineer Dies In Crash of 2 Empty Trains
description: An empty commuter train traveling north to pick up passengers smashed into a train stopped between stations here this morning, killing an engineer and shutting down train service from Connecticut and eastern Westchester County at the height of the rush hour.

title: Farrar, Straus Names Executive Editor
description: Linda Healey, an editor at W. W. Norton, has been named executive editor and associate publisher of Farrar, Straus & Giroux. The announcement was made yesterday by Roger W. Straus, president of the company.

title: Currents; Furniture Pretty as a Picture
description: TO Jamie Brant, the most undistinguished furniture can be turned into colorful, functional art by careful repair and a refined use of paint.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Basic American Medical Inc., Indianapolis, a health care organization, named Robert D. West executive vice president and chief operating officer and William S. Hussey senior vice president of hospital operations.

title: Life of Indiana reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Penders to Texas
description: Tom Penders, who revitalized the basketball program in two seasons at Rhode Island, was named the Texas coach yesterday, replacing Bob Weltlich, who was dismissed March 14. ''The coach, in my mind, is one of the top coaches in the United States,'' Athletic Director DeLoss Dodds said of Penders. Penders said that Texas presented an opportunity he couldn't resist. Penders, who was hired in October 1986 by Rhode Island, had a 48-17 record in two seasons, leading the team to a 28-7 mark this season and the East Regional semifinals in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.(AP)

title: Fear Rules the Lives of Some of Houston's Elderly
description: Novella Davis spends her days tending her rose bushes, snapdragons and chrysanthemums and her nights guarding her fortress-like brick house.

title: 5 Gold Producers Merging in Canada
description: In the second big combination of Canadian gold producers in less than a year, International Corona Resources Ltd. said it planned to merge with four other Canadian mining companies. The move would create one of North America's largest gold producers, although it apparently would not be as large as the mid-1987 merger of three Canadian producers to form Placer Dome Inc.

title: U.S. Vehicle Sales Post 11% Rise
description: Late March sales of American-made cars and light trucks were up about 11 percent from the comparable period last year, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: Long-Term Bonds in Late Rally
description: Treasury note and bond prices rallied yesterday afternoon in sympathy with improvement in the dollar and with a push from the Federal Reserve, which bought bonds for its own account and a customer.

title: Youth Charged in Shooting
description: A 17-year-old boy who killed a man he thought was breaking into his house has been charged with murder for what the Spartanburg police called ''technical reasons.'' The defendant, James Ronald Sutton, told the police he heard the doorbell ring, then heard a screen being removed before shooting through a window late Sunday. The dead man was identified as Freddie Edward Dawkins Jr., 22, of Spartanburg, who had a criminal record. Lieut. Charles Wolfe said filing charges was the first step toward allowing the courts to clear the youth.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Eastern Orthodox Good Friday and the seventh and eighth days of Passover, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City tomorrow and Saturday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Flaws Threaten Shuttle's Aug. 4 Liftoff Date
description: Persistent engine and booster-rocket problems are threatening to delay the resumption of the space shuttle's flight beyond a scheduled Aug. 4 liftoff.

title: New York Voter Drive Offset by Purge of Rolls
description: A $532,000 voter registration drive in New York City, financed by the Federal and city governments, has produced 164,000 new registrants for the Democratic Presidential primary on April 19. But the increase was wiped out by the loss of registrants dropped from the rolls for failure to vote or other reasons.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, a report in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page yesterday omitted a quotation by Dot Koester, spokeswoman of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, about a requirement for employees to wear ties for photographs on identity cards. She said, ''For a formal Government ID card, we like our people to look as professional as they are.''

title: MGM-UA Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Japan Is Denied Fishing in U.S.
description: President Reagan turned down a Japanese request to fish American waters because the Commerce Department has accused Japan of violating an international moratorium on commercial whaling.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Cavaliers Edge Bullets: Mark Price scored 15 of his 20 points in the second half last night as Cleveland beat Washington, 98-87. It was the Cavaliers' sixth straight victory over the Bullets.

title: Mamma Leone Masks the Phantom
description: The Phantom may be a cold-blooded murderer, but hey, the guy has feelings. Hurt the Phantom's feelings and you hurt the Shubert Organization's too.

title: Elexis Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes tax loss carryforwards of $105,000.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Danger: Veto Ahead
description: The Reagan Administration is trying to leave no doubt that the President will veto a trade bill requiring companies to give employees 60 days notice before closing plants or laying off workers.

title: Review/Piano; Villa-Lobos and His Idol
description: Anna Stella Schic, who collaborated with Heitor Villa-Lobos and introduced some of his works, devoted her recital Tuesday evening at Weill Recital Hall to the Brazilian composer and to his musical idol, J. S. Bach. She chose two relatively little-heard fantasias and fugues - B.W.V. 904 in A minor and B.W.V. 906 in C minor, the latter completed by Michel Philippot - and played them with a firm, austere stride, strongly etched dynamics and a fine, sensitive touch.

title: ISRAELI GIRL KILLED BY ROCKS IN MELEE
description: An Israeli girl hiking with other teen-age Jewish settlers was stoned to death by Palestinian villagers here today, the army said, and settlers shot and killed two Palestinans as a holiday outing turned into a melee.

title: New Clothes Aid a Fight on Truancy
description: TRUANCY is a growing problem in the Tenderloin, a poverty-stung section in downtown San Francisco. But an organization has offered a solution that requires only a change of clothes and truckloads of generosity.

title: An Expensive Consolidation For Continental Airlines
description: A year after it bought People Express and Frontier Airlines, Continental Airlines is still struggling to smooth out its operations and there have been times when it has been short of cash.

title: Southdown Will Buy Moore McCormack
description: Overcoming two months of spirited resistance, Southdown Inc., a Houston cement and energy company, today succeeded in its quest to buy Moore McCormack Resources Inc., a cement maker based in Stamford, Conn., for $512 million. The transaction is worth $40 a common share.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ivan Lendl, the world's top-ranked men's tennis player, has been forced to withdraw from next week's Japan Open in Tokyo because of the stress fracture in his right big toe. . . . Irving Fryar, the Patriots' wide receiver, was indicted Tuesday on three counts by a Burlington County grand jury in Mount Holly, N.J. Fryar was charged with unlawful possession of a handgun, unlawful possession of a shotgun and possession of a prohibited device: hollow-point bullets found in the handgun.

title: Ethiopia, Pressing War on Rebels, Bars Aid Workers in Drought Area
description: The Ethiopian Government today ordered all foreign relief workers to immediately leave the drought-stricken provinces of Eritrea and Tigre because of its escalating war against rebels.

title: Rivals Will Be Big Spenders For the Battle of New York
description: In New York, one of the most expensive battlegrounds in the Presidential race, three Democratic campaigns plan to spend more money than they have in any other state thus far.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Paddington Corp. to Geer, DuBois for Malibu, a rum liqueur, and Rumple Minze, a peppermint schnapps.

title: Marcade Group Inc reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $1,227,000 from restructuring and $2,160,000 from a tax benefit. c-After extraordinary gains of $14,713,000 from restructuring and $82,000 from a tax benefit.

title: Income Opportunity Realty Trust reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $534,000 on sales of Ginnie Maes.

title: Robertson Ends Active Campaigning
description: Pat Robertson said today that he was no longer an active candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination and would not campaign in New York before the primary April 19.

title: Matt Henson, Aide at Pole, Rejoins Peary
description: Seventy-nine years to the day after he reached the North Pole with Comdr. Robert E. Peary only to spend most of the rest of his life in historical oblivion, Matthew Alexander Henson was given a hero's burial today in Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Sentex Sensing Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Ford Problem On Dealership
description: A publicly held British corporation has proposed to acquire a 50 percent share of a large Southern California dealership group, in an offer that presents the Ford Motor Company with a decision about whether to allow its dealers to go public. Campbell Automotive Group

title: Wilshire Oil Co of Texas reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The losses in the year-ago periods were mainly because of accounting changes involving the re-evaluation of the company's oil and gas.

title: Islanders Win In Overtime, 4-3
description: The Islanders, in the backs of their minds, knew they had been through this kind of turmoil before, had experienced the anxiety and exhaustion that come from fighting a playoff duel in which neither combatant seems to have the upper hand.

title: Sandinista 'Strategy': Real or Bogus?
description: A document circulating in Managua that purports to be a list of the Sandinista Government's objectives for 1988 - including the use of ''revolutionary terror'' - was disavowed today by a Government spokeswoman.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, APRIL 7, 1988
description: MARKETS Surging stock prices activated the curb on computerized trading at the New York Stock Exchange for the first time. The suspension, which comes into play when the Dow Jones industrial average moves 50 points, cooled off the market briefly. But the Dow regained its strength as program traders began executing buy orders manually and closed at 2,061.67, up 64.16 points. [ Page A1. ] Late gains produced the second-largest rise of the year for the Dow Jones industrial average. The increase of 64.16 points, or 3.2 percent, to 2,061.67 was its ninth-best point rise ever. Volume was 189.8 million shares, up sharply from Tuesday's level. [ D1. ] Treasury note and bond prices rallied in sympathy with improvement in the dollar and with a push from the Federal Reserve, which bought bonds for its own account and for a customer. The strongest gains were in the longest-term Treasury issues. [ D14. ] The dollar rallied for a second straight day, buoyed by news reports from Japan that the Group of Seven would make a commitment not to let the dollar slip below 125 Japanese yen. Gold fell $3.60 in New York, to $448.25 an ounce. [ D16. ] Cattle futures continued their advance on the Chicago Merc, following Tuesday's late recovery. [ D16. ] INTERNATIONAL The U.S. will try to stimulate more trade with Moscow. Commerce Secretary Verity won approval of the plan after two months of Cabinet discussion. The Treasury and State Departments gave him strong support, one official said, and only the Pentagon voiced reservations, fearing that an improved Soviet economy would mean a stronger adversary. [ A1. ] President Reagan denied a Japanese fishing request because Japan violated an international moratorium on whaling. The Government called the action ''the strongest permitted by the Packwood-Magnuson Amendment.'' But environmentalists complained that it was little more than a slap on the wrist. [ D1. ] Argentina will lift most price controls on April 16, ending its latest unsuccessful effort to halt inflation. [ D5. ] THE ECONOMY Late March sales of American-made vehicles rose 11 percent from a year ago. The Big Three increased their market share to about 77 percent, up about 2.5 percentage points from a year ago. And for the first time since voluntary export restraints were adopted in 1981, Japanese auto makers failed to ship their annual quota of cars. [ D1. ] The average interest rate on fixed-rate mortgages fell to an 11-month low of 10.34 percent in early March, from 10.48 percent a month earlier, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported. [ D2. ] Yields were mixed on C.D.'s, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds for the week ended yesterday. [ D7. ] COMPANIES Continental Airlines is still struggling to smooth out its operations and has been short of cash at times, a filing with the S.E.C. shows. Some analysts think Texas Air, its parent, will have to sell Eastern Air Lines to concentrate on Continental. [ D1. ] Macy would have sold four Federated store divisions for almost $3 billion if it had won its takeover battle with Campeau. [ D4. ] Moore McCormack agreed to be bought by Southdown for $512 million, or $40 a share, ending two months of resistance. [ D4. ] Beazer's $1.7 billion bid for Koppers was temporarily halted by a Federal district judge. [ D4. ] Lord, Geller named several new executives to replace managers who left to start a new agency. [ D19. ] Saudi Arabia's oil minister will head Aramco. [ D2. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Larry Silverstein seems unwilling to rent out 7 World Trade Center unless he gets his price. Meanwhile, the skyscraper remains 86 percent vacant. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] One major uncertainty will end for Pennzoil and its stockholders and another will begin when Texaco turns over $3 billion to settle the two companies' legal dispute. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Flock Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $234,350 and a gain of $718,974 from forgiveness of debt for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss d-Includes a tax credit of $89,963.

title: Long-Distance Charges Cited in F.C.C. Warning
description: Some new telephone concerns are charging 10 times as much as the major telephone companies for operator-assisted long-distance calls, the Federal Communications Commission said Tuesday.

title: Mortgage Rates Drop, But a Rise Is Expected
description: The average interest rate on fixed-rate mortgages fell to an 11-month low at 10.34 percent in early March, from 10.48 percent in early February, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.

title: Stars to Go reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter included non- recurring charges of $2.7 million from the consolidation of the company's distribution system, the writeoff of installation costs relating to about 1,100 video centers closed during 1987, and costs associated with the company's efforts to restructure its debt and raise additional equity capital.

title: Books of The Times; A Riskily Told Story Of a Battle With Death
description: Sailing By Susan Kenney 320 pages. Viking. $18.95.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Our painter etched our new galvanized aluminum gutters and downspouts with white vinegar before painting them with an oil-based exterior paint. The gutters were four to six months old at the time. Now the paint is peeling and flaking off. Besides removing the paint, what else should we do to the gutters?

title: Investigator in Brawley Case Is Arrested as a Drug Dealer
description: A longtime state investigator who recently asked to be removed from the task force investigating the case of Tawana Brawley was arrested late Tuesday in Brooklyn as a drug dealer, the police said.

title: Volvo Denies Any Interest in Pillsbury
description: The food division of Sweden's diversified car maker A.B. Volvo is not negotiating to buy the Pillsbury Company, a spokesman said. ''We have not been talking to Pillsbury, and we are not talking to Pillsbury,'' said Bjorn Allguren, public relations director at Volvo's Provendor A.B.

title: Credit Rock Lyrics for Drop in Youth Crime?
description: To the Editor:

title: Delegate Tally
description: Current breakdown of Presidential preference of delegates to national political conventions, compiled by The New York Times. Preferences are based on state laws, party rules, delegates' public statements and projections from early results in caucus states. DEMOCRATS Dukakis 722 Jackson 684 Gore 381 Simon 166 Undetermined* 483 Total delegate votes: 4,163 Chosen so far: 2,436 Needed to nominate: 2,082 REPUBLICANS Bush 860 Robertson 17 Undetermined* 266 Total delegate votes: 2,277 Chosen so far: 1,153 Needed to nominate: 1,139 * Includes some delegates whose chosen candidate has withdrawn.

title: Mark IV Chief Spurs Growth by Purchases
description: Salvatore Alfiero, the 50-year-old chairman and chief executive of Mark IV Industries, is not well known as a takeover specialist, but he has increased Mark IV's revenues tenfold in the last three years through small acquisitions.

title: What's the Message? Good Design Starts At the Office Door
description: IN midtown Manhattan - beyond a marbled lobby of cathedral-like proportions, beyond a travertine-lined foyer and crystal-clear glass doors - sits a serene lace-collared receptionist. She is an appropriate introduction to the beige-carpeted halls of one of the country's largest and most prestigious law firms.

title: Washington Scientific Indusries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 13
BGS Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; I.R.S.'s Phobia
description: Worries that an overwhelming number of Americans might wait until the last minute to file their tax returns this year because of all the changes in the tax law seem to be easing at the Internal Revenue Service. The latest tally shows that tax return filings are running about even with last year, with 58 million returns filed as of April 1. The agency now estimates that only 6.2 million taxpayers will file for extensions, up from 5 million last year.

title: Gore Persists in Attacks Over Cuomo's Objection
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. today continued to assail Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, despite a private request from Governor Cuomo to refrain from doing so.

title: Silence by Law
description: Suppose a Defense Department employee had learned about the White House plan to sell arms to Iran in exchange for hostages. He told a reporter, and the story appeared. As a result, the reporter and his editor were called before a grand jury, ordered to name the source - and imprisoned when they refused.

title: Brazil Car Exports Soar
description: Brazil's motor vehicle exports soared by 72 percent in value in the first quarter of this year, industry figures released today showed. The National Association of Automotive Vehicle Manufacturers said exports from January to March were worth $757 million, compared with $440 million in the first quarter of last year. The motor vehicle industry is now Brazil's leading export sector, with vehicle exports last year worth a record $2.7 billion. Its principal market is Latin America.

title: The Vote in Wisconsin
description: $ Dukakis Jackson Gore TOTAL 48% 28% 17% Men 46 * 29 * 17 Women 50 * 27 * 17 Whites 51 * 23 * 18 Blacks 9 * 88 * 2 18-29 years old 40 * 38 * 16 30-44 years old 41 * 34 * 19 45-59 years old 50 * 26 * 16 60 and over 58 * 18 * 18 Liberals 44 * 38 * 11 Moderates 51 * 24 * 18 Conservatives 46 * 27 * 22 Not a high school 54 * 22 * 21 graduate High school graduate 54 * 26 * 15 Some college 42 * 31 * 18 College graduate 40 * 33 * 20 Postgraduate study 45 * 30 * 16 Based on questionnaires filled out by 2,061 Democratic primary voters leaving polling places in 49 randomly selected precincts on April 5. HOW THE POLL WAS TAKEN The New York Times/CBS News poll was based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left polling places throughout Wisconsin on Tuesday. The poll included 2,061 Democratic primary voters in 49 randomly selected precincts.

title: Senators in Arizona Vote to Pay the Fees For Ousted Governor
description: The State Senate voted today to pay former Gov. Evan Mecham's legal fees for the impeachment trial that removed him from office.

title: Bush Praises Dole's Views After a Meeting
description: Vice President Bush today showered praise on Senator Bob Dole, once his leading challenger for the Republican nomination, saying that they shared common views on several issues including not raising taxes.

title: Winjak Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
Coachman Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the year-ago results were not available; the company went public in August 1987.

title: Yields Mixed For Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mostly mixed for the week ended yesterday.

title: Valex Petroleum reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a writedown of oil and gas properties of $2,235,439.

title: Consolidated Capital Special Trust reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After gains on sale of investments of $201,000 for the latest year and $3,606,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: W. Russell Boss, Pen Executive, 79
description: W. Russell Boss, former president and chairman of the A. T. Cross Company, a maker of expensive pens and pencils, died Monday. He was 79 years old.

title: U.S.-Japan Futures Accord
description: In a move that signals a growing alliance between the United States and Japanese futures industries, the Chicago Board of Trade and the Tokyo Stock Exchange agreed today to cooperate in the trading of several key futures contracts.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, page B2 was omitted from some copies yesterday, and a duplicate of page D2 appeared in its place. The missing page carried an article on New York legislators' decision to adopt parts of the state budget; the continuation of an article about clamming in New Jersey; and an article about a Queens fisherman who found a bag containing $5 million in bonds and checks. Readers wishing copies of the page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Jackson Is Arming His Campaign With Substance
description: Jesse Jackson wanted to talk numbers: budget statistics, excess costs, business entertainment deductions. But, he was asked, what about passion? What about oratory? What about rhyming? Numbers don't rhyme.

title: Bridge
description: The recent Spring Nationals in Buffalo provided a string of successes for players from the New York metropolitan region.

title: A Parent's Career
description: To The Home Section:

title: New York's Decay Exposed!
description: LEAD: The April 11 issue of the New Republic, a Washington publication, brings us startling news. Articles by Howard Kurtz, the New York bureau chief of The Washington Post; Irving Kristol, a newly installed occupant of a Washington think tank, and William Tucker, a Brooklyn resident included, I suspect, as geographical camouflage, arrive at an identical conclusion.

title: Why We Need to Know How long Tax Forms Take; Red Tape Increases
description: To the Editor:

title: Celtics Will Play Abroad
description: The National Basketball Association took a major step in Commissioner David J. Stern's foreign policy today with the announcement that the Boston Celtics would play in an open tournament in Madrid in October.

title: The Life and Works Of Romare Bearden Recalled in a Tribute
description: A memorial service for Romare Bearden, a leading American painter and collagist who died March 12, was held yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., and Union Carbide Corp., Danbury, Conn., tentatively agreed to form a joint venture that would supply technology, products, engineered systems and services to the oil and gas industries.

title: Afghanistan - a New Lebanon?
description: LEAD: Reagan Administration officials are eagerly anticipating a moral and geopolitical triumph for United States policy in Afghanistan, as agreement nears on terms for continued aid to rebels that could set the stage for a withdrawal of Soviet troops by 1989.

title: G.E. and Roper Agree on Merger
description: The General Electric Company and the Roper Corporation said they had reached a definitive merger agreement that would allow G.E. to move ahead with its proposed $507.6 million acquisition of Roper. G.E. also extended the deadline of its tender offer by seven hours, until midnight Monday. G.E. has offered $54 a share for Roper's outstanding stock.

title: Bruce a Falcon
description: The Atlanta Falcons, who have the No. 1 selection in the National Football League draft April 24-25, announced the signing of Aundray Bruce, the Auburn linebacker, to a five-year contract. Terms were not disclosed, but the deal was believed to be for more than $3.5 million, including a signing bonus of $1 million. The Falcons, who had the worst record in the league last year at 3-12, decided March 30 to select the 6-foot-5-inch, 231-pound Bruce.(AP)

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Melissa's best interests will be served by unsupervised, uninterrupted liberal visitation with her mother.'' - Judge Birger M. Sween. [ A1:2. ]

title: Court Stance on Texaco
description: Despite a last-minute plea by a Texaco shareholder, the United States Supreme Court declined yesterday to accelerate its review of the dispute between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company.

title: Lancer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Results for the latest fourth quarter and year include a cumulative inventory adjustment, which reduced net by $1,485,860.

title: Dismissed and Defrocked, Ex-Pastor Still Divides Lutheran Parish
description: Try as they may, Lutherans in this mill town cannot seem to forgive or forget after an outspoken pastor left their church a house divided.

title: Coach Had His Rules
description: KERRY BRINSON did not like the jacket and tie on his new high school football coach. He didn't like the big vocabulary or the fact that the new coach had a doctorate in psychology.

title: Manning Honored
description: Two days after leading Kansas to the national title with an 83-79 victory over Oklahoma, Danny Manning received the John R. Wooden Award as college basketball's best player, and called it all ''storybook stuff.'' The 6-foot-10-inch Manning - in balloting by 1,000 news media representatives - won the award, named for the highly successful former U.C.L.A. coach, with 865 points. Hersey Hawkins of Bradley, the nation's leading scorer, finished second (845 points), followed by Sean Elliott of Arizona (424), Danny Ferry of Duke (386) and Gary Grant of Michigan (160).(AP)

title: Advertising; Lord, Geller Fills 2 Posts In Top Rank
description: DEPLETED high and low by defections, the staff of Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein is getting an infusion of management talent.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Exit Mecham, Unbowed; Exeunt Lawyers, Puzzled
description: The first gubernatorial impeachment trial in nearly 60 years had a full complement of lawyers, last-minute switches of lawyers, lawyers appearing as witnesses and one or two literary allusions to lawyers.

title: Gibraltar I.R.A. Shootings Are Vigilantism
description: To the Editor:

title: California Utility's Bonds Yield 9.25%
description: The Southern California Edison Company is offering $150 million of 9 percent first- and refunding-mortgage bonds due in 1998 at a price of 98.39 to yield 9.25 percent. The underwriters are led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Bids Urged on Japan Work
description: Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. today urged American construction concerns to take advantage of a new agreement with Japan intended to open Japanese construction projects to United States companies.

title: Unfair Comparison
description: To The Home Section:

title: Home Improvement
description: DRIVING nails in less than ideal situations - in cramped or hard-to-reach areas, or where nails must enter wood at steep angles - can be enormously frustrating. And nails that are not driven correctly can cause other problems.

title: Tactical Changes Help Yanks
description: In their opening-day victory, the Yankees unleashed the power with which they hope to steamroll their way to a division championship. In their second-day victory yesterday, the Yankees showed that they can use other, more subtle tactics to win.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: A Quandary for I.B.M. Over Its New PC Line
description: Shortly after the International Business Machines Corporation introduced its highly successful personal computer seven years ago, competitors began flooding the market with cheaper ''clones.'' The reproductions cost I.B.M. sales, but they established the PC as an industry standard and assured the computer giant's dominance in the young business.

title: Review/Television; The 'Clarifying Mirror' of One Poet
description: An incredible fresh genius impersonating an ordinary woman. That is how James Merrill, the poet, wittily describes Elizabeth Bishop (1911-1979), the subject of this week's essay on ''Voices and Visions,'' the public-television series on American poetry. ''Elizabeth Bishop: One Art'' is beautifully produced, directed and written by Jill Janows. Carried by PBS stations at varying times, it is being broadcast on Channel 13 tonight at 10.

title: More Than a Club: It's Open House
description: HER outfit was simple, really, just a white jacket, black skirt and black-and-white striped stockings. But in the dim library, against oak specimen cases displaying stuffed flamingos and wolf skeletons, the young woman looked crisp and graphic as she took her billiard cue and leaned into her shot. Her friends, also casually well dressed, circled the table, chalking their cues.

title: Dow Jumps 64.16 Points, To 2,061.67
description: Stock prices soared on Wall Street in late trading yesterday, propelling the Dow Jones industrial average to its second-largest point gain of the year and its ninth-best rise ever.

title: Fugitive in a Mafia Case Turns Up Dead
description: Armond Dellacroce, the son of a former top Mafia figure, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Monday in the Pocono Mountains area of Pennsylvania, where he had been living as a fugitive for two years, Federal officials announced yesterday.

title: Autoclave Engineers reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Miller, Herman Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
Deciding to Nurse: Weighing the Factors
description: SOME BENEFITS

title: Thompson Medical Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Shortage of Doctors Viewed As Likely by End of Century
description: The often predicted glut of physicians by the end of this century may not occur, and there may even be a shortage, say two reports in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Reno Sweeney Alumni to Stage AIDS Concerts
description: Among New York's nightclubs, the name Reno Sweeney, taken from a character in ''Anything Goes,'' has a special significance. From 1972 until it was sold in 1979, the intimate West 13th Street club was at the hub of a cabaret revival that was finally curtailed by the onslaught of disco. During its seven-year life, Reno Sweeney offered a platform for a new generation of performers, including Peter Allen, Melissa Manchester and the Manhattan Transfer.

title: Laxalt Wins on Fees in Long Legal Dispute
description: Attorneys for Paul Laxalt will receive nearly $650,000 for their part in a $250 million libel suit the former Republican Senator from Nevada filed against McClatchy Newspapers and later dropped, attorneys have announced.

title: Chase and 2 Rivals Organize Unit to Lend to Europeans
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank has joined hands with two of its competitors to offer European companies and government agencies access to low-cost financing in the American commercial paper market.

title: INSIDE
description: Hanoi Urges Food Aid

title: Review/Recital; A Soprano Who Reveals Herself
description: Since her New York debut in the Young Concert Artists Series in 1981, Marvis Martin has gone from success to success, amassing awards, medals and glowing reviews as a song recitalist, concert singer and opera performer. On Tuesday evening the Florida-born soprano took another step up the career ladder when she appeared at Alice Tully Hall under the auspices of the same invaluable organization as recipient of its Michaels Award.

title: Finalco Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,623,000 from an accounting change.

title: Butler, John O Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Review/Dance; Swiss Modern Sampler
description: A chance to sample Swiss modern dance is being provided by a series of performances by Swiss choreographers that continues through tomorrow night at the Swiss Institute, 35 West 67th Street. The opening program on Tuesday night featured Judith Scherer and Christine Brodbeck, both of whom choreographed in an athletic and slightly hard-edged style.

title: Stock Prices Surge in Tokyo
description: Stock prices flirted with all-time highs early today in Tokyo, while the dollar moved higher against the Japanese yen in foreign exchange trading.

title: Review/Dance; Paul Taylor Opens With A Premiere
description: If it's the Paul Taylor Dance Company, it must be spring. Or so one has assumed through the 1980's ever since Mr. Taylor and his merry band became an April fixture in New York.

title: Baby M's Mother Wins Broad Visiting Rights
description: In a ruling that completed a sharp reversal of her fortunes in the Baby M dispute, Mary Beth Whitehead Gould was granted broad rights today to see the daughter she bore to William Stern two years ago under a surrogacy contract.

title: Columbia U. Awards Bancroft History Prizes
description: Columbia University awarded the 1988 Bancroft Prizes in American history last night to Peter R. Kolchin for his book ''Unfree Labor: American Slavery and Russian Serfdom'' (Harvard University Press) and to Michael S. Sherry for ''The Rise of American Air Power: The Creation of Armageddon'' (Yale University Press).

title: Parent & Child
description: For many children, the traditional two-parent family is no more a part of everyday life than the castles and magic of fairy tales. One of every 4 children in the United States lives with only one parent, according to the Census Bureau; that is far more than in 1960, when the proportion was 1 in 10. Researchers say that 60 percent of today's children will spend some time in a one-parent household before they leave home.

title: Alan Paton Recovering After an Operation
description: The author Alan Paton is recovering from surgery for an undisclosed ailment, the South African Press Association reported today.

title: Panama War of Nerves: A Risk of Overreaction
description: In resisting the State Department's push for stronger action to force Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from power in Panama, the Defense Department is warning that military restraint is needed if other forms of American pressure are to be effective.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Deficit Busters
description: The National Economic Commission, which was created last December to find a way to cut the budget deficits, opened for business yesterday at a cozy Victorian town house a block from the White House.

title: Chipwich Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $100,000 from the settlement of liabilities under a reorganization plan. c-Net income and includes a tax credit of $9,013.

title: Austria Marketing Bond Issue in U.S.
description: Austria offered $100 million of 9 1/8 percent bonds yesterday. Due in 1999, they were priced at 99.275 to yield 9.23 percent. The underwriters were led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the opening of Florence Gould Hall in New York City gave an incorrect date for a concert to celebrate Olivier Messiaen's 80th birthday. It is scheduled for April 16. The article also mentioned a second concert that had been announced to honor Mr. Messiaen; that concert will not be held.

title: Royal House, U.S. Touch
description: She's been a member of Britain's royal family for less than two years. But the Duchess of York - or Fergie, as the tabloid press still delights in calling her - has developed a knack for doing things her way, even when it means giving royal propriety a gentle nudge.

title: Shultz Is Making Little Headway on Mideast Plan
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz's Middle East mission neared an end today without making any apparent headway in moving the region's leaders closer to the negotiating table.

title: Catholics Debate Changes in Schools
description: Eighteen thousand Roman Catholic school administrators are in New York City to talk about how to grapple with the effect of national population shifts, among other things. Such shifts have left Catholic dioceses with hundreds of schools in inner-city areas where there are fewer Catholics and thousands of children in some suburbs where there are few Catholic schools.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Richard B. Cohen and Frank A. Sampogna have been promoted to executive vice presidents at Wells, Rich, Greene.

title: Review/Music; Works by Russian Jewish Composers
description: In conjunction with three concurrent exhibitions relating to aspects of Jewish life in Russia and the Soviet Union, the Jewish Museum (1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street) is presenting two concerts of music by Russian Jewish composers.

title: Amertek Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $1,333,760 special gain. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Iran-Contra Trial Judge Rejects Security Plan
description: The Federal district judge in the Iran-contra case rejected today as too cumbersome a proposal by the independent prosecutor for preventing the unauthorized disclosure of 150,000 pages of classified documents that might become evidence in the case.

title: Jewish National Fund No Apartheid Enforcer
description: To the Editor:

title: Devon Resource Investors reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Argentina Will End Most Curbs on Prices
description: Ending its latest unsuccessful effort to halt inflation through wage and price controls, Argentina announced today that most price controls would be lifted April 16.

title: Paine Webber Banker Looking for a Change
description: W. Peter Slusser, who built the mergers and acquisitions department at Paine Webber Inc., is planning to practice his investment banking skills elsewhere, at either an existing firm or one he establishes.

title: Currents; Tile Moves Out of the Bathroom
description: THE interior designer John Saladino believes that in the United States tile suffers from neglect, that it is underused and undervalued.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a New York City prison barge incorrectly reported a statement by the counsel to Assemblyman Sheldon Silver, who had sued to prevent the use of the barge. The counsel, Fred Jacobs, noted Correction Department statements that prison crowding had eased, and he said an earlier department contention that there was an overcrowding emergency was a sham.

title: Magic Johnson Pact
description: In 1984, when Magic Johnson signed a contract with the Los Angeles Lakers that was set up to pay him $1 million a year for 25 years, it was considered among the richest in the National Basketball Association. But since then, several players have achieved comparable agreements. Now Johnson has reached agreement with Jerry Buss, the owner of the Lakers, to restructure the contract, condensing the final $21 million owed Johnson into 7 years instead of 21. He will receive $3 million a season until the end of the 1993-94 season, when he plans to retire.(AP)

title: Mets Are Blown Out by Perez of Expos
description: The Mets got a jolt of reality tonight after their opening-day fantasy. Nobody hit six home runs, upwind or downwind. Nobody hit a moon shot off the roof. Nobody hit much of anything.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-13 Mikhail S. Gorbachev flew to Asia, apparently for a meeting with the Afghan President, as signs persisted that an agreement was near on the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan. Page A1 An Israeli girl was stoned to death by Palestinian villagers in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, the army said. In the same clash settlers shot and killed two Palestinians as a holiday outing turned into a melee. A1 The Shultz Mideast mission neared an end without the Secretary of State making any apparent headway in moving the region's leaders closer to the negotiating table. A8 More American-Soviet trade is sought by the Reagan Administration, according to Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr., who is about to visit Moscow. A1 Ethiopia ordered a pullout of all foreign relief workers immediately from the drought-striken provinces of Eritrea and Tigre amid its accelerating war against rebels. A1 Vietnam faces serious malnutrition because of falling food production and a rising population, according to the Government, which said it would welcome emergency food aid from the United States. A3 Tons of cocoa are piling up in warehouses around the world. The glut is the result of improvements in technology and nearly perfect growing weather. D1 Iran reports Iraqi attack kills 37 civilians A9 National A16-25, D22-23 Soaring stock prices on the New York Exchange kicked off a curb on computerized program trading for the first time, but the impact was limited as program traders began executing buy orders manually. A1 Stock prices jumped as a stronger dollar propelled the prices of Treasury bonds higher and shifted investors' focus to equities. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 64.16 points, to 2,061.67. D1 Murders of old Houston residents are causing them to change their life styles. Since November, 14 residents aged 60 to 84 have been slain during a rape, robbery or burglary. A16 Sequoia National Forest tree cutting has been ordered halted by a Federal appeals court pending the completion of a study analyzing the environmental consequences of the logging in hundreds of acres. A16 Artists face disastrous losses because of the new tax law. Under the statute, they cannot deduct ''work-related expenses'' unless their works have been sold. C19 Reading Market journal: Old vs. new A16 Judge ready to discuss Iran-contra trial date A17 Arizona Senate votes to pay ousted Governor's legal fees A20 Politics D22-23 Michael S. Dukakis's triumph in the Wisconsin primary Tuesday gave the Democratic Party a widely acknowledged front-runner for the first time in the contorted 1988 Democratic Presidential campaign. D22 More money will go to New York than to any other state for the Presidential campaigns of Governor Dukakis, Senator Albert Gore Jr. and the Rev. Jesse Jackson. D23 Politics in New York, where the Presidential primaries will be held April 19, involve better than 100 ethnic groups, a culture that thrives on gossip and two politicians unlike any others you will ever meet. A1 Jesse Jackson sought numbers, wanting to discuss budget statistics, cost overruns and business entertainment deductions. ''I'm trying,'' he said, grimacing, ''to be Presidential.'' D22 Albert Gore Jr. continued to assail Gov. Michael A. Dukakis and the Rev. Jesse Jackson on the campaign trail, despite a private request from Governor Cuomo to refrain from doing so. D22 Pat Robertson has withdrawn from the Republican Presidential race. The former religious broadcaster acknowledged that Vice President Bush has the nomination sewed up. D23 New York City voter registration falls short D23 Several cities get new mayors D23 Washington Talk A24 A Capitol aide's rare long-run career is ending Regional B1-6 Baby M's mother won broad rights to see the daughter she bore to William Stern under a surrogacy contract. Beginning at once, she will be able to have the girl at her home one day a week for up to six hours. A1 A powerful Queens judge, Surrogate Louis D. Laurino, was censured for ethical misconduct by a state agency. It found he had pressured a lawyer to hire the surrogate's son and a nephew and had made an improper political gift. A1 Armond Dellacroce died of a cerebral hemorrhage in the Poconos, where he had been living as a fugitive for two years, Federal officials announced. The dead man was the son of a former top New York Mafia figure. B3 Three men charged with murdering a rookie police officer in Queens in February are suspected of having been the armed robbers who stole $7,000 in cash from a Queens warehouse last October, the authorities said. B3 An empty Metro-North train hit another passengerless train, killing arailroad employee and delaying tens of thousands of commuters on the New Haven line. B1 East Harlem is virtually certain to be chosen as an economic development zone, according to New York State officials. The designation would provide state aid to businesses. B1 Cornell hotel students seek to help the hungry B1 School is closed because of lead paint B2 School aid issue blocks passage of state budget in Albany B2 Brawley case investigator arrested on drug charge B3 Cancer victim's husband describes her death B4

title: Orson Welles Still Fascinates
description: When Orson Welles died in 1985, he left behind a pile of scripts that were never made into movies.

title: TM Communications Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest year's results restated to reflect the discontinuance of the corporate communications portion of the company's business.

title: Computer Trading Is Curbed, But Stocks Soar 64.16 Points
description: A steep climb in prices on the New York Stock Exchange kicked off the exchange's curb on computerized program trading for the first time yesterday afternoon. The suspension cooled off the market briefly, but the impact was limited and the Dow Jones industrial average regained its strength as program traders began executing buy orders manually.

title: Anthony Pelissier, Actor, 75
description: Anthony Pelissier, an actor who later won fame as a director of plays and films, died Saturday in Eastbourne. He was 75 years old.

title: AP Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $2,576,745 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $799,507. c-Net income and after a loss of $2,267,123 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary charge of $754,902.

title: Why We Need to Know How Long Tax Forms Take
description: To the Editor:

title: Rival Moslems Clash in Lebanon; 13 Killed
description: Rival Shiite Moslem factions, using machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades, clashed in southern Lebanon today for the second consecutive day, and the police said 13 people were killed and 40 wounded.

title: HEALTH: Medical Devices; F.D.A. Warns Against the Misuse Of Electric Muscle Stimulators
description: The Government says a classic form of health quackery has been modernized and is making a comeback in parts of the country.

title: Santa Monica Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Per share net results reflect a 20 percent stock dividend paid Feb. 1, 1988.

title: Canyon Resources Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1.8 million from the reorganization and sale of a portion of Australian assets. c-Net loss

title: Dollar Up, Aided by Reports About the Group of Seven
description: The dollar rallied for a second consecutive day in choppy trading yesterday, buoyed by Japanese news reports that the Group of Seven nations next week would make a commitment not to let the dollar slip below 125 Japanese yen, a level it had recently pierced.

title: Trace Products reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After tax loss carryforwards of $1,018,000 for the quarter and $1,791,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: Driesell Returns
description: Lefty Driesell, who resigned as the Maryland basketball coach in the aftermath of the cocaine-induced death of Len Bias nearly two years ago, was named coach at James Madison in Harrisonburg, Va., yesterday. ''I don't have anything to prove to anybody,'' Driesell told a news conference. ''I'm a basketball coach. I've won games, and I've won them within the N.C.A.A. rules.'' The James Madison president, Ronald Carrier, said Driesell's five-year contract is worth $65,000 a year, and the James Madison Foundation will pay him $10,000 a year as an annuity toward his retirement. (AP)

title: Intermark Gaming International reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $704,269 from tax loss carryforwards. c-Net loss

title: Saudi Named Aramco Chief
description: The Saudi Arabian oil minister, Hisham Nazer, has replaced an American to become the first Saudi chairman of the Arabian American Oil Company, his nation's major oil-producing company.

title: Review/Theater; An All-American Couple and Their Son the Bear
description: In Nicholas Kazan's auspicious one-act comedy, ''Just Horrible,'' the all-American family that sits down to its evening meal is typical except in one crucial respect. Clarence (Peter Hedges), the 7-year-old son of Bill (Larry Bryggman), a stern businessman, and his flighty wife, Frannie (Anita Gillette), has become a lethal menace in the neighborhood. By some awful trick of nature, the boy was born a grizzly bear and, as he has matured, has acquired a taste for human blood.

title: In East Harlem, High Hopes for Economic Zone Plan
description: New York State officials, on a walking tour of East Harlem, said yesterday that parts of the neighborhood were virtually certain to be chosen as an economic development zone, which would provide state assistance to businesses.

title: How the $3 Billion Changes Hands
description: The payment of the largest cash settlement in the history of American justice will probably take less than two hours this morning. It will require some nimble relays within the banking system when Texaco Inc., in White Plains, transfers $3 billion to the Pennzoil Company, in Houston.

title: MGM/UA Reports Merger Inquiries
description: The MGM/UA Communications Company said it had received additional inquiries about a possible takeover. The movie studio, whose stock soared Monday and Tuesday and rose another 12.5 cents today to close at $13.75, did not provide details on the inquiries, nor did it say how many it had received.

title: Record Attendance At London Theaters
description: Eleven million people, a record number, went to theaters in London's West End last year, the Society of West End Theaters announced today.

title: Locked Iron Gate Blocks Escape As 4 Die in House Fire in Queens
description: A two-alarm fire killed a mother, her teen-age daughter and two of the woman's young nephews yesterday morning at their frame house in Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: Grass and Hopes Grow at Augusta
description: The greens at Augusta National Golf Club are as hard as they were last year when golfers had trouble keeping their approach shots on the steep landing strips.

title: Digital Communications Asociates reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,854,000, or 12 cents a share, from the sale of an investment in common stock in Ungermann-Bass Inc. c-Includes tax loss carryforwards of $1,400,000. Year-ago operating net for the 9 months included a charge of $2,018,000, or 13 cents a share, to terminate a distribution agreement.

title: Market Place; A Cautious Attitude At Pennzoil
description: ONE major uncertainty will end for the Pennzoil Company and its stockholders today, and another will begin, when Texaco Inc. transfers $3 billion by wire to a Houston bank, the price of peace in their long-running corporate legal war.

title: Stanwood Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Don't Blame Private Carters for New York's Garbage Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: Reading Market Journal; New Convention Center Threatens an Old Jewel
description: It is not difficult to understand why Philadelphians are fearful about what some see as a major threat to the Reading Terminal Market, one of the jewels of this city.

title: HEALTH: Infant Care; Why Fewer Blacks Choose to Breast-Feed Than Do Whites
description: From a generation of bottle babies has come a resurgence of interest in breast-feeding in the United States. But not all babies have the opportunity to benefit from this natural approach to nurture and nourishment because of a largely unexplained racial disparity in nursing practices.

title: Review/Concert; 'Just Music,' Play on Words
description: ''Just Music,'' the title of Paul Gallagher's concert of his own music on Monday evening at CAMI Hall, is a play on words meant to evoke the directness of his endeavor, the fact that his works use just (rather than tempered) intonation, and the social conscience behind his music.

title: Artists Fear Impact of Curb on Tax Writeoffs
description: In 1987, Loren Madsen, a New York sculptor, spent about $20,000 to make eight abstract sculptures - his total artistic output of the year. In most tax-filing seasons, whether he had sold all of his sculptures or none, Mr. Madsen would follow the business practice common to artists and deduct the full $20,000 from his income tax as ''work-related expenses.''

title: Thailand to Phase Out Unit Accused of Abusing Refugees
description: The Thai Government and the United Nations Border Relief Operation, which oversees the health and safety of Indochinese civilians in camps along the Thai-Cambodian frontier, have agreed that a security task force accused of human rights violations against refugees will be phased out within a month.

title: Twins Disjoined at Head Leave the Hospital
description: Benjamin and Patrick Binder, twins from West Germany who were born joined at the head, were discharged from Johns Hopkins Hospital here Wednesday, seven months after a rare medical procedure in which their skulls and circulatory systems were separated.

title: Manhattan Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss The results for the latest periods included non-recurring income of $425,000 for the quarter and $1,371,000 for the year, and an extraordinary tax credit of $1.5 million and a tax provision of $4 million, both for the year. The results for the year-ago periods included a non-recurring loss of $431,000 for the quarter and non-recurring income of $9,333,000 for the year, and both periods included a business restructuring charge of $7.5 million. The share earnings and the shares outstanding are fully diluted and were adjusted for the 4 percent stock dividend distributed on July 1, 1987, to shareholders of record on June 10, 1987.

title: Taiwan Trade Surplus
description: Taiwan's trade surplus reached a four-year low in March, officials said today. They said the decline should help to ease the island's trade frictions with the United States. The surplus fell to $160 million (American), from $990 million in February and $1.45 billion a year earlier. March exports totaled $4.51 billion, up a bit from $4.31 billion in February, but imports came to $4.35 billion, a sharp rise from $3.32 billion.

title: Remember the World
description: To The Home Section:

title: Baby Boomers Help Push Median Age Past 32
description: America's population is older than ever, with the median age exceeding 32 years for the first time, new Census Bureau figures showed Tuesday.

title: Macy Had Plan to Split Federated
description: A day after a victorious Campeau Corporation said it planned to dispose of $4.4 billion in assets of Federated Department Stores Inc., R. H. Macy & Company said yesterday that before it lost the takeover war it had signed agreements to sell four Federated store divisions for almost $3 billion.

title: One City's Child Care Partnership
description: LEAD: WHEN Meg Franklin was interviewed at a local radio station about her work with the Bay Area Employer Child Care Coalition, she learned another lesson on the plight of working parents. The reporter, a single mother, said that the day before, she had covered a story that kept her at work until 1 A.M., and she considered herself lucky to have persuaded her baby sitter to stay until she finished the job.

title: Protect the Maker's Mark on Antiques
description: LEAD: In 18th-century England, only a few cabinetmakers placed labels on their creations to identify themselves by name. Early Colonial craftsmen who were trained in England and those they taught in North America may have influenced cabinetmakers here, for surviving labeled furniture is rare.

title: Corrections
description: A report in Sports Pages yesterday about baseball's progress in hiring minority-group members for management misstated the race of Cookie Rojas in some editions. Mr. Rojas, the California Angels' manager, is white.

title: They Grin or Bear It as Smoking Curbs Take Effect
description: Like a puff of smoke, a way of life in New York City began to disappear yesterday as smokers complied, sometimes grudgingly, with the city's new law that severely limits smoking in most public places.

title: S.A.T. Scores: An Analysis Proves Alarming
description: In spring, the thoughts of young men and women who took the Scholastic Aptitude Test the previous fall turn to whether years of studying, months of coaching or last-minute guessing were sufficient to help them get into the college of their choice. By next week, they'll know. Meanwhile, troubling questions are being raised about the test scores themselves, which many college admissions officials use to help predict student performance.

title: Currents; Nature's Revenge On 5th Ave.
description: AT the new Williwear shop for men and women, James Wines has created an interior that he calls ''nature's revenge on Fifth Avenue.''

title: Merck Clarification
description: Merck & Company, clarifying a company comment in an earlier interview, said that ''while the Merck board, from time to time, reviews such matters, no further dividend increase or stock-repurchase program is under consideration.''

title: Windsor Life Insurance Co of America reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After capital gains of $90,000. c-Net income and after capital gains of $366,000.

title: Why Jesse Jackson's Message Has Such Appeal
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Is Hopeful but Waiting on Afghan Settlement
description: Reagan Administration officials voiced cautious optimism Thursday that a settlement would soon be formally concluded that would lead to the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan.

title: Budget Clash in Albany; Diverse Concerns of Cuomo and Legislators Are Reflected in the Conflict Over Spending
description: Keeping more than 200 state legislators with vacation plans and a Governor with a heavy political schedule here this week to pass a state budget would not have been easy if the issue had really been whether the state could afford to spend $40 million more on education aid.

title: AT THE BAR
description: There were lawyers in the gallery, at counsel's table and even in the jury box. Some had to stand. One participant said he had never seen so many lawyers in one place except a bar convention or an alumni dinner.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Building Maintenance Industries, San Francisco, named William W. Steele executive vice president and chief operating officer. In addition, Jack Egan, chairman of its janitorial services group, will assume the additional post of president of the group.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Busy Weekend for Prospects
description: Most of the favorites for the Triple Crown races will be running today and tomorrow, making their penultimate starts before the Kentucky Derby on May 7.

title: Edwards, A G & Sons Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Review/Film; 'Above the Law,' a Detective's Battle
description: Come the end of the year, ''Above the Law'' may well rank among the top three or four goofiest bad movies of 1988. The film, which opens today at the National and other theaters, is the year's first left-wing right-wing-movie. It's an action melodrama that expresses the sentiments of the lunatic fringe at the political center.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON NEW AND RENEWABLE SOURCES OF ENERGY - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Carl Ingram, Executive, 60
description: Carl Ingram, vice president of Kamco Supply Corporation, a Brooklyn-based supplier of building materials, died of cancer Monday at New York University Medical Center. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan and Fire Island, L.I.

title: Williams-Sonoma Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss of $600,000 from the settlement of class action lawsuit for the quarter and the year.

title: Former Rep. Steiger Guilty
description: A jury today convicted former Representative Sam Steiger of theft by extortion for threatening a parole board member to get his vote on a personnel matter while serving in the administration of Gov. Evan Mecham. Mr. Steiger, who was a top aide to the now-ousted Republican Governor, was accused of threatening Ron Johnson, a member of the state Board of Pardons and Paroles.

title: Shiite Militia Routs Its Pro-Iran Rival in Lebanon
description: Lebanon's main Shiite Moslem militia said today that it had gained total control of the largest Shiite town in southern Lebanon after routing the Party of God, a pro-Iranian group, in three days of large-scale fighting.

title: Strong Demand for Pound Helps Depress the Dollar
description: Strong demand for British pounds, much of it from big multinational corporations, helped depress the dollar yesterday.

title: Reggae's Rhythms And Roots in 2 Shows
description: JAMAICAN reggae - bass heavy, beat heavy, political and sensuous - has made its way around the globe, leaving its calling card wherever it goes. Whether it is the preachifying reggae of Bob Marley or the watered-down reggae of the Police, the music has influenced the blandest of pop songs and raised political issues where they had not been raised before.

title: Los Angeles Journal; Winning the West From Nostradamus
description: As newcomers soon learn, Southern California is world headquarters for all manner of the New Age paranormal and the unorthodox: channelers to past lives, the healing power of quartz crystals, not to mention colonic hydrotherapy.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Simon Halts Campaign But Keeps His Delegates
description: Senator Paul Simon announced today he was suspending his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination but would retain control of the delegates he has won, at least until the primaries are over.

title: U.S. and Soviet Would Suspend Arms Shipments After an Accord
description: The Reagan Administration and the Soviet Union intend to suspend all arms deliveries to Afghanistan after the conclusion of an agreement of a Soviet troop withdrawal, knowledgeable officials said today.

title: The Salsa Refugees
description: Mario Rivera, a saxophonist, is to lead his Latin-jazz band, the Salsa Refugees, tomorrow at Sound of Brazil, 204 Varick Street (243-4940). Sets begin at 11 P.M., 1 and 2:30 A.M.; there is a $16 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Yankee Game Rained Out
description: After two season-opening victories over the Minnesota Twins, the Yankees were finally stopped last night. But it was rain, not the defending World Series champions, that did it.

title: Unifirst Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
