Five people were killed when anti-American demonstrators set fire to an annex of the United States Embassy. Page 1 U.S. criticizes delay in Honduran response to riot 6 News analysis: Anti-Americanism and growing resentment over U.S. domination of Honduras contributed to the attack Thursday night on a wing of the U.S. Embassy in Honduras, diplomats and Hondurans said. 6 Payments to Panama must end, President Reagan ordered, increasing economic pressure on Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The order covers payments by American companies or Panamanian subsidiaries and by American citizens. 1 A hijacked Kuwaiti airliner landed in Cyprus with more than 50 passengers aboard after a dramatic attempt to put down in Beirut, where authorities refused to grant the pilot permission to land. 1 An Israeli girl was killed by a bullet from the rifle of a Jewish settler guarding her and was not stoned to death, the army said. Tirza Porat's death Wednesday had brought calls for vengeance against Arabs. 1 George Shultz ended his mission to the Middle East and promised to return to continue pressing an American plan for peace there. The Secretary of State did not say when he would return. 8 Full agreement on an Afghan treaty was announced by the United Nationsmediator in Geneva. The Soviet Union will withdraw its 115,000 soldiers from Afghanistan under the treaty, which also provides for the return of Afghan refugees. 7 Shultz and Shevardnadze may attend Afghan signing 7 The legislative campaign in Korea is shaping up as a rerun of the presidential race. The opposition is divided, and the ruling party is expected to keep control in elections on April 26. Voters seem weary of political struggle. 3 South Africa strengthened control over South-West Africa by giving its representative in the territory, which is known as Namibia, power to silence radical opposition and censor the press. 3 National 9-12, 32 Jimmy Swaggart was defrocked as a minister of the Assemblies of God for rejecting punishment ordered by national leaders of the church. Shortly after the church announcement, Mr. Swaggart resigned from the church. 1 Baby-boomer interest in gardening is fueling a surge in the sales of lawn and garden care products. Sales in 1987 totaled $17.49 billion, a 47 percent increase in sales since 1983 and 23 percent above 1986. 1 Water rights on a Colorado river were donated to a conservation group by the mining company that owned them. Environmentalists say the gift could provide a novel way to protect endangered rivers like the Gunnison. 9 Lyn Nofziger was sentenced to 90 days in prison and fined $30,000 for illegal lobbying on behalf of the Wedtech Corporation. The former White House political director will remain free pending the outcome of his appeal. 9 A show of force against youth gangs by the Los Angeles police is planned this weekend to counter increased violence by the gangs. The police planned to blanket crime-ridden neighborhoods with 1,000 officers. 9 Stock prices rose in moderate trading as the Dow Jones industrial average gained 28.02 points to 2,090.19 Late trading strength in computer stocks and optimism over upcoming currency talks helped push prices up. 37 Entrapment in claimed in Zaccaro case 9 Iran-contra prosecutor says some immunity is ineffective 11 Administration challenges special prosecutor law 11 University of North Carolina names chancellor 12 Politics 10-11 Mayor Koch defended his attacks on the Rev. Jesse Jackson and accused the Democratic Presidential candidate of evading the issue of Israeli security. 1 The Democratic Presidential race went to Long Island. As the three candidates stumped in Nassau and Suffolk counties, a poll showed Gov. Michael S. Dukakis strengthening his front-runner position for New York's primary April 19. 10 Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, in a speech at St. John's University in Queens, called for the United States to lead an international campaign against narcotics. Gov. Dukakis proposed financing it with foreign aid money. 10 New York gay newspaper endorses Dukakis 10 Gore and Dukakis in Round 1 of TV bout 11 Regional 33-36 The inquiry on Tawana Brawley has found no evidence, authorities said, to support charges by Miss Brawley and her lawyers that 3 white law-enforcement officials brutalized the black teen-ager in a kidnapping last fall. 1 A New York campaign finance law, passed 2 months ago by the City Council, still allows some disputed fundraising practices, supporters and critics say. The restrictions apply only to candidates who accept public funds. 33 Rumors on the sale of the '21' Club, a Manhattan restaurant that underwent a multimillion-dollar renovation, are being fueled by staff cuts and menu changes. Its principals have denied the rumors. 33 The defense in a racketering trial accused Federal prosecutors of using false testimony and deceptive tactics against 11 men charged with taking part in the activities of the Genovese organized-crime family. 35 Cockroaches are alive and thriving in New York and other cities, participants in a seminar on urban entomology said. Worst of all, they said, roaches are not only disgusting but hazardous to the health. 35 Man charged in death of his companion's 3-year-old daughter 33 Bridgeport seeks fiscal rescue 33 Albany budget talks stall over contracts 34 Ex-militia chief gets prison term 35 Ex-customs broker held in diversion of U.S. duties 35

title: Fernandez Falters; Carter Hits Homer
description: When it's 40 degrees and the wind is gusting to 20 miles an hour, and you're a surfer from Honolulu who doesn't like cold weather, and you just suffered back spasms in spring training, this probably wasn't your night to pitch. And for Sid Fernandez, it wasn't. The 25-year-old left-hander made his 1988 debut for the Mets, and it was a somewhat stormy one. The Philadelphia Phillies nicked him for one run in the first inning and another in the third, and then Lance Parrish nailed him with a 430-foot home run for two runs in the fourth. And just like that, the Mets were beaten by 5-1 and, despite all their long-range hitting this week, they were suddenly a .500 ball club after four games.

title: Revisions in U.S. Tax Code Saved Reagans About $6,000 in 1987
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, paid nearly $6,000 less in Federal income taxes for 1987 than for 1986 after the sweeping changes in the tax code, although their gross income was higher last year, the White House disclosed here today.

title: Guard Is Killed at Market
description: A 30-year-old security guard was shot to death in a Brooklyn supermarket yesterday when he approached two youths who were believed to be shoplifting, the police said. The youths escaped. The guard, Leslie Sterling, of 118-14 193d Street in St. Albans, Queens, was shot once in the chest about 10 A.M. when he approached the youths in the Waldbaum's supermarket at 1380 Pennsylvania Avenue in the East New York section. A police spokesman, Officer Peter O'Donnell, said that the youths, said to be between 12 and 18, fled in a light green car.

title: State Wins $600 Million in Suit
description: A Federal jury awarded South Dakota $200 million today in the state's antitrust suit against Kansas City Southern Railway Company over the demise of a coal slurry project.

title: John Glessner Lee, 89, Aviation Engineer
description: John Glessner Lee, a pioneering aviation research engineer who was instrumental in the founding of the University of Hartford, died at a nursing home here Thursday. He was 89 years old and lived in Stonington, Conn.

title: 90-Year-Old Is Re-elected
description: A 90-year-old retired obstetrician, who is Florida's oldest elected official, has won his sixth four-year term on the town council. The official, Louis Haas, joined the council in 1968. He is the oldest elected official known to the National League of Cities and the American Association of Retired Persons in Washington. ''If I live another four years, I surely will be'' the oldest, Dr. Haas said after his victory Tuesday.

title: Nigeria Passport Fraud
description: All staff members of the Nigerian passport office in the central city of Minna have been arrested on charges of selling passports to foreigners, the Nigerian state radio reported Friday. A broadcast monitored in Abidjan said the fraud was exposed when immigration officials arrested citizens of the neighboring nation of Niger who could not speak any of Nigeria's languages.

title: British Rate Cut to Slow The Pound
description: Seeking to slow the pound's surge, Britain reduced domestic interest rates yesterday to the lowest level in a decade, and major British banks followed the central bank's move by cutting their main lending rates.

title: Reagan Halts All Payments To Panamanian Government
description: President Reagan, increasing the economic pressure on Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, ordered a halt today to all payments to the Government of Panama by American citizens or by United States corporations or their Panamanian subsidiaries.

title:
Your Money;
Making the Most Of a Windfall
description: LEAD: WHEN a young Dallas woman received a $185,000 settlement from a lawsuit after one of her children died in an accident, her friends and relatives beseiged her with requests for loans and gifts. She turned to Kathleen Muldoon, a financial planner with Carter Financial Management in Dallas. ''We put all of the money in certificates of deposit, so she could say the money was tied up,'' Ms.

title: Koreans Open Assembly Campaign
description: South Korea's capacity for the promise and the potential disorder of democracy was put to a new test today with the official start of a campaign for National Assembly elections this month.

title: Oil Prices Slip Somewhat On Eve of OPEC Meeting
description: Five leaders of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries gathered here today for talks that analysts said would test the group's resolve to bolster world oil prices.

title: Polysar of Canada Rejects Nova Bid
description: The Polysar Energy and Chemical Corporation rejected a takeover bid of $1.17 billion (Canadian), or about $943.5 million (American), by the Nova Corporation of Alberta to buy the assets of the Ontario petrochemical company.

title: ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Consists of net from operations of $2,543,000, or 15 cents a share, and a $2,035,000 gain from the repurchase of debt. c-Consists of net from operations of $6,645,000, or 32 cents a share, and a $1,192,000 loss from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said its net for the latest quarter benefited from the reversal of $15.6 million of unrealized loss before income taxes in its investment portfolio at the end of fiscal 1987. Adoption of FAS No. 96 relating to income taxes in 1987 resulted in a restatement of the first-quarter results. Utilization of the tax-loss carryforward of $3,686,000, or 17 cents a share, was restated as a reduction in the income tax provision, and the cumulative effect resulted in a decrease in net income of $1,192,000.

title: Final Arguments Made In Documents Case
description: Lawyers made closing arguments today in the trial of Charles Merrill Mount, an art scholar and historian who has been charged with illegally transporting documents and letters stolen from the Library of Congress and the National Archives.

title: Coping With the Tax Deadline
description: With all the complications in the tax law this season, more than the usual number of procrastinators are expected to seek a reprieve from next Friday's filing deadline.

title: Scenic Design for In-Store Try-Ons
description: People trying on spring and summer clothes may be seeing themselves in a new light. Many retailers have been refitting their dressing rooms in recognition of what shoppers intuitively know: dressing rooms can be a major factor in sales.

title: Review/Concert; Debussian Allusions in New Works
description: Debussy, long an exotic and somewhat lonely figure in music history, seems suddenly to have become a role model. The coloring of his music alludes mistily to the far away and the elusive; the grammar has an ambiguous way of getting ancient modal responses out of modern extensions of diatonic harmony. This suits young composers just fine. Oldness, with nostalgia and mystery added in, has sales appeal; a little newness maintains self-respect.

title: Louisiana-Pacific
description: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation has received $440 million from the Federal Government as final payment for 26,544 acres of timberland taken in the 1978 expansion of California's Redwood National Park. With previous payments, the wood-products manufacturer has received $665 million in principal and interest for the timberland. About $100 million of the settlement will be used to pay back taxes on the land, and $170 million will repay long-term debts that carried provisions for repayment after a settlement was received. Louisiana-Pacific has 128 plants and mills throughout the United States.

title: University of North Carolina At Chapel Hill Fills Top Post
description: Paul Hardin, a North Carolina native who has developed a tough reputation in managing athletics at the college level, was unanimously elected today as the new chancellor of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

title: Shamrock's Deal
description: Shamrock Holdings Inc., unsuccessful in a takeover bid for the music and video retailer Wherehouse Entertainment last year, has agreed to buy Show Industries, parent of a rival California chain, Music Plus, for undisclosed terms. But analysts said Shamrock probably paid about $40 million for the 54-store chain, based on the $118 million price for which Wherehouse was eventually sold.

title: Zoeller Is Critical Of Masters Course
description: Fuzzy Zoeller, winner of the 1979 Masters, leveled strong criticism today of the playing conditions at the Augusta National Golf Club when he accused the Masters officials of ''tricking up'' the greens.

title:
Patents;
Making a Bicycle Look Like a Motorcyle
description: LEAD: A bicycle can be fitted with equipment to make it look and sound like a motorcycle. Leonard R. Griffin, a service technician in St. Louis, received patent 4,735,592 this week for a simulated exhaust pipe and a device that engages the bicycle wheel spokes to create sound resembling that of a motor.

title: Civil Rights Act Only Imposes New Quotas; Commission News
description: To the Editor:

title: Advanced Micro Devices Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest first quarter reflects its recent merger with Monolithic Memories Inc.

title: The Shoe Was Sittin' Chilly
description: THE most remarkable hands in the history of sports may belong to a man who wears a size 1 1/2 shoe.

title: Streamlining Debt
description: If you itemize on your tax return, you will feel the pinch of the shrinking deduction for interest charged on credit card debt and personal loans. This may be an incentive to consider debt consolidation and repayment. If you are a homeowner, a home equity credit line would provide the money to repay debts and retain a full deduction for the interest. Other options to raise cash to pay off debts include unsecured personal loans and credit card cash advances. Unsecured personal loans can range from $2,000 to $25,000, depending on your credit rating. Credit card cash advances may be subject to a cap; also, interest rates for cash advances may be higher than for revolving credit. $ Loans Rates* Advantage Disadvantage Home equity 10.5% Least costly; Default may put interest fully home at risk. deductible Unsecured 15.78% Relatively simple High rate and personal to obtain curtailed tax deduction. Credit card 18.21% Can be obtained Highest rate of all advance immediately personal loans. * National average. Source: Bank Rate Monitor, North Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Review/Jazz; The Modes of James Moody
description: Performances by the saxophonist James Moody are often frustrating: he's one of the great living saxophonists, but he sometimes seems at a loss over what to do with his talent. An extraordinary improviser, he's assimilated the ascetic, blunt language of 1960's modalism into the slippery, elliptical phrasing of 1940's bebop. And he's a master of chords, making each chorus he takes a wonder of harmonic invention.

title: Benoit Sidelined
description: Joan Benoit, winner of the first women's Olympic marathon in 1984, will probably not run in the United States Olympic marathon trials, her coach said yesterday. ''There is a real slim chance, but we're looking at 99 percent that she won't run,'' Bob Sevene told The Associated Press in a telephone interview.

title: U.S.-Japan Beef Dispute
description: The Reagan Administration said today that Japan had refused a United States plea to settle through mediation their dispute over imports of American beef and citrus fruits. The refusal came hours after the United States trade representative threatened retaliation over the issue.

title: Chip Maker Shows Profit
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. returned to profitability in the first quarter, a reflection of improved sales in the semiconductor industry and its acquisition last year of Monolithic Memories.

title: Banker's Note Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Net income

title: Pro-Iran Party Yields To Militia in Lebanon
description: Pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem fundamentalists accepted defeat in southern Lebanon today at the hands of Amal, the more powerful and mainstream Shiite militia.

title: Campeau Has His Critics in Canada
description: When Robert Campeau, whose Campeau Corporation is taking over Federated Department Stores Inc., told a news conference this week that he preferred the business climate in the United States to that of his native Canada, he touched a sensitive nerve. The 63-year-old entrepreneur is discovering that many of his countrymen do not take kindly to suggestions that Canada is not as satisfying a venue for the ambitious as the United States.

title: 2 Backers of Change Named to Top Posts By Chinese Congress
description: China's highest body of state power today elevated a pioneer of China's economic changes of the late 1970's to the chairmanship of the congress, and a veteran of the Long March who is also associated with the changes to the ceremonial post of President.

title: Centrust Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Shultz May Attend Afghan Signing
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, will probably go to Geneva next week to attend the signing of the accords calling for the withdrawal of Soviet forces from Afghanistan, Administration officials said today.

title: U.S. Charges 2-Hour Delay in Riot Response
description: Administration officials criticized Honduras today for what they said was a two-hour delay in responding to a riot at the United States Embassy compound in Honduras.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the eighth day of Passover, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Corrections
description: A map with the Weather Report Friday, showing expected high temperatures and precipitation for the United States, was printed in error; it was a week old. Readers wishing copies of the correct map may write to the News Desk, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., said that its Bendix Electronics Group had signed a licensing agreement to manufacture air bag crash sensors designed by Breed Automotive Corp.

title: Olson Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $58,000 for the quarter and a loss of $4,638,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Net income and after income of $571,000 for the quarter and $1,305,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and extraordinary gains of $1,042,000 and $1,603,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The year-ago periods' results were restated for discontinued operations.

title: General Building Products Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: Teams Are Lining Up to Sign Klecko
description: The Jets have given up on Joe Klecko, but Coach Ron Meyer of Indianapolis wants the 34-year-old defensive lineman as the Colts' starting nose tackle.

title: Gore and Dukaksi: Round 1 on TV
description: Meet the new and improved Albert Gore Jr., less formal in olive drab and open blue collar instead of navy serge and red tie, but still tough enough to propose ''using the military to help stop drugs at our borders.''

title: Corrections
description: A correction in this space on March 8 about an obituary of Max. L. Heine securities executive, misidentified his associate Joseph C. Galdi. Mr. Galdi was the founder and first president of the Mutual Shares Corporation, of which Mr. Heine was later president.

title: The Smell of Money and the Whisper of Tourists
description: The island of Saba rises from the Caribbean Sea in a steep jungle-covered cone of rock. From a distance it sometimes resembles a bluish-green gumdrop. It is a tiny place, covering no more than five square miles, with about 1,100 people, some proudly claiming to be descendants of British pirates.

title: New Campaign Law: No Bar to Old Abuses
description: If New York City's new campaign finance law had been in effect in 1985, it would not have barred some of the most disputed fund-raising practices by candidates in that year's election.

title: Albert A. Jewett, Banker, 78
description: Albert A. Jewett, retired chairman of the Riverhead (L.I.) Savings Bank, died Wednesday at Central Suffolk Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Riverhead.

title: Fight on Contracts Stalls Budget Talks in Albany
description: For the first time in almost three weeks, state leaders met face to face this afternoon to negotiate a budget, emerging only to say that negotiations had broken down.

title: Jazz at Carlos 1
description: Helen Merrill, a jazz singer, is to perform tonight and tomorrow at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., with a 12:30 A.M. set tonight; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

title: Poll Finds Dukakis Extending Lead As the Candidates Stump New York
description: The Democratic Presidential contenders stumped the sprawling suburbs of Long Island yesterday as a new poll showed Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts strengthening his front-runner position for the New York primary April 19.

title: Mylex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Treasury's Bootlickers
description: With exquisitely perverse timing, the Reagan Administration is thinking about how to bash Nicaragua with economic warfare just as the Sandinistas and contras are trying to end their political and military warfare.

title: About New York; Writer's Auction: Self-Promotion In a Penthouse
description: Short of committing a felony, something truly heinous, it's hard to call attention to yourself in this town. People try, all the same, especially those headstrong ones after a piece of the arts. Alan Ira Rosenberg is a particularly shameless case in point.

title: I.B.M. to Allow PS/2 Copies But Will Increase Royalties
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would let makers of I.B.M.-compatible computers license the patents necessary to produce copies of its new PS/2 computer line.

title: Bella Weitzner, 97, Ex-Curator of Museum
description: Bella Weitzner, an anthropologist who was associated with the American Museum of Natural History for 80 years, died of a circulatory ailment Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 97 years old.

title: Hachette's Plans For Grolier Inc.
description: Hachette S.A., the Paris-based publishing company that is trying to acquire Grolier Inc., said that if its offer succeeded it would sell Grolier's educational toy unit to the Walt Disney Company for $52 million. Grolier, which publishes encyclopedias and is based in Danbury, Conn., rejected as inadequate the initial $21-a-share offer by Hachette, but has yet to respond to a sweetened bid of $24 a share, or $424 million, for the shares it does not already own.

title: Installment Debt Climbed In February
description: Consumers continued to take on new installment debt at a rapid pace in February as borrowing for automobiles rose at an annual rate of 14.7 percent, Federal Reserve statistics indicated today.

title: New Heights
description: Michael Jordan's spectacular feats as a scorer, defender and playmaker have made him a force to be reckoned with since he joined the Chicago Bulls in 1984. The feats have also nearly tripled Chicago's home attendance to an average of 18,042 fans per game and transformed the Bulls from also-rans into contenders.

title: First Chicago Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said its provision for credit losses in the latest first quarter was $100 million, compared with $75 million in the year ago first quarter.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''If you fail to clear the runways within a few minutes, we will land in the sea.'' - The pilot of a hijacked Kuwait Airlines jet.

title: Bridge
description: Climbing out on a limb and then hoping it will bear your weight is an exciting exercise. Whether you are a tree climber or a bridge player, you nervously face the prospects of a heavy fall.

title: Bertram Jacobs, Fire Official, 71
description: Bertram Jacobs, a retired deputy chief of the New York City Fire Department, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday at St. Clare's Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Two Friends' Paths Part Ways for Now
description: They were at opposite ends of the draw here, which is sometimes the only distinction between them. For the better part of two years now, Zina Garrison and Lori McNeil have been thought of as an entry in women's tennis, two childhood friends from Houston who learned to play on public courts and who are ranked near the top of the game. They shared a coach, practice time and the glory, and one could usually be found in the stands rooting for the other in a big match.

title: Bridgeport Asks Legislature For $34.4 Million Bailout Plan
description: Officials here have asked the General Assembly to approve a $34.4 million bailout plan that will clear the city's mounting debt but also place its long-muddled finances under state supervision.

title: Man Guilty in Hired Killer Case
description: A man has been convicted of Federal charges that he masterminded an attempted contract murder initiated by an advertisement in Soldier of Fortune magazine.

title: Oil Well Set Near Paris
description: The French oil group Elf Aquitaine will start drilling for oil just outside Paris in July, the company said today. Drilling will start in Ivry, two miles southeast of the French capital. More drilling is planned by the end of the year if the results are positive, Elf said in a statement.

title: What Led to the Afghan Accord
description: Mikhail Gorbachev says that an accord will be signed next week leading to the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan within nine months. The Soviet departure won't end the fighting in that country. But it opens the door to an eventual resolution by the Afghan people themselves. And it makes a historic contribution, probably more than any arms agreement has done, to Soviet-American relations.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Pete Gillen, who coached Xavier to three consecutive Midwest Collegiate Conference basketball titles and accompanying National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament berths, has received a two-year contract extension through the 1993-94 season. . . . Ray Roundtree, the Penn State wide receiver who had 45 receptions for 928 yards and 9 touchdowns in the last three seasons, has been refused one more year of eligibility by the N.C.A.A. Roundtree had applied for redshirt status for his freshman year when a groin injury restricted him to 40 plays in three games.(AP)

title: Air Crash Hearing in Alaska Focuses on Reduction in Fine
description: The Federal Aviation Administration reduced to $16,500 a staff member's recommendation of a $250,000 fine against a commuter airline that was later involved in a crash, according to testimony at a Federal hearing.

title: New York City Pensions Are Deferred Pay, Not Public Assistance
description: To the Editor:

title: Sulcus Computer reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
BUSH IS PROMISING STRESS ON ETHICS
description: Vice President Bush said today that if he was elected President his Administration would place added emphasis on ethics among government officials.

title: Army Believes Israeli Girl Was Killed by a Guard
description: An Israeli girl whose death brought fierce cries for vengeance against Arabs was not stoned to death, but killed by a bullet from the rifle of a Jewish settler guarding her, the army said today. Senior army commanders said they believed that the guard fired the fatal shot in panic.

title: Review/Violin; West German Protegee 8 Years After Debut
description: In the eight years since she made her debut with the New York Philharmonic, a lot has happened to Anne-Sophie Mutter. She has blossomed from a teen-age West German protegee of Herbert von Karajan to a loudly trumpeted (if one can trumpet a violinist) young star on the international instrumental scene. Thursday night she appeared with Charles Dutoit and the Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall for the first time since her debut, playing Beethoven's Violin Concerto.

title: Judge Seals the Court File On Sole Air Crash Survivor
description: The lone survivor of the nation's second worst air disaster should be allowed to ''grow without the glare of publicity,'' a judge said in closing the court files of 4-year-old Cecelia Cichan.

title: INSIDE
description: Afghan Accord Completed

title: Quaker State Takeover Bid
description: The Quaker State Corporation, the motor oil refining company, has received a $695 million takeover offer from an investment group.

title: Treasury Bonds Advance Sharply
description: Treasury bond prices climbed strongly in light trading yesterday in a rebound that market participants attributed largely to technical factors.

title: Botha, on Visit to Namibia, Moves to Tighten Control
description: President P. W. Botha tightened South Africa's control over South-West Africa today by giving Pretoria's representative in the territory new powers to silence radical opposition and censor the press.

title: Dukakis Says U.S. Must Take Drug War Abroad
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts toughened his Presidential campaign yesterday with a call for the United States to lead an international effort against drugs, using ''several million dollars'' of foreign aid money.

title: Martin Lowenfish, Architect, 85
description: Martin Lowenfish, an architect, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. He was 85 years old.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL NATIONAL BASKETBALL ASSOCIATION - Suspended James Donaldson, Dallas Mavericks center, and Mark West, Phoenix Suns center, for one game and fined them $4,000 each for fighting during a game on Wednesday. COLLEGES EASTERN NEW MEXICO - Named Earl Diddle basketball coach. PENN STATE - Announced that the National Collegiate Athletic Association refused to give Ray Roundtree, wide receiver, an additional year of eligibility. He sought redshirt status for his freshman year, when a groin injury restricted him to 40 plays in three games. RICHMOND - Signed Dick Tarrant, basketball coach, to a multiyear contract. XAVIER (OHIO) - Signed Pete Gillen, basketball coach, to a two-year contract extension. TENNIS UNITED STATES TENNIS ASSOCIATION - Named Nick Saviano national coach.

title: The Dog Patrol
description: To the Editor:

title: Unitel Video Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, APRIL 9, 1988
description: MARKETS Stock prices rose to their highest level since the crash in October. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 28.02 points, to 2,090.19, surpassing the previous post-crash high of 2,087.37 set on March 18. Analysts said the surge, most of which came late in the day, was caused by strength in computer stocks, optimism over the Group of Seven currency talks scheduled for next week and a new bout of program trading. For the week, the Dow gained 102.06 points, or 5.1 percent, with much of the lift coming from the 64-point surge on Wednesday. [ Page 37. ] Treasury bond prices climbed in light trading, in a rebound that market participants attributed largely to technical factors. The rally helped cut the yield on the bellwether long-term bond to 8.68 percent, from 8.79 percent the previous day. A good part of the gain was attributed to buying by short-sellers. [ 40. ] The dollar drifted lower while the British pound held its ground, despite cuts in British interest rates. Gold prices nudged upward, with a late New York quote of $449 an ounce, a gain of 15 cents. [ 46. ] Crude oil prices slipped slightly in quiet trading on the belief that the weekend OPEC meeting would do little to raise prices. [ 46. ] COMPANIES I.B.M. will sell licenses allowing copying of its new PS/2 computer line, conceding that the competition is necessary to help the machines become an industry standard. The spread of cheaper ''clone'' machines helps create a demand for I.B.M.-compatible software, making the entire industry more dependent on I.B.M. At the same time, I.B.M. said it would raise the cost of obtaining these licenses by as much as five times its current licensing fees. [ 37. ] The stock of Staley Continental surged above the $32 a share offered by Tate & Lyle. Staley's stock gained $5.875, to $37.375, and was the most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange. Tate & Lyle, a British company, has held a stake in Staley, a maker of corn sweeteners, for some time and has a joint European venture with Staley. Tate & Lyle said it wanted to ''return Staley to basics'' by selling many of the food-distribution operations that Staley has acquired. [ 37. ] Six radio stations will be involved in a $300 million merger of Metropolitan Holdings and Sillerman Acquisition. Metropolitan's holdings include the New York stations WNEW-AM and -FM. [ 39. ] Quaker State received a buyout offer of $695 million, or $26.50 a share, from a group led by a New York investment firm. [ 38. ] West Point-Pepperell suffered one serious blow and narrowly fended off another in its quest for control of J. P. Stevens. [ 48. ] The deadline on a bid for First City Bancorp was extended again as many bondholders continued to balk at the terms. [ 40. ] American Stores said it had received a commitment for $2.5 billion in financing for its battle to acquire Lucky Stores. [ 39. ] THE ECONOMY Consumer borrowing rose by $5.3 billion in February, an annual growth rate of 10.3 percent. The increase was led by a 14.7 percent annualized rise in the amount of money borrowed to buy automobiles. Analysts said this latest sign of consumer confidence was another indication that the economy remained on course for growth of 2 percent or more this year. [ 37. ] INTERNATIONAL British interest rates were cut to their lowest level in a decade to stem the rise of the pound in the currency markets. The pound's strength threatens to make British goods less price-competitive internationally. The Bank of England lowered a key lending rate by three-eighths of a percentage point, to 8 percent. [ 40. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Windfalls are usually welcome but caution is in order for anyone who comes into a large sum of money. Experts say the first thing to do is nothing. They recommend parking the money in a safe, interest-bearing account for six months or so until a comprehensive strategy can be devised. Your Money. [ 38. ] An organ-imaging method that offers improved detection of cancer and infectious diseases has been developed by a New Jersey company. Patents. [ 38. ]

title: The Avant-Garde Ex Post Facto
description: When the novelist Robert Coover organized a conference called ''Unspeakable Practices: A Three-Day Celebration of Iconoclastic American Fiction,'' he invited some old friends to Brown University. There would be panel discussions that might define literary post-modernism once and for all, Mr. Coover said, but mostly it would be ''a family gathering'' to mark John Hawkes's retirement as a teacher of writing at Brown. And it was a family gathering, complete with a family squabble, a reconciliation and an odd feast of roast piglet and Portuguese wine.

title:
CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Gotham Foils Superlock
description: LEAD: Most Kryptonite locks are no match for New York City bicycle thieves, it seems. On March 1, bike shops pasted this notice on all Kryptonite locks, except the new four-and-a-half-pound motorcycle model: ''This Kryptonite lock is not guaranteed in New York City.''

title: Koch Defends Attack on Jackson, Saying He Evades Issue of Israel
description: Mayor Koch continued yesterday to defend his attacks on the Rev. Jesse Jackson, accusing the Democratic Presidential candidate of evading an issue he ought to discuss.

title: Bay Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The latest quarter and 9-month results include gains on the disposition of investments of $213,000 and $3,528,000, respectively. The year-ago quarter and 9-month results include gains on the disposition of investments of $5,000 and $7,052,000, respectively.

title: Burmah Oil Plc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary charges of $400,000 for the latest year and $30.2 million for 1986. The results are in U.S. currency. The account was prepared using U.K. GAAP, and the items were translated using an exchange rate of 1 pound sterling equals $1.88 in effect on Dec. 31, 1987, and 1 pound sterling equals $1.48 for 1986.

title: Review/Jazz; Drums With a Different Beat
description: Errol Parker's music fills in conventional outlines in thoroughly eccentric ways. While he plays piano as well as drums, on Wednesday at the Knitting Factory he stayed behind his drum set, which substitutes a conga for a snare drum, and led a sextet in compositions and arrangements resembling mainstream, post-bop jazz - briskly swinging song forms with smooth, chromatic harmonies. But as with the drum kit, standard elements were altered and personalized from the bottom up.

title:
Patents;
Aircraft for NASA Has Three Fuselages
description: LEAD: An aerospace engineer at the Langley Research Center in Hampton, Va., has invented a multibody aircraft for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The engineer, Richard M. Wood, was awarded patent 4,735,381 this week.

title: Forty Niner Shows Speed at Keeneland
description: Forty Niner, the favorite for the Kentucky Derby May 7, ran his most impressive race of the year yesterday when he scored a five-length victory in the $72,625 Lafayette Stakes at Keeneland in Lexington, Ky.

title: This Spring, Iran and Iraq Take Their War to the People
description: FOR several months, the Iran-Iraq war has been locked in a bloodstained attrition on land, at sea and in the so-called war of the cities waged by missile strikes against civilian targets. Though the images might seem familiar, this year the dynamics of the war have changed.

title: Israel Must Let Palestinians Go or Lose Its Soul; What Einstein Foresaw
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
Wholesome Granite Springs Fare
description: LEAD: PAMELA and Ron (Fritz) Lunge have hit their stride, and, after a shaky opening three years ago, Fritz's in Granite Springs is running smoothly. This is the kind of restaurant the county needs more of. A mural of giant pastel irises has a floral motif bolstered by loads of dried, fake and fresh flower arrangements that soften the boxy angles of the dining room.

title: Find Your Comfort Level
description: IT'S A MUTUAL GROWTH process,'' said Presidential candidate Jesse Jackson of his appeal to white voters, ''what I call 'raising the comfort level.' ''

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Newspapers Urge Reversal; Court Ruling on Leaks Could Make It a Crime To Talk to the Press
description: EVERY day, officials ranging in power from Cabinet members down to civil servants leak to reporters bits of information about defense and foreign policy that have been classified as secret.

title: DEALING WITH GORBACHEV
description: Good for The New York Times Magazine for publishing Richard Nixon's piece on Mikhail S. Gorbachev (''Dealing With Gorbachev,'' March 13). You will no doubt receive some flak about giving major space to a man who disgraced and humiliated this nation like no other American in history, but the piece is important because it should teach younger Americans about the style of thinking in Mr. Nixon's generation, which fostered the 43-year cold war and, despite our current social and economic ills, would maintain it at all costs.

title: TEXAS WINS N.C.A.A. TITLE
description: Kirk Stackle and a record-breaking relay team led Texas to the team title tonight in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 65th annual men's swimming championships.

title: In Wake of Mergers, Newly Unemployed
description: ACQUISITIONS, divestitures, mergers and reorganizations spell surplus: a surplus of employees, as white-collar workers at Westchester companies, including General Foods, Nestle, Union Carbide, AMF, Stauffer Chemical and Gimbel's, have discovered.

title: Australia
description: To the Editor: C. C. O'Hanlon's article on Byron Bay, Australia (''A Balmy Beach Town in New South Wales,'' Travel, Feb. 14), both surprised and delighted us. My family has been carrying on a sustained love affair with Byron, visiting there every second year in January for the last 12 years.

title: SUPPORT OF PARTY OFFICIALS GIVES DUKAKIS HIS LEAD
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts has built his small lead in the Democratic delegate race largely among the Democratic National Committee members, governors, Congressmen and other party leaders who go to the convention by virtue of their office or party title.

title: Worker Killed at Restaurant
description: A kitchen worker was fatally stabbed yesterday in a dispute with a co-worker at a midtown Manhattan restaurant, the police said. The victim, Joshe Calderon, 27 years old, was stabbed in the back during an argument with Efraim Mathos at Wolf's Delicatessen, 57 West 57th Street. Mr. Calderon died at Roosevelt Hospital. A police spokesman, Sgt. Maurice Howard, said Mr. Mathos fled. The two men lived in a Bronx shelter.

title: General Dynamics
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: The Yellow Pages, Cabbie, Please

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. Some of the bricks on the side of my brick stoop are flaking off and chipping, leaving saucerlike depressions. I have tried filling these with mortar and cement, but this didn't work. Is there a way I can fill the depressions or somehow treat the bricks to prevent any further deterioration?

title: DEALING WITH GORBACHEV
description: Perhaps a revealing innacuracy in Richard Nixon's otherwise comprehensive and lucidly written article is the paragraph:

title: Lisa Holzwarth Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. H. Albert Holzwarth of Bangor, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Ann Holzwarth to William Harris White, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. White of Norwell, Mass. Ms. Holzwarth and her fiance, 1984 graduates of Bowdoin College, plan to marry in June. The future bride is an account officer at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York. Mr. White is a member of the class of '88 at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Motor Memories

title: Rockville Centre Wary Of Hospital Expansion
description: LEAD: MERCY HOSPITAL in Rockville Center, with 387 beds, plans a major $33 million expansion on its 30-acre site, but the Rockville Centre Village Board is wary of the scope of the plan.

title: Elizabeth Traynor Weds T. G. Fowler
description: Elizabeth Ann Traynor, an associate editor at G. K. Hall & Company in Boston, was married yesterday in New York to Thomas Grasselli Fowler, a buyer with Shreve, Crump & Low the Boston jewelry and gift concern. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the chapel of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: 262 Chosen for Guggenheim Awards
description: The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation announced last week that it had chosen 262 artists, scholars and scientists as recipients of its 1988 fellowships.

title: 'Jaws' With No Shark?
description: What if Bruce, the finny terror of the Amity populace, ahd turned vegetarian? What if Humphrey Bogart and Claude Rains had hopped on board the plane that foggy night in Casablanca? Ever yearned to rewrite the ending of a movie? For a baker's dozen of cultural figures, the attraction was - though not fatal - irresistible. Page. 31.

title: Tucson
description: To the Editor: Elizabeth Neuffer's description (''Taking Off From Tucson,'' Travel, Jan. 31) of the natural and historical sights within a day's drive of Tucson was remarkably comprehensive, with one major omission: Old Tucson in the Tucson Mountain complex near the Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum and the Saguaro National Monument West. This manmade attraction (''Twelve Miles and One Hundred Years From Town'') is surpassed only by the Grand Canyon in the number of visitors drawn to Arizona sights.

title: By NEWGATE CALLENDAR
description: Partly it's a parable, taking us from Eden to a problematic future. Partly it's a social study about benevolent dictatorship. It has a lot to do with human greed. It's also a rattling good adventure story. It is ISLAND by Thomas Perry (Putnam, $18.95), and whatever it is, it's wacky, imaginative, funny, serious and altogether different.

title: Rail Line Shortfall: Places to Park
description: LEAD: GETTING a permit to park at some New Haven Line railroad stations can be as difficult as getting season tickets for the New York Giants.

title: Agencies Act to Repair Rock Cuts
description: LEAD: FOLLOWING a rockslide on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in Greenburgh last January that killed a motorist, the Thruway Authority has identified nine rock cuts in the county that need repairs and has revised its inspection procedures for pinpointing problem sites, officials said.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Amityville $210,000 390 Jervis Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 24-year-old ranch; den, fireplace, basement, pool, 1-car garage; taxes $4,000. Bayport $450,000 10 South Gillete Street 8-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 100-year-old Victorian; 3 fireplaces, butler's pantry, basement, 1.75 acres; taxes $6,200. Massapequa $700,000 300 Riviera Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split level; den with fireplace, dining room; taxes $6,500. Patchogue $115,000 20 Prospect Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 80-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, porch, 1-car garage; taxes $1,800. Quogue $90,000 24 Grove Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,100. Sayville $249,000 27 Timber Ridge Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old colonial; fireplace, skylights, whirlpool bath, brick patio, 1.5 acres; taxes $4,700. OTHER AREAS Scarsdale, N.Y. $375,000 24 Sheldrake Place 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old colonial; den, paneled playroom, cul de sac; taxes $6,600. Cornwall, Conn. $420,000 College Street 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 18th-century colonial; 2 barns, bordering state forest, 10 acres; taxes $2,941. Maplewood, N.J. $267,000 145 Lenox Terrace 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 2 half-baths, 43-year-old colonial; den, c/a, patio, fireplace; taxes $5,119.

title: Silver Anniversary Auction Will Offer Many Valuable Lots
description: THE Robert A. Siegel Auction Galleries will conduct its 25th ''Rarities of the World'' auction on April 23 at 1 P.M at the New York Helmsley Knickerbocker, 3d Avenue and 42d Street. This Silver Anniversary auction will offer 818 lots that are expected to realize between $2.5 and $3 million. The sale is well balanced with value in most United States specialties and an above-average foreign rarities section.

title: Hong Kong
description: To the Editor: Amanda Mayer Stinchecum's article on Hong Kong tailors (Travel, Feb. 21) reminded me of my transaction with James Chen during a 38-hour stay in Hong Kong in 1985. Following breakfast on a hot July morning, I went in search of someone to make a silk blouse and wool culottes. The house of Chen was nearby. I had made sketches on a sheet of notepaper. By 11 A.M. we had debated about the designs and selected the fabrics. Measurements had been taken and a 5 P.M. fitting scheduled. One blouse had become three.

title: LONG ISLAND FOLLOW-UP
description: Medical Center

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AN UNCOMMON SAILOR: A Portrait of Admiral Sir William Penn. By Lucie Street. (Dunne/St. Martin's, $12.95.) In ''An Uncommon Sailor,'' the English writer Lucie Street blows a thick layer of dust off the reputation of Sir William Penn. He is remembered as the father of the Quaker who founded Pennsylvania, but Ms. Street sees him as an admiral who ''should be ranked with Drake and Nelson as one of the great makers of the English naval tradition.'' In a life that spanned just 49 years, Penn revamped naval tactics, commanded the fleet that captured Jamaica and served in Parliament. Pennsylvania was granted to his son as a reward for these services. Penn clearly deserves recognition, but this slim biography may laud its subject too highly. Ms. Street praises Penn for his joint loyalties to king and Parliament. During the Commonwealth, however, this amounted to playing both sides and was part of the reason Cromwell sent Penn to the Tower. The House of Commons charged him with embezzling goods from captured ships - an accusation Ms. Street brushes aside rather lightly. Hasty research is a graver problem. Ms. Street claims ''it is probable that Penn conducted'' the English squadron that captured New Amsterdam in 1664. In fact, it was Col. Richard Nicolls. And one wishes the book drew more on one eyewitness: Penn's Navy Board colleague Samuel Pepys, whose acerbic eloquence deserves quotation. Ms. Street summarizes what Pepys recorded: Penn was fond of ''drinking the susceptible into a stupour, singing bawdy songs and supping at midnight off bread-and-butter on the roof.'' And there she stops, which is a shame: this warts-and-all portrait of Penn is intriguing.

title: A Compact for Boston's Hard Work High
description: AT AGE 15, Maria is facing fractions again. Her challenge this sixth period in Boston's English High School class in basic math is identifying lowest common denominators. Can two-sixteenths be reduced further? She stares at the problem, unsure how to respond until a tutor guides her painstakingly through numerator and denominator toward the realization that 16 can be divided by 2. It is another small breakthrough for Maria, who, in a class the teacher ranks at the fourth-grade math level, began the year having difficulty with sums and decimals.

title: Disarming Dream
description: MADE IN HEAVEN Starring Timothy Hutton and Kelly McGillis (in photo), Ann Wedgeworth, Maureen Stapleton, Debra Winger. Directed by Alan Rudolph. 1987. Lorimar Home Video. 102 minutes. $79.95. Rated PG. One brief sexual interlude.

title: Shops Offer 18th-Century Reproductions
description: IF, tired of the contemporary look, you contemplate furnishing in 18th-century style, Deborah Weinstein and Judith Wick of the Dovetail can probably help. A visit to Mrs. Weinstein's shop in Wilton or to Mrs. Wick's in Avon will take you into the period that is their specialty.

title: Israel Must Let Palestinians Go or Lose Its Soul; Russians Should Know
description: To the Editor:

title:
INVESTING;
Fund Managers Ride High - at Last
description: LEAD: AFTER many embarrassing years of lagging the broad market indexes, the average mutual fund manager has beaten them for the second quarter in a row. In the latest quarter, ended March 31, the primary reason was the improved performance of the stocks of the smaller-capitalized companies, analysts said.

title: Career Ladders for Teachers on The Rise
description: FIVE YEARS AGO this month, the National Commission on Excellence in Education declared that America was ''A Nation at Risk'' because of the failings of the American educational system. One way to mitigate the risk, it suggested, is a ''career ladder,'' an incentive pay plan that rewards teachers and administrators for doing better work or for taking on more responsibilities.

title: Brooklyn Program Joins Black Retirees and Pupils
description: When James A. Malone was growing up poor in Akron, Ohio, he and his nine brothers and sisters did not lack black role models. ''I wasn't isolated from middle-class adults,'' he said. ''And believe me, they made a difference in my life.''

title: Improving Kitchens and Baths
description: Renovating out-of-date bathrooms and kitchens requires a knack for efficient space-planning as well as an eye for interesting materials. Today designers are experimenting with new ways to use such traditional surfaces as marble or granite, and manufacturers are turning out a wealth of products that are both esthetically pleasing and easy to maintain.

title: POSTING: Where Roses Bloomed; 40 Town Houses for Tranquil Bayport
description: Bayport, L.I., is not a resort, although Fire Island, just across the Great South Bay, is. It is also not the most developed area on the South Shore, although Suffolk's largest downtown, Patchogue, and airport, Long Island-MacArthur, are nearby. Founded by clammers and rose growers, Bayport has remained a quiet, year-round community off the Montauk Highway, not the Long Island Expressway.

title: New Plays in New York For $5 a Ticket-It's True
description: ON THE NIGHT AFTER ''Phantom of the Opera'' opened to great fanfare on Broadway, a capacity crowd of 74 jammed into an upstairs theater at Playwrights Horizons for the first performance of ''Cold Sweat,'' a new play by Neal Bell.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
Selling Marie Fontaine's Moth & Freckle Cure
description: LEAD: From Mother Swan's Worm Syrup to Dr. Gutmann's Russian Vapor-Baths, Robert Jay's short, colorfully illustrated study, THE TRADE CARD IN NINETEENTH-CENTURY AMERICA (University of Missouri, $30), gives the reader an insightful glimpse of Americana. While some people may use this volume as a collector's guide, Mr.

title: Kelly Lambert, Teacher, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel W. Lambert 3d of Lawrenceville, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter Louisa Kelly Lambert to George T. J. Walker, a son of Pamela H. V. Walker of St. David's, Ontario, and George F. Walker Jr. of Niagara Falls, Ontario. The couple plan to marry in August.

title: Does Steinbrenner Help or Hurt The Yanks?
description: The question is irrelevant. Think back to the feuding Oakland A's of the early 70's and the swaggering Yankees of the late 70's. Neither of these teams was enamored of their owner. These guys are professionals and the bottom line is what they do between the white lines, not outside them. SCOTT BALDINGER Nyack, N.Y.

title: High-Style Leather in Vibrant Hues
description: LEATHER is still showing some vital signs of its earlier tough-guy image. Motorcycle jackets, for instance, remain very much a part of our culture; they're even enjoying a revival as part of fashion's retro movement.

title: INVESTORS' DREAM: SCHMIDT CASHES IN
description: To understand why some investors have been turning to baseball cards, consider that a 1973 Topps Mike Schmidt, which cost about a penny in 1973, has recently sold for as much as $170, an increase of well over 1 million percent in just 15 years.

title: He Puts College Angst to Song
description: JITTERS, S.A.T.'s, fear, college applications, anxiety, deadlines, response day - terror.

title: Manhattan Hotel Construction Surges
description: A COUPLE from Columbus, Ohio, checked into the Waldorf-Astoria last month, taking advantage of a special weekend rate. For $170.64 a night, the couple, Tom and Maria Harkins, and their two sons obtained accommodations that normally would have cost $100 more.

title: Melissa Cleveland Married in Boston
description: At the Church of the Covenant in Boston, Melissa Carol Cleveland, a daughter of Dr. Richard J. Cleveland of Wellesley, Mass., and the late Marjorie Hanna Cleveland, was married yesterday to Stephen Carol Bernhardt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carol Francis Bernhardt of Dedham, Mass. The Rev. Michael A. Granzen, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Edward Weinfeld Memorial
description: A memorial is scheduled to be held Thursday in Manhattan for Judge Edward Weinfeld, who was the oldest active Federal district judge in the country when he died Jan. 17 at age 86. Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the United States Supreme Court is scheduled to be among the speakers at the service, which will be held in the Federal Court House at Foley Square, where Judge Weinfeld served for 37 years. Chief Judge Charles L. Brieant of the Southern District of New York will preside over the service, beginning at 4 P.M. Judge Morris E. Lasker is to introduce the speakers, who are to include Chief Judge Wilfred Feinberg of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Vacation Rental Market Holding Firm
description: LEAD: DESPITE fears that last October's stock market crash would have repercussions on the 1988 vacation home market, rentals and sales in the Hamptons have been unexpectedly strong. The market is softer on Shelter Island and on the North Fork, but in the East End's most exclusive areas, it seems stronger than usual.

title: Testing Britain's School 'Reform'
description: IN BRITAIN, new national tests will be a key tool in the Government's effort to enact the most far-reaching changes in that nation's education system in 40 years. Introduced in Parliament last November, the education reform bill calls for a unified national curriculum backed up with a series of tests administered to children at the ages of 7, 11, 14 and 16. The overhaul of the system reflects Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's free-market philosophy and her commitment to modernizing British classrooms to strengthen the national economy.

title: Trying to Undo A Prison Record
description: IF THE object of a prison sentence is to rehabilitate the prisoner, then the story of Dr. Timothy McCormick of Pittsburgh could be one of the nation's brighter successes. So far it isn't. He was accused in 1974 of transporting marijuana in a suitcase for a friend. Dr. McCormick says that he was tricked into doing it; that he thought the suitcase contained clothing.

title: Architecture: Cycles of Invention
description: There was a time, a decade or so ago, when nothing in architecture was more startling than the mere idea of putting a gable on a house. How clever, how brazen even, such a thing seemed to eyes conditioned by years of sleek metal and glass. Since most of architecture's estabishment still embraced the cool lines of modernism, a gable -- or a pediment or a cornice or almost anything else from the traditional language of architecture -- symbolized breaking away. There was no small irony to this, of course: What was modern became old-fashioned; what had been old-fashioned became modern.

title: A Wee Union for Bargaining
description: HERE'S a new setting for labor-management relations: an elementary school where sixth-graders and teachers negotiate the amount of homework assigned. The school is Public School 38, the James F. Murray School, in Jersey City - and if the pupils abide by the bargain, completing all homework and classwork for five consecutive days, they earn a free period as well.

title: Visits to Colleges Inspire Youths
description: EIGHTH-GRADE teachers at Dolan Middle School in Stamford are telling their students to ''think college.'' And they are not just saying that in classrooms.

title: Micro-loans
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: WHERE THE TRUTH LIES. By Helen Hayes and Thomas Chastain. (Morrow, $16.95.) This self-professed ''novel of glamour and murder in Hollywood'' begins with the fictional movie director Jack King's observation: ''In this town life doesn't imitate art; life imitates artifice.'' At least the legendary actress Helen Hayes and her collaborator, the novelist Thomas Chastain, give readers fair warning.

title: Transforming A Rental
description: The location may be perfect and the number of rooms exactly right, but the owner's taste - Grandma's chipped china and green industrial carpeting - is not yours, and the furniture - hulking misshapen lumps for sofas and unpainted bureaus - resembles that of a rooming house.

title: Investors Hope A Rich Future Is in the Cards
description: NEVER mind that the stock market crash and an uncertain economic outlook have plunged many investors into despair.

title: ON THE ROAD WITH GORBACHEV'S GURU
description: ABEL G. AGANBEGYAN, ECONOMIC guru and brain-truster to Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, strode through the human maelstrom on the floor of the Chicago Board of Trade. Engulfed by the shouting babel, he stood like a Soviet Gulliver - a large, lumbering Armenian with a thick thatch of wavy black hair - exploring how the American market operates.

title: Sound Ideas
description: A century ago, the novelist Edward Bellamy blithely predicted that by the year 2000 all human strife would be ended. Taking his cue from the newly invented telephone, he envisioned music being conveyed electrically into every home. Universal exposure to so benign an influence, he believed, would resolve all conflict.

title: ART AND INTRIGUE
description: A RENAISSANCE TAPESTRY The Gonzaga of Mantua. By Kate Simon. Illustrated. 309 pp. New York: Harper & Row.

title: Freed to Criticize, Some Criticize Freedom
description: IN a Moscow apartment Thursday night, someone flicked on the television to hear Mikhail S. Gorbachev's triumphant announcement that peace was at hand in Afghanistan. The buoyant Soviet leader said the last deadlock - over a mutual Soviet and American cutoff of military supplies - had been broken, and Soviet troops might begin their trip home as early as May 15, ending one of the most troublesome legacies that Mr. Gorbachev has inherited.

title: To Russia, for Partners and Profits
description: THE miniature business miracle began in January at a diplomatic reception in Oslo for the Soviet Prime Minister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. What captured his interest was not diplomacy but a more consuming passion: fishing.

title: Buckets of Bows, Barrettes and Turbans
description: AS fashion designers have shown more feminine flourishes, extravagant hair ornaments have followed. At Block Pharmacy (1282 Third Avenue, near 74th Street), about 50,000 bows, combs, headbands, barrettes, snoods and turbans are on display. More than 4,000 hair ornaments, at $2.50 to $275, are sold each week, said Rosette Lobell, the store's buyer.

title: Anne Dayton Weds Banker
description: Anne Sherman Dayton, a daughter of Mrs. Leland Stanford MacPhail Jr. of New York and Bruce Bliss Dayton of Minneapolis, was married yesterday to Robert Malcolm Buxton, the son of Baroness Guy de Gunzburg of New York and Paris and William Edgar Buxton of Memphis. The Rev. Dr. Seymour Flynn performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Licensing Of Cats Resisted
description: LEAD: DESPITE a year's effort by the state's Department of Health to promote the licensing of cats, fewer than 10 percent of the state's 567 municipalities currently do so, according to a survey conducted by the department last December.

title: An Emerging Theory on Blacks' I.Q. Scores
description: MOST social scientists know - though few publicly discuss it - that there has been a puzzling gap of about 15 points in I.Q. test scores, on average, between blacks and whites in America ever since the tests were first widely used more than 70 years ago. After long debate over why blacks score lower, and what it means, a fresh theory is putting the discussion into perspective.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Cairo Collection Heading Home

title: NEIGHBOR HELD IN DEATH OF HARLEM WOMAN, 92
description: A 92-year-old Harlem woman who was well liked in her neighborhood was found strangled in her apartment, and a 27-year-old woman from the same building was charged yesterday in her death.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Takoma Park, Md.;
Battling to Aid Illegal Renters
description: LEAD: CITIZENS of this wooded enclave are fighting a law that threatens to lead to the eviction of hundreds of tenants living in apartments illegally carved out of houses in single-family zones.

title: Sacred Music by Sweet Voices
description: ONE AFTERNOON LAST week, Peter Phillips, the director of the Tallis Scholars, stopped in at Corpus Christi Church on Manhattan's Upper West Side, partly to check out the acoustics, but mainly to look at its balcony arrangement.

title: New Jersey Guide
description: HOLOCAUST OBSERVANCES

title: JAPANESE-STYLE RACE CAPTURED BY IRELAND
description: The first American running of a Japanese national sport turned into a dramatic triumph for Ireland and a victory for California yesterday as 305 of the world's top distance runners braved biting winds and New York potholes to compete in the America's Ekiden, a five-stage, 50-kilometer relay through the streets of Manhattan.

title: Review/Piano; A Double Medal Winner In Heavyweight Program
description: Barry Douglas won the gold medal in the 1986 Tchaikovsky piano competition in Moscow, a year after taking the bronze in the Van Cliburn contest. It was no surprise, therefore, to find him handling the keyboard with exceptional facility in his first New York appearance on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall. Furthermore, the 27-year-old pianist from Northern Ireland put us on notice with the weight of his program that he was not afraid to risk dramatic failure. Anyone who plays Beethoven's ''Hammerklavier'' Sonata in public deserves a tip of the hat for raw courage. The fact that it can eat a good pianist alive lends a certain shiver of anticipation to any performance.

title: West Germany Honors Its American Friend
description: The President of West Germany, the Mayor of West Berlin, the chairman of Daimler-Benz and many other luminaries gathered here to mark the retirement of an American who as student, reporter, soldier and administrator played an intimate role in more than a half-century of German-American relations.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PRETTY GIRLS. By Garret Weyr. (Crown, $15.95.) In this dreary portrayal of female collegians in the 1980's, Garret Weyr takes on her own alma mater, the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill. Here Alexandria, Penelope and Caroline become friends as they discover their physical and mental similarities. ''Not pretty girls in the classical sense,'' but tall and tough-minded, they find refuge in their notion of themselves as the Amazon Club. Alexandria, an obsessive New Yorker, is bulimic (''She does not believe in dieting; she believes in vomiting'') and a recovering rape victim; Penelope falls in love with a beautiful homosexual and then, out of frustration, has hurried sex with an old lover, which results in pregnancy; Caroline, who's lost her boyfriend to ''a pretty girl'' and her older brother to the Vietnam War, suffers from jealousy, loneliness and depression. The Amazons' acquaintances confront drug abuse, fears of lesbianism and suicide - and all in a single semester of their sophomore year. Unfortunately, this disappointing first novel often seems sophomoric itself (''Fate works in mysterious ways,'' Alex thinks; ''A name change doesn't take you away from what you are,'' she later opines. ''Does anything?''), and its unrelieved drumming of pain and anxiety fails to engage the reader. In addition, by choosing to assemble her plot out of short, disjointed scenes, Ms. Weyr ends up with a patchy structure that is unable to support her story.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A Good Show That's Getting Even Better
description: LEAD: WITH astute management and outstanding volunteer support, the Northern New Jersey Antiques Show and Sale at Newark Academy here has evolved into a good event made even better in recent years.

title: Afghan Guerrilla Warns of Disorders in Pakistan
description: The leader of the Afghan guerrilla alliance today rejected the accord on withdrawal of Soviet troops and raised the threat of unrest among Afghan refugees in Pakistan.

title: Does Steinbrenner Help or Hurt The Yanks?
description: It is interesting that after Dave Winfield's book had been available for about a month, George Steinbrenner went public with his comments - a week or so before the Yankees' home opener. Steinbrenner won't hurt the Yankees in the standing, but may help them at the gate. NORM LEVISON New York

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: HISTORY
description: THE BOSTON COFFEE PARTY By Doreen Rappaport. Illustrated by Emily Arnold McCully. 64 pp. New York: An I Can Read Book/Harper & Row.

title: Convention Delegates: A Closer Look
description: Current breakdown of Presidential preference of delegates to national political conventions, compiled by The New York Times. Preferences are based on state laws, party rules, delegates' public statements and projections from early results in caucus states. Republicans do not have superdelegates. The number of Democratic delegates needed for nomination is 2,082 and the number of Republican delegates is 1,139. DEMOCRATS There have been 2,440 delegates chosen so far.

title: Ally of Army Mutiny Leader Escapes Detention in Manila
description: A rebel officer who led the attack on a Government television station during an attempted coup in August escaped with his guard from an army camp where he was detained, the army Chief of Staff said today.

title: Behind Five Top Films, Five Obsessions
description: MOVIES ARE A COLLABORATIVE ART, but some teammates are more equal than others. There is often one person who is a catalyst, the spark that makes a movie happen or makes it happen in a particular way. Most movies bump up against a hundred obstacles in their journey from first-draft screenplay to final picture. A bankable star can wheedle a studio into producing a movie it would otherwise never have touched. A director with a wicked sense of humor can turn a melodrama into a black comedy.

title: PRESS IS TAKEN TO TASK ON IRRADIATION STORIES
description: Recent articles about safety violations in the irradiation industry should alert the public to act on an issue which, although fital, has received less coverage than baseball or the sexual escapades of politicians and evangelical leaders.

title: CAMPAIGN OF BUSH GIVES UP SPOTLIGHT
description: Whenever Vice President Bush made public comment on a campaign swing the last two days, he offered words that were not likely to attract much attention.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 27 about handling infectious materials gave an inaccurate location for the Whiting & Davis Company. It is in Plainville, Mass.

title: Private Schools' Thin Edge
description: ARE PRIVATE schools worth the high cost America's parents are paying to send their children to them? The position taken by the Federal Department of Education's Assistant Secretary for Research could make them think twice.

title: A Democracy That Suits the Generals
description: WITH a civilian serving as its President since 1985 and a freely elected Congress now close to completing work on a new Constitution, Brazil is routinely included among Latin America's ''new democracies.'' Brazilians, though, know different. And last month, when the armed forces ruled yet again that the country was not ready for full democracy, any remaining doubts were dispelled: Brazil's military brass still has the last word here.

title: Memorial to Women Veterans Is Sought
description: AFTER four years of lobbying, an effort by supporters in New Jersey and their counterparts across the country to add a statue of a servicewoman to the Vietnam Memorial in Washington is heading toward a conclusion.

title: Paper Mill: 'Superstar' In a Glitzy Production
description: WHEN it comes to putting on a big-time musical, the Paper Mill Playhouse has resources to produce the real thing. With ''Jesus Christ Superstar,'' though, the state's foremost showplace for musicals seems to be faking it.

title: A PHOTOGRAPHER OF THE DEAD
description: THE SURPRISE OF BURNING By Michael Doane. 254 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: SANCTIONS WORRY FOES OF NORIEGA
description: Panamanians opposed to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega reacted with a mixture of puzzlement and cynicism today to President Reagan's decision to force American companies and individuals to withhold taxes and other fees from the military Government.

title: The Ascent of Books on Decline of U.S.
description: IT is unusual for an academic treatise to become a runaway best seller, but Paul Kennedy's ''The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers'' has been on the lists since February. Like a less popular work by David P. Calleo, ''Beyond American Hegemony,'' Mr. Kennedy's book contends that this nation's military spending is outstripping its economic strength, which could lead to a decline in American power.

title: Stamford Seeks to Ease Traffic Woes
description: LEAD: WITH the prospect of bumper-to-bumper congestion less than a decade away, Stamford is looking for ways to reduce peak-hour traffic.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. Some of the bricks on the side of my brick stoop are flaking off and chipping, leaving saucerlike depressions. I have tried filling these with mortar and cement, but this didn't work. Is there a way I can fill the depressions or somehow treat the bricks to prevent any further deterioration?

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. Some of the bricks on the side of my brick stoop are flaking off and chipping, leaving saucerlike depressions. I have tried filling these with mortar and cement, but this didn't work. Is there a way I can fill the depressions or somehow treat the bricks to prevent any further deterioration?

title: Bermuda Untamed
description: THE Bermuda National Trust has preserved several areas of land where an untamed, wild Bermuda coexists with the pink sand beaches, pastel-colored houses with trim lawns and neatly coiled bougainvillea. It is a Bermuda that was there long before horses pulled fringed surreys along dusty coral roads, and even before the Spanish explorer Juan de Bermudez discovered the islands in 1515.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on March 27 about lost and stolen airline tickets carried an incorrect report from United Airlines about its policy. The passenger fills out a lost-ticket form starting a 60-day waiting period. If the ticket is not used within that period, a refund, less $50, is authorized.

title: Solving a Perennial Problem
description: ''To own a bit of ground, to scratch it with a hoe, to plant seeds, and watch their renewal of life - this is the commonest delight of the race, the most satisfactory thing a man can do.'' Thus wrote Charles Dudley Warner in 1870 in ''My Summer in a Garden,'' one of the classics of American horticultural literature. But he was no sentimental fool about work for work's sake. Essential to any gardener's life, he said, is the love of digging in the ground ''(or of looking on while he pays another to dig).''

title: Blame the Men
description: THE FAILURE OF FEMINISM By Nicholas Davidson. 392 pp. Buffalo: Prometheus Books. $24.95.

title: BEAUTIFYING LIES AND POLYPHONIC WISDOM
description: THE ART OF THE NOVEL By Milan Kundera. Translated by Linda Asher. 165 pp. New York: Grove Press. $16.95.

title: THE HEART'S ETERNAL VOW
description: LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA By Gabriel Garcia Marquez. Translated by Edith Grossman. 348 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: America's Test Mania
description: THERE'S an old Army saying, 'If it moves, salute it,' '' said Gregory R. Anrig, president of the Educational Testing Service. ''Today some reformers seem to be saying 'If it moves, test it.' ''

title: Shell-Rich Marco Island
description: FROM the highest elevation in southwest Florida the vista opens wide across the Gulf of Mexico. But there's no fear of altitude sickness as you scan the horizon, for you're only 58 feet above sea level on Indian Hill, in a residential neighborhood on Marco Island. And even this gentle mound is an artificial height, laboriously created, basket by shell-filled basket, over hundreds of years by Calusa Indian women. They harvested clams, mussels, oysters and conch in these waters and then carried the shells to concentrated sites in efforts to lift their homes above the wet and boggy soil.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: CHESHIRE;
Town Finds Fame In Growing Plants
description: LEAD: EARL KURTZ stood among the acres of his greenhouses and said, with evident satisfaction, ''Plastic.''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: HISTORY
description: LEAD: THE LAST SILK DRESS By Ann Rinaldi. 350 pp. New York: Holiday House.

title:
GARDENING;
Preserving the Roots and Health of Plants
description: LEAD: PLANTS rely on the soil for several factors that are essential to their well-being.

title:
GARDENING;
Preserving the Roots and Health of Plants
description: LEAD: PLANTS rely on the soil for several factors that are essential to their well-being.

title: Where Taxpayers Have Their Say
description: YOU'RE steaming mad. Not only are you struggling to complete your 1987 tax return by Friday, but now the Internal Revenue Service is denying a $250 charitable deduction from the return you filed two years ago. You think you're justified - the deduction was for the Sunday collection at church - but you don't have receipts to substantiate it.

title: 'Someday I'd Even Like to Make a Living at It'
description: ALTHOUGH micro-breweries have enjoyed explosive growth in recent years, most of the new companies have had disappointing profits, and a few have sunk under the weight of debt and sluggish sales.

title: SHE HUNG THE MOON AND PLUGGED IN ALL THE STARS
description: THE BEAN TREES By Barbara Kingsolver. 232 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title:
BLACKBOARD NOTES;
Job Trade-Off: Drug Test
description: LEAD: COLLEGE SENIORS who graduate this spring can expect better job opportunities and bigger paychecks when they go looking for work. But there's a trade-off: before they're hired for that big job, they can also expect a mandatory drug test.

title: Roy E. Weatherby Sr., Firearms Innovator, 77
description: Roy E. Weatherby Sr., a leading authority on ballistics who was the creator of the famed Weatherby rifle favored by big-game hunters, died Tuesday. He was 77 years old It was Mr. Weatherby's perfection of his theory on high velocity, and the resulting Weatherby Magnum cartridges, that led to the development of the Weatherby rifle.
