title: RICHARD FORD'S UNCOMMON CHARACTERS
description: RICHARD FORD AND his wife, Kristina, have just rented another house, a double trailer they plan to use as a hunting cabin next fall. It's about 30 miles east of Great Falls, Mont., snug up against the Highwood Mountains, an isolated range of peaks that seems to have just sprouted out of the high plains from seeds dropped randomly by the wind. Temperature today is in the single digits though the sun is brilliant. There's nothing much out here but the trailer, the mountains behind it, a cold creek, a vast, rolling plain and the three of us.

title: Death by Stone and by Bullet
description: Tirza Porat, a 15-year-old Israeli, fell to the ground in the West Bank last Wednesday. She was killed by Palestinian-hurled stones or by a bullet from the gun of an Israeli protector. But however and by whomever, both sides are accountable -just as both are responsible for the more than 130 Palestinians who have been killed during uprisings over the last months.

title: THE IMPOSSIBLE DREAM
description: AMERICA INVULNERABLE The Quest for Absolute Security From 1812 to Star Wars. By James Chace and Caleb Carr. 367 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.

title: CROWDING IS CITED IN MENTAL WARDS
description: With psychiatric wards facing unprecedented overcrowding, more than 6,000 hospital beds in New York State are being tied up by mental patients who do not need to be hospitalized, according to a state report released yesterday.

title: Summertime, and the Learning Is Pleasing
description: FINDING the right summer activity for a child too young to draw a paycheck or too blase for Camp Cowabunga (or the like) can be a daunting task for parents. Happily, an interesting mix of programs can be found for children as young as 6 and ranging up to 18-year-olds who prefer educational and cultural enrichment to the rigors of a job.

title: On Bumpy '88 Trail, A Steadfast Dukakis
description: One day not long ago, while flying to a campaign event, Michael S. Dukakis wandered to the back of his chartered plane to chat with the press, then borrowed a reporter's copy of a new, still undelivered stump speech, billed as the newly passionate, exciting Dukakis message.

title: WASTEFUL PACKAGING AND TRASH DISPOSAL
description: The article March 6 about the rise in tipping fees at resource recovery facilities (''Towns Facing Bigger Bills for Trash'') misses an opportunity to look at some larger issues of the solid-waste problem.

title: Eleanor Mondale Wed in Wisconsin To Keith Van Horne, Football Tackle
description: The marriage of Eleanor Jane Mondale, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Mondale of Minneapolis, to Keith Van Horne, a son of Jean A. Van Horne of Clarendon Hills, Ill., and the late John Van Horne, took place yesterday at Wintergreen, the home of the bride's maternal grandparents, the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. John Maxwell Adams, in Hudson, Wis.

title: South Africa Defiant On Namibia, Tutu Says
description: Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu, on a tour of this South African-administered territory, accused the Pretoria authorities today of defying the world by strengthening its rule of South-West Africa.

title: Anne Waggenspack Wed in Louisiana
description: At St. Joseph Roman Catholic Cathedral in Baton Rouge, La., Augusta Anne Waggenspack, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Clay A. Waggenspack of Baton Rouge, and Dr. Thomas Arthur Sporn, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Michael B. Sporn of Bethesda, Md., were married yesterday by the Rev. Thomas Cleary, a great-uncle of the bridegroom.

title: Finales Abound As Seasons Wane
description: IT seems a little early for seasonal finales, but the week brings a whole raft of them, including three at 4 this afternoon.

title: Mimi Kidd Is Married
description: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, Mimi Kidd, a vice president in private banking at the Republic National Bank of New York, was married yesterday to John Anthony Barone, the director of marketing and sales in Carney, N.J., for the Gardner Asphalt Company. The Rev. Kenneth O. Jones officiated. The bride, who will retain her name, is the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. A. C. Kidd of South Orange, N.J. Her previous marriage ended in divorce, as did that of her husband, a son of Samuel Barone of Bound Brook, N.J., and the late Mrs. Barone.

title: Earl Wild Harvests a Cornucopia of Liszt
description: IN THE 1986-87 SEASON, EARL WILD observed the centenary of the death of Franz Liszt with three concerts that covered a great deal of Liszt's output.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: HISTORY
description: CHINA'S LONG MARCH 6,000 Miles of Danger. By Jean Fritz. Illustrated by Yang Zhr Cheng. 124 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons.

title: STREETSCAPES: Saw Mill River Parkway Gas Station; An Abandoned Rustic Haven for the Sunday Driver
description: NOW vacant and vandalized, the rustic gasoline station on the southbound Saw Mill River Parkway near Farragut Avenue in Yonkers has so far escaped demolition, although others on the Westchester parkways have been taken down.

title: Government Greed Is Bad for Everyone
description: NEW JERSEY state government has got greedy, and if we don't stop this nonsense soon, taxpayers are going to be in a lot of trouble.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Takoma Park, Md.;
Battling to Aid Illegal Renters
description: LEAD: CITIZENS of this wooded enclave are fighting a law that threatens to lead to the eviction of hundreds of tenants living in apartments illegally carved out of houses in single-family zones.

title: Thomas B. Pickens, Oilman, 90
description: Thomas Boone Pickens, an oil-lease buyer and the father of the investor T. Boone Pickens Jr., died Monday. He was 90 years old.

title: THE REGION: Sanitation vs. Medical Workers; Do Municipal Salaries Reflect A Worker's Relative Worth?
description: WHY is a garbage collector worth more to New York City than an ambulance technician?

title: Fighting Narcotics: U.S. Is Urged to Shift Tactics
description: No President has spoken out more against drugs than President Reagan. No Administration has signed more anti-drug treaties or spent more money to stem the flow of drugs into this country.

title: PRIVATE MEANS
description: SUE FARRELL PROPELS HER VISITOR AMONG THE RACKS OF knit tops, silk dresses and gabardine suits, pausing to pull out a linen blazer. ''This,'' she says, pointing to its gilded embroidery and fanciful beadwork, ''is for the girls who want a little glitter in their lives.'' ''And those'' - she indicates a nearby group of daintily pleated blouses - ''are for a quieter sort of lady.''

title: Family Outing On a Slow Boat In the Midlands
description: OUR family venture on the canals of England started innocently enough. Years ago I had become fascinated with ''the river'' in ''The Wind in the Willows.'' Then, reading Jerome K. Jerome's ''Three Men in a Boat,'' an account of a week's boating holiday on the Thames in the late 1800's, during a visit with friends in London, I mentioned how nice it would be to explore the waterways. Two weeks later in the middle of August, our friends arranged for us to board a rented narrowboat at Stoke Prior in the Midlands.

title: Cheating: Alive And Flourishing
description: ALL THE professors I know say they are seeing a higher percentage of classroom cheating.'' - Richard A. Dienstbier, psychology professor, University of Nebraska.

title: Ranger Fan's View of Potvin
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ms. Green, Architect, To Marry Eric Berger
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Green of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Fredda R. Green, to Eric D. Berger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen H. Berger of Roslyn, L.I. The wedding is to be in September.

title: If We Forget, Who Will Be Next?
description: WE CALL them survivors of the Holocaust and, with indulgence, they allow us to do so. It's easier that way. How otherwise to explain, after 45 years, that they are nothing more than its living victims?

title: Serene Now, Antietam
description: MORE than anything else, the battlefield at Antietam, site of the bloodiest day in the nation's wartime history, is a monument to the American private soldier who stands in the rear rank on parade but in the front rank on attack.

title: For Blacks, Not All Goals In Basketball Are on Court
description: WHEN the Black Coaches Association held its first open forum last week, before the final game of the national college basketball championship in Kansas City, it was one of the few times since the 1968 Olympic boycott that blacks had come together to exert pressure on the sports establishment.

title: A Useful Guide for a Fly Fisherman's First Season
description: ALTHOUGH I have a tendency to wince when yet another book dealing with fly fishing for trout comes my way, I was pleased to discover that Richard Talleur's ''The New Fly/Fishing for Trout/A Guide for Beginners'' (Winchester Press) is first rate. If you are starting from scratch, it will keep you busy and answer all your questions for at least one season.

title: Seeing Schubert Whole
description: ALFRED BRENDEL HAS LONG taken it upon himself not only to challenge but also to change certain stereotypes about Schubert's music.

title: One-Stop Shopping for a Home Is Near
description: LEAD: INCREASING numbers of real estate agencies are using computers to help home buyers select and obtain mortgages, feeding the trend toward ''one-stop shops'' where customers can find a house, a mortgage and homeowner's insurance.

title: When It's 'We Regret to Inform You...'
description: ON April 16, 14 years ago, I fingered ''16'' on my bathroom mirror before I cleaned it.

title: OPEC and 7 Non-Members Plan to Meet to Adjust Prices
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced today that it planned to meet here in two weeks with at least seven oil-producing nations who are not OPEC members to agree on ways to stabilize world oil prices, including a global cut in oil production to raise prices above present levels.

title: DEBATING LUNACY
description: MIND-FORG'D MANACLES A History of Madness in England From the Restoration to the Regency. By Roy Porter. 412 pp. Cambridge, Mass: Harvard University Press. $38.50.

title: Ballet School Gives Awards
description: The School of American Ballet has announced the winners of the annual Mae L. Wien Awards. Antonina Tumkovsky, a teacher at the school for 39 years, and Gretchen Patchell, Eric Lindemer and John Selya, all students at the school, will receive the award, which was established by the family of the late Mrs. Wien, an arts patron. The prizes, $10,000 in cash, are intended to honor outstanding faculty members and students who show exceptional promise. Peter Martins, a director of the New York City Ballet and chairman of the school's faculty, will present the awards at a dinner on Tuesday at the New York State Theater.

title: On-the-Job Learning
description: PRINTING a daily newspaper aboard an ocean liner plowing through rough seas, while his co-workers turned green with seasickness, was not something Antonio Sierra learned about back in his printing classes at the Rochester Institute of Technology. Nor had he received instruction on how to repair the ship's broken printing press so that he could continue publishing its standard 18,000 items a day. But then again, neither had his professors described how beautiful Barbados really is, nor how wonderful its people.

title: After White House, Back to the Stars
description: The Santa Monica Mountains, which erupt along the Southern California coastline here, soften into steep, verdant hills in Bel Air, an elegant community where money is characterized rather simply: Not old or new, just lots of it.

title: Judge Delays Mecham Trial
description: A judge has granted a defense lawyer's motion to delay the criminal trial of former Gov. Evan Mecham and his brother, Willard, for a month. Judge Michael Ryan announced his decision Friday in Maricopa County Superior Court after the lawyer, Michael Scott, said he had a scheduling conflict. Judge Ryan agreed to postpone the Mechams' trial to May 19 from April 21.

title: LAUGHTER AND HOPE
description: Melvin Konner underestimates the power of positive thought in his article. Speaking as someone who spent a prolonged period of time in the hospital fighting for my life, I do not doubt that a strong mental attitude can help in fighting illness.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: APRIL 10, 1988
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 5 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 2 5 OVER THE EDGE, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) A psychologist-detective solves a string of vicious murders. 3 3 WATCHERS, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $4.95.) Two creatures - one good, one evil - emerge from a secret government laboratory. 4 * 3 BOLT, by Dick Francis. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A star jockey has to contend with a romantic crisis, a family feud and an arms-selling intrigue. 5 * 2 THE LADIES OF MISSALONGHI, by Colleen McCullough. (Avon, $3.95.) A woman's adventures flying in East Africa and across the Atlantic in the 1930's. 10 31 THE BRIDGE ACROSS FOREVER, by Richard Bach. (Dell, $3.95.) The author recounts his search for a true love. More ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons. 2 1 FEELING GOOD, by David D. Burns. (Signet/ NAL, $4.95.) A physician's treatment for depression without the use of drugs. 3 11 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1988 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. 4 46 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) Latest edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology. 5 44 CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $6.95.) Cartoons about a boy, his toy tiger and his parents. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 retail outlets, including newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets and bookstores. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: DEALING WITH GORBACHEV
description: Although I never voted for Richard Nixon and never, indeed, liked him, I found his article a superior piece of analysis - incisive, cogent, and terse. As in his other writings on world events and world leaders, Mr. Nixon proves once again that foreign affairs is his forte; he excels at it.

title: Advice From The Experts
description: When top architects and designers were asked to pinpoint what they considered the most common design problems, the one they most frequently cited was the classic puzzle of inadequate space - rooms that are either just too small or those that are poorly proportioned. Second to space considerations were the problems of everyday wear and tear on walls and floors, and less-than-ideal views. The professionals were then asked to come up with innovative ways to deal with these problems. The only criteria were that the solutions be inexpensive and simple to carry out. The following ideas require only the right materials and a little ingenuity. CREATING A VIEW

title: A Terrorist State
description: Last Thursday morning Albie Sachs, a South African lawyer living in exile in Mozambique, walked to his car and turned the key in the door lock. As he did, a powerful bomb went off. It shattered windows down the block. Mr. Sachs lost his arm. Miraculously, he survived.

title: 'Doomed' Hotel That Lives On
description: SINCE opening in 1921, the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles has had ample publicity as a mecca for movie, political and social luminaries. But starting in May 1986, the news was more like an obituary.

title: In The Natural State
description: LEAD: THIS COLUMN is about bird watching. There. I think that says it plainly enough. It is about bird watching . . . and how much fun it is, and how New Jersey is such a terrific place for it, and how to get started and how I think that only someone who has never tried it could fail to fall under its spell.

title: THE LONG ROAD BACK
description: Having been born only four years before the end of the Vietnam conflict, able only to read about the protests of 1967 and '68, I cry. I rage inside at the lack of proper attention to Vietnam veterans on the part of the United States Government and the Veterans Administration. Monuments and movies can serve only to refresh the memory and renew the pain of Vietnam. We, as a nation, must concentrate on nursing the battle-scarred psyche of the Vietnam veteran, not just paying it homage.

title: WHAT IS YOUR MOST POLITICALLY INCORRECT FANATASY?
description: TRUTH OR DARE Encounters With Power, Authority, and Mystery. By Starhawk. 370 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: Robin Dahlberg Becomes a Bride
description: Robin Lee Dahlberg, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard C. Dahlberg of La Jolla, Calif., and Edwin Simonds Maynard, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin P. Maynard 3d of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and Prouts Neck, Me., were married yesterday at the Darlington House in La Jolla. Msgr. Joseph Topping performed the ceremony.

title: Review/Music; Ensemble Reinvents Its Repertory
description: The Downtown Ensemble presented ''Graphic Music I'' - the first of two concerts devoted to music written pictorially rather than in standard notation - at the Greenwich House Music School (46 Barrow Street) on Thursday evening. Works of this kind are hybrids, their musical dimensions intertwined with elements of visual arts and game playing, and the ones the ensemble offered were certified oldies, composed between 1951 and 1972. Yet because the vagaries of their scoring require that they be composed anew at each playing, the pieces will always sound new.

title: New York Report Faults Handling of Estates
description: The offices that handle the estates of people who die without wills or heirs in Nassau, Onondaga and Monroe Counties have such serious problems that the public trust is compromised, New York State Comptroller Edward V. Regan and Attorney General Robert Abrams said this week.

title: India Sees Hope in New Sikh Leaders
description: As they have for centuries, Sikh religious leaders conclude each day in the immense Golden Temple here with a handful of devotees chanting prayers. This week, the ceremony was also guarded by young Sikhs with automatic rifles.

title: CAYTON AND KING BATTLING OVER TYSON
description: The power struggle for control of Mike Tyson - thought to be at a truce -has apparently escalated between the fighter's manager, Bill Cayton, and his promoter, Don King.

title: Recalling the Day F.D.R. Died
description: OUR division was slogging through Bavaria, on our way to Obersaltzburg and Hitler's ''last redoubt'' -the fabled place where the Nazi fanatics were going to make their last stand, taking thousands of Allied G.I.'s with them as the Third Reich -the Reich that would last 1,000 year -came crashing down.

title: Homelessness Under Study
description: AT A Los Angeles inner-city high school, students in a government class are creating a video documentary on homelessness. In a Yale University seminar, students spend an entire day on the streets with New Haven's homeless. In New York City a pen-pal program has been set up between students at the Fieldston School, a private school in the Bronx, and homeless students at a public elementary school on the Lower East Side.

title: Review/Jazz; Helen Merrill Sings the Blues
description: The singer Helen Merrill puts her performances together phrase by phrase. Each one gets its due, and Ms. Merrill, relying on chilly silences left between words and the texture of each phrase, comes out with masterly interpretations, restrained technically but emotionally intense.

title: Hardwick And Kean Split on Aid To Localities
description: NEW JERSEY'S local governments are asking the state again to help them balafce their budgets without cutting services or raising local property taxes, but an aid plan endorsed by Governor Kean already has run into trouble in the Republican-controlled Assembly.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE PRIZE PULITZER. By Roxanne Pulitzer with Kathleen Maxa. (Villard, $17.95.) Roxanne Pulitzer is in the papers again, this time on the best-seller list instead of in the headlines. In ''The Prize Pulitzer,'' written with Kathleen Maxa, she reprises her role as, in her own words, the ''well-kept wife'' in Palm Beach, Fla., who would fight a losing battle for custody of her twin sons, Mac and Zac.

title: Crowd Detains Driver Suspected of Drinking
description: Ten to 13 motorists surrounded and stopped a man suspected of drunk driving on Interstate 84, holding him until the police arrived, the authorities said.

title: Debuts; Recitals by a Soprano, A Violist and a Guitarist
description: Deborah Cole

title: Hard Times for Three Big Banks
description: THE New York banking scene is going through wrenching change that is likely to lead to a major realignment of banking power within the city and the nation over the next few years.

title: Julie Blaisdell Married To Brien Philip Moylan
description: Julie Gay Blaisdell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Blaisdell of Overland Park, Kan., was married there yesterday to Brien Philip Moylan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Moylan of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Charles Spivey performed the ceremony at the Knox United Presbyterian Church.

title: Review/Recital; Helen Donath, Soprano
description: Helen Donath, an American soprano, has spent her most productive years in Europe, but she came to the Metropolitan Museum with her husband and accompanist, Klaus, on Thursday, to sing an all-German-language program.

title: Earthquake Off New Guinea
description: A severe earthquake struck the Bismarck Sea off the north coast of New Guinea this morning, the Royal Observatory in Hong Kong reported. The quake measured 6.5 on the Richter scale, the observatory reported, adding that there were no immediate reports of casualties or damage.

title: The Low Dollar Has Worked Wonders
description: NEARLY two centuries ago Alexander Hamilton, in his famous ''Report on Manufactures,'' tied the future of the United States to the health of its manufacturing sector. Hamilton's prescient words still ring true today.

title: Winning Colors Is First on Coast
description: Eugene Klein's massive filly, Winning Colors, dominated eight helpless colts in the $500,000 Santa Anita Derby here today, galloping home by seven and a half lengths and thrusting herself squarely into the picture for the Kentucky Derby.

title: Stacy Pancoast, Consultant, Wed To F. W. Clark Jr.
description: The marriage of Stacy Pancoast, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Pancoast Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., to Frank William Clark Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark of Boston, took place yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Bronxville. The Rev. Christopher L. Webber performed the ceremony.

title: Try This for a Wow Finish!
description: AS THE ANNUAL BESTOWAL of Academy Awards grows near, thoughts turn naturally to well-remembered films and, sometimes, to putting new endings on old favorites.

title: Writing New Rules for the Credit-Card Game
description: TOUGH new rules on what credit-card companies must tell their customers became law in New York State last month, but they may not be on the books for long. Representative Charles E. Schumer wants to pre-empt them with Federal regulations that some consumer groups say are less stringent.

title: On Sabbath in Israel, Silence Over Girl's Killing in Village
description: There has been no public response here yet to reports that an army investigation found that a teen-age girl whose death had drawn vows of vengeance against Arabs was killed by a bullet, apparently fired in panic by her Israeli guard.

title: Electronic That Help At Home
description: Some years ago, as the newly developed microcomputer chip was wed - for better or worse - to more and more electronic products, industry pundits observed that the silicon chip was ''a solution in search of a problem.''

title: A Chill Over the Hot New 'Hybrids'
description: LAST year, executives at the Wells Fargo Bank in San Francisco began looking for new ways to attract deposits. One proposal caught their attention: Given the bank's involvement in the California Gold Rush, why not offer a certificate of deposit with an interest rate pegged to the price of gold?

title: Ex-Commissioner Faults Koch on Computer System
description: Patrick W. McGinley, the former Commissioner of the New York City Department of Investigation, accused the Koch administration last week of hypocrisy and ineptitude in its handling of a long-delayed anti-corruption computer system that he proposed six years ago.

title: Does Steinbrenner Help or Hurt The Yanks?
description: George Steinbrenner has hurt the Yankees because he seems to criticize valuable players and stand up for deadbeats. He has criticized Mike Pagliarulo, who hit the most home runs last year and proved to be an invaluable third baseman. He even accused Don Mattingly of chasing individual records at the expense of the team. Yet he gives the volatile Billy Martin chance after chance and sticks up for Rickey Henderson, who has not given the Yankees a full season of production. DIANE LESNIEWSKI Astoria, Queens

title: Headliners; Tibet vs. China
description: It is a tenet of Buddhism that the path to salvation avoids the extremes of self-mortification and self-indulgence and runs between them, in the middle. There, too, lies the path by which the Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhists, apparently hopes to return to his native land. The Dalai Lama, who fled to India in 1959 after Chinese troops quelled an uprising by Tibetan nationalists, was visiting Great Britain last week when the Chinese offered to allow him to return to Tibet if he would abandon the cause of nationalism. The 52-year-old spiritual leader rejected the offer but did not close the door to some other compromise with Beijing. ''We need more patience, more determination,'' he said. ''I am trying to find some way, a middle way.''

title: The Mellow Art of the Micro-brewer
description: WHILE Miller and Budweiser struggle for America's mass beer market, a growing number of small producers are finding and fueling a demand for specialty brews among more discriminating drinkers. Even though sales of these micro-beers doubled last year, to 100,000 barrels, their share of the American market of 178 million barrels a year market remains minuscule. But fans maintain these brews are beerdom's last bastion of quality.

title: Helping Steer the Deprived Young
description: In early 1987, Victoria Barton was a frightened teen-ager expecting her first child, worrying about caring for an infant and lacking plans for the future.

title: An Artist for the Masses
description: LEAD: KENNETH E. SHOTWELL sees his artwork everywhere he goes. ''I can go to just about any hotel and see it on the walls,'' he said. ''I've seen it on TV, in the backgrounds of soap operas.''

title: When the Clumsy Tripod Must Go Along, Too
description: TRIPODS are great for holding cameras steady during long exposures, but they're the world's biggest pain to pack. Mine seems particularly egregious, although it has the same unwieldy construction as the rest of its species. Its legs stick out one way, while the handles used to position the head stick out another. The head, which is fat enough to hold a view camera, is also chubby enough to bump into every doorway I go through.

title: FAREWELL, FRIEND
description: No Russell Baker in the Sunday Times Magazine? You might as well say, ''No, Virginia, there is no more Sunday!'' Sunday's routine begins with Russell Baker, proceeds to William Safire, goes on to the puzzle. Without Russell, pray, where do we begin?

title: Vegetables With International Appeal
description: THE cookbook shelf is filled, increasingly, with vegetarian volumes. In recent years these have departed from the ''health food'' approach that first made its appearance in the 1960's and now appeal to a wider audience. Vegetable cookery is no longer the exclusive province of the counterculture. It has become mainstream.

title: A Celebrity Chef Moves the 'Brew Pub' Upscale
description: WHAT could lend greater credence to claims of boutique beer enthusiasts than an alliance with a superstar chef - someone, say, like Wolfgang Puck?

title: Tickering Produces 'Fastest Street Car'
description: LIFE can be slow in the shoreline community of Old Lyme, but that is not said about the car that comes out of Callaway Engineering in a small industrial park there.

title: Leiter Sparkles For Yankees (4-0)
description: Late yesterday afternoon, as the stands were beginning to fill with fans, Al Leiter walked down the runway at Yankee Stadium and watched his teammates take batting practice. His eyes brightened, like those of a child attending his first game.

title: A Musical With A Bundle of Letters In Leading Roles
description: LOOKING BACK ON THEIR CHILD-hoods, most show-business veterans can vividly remember the epiphanies that inspired them to hit the boards. For Michael Rupert, the 36-year-old star and composer of the Broadway musical ''Mail,'' which opens Thursday at the Music Box Theater, the moment of revelation came when he discovered the musical theater by way of television. ''Mail'' portrays an angst-ridden novelist who finds his past staring at him in a bundle of letters that burst into life.

title: Recycling's 'Superhero' Zaps Trash With Song
description: Schools are booking the song-and-dance act of Ray Cycle, ''superhero'' of the state recycling program.

title: Co-op Conversion
description: To the Editor:

title: Currency Crisis Is Ravaging Vietnam's Fragile Economy
description: The Vietnamese economy, among the world's weakest, has suffered several catastrophic blows in the last few weeks, and the troubles could have immediate and long-range political consequences.

title: The Perfect Job
description: What makes a job perfect? The challenge? The money? The commutation?

title: Susan C. Peter Married To Jerry J. Jameson Jr.
description: Susan Carol Peter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Werner B. Peter of Madison and Mantoloking, N.J., and Jerry James Jameson Jr., a son of Gail Jameson of Santa Rosa, Calif., and Mr. Jameson of Studio City, Calif., were married yesterday at the Good Shepherd Roman Catholic Church in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: POSTING: 38-Acre Business Park; Airport Access
description: ''Accessibility'' may be as much of a cliche among commercial developers as ''location, location, location'' is among residential brokers. But with a planned business park in Wall Township, N.J., K. Hovnanian Investment Properties has staked a convincing claim on it. Expecting business tenants to follow transportation technology past rivers, rails and roads to runways, Hovanian selected 38 acres alongside Allaire Airport for its $50 million project. The site on Route 34 in Monmouth County is near the intersection of I-195 and the Garden State Parkway, but Allaire - with 150,000 landings a year, one of the busiest private airports in the country - was the main commercial attraction.

title: Singers Strive for Literacy in Musical Notes
description: MUSICAL notation, like any language, must be read and translated into sound and meaning. Considering music's universality, however, this country's literacy level is low, say some educators in the field.

title: With Manila Mutineer Free, Soldiers Wait
description: The coconut groves along the seashore here are one of the many places where Gregorio Honasan, the fugitive mutineer, is rumored to be hiding, planning his next move against the Government.

title: It's Never Too Late to Learn
description: MANY years ago, I read a letter to Ann Landers in a Philadelphia newspaper that made a lasting impression on me. The writer said that he had always wanted to take piano lessons but that because he was almost 60, he guessed he had ''missed the boat.''

title: Lisa Grunwald, an Editor, Is Wed to Stephen J. Adler
description: Lisa Grunwald, the features editor of Esquire magazine, and Stephen J. Adler, the news editor for law at The Wall Street Journal, were married last evening at the Water Club in New York. Rabbi James Prosnit performed the ceremony.

title: Kitchens and Baths: Remodeling Strategies
description: Kitchens and bathrooms are undoubtedly the most daunting rooms to remodel in any home, conjuring up nightmarish images of ruptured pipes and cracking porcelain. Not only must they satisfy the greatest number of personal and structural considerations, but modifying them nearly always involves disruption of daily living habits, the purchase of potentially expensive fixtures and materials, and delving into a home's most costly-to-work-on systems: plumbing, electricity and, sometimes, even heating and ventilation.

title: MAN BITES PRESS
description: THE COMING BATTLE FOR THE MEDIA Curbing the Power of the Media Elite. By William A. Rusher. 228 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company.

title: New Buses Planned For Newark Riders
description: JEROME C. PREMO, executive director of N.J. Transit, predicts that the delivery of 384 new buses by next spring will lay to rest many longstanding complaints by Newark residents who commute to New York City on buses they contend are old and unreliable.

title: Joel Hall Uses Choreography as a Social Science
description: Joel Hall is a humanist. His eyes stare piercingly at you as he speaks, pausing every few moments to ask, ''Do you know what I mean?'' Thoughts tumble out about the homeless, about the American heritage and about his own black heritage. And that humanism tends to inform his works, which will be presented by the Joel Hall Dancers in performances through tonight at the Joyce Theater. But that is one of the few easily categorized facts about the Chicago-based company.

title: POWER ISN'T CHEAP AND OPTIONS ARE FEW
description: Re the article ''Governor Confuses Lilco Issue'' on March 20: Governor Cuomo, who launched his Long Island Power Authority (LIPA) with the slogan ''Power as Cheap as Freeport,'' has changed his tune. Now that a Lilco takeover is imminent, it is reported that a LIPA takeover will increase Long Island's electric bills, not decrease them. That is the latest episode in the sorry LIPA saga.

title: J. C. Giordano 3d And Errol Train Planning to Wed
description: Errol Cuthbert Train and John Carl Giordano 3d, a son of Mr. Giordano Jr. of Middletown, N.J., and the late Mary Kay Wertheim Meyer, plan to marry June 18, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Russell E. Train of Washington, have announced.

title: The Drug Thugs and Mr. Meese
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese, awake at last to the challenge of international narcotics crime, proposes a multinational narcotics police force. It would protect public officials and otherwise redress the balance of firepower in countries where the drug lords have become a law unto themselves.

title: L.I. Economy Turns Cautious
description: LEAD: WHEN Nassau and Suffolk officials receive a state report later this month of sales tax receipts for the first quarter of 1988, they expect the figures will show that receipts are up again in both counties.

title: For Pacific's Atomic Nomads, A Symbolic Ground-Breaking
description: The elders of Bikini, keepers of memory and hope for a people displaced for 42 years, returned to their homeland for a day of solemn ceremony. They were marking the start of a project to clean up the former nuclear test site and restore it as a fit place to live.

title: State Seeks Ways to Retain Manufacturing Companies
description: MANUFACTURING jobs are leaving the state, particularly Fairfield County, in growing numbers, and business and legislative leaders are concerned enough to want to do something about it.

title: A Project That Weaves the Cityscape Together
description: FOR A GENERATION NOW, REAL ESTATE developers have tended to describe their large urban projects as if they possessed a magical quality.

title: Jean Colloton Married To Randall Lee Brooks
description: At St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., Jean Marie Colloton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Edmund Colloton of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Randall Lee Brooks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Brooks of Suffolk, Va. The Rev. Steven DeLuca performed the ceremony.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: NONINDIFFERENT NATURE. By Sergei Eisenstein. Translated by Herbert Marshall. (Cambridge University, $37.50.) We have Joseph Stalin to thank, in part, for Sergei Eisenstein's brilliant theoretical writings on film; had he not made it so difficult for the great Russian director of ''Potemkin'' and ''Ivan the Terrible'' to practice what he eventually preached, Eisenstein's legacy would undoubtedly have contained more films and fewer analyses like this one. Written during and shortly after World War II, these essays represent the mature phase of Eisenstein's thinking about film - which he regarded as the highest of the arts, a complex synthesis of painting, sculpture, music and poetry. Alternately chatty and recondite, Eisenstein skips across the terrain of the arts, from the peaks of high culture to the valleys of mass culture. He employs his notion of linear, or horizontal, montage (the collision of opposing images) as a jumping-off point for an exploration of ''vertical montage,'' by which he means the integration of landscape, lighting, camera angle, color and gesture. The highest expression of vertical montage is the point at which representation passes into music. By music, he means ''that inner 'plastic music' that, in the various stages of silent film, bore within itself the actual plastic composition of film.'' This job falls to landscape - ''the freest element of film, the least burdened with servile, narrative tasks, and the most flexible in conveying moods, emotional states, and spiritual experiences.'' Altogether, ''Nonindifferent Nature'' is a fascinating book. The introduction by the film scholar Herbert Eagle is excellent, and Herbert Marshall's translation makes a potentially inaccessible work readable and even engaging.

title: The Reality of Crime On Campus
description: A MAN ON A university campus walks up to a woman he has never met and bites her breast in a collegiate fad known as ''sharking.'' Racial brawls break out on campuses from Massachusetts to Maryland. Four university football players in California gang-rape a woman. A student rapes and strangles a 19-year-old college freshman in her Pennsylvania dormitory room. Another student murders two others in a Michigan dormitory with a sawed-off shotgun.

title: Coming to Terms With Bilingualism in New York City Schools
description: IN 1974, The United States Supreme Court ruled that students who do not speak English are entitled to special language instruction as a matter of equal educational opportunity. Fourteen years later, the goal of complying with a consent decree based on that ruling may finally be in sight for the New York City school system.

title: The Time for Roses
description: BE careful with footwork in the asparagus patch where young spears are starting to emerge; as soon as they are of edible height on mature (over two years) plantings, for best flavor break them off just in time for dinner. Finish pruning fruit trees. Indoors, turn seedlings daily if set near windowsills to keep stems straight; don't neglect half-rate applications of water-soluble fertilizer to support their growth. Last call to start tuberous begonias and caladiums indoors for planting outside in shaded nooks in May. Rose Care

title: Private Terms Wins Gotham
description: Nearly everyone expected an undefeated colt to win the Gotham Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday, but few thought it would be Private Terms instead of Seeking the Gold.

title: Tack to the Future: Teen-Age Summer Jobs
description: LEAD: AFTER working last summer as a construction helper at David Linker Ltd., restorers and conservators of fine furniture, 18-year-old Graham Davis decided to become an apprentice at the Brooklyn shop.

title: A Surrender, of Sorts, to Vacation
description: THE vacations of my youth centered on several rituals that, in the arrogance of memory, I like to think were endemic to the Freedman family. There was the traditional argument between my mother and father about spending the next summer's holiday together in Florence instead of with three kids on Lake George. There was the time-honoredmewling by my brother, my sister and me -often accompanied by pulling sweatshirts over our heads or thrusting tearful faces in the crease of the car's back seat - whenever night fell on the highway without a motel beckoning Vacancy. And, last, there was the telephone call my father made to his office.

title: Two Young Winners Play Their Cards Right
description: AN unusual record was set in Buffalo, N.Y., on March 17, just before the start of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals. A month after his 17th birthday Brad Moss of Manhattan won the non-life master Grand National Pairs Championship and became the youngest player to win a national title.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Maurice Starring James Wilby, Hugh Grant, Denholm Elliott, Ben Kingsley, Rupert Graves, Judy Parfitt, Billie Whitelaw, Simon Callow, Phoebe Nicholls. Directed by James Ivory. 1987. Lorimar Home Video. 139 minutes. $79.95. Rated R.

title: From Kudelka, Pinteresque Ballets
description: JAMES KUDELKA, THE 32-year-old Canadian choreographer, has been called the Harold Pinter of dance. A darkly intense man with short-cropped black hair and restless eyes, his works teem with shadowy undercurrents of emotional ambiguity and inference. By critical consensus, he is a new voice in ballet, and on Tuesday, his choreographic art will be given major display when Les Grands Ballets Canadiens opens a brief season (through April 17), at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: CHILDREN WITHOUT REMORSE
description: AT A TENDER AGE Violent Youth and Juvenile Justice. By Rita Kramer. 309 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $18.95.

title: LAUGHTER AND HOPE
description: I suspect that Dr. Melvin Konner has unintentionally presented a distorted view of Bernie Siegel's work as described in his book ''Love, Medicine, and Miracles.'' Dr. Siegel never suggests that conventional medical therapy be supplanted by any form of faith healing. Rather, he depicts a humanistic therapeutic approach integrating imagery (psycho-) therapy with standard forms of medical treatment. His approach is based on the concept that biologic function is the result of a mind-body duality that not only maintains the biologic self in wellness, but also plays a critical role in the causation of certain diseases and their response to treatment. Although this concept has not been formally included in the traditional Western medical curriculum, there exists a voluminous cache of research data as well as personal clinical experience compelling enough to convince many medical practitioners, myself included, that the psyche has a substantial role in the causation and clinical course of a disease.

title: Wedtech Lawyers: Contrast of Styles
description: Mario Biaggi's lawyer has the force of a longshoreman. He conveys disbelief, impatience and delight by rolling his eyes upward, whipping off his glasses or lifting his brows.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Who Should Be Hockey's M.V.P.?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Dance-Theater That's Dazzlingly Distinctive
description: ''BROKEN HILL,'' A NEW piece by the trio of choreographers who call themselves Kinematic, embodies an American brand of dance-theater very different from the genre that has grown up in Europe.

title: TALKING: Radon; Avoiding Problems In a House
description: LIKE other problems in home-buying - termites, asbestos or water in the basement - the presence of unacceptable levels of radon gas can create complex and troubling issues for purchasers.

title: In One Room, Less Is More
description: Visitors are graciously instructed to leave their shoes at the entrance to this L-shaped Manhattan studio because, as the tenant, Robert Homma, explains, ''I eat, sleep and live on one surface.'' Only by padding around in stocking feet and assiduously using a Dustbuster is he able to keep the 16 tatami mats that line the floor as clean as the day they were installed. Yet this seemingly impractical and decidedly Oriental approach - using the traditional Japanese woven rice-straw mats and a minimum of objects - makes this one room appear to provide more than ample living space.

title: Familiar Food, Easy Atmosphere
description: EVEN if you've never visited the Polo Club in Roslyn Heights, it will seem familiar.

title: CUOMO PUTS DOWN NEW DRAFT EFFORT
description: Governor Cuomo asked Westchester County Democrats today not to go forward with efforts to mount a drive to draft him as a Democratic Presidential candidate.

title: Some Plain Talk and Advice About: Hemlines
description: THIS MAY SEEM LIKE HERESY, BUT A hemline is not the be-all-and-end-all of fashion. How much of your leg shows, or does not, is just one piece of the seasonal shifting around of stylish silhouettes. It is just as important to watch what happens to your shoulders, your breasts, your waist - your shape in general.

title: A New Procedure For Primary Vote
description: PRIMARY DAY, which arrives in the county in just nine more days, will confront Westchester voters with the largest array of delegate choices in county election history. So many men want to be President and so many voters want to be convention delegates that harried state election officials first considered using paper ballots. But in the end they opted instead for a radical new voting-machine procedure.

title: New Head of Police Speaks Out
description: DANIEL P. GUIDO, who was appointed head of the Suffolk Police Department by Patrick G. Halpin, is the first person from outside the county ever to lead the department, which has been under investigation by local, state and Federal agencies.

title: It's Tuneup Time For Lawn Mowers
description: LIKE automobiles, gasoline-powered lawn mowers require periodic engine maintenance for trouble-free operation. At the start of a new mowing season, three chores in particular must be performed.

title: PBS Wins 7 Awards
description: The Public Broadcasting Service has won seven Peabody Awards for excellence in broadcasting in 1987, and the Cable News Network has been cited as television's ''channel of record for breaking news.''

title: Sharon Tracy Is the Bride Of Marc Mitchell Sussman
description: The marriage of Sharon Tracy to Marc Mitchell Sussman took place last evening at the Atrium Club in New York. Rabbi Bernhard Cohen and Cantor Bruce Halev officiated.

title: AMERICAN LEAGUE PIONEER
description: PRIDE AGAINST PREJUDICE The Biography of Larry Doby. By Joseph Thomas Moore. Illustrated. 195 pp. New York: Praeger Publishers/Greenwood Press. Cloth, $35. Paper, $12.95.

title: New Effort to Stem Watershed Abuse
description: NEW YORK CITY environmental officials have stepped up their efforts to control the abuse of watershed property in Westchester by county residents.

title: Smalley Retires
description: HE finally earned a World Series ring last fall and he had been leaning toward retirement since being released this spring, so it was not that big a surprise yesterday when Roy Smalley officially called it quits after after a 13-year major league career.

title: Kathleen M. Anderson Marries E. C. Mooney
description: The marriage of Kathleen Melanie Anderson, a senior editor at Poseidon Press in New York, to Edward Comstock Mooney, a novelist and a senior editor at Art in America magazine, took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension in New York. The Rev. Donald R. Goodness performed the ceremony.

title: The Making of Americans
description: Legal Immigrants and where they came from

title: Erskine Hawkins Blows Sweet Sounds in Catskills
description: The ''20th-Century Gabriel'' is still blowing his horn, but he's making the scene these days in the Catskills, not Harlem. He's the trumpeter Erskine Hawkins, for many years a fixture with his big band at the Savoy Ballroom in Harlem, and now a fixture with a small band at the Concord Hotel here, where he came for a one-week booking and decided to stay. Recently he marked his 20th anniversary at the huge resort.

title: A Stylish Setting for Sichuan Fare
description: IT was good news to hear that the beautiful dining room on the second floor of Le Pavilion in Stamford was taken over as a branch of the Manhattan restaurant Sichuan Pavilion.

title: An Unfamiliar Hamptons on Film
description: ''MASQUERADE'' has everyone guessing. Is the mansion in the new Rob Lowe-Meg Tilly movie in East Hampton? Or is it in Southampton? Strong opinions form on both sides.

title: Does Steinbrenner Help or Hurt The Yanks?
description: Your question only fuels outrage from respondents that reflect news-media-influenced opinions. Let George Steinbrenner alone. JANE C. SMITH Enola, Pa.

title: Review/Opera; Ordinary Vampires, In One Act
description: Golden Fleece Ltd. in 12 years of operation has presented nearly 60 new operas, most of them written and developed for the ensemble. The latest three, heard Friday evening at the Sanford Meisner Theater (164 11th Avenue), are short - about 15 to 40 minutes - and are generally more in the nature of acting-workshop sketches with unambitious, functional music than operas in the familiar sense. As long as one listened in that spirit, there were moments of interest and enjoyment to be gleaned.

title: Daniels's Heroics Lead Reds Past Astros
description: Kal Daniels hit two bases-empty home runs and singled home the winning runs in the bottom of the ninth inning today, leading the Reds to a 5-4 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: Steinbrenner And the Games
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: High Hopes for the Hamptons
description: THE rites of spring, Hamptons style:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: MORTAL FEAR. By Robin Cook. (Putnam, $17.95.) Dr. Jason Howard is a staff physician at a Boston hospital owned by a corporation called the Good Health Plan, a misnomer if there ever was one. In a matter of weeks, Dr. Howard loses five patients, all of whom had been in apparent good health, under conditions that are mysterious, even sinister: they age rapidly as they die.

title: Ballet in Boston Unveils Plan for a Larger Home
description: The Boston Ballet has announced plans for a $4.6 million expansion of the company's home and its school. The new facility is expected to be a boon to smaller dance companies in the city.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Where Are the Tax Shelters of Yesteryear?
description: LEAD: It is the Ides of April, a season that, this year, inspired the question: Did you ever see a grown man cry? I called an accountant to explain the complicated 1988 tax laws to me. ''Nobody understands it at all,'' he said reassuringly.

title: BUDAPEST LETTERS: NEW THEMES, NEW WRITERS
description: LEAD: GRAY becomes this city, somberness gives it dignity. The gingerbread facades along the Grand Boulevard, the neo-Baroque and Art Nouveau confections of the inner city appear more venerable in the end-of-winter haze. In another world, a larger, brasher, more ambitious Hungary tried hard to outdo Vienna, the Imperial City - hence Budapest's oversized public buildings, its impressive but stagy architecture and the Grand Boulevard, which today, choked with mud-splattered Russian and East

title: Revision of Schools Draws Lawsuit
description: LEAD: A GROUP of Commack parents who failed to block a school district reorganization plan, now scheduled to go into effect in September, have filed suit in State Supreme Court to halt the plan.

title: Pick Candidates By Peer Review
description: Despite all the despair voiced about the process of picking Presidents, there is hope.

title: Fix-It Fever Strikes Before the Big Bash
description: YOU'RE planning your annual big bash. Once a year you have a really great party for 50 or 60 of your closest friends. As you tour the house beforehand, seeing it as if for the first time, You decide it is finally, absolutely, definitely time to fix up the bathroom.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 'NATION ON THE MOVE'

title: Adaptable Antiques
description: Antiques have many attractions: They represent substance and continuity while evoking the past, their various styles suit numerous tastes and they are frequently handcrafted with a quality no longer seen today. But because they were often created for a culture that no longer exists, their intended purpose may not be applicable to a 1980's life style.

title: Veterans' Office Sets Up 6 Offices
description: LEAD: WITH the opening of its regional office in New Britain, the year-old State Office of Veterans' Affairs has filled its mandate to reach out to residents who may not be receiving all the benefits they are entitled to.

title: ROUND AND ROUND THE EUPCACCIA GOES
description: THE ARK SAKURA By Kobo Abe. Translated by Juliet Winters Carpenter. 336 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE NANNY. By Dan Greenburg. (Macmillan, $17.95.) Phil and Julie, a plastic ''Thirtysomething''-ish couple, are losing sleep over their new baby. Exhaustion is wrecking their careers: Phil's an adman with a conscience, Julie's trying to start a decorating business. Their relationship is falling apart; they haven't slept together in who knows how long.

title: History Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: A Computer Link for Libraries
description: WESTCHESTER has become one of the first counties in the United States to have a computerized central-information network that links county government departments, a public library and academic libraries.

title: The Versatility of Color
description: Most people would have the same reaction to a lime-green living room that Gelett Burgess had to the purple cow he immortalized in one of his poems: He had never seen one, nor did he hope to. But according to a number of decorators and design experts, a creative approach to color -whether it's an unusual shade or merely an unusual placement - not only enlivens a room but maximizes its assets and minimizes its flaws.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CRIMINAL TENDENCIES. By William O'Rourke. (Dutton, $19.95.) This crime thriller, William O'Rourke's third novel, is set within the glitzy, sleazy confines of Key West - ''Disneyland for dropouts,'' as one of the characters thinks of it. With the Mariel boatlift of 1980 as a sociohistorical backdrop, the author assembles a sorry gang of small-time criminals and their mixed-up girlfriends, along with a few jaded writers, and sets them loose on the island. The gang, led by Jay Winston Cross, a neurotic, spoiled art thief, sets out to steal a valuable collection of prints by the ornithologist John James Audubon from a poorly guarded museum. At first, the writers - a burned-out journalist, an idealistic poet and a corrupt novelist - watch this odd heist from a safe distance. But as the story progresses, the distinction between thief and writer becomes blurred; everyone, it seems, has a penchant for crime and self-destruction. And everyone - including the poorly educated ex-convicts - has an uncanny tendency to view the world in metaphor. Thanks to Mr. O'Rourke's gifted eye for sordid detail, the imagery is original and provocative. Sometimes, though, he gets carried away (early on, for example, a pile of unclaimed shoes in a cobbler's shop is described as ''a real Auschwitz bundle''). Mr. O'Rourke's ambitious novel, rich with allegorical and political possibilities, can be as dazzling as the tropic sun. But if you're not careful, ''Criminal Tendencies'' will quickly wear you out and make you long for simpler pleasures.

title: Civil Rights Reunion
description: LEAD: FORMER members of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee who participated in the sit-ins and Freedom Rides of the 1960's will reunite this week at Trinity College in Hartford for a three-day conference on the history of the civil rights organization.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: The Role of Brokers; Advocate for Tenants or Hired Gun for Landlords?
description: WILLIAM F. BEERMANN hopes never to repeat his most wretched experience of 1987: hunting for Manhattan office space with an aggressive pack of leasing brokers.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
YOUNG CULTISTS
description: LEAD: ELLEN R. MOREHOUSE said she was ''shocked'' when she first learned of Westchester youths participating in occult practices. But Mrs. Morehouse, executive director of Student Assistance Services in White Plains, said she was ''even more shocked'' to discover the extent of the problem.

title: Gifts of Passage for the Graduate
description: SCHOOL graduation is one of those rites of passage that begs for a gift. A child's first graduation - from nursery school, becomes a big day in the short life of a 5-year-old -certainly deserving of a present. Clearly, some graduations are more important than others. ''The younger the child, the smaller the occasion - and the gift,'' advised Judith Martin, author of ''Miss Manners' Guide to Rearing Perfect Children.'' For older students, the best gifts this year fall conveniently into two categories - traditional and electronic. Travel, that literal rite of passage, is still a highly coveted present. For high school students, it is not simply a merry adventure. ''It may give them an edge on getting into college,'' said William L. Gertz, vice president and director of marketing for the American Institute for Foreign Studies, which is based in Greenwich, Conn., and arranges for students to study abroad.

title: Michelle Becce Marries
description: Michelle Ann Becce, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Becce of Matawan, N.J., was married yesterday to Edward Zuppe, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Zuppe of Old Bridge, N.J. The Rev. William C. Anderson performed the ceremony at St. Benedict's Roman Catholic Church in Holmdel, N.J. Mrs. Zuppe is a food service director for the Marriott Corporation in Holmdel. Mr. Zuppe is the general manager of the Reliable Fire Protection Company in South Brunswick, N.J.

title: Special Today; Education Life
description: Among the reports in this issue:

title: A Crucial Time
description: THE BATTLE OF ALGIERS Directed by Gillo Pontecorvo Axon Video. 1966. Subtitled in English. 125 minutes. $79.95.

title: Practical Traveler; Hotel Rankings: A Guide to Stars
description: SYSTEMS used overseas for grading hotels with stars are not necessarily more helpful than the chaos that would result from adding up all the ratings in commercially published guidebooks and dividing by your shoe size. The problem for the American traveler is that no set of criteria is universal. One country's three-star might not cut the horseradish across the ocean, or even the river. Sometimes American handbooks listing overseas places by their stars give no indication of whether the ratings are the same from country to country.

title: Motorists Facing Delays at Tunnel
description: LEAD: MOTORISTS using the Lincoln Tunnel will encounter lane reductions in New Jersey and New York City throughout the summer.

title:
DINING OUT;
Those Neighborhood Trattorias
description: LEAD: ONE OF the things that New Jersey does best is the little neighborhood trattoria.

title: The Fight Against Drug Trafficking: Setting Priorities
description: Most Important International Problem

title: PARENTS AND TEACHERS: THE REAL GOALS
description: I would like to respond to the article ''Fray at Southampton P.T.A.'' [ March 13 ] . The National PTA and all its member units have specific objectives, and these objectives have nothing to do with cupcakes or insurance coverage or usurping authority.

title: POSTING: Farmers Market Jamaica; A Home At Last
description: Since its formation 12 years ago, Farmers Market Jamaica has been pushed around quite a bit. But that is just fine with its operator, the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation. The open-air market was created to use vacant city-owned land in the east Queens neighborhood until more intensive uses could be found. The market's nomadic life results from the success of that strategy; at its first location, for instance, is a million-square-foot Federal office building. As the market prepares to begin its 13th season on Friday, plans are being completed to move it to its fourth, but this time permanent, location.

title: A Safe Approach to Pest and Disease Control
description: IDENTIFY the problem, then act with a reasonable solution. This approach, rather than a shoot first, ask questions later method, is the safer one for gardeners to follow when controlling pests and diseases.

title: Dr. Pennoyer, a Psychologist, Is Wed To John W. Auchincloss 2d, a Lawyer
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, Dr. Tracy Pennoyer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Pennoyer of New York and Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Winthrop Auchincloss 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis S. Auchincloss of Manhattan and Claryville, N.Y. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: Why Bother Watching A Woeful Remake?
description: ''RED RIVER.'' ''DAVID COPPERFIELD.'' ''Roman Holiday.''

title: Zaccaro Guilty of Cocaine Sale; Appeal Planned
description: A jury today found John A. Zaccaro Jr. guilty of selling cocaine to an undercover officer two years ago, rejecting a defense lawyer's argument that the officer had entrapped Mr. Zaccaro.

title: THE BEST YEARS OF HIS LIFE: AN INTERVIEW WITH GABRIEL GARCIA MARQUEZ
description: FOR Gabriel Garcia Marquez, the pleasure and turmoil of writing change from novel to novel. In the case of ''One Hundred Years of Solitude,'' he thought so long and hard about the story that when he finally sat down to commit it to paper, it came in a great burst. But he had difficulty writing ''The Autumn of the Patriarch,'' a novel he published seven years before he won the Nobel Prize in 1982. With that book, he recently recalled, ''I was doing well when I could finish four lines a day''; the whole project occupied him, off and on, for seven years.

title: DEALING WITH GORBACHEV
description: In publishing Mr. Nixon's article on Gorbachev, The Times shows clear hypocrisy. The paper castigated Nixon throughout his political career, and now that his name is commercially valuable, it features him in its magazine. I recognize that Nixon has plenty to gain -money and stature - for his piece in the magazine, but I would have thought The Times might cling to its principles, however misguided. DAVID W. HARRISON New York, N.Y.

title: Florida Senate Pages Held
description: Nine teen-age pages in the Florida State Senate have been arrested at an unsupervised beer party at a motel, the Leon County Sheriff's Department has reported. The teen-agers, arrested Thursday night, face up to 60 days in jail and fines of up to $500. They range in age from 16 to 18,

title:
MUSIC;
State Opera Will Offer 'Don Giovanni'
description: LEAD: IN HONOR of the 200th anniversary season of Mozart's ''Don Giovanni,'' the New Jersey State Opera will perform the work twice at Symphony Hall, Newark, as its final 1987-88 production.

title: Designs for Two Kitchens
description: In the 1920's and even earlier, the classic urban kitchen of the affluent was a large, dreary space where few family members ever made so much as a piece of toast themselves. Often approached by a long butler's pantry, these rooms were designed in an era when the kitchen was considered a private place, off-limits to visitors.

title: The Price of Reading Is Eternal Vigilance
description: ''YOU know,'' a friend of mine said not long ago, ''most people read badly. Even the good readers read badly. I'm not talking about what they read, but how. Look at me - I'm 53 years old and I'm just learning how to read.

title: The Lessons of Hate
description: The tension and the harshness of vocabulary appear higher than ever in Israel. But that isn't exactly so. It is an impression nourished by the foolish assumption that the status quo could go on indefinitely, that if it didn't heal wounds, time would blunt the urge to violence and restore quiescence.

title: Ethics to Be the Topic At Two Conferences
description: LEAD: ETHICAL issues will be highlighted in two conferences in the county this month - one devoted to government and the other to an aging society.

title: 'STOP TRYING TO RESCUE ME'
description: SAILING By Susan Kenney. 320 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: Governor's Choice For Party Chairman Loses in Mississippi
description: Mississippi Democrats dealt a blow today to the influence of Gov. Ray Mabus, electing the incumbent state party chairman over a candidate backed by the Governor.

title: THE SELLING OF VERMONT
description: IT MIGHT HAVE BEEN ANYPLACE IN the United States, but it looked like nowhere in particular. All around was the sort of cartoon architecture that more and more makes us appear to be a civilization of overfed clowns - the golden arches of burgerdom, the revolving red-and-white-striped chicken bucket, the fake mansard roof announcing the ubiquitous pizza - plus a full complement of motels, car dealerships, discount merchandise plazas with their vast parking lagoons. In short, a typical commercial strip, miles long. Beyond it all, vaguely visible through the thicket of utility poles, high-voltage wires and traffic signals, loomed distant mountains, gray in the winter haze. In fact, this was Route 7 just south of Rutland, Vt.

title: Song In a Cold Climate
description: MUSICAL TALENT IS LIKE AN UNDER -ground river, surfacing here and there for reasons a cultural geologist may guess at, but following no discernible pattern. The upsurge of creativity that took place in Austria in the late 18th and early 19th centuries when a swarm of gifted composers appeared - think only of Mozart, Haydn, Beethoven and Schubert flourishing in a single city, Vienna - defies a simple explanation. I am not even sure anyone has offered a good complicated one.

title: Homage to A Curator With A Sure Touch
description: ONE OF THE MOST TELLING OF current exhibitions, and in its way one of the most poignant, is ''Making History at the Brooklyn Museum: John I. H. Baur.'' The reader should know that Jack Baur (as he was universally known) was born in 1909 and died in 1987. He was curator of painting and sculpture at the Brooklyn Museum from 1936 to 1952, at which time he went to the Whitney Museum of American Art, of which he was director from 1968 to 1974.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Sublets Create a Glut in Fairfield Offices
description: FORCED to cut back operations because of mergers and selloffs, some companies in Fairfield County are subletting space on their long-term leases, creating a buyer's market for commercial space.

title: Economy Shelters For the Homeless
description: IT was a stopgap suggestion to help the homeless: an outdoor shelter built of plywood, just big enough for one person.

title: Campus Drinking: Colleges Confront 'Issue of the 80's'
description: LEAD: THE recent alcohol-induced death at Rutgers University, a near-fatal coma at Princeton and a rape on campus at Stony Brook in which alcohol was implicated have forced administrators to confront one of the thorniest issues they face: the extent to which they can and should seek to control students' drinking in an era in which autonomy is often valued above authority.

title: Premiere of Song Cycle To Be in Tarrytown
description: BRTHDAY parties are often fun, but rarely do they also enrich the contemporary music legacy. The 40th Anniversary Gala of the Sleepy Hollow Concert Association should do just that, however, because the celebration concert by the superb young baritone Christopher Trakas will feature the world premiere of a song cycle especially commissioned from Richard Hundley for the occasion.

title: Honduran Tells of Torture
description: A lawyer for Mr. Matta said yesterday that the Honduran had been ''illegally kidnapped'' and ''brutally tortured'' by United States law enforcement officers.

title: Navratilova Comes Back to Defeat Maleeva and Gain Final
description: Sometimes, a tennis score can be deceiving. It may not reveal the fragile nature of the player in the lead or the perseverance of the opponent trying to catch up. There were not many people watching today's semifinal of the Family Circle Cup who thought that Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria had bought a ticket to the final just because she won the first set and was up a break in the second - not with Martina Navratilova on the other side of the net.

title: AS CLOSE TO HEAVEN AS WE GET
description: LEAD: IN THE FERTILE LAND By Gabriel Josipovici. 212 pp. New York: Carcanet. $18.95.

title: P. S. du Pont 3d, 77, Candidate's Father And Business Leader
description: Pierre S. du Pont 3d, a retired business executive and former vice president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, died early yesterday at his home in Rockland, Del., after an illness of six months. He was 77 years old.

title: How King Became Part of a Family in '68
description: THE television flashed the news of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King's death into our living room 20 years ago. I was 11 years old and could not understand why my mother was crying.

title: Indian Past in Pound Ridge Explored
description: LEAD: FOR years, Leonard J. Scofield has been finding projectile points and other Indian artifacts on the grounds of his Pound Ridge home, while his wife, Ethel, has discovered nothing.

title: Harsh Words Fly
description: Strong feelings that have festered below the surface at the Masters for years could no longer be contained by the somewhat artificial veneer of serenity, green jackets and lawn parties at the Augusta National Golf Club. They erupted in words as the tournament overseer criticized the rising cost of purses demanded by the pros, who for two days have criticized Masters officials for the condition of the course.

title: Fine Debut Marks 'Anna Christie'
description: EUGENE O'NEILL'S Pulitzer Prize-winning ''Anna Christie,'' which opened in 1921, remains one of this master's most accessible plays. Currently at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, this highly romantic drama about people whose lives are shaped by circumstances as arbitrary as storms at sea still manages to pack a dramatic wallop.

title: What's Doing In Toronto
description: Spring is the chanciest season in Toronto - some years the darling buds of May hardly show themselves before June. But Torontonians, who live with an almost dizzying array of urban distractions, don't have to sit around pining for nature's largess. If the weather cooperates, they can stroll on the boardwalk at the Beaches or take the ferry to the Islands; if it doesn't, there are plenty of alternatives at hand.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Pittsburgh;
Condos Draw A Builder Back
description: LEAD: RYAN HOMES, the largest builder of single-family homes in the Pittsburgh area, has re-entered the city building market for the first time since 1971.

title: Wendy Wheatley Marries D. W. Riefler
description: The marriage of Wendy Thompson Wheatley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Wheatley Jr. of Old Brookville and Bridgehampton, L.I. to Duncan Winfield Riefler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald B. Riefler of Glen Cove, L.I., took place yesterday. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattington Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: Mothers' Legacies, Gifts of Hand, Heart and Soul
description: RILEY'S box sat in a corner of my studio. This large wicker chest had been here since my daughter and her husband announced they would become parents.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Katonah, N.Y. $255,000 Parent Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 33-year-old frame ranch; eat-in kitchen, family room, 1.75 acres; taxes $3,216. Mamaroneck, N.Y. $224,000 739 Meadow Street 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old brick Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, playroom, walk to station; taxes $2,900.
