Litchfield, Conn. $695,000 Brush Hill Road 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 10-year-old barn-style home; fireplace, overlooking 17-acre pond, 6 acres; taxes $1,350. OTHER AREAS Patchogue, L.I. $115,000 20 Prospect Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 80-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, porch, 1-car garage; taxes $1,800. Quogue, L.I. $90,000 24 Grove Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,100. Maplewood, N.J. $267,000 145 Lenox Terrace 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 2 half-baths, 43-year-old colonial; den, c/a, patio, fireplace; taxes $5,119.

title: Spain Preparing to Celebrate Jews in Its Past
description: This town of 65,000 was once considered the Jerusalem of the West, and in medieval times its Jewish quarter was the most influential, intellectual and prosperous in Spain.

title: Behind a Midwestern Miracle
description: BACK in 1982, everyone knew that the venerable Harnischfeger Corporation - the epitome of American heavy industry - was in big trouble. But not even the new boss realized, when he arrived in August of that year, how close the industrial, mining and construction-equipment maker had come to the edge of the abyss.

title: Second Meese Nominee Belongs to All-White Club
description: Francis A. Keating 2d, like the other top deputy recently named by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, belongs to an all-white country club, raising the prospect that both of the new choices could face confirmation difficulties.

title:
ART;
Juried Show Offers a Range of Moods and Messages
description: LEAD: WITH more than 700 entries to choose from, Ivan Karp, director of the O. K. Harris Gallery in Manhattan, had his work cut out for him as judge of this year's Huntington Township Art League juried exhibition at the Heckscher Museum. The final 71 selections are, according to him, ''proof that mature professionalism is possible in every place that the arts are free to flourish.

title: Chemical Advisory Off to a Late Start
description: LEAD: A FEDERAL program to inform the public of hazardous chemicals used by private industry has got off to an inauspicious start.

title: New Elements, Old Effects
description: This 1920's stone house, dramatically situated on the top of a hill, looks as if it were transported from the English countryside. The private walled entrance court, casement windows, stone terracing and outbuildings and 19th-century cast-iron garden furniture could well be included in the setting for an old romance. Yet with all its English allure, the home is only an hour's drive from Manhattan.

title: JAPAN'S BIG SPENDERS
description: KIRA AKAGI LIKES FINE CARS. He owns a Rolls-Royce, a Bentley, a Mercedes and a Porsche. He is awaiting the arrival of another Porsche, the 959. Although the 43-year-old entrepreneur will seldom get the chance to drive his new, $350,000 sports car -he will be too busy running a $600 million group of real-estate firms, clothing boutiques, sports clubs, travel agencies, restaurants and a racing team -that doesn't trouble him. ''I get a feeling of satisfaction,'' he says, ''from owning it.''

title: Q&A
description: Barbuda Question:I am having a terrible time trying to arrange accommodations on Barbuda, sister island of Antigua. There is no phone service. Any suggestions? - I. W., Ann Arbor, Mich. Answer:The island of Barbuda, 15 miles long and up to 8 wide, has about 60 rooms for visitors. There are no paved roads. Until a few years ago there were no telephones, but several have now been installed. The number of the Sunset View Resort, for example, where a double room costs about $55 a day in summer and $75 in winter, is 809-460-0016. The Thomas Guesthouse number is 809-460-0004; its year-round rate for a double room is about $25 a day. But reservations for Barbuda are generally made in Antigua. A hotel booking agency that can help is the Earl's Complex, Church Street, St. John's, Antigua (telephone, 809-462-4488). It represents the Earl's Villa, a small group of efficiencies on Barbuda, which cost $50 a day for two, and also arranges flights. The Earl's Complex said round-trip air fare between Antigua and Barbuda, 28 miles away, is about $30 for a day trip and $43 for a visit of up to 21 days. (These fares are based on calculating the Eastern Caribbean dollar at 2.60 to the United States dollar.) Another place to stay on Barbuda is Coco Point Lodge, which has a representative on Antigua (809-462-3816). General information can also be sought from the Antigua-Barbuda Department of Tourism (Post Office Box 363, St. John's, Antigua; 809-462-0029, and 610 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10020; 212-541-4117).

title: Amy Wilkoff Marries
description: Amy Lynn Wilkoff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald J. Wilkoff of Merrick, L.I., was married last evening to Warren George Heller, a son of Donald Heller and Mrs. Jonas Brown, both of Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Sanford Saperstein officiated at Temple Israel in South Merrick, L.I. Mrs. Heller, a member of the corporate finance department at Josephthal & Company, graduated from the University of Massachusetts. Mr. Heller, a graduate of Hobart College, is a vice president of Goldman Sachs & Company.

title: John Wesley
description: To the Editor: There was a modest ecclesiological error in Leslie Mandel-Viney's article ''On foot in a London Village'' (Travel, March 20). We are told of ''a series of John Wesley walking tours,'' which ''will honor the 250th anniversary of Wesley's conversion to Methodism.''

title: Lacroix or Le Cash?
description: WHAT WOULD you rather have?

title: THE MAN WITH EXTRAORDINARY QUALITIES
description: POSTHUMOUS PAPERS OF A LIVING AUTHOR By Robert Musil. Translated by Peter Wortsman. 145 pp. Hygiene, Colo.: Eridanos Press. Cloth, $21. Paper, $12.

title: New Company Hopes To Expand in Stamford
description: WHEN Steve Karp resigned as artistic director of the Maxwell Anderson Playwrights Series of Stamford last month, he proceeded with his plans, but with a new company.

title: Social Events; Many Parties, Many Causes
description: Museum Party . . . April 11 - The Metropolitan Museum's ninth annual spring dance will be held from 9:30 P.M. to 1 A.M. in the Temple of Dendur. There will be an open bar and snacks at the black-tie benefit. Tickets, $125 at the door. Information: 212-879-5500. . . . Museum Preview April 11 - ''Blatas and His New York World of Music and Theater,'' an exhibition of Arbit Blatas's oil paintings, sculptures and drawings of people of New York theater, music and opera from the past 40 years will be shown at a benefit preview at the Museum of the City of New York. The preview of the exhibition, which opens to the public April 12, will be from 6 to 8 P.M., with music, hors d'oeuvres and cocktails. Tickets, $35, from 212-534-5974. Briefly Noted: April 11 - The Police Athletic League's 16th Superstar Dinner will be held at the Pierre, with cocktails at 6 followed by dinner, dancing, entertainment and an award presentation to the real estate developer Larry Fisher. Tickets for the black-tie benefit, $1,000, from 212-477-9450. April 12 - Cocktails at 5:30 followed by dinner at the Marriott Marquis and a performance of ''The Phantom of the Opera'' will benefit the New York chapter of the Arthritis Foundation. Tickets, $100, $125 and $150 for the performance, plus $75 for cocktails and dinner, from 212-477-8316. April 12 - Ann Reinking will be the hostess, and Christopher Reeve and Peter Allen the special guests, at a benefit at the Plaza for the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival. Cocktails at 6 will be followed by dinner and the movie ''Hope and Glory.'' Tickets, $250, from 413-637-1322. April 12 - The New York City School Volunteer Program, which provides individual tutoring, will benefit from a cocktail party at 6 on the 50th floor of the Equitable Life Assurance Building, Seventh Avenue at 50th Street, followed by a preview performance of the musical ''Chess.'' Tickets, $300 and $500, or $150 for the show alone, from 212-213-3370. April 13 - A black-tie party at the opening of the new restaurant Metro, 23 East 74th Street, will benefit the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind. The dinner-dance starts with cocktails at 7:30. Tickets, $150, from 212-355-2200, extension 186. April 13 - Artists, designers, architects and others of note have created 40 works inspired by the American flag. The works, which may be viewed April 10 to 13 at Sotheby's, will be auctioned there, after a reception at 6 P.M., to benefit the New York Landmarks Preservation Foundation. Tickets, $125, from 212-529-5452. April 13 - The European Community Youth Orchestra, conducted by Erich Leinsdorf, will mark its inaugural American concert tour with a benefit performance for Very Special Arts, which provides artistic opportunities for handicapped people. A Champagne reception follows the 8 P.M. performance at Avery Fisher Hall. Tickets, $100, from 914-592-2180. April 14 - A reception at 6, followed by a concert and then by dinner, will benefit the 92d Street Y's social, educational and social service programs. The pianist Vladimir Feltsman will be the soloist with the New York Chamber Symphony of the 92d Street Y. Tickets for the black-tie benefit at the Y, $150 for the reception and concert, and $500 and $1,000 for the entire evening, from 212-427-6000, extension 248. April 14 - Drawings by architects from the United States, the Soviet Union and 10 other countries will be auctioned at a benefit from 6 to 8 P.M. for Architects/Designers/Planners for Social Responsibility at the Max Protetch Gallery, 560 Broadway (Prince Street). Tickets for the reception and auction, $25, from 212-334-8104 or at the door. April 14 - Cocktails at dockside at 6:30 P.M. and a cruise, with dinner and dancing, around New York harbor from 8 to 11 aboard the yacht Princess will celebrate the Brooklyn Y.M.C.A.'s 100th anniversary. Boarding is at Pier 1, at the foot of Cadman Plaza West in Brooklyn Heights. Tickets, $200, or $135 for Y members, from 718-875-1190, extension 200. April 14 - The 225th anniversary of Touro Synagogue in Newport, R.I., the oldest house of Jewish worship in the nation, will be marked by the Touro National Heritage Trust with a black-tie dinner-dance benefit at the Sheraton Centre, starting with cocktails at 7. Tickets, $500, from 212-713-0052. April 15 - The Leukemia Society's Salute to Corporate Stars will be held at the Plaza. Cocktails at 6:30 precede dinner, dancing and entertainment. Tickets for the black-tie benefit, $400, from 212-679-1939. April 15 - A black-tie dinner-dance at the St. Regis Roof, starting with cocktails at 7:30, will benefit the Visiting Nurse Service of New York. Tickets, $150, from 212-794-9200. Swedish Salutes April 15 - This year marks the 350th anniversary of the arrival of the first Swedish settlers in the American colonies, and in one of many celebrations Northern Lights Productions, an Off Broadway company devoted to the translation and production of contemporary Scandinavian plays, is holding a benefit party. Festivities, including some play readings by Aidan Quinn, John Malkovich and Joan Allen, will be at the Puck Building, Lafayette and Houston Streets. Tickets, $30 from 212-529-6105, $40 at the door. April 16 - ''A Tribute to Birgit Nilsson and the Swedish Vocal Tradition in America'' will be held at Carnegie Hall at 7, followed by supper in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza attended by King Carl XVI Gustaf and Queen Silvia of Sweden. The benefit will establish an operatic scolarship fund. Tickets, $150 for the performance and supper in the Baroque Suite at the Plaza, and $300 for the performance and the ballroom supper, from 212-944-5700.

title: REDEFINING THE BOUNDARIES: Who May Come In; Immigration Bill: Looking for Skills And Good English
description: THE public obsession with closing the borders to unwanted immigration has obscured a growing and in some ways more profound debate over what kind of immigrants we do want. More than half a million people enter the United States each year as legal immigrants, taking the first step toward citizenship under a system that has not been changed substantially in 23 years.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Sea Cliff
description: LEAD: ON a Saturday night not long ago, Sea Cliff residents gathered upstairs at the firehouse for the ''Base Ball,'' an annual benefit for the local Little League. Pennants inscribed with the names of village merchants hung from the walls and many people came dressed as their favorite major league players.

title: WRITERS UNDER SUSPICION
description: DANGEROUS DOSSIERS Exposing the Secret War Against America's Greatest Authors. By Herbert Mitgang. Illustrated. 331 pp. New York: Donald I. Fine. $18.95.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Biologist in the Mirror What kind of anxiety does a famous molecular biologist face when he wakes in the morning? This is from ''The Statue Within: An Autobiography,'' by Francois Jacob (Basic Books).

title: Moira J. Dolan Is Bride Of David Mandelbaum
description: Moira Joan Dolan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Dolan of New York, was married yesterday to David Mandelbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Mandelbaum, also of New York. Civil Court Judge Michael D. Stallman performed the ceremony in a private Manhattan loft.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Has the Excitement Gone From Commemorative Coinage?
description: LEAD: AFTER a lapse of nearly 30 years, commemorative coinage was resumed in 1982. Yet some of the excitement has given way to exasperation.

title: MOSCOW PREPARING A SHUTTLE LAUNCH
description: As the crippled United States space program struggles to get back on its feet, the Soviet Union is gearing up for the launch of its first shuttle on an unmanned mission.

title: Israel Must Let Palestinians Go or Lose Its Soul
description: To the Editor:

title: Does Steinbrenner Help or Hurt The Yanks?
description: When I wear my Yankee cap, my friends ridicule me for rooting for the team George Steinbrenner owns. He let Reggie go; hired Billy Martin (again), and sold so many games to pay television that people in Brooklyn have to follow the team on radio and in the papers or else forgo being fans. He has hurt the team and the tradition so much I do not bleed pinstripes anymore. LORIN DUCKMAN Brooklyn

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We've learned to dry our tears of sorrow with dollar bills. But money never takes the place of Bikini.'' - Lore Kessibuki, visiting his island homeland. [ 22:3. ]

title: Meese Links Embassy Riot to Traffickers
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that anti-American riots in Honduras this week in which five Hondurans died demonstrated ''the tremendous power of the narcotics traffickers and what they are apparently trying to orchestrate.''

title: Elizabeth Thacher Speers Is Married To D. S. McCormick, Ph.D. Candidate
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan, Conn., Elizabeth Thacher Speers, the daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. of New Canaan and Center Sandwich, N.H., was married yesterday to David Speir McCormick, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert V. McCormick of Madison, N.J., and East Hampton, L.I. The bride's father, pastor of the church, and her brother the Rev. Thomas G. Speers 3d, pastor of the Dickey Memorial Presbyterian Church in Baltimore, performed the ceremony.

title: DATA UPDATE: April 10, 1988
Anne Lewis Is Married
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., Anne Beals Lewis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley P. Lewis of Southport, was married yesterday to J. William Drake 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Drake Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund performed the ceremony.

title: Headliners; Nicholson vs. Cuomo vs. Nicholson
description: Governor Cuomo and a couple of his former law students will soon be getting together to talk about old times, but the occasion won't exactly be a friendly reunion. Mr. Cuomo's former students, Michael and Diane L. Nicholson, are also his former law partners, and they are suing and being sued by Mr. Cuomo in a longstanding dispute over more than $4 million in legal fees obtained by their law firm after Mr. Cuomo resigned in 1975. The case came to trial last week, with Mr. Cuomo contending that some of the money is rightfully his. Mr. and Mrs. Nicholson say the Governor relinquished his right to any fees by accepting a $100,000 settlement when he quit. Mr. Cuomo, who is expected to testify, has said the Nicholsons sued mainly to embarrass him politically.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the Travel Advisory column on March 20 about rail passes misstated the length of validity for one Eurailpass. The $298 pass is valid for 15 days. A brief report with the chart incompletely described the availability of rail passes. They are available through travel agents.

title: Knicks in Middle of Fuzzy Picture
description: Not since the National Basketball Association increased its playoff field from 12 to 16 teams for the 1982-83 season has there been so much uncertainty in filling out the eight-team Eastern Conference schedule and the opening-round pairings.

title: U.S. LIMITING STAYS OF FOREIGN NURSES
description: Thousands of foreign nurses recruited to help ease the nation's severe nursing shortage will be forced to leave because the Federal immigration agency refuses to extend their temporary visas to work in the United States.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Holocaust Museum
description: LEAD: The Shoah Research Institute at Temple Israel in White Plains will be a museum and library relating to the Holocaust, but there won't be any pictures or descriptions of atrocities. ''We don't want dead bodies,' said Leon Wolfe, a historian and one of the institute's founders. ''We want to erect a monument to the six million, but we want to depict the beautiful life of Jews over the centuries.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: OPERATION BABYLON. By Shlomo Hillel. Translated by Ina Friedman. (Doubleday, $19.95.) From 1947 to 1952, approximately 125,000 Jews emigrated from Iraq - the oldest community in the Diaspora - to Israel. Shlomo Hillel, born in Iraq and today Speaker of Israel's Knesset, played a pivotal role in that exodus, working behind the lines first to ferry Jews out of the country clandestinely and then, after Iraq agreed to relax emigration restrictions briefly in 1950, to organize the airlift of nearly the entire remaining Jewish community.

title: Review/Dance; From Europe, With Love and Therapy
description: A good many sins have been committed in dance in the name of postmodernist abstraction and ''body work,'' or dance drawn from now-popular physiotherapeutic techniques. But ''Solo Piece,'' created and performed by Jeanette Engler on Thursday, did much to redeem the genres. Presented at the Swiss Institute in a four-day festival of Swiss choreography coordinated by Emilio Schlaepfer, the solo was an inspired model of its kind.

title: Does Steinbrenner Help or Hurt The Yanks?
description: In answer to your question: ouch. SUSAN WILCOX New York

title: J. R. Hewitt Weds Katherine Heller
description: Katherine Holland Heller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Blanchfield Heller of Bedford, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Robert Hewitt, the son of Donald Birch Hewitt of San Diego and the late Edith Marie Hewitt. The Rev. Joseph Blanchfield, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: Does Steinbrenner Help or Hurt The Yanks?
description: Why restrict the question to the Yankees? George Steinbrenner has already besmirched the images of sportsmanship and free enterprise in America. Now that he has been accorded a wider stage upon which to perform, his next achievement could well be the extinguishing of the Olympic flame. ROBERT N. GOLDMAN New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: BROOK BENTON, SINGER OF HIT TUNES KNOWN FOR HIS BALLADS, DIES AT 56
description: Brook Benton, the popular baritone singer and writer of ballads who had many hit songs in the late 1950's and 60's, died of pneumonia yesterday at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Queens. He was 56 years old and lived in Queens.

title: Inquiries Into Research Start
description: The National Institutes of Health and two Congressional panels are about to begin investigating charges that a report on molecular biology research by a Nobel laureate and his colleagues misrepresented data.

title: Strength to Be Free
description: There are men and women in our history whose spirits are so strong and deeds so grand that their visceral magnetism endures after other popular figures fade. The lives of two such women are well presented in recent books by Jeri Ferris in Carolrhoda Books' Creative Minds series -WALKING THE ROAD TO FREEDOM: A Story About Sojourner Truth, illustrated by Peter E. Hanson, and GO FREE OR DIE: A Story About Harriet Tubman, illustrated by Karen Ritz (each $9.95; Ages 7 to 10). Harriet Tubman risked her life hundreds of times to help Southern slaves find freedom in the North, even as members of the Resistance smuggled Jews out of war-torn Europe and present-day Americans affiliated with organizations like Amnesty International take risks to win freedom for Nicaraguans and Haitians. Sojourner Truth selected her own name, after a series of slave names taken from her masters, to convey the essence of her lifelong mission. She traveled around the United States to spread the truth about the equality of all people.

title:
FOCUS: Peoria, Ill.;
Bouncing Back From Recession
description: LEAD: WHEN the Spirit of Peoria is christened next month, the paddle-wheel riverboat will be the latest addition to a city rebuilding its downtown.

title: Escape Clause For Authors
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'Sex Wars'
description: To the Editor:

title:
DANCE;
Hartford to Feature New Choreography
description: LEAD: DANCERS from around the state will come together to show innovative new work in downtown Hartford next weekend, in the second Connecticut Choreographers Showcase, co-sponsored by Real Art Ways and Dance Services Network .

title: Amy Cifrino Wed To W. A. Rooney In Massachusetts
description: Amy Cifrino, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Cifrino of Cohasset, Mass., and William Anthony Rooney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis C. Rooney Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday. Msgr. John A. Broderick performed the ceremony at St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in Cohasset.

title: Eye on the Doughnut
description: IF YOU ASK my opinion - and even if you don't - one of the least wonderful things about having a technical job is that when you come home after work and the spouse of your choice says, ''Did you have a nice day, dear?'' you can say ''Yes,'' ''No'' or ''None of the above.'' But chances are you can't explain why. Not really well, anyway.

title: China Affirms Li Peng as Prime Minister
description: Li Peng, an electrical engineer who studied in the Soviet Union during his 20's, was confirmed today by China's Parliament as the country's Prime Minister.

dining room, music room, large kitchen, full basement, 2-car garage; 1/2-acre lot; taxes $600 (Broker Pearl Foreman Realty)

title: Marsha Harrison Wed To John B. Kleinheinz
description: Marsha Wynne Harrison, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Martin Harrison of Fort Worth, was married yesterday to John Burke Kleinheinz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Anthony Kleinheinz of Lake Oswego, Ore. The Rev. Lawrence Burke, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Plaza in New York.

title: Israel Must Let Palestinians Go or Lose Its Soul; P.L.O. Hasn't Changed
description: To the Editor:

title: THEIR TICKETS OUT OF MELTENVILLE
description: THE FIFTH STATION By Kevin McIlvoy. 176 pp. North Carolina: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill.

title: ARE WOMEN BETTER DOCTORS?
description: THERE WAS A CONUNDRUM THAT used to turn up now and then, when I was in high school, designed to test your level of consciousness. A father and son go fishing, and on the way home they're in an auto accident.

title: PERSPECTIVES: The Lefrak Plan; Using Condo Sales to Assist New Rentals
description: SOUTH of Delancey Street, the Lower East Side is something of a housing museum. Most of the governmental programs used to produce new urban housing since the days when Alfred E. Smith was Governor are on view there.

title: South Africa
description: To the Editor ''South Africa's Economy Faces an Unsteady Future'' (March 13) ignores the fact that labor reform in South Africa is one of the major achievements of the reform initiatives undertaken by my Government in recent years. Where else in Africa (or indeed in the third world) is trade union activity of the kind seen at work in South Africa to be found, let alone officially permitted?

title: Detroit Gains - At Japan's Expense
description: Vehicle sales showed a strength that continues to defy predictions that sales would sag this year. In the final 10 days of March, sales of American-made cars and light trucks were 11 percent higher than in the 1987 period. Among the Big Three, Chrysler had its best March in 15 years, completing its best first quarter ever. Perhaps even more encouraging to Detroit was a rise in the Big Three's market share to 77 percent while Japanese imports fell to a 16.1 percent share. And, measured in proportion to their sales rates, the Japanese, for the first time, have higher inventories than the American auto makers.

title: Amy Butler and Christopher J. Grant Are Married
description: At the Immaculate Conception Chapel of Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J., Anne Mary Butler, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John K. Butler of Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to Christopher Joseph Grant, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Grant of Watchung, N.J. The Rev. Richard M. Nardone performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Hard-Rock Commonplaces With a New Spin
description: WHEN LATE-1980'S ROCK seems to be humorlessly high-minded, slickly synthetic, tiresomely pandering or so implacably conceptual it's just no fun, there's an alternative: Australia. Heard from across the Pacific, against the background of American and British rock, Australian rock can sound like a wallaby of a different color; rowdy, guitar-driven, solid on the backbeat and tuneful, too.

title: Anna Wilkins Is Wed at Stanford
description: The marriage of Anna Sharon Wilkins, a daughter of Nancy S. Wilkins of Truckee, Calif., and Dr. Edmund E. Wilkins Jr. of Dalhousie, New Brunswick, to Thomas Handasyd Perkins Henderson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Welles Henderson of Philadelphia, took place yesterday at the Memorial Church on the campus of Stanford University. The Rev. Penelope Duckworth, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Deda Troeger To Wed in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Curtis R. Troeger of New Canaan, Conn., and Woodland Valley, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Ann Troeger to Donald J. Sandor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph J. Sandor of New Canaan. A July wedding is planned.

title: NO ONE SAID 'KNOCK IT OFF'
description: BUDDY BOYS When Good Cops Turn Bad. By Mike McAlary. 288 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: IT'S TEMPTING to describe Jean Hollander as a poet of the pastoral, especially after a visit to Hopewell, Mercer County, where her home, unseen from the main road, sits far back between rolling pasture and woods.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Okamoto Leads by 1 Shot: Ayako Okamoto of Japan shot an eight-under-par 63 yesterday for a one-shot lead over Colleen Walker after three rounds of the $225,000 San Diego Inamori Classic at Poway, Calif. Okamoto made eight birdies as she completed 54 holes in 203. Walker had a 69 yesterday.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''As they say in poker, 'If you've been in the game 30 minutes and don't know who the patsy is, you're the patsy.' '' -Warren E. Buffet, chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, in the company's annual report.

title: THE UNSPARING DISEASE
description: CRISIS Heterosexual Behavior in the Age of AIDS. By William H. Masters, Virginia E. Johnson and Robert C. Kolodny. 243 pp. New York: Grove Press. $15.95. AIDS: THE FACTS By John Langone. 247 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $8.95. THE AIDS BUREAUCRACY By Sandra Panem. 194 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. Cloth, $22.50. Paper, $9.95. AIDS The Ultimate Challenge. By Elisabeth Kubler-Ross. 330 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $17.95. SOMEONE WAS HERE Profiles in the AIDS Epidemic. By George Whitmore. 211 pp. New York: NAL Books/New American Library. $17.95.

title: Israel Must Let Palestinians Go or Lose Its Soul; Just Get Out
description: To the Editor:

title: FAREWELL, FRIEND
description: Unlike the heartless editor in Russell Baker's farewell column, I shed genuine tears after reading Mr. Baker's valedictory. He made so many people smile, even laugh aloud, or, more remarkably, think seriously. We admirers would phone one another to discuss and dissect with great joy and laughter his current column, or clip it out to send to distant friends and relatives.

title:
ART;
Bronx Museum Calls On Eight Artists From Westchester
description: LEAD: WESTCHESTER and the Bronx are usually thought of as polar opposites. Westchester is regarded as a place where the problems of modern life, if not avoided, have been smoothed out. But the Bronx has become synonymous with a concentration of those problems. Therefore, although an exhibition such as ''Focus on Westchester'' at the Bronx Museum of the

title: Light Day of Stumping for Dukakis and Jackson in New York
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson campaigned in Brooklyn yesterday while Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts went to Pennsylvania and upstate New York. Senator Albert Gore, Jr. of Tennessee took the day off.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: A SIMMERING dispute between Federal and state agencies over development in the Hackensack Meadowlands heated up recently with the veto, by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, of a wetlands permit there.

title: Maine Strikers Press Larger Agenda
description: As the strike at the International Paper Company's plant here enters its 11th month, union members say their fight is no longer against just one large corporation but has become a battle to revitalize a complacent labor movement.

title: An Actress Who Reads the Soul of Fugard
description: WHEN ATHOL FUGARD AND THE AC-tress Yvonne Bryceland first worked together in a 1969 production of the playwright's ''People Are Living There,'' ''it was already clear,'' says Mr. Fugard, ''that in Yvonne I had found an interpretive artist who totally understood what I was trying to achieve as a writer and who had the courage and mystery that I desperately needed as a director.'' Ms. Bryceland makes her New York stage debut as the reclusive sculptress Miss Helen in Mr. Fugard's ''Road to Mecca'' on Tuesday at the Promenade Theater.

title: Tracking Wiltshire's White Horses
description: ''THERE'S an old White Horse cut in the side of the highest hill hereabouts and many folks sets a good deal of store by it. '' The words are those of Thomas Hughes, the 19th-century British writer who gave us ''Tom Brown's Schooldays.'' Hughes grew up in the village of Uffington, beneath a northern escarpment of the Berkshire Downs some 50 miles west of London. There, engraved in the earth near the crest of an 856-foot-high prominence known as White Horse Hill, overlooking the undulating Vale of the White Horse, lies one of England's most magnificent and beloved historic monuments: the figure of a horse, abstract, but unmistakably equine, careening across the downs.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. Some of the bricks on the side of my brick stoop are flaking off and chipping, leaving saucerlike depressions. I have tried filling these with mortar and cement, but this didn't work. Is there a way I can fill the depressions or somehow treat the bricks to prevent any further deterioration?

title: POSTING: High-End in Hackensack; 18-Story Rental
description: Citing a ''crisis for rental housing,'' Anthony Palmieri broke ground late last month on Excelsior II, sequel to Excelsior I, in Hackensack, N.J. The sister projects on Prospect Avenue near Beach Street represent an increasingly rare commodity in the Northeast: high-end rental housing. ''The individual who would rent today has been neglected,'' Mr. Palmieri said, noting that most builders are creating condominiums and cooperatives. He was also encouraged to build rentals by state and city laws that exempt new construction from rent control.

title: Black, White and Beautiful
description: LATE LAST YEAR WHEN CINEPLEX ODEON AC-quired the Regency Theater, Manhattan's finest repertory house, angry tens of film aficionados demonstrated in the streets and signed petitions.

title: 'Drug-Free School Zone' Signs Stir Controversy
description: THE new ''Drug-Free School Zone'' signs cropping up across the state are being viewed in a number of ways, not all of them favorable.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Gilbert, Ariz.;
A Housing Mix Amid Farms
description: LEAD: THE developers of an 800-acre community in this town of citrus farms 25 miles southeast of Phoenix are building more affordable houses in response to a changing home market.

title: What's Ahead for the Fed?
description: The jobless rate is down and much of the economy is at near capacity - the classic condition for inflation. Typically, the Federal Reserve responds to these pressures by raising interest rates. Last week, the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds jumped to 8.87 percent, the highest since January. Is the Fed now worried about inflation? How will it respond? FRANCIS H. SCHOTT Senior vice president and chief economist, The Equitable Life Assurance Society.

title: How Jesse Jackson Made History While Losing Wisconsin
description: CERTAIN Presidential primaries feel special at the time and are remembered many years later. A man and a place come to be linked indissolubly in political memory, whether or not he wins there. So it was for John F. Kennedy in West Virginia and Eugene J. McCarthy in New Hampshire.

title: Lisa Klem, Sales Manager, Wed to Kenneth R. Wilson
description: At Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson, N.J., Lisa Anne Klem, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Klem of Rumson, and Kenneth Ralph Wilson, a son of Delbert Wilson of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Hazel Leonard Wilson, were married yesterday by the Rev. William J. Carton.

title: Former Teamsters Employee Is to Testify Against Presser
description: A man has pleaded guilty here in an arrangement that will make him an important witness at the racketeering and embezzlement trial of the president of the teamsters' union.

title: For the Adventurous, The Amazon Mystique
description: AMERICA'S boom in boutiquebeers is not confined to the 75 or so domestic micro-brewers. A number of unfamiliar foreign brands, like Mort Subite from Belgium, Old Peculiar from Britain and Hinano from Tahiti have recently begun to surface in the United States. In all, some 600 foreign labels are sold in this country, representing about 6 percent of sales. Imported beers were the only ones to register growth in the American beer market in 1987.

title: GLUCK IS CRITICIZED ON I-80 ALTERNATIVES
description: The comments of Transportation Commissioner Hazel Frank Gluck in the March 27 article on the Interstate 80 commuter problem, about finding another means of getting to work, are ridiculous.

title: Down the Garden Path
description: ''THE IDEA,'' SAYS STEPHEN K-M. Tim, ''was to tell the story of plant evolution, where possible using live plants.'' Mr. Tim is vice president of science and publications at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden in New York, which is opening its new Conservatory, consisting of a greenhouse and three other glass pavilions, on May 19. He is the principal architect of the Trail of Evolution, a 100-foot long, 17-foot high exhibit in the central greenhouse, which traces the history of plant life to its beginnings, some 3.5 billion years ago. ''You can go to any natural history museum and see displays of evolutionary history,'' Mr. Tim says. ''But it's always behind glass, a little stilted. There's nothing alive there. And in most cases, the emphasis is on the animal side; plants have been relegated to a background position. I thought, 'Enough of that.' ''

title: Keep Sports Agents Off the Campus
description: ONE of college football's biggest problems is that of unscrupulous agents tampering with undergraduate athletes.

title: Steps Taken to Ease Tension in Carolina County
description: Gov. James G. Martin of North Carolina is making what he concedes is an extraordinary move in supporting creation of another judicial post here in racially troubled Robeson County and promising to appoint a member of a minority group.

title: Perils of a Playwright Getting In on the Act
description: IT WAS NOT MY ORIGINAL INTENT to play Gus Gilbert, the aging redneck owner of a scruffy Texas beer joint, in the recent five-week premiere production of my latest play, ''The Night Hank Williams Died,'' at New Playwrights' Theater in Washington. I have been a writer most of my life, an actor only infrequently. Most of my stage experience occurred in the long ago in amateur productions or in a few outdated Army training films. Almost a decade ago I played 16 performances on Broadway in ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas,'' which I had the luck to co-write, substituting for Henderson Forsythe when he took a vacation from his Tony-award winning role as Sheriff Ed Earl Dodd. But Sam Shepard or Woody Allen I am not.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: HISTORY
description: SIR FRANCIS DRAKE His Daring Deeds. Written and illustrated by Roy Gerrard. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: THE WORLD: Nicaragua and Panama; U.S. Pressure Points In Central America Are Refusing to Yield
description: THE limits of American power in Central America, a region the United States once dominated, became starkly visible again last week in Panama and Nicaragua.

title: Betsy Reid Wed To B. D. Ayres Jr.
description: Betsy Bailey Reid, a former director of the Arms Control Media Project in Washington, and B. Drummond Ayres Jr., a national correspondent for The New York Times based in Washington, were married yesterday. The Rev. William Billow performed the ceremony at St. Alban's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: Israel Must Let Palestinians Go or Lose Its Soul; Soviet Role in Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: The City Hangs Up A 'No Smoking' Sign
description: NEW YORK CITY'S new antismoking law took effect Wednesday, and immediately, thousands of city smokers were fuming.

title: N.H.L. Rewards Poor Performers
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A 'Time for Parents to Speak Up'
description: Eleanor Einzing [ ''Children of the Divorced: Children in Need,'' Westchester Opinion, March 13 ] touched on a point that needs all the attention it can get: the role of parents as vocal advocates for children and their needs. The most recent statistics show that 52 percent of all children under one year of age have working mothers. If all of these women voted for candidates who represented their issues, parental leave and child-care assistance would be in place. If all working parents spoke up in their school districts, before- and after-school programs would be available. If the employees who are parents would address child-care concerns in the workplace, flexible schedules and dependent-care assistance would be part of business plans.

title: A 'Butterfly' That Hovers Over The Issues of Racism, Sexism And Imperialism
description: IF YOU WANT TO BE TAKEN seriously as a playwright, the quickest way is to set up as a thinker. Nothing is more calculated to make audiences assume a respectful expression than the suggestion that they are about to have some ideas dished out to them, and in a theater world that generally offers little in the way of intellectual nourishment, it is easy enough to see why.

title: REDEFINING THE BOUNDARIES: Who May Come In; PRO & CON: What Price An Anarchist?
description: A COUNTRY'S borders provide not only identity in the eyes of the world but an important measure of self-definition. Whom a nation permits to enter, whom it excludes, whom it welcomes or fears - all indicate how a country sees itself, its present and its future.

title: A Divided Society Is an Unjust Society
description: UNLESS whites and blacks are truly interested in nothing more than protesting, preserving and expanding the status quo - whites living with whites, blacks living with blacks -we face an ever increasingly polarized society, in which racial divisiveness, escalating violent crimes and ''racial incidents'' become a way of life for all American citizens who live in or near a multiethnic society.

title: Pop View; Wait a Minute, Mr. Postman: Sting Takes on His Critics
description: STING IS AT IT AGAIN. IN California recently, I came upon an arch letter the rock star had sent to The San Francisco Chronicle, complaining about a review of his recent Bay Area concert and challenging the critic to come up on stage at his next show and prove that he has the talent to entertain an arena-sized audience for 10 minutes.

title: FAREWELL, FRIEND
description: Russell Baker has given us 15 years of delightful and provocative writing to brighten up our Sundays. If he now decides that he has had enough, he has earned the right to stop.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Revere, Mass.;
Office Space On the Ocean
description: LEAD: THE first new office building in 30 years for this blue-collar city of 42,000 is almost ready for occupancy.

title: DATA BANK: April 10, 1988
With Help From Friends, Oscar's a Wit and Raconteur
description: MORE THAN A BILLION people all over the world will watch it, but it begins to take shape on 3-by-5 file cards on the pool table at Ernie Lehman's house. And Mr. Lehman knows, going in, that however it finally happens, no one will be fully satisfied with the show. They never have been.

title: MATTINGLY AN EXCEPTION TO BATTING RULES
description: IN the last four seasons, Wade Boggs of Boston has had the best batting average in the major leagues but ranks only 92d in home runs, 51st in runs batted in and 106th in r.b.i. per plate appearance. Tony Gwynn of San Diego is second in hitting but 112th in home runs, 95th in runs batted in and 123d in r.b.i. per plate appearance.

title: A Marshall Spirit
description: SHOCK, outrage, sheepishness at having been bamboozled and grudging admiration all went into making up the meaning of a ''Marshall swindle'' or, later, just plain ''swindle.''

title: Anne Webster Wed to Charles Leight
description: Anne Elizabeth Webster, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Armstrong Webster of Glen Ridge, N.J., was married yesterday in Tucson, Ariz., to Charles David Leight, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold C. Leight of Denver. The Rev. Victoria G. Curtiss of St. Mark's Presbyterian Church in Tucson performed the ceremony at the Waterfall at the Ventana Canyon Resort Hotel.

title:
THE NATION: Public Land;
Are Forests Worth More Unspoiled Or Developed?
description: LEAD: THE gray, snow-mottled peaks of southern Montana's Gallatin range are mostly public property.

title: THE WORLD: A Voice From Jerusalem; Confronting the 'Infuriating Smugness' of the Diaspora
description: LIVING at this distance, I don't know what the catch phrase is today, but a short while back the fund-raising rubric the United Jewish Appeal proclaimed used to be ''We Are One.'' It was short, sweet and - from the liturgical echo of oneness to its historical evocation of common source and destiny - apt.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE SCARSDALE POLICE DEPARTMENT;
A Goal Is Set for Highest Professional Standards
description: LEAD: DONALD W. FERRARO, Chief of the Scarsdale Police Department, doesn't mind doing lots of paperwork. Jack Craven describes himself as ''administratively inclined.'' That's a good thing, because the two men are at the helm of a project that will keep them busy with facts, figures and data-filing for the next two years.

title: The Ultimate Gift
description: LOYALTY and gratitude frequently prompt people to make major gifts to colleges. Often, though, others have equally simple reasons for their gifts.

title: Gubernatorial Hopeful Dies in Montana Crash
description: A candidate for the Republican gubernatorial nomination, Secretary of State Jim Waltermire, died in a plane crash late Friday, his campaign manager said today.

title: N.C.A.A. Ignores Quality, Quantity
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Cable TV Dispute: A Case Study for State
description: LEAD: WHAT began as a dispute between a county cable television company and a citizens group that produces local programming has evolved into a case that is drawing the attention of a state commission compiling rules on community access to cable.

title: No Headline
description: IN a one-room pottery enterprise deep in the heart of medieval Fez in north central Morocco, I came upon a surprising new excuse for lingering over a shop's merchandise. The only exit was suddenly blocked by the menacing rear end of a mule. One of the ''taxis of the medina,'' the mule had just arrived with a load of newly fired Fassiware from the potter's section outside the city walls. Perhaps recognizing the destination, it settled into the shop's door while the driver tugged, threatened, then finally gave up and began to loosen the ropes binding the canvas burden.

title: HOW BASEBALL'S TOP ROOKIES STACK UP
description: The sheer, naked prospect that any new player may develop into Hall of Fame material has been enough to drive up the price of each year's rookie cards before the ink is dry. As the season - and the seasons - unfold, most drop to the level of common players. But while their careers are young and there is still even a remote prospect of stardom, their rookie cards sell at a premium.

title: Prison Populations at Issue
description: IN AN attempt to contain the rising costs of housing New Jersey's rapidly growing prison population, some lawmakers, corrections officials and academics are seeking a review of mandatory sentencing laws.

title: State of the Arts and the Budget
description: Although no source is given, Claudette Beaulieu's statistic [ ''Sponsoring the Arts: Good Business,'' Westchester Opinion, March 27 ] that more people attended events at Lincoln Center and Carnegie Hall than at Yankee Stadium and at Shea Stadium in 1987 may well be accurate. Certainly, as executive director of the New Orchestra of Westchester, she is in a position to know exactly how much people spent on food and beverage service (if not on clothing and hair dressers) for the most recent dinner-dance to benefit the ensemble.

title: Queens Woman Found Slain In Car at a Shopping Center
description: The body of a woman who had been stabbed to death was found yesterday afternoon in the back of her car at a shopping center in Whitestone, Queens, the police said.

title: Seeing France Sans Frills By Barge
description: FRANCE'S inland waterways offer a refinement wonderfully out of step with modern times: the joy of traveling and savoring the splendors of France very, very slowly. Permitted speeds on canals are between 6 and 10 kilometers an hour (3.75 to 6.25 m.p.h.), and on the rivers 10 to 25 kilometers an hour (6.25 to 15.6 m.p.h.). Locks, open only from 6:30 A.M. to 7:30 P.M. with time off at the dot of noon for lunch, slow progress even further.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: New & Noteworthy
description: ME AND DIMAGGIO: A Baseball Fan Goes in Search of His Gods, by Christopher Lehmann-Haupt. (Dell, $3.95.) After spending a season observing the big leagues, the New York Times book critic Christopher Lehmann-Haupt contemplated the uneasy relationship between those who play baseball and those who sit in the press box and write about it. ''Seldom is the awkwardness of this situation so freshly and unabashedly reflected as in this book,'' Roy Blount Jr. said in The Times in 1986. STARING AT THE SUN, by Julian Barnes. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $7.95.) On the eve of her 100th birthday, in 2021, an Englishwoman named Jean Serjeant, who once left a ''second-rate life'' with a boring husband to seek enchantment and the wonders of the world, boards an airplane and flies into the sun. Last year our reviewer, Carlos Fuentes, called the novel ''a marvelous literary epiphany'' and praised Julian Barnes, the author of ''Flaubert's Parrot,'' for using his ''great precision of language, ironical detachment and talent for the incarnation of ideas'' to let his readers ''witness a reality we do not normally see.'' TANIA: A Biography and Memoir of Isak Dinesen, by Parmenia Migel. (McGraw-Hill, $8.95.) Karen Blixen's nom de plume was Isak Dinesen, but to her friends she was Titania - Tania for short. In 1967, when this memoir by Parmenia Migel was first published, our reviewer, William Jay Smith, called it ''a remarkably sensitive book that . . . never for one moment loses sight of [ Dinesen's ] magic. . . . Miss Migel has told Tania's own story as she would have wished it told, with accuracy and care, with wit and style.'' WHO KILLED PALOMINO MOLERO? by Mario Vargas Llosa. Translated by Alfred Mac Adam. (Collier/ Macmillan, $6.95.) The Peruvian novelist Mario Vargas Llosa uses a detective story about the murder of a young singer to explore the ambiguities of truth, justice and evil. ''Evoking landscape and mores in writing that is spare, rich and cruelly beautiful, he both satisfies the requirements of the genre and demonstrates that it too can resonate like any other form of fiction,'' Richard Lourie said in The Book Review last year. THE NEW AMERICAN GRANDPARENT: A Place in the Family, a Life Apart, by Andrew J. Cherlin and Frank F. Furstenberg Jr. (Basic Books, $9.95.) Increased longevity and the ever-advancing demographic bulge are creating a country that is top-heavy with grandparents, who are providing their children's children with something halfway between a parental authority figure and an aging friend. In 1986 Maggie Scarf said here that this sociological study is ''a bit dry in places,'' but that it provides a ''comprehensive and intriguing portrait of grandparenting in America today.'' A NIGHT AT THE MOVIES: Or, You Must Remember This, by Robert Coover. (Collier/Macmillan, $7.95.) Written in the form of absurd cinematic parodies, Robert Coover's collection of short fiction shows that the printed page can be more malleable to the imagination than the silver screen. ''The book gives us a long, exhilarating evening at an old-fashioned movie palace,'' Edmund White said here last year. ''Mr. Coover has understood the potential of the movies to persuade and to subvert but also to go out of control.'' THE CAPTIVE PUBLIC: How Mass Opinion Promotes State Power, by Benjamin Ginsberg. (Basic Books, $8.95.) By managing mass opinion, Benjamin Ginsberg writes, governments use democracy as a means of social control. Last year our reviewer, Mark Crispin Miller, said the author's ''quasi-Orwellian vision is oversimple,'' but he found the book ''largely admirable.'' OVERHEAD IN A BALLOON: Twelve Stories of Paris, by Mavis Gallant. (Norton, $7.95.) When these interlocking stories by the Canadian writer were published last year, Phyllis Rose said in these pages that Mavis Gallant ''conjures up [ Paris ] more knowingly than any other fiction writer in English. . . . In the taut, high-wire literary performances in this volume, [ she ] is at the top of her form.'' A GOOD ENOUGH PARENT: A Book on Child-Rearing, by Bruno Bettelheim. (Vintage, $9.95.) Last year our reviewer, Barbara Ehrenreich, said she wondered how Bruno Bettelheim thought today's two-paycheck families would have time for his leisurely, permissive approach to child raising. But she found the book ''a reassuring corrective to the hubris that leads many parents to think they can mold a child to meet their exact specifications.'' SERENISSIMA, by Erica Jong. (Dell, $4.95.) An intellectual American actress travels to the 16th century and has a lurid affair with William Shakespeare. In 1987 Michael Malone said in The Book Review that he didn't like this novel as much as he did ''Fanny,'' but he praised Erica Jong for ''her careful research, her rich descriptive facility and her deep love of the period.'' THE TOMORROW MAKERS: A Brave New World of Living-Brain Machines, by Grant Fjermedal. (Tempus, $8.95.) If the mind is a program, theoretically it can be ''downloaded,'' or fed, into computerized robots, granting a kind of immortality. Last year one reviewer said this book about computer scientists and robotics is ''a virtual smorgasbord of artificial intelligence.'' MEMOIRS OF MANY IN ONE, by Alex Xenophon Demirjian Gray. Edited by Patrick White. (Penguin, $6.95.) A madwoman's fantasies, cast as a memoir edited by the author, allow Patrick White to write a story about writing stories. In 1986 our reviewer, Jonathan Baumbach, called the novel ''an elegant book, a comic meditation on the nature of art (and putative madness), a minor 'Tempest' in a career of sometimes oversized teapots.''

title: A New Company Forms in Stamford
description: >WHEN Steve Karp resigned as artistic director of the Maxwell Anderson Playwrights Series of Stamford last month, he remained right where he was and proceeded with his plans - with a new company.

title: 'A Lot of People Just Can't Control Dogs'
description: LAURIE FASS calls herself an animal behaviorist who helps owners break their pets of troublesome habits. She runs the Dog Training and Counseling Service at her home on Old Farm Drive in Newington. She also makes house calls.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Prospects column of March 27 omitted a phrase from the remarks of Ted McCourtney. In reference to initial public offerings, Mr. McCourtney said: ''The market value at the time a company goes public is not so important. What is important is the longer term value.''

title: Charles Ryskamp Brings a New Look To the Frick
description: FOR CONNOISSEURS OF THE Frick Collection, part of the pleasure of frequent visits is the sense of permanence: paintings and sculptures from the 13th century to the late 19th century are in their familiar settings, enhanced by choice decorative furnishings that give the galleries their rich domestic elegance. But the Frick, on Fifth Avenue at 70th Street, has never been a totally preserved environment of objects simply to be dusted off and left alone. And since Charles Ryskamp became the new director last June, following his long stewardship of the Pierpont Morgan Library, visitors have begun to note the impact of small, gradual, but significant changes in the galleries.

title: Coping With Common Problems
description: Decorating a room often brings to mind the same horrors as shopping for clothes: Proportion is always a problem, and so often our fantasies have little to do with reality. But fortunately, design imperfections can be remedied more quickly than physical ones, and with less pain.

title: Troopers Increase Truck Inspections
description: LEAD: TRUCKS, especially those carrying hazardous material, are coming under increasing scrutiny from State Police teams assigned to inspect commercial vehicles and catch overweight trucks.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: PETER AND THE WOLF

title: 'Safety-First' Convoy Will Sail for England
description: The North Atlantic tends to be an inhospitable ocean for yachts, especially at this time of year. Knowing that, 10 American offshore racers who plan to compete in the trans-Atlantic sailboat race from Plymouth, England, to Newport, R.I., this summer have decided to sail in company to the race site.

title: Does Steinbrenner Help or Hurt The Yanks?
description: Steinbrenner definitely helps the Yankees . . . and Jack Clark will play in 150 games, Billy Martin will manage the team into the 1990's and a Winfield for Fred Lynn trade would be a brilliant move. STEVEN USLANER Fresh Meadows

title: 'Sex Wars'
description: To the Editor:

title: After a Sojourn In Film, He finds Play's the Thing
description: LEAD: ''ABOUT THREE YEARS AGO, I started to be aware that I really knew what I was doing technically,'' says Stephen Metcalfe, whose new play, ''Emily,'' a thorny comedy about a female stockbroker, opens Tuesday at the Manhattan Theater Club. Playgoers familiar with Mr. Metcalfe's earlier works, most of which had premieres at that same theater, will be quick to note the distinct change in approach.

title: Flyers Set Back Capitals By 4-3
description: Dave Poulin had a goal and two assists as the Philadelphia Flyers beat the Washington Capitals, 4-3, tonight. The Flyers took a lead of 2 games to 1 in their Patrick Division series.

title: McGwire Fed Up
description: THE next time somebody throws a baseball at the head of Mark McGwire of Oakland, the American League rookie of the year last season, he had better do some ducking himself. ''I'm tired of it,'' said McGwire, whose 49 home runs for the Athletics last season shattered the mark for rookies and whose first one this season nearly led to a fight.

title: Caution Sign For Runners
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Corporate Role in Day Care
description: LEAD: WEN the Phelps Memorial Hospital Center decided to establish its own child-care center, hospital administrators knew that there was a pressing need for the service.

title: Britain's Presence in Ulster Draws Rebuke by a Kennedy
description: The British have no right to be in Northern Ireland, Representative Joseph P. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, told a cheering crowd today at the conclusion of an Irish visit.

title: Argentina Links Man Killed by Police to a Wave of Bombings
description: The Government of President Raul Alfonsin, under pressure from military dissidents, has charged that a man shot to death by the police last week was a supporter of army rebels and that the man might have been involved inbombings.

title: Review/Opera; New Leads For Met's 'Trovatore'
description: Six enormous ebony pillars trundled to and fro on the Metropolitan Opera stage on Wednesday evening, dragging with them Verdi's ''Trovatore'' in the misguided production the company introduced in November. There were new singers in most of the principal roles, and a new conductor in the pit.

title: The Race to Commercialize Substitutes
description: Allied-Signal Inc. is the second largest domestic producer of chlorofluorocarbons. Marylyn I. Montgomery, vice president and general manager of Allied-Signal's Genetron business, and Bernard Sukornick, director of fluorochemicals research, talked with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about why Allied-Signal plans to continue production of chlorofluorocarbons as it seeks suitable substitutes.

title: 'Turtle, Bear, Badger, Wolf': The Indians' Affinity for Nature
description: LEAD: THE unique way that American Indians view the animal kingdom is the focus of an exhibition at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center called ''Turtle, Bear, Badger, Wolf.''

title: The Magic of Babies Makes Three a 'Perfect Number'
description: I CAN remember vividly the reaction of family and friends to my first pregnancy seven years ago. They were excited and thrilled, especially my parents and in-laws, who were anticipating their first grandchild.

title: Officials Resign In Track Fraud
description: Six Italian track and field officials accused of fixing a long-jump result in the 1987 world championships resigned today.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 880 KEYS FOR 300 FINGERS Thirty pianists will simultaneously play 10 Steinway baby grands today in the Piano Monster Concert, a benefit to raise $43,000 for a 9-foot Steinway piano at the University of Connecticut.

title: Corrections
description: A map of Miami on Feb. 7 included a number of errors, including the mislabeling of streets and the misplacing of labels for areas of the city. A corrected map follows.

title: Joining the Jayhawks
description: WITHIN hours of Larry Brown's decision to remain as coach at Kansas, Rick Calloway announced he was transferring there from Indiana. But according to the father of Calloway, a 6-foot-6-inch junior forward, Brown's decision had nothing to do with Calloway's decision to play for the Jayhawks, who won the national championship last week. Indiana took the title last year.

title: Why Du Pont Gave Up $600 Million
description: IN 1974, when stratospheric ozone depletion was still a theory, E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company made a pledge: If scientists proved that chlorofluorocarbons were a threat to public health, the company would stop making the chemicals. On March 24, 1988, Du Pont honored that commitment and announced its intention to phase out production of the most ozone-damaging C.F.C.'s over a 10-year period.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Trenton to Get a $35 Million Retail Project
description: LEAD: A DYING business center just four years ago, Trenton's downtown is staging a comeback. Modern office towers are being constructed and many time-worn buildings are being restored along State Street, the city's main commercial stretch.

title: POLLS APART
description: IMAGINE, IF YOU WILL, THIS little scene: You're at home, relaxed in front of the television screen. The doorbell rings. The caller is a polltaker. He asks the usual stuff about political party affiliation and your preference among the candidates. Then he says, ''May I ask you what is your favorite wine?''

title: 6th Hospital Joins Consortium
description: LEAD: THE Jersey Shore Medical Center here last week became the sixth hospital to join University Health System of New Jersey, a consortium of teaching hospitals and the state-financed University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Portland, Ore.;
A Partnership For Downtown
description: LEAD: PRIVATE enterprise has joined with city government here to bolster apartment development in a long-neglected area of downtown.

title: Barbara L. Kagan Is Wed to Thomas A. Kornreich
description: Barbara Lynne Kagan, the daughter of Mrs. Charles M. Kagan of New York and Southampton, L.I., and the late Mr. Kagan, was married last evening to Thomas Adam Kornreich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton A. Kornreich of Harrison, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: The Quizzes of a Lifetime
description: LEAD: VISION TESTS, hearing tests, drivers' tests, S.A.T.'s, G.R.E.'s, I.Q. tests, physical fitness tests, final exams, midterms, blood tests, vocational aptitude tests - people take some or all of these tests during a lifetime. For children, test-taking is such an integral part of school that they may view it as a natural life function.

title: Headliners; Stern vs. Whitehead Gould
description: The acrimonious court battles centering on 2-year-old Melissa Stern apparently have come to an end with neither side feeling like a loser. In the latest chapter of what has come to be known as the Baby M case, a New Jersey judge last week granted broad visitation rights to Mary Beth Whitehead Gould, who bore Melissa under a surrogacy contract with William Stern. After Mr. Stern and his wife won custody of Melissa, Mrs. Whitehead Gould's visitation rights were severely limited. Under the new ruling, she will have Melissa in her home one day a week at the beginning and, later, two days a week. But she is barred from public discussions that would infringe on the baby's privacy, and barred from selling movie rights to the case. The Sterns said they were ''thrilled'' by the publicity restraints. Mrs. Whitehead Gould, through her lawyer, said she was ''delighted and grateful.''

title: India
description: To the Editor: It made interesting reading to go through ''Enfolding India in a Length of Cloth'' by Iris Ihde Frey (Shopper's World, Feb. 28), but the author mistakenly indicated that the spinning wheel is symbolically represented on the Indian national flag. Actually, the wheel on the flag is a replica of the wheel of law from the lion capital (pedestal) erected by Emperor Ashoka in Sarnath in the third century B.C. It has 24 spokes, each representing a virtue.

title: Furor Over 'an Ideological Manifesto'
description: Excerpts from the Soviet newspapers Sovetskaya Rossiya and Pravda, reflecting the conflict over Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policies. RAMPANT NEGATIVISM

title: THE LONG ROAD BACK
description: It is unfortunate that the focus of Kim Heron's compelling article on the Outward Bound therapy program for Vietnam veterans suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder (''The Long Road Back,'' March 6) was on the tragic biographies of the patients rather than the innovative therapy and tirelessness of Bob Rheault.

title: Special Today; Home Design/Magazine, Part 2
description: Special reports in this issue include:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE CHINABERRY ALBUM. By Ruth Coe Chambers. (Mercury House, $16.95.) The World War II Gulf Coast town of Bay Harbor has a prominent Baptist church, ''nigra'' quarters tucked discreetly across the tracks, and a tradition that well-bred children should be seen and not heard. Nine-year-old Anna Lee Owens has been trained in that tradition, so she suffers in silence her childhood fears that a bully named Hazel will catch her alone - or that her beloved Uncle Johnn will marry and move away. Even complicated predicaments have simple consequences for Anna Lee; when she surprises a neighbor being beaten by her husband, Chester, Anna Lee's biggest fear is that she won't be allowed to visit them anymore. But the stakes become higher when Chester begins to pursue and molest Anna Lee, making sure she won't tell by offering a two-pronged threat: if she talks, either her father will shoot Chester and go to jail, or Chester will shift the blame to Uncle Johnn. Thus the girl begins a year of protecting everyone she loves by her silence. In this first novel, Anna Lee's narration is usually true to her age, although sometimes she seems just a bit too insightful. For the most part, however, Ruth Coe Chambers uses Anna Lee's point of view artfully as she explores the terror of growing up in a world full of conflicting rules and values. When Chester nearly rapes the girl, and everyone believes his version of the story, Anna Lee's protective silence turns to actual muteness. Here ''The Chinaberry Album'' falters a little, with a fire and even an alligator attack used to set things right. But by then Anna Lee and her loved ones have inspired enough affection that even the most pragmatic reader couldn't wish for any other ending.

title: Israel Must Let Palestinians Go or Lose Its Soul; Laser-Era Warfare
description: To the Editor:

title: ISLANDERS AGAIN FALL TO DEVILS
description: It was only appropriate that the spotlight, which escorted each member of the Devils onto the ice at the game's start, circled Sean Burke last and lingered with him longest.

title: Fiero Facing Its Swan Song Amid Some Mourning
description: THE auto show was in New York this week. Lots of hot lights, red neon, cars glittering on revolving platforms. And, at the Pontiac stand, there was one sad white Fiero, among other things.

title: Cheeses With an Irish Accent
description: IMAGINE that you are nearing the end of a Lucullan dinner at White's on the Green, one of the finest restaurants in Dublin. You have delighted your senses with appetizer, entree and salad. You toy with the idea of dessert, but then the waiter rolls around a cheese trolley, and you decide on that instead. Or, imagine that you have wandered into the Cheese Board, a cozy shop in Westbury Mall, off Grafton Street in Dublin, planning to purchase an assortment of cheeses for a cruise up the River Shannon.

title: A Lonely Road for a Modem Maker
description: PONY EXPRESS, telegraph, telephone, overnight letters, computers and modems - a constant progression of communications technology, fueled by the belief that faster is better. Faster transmission is of no value, however, if the message is incomprehensible or if the accuracy suffers.

title: Patterns of Addiction
description: MY ONLY CONSCIENTIOUS EFFORT TO take up an addictive substance came a cropper because it didn't give me any pleasure. I was 14 years old. The substance was cigarettes; the place was my best friend Mike's house. His parents being away for the evening, we agreed that the time had come. We went looking for an open pack. There wasn't one. So Mike, who could do anything with his hands, decided to extract one cigarette from a closed pack and then reclose it. This he accomplished over the next hour or so, right down to gluing the red cellophane strip back in place so that neither of his parents, in the urgency of craving, would ever notice that the pack had been tampered with, or that it was one shy of 20 cigarettes. (In retrospect, I can hardly comprehend how difficult it was for us good kids to do bad things in Tacoma, Wash., in the mid-1950's.) After all that foreplay, the moment of consummation arrived. I was expecting a thrill so intense that it would make me feel even guiltier than sex, as much as I knew of it. No such luck. For want of technique, I suppose, I didn't even get sick.

title: Japan's 'Examination Hell'
description: LIKE MANY 18-year-olds in Japan, Mayumi Yamamoto has long been immersed in serious training for her college-entrance examinations. But she went into high gear in early February, two weeks before the first in a series of exams.

title: Some Questions Just Have No Answers
description: USUALLY I vacation with my parents in Florida during the winter, so when an invitation came to spend a week in Colorado Springs, I hesitated about accepting. I was born with cerebral palsy, and these days the cold weather is especially bad for my legs. But the prospect of a vacation with Lynn and her husband, Alan, two professional dancers, and a chance to see a part of the country where I had never been, was too enticing.

title: Rochester Testing for Tainted Ground Water Near Tanks at Kodak
description: Reports that hazardous chemicals have been leaking from beneath Eastman Kodak Company tanks have prompted officials here to begin the most extensive environmental and health studies in the community's history.

title: Hijackers Kill Guard on Jetliner And Attack Passengers in Cyprus
description: The hijackers of a Kuwaiti jumbo jet beat and then shot and killed one of their 50 hostages today, during a long stalemate with Cypriot officials over whether the plane would be refueled.

title: FAREWELL, FRIEND
description: I will miss the Sunday Observer column (''Farewell, Friend . . .'' by Russell Baker, March 13). As a writer, I found a nice symmetry to Bill Safire's pointing out what we do wrong, followed by Russell Baker's showing us how it should be done. ROBERT A. BASSI Downers Grove, Ill.

title: UNDER WRAPS
description: UNWRAPPING A PACKAGE IS AT LEAST half the fun. Break a shining crust with your fork, releasing a cloud of fragrance. Slice through a casing of salmon or cabbage to reveal the savory contents within. Or just pick up a crisp calzone with your fingers and give it a good bite. No matter the attack, the initial pleasure of food wrapped in edible packages is always the same, a present that holds a surprise.

title: FAREWELL, FRIEND
description: BAKER ABLE. TIMES CONFUSED. KEEP RUSSELL. CANCEL NEWS. CAROL PEPER East Moriches, L.I.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: HEARING FROM WAYNE: And Other Stories. By Bill Franzen. (Knopf, $15.95.) You won't find any tales about the cocaine-snorting night-club set or two-career couples with a child and a country home in Connecticut in this entertaining collection of short stories. No sirree, Bob. Bill Franzen writes about people named Effie and Norv who live in towns like Eagle Grove and Crescent Valley somewhere in the Midwest.

title: How to Avoid a Phony Powder Horn
description: THE TRICKERY EXPLORED in the exhibition ''April Fool: Folk Art Fakes and Forgeries'' is as old as art itself and always a subject of absorbing interest to collectors. What is new in this show of 40 hoaxes is its focus on folk art.

title: Tax Power Means the Power to Build
description: THREE of America's distinguished jurists - Daniel Webster, John Marshall and Oliver Wendell Holmes -all equated the power to tax with the power to destroy.

title: Lyle Leads By 2 Strokes At Masters
description: Sandy Lyle, who has two victories on the American PGA Tour this year, ran afoul of Amen Corner at Augusta National Golf Club today, driving his 13th tee shot into Rae's Creek left of the fairway. Thus began a temporary slide for Lyle, whose four-shot lead dwindled to two in the third round of the 52d Masters.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: SOME years ago an actress who was a client of Lionel Larner's gave him a gift. It didn't cost a cent and it was something he had never heard of before, but he still uses it as often as possible, and always happily.

title: Contra Leaders Threatening To Boycott Talks in Managua
description: Leaders of the Nicaraguan guerrillas said today that it was no longer certain their leaders would arrive in Managua for peace talks as scheduled next week.

title: Can't Buy Happiness
description: ALTHOUGH Earle Bruce received a payment of $471,000 as a buyout of his contract when he was dismissed as football coach by Ohio State last November, the 57-year-old veteran of 35 years on the sideline is not a happy man on the sideline this spring.

title: Crosby Noyes, 67, Dies; Ex-Reporter in Europe
description: Crosby S. Noyes, a longtime reporter and editor for The Washington Star, died Thursday after a heart attack. He was 67 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title:
GARDENING;
Preserving the Roots and Health of Plants
description: LEAD: PLANTS rely on the soil for several factors that are essential to their well-being.

title: Correction
description: An article on page 44 of the Travel section today, about Marco Island, Fla., missstates the year in which William D. Collier discovered objects that turned out to be 1,500 ancient metal and wooden artifacts. It was 1895.

title: Simone Blau, Executive, Weds Brian Douglas Gell
description: Simone Gail Blau, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley M. Blau of Scarsdale, N.Y., and East Hampton, L.I., was married last evening to Brian Douglas Gell, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Barry E. Gell of Fort Lee, N.J., and Monterey, Mass. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. officiated at the Metropolitan Club in Manhattan.

title: NO TO 'LEFTWARD DRIFT'
description: THE NEW CRITERION READER The First Five Years. Edited, and with an introduction, by Hilton Kramer. 429 pp. New York: The Free Press. $24.95.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: H. H. RICHARDSON: Architectural Forms for an American Society. By James F. O'Gorman. (University of Chicago, $24.95.) Just what was American about America worried and interested intellectuals during much of the 19th century. But few people had to deal with the country's cultural nationalism more visibly than architects, and few architects did it more successfully than Henry Hobson Richardson, who practiced, mostly in Boston, from 1865 until his death in 1886. His career alone pivoted the issue from a question to an answer. In this compact, clearly organized book, James F. O'Gorman, a professor of American art at Wellesley College, charts Richardson's architectural progress: first his Beaux Arts education, then his picturesque eclecticism, then his Romanesque eclecticism and finally his elemental architecture of simplicity and repose. The mature buildings, such as the Marshall Field warehouse in Chicago, emphasized natural materials rather than decoration and were commanding American products that established a tradition Louis Sullivan and Frank Lloyd Wright would later follow and deepen. But for Mr. O'Gorman, style - even an American style - is not the only issue. He interprets buildings as part of social history. Richardson started practicing just after the Civil War, as rural America became urban and the agricultural economy became industrial. The country required different types of buildings, and he helped invent them. He also gave shape to the new suburban house and to the new train depot between suburb and city. The best of Richardson's buildings were a double invention -different classes of buildings and a different, more American character.

title: LET SEVE ESCAPE HIS BAN
description: HIS drive off the first tee soared left into the pine trees and stopped on the edge of the rough along Augusta National's ninth fairway. Another dozen tall pine trees stood like sentries between his ball and the pin on the first green, about 135 yards away beyond a gaping bunker. And as Seve Ballesteros surveyed his options, a spectator surveyed the Spaniard who plays golf as if he had a knife between his teeth.

title: Pupil Rewards Teacher With a Trip to Japan
description: LEAD: TO prepare her for a two-week trip to Japan that starts tomorrow, Lucy Duffy's friends gave her travel books, and she listened to Berlitz language tapes. Although that is a common way to plan for a vacation, for Mrs. Duffy of Woodbridge, the trip will be far from ordinary.

title: Does Steinbrenner Help or Hurt The Yanks?
description: George Steinbrenner has little idea of the professionalism that has characterized the Yankees in better days. His overweening ego has placed him on center stage instead of the players, and his lack of a world championship since the 70's is proof of his failure as a good leader. NICHOLAS DEBORD New York

title: 'The Street' Is Miles From 'Miami Vice'
description: THE PREMISE IS FAMILIAR enough: two police officers in a patrol car, cruising through the mean streets of a tough city.

title: Grumman's Power Change
description: MANY of the Long Island Lighting Company's 981,000 electrical customers wonder whether supply problems will lead to voltage cuts and sporadic blackouts in the next few summers, but Lilco's largest customer stopped wondering last month and broke ground on a power plant that will, at most times, make the company a supplier to Lilco instead of a customer.

title: Reprise of Gandhi Salt March Prompts Gibes
description: Nearly 60 years after Mohandas K. Gandhi electrified the world by walking 241 miles to the Arabian Sea to defy a British tax on salt, Indian politicians led by another Gandhi - the Prime Minister -have just completed a re-enactment of the original march.

title: Los Angeles Dragnet Over Gang Violence Leads to 592 Arrests
description: A police dragnet aimed at street violence and drug dealing in the city's gang-plagued neighborhoods led to the arrest of 592 people overnight. More than half those arrested were suspected of being gang members, the authorities said today.

title: Ambitious Eradication Goals and Withering Obstacles
description: Perhaps the most ambitious goal of a Cabinet-level internal report on drug strategies is to cut in half coca leaf production in Latin America over the next five years.

title: New Constituency: State Workers
description: LEAD: IN her fourth week as chairwoman at the Workers' Compensation Board, Barbara Patton came back from lunch one afternoon to find her Brooklyn office building under siege.
