A disgruntled workers-compensation recipient with a gun was holding two lawyers hostage, protesting a $23,000 settlement he had received in

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: HONORING BECKETT

title: Q and A
description: Violations in a Conversion

title: Soviet Reply Seems Positive on Afghan Arms
description: The Soviet Union has formally responded to an American compromise proposal that would permit continued military assistance to the Afghan guerrillas as long as Moscow provided such aid to the Kabul regime, Administration officials said today.

title: Miss Morris Wed To E. M. Harris
description: At the Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton, N.J., Patricia Ann Morris, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mac Glenn Morris of Princeton, was married yesterday to Edward Michael Harris, a son of Marie Harris of New York and the late John A. Harris. The Rev. Wallace M. Alston performed the ceremony.

title: Gunman Slays 18-Year-Old For Making Noise at Movie
description: An 18-year-old Manhattan man was shot to death in a movie theater Friday night by a man who complained the victim was making noise during the movie.

title: 'Sex Wars'
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-25 The United States war on drugs has repeatedly been subordinated to other American interests, officials say. But legislators are demanding more effective action against countries that tolerate the drug industry. Page 1 Anti-American riots in Honduras demonstrated the organizational power of drug traffickers, according to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, who said he believed narcotics traffickers sponsored the demonstrations. 16 Hijackers of a Kuwaiti jet killed one of their 50 hostages during a stalemate with Cyprus over whether the jet would be refueled and allowed to leave with the hostages. The hijackers released one passenger. 1 The economy of Vietnam is in chaos, according to Vietnamese officials. The value of the currency has declined by more than half, and foreign investment is unlikely to materialize in the near future. 1 A project to restore Bikini Atoll and make the former nuclear test site habitable has begun. Bikini's leaders returned Thursday for a ceremony and asked that Washington guaranteefinancial and technical support. 1

title: Minister Urges Giuliani To Lead Brawley Case
description: Tawana Brawley would cooperate if a Federal grand jury were impaneled to investigate her assertions that she was kidnapped and sexually assaulted by a group of white men, a spokesman for Miss Brawley said yesterday.

title: New Jersey Symphony Expanding Its Season
description: LEAD: THE New Jersey Symphony Orchestra has announced plans for an expanded 1988-89 season that will include three primary series and thematic programming featuring a three-part turn-of-the-century music festival, along with a greater commitment to American composers.

title: Interest Grows in Contraception as a Means of Wildlife Management
description: Animal lovers have long argued that hunting is immoral and a form of cruelty, and hunters have long retorted that their sport is a socially constructive exercise and a form of wildlife management as well.

title: A Tale of Magic Wrinkle Creams
description: Once upon a time there was a rich and powerful industry that sold shimmer and sheen from elegant little bottles and tubes that cost a tiny fortune.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Blocks Cuban's Prize

title: Cows Nourish Farm Economies of Indonesia
description: Iro Sumarto, a poor farmer once lucky to wring a few dollars a week out of his little market garden, spends a lot of time these days down at the village barn taking part in an agricultural revolution.

title: CHICKEN BIG: Donald W. Mabe; At Perdue Farms, a New Chief, an Old Pecking Order
description: SEVERAL years ago - Don Mabe doesn't remember exactly how many -Marvin Bower, then a managing director at McKinsey & Company, visited Perdue Farms Inc. ''He got to know Frank, and he said, 'There'll never be another chief executive here as long as Frank lives,' '' recalled Mr. Mabe, a 30-year Perdue Farms veteran. ''A lot of people thought he was right.''

title: Sports of The Time; Americans Prepare for Lights, Cameras and Soccer
description: SMILE, everybody, you're on television.

title: Napeague Water Hookups Sought
description: LEAD: WITH the tourist season around the corner, owners of oceanfront resorts and restaurants in Napeague, a narrow strip of land between Amagansett and Montauk, are hoping this week to receive approvals from the Town of East Hampton to hook up to a public water pipe built and paid for by the owners nearly three years ago.

title: Homesick Pacific Otters Hinder Relocation Plan
description: You can lead an otter to new water, it seems, but you can't always make it stay there.

title: Chess Grandmaster Barred From Taking Prize to Cuba
description: A chess grandmaster from Cuba who won $10,000 in the prestigious New York Open chess tournament last month has been barred from taking his prize money out of the United States.

title: Navy Honors Submariners Lost in '63
description: Electrician's Mate First Class Neal D. Collier thought it was important for the Navy to mark the 25th anniversary of the sinking of the nuclear-powered submarine Thresher.

title: White Plains Views Plans On Expansion By 2 Hospitals
description: THIS city, which earlier refused to consider a major development proposal by New York Hospital on the institution's Bloomingdale Road property, is now facing not one but two hospital building plans, both of which would dramatically affect White Plains neighborhoods.

title: LAUGHTER AND HOPE
description: Congratulations to Melvin Konner for his article ''Laughter and Hope'' (Body and Mind, March 13). Four years ago, when I was told I had a rare, systemic form of cancer, I did everything but laugh. Indeed, I was furious at anyone who dared tell me that I should have a ''positive attitude.'' How could I feel positive when I was constantly sick from the side effects of potent chemotherapeutic drugs, was totally bald, and saw my family shattered and frightened?

title: Capturing a Sculptor in Stone and Film
description: LEAD: IT took the sculptor Jacob Lipkin three years to carve his life-size image of Icarus falling from the sky. The massive marble of his final artwork dominates the sculpture-filled garden at his modest North Babylon home.

title: Joy on Opening Day
description: 'I don't care how far they go. A home run counts as one run.' - Darryl Strawberry, who hit two very, very long home runs in the Mets' 10-6 win over the Montreal Expos.

title: Review/Dance; 2 Decades of Pomare Choreography
description: Examples of 20 years of choreography by Eleo Pomare were on view Thursday night when the Eleo Pomare Dance Company performed at the Schimmel Center for the Performing Arts at Pace University. Mr. Pomare's range was always admirable, although his dances varied in quality.

title: Mets Look Awful In Loss to Phillies
description: The Mets, who were supposed to dominate the National League with deep pitching and fierce hitting, got neither again today and lost for the second straight time to the Philadelphia Phillies, 9-3.

title: Home Depot's Success Formula
description: SHARES of Home Depot Inc., like virtually every other stock, crumbled in October's market crash. Home Depot fell to $12.125 a share, from a peak of $28. But unlike many stocks, Home Depot has sharply rebounded and was trading last week around $24. Such strength is not unusual for the stock. It jumped fourfold at the beginning of the 1980's bull market and, after giving back some of those gains, more than tripled between January 1986 and the crash.

title:
GARDENING;
Preserving the Roots and Health of Plants
description: LEAD: PLANTS rely on the soil for several factors that are essential to their well-being.

title: America's Decline: A Myth
description: LEAD: Is American power declining? No, but the success of Paul Kennedy's ''The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers'' is symptomatic of Americans' belief that it is. When a history professor's book with 1,298 footnotes becomes No. 2 best seller, it suggests something about the audience.

title: NEW DRUG FINDINGS ON HEART ATTACK BUOYING DOCTORS
description: New findings about drugs that dissolve deadly clots are transforming the treatment of heart attack, greatly improving the patient's chances of surviving.

title: Margaret Sutherland Wed To William Louis Nagy Jr.
description: Margaret Kelly Sutherland, a documentary production associate, and William Louis Nagy Jr., a vice president of production control, both at ABC News, were married yesterday. Acting Justice Richard L. Price of State Supreme Court officiated at a private loft in New York.

title: Miss Schneiderman Weds Dr. P. L. Fox
description: The marriage of Faline Carol Schneiderman, an archeologist, and Dr. Paul Lewis Fox took place yesterday at Holiday Point at Candlewood Lake in Sherman, Conn. Barbara Ackerman, a probate judge in Sherman, officiated.

title: True Bargains in Speakers
description: A RECENT SURVEY REVEALS the somber fact that the average price of audio products has risen faster than the general cost of living, as gauged by the Consumer Price Index. According to data compiled by Audio Video International, a leading trade journal, the average list price of loudspeakers has soared 173 percent since 1980. At the same time, the mean price of stereo receivers has risen 53 percent.

title: Air Force Hears Views on Having MX Missile as a Neighbor
description: When Air Force representatives came here to discuss their plan to deploy nuclear weapons on commercial railroad lines in the region, Harold Smith was not worried.

title: The Tracking Controversy
description: I REFUSE TO BELIEVE that the American public intends to have its children sorted before their teens into clerks, watchmakers, lithographers . . . and so forth, and treated differently in their schools according to their prophecies of their appropriate life careers. Who are we to make these prophecies?'' - Charles W. Eliot, president of Harvard, 1892.

title: Sir John Clements, Stage Veteran, Dies at 77
description: Sir John Clements, an actor, producer and theatrical manager, died Wednesday. He was 77 years old. Sir John made his stage debut in 1930 and joined Sir Philip Ben Greet's Shakespearean company in 1931. Four years later, he founded the Intimate Theatre in Palmer's Green in north London, where he appeared in nearly 200 plays.

title: '87 Campaign Gifts Totaled $1 Million
description: LONG ISLAND'S five House members accumulated more than $1 million in campaign contributions during 1987 from corporations, interest groups and individuals, though only one of the lawmakers, Representative Robert J. Mrazek, faces announced opposition in the 1988 elections.

title: Diane Monteleone Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Diane Marie Monteleone, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Monteleone of Mount Kisco, N.Y., to Winston William Hutchins, a son of Mrs. C. Raymond Hutchins of Baltimore and the late Mr. Hutchins, took place yesterday at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford, N.Y. Msgr. Thomas Gartland performed the ceremony.

title: Outdoors: Spring Turkey Hunting Takes Dedication
description: IF you are serious about trying to bag a turkey in New York State's spring season, you should set aside at least a week's vacation for that endeavor and eschew all social engagements.

title: West Bank Settlers Turn Anger Against the Army
description: In Israel's bitterly divided internal politics, the news that a teen-age girl was shot dead, apparently by a Jewish settler firing in panic, rather than being stoned to death by an Arab mob, has apparently made little difference in passionately held positions.

title: INSIDE
description: Hachette to Buy Grolier Hachette, France's top publisher, has arranged to buy Grolier, an American educational publisher, in a deal worth about $449 million. Page D1. Hijackers' New Threat A Kuwaiti jet's hijackers pledged to carry out a ''slow, quiet massacre'' of their hostages, but were persuaded to pull back on the threat. Page A6. Hope at Russian Easter Russian Orthodox believers celebrated Easter in Kiev amid hopes that the Government will become more tolerant of religion. Page A3.

title: 10 Western States Try College Exchange Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Digging the World's Grave With Military Spending
description: To the Editor:

title: Sassy: Like, You Know, for Kids
description: Can a new magazine that uses teen-age jargon and focuses on subjects ranging from sex, makeup and clothes to sex, makeup and clothes make it in today's market? The answer so far appears to be yes.

title: What's in a Name
description: In the creative world of television, the tried and true and the truly new mingle, not necessarily in equal measure, as producers offer fare they hope will catch the eye of network programmers.

title: The Tax Cheats: Selfish to the Bottom Line
description: Another season of moral ambivalence will end this week when the tax deadline passes, and researchers are beginning to learn how that ambivalence mixes with opportunity and other factors to produce tax cheats.

title: Call It A Big Sandy
description: THROUGH the years, the Masters has inspired some historic shots, from Gene Sarazen's 4-wood for a double-eagle 2 at the 15th hole in 1935 to Larry Mize's 60-foot chip into the cup at the 11th to stun Greg Norman in last year's playoff. But on the 18th hole at Augusta National's theater in the pines yesterday, Sandy Lyle hit a 7-iron out of a fairway bunker 145 yards over another bunker in front of the green, to within 10 feet of the cup. Then he made his 10-foot birdie putt. Never before had a golfer gotten down in two from that bunker to win the Masters.

title: POLICE BLAME ABC FOR ABRUPT RAID
description: Law-enforcement officers say they were forced to raid a suspected drug ring weeks early because a television network had refused to hold off broadcasting a news report on drug sales.

title: Review/Dance; New 'Fille Mal Gardee' From Washington Ballet
description: There was indulgent laughter and a cry or two of ''yeah'' from the audience when the dancers of the Washington Ballet came forward for their curtain call at the end of ''La Fille Mal Gardee'' on Saturday at the Brooklyn Center at Brooklyn College. And that seemed a perfect response to Fernand Nault's infectiously sunny production of this 18th-century French classic, set to music by Hertel, with its charming Kate Greenaway-style sets and costumes by Leo Meyer and Judanna Lynn, respectively.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Mayotte Wins in Chicago: Tim Mayotte, seeded No. 2, combined a mixture of passing shots with a strong net game yesterday to win his second consecutive $315,000 Volvo Chicago championship, defeating Paul Annacone, 6-1, 6-3. Mayotte of Boston, ranked ninth in the world, earned $75,000.

title: Giving Sailors A Leg Up
description: Manufacturers who design footwear for the marine industry usually look for ways to keep the feet dry. Now they've come up with a shoe that allows one's feet to get wet.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * EMI Music Worldwide, Hollywood, Calif., appointed Jim Fifield president and chief operating officer.

title: A Novel Mood at CBS, Where Last Is a First
description: IN the Hollywood end of the television business, this is the ''development season,'' when the networks' programming departments peruse the scripts and pilots they have ordered and choose the new shows for their fall lineups. It is a heady time, ruled by hunch and charged with possibility, with millions of dollars on the line. Brandon Tartikoff, the chief programmer at No. 1 NBC, says he lives for this time of year. Kim LeMasters, chief programmer at No. 3 CBS, is said to have told friends that he may not live through this month.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, APRIL 11, 1988
description: THE MEDIA BUSINESS Grolier has tentatively agreed to be acquired by Hachette, the companies said. Grolier's board is scheduled to meet today to consider the proposal of $24.25 a share in cash for the 95 percent of the company's common shares that Hachette does not already own. The deal's value would total about $449 million. [ D1. ] ''Creatives'' under 30 are beginning to make their mark on the advertising industry. Note the commercial starring a banker with a Hula-Hoop and the one featuring the liar Joe Isuzu. [ D8. ] Sassy, a magazine for teen-age girls, may be off to a good start. The first issue in March - with enough you knows, so anyways, hot outfits and totally somethings to send most adults screaming from the room - attracted 16,500 new subscriptions. [ D8. ] CBS finds itself in the novel and unenviable position of being last in the ratings at the start of the ''development season,'' when the networks' programming departments peruse the scripts and pilots they have ordered and choose the new shows for their fall lineups. Television. [ D8. ] Describing the Esquire Man would be too difficult for mere mortals, the founders of the Kirshenbaum & Bond agency decided, so they will use Esquire's promotional advertising to say what he is not. Advertising. [ D9. ] THE ECONOMY Special provisions in the trade bill have created a powerful constituency for it, even as debate continues over other, more controversial aspects of the legislation. Hard bargaining is expected this week between the White House and Congress, with President Reagan setting the stage by reiterating his veto threat in his radio address Saturday. [ A1. ] If Mr. Reagan does sign the bill, it will be the end of the line for the 1980 Crude Oil Windfall Profit Tax, one of the most vigorously debated pieces of legislation of the Carter Administration. [ D10. ] What kind of person cheats on his or her taxes? The picture emerging from surveys finds an interaction between ample opportunity, an atmosphere of lax attitudes and specific personality traits. [ A1. ] The Colorado Legislature is expected to consider a proposal to bail out 14 failed industrial banks and pay 9,000 depositors who have been waiting six months for their savings. [ D1. ] COMPANIES A jury has decided that the Kansas City Southern Railway and its parent company must pay from $200 million to as much as $844.2 million to South Dakota, company officials said. The verdict stems from a civil antitrust and tort action brought by the state in Federal District Court in Sioux Falls. [ D1. ] West Point-Pepperell must raise its bid to at least $66 a share for J. P. Stevens if it wants to thwart a competing $64-a-share, all-cash offer from Odyssey Partners that expires today at midnight, professional traders said. [ D4. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Tate & Lyle and Staley Continental's battle is perhaps the most acrimonious one the sweetener industry has ever seen. Tate & Lyle is offering Staley's stockholders $32 a share, or a total of $1.3 billion, and inviting its top management to take a brisk walk off the corporate gangplank. [ D12. ] The Dominican Republic is the fastest-growing tourist spot in the Caribbean. Last year, it led all other countries in the region in volume of growth, with an increase of 123,600 visitors, for an annual total of 675,000. [ D12. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Basil can cost more if its name is mispronounced at the Fairview Market in Upper Manhattan, or at least that is the image conveyed by the manager of the grocery, which attracts 50,000 customers a week. New Yorkers & Co. [ D1. ] Taxpayers and accountants seem to be weathering this tax-filing season in better psychological shape than might have been expected. So far, clinical therapists say they have not detected an alarming rise in stress casualties that some had feared would result from the heavier workload for accountants and the complicated changes facing taxpayers. Tax Watch. [ D2. ] The Brazil Fund is the latest entry among closed-end funds investing in the stocks of a single country. Market Place. [ D6. ] The recent drop in interest rates has temporarily masked the continuing bearish sentiment, analysts said. Credit Markets. [ D7. ]

title: Reliability of New York Subway Cars Showing Gains
description: New and rebuilt subway cars on New York City's oldest lines have raised the system's mechanical reliability to a level not seen by riders since before the city's fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's, according to the Transit Authority.

title: Enemy Within: Drug Money Is Corrupting the Enforcers
description: Law enforcement specialists say corruption within the American criminal justice system is more widespread now than at any time since Prohibition because of the explosion in the power and profits of the multibillion-dollar illicit drug industry.

title: Review/Dance; Paul Taylor Offers The Familiar Made New
description: Over the years, Paul Taylor has created a modern-dance repertory that is remarkable for its diversity and excellence. Nevertheless, though he choreographs works in many styles, he returns to certain themes again and again.

title: IRIS DRAGER, TV DIRECTOR, Weds Howard N. Gordon
description: Iris May Drager, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Drager of New York, and Howard N. Gordon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Gordon of New City, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Tower Suite of the Time and Life Building. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg performed the ceremony.

title: Hearts in Astoria Swell As Dukakis Hits New York
description: As Michael S. Dukakis's campaign gathers momentum, a swirl of ethnic pride, simple emotion and new political involvement has absorbed the Greek-American community of Astoria, Queens, the largest concentration of Greeks outside Greece.

title: Hospitalizing the Homeless: Plan Is Lagging in New York
description: When Mayor Koch began a program last year to hospitalize severely mentally ill homeless people against their will, many opponents of the plan feared large-scale roundups of the homeless.

title: Testing Fitness By the Standards Of a Few Good Men
description: ''THE MARINES are looking for a few good men'' is a well-known United States Marine Corps recruiting slogan. But the men - and women - must be kept fit if the Marines are to maintain their reputation as the toughest of the tough.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Commission's Future
description: Some people are wondering what's going on at the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. The commission, which is in the midst of major initiatives involving natural gas and electricity, faces the prospect that all five of its commissioners will have left by year's end.

title: Dominican Republic Tourism Surges
description: Fountains gush on the perimeter of the driveway and lights flash along the rim of the long pink cement canopy of the Jaragua Hotel - the latest and by far the plushest resort to open in the Dominican Republic.

title: Hrudey Repays Islanders' Trust
description: It was a night for a goaltender's adrenaline to race.

title: In Brooklyn, Shadow of Jackson Follows Gore
description: Joe Levine and Al Farber shook Senator Albert Gore Jr.'s hand yesterday afternoon as the Tennessean stepped quickly into the cavernous Brighton Beach Baths in Brooklyn.

title: Meese Sees Peru Drug Fields And Promises Better Action
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that drug eradication efforts in Peru, which is believed to produce more of the base crop for cocaine than any other country, have had almost no effect.

title: An Amazing Fellow
description: Kayode Vann is not an easy person to track down. In the fall and winter he's likely to be playing basketball as a star for the Berkeley-Carroll Street School in Brooklyn, unless, of course, he's pushing pawns with the private school's chess club, conducting meetings as the president of the student council or honing his fencing skills with a neighborhood friend.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Why does one of my baseball cards show that Tony Fernandez played in 163 games for Toronto in 1986, when the Blue Jays had an 86-76 record, which adds up to 162 games?

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Hundreds may have died in Pakistan in explosions that destroyed an army ammunition depot in a densely populated area between the twin cities of Rawalpindi and Islamabad. Page A1 Afghan guerrillas downed a plane near the Soviet border. All 29 people aboard the Soviet-built aircraft were killed, the Afghan radio said. It did not say whether the plane was a Soviet or Afghan transport. A1 Drug-financed corruption of officials is more widespread in the United States than at any time since Prohibition, law enforcement specialists say. Graft touches Federal agents and rural sheriffs. A1 The world trade in illegal drugs involves so much money that it threatens the economic stability of some countries and could jeapordize the integrity of U.S. financial institutions, officials say. A12 Drug eradication efforts in Peru have had almost no effect, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said. Peru is estimated to produce more coca, the base crop for cocaine, than any other country. A14 Greater official tolerance of religion in the Soviet Union may be in the air as the Orthodox Church nears its 1,000th anniversary, even though the country officially remains an atheistic state. A3 Make the Soviet Union more open to Western publications and broadcasts, President Reagan challenged Mikhail Gorbachev. The speech, delivered to broadcasters, was said to set a tone for their meeting in Moscow. A3 Negotiators persuaded the hijackers of a Kuwaiti airliner to pull back from a threat to massacre the plane's passengers. P.L.O. officials conducted extensive negotiations aimed at freeing the hostages. A6 The death of an Israeli teen-ager, apparently caused by a Jewish settler, has embroiled the army in a dispute with settlers and right-wing politicians, who are attacking the military investigation of the death. A10 At a girl's school in Manila the frequent attendance at street protests symbolizes the leftward drift of the Philippine middle class. Some of St. Scholastica's students, daughters of Manila's elite, have protested against the Aquino Government. A4 NATIONAL A16, B6-10 Special provisions in the trade bill that Congress is trying to complete this week may mean windfalls for companies making everything from drugs to diapers and frozen cranberries. President Reagan has threatened to veto it. A1 The personality of tax cheats is being investigated by researchers. They find in flagrant tax cheats, a tendency to take risk, to manipulate people and to place high stress on financial success. A1 An appearance by Louis Farrakhan, the Black Muslim leader, at the University of Pennsylvania this week is seen as a pivotal event on the campus, where relations among blacks and whites have become tense. A16 Delay in bombing North Vietnam was the biggest mistake of his Presidency, Richard Nixon said in a television interview. The former President said he and his aides mishandled the Watergate crisis ''beyond belief.'' B6 Hachette S.A. will buy Grolier Inc., the two companies announced. Hachette, France's largest publishing company, will pay about $450 million for Grolier, an American publisher of educational materials. D1 POLITICS B8-9 Mario Cuomo says he will refuse a draft as the Democratic Party's Presidential nominee. It is the first time that Gov. Cuomo has explicitly ruled out the possibility that he would accept a draft. A1 In an interview, Sen. Albert Gore Jr., the Democratic Presidential candidate, said he wants a U.S. arms control policy that would make it impossible for either side to gain an advantage from a nuclear first strike. B8 Jesse Jackson would not negotiate with P.L.O. leader Yasir Arafat, he said, if he were elected President. The Democratic candidate said the United States should challenge the P.L.O. to repudiate its goal of annihilating Israel. B9 In Brooklyn, shadow of Jackson follows Gore B8 New Yorkers welcome Jackson like a celebrity B8 WASHINGTON TALK B6 Switching from House to Senate: worlds apart REGIONAL B1-5 Forced treatment for homeless people who are mentally ill has affected fewer people than had been expected. Ordered last year by Mayor Koch, the program has been slowed by court challenges and overcrowding. A1 A fugitive wanted for six murders in Maryland and New York City was captured by 30 heavily armed police in Brooklyn Saturday night, weeks after being seen on a television show about the nation's most-wanted fugitives. B1 New and rebuilt subway cars on New York City's oldest subway lines have increased the system's mechanical reliability to a level that has not been seen since before the fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's. B1 Pride among Greek-Americans in Astoria, Queens, has been stirred by Michael S. Dukakis's Presidential campaign, which has also generated new political involvement in the largest community of Greeks outside Greece. B1 A museum about the Holocaust is collecting artifacts from survivors and other witnesses to the Nazi death camps. Organizers say the process of gathering the collection is part of passing on the memory of the Holocaust. B1 Survey provides profile of Koch homeless program B2 Goal at Creedmoor: lessons in living for homeless B2 New police-fire rules make rift worse B3

title: 2 Reports on Media Begin Today
description: With this issue, The Times introduces two new groups of articles about the printed and broadcast media.

title: Bridge
description: Leading your partner's suit is a deeply ingrained instinct with many players, and they tend to do it, from force of lifelong habit, even when there are obvious contraindications.

title: Plans Vary On Ozone
description: The E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company's decision to eventually end production of chemicals that destroy ozone has been matched by only one of the six other companies in the field in the United States.

title: New Barracks and Air Quality
description: A study has found that Army trainees housed in modern barracks were about 50 percent more likely to contract a respiratory infection in basic training than those who stayed in older, better ventilated buildings.

title: 17-Year-Old L.I. Boy Is Held In Sexual Abuse of 2 Children
description: Huntington, L.I., April 10 (AP) - A 17-year-old high school student was arrested today in connection with the sexual abuse of two young boys, the police said.

title: With Burke in Goal, the Devils Can Let Themselves Dream
description: SEAN BURKE has no use for labels. He resists them much the way he does hockey pucks, with an almost casual agility and as little outward emotion as possible save for cold disdain.

title: Soviet Urged to Cut Barriers to West's Ideas
description: With White House attention turning toward the coming summit meeting in Moscow, President Reagan challenged Mikhail S. Gorbachev today to open the Soviet Union more fully to Western newspapers, journals and broadcasts.

title: Brook Benton, Singer of Hit Tunes Known for His Ballads, Dies at 56
description: Brook Benton, the popular baritone singer and writer of ballads who had many hit songs in the late 1950's and 60's, died of pneumonia Saturday at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, Queens. He was 56 years old and lived in St. Albans, Queens.

title: Metro Matters; Political Wooing: Everyone Wants To Be Endorsed
description: So valued is the slightest signal of support from the Lubavitcher Rebbe that during the 1973 mayoral campaign, Representative Edward I. Koch made a midnight pilgrimage to the Rebbe's Brooklyn headquarters.

title: Market Place; A Growing List Of Country Funds
description: THE number of closed-end funds investing in the stocks of a single country continues to expand, as American investors remain eager to diversify their holdings outside the United States markets and dollar-denominated securities.

title: Staying The Same
description: If the word ''news'' means the report of change, can the absence of change be news? Put another way, when can trendlessness become trendy?

title: Chicago Journal; For Those Who Make Oscars, Tonight Is Special
description: Unless daydreams count, Ruda Harvey has never been to Hollywood. She lives in a modest bungalow here with her husband, Elvert, not far from the small factory where they have worked for nearly 20 years.

title: 7th Ave. Favors Pants as Fall Shows Open
description: Before the first models take to the runways this week as the fall and winter fashion openings unfold on and off Seventh Avenue, some basic trends for the new season seem securely established.

title: Canadian Ballet Names Bruhn Prize Contestants
description: The National Ballet of Canada has announced the dancers who will compete for the first annual Erik Bruhn Prize. The competition was established by Mr. Bruhn, who died in 1986, to encourage young talent in the four ballet companies with which he was most closely associated during his career as a dancer and administrator.

title: Flaws in Market Argument for Abortion Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Obsolete Arms Production, Obsolescent Military
description: LEAD: In a historic change that is now just about complete, America's military manufacturing systems - insulated from the intense competition of global markets - have become largely decoupled from, and far less efficient than, those of commercial manufacturers. As a result, our armed forces' effectiveness will decline steadily no matter how much we spend.

title: Antitrust Verdict Impedes Kansas City Southern's Bid
description: In a striking jury verdict, Kansas City Southern Industries and a subsidiary, the Kansas City Southern Railway Company, have been ordered to pay from $200 million to as much as $844.2 million to South Dakota, company officials said yesterday.

title: Navratilova Beats Sabatini in Final
description: There is only one place separating Martina Navratilova from the top of women's tennis, but there are more obstacles in her path than there were 10 years ago, when she became No. 1 for the first time. Almost every victory takes a toll now, requiring her to summon all the experience and resolve she can muster. Even at 31, however, it is a price she is more than willing to pay.

title: Foreign-Held Farmland
description: Foreigners continue to own just under 1 percent of United States agricultural land, slightly more than the level of a year ago, the Department of Agriculture said Thursday. The department's Economic Research Service said its 1987 year-end review of reports under the Agricultural Foreign Investment Disclosure Act found 12.5 million acres of agricultural land in foreign hands, 202,000 acres more than reported in 1986. Corporations held 80 percent of the foreign-owned land, with the balance held by individuals, partnerships, institutions and other entities.

title: Tax Watch; A Stressful Time For Taxpayers
description: DESPITE all the confusion and worry over the numerous changes wrought by the Tax Reform Act of 1986, taxpayers and accountants appear to be weathering this tax-filing season in better psychological shape than might have been expected.

title: Review/Jazz; Duo's Moody Melodies
description: The Ethnic Heritage Ensemble -Ed Wilkerson Jr. on saxophones and Kahil El Zabar on various percussion instruments - starting an hour late and minus its trombonist, Joe Bowie, played a moody, evocative set at the Kraine gallery Saturday night.

title: New Leader Reported At China Central Bank
description: A Hong Kong newspaper has reported that a 50-year-old Soviet-trained engineer, Li Guixian, has been chosen to head China's central bank, the People's Bank of China.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Hunger in South Africa
description: Even as Congress considers imposing further sanctions to close off more economic channels to South Africa, a Johannesburg-based organization is seeking to increase its financial ties to America. Operation Hunger, a nonpolitical organization responsible for feeding 1.3 million poor South Africans, has been approved by the Internal Revenue Service this year as a tax-exempt charity.

title: LAWYER ARRESTED BY SECRET SERVICE
description: A man was taken into custody by the Secret Service yesterday in lower Manhattan after an incident in which witnesses said he was beaten by a Federal agent.

title: Review/Music; Message Songs From Ziggy Marley
description: Ziggy Marley has shouldered a daunting legacy - the memory of his father, Bob Marley, who carried Jamaican reggae to an international audience. Reggae performers have been scrambling to become ''the next Bob Marley'' since his death in 1981, but none has had Mr. Marley's combination of talent, political fervor and charismatic presence. And now there is a schism between Mr. Marley's former band, the Wailers (which now tours with a new lead singer), and his family, headed by his wife, Rita Marley, who advises her four children in the Melody Makers: Ziggy, Stephen, Cedella and Sharon.

title: Manila Journal; The Belles of St. Scho: Anything but Cloistered
description: In the blue-and-white uniforms of their convent school, a white flag with a dove of peace fluttering above their heads, the little group of students from St. Scholastica's College stood out from their fellow protesters, tough, sometimes masked marchers bearing militant red banners.

title: Orioles Are Beaten Again, 6-3
description: Jay Bell hit a two-run triple in a four-run fourth inning and Carmen Castillo had three hits and two runs batted in as the Cleveland Indians won their fifth straight game today, beating the Baltimore Orioles, 6-3.

title: New Yorkers Welcome Jackson Like a Celebrity
description: ''Don't push, please,'' barked a young Secret Service agent on a Brooklyn street corner Saturday morning as a crowd ignored him.

title: HEATHER FREIRICH WED TO ENGINEER
description: At the Church Center for the United Nations in New York, Heather Haskell Freirich, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Freirich of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday to Michael Rome, the son of Malka Rome and Sinai Rome, both of Jerusalem. Cantor Robert Abelson performed the ceremony.

title: China Always Fears for Students Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: Cries of 'Don't Die' and Sight of a Beaten Child Moved a Passer-By
description: William I. Stein said his first inclination was to ignore the shabbily-dressed man screaming over a baby stroller on a street corner in Manhattan.

title: Washington Talk: Congress; From House to the Senate: Into Another World
description: In a city of titles, few have quite the resonance or the aura of ''Senator.''

title: New Capital City With an Industrial Twin
description: Since it rose on a plateau of wheat fields and sugar cane in the 1960's, Pakistan's new capital of Islamabad has become nearly contiguous with its larger twin, Rawalpindi, whose importance had been largely as an industrial center and military station with a rail junction.

title: ELIZABETH COHEN WEDS PATRICK HAMILL
description: Elizabeth Robin Cohen, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Burton M. Cohen of Warren, N.J., was married at her parents' home yesterday to Patrick Joseph Hamill, the son of Virginia E. Hamill of Jersey City and the late Judge Edward F. Hamill. Rabbi Alfred Landsberg and the Rev. Francis J. Hamill, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: The Glory and Tragedy of the Partial Test Ban
description: This year, as we mark the 25th anniversary of the partial nuclear test ban treaty, we should not only remember what it was but what it could have been.

title: Carter Oil Tax Hangs by a Thread
description: It will be the end of the line for one of the most vigorously debated pieces of legislation of the Carter Administration, the 1980 Crude Oil Windfall Profit Tax, if President Reagan signs Congress's omnibus trade bill.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Spreading Blossoms
description: Only a few petals remain after the glorious unfurling of the capital's Japanese cherry blossoms.

title: Review/Blues; Kirkland's
description: Eddie Kirkland, the blues guitarist and singer, ran out on stage Friday night and announced he had the flu, then played a perfect set. Dressed in a red and gold lame headdress sprouting with jewels, and backed by an ace band, including the great rhythm-and-blues drummer Charles Otis, Mr. Kirkland leveled the idea that urban blues is dust-covered museum music.

title: Buyout Firm's Patience Pays Off
description: When Jack Nash and Leon Levy left Oppenheimer & Company, the Wall Street firm, to start their own investment boutique in 1982, they named it Odyssey Partners after the Greek tale. ''After all,'' Mr. Levy said, ''the Odyssey is nothing but a journey fraught with opportunity and peril.''

title: An Oscar-Night Warning: No Party at Polly's
description: Around Manhattan, they're calling it the Polly tragedy. For the first time in nine years, Polly Bergen won't be giving her Park Avenue Oscar-night bash, the one that everyone called ''Polly's party.'' And without Polly's party, where is one to go tonight while America tunes in to the 60th annual Academy Awards ceremonies?

title: Metro Datelines; Roadway Is Shut On the Williamsburg
description: The eastbound outer roadway on the Williamsburg Bridge was closed to vehicular traffic yesterday - not long after it was reopened after having been shut down late last month.

title: Creedmoor's Goal: Lessons in Living
description: At the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens Village, the homeless patients, who once slept on sidewalks and begged for their dinner, can choose from swimming, arts and crafts, movies, music, cooking and sewing, or can take shopping trips to neighborhood stores.

title: Flyers Rally From 4-1 Deficit to Beat Capitals in Overtime, 5-4
description: Murray Craven's five-foot backhand shot 1:18 into overtime carried the Philadelphia Flyers to a 5-4 victory over the Washington Capitals tonight and a 3-1 lead in their four-of-seven-game National Hockey League Patrick Division playoff series.

title: Gore Gives Views On Major Issues
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. defines his positions on arms negotiations, the budget deficit and other issues in an interview conducted in advance of the New York State primary election.

title: Anger at Suspect's Expulsion to U.S. Smolders in Honduras
description: Heavily armed troops in camouflage uniforms patrolled the streets of the Hondurdan capital today, maintaining the public order, but the widespread popular resentment provoked by the Government's decision last week to hand a suspected drug trafficker over to the United States otherwise showed few signs of abating.

title: Rev. Craig Casey, 52, Church Pension Leader
description: The Rev. Craig Walter Casey, executive vice president and manager of the Episcopal Church Pension Fund, died of lung cancer Saturday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 52 years old.

title: Apple Accused By Microsoft
description: The Microsoft Corporation filed a countersuit last week charging that Apple Computer Inc. had broken a 1985 settlement agreement between the two companies and had interfered with Microsoft's relationship with other software developers. Microsoft's filing was in response to the suit Apple filed March 17, which contended that Microsoft's Windows 2.03 program and the Hewlett-Packard Company's New Wave program both infringed on its copyrights for the Macintosh's visual displays.

title: Trillions, Trillions All Around
description: Good news: The big surpluses accumulating in the Social Security trust fund probably will cover the multitrillion-dollar cost of the baby boom generation's pensions. But there's an enormous catch. The annual surplus, likely to top $500 billion by the year 2015, will also act as a fiscal brake on the economy, draining off private purchasing power and threatening jobs and income.

title: Knicks Enhance Playoff Chances
description: The Knicks will announce the sale of playoff tickets on Monday, something that appeared unlikely two and a half months ago.

title: Agency to Survey Discrimination in Housing
description: Hundreds of specially trained black, Hispanic and white couples will be sent out by the Federal Government to pretend they want to buy or rent houses or apartments, participating in the first major study of housing discrimination in a decade.

title: Yanks' Numbers Add Up to Perfect Start
description: The numbers for the day, with no $25 million lottery prize at stake, were 5, 7, 6 and 5. A couple of other numbers, .857 and .118, were intriguing, too.

title: Review/Dance; New Troupe Treats Philadelphians to 'Giselle'
description: The Pennsylvania and Milwaukee Ballet is the new name of the company once known as the Pennsylvania Ballet. The troupe joined forces with the Milwaukee Ballet in September, and the promising results are on view this week at the Shubert Theater with a production of ''Giselle'' and ''Grand Fugue,'' a premiere by Robert Weiss, the Pennsylvania Ballet's artistic director since 1982 and now artistic director of the combined troupe.

title: P.L.O. Persuades Hijackers of Jet to Back Off Threat of 'Massacre'
description: The hijackers of a Kuwaiti airliner vowed on Sunday to carry out a ''slow, quiet massacre'' of their passengers, but negotiators persuaded them to pull back from their threat.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Vast Flow of Cash Threatens Currency, Banks and Economies
description: The vast international trade in illegal drugs is being viewed and prosecuted not just as a criminal network but as a multinational business.

title: BETH WEINER MARRIED TO CHARLES D. FINKLE
description: Beth Merrie Weiner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Weiner of White Plains, was married yesterday to Charles Douglas Finkle, the son of Dr. Robert H. Finkle of Chillicothe, Mo., and Colleen Winholtz of Independence, Mo. Cantor Raymond Smolover performed the ceremony at the Water Club in Manhattan.

title: What Is Originality?; Pulitzer Panel to Decide in Dispute Over Award to Philadelphia Inquirer
description: This week, in a rare re-examination, a select panel of the Pulitzer Prize Board is to review a challenge to the award of a Pulitzer 10 days ago to The Philadelphia Inquirer.

title: Cuomo, for the First Time, Asserts That He Will Not Accept a Draft
description: Governor Cuomo, who had repeatedly refused to rule out accepting a draft as the Democratic Party's Presidential candidate, said today for the first time that he would not accept any draft.

title: Brazil Sets Wage Freeze
description: Brazil's Finance Minister, Mailson Ferreira da Nobrega, has announced a two-month freeze on the wages of all federal employees and other measures in an attempt to avert a collapse of the Government's finances.

title: Hershiser Pitches Dodgers to a Sweep
description: Orel Hershiser allowed five hits over eight and one-third innings, taking a shutout into the ninth inning, before Atlanta snapped his streak of 17 scoreless innings, but the Dodgers beat the Braves, 3-1, this afternoon.

title: Metro Datelines; A Kidnap Suspect Leads a 21-Car Chase
description: A shotgun-wielding man abducted a Connecticut supermarket clerk, then exchanged gunfire with police officers during a two-state, 21-car chase that ended when he jumped into the Hudson River, offcials said yesterday.

title: A Show on the 60's Helps a Network in the 80's
description: When it is considered at all, the suburban coming-of-age experience -safe, homogenized, numbingly mundane - is usually the material of satire, rendered in mocking tones. But a new television series that looks back at 1960's suburbia with fond reverence, even a kind of longing, has struck a chord with viewers, and become the hottest new show of the year.

title: Jackson Seeks To Soften Stand On Middle East
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, striking a conciliatory note on the Middle East nine days before New York's Presidential primary election, said yesterday that if he was elected President he would not negotiate with Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Xanadu's Founder Wins A Strong Endorsement
description: The acquisition of 80 percent of the Xanadu Operating Company last week by Autodesk Inc. was probably not large in terms of dollars, though the amount was not disclosed. But the purchase represented a strong endorsement of the principles of Theodor H. Nelson, Xanadu's founder and an early visionary of the personal computer movement.

title: Tim S. Mayer, 43, Stage Director, Author, Lyricist and Playwright
description: Timothy S. Mayer, a stage director for resident theaters in Boston and Washington, died of lung cancer in Linlithgo, N.Y., on Saturday. He was 43, and lived in Boston.

title: Further Rate Drops Not Expected
description: The recent drop in interest rates has temporarily masked what continues to be strong bearish sentiment in the credit markets, analysts said.

title: Tate & Lyle Faces a Struggle in Bid for Staley
description: The $1.3 billion bid last Friday by Britain's Tate & Lyle P.L.C. for Staley Continental Inc. is already shaping up as perhaps the most acrimonious takeover battle the sweetener industry has ever seen.

title: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Philip L. R. DuVal & Associates, a magazine advertising rep firm, has opened in New Canaan, Conn., with Natural History magazine as its first client.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 10, 1988: MONDAY Dana Corp PS Group TUESDAY Crompton & Knowles Staley Continental Inc Diversified Energies TECO Energy Procter & Gamble WEDNESDAY Hartmarx Corp Tokheim Corp Pacificorp Walgreen Co Texas Industries FW Woolworth Co THURSDAY Ford Motor Universal Foods NERCO Inc Zayre Corp FRIDAY Communications Satellite Twin Disc

title: Gorbachev Terms Security of Israel Vital to Peace
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, said Saturday that Israel's security and statehood are as important in any Middle East peace settlement as similar rights for Palestinians.

title: Books of The Times; Strategy and Tactics to Win the Global Struggle
description: 1999 Victory Without War. By Richard M. Nixon 336 pages. Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Coming Back
description: Exceptional high school athletes are supposed to play quarterback on the football team. Craig Gilstrap did that for two years. They are supposed to pitch for the baseball team. Gilstrap is starting his third season on the mound.

title: Off the City's Streets: Profile of the Program
description: When complaints quickly arose that Project Help focused only on the commercial and more affluent areas of Manhattan, the program was expanded to reach north of 110th Street. Despite this effort, only one mentally ill homeless person had been taken from the streets of upper Manhattan.

title: U.S. Hondas Go to Japan
description: The first cars made in the United States by a Japanese company arrived in Tokyo Friday when the Honda Motor Company unloaded 540 autos. ''We hope this will help reduce trade tensions between the two countries and eventually cut down the trade surplus,'' a Honda spokesman said. The Accord cars were made by Honda's wholly owned subsidiary, Honda of America Manufacturing, in Marysville, Ohio.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm not looking for anything. I don't want to be a candidate. I don't want a big role at the convention. I don't want to be a Cabinet member. I don't want to be a big shot. What I want is to help one of these three -Jackson, Dukakis, Gore - become President. It's as simple as that.'' - Gov. Mario Cuomo. [ B9:5 ]

title: A Broadway Impresario Whose Hit Is Food
description: Steven W. Jenkins has a food attitude. He can't stand little jars of jelly with gingham around the lid. Factory-made cheeses make him moan. Ask for fresh ''bazzle'' rather than ''baysil'' and he will charge you an additional 10 cents a bunch for what he considers your mispronunciation.

title: Review/Concert; The Sounds of Vienna
description: A young conductor named Hobart Earle is creating an exchange between Vienna and the United States that reflects on a smaller scale the Soviet-American festival so recently witnessed in Boston. Mr. Earle has set up an annual American Music Week in Vienna, and on Saturday night, he brought his ensemble for Viennese Music-New York to Merkin Concert Hall in a program of Austrian composers.

title: Report Finds Some Federal Agencies Weak on Radon Threat
description: Federal agencies involved in housing, hampered by a lack of Congressional guidance, are doing little or nothing about the threat from radon, a gas that has been linked to cancer, the General Accounting Office says.

title: Putnam's Joins New Age: Dead Men Do Tell Tales
description: One of the fastest-growing book categories is New Age, a catch-all for everything from self-help and spirituality to extraterrestial travel and spirit possession. G. P. Putnam's Sons largely resisted the New Age trend - until a psychic medium gave its executives ''readings'' with the dead that so bowled them over they signed him to a six-figure deal.

title: 3-Cent Stamps Scarce At Some Post Offices
description: Shortages of 3-cent stamps are being reported at some post offices, although depleted inventories are being rapidly refilled, according to the Postal Service.

title: Digging the World's Grave With Military Spending; The Common Security
description: To the Editor:

title: When Neighborhoods Take Up the Drug Battle
description: To the Editor:

title: Holocaust Museum Seeks The Artifacts of Suffering
description: One day last fall, a 70-year-old woman named Frania Blum walked into a midtown Manhattan office with a small package under her arm. Before the assembled office staff, she opened the package and took out its contents: a small, slightly faded blue-checked dress.

title: Advertising's Youth Brigade Flouts Tradition
description: The television commercial starring a banker with a Hula-Hoop bears little resemblance to the magazine advertisement for raincoats that contains neither rain nor coats. Yet the two ads - and others featuring live chickens, bare legs and a mendacious auto salesman - were all developed by writers and art directors who are barely scratching their fourth decade of life.

title: Iranians Say Iraq Has Ended Lull in Attacks Against Cities
description: Iraqi jets bombed a village near the Iranian Kurdish border town of Marivan on Sunday, wounding several people and damaging houses, the Teheran radio reported.

title: Man Wanted as the Killer of 6 Is Caught Because of TV Show
description: A man sought for five murders in Maryland and one in New York City was captured by 30 heavily armed police officers in Brooklyn Saturday night, weeks after being seen on a television show featuring the crimes and profiles of the nation's most-wanted fugitives.

title: In Tense Times at Penn, Enter Farrakhan
description: This Wednesday, in what is seen as a pivotal event on a campus where racial relations have reached a tense and delicate state, Louis Farrakhan is scheduled to bring to the University of Pennsylvania the views that have made him a target of widespread condemnation as anti-Semitic.

title: Japan Cited On Forklifts
description: The Commerce Department ruled Friday that Japanese companies were selling forklift trucks on the United States market at less than cost, paving the way for anti-dumping duties to be levied.

title: Texaco to Sell Unit
description: Texaco Inc., which earlier this month emerged from bankruptcy, confirmed today that it planned to sell its West German subsidiary, Deutsche Texaco A.G., to help pay for its reorganization. A spokesman for Deutsche Texaco said the parent company had informed the West German subsidiary of its intention, but no deal had been made. The sale has been rumored since Texaco said in January that it planned to sell some European refining assets. Veba A.G., a West German utility and chemicals group, has denied press reports that it is a potential buyer.

title: U.S. SENDS A TEAM TO AID PAKISTANIS
description: The Pentagon dispatched a Navy bomb disposal team to Pakistan today after a fire touched off multiple explosions at a munitions depot near Islamabad, a Pentagon spokesman said.

title: Metro Datelines; Thieves Take Snakes, Spiders and Rats
description: Burglars stole $8,000 worth of snakes, spiders, scorpions and lizards from an exotic pet shop, and they even packed their captives a lunch, taking rats, mice and meal worms, too, the police said.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None

title: Police-Fire Rules Making Rift Worse
description: Five months after New York City issued new emergency procedures for the Police and Fire Departments in an effort to lay a long dispute to rest, officials from both agencies say the rules have actually made relations worse.

title: Ex-Scoutmaster Is Slashed; An Ex-Boy Scout Is Charged
description: A 25-year-old former Boy Scout was being held this weekend on $110,000 bail after he slashed a retired scoutmaster over a 12-year grudge about a merit badge, the police say.

title: Pepperell Under Pressure To Raise Bid for Stevens
description: West Point-Pepperell needs to raise its bid significantly for J. P. Stevens & Company if it wants to thwart a competing $64-a-share offer from Odyssey Partners that expires today at midnight, professional traders said yesterday.

title: The Ugly 'Yellow Peril' Stigma Lives On
description: Listening to the radio the other day, I heard Richard A. Gephardt still defending his defunct protectionist trade amendment. His proposal to impose stiff penalties against countries running large trade surpluses with the United States could have triggered a trade war. But the former Presidential candidate was still insisting that the issue was fairness, not protectionism.

title: Advertising; Tarlow Starts Agency With a Familiar Name
description: Play it again, Dick.

title: P. S. du Pont 3d, 77, Candidate's Father And Business Leader
description: Pierre S. du Pont 3d, a retired business executive and former vice president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, died early Saturday at his home in Rockland, Del., after an illness of six months. He was 77 years old.

title: Politics as Usual Needs Its Blue Ribbon Panels
description: To the Editor:

title: Hazel Garland, Editor, 75
description: Hazel Garland, a journalist who was one of the first black women to edit a nationally circulated publication, died last Tuesday of a heart attack. She was 75 years old.

title: Shipping Out
description: Bill Nixon finished next to last Friday night in three-meter diving in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I swimming championships in Indianapolis. So why is his college sending him on a six-month all-expenses-paid trip to the Mediterranean and maybe Africa and South and Central America?

title: Lyle Surges to Take Masters
description: Sandy Lyle, an unflappable Scot, struck a nearly perfect 145-yard bunker shot to the 18th green at Augusta National Golf Club today and then sank the remaining 10-foot putt for birdie 3 to win the 52d Masters by a stroke over Mark Calcavecchia.

title: 42 Die in a Thai Bus Plunge
description: A crowded bus blew a front tire and plunged into an irrigation canal in central Thailand, killing at least 42 people and injuring 11, the police said today.

title: Towle's New President Likely to Take the Helm
description: Christopher McGillivary has been named president of the Towle Manufacturing Company, an enterprise that calls itself the oldest corporation in Massachusetts but one that has had difficulty surviving the 1980's.

title: Change Expected in Testing
description: An electrical testing company here has won a court ruling against the Occupational Safety and Health Administration that is expected to end two other companies' dominance of the American market for product testing.

title: VIRGINIA CHENG IS MARRIED TO J. P. SHAMES IN QUEENS
description: Virginia M. Cheng and Jonathan P. Shames were married yesterday at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Lester Bronstein officiated.

title: Cavaliers Humble Nets, 119-105
description: Brad Daugherty and Mark Price have been through it together.

title: Hachette In Accord For Grolier
description: Hachette S.A., France's largest publishing company, has arranged to acquire Grolier Inc., an American publisher of educational materials, officials of the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Gore in His Own Words: Excerpts From an Interview on Campaign Issues
description: Here are excerpts from an interview with Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee conducted by reporters and editors of The New York Times in advance of New York's April 19 Presidential primary: Foreign Policy

title: Trade Bill Has Special Favors For Companies
description: Buried deep in the 1,000-page trade bill that Congress is trying to complete this week are provisions benefiting companies making everything from drugs and disposable diapers to cooking ware and frozen cranberries.

title: Advertising; Avrett Agency Hired By Vitamin Producers
description: The Council for Responsible Nutrition, a trade association of manufaturers of vitamins and minerals, has retained Avrett, Free & Ginsberg to prepare a TV and print ad campaign to encourage consumers to buy more of their goods to supplement their diets. In 1985 the American market in this field was $2.6 billion at retail.

title: Big New York State Issue Is Scheduled
description: Treasury financings this week include today's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills and tomorrow's $6.25 billion auction of new seven-year notes.

title: New Hopes for a Global Oil Coalition
description: Embattled but far from dead, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is embarking on a great new adventure, trying to assemble what amounts to a global oil coalition.

title: The Seamy Side of Congress
description: Hear, for once, a tale of extravagant Government waste that isn't the Pentagon's fault. This year the Pentagon is going to buy 300,000 tons of anthracite coal it doesn't want and pile it in a field in eastern Pennsylvania. It has been buying this coal for nearly 25 years, usually against its wishes and always under pressure from Pennsylvania's Congressional delegation.

title: Liberace Auction: Glittering Ghost
description: It's been a little over a year since Liberace died and Willie Collins has taken up where the flamboyant showman left off. So this weekend Mr. Collins came over from Las Vegas to pick up some candelabra and other authentic props for his new Liberace look-alike show at auction here.

title: Francis E. Conrad, V.A. Official, 51
description: Francis E. Conrad, a high-level Veterans Administration official, was stabbed to death Thursday. He was 51 years old.

title: Walker Balances Bulk With Ballet
description: Herschel Walker raised a 115-pound ballerina high overhead, strode forcefully without the slightest quiver, then leaned forward as she uncoiled gracefully across his muscular back.

title: On the Russian Easter, Believers See Greater Soviet Tolerance
description: By midnight, when Metropolitan Filaret of Kiev stepped forward at St. Vladimir's Cathedral to announce that ''Christ is risen,'' some of the hardy worshipers at the altar rail had already been on their feet for six hours awaiting the climax of the central pageant in the Russian Orthodox Church.

title: 2 Derby Hopefuls Reflect Past
description: The outlook for the Kentucky Derby May 7 is starting to seem a lot like the Derby picture of just four years ago.

title: Islanders Win; Tie Series at 2-2
description: Brent Sutter scored a short-handed goal with 15 minutes 7 seconds gone in an overtime period tonight to complete a wild game and carry the Islanders to a 5-4 victory over the Devils at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Review/Concert; Celebrating a Ukrainian Composer's 50th Birthday
description: Continuum has given several concerts of recent Soviet music over the years, focusing both on the larger scene and on individual composers. One composer considered among his country's leading lights is Valentin Silvestrov, a Ukrainian. In a belated celebration of Mr. Silvestrov's 50th birthday (which was last September), Continuum performed five captivating works of his on Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Panama Asks Region To Help It Obtain Cash
description: The virtually bankrupt Panamanian Government called on other Latin American nations for help today as the United States tightened economic sanctions to oust the military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Finance Minister Ricaurte Vasquez, in a letter to a regional economic organization, the Latin American Economic System, asked the other governments to help Panana ''find a mechanism to convert available liquid assets in U.S. dollars into cash.''

title: Advertising; Esquire Ads Poke Fun at Nonreaders
description: WHILE working for their new client, Esquire magazine, Richard Kirshenbaum, 26 years old, and Jonathan Bond, 30, founders of the Kirshenbaum & Bond agency, came to the conclusion that describing the wondrous but complex Esquire Man would be too difficult for mere mortals. Instead they will use Esquire's promotional advertising to say what he is not.

title: BLAST IN PAKISTAN AT WEAPONS DEPOT KILLS AT LEAST 75
description: Hundreds of people were feared killed today in explosions that destroyed an army ammunition depot in a densely populated area between the twin cities of Rawalpindi and Islamabad, the capital.

title: Tyson Has Big Questions About Money
description: Mike Tyson intends to have a bigger say in the business of being heavyweight champion. Tyson, who has been at the center of a conflict between his manager, Bill Cayton, and his promoter, Don King, for control of his career, wants the control in his hands.

title: Sputtering Mets Salvage 4-3 Victory
description: The Mets salvaged the final game of an otherwise disturbing series today when they edged the Philadelphia Phillies, 4-3, on a pair of home runs by Mookie Wilson, the reluctant role-player.

title: A Challenge To Chip Accord
description: The European Community on Friday urged the world trade body GATT to rule that a Japan-United States accord to maintain high prices for Japanese microchip exports violated free-trade rules.

title: Nixon's Big Regret: Bombing Delay
description: Richard M. Nixon said today that his delay in the bombing and mining of North Vietnam was the biggest mistake of his Presidency and that he and his aides had mishandled the Watergate crisis ''beyond belief.''

title: The Season of Andy Warhol: The Artist as Persistent Presence
description: One of the more remarkable of current art-world phenomena is the afterlife of Andy Warhol. After a well-known artist dies, there is customarily a pause for reassessment, a general desire to look elsewhere and quite possibly a sag in reputation. Yet this is, beyond a doubt, the season of Andy Warhol, who died just over a year ago but who is still very much among us as a persistent and almost all-permeating presence.

title: Metro Datelines; Off-Duty Officer Dies In a Traffic Accident
description: An off-duty police officer was killed and another, her husband, was injured when their car went out of control on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway yesterday morning, the police said.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Japan, as Seen by China, Nervously
description: China shivers when the U.S. presses Japan to spend more on defense. From Beijing, Japan's military force looks quite adequate; adding more seems threatening. A visitor finds that Japan's economic might and growing military muscle worries many Chinese academics and political officials, people who otherwise find world politics today mostly positive and increasingly hospitable for a newly emerging China.

title: Colorado Seeks Sale Of 14 Banks
description: A proposal to bail out 14 failed industrial banks and pay 9,000 depositors who have been waiting six months to withdraw their savings is expected to be presented to the Legislature here this week.

title: Bomb at Saudi Airline Office In Pakistan Hurts at Least 7
description: At least seven people were wounded in the explosion of a powerful bomb at a Saudia Airlines office in Karachi tonight, the police said.

title: Prepare Your Equipment for Summer Hibernation
description: WHEN temperatures rise, buds begin to appear and days grow longer, most skiers simply pick up their golf clubs or tennis racquets and start a different activity. Skis and boots are forgotten for the summer, left where they were dropped after the last trip to the slopes.

title: Carolina Freight Carriers Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Advertising; People
description: * Alan W. Muncaster will assume the new post of staff vice president of corporate communications at Northwest Airlines on May 9.

title: Interco Incorporated reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 20
description: The company said latest year included a pre-tax charge of $11.6 million from restructuring.

title: Sports People; Delle Bovi Resigns
description: Bob Delle Bovi has resigned after two seasons as the basketball coach at Manhattan College. Manhattan had a 13-43 record during Delle Bovi's two seasons, including a 7-21 mark last season.

title: Intermagnetics General Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Colorado Danger Signs On Medical Emergency
description: The town's only doctor left long ago and the closest clinic closed its doors in February. So what now passes for emergency medical care on this part of the Colorado high plains is a 10-year-old ambulance with a volunteer crew and a bumpy 45-minute ride to Denver.

title: C. Gilbert Taylor, 89, Inventor of Small Plane
description: C. Gilbert Taylor, a self-taught aircraft designer whose Taylor Cub evolved into the overwhelmingly successful Piper Cub of the 1930's and 1940's, has died March 29 in Houston. Mr. Taylor, who was 89 years old, had suffered from Parkinson's disease for more than a year, said his daughter, Carol Taylor Sharp.

title: Meese Sought to Hire Friend Until Official Word of Inquiry; Meese Hints at Leaving
description: Mr. Meese hinted today that he would consider leaving his post before the end of President Reagan's term next year.

title: Viking Freight System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 26
description: b-Includes a credit of $960,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting.

title: Advertising; Commercial Makers' Unions in Tentative Pact
description: Advertising industry representatives announced yesterday that a tentative agreement had been reached with the talent unions that have been on strike for three weeks, curtailing the making of commercials. Although the agreement was reached on Saturday, details of the agreement will not be made public until the unions vote on it this week.

title: Jackson's Absence Fails to Dim Party
description: Percy Sutton was feeling a touch apologetic.

title: Our Towns; Chain Treats Inn for Homeless As a Weak Link
description: Gordon Weiss has owned the Red Bull Best Western Motor Inn here since 1979. At times he has set aside a block of his 160 rooms for people staying in the area for extended periods. He has housed I.B.M. workers who are transferred here temporarily for months. He has had construction crews that built the nearby Galleria Mall. ''They're the toughest,'' Mr. Weiss said. ''They make a mess, they drink. You really have to watch them.'' They left, and for a year he has had 30 homeless families at the motel, placed by Westchester County. Social service officials are pleased. ''They run it well,'' said Daniela Misch, a caseworker. The homeless seem to like it. ''The best motel I've been in since I've been homeless,'' said Dalevis Hampton. ''I asked my social worker, 'Don't move me.' '' The local police chief, Stanley Still, says the motel has not been a crime or drug spot: ''The management seems to have control.''

title: Sports People; New Medals
description: With the blessings of the King of Sweden and the International Olympic Committee president, the world's oldest living Olympic champion will receive replicas of the medals he misplaced nearly 60 years ago.

title: JEWISH AUDIENCE WOOED BY DUKAKIS
description: Michael S. Dukakis campaigned among Jewish leaders yesterday and took pains to absolve the Israeli Government of fault in the Palestinian disturbances on the West Bank.

title: A Mantra for Courage From 'Julius Caesar'
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, said its board had adopted a defense against hostile takeover bids. BankAmerica said the plan would give holders of each common share the right to buy one-hundredth of a share of a new series of preferred stock at an exercise price of $50.

title: Atlas Consolidated Mining & Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The figures have been converted from Philippine pesos at a rate of 20.6586 pesos to $1 for the latest year, and 20.3489 pesos to $1 for 1986.

title: Carter Set for Home Opener
description: The Mets will make their first appearance in New York in six months today when they open their home season with full fanfare at Shea Stadium, with Ron Darling pitching against the Montreal Expos and with many explanations for their slow start on the road last week.

title: Exiled Soviet Dissidents' Group in Dispute Over Threat to Dissenters
description: On the surface the Center for Democracy, an organization of exiled Soviet dissidents that is supported by Federal money, carries out the sort of human rights activities normally praised by nearly everybody.

title: Bush's Wonder Weapon
description: The only weapon a President needs to reduce the Federal deficit, George Bush proclaims, is the line-item veto. Give it to the man in the White House ''and watch the spending go down.'' If he really believes that, and if he's elected President, the deficit may be with us forever.

title: Koch, After Cuomo Statement on Draft, To Endorse Gore or Dukakis This Week
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would soon endorse one of two Democratic Presidential candidates competing in the New York primary, now that Governor Cuomo had convinced him that he would not accept a draft.

title: Jones Intercable Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the prior fourth quarter and year results are not available. The partnership had no operations before November 1986.

title: Cooperative Hunting By Hawks
description: HARRIS'S hawks, like lions, hunt in cooperative groups to improve their chances of catching prey, a biologist at the University of New Mexico has discovered.

title: NEW SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Final terms for a Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan were reached by the United States and the Soviet Union. Washington said the accord, which lets both sides arm combatants, would be signed on Thursday in Geneva. Page A1 Military analysis: The Soviet Army enjoyed an impressive reputation before the war in Afghanistan. While the military may be relieved by the decision to withdraw forces, its reputation has suffered. A16 Meetings on American-Soviet trade opened in Moscow. Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov complained to Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr., who heads the American group, that trade relations are inadequate. D8 Israel expelled eight Palestinians into southern Lebanon and ordered the deportation of 12 others. They were the first deportations since Jan. 13, when Israel expelled four Palestinians. A1 Federal drug programs are failing because they emphasize a crackdown on suppliers and neglect the task of drawing drug users away from the habit, experts say. Efforts to reduce supplies have been ineffective. A1 Hijackers of a Kuwaiti jet killed a second hostage and then put a passenger on the radio to announce that more people were facing death. The killing halted negotiations over the plane's fate. A1 An explosion in Pakistan on Sunday may have been caused by saboteurs, President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq suggested. Hundreds may have died in the explosion, which struck the cities of Rawalpindi and Islamabad. A1 China's education policies are being protested openly by some students and teachers discontented with conditions. Education has emerged as a troubling issue during the current session of parliament. A4 Francois Mitterrand is campaigning for re-election as President of France, not just as the Socialists' candidate. He is now a moderate on economic issues, but his sympathetic stand toward immigrants has surprised many. A3 Panama sanctions puzzle companies A6 NATIONAL A20-33, B6-7 Greater roles for women in the Roman Catholic Church are recommended at almost every level except the priesthood in a draft report by a committee of United States bishops, who also condemned sexism. A1 Drugs have corrupted Italy's Mafia, a former member of the Sicilian Mafia testified at the most extensive Senate hearings on organized crime in 25 years. Tommaso Buscetta said he no longer felt bound by the code of silence. A20 Access to emergency medical care has become a serious problem for many rural areas in the United States. It has become acute in western states like Colorado where great distances separate small towns. A20 Democrats in Houston are furious that the new Democratic Committee chairman supports Lyndon LaRouche. Committee members hope to strip the chairman of all power by the time he is sworn on May 2. A24 Sale of Texaco's German subsidiary is being negotiated as part of the company's post-bankruptcy restructuring plan, according to company executives. The potential buyers have not been identified. D1 Presidential veto of a trade bill now nearing completion could be overriden by Congress, Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, suggested. President Reagan has warned of a veto if two sections are not modified. D9 POLITICS B6-7 Mayor Koch said he will endorse either Gov. Michael S. Dukakis or Senator Albert Gore Jr. for the Democratic Presidential nomination. Mr. Koch said he would make the endorsement after talking with each man. B6 Michael Dukakis absolved Israel of fault in the Palestinian disturbances on the West Bank. In an appearance before a conference of Jewish leaders, he refused to take a stand on a Palestinian state. B7 WASHINGTON TALK A32 Colleagues help as Senators campaign REGIONAL B1-5 A murder suspect was captured in a routine anti-drug operation on the Lower East Side Sunday night. The former convict, sought in two Pennsylvania slayings, was caught when police stopped his pick-up truck. B1 The Red Hook Marine Terminal in Brooklyn, the last major cargo handling operation in New York City, is bustling. But the terminal needs more help from the Port Authority, which owns the terminal, to compete with New Jersey, officials say. B1 Bus trips to Altantic City's casinos bring more than 14.2 million people a year to gamble there. Many are elderly, taking the trip as much for the experience as the prospect of winning. B1 Fights over gold jewelry at the West Side High Scool in New York City prompted the principal, Edward Reynolds, to forbid students from wearing thick gold chains, breast plates and outsize medallions to school.
