B1 A reform of prison health services must be carried out in New York City, according to a consultant, who said its capacity must be tripled to meet the rising inmate population and AIDS caseload. B5 Albany budget talks snagged on school aid B2 Two women are killed in Queens B5 Subway trains halted on Williamsburg Bridge B3 La Guardia president going to Bank St. B4 Three traffic agents arrested on bribe charges B3

title: Offshore Leases Delayed
description: A heavy workload has caused the Interior Department to postpone seven offerings of offshore oil and gas leases in 1989, 1990 and 1991, the department said today. Four are in Federal waters off Alaska, two off California and one off the Middle Atlantic States. The revised schedule shows 34 offerings remaining in the five-year drilling plan adopted last July.

title: First Virginia Banks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago quarter results are restated to include the accounts of three banks acquired in 1987.

title: The Death of Federalism
description: LEAD: A century and a half ago, Alexis de Tocqueville noted America's tendency to sacrifice individual freedoms in favor of the larger social order. The trait he discerned as early as 1831 is still apparent, and the Civil Rights Restoration Act, recently passed, vetoed and reaffirmed, is the latest evidence.

title: Minimum Wage: A Perverse Policy
description: LEAD: Congress appears ready to approve an increase in the Federal minimum wage, a perverse policy that hurts the low-income families it seeks to help. A bill calling for a $5.05 minimum recently passed the House Education and Labor Committee, and a similar bill calling for $4.65 is pending in the Senate Labor

title: Review/Opera; Young Singers Compete at the Met
description: The winners' concert of the Metropolitan Opera auditions Sunday afternoon offered, naturally enough, more in the way of prospects and potential than of consolidated achievement. Some of the potential is considerable; nevertheless, it was a dispiriting event, because the general level of vocal cultivation and readiness was not very high.

title: The Oscar Winners
description: FILM, ''The Last Emperor'' (Columbia Pictures). FOREIGN-LANGUAGE FILM, ''Babette's Feast,'' a Panorama Film International Production in cooperation with Nordisk Film and the Danish Film Institute. DIRECTOR, Bernardo Bertolucci, for ''The Last Emperor'' (Columbia). ACTOR, Michael Douglas, for ''Wall Street'' (20th Century-Fox). ACTRESS, Cher, for ''Moonstruck'' (M-G-M). SUPPORTING ACTOR, Sean Connery for ''The Untouchables'' (Paramount). SUPPORTING ACTRESS, Olympia Dukakis, for ''Moonstruck'' (M-G-M). ORIGINAL SCREENPLAY, John Patrick Shanley, for ''Moonstruck.'' SCREENPLAY ADAPTATION, Mark Peploe and Bernardo Bertolucci, for ''The Last Emperor.'' CINEMATOGRAPHY, Vittorio Storaro for ''The Last Emperor.'' EDITING, Gabriella Cristiani for ''The Last Emperor.'' ORIGINAL SCORE, Ryuichi Sakamoto, David Byrne and Cong Su, for ''The Last Emperor.'' ORIGINAL SONG, ''(I've Had) The Time of My Life,'' from ''Dirty Dancing.'' Music by Franke Previte, John DeNicola and Donald Markowitz; lyrics by Mr. Previte. ART DIRECTION, Ferdinando Scarfiotti, art direction; Bruno Cesari, set decoration, for ''The Last Emperor.'' COSTUME DESIGN, James Acheson, for ''The Last Emperor.'' SOUND, Bill Rowe and Ivan Sharrock for ''The Last Emperor.'' MAKEUP, Rick Baker, for ''Harry and the Hendersons.'' VISUAL EFFECTS, Dennis Murem, William George, Harley Jessup and Kenneth Smith for ''Innerspace.'' SHORT FILM, ANIMATED, ''The Man Who Planted Trees,'' Societe Radio-Canada/ Canadian Broadcasting Corp.; Frederic Back, producer. SHORT FILM, LIVE, ''Ray's Male Heterosexual Dance Hall'' (Chanticleer Films). DOCUMENTARY, FEATURE, ''The 10-Year Lunch: The Wit and Legend of the Algonquin Round Table,'' Aviva Films; Aviva Slesin, producer. DOCUMENTARY, SHORT SUBJECT, ''Young at Heart,'' Sue Marx Films Inc.; Sue Marx and Pamela Conn, producers. IRVING G. THALBERG AWARD, a special award given to a film maker for the body of his work. To Billy Wilder, writer and director.

title: Toronto Sun Acquisition
description: The Toronto Sun Publishing Corporation said today that it had agreed in principle to acquire Bowes Publishers Ltd. of Edmonton, Alberta. Bowes publishes 14 newspapers and 6 magazines in Alberta, British Columbia and Ontario. The company will pay $28.2 million for 60 percent of the outstanding shares of Bowes, which is privately owned. The remainder of the shares will be purchased in six years, during which time Bowes would be allowed to manage itself. Toronto Sun said it would have two seats on Bowes's five-member board of directors.

title: Heritage Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
This Weapon Is Smarter Than You Might Think
description: To the Editor:

title: FMC Gold reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. AND MOSCOW AGREE ON PULLOUT FROM AFGHANISTAN
description: The United States announced today that it had reached agreement with the Soviet Union on the remaining terms for a Soviet troop withdrawal from Afghanistan. It said the agreement would be signed on Thursday in Geneva.

title: Soviet Calls for U.S. Trade Treaty
description: Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. was offered warm greetings and words of reproof upon his arrival here today as Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov criticized American-Soviet trade relations as inadequate.

title: 3 Traffic Agents Facing Charges In Bribe Scheme
description: Three New York City traffic agents in midtown and upper Manhattan were arrested yesterday and charged with taking ''a few hundred dollars'' in $10 to $50 bribes for not issuing tickets or for altering summonses so that motorists could avoid fines, officials said.

title: Central Bancshares of the South Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest and year-ago first quarter earnings reflect a change in accounting for loan fees and origination costs in accordance with FAS No. 91. The company also said the effect of the accounting change was to decrease previously reported 1987 first quarter earnings by $871,000, or 4 cents a share; the effect on 1988 first quarter earnings wasn't material.

title: A.T.&T. Chief Steps Aside Temporarily
description: The chairman and chief executive of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, James E. Olson, has temporarily relinquished his duties after undergoing major surgery, the company said yesterday.

title: Fine Homes International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said year-ago first quarter results are not comparable because it had been a wholly owned subsidiary of Merrill Lynch & Co.

title: Miss Brawley's Is Not a Federal Case
description: Tawana Brawley has so far refused to cooperate with state authorities investigating her claims of racially motivated abduction and assault. But now, one of her advisers says, she'd be willing to testify for the Feds. Her willingness to cooperate is welcome but misdirected.

title: Review/Television; Video Verite Style for Police Story
description: It all began in the late 1970's with a PBS documentary made by Alan and Susan Raymond. ''The Police Tapes'' went to a police precinct in a run-down Bronx neighborhood to record, with hand-held cameras, real cops on the job, from station-house roll call to car patrols. The ''supporting cast'' included junkies, would-be suicides, wife abusers and other ordinary denizens of urban decay. That single documentary was a crucial source for both an ambitious film, ''Fort Apache, the Bronx'' starring Paul Newman, and a hit television series, ''Hill Street Blues.'' Both imitations were, however, far slicker than the murky, rough-edged original.

title: A.T.&T. Will Offer New Unix Software
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it plans to offer new software that will make it easier for a wide range of customers to use computers based on its Unix operating system.

title: New York's Blacks Fearful of Being 'Written Off'
description: In the New York Democratic primary, where an understanding of the state's complex ethnic makeup has long been considered a key to success, many blacks say they have been ''written off'' by the Presidential campaigns of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee. Blacks make up about a quarter of New York's Democratic electorate.

title: By Design; Joys and Pitfalls of Bright Colors
description: Next fall, store racks should be chockablock with vibrant colors. The clothes American designers are now introducing include blazing reds and oranges, screaming greens, bright blues, passionate purples and exuberant yellows. These will be competing for space with the usual sober shades of black, brown, camel and gray.

title: Excerpts From Draft Pastoral Letter on Women by Catholic Bishops in U.S.
description: Following are excerpts from the conclusion of a draft pastoral letter on women issued today by Roman Catholic bishops in the United States:

title: U.S. Panama Curbs Questioned
description: Several American companies with operations in Panama said yesterday that they had just received details about the Reagan Administration's sanctions and that they were unsure how to comply with an executive order halting all payments to the Panamanian Government.

title: Dr. Benjamin Zohn, Allergist, Is Dead at 86
description: Dr. Benjamin Zohn, an allergist and a founder of the American Association of Retired Persons, died of lung cancer Sunday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 86 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Sports People; Rutgers Picks Wenzel
description: Bob Wenzel, a Nets assistant coach and a former player at Rutgers, was named yesterday as head coach of the Scarlet Knights.

title: Rightist Gain Could Be the Making of Salvador; Not Free or Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: Sweden Has a Better Way of Dealing With Dead Automobiles
description: To the Editor:

title: Paul R. Hanna, Professor, 85
description: Dr. Paul R. Hanna, a leading authority on education and senior editor of a series of social science and spelling textbooks used in elementary schools across the country, died Friday. He was 85 years old.

title: Astronomers Detect A Very Distant Galaxy
description: USING telescopes on Hawaii's Mauna Kea volcano, astronomers have detected a galaxy almost twice as far away as any previously documented.

title: 4 Helping U.S. In Wedtech Case Called Vultures
description: A Government witness in the trial of Representative Mario Biaggi and six others testified yesterday that she once described one of the defendants as a ''victim'' and referred to the four executives cooperating with the Government's prosecution as ''vultures.''

title: 2-Part Philadelphia Electric Offering
description: The Philadelphia Electric Company is selling, in the competitive bond market, a total of $250 million, in two parts, of first and refunding bonds with 10-year and 30-year maturities.

title: Escalade Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 19
description: b-Includes a credit of $161,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: J.P. Stevens Gets 2 Sweetened Bids
description: West Point-Pepperell Inc. yesterday sweetened its bid for J.P. Stevens & Company for the third time, only to have its latest offer bested by Odyssey Partners.

title: Dow Jones & Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $64,491,000, or 67 cents a share, from the previously reported sale of the company's book publishing subsidiary, Richard D. Irwin Inc., for $135 million. c-Includes an after-tax gain of $29,364,000, or 30 cents a share, from the sale of the company's interest in South China Morning Post Ltd. The company said this year's first quarter earnings included Telerate Inc., which is 56 percent owned by Dow Jones. The year-ago first quarter results include Telerate's contribution through the equity method of accounting. Since Oct. 1, 1987, Dow Jones has consolidated Telerate's results with its own for financial reporting purposes.

title: John H. Dent, Former Legislator, 80
description: Former Representative John H. Dent, a 10-term Democrat from western Pennsylvania, died Saturday. He was 80 years old.

title: Kodak in Debt Market Again With $400 Million in Notes
description: For the third time in almost a month and a half, the Eastman Kodak Company has entered the debt market with a large issue. It is offering $400 million of 9 1/2 percent notes, due in 2000, at a price of 99, to yield 9.642 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Drugs and Sicilian Mafiosi: No Omerta Among Thieves
description: A former member of the Sicilian Mafia told senators today that ''money, drugs and greed'' have corrupted the underworld organization.

title: Sports People; Rules Questions
description: Clinton Smith, the top scorer on the Cleveland State basketball team that went to the National Collegiate Athletix Association tournament in 1985-86, played that season while on probation for a felony conviction, according to a report yesterday in The News-Herald of Willoughby, Ohio.

title: F.D.I.C. Terms on Loan Sale
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today that it would try to sell $1.2 billion in loans it acquired in the 1984 bailout of the Continental Illinois National Bank at a tentative average minimum price of 33 cents on the dollar.

title: New Attacks End Lull in Gulf Missile War
description: Iraqi missiles struck Teheran and the city of Isfahan today, ending a three-day lull in the Persian Gulf missile war and prompting Iran to vow reprisals.

title: Harry Joseph, Psychoanalyst, 73
description: Dr. Harry Joseph, a psychoanalyst, died Wednesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Afghan War: Soviet Army Loses Luster
description: The Soviet Union's decision to withdraw its forces from Afghanistan beginning next month seems certain to stir mixed emotions within the Soviet military. Although the Soviet armed forces may well be relieved to be rid of a war that has dragged on for eight years, the reputation of the Russian military has been badly tarnished by the experience.

title: Bad Dropout Logic
description: To the Editor:

title: CUNY Educator Picked For Bank Street College
description: Dr. Joseph Shenker, a nationally known educator who is president of Fiorello H. La Guardia Community College in Long Island City, Queens, will be named president of the Bank Street College of Education tomorrow, officials at both institutions said yesterday.

title: Salvador Won't Free 3 Held in Killing of Marines
description: Three Salvadorans charged with involvement in the killing of four United States marines and nine civilians in 1985 will not be freed under a new amnesty law here, President Jose Napoleon Duarte said today.

title: Inglorious End For Yank Streak
description: The end of the winning streak did not seem to sit well with Billy Martin. When it was over late this afternoon, the manager of the Yankees sat on a table in the visitors' clubhouse at Exhibition Stadium, sipped calmly on a beer and promised a change at shorstop.

title: INSIDE
description: Oil Prices Rise Sharply Oil prices rose sharply after OPEC said it would meet later this month with other oil-producing nations in an attempt to force up prices by reducing supplies of oil. Page D1. Sale Planned by Texaco Texaco's attempt to sell its West German subsidiary for about $1.6 billion raises the possibility that it may be seeking the sale of more assets than previously announced. Page D1. Slaying Suspect Seized Making a routine check, the New York police found an ex-convict suspected of killing two co-workers at an archeological site near Philadelphia and of injuring two others. Page B1. A Patented Mouse The United State Patent Office will announce its first patent on an animal today - a genetically altered mouse created in a Harvard lab. Page A21.

title: Wrong Kind of Show
description: Daffodils, as Shakespeare wrote, take ''the winds of March with beauty,'' but by mid-April they tend to become crisped and sere, and that is the sad prospect of Washington's millions of daffodils at the time of the American Daffodil Society meeting here at the end of next week.

title: A French Offer For Wolverine
description: The Compagnie de Saint-Gobain, of Paris, offered $23 a share, or about $86 million, to acquire Wolverine Technologies Inc., of Dearborn, Mich. Saint-Gobain's offer was $4.50 a share more than an offer by Ply-Gem Industries of New York. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Saint-Gobain said the $86 million figure assumed that Ply-Gem would not exercise its option to buy about 67,000 shares for $14.12 each.

title: Nets Lose to Pacers at Buzzer
description: John Long's 18-footer at the buzzer gave the Indiana Pacers a 95-93 victory tonight and handed the Nets their 11th consecutive loss.

title: Careers; Prospects In Industry Improving
description: READING company annual reports that come out every spring - a good idea for any job hunter - can provide an indication of what fields might expect strong employment growth. To read the Eastman Kodak Company's report is to learn that there is a new emphasis on manufacturing in the United States. And a number of surveys on job offers and salaries back this up.

title: Pakistan Chief Hints Sabotage In Arms Blasts
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq raised the possibility today that a devastating explosion at a Pakistani ammunition depot on Sunday might have been the work of saboteurs.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Lincoln Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend distributed in May 1987, and are fully diluted.

title: Charles S. Vaughn, Airline Executive, 83
description: Charles S. Vaughn, an assistant vice president of Pan American World Airways who was also among the first to fly transoceanic passenger planes, died March 28 at the Saybrook (Conn.) Convalescent Hospital after a short illness. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhasset, L.I.

title: Bonds Give Up Friday's Gains
description: Bond prices fell sharply in thin trading yesterday, giving up virtually all of the gains recorded on Friday.

title: New Vehicles Test an Ancient Engine - the Human Body
description: On land, on the sea and in the the air, the race is on to go farther or faster with that most basic of engines, the human body.

title: Tyson Holds Conference
description: Mike Tyson flew unexpectedly to New York today and met with his assistant manager, Steve Lott, and later spoke by phone to his manager, Bill Cayton.

title: Videotex: The I.B.M.-Sears Venture Is Ready
description: The nation's largest computer company and its largest retailer this year will try what others have failed to do - to make a success of a home electronic information service.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON DECOLONIZATION: SUBCOMMITTEE ON SMALL TERRITORIES - 10:30 A.M. AD HOC COMMITTEE ON INDIAN OCEAN -10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: U.S. Plans to Issue First Patent on Animal Today
description: The United States Patent and Trademark Office plans to announce its first patent on an animal on Tuesday, an official said tonight.

title: The Metamorphosis at Primerica
description: Gerald Tsai Jr., chairman of the Primerica Corporation and architect of its transformation from the American Can Company, continues to wheel and deal, selling subsidiaries to reduce debts incurred during its rapid expansion into the insurance and securities businesses.

title: Alan Paton, Author And Apartheid Foe, Dies of Cancer at 85
description: Alan Paton, the South African author and political leader whose powerful 1948 novel ''Cry, the Beloved Country'' aroused many of his countrymen and much of the world against apartheid, died of throat cancer early Tuesday, South African time, at his home outside Durban, his wife Anne said. He was 85 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The dialogue between women and men must continue to be expanded so that our recommendations become part of the living heritage of our Catholic people and our institutions. Implementation is essential, for ours must not be a counterfeit love of formal politeness, impersonal tolerance or empty words.'' - Draft of letter by U.S. Roman Catholic bishops. [ A30:6. ]

title: Total System Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Henry G. Kier, Photo Merchant, 87
description: Henry G. Kier, retired owner of Kier's Celebrity Photos, a shop on West 40th Street in Manhattan specializing in movie stills, died Friday at a nursing home in Lakewood, N.J., after a brief illness. He was 87 years old and lived in Queens.

title: Advertising; Patrick Media Becomes An Adviser to China
description: The Patrick Media Group, formerly Foster & Kleiser and the country's largest outdoor operator, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Outdoor Advertising Agency of China to help that country modernize its outdoor operation. Outdoor advertising is billboards, and about a quarter of the money spent for advertising in China is spent on them.

title: A Briton of Stuart Lineage Will Head Knights of Malta
description: A descendant of Britain's royal Stuart family was elected leader of the Knights of Malta, an ancient Roman Catholic charitable order, it was announced today.

title: National City Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Schulman Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Saigon and Kabul
description: In the 1970's, when the United States was facing military disaster in Vietnam, the Soviet Union stepped in to help the Americans save face and salvage as much political capital as possible.

title: Texas Democrats Are Out to Hogtie an Unwanted Party Chairman
description: Claude Jones is scheduled to be sworn in as chairman of the Harris County Democratic Committee here on May 2. By that time, committee members hope to have removed every smidgen of power from his office.

title: A FOE OF NORIEGA FLIES INTO EXILE
description: A key opposition figure flew into exile in Venezuela overnight after the military Government gave him a choice of an airline ticket or an extended stay in an island penal colony.

title: Threat Seen To Plants In Medicine
description: AS many as 60,000 plants with valuable medical properties are likely to become extinct by 2050, according to one of organizers of a recent conference sponsored by the World Wildlife Fund, the World Health Organization and the International Union for Conservation of Nature.

title: From Rock to Riches For Music Plus Founder
description: Louis C. Fogelman found his calling amid the pulsing rock-and-roll of the 1960's. Having recognized rock's emotional impact on his peers, he established two retail music chains that catered to their tastes.

title: How to Beat the Mega-Carriers
description: When Robert L. Crandall completed a give-and-take session last month on the state of American Airlines, the 2,300 employees gathered in a hangar at the airline's huge maintenance base in Tulsa, Okla., gave their chief executive a rousing ovation.

title: U.S.-Japan Farm Talks
description: The United States and Japan will resume talks Tuesday on Tokyo's quotas on beef and citrus imports, the United States trade representative's office said today.

title: Sports of The Times; From Shoulder Pads to Tutus
description: UNTIL now, the most prominent marriage of the performing arts and sports probably occurred when Mike Reid, the 6-foot-3-inch, 255-pound defensive tackle for the Cincinnati Bengals in the 1970's, appeared with symphony orchestras. He was extraordinary. Not only could he play the piano, he could lift it, too.

title: Orange-Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,051,000, or 42 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. Stoneridge Resources Inc. owns 46 percent of the outstanding shares of Orange-Co.

title: Iomega Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 3
description: b-Net loss

title: Area Code Change in Florida
description: The burgeoning population growth of southern and central Florida has prompted a new area code, 4o7, for telephone customers from Boca Raton to Orlando. Southern Bell officials said the new 407 area code, scheduled to go into effect at midnight this Saturday, will be assigned to about 2.1 million telephone numbers, while nearly 1.7 million in Broward, Dade and Monroe counties will keep the old 305 area code.

title: Texas Senate Primary Today Pits 2 Survivors of March 8
description: Representative Beau Boulter faces a Houston businessman, Wes Gilbreath, in a primary runoff Tuesday for the Republican nomination to challenge Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Democratic incumbent.

title: Ypsilanti Journal; Aging Auto Shop Is a Mecca for Hudson Fanciers
description: The last Hudson automobile rolled off the assembly line in 1957, a matter that is of minor concern to Jack C. Miller. He is still very much a Hudson dealer, the last of his kind in the country.

title: Charles the Outspoken Tangles With a Tory
description: The Prince of Wales's campaign to create a role for himself as a spokesman on issues of public welfare has landed him in a scrap with the former chairman of the Conservative Party.

title: Hijackers of Kuwaiti Plane Kill Another Hostage
description: The hijackers of a Kuwaiti airliner killed a second hostage today and then put a passenger on the radio to announce that more people were facing death.

title: Computer Fair Matures
description: The 13th West Coast Computer Faire ended here Sunday with some of its idiosyncratic, countercultural credentials intact, but fraying. Apple, born not many miles away in Silicon Valley, was not present; I.B.M. was.

title: Martin E. Citrin, Executive, 59
description: Martin E. Citrin, a business executive who was the only non-family executor of the estate of Henry Ford 2d, has died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound, the police said. He was 59 years old and lived in Bloomfield Hills.

title: Moscow's New Slant on the Mideast
description: The Soviet Union appears to be shifting its Middle East policy to take Israeli interests into account and claim a role for itself as a peacemaker in the region.

title: A Terminal Bustles And Bristles
description: When the Atlantic Emblem steamed into New York harbor from Japan Friday, crews unloaded her cargo of 10 new Kawasaki subway cars at the Red Hook Marine Terminal in Brooklyn, the last major cargo handling operation on New York's waterfront.

title: Bishops' Panel Would Expand Role of Women
description: In a draft report, a committee of United States Roman Catholic bishops recommended yesterday expanding the leadership roles of women at almost every level of the church except the priesthood.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alexander's Inc., a department store chain, appointed Raphael Present senior vice president, general manager.

title: Today: Added Tables In Business Day
description: Beginning today, Business Day is expanding a variety of statistical tables and charts published Tuesdays through Saturdays. Company news coverage is also being enlarged.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: First National Bancorporation Georgia reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KEY RATES
Market Place; The Japanese Role In Bond Liquidity
description: LEGISLATION attached to the trade bill that could bar Japanese firms from acting as primary dealers in United States Government securities could severely disrupt the bond market, many large institutional investors and traders say.

title: First Wachovia Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Budget Cuts Are Rescinded
description: The Air Force backed down today from a decision to close or consolidate 37 of its 151 college Reserve Officer Training Corps units. It had announced in January that it was closing 30 units and consolidating seven others into programs at nearby schools in an effort to eliminate 200 positions and save more than $10 million annually. Today's decision will be reviewed at the end of the spring term in 1990, a service spokesman said.

title: Texaco in Talks to Sell German Unit
description: Texaco Inc. is negotiating to sell its German subsidiary as part of its post-bankruptcy restructuring plan, company executives told their German subordinates last week in Hamburg.

title: Loan Banks Will Set Rates
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks will announce today the interest rates for a three-part financing totaling about $2.36 billion.

title: Stocks Rise Broadly Again; Dow Up 5.80
description: Stocks gained broadly again yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average 5.80 points higher, to 2,095.99, its loftiest closing level since the October crash.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, which generally issues short-term floating-rate notes monthly, is offering $350 million of notes due on Oct. 13 at a price of par through various securities dealers.

title: Merrill Lynch & Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company, which reported lower first quarter revenue and net income in the latest period, said its commission revenue declined 33 percent to $440 million from the record 1987 commission revenue quarter because of reduced stock market activity.

title: Permit Violations Halt Conversion of a Theater
description: The planned conversion of the Walker Theater, a Brooklyn movie palace, into a discount clothing store has been stopped by the New York City Buildings Department because the owner has no work permits and had filed an incomplete application.

title: School Bans A New Peril: Flashy Gold
description: Students returning to West Side High School in Manhattan yesterday after the spring break found a surprise. Their principal stood at the front door and issued an ultimatum: no more ''big gold'' jewelry.

title: A Decade of TV Finds a Home
description: The stuff of drama - over 24,000 scripts of prime-time network fiction broadcast since 1976 - is in residence at the University of Pennsylvania's Annenberg School of Communications in Philadelphia.

title: Washington Federal Savings & Loan Assn (DC) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Electromedics Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $157,399 from the conversion of debentures. c-Net income

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, APRIL 12, 1988
description: Companies

title: Park Communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Neiman Shifts Key Executives
description: The Neiman-Marcus Group, a leading specialty retailer spun off last September by Carter Hawley Hale Stores, has moved to coordinate its major businesses by naming Ira Neimark, chairman and chief executive of its Bergdorf Goodman subsidiary, to the additional post of vice president of merchandise development for the Neiman-Marcus Group.

title: F.A.A. Details Rules Of Smoking Ban in Air
description: The airline smoking ban that goes into effect April 23 on commercial planes will apply to any flight scheduled for two hours or less even if delays cause it to take longer, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: Talking Business; with Smith of Interfaith Center; Companies Face The Social Issues
description: As the busiest time for corporate annual meetings arrives, scores of companies will be facing shareholder resolutions dealing with a variety of social issues.

title: BSD Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter net is restated to reflect the adoption of FASB Statement No. 91, which affects the company's loan-fee accounting policy. Year-ago first quarter earnings were originally reported as $240,000, or 7 cents per share.

title: Forecasts From Flakes
description: Several dozen volunteers in and near Denver have been using hand-held microscopes to examine snowflakes during snowstorms in an effort to improve the ability to forecast the severity of snowfalls. The purpose of the study is test the theory that large, star-shaped flakes indicate heavy snow accumulations, while granular flakes frosted with tiny accumulations of ice known as graupel, indicate a lesser snowfall.

title: Testing an Iron Fist
description: Since the Senate passed a landmark banking bill last month that will reorder the regulatory structure of banking and securities underwriting, the House has come under pressure to pass its own legislation.

title: J.&J. Ends Playtex Talks
description: Johnson & Johnson said today that it had ended negotiations to acquire Playtex Family Products.

title: Patterns
description: The Price of Mink Prices for mink coats, which are pivotal to the fur industry, are on a roller-coaster ride. They rose sharply last winter, and are expected to fall just as fast in the winter ahead.

title: Machine Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes tax credits of $16,000 for the quarter and $30,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Museum to Display Working Model of Atom
description: THE New York Hall of Science has created what its director believes to be the world's first realistic working model of an atom.

title: Article 813588 -- No Title
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, seeking to raise capital, announced yesterday that it would sell its consumer finance subsidiary to the American General Corporation, a Houston-based financial services and insurance company, for $705 million in cash and cash dividends.

title: European Research Plan
description: Research ministers of the European Community agreed today to spend $2 billion in the next five years on research in information technology. The plan, called Esprit II, is intended to help European companies compete with those from the United States and Japan. A community official said the program, which involves 5,500 researchers from 12 countries, would represent a third of European basic research in information technology.

title: Suspect in 2 Killings Seized in Routine Check
description: Stopping a pick-up truck on the Lower East Side as part of a routine anti-drug operation Sunday night, the police said they found a former convict suspected of killing two co-workers and injuring two other people at an archeological site near Philadelphia.

title: 'The Last Emperor' Wins 9 Oscars And Is Named Best Film of 1987
description: ''The Last Emperor,'' an epic retelling of the life of Pu Yi, who became emperor of China as a 3-year-old boy and died a simple gardener, swept its way to nine Academy Awards tonight, including best picture, director, and screenplay adaptation. Bernardo Bertolucci, the first Italian to win the Oscar as best director, shared the screenplay prize with Mark Peploe.

title: Police Discover 2 Women Slain In Apartments
description: The bodies of two women, their throats slashed, were found by the police yesterday in their apartments in two separate neighborhoods in Queens, but the police did not believe the killings were related.

title: Subway Theft Case Dropped in Dispute on Arrest
description: A judge yesterday dismissed a larceny case against a man who had already served two years in prison, convicted in part by the testimony of a former Transit Authority police officer who is accused of making false arrests.

title: Dole Returns to Senate Duties
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas returned to his Capitol duties today after months on the Presidential campaign trail, and he made clear that he wants to keep his job as Senate Republican leader.

title: Dow Jones Net Up by 55.3%
description: Dow Jones & Company, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, Barron's and other publications, said yesterday that its net income rose 55.3 percent in the first quarter of 1988, to $103.6 million, or $1.08 a share, compared with $66.7 million, or 69 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues rose 37.4 percent, to $392.5 million, from $285.6 million a year earlier.

title: New York's Mayor Needs a Mandate
description: Governing New York City is hard enough. A mischievous bill gaining momentum in the Legislature could make the job even tougher. It would tamper with the city's runoff election system.

title: Cuba Still Pan Am Site
description: The president of the Pan American Sports Organization has said that he thinks the 1991 Pan American Games will remain in Havana.

title: Bertolucci Wins the Battle of Foreign Directors
description: From the beginning, Hollywood has welcomed foreigners. The first Academy Award for best actor 60 years ago went to a German, Emil Jannings, and the parade of directors fleeing Nazi Europe - Billy Wilder, Michael Curtiz, Ernst Lubitsch, Fred Zinnemann - certainly enriched the American postwar film industry. Then, of course, there was the venerated Alfred Hitchcock, who was British.

title: Sports People; Stadium Display
description: As part of its bid to become the host country for the 1994 World Cup soccer tournament, the United States yesterday began a weeklong display of its soccer facilities to five members of a technical-inspection group from the Federation Internationale de Football Association, the international governing body of soccer.

title: Vipont Pharmaceutical reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax loss carryforwards of $261,700 for the quarter and $588,200 for the 6 months. c-After tax loss carryforwards of $223,400 for the quarter and $381,800 for the 6 months.

title: Oil Prices Surge as OPEC Asks Non-Members to Talks
description: Oil prices rose sharply yesterday on news that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would meet with other oil producers to discuss restricting production in an effort to secure higher prices.

title: Georgia to Bar Executions of Retarded Killers
description: Under a new law that takes effect in the summer, Georgia will prohibit the execution of murderers found ''guilty but mentally retarded.''

title: Shearson Defends Koppers Role
description: The Koppers Corporation's battle against the $1.69 billion hostile takeover offer from Beazer P.L.C. of Britain came to Capitol Hill today, with several senators criticizing the roles of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. and its parent, the American Express Company, in the deal.

title: Fashion; The Blass Brand of Casual Chic
description: A lavish sable collar framed the neckline of an amethyst-blue velour bathrobe worn over a plum-colored T-shirt and darker plum trousers. A tailored cashmere jacket swung casually over a cashmere sweater and lace trousers embroidered in jet beads.

title: McGraw-Hill Acquisition
description: McGraw Hill Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the scientific and technical book unit of Macmillan Inc. Terms were not disclosed. The book unit has more than 200 scientific and technical titles that are geared to the university, graduate and professional markets. They will be part of the McGraw-Hill Book Company's college, professional and international group.

title: I.M.F. Planning to Help Victims of High Rates
description: The International Monetary Fund's 151 member governments have completed negotiations on a new contingency lending facility to assist countries hit by such adverse circumstances as sustained higher interest rates or destructive droughts.

title: U.S. Assailed at World Court on P.L.O. Office
description: The United States was formally accused today before the World Court of breaking its obligations under international law by enacting legislation to close the Palestine Liberation Organization observer mission to the United Nations.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the income tax returns of President and Mrs. Reagan misstated a provision of the new tax law. Taxpayers over 65 years old no longer get an extra exemption; there is a larger standard deduction for those in that age group, but those who itemize their deductions, like the Reagans, get no extra benefit.

title: Sanofi Lifts Stake In Perfume Maker
description: The French pharmaceutical group Sanofi said it had acquired a 30 percent stake in Parfums Nina Ricci Paris, increasing its holdings to 38 percent. Sanofi did not disclose the price it paid for the perfume company's shares. Parfums Nina Ricci Paris draws 70 to 80 percent of its income from manufacturing scents. It also has French and foreign subsidiaries, including the ready-to-wear fashion house Couture Nina Ricci.

title: As Costs Appreciate, Colleagues Appreciate Help
description: It arrived in several hundred thousand households across the the United States, neatly folded in a large envelope that bore a Washington return address and the cryptic teaser: ''Why I'm sending you a yarmulke.''

title: Art Scholar Guilty in Sale Of Letters
description: An art scholar and biographer was found guilty in Federal District Court here today of transporting stolen historic documents, including letters from Abraham Lincoln and Winston Churchill, that belonged to the National Archives and the Library of Congress.

title: 8 ARABS DEPORTED TO SOUTH LEBANON BY ISRAELI ORDER
description: Israel expelled 8 Palestinians to southern Lebanon today and ordered the deportations of 12 others.

title: Raves For New Hub's Amenities
description: ''It's gorgeous,'' exclaimed Debbie Williams as she and her husband sat in the new American Airlines terminal here, with its wide walkways and simple decor.

title: Sutter's Instinct Rescues Islanders
description: For a moment, Brent Sutter, the consummate team player, forgot about his team, and in that moment he became the second player in National Hockey League history to seal a playoff victory with a short-handed goal in overtime.

title: Agents Used Copter Gust to Set Up Shot at Suspect
description: An F.B.I. marksman waited until a kidnapper was knocked down by wind from a helicopter rotor, separating him from the child he was carrying, before firing the shot that killed the fugitive, agents said today.

title: Beijing Journal; From the Ivory Tower, a Chorus of Dissonance
description: China's most prestigious institution of higher learning, Beijing University, is grappling with discontent among teachers and students over the school's austere living conditions and, more broadly, the country's basic educational policies.

title: A Talmud In Modern English
description: Random House plans to publish the Talmud in stages in a modern English translation that will make the 1,500-year-old compilation of Jewish oral law, legends and philosophy both more understandable and more widely accessible to the English-speaking world.

title: Murder Suspect Flees in Van
description: The police searched today for a 27-year-old murder suspect who drove off in a van after his guards went into a store and left the keys in the ignition. Richard Lacy Letner Jr., charged in the murder of a California nurse, kicked out a window in the back of the van and drove away in handcuffs Sunday afternoon. The suspect drove a block before unlocking his shackles and fleeing on foot, the police said. The suspect had been captured in Iowa and was being returned to California.

title: World History, as Tree Rings Tell It, Gains Accuracy
description: Recent studies of tree rings in Europe and the United States have given scientists astonishingly precise new gauges for reconstructing the history of volcanoes, climate and human endeavor in the last 8,500 years.

title: Results Plus
description: Horse Racing Hometown Queen Is First: Loblolly Stable's Hometown Queen rallied wide in the stretch for a 4 1/2-length victory yesterday in the $33,000 Striking Purse for fillies and mares at Aqueduct, giving the Jose Santos his third winning ride of the day. Antique Mystique ran second, two lengths in front of favored My Heroine. The winner, a 4-year-old daughter of Pleasant Colony, was timed in 1:23 4/5 for the seven furlongs and paid $5 for $2 to win.(AP) Tennis Nystrom Upset in France: Jan Gunnarsson of Sweden upset Joakim Nystrom in the first round yesterday in the $145,000 Nice Open in France. Gunnarsson, ranked 57th in the world, ran off nine games in a row at one point to defeat second-seeded Nystrom, also of Sweden, 7-5, 6-3. Gunnarsson will meet Guillermo Vilas of Argentina in the second round. Vilas was a 6-3, 6-1 winner over Andreas Maurer of West Germany. Seventh-seeded Jim Pugh also lost in the first round. Karel Novacek of Czechoslovakia beat the American, 6-3, 7-6. Ronald Agenor of Haiti, seeded fifth, easily defeated Jaro Navratil of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 6-2. In other first-round action, Horst Skoff of Austria defeated Ricki Ostherthun of West Germany, 7-6, 6-3; Tore Meinecke of West Germany downed Josef Cihak of Czechoslovakia, 6-2, 7-6; Libor Pimek of Czechoslovakia whipped Yaya Doumbia of Senegal, 6-4, 6-0; and Niclas Kroon of Sweden beat Florin Segarceanu of Rumania, 6-0, 6-4. (AP)

title: Pilots Call Air Travel Less Safe
description: More than two-thirds of pilots responding to a survey said flying had become more dangerous in the 10 years since the industry was deregulated, but many stressed they continue to regard it as the safest way to travel.

title: Education Aid A Major Hurdle In Budget Talks
description: Eleven days after New York State was supposed to have a new budget, Democrats and Republicans remained deadlocked today, forcing some school districts to scramble for loans to replace $1.5 billion in state aid they expected to receive this week.

title: Ex-Wife Calls Le Pen A Raving Anti-Semite
description: The former wife of Jean-Marie Le Pen, leader of the ultra-right National Front, has made a new series of embarrassing allegations about the presidential candidate just as his standing in the polls appears to be on the rise.

title: Devils' Lapse in 3d Erases Series Lead
description: Doug Brown's goal late in the second period Sunday night, like so many of the Devils' goals, came as the result of collective industry and individual opportunism. It was hardly unique, but the position it left the Devils in clearly was.

title: Rules on Federal Drug Tests
description: The Department of Health and Human Services published guidelines today for the clinical procedures that Federal agencies must follow in testing employees for drug use.

title: 2 Kirov Stars to Dance With Ballet Theater
description: Altynai Assylmuratova and Faruk Ruzimatov, principal dancers with the Kirov Ballet in Leningrad, will appear as guest artists with the American Ballet Theater during the company's 1988 spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Ballet Theater announced yesterday. This will be the first time that dancers from the Soviet Union have performed with the company.

title: Bush's Pal
description: Few people doubt that Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d will leave the Administration to work full time in the Presidential campaign of his buddy of 30 years, tennis partner and fellow Texan, Vice President Bush. Not even Mr. Baker seems to doubt it.

title: Nobel Winner Is Caught Up In a Dispute Over Study
description: Seventeen pages of private laboratory notes that fell into the hands of an obscure junior scientist have set off a bitter dispute over the accuracy of a scientific paper whose authors included a Nobel Prize winner, Dr. David Baltimore of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: A Prelude to Peace in Afghanistan
description: Secretary of State Shultz will fly to Geneva this week for the signing of the Afghanistan accord, which promises a withdrawal of 115,000 Soviet troops. The agreement is historic, and probably the best that could be expected of an intricate and messy war. But it offers not peace, only the prelude to a peace. Should the Russians go home before the 10 months stipulated, the belligerents would still have ample arms to keep fighting - and the hope of further arms if the deal goes sour.

title: Rightist Gain Could Be the Making of Salvador; Murder With Impunity
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Q. What would happen to a person who died in space? And how would fertilization, gestation and birth in space differ from what would happen on Earth? A. In effect, a person who died in the icy vacuum of space would be freeze-dried, space experts theorize. The water in the body would freeze and eventually dissipate into space.

title: U.S. Attacks Drug Suppliers But Loses Battle of the Users
description: The Federal Government's programs to control drug abuse are failing because they emphasize a futile crackdown on suppliers while neglecting the more important task of weaning the American public from its habits, according to a range of experts in the drug fight.

title: Dutch to Defy Beckett On Women in 'Godot'
description: A Dutch theater has said it will defy a ban by the playwright Samuel Beckett on women performing his play ''Waiting for Godot.''

title: Rex Reed Enters Plea Of Guilty to Trying To Evade State Tax
description: The movie critic Rex Reed pleaded guilty today to charges of attempted state-tax evasion in a dispute he attributed to faulty advice from his former accountant.

title: Bridge
description: One of the world's great players made a rare appearance in the New York metropolitan region during the weekend and added to his large collection of titles.

title: DNA and Crime: Identification From a Single Hair
description: SCIENTISTS have successfully analyzed traces of DNA from single human hairs in research expected to have important applications in crime detection and many other areas.

title: Ardshiel Chief's Path Took Many Turns
description: Ardshiel Inc., a small New York-based investment banking firm, has maintained a low profile despite the colorful career of its chairman and president, Henry Brown Turner.

title: Where the Candidates Are Today
description: Schedules subject to change. 10 to 11:30 A.M.: The three Democratic candidates are to take part in a televised debate, sponsored by The Daily News, at the Felt Forum in Manhattan. Attendance is by invitation only but Channel 13 will broadcast it live. 7 P.M.: The three men will meet again at a National Women's Political Caucus Presidential Forum. Borough of Manhattan Community College, Theater No. 1, 199 Chambers Street. Michael S. Dukakis 3:30 P.M.: Meets working mothers, Ryan Community Health Center, 160 West 100th Street, Manhattan. 6:10 P.M.: Women's rally, Insurance College, 101 Murray Street, Manhattan. Jesse Jackson 12:30 P.M.: Latinos For Jackson rally. James Monroe High School, 172d Street and Boynton Avenue, the Bronx. 9 P.M.: Rally at Co-op City. Murray Lerner Auditorium, Co-op City, 177 Dreiser Loop, the Bronx.

title: 1,000 Are Arrested by Police In Los Angeles Gang Sweep
description: The police arrested more than 1,000 people in a weekend offensive against drug dealers and street gangs.

title: Chess
description: Jan Timman made light work of the Linares International Tournament in Spain. The 36-year-old Dutch grandmaster achieved an 8 1/2-2 1/2 score to put a point-and-a-half distance between himself and the field.

title: Knicks Win in Overtime
description: In recent weeks, Coach Rick Pitino has been using Patrick Ewing and Bill Cartwright, his 7-foot centers, together more and more.

title: Metromedia's Orion Stake
description: The Metromedia Company has increased its stake in the Orion Pictures Company to 44.1 percent, from 39.5 percent, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Advertising; Moonlight Musk Drive Heats Up
description: MOONLIGHT MUSK, a cologne for the under-25 single woman that has done surprisingly well in mass merchandisers' outlets without national advertising, will be supported by a magazine campaign for the first time next fall. Great things are expected at the home office.

title: Mitterrand Above the Campaign Trail
description: Punctually, just in time to appear live on the 8 o'clock evening news programs, Francois Mitterrand materialized at the back of the vast tent and, with a fluttering spotlight tracking his progress, threaded his way past 20,000 jubilant partisans to a stage festooned with 46 blue, white and red flags.

title: NBC News Still Has Money Worries
description: Last week, NBC News, which is the least cost-effective of the three major broadcast news operations, received a jolting reminder of corporate expectations in this age of cost efficiency. At an NBC management seminar in Scottsdale, Ariz., it was suggested that one way to assure economic success for the company was to eliminate NBC News.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some editions yesterday above a news analysis article about a Pulitzer Prize controversy misstated the subject of the dispute, between The Philadelphia Inquirer and The National Journal, a weekly magazine. The publications have differed about the originality of The Inquirer's winning reporting, not about a source. Later developments are reported today on page C20.

title: U.S. Judge Bars Use of Strychnine as Rodent Bait
description: A Federal District judge enjoined Federal officials today from continuing to allow farmers and ranchers to use the poison strychnine as a rodent bait when it poses a threat to bald eagles, wolves, grizzly bears, migratory waterfowl and other protected wildlife species.

title: First Financial Management reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Brawley Aunt Seized On Shoplifting Charge
description: Tawana Brawley's aunt, who was arrested on shoplifting and bad check charges Saturday, said today that the police were harrassing her in order to force her and her family to cooperate in the Brawley investigation.

title: Quest for Lean Meat Prompts New Approach
description: SCIENTISTS say the nation is on the verge of a new agricultural revolution, a radical approach to livestock production involving the manipulation of the animals' own hormones to produce cheaper and more nutritious meat and dairy products. If the new methods are widely adopted, as farm experts say they must be for reasons of health and economics, they will yield animal products that are richer in proteins but lower in fats and calories. Unlike previous changes in farm animals achieved through decades of painstaking genetic selection and cross-breeding, the new approach could transform food animals virtually overnight by manipulating their natural hormones and other body chemicals that regulate growth. The manipulations would influence the animals' use of nutrients in feed.

title: Meese Sought to Hire Friend Until Official Word of Inquiry
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d asked a longtime friend if he was interested in taking a key Justice Department post a week or so before being notified formally that the friend was under investigation in the Wedtech scandal, a lawyer for Mr. Meese said today.

title: Small Gains By Area Stores
description: The retail sales of large New York stores in March showed a modest average gain of 4.5 percent from the month a year earlier, a spot-check has found.

title: Sudbury Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $963,000.

title: Willy Schaeffler, Skiing Coach, 72
description: Willy Schaeffler, who coached the 1972 United States Olympic ski team and won 13 National Collegiate Athletic Association skiing titles as coach at the University of Denver, died Saturday. He was 72 years old. Mr. Schaeffler helped to found the Special Olympics and the Professional Ski Instructors of America.

title: Phone Book For the PC
description: HERE we are in the first paragraph, and we need to look up a telephone number. Normally we'd put the writing on hold, dig under a few inches of press releases to find the local telephone book, flip back and forth for a while trying to look up the area code for Kirkland, Wash., -oops, no listing, so let's try Seattle -call directory assistance and ask for the number of General Information Inc. The computerized voice would drone out the number and we'd jot it down on a scrap of paper. We would punch the numbers onto the telephone - oops, misdial, let's start again -and get a busy signal.

title: Casino Express: Bus Trip for the Spirit
description: It was a Wednesday, and bus 578 was chugging down Second Avenue. Bertha was on it ''because it's cheaper than going to a psychiatrist.'' Helen was there ''because it's better than sitting home.'' Josephine, a retired seamstress, turned the question around: ''Why not?''

title: Rightist Gain Could Be the Making of Salvador
description: To the Editor:

title: Cannon Group Details A Reorganization Plan
description: Cannon Group Inc. said today that, as part of a proposed reorganization, its European stockholders had agreed to inject at least $100 million into the company in the next year and to arrange for a $100 million credit line.

title: Financial Listings Expanded
description: Beginning today, The New York Times is significantly expanding the financial statistical data published Tuesday through Saturday.

title: With Calm, Lyle Storms to the Top
description: Sandy Lyle pulled himself together after nearly falling apart around Amen Corner, then dug himself out of a bunker with one of the more memorable major-tournament shots to win the 52d Masters on Sunday. With the victory, Lyle suddenly stood alone as the premier golfer in the world.

title: Rig Count Off in Week
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States dropped by 25 last week, to 916, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. The rig count, a widely watched industry index of drilling activity, stood at 749 a year ago.

title: Pulitzer Board Affirms Prize to Inquirer
description: The executive committee of the Pulitzer Prize Board unanimously reaffirmed yesterday the Pulitzer awarded 10 days ago to The Philadelphia Inquirer after considering a challenge to the award by The National Journal.

title: Compaq Forecast
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said its earnings and sales for the first fiscal quarter should exceed both the period a year earlier and the forecasts made by analysts. The portable-computer maker said it expected to report sales of more than $425 million, compared with predictions of $360 million to $390 million. Compaq earned 56 cents a share on sales of $211 million in the first quarter of 1987. Compaq's stock jumped $2 today, to $54.75 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Success Seen For Trade Bill Despite a Veto
description: Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, suggested today that Congress could override a veto if President Reagan rejected the trade bill that is nearing completion.

title: Albany Bill Again Asks A Stadium Alcohol Curb
description: A bill to establish no-drinking sections at each of New York State's major professional sports arenas was introduced today in the State Senate, a year after a similar effort collapsed in the face of opposition from the Yankees and the Mets.

title: Japan Reports Trade Status
description: Japan'sj trade surplus continued to decline last month from levels a year earlier, but it widened from February's figure, the Finance Ministry announced todya.

title: Review/Dance; A Finnish Flourish
description: Finland's opera singers, especially its fabulous basses, are renowned the world over. Not so its ballet dancers, although a few were able in the past to establish independent careers and reputations by going abroad or appearing as guests with foreign companies.

title: Mary Hill Fried, Writer, 74
description: Mary Hill Fried, a writer, an artist and a founder of the American Carousel Association, died of cancer of the liver and colon Thursday at Doctors Hospital. She was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Talking Pardons, Unforgivably Early
description: Richard Nixon, in television interviews promoting his new book, is offering advice about Presidential pardons. He's certainly an authority of sorts, having received American history's most famous pardon from President Gerald Ford. Mr. Nixon regrets not having pardoned his own top aides before they were tried for Watergate crimes. Now he suggests that President Reagan should, before leaving office, pardon his indicted former aides if he concludes they lacked criminal ''intent'' in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Arizona's Elliott To Stay in School
description: Sean Elliott, the all-America junior, announced today that he would stay at Arizona for his final year, ending speculation that he would pass up his final season of college eligibility and instead make himself available for the National Basketball Association draft.

title: Reynold E. Church, Surgeon, 85
description: Dr. Reynold E. Church, a New York surgeon, died of a heart attack last Tuesday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 85 years old.

title: Sheldahl Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,004,000 from termination of a pension plan for both the quarter and 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $168,000 for the quarter and $101,000 for the 6 months.

title: Merrill Lynch Net Fell 37.1% in First Period
description: Merrill Lynch & Company reported yesterday that earnings for the first three months of 1988 totaled $68.3 million, or 62 cents a share. The profit was 37.1 percent lower than that reported in the comparable period a year ago, which occurred during the bull market surge and was the third strongest in Merrill's recent history.

title: Prison Health Agency Assailed in New York
description: Finding ''major problems'' in New York City's prison health services, a city consultant has called for revamping the agency. He has also proposed replacing the ''antiquated'' infirmary on Rikers Island and eventually tripling its capacity to meet the rising inmate population and AIDS caseload.

title: New Drug Therapy Blocks Severe Jaundice in Infants
description: PRELIMINARY tests indicate that a new drug prevents severe jaundice in newborn babies, a common problem that, if not rapidly reversed, can result in brain damage.

title: Books of The Times; The Mystery and the Fullness of Life
description: The Death of Methuselah And Other Stories By Isaac Bashevis Singer 244 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: Telerate Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in October 1987. The company also said the net income figure for the latest first quarter was slightly diluted by the October 1987 acquisition of CMQ Communications Inc. of Canada; the effect on the year as a whole will not be dilutive.

title: Baseball; Pirates Top Phillies; Set Crowd Record
description: Barry Bonds tripled and scored in the first inning and hit a home run in the third, and Mike LaValliere had a three-run double as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-1, tonight before the largest home crowd in Pirates' history.

title: Golf Paints a Pretty Picture for Viewers
description: NO sport looks prettier on television than golf. And no golf course has the magic of Augusta National. The essence of the sport - hitting that small ball, then walking after it amid the dogwood and azaleas, taking gulps of fresh air - was captured once again by CBS over the weekend. It helps that the producer-director, Frank Chirkinian, lives in Augusta, plays golf there, and has been doing the event for 30 straight years.

title: F.T.C. Ruling On Reynolds
description: The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the reinstatement of a complaint against an R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company advertisement that played down the health hazard from smoking.

title: Farmers and Batus May Hold Talks
description: Farmers Group Inc. said it was willing to hold acquisition talks with Batus Inc., which has offered $4.5 billion, or $63 a share, for the company. The Los Angeles-based insurer said it was continuing to hold talks with an unidentified third party over a possible leveraged buyout. But Farmers said it would now release confidential corporate information to Batus, a subsidiary of the British tobacco conglomerate B.A.T. Industries.

title: Desert Partners Expands USG Bid
description: Desert Partners, a group led by the Texas oilmen Jack E. Brown and Cyril Wagner Jr., said that it had expanded its tender offer for the USG Corporation to 39 million shares from 21 million. The partnership, which made its $42-a-share offer for the nation's largest gypsum producer on Feb. 24, also extended the offer to midnight on April 22. About 12.6 million shares, or 25 percent of USG's common stock outstanding, had been tendered through last Friday, Desert Partners said.

title: Dauphin Deposit reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results for both periods reflect the acquisition of Colonial Bancorp in the third quarter of 1987.

title: Dukakis Fund-Raiser Draws About 200 at $1,000 a Ticket
description: Stepping from an elevator into the foyer of an opulent Fifth Avenue apartment last night, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts found himself in a crush of 200 supporters at a $1,000-a-ticket fund-raiser.

title: Jewelcor Accepts Buyout Proposal
description: The board of Jewelcor Inc. said it had accepted a $19-a-share leveraged buyout proposal from a management group led by Seymour Holtzman, the jewelry company's chief executive, and First Boston Inc. Mr. Holtzman is also Jewelcor's largest shareholder, controlling 23.7 percent of the 3.2 million shares outstanding. The total value of the proposed leveraged buyout, minus Mr. Holtzman's current holdings, is about $46 million in cash.

title: Irving Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the higher earnings enabled the corporation to recognize $12.3 million in tax benefits related to the special LDC provisions for credit losses taken in 1987. Partially offsetting these favorable factors was an increase in noninterest expenses.

title: Italy Finds Accord on New Government
description: Prime Minister-designate Ciriaco de Mita said today that he had reached agreement on a coalition to form Italy's 48th postwar Government and end a month-long political crisis.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * The Record, a New Jersey newspaper, to Justamere Advertising.

title: International Paper Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Airline Deregulation Creates Massive Problems; Discomfort at Airports
description: To the Editor:

title: Arizona's Supreme Court Blocks A Special Gubernatorial Election
description: The Arizona Supreme Court ordered the cancellation today of the May 17 gubernatorial recall election because its target, former Gov. Evan Mecham, has been impeached and removed from office.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Dismissed Cal Ripken Sr. as manager. Named Frank Robinson manager. Sent Jim Traber, first baseman-outfielder, outright to Rochester of the International League. Purchased the contract of Tito Landrum, outfielder, from Rochester. TORONTO (AL) - Placed Rance Mulliniks, third baseman, on the 15-day disabled list. Activated Manny Lee, infielder, from the 15-day disabled list. ATLANTA (NL) - Placed Chuck Cary, pitcher, on the 21-day disabled list. Recalled Gary Eave, pitcher, from Richmond of the International League. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Placed Mike Dunne, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list. Purchased the contract of Miguel Garcia, pitcher, from Buffalo of the American Association. BASKETBALL ROCHESTER (CBA) - Named Scott Carlin head coach. YOUNGSTOWN (IBA) - Signed Bill Toole, guard. FOOTBALL SAN DIEGO (AFC) - Acquired Mark Malone, quarterback, from the Pittsburgh Steelers for a 1988 eighth-round draft choice and a conditional pick in 1989. COLLEGES EASTERN KENTUCKY - Named Larry Joe Inman woman's basketball coach. U.C.L.A. - Named Jim Harrick head basketball coach. WEST VIRGINIA - Named Shelly Poe sports-information director.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 13, 1988
description: COMPANIES First Republicbank predicted a loss of $1.5 billion for the first quarter, mainly because of increased reserves for troubled real estate loans. The amount, which stunned analysts, would be the second-highest quarterly loss in banking history. First Republicbank also named a new chairman and chief executive. [ Page D1. ] With Texas savings institutions losing $7 million a day, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board is being urged to move immediately to close or merge dozens of failed associations. [ D2. ] The F.A.A. ordered all Boeing 747-200 jets to be examined promptly for defects that could lead to fires. Boeing admitted that the 747 and 767 jets have technical problems. [ A17. ] Westinghouse sold a 45 percent stake in its power-distribution business to Asea Brown Boveri for $500 million. [ D4. ] Coca-Cola and CPC International reported higher profits, crediting strong overseas sales. [ D4. ] MARKETS Oil prices reached their highest level since early December, at $18.09 for West Texas Intermediate, as the market continued to react to news about OPEC's efforts to limit supplies. [ D1. ] Stock prices gained for the sixth day in a row, but trading was again subdued. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 14.09 points, to 2,110.08, setting another post-crash high. [ D1. ] The dollar rose in quiet trading. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold closed at $450.90 an ounce, down $1.90. [ D18. ] Treasury prices rose modestly, helped by a stronger dollar and arbitrage-related buying after a note auction. [ D15. ] A new N.A.S.D. report seeks public disclosure of the records of stockbrokers who have violated securities regulations. [ D7. ] THE ECONOMY New York has reached its highest office vacancy level in a decade - about 13 percent, real estate executives say. [ B1. ] An extra deposit insurance premium would be phased out in the savings industry over four years, but only for the healthiest institutions, under a new Federal proposal. [ D2. ] Three Democratic Presidential candidates are urging the preservation of a trade-bill provision requiring companies to warn of plant shutdowns or layoffs, despite the White House's threat of a veto. The move by Michael S. Dukakis, Albert Gore Jr. and Jesse L. Jackson could make the provision an election issue. [ D7. ] The dean of the Columbia Business School stepped down in a dispute over faculty hiring. [ D1. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS I.B.M. has assigned some advertising business to the agency formed by six top executives who left Lord, Geller. But it said the bulk of its advertising remains with Lord, Geller. I.B.M. provides half the agency's billings. [ D1. ] Lorimar-Telepictures said it had broken off merger talks with Warner Communications. [ D16. ] Affirmation of a $3 million libel award has produced talk of an increase in libel suits and a chilling effect on reporting. [ D16. ] HDM, a joint-venture agency with about $1.4 billion in billings, takes a global approach. Advertising. [ D17. ] TECHNOLOGY The U.S. issued the world's first patent for a higher form of life, a genetically altered mouse created by Harvard researchers. [ A1. ] High-definition videotape technology is beginning to replace 35-millimeter film because it is cheaper and easier to edit, but its real impact will be in improving the quality of television. [ D6. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The case against index arbitrage is soft. While investors may see the strategies as making shares riskier, this is slippery ground for anchoring of regulation. Peter Passell. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] The reluctance of many investors to buy or sell is increasing the volatility of stock. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Food Notes
description: From Long Island

title: Bhopal Hearing Delayed
description: District Court Judge M. W. Deo canceled today's hearing on the Bhopal gas disaster, the United News of India reported, but set an April 23 deadline for outlining a hearing schedule in the case. Lawyers for both the Union Carbide Corporation and India's Government said they had not yet received copies of a higher court's ruling on Judge Deo's order that Carbide pay interim relief to victims.

title: First Peoples Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credit from tax benefits of $962,000 and $910,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: Computer Research Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The company said the latest quarter share earnings equals less than one cent a share.

title: Nichols Institute reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $210,000 from an accounting change.

title: How Not to Stop China's Brain Drain
description: In 1979, determined to bring China into the modern world, Deng Xiaoping began sending bright students to learn abroad. Now China's leaders have apparently concluded that not all the new ideas thus gained are attractive and that not all the students will be returning. The leadership has sharply cut back the program. Such pinched timidity can only set back the course of reform.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-15 Hijackers released 12 hostages from a Kuwaiti jet and flew to Algeria with 38 hostages. They said they would keep the plane until Kuwait releases 17 Moslem fundamentalists being held for terrorist acts. Page A1 An accused hijacker of a TWA plane, Mohammed Hamadei, was under 21 during the planning of the 1985 hijacking, a West German court ruled. It sent the case to juvenile court to decide whether he would be tried as an adult. A8 El Salvador's rightist opposition, Arena, arguing that an official electoral count has defrauded it of a majority in Parliament, asked the nation's Supreme Court to nullify the election results. A3 American interests in Honduras have been harmed by Honduran frustrations over Washington's policies, experts say. The decision to hand over a drug trafficker to the United States touched off violence at the U.S. Embassy. A10 New Government leaders in China, slightly younger and better educated than the previous ones, were approved by parliament, which also granted constitutional protection to private enterprise. A3 Family planning in Colombia has overcome Government and church resistance to promote contraception for women. One group now is promoting vasectomies for couples who want no more children. A14 Senegal has emerged as a source of illegal immigrants to the United States. U.S. consular officials are scrutinizing more closely, and often rejecting, the requests of West Africans to come to America. A15 U.S. marine slain in Panama A3 Seoul journal: A Kim tumbles from the ranks of angels A4 40 wounded in Palestinian protests A6 Israelis to attend Warsaw ghetto rites A8 National A16-25 Robert C. Byrd will step down as Senate majority leader at the end of the year. Mr. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, said he would not leave the Senate and would run for re-election this year. A1 A patent for a higher form of life was issued for the first time for a genetically altered mouse used in studies on cancer development. The Government issued patent 4,736,866 to Harvard University. A1 The rise of Cuban-Americans to prominence in Miami will become even more pronounced as the second generation comes of age. Cuban-Americans this year are marking the 30th anniversary of Fidel Castro's revolution. A1 Use of sign language and speech in an address by Marlee Matlin, a deaf actress, has prompted debate within the deaf community. Miss Matlin's decision to speak at the Academy Awards angered some. A16 Safety complaints about Boeing jets have prompted the Federal Aviation Administration to order all 593 Boeing 747-200 passenger planes now operating to be examined for defects that could cause fires. A17 Dublin journal: Ugly words over beautification ordinance A16 House panel asks review of nuclear fusion efforts A17 Politics A24-25 Democratic Presidential candidates politicked for votes in Brooklyn, at a high school in the Bronx and at fund-raising affairs in Manhattan with a week to go before the New York primary. A1 Public emphasis on the drug issue is being used by Democratic Presidential candidates to demonstrate toughness on foreign policy. Voters rate the Reagan Administration's drug efforts as a failure, a survey showed. A25 Washington Talk A18 Civil rights panel battles some it would help Regional B1-5 Compromise on the Indian museum was reached between Congress and New York officials. The Museum of the American Indian will move to lower Manhattan. Its building in Washington Heights will become a branch. A1 The Indian museum's collection of artifacts of the Western Hemisphere has been stored largely out of public view, with less than 1 percent of its one million pieces of pottery, clothing and weapons on display. B4 The Williamsburg Bridge was closed to all traffic for two to three weeks on the recommendation of New York City engineers who are inspecting structural weaknesses in the bridge, officials announced. A1 Office vacancies in New York City have reached their highest level in a decade, according to real-estate executives. Staff cutbacks by banks and investment houses have contributed to the drop in occupancy rates. B1 A retirement party for a bus driver is being given by the Transit Authority. Passengers who have written letters praising Govan Brown, a New York City bus driver for 20 years, and his fellow drivers will attend. B1 News analysis: Campaign financing is under scrutiny in New York because of excesses. But the campaign-finance system requires politicians to raise large sums of money to attract the attention of voters. B1 Connecticut's Republican Senator, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., has inched further to the left as his party has shifted to the right. Seeking election to a fourth term, he has become the G.O.P.'s odd man out. B1 A new bill on garbage disposal, agreed to by state leaders, will require New Yorkers to separate recyclable materials from the rest of their garbage by 1992. But it may not solve the state's solid-waste crisis. B2 Senate Republicans clash on Albany budget B2 Group for elderly gays celebrates its anniversary Party B3 Man held in kidnap of witness to Bronx attack B3 Political influence issue raised on Wedtech B3

title: Pacer Having Rough Season
description: At this point last season, Chuck Person of the Indiana Pacers was headed for rookie-of-the-year honors with no challengers in sight, much like Mark Jackson of the Knicks this season. Person was to the Pacers what Walt Frazier used to be to the Knicks when Red Holzman would refer to him as ''my main man.''

title: JET LEAVES CYPRUS TO LAND IN ALGIERS
description: Eight days after it was hijacked, a Kuwaiti airliner took off early today for Algeria, leaving behind 12 freed hostages. [ The Kuwaiti jet landed at the Algiers airport after a nearly four-hour flight, Reuters reported from Algiers. [ The Associated Press said the pilot said by radio to the control tower, ''The terrorists demand that all vehicles be removed from the vicinity of the airplane.'' Several trucks that had approached the plane pulled back. ] Before taking off from Cyprus, a hijacker radioed a message stating: ''We maintain our demands. We insist we will hold onto the plane until martyrdom.'' The hijackers' principal demand is for the release of 17 Moslem fundamentalists held in Kuwaiti jails for terrorist activities.

title: Material Sciences Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
