Split Senate Panel Refuses to Back Sanctions Against Mexico
description: A bitterly divided Senate Foreign Relations Committee refused today to recommend sanctions against Mexico for its involvement in drug production and trafficking.

title: Reports Thrive in a Frugal Age
description: In this era of keen global competition, American companies like to portray themselves as penny pinchers with hardly an ounce of fat. But at least one expensive tradition remains inviolate at most companies: the lavish annual report.

title: Review/Ballet; From Montreal, and All Stravinsky
description: The return to New York of Les Grands Ballets Canadiens for the first time since 1984 and this time to the Brooklyn Academy of Music, confirms the venturesome and creative policy the company from Montreal has displayed in recent years.

title: An Endangered Species
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a Republican representing Democratic Connecticut, revels in his maverick ways. Page B1.

title: Air Canada reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $4.5 million from defeasance of debt and capital lease obligations.

title: All Goes Well as Mets Shut Out Expos
description: Before a resplendent gathering of 50,309 spectators on the 25th anniversary of Shea Stadium, the Mets played their aces with dramatic effect yesterday as they opened their home season with a 3-0 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: Carl Karcher Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,837,000 and $4,162,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss

title: Review/Television; Annals of Family Women Over Several Generations
description: Stretching for poignancy doesn't necessarily have anything to do with believablity. Consider tonight's episode of ''A Year in the Life'' (on NBC at 9 P.M.), certainly one of television's nicer series these days as it earnestly follows the travails and triumphs in the lives of a single Seattle family. With Richard Kiley as the family patriarch, a tower of integrity, what's not to like? But, just as in real life, there are limits.

title: Falcon Oil & Gas Co Inc reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
New Team Gives Britoil A Solid Scottish Accent
description: The board of Britoil P.L.C. has recommended to shareholders the appointment of Sir Robin Grieve Duthie as chairman and John Saint as chief executive.

title: Criticare Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Swiss Bank Scrutiny
description: Swiss banks and big financial institutions will come under closer supervision in accepting funds from foreign leaders, the Swiss Banking Commission said today.

title: The Woman Who Knew Too Much
description: Tax time always reminds me of the woman who understood tax law. She often boasted about it, saying, ''One thing I understand is tax law.'' One night she said it to Senator Robert Packwood, a member of the Senate Finance Committee, which constantly revises the tax law.

title: Universal Health Realty Inome Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Snyder General Adds Allis Unit
description: The Snyder General Corporation agreed today to acquire the Allis-Chalmers Corporation's air quality control subsidiary for $245 million cash, the two companies announced.

title: George J. Ginandes, Pediatrician, 84
description: Dr. George J. Ginandes, a pediatrician and professor emeritus at Mount Sinai Medical Center, died of a heart attack Sunday at Mount Sinai. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Devils Triumph And Lead Series
description: While the Devils spoke about making a league-wide statement, the Islanders talked about regrouping, a posture they've been forced into by New Jersey, the ingenue team that has turned into an intimidator.

title: Washington Talk: Civil Rights Commission; On AIDS, Panel Battles Some It Wants to Help
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights, which under the Reagan Administration has embroiled itself in a number of bitter policy controversies, is about to jump into another bubbling pot by entering the national debate over AIDS, which some in the Administration have declared the nation's No. 1 health priority.

title: Home Loan Bank Bonds
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks is offering $2.36 billion of bonds in a three-part financing through various securities dealers.

title: Palm Beach Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-Net income c-Net loss Palm Beach's preferred stock is traded on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: Grist for the Mill: Whole-Grain Foods and a Bit of History
description: LEAD: POP into the mill room at the Kenyon Cornmeal Company in Usquepaugh, R.I., about 40 miles southwest of Providence, and you hear the rumble of heavy granite stones grinding grain. Kenyon is one of a handful of mills in New England where people still practice the ancient craft of stone grinding, a slow, laborious process in which kernels of grain are ground into flour between two rotating stones.

title: AM Ex-Official Settles Charges
description: A former senior official of AM International Inc. today settled Federal civil charges, brought almost three years ago, that he participated in a scheme to overstate the company's earnings in the early 1980's.

title: Ply-Gem to Drop Offer for Wolverine
description: Ply-Gem Industries said it had agreed to drop its bid of $18.50 a share for Wolverine Technologies Inc., clearing the way for Monday's counterbid by Compagnie de Saint-Gobain, which bid $23 a share, or about $86 million.

title: Magic Years Child Care & Learning Centers reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Alan Paton, Author Who Fought Against Apartheid, Is Dead at 85
description: Alan Paton, the South African author and political leader whose powerful 1948 novel ''Cry, the Beloved Country'' aroused many of his countrymen and much of the world against apartheid, died of throat cancer early yesterday at his home outside Durban, his wife, Anne, said. He was 85 years old.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Cavaliers 116, Hawks 103: Ron Harper scored 25 points and Mark Price added 22 points and a career-high 14 assists as the Cavaliers won their fourth consecutive game last night. Cleveland, winning for the seventh time in its last eight games, led by as many as 26 points in the third quarter. The Cavaliers dominated play from the outset, leading, 33-22, at the end of one quarter and by 65-48 at halftime. Price had 17 points and 11 assists in the first half, and Harper added 17 first-half points. Cleveland continued to expand the margin in the third quarter, connecting on their first seven field-goal attempts, including four by Mike Sanders, for an 81-56 lead. Cleveland led, 92-69, entering the final quarter, and the visiting Hawks closed to within 7 points on a layup by Leon Wood with 46 seconds remaining. The Hawks lost their third consecutive game following a seven-game winning streak. Dominique Wilkins scored 28 points and Kevin Willis had 16 for the Hawks, who fell two and a half games behind first-place Detroit in the Central Division. Cleveland built its lead to two games over Indiana in the battle for the sixth playoff spot in the Eastern Conference.(AP) TENNIS Pate Advances: David Pate overwhelmed Tim Pawsat, 6-1, 6-2, yesterday in the second round of the $752,000 Japan Open in Tokyo. Pawsat broke Pate's service in the first game of the match, but the fifth-seeded Pate, ranked 20th in the world, swept the next six games. Pate, from Las Vegas, Nev., was never in trouble during the match, which took just one hour on the hard court of the Ariake Tennis Park. In the first round of women's play, top-seeded Natalia Zvereva of the Soviet Union needed just 64 minutes to beat Masako Yanagi of Japan, 6-0, 6-4. Larisa Savchenko of the Soviet Union, seeded second, defeated Kumiko Okamoto of Japan, 6-4, 2-6, 6-3. In other matches, Catarina Lindqvist of Sweden, seeded third, was beaten by unseeded Brenda Schultz of the Netherlands, 6-1, 1-6, 3-6, and unseeded Natalie Bykova of the Soviet Union, upset Etsuko Inoue of Japan, seeded seventh, 6-0, 4-6, 1-6.(AP)

title: Dublin Journal; Ugly Words Over a Law to Beautify
description: Martha Burden, a grandmother who lives in this bedroom community east of San Francisco, was in a supermarket the other day when she overheard a conversation between two shoppers.

title: A Cramped Museum Filled With Indian History
description: Since it was founded and endowed by George Gustav Heye in 1916, the Museum of the American Indian has had to store its vast collection of artifacts from Indians of the Western Hemisphere - ranging from Aztec to Zuni - largely out of public view.

title: Campaign Issues. What Issues?
description: Yes, there have been some sharp questions about race, religion and politics: Why was Mayor Koch so harsh about Jesse Jackson and Jews? Why won't Mr. Jackson address Jewish concerns about his views face to face? Why won't Michael Dukakis toe a purist pro-Israel line? Must Albert Gore toe so purist a pro-Israel line?

title: Fitzwater Says Fake Quotation Angers Reagan
description: President Reagan's former spokesman has acknowledged that he manufactured quotation by the President on two occasions, and Mr. Reagan's current spokesman today angrily characterized the actions as a ''damn outrage.''

title: Damon Biotech reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
West Point-Pepperell Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 26
description: b-After a loss of $3,324,000 for the quarter and a gain of $1,741,000 for the 6 months, both from the sale of discontinued operations. c-After net from discontinued operations of $414,000 for the quarter and $1,753,000 for the 6 months.

title: Theater Pared to Voice: Star Actors on Radio
description: ''The witness is through. Stand away. Stand away!''

title: Circuit Research Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
For Gore, an Ebullient Fete
description: If the Presidential candidacy of Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee is indeed in any jeopardy, it was hard to detect it in the ebullient mood of the crowd at the Pierre Hotel last night.

title: Plan to Sell 45% Of Air Canada
description: The Canadian Government plans to sell 45 percent of Air Canada, the national airline, to the public, Deputy Prime Minister Don Mazankowski announced in Parliament today.

title: Exxon Plans Swap
description: The Exxon Company U.S.A. said it planned to discontinue gasoline sales by Oct. 31 in certain West Coast markets that are uncompetitive and instead would bolster its market position near its San Francisco-area refinery. Exxon will swap 90 stations in California, Washington, Nevada and Oregon for 92 stations owned by Texaco Inc. in San Francisco and Sacramento.

title: Waste Recovery reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CPC International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Harvard Gets Mouse Patent, A World First
description: Calling it a ''singularly historic event,'' the United States today issued to Harvard University the world's first patent for a higher form of life, a mouse specially developed by researchers at the Harvard Medical School through techniques of genetic manipulation.

title: The Sinking Orioles Turn to Robinson for Help
description: Frank Robinson became baseball's first black manager in four years when he was named today to replace Cal Ripken as the manager of the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Campaign Stirs Conflicts Among Gay Voters
description: The words, spoken from the platform of the Democratic National Convention, stopped Ron Najman in his tracks and made his heart pitch with pleasure. ''The lesbian and the gay,'' the Rev. Jesse Jackson was telling the assembled thousands at the climax of the 1984 political season, were part of the ''American quilt,'' valued members of a variegated society.

title: Marietta Settles
description: The Justice Department said it had recovered $272,000 from the Martin Marietta Corporation in connection with Government claims that the company submitted false vouchers for work on the space shuttle. John Bolton, the assistant Attorney General in charge of the civil division, said the out-of-court settlement, reached on Monday, fully satisfied the Government's claims. Spokesmen for the Bethesda, Md., contractor were not immediately available for comment.

title: About Education
description: Some years ago, during a newspaper strike in New York City, reporters and editors reviewed the news of the week on television every Sunday. James Reston, the New York Times columnist, opened his segment one time saying, ''How do I know what to think when I can't read what I've written?''

title: Ryan's Family Steak Houses Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
Emulex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
In the Pantheon of Fine Olive Oils, the Top
description: MAURIZIO CASTELLI remembers the American woman who asked about the olive trees that spread in silvery clusters down a terraced Tuscan hillside: were they extra-virgin olive trees, she wanted to know, or the regular kind?

title: Germans Send Hijacking Suspect to Juvenile Court
description: A Frankfurt court ruled today that a suspect in the 1985 hijacking of a Trans World Airlines jetliner was under 21 at the time. It sent his case to juvenile court to decide whether he should be tried as a youth or as an adult.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American National Can Corp., Chicago, a packaging manufacturer whose parent company is Triangle Industries, promoted Roger W. Stine to senior vice president for manufacturing of its Beverage Metal Container division.

title: Griffin Set to Begin Resorts Tender Bid
description: In another attempt to put pressure on the board of Resorts International Inc., the entertainer Merv Griffin said he intended to begin a $36-a-share tender offer for 51 percent of Resorts' class A shares by next Monday.

title: Interim A.T.& T. Chief Called Tough Manager
description: Robert E. Allen, who is running the American Telephone and Telegraph Company during the illness of its chairman and chief executive, James E. Olson, is described by analysts as a tough manager who does not show it.

title: Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Quaker Spurns Bid
description: The Quaker State Corporation is spurning an unsolicited $675 million takeover bid from Ardshiel Inc., an investor group led by a New York investment banking firm, in favor of independence. ''My strong view is that it is in the best interests of Quaker State to remain independent,'' said Quentin E. Wood, the company's chairman, in a statement. The motor oil refining company said the $26.50-a-share proposal submitted Friday by Ardshiel did not contain definitive financing.

title: Party Celebrates Club for Gay and Gray
description: The first time Gean Harwood, 79, and Bruhs Mero, 77, went to Radio City Music Hall together was the opening night in 1932. Last night, the two men, who have been together 58 years, were there again. They joined more than 200 men and women of all ages for a fund-raising dinner celebrating the 10th anniversary of Senior Action in a Gay Environment. The organization's goal is to provide services and programs for elderly homosexuals.

title: Taiwan's Gold Imports Surge
description: Flush with cash, Taiwan is rapidly becoming a leading gold importer, bullion dealers said today.

title: Disc Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,547,164 from the settlement of secured debt and leases. c-Net loss The company filed for Chapter 11 protection in October 1987.

title: Consolidated Papers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reception for Bush Puts Money on Ice
description: Any doubts about who has the Republican Presidential nomination on ice were dispelled last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza Hotel where a spectacular ice sculpture spelled out Vice President Bush's surname in three-foot high letters beside a frosty American eagle, poised for flight.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Cuomo in the Capital?
description: No matter what the vote count on Primary Day in New York City next Tuesday, the following day will find Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in Washington.

title: 2 Industrialists Are Among 20 Buying an Estate for Reagans
description: The industrialists Holmes Tuttle and Earle Jorgensen are among the 20 or so friends of President Reagan who gave at least $156,000 apiece to buy a California estate for the Reagans to occupy when they leave the White House, documents released today show.

title: Louisiana Executes Man, 34, Convicted of Murdering Five
description: A Guyanese immigrant convicted of killing his girlfriend and four members of her family, including a 4-year-old girl, was executed early today in Louisiana's electric chair.

title: Hamilton Fish 3d Joins Race for House
description: Hamilton Fish 3d, the 36-year-old former publisher of The Nation, announced yesterday that he will run for Congress. Six generations of his family have now run for Congress; Mr. Fish is the first Democrat.

title: Amistar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
National Bancorp of Alaska reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share figures reflect a 20 percent stock dividend paid last October.

title: LESSONS
description: No doubt a fair number of houses have been painted during a professor's sabbatical, and it is probably true that while on academic leave, someone brought a tan or two to chestnut maturity. But for every Aegean port that was visited, 100 ancient texts were read; for every redwood deck sanded and stained, 1,000 monographs were polished.

title: Wedtech Hired Biaggi Firm For Influence, Witness Says
description: A young lawyer who worked in the former law firm of Representative Mario Biaggi testified yesterday that the Wedtech Corporation would never have hired the firm without its political connections.

title: Real Estate; Office Space Thriving At Fort Lee
description: WHILE the demand for office space in many parts of northern New Jersey has softened considerably in the last year or so, the market in Fort Lee, the small community at the New Jersey end of the George Washington Bridge, seems to be stronger.

title: Eating Well
description: THE egg, its once enviable reputation as a top-quality source of nutrients besmirched by its high cholesterol content, is under new scrutiny after a report last week implicating it in salmonella outbreaks.

title: Scotty's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 26
Dutch Hail Concertgebouw's 100th
description: An audience of 1,600, including Queen Beatrix and Prince Claus, joined an orchestra and chorus of 500 Monday night at a performance of Mahler's Eighth Symphony that celebrated the 100th anniversary of the Concertgebouw.

title: Review/Film; Sexual Stereotypes and Role-Playing
description: Sexual jealousy is the main force at work in Sheila McLaughlin's ''She Must Be Seeing Things,'' but you'd never know it from the film's amiable, even dispassionate mood. Miss McLaughlin seems more concerned with contemplating this idea than with dramatizing it, and the same can be said for her film's exploration of various sexual stereotypes and its fascination with role-playing. A little more energy would have helped, however. As it is, ''She Must Be Seeing Things'' is a modest, agreeable and doubtless very personal film that never develops any real urgency.

title: High Price Of Elections; Questions Increase As Do War Chests
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican candidate for governor in 1982, left a fund-raising party in a private Syracuse club one evening two months before the election and returned to his car. A wealthy businessman who was running for public office for the first time, Mr. Lehrman sat down and sighed.

title: 2 Accused of Selling A Stolen Diamond
description: Two brothers were held without bail yesterday on a charge of interstate transportion of a stolen diamond that had been in the possession of a missing gem dealer.

title: In Philadelphia, a Food Haven
description: BOB MOYER, who had just a moment to talk between customers on a recent Saturday afternoon at the Reading Terminal Market in Philadelphia, reminisced about conditions there less than a decade ago.

title: Telecast Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest year loss included one- time charges of $1,530,581 because of the writeoff of assets, $600,000 because of loan guarantees and stock price guarantees for the acquisition of Telstar Corp. and $210,000 for launching costs for Telecast Cinema.

title: Man Held in Abduction of Racial Attack Witness
description: A Long Island man has been arrested on charges that he kidnapped an important witness in a Bronx racial attack and held her hostage in a car for 48 hours while warning her not to testify in the case. But the police said yesterday that they had found ''inconsistencies'' in the woman's account of the abduction.

title: Messner, Vetere Sets Theme for Rockport Ads
description: For its first campaign for the Rockport Corporation, makers of a line of walking shoes for both sexes, Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey has come up with the theme line ''Shoes that help you live longer.''

title: Easing of Strong Savings Units' Insurance Fee Is Urged
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board proposed today to gradually reduce the extra deposit insurance premium it has assessed the savings industry since 1985, but the plan would apply only to the healthiest savings and loan associations.

title: Review/Music; Illuminating Palestrina
description: Much recorded, much traveled, the Tallis Scholars made their New York debut at the Corpus Christi Church Sunday afternoon. The 10 singers from Britain are directed by Peter Phillips, and most of their work centers on the Renaissance. Palestrina and his school provided Sunday's texts.

title: Libel Awards: Million-Dollar Barrier Is Breached
description: Until April 4 the highest libel judgment ultimately confirmed by the courts was well below $1 million. But with the Supreme Court's affirmation of a libel award in which CBS must pay $3 million to the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, what lawyers referred to as the ''million-dollar barrier'' has been breached.

title: Television Ad Bureau Announces Promotions
description: William G. Moll, who became president of the Television Bureau of Advertising in September, took the occasion of the National Association of Broadcasters' meeting in Las Vegas to announce promotions and additions at the bureau.

title: 5 Robins Trustees Named
description: The Federal judge overseeing the A. H. Robins Company bankruptcy case named five trustees today to oversee a $2.6 billion fund to pay claims by women injured by the drug company's Dalkon Shield contraceptive device.

title: Chip Maker's Stock Is Heavily Traded
description: Shares of the National Semiconductor Corporation, a computer chip and systems manufacturer, were heavily traded on Wall Street after a mutual fund group disclosed that it owns 5.3 percent of the company's stock. While the stock price for National Semiconductor, based in Santa Clara, Calif., closed only 12.5 cents higher, at $13.375, on the New York Stock Exchange, it was the fourth-most-active stock, with 1.61 million shares traded.

title: Nicaragua Opposition Paper Gets Newsprint and Reopens
description: The opposition newspaper La Prensa, which was shut down for five days after running out of newsprint, resumed publication this afternoon.

title: Airline Deregulation Creates Massive Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: Edward G. McDonnell, Construction Executive, 79
description: Edward G. McDonnell, president of a structural steel erecting company that helped build many prominent buildings in New York City, died of heart failure Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Service Charges Gain as Tips Are Taxed
description: Fed up with Congress for taking a bigger bite of tips, the chef and owner of the Briarhurst Manor Inn, O. Sigi Krauss, has done away with tipping in his restaurant in Colorado Springs. He has added a 20 percent service charge in its place.

title: Mayfair Super Markets Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding are class A and are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split issued in August 1987.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Shultz Branching Out
description: While it would not exactly rate as commuting, Secretary of State George P. Shultz has journeyed to and from Moscow three times in the last year and is setting off again for the Soviet capital next Tuesday.

title: Tyson's Camp Still Sparring
description: Until recently, Mike Tyson created headlines by what he did in the prize ring.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the new American Airlines terminal at Raleigh-Durham Airport in North Carolina incorrectly reported the location of the airport. It is in Morrisville, N.C.

title: Chargers Get Malone
description: With the retirement of Dan Fouts, the San Diego Chargers went shopping for a quarterback. Yesterday they found one in the bargain basement when they picked up Mark Malone from the Pittsburgh Steelers for an eighth-round draft pick.

title: Statesman Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $682,000 for the quarter and $1,559,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,328,000 for the quarter and $2,249,000 for the year. Statesman attributed the earnings decline in the latest year to fewer net realized gains on securities transactions and non-insurance operations.

title: Regulator Urged to Act On Texas Savings Units
description: With Texas savings institutions losing a total of $7 million a day, industry executives, advisers and the state's Congressmen say they have urged the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to move immediately to close or merge dozens of failed associations.

title: Review/Piano; Brendel's 2 Ways of Playing Schubert
description: For the piano-playing amateur, there are two important varieties of recital. One sends the poor key-banger straight home, exhilarated and determined to practice. The other sends him wandering out into the night in despair, ready to sell his instrument and take up the autoharp. Alfred Brendel played both types of recital on Monday evening in the first of four Schubert programs at Carnegie Hall.

title: California Offers $160 Million Issue
description: The State of California entered the debt market yesterday for the second time this year, offering a $160 million competitive issue through underwriters led by BankAmerica Capital Markets Group.

title: Cherokee Group reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: The company said the latest first quarter included results from its 80 percent owned subsidiary, Chutes Corp., but did not include the results of Pallmark International, acquired by Cherokee at the end of the first quarter.

title: Iran-Contra Pair Seen By Bush as Not Guilty
description: Vice President Bush said for the first time yesterday that he hoped two of the leading figures in the Iran-contra affair would be found not guilty of criminal acts.

title: 'Orderly Transition' For Marine Midland
description: Geoffrey A. Thompson was named chief executive of Marine Midland Banks Inc. yesterday, succeeding John R. Petty, who plans to retire on May 27.

title: Guinness Bail Renewed
description: A British magistrate extended bail today for the former chairman of Guinness P.L.C., Ernest Saunders, and five other men who face a total of 92 charges relating to the Guinness takeover of the Distillers Company.

title: Damon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a $560,000 gain associated with the favorable settlement of litigation. c-Includes a $35,000 gain from the purchase of debentures. The company said the latest 6-month sales includes $1.1 million associated with the favorable settlement of litigation.

title: Colombians Turning to Men for Birth Control
description: Over the past two decades, a handful of birth control advocates have overcome the resistance of men and women, the indifference of the Government and the opposition of the Roman Catholic Church to convert Colombia's family planning program into a model for third-world countries.

title: Intervoice reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $22,567.

title: Lorimar Talks Break Off
description: The Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation said yesterday that it had broken off merger talks with Warner Communications Inc.

title: Israeli Aides to Visit Warsaw
description: The Israeli Deputy Prime Minister, Yitzhak Navon, and Justice Minister Avraham Sharir are expected to arrive in Poland Wednesday for a one-week visit to take part in ceremonies to mark the 45th anniverary of the Warsaw ghetto uprising.

title: Bidding for Spurs
description: He's been itching to regain full control of the San Antonio Spurs, but Red McCombs, who has offered to buy out his partners, may have touched off a bidding war for the team.

title: The Williamsburg Bridge Is Shut For 2 Weeks as Cracks Are Found
description: The crumbling Williamsburg Bridge, which 240,000 commuters depend on for passage between Brooklyn and Manhattan each day, was closed to all traffic last night and will not open for at least two weeks.

title: Boeing 747 Inspections Ordered Because of Fuel Leak Complaints
description: After several safety complaints by major airlines, the Federal Aviation Administration has ordered all 593 Boeing 747-200 model passenger planes now operating to be examined for defects that could lead to fire in the cargo area.

title: Democrats Get Lift From Issue of Drugs
description: The drug issue is now giving the Democrats a major lift in the 1988 Presidential campaign, despite the Reagan Administration's heavy new spending on drug enforcement and the public emphasis it has placed on the international drug trade.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Democratic Presidential candidates campaigning in New York incorrectly characterized a remark by Rabbi Balfour Brickner of the Steven Wise Free Synagogue. Rabbi Brickner said he considered the Rev. Jesse Jackson a credible candidate; he did not endorse Mr. Jackson's candidacy.

title: For China, 'Rejuvenated' Leadership
description: China's parliament approved a new lineup today of Government leaders who are widely seen as committed to its ambitious program of economic restructuring.

title: Integrated Net Service Started by Southern Bell
description: The Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company began offering a new class of services today that gives businesses the ability to transmit voice, data and video pictures simultaneously on the same telephone line.

title: Shift on Food Packaging
description: Companies using ozone-destroying chemicals to make plastic-foam food packaging will switch to other compounds by the end of the year, their trade association, the Foodservice and Packaging Institute, said today. It was the first statement by the group although manufacturers had already taken a similar stance. While food packaging accounts for only 1.5 percent to 2 percent of the United States production of the chemicals in question, chlorofluorocarbons, some environmentalists have focused on food packaging as a highly visible and unessential use of the chemicals.

title: Energy Official Resigns
description: C. Michael Naeve will leave the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to rejoin his old law firm on April 30, the commission announced Monday.

title: Beyond the Question of I.N.F. Verifiability
description: Soon the Senate will debate ratification of the treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces. This agreement is the first major American-Soviet arms control treaty to come before the Senate since the ill-fated 1979 SALT II agreement, and it deserves Senate support. As with the strategic arms limitation treaty - indeed, with all arms control treaties - a central issue in the I.N.F. debate will be this: Is the treaty ''verifiable''?

title: HDM Takes A Global Approach
description: TIM POLLAK and Alain de Pouzilhac represent the new breed of international ad executives.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As far back as you want to go, you will find criticism of the Senate. It is not meant to be efficient. The problem with the Senate is with ourselves, and to fix it we have to fix ourselves.

title: Spearhead Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Grace Bechtold, 80, A Longtime Editor For Bantam Books
description: Grace Bechtold, a vice president and executive editor of Bantam Books, died of cancer Monday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ReadiCare Inc reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
National Hardgoods Distribuors Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: The year-ago periods included a non-recurring gain of $223,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: J.C. Penney Notes
description: The J. C. Penney Company is offering $200 million of 9.45 percent notes due in 1998 at a price of 99.84, to yield 9.475 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. Noncallable for the first seven years, the notes yield about 87.5-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. They are rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by Standard & Poor's.

title: Coca-Cola Net Up 13% In Quarter
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its income rose 13.5 percent in the first quarter, while CPC International Inc., the food conglomerate, posted a 35.5 percent jump. Both companies credited part of the improvements to stronger overseas sales, which rose as the dollar weakened against foreign currencies.

title: Judge Bars Trial in Fall In the Iran-Contra Case
description: The judge handling the Iran-contra case said today that he would not hold the trial in the midst of the fall election campaign.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs; Oilers, Flames and Blues Clinch Series
description: Mark Messier figured in the first four Edmonton goals, all on the power play, and Wayne Gretzky had a goal and four assists to spark the Oilers to a surprisingly easy 6-2 victory tonight that eliminated the Winnipeg Jets from the National Hockey League playoffs.

title: Valley Forge Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $112,129 for the quarter and income of $645,966 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and tax loss carryforwards of $193,388 and $1,726,388 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After net of $41,020 for the quarter and a loss of $238,713 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and tax loss carryforwards of $281,023 and $1,008,297 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Calvin Klein: Hot Colors, Pure Line
description: HE was aiming for architectural purity, Calvin Klein explained after his fall and winter fashion opening yesterday morning. That is what he achieved with strong, simple silhouettes and intense colors.

title: Classical and African Dance Mix
description: Dance Theater of Harlem gave 750 New York City schoolchildren a lesson yesterday in classical ballet and the persistence of the dance impulse in human history. The ''teachers'' were dancers from the ballet company, members of the Amabutho Zulu Warriors, currently performing with Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, and some of the schoolchildren themselves, who swarmed up on the stage of Davis Hall at City College for an exuberant demonstration of the newest in social dancing.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Texas Bank Loss Put at $1.5 Billion
description: The deeply troubled First Republicbank Corporation today estimated a loss of $1.5 billion for the first quarter, mainly because of increased reserves for escalating problems with its real estate loans. That estimate is three times what analysts had anticipated.

title: Revenue Bonds Priced For Medical Facilities
description: Two tax-exempt revenue bond issues worth a total of $316.3 million were tentatively priced yesterday through underwriting groups led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Rubbermaid Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
House Panel Asks Assessment of Fusion Field
description: Citing unexpected breakthroughs by Federal scientists, the House Armed Services Committee has called for an independent assessment of the field of small-scale nuclear fusion to help Government experts chart its future and select a giant new fusion machine that could cost up to $1 billion.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Special Children's Inn
description: Seriously ill children receiving experimental treatments at the National Institutes of Health should find i 1/8 easier to get the emotional and physical support of their families next year.

title: 2 Act to Lift Stake In Henley Concern
description: Two Middle Eastern businessmen -Toufic Aboukhater of Lebanon and Said Khoury of Kuwait - said they plan to seek Federal approval to raise their stake in the Henley Manufacturing Company to more than 15 percent, from 12.9 percent.

title: Basketball Rebuilding Starts at Rutgers
description: Seven years ago, Bob Wenzel stepped onto the campus of Jacksonville University for the first time, looking for a job as head coach of a major college basketball team.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet

It is widely found in Indian dishes and is almost indispensable in the preparation of meat stews and sausages of Morocco, Algeria and

title: IP Timberlands Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest quarter net was affected by the completion of the second phase of a timber land sales agreement with John Hancock Insurance Co. The sale contributed $17 million to partnership earnings, or about 12 cents a unit. Share earnings represent per class A depositiary units.

title: Conservative-Led Coalition Gets Final Approval in Italy
description: Ciriaco de Mita, the Prime Minister-designate, received final approval from coalition members today to form Italy's 48th post-World War II Government and said he would present his Cabinet list to the President.

description: b-Net income

Latest in Vending Machines: One That Cooks for You
description: You can order coffee, candy bars, sandwiches and cigarettes from vending machines. Now, thanks to a partnership between an inventor and Ore-Ida Foods Inc. of Boise, Idaho, it will soon be possible to put 75 cents in a coin-operated dispenser and 35 seconds later receive a precisely measured three and a half ounces of steaming hot french fries.

title: Zenn Kaufman, Marketing Specialist, 81
description: Zenn Kaufman, a marketing specialist, writer and lecturer, died of heart failure April 6 at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Norwalk.

title: Beres Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $195,000 for the latest year and $10,000 for 1986.

title: Gibson, C R Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflects a 5-for-4 stock split paid Oct. 30.

title: I.B.M. Proud of Role In South Africa

title: 2 Sentenced in Death Of a Homeless Man
description: Two men were sentenced yesterday to the maximum of 25 years to life in prison for the slaying of a homeless man whom they beat and set afire in a vacant bungalow in Far Rockaway, Queens, in 1984.

title: Classroom Focus Shifting to the Art of Thinking
description: Children in kindergarten here are learning how to think. Not just to read and write and spell, but to think.

title: Byrd to Step Down at Year's End As Leader of Senate's Democrats
description: Ending months of speculation, Robert C. Byrd said today that he would step down as Senate majority leader at the end of the year, opening the way for new leadership when the next President takes office in January.

title: Legislators Reach an Accord On New Bill on Solid Waste
description: New Yorkers will be required to separate recyclable materials like paper, glass, metal and plastic from the rest of their garbage by 1992 under a bill agreed to by state lawmakers.

title: When Pipe Making Becomes One Part Craft, One Part Art
description: LEAD: GRACE can come unasked, in places where it is not supposed to rear its beautiful head. Who would think, for instance, that a briar pipe could be a great smoke and an art object, too?

title: Review/Theater; Athol Fugard's 'Road to Mecca' Examines the Core of Artistry
description: The artist at the center of Athol Fugard's new play, ''The Road to Mecca,'' does not want to change the world. Miss Helen, as she is known, is a reclusive old widow in a dusty, isolated village in the South African wilderness. Her art is an oddball collection of concrete sculptures exhibited in her garden - wise men, mermaids and animals that she calls her ''Mecca.'' Her sparse audience is her neighbors, most of whom regard her not as an artist but as the town madwoman, a laughingstock.

title: Newmil Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share earnings for the year- ago periods have been restated to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split Feb. 15.

description: Debt

COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Stores Co., Salt Lake City, said it was willing to negotiate the price of its $1.74 billion takeover offer for Lucky Stores Inc. if it was provided with confidential financial data that the supermarket chain has provided other parties.

title: Koch Drops Plan to Ban Bikes
description: The Koch administration, faced with strong opposition from bicyclists, environmentalists, civic groups and many public officials, has dropped its plan to ban bicycles from three midtown avenues during much of each business day, officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about an appearance by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis before a Jewish organization misidentified the organization and misspelled the name of its chairman, Morris Abram. The group is the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations. In some copies, the name of the executive director, Malcolm Hoenlein, was also misspelled.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Hodel Breaks Ranks
description: At the urging of President Reagan himself, Administration officials have so far generally stood aside from this year's political campaigns of both Democrats and Republicans.

description: In ''Stranger in a Strange Land,'' the science-fiction cult classic by Robert A. Heinlein, Martians became Water Brothers after ritually sharing sips of water as a symbolic gesture of closeness.

description: EVEN before Darryl Strawberry lobbed an artillery shot over the right-field fence as a salute to the fans who had cheered him, the Mets had another sign of normalcy. Kevin McReynolds was back in left field.

title: Seoul Journal; A Kim Has Tumbled From Ranks of Angels
description: Old friends and former allies shake their heads and say they wish Kim Dae Jung had heeded this admonition, which he wrote in 1982 while imprisoned on trumped-up sedition charges:

title: Your Tax Dollars At Work And Play
description: LEAD: Congratulations. You probably are about to make your largest ''purchases'' of the year. According to the Tax Foundation, a private research organization, the median family of four paid $4,722 in Federal taxes last year.

title: Compromise Is Reached to Keep Indian Museum in New York City
description: The divisive issue of how to assure the future of the Museum of the American Indian in New York City was all but settled today in a compromise reached by members of Congress, Mayor Koch and State Attorney General Robert Abrams.

title: Restructuring For Airbus
description: Government participants in Airbus Industrie approved guidelines today to overhaul management of the European aircraft consortium. Britain's Trade and Industry

title: Jesse Lasky Jr., 79; Was a Screenwriter
description: Jesse L. Lasky Jr., an author and screenwriter, died of cancer on Monday at his home in London. He was 79 years old and had been dividing his time for more than 25 years between residences in London and Salta de Agua, Spain.

title: I.B.M. Gives Lord, Einstein Short-Term Assignments
description: Lord, Einstein, O'Neill & Partners has received advertising assignments from the International Business Machines Corporation, the largest client of Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein.

title: Report Urges Public Access To Broker-Violation Data
description: The records of stockbrokers who have violated securities laws and regulations should be available to the public and should be thoroughly checked by investment firms before the brokers are hired, a new report says.

title: For Cuban-Americans, an Era of Change
description: In their eyes they are as American as a Burger King Whopper. They prefer speaking English to Spanish, and they may even admit that they are bored by the unending preoccupation their parents' generation has with Fidel Castro.

title: Bridge
description: Among those who are at the top of the tree as players, writers or teachers, there is only one who is constantly active in all three categories. He is Eddie Kantar of Los Angeles, a former world champion who was a Vanderbilt knockout team winner in Buffalo last month.

title: Homes, at Last, for the Indian Museum
description: A compromise worked out by Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and Daniel Inouye of Hawaii splendidly resolves the prolonged impasse over the Museum of the American Indian.

title: Senate Republicans Clash With Anderson on Budget
description: A meeting of Senate Republicans became a battle for control of the house this evening after one member proposed what amounted to a vote of confidence for the Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson.

title: Theodore Harris, 75, Composer and Teacher
description: Theodore Harris, a prolific but largely unrecognized composer, died Monday night at his home in Brooklyn. He was 75 years old.

title: Reagan-Nixon Stand on Records Is Rejected, 3-0, by Appeals Panel
description: A Federal appeals court today rejected the Reagan Administration's view that the Constitution gives former Presidents broad power to squelch public disclosure of papers, tapes and other internal records of their Presidencies.

description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $200,000 for the quarter and $800,000 for the 6 months.

Ex-Rep. James Domengeaux, 81
description: Former Representative James Domengeaux, who is credited with preserving the French language in his native state of Louisiana, died of acute leukemia Monday in Lafayette, La. He was 81 years old.

title: Oil Prices Extend Gain; Greater Demand Seen
description: A skittish market bid up the price of the most widely traded United States crude oil by 20 cents yesterday, to $18.09 a barrel, its highest level since early December.

description: Adam Zagajewski, a Polish poet, will take part in a lecture and a reading from his works on Monday at Queens College, Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway, Flushing.

title: Meese Action in Inquiry Cited
description: In an interview with the Federal Bureau of Investigation on the Wedtech scandal, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d neglected to mention Justice Department job discussions he had a few weeks earlier with a Wedtech consultant, E. Robert Wallach, Mr. Meese's attorney said today.

title: Dukakis in His Own Words
description: The candidate gives his views on a range of campaign issues in an interview with New York Times reporters and editors. Page A24.

description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had named Theodore F. Bluey, a partner with the Big Eight accounting firm of Deloitte, Haskins & Sells, as the chief accountant in the S.E.C. enforcement division.

title: Sun Microsystems And Xerox in Pact
description: The Xerox Corporation and Sun Microsystems Inc. said they had signed a five-year agreement that calls for Xerox to purchase or manufacture more than $200 million worth of Sun's computer work stations. The announcement, which solidifies an alliance that the two companies made public last October, is based on Xerox's decision to adopt a Sun computer design called Sparc.

The school announced that Jim Harrick, a former U.C.L.A. assistant who has been the coach at Pepperdine for nine years, would replace Walt Hazzard, who was dismissed two weeks ago.

title: Market Place; Price Volatility Unnerves Traders
description: PROFESSIONAL investors have so little conviction about the direction of the dollar, stocks or bonds that they are almost at a standstill. They are reluctant to buy stocks, but they are also reluctant to sell them.

description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are restated to reflect the 5 percent stock dividend in March 1988.

title: Honduran Anger at U.S. Is Product Of Washington Policy, Officials Say
description: At the American Embassy here, workers are already clearing away debris from the annex building set ablaze late last week. But the damage done to American interests in this strategic Central American nation will be much harder to repair, Honduran political leaders and foreign diplomats here say.

title: Review/Opera; Balletic Staging of 'Dido and Aeneas'
description: Could it be a trend, or are the recent examples of balletic opera staging simply coincidence? One remembers fondly a choreographed small-company production of Massenet's ''Cendrillon'' not too long ago; then on Sunday there was Purcell's ''Dido and Aeneas'' at Symphony Space - a joint venture by I Cantori di New York and the New Opera Theater from New Orleans.

title: More College Applications Bring More Rejections
description: In this prime week of cheers and tears as high school seniors hear from college admissions offices, B and C-plus students are increasingly being rejected by colleges that would have accepted them a few years ago.

title: Syracuse Offers a Twin Bill in Lacrosse
description: Jack Emmer, the lacrosse coach at Army, told Roy Simmons Jr., his counterpart at Syracuse, that the greatest recruiting feat possible was to enroll a star athlete who was also a fine student and a good person.

The brands in the package include Gucci, Arpege by Lanvin, Camp Beverly Hills, Maja, 4711 Cologne, Pavlova, Ivoire by Balmain and Dallas Men's Cologne. Additionally, the agency will be working for Payot Cosmetics. The former agency was Euramerica, a subsidiary of the Ogilvy Group.

description: As the only living example of his perilously endangered species - a Republican elected to statewide office in Connecticut - Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. might expect to be accorded some esteem and deference by those who lead his party.

description: The thrift went public in April 1987.

title: Estee Lauder Prepares Fragrance Campaign
description: Estee Lauder Inc. is excited about its new fragrance called Knowing; about the model Paulina, the new Estee Lauder woman who will represent it, and about the commercial directed by Peter Kagan that is intended to make stars of them both.

title: Hipotronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
Topics of The Times; Oscars for the Emperor
description: Thanks to nine Oscars, including the one for best picture, millions more will now be likely to see ''The Last Emperor.'' They'll find more than the standard Hollywood epic - in story, setting, history and even the international flavor of the production.

title: Armed Man at Jackson's Speech
description: A speech by the Rev. Jesse Jackson at Co-op City in the Bronx was disrupted last night when Secret Service agents jumped on an armed man who was crawling close to the stage with a camera.

title: Devils' No. 1 Line Is Working Fine
description: From the Devils' viewpoint, it was only a matter of time before the team's premiere line combination got its act together in the Stanley Cup series against the Islanders.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ed Whitson, the pitcher who led the Padres to their first victory of the season against the Giants in San Francisco last Sunday night, was charged with drunken driving shortly after returning to the San Diego area several hours later. After being stopped for speeding and given a sobriety test, he was booked and then released on bond. . . . Glenn Anderson of the Edmonton Oilers was fined $500 for a high-sticking Steve Rooney of the Winnipeg Jets in a playoff game last Saturday. . . . Gary Dunn, a nose tackle for the Steelers, underwent arthroscopic surgery to repair cartilage damage to his knees. . . . Lafester Rhodes, who averaged 22 points game for Iowa State last season, was arrested in Ames, Iowa, on second-degree burglary charges. The police said he ransacked an apartment belonging to his former girlfriend. Nothing was stolen, the police said.(AP)

title: Economic Scene; Soft Case Against Index Arbitrage
description: IF the big players are unhappy with the New York Stock Exchange's new restrictions on index arbitrage, they aren't advertising it. There was hardly a peep of protest on April 6 when the so-called collar slipped into place for the first time, temporarily denying the arbitragers use of the exchange's high-speed computers.

title: PACE IS QUICKENING IN NEW YORK RACE
description: One week before the critical New York Democratic Presidential primary, the Democratic campaign touched a lot of bases yesterday: the 40th and 41st candidate forums of the long campaign, politicking for Jewish votes in Brooklyn's Borough Park, a tumultous Bronx high school audience and fancy fund-raising events at the Hotel Pierre and the Plaza.

title: Stewart & Stevenson Servces Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Maverick Restaurant Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The latest year results included a one-time loss of $372,275 on the disposition of real estate in Columbia, S.C.

title: F.D.A. Faulted for Shift On Food Label Rules
description: A Food and Drug Administration proposal that would allow food manufacturers to put health claims on labels violates Federal law and could subject the public to deceptive and unfounded assertions, a House committee report has concluded.

title: Oxford Energy reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said 1986 revenue includes a non-recurring payment of $2.19 million.

title: New York Office Vacancy Level Is Highest Since 70's
description: With landlords struggling to fill several new office towers, and with banks and investment houses cutting back their operations, New York City has reached its highest level of office vacancies in a decade, according to real-estate executives.

title: Kimbark Oil & Gas Co reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Vyquest Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $259,000.

title: Lurton Blassingame, 84, Agent
description: Lurton Blassingame, a longtime New York literary agent, died in his sleep at his home in Mobile, Ala., last Thursday. He was 84 years old and suffered from liver cancer.

title: Deaf Actress's Use of Speech Proves Divisive Among Peers
description: It was an emotional moment at the Academy Awards ceremony Monday night.

title: Telecrafter Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The company said increase revenue in fiscal 1988 reflects the combination of the financial results of Telecrafter and Wegener Communications Inc.

title: Topics of The Times; Alan Paton's Great Fear
description: Alan Paton, who died yesterday at 85, saw apartheid through the eyes of a liberal white South African of British origin. But he expressed universal truths in ''Cry, the Beloved Country.'' His magnificent novel was a moral as well as literary achievement. The most urgent truth was spoken by the main character, a Zulu wanted by police for murdering a white man: ''I have one great fear in my heart. One day when they [ the whites ] have turned to loving, they will find we are turned to hating.''

title: The Pop Life
description: Nell Carter Returns

title: Catholic U. Trustees Vote to Bar Curran From Theology Dept.
description: The trustees of Catholic University voted yesterday to bar the Rev. Charles E. Curran from teaching in the school's theology department but left open the possibility that the theologian might find another teaching position in the university.

title: Success for an Oft-Rejected Novelist
description: On Monday, several paperback publishers will be bidding against one another for the right to pay more than $325,000 for a book that was rejected by several major New York publishers and written by an author who could not find an agent in New York.

title: Review/Television; An Identity Crisis for the Oscars
description: When Monday night's Academy Awards show followed glimpses of Charlie Chaplin, Laurence Olivier and Groucho Marx with the ''Police Academy'' star Steve Guttenberg, who presented the best documentary award to a film about the wits of the Algonquin round table, it was clear that Oscar is experiencing a serious identity crisis. It was also clear that the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is its own worst enemy.

title: Oversugaring in 11 Beaujolais Is Reported
description: A French consumer magazine, Que Choisir, reported in its March issue that 11 of 21 1986 Beaujolais wines that the magazine tested were overchaptalized.

title: Salvador Rightists Want Vote Nullified
description: The main rightist opposition party has declared that it was defrauded of a majority in recent municipal and legislative voting and demanded that the Supreme Court nullify the official results.

title: Highland Superstores reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $5,685,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: VWR Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After a gain of $570,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-After a gain of $6,897,000 from the sale of investments.

title: Not So Simple to Blow the Whistle on Those Who Seek Bribes
description: To the Editor:

title: Palestinians Protest Expulsions; 40 Are Wounded
description: Israeli troops wounded more than 40 people in the occupied territories today in violent protests against the expulsion of eight Palestinians on Monday.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Inch Up
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes inched modestly higher yesterday, helped by a stronger dollar and flurries of arbitrage-related buying following the Treasury's auction of seven-year notes.

title: Quipp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Iran Says It Killed Many Iraqis in New Drive
description: Iran said today that its troops had killed or wounded 2,700 Iraqi soldiers in a major new drive into northeastern Iraq.

title: Portage Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Sonoco Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 3
description: b-Included equity in earnings of affiliates of $381,000 for the latest first quarter and $384,000 for the year-ago period. The share earnings reflect the 2-for- 1 stock split on June 10, 1987.

title: Superior Industries International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Darling Changes Style for Success
description: If Ron Darling accomplishes nothing else this season, he has already succeeded in one of his quests.

title: About New York; Elephant Picnic And Life Story: An Ordinary Day
description: So another ordinary Tuesday dawns and you rise, knock the dust off your grinders and mosey out to poke around. There's the usual complement of runners and dog walkers on the street, and the wind kicks up a garbage storm on the corner, a cellophane and plastic-foam dust devil. You hunch the shoulders, lower the head like a bull and press on.

title: Review/Opera; Levine's Illness Means a Debut for a Scot
description: In one of those twists of fate upon which young musicians hang their wildest hopes, a pinched nerve forced James Levine to withdraw at the last minute from conducting Berg's ''Lulu'' at the Metropolitan Opera. This allowed Donald Runnicles, a 33-year-old assistant conductor at the house, to make his debut last Thursday. He returned to the podium on Monday evening, leading a vivid, dramatic performance.

title: Marion C. Morris, 85; Served Health Agencies
description: Dr. Marion C. Morris, a bacteriologist and immunologist who held posts with several public and private health agencies, died of heart failure April 1 at New York Hospital. She was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bandag Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Juvenile Court in Hijacking
description: A Frankfurt court said a juvenile court should decide whether to try a suspect in the hijacking of a T.W.A. jet as a youth or as an adult. Page A8.

title: Transplant Program Suspended
description: The Loma Linda University Medical Center, which has been using life support equipment to maintain infants born with most of the brain missing, has suspended its efforts to preserve such babies' organs for transplanting.

title: Dow Rises By 14.09 to Top 2,100
description: Stock prices advanced for the sixth day in a row yesterday, but trading was again subdued.

title: VLSI Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 27
description: b-Net income

title: Japan Glimpses The Light
description: TOKYO

title: Premier Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the most significant factor in its first quarter loss was the increase in loan loss reserves by 20 percent to $82.5 million.

title: Display of Glitter in Washington Welcomes Sweden's Royal Couple
description: When royalty comes to town, Washington pulls up its socks.

title: INSIDE
description: Devils Lead Hockey Series

title: Review/Television; The National Problem of Child Care
description: ''Who Cares for the Children?'' makes a thoughtful case: the future is threatened because children today get short shrift; the scarcity of good day-care centers is a national problem. The program, on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, is persuasive.

title: Slain Officer Was Honored For His Work
description: Officer Anthony Oswald McLean of the New York City housing police was on duty less than three years but he had already been cited four times for meritorious police work and was regarded by colleagues and supervisors as a dedicated officer.

title: Talking Deals; The CBS Rumors On Network Sale
description: FROM book publishers to cable television stations to magazine groups, media properties are high on the takeover target list these days. But for many of these deals there are no textbook examples and coming up with a price tag that both sides view as fair is difficult.

title: Baseball; Pirates Blank Phillies
description: Brian Fisher allowed five hits over seven and two-thirds innings tonight and the Pittsburgh Pirates turned four Philadelphia errors in the first three innings into four runs in beating the Phillies, 7-0.

title: LOUISIANA MAN DIES IN ELECTRIC CHAIR
description: Leslie Lowenfield was executed in the electric chair early today, denying to the end that he had killed his former girlfriend and four of her relatives, including her 4-year-old daughter, in a jealous rage.

title: Mead Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 3
description: The latest first quarter earnings included a 17-cent-a-share gain from the sale of the company's recycled paperboard business. The share earnings and shares outstanding reflect the June 1, 1987, 2-for- 1 stock split. The share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Review/Theater; Gay Issues, in '10 Percent'
description: Tom Wilson Weinberg's ''10 Percent Revue'' is by no means the first musical to deal with gay and lesbian sexuality, but in confronting a range of contemporary gay-related issues, from the AIDS crisis to lesbian motherhood, it is venturesome in its modest little way. The show is at the Susan Bloch Theater, 307 West 26th Street.

title: Of Blacks and Jews
description: Nobody likes to say it aloud, but let's face it: Next week's New York Democratic primary pits the blacks against the Jews.

title: Altera Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Gaza Woman Dies After Tear Gas Attack on Home
description: A 70-year-old Palestinian woman died after a tear gas canister was tossed into her Gaza Strip home by Israeli soldiers today, according to army and other reports.

title: Charter Power Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Review/Concert; Sawallisch Conducts the Philadelphia
description: When Wolfgang Sawallisch first appeared in this country in 1964 as music director of the Vienna Symphony he was a studious, determinedly correct conductor who looked like Clark Kent and gave unobjectionable performances of the unchallengeable classics. Most young musicians who begin their careers in that way spend honorable lives redefining the concept of monotony. On the basis of Tuesday evening's concert by the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, Mr. Sawallisch has escaped that fate. If anything, the 64-year-old conductor's approach was too exuberant at times, coaxing the orchestra into uncharacteristically rough-edged attacks and shaggy releases.

title: Pop Art
description: Pepsi-Cola's looping logo has dominated New York City's East River skyline for 52 years. The huge neon sign on the bottling plant in Queens, across from the United Nations, is a familiar sight from the F.D.R. Drive. That certainly makes it a landmark, in the colloquial sense. Now someone at the Landmarks Preservation Commission proposes that it officially be so designated.

title: EXECUTION BACKED IN DRUG SLAYINGS
description: Vice President Bush today called for the ''swift'' application of the death penalty to criminals convicted of drug-related murders and challenged the Democratic Presidential aspirants to endorse similarly strong measures to reduce the flow of illegal drugs.

title: International Business Mahines Corp (IBM) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said first quarter gross income of $11,749,000,000 included sales of $7,430,000,000, maintenance services income of $1,869,000,000, program products income of $1,708,000,000 and income from rentals and other services of $742 million. Year-ago first quarter gross income of $10,681,000,000 included sales of $6,500,000,000, maintenance services income of $1,952,000,000, program products income of $1,404,000,000 and income from rentals and other services of $825 million. Revenue represents gross income.

title: Helmsleys Face An Indictment On Tax Charge
description: Indictments of the real-estate and hotel magnate Harry B. Helmsley and his wife and business partner, Leona, on fraud and tax-evasion charges are expected to be unsealed today in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Washington Talk: The Pentagon; What Terrifies the Toughest Soldiers? A Civilian Military Plan
description: The Joint Chiefs of Staff and other senior military officers, long wary of their civilian superiors' penchant for making what they see as ill-considered plans for employing the armed forces in crises, have had their mistrust renewed by recent proposals to deploy combat troops to Panama.

title: Dotson Sparkles As Yanks Roll On
description: Within their clubhouse, the Yankees are still trying to sort out their problems at shortstop: Rafael Santana appears to be out, Bobby Meacham is in and Randy Velarde is waiting patiently for a chance to play. But on the field, they remain stable and strong.

title: Walgreen Co reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Bridgeport Newspapers Purchased
description: An Illinois publishing company owned by Thomson Newspapers Inc. agreed today to buy the Post Holding Company, publishers of The Bridgeport Post, The Telegram and The Sunday Post.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday of Jesse Lasky Jr., an author and screenwriter, misidentified a novel on which he collaborated. It was ''The Offer.''

title: Algerians Board Hijacked Kuwaiti Jet to Open Talks
description: Algerian officials conducted intensive negotiations Wednesday with the hijackers of a Kuwaiti jetliner, visiting the airplane at least three times after it arrived from Larnaca, Cyprus.

title: Doris P. Haywood, Insurance Executive, 72
description: Doris P. Haywood, a retired vice president at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died of cancer of the trachea on Sunday in Baltimore. She was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Allied Bankshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes securities gains of $599,000 and $833,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: Campaign Trail
description: Koch Slogan Lives On

title: Digital Net Off Slightly In Quarter
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation reported yesterday that third-quarter net income fell slightly, to $305.1 million, from the comparable quarter a year earlier. The company blamed disappointing sales of its most powerful computers.

title: Books of The Times; Lone Cowboy vs. Settlers Circling Their Wagons
description: Trading Places How We Allowed Japan to Take the Lead By Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr. 365 pages. Basic Books. $19.95.

title: Hawkeye Bancorporation reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $7,446,000 from extinguishment of debt.

title: Argonaut Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $29.2 million from the sale of investments. c-Includes a gain of $10.6 million. The company said the gains in the latest first period was primarily from the sale of investments in Brockway Inc., in response to a tender offer.

title: New Chairman At Fred Meyer
description: Fred Meyer Inc., a retailer of general merchandise, food and apparel, said today that Frederick M. Stevens had been elected chairman and chief executive of the company, based in Portland, Ore. The 51-year-old Mr. Stevens succeeds Oran B. Robertson, 70, who will remain on the board and serve as chairman of the board's executive committee.

title: Seagate Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rent Subsidies for Poor Backed by Democrats
description: For more than a year a coalition of churches and synagogues has been unsuccessfully urging Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch to provide rent subsidies that would enable homeless families to move out of New York City's welfare hotels.

title: Digital Equipment Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 26
Canrad Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest net reflects the acquisition of certain assets and the business of Page-Wilson Corp.'s measurement systems division.

title: CMS Advertising reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 14.9% of Rowntree To Jacobs-Suchard
description: The Swiss food group Jacobs-Suchard A.G. secured 14.9 percent of the British confectioners Rowntree Mackintosh P.L.C. in a stock raid that analysts said could herald an eventual full bid. Rowntree issued a statement calling the move ''wholly unwelcome.''

title: Higher Costs Reported for Modernizing Air System
description: The Federal Aviation Administration's ambitious modernization of its air traffic control system will cost billions of dollars more than the agency estimated, a Congressional report says.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; DDB Needham Retail Gets Atari Division
description: DDB Needham Retail has landed Atari's Entertainment Electronics division, with a 1988 budget of $10 million. The former agency was Bohbot & Cohn in New York.

title: The Stakes in Algiers
description: People everywhere seem to be hardening their hearts toward terrorism. The hijackers of the Kuwaiti airliner now in Algeria might once have won sympathy from Moslem extremists and played on concern elsewhere for their hostages' lives. Now, after nine days, there seems to be a rising realization that the only way to protect future travelers is to refuse the hijackers' demands of the present.

title: Review/Cabaret; Seeing Songs as Jewels
description: Jonathan Schwartz, one of the most esthetically fastidious of cabaret artists, has long preferred to work and rework the same core of favorite songs, many of them with music by Jerome Kern or by his father, the late Arthur Schwartz. Typically, the singer approaches each song like a treasured jewel, holding it up to the light to discover at its center an idealized vision of urbane romance.

title: Compromise on Trade Bill Now Sought by Democrats
description: Congressional Democrats moved toward a compromise with the White House today on controversial elements of the trade bill, increasing chances that the legislation might escape a veto.

title: Comdata Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said comparable year-ago figures are not available; the company was formed in 1987 to acquire Comdata Network Inc. in September of that year.

title: Whirlpool Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a credit of $10.8 million from an accounting change.

title: Peter Krueger, Christie's Executive, 32
description: Peter Krueger, vice president in charge of European furniture at Christie's auction house, died Tuesday of complications from AIDS at the Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 32 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Societe Generale Shareholder Vote
description: Shareholders of Societe Generale de Belgique S.A. are scheduled to vote Thursday on the fate of Belgium's largest holding company, which is at the center of a bitter takeover battle. The special meeting, expected to attract some 1,000 shareholders and their representatives, is to be held in a specially built tent at the company's headquarters.

title: Sports People
description: A Chance for Cordero Angel Cordero Jr. will get a chance at a fourth Kentucky Derby victory aboard Brian's Time next month. The 45-year-old jockey inherited the mount yesterday because Randy Romero, who had been riding both Brian's Time and Seeking the Gold, has a commitment to the Phipps Stable to stay with the latter colt.

title: 2 Aviation Companies Indicted in Iran Sales
description: A West German franchisee of the Beech Aircraft Corporation and an Arizona aviation company have been charged with illegally exporting sophisticated military navigational equipment to Iran between 1983 and 1987, according to Federal grand jury indictments unsealed today in San Diego.

title: Little Change In Yields
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were little changed for the week ended yesterday.

title: For TV and Film Actors on Stage, The Rewards of a Sizable Pay Cut
description: Malcolm-Jamal Warner has been a television star since the age of 13, when he began his career as Bill Cosby's son on ''The Cosby Show.''

title: The New York Times Company reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included equity in earnings of forest products group of $6,834,000 for the latest first quarter and $3,129,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Health; Personal Health
description: The advertisements for a popular laxative that simply say, ''Have a good morning,'' recognize the fixation Americans have on a daily bowel movement and the fact that many people pursue this goal in vain. Unfortunately, overreliance on the solution subtly suggested by the advertisement is one of the major causes of this common problem, doctors say.

title: Sports People
description: Comings and Goings Charles Oakley of the Chicago Bulls, who is leading the National Basketball Association in rebounding, signed a six-year contract worth$1 million a year, according to a report in The Chicago Sun-Times. The new agreement supersedes a contract with one year to go that was worth $375,000 annually. . . . Sandy Lyle, the Scot who won the Masters golf tournament last Sunday, has entered the $700,000 Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic to be held at the Westchester Country Club in Harrison, N.Y. . . . When Jon Peters, a junior at Brenham High School in Texas, beat Conroe-Oakridge, 5-0, Tuesday night, he pitched his 34th consecutive victory, breaking the national high school record set by Mike Pill of West Covina High in Edgewood, Calif., from 1975-77. . . . The World Basketball League, the league for players 6 feet 4 inches and shorter that begins play May 18, has named as its first commissioner, Steve Ehrhart, former president and general manager of the Memphis Showboats of the now defunct United States Football League. . . . John Leone, an assistant coach, has succeeded Butch van Breda Kolff as head coach at Lafayette, after van Breda Kolff left for Hofstra. Tom Asbury, another assistant coach, has replaced Jim Harrick as head coach at Pepperdine, after Harrick took the U.C.L.A. job.(AP)

title: Hachette to Buy Magazine Publisher
description: In its second big deal in American publishing this week, Hachette S.A. of France agreed yesterday to pay $712 million for Diamandis Communications Inc., owner of Woman's Day, Car and Driver, Popular Photography and other consumer publications. The acquisition of the New York-based company will make Hachette the largest magazine publisher in the world, with 74 publications in 10 countries.

title: President Quits Biogen To Join Newer Concern
description: Mark B. Skaletsky is resigning as president and chief operating officer of Biogen N.V. to become chief executive of Enzytech Inc., a year-old biotechnology company.

title: Legislature Stalls Again On Budget
description: Almost two weeks after the state's $28.4 billion budget was supposed to be in place, Republican and Democratic leaders found themselves at an impasse again today when both sides chose to hold their political ground rather than pass legislation that would have amounted to an agreement by default.

title: Group of 7 In Pledge On Dollar
description: The United States and its six principal economic allies reasserted their commitment to a stable dollar today, applauded their efforts in keeping it from plunging since December and renewed their promises to do more to run their economies better.

title: Russell Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 3
Man Is Arrested Carrying Bombs On Jersey Pike
description: NEWARK, Thursday, April 14 - An anti-terrorist task force is investigating a Japanese man arrested on the New Jersey Turnpike on Tuesday with three 18-inch homemade bombs filled with gunpowder and shotgun pellets, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Teledyne Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included equity in net of unconsolidated subsidiaries of $30.6 million for the latest first quarter and $21.8 million for the year-ago period, and gains on investment sales of $63.8 million and $4.7 million for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Sports People
description: Arrested at Gunpoint Tommy Kane, an outstanding wide receiver for Syracuse University who caught 14 touchdown passes last season, was arrested at gunpoint in Syracuse on Tuesday on charges that he assaulted a police officer and then attempted to drive away. According to the police, he spent Tuesday night in jail, charged with second-degree assault and obstructing governmental administration.

title: Soviet Ends Silence on Stalin Wife's Suicide
description: The 1932 suicide of Stalin's wife has been made public for what is believed to be the first time in the Soviet Union.
