title: Grandmother's Silver Meets the Here and Now
description: THOSE who think of silver objects only in traditional terms may be surprised by the diversity of contemporary pieces in ''Silver in Service,'' an exhibit of 60 pieces by modern craftsmen that is on display at Fortunoff, the specialty shop at 681 Fifth Avenue (54th Street).

title: Review/Music; The Complete Bach 'Clavier'
description: To undertake a formal New York debut is one thing. To undertake it in two evenings playing the complete ''Well-Tempered Clavier'' of Bach is another, but that is just what Margaret Irwin-Brandon is doing. The harpsichordist offered Book I Tuesday night at Weill Recital Hall, with Book II scheduled for next Tuesday.

title: Call for a National Arts Commission
description: Declaring this to be ''a time of crisis in the state of the arts,'' the historian Arthur Schlesinger Jr. called last night for the next President to establish a national commission on the arts, whose mandate would be ''to examine the range of governmental activity affecting the arts, to propose a comprehensive arts agenda and to set goals for national arts policy in the 1990's.''

title: Drug Residues Found in Milk
description: Residues of a potentially cancer-causing drug that is used in some animal feed have been found in milk samples collected in 10 major American cities, officials of the Food and Drug Administration have reported.

title: Wider Emphasis on State of Bridges
description: The decision to close the Williamsburg Bridge for safety reasons has highlighted broader concerns about the maintenance and inspection of the 2,025 bridges in New York City, about 50 percent of which are now listed as ''structurally deficient,'' according to state transportation officials.

title: David Greer, 55, Dies; Music School Founder
description: David Greer, founder and director emeritus of Bloomingdale House of Music, was found dead in his apartment on the Upper West Side last Friday. He was 55 years old.

title: Panel Limits Role of States In Electric Sales to Utilities
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission voted yesterday to revoke the authority of New York State, and presumably all other states, to require utilities to buy electricity from small producers at prices above the prevailing wholesale cost or the utilities' own generating cost.

title: A Freed Contra Leader Tells Of 4 Years in Sandinista Jails
description: The highest-ranking contra officer to be taken prisoner by the Sandinistas is spending his first days of freedom here seeing a doctor and talking about his four and a half years in Nicaraguan jails.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-21 The gunmen holding a Kuwaiti jet acquired many weapons and explosives while the hijacked airliner spent three days in Iran last week, according to several passengers who were released in Cyprus. Page A1

title: City Investigates New Restaurant Bribes
description: As a group of current and former New York City restaurant inspectors were being indicted yesterday on extortion charges, the city's Health Commissioner said Manhattan restaurant operators were still offering bribes to inspectors in hopes of persuading them to overlook health violations.

title: State Says L.I. Landfill Skimped on Clay Liner
description: Buried beneath 130 feet of garbage here is a growing mystery that could force the Town of Southampton to close its landfill and begin trucking its garbage off Long Island at a cost of millions of dollars.

title: Irina Ratushinskaya To Read Her Poetry
description: Irina Ratushinskaya, a poet who was a political prisoner in the Soviet Union for several years, will read her poetry at 8 P.M. April 25 at the 92d Street Y. She will appear with Adam Zagajewski, an exiled Polish poet. Admission is $8 for nonmembers.

title: 3 States Study Pepperell Bid
description: The offices of the attorneys general of New York, South Carolina and North Carolina said yesterday that they were investigating the antitrust implications of a possible merger of West Point-Pepperell Inc. and the J.P. Stevens Company, two makers of designer sheets and towels. Stevens, citing regulatory hurdles, favors a rival bid from Odyssey Partners, an investment firm.

title: Without Any Rights?
description: Thirty-five years ago the Supreme Court held that an alien legally resident in this country cannot be made to leave without a fair hearing. ''His status as a person within the meaning and protection of the Fifth Amendment,'' Justice Harold H. Burton said, ''cannot be capriciously taken from him.''

title: Metro Matters; Draft 'Padlock': The Long Path To a Cuomo No
description: Mario M. Cuomo is a man of his words. There have been many of them in the last year about whether he would accept a draft from his party to run for President.

title: Liberty National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Music; 23 Guitars and a Melody
description: The 23 acoustic guitarists that make up the League of Crafty Guitarists sat in a semicircle facing the audience at Washington Square Church on Monday night. Starting on the left, each guitarist played one note in sequence, person by person, until a melody landed in the lap of Robert Fripp, their leader, on the far right. The composition set the rules for the rest of the sold-out show: mixing theater, music, and audio effects, Mr. Fripp turned music making into an amiable ritual.

title: Keep the Auto Insurance Business Competitive; Cost of Litigation
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Caseworkers Indicted in Deaths of Infants
description: Criminal misconduct charges have been filed against two former social workers in the deaths of two abused children whose cases they monitored.

title: First Union Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Boxing Notebook; Camacho Looking for Suitable Opponent
description: Two new promoters, Gerry Cooney and Dennis Rappaport, as SuperFights Unlimited Inc., stage their first bout tonight: Roberto Duran against Paul Thorn in Atlantic City, televised by the USA Network, starting at 9 o'clock.

title: Winfield Heckert, 85; Helped Develop Nylon
description: Winfield W. Heckert, a chemist who worked on the development of nylon, died April 4 in a nursing home in Wilmington, Del., after a long illness. He was 85 years old and lived in Wilmington.

title: Steel Complaint Rejected
description: The European Community executive commission today dismissed complaints by West German steelmakers over illegal state subsidies reportedly given to other European steel companies. ''We have no proof of illegal British or French subsidies,'' a commission spokesman said. The West German Iron and Steel Federation had said on Tuesday that it wanted the commission to examine apparent violations of a European Community ban on subsidies not directly related to plant closings.

title: Bolidism: Furniture That's on the Move
description: ''BOLIDISM,'' Massimo Iosa-

title: Designs Take Heed Of Human Frailty
description: WHEN Ronald L. Mace attended the North Carolina State School of Design in the early 1960's, the world around him was not accessible. A wheelchair user since age 9, when he contracted polio, Mr. Mace had to be carried up and down the stairs to attend classes, and could not get his wheelchair into the bathrooms. Much has changed since Mr. Mace's student days, in part because of the efforts of people like the 46-year-old architect himself, a pioneer in the field of accessible architecture and ''adaptable'' housing: houses or apartments with built-in features designed to accommodate the changing needs of all occupants as they age.

title: In Syracuse, Students Are the Disenfranchised
description: To the Editor:

title: Montreal Journal; In Plain English, Printer's Sign Is a Cause Celebre
description: Allan Singer has paid a price for his principles, and whether that makes him courageous or stubborn could get you a good argument in many of this city's bistros and bars.

title: Drug Use Found in 20% of Crews in Train Wrecks
description: One in five crews involved in train accidents last year had at least one member who tested positive for drugs or alcohol, the General Accounting Office reported today.

title: Ad or Art? A Connecticut Court Must Say If Statute Covers Statue
description: For an hour today, Connecticut's highest court listened to arguments on whether a 32-foot-tall sculpture was a work of art, or merely a sign.

title: On Main Street, a Parade of Views as Vote Nears
description: As the campaign for President comes to this historic Hudson River village, the process of running through the choices can almost be seen on the faces on Main Street.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Health Insurance in Massachusetts To Cover All; Victory for Dukakis
description: The State Legislature narrowly approved a bill early today that would make Massachusetts the first state to guarantee health insurance to all residents.

title: Caterpillar Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Television; Programs Especially for the Young
description: Suddenly, it seems, quality programming for young people is popping up on the schedule. Tomorrow, two circuses come to television town. And tonight at 8 o'clock on cable, the Arts & Entertainment Network offers the premiere of a mini-series of half-hours based on Gerald Durrell's autobiographical book ''My Family and Other Animals.''

title: At Bengali School: Slates, Then Land to Till
description: It took just five minutes to memorize her homework poem, said Nazma Akhtar proudly, and she can recite it so fast that the words run together in a flash of 10-year-old enthusiasm: Orange flower, orange flower, Flower of orange, Orange flower will get married With emeralds in her ears.

title: Flyers' Hextall Struggles
description: Ron Hextall isn't talking, which brings to two the number of things he isn't doing lately. Stopping pucks is the other.

title: De la Renta: Luxury, Variety, a Special Grace
description: SIZZLING colors. A symphony of lengths. High-waisted coats and floating capes. Chemise dresses and pants, pants, pants. All the fashion touchstones of the new season were on hand at Oscar de la Renta's fall and winter opening in Manhattan yesterday, beautifully executed.

title: University Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jet in Unscheduled Landing
description: A Korean Air Lines Boeing 747 jetliner flying from Seoul to New York made an unscheduled landing here early today after a man wielding scissors was restrained by passengers and crew members. The police said a few people, including the assailant, suffered minor cuts. The assailant was removed from the plane and taken to a mental hospital for observation.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Bank International, a unit of the American Express Co.'s American Express Bank Ltd. that serves international clients under the provisions of the Edge Act, said Antonio Moreno had joined the bank as senior vice president.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bank of New York announced that its tender offer of 1.575 shares of its common stock and $15 a share for each share of Irving Bank Corp. had been extended to April 21.

title: Texas Bank's Leader Faced Disaster Before
description: If Albert V. Casey has any detailed knowledge of banking, it is because ''I've been a borrower,'' he told reporters Tuesday, moments after he accepted the job as chairman and chief executive of the struggling First Republicbank Corporation.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY AD HOC COMMITTEE ON INDIAN OCEAN-10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMISSION ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL COMMISSION ON TRANSNATIONAL CORPORATION- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: THE decision to become a parent begs the next question: how many children? For many people, especially those not sure whether to have one or two children, it is a question not easily answered.

title: Cities' Total Debt: 8 Owe a Fifth of It
description: Eight cities account for more than one-fifth of all the debt owed by American cities, the Census Bureau reported today. Municipal debt in the United States totaled $164.8 billion at the end of the fiscal year 1986.

title: Farrakhan Restates His Support Of Jackson in Criticizing the Press
description: Louis Farrakhan, the Black Muslim leader who is widely viewed as anti-Semitic, said tonight that although the Rev. Jesse Jackson had denied and rejected him, he still supported Mr. Jackson for President.

title: First of America Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mayfair Super Markets Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding shown above are class A. The class B share earnings for the latest periods are 40 cents for the quarter and 78 cents for the 6 months, compared with the year-ago periods of 29 cents and 56 cents, respectively. The shares outstanding for class B for the latest periods were 1,481,762 for the quarter and 1,483,714 for the 6 months, compared with 1,575,080 and 1,576,522 for the year-ago periods, respectively. Class A and class B share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split issued in August 1987. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Williamsburg Bridge Decay Is Worse Than Feared
description: The Williamsburg Bridge, eerily silent and nearly empty yesterday after being abruptly and completely closed for safety reasons on Tuesday night, is far more corroded in its steel roadbed structure than engineers had previously feared.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I can tell you right now that I have no affection for these 'kiss and tell' books that are being written, and I find it entirely fiction.'' - President Reagan, on a book by his former press secretary. [ A22:1. ]

title: Costly New Medications Overtake Diuretics in Treating Blood Pressure
description: After years of prescribing diuretics for patients with high blood pressure, doctors are increasingly turning to expensive new drugs that they believe will be more effective.

title: Morgan, J P & Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said latest first quarter net income increased about $43 million as a result of a U.S. federal income tax refund and related interest. The credit loss provision for the latest quarter was $50 million, compared with $35 million for the year-ago period.

title: Thruway Approves A Toll Rise
description: The New York State Thruway Authority board today approved an increase in tolls of 40 percent for trucks and 30 percent for automobiles.

title: Reagan Expresses Surprise At Fabrications by Ex-Aide
description: President Reagan, commenting for the first time on the newly published book by his former spokesman Larry Speakes, said today that he had been unaware that the aide had fabricated Presidential quotations and given them to the press.

title: Georgia-Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter included a pre-tax gain of $6 million from liquidation of investments.

title: Amoco and Exxon
description: The Amoco Production Company, a unit of the Amoco Corporation, and its partner, the Exxon Company U.S.A., said they had discovered a significant oil and gas field in the Gulf of Mexico. ''Results of a well drilled by Amoco and Exxon indicate that this Viosca Knoll discovery could be one of the larger deep-water finds to date in the Gulf of Mexico,'' said Richard Flury, an Amoco vice president. Development of the tract in Federal water 55 miles east of the Mississippi River delta could begin in the early 1990's, Mr. Flury said.

title: BanPonce Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Jazz; All-Stars from Australia
description: A dozen of Australia's leading jazz musicians, brought together as the Australian Jazz Orchestra as part of the celebration of Australia's bicentennial, is making a brief American tour, which has brought them to Carlos 1, Avenue of the Americas between 9th and 10th Streets, for three days through tonight.

title: USG Lists Choices On Buyout Offer
description: The USG Corporation filed a report with the Securities and Exchange Commission outlining its alternatives in fighting a $1.9 billion hostile tender offer from Desert Partners Ltd., a partnership controlled by the Texas oilmen Jack E. Brown and Cyril Wagner Jr. Desert Partners has offered to purchase up to 39 million shares of USG at $42 a share.

title: For France, 2 Candidates, One Ad Firm
description: Jacques Seguela and Jean-Michel Goudard are partners in one of France's most successful advertising companies. But they represent two powerful clients competing for the same market - votes in the nation's presidential election.

title: Senate Panel Urged to Toughen Curbs on Killing of Dolphins
description: Senators and environmentalists joined today in calling for an end to the accidental but extensive slaughter of dolphins by foreign fleets fishing for tuna in the Pacific.

title: Federal National Mortgage Assn (FNMA) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains on sales of mortgages of $9.3 million and $27.0 million for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: Maxicare in Accord On Repaying Debt
description: Maxicare Health Plans Inc. said it had agreed with its banks on terms for restructuring $175 million in debt. The Los Angeles company had previously reported a $60.9 million loss for 1987, putting it out of compliance with its agreements with the banks, led by the Bankers Trust Company.

title: A Fauvist's Intact Studio Is 'Privatized'
description: LEAD: The home and intact studio of an important French modern artist have been acquired by a private buyer, rather than by an organization that had sought to insure permanent public access to the landmark site.

title: Review/Theater; The Fanon Prescription
description: For Frantz Fanon, Algerian psychoanalyst and ideologist of violent revolution, the diagnosis and treatment of a colonized people required as much Marx as Freud. Toby Armour's play ''Fanon's People'' is based on Fanon's most influential book, ''The Wretched of the Earth.'' Published in 1961, the year of his death, it drew on his experiences with Algerian revolutionaries to argue that national liberation was the only therapy for the ailments of colonialism.

title: Keep the Auto Insurance Business Competitive
description: To the Editor:

title: Automatic Data Processing Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Music: Noted in Brief; Charles Neidich Offers New Clarinet Concerto
description: Charles Neidich won the Naumburg Foundation's clarinet competition in 1985 and is still collecting parts of his prize, the latest installment of which was the concerto by Joan Tower that he unveiled at the American Symphony Orchestra's Sunday afternoon concert, conducted by Jorge Mester, at Carnegie Hall.

title: Karol Fageros Short, Tennis Champion, 53
description: Karol Fageros Short, a former tennis champion who stirred a clothing controversy at Wimbledon 30 years ago, died of cancer Tuesday. She was 53 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Dow, Ending Six-Session Rally, Falls 2.98
description: LEAD: Wall Street ended its six-session rally yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell back from its latest post-crash high, closing at 2,107.10, off 2.98 points.

title: Review/Rock; Mayhem by the Screaming Messiahs
description: Mayhem lurks within loud, basic rock-and-roll. As the music tears along, a listener ought to wonder just how long mere song structure can keep the lid on devastating emotions. Although most rockers like to think their music carries a sense of danger, few bands come closer to raw mayhem than the Screaming Blue Messiahs, the English trio that rocked the Ritz on Friday.

title: Reading Lamps: Versatile And Easy on the Eyes
description: THEY come shaded in silk and lavishly fringed, in hand-hammered copper, even in paper printed in mock tortoiseshell. Floor lamps, in many guises and fitted with standard incandescent bulbs, are once again gaining popularity, especially for reading.

title: Branch Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results reflect the application in 1988 of Statement No. 91 of the Financial Accounting Standard Board.

title: It's Almost Like Being In Paris
description: VISITORS to Paris in the last few years have no doubt noticed that the city is in architectural ferment. From I. M. Pei's glass pyramid in the majestic courtyard of the Louvre to the Musee d'Orsay by Gae Aulenti and the Opera House at the Place de la Bastille by Carlos Ott, exciting, large-scale projects are changing the look of the historic city.

title: Ewing Has 41 in Romp
description: With Patrick Ewing's awesome scoring leading the way, the Knicks' speeding playoff express moved into the No. 7 spot last night with an easy, 127-107 romp of the slipping Indiana Pacers at Madison Square Garden.

title: Securities Industry Loss
description: In the wake of the October stock market collapse, the securities industry absorbed an unprecedented $2.25 billion pretax loss for the fourth quarter in 1987, according to a report by the Securities Industry Association.

title: Carnegie Hall Announces 1988-89 Season
description: Carnegie Hall announced yesterday that its 1988-89 schedule will include four concerts by the Vienna Philharmonic conducted by Leonard Bernstein, who will be at the end of his yearlong 70th-birthday celebration. Also on the schedule is the rarely seen Sergiu Celibidache, who will make two appearances leading the Munich Philharmonic. Returning to the hall after a brief absence is the Chicago Symphony, in two concerts conducted by Sir Georg Solti.

title: CBS Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $866.6 million. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $40.9 million. Prior year results are restated for the disposal of the company's magazine and recorded music operations.

title: Colt Earnings Surge
description: Colt Industries more than doubled its first-quarter profit, to $23.2 million, or 64 cents a share, from $9.4 million, or 28 cents a share, a year earlier, the metal-products company said yesterday. Sales rose 1.3 percent, to $415.3 million from $410.1 million.

title: U.S. BEGINS INQUIRY ON FINANCIAL VIGOR OF TEXAS AIR CORP.
description: The Government today announced a broad investigation of the Texas Air Corporation, the nation's largest airline company, to determine its financial stability and whether its management ''is disposed to comply'' with safety rules.

title: Owner of Office Leased by U.S. Helped Meeses
description: A prominent Washington real estate developer arranged a job for the wife of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d while the developer was negotiating a $50 million office lease for the Justice Department in a building he owned, according to public records and a spokesman for Mrs. Meese's employer.

title: Amazon Projects Threaten More Indians
description: To the Editor:

title: King World Productions reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Pollution of Boston Harbor Brings a Fine of $2.4 Million
description: Massachusetts will pay $2.4 million for polluting Boston Harbor in a settlement reached after negotiations over several years, a top state official said today.

title: Bill to Protect Historic Shipwrecks Goes to Reagan
description: The House of Representatives today approved a measure intended to protect thousands of historic shipwrecks from the intentional or accidental harm caused by sport divers, archeologists and salvagers.

title: Ad Hoc Events on Ghetto Revolt Irk Warsaw
description: Plans to organize independent events to mark the 45th anniversary of the Warsaw ghetto uprising have provoked bitter Government charges that the political opposition is exploiting the ghetto memory for ''petty, shallow and ad hoc political games.''

title: Nissan to Export Fewer Cars to U.S.
description: The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's No. 2 auto maker after the Toyota Motor Corporation, will reduce car exports to the United States to ease pressure from mounting inventories, Nissan officials said. They would not say how big a reduction is planned, but Japanese press reports, which Nissan called speculative, said the company will cut shipments of passenger cars by about 30 percent, to 200,000, in the April-September period, from 283,000 a year earlier.

title: For Commuters and Shopkeepers, a Trying Day Without the Williamsburg
description: The first full day of commuting without the Williamsburg Bridge witnessed crowded subways and rush-hour delays yesterday, with bumper-to-bumper vehicle tie-ups stretching for miles.

title: Delegate Tally
description: Current breakdown of Presidential preference of delegates to national political conventions, compiled by The New York Times. Preferences are based on state laws, party rules, delegates' public statements and projections from early results in caucus states. DEMOCRATS

title: Devils Cautious Despite Edge
description: The Devils are a game away from eliminating the Islanders from the Stanley Cup playoffs, but they refuse to admit they have the advantage over their Patrick Division rivals.

title: Calendar: A Look at a Borough's History
description: History of Queens, Queens Historical Society, Kingsland House, 143-35 37th Avenue, Flushing; 718-939-0647.

title: Market Place; Fund Managers Beat the Indexes
description: AFTER trailing the Standard & Poor's 500 index for four of the last five years, the average independent investment manager beat that index in the first quarter, and by a large margin.

title: Japan Trade Bank Enters U.S. Market
description: The Export-Import Bank of Japan is entering the United States debt market by offering $150 million of 9 percent guaranteed notes due in 1998 at a price of 99.075, to yield 9.142 percent, through a group of underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: The Injustice Department
description: LEAD: When it comes to demonstrating hostility to enforcing civil rights laws, the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division, under Assistant Attorney General William Bradford Reynolds, never gives up. He recently announced his intention to obtain dismissal of more than 200 school desegregation cases. Permanent injunctions against racial discrimination would also be dissolved.

title: Review/Dance; Premieres Offered By Muller
description: Jennifer Muller/The Works is a company of sleek, good-looking dancers who perform sleek and good-looking dances and look as if they enjoy it. And there is an audience for that, to judge by the exuberant applause that greeted Ms. Muller and her dancers in curtain calls on Tuesday, at the opening of a two-week season at the Joyce Theater. But there is not much going on beneath that pretty outer shell.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Letters of Hate
description: Madalyn Murray O'Hair, the matriarch of the American atheist movement, is luxuriating in what she says ''must be the longest running hate-mail campaign in history.''

title: Changing the Face of West Berlin
description: IT was a do-it-yourself Saturday last month as ordinary West Berliners moved ordinary furniture into a new apartment building on Wilhelmstrasse, a short block from the Berlin wall. On the bleak street, once the site of the headquarters of the Gestapo and the S.S., the sight of people balancing armchairs on their shoulders and threading sofas through narrow doorways was an almost miraculously normal scene.

title: Sports People
description: Accidental Shooting Walter Payton, who retired from the Bears as the National Football League's career leader in rushing yardage after last season, was involved in the accidental shooting of the manager of Payton's suburban Chicago restaurant yesterday, police said.

title: Review/Jazz; Robbie Scott in His Monday Mode
description: From Tuesdays through Sundays, Robbie Scott is Bobby Short's drummer at the Cafe Carlyle, but on Mondays he leads an unusually versatile 11-piece orchestra, the New Deal Swing Band, at the Red Blazer Too, a restaurant at 349 West 46th Street.

title: Westinghouse Electric Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago figures were restated to reflect accounting changes which reduced net by $3.5 million and revenue by $6.1 million.

title: RUSSIANS EXPLAIN '79 ANTHRAX CASES
description: Soviet doctors are visiting the United States this week to present the most detailed public explanations to date of a 1979 epidemic that is at the center of American assertions about Soviet biological warfare programs.

title: Review/Dance; A Mystical Celebration
description: One could not doubt the seriousness of ''Summ,'' the mystical work choreographed and designed by Manhong Kang presented Sunday night at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights. Yet, though high-minded, ''Summ'' was theatrically anemic.

title: First Pennsylvania Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains of $3.5 million on sale of investment securities and a gain of $1.5 million from the sale of lease financing residual values. c-Includes investment gains of $500,000.

title: Barnett Bank Of Florida Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest first quarter includes the effect of adopting statement ofASAS No. 91, whi r requires banks to recognmze certain loan fees and costs or r the term of the loan rather than at the time it is made. Prior year was restated to reflect the accounting change.

title: Marketing Systems of Amerca reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Itokin America, a marketer of Japanese apparel, to Gleckler & Company, for the introduction of Minna, a line for juniors.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Driving Without the Williamsburg Bridge
description: If you must drive between Brooklyn and Manhattan, remember:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Senate's Lame Duck
description: On his first day as the Senate's lame-duck majority leader, Robert C. Byrd added an authorial note to his authority at a news briefing yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: Hachette to Buy Diamandis

title: Jackson's Burden Among Jews: Fear Overpowers Unity on Civil Rights
description: Some Jews speak of pain, some speak of anger. Some recall, with a bittersweet nostalgia, the days of civil rights solidarity and wonder why that feeling disappeared. For a very large share of New York's Jewish voters, the most important thing about the 1988 Presidential campaign is the candidacy of Jesse Jackson.

title: Recalling Opulent Interiors Of 1800's
description: LEAD: PROOF positive that conspicuous wealth and display are not limited to a certain set of New Yorkers in the late 1980's may be witnessed through July 15 at the New-York Historical Society in an exhibition on lavish interiors of 19th-century houses in New York.

title: Eastern Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $193,198 from discontinued operations. Year-ago figures are restated to reflect the sale of the company's Pattin division.

title: A 3-Part Offering By RC Holdings
description: RC Holdings Inc., formed by Odyssey Partners, First National Bank of Chicago and Allen & Company to effect the leveraged buyout of Research-Cottrell Inc. in July 1987, is offering $275 million of debt securities in three parts through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Leftists Defy Sandinistas As Labor Strife Hits Peak
description: As the Sandinistas and contras prepare for full-scale peace talks, labor conflict in Managua is reaching its highest level since the 1979 revolution.

title: William Styron Chosen For MacDowell Medal
description: The writer William Styron is this year's recipient of the Edward MacDowell Medal for lifetime achievement. The award is given annually to a writer, composer or artist for excellence in the arts by the MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, N.H.

title: Police Officer Is Fatally Shot in Brooklyn Housing Project
description: A 27-year-old housing police officer wearing a bulletproof vest was shot once and fatally wounded early yesterday in a Brownsville public housing project in Brooklyn that has long been troubled by crime and drug trafficking.

title: Big Florida School District Offers $134.4 Million Bonds
description: The Broward County School District of Florida, the country's eighth-largest school district, is offering $134.4 million of bonds with a maximum yield of about 7.825 percent for an issue maturing in 2007.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Peggy Green, Jack H. Irving and Carol Karasick have been promoted to executive vice presidents at Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton.

title: Willamette Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kaydon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reagan on Democratic Campaign Special to The New York Times
description: President Reagan, in an assessment of the 1988 Presidential campaign, said today that it was unfortunate that the Rev. Jesse Jackson's campaign seemed to have drawn attention more because he is black than because of his policy proposals.

title: Colt Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 3
description: b-Includes a gain of $11,732,000 from the sale of Fairbanks weighing division, and is after $39,813,000 interest expense and a charge of $2.5 million from fees related to the pending merger of the company with Colt Holdings Inc. c-After $44,547,000 of interest expense.

title: Music: Noted in Brief; Mozart and Schubert Heard at the Frick
description: The Coull String Quartet, a British ensemble, made its New York debut Sunday afternoon at the Frick Collection. Formed in 1974 and named for its first violinist, Roger Coull (the other players are Philip Gallaway, violinist; David Curtis, violist, and John Todd, cellist), the group produces a bright, robust sound and plays with a stylistic command that matches its exuberance.

title: Sports People
description: Measure Vetoed Gov. Kay Orr of Nebraska vetoed yesterday a measure that would have paid football players at the University of Nebraska. She said she objected to it because ''an expression to the National Collegiate Athletic Association through the enactment of a statute is inappropriate.''

title: Bronx Woman Recants Kidnapping Assertion
description: A Bronx woman who was beaten during a racial attack last month lied to investigators when she told them she had been kidnapped over the weekend by a man who warned her not to testify at the trial scheduled in the attack, the Bonx District Attorney said yesterday.

title: Furniture By Women On Exhibit
description: TWO women, one an art dealer and the other a furniture historian, have collaborated on an exhibition that focuses on the role of women in furniture design. ''Pioneer & Pioneering 20th Century Women Furniture Designers & Furniture Designer/Makers'' - a tongue-twister of a title - is an informative presentation of a little-investigated subject.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: THE most important outfit of a Catholic girl's childhood, with the exception of her first Communion dress, was the annual Easter outfit. Ah, it was grand, and silly. White patent-leather shoes, perhaps a blue suit with a bolero jacket, short white gloves and socks, a purse and, of course, a hat. My mother had a soft spot for straw sailors with a ribbon around the brim and an elastic underneath the chin to hold it on, an elastic as itchy as my petticoats. In snapshots, I look pretty hilarious in this get-up. To begin with, it takes at least a decade of being saddled with a purse before you really know what to do with one. And I always looked cold, because I always was.

title: Atom Waste: Worth Money To Bikinians?
description: While the people of Bikini struggle to rid their homeland of contaminants from atomic bomb testing after World War II, the Government of their island group has cracked open the door to a new nuclear presence in the central Pacific republic.

title: Zenith Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included inventory writedowns of $4.8 million.

title: IC Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $19,600,000 and a gain of $23,700,000 from an accounting change. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,400,000.

title: Utility Fined $50,000 for Reactor Problem
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission has fined Northeast Utilities $50,000 because the company failed to monitor reactor pressure properly at the Millstone 3 nuclear power plant during a recent shutdown, a spokesman for the utility said today.

title: Stephane Grappelli's All-Star Birthday
description: The jazz violinist Stephane Grappelli is sitting in his hotel lobby, waving animatedly to his bassist. Dressed in plaid flannel pants, a paisley wool shirt and loafers, his silver hair slicked back, he looks like a kindly, avuncular gentleman farmer. His eyes are blue, washed-out. He doesn't look like he's been playing jazz for 50 years, nor does he seem worried about his concert tonight at Carnegie Hall, an all-star celebration of his 80th birthday. ''Where can I find clothes to buy?'' he asks seriously, as if the answer might change the course of history. ''Saks?'' ''Too busy, unless you go early in the morning,'' says his press agent. ''Ahh''

title: Restoring the Glow of Faded Rosewood
description: LEAD: Brazilian rosewood, a great favorite in the Victorian period, was probably more popular with the polisher than with the cabinetmaker. This dense wood came from slender trees that could not produce wide boards. The framework and narrow panels of a piece of furniture were usually made of solid wood, but the wide surfaces were made of veneer, or thinly sliced wood.

title: Woman Has Abortion, Violating Court's Order on Paternal Rights
description: A pregnant 18-year-old Indiana woman whose boyfriend won a court order last week forbidding her to have an abortion violated that order and had the abortion yesterday, about the time the Indiana Supreme Court was to consider whether to take up her appeal.

title: HIJACKERS TOOK ON WEAPONS IN IRAN, EX-HOSTAGES SAY
description: The pro-Iranian gunmen holding a Kuwaiti airliner acquired a substantial arsenal of weapons and explosives while the hijacked jumbo jet spent three days in Iran last week, several passengers released here said today.

title: China Gives Managers Greater Control in Industry
description: A law intended to strip grass-roots Communist Party committees in state enterprises of much of their power and concentrate decision-making in the hands of technocratic managers was approved by China's legislature at its closing session today.

title: NCNB Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $4.1 million, or 5 cents per share, from the sale of certain factoring assets. c-Included securities gains of $6.4 million, or 8 cents per share, for the latest first quarter and $4.4 million, or 6 cents per share, for the year-ago period.

title: Too Soon to Back Down on Drugs
description: Latin American governments fall hostage to billion-dollar drug cartels. Drug dealers corrupt American law enforcement officers with bribes of $50,000 for overlooking single loads of narcotics. And the flood of drug imports rises so relentlessly that people of intelligence and good will are starting to raise despairing questions:

title: Critic's Notebook; The Games Public Television Plays
description: Will the real public television please stand up? It could be the name of a new game show, but, unfortunately, the question has come to haunt the system that was established, in the words of E. B. White, to ''address itself to the ideal of excellence, not the idea of acceptablilty.'' As they say in the very best New York neighborhoods, lotsa luck.

title: Health; When a Baby Cries: Researchers Seek Clues To Potential Problems
description: Perhaps no sound is so compelling to parents as the crying of their baby. Now scientists are finding that the wail of a newborn infant can signal not just hunger or discomfort but may sometimes warn of serious neurological trouble.

title: First National Cincinnati Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains from an accounting change of $3,066,000 for the latest quarter and $4,297,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: Little Improvement Is Seen In Mistake Rate of I.R.S.
description: Though the tax season has been proceeding relatively smoothly in the face of the vast changes in the tax law, Congressional investigators testified today that the Internal Revenue Service is still making an alarming number of mistakes.

title: Plaza Won't Be the Plaza Without Eloise
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Telecommunicaions reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Voyage in Africa Yields Tale of Stubbornness
description: This is a tale of one man and his donkeys, of unwavering commitment and loyalty in the face of broken bones, bankruptcy, angry fists and a hodgepodge of other woes. Four years ago, George Tardios, a poet and English lecturer from London, set out to retrace the 1,500-mile journey that Sir Henry Morton Stanley made in 1871 across what is now Tanzania to find Dr. David Livingstone.

title: Bet Twice a Winner
description: Bet Twice, last year's Belmont Stakes winner, scored a 3 1/2-length victory in his first start as a 4-year-old yesterday in an allowance race at Keeneland Race Course in Lexington, Ky.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Chesnokov Beats Gioroni: Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, the top-seeded player, struggled a bit in the first set, then breezed in the next to advance yesterday to the second round of the Swatch Open tournament at the Nice Tennis Club in France. Chesnokov, who has improved his world raking from 52d to 17th this year, had to play almost two hours before disposing of Michele Gioroni of Italy, 7-5, 6-2. In other matches, Guy Forget, seeded eighth, downed Thierry Champion, 6-3, 6-3, and Thierry Tulasne eliminated Tarik Benhabiles, 7-5, 7-6. Jean-Philippe Fleurian of France beat Gustavo Garetto of Argentina, 6-3, 7-6, and Jerome Potier of France upset Jimmy Arias of the United States, seeded fourth, 3-6, 6-2, 6-4, in the completion of suspended matches. Also, Henri Leconte of France, seeded third, defeated Diego Narciso of Italy, 7-5, 6-1.(AP) Carlsson Defeats Davin: Kent Carlsson of Sweden, seeded first, defeated Franco Davin of Argentina, 7-5, 6-1, in the second round of a $93,400 tournament at the Club de Campo in Madrid. In other second-round matches, Roberto Arguello of Argentina beat Joergen Windahl of Sweden, 6-3, 6-4; Alberto Mancini of Argentina downed Emilio Sanchez of Spain, seeded third, 2-6, 6-3, 6-3, and Fernando Luna of Spain beat Martin Jaite of Argentina, seeded second, 6-4, 6-1. Eduardo Mazza of Italy upset Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina, seeded fourth, 7-5, 6-2; Alberto Tous of Spain beat Pedro Rebolledo of Chile, seeded seventh, 6-3, 6-4; Eduardo Massi of Argentina eliminated David de Miguel of Spain, 6-4, 6-3, and Carl Limberger of Austria, defeated Tomas Carbonell of Spain, 6-1, 3-6, 6-2.(AP) Rive and Shiras Advance: Joey Rive and Reif Shiras overcame two fellow Americans, Gary Donnelly and Jim Grabb, 1-6, 6-4, 6-2, to advance to the quarterfinals of the men's doubles in the Japan Open in Tokyo. In another second-round match, Andy Kohlberg and Robert Van't Hof, seeded third, beat two other Americans, Matt Anger and Greg Holmes, 6-4, 7-6. In first-round doubles matches, an American team, Peter Fleming and Tim Pausat, seeded seventh, beat Wolfgang Popp of West Germany and Eliot Teltscher of the United States, 6-4, 6-4, and Brad Drewett and Kim Warwick of Australia, seeded fifth, defeated Todd Nelson of the United States and Roger Smith of the Bahamas, 6-3, 6-4. (AP) Navratilova Gains: Navratilova advanced yesterday toward her first meeting against Steffi Graf in seven months by beating Sabrina Goles 6-3, 6-3 in the Bausch and Lomb Championships on Amelia Island, Fla. Navratilova, seeded second, will meet ninth-seeded Sandra Cecchini of Italy. The top-seeded Graf, who did not play yesterday, will face a qualifier, Donna Faber of Bradenton, Fla., in today's third round. Faber surprised 12th-seeded Judith Wiesner of Austria, 6-3, 4-6, 6-3. Laura Garrone of Italy beat 11th-seeded Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia 7-6, 6-0. Kathleen Horvath of Largo, Fla., upset seventh-seeded Mary Joe Fernandez of Miami 7-6, 6-3. Third-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina eliminated Beverly Bowes of Lubbock, Tex., 6-4, 6-4. In other matches, Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany beat Camille Benjamin of Bakersfield, Calif., 6-2, 6-2 and Zina Garrison of Houston beat Halle Cioffi, a University of Florida freshman, 6-1, 3-6, 6-3. Cecchini beat unseeded Shaun Stafford, a sophomore from the University of Florida, 6-1, 6-2.(AP)

title: Pope & Talbot Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
7 Step Down At Columbia
description: Seven professors stepped down yesterday from administrative positions at the Columbia Business School after a dispute over faculty hiring.

title: Laclede Steel Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results include a charge of $924,000 from a special retirement program.

title: Mcorp Expects $58.2 Million Loss in First Quarter
description: Mcorp, the second-largest bank holding company in Texas, said today that it expected a $58.2 million loss for the first quarter, nearly as much as its $59.5 million loss in the last quarter of 1987.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: CELEBRATING spring by dancing around a Maypole may have waned, but the homeowner's annual spring trek around the house is alive and well. Touring the exterior of your home is an opportunity to assess and repair winter damage. And small efforts at patching and rejuvenating, if made early, can prevent major work later.

title: Manassas Journal; Ex-Marine Is Leading New Battle of Bull Run
description: People here are calling it the Third Battle of Bull Run, and it has drawn much attention from northern Virginia suburbanites. The struggle pits conservationists and Civil War buffs against those who see themselves as the forces of progress.

title: Ballet Theater Season To Offer 3 New Works
description: New dances by Agnes de Mille, Clark Tippet and Mark Morris will be part of the American Ballet Theater's spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House, from next Monday to June 11. The ballets are ''The Informers,'' choreographed by Miss de Mille to Celtic tunes; ''Bruch Violin Concerto No. 1,'' choreographed by Mr. Tippet, a principal dancer with the company, and ''Drink to Me Only With Thine Eyes,'' choreographed by Mr. Morris to music by Virgil Thomson.

title: ETHIOPIA CURTAILS FAMINE AID WORK
description: Ethiopia's chief relief official said today that international famine-relief operations in the north would be allowed to resume only after the Government defeats rebel troops there.

title: Immucor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes tax credits of $152,761 and $401,842 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $93,381 for the quarter and $281,595 for the 9 months.

title: F. A. Gianninoto, 85, Designer
description: Francesco A. Gianninoto, an industrial designer whose creations included the Marlboro flip-top cigarette box, the orange roof for Howard Johnson restaurants and Elsie the Borden cow, died of kidney failure last Friday at the Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Redding, Conn.

title: Baseball Notebook; Rookie Shortage in Majors
description: After two years of lush rookie growth, the major leagues have opened this season with a mediocre market on first-year players. No Mark McGwires or Kevin Seitzers or Wally Joyners or Jose Cansecos are to be found.

title: Canterbury Educational reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Princeton Outrows Penn for Childs Cup
description: LEAD: Princeton's heavyweight crew spoiled the debut of its counterpart from Pennsylvania today, defeating the Quakers in the varsity and junior varsity races to win the Childs Cup, America's oldest collegiate rowing trophy.

title: Why Nuclear Arsenal Is Israeli Open Secret
description: To the Editor:

title: Consul Restaurant Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $160,000 from net operating loss carryover.

title: Review/Theater; An Update On Sin In America
description: Watchface, a young, seven-member performance group based on the Lower East Side, belongs to the broad tradition of experimental theater that encompasses the Talking Band, Mabou Mines and other ensembles in which individual actors, writers and dancers pool their talents into collective collages. Their work is strongly dance-oriented and uses ritualized ensemble movement along with the group chanting of slogans and cliches to suggest powerful social pressures pulling at individuals.

title: Washington Bancorporation reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Washington Bancorporation is the parent company of the National Bank of Washington.

title: Glatfelter, P H Company reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results for the latest period include the contribution of the Ecusta division, acquired in May 1987. For the period, the division had sales of $53,219,000 and net income of $3,367,000, or about 14 cents a share.

title: J.P. Morgan Posts 24.3% Gain in Net
description: J. P. Morgan & Company yesterday reported a 24.3 percent increase in first-quarter net income. This included a one-time gain from a Federal tax refund and reflected higher earnings from the corporate finance activities of its principal subsidiary, Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

title: Sports People; McEnroe Returns
description: In Tokyo to play for the first time in eight months in a major tournament, the $752,500 Japan Open, John McEnroe said yesterday he would compete actively for the next year and a half before deciding on the rest of his tennis future. He has not played in a major competition since last September in the United States Open.

title: Rustlers Kill 15 Kenyans
description: Nine men were accused of sweeping into a nomadic camp, tying up 15 men and hacking them to death in a goat-rustling raid, a newspaper reported today. Wielding spears, rifles and machetes, the rustlers killed the nomads and stole 2,500 goats in a March 30 raid near Garbatulla, about 320 miles north of Nairobi, according to the independent Daily Nation. Police tracked down the nine suspects, all Kenyans of Somali origin, earlier this month. The suspects denied the charges in court Tuesday, and another hearing was set for April 26, the newspaper said.

title: The President's Misspokesman
description: Larry Speakes has disclosed that, as President Reagan's press secretary, he sometimes manufactured Presidential quotes. On two occasions detailed in a kiss-and-tell book about his life at the top, Mr. Speakes says he put words in Mr. Reagan's mouth and fobbed them off on unsuspecting reporters. Worse, the President didn't object.

title: Reagan Defends Effort Against the Drug Trade
description: President Reagan today defended the Administration's efforts to rid the nation of illegal narcotics.

title: MANY IN CONGRESS HAIL AFGHAN PACT
description: The Afghanistan settlement was praised by many members of Congress today as Secretary of State George P. Shultz prepared to leave for Geneva for the signing ceremonies.

title: Lojack reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
Q&A
description: Q. My house has aluminum siding.

title: Eldon Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 19
Bridge
description: A few lucky players picked up the hand of a lifetime Monday night. They found themselves with the South hand shown in the diagram, with immediate prospects of a grand slam.

title: Genetics Institute reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After a gain of $5,732,000 from the sale of equity investment.

title: John M. Cory, 74, Ex-Head of Library In New York City
description: John Mackenzie Cory, who retired in 1978 as director of the New York Public Library after 27 years with the institution, died of a heart attack on Monday. He was 74 years old and lived in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Marines Fire on Panama 'Intruders'
description: United States military spokesmen said today that 100 marines had been drawn into a two-hour night firefight with ''40 to 50 unauthorized personnel'' in military uniforms who had been spotted on the grounds of an American fuel depot.

title: Vehicle Sales Off 10.8% In Early April Period
description: Early April sales of new American-made cars and light trucks dropped 10.8 percent from the comparable period last year, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: If Felons Publish, They Should Profit
description: LEAD: The New Jersey Assembly, by a 78-0 vote, recently approved an amendment to existing legislation that would prevent imprisoned criminals from realizing any profits whatsoever from any book or movie they have written while in prison. This measure, if enacted into law, would discourage me from using my First Amendment rights.

title: FlightSafety International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Child Care for Job-Training Teen-Age Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: Names Parents Choose
description: Ashley and Samantha are in, but Elizabeth is out after 23 years. Jason is passe, but Matthew is back for the first time since the days of John, Paul, George and Ringo.

title: Senate Vote on Drugs Breaches Budget Limit
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly tonight to spend more money on enforcing drug laws even though the budget would then exceed spending limits agreed to by Congress and President Reagan last fall.

title: Review/Theater; Hollywood Ambitions, Cold Realities
description: Etta Jenks arrives in Los Angeles hopeful, homeless and eager to become a movie star. Discouraged by a lack of opportunity, she is soon acting in pornographic films and her Hollywood ambitions fade into memory. Marlane Meyer, a California playwright, has taken this ancient story and turned it into a sardonic, eye-opening plunge into a contemporary netherworld. Ms. Meyer's play, ''Etta Jenks'' (at the Apple Corps Theater) may chill theatergoers with its amoral air, but as a slice of seamy life, it has the hard-edged intensity of a Martin Scorsese film.

title: CBS Income Surges on Asset Sales
description: CBS Inc., the holding company that owns one of the three nationwide television networks, reported yesterday that its net income for the first quarter of 1988 increased by more than eighteen-fold from the comparable period a year ago, primarily as a result of the sale of its records division to the Sony Corporation in January.

title: Review/Music; A Palette of 6 Composers
description: Musicians' Accord, a contemporary music group resident at City College, lists composers of every stripe among its advisers and supporters, from neo-Romantics to post-Minimal experimentalists. Given that, the range of styles it offered Monday evening at Weill Recital Hall was rather constricted, with the emphasis on angular aridity, broken only occasionally by bursts of lyricism or flights of spirited fantasy.

title: For Many Jews, Jackson Is Issue
description: For many Jewish voters, the New York primary campaign is very much about one candidate, the Rev.

title: Commerce Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
League Is Tougher In Gooden's View
description: The Mets spent the day off yesterday looking for apartments and houses for the summer after a rousing return to New York in their home opener. But they agreed that the most critical thing they had to find was the pitching that carried them to their championship in 1986 before it broke down in 1987.

title: UST Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago figures restated to reflect the acquisition of Valley Bank and Trust Co. on April 2, 1987.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Commercial Maker Seeks The Story
description: AFTER spending the winter months in the warmer climes of Los Angeles as he usually does, Rick Levine, the television commercial director, was recently back in New York - for a day or two at least.

title: Engineer Cited in Metro-North Crash
description: Railroad officials said yesterday that a commuter train crash in Mount Vernon, N.Y., last week was probably caused by the failure of an engineer to engage an automatic safety system or to heed outside signals telling him either to slow or stop.

title: Farmers and Batus In Dispute on Talks
description: The Farmers Group Inc. and Batus Inc. continued to spar over ground rules for negotiations on Batus's proposed $4.5 billion takeover of the insurer. Faced with an afternoon deadline to meet Farmers' conditions for talks, Batus, a subsidiary of Britain's B.A.T. Industries, said it was willing to raise its $63-a-share bid but refused to meet Farmers' terms.

title: Review/Concert; An Abundance of Chausson
description: A program devoted entirely to the works of Ernest Chausson does not, apparently, stir much enthusiasm in New York's concertgoing public; the concert by the New York University Chamber Music Society at Merkin Hall Monday was very sparsely attended.

title: Australian Stock Loss
description: Ten government agencies, which invest in stocks, lost $918 million (about $680 million American) in October's market crash, the Victoria state parliament was told in an auditor's report today.

title: Home Savings & Loan Assn of Durham reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Edwin B. Katte, Banker, 74
description: Edwin B. Katte, a retired vice president and trust officer of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 74 years old.

title: York International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
International Research & Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Oneok Inc reports earnings for 12mo Feb 29
Lawyer Says Biaggi's Firm Got Stock for Unpaid Services
description: A lawyer who worked for the former law firm of Representative Mario Biaggi testified yesterday that he was told by one of the partners in 1985 that the Wedtech Corporation gave the firm 5 percent of its stock for unpaid services.

title: Missile Pact's Application to Exotic Arms Debated
description: Two former senior Administration officials have told Congress that American and Soviet negotiators never considered exotic weapons like lasers and particle beams in negotiating a new treaty banning medium- and shorter-range missiles based on land.

title: Afghan Opium Yield Up As Pakistan Curbs Crop
description: The mountains on both sides of the rugged border of Pakistan and Afghanistan are abloom again with poppies. Before the year is out, their sap, refined into a white powder, will be pouring into the veins of heroin addicts in the United States.

title: Sunwest Financial Service reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $3.1 million gain from the sale of bonds.

title: A Tribute To a Man Of Design
description: TONIGHT, collaborators, friends and admirers of Charles Eames will join his wife, Ray, in a celebration of the career of the industrial designer and architect, who died in 1978. For 38 years, the Eames office in Venice, Calif., created important projects in architecture, furniture, exhibitions, films and graphic design.

title: Put Children Ahead of Career, 3 Experts Advise
description: To balance work and family, parents must reorder their priorities to put their children before their jobs and possessions, three child-care experts said here last Saturday at a forum titled ''Making Work and Family Work.''

title: Ariel Dorfman, Agonized Exile, Writes to Fight
description: When the Chilean President Salvador Allende Gossens died in a military coup in 1973, and his democratically elected Government was overthrown, Ariel Dorfman went into political exile. Supporters of Allende were being tortured and murdered or simply disappearing; Mr. Dorfman, a young journalist and university professor, thought that surely the dictatorship established by Gen. Augusto Pinochet would fall and it would soon be safe to return to Chile.

title: Kentucky Utilities Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Life Seen For Old Store In Times Sq.
description: At a venerable but historically treacherous Times Square site, Charles B. Moss Jr. is rebuilding the former Bond clothing store as a complex called Criterion Center, adding a legitimate theater, cabaret and lounge to an existing movie house.

title: Hathaway Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: One Black Manager
description: Frank Robinson's appointment Tuesday as manager of the Baltimore Orioles means that a black man is once again in charge in a major league dugout. But Mr. Robinson is an established commodity, and it would be a mistake to construe this as a big step forward in the effort to deepen the pool of potential black managerial talent.

title: I.B.M.'s Net Up 16.3% As Big Computers Sell
description: Showing significant strength in sales of its most expensive and powerful computers, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that its first-quarter net income rose 16.3 percent, to $913 million, from the year-earlier quarter.

title: KEY RATES
Ex-Seoul Chief Quits Posts Over Scandal
description: Former President Chun Doo Hwan, under heavy fire because of a corruption scandal surrounding his brother, resigned today from his remaining posts in the Government and ruling party, and apologized publicly ''for causing trouble to the people.''

title: Signet Banking reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Health; Physicians May Safely Stop Drugs for Some Epileptics
description: Doctors may safely discontinue medication for many epilepsy patients who rely on the drugs to control seizures, according to a new study.

title: Dr Pepper/7-Up Stake to Be Sold
description: Hicks & Haas, the leveraged buyout specialists active in the soft-drink industry, announced today that it had agreed to sell a 49 percent share in what will become the Dr Pepper/Seven-Up Companies to the merchant-banking arm of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. for $600 million. An agreement in principle to merge the Dr Pepper Company and the Seven-Up Company was announced today.

title: When the Lawn Yields to the Meadow, the Perfect Perennial
description: FOR several years many American gardeners have shown increasing interest in meadows. They eye their lawns, consider the expenditure of time and money and energy they require and flirt with the notion of replacing them with summer wildflowers, like black-eyed Susans, Queen Anne's lace and chicory.

title: Music: Noted in Brief; 12 Early Sonatas On Period Instruments
description: ''Sonata,'' in the 17th century, meant simply a piece to be ''sounded'' by instruments, not a particular form for organizing a composition. The most common disposition for much of that time was a trio of players: one for the treble line, one for the bass, one - whose part might not be written down - to fill in harmonies. Twelve such works, all from Italy, were offered at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday evening by three leaders of the early instruments movement: Frans Brueggen playing recorder; Gustav Leonhardt, harpsichordist, and Anner Bylsma, cellist. A smaller room would have been better, but the concert was a success.

title: Ousted Police Chief Is Dead
description: Police Chief Jess F. (Doc) Hale of Little Rock, suspended last month after his arrest on theft charges, was found dead Tuesday in his home. He apparently committed suicide. Mr. Hale was arrested March 10 outside a Little Rock drug store and was charged in the theft of less than $200 from a cash register. He pleaded not guilty and was released on his own recognizance. His trial was to begin May 24. Tom Dalton, the Little Rock City Manager, said the fatal gunshot wound ''appears to be self-inflicted.'' There was no suicide note.

title: Women Seek Place on the Masthead
description: The annual convention of the overwhelmingly male American Society of Newspaper Editors today addressed the issue of the dearth of women in top positions at the nation's newspapers.

title: Times Company Net Up 11%
description: The New York Times Company yesterday reported record first-quarter net income of $45.5 million, or 56 cents a share, an increase of 11 percent over the figure for the first quarter of 1987.

title: EAC Industries Inc reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,131,000 for the latest year and $487,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Recall Effort in Denver Fails
description: A recall effort to oust Mayor Federico Pena has apparently failed, an election official announced today, saying that petitions submitted fell more than 2,000 names short of the number required by law.

title: Keystone Heritage Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend payable May 10 to holders of record April 29.

title: Applied Power Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains from tax benefits of $200,000 and $650,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $10,435,000 for the quarter and $10,291,000 for the 6 months.

title: Retail Sales Rose 0.8% In March
description: Propelled by Easter buying at department and food stores, retail sales rose a healthy eight-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: International Electronics Research Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income

title: A Lift for Torn Luggage
description: WHEN an overzealous baggage handler mangles your suitcase, where do the airlines send it for repair? American, Eastern, Pan Am and United, among others, send damaged bags to John R. Gerardo Inc., a 99-year-old luggage repair company that takes in about 500 bags a week from airlines alone.

title: A POWER STRUGGLE IS SEEN IN MOSCOW
description: Reports of a bitter clash between Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the Communist Party's No. 2 official, Yegor K. Ligachev, have swept Moscow in recent days, reviving questions about political instability in the leadership.

title: Iraq Says It Repulsed Offensive
description: Iran and Iraq today both reported heavy fighting in northeastern Iraq where Iran mounted an offensive this week. The two sides also reported new Iraqi missile attacks on Teheran, the Iranian capital.

title: Hibernia Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Gorbachev Encourages U.S. Ties
description: The Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev told 500 American executives and top officials of the Commerce Department today that better international relations and Soviet economic reforms offer potential for a new economic relationship between the two superpowers.

title: Gillette Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Morton Downey Found Not Guilty of Assault
description: A Municipal Court judge today found a television talk show host, Morton Downey Jr., not guilty of charges that he assaulted a guest on his program.

title: NEW CHART ON MARKET 'SENTIMENT'
description: Beginning today, The New York Times's market indicators will include a weekly chart of the putcall ratio, a measure of stock market ''sentiment,'' or expectations.

title: Koch Hints That New York City May Have More Money to Spend
description: Mayor Koch, who has forecast fiscal retrenchment for New York City all winter long, yesterday gave the first gentle spring hint that there might be more money to spend in his budget for the coming fiscal year than he has so far found.

title: New Premier in Italy Forms 5-Party Cabinet
description: Ciriaco de Mita, the Christian Democratic leader, unveiled his new Cabinet today as he formed Italy's 48th postwar Government.

title: Police Chief in Dallas Resigns After Months of Controversy
description: Police Chief Billy Prince, under fire from top city officials for criticizing City Council members and opposing changes in the Police Department, has resigned.

title: Citytrust Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: All financial data for 1987 has been restated to reflect new methods of accounting for loan fees and income taxes which were adopted in the fourth quarter of 1987.

title: Sports of The Times; The Last Of the Rockies
description: WHILE most National Hockey League players were still mucking in the corners, Aaron Broten and Joe Cirella always had a head start on vacation, not that it was much fun.

title: Banks Waits for N.F.L. Calls
description: Carl Banks is sitting at home in Flint, Mich., hoping the telephone will ring. He hopes the caller will be a National Football League team offering big money for his services, and if that team is the Giants, so much the better.

title: Raytheon Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 3
Woody Kling, 62, Dies; Writer of TV Comedy
description: Woody Kling, a television comedy writer, died of lung and brain cancer at U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles Sunday. He was 62 years old.

title: North Side Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $773,000 for the quarter and $1,814,000 for the 6 months. The latest 6 months results included a pre-tax charge of $1.76 million from losses on the sales of two delinquent real estate loans and two properties classified as other real estate.

title: Lee Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $11,160,000 on the sale of assets.

title: Bond Prices Move Slightly Higher
description: Bond prices inched higher in light trading yesterday as market participants awaited this morning's report on merchandise trade.

title: Book Fair: An Amplitude Of Ephemera and Curiosa
description: Writing with a ballpoint pen in green ink on the back of one of the manuscripts of his wife, Mary, in 1951, Ernest Hemingway jotted down some possible titles for a book he was working on that he called his ''sea'' story. The titles included: ''The Strange Old Man,'' ''A Strange Old Man'' and ''Book IV of an Untitled Work.'' Elsewhere, he tried ''What Men Can Do.'' Finally, he settled on: ''The Old Man and the Sea.''

title: Westinghouse Credit reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago figure restated to reflect implementation of SFAS No. 91.

title: Imperial Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
In Baltimore, a New Style at City Hall
description: When William Donald Schaefer was Mayor of Baltimore, it sometimes seemed that his name was emblazoned on every city park bench, garbage truck, office building and new construction project that might come within even the peripheral vision of a voter.

title: Dukakis Gets Puerto Rico Delegates As He and Gore Argue Nuclear Force
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. strongly attacked Gov. Michael S. Dukakis yesterday as making what he called ''unwise and irresponsible'' statements on the use of nuclear force, while Governor Cuomo called the Rev. Jesse Jackson's success ''the manifestation of the American idea at its very best.''

title: Corrections
description: A report in Business Day yesterday about a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of AM International Inc. incorrectly identified some defendants in the case. The commission is continuing its investigaton of the accounting firm Price Waterhouse and three of its partners. The brokerage house Paine Webber

title: Islanders' Coach Expects Better Effort
description: As the Islanders straggled off the ice from what could be their final practice this season at their home arena, their coach, Terry Simpson, took inventory of his team's shortcomings.

title: Cambridge Medical reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bridge
description: Some deals appear to belong in Ripley's ''Believe It or Not.'' An example is the diagramed deal reported in a Finnish publication a decade ago.

title: Sun Microsystems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
description: Both year-ago periods' results restated to reflect acquisitions made by Sun during the fourth quarter of that year.

title: The Fewer the Votes, The More Each Counts
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; 'Return to Snowy River,' a Sequel
description: There is a perfectly nonthreatening first love in ''Return to Snowy River,'' between a boyish, handsome hero and a tomboyish, beautiful heroine. She has a stern, loving father. A handsome villain wants to marry her. But the strongest characters in this 19th-century Australian adventure are the horses. Wild horses stampede through emerald-green woods and glide in slow motion across a river. There are race horses, tame horses, dead horses, everywhere magnificent horses.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Fast Track Gone
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has closed down a fast track to power and influence for young economists by eliminating the position of special assistant to the chairman. Earlier, the assistants of the former chairman, Paul A. Volcker, had moved on to positions in the Federal Reserve banks and on Wall Street.

title: KEY RATES
Korean Air Lines's Deal With Boeing
description: Korean Air Lines has ordered six advanced-model 747-400 jumbo jets and placed options on four more planes in a deal worth more than $1.5 billion, the Boeing Company announced. The airline also made public a previously unannounced $374 million order from K.A.L. for a 747-300 Combi and two 747-200 freighters to be delivered later this year. The package includes spare parts and support, a Boeing Commercial Airplanes spokesman, Tom Cole, said. K.A.L. already has three 747-400's on order for delivery beginning in April 1989. Deliveries of the new 400 series orders will continue into 1994.

title: Boise Cascade Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-3 stock split in January. The company said sales, costs and expenses of its consumer packaging division, which was sold at the end of the 1987 first quarter, were eliminated from the year-ago first quarter report. The division's operating income of $2,171,000 was included.

title: Review/Dance; Taylor Dancers in Work by a Company Alumnus
description: ''Homeward,'' a new dance by Christopher Gillis that was presented by the Paul Taylor Dance Company on Wednesday at City Center, is thought-provoking on a number of levels. Mr. Gillis created his first major piece of choreography a year ago, when Mr. Taylor generously sponsored a program of work by four of his dancers. In last year's piece, a solo called ''Paean,'' Mr. Gillis essentially explored the potentials of his own way of moving, in a piece whose sense of mass and shape clearly owed something, too, to Mr. Taylor's view of dancing. Now Mr. Gillis has branched out.

title: Cullen-Frost Bankers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Intergraph Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Washington Talk: Justice Department; Officials Sing Discordant Tunes on Minority Pacts
description: For years, the Reagan Administration's much-proclaimed opposition to racial preferences that favor members of minority groups and women over white men has had a soft spot in it.

title: Sequel Is Being Written To 'Gone With the Wind'
description: A 54-year-old Southern author who attended Vassar College on a scholarship from the United Daughters of the Confederacy has been chosen to write a sequel to ''Gone With the Wind.''

title: Dr. Robert S. Mendelsohn, Medical Critic, 61
description: Dr. Robert S. Mendelsohn, a physician, author and critic of the medical establishment, died after a brief illness at his home here April 5. He was 61 years old.

title: The Law: At the Bar
description: Long before Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power, the spirit of glasnost swept through the American Bar Association. However different the two countries' political systems, the association's leaders believed that American and Russian lawyers spoke a common language, one that could be used to promote peace.

title: Review/Film; Rudolph's 'Moderns' Looks at la Vie de Boheme
description: Since he made ''Welcome to L.A.'' in 1974, Alan Rudolph has been demonstrating that a modest amount of talent and money, and a lot of nerve, can buy a certain degree of credibility and visual style.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Saxophonic Quotations Sonny Rollins, Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street (840-2824). The tenor saxophonist Sonny Rollins unfurls solos laden with danger. They'll work themselves into a closet, shut the door, then miraculously appear somewhere else in the room. And he has a sense of humor. Quotes -everything from cartoon music to Irving Berlin - tumble out of his saxophone, making his solos immense pastiches of American culture. Though his material isn't always perfect, and though his band sometimes stumbles instead of swings, Mr. Rollins himself is without peer: he's one of the greatest saxophonists America has produced, a musician who keeps an audience tense with anticipation. The show is at 8 tonight. Tickets: $20. Keyboard Nights

title: STOCK PRICES FALL
description: In a major surprise, the nation's trade deficit grew sharply to $13.8 billion in February, as imports surged more than twice as much as exports, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: An All-Star Weekend Of Gospel
description: Gospel is never far from the surface of American culture. Wherever black churches bind families and communities, a thriving, ecstatic performing tradition has evolved through generations - a tradition as familiar, even to nonbelievers, as the high-flown melismas of Whitney Houston or the oratorical cadences of Jesse Jackson.

title: Queens House Fire Kills Boy
description: A 12-year-old boy was killed yesterday morning in a house fire in South Jamaica, Queens, that fire officials have classified as arson.

title: Waitz Is Anxious
description: In her eight victories in the New York City Marathon and in her triumphs all over the world, Grete Waitz has always appeared calm, relaxed, impervious to the pressures of running and winning. Now, she says, ''I am nervous, excited, like I never ran before.''

title: Greenman Brothers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Includes $1,049,000 from a cumulative accounting change for both the quarter and year. c-Restated to reflect an accounting change. The company said the net was reduced by LIFO adjustment of $729,000 in the latest quarter and year, and $27,000 in the prior quarter and year. Year-ago quarter and year include a restructuring provision which reduced results by $798,000.

title: MNC Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter included a $12 million reduction in deferred tax liabilities, which was the cumulative effect of the adoption of FASB Statement No. 96, accounting for income taxes.

title: First Michigan Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The 'Hidden' News on Society Pages
