description: LEAD: Anytime I want to plug into what's going on in American life, I find the society pages more fertile territory than the news sections. In the engagement and wedding announcements, the message seems clear: At least in urban areas, our lives have begun to mirror comedy films.

title: Taxpayer Complaints Seem to Be Getting Louder
description: With tax season drawing to a frantic conclusion, the grumblings of Americans seem to have grown louder as they learn from their accountants exactly what the new system has wrought.

title: At Shortstop for the Yankees: Confusion
description: They have a history of unusual and unpredictable moves, and today the Yankees made another one.

title: New President Named At Hill, Holliday USA
description: Jack Sansolo, 43, already vice chairman, marketing and worldwide development, of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, has been given the additional job of president, H.H.C.C. USA, which puts him in charge of the Boston and New York offices. Jack Connors remains president and chief executive of the entire company.

title: FIERCE FIGHTING STILL LIKELY
description: Pakistan, Afghanistan, the Soviet Union and the United States signed agreements today providing for the withdrawal of Soviet forces from Afghanistan and the restoration of a nonaligned Afghan state.

title: Macy Restructuring Is Seen; New Units Are a Key Factor
description: In an effort to slash expenses and tighten controls, R. H. Macy & Company will undergo a sweeping internal consolidation, retailing industry sources said yesterday. The move is said to spring from Macy's agreement last week to acquire the Bullock's and I. Magnin divisions of Federated Department Stores Inc.

title: Market Place; A Brighter View Of Hospital Corp.
description: THE outlook for the Hospital Corporation of America seems to have brightened after a year of major restructuring, and some analysts are predicting that the big Nashville-based chain may lead the way in improved performances in the hospital business.

title: Inventories Climb Slightly
description: Rebounding sales helped dampen growth of business inventories in February to a slight one-tenth of 1 percent after four big monthly increases, the Government reported today.

title: Baltimore Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $323,000 from the extinguishment of debt. c-Includes a gain of $2,600,000 from an accounting change.

title: On Stage
description: Simon Says: Slam the Doors

title: EA Engineering Science & Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29

BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Dr Pepper/7-Up Deal Is Profitable for Pair
description: LEAD: For two investment partners, Thomas O. Hicks and Robert B. Haas of Dallas, Wednesday's sale of part of their Dr Pepper and Seven-Up companies to Prudential-Bache for $600 million, was, in the words of Dr. Pepper's current advertising campaign, ''Just what the doctor ordered.''

title: Strickland's Move
description: Rod Strickland, a junior guard at DePaul, will probably not make use of his final year of college eligibility, and it is likely that he will make himself available for the National Basketball Association draft June 28. ''The handwriting's on the wall,'' said Bill Bradshaw, the athletic director. ''If I only had $5 left, that's what I'd bet on now. Rod hasn't told me definitely that he's gone, but his lips say one thing and his eyes say another.''

title: Potlatch Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said latest quarter results were helped by a reduction of $3.2 million in expense related to stock appreciation rights compared to 1987.

title: 2 Palestinians Killed in Clashes With Israeli Army
description: Two more Palestinians were shot to death by soldiers in the West Bank today during a clash in which rocks were thrown at troops.

title: Peoples Heritage Savings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Refac Technology Developent Corp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $153,000 for the quarter and net of $18,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $146,000 for the quarter and $374,000 for the year, and tax benefits of $6,000 and $15,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Military Infighting Seen Behind Honduran's Arrest
description: A bitter factional struggle within the armed forces contributed to the Honduran decision last week to hand over a major drug-trafficking suspect to the United States, and that action has in turn intensified the struggle, according to Honduran Government officials and foreign diplomats here.

title: Honk Kong Exchange Case
description: The former Hong Kong stock exchange chairman, Ronald Li, who is already accused of bribery, may face more charges linked to corruption, the prosecution said today.

title: Lin Broadcasting Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $711,000 from discontinued operations. The company said the latest first quarter net income was reduced by $3.4 million because of market price declines in adjustable rate preferred stocks.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Heavy Emphasis On Graded Stakes
description: Nearly 40 3-year-olds are being considered for the Kentucky Derby, but only 20 will be permitted to start on May 7. Some of the most prominent candidates could be among those excluded.

title: Suitor Sees Irving Bid Advancing
description: The chairman of the Bank of New York Company said yesterday that he believes he has won shareholder backing to issue new shares needed for the bank's $1.08 billion hostile bid for Irving Bank Corporation.

title: Italian Loses Fight for Seats On Belgian Societe Board
description: The Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti lost the showdown today in his battle for Societe Generale de Belgique, Belgium's largest company.

title: Managua Journal; And on the Home Front, They Watch Home Plate
description: From the miserable slums of Managua to the remote jungle villages that dot the Atlantic coast, all Nicaraguans have a common focus this week.

title: General Nutrition Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 6
description: b-Net income

title: Gore In the Big City
description: A strange thing is happening to Al Gore on his way to the New York primary. Actually, quite a number of strange things are happening to him.

title: NEW YORK IMPACT COULD AID JACKSON
description: Mayor Koch threw a surprising twist into New York's Democratic Presidential primary yesterday, endorsing the underdog, Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee, and saying it was ''irrelevant'' that the move might help his least favorite candidate, the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: Ford Plans to Raise 2d-Period Dividend
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would increase its second-quarter dividend to 60 cents a share from 50 cents a share, the amount paid in the previous two quarters. It is to be paid in June to shareholders of record as of May 2. The increase is the 10th since the third quarter of 1983, when Ford resumed paying a dividend after an 18-month hiatus during the 1982-83 recession.

title:
About Real Estate;
Co-ops Built in Brooklyn For Low-Wage Families
description: LEAD: There are few city neighborhoods without at least one nonprofit group working to provide decent, affordable rental housing for low-income households. But one group, Brooklyn Ecumenical Cooperatives, which operates out of a storefront on Atlantic Avenue in downtown Brooklyn, has a special goal - giving local residents a chance at home ownership.

title: Another Hostage Freed as Captors Negotiate
description: The hijackers of a Kuwaiti airliner released one hostage tonight, but prospects for the release of the other captives shifted throughout the day.

title: Senators Seek Delay of Military Sale to Saudis
description: A bipartisan group of 58 senators asked the Reagan Administration today to delay plans to sell Saudi Arabia $450 million in military equipment because of disclosures that the Saudis had purchased missiles from China.

title: Frank Skaff, Baseball Manager, 74
description: Frank Skaff, a former interim manager of the Detroit Tigers and an infielder who batted .320 as a major leaguer, died Tuesday while scouting a college game here for the Tigers. He was 74 years old.

title: Warhol's World on View: Gems and Cookie Jars
description: Andy Warhol liked multiples in his art and in his collecting.

title: Unisys Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dukakis Arms Control Views Drawing Scrutiny
description: A dispute this week between Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and Senator Albert Gore Jr. has called attention to the Massachusetts Governor's views on arms control.

title: Equimark Goes To Biederman
description: Biederman & Company has emerged triumphant from a competition involving a coven of ad agencies seeking the $10 million Equimark account.

title: Court Curbs Lord, Einstein Agency
description: The Lord, Einstein, O'Neill & Partners advertising agency was ordered yesterday not to solicit or accept any clients or personnel of the Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein agency until a court hearing later this month.

title: Ewing Varies Shots and Is Unstoppable
description: For almost three seasons Patrick Ewing lived by the turnaround jumper. It was a shot that he would shoot straight up and, in many cases, fading away. If the shot missed, it left him out of the play and in poor rebounding position.

title: Review/Concert; Simon Rattle Conducts
description: The City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra, born in provincial circumstances 68 years ago, has moved into international society in recent seasons under its energetic and photogenic principal conductor, Simon Rattle. So sweeping has been its success that some British music critics have taken to using the Birmingham as a stick with which to beat London's more famous orchestras. If that puts a weight on the shoulders of the 33-year-old Mr. Rattle, who led the orchestra on Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall in its New York debut, his assured performances did not show it.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Hindustani Instruments Ken Zuckerman with Swapan Chaudhuri, Washington Square Methodist Church, 135 West Fourth Street (Information: 206-1050). One of the few Westerners playing Hindustani music, Ken Zuckerman, a student of the great Ali Akbar Khan, is regarded as an eloquent performer on the sarod, a 10-string lute that is one of northern India's most popular instruments. Mr. Zuckerman, who is also an expert in Renaissance and medieval lutes, resides in Switzerland, where he teaches at the Music Academy of Basel. He will be accompanied by the noted tabla player Swapan Chaudhuri. The concert is tomorrow at 8 P.M., and tickets are $10. A Jule Styne Tribute

title: Standard Microsystems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income

title: Marines at U.S. Depot in Panama Beat Bushes for Elusive 'Intruders'
description: American soldiers searched hundreds of acres of jungle for a second day today but failed to turn up any physical evidence of the ''40 to 50 unauthorized personnel'' that a company of marines said they fought with for two hours on Tuesday night.

title: Eugene K. Denton, 99, the Dean Of Retail Trade on Fifth Avenue
description: Eugene K. Denton, owner of the Tailored Woman, a New York specialty shop, for 48 years and a prominent breeder of Aberdeen Angus cattle in New Jersey, died Wednesday at the Sarah Frances/Tally Ho Manor nursing home in Boonton, N.J., where he had lived for five years. He would have been 100 years old on May 27.

title: Sherwin-Williams Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $490,000.

title: Albany Afternoon PaperClosing After 145 Years
description: At about 2:30 P.M. Friday, Angelo Serafino will shut off the presses at The Knickerbocker News for the last time, and Albany's No. 2 newspaper will go the way of afternoon papers in a number of American cities.

title: First Bancorp of Ohio reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Utilities Settle Nuclear Suit
description: Three Washington state utilities said today that they would pay $20 million in an out-of-court settlement to bondholders in the securities fraud lawsuit in connection with the $2.25 billion default in 1983 on two scrapped Washington Public Power Supply System nuclear plants.

title: Celebrity Readings To Inspire Children
description: The artist Keith Haring, the cookie innovator Famous Amos and the comedian Soupy Sales are a few of the celebrities who are to read aloud to children from 11 A.M. to 1 P.M. tomorrow, at the Children's Museum of Manhattan and at public libraries throughout the New York area. The readings, which are part of a six-week campaign to promote reading, are co-sponsored by Fox TV/Channel 5, the New York City Board of Education, and the public libraries of New York City, New Jersey, and Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: Empire of America Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary credit of $2,700,000.

title: The Near Totalitarian I.R.S.
description: With more than 110,000 employees nationwide, a vast network of computers and virtual freedom from external review, the Internal Revenue Service has become one of the most fearsome Federal agencies.

title: Review/Art; A Show of Great Artists Copying Great Artists
description: An exhibition that brings dignity, variety and many an echo of supreme achievement to the downtown art world in Manhattan is ''Creative Copies: Interpretative Drawings From Michelangelo to Picasso'' at the Drawing Center. The show is one of the most ambitious and imaginative ever mounted by a small nonprofit institution. It was organized by Prof. Egbert Haverkamp-Begemann of New York University, with the collaboration of Caroline Logan and the active assistance of a group of Ph.D. students. (By his account, they ''helped to select the drawings, and wrote entries for the catalogue.'') Lists normally make dull reading, but it has to be said that the artists represented in the show include Michelangelo, Leonardo, Durer, Tintoretto, Rubens, Poussin, Claude, Rembrandt, Watteau, Boucher, Fragonard, Ingres, Delacroix, Degas, Cezanne, Matisse and Picasso. Many a great museum would be proud to have a show of that stature.

title: Review/Dance; Faith, Death and a Swivel Chair
description: Not one but two unusually gifted Canadian choreographers literally swept audiences up from their seats Wednesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, during the second program of Les Grands Ballets Canadiens.

title: A News Magazine Planned for September
description: In September, The Christian Science Monitor plans to introduce a monthly news magazine called World Monitor.

title: Islanders Can't Match the Past
description: The Islanders carried a history of Stanley Cups won and improbable playoff comebacks into their series with the Devils. But the aura of past successes, many of them stunning, could not sustain the Islanders at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight and they eventually fell prey to a rougher, hungrier opponent.

title: Hope In-Law for Bork Seat
description: President Reagan announced today that he planned to nominate Judith Richards Hope, daughter-in-law of his old friend Bob Hope, to succeed Robert H. Bork on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. Mrs. Hope is a Washington lawyer and was a White House official in the 1970's. Judge Bork quite the bench in February, four months after his nomination to the Supreme Court was defeated by the Senate.

title: Grand Jury Queries Two Who Arranged Job for Meese's Wife
description: A Federal grand jury today questioned two members of the family that arranged to pay the wife of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d while leasing office space to the Justice Department.

title: Clemens Strikes Out 13; Red Sox Sweep
description: Roger Clemens pitched a six-hitter and struck out 13 today as the Boston Red Sox handed the Milwaukee Brewers their sixth consecutive loss, 2-0, on two unearned runs in the third inning.

title: Review/Theater; 'Doctor Faustus' Updated
description: In his essay ''The Two Hells of Doctor Faustus,'' Jan Kott suggests that with a certain stretching of the imagination, one could find both Faust and Hamlet at Wittenberg at the same time. ''Over a glass of sack in a local tavern,'' he conjectures, Faust could have told Hamlet ''how he summoned the ghosts of the dead.'' It is with this provocative idea in mind that one watched Leonardo Shapiro's unexciting production of ''The Tragical History of the Life and Death of Doctor Faustus'' at La Mama Annex.

title: Knight-Ridder Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
State Street Boston Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Neworld Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $191,000 from the sale of loans.

title: Sage Advice From R.N.
description: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court is George Bush's ''dream pick'' for his Vice Presidential running mate, The Washington Post recently reported. Mr. Bush would do better - it says here - to listen to Richard Nixon, who's been on one end or another of five national tickets, and who thinks Bob Dole would be the best choice.

title: 5 Eastern Planes Flunk
description: Federal officials grounded five Eastern Airlines planes because of safety violations as part of the Government's inspection of the company's 267 aircraft.

title: United Technologies Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: In the latest quarter, the company's board approved restructuring actions resulting in pre-tax charges to first quarter income of $148.8 million. The quarter also included pre-tax gains of $156 million from previously announced sales of Essex and certain assets of UT Credit Corp.

title: 'Wenceslas' Closing
description: The New York Shakespeare Festival production of Larry Shue's ''Wenceslas Square'' is closing Sunday at the Public Theater. It is to reopen at the Kennedy Center in Washington on July 5 for a five-week run.

title: Navajos Regain Custody of Baby in Dispute
description: A couple who sought to adopt the baby of an unmarried Navajo woman have agreed to give the baby back, but they have vowed to fight alongside the mother to regain custody of the child from the tribal authorities.

title: 5% Stake in Centel
description: The investor Asher B. Edelman and Metro Mobile CTS Inc., a New York-based maker of cellular telephones, raised their stake in the Centel Corporation to 5 percent of the company's shares outstanding, paying about $94 million. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the group suggested the sale of all or part of Centel, which is based in Chicago with interests in cable television, data processing, cellular communications and electricity. Centel rejected the group's approach.

title: Hardball in Capital
description: After the 14-member Task Force on the Expansion of Major League Baseball, made up of senators interested in seeing an expansion team in their states, met in Washington yesterday with Donald M. Fehr, executive director and general counsel of the players' association, there were threats to start playing hardball with baseball's antitrust exemption.

title: FNW Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pakistani Leader Says Blast At Arms Depot Was Sabotage
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq said today that he believed the devastating explosion at an ammunition dump near here Sunday was an act of sabotage.

title: Motorola Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Perelman Says Quest For Gillette Isn't Over
description: Ronald O. Perelman, Revlon Group Inc.'s chairman and thrice-rebuffed suitor for the Gillette Company, said yesterday that he had not lost interest in acquiring Gillette, according to participants at a conference in Beverly Hills.

title: First Eastern Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect the merger with Liberty Bancorp Inc. in October 1987.

title: Griffin Wins Resorts In Deal With Trump
description: Donald J. Trump, under pressure to accede to a deal that would benefit other shareholders of Resorts International Inc., dropped his opposition and agreed to sell his controlling interest in the Atlantic City hotel-casino company to Merv Griffin, the two men said today.

title: The Law: Merger Takes Chicago Firm Under
description: Since its beginnings here in 1872, the law firm of Isham, Lincoln & Beale has been one of Chicago's most venerated; the Lincoln in the name comes from one of the firm's founders, Robert Todd Lincoln, son of Abraham Lincoln.

title: Federal Paper Board Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
How About Incentives to Keep Small Businesses in New York?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dover Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Johnstown American Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income

title: Bid for Les Echo
description: Pearson P.L.C., a British conglomerate that publishes The Financial Times, said it had modified the terms of its offer for the Paris financial daily newspaper Les Echos. Pearson, which also has interests in banking, fine china and oil, modified the offer of $:88 million, or about $165 million, in an effort to overcome apparent French Government objections to the takeover. Under the new offer, a substantial minority stake in Les Echos would continue to be under French control for another year. In addition, the new offer includes pledges that certain French interests would keep their stakes in Pearson.

title: Punishing Toshiba Is a Secondary Boycott; Again, Overproduction
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; In 'Tokyo Pop,' Youth Cultures Clash
description: You don't have to be a fan of rock music to get a kick out of ''Tokyo Pop,'' a wedding of American and Japanese youth cultures as seen through a fun-house mirror.

title: Capitals Tie Series At 3 Games Each
description: As expected, there was a collapse here tonight, one that produced all the unsightly debris usually found in the vicinity of the Washington Capitals in April. This time, though, the Capitals, after mounting their second admirable stand in three days, were the ones who walked away from it all unhurt.

title: Jung Knew What the Nazis Would Do With Him
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Catholic Bishops On Missile Shield Plan
description: Following are excerpts from a statement issued yesterday by a committee of Roman Catholic bishops in the United States on the moral evaluation of nuclear deterrence:

title: N.H.L. Playoffs; Canadiens, Bruins And Wings Gain
description: Stephane Richer scored twice in the opening period and Montreal's defense shut down Hartford's attack the rest of the way tonight as the Canadiens advanced to the Adams Division finals with a 2-1 victory over the Whalers.

title: NBD Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reporter's Notebook; Poignant Change at the Top of the Editors' Society
description: There is a poignant undercurrent beneath the shoptalk and cocktail gossip at this year's convention of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

title: Silicon Valley Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said 1987 per share earnings have been restated to reflect two 5 percent stock dividends paid during 1987.

title: Clark, Dwight Firm Formed in Connecticut
description: Donald R. Dwight, newspaper publisher and Republican politician, and Harry W. Clark, former advertising and public relations man and once an aide to Republican members of Congress, have formed Clark, Dwight & Associates in Greenwich, Conn., to specialize in corporate and financial communications and affairs and public relations.

title: Assets of Funds Decline
description: Assets of the nation's 419 money-market mutual funds decreased $2.02 billion, to $274.78 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 112 institutional funds decreased $519.8 million, to $75.24 billion. Assets of the 210 general purpose funds were down $1.41 billion, to $82.23 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds decreased $97.4 million, to $117.30 billion.

title: Review/Theater; Epistles Set to Music, In Colker-Rupert 'Mail'
description: No doubt the newly increased, much reviled postal rates have made us all think twice before sending that extra postcard or thank-you note. But after sampling the avalanche of sung correspondence that comprises ''Mail,'' the musical at the Music Box, you may wish the post office had discouraged letter-writing entirely by raising the price of a first-class stamp to, say, five bucks. ''Mail'' is to epistolary fiction what Hallmark cards are to the poems of Robert Browning. Its hero, a struggling New York novelist named Alex Berkowitz (Michael Rupert), seems to receive more mail than most best-selling authors, yet it all sounds so anonymous that every letter might well have been addressed to ''Occupant.''

title: U.S. Redoubles Efforts for an Angolan Settlement
description: American officials have stepped up efforts to negotiate a settlement to the war in Angola as new indications have emerged that the Angolans would accept the withdrawal of all Cuban troops from their country over several years.

title: Relief for the Russians
description: After eight years of stalemated war in Afghanistan, the Soviet people seem ready to bring their sons home from a conflict that the Russians never really understood, and this has in subtle but significant ways changed their country and its outlook on the world.

title: Cerone to Red Sox
description: Rick Cerone, the catcher released by the Yankees at the end of spring training, signed a one-year contract yesterday with the Red Sox and will be in uniform for the game in Boston with the Texas Rangers today.

title: Unisys, Sun Microsystems and Apollo Up
description: The Unisys Corporation, the nation's second-largest computer manufacturer after I.B.M., said yesterday that its first-quarter net income rose 35.5 percent from the period a year earlier. The company said earnings had exceeded expectations and attributed the gains to cost-cutting measures as well as strong sales of work stations, document processors and entry-level and medium-range mainframe computers.

title: Plan for Dual Trading Halt Weighed
description: The chairmen of the New York Stock Exchange and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange said today that they were developing a plan to shut down all trading in stocks and stock-index futures when the Dow Jones industrial average moved up or down between 200 and 300 points in one day. Their comments were made in testimony before the House Energy and Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Telecommunciations and Finance as the Dow was heading toward a decline of more than 100 points, ''You've got to let the market seek its own level, but there comes a time when a systematic halt - a safety net - that is known in advance is helpful,'' said John J. Phelan Jr., chairman of the Big Board.

title: 10 Years in Afghanistan: The Soviet Vietnam
description: 1978 April 12: Coup overthrows dictatorship of President Mohammad Daud, who is killed. April 30: Pro-Soviet junta installs Government led by Mohammad Noor Taraki, head of Marxist party, and including Babrak Karmal as Vice President and Hafizullah Amin as Deputy Prime Minister. Government starts purge. June 30: Eight right-wing groups say they wage guerrilla war. Dec. 4: Moscow and Kabul sign friendship treaty; infighting weakens Taraki, raises Soviet influence. 1979 Jan. 7: Afghans in Pakistan say 5,000 guerrillas fight Soviet and Afghan Government forces. Feb. 14: Gunmen kidnap U.S. Ambassador Adolph Dubs, who is killed; U.S. charges Soviet role. March 21: Guerrillas mount first serious attack on Herat, killing dozen Russians. A week later Amin becomes Prime Minister. April 12: Washington denies Soviet charges that it arms guerrillas. Aug. 2: Washington warns Moscow against intervention. Days later, mutiny erupts in Kabul. Sept. 16: Taraki reported to resign, is later confirmed killed. Amin becomes President. Dec. 21: U.S. reports three Soviet divisions at Afghan border and 1,500 Soviet troops near Kabul. Dec. 26: Washington reports airlift of Soviet troops; Moscow denies it. Dec. 27: Karmal returns from exile to replace Amin, who is killed. Dec. 28: Moscow applauds Karmal's installation; Carter calls Soviet intervention a ''grave threat to peace'' and warns of ''serious consequences.'' Dec. 30: Moscow says it moved a ''limited'' contingent to Afghanistan to counter attack from abroad. 1980 Jan. 4: Carter announces first punitive measures. Jan. 5: Soviet troops total 100,000. Jan. 23: ''Carter Doctrine'' calls for resisting Soviet expansionism beyond Afghanistan. Feb. 25: Karmal Government paralyzed by anti-Soviet strikes; mass arrests reported. March 9: Up to 5,000 Soviet casualties rumored in Soviet Union. April 4: Soviet troops reportedly control cities, guerrillas the countryside. April 12: U.S. Olympic Committee heeds Carter bid for boycott of Summer Olympics in Moscow. 1981 April 24: Reagan lifts 15-month curb on grain exports to Soviet Union. Mid-December: Afghan refugees in Pakistan estimated at 2.5 million. 1982 Nov. 9: Diplomats report fuel-truck blast killed hundreds of Soviet and Afghan soldiers and civilians. 1983 Dec. 6: Diplomats report Soviet retreat north of Kabul after heavy losses. Dec. 29: Soviet deserter tells of low troop morale and drug use. 1984 Jan. 10: Guerrillas reportedly shoot down three Soviet jets in first major success against air power. Nov. 27: U.S. officials say aid to guerrillas has doubled to $280 million a year. Dec. 16: Soviet saturation bombing of villages reported to kill thousands. 1985 May 16: Seven guerrilla groups form united front, but political and social divisions continue. June 20: Pakistan and Afghan regime open secret talks in Geneva under U.N. auspices. November: Soviet press starts reporting soldiers' heroism amid public questioning of war effort. 1986 May 4: Karmal resigns and is succeeded by Najibullah, former intelligence chief. July 28: Gorbachev reports six regiments will pull out by Dec. 31. Major Soviet offensive follows. Aug. 8: Parties ''far apart'' at Geneva talks. 1987 Jan. 1: Kabul announces cease-fire; guerrilla response negative. Nov. 28: Diplomats say Moscow wants to pull out its troops, even if that ends Najibullah regime. Days later, at Washington summit, Gorbachev offers 12-month withdrawal timetable. 1988 Feb. 8: After indicating Moscow will not insist on acceptable regime, Gorbachev sets May 15 to start withdrawal if Geneva talks succeed by March 15. March 4: U.N. mediator in Geneva reports basic agreement; in weeks, talks stall over Soviet-American differences on arms shipments. April 14: After agreement on arms issue, accord on Soviet withdrawal is signed in Geneva.

title: Helmsleys Plead Not Guilty To $4 Million in Tax Evasion
description: Harry and Leona Helmsley evaded more than $4 million in income taxes by fraudulently charging such luxuries as a $1 million marble dance floor above a swimming pool, a $45,000 silver clock and a $130,000 stereo system to their hotel and real-estate empire, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Performing Arts On College Stages: High Quality At Low Prices
description: BEYOND Lincoln Center and Broadway, City Center and Carnegie Hall exists a vast, yet little-known performing-arts circuit in New York where top musicians, dancers and actors can be seen almost every day at a fraction of mid-Manhattan prices.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; The British Are Amused
description: The revelation by Larry Speakes that as Ronald Reagan's spokesman he had written comments on daily events and then put them in the mouth of the President of the United States was treated with ethnocentric amusement in London by Bernard Ingham, the press spokesman of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

title: Bid for Air Wis Of $125 Million
description: Air Wis Services Inc., the Appleton, Wis., holding company for Air Wisconsin airline, said today that it had received a sweetened $125 million tender offer from two of its directors, one of whom had served as chairman until last month.

title: Warner Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $29.7 million provision for income taxes for the latest first quarter, compared with $17.2 million for the year-ago period. Results for the 1987 quarter have been restated.

title: Contenders Take Aim At Prized Endorsements
description: Politicians spend considerable time on the telephone and in meetings seeking endorsements of their fellow politicians, contributors, union chiefs and community leaders.

title: Keillor's Tale-Spinning To Help Soup Kitchen
description: The radio personality and novelist Garrison Keillor is to tell tales of American life at 7 P.M. Sunday, at the Church of the Holy Apostles, 296 Ninth Avenue, at 28th Street. Mr. Keillor, the creator and star of the ''Prairie Home Companion'' radio shows and the author of ''Lake Wobegon Days'' and ''Leaving Home,'' will perform with piano accompaniment by Butch Thompson. All proceeds will benefit the Holy Apostles Soup Kitchen, which provides services including legal and medical assistance and a bag-lunch program for welfare hotel residents in the church's neighborhood.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY SWEDISH HERITAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The stage has now been set for the Afghan people to determine their own future, free of Soviet forces, and for the refugees to return home.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz. [ A1:6. ]

title: Chambers Development Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,272,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: The Politics of Defense
description: Few issues so clearly separate the Presidential candidates as national security. On the right marches George Bush. A little right of center is Albert Gore, a little left of it Michael Dukakis, and way beyond him Jesse Jackson. But position papers aside, there's another measure that voters will try to divine, from the candidates' signals and body language: Who would most adroitly mix diplomacy with force, and best manage the vexed politics of defense in Washington.

title: First Federal of Michigan reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $4,000 and $416,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively. The company said latest first quarter operating net includes pretax gains of $13.7 million from sales of loans and receivables . The company also said year-ago operating net includes pretax gains of $51.8 million from sales of loans and receivables.

title: News Summary
description: International A2-13 Afghan accords were signed in Geneva providing for the withdrawal of Soviet forces from the country and the creation of a nonaligned Government. Page A1 News analysis: Afghan chaos is expected to resume under the Geneva accords. More than one million Afghans have been killed and nearly one-half of the population has been uprooted. A1 The Afghan war changed the Soviet Union and its outlook on the world in subtle but significant ways. A1 A deep rift in the Honduran military contributed to the release of a major drug-trafficking suspect to Washington and that action has intensified the struggle, Government officials and foreign diplomats said. A1 A blast outside a G.I. club in Naples killed at least five people and wounded 15, including several American sailors. The police said the bombhad apparently been placed in or under a car. A3 A U.S. Navy frigate was damaged by an underwater blast in the central Persian Gulf that wounded at least 10 crew members and partly flooded the ship. However, she headed under her own power toward Bahrain. A3 Hijackers released one hostage but prospects for the release of other captives aboard a Kuwaiti airliner shifted as the hijackers held long talks with Algerian officials on the 10th day of the odyssey. A9 Sanctions against Mexico were voted overwhelmingly by the Senate on the ground that it has failed to cooperate fully in halting the flow of drugs across its borders. The measure must also be approved by the House. A6 National A14-22 The nation's trade deficit soared to $13.8 billion in February as imports surged more than twice as much as exports, the Commerce Department reported, surprising analysts. A1 The dollar plunged in reaction to the widening American trade gap, forcing world central banks to intervene to restore stability. D5 Stock prices also plummeted. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 101.46 points, or 4.82 percent, to 2,005.64. It was the index's fifth-worst point loss in history. A1 The grumblings of taxpayers have increased as the filing deadline nears. The simplicity and relief promised by architects of the new system have eluded many people. D2 A Navy heart surgeon was freed after a military appeals court set aside his conviction. The surgeon, Comdr. Donal M. Billig, was found guilty in 1986 of responsibility for the deaths of three patients. A17 Richard Nixon is in greater demand than ever. The former President, who appeared on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press'' last Sunday, plans several other television appearances and at least five speeches around the country. A14 A jetliner engine exploded and sliced into the plane, forcing the pilot to make an emergency landing in Charleston, W. Va. No injuries were reported among the 60 people aboard the Piedmont Airlines craft. A14 Storm brewing over Cape Hatteras lighthouse A14 E.P.A. declines to toughen rule on sulfur dioxide A16 U.S. Catholic bishops on nuclear deterrence A18 Politics A20-21 Mayor Koch backs Albert Gore Jr., the underdog, for the Democratic Presidential nomination. Mr. Koch said it was irrevelent that his endorsement might aid his least favorite aspirant, Jesse Jackson. A1 Gov. Michael S. Dukakis staked out an ambitious arms control platform that is much more liberal than the views of many Democratic military experts, who accuse the Presidential aspirant of naivete. A20 Hopefuls vie for best endorsements A21 Washington Talk A22 Reagan aides' disharmony on minority pacts Regional B1-5, B28 Harry and Leona Helmsley evaded more than $4 million in income taxes by fraudulently charging such luxuries as a marble dance floor above a swimming pool to their hotel and real-estate empire, the authorities said. A1 A key prosecution witness recanted key parts of his testimony against three reputed Mafia figures on trial in the murder of a police detective. Prosecutors contended the witness, Frank Simone, was recanting because of intimidation. B1 The state is studying all bridges in New York City that have deterioration levels similar to those on the Williamsburg Bridge, which was closed on Tuesday because of safety hazards. B4 A masked rapist left only one clue, his voice, in a series of attacks on Long Island. Prosecutors are relying on a ''voice lineup'' as the main way to identify the suspect, Scott Carroll, 27 years old, of Staten Island. B1 An anti-terrorist task force is investigating whether a Japanese man arrested with three homemade bombs on the New Jersey Turnpike has links with the Japanese Red Army, a left-wing group, the authorities said. B3 Jersey Shore residents are fearful about a chemical company's plan to build a $90 million plant in Toms River. The company, Ciba-Geigy, has been fined $1.45 million for dumping hazardous waste on its land. B1 The Knickerbocker News of Albany is folding and the staff of the afternoon newspaper is merging with that of the morning newspaper, The Times-Union. Both are owned by a division of the Hearst Corporation. D16 The Albany pas de deux on the budget B3 New York official says U.S. energy agency is arrogant B3 Boy killed in house fire in Queens B3 Arborcide at Temple Square B3 Two ex-military contractors indicted in fraud B28

title: Upjohn Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Playbill for What's On at Colleges in New York
description: Here is a sampling of performing arts being presented on college stages in New York. Events at colleges in the City University of New York system are listed in a free calendar that may be obtained by writing to the Office of Community Relations, City University of New York, 535 East 80th Street, New York, N.Y. 10021. The Association for a Better New York also publishes a monthly calendar of performing arts and other events at New York colleges. Write to 355 Lexington Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017. BARNARD COLLEGE, Broadway and 116th Street, 280-2079 or 280-2037. The Minor Latham Playhouse, the college's 200-seat main stage at Broadway and 119th Street, has generally free theater, dance and music throughout the school year. Each spring, the Barnard-Columbia Greek Drama Group presents Greek drama in ancient Greek. Tonight and tomorrow at 8: Aristophanes' ''Clouds.'' Tickets are $6 ($3 for students.) BARUCH COLLEGE, 17 Lexington Avenue, at 23d Street, 505-5891. Occasional free concerts include Maria Bachmann, a violinist, in Nallin Recital Hall on April 20 at 3 P.M., and ''post-modern dances'' by the Wendy Osserman Dance Company April 21 at 12:45 P.M. in the Studio Theater. BOROUGH OF MANHATTAN COMMUNITY COLLEGE, 199 Chambers Street, 618-1980. The college's Triplex theater complex has become a major downtown performance venue since opening in 1984. More than 300 professional and college events, including concerts, plays, children's theater and dance performances, are held annually in the 923-seat proscenium theater, the 282-seat Off Broadway theater and a 99-seat theater. Dance Brazil will present sambas, candomble and other folk dances tomorrow at 8 P.M., and Airjazz, a trio of dancers and jugglers, will perform April 22 and 23; tickets for both are $15 and $12. Performances geared to children are every other Saturday from October through May at 1 P.M. (the next is April 23). BRONX COMMUNITY COLLEGE, University Avenue and West 181st Street, the Bronx, 220-6312. Generally free student and professional concerts are presented in the 600-seat Hall of Fame Playhouse and the Gould Memorial Auditorium, and afternoon recitals are often held in the 280-seat Schwendler Auditorium. Coming: the Annabella Gonzalez Dance Company, April 18 and 25 at 11 A.M. and 1 P.M.; the Bronx Arts Ensemble, May 2 and 23, and Dizzy Gillespie, May 22. BROOKLYN COLLEGE, Campus Road and Hillel Place, near Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues, Brooklyn, (718) 434-1900. B.C.B.C. is short for the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College. About 80 performances by professional artists - presented by the center, an independent entity - and 250, mostly free recitals, chamber-music concerts and other college-sponsored events are held in the 2,500-seat Whitman Hall, the 500-seat Gershwin Theater and the 165-seat Sam Levenson Recital Hall each year. The Jazz Tap Ensemble, with Harold Nicholas, performs tomorrow at 8 and Sunday at 2 P.M.; tickets are $8 to $16. Coming: Mel Torme on May 7 (tickets, $15). CITY COLLEGE, West 133d Street and Convent Avenue, 690-4100. Aaron Davis Hall includes a 750-seat concert hall, a theater and a workshop space where professional and college performers appear throughout the year. Arthur Mitchell's Dance Theater of Harlem performs tonight and tomorrow at 8 and Sunday at 2 P.M.; tickets are $15. CITY UNIVERSITY GRADUATE CENTER, 33 West 42d Street, 642-2641. Occasional, mostly free performances are presented in the auditorium or third-floor studio, including an 18th-century dance workshop by Wendy Hilton on April 22 at 2:30 P.M.; a jazz concert by Howard Brofsky and Friends on April 26 at 8 P.M., and a staged reading of ''Othello'' by Sheer Shakespeare on April 29 at 6:30 P.M. COLLEGE OF STATEN ISLAND-ST. GEORGE CAMPUS, 120 Stuyvesant Place; SUNNYSIDE CAMPUS, 715 Ocean Terrace; (718) 390-7992 or 390-7951. Free concerts are presented many Sunday and weekday afternoons at the St. George campus's 125-seat College Hall, one block from the Staten Island Ferry; Ann Sohm, soprano, and Ed Brown, lutist and guitarist, perform Sunday at 3 P.M. The Williamson Theater at the Sunnyside campus presents regular concerts, including one called ''Shakespearean Inspirations'' by the Staten Island Symphony on Sunday at 3 P.M. (tickets are $9; $6.50 for students and the elderly). COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY, Broadway and 116th Street, 280- 2845. Plays and concerts take place in such facilities as Earl Hall, the Horace Mann Theater at Teacher's College, St. Paul's Chapel, Teatro Piccolo of Casa Italiana and Maison Francaise in Buell Hall and the Kathryn Bache Miller Theater (formerly McMillin Theater), now undergoing renovation. The Columbia 1988 Varsity Show, ''The Bonfire of Humanities,'' will be presented tonight and tomorrow at 8 (and April 21-23) at Ferris Booth Hall; tickets are $5; $3 for students. A jazz duo plays in the Faculty House today at 5 P.M.; the Barnard-Columbia Chorus performs with the University of Virginia Singers in St. Paul's tomorrow at 8 P.M., and the Columbia University Orchestra presents the original five-movement version of Mahler's First Symphony at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street, Sunday at 8 P.M. COOPER UNION, 7 East Seventh Street, 353-4195. The Brooklyn Philharmonic presents a ''Meet the Moderns'' concert in the school's historic, 900-seat Great Hall tonight at 8; tickets are $7. Another regular performer, the American Jazz Orchestra, will appear May 5 at 8 P.M. FASHION INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY, 27th Street and Seventh Avenue, 760-7642. The 850-seat Haft Auditorium and smaller Katie Murphy Amphitheater are used by many professional companies, including the Village Light Opera. Their ''Oklahoma!'' opens April 23; tickets are $9 to $20. The Little Orchestra Society gives a classical concert for toddlers Sunday at 1:30 and 2:45 P.M.; tickets are $20. FORDHAM UNIVERSITY AT LINCOLN CENTER, 113 West 60th Street, 841-5267. The Pope Auditorium and Studio Theater accommodate two dozen theater productions a year. ''The Wiz,'' directed by Ben Harney, runs from April 21 to 30; tickets are $10 ($5 for students and the elderly). HERBERT LEHMAN COLLEGE, Bedford Park Boulevard West, the Bronx, 960-8833. Lehman Center for the Performing Arts includes a 2,300-seat concert hall, a 500-seat theater and two smaller spaces where music, theater, dance and comedy are presented. Samuel Beckett's ''Company'' will be staged in the theater tomorrow at 8 and Sunday at 3 P.M. as part of a five-day Beckett festival; tickets are $10. The Boys Choir of Harlem will perform in the concert hall Sunday at 2 P.M.; tickets are $11 to $15. Coming later: the Aeolian Chamber Players, April 22; Pilar Rioja, April 24, and Pilobolus, April 30. HOSTOS COMMUNITY COLLEGE, 500 Grand Concourse (at 149th Street), the Bronx, 960-1009. The college is using the Teatro Puerto Rico, 490 East 138th Street, until moving into the 900-seat Savoy Manor Ballroom next winter. Coming: Dave Valentin, flutist, and Noel Pointer, jazz violinist, on May 5 at 7 P.M.; tickets are $7 and $5. HUNTER COLLEGE, 68th Street between Lexington and Park Avenues, 772-4448. Theater, dance and music can be found in the large college auditorium, the 700-seat Playhouse and the Little Theater. Euripides' ''Alcestis'' will be presented tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M.; tickets are $6 ($3 for students and the elderly). The Hunter College Symphony and Choir will present Mozart's Requiem and 36th Symphony April 27, Thurber's ''Many Moons'' is scheduled from April 28 through May 1, and the college dance company gives its spring concert April 28 through 30. JEWISH THEOLOGICAL SEMINARY, 3080 Broadway (at 122d Street), 678-8979. A two-part concert on Sunday at 4 and 7:30 P.M., featuring Habrera Hativit - a Jewish jazz-blues group - and Shlomo Bar, an Israeli composer-musician, will open celebrations of Israel's 40th anniversary; tickets are $10 for the first part, $5 for the second. JUILLIARD SCHOOL, Broadway and 66th Street, 874-7515. More than 300 concerts - including the free ''Wednesdays at 1'' series, student recitals, and performances by two student orchestras, a chamber ensemble and a contemporary-music ensemble - are presented each year at Alice Tully and Avery Fisher Halls, and the 933-seat Juilliard Theater and the 278-seat Paul Recital Hall. The drama division's spring season continues through May 1 with four productions, including Turgenev's ''Month in the Country'' tonight, tomorrow and April 19 and 20 at 8, and Sam Shepard's ''Suicide in B Flat'' on Sunday (and April 18, 21 and 22) at 8 P.M. Tickets are $5. Four recitals are scheduled this weekend. KINGSBOROUGH COMMUNITY COLLEGE, 2001 Oriental Boulevard, Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, (718) 934-5596. The 750-seat Performing Arts Center and Little Theater are the sites for many concerts, including free dance performances on April 22 at 3 and April 23 at 7:30 P.M. Gerard Schwarz and the Mostly Mozart Orchestra, with the pianist Horacio Gutierrez will give a concert April 30 at 8 P.M.; tickets are $16 and $15. LA GUARDIA COMMUNITY COLLEGE, 31-10 Thomson Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 482-5151. Jazz concerts to children's operas fill the La Guardia Theater during the school year. Coming attractions for children: the Kaleidoscope Dancers tomorrow at 1 P.M. and a program called ''Music From Around the World'' on April 30 at 1 P.M.; tickets are $4; $2 for children. An international dance festival featuring a half-dozen companies will be held May 7 from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.; tickets are $5; $3 for children and the elderly. LONG ISLAND UNIVERSITY-BROOKLYN CAMPUS, Flatbush and DeKalb Avenues, Brooklyn, (718) 403-1051. Free jazz concerts are held in the Triangle Theater; the next one is Tuesday at 4 P.M. The Diane Jacobowitz Dance Theater, the college's resident company, performs May 13 through 15; tickets are $7. MANHATTAN COLLEGE, Manhattan College Parkway, Riverdale, 920-0247. The Manhattan College Players and Singers, two student groups, present plays and concerts in the large Chapel of De La Salle and His Brothers and the 450-seat Smith Auditorium. The Players' next production, John Guare's ''House of Blue Leaves,'' will run from May 5 to 8; tickets are $5; $3 for students and the elderly. MANHATTAN SCHOOL OF MUSIC, Broadway and 122d Street, 749-2802, extension 452. More than 300 (generally free) recitals and concerts are presented each year in Borden Hall and the smaller, Hubbard and Pforzheimer recital halls. The Manhattan Philharmonia, one of two student orchestras, performs music by Brahms, Mozart and Kodaly tonight at 8 in Borden, and eight recitals are scheduled this weekend. MANNES COLLEGE OF MUSIC, 150 West 85th Street, 580-0210. Concerts and recitals (generally free) by the school's orchestra, chamber ensembles or the early-music Mannes Camerata are presented almost every night from October through May in the 200-seat Mannes Concert Hall or the John Goldmark Recital Hall. The Mannes Trio performs music by Haydn, Martinu and Smetana tonight at 8, a faculty recital by the guitarist Stanley Dorn is tomorrow at 8, and the Mannes Repertory Orchestra performs Monday at 8 P.M. MARYMOUNT MANHATTAN COLLEGE, 221 East 71st Street, 517-0475. Dance and theater productions by visiting professional companies and student groups, as well as concerts and children's plays, are presented in the 249-seat Marymount Manhattan Theater, the 435-seat Great Hall, and the tiny Box Theater. Six short plays by Samuel Beckett will be presented May 4 to 8; tickets are $5 ($3 for students and the elderly). NEW SCHOOL FOR SOCIAL RESEARCH, 66 West 12th Street, 741- 5689. Each semester, jazz concerts have been presented most Fridays at 6 P.M. and classical concerts most Sunday afternoons in the 500-seat Bernhard Mayer Auditorium. The Oval Window Chamber Ensemble performs Monday at 8 P.M. (tickets are $3). NEW YORK CITY TECHNICAL COLLEGE, 300 Jay Street, Brooklyn, (718) 643-5656. Performances are in Klitgord Auditorium, where City Tech Theaterworks presents ''Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat'' on April 28 to 30 at 7:30 P.M. and May 1 at 4 P.M.; tickets are $8 ($5 for students and the elderly). NEW YORK UNIVERSITY, locations throughout Greenwich Village, 998-1212. Each year, the university's Tisch School of the Arts presents scores of mostly free theater and dance performaces at 721 Broadway, between Waverly and Washington Place; 111 Second Avenue, between Sixth and Seventh Streets, and the N. Y. U. Theater, 35 West Fourth Street. Recitals, chamber-music and jazz concerts are also presented at Loeb Student Center, 566 La Guardia Place, and Maison Francaise, 16 Washington Mews. The school's Second Avenue Dance Company presents its free spring concert tonight through Monday at 8 at 111 Second Avenue. Schnitzler's ''Ronde'' is presented by the Lee Strasberg Theater Institute at 721 Broadway tonight and tomorrow at 8 and Sunday at 2 P.M. And a free concert of music by Faure, Poulenc and Satie will be held at Maison Francaise Sunday at 3 P.M. A ''Beyond Vaudeville'' variety show, which will benefit the Coalition for the Homeless, will be held at Loeb Student Center tonight at 7:30 P.M.; admission is $2.50. The graduate acting department will present Shaw's ''Candida'' and Shakespeare's ''Comedy of Errors'' in repertory beginning April 28. PACE UNIVERSITY-CIVIC CENTER CAMPUS, Spruce Street and Park Row, 488-1715. Dozens of student and professional concerts, plays and children's shows are presented each year in the 600-seat Schimmel Theater. Euripides' ''Electra'' will be performed April 21 to 23 at 7:30 P.M. and April 24 at 2; tickets are $5 ($3 for students and the elderly). QUEENS COLLEGE, Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway, (718) 520-7322 or (718) 793-8080. Colden Center is one of the leading performing-arts centers serving Queens and Nassau County. Scores of performances by top orchestral groups, dance companies and other artists are presented annually at the 2,143-seat concert hall and 500-seat theater. Ashford and Simpson, the popular singers, appear tomorrow at 8:30 P.M.; tickets are $19 to $25. The Queens Symphony Orchestra will perform with Theodore Bikel in a ''pops'' program Sunday at 2 P.M.; tickets are $14 to $19; $10 for the elderly and $5 for students. A musical celebration of Queens College's 50th anniversary will be held Sunday at 7:30 P.M., featuring the Jimmy Heath Quintet, the Festival Alumni Orchestra, Tony Randall and soloists; tickets are $5. Coming: Cleo Laine, April 24; ''Footnotes,'' a dance concert, April 27 through May 1; the Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra, April 30; Pilobolus Dance Theater, May 1, and Itzhak Perlman, May 22. Free recitals are frequently presented in the Rathaus Recital Hall and student plays are performed in the Little Theater. QUEENSBOROUGH COMMUNITY COLLEGE, 56th Avenue and Springfield Boulevard, Bayside, Queens, (718) 631-6311. College and professional performers appear in the school's 875-seat theater. The Oakland Ballet will perform ''Giselle'' April 30 at 8 P.M.; tickets are $10 and $12. The Queensborough Orchestra will present its Spring Pops Gala April 23 at 8 P.M., and the Cremona String Quartet will appear in Kurzweil Recital Hall April 24 at 3 P.M.; tickets are $6. ST. JOHN'S UNIVERSITY, Grand Central and Utopia Parkways, Jamaica, Queens, (718) 990-6364. Classical and rock concerts are presented in the 6,000-seat Alumni Hall and the 600-seat Marillac Auditorium. The Chappell Players, a college theater troupe, will perform O'Neill's ''Moon for the Misbegotten'' April 22 and 23 at 8 P.M. and April 24 at 3 P.M.; tickets are $6. ST. JOSEPH'S COLLEGE, 245 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, (718) 636-6800. The college's Chapel Players present the musical ''Most Happy Fella'' April 22 and 23 at 8 P.M. and April 24 at 2 P.M.; tickets are $6. YESHIVA UNIVERSITY, Amsterdam Avenue and 185th Street, 960-5400. The university's Furst Hall will be the site for an April 24 musical celebration of Israel's 40th anniversary, featuring Yoel Sharabi, an Israeli singer, and the Shema Yisroel Orchestra. The time is 2 P.M. Tickets are $10. YORK COLLEGE, 94-20 Guy R. Brewer Boulevard, Jamaica, Queens, (718) 262-2062. Free concerts include an April 26 performance by the York College Electric Guitar Ensemble at noon, and an April 29 performance by Kenny Burrell, a jazz guitarist.

title: Cracks in Foreign Policy Tax Paris's 'One Voice'
description: As he boldly seeks a second seven-year term, President Francois Mitterrand has sought to give foreign policy a central place in his campaign. But his main rival, Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, has played down an issue where the President has the constitutional upper hand.

title: Aaron Joseph Farfel, Ex-University Official, 82
description: Aaron Joseph Farfel, former chairman of the University of Houston Board of Regents, died Tuesday at Methodist Hospital in Houston. He was 82 years old and lived in Houston, where he was a longtime community leader.

title: Pfizer Bid Denied
description: Ciba-Geigy A.G. denied that it plans a takeover of the United States phamarceutical company Pfizer Inc.. Rumors that Ciba-Geigy would make a bid pushed Pfizer's stock up $2.50, to $59.25, on the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday, but after today's denial, it tumbled $3.25, to $56.875, as the overall market plummeted.

title: Piano Duo at Carnegie
description: The piano duo of Katia and Marielle Labeque are to play the Bruch Concerto for Two Pianos (Op. 88) with the Monte Carlo Philharmonic Orchestra on Sunday at 3 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. Also on the program, which is to be conducted by Lawrence Foster, are the Dukas Symphony in C, and Roussel's ''Bacchus et Ariane,'' Suite No. 2. Tickets are $11 to $15. Information: 247-7800.

title: Punishing Toshiba Is a Secondary Boycott
description: To the Editor:

title: Boy, 14, Shot to Death; Friends Questioned
description: A 14-year-old Brooklyn boy died of a gunshot wound in the living room of a friend's apartment yesterday, the police said.

title: Strong Left Arms Lift Yanks, Mets; Yankees 7, Blue Jays 3
description: For nearly four innings today, he looked like any other rookie pitcher trying to make it in the big leagues. And then Al Leiter, the 22-year-old left-hander with the overpowering fastball, suddenly began striking out batters.

title: Colonial BancGroup reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dime Savings Bank of Wallingord reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jetliner Engine Explodes, Ripping Holes in Plane
description: An engine on a Piedmont jetliner cruising at 31,000 feet exploded into jagged pieces today, slicing through both sides of the plane and forcing the pilot to make an emergency landing as some passengers screamed and some fainted.

title: Security Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter restated to include, on a pooling-of-interests basis, the Aug. 31 acquisition of Rainier Bancorp and the retroactive adoption of FAS 91. The results are after preferred stock dividends of $4.2 million in the latest quarter and $3.3 million for the year- ago period. The first-quarter provision for credit losses was $78.6 million, down $20.8 million from the year-ago period.

title: In an Unusual Long Island Trial, One Key Clue: A Rapist's Voice
description: In a series of rapes that shattered the peace of the South Shore for more than two years, a masked rapist confronted his victims as they slept and then skillfully covered his tracks, leaving behind only one clue: his voice.

title: New York Primary: Who's For Whom
description: These partial lists of endorsements were provided by the candidates. GOV. MICHAEL S. DUKAKIS POLITICS Representative Gary Ackerman, Queens City Councilman Sal Albanese, Brooklyn Herman Badillo, former representative Carol Bellamy, former City Council president State Senator Abraham Bernstein, Bronx Assembly Minority Leader Judith Bleakley, Dutchess County Mayor Steven Carlson, Jamestown Assemblywoman Elizabeth Connolly, Staten Island County Legislator Harriet Cornell, Rockland County Edward Costikyan, former Manhattan Democratic chairman Joseph F. Cranele, Erie County Democratic leader Carlos Cuevas, city clerk City Councilman Michael DeMarco, Bronx Assemblyman Thomas DiNapoli, Nassau County City Councilwoman June Eisland, Bronx Barbara J. Fife, Democratic National Committeemember Thomas Fink, secretary, Democratic State Committee Assemblyman George Friedman, Bronx Democratic chairman City Comptroller Harrison J.
