description: An article last Sunday on the Peabody Awards omitted three winners:

title: Review/Jazz; Art Songs In Popular Context
description: Cassandra Wilson writes and sings deceptive, ambiguous music, tricking listeners into hearing the familiar where the familiar doesn't exist. At her show at the Kraine Gallery (85 East Fourth Street) Tuesday night, where she helped start off a week-long series of new-music concerts, Ms. Wilson latched on to the power of pop - good melodies, an assortment of rhythms and dance beats, songs and electronics - without sacrificing any of jazz's improvisational or musical power. Without condescension, she has made an intelligent attempt to cultivate, by taking the best from both forms, an audience that reaches beyond the limits of each idiom.

title: Carla P. Pavone, Sales Strategist, Becomes a Bride
description: Carla Petra Pavone, the daughter of Charlotte S. Pavone of Scarborough, N.Y., and Emil A. Pavone of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Morris Allan Stockburger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto G. Stockburger of Bottineau, N.D. The Rev. Robert F. Dorer performed the Protestant ceremony at the United Church of Pocantico Hills, N.Y.

title: Special Today; Good Health/Magazine, Part 2
description: Special reports in this issue include:

title: Correction
description: The Westchester Guide on April 3 incorrectly described the confirmation of Antonin Scalia as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court. He was unanimously approved by the Senate in a 98-0 vote.

title: THRICE-TOLD TALES
description: As a West Point cadet, I read Owen Edwards's article ''Thrice-Told Tales'' (About Men, March 20), with dismay and anger. As leaders in the Army, we are taught that anything less than the full truth is unacceptable. Is it any wonder that society's permissiveness toward lying has resulted in the Iran-contra scandal, politicians' lying about their backgrounds, and ministerial fiascoes? BRADLEY K. WOODS West Point, N.Y.

title: A TOP A TRAIN STATION, A BUILDING THAT IS RIGHT ON TRACK
description: IT IS NOW 20 YEARS SINCE THE OPEN-ing of the ''new'' Pennsylvania Station in New York, that depressing maze of underground corridors pretending to be a train terminal. This place would have been one of the more notable architectural disasters of the 20th century even if it had not required the demolition of the old Pennsylvania Station to make it possible, and two decades have done nothing to make the station any better than it was the day it was finished.

title: Public Attitude Key to Ruling On Alcohol And Minors
description: FOR a century, the Connecticut Supreme Court had held that a person who served liquor could not be held liable for the actions of the person who consumed it. The reasoning was that someone became drunk not by being given alcohol, but by the voluntary act of drinking. Last week, the court changed its mind. In a case concerning a Ridgefield man who gave a high school graduation party for his son that led to the death of a guest in an automobile accident, the court ruled that adults who serve alcohol to minors could be held responsible for injuries caused by the underage drinkers.

title: Will the Trade Gap Grow?
description: The announcement of February's $13.8 billion trade deficit - the largest in six months - sent a shock through the economy. The stock market fell sharply and the dollar dropped too. How should the trade figures for February be understood? Are they part of a trend, or just an aberration? Carl B. Weinberg Chief economist, High Frequency Economics.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''You get better odds in Las Vegas.'' - Representative J.J. Pickle, Democrat of Texas, on the 38 percent error rate in I.R.S. responses to taxpayers.

title: Washington Office an Asset to State
description: TO A STRANGER in town, the State of New Jersey's Washington office, just down the street from the Capitol, looks much like that of a New Jersey Congressman's.

title: STERLING CAST PUTS POLISH ON A SPY THRILLER
description: BETWEEN IMPLAUSIBILITY and imbecility falls the shadow of the spy story. In that dim and twisty neighborhood, we fans of the genre are happy to suspend disbelief if only our good will and imagination are not imposed on. We are ready to grant, for starters, that the espionage agencies of all countries harbor traitors (known in the trade as moles), that secrets that can determine the fate of nations are about to be passed into the wrong hands, that a few remarkable people skilled in the operation of weapons and eavesdropping devices, long-range cameras and itty-bitty microdots, karate kicks and other spookish arts will outdoublethink the other side in the nick of time, but not before the end of the show.

title: A Fateful Choice
description: Israel became a state on May 14, 1948. A month later its Government faced a fateful issue. Irgun Zvai Leumi, the right-wing terrorist group that had operated during British rule, tried to bring thousands of guns in on a chartered ship, the Altalena.

title: A Good Gaijin Obeys
description: MAX DANGER The Adventures of an Expat in Tokyo. By Robert J. Collins. 206 pp. Rutland, Vt.: Charles E. Tuttle Company. Paper, $8.95.

title: Smart Jumps to Head of the Class
description: Thirty-four snappy collegiate seniors scouted by each National Basketball Association team formed the all-star classic here this week.

title: Rowing to a Better Heart
description: OURS IS AN ERA OF POST-MODERNISM. In architecture and in the arts, America's current culture blends the new with the old, modern materials in classic forms. There has been a recognition of late that progress does not mean excluding tradition, but incorporating it. This trend is also evident in the resurgence of rowing. There are many ways to get in shape and strengthen the cardiovascular system. There are other ways to enjoy being near the water. But there are not a lot of vigorous sports or aerobic exercises with such exquisite charm.

title: The Theme of Patriotism From Foreign Lands
description: DESPITE the weakening of the dollar and its impact on imports, a flood of new issues from foreign lands continues. In most instances the themes are selected for their relevance to the issuing nation. There also are instances in which they clearly are selected for their appeal to United States collectors.

title: ROCK POETS FROM CANADA ROLL ANEW
description: ENGLISH-SPEAKING Canadians offer a piquant regional variation within the North American cultural community. That is not to say that all Canadians act or sound the same, or that Joni Mitchell, Jane Siberry and Leonard Cohen, all of whom have released records recently, speak with a unified voice.

title: Strong Demand for a Short Supply of Professors
description: A FREQUENT issue of debate among business academics is whether entrepreneurship can be taught or whether success is more a function of personality and experience. Many successful entrepreneurs, of course, have never taken a business course in their lives.

title: THE LITTLE NETWORK THAT COULD
description: It was disappointing to see Ernest Leiser dismiss a fifth of CNN's programming as ''a couple of half-hour business-news shows'' (''The Little Network That Could,'' March 20). But it is not surprising. Broadcast network producers rarely understand business news, so they usually don't consider it worth coverage.

title: Goodspeed Is At Full Speed As It Turns 25
description: THE CHOREOGRAPHER SAYS the stage is the size of his living room. The musical director can only fit 14 musicians in the orchestra pit. And in the rehearsal studio, the director has to compete with a nearby waterfall. But as these theater professionals prepare to open the Goodspeed Opera House silver anniversary season Wednesday with a revival of ''Wonderful Town,'' not one of them is complaining.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: BACK in 1954, Alvin Thaler drove a cab for a year or so and he learned a lot of things. He learned, for instance, that there is no shorter time span than that between a light turning green and taxi drivers sounding their horns. He learned at what intersections you have to go a little faster to make the light. He learned about ''even east,'' which means that most even-numbered streets go east. And he learned that he could drive a car in Manhattan without getting ulcers.

title: Meese's Choice for Deputy Is Still Undecided
description: Justice Department officials said today that John C. Shepherd, selected by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d as his new chief deputy, would not make a decision before Monday on whether to withdraw his name from consideration for the job.

title: 100 of Chernobyl's Evacuees Said to Have Sneaked Home
description: About 100 people who were evacuated from Chernobyl have sneaked back to their homes in areas where radiation levels are still above normal, the official press agency Tass said today.

title:
ART;
Guild Hall Strikes Gold in 50th Edition Show
description: LEAD: WHEN Guild Hall requested the submission of works on a gold theme for the 50th edition of its annual Artist Members Exhibition, it stimulated the kind of imaginative fantasy that can produce a spirited exhibition.

title: The Money Men and the Candidates
description: LEAD: FOR the past year, the Presidential race has been highly visible inthe cornfields of Iowa, at the factory gates of New Hampshire and now - with the state primary two days away - on the sidewalks of New York.

title: State Examines Drugs In Public Housing Units
description: LEAD: PUBLIC-HOUSING projects, suspected of being distribution points for drug traffickers, are facing scrutiny in state hearings.

title: THE PAPERBACKING OF THE AMERICAN MIND
description: MUCH wondering comment has been aroused by the enormous and quite unexpected success of Allan Bloom's ''Closing of the American Mind: How Higher Education Has Failed Democracy and Impoverished the Souls of Today's Students.'' Its appearance in a paperback edition next month will earn it renewed attention and almost certainly, judging by past experience, sales two or three times greater than those of the hard-cover original, which was on the best-seller list for almost a year.

title: U.S. Officials Link Pakistan Blast to Kabul Regime
description: One week after a major explosion at a Pakistani ammunition dump, Defense Department officials say that they believe that the explosion was the work of agents of the pro-Soviet regime in Kabul.

title: Judith M. White And Dan Rather, Lawyer, to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Thomas J. White of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, and Westhampton, L.I., of the engagement of her daughter Judith Mattson White to Dan Martin Rather, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Dan Rather of New York. A fall wedding is planned.

title: Sabatini Rallies to Beat Graf
description: Gabriela Sabatini came back from a 3-0 deficit in the third set today to upset top-seeded Steffi Graf, 6-3, 4-6, 7-5, in the semifinals of the $300,000 Bausch & Lomb championships.

title: Emphasis on Stop
description: The revised definition of rule 8.01(b) of the Official Baseball Rules, written by the Official Playing Rules Committee and approved by the Players Association, clarifies the definition of a balk.

title: Civil Defense Truck Crash Kills 5 in Jordan
description: A Jordanian civil defense truck, headed to the site of a fire started by the explosion of a bomb, crashed into a building here today, killing five people and injuring four, Jordanian officials reported.

title: Garbage In and Out? Recycling Begins at Home
description: I couldn't agree more with the closing questions of Steven Meyerowitz's article, ''Garbage In, Garbage Out,'' but:

title: Each Year, a Million New Businesses
description: WHY do some new businesses succeed spectacularly while others fall flat on their faces? What personality traits make for a successful entrepreneur? How important is business education in determining entrepreneurial success?

title: Broad Beans Herald Roman Spring
description: THE markets and restaurants of Rome exhibit at this time of the year an explosion of fresh fruit and vegetables. Small, tender, violet-colored artichokes, the long, slender stalks of wild asparagus, crisp puntarelle, a chicory-like green much favored for first-course salads, tiny, sweet peas called piselli romaneschi, the succulent, spinach-like vegetable called agretti. All the products of the little truck gardens that proliferate around the city are heaped in market stalls or laid out in restaurant displays for stately Roman gourmands who examine the fare of the day and make their selections before proceeding to their tables.

title: Easing Access for Disabled Visitors
description: Climb the mountains and get their good tidings; Nature's peace will flow into you as sunshine into flowers; The winds will blow their freshness into you and the storms their energy, and cares will drop off like autumn leaves. JOHN MUIR (1838-1914)

title: Of French Fries And Trade Gaps
description: FACING a wide imbalance of trade with Asian countries like Japan, the United States Government is ready to try anything to close the gap - even french-fried potatoes.

title: T. M. Valenzuela Weds Sylvia Brown
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Washington, Sylvia Elisabeth Anne Brown, a daughter of Capt. and Mrs. Nicholas Brown of Baltimore and Middleburg, Va., was married yesterday to Thomas Mark Valenzuela, a son of Mrs. Anthony Valenzuela of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Valenzuela. The Rev. Frederic Howard Meisel performed the ceremony.

title: P.L.O. Accuses Israel in Killing Of Senior Arafat Deputy in Tunis
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization accused Israel of assassinating the P.L.O.'s most senior military figure at his home in Tunisia early today. Two bodyguards and a Tunisian driver also were slain.

title: Tribute to Craig
description: THINGS haven't been the same in Easton, Mass., since Donald Craig died earlier this year. That's because Craig had held a seat on the local health board for 32 years, and some Easton residents find it hard to accept the fact that there is no longer a Craig on the board. If one budding politician has his way, however, it won't be long before there is another Craig on the board. Donald's son, Jim Craig, the goalie on the United States hockey team that won the gold medal at the 1980 Winter Olympics, said he was running for his father's old seat.(AP)

title: One Man's Milagro
description: To the Editor:

title: GORBACHEV EFFORT TO RESHAPE SOVIET FACING PARALYSIS
description: There is a growing sense in the Soviet Union that key elements of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's effort to reshape the country have been crippled, if not paralyzed, by inertia and resistance in the Communist Party and in the Government.

title: THE WILL TO STAY WELL
description: SOME PEOPLE SEEM TO BE ABLE to keep themselves from getting sick at inconvenient times. They work well under pressure, but often become ill after it eases. Others find that even as tension is building, or perhaps because tension is building, they thrive and stay healthy.

title: On Making a Difference, if Not a Revolution
description: To the Editor:

title: Outdoors; Fishing for Bass In Unusual Habitat
description: IT was a peculiar setting in which to be going striped bass fishing. Only the gulls watched as I trudged along Crabmeadow Beach toward the power plant outflow in the late-winter morning. Walking on the sand was made even more strenuous than usual by chest waders and a rain-slicker whose elasticities were tested by too many layers of clothing. The climate was not inviting - a chill breeze off the Connecticut Hills raised a moderate chop across Long Island Sound before climbing the snow-whitened bluffs lining this beach in Northport, L.I.

title: Shoreline Plan Raises Erosion Fears
description: LEAD: BECAUSE of erosion and storm damage, Southampton Town officials are increasingly concerned about development plans along the remaining stretches of barrier beach fronting the Atlantic Ocean. This concern has prompted the Planning Board to try to assert control over a 15-acre parcel of land, in East Quogue between Dune Road and the ocean, upon which its owner plans a 15-lot subdivision.

title: Democrats Prepare for Decisive Primary
description: WITH considerably less fanfare, more Democrats are expected to vote in Tuesday's primary on Long Island than voted in New Hampshire earlier this year at the beginning of the campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: 14 PALESTINIANS DIE IN WORST DAY OF ARAB UPRISING
description: In the bloodiest day of four months of protests, the Israeli Army shot and killed at least 14 Palestinians today as the Palestinians reacted angrily to the assassination of the Palestine Liberation Organization's military commander in Tunis earlier in the day.

title: Upstate Voters Said to Hold the Key For Dukakis in New York Primary
description: There are two ways to look at the electoral calculus for Tuesday's Democratic Presidential primary.

title: Inmates Wary After Massachusetts Rights Ruling
description: The state Supreme Court has ruled that prisoners are placed in solitary confinement and kept there in violation of their rights under the state constitution, but inmates and their lawyers say it may be some time before those conditions change.

title: The Candidates and the Middle East
description: No national security question rings louder in the Presidential campaign than the Arab-Israeli conflict. The Middle East may well be the most flammable place in the world. So it's critical for voters to know how the next President proposes to prevent war there. New Yorkers have served the nation well in pressing the candidates to spell out their positions in advance of Tuesday's Presidential primary.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending April 2 MANHATTAN Chelsea $280,000 77 Seventh Avenue (14th St.) (Vermeer) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 650-sq.-ft. co-op in postwar building; 24-hr. doorman, wrap-around terrace, Hudson River view; maintenance $576, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Ambrose Mar-Elia) Chelsea $175,000 54 West 16th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 850-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; dining foyer, parquet floors; maintenance $486, 62% tax-deductible (Broker: Buchbinder & Warren) Union Square Area $980,000 5 East 16th Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 4,100-sq.-ft. loft-condo in a recently renovated prewar building; 3 exposures, 13-ft. ceilings, 2,500-sq.-ft roof rights; common charge $1,000, taxes $4,080 (Broker: Sinvin Realty) Upper East Side $136,000 315 East 88th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 550-sq.-ft prewar co-op; high-ceilings, windowed kitchen, hardwood floors; maintenance $415, 60% tax-deductible (Broker: Klara Madlin Real Estate) Upper West Side $580,000 225 Central Park West (82d St.) (Alden) 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 2,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, dining room, large windowed kitchen, Central Park views; maintenance $2,125, 74% tax-deductible (Broker: Thompson Realty) BRONX Parkchester $208,000 1802 East 174th Street 2-family, detached frame house; 4 bedrooms, 2 baths, dining room, large kitchens in each; full basement, 3-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,200 (Broker: Marland Real Estate) Riverdale $88,000 5601 Riverdale Avenue (Riverdale Terrace) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 700-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; part-time doorman, entry foyer, large remodeled kitchen and bath, wall to wall carpeting, washer/dryer hookup; maintenance $380, 54% tax-deductible (Broker: Susan E. Goldy) BROOKLYN Brooklyn Heights $360,000 61-69 Pierrepont Street 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 1,900-sq.-ft. co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; dining room, large kitchen, fireplace, high-ceilings, bay window, parquet floors; maintenance $946, 48% tax-deductible (Broker: William B. May) Prospect Heights $80,000 408 St. John's Place 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 600-sq.-ft. co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; dining area, remodeled, windowed kitchen, hardwood floors, washer/dryer hookup; maintenance $286, 48% tax-deductible (Broker: Dowling & Peltz) QUEENS Bayside $263,000 217-59 54th Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, detached Tudor; dining room, large kitchen, Florida room, fireplace, 1-car garage; 40- by 100-ft, lot; taxes $1,200 (Broker: Century 21/Weber & Rose) Jackson Heights $309,000 78-19 32d Avenue 2-family, attached brick house; 3 bedrooms, large kitchen in primary unit; 1 bedroom in other; 1 bath in each; finished basement, 1-car garage, 20- by 107-ft. lot; taxes $1,600 (Broker: Century 21/ Metalios Real Estate) STATEN ISLAND New Dorp Heights $227,000 50 Bishop Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single family, detached Tudor; entry foyer, dining room, fireplace, breakfast room, finished basement, detached 1-car garage, 50- by 104-ft. lot; taxes $1,215 (Broker: Century 21/Appleseed Agency) Stapleton Heights $255,000 44 Pommer Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached Victorian; 2 front parlors, fireplace, dining room, large kitchen, sleeping loft in attic, walk-in pantry, parquet floors, wrap-around porch, full basement, 45- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,100 (Broker: Rand Properties)

title: LIKE SORCERY, LIKE SEX
description: THE DEATH OF METHUSELAH And Other Stories. By Isaac Bashevis Singer. 244 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: VIETNAM LEADERS MEET WITH GANDHI
description: India's Prime Minister, Rajiv Gandhi, met Vietnam's new Communist Party leader for the first time here today to discuss relations between the two countries and ways to help resolve the nine-year war in Cambodia, according to diplomats following the talks.

title: Yankees Go Quietly As Rhoden Is Rocked
description: The way Billy Martin charged out of the dugout and ran toward second base today, it seemed a certainty there would be obscenities and dirt flying in every direction at County Stadium.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Guilford, Conn. $200,000 735 Maple Hill Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 10-year-old raised ranch; stained-glass windows, large deck, 1.4 acres; taxes $1,860. Madison, Conn. $197,000 1471 Durham Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 12-year-old raised ranch; huge family room with wood stove, 6.3 acres; taxes $1,905. Sharon, Conn. $900,000 Eggleston Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 1830 Federal farmhouse; 1-bedroom guest house, barn, 81 acres; taxes $3,475. Bedford, N.Y. $840,000 Old Corner Road 5-bedroom, 4-bath, 41-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, den, screened porch, pool, 4 acres; taxes $8,544. Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. $590,000 2 Summit Drive 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 53-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, pool, walk to station and schools, 0.75 acre; taxes $9,202. Peekskill, N.Y. $215,000 Jacob Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 138-year-old frame colonial; barn, pond, 2.5 acres; taxes $2,770. OTHER AREAS Bernards Township, N.J. $220,000 410 South Maple Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, hardwood floors, deck; taxes $1,972. Keansburg, N.J. $139,000 25 Johnson Lane 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 24-year-old ranch; c/a, eat-in kitchen, den; taxes $2,673. Huntington, L.I. $280,000 5 Christa Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old ranch; dining room, finished basement; taxes $3,500.

title: Jury Hears Testimony on Impact of Cigarette Ads
description: A witness for three tobacco companies testified this week that cigarette advertising had ''little or no'' influence on whether people smoke or on how much they smoke, regardless of the content of the advertisements.

title: DESTINATION: MARS
description: I am interested in the opinion of young people regarding space travel, because they will be tax-paying adults when and if a manned trip to Mars becomes a reality (''Destination: Mars,'' by John Noble Wilford, March 20). So as the ranking Republican on the House Appropriations Committee, which allocates funds for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, I conducted a poll of their attitudes on space exploration through Science World, a Scholastic magazine.

title: Santana's Agent Asks for Trade
description: The agent representing Rafael Santana, the beleaguered Yankee shortstop who drew the wrath of Billy Martin after making a costly error last Monday, said today he had asked the team for a trade.

title: U.S. Asked to Oversee Twain Compound
description: LEAD: A NATIONAL conservation group has recommended that Nook Farm, the Hartford compound of the Mark Twain and Harriet Beecher Stowe houses, be brought under the protection of the National Park Service. It is now overseen privately, by the Mark Twain Memorial Foundation and the Stowe-Day Foundation.

title: Elizabeth Pincus, 88, Active in Civic Work
description: Elizabeth Notkin Pincus, long active in civic affairs in Worcester, Mass., in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 88 years old and a former resident of Worcester and, more recently, Montreal.

title: Lew Grade, at 81, Retains His Zest for a Deal
description: FOR 11 YEARS NOW, THE short, stout man has carried the dignified title of Lord Grade of Elstree. But in his heart of hearts, he is still Lew Grade, the show business wheeler-dealer with the $10 cigar.

title: 3-D Stereo: Get Out Your Glasses
description: RADIOLOGISTS look at a two-dimensional X-ray to determine the extent of a hip fracture. An architect draws two-dimensional plans for a house. A stock market analyst tries to incorporate several sets of data onto a single two-dimensional chart. A chemist peers at a two-dimensional computer image of a molecule.

title: Now, Apprentice Professionals
description: WHEN people think of an apprentice, they generally think of a skilled craftsman, not an accountant. But when Karin Vickers graduated from Hofstra University with a degree in accounting in 1986, she had a hard time finding a job in her field. Rather than take a low-paying menial job, she turned to the apprentice system.

title: NATIONAL LEAGUE; 0-10 Braves Set Mark For Losses at Start
description: The Atlanta Braves set a National League record with their 10th consecutive loss starting the season, as Pedro Guerrero drove in four runs in the Los Angeles Dodgers' 7-4 victory today.

title: A Mandate for Japan
description: Thoughtful Japanese analysts are grappling with a political and philosophical problem that is probably unique in the history of nations. It may be a sign of what the 21st century will need to be about.

title: Hilary Ballon Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ballon of New York have annnounced the engagement of their daughter Hilary Meg Ballon to Orin Stuart Kramer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Julian Kramer of South Orange, N.J. A January wedding is planned.

title: 'Al-Kemi' and Schwaller de Lubicz
description: To the Editor:

title: THE LURE OF THE POLITICAL ROAD
description: As a Presidential campaign veteran, I enjoyed reading John Homans's article ''The Lure of the Political Road'' (March 13). I recently returned from a weekend in Plains, Ga., where I made advance arrangements for Gov. Michael S. Dukakis for a meeting and press conference with former President Jimmy Carter. The article captured the sense of adventure and excitement that keeps people involved in high-pressure politics.

title: Brookhaven Debates Boundaries on Moratorium
description: LEAD: RESIDENTS, Brookhaven Town officials and developers are fighting a tug-of-war over how far the boundaries of a town-proposed moratorium should extend.

title: On Making a Difference, if Not a Revolution; 'I Miss the Passion'
description: To the Editor:

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Volunteers of Year
description: LEAD: Gerald Eisner, a 67-year-old Scarsdale resident, is a retired engineer whose idea of ''being helpful'' is creating computer programs for nonprofit groups and then teaching staff members and volunteers how to use them. For his efforts, he has won the Westchester Volunteer of the Year Award for 1988.

title: LOVES OF A RECLUSE
description: SOFT WATER By Robert Olmstead. 226 pp. New York: Vintage Contemporaries. Paper, $6.95.

title: An Old-Fashioned Slam
description: COMPARING the heroes of yesteryear with those of today is a popular nostalgic exercise, which is easy in some activities but difficult in others. In the past half century the best one-mile runners have improved by about 20 seconds and the best high jumpers have improved by a foot. Against that, comparisons between Joe Louis and Mike Tyson, or the stars of baseball and football, are inevitably more controversial, subjective and enjoyable.

title: Correction
description: A map on March 27 with an article about Washington labeled Dupont Circle incorrectly. It is at the intersection of New Hampshire, Connecticut and Massachusetts Avenues.

title:
GARDENING;
Planning Company for the Early Tulip
description: LEAD: TULIPS can be counted on to provide a splash of color in late April and early May, but what can be planted as companion plants to flower at the same time?

title: FORGET MURDER AND CAR CHASES: NOT IT'S 'SLICE OF LIFE' SHOWS
description: IS THE TELEVISION PLOT DEAD? IN the emerging strain of slice-of-life ''dramedies'' currently favored by the networks, nothing (in the dramatic sense) seems to happen anymore. ABC's ''thirtysomething'' offers us life style writ large; a group of friends, their lives vaguely defined by a prior decade that could be the 60's or the 70's, kvetch their way through the business of middle-class life in the 1980's. NBC's ''Days of and Nights of Molly Dodd'' meanders through the hair-raisingly unstructured world of a New York City woman in her mid-30's, anchored by neither marriage nor career. And Kevin, the 32-year-old narrator of ''The Wonder Years'' (whose ratings are buoying the flagging fortunes of ABC), recalls the feel of the summer of 1968 when, as a chubby suburban adolescent, he struggled to be cool, got his first taste of death when the neighborhood's teen-age hero was killed in Vietnam and achieved his first fumbling kiss.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: WRITING RED: An Anthology of American Women Writers, 1930-1940. Edited by Charlotte Nekola and Paula Rabinowitz. (Feminist Press, $12.95.) This is the first comprehensive anthology of radical American women writers of the 1930's - years in which the women's movement is commonly thought to have lain dormant.

title: The Irreverence of Cocteau Sparkles Once More
description: JEAN COCTEAU'S BALLETS, BY definition, set out to look as much unlike ballets as possible, and ''Les Maries de la Tour Eiffel (The Wedding on the Eiffel Tower),'' which was seen in a new version in New York last week, is no exception. Cocteau created this satiric work, with choreography by Jean Borlin, in 1921 for Les Ballets Suedois, the avant-garde Swedish troupe directed by Rolf de Mare in Paris from 1920 to '25.

title: Key Italian Senator Is Killed by Gunfire; Brigades Link Cited
description: An Italian senator who was considered an ally of the new Christian Democrat Prime Minister, Ciriaco de Mita, was shot and killed today, the police said. A faction of the Red Brigades guerrilla group took responsibility for the killing.

title: TALKING: Health Clubs; New Law Requires Bonding
description: A NEW law in New York State intended to halt abuses in commercially run health clubs will require certain co-ops, condominiums and homeowner associations with recreational facilities to file a bond or set aside special reserves by July 1. The amount may range from $25,000 to $100,000.

title: Macbeth, Beware the Tour
description: LEAD: THE WITCHES WERE WORKING overtime. That is one explanation for the cauldron of troubles stirred up as the latest version of Shakespeare's ''Macbeth,'' starring Christopher Plummer and Glenda Jackson, lurched its way to Broadway.

title: Mary T. Danforth Planning to Wed
description: Senator and Mrs. John C. Danforth of Washington and Newburg, Mo., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Taylor Danforth to Thomas Hoch Stillman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Stillman of Edina, Minn. A September wedding is planned.

title: In the Hospital
description: To the Editor: When I read Carlton Zucker's report of his stay in the Israeli hospital (''The Lessons of a Hospital Stay Abroad,'' Travel, Jan. 17), it evoked memories of my experience with Egyptian medicine during a tour that my wife, who is a physician, and I took last October. While in Aswan, I fell getting off a bus. I was injured so severely that I blacked out and my ankle swelled up double or triple its usual girth.

title:
ART;
Invitations to the Unaffiliated
description: LEAD: THE group exhibition at the Hillwood Gallery, on Long Island University's C. W. Post Campus in Brookville, is the sixth in a series that spotlights artists not affiliated with a commercial gallery. These eight are among the thousands in the same position who nevertheless exhibit regularly, often in invitationals such as this, at museums, galleries and art centers around the country and abroad.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Chemical Weapons; 'Poor Man's Atomic Bomb' Is Once Again Used in Battle
description: SEARED lungs, clouded eyes and scarred flesh - the stigmata of mustard gas -became all too familiar to Americans who were gassed during World War I. In the 70 years since, most of the chemically maimed survivors have died, but once again, poison gas victims are recovering in an American hospital.

title: Delays are Expected on Turnpike Spur
description: RUSH-HOUR snarls are expected this week on the north- and southbound lanes of the western spur of the New Jersey Turnpike between Newark and the George Washington Bridge. The reason for the anticipated delays is a reduction in the speed limit to 35 miles an hour where the center lanes are closed for redecking.

title: Olympic Profiles: Tim Daggett; Gymnast's Scars Spurring Him On
description: TIM DAGGETT remembers the vault, the flip and the awful sound of his left leg breaking. When the flip began he was a mainstay on the American men's gymnastics team. Hours later he was lying in traction, his career in ruins.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
On the Public's Value Of Private Collections
description: LEAD: ARE rare coins worth more money when they come from important collections? The question seems pertinent following the recent sale of United States coins from the Norweb Collection.

title: >Wendi Nortman Marries
description: Wendi Lynn Nortman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Nortman of Boca Raton, Fla., and Saul Adler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Adler of Muttontown, L.I., were married yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria. Rabbi Julius Goldberg and Cantor Morris Wolk officiated. The bride's father is a senior vice president of Pacificorp Capital in Woodbury, L.I. and Boca Raton. The bridegroom is a vice president of Crest Industries, a gift importer in Deer Park, L.I. His father is the company's president.

title: POSTINGS: The Ginkgo Pact; Detente on 64th
description: The Indiana limestone to rebuild the facade of 110 East 64th Street will arrive in a few weeks. By then, however, the ginkgo tree in front will be in full leaf and the costly refacing may be hard to see. The town house and the tree, both six stories high, have lived together in peace, more or less, for 25 years. But in 1985, the owner of both, Matt Sabatine, wanted to create a garage in the house and chop down the ginkgo to provide access. The notion upset the neighborhood and brought the intervention of Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern.

title: Officials in Maine Agree To Buy Land for Public
description: The state of Maine has agreed to acquire 7,000 acres of forest land and frontage along two pristine lakes near Acadia National Park.

title: American League; Orioles, in 11 Innings, Lose 11th Straight
description: Gary Gaetti hit a home run leading off the eighth inning today to give the Minnesota Twins a 3-2 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: If You Like Walking on Water
description: FEW areas of human endeavor have eluded the fertile imaginations of inventors. So there was no stir at the United States Patent Office last October when it announced the award of Patent 4,698,039 to Benjamin H. Watson of Renton, Wash., for equipment to let people walk on water.

title: Houston Democrats Strip Chairman of Power
description: The executive committee of the Democratic Party in Harris County has stripped virtually all power from the newly elected chairman, a supporter of the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. The committee, consisting of the 664 precinct chairmen in the county, which includes all of Houston, acted Friday, giving final approval on a voice vote to new party bylaws that had been initially passed March 11, three days after Claude Jones's surprising victory over the incumbent chairman, Larry Veselka.

title: Patch Asphalt Driveways Promptly
description: ASPHALT driveways suffer abuse in all seasons, but especially in early spring, when alternating freezes and thaws produce cracks, crumbled areas and potholes. Luckily, most driveway damage is reasonably easy to repair.

title: Program Provides Haven for Asian Refugee Children
description: LEAD: FIVE years ago, Tuan Tran, a bright but illiterate 15-year-old, piloted an overcrowded fishing boat out of Vietnam and spent several months in refugee camps before being resettled in the United States.

title: Nurses, in Short Supply, Take Skills on the Road
description: Susan Smith, a nurse in the operating room at University Hospital here, plans to spend spring on Long Island, summer and fall in New England and winter in Hawaii. She is a traveling nurse. The nursing shortage has spawned a growing industry of traveling nurses, nurses-for-hire who crisscross the country plugging gaps at short-staffed hospitals, typically working three months at one hospital before moving on to the next.

title: PEASANTRY AND MAJESTY
description: THE WATER OF THE HILLS Jean de Florette & Manon of the Springs. By Marcel Pagnol. Translated by W. E. van Heyningen. Illustrated. 440 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. Paper, $14.95. Cloth, $30.

title: Hamilton Fish Throws His Hat Into the Ring
description: HAMILTON FISH 3d selected the sidewalk in front of an empty store here last week, the site of former Representative Richard L. Ottinger's district office, to announce his candidacy for the seat now held by Representive Joseph J. DioGuardi, a Republican.

title: Lieut. Michael Whiting To Marry Wendy Zeh
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Zeh of Clifton, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Ann Zeh, to Lieut. Michael David Whiting, U.S.N., a son of John D. Whiting of Washington and the late Diane Tweed Whiting. The couple plan to marry in September.

title: C. R. Plaut Weds Miss Winkelstein
description: Federal Hall in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Nancy Winkelstein, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Winkelstein of New York, to Christopher R. Plaut, the son of Richard L. Plaut and Gloria A. Plaut, both of New York. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Irwin C. Lowenheim, who was assisted by the Rev. Herbert B. Anderson, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Pond Algae And the Amur
description: The article ''Weed-Gobbling Fish to Be Stocked in Ponds'' (March 20) claimed that the Amur (grass carp) eats both aquatic weeds and algae.

title: Leafs Blame Coach
description: WHY did the Toronto Maple Leafs manage only 21 victories during the National Hockey League season? According to two players, Miroslav Frycer and Borje Salming, it wasn't the players' fault. The blame, they said, rests with Coach John Brophy. Asserting that 90 percent of the players ''despise working for the coach,'' Frycer said he would not be playing for Brophy next season.

title: Finns Won't Prosecute Rust For Illegal Flight to Moscow
description: Finland has decided not to prosecute Mathias Rust, the young West German who landed a small plane in Red Square in Moscow last May, an official statement said today.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SHAKESPEARE ALIVE! By Joseph Papp and Elizabeth Kirkland. (Bantam, $4.50.) Like Shakespeare's plays, ''Shakespeare Alive!'' targets a broad-based audience. The authors - Joseph Papp, founder of the New York Shakespeare Festival, and Elizabeth Kirkland, a writer and associate of Mr. Papp's - have performed a remarkable feat of synthesis, weaving together bits and pieces of information, from Elizabethan styles of life to current performance practices, to make the plays understandable in their original context as well as our own.

title: Dancing to the Beat of the Past
description: PETER PRICE spent most of a recent Monday changing the tires and replacing a generator of a twin-engine plane at Sikorsky Memorial Airport in Stratford, where he is a mechanic.

title: Ellen Thompson Plans To Wed D. W. Brinkley
description: The engagement of Ellen Treacy Thompson to Douglas Wright Brinkley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Brinkley of Baltimore, has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John C. Thompson of St. Joseph, Mo. A June 25 wedding is planned.

title: Close Scrutiny, More Balk Calls Give Some Players Pause
description: DOUG JONES, a Cleveland Indians relief pitcher, did it with the bases loaded in the eighth inning and the game tied, 6-6, and the Minnesota Twins won, 7-6. Les Lancaster, a Chicago Cubs reliever, did it with runners at first and second in the seventh inning and the game tied, 3-3, and Bob Horner hit a sacrifice fly that gave St. Louis a 4-3 victory.

title: THE DRUGGIST'S CRUCIAL NEW ROLE
description: GRAHAM CONDIE REMEMBERS when every drugstore had a soda fountain, and folks called the local pharmacist ''Doc.'' There weren't many effective drugs, and those that existed were often mixed right in the store. ''Making pills was somewhat of an art,'' recalls Condie, a 93-year-old retired pharmacist in Seattle. ''I once saw a fellow hand-coat them.''

title: On Making a Difference, if Not a Revolution; Work to Be Done
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Town-House Living, but Estate Elegance
description: LEAD: THE breakup of Gold Coast estates on Nassau's North Shore has been under way for many years, but the pace is picking up as elderly owners sell off their properties or heirs feel it is time to sell with the market at a high peak.

title: Who Should Be Hockey's M.V.P.?
description: It would appear that Mario Lemieux of the Penguins is a shoo-in for the award. I'm here to tell you it ain't so. Give the scoring trophy to Lemieux with all the accolades of being the top scorer, but please don't assume that he will also walk off with the m.v.p.

title: On Making a Difference, if Not a Revolution; Back to Woodstock!
description: To the Editor:

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Lenox, Mass.;
Old Campus, New Owners
description: LEAD: APPROPRIATE new uses are being sought for the 69-acre Lenox campus formerly used by The Bible Speaks, an evangelical ministry, that vacated the facility last summer after a former member, Elizabeth Dayton Dovydenas, won a lawsuit to reclaim $6.6 million in donations she had made.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SUMMER LIGHTNING: And Other Stories. By Olive Senior. (Longman, $8.95.) ''Somewhere between the repetition of Sunday School lessons and the broken doll which the lady sent me one Christmas I lost what it was to be happy.'' So begins the narrator in ''Love Orange,'' one of 10 short stories in Olive Senior's remarkable, if uneven, collection. A brief tale of innocence lost, ''Love Orange'' succeeds in establishing a tone that draws the reader in as it makes its way toward a painful conclusion: the end of belief is the beginning of maturity. Ms. Senior is a writer who shares with the Antiguan Jamaica Kincaid and the Barbadian Paule Marshall the ability to merge island syntax with British inflection. The result is a language that is deft and lyrical. Ms. Senior's stories, all set in Jamaica, are peopled with characters who believe that their dream life is every bit as significant as their daily one, though this belief makes for seductive prose, not necessarily convincing plot lines. The most winning stories are those in which plot barely makes an appearance, as in the title story. It is when Ms. Senior depicts mood, atmosphere and the inner life of her characters that her work avoids a tendency toward the maudlin or the melodramatic. ''Summer Lightning'' is an original contribution to the flourishing school of West Indian writers who create rooms we've never seen before, voices we've never heard.

title: Who Should Be Hockey's M.V.P.?
description: Mario Lemieux should be hockey's m.v.p. The fact that the Lemieux and the Penguins are out of the playoffs should not be a considered in depriving him of the m.v.p. Of the team's 319 goals, Lemieux scored 22 percent of them and has either scored or assisted on 53 percent. LEON KOVAR Massapequa, L.I.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. When we purchased our 40-year-old house about two years ago, we were told that a new roof had been installed about seven years before that. Recently we had to rip off and replace the old gutters and found that the bottom wood edge of the roof was rotten, with pieces starting to fall off. Does this mean we have to take off all the shingles, or can a partial job be done to correct this problem?

title: DESTINATION: MARS
description: Perhaps the Soviet Union's true interest in the planet Mars is based on ideological considerations. After all, Mars is known as the ''red'' planet, and if the Russians land there by 2017, it would coincide with the 100th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution. ANDREW B. BORINSTEIN New York, N.Y.

title: Test Reports
description: REACTING to reports of cocaine use by a former basketball player, Vernon Maxwell, the University of Florida reported 14 positive tests for drugs out of 1,265 tests administered by the school from July 1987 through March 1988. ''We have conducted more drug tests already this year than have been done in previous years,'' Athletic Director Bill Arnsparger said, declining to identify the athletes involved or their sports. ''The results continue to show that 1 percent of the total tests run on our athletes are positive.''

title: Landmark Hostel
description: To the Editor:

description: Weeks This Last On Week Week Fiction 1 1 6 THE ICARUS AGENDA, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) A congressman's secret dealings with terrorists may bring him the Presidency - or death. 2 2 24 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 3 3 5 TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Dirk Pitt leads a global pursuit of hijackers of an ancient Egyptian literary trove. 4 5 5 INHERITANCE, by Judith Michael. (Poseidon, $18.95.) A woman finds herself enmeshed in the jealousies and conspiracies of a wealthy family on Boston's Beacon Hill. 5 4 6 HOT MONEY, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) Which member of a gold arbitrager's family was responsible for the murder of his fifth wife? 6 9 2 KING OF THE MURGOS, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $16.95.) And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $18.95.) A shining and commodious novel by the author of ''One Hundred Years of Solitude,'' concerning love and time: a love that is sworn to last forever, and nearly does; a time that cycles around so nothing - or everything - is totally new.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Bowling Weber Takes Title: Pete Weber took advantage of an open frame by Marshall Holman in the championship game yesterday to win the United States Open in Atlantic City. In claiming his 11th P.B.A. championship, Weber beat Holman, 203-171, in the $500,000 event, the richest on the Professional Bowlers Association Tour. The victory was worth $100,000. Down by 11 pins after five frames, Holman failed to convert a 10-pin in the sixth frame. Weber, who had struck in the fifth frame, threw another strike in the sixth and cruised to the victory.(AP) Golf Couples Ahead by a Shot: Fred Couples shot a three-under-par 68 yesterday to hold off David Frost of South Africa and take a one-shot lead after the third round of the $700,000 Heritage Classic in Hilton Head Island, S.C. Couples sqaundered a couple of shots when he three-putted from five feet for a double-bogey 5 on the 17th hole. He missed a hurried second putt from less than six inches. Couples finished 54 holes at 201, 12 under par.(AP) Horse Racing Aptostar Wins at Aqueduct: Aptostar, the only 3-year-old in the field of eight fillies and mares, came from off the pace yesterday to carry her light impost of 103 pounds and Julie Krone to a neck victory in the $117,800 Bed o' Roses Handicap at Aqueduct. Clabber Girl was second 2 3/4 lengths ahead of Psyched, who reached the wire 1 1/2 lengths before the favorite, Cadillacing. Aptostar went a mile on the fast track in 1:35 2/5 to earn $70,680 for her owner, Centennial Farms. She was coupled in the wagering with With a Twist. The entry returned $16.20 for $2 to win. Lost Code Triumphs: Lost Code never trailed yesterday, holding off a late charge by Cryptoclearance to win the $500,000 Oaklawn Handicap for older horses at Oaklawn Park in Hot Springs, Ark. Trained by William L. Donovan, Wendover Stable's Lost Code finished the Grade I stakes in 1:47, just two-fifths of a second slower than the Oaklawn track record for a mile and an eighth set by Snow Chief in last year's Oaklawn Handicap. Lost Code paid $3.80, $2.80 and $2.40 for $2 across the board as the betting favorite.(AP) Tsar Baby Wins Golden State Stakes: Tsar Baby, a 5-2 choice, took the lead at the outset and defeated a field of nine other 3-year-olds to win the 24th running of the $150,000 Garden State Stakes yesterday by 3 1/2 lengths at Garden State Park in Cherry Hill, N.J. Tsar Baby, ridden by Herbert McCauley and trained by Wayne Lukas, also won the $100,000 Cherry Hill Mile two weeks ago.(AP) Rowing Protest Mars Harvard Victory: A protest by the Washington heavyweight men's varsity crew marred the opening round of the third annual Redwood Shores-Stanford Rowing Classic yesterday at Edwood Shores, Calif. In the opening strokes of the 2,000-meter distance of a race that matched Washington and Harvard, Washington's No. 3 man, Bob Shepard, lost control of his oar when the gate on his oar lock popped open. Washington did not signal its distress until it had proceeded 200 meters into the race. Washington stopped, however no referee signaled Harvard to break off the racing. After Harvard finished and was declared the winner, Washington protested that the race should have been stopped to allow the Huskies to secure the No. 3 man's oar lock, and then rerow the entire race. The Huskies' protest was disallowed, and Harvard advanced to the next round where it will meet U.C.L.A., the winner yesterday over Brown. School Track Uniondale Boys Triumph: Uniondale (L.I.) High School, led by the McQueen Twins easily captured the boys team title yesterday at the Nanuet (N.Y.) relays. The Knights, in winning this meet for the second straight year and the fourth time in the last five years, tallied 87 points. Kevin and Kelvin McQueen, identical twin seniors, combined to win the high jump relay at 12 feet and then teamed up with Joe Greenridge to win the 300 meter shuttle hurdles relay in 44.8 seconds. Pat Austin also won two gold medals as a member of Uniondale's triple and long-jump relay victors. In the girls' competition yesterday, Suffern High School, with four event winners, gained the team title with 68 points. Gymnastics Nebraska Wins Title: Tom Schlesinger, a senior, scored a 9.85 as the last man on the high bar Friday night as Nebraska won the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's gymnastics championship in Lincoln, Neb., with a record 288.15 points. Illinois was second with 287.15 points and U.C.L.A. was third with 285.15. Nebraska also held the previous N.C.A.A. team scoring record of 287.80 points set in 1983. Nebraska's top individual performance in the team championship competition was a 9.9 from Kevin Davis on the pommel horse. The only other 9.9s in the team competition were recorded by Chris McKee of Illinois in the floor exercise and by David Moriel of U.C.L.A. on the high bar.(AP)

title: 'A Lack of Virtue'
description: 'Although I exerted myself to the utmost to promote the welfare of the people during my presidential term, I failed to control my brother. It is because of my lack of virtue. ' - Chun Doo Hwan, former President of South Korea, resigning his remaining political posts last week because of a corruption scandal involving his brother.

title: Reservists Revel in Flight Time
description: AT 37,000 feet, this C-141-B Lockheed Starlifter lumbers on toward McGuire Air Force Base near Wrightstown in Burlington County.

title: The Future Is Here
description: FOR yet more evidence that computer control is the future of 35-millimeter photography, one need look no further than the new Nikon N8008. Introduced to the press last week, this new-age single-lens-reflex camera has all the electronics of a guided missile, though without the harmful effects. It replaces two venerable Nikon models, the FE-2 and the FA.

title: Crimes Reported to the Police Increase for 3d Year
description: The amount of serious crime reported to the police rose in 1987 for the third consecutive year and was up in all regions of the country except the West, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.

title: Candidates Make Final Push for Increasing Turnout
description: In a last weekend political blitz, hundreds of Democratic campaign workers made phone calls, rang doorbells and distributed literature across the state in an effort to turn out voters in Tuesday's crucial New York Democratic Presidential primary.

title: It's Good News From China for Billy Graham
description: The sanctum of Chinese Communism opened its doors today to the American evangelist Billy Graham, who is visiting China for the first time.

title: What's Doing In Buenos Aires
description: In the waterfront neighborhood of La Boca, a narrow street called Garibaldi leads visitors into the Buenos Aires district that is synonymous with Argentina's big Italian immigration of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Far from the land of their forebears, Genoese sailors came home from the sea carrying bright-colored paints to cover their humble tin and wooden houses in splashy red, yellow, blue and green.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. When we purchased our 40-year-old house about two years ago, we were told that a new roof had been installed about seven years before that. Recently we had to rip off and replace the old gutters and found that the bottom wood edge of the roof was rotten, with pieces starting to fall off. Does this mean we have to take off all the shingles, or can a partial job be done to correct this problem?

title: Decline and Rebirth of a Neighborhood
description: In 1963, Albert Shapiro, a native of the Bronx, bought a bar in the Adams-Morgan neighborhood of Washington. He and his girlfriend renamed the place Millie & Al's and opened for business. It was a rough place at first, three fights a night, but now all that has changed.

title: Review/Jazz; Lussier, Zorn And Tenko
description: Rene Lussier, the French guitarist, said ''Bonsoir''; the American saxophonist and composer John Zorn said ''Yo,'' and the Japanese vocalist Tenko screeched, starting out the first set of a freely improvised show on Wednesday night at Roulette. For the next few minutes information fell like rain: Mr. Lussier, stamping his feet, broke chords into double stops while Mr. Zorn held long tones, and Tenko howled.

title: Headliners; Home Improvement
description: Leona and Harry B. Helmsley, ranking members of New York City's real-estate royalty, last week wound up in the company of accused common criminals in State Supreme Court. The Helmsleys, whose holdings include the Empire State Building and the Helmsley Palace Hotel, were charged with evading more than $4 million in state and Federal income taxes by fraudulently charging to their businesses millions of dollars in renovations to their Connecticut estate. Lawyers for the 80-year-old Mr. Helmsley and his 68-year-old wife, called ''the queen'' in Helmsley hotel commercials, said they would fight the charges ''tooth and nail.'' After waiting their turn for arraignment, the Helmsleys pleaded not guilty.

title: Correction
description: The Long Island Follow-Up column last week gave an incorrect telephone number for the Breast Cancer Hotline in Nassau County. The correct number is 248-8866.

title: TOP-RANKING ASIAN WILL LEAVE POLICE
description: Hugh H. Mo, who as deputy police commissioner of trials was the highest-ranking person of Asian descent in New York City government, is resigning at the end of the month to join a law firm.

title: TRANSIT NOTES
description: LEAD: TRANSPORTATION initiatives designed to lead to a smoother flow of traffic along the U.S. 1 corridor in Mercer and Middlesex Counties are under study by the state's Department of Transportation.

title: Safe Rafting Takes Expertise
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. When we purchased our 40-year-old house about two years ago, we were told that a new roof had been installed about seven years before that. Recently we had to rip off and replace the old gutters and found that the bottom wood edge of the roof was rotten, with pieces starting to fall off. Does this mean we have to take off all the shingles, or can a partial job be done to correct this problem?

title: New & Noteworthy
description: LOOK HOMEWARD: A Life of Thomas Wolfe, by David Herbert Donald. (Fawcett Columbine, $12.95.) Last month, this biography of a man - who the Harvard historian David Herbert Donald says ''wrote more bad prose than any other major writer I can think of'' - won Mr. Donald his second Pulitzer Prize. ''A six-and-a-half-foot, hard-drinking monomaniac who believes himself to be the Great American Writer would appear to be fiction rather than fact,'' our reviewer, Harold Bloom, said last year, ''but Mr. Donald's Wolfe is very real. He is something like a parody of Nietzsche.'' DONA FLOR AND HER TWO HUSBANDS: A Moral and Amorous Tale, by Jorge Amado. Translated by Harriet de Onis. (Avon, $7.95.) A Brazilian woman is in love with both of her husbands: Teodoro, the polite and civilized local pharmacist, and Vadinho, who appealed to her wilder side. Vadinho, unfortunately, is dead, but through an act of spiritual prestidigitation she has him resurrected - and gets to keep Teodoro, too. In 1969, our reviewer, David Gallagher, called the novel ''remarkable . . . for the coolness with which the author is able to impose his extraordinary characters on us. Like them, we learn to take exoticism and magic in our stride.'' During the next year, Avon will be releasing new editions of other Amado novels. In GABRIELA, CLOVE AND CINNAMON ($7.95), translated by James L. Taylor and William Grossman, a beautiful young migrant worker comes to the city and falls in love with a well-to-do restaurateur. In 1962 our reviewer, Juan de Onis, called this story of clashing subcultures ''an exciting and enjoyable romp of a book, rich in literary delights.'' THE VIOLENT LAND ($7.95), translated by Samuel Putnam, is about the men and women who flock to the forests of Bahia, hoping to make their fortunes in the cacao trade. CAPTAINS OF THE SANDS, translated by Gregory Rabassa, and SHIPS AFIRE, translated by J. J. Armas Marcelo (both $7.95), will appear for the first time in English. A PERFECT WOMAN, by Carolyn Slaughter. (Penguin, $4.95.) What good is a perfect life if you're going to die anyway, Humphrey wonders, as he proceeds to fall in love with Sylvie, who has everything that Beth, his wife, is lacking. Of course, Beth has virtues that Sylvie cannot provide. ''From the outset this darkly delicious book celebrates the power of woman,'' Lucie Prinz said in The Book Review in 1985. The novel ''has a satisfying bite and the sweet tang of just desserts.'' The same publisher has released a new edition of Carolyn Slaughter's novel THE BANQUET ($4.95), in which a man obsessed by his mother's suicide falls in love with Blossom, a seemingly perfect shop clerk. In 1984 our reviewer, Jill Grossman, called it ''a carefully modulated story of psychopathological love. . . . We know from the first page that something terrible will happen to Blossom, and it is a mark of the author's ability that what does happen is surprising, though no less appalling than what we had expected.'' THE ECONOMIC EMERGENCE OF WOMEN, by Barbara R. Bergmann. (Basic, $10.95.) Every decade since the late 19th century, more women have joined the work force. But breaking through the fossilized social structures that keep them from achieving economic equality will require Government intervention, the author believes, both in the marketplace and in the home. In 1986, Wendy Kaminer said in The Book Review that much of the material here was familiar but lucidly drawn. ''Readers can glean . . . the simple truth that family life and employment patterns for women will change together or not at all.'' The same publisher has reissued WOMEN'S WAYS OF KNOWING: The Development of Self, Voice, and Mind ($10.95). In this book, Mary Field Belenky, Blythe McVicker Clinchy, Nancy Rule Goldberger and Jill Mattuck Tarule argue that women have been suppressed, not only economically but also by an authoritarian school system that ignores an important fact: women have different ways of learning things than men. ''Like a hot pepper, the bite in this book comes after it has been consumed,'' Sara Neustadtl said here in 1986. ''The final vision of confident, knowing women makes the tragedy of those trapped in silence even more chilling.'' THE OLD DEVILS, by Kingsley Amis. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $7.95.) When the Weavers leave the literary life in London to come home to Wales, they reawaken a tangle of promiscuous liaisons among their friends who stayed behind. Last year in The Times, Michiko Kakutani said she was relieved to find that in this novel, which won Britain's Booker Prize in 1986, Kingsley Amis has moved beyond misanthropic diatribes to produce a satire that is compassionate. ''The reader is less engaged by the slapstick elements of this book than by its thougtful, even melancholy, portrayal of its characters' attempts to come to terms with the past.'' The same publisher has reissued Mr. Amis's 1984 novel STANLEY AND THE WOMEN ($6.95). THE RACHEL PAPERS, by Martin Amis. (Harmony, $7.95.) In the first novel by Martin Amis, Kingsley Amis's son, Charles Highway is determined to sleep with an older woman before he graduates from his teens. ''It takes a certain comic talent to make Charles the delectably unappetizing creature he is, and Martin Amis has it,'' Grace Glueck said here in 1974. INTIMATE PARTNERS: Patterns in Love and Marriage, by Maggie Scarf. (Ballantine, $4.95.) People often look to marriage as a way of remaking themselves and beginning their lives anew. But Maggie Scarf shows in ''Intimate Partners'' that it is likely they'll end up reliving the problems of their childhoods instead; only the arena will have changed. Last year, Carol Tavris said here that the book was not dispassionate or critical enough. But other reviewers have praised it, including one who said it explained the art of family therapy in ''straightforward, jargon-free language'' illustrated with case studies that are rendered ''with the prose of a novelist.'' THE SECRET MUSEUM: Pornography in Modern Culture, by Walter Kendrick. (Penguin, $7.95.) Pornography, Walter Kendrick writes, is as old as Pompeii, where embarrassed anthropologists found rooms adorned with lascivious frescoes. ''Mr. Kendrick writes crisply and amusingly,'' The Times's John Gross said last year. ''When he is not straining too hard, [ he ] can be highly illuminating . . . and he concludes on a satisfyingly forceful note, with a brisk dismissal of the Meese Commission report.'' SOMEBODY ELSE'S LIFE, by Morris Philipson. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) A philosophy professor with an identity crisis decides that the ticket to an authentic life is a lot of money, so he embarks on a plan to write a best seller about an art counterfeiter. Then his girlfriend persuades him that it would be more profitable to commit the imaginary crime. Last year, Benjamin DeMott said here that Morris Philipson's fifth novel ''frequently seems morally confused'' but added that he found it ''carefully plotted,'' ''readable and intermittently entertaining.'' The same publisher has reissued Mr. Philipson's novel THE WALLPAPER FOX ($7.95), about a wealthy family whose members are each, in a different way, living a lie. ''This solid and serious novel . . . raises disturbing and complicated questions about the capacity of family life to mitigate an increasingly barren modern experience,'' J. L. Crain said in The Book Review in 1976. ''The author's vision is a melancholy but compassionate one.'' ONLY WHEN I LAUGH, by Len Deighton. (Mysterious Press, $4.95.) A confidence man believes he and his cohorts are driven by a Darwinian imperative: depriving ''the stupid and the inefficient of wealth and prestige.'' Last year our reviewer, Alan Caruba, said the novel, which was published in England two decades ago, ''shows that this British writer was already a splendid storyteller. . . . Even then he displayed affection for gifted miscreants.'' THE SOCIETY OF MIND, by Marvin Minsky. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $9.95) Philosophers once begged the question of how the brain works by assuming there is a homunculus, or little person, inside. But how does the homunculus think? Marvin Minsky avoids the infinite regress that inevitably accompanies this intellectual subterfuge by supposing that the mind is a society of many different homunculi, each so simple and stupid that its behavior can be explained mechanistically. But when they interact, intelligence emerges. Last year our reviewer, James W. Lance, called this ''an ingenious and stimulating book . . . leaping from thought to thought with admirable agility.'' VALIDE: A Novel of the Harem, by Barbara Chase-Riboud. (Avon, $4.95.) A young woman captured in Martinque in the late 1700's is sold into an Ottoman sultan's harem, but she rises through the ranks to become a despotic empress. In 1986, Wendy Smith said in The Book Review that Barbara Chase-Riboud's novel is marred by ''stilted, unreal prose,'' but ''the ideas themselves are provocative. . . . [ She ] has clearly thought long and hard about slavery - what it does to the people caught up in it and, more fundamentally, what aspects of human nature its existence expresses.'' The same publisher has reprinted SALLY HEMINGS ($4.95), the author's 1979 novel about a slave who some historians maintain was Thomas Jefferson's concubine and the mother of five of his children. THE JEFFERSON SCANDALS: A Rebuttal, by Virginius Dabney. (Dodd, Mead, $9.95.) Despite what Barbara Chase-Riboud and some historians, such as Fawn M. Brodie, have written, President Jefferson did not have a black mistress, Virginius Dabney believes. ''Despite a slight tone of protesting too much, [ he ] is reasonable in his research,'' Herbert Mitgang said in The Times in 1981. ''A reader comes away with the impression that, whatever the truth may be behind the bedroom doors, Jefferson can survive both his detractors and defenders.'' MIAMI BLUES, by Charles Willeford. (Ballantine, $2.95.) After ''a blithe psychopath from California'' comes to Miami and robs a policeman of his badge, gun and dentures, the victim is determined to take revenge. In 1984, Newgate Callendar said here that Charles Willeford handled the plot ''with thorough professionalism. . . . The prose is clean and tough and flows easily.'' MIAMI: City of the Future, by T. D. Allman. (Atlantic Monthly, $5.95.) Miami, T. D. Allman writes, is now ''the coolest, hippest, hottest metropolis in the universe.'' Last year our reviewer, J. Anthony Lukas, who has written more reservedly about Boston, said that the author's hyperbolic prose was appropriate for this energetic Southern city with its drugs, pink flamingos, pastel stucco buildings and exotic Art Deco hotels. ''Sometimes it seems this whole damn book is adjectives. . . . Some of Mr. Allman's best pages are about [ Florida's ] most fantastical phenomena.'' BOLT, by Dick Francis. (Fawcett Crest, $4.95.) In another of Dick Francis' mysteries about horse racing, a jockey named Kit Fielding must save his career, his fiancee and her family from various evils. ''The result is a novel that races along with all the alacrity of one of Kit's mounts,'' Mel Watkins said in The Book Review last year. ''A subtle twist at the end makes the jaunt all the more enjoyable.'' WHERE IS NICARAGUA? by Peter Davis. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) During two visits to Nicaragua, in 1983 and 1986, Peter Davis was struck by the interplay between the Sandinistas' revolutionary experiment and the manner in which it is perceived by people in the United States. The author ''advances his argument not by polemical thrust but by color, juxtaposition and tactful analysis,'' Jefferson Morley said here last year. ''Amateurs like Mr. Davis seem to be able to capture Central America in a way that Central America professionals rarely do.'' BEHIND THE FRONT PAGE: A Candid Look at How the News Is Made, by David S. Broder. (Touchstone/ Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) The Washington Post political reporter David S. Broder believes there is something perverse about the journalist's self-imposed exile - the wish to remain apart from ''the most profound experiences of your friends, your neighbors, your city, or your nation. We are voyeurs, not participants.'' Last year our reviewer, Thomas Griffith, said he liked the way Mr. Broder ''avoids being holier than his colleagues. . . . He writes in sprightly, anecdotal fashion, but a melancholy awareness . . . suffuses this honest book.'' WALKING ACROSS EGYPT, by Clyde Edgerton. (Ballantine, $3.95.) Mattie Rigsbee, an elderly widow, becomes entangled with a thief, a dogcatcher and other eccentric North Carolina denizens. Last year our reviewer, Kathryn Morton, who admired the author's first novel, ''Raney,'' said this one got off to a slow start but ultimately redeemed itself. THE FIRST THREE MINUTES: A Modern View of the Origin of the Universe, by Steven Weinberg. (Basic, $7.95.) Drawing on discoveries in cosmology and particle theory, a Nobel laureate in physics attempts to reconstruct how the universe might have been just after the big bang. In 1977 one reviewer called the book, which has been updated, ''science writing at its best. There is no sacrifice of accuracy for sensational effects, at the same time the difficult mathematics is kept to a minimum.'' A YELLOW RAFT IN BLUE WATER, by Michael Dorris. (Warner, $7.95.) By telling the story of a Montana Indian family three times - through the eyes of a young woman, her mother and her grandmother - Michael Dorris reveals, layer by layer, how it feels to live in a society that is slowly being eroded by television and other devices of cultural conquest. Last year Anatole Broyard said here that Mr. Dorris's first novel ''realizes one of the extravagant dreams of anthropology -to describe a dying culture almost as if you were dying with it.'' SAMURAI AND SILK: A Japanese and American Heritage, by Haru Matsukata Reischauer. (Belknap/ Harvard University, $10.95.) One of Haru Matsukata Reischauer's grandfathers was a Japanese silk magnate, the other a member of the ruling samurai class who became a prime minister. The story of these men and their descendants has resulted in ''a very entertaining and interesting book,'' Ian Buruma said in The Book Review in 1986. The author ''has succeeded in bringing alive some of the people who shaped modern Japan.'' TEMPORARY SHELTER, by Mary Gordon. (Ballantine, $3.95.) When this collection of 20 fatalistic tales of vulnerable, depressed women was published last year, Rachel Billington said in The Book Review that the short story can be ''a testing ground for any novelist, particularly one whose talents lie rather in conveying the intimacies of a woman's mind than in any stylistic finesse.'' Still, she found ''some stories that are touching, and some that are memorable.'' ROBERT KENNEDY: A Memoir, by Jack Newfield. (Plume/New American Library, $7.95.) Twenty years after the assassination of Robert F. Kennedy, no other white leader offers as much hope of revitalizing American liberalism as Kennedy did, Jack Newfield writes in a new introduction to this biography. In 1969 our reviewer, Larry L. King, called this ''a perceptive and moving book'' that ''brings to Kennedy's personality those shadings, complexities and internal furies that would have made him a great character in fiction.'' The same publisher has reissued Kennedy's 1969 book THIRTEEN DAYS: A Memoir of the Cuban Missile Crisis ($3.95).

title: >Firemen Try to Attract New Blood
description: THE banner in front of the Syosset Fire Department reads, ''Fire Fighters Wanted: Help Us Help You.''

title: DESTINATION: MARS
description: John Noble Wilford's article gave promise of a realistic view of solar-system exploration. It turned out to be just the same old space hype. All that beautiful machinery on the surface of Mars, and all those people running around in their space suits -for what?

title: CONCERNS RAISED ON THE '90 CENSUS Special to The New York Times
description: Language proposed for use on the 1990 census questionnaire, intended to determine the number of Asians in the United States, will confuse respondents and lead to inaccurate counts, two Congressmen have told a House panel.

title: Kati Johnston, Producer, Is Wed To Stewart Russell
description: St. Patrick's Cathedral was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Kati Johnston, a film producer, and Stewart Russell, an actor and the business manager of the Jean Cocteau Repertory company in Manhattan. The Rev. Robert J. Verrigni performed the ceremony.

title: Capitals Win Series on Overtime Goal
description: When he arrived from Quebec last June, Dale Hunter gave the Washington Capitals a quality they had sorely lacked in the past, his new teammates acknowledged and his new coach insisted.

title: 1948: Live . . . From Philadelphia . . . It's the National Conventions
description: It is now 40 years since networks began live television coverage of political conventions. Back in 1948 it took fewer than 300 journalists and technicians, and what they provided was carried by four networks to 18 stations in nine cities. Although radio had never attempted it, television began with gavel-to-gavel coverage, not because it was noble, but because it was cheaper than providing entertainment from studios in New York. Television was not yet profitable. But making television sets was, and two of the networks were owned by set makers, NBC by RCA, and DuMont by DuMont, a David among Goliaths both as network and manufacturer. As well as the manufacturers, the major parties wanted television coverage, and broadcasting is a federally licensed business. So broadcasting, with its profits and its heart in radio, agreed to television coverage, and the parties agreed to meet in the same city to make it easier, in Philadelphia, where the coaxial cable meets the Schuylkill.

title: U.S. Is Reportedly Weighing Retaliation for Mining of Gulf
description: The Reagan Administration is weighing a possible military response to what officials view as a resurgence of Iranian mine laying in the Persian Gulf, officials said today.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. When we purchased our 40-year-old house about two years ago, we were told that a new roof had been installed about seven years before that. Recently we had to rip off and replace the old gutters and found that the bottom wood edge of the roof was rotten, with pieces starting to fall off. Does this mean we have to take off all the shingles, or can a partial job be done to correct this problem?

title: Kitty Lorentzen, a Writer, Is Engaged to Jamie Cornell
description: Cornelia Maria Lorentzen and James Keen Cornell, the son of Mrs. Mortimer Ryon of Solebury, Pa., and Nantucket, Mass., and M. Keen Cornell of Bear Creek and Pocono Lake Preserve, Pa., plan to marry in October, the future bride's mother, Mrs. Robert Pollard 3d of Sugar Hill, N.H., and Palm Beach, Fla., has announced.

title: The How and Why of Candidates' Campaign Cash
description: THIS is the season for political fund-raisers, and a Long Islander, Joel Boyarsky, emerged in the last year as a major player.

title: A NEW PRESIDENT FOR COOPER UNION
description: John Jay Iselin, former president of WNET-TV, has been named president of the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: Letter on Irradiation Is Called Misleading
description: The letter by Dr. Melvin A. Benarde in the March 20 issue, entitled ''Irradiation Article Called Misleading,'' is itself misleading.

title: A Walk on the Weird Side in L.A.
description: YOU'VE all had your little laugh at the weirdness of Los Angeles. You think you're an authority on the subject, just because you've strolled past the Chinese Theater on Hollywood Boulevard, gawked at the ersatz canals in our beachside version of Venice or giggled at Forest Lawn's ''authentic'' reproduction of Michelangelo's ''David,'' complete with a push-button activated, tape-recorded dramatization of the battle between David and Goliath. You don't know the half of it. Los Angeles is far more weird than any run-of-the-mill tourist can know. How many have seen the porno theater in the shape of a Mayan temple, the giant pig murals of Vernon, the rocket ship tombstone of Hollywood Memorial Park, the religious radio station in the shape of a 1930's ocean liner and the mausoleum so ornate that the staff hands out picture postcards? If any of these spots existed in one of America's more tradition-bound cities, it would be listed in all the local guidebooks and be on the tour bus routes. In L.A. these gems remain almost undiscovered, even by much of the resident populace.

title: Fermat's Last Theorem Still Has 0 Solutions
description: NOT many of the old problems are left, and none are as notorious as Fermat's Last Theorem, so the telephone lines and computer message networks of the mathematics world buzzed over the last month with the news that this 350-year-old enigma of number theory might finally have succumbed.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
A Mixed-Income Project Roils Hoboken
description: LEAD: OVER the last 15 years Hoboken has been transformed from a moribund factory and port town into a residential community on the rise.

title: Elisa Hoen Weds Simon Wakefield
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Glyndon, Md., Elisa Hoen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Hoen Jr. of Glyndon, was married yesterday to Simon Benedict Wakefield, a son of Sir Peter and Lady Wakefield of Twickenham, Middlesex, England.

title: FOUR SCULPTORS WITH INTENSE VISIONS
description: SCULPTURE IN NEW YORK THIS April has a confidence that it has not had in a while. The themes are big. Sculptors 35 to 45 years old seem capable of a new completeness and sweep.
