The days when sculptors felt defensive or apologetic about an intimate involvement with materials, the physical mass of their objects and the need to make art that could refer to anything, are over.

title: THE FITNESS QUEST
description: EVENTUALLY, EVERY PERSON who exercises seriously begins to search for the single, perfect fitness activity. But this search is bound to be frustrating. Running, for example, provides superb aerobic conditioning, can be done most anywhere with minimal equipment and is either a solo or group activity. But over time it takes a terrible toll on the knees, shins, ankles and feet, and it does little for the upper body. Racquet sports provide good aerobic exercise, but they require courts, companions, carefully meshed schedules and good hand-eye coordination. Cycling is an excellent aerobic activity, but it largely ignores the upper body and can torture vulnerable knees. Aerobic dancing will quickly get the heart rate up, but even the newer low-impact variety can damage knees and leg tendons. Swimming is also aerobic and places minimal stress on joints, but it requires a nearby body of water, heated in the winter, and dressing rooms. Skiing, particularly cross-country skiing, is at the top of the aerobic fitness activity list. But snow is, of course, essential, unless you work out on a skiing machine. Walking has many pluses, but requires large amounts of time to provide aerobic benefit.

title: Elyse Michele Walker Is Married to Jon Weiner
description: Elyse Michele Walker, a daughter of Mrs. Derek Jackson of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Stanley Walker of Newtown Square, Pa., was married last evening to Jon Weiner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Weiner of Easton, Mass. Rabbi Peter Weintraub performed the ceremony at the Danbury (Conn.) Hilton.

title: The Man in Blue Is Becoming the Star of the Game
description: Daddy, Daddy, can we go to another ballgame real soon? I liked the hot dogs and thesoda and the home run and the lights on thescoreboard, but what I really liked best,Daddy, was when the man in the blue uni=form waved his arm and let the runner takethe next base. Gosh, that was fun. The fansyelled and the manager yelled and theplayers yelled. It was like playing SimonSays. When I grow up, I'm going to be a manin blue, too, so I can wave my arm and let therunners move on. BASEBALL is the best spectator sport ever invented, but it has a marvelous tendency to shoot itself in the foot, likeInspector Clouseau on a case. The dilution ofthe strategic inner game by the designatedhitter is well documented. Expansion hasrobbed the American League of rivalries byscheduling more games outside the divisionthan within it Now we have the Great Balk Hula-HoopPet-Rock Frolics of 1988. And one can onlyshudder about what will happen if thesejokers get serious about interleague play.Boom. They'll blow off their own toes Maybe it's only a fad, like yo-yos or Nehrujackets, but the balk keeps getting in the wayof the game. Two weeks into the season, thefans have become conditioned to expect abalk. You could hear them out in wintry SheaStadium Friday night and yesterday, shout=ing ''balk'' every time a Met runner got onbase Balk-mania could turn fans into moochers,freeloaders, wishful thinkers. No longer willthey dream of a rousing double into the cor=ner, a masterful hit-and-run, a drag bunt.Nowadays, with runners on base, they whine,''Balk!'' Yesterday, the umpires restrainedthemselves on national television to one balkas the Mets defeated the Cardinals, 6-4.

title: Susan J. Benson, An Editor, Is Wed
description: The marriage of Susan Jill Benson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wendell R. Benson of Forest Hills, Queens, and Louis Michael Gutenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Robert Gutenberg of Short Hills, N.J., took place last evening at the Shackamaxon Country Club in Scotch Plains, N.J. Rabbi Henry M. Weiner officiated.

title: Flowers for Spring
description: FERTILIZER is important for all plants, especially those that have dawdled; give them a boost with a general formula such as 5-10-5 or 10-10-10; trace a circle of it around the crowns. Pull away winter mulches, but be careful if working around perennials and shrubs as many are shallow rooted. Sow another half-row of radish, peas and spinach to keep harvest coming. Daffodils

title: Girl Watching
description: ONLY TWO CAN PLAY Starring Peter Sellers (in photo, left), Mai Zetterling (in photo, right) and Richard Attenborough. Directed by Sidney Gilliat. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 106 minutes. $69.95.

title: An Elegant Spot for Expert Italian
description: THE French may have a culinary beachhead in Greenwich, but the Italians have arrived with a challenger. La Strada sets new standards of stylishness for Italian restaurants in Fairfield County, with elegant surroundings and a menu to match.

title: THE NEW MARITAL THERAPY
description: In Martha Weinman Lear's article ''The New Marital Therapy'' (Body and Mind, March 6), one message that is being sent to couples in distress is ''let the buyer beware.'' Those of us who ''bought'' the 1970's ''self-actualizing'' theory can't ask for a refund! What hurts, apart from the domestic debris, is knowing that therapists like Laura Singer can so easily put on another hat, drop the confrontational method, and, using the new computerized jargon, counsel anguished couples to ''bond'' the ''unit.'' MELISSA LONDEZI New City, N.Y.

title: WHY I'M QUITTING THE SENATE
description: THE SENATE CAMPAIGNS OF 1988, like the Democratic Presidential primaries, may well be remembered not so much for those candidates who ran, as for those who chose not to run. Seldom have so many senators in midcareer chosen to call it quits.

title: Attack on Chinese Reporter
description: A Chinese television reporter was beaten by security guards while covering a flower show, a newspaper said today in a rare report on the activities of Chinese police. Worker's Daily said Zhang Jianhua, a reporter for a television station in Henan Province, was in a park just before its annual peony show when four security guards surrounded and attacked him.

title: Town in Maine Gets An Offer of Diapers For Welfare Clients
description: The owner of a Syracuse, N.Y., trading company has offered to supply this central Maine town with as many cloth diapers as it needs to show his support for the town's decision to prohibit people on welfare using state funds to buy disposable diapers.

title: Disney World
description: To the Editor: The chairman of Walt Disney Enterprises, Michael D. Eisner, seems to have a typical Yuppie mentality: that only money is important. In spite of handsome earnings, he is riding roughshod over the Walt Disney philosophy. Not only is the entry fee rising, everything in the park is doing the same. He proudly says he is going to keep raising prices until people rebel.

title: Fitting the Budget to Vision and Reality
description: ALTHOUGH members of the Legislature introduce thousands of bills each year and pass hundreds, the only item of business they really must accomplish before they adjourn is to adopt the state budget.

title: Radford & Wayne
description: To the Editor:

title: TAKING CARE: ALLERGIES
description: FOR MILLIONS OF ALLERGY sufferers, the balmy breezes of spring herald the seasons of misery. But a recent flowering of medical research has ushered in a new season in the battle against hay fever and asthma. ''Our capacity to treat these diseases is night-and-day better because we have a marked increase in our knowledge of what goes on inside the nose and airways,'' says Dr. Michael Kaliner, director of the Allergic Diseases Section of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. This knowledge has led to the development of the first drugs that prevent attacks of hay fever and asthma, helped clarify the most appropriate uses for allergy shots and given rise to behavioral strategies for controlling asthma.

title: Suzanne Garber Plans To Wed Robert Freier
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jerome M. Garber of Old Westbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Suzanne Allison Garber to Robert Keith Freier, the son of Sheila V. Freier of Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Benjamin D. Freier. An August wedding is planned.

title:
INVESTING;
Playing Oil Through the Drillers
description: LEAD: THE last place skittish investors would probably look now for ideas is in the volatile oil stocks. Although crude prices appear to be firming, the oil sector, thanks to OPEC-related machinations, is considered by many to be a minefield.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday on the 1988 John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation fellowships omitted three winners: Alice Kessler-Harris, professor of history at Hofstra University; Lucy Freeman Sandler, professor of art history at New York University, and Joseph Santore, a painter in New York City.

title:
GARDENING;
Planning Company for the Early Tulip
description: LEAD: TULIPS can be counted on to provide a splash of color in late April and early May, but what can be planted as companion plants to flower at the same time?

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: UPLIFT THE RACE: The Construction of ''School Daze.'' By Spike Lee with Lisa Jones. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) ''What is ''School Daze'' then? Maybe it's just a Spike Lee Joint,'' muses the film maker in this fascinating account co-written with Lisa Jones, a second assistant director on the new film. Mr. Lee won big with his first feature film, the low-budget ''She's Gotta Have It.'' With ''School Daze,'' he faces the pleasures and pains of big-time movie making with characteristic -and engaging - bravado. ''Uplift the Race'' comprises both the uncut screenplay of ''School Daze'' and a remarkably candid series of interviews with the film's cast and crew. Those interviewed speak freely of the difficulties caused by the relative inexperience of the crew and of mishaps both serious and silly, such as the time a crucial sweater is accidentally packed up and almost shipped to Los Angeles. They also talk about their enormous enthusiasm for the film and their belief in Mr. Lee's vision. The crew (Mr. Lee among them) also discuss the internecine struggles and the racial tensions that sprang up on that rarest of things in Hollywood: a predominantly black sound stage. One of the white crew members even reports his annoyance at being asked for the white perspective, wondering, ''Am I the quintessential white person?'' - a statement many black readers will find ironic. Despite the tensions and pressures of putting ''School Daze'' together, the book ends on a note of exhilaration and affirmation.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Bernards Township $220,000 410 South Maple Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, hardwood floors, deck; taxes $1,972. Keansburg $139,000 25 Johnson Lane 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 24-year-old ranch; c/a, fenced yard, eat-in kitchen, den; taxes $2,673. Livingston $225,000 10 Stony Hill Place 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 35-year-old split level; patio, fireplace, 1-car attached garage; taxes $3,030. Millburn $251,000 128 Greenwood Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 48-year-old colonial; family room, fireplace, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $3,466. Morristown $233,500 43 Georgian Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old colonial; deck, c/a, family room; taxes $2,393. West Orange $182,000 322 South Cloud Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 45-year-old colonial; front porch, fireplace, den, 2-car garage; taxes $2,964. OTHER AREAS Sharon, Conn. $900,000 Eggleston Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 1830 Federal farmhouse; 1-bedroom guest house, barn, 81 acres; taxes $3,475. Peekskill, N.Y. $215,000 Jacob Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 138-year-old frame colonial; barn, pond, 2.5 acres; taxes $2,770. Huntington, L.I. $280,000 5 Christa Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old ranch; dining room, finished basement; taxes $3,500.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Low-Income Housing; Manhattan 421a Carrot Bitten in Brooklyn
description: >IMAGINE a private company buying land and building housing, and then turning it over mortgage-free to lower-income people to rent for only the cost of operating and maintaining the buildings.

title: A CONVERTED DC-8 OFFERS NEW VISION
description: For Rosemond Bannerman, an ophthalmic nurse from Ghana, it was ''my first refresher course since leaving school in Britain in the 1960's.''

title: Sail America Plans Second Multihull
description: The Sail America yachting syndicate is building a second catamaran, identical to a design announced earlier this year, in preparing for the San Diego Yacht Club's defense of the America's Cup against New Zealand.

title: Zen Group Aiding Homeless in Yonkers
description: MEDITATION, interfaith expression and social action are some of the watchwords of the Zen Community of New York, which has spent the last few years using its money to live up to its traditions and to develop an unusual program to aid the homeless of Yonkers.

title: Priscilla Cohen to Marry Antony P. Weiner in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ira Cohen of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Priscilla Alden Cohen, to Antony Peter Weiner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Weiner of Encino, Calif. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: Business of Providing Crime Protection
description: WHEN it comes to the security-equipment industry, crime does pay.

title: Near End of Yearlong Mob Trial, Pointed Remarks
description: An undercurrent of animosity has crackled between a lawyer and the judge in a major racketeering trial focusing on the Genovese crime family.

title: ART WAS NOBLE, SHODDY WAS KING
description: LEAD: THE COLLECTED LETTERS OF WILLIAM MORRIS Volume Two: 1881-1888. Edited by Norman Kelvin. Illustrated. Two parts. 921 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. Part One, $45; Part Two, $49.50.

title: NOW LIEDER LOVERS HAVE A NEW REASON TO SING
description: THE VOCAL EVENT OF the New York season was Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau's week of Carnegie Hall concerts last month: After eight years' absence, the great baritone packed the hall from stage seats to rafters (and at top prices), earning the loudest tributes in standing ovations and the quietest in rapt attention to his demanding programs. It's easy to pay close attention to Mr. Fischer-Dieskau because he himself pays so much more attention than most singers.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DOCTOR ZAY. By Elizabeth Stuart Phelps. (Feminist Press, $8.95.) ''Doctor Zay,'' originally published in 1882, is a love story with rural Maine as its background. Waldo Yorke is a spoiled, wealthy young man from Boston, who meets with a severe accident while traveling along the ''wild Maine coast''; Dr. Zay is the brilliant physician who attends his recovery. The story is told largely from the young man's point of view; he moves from shock and horror at the initial discovery that his doctor is a woman, to respect and fascination as he slowly recuperates and watches her in action, to passionate love. Most of the book takes place during Waldo's convalescence; the scenes of medical practice in a rural place are detailed and very affecting, as Dr. Zay pits herself against infant mortality, against accidents and disease, against the harsh realities of the life lived by her patients. Her own life is hard but full; this novel does an unusually good job of communicating the kinds of frustrations and satisfactions that make up a specific vocation. Waldo strives to become worthy of Dr. Zay, only to find himself brought up against a new problem: she will not give up her profession; she is not sure she can marry at all. She tells him: ''You have been so unfortunate as to become interested in a new kind of woman. The trouble is that a happy marriage with such a woman demands a new type of man.'' Phelps does a superb job of writing dialogue that allows for the discussion of the problems central to this novel, while remaining true to her characters, engaging and frequently funny. Waldo and Dr. Zay are both appealing people; it is fascinating to watch them struggle with hard choices in a world that does not feel at all far away.

title: Q&A
description: Rail Passes Question:For a single traveler (mid-20's) is it possible to obtain some sort of pass for rail travel in the United States and in Canada - similar to Eurailpass? - P. A., Yardley, Pa. Answer:Neither the United States nor Canada has an open-ended, nationwide pass allowing unlimited rail travel. The closest thing to it on Amtrak is the All Aboard America fare, which permits a limited number of journeys but can save money. Via Rail, Canada's national passenger railroad system, has its Canrailpass, but, unlike Europe's national train passes and Eurailpass (valid in 16 countries), it is for travel on one or other of four regions, and there are prices for low season and high.

title:
PAPERBACKS;
Porter McKay, justice Machine: Secrets of a Male Fantasy Writer
description: LEAD: PORTER McKAY slumped against the rough bark of a giant mesquite tree in the steaming heat of the Amazon rain forest.

title: Airline Meals
description: To the Editor: The perils of ordering special meals on airline flights cannot be overlooked. A while back we traveled from Fort Lauderdale to Detroit with Delta Airlines and ordered a cold seafood plate instead of the regular meal. Delta responded with a hot seafood plate. We wrote them a letter to complain and they apologized.

title: Crime
description: It is the immediate future, and Congress is getting ready to pass a law permitting certain kinds of murder. A powerful, clandestine group called the Hunt is behind it. The members think legal murder will be the salvation of the free world. (Don't ask why; just read the book.) Another clandestine group, equally powerful, is made up of the best scientific brains in America, and it makes the Mafia look like the P.T.A. It too thinks it will be the salvation of the free world. Then an ordinary man whose wife has been killed in Paris by terrorists joins the Hunt. He wants to kill.

title: 'Al-Kemi' and Schwaller de Lubicz
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERIC'S RED ARMY
description: THE GROUND TREMBLES IN THE HALF light of early morning as dozens of camouflaged tanks and troop carriers race by, their corrugated tracks criss-crossing the landscape. The smell of the overturned Mojave Desert earth hangs in the air, mingling with diesel fumes and the smoke laid down to cloak troop movement. Overhead, a low-flying airplane drops luminescent flares to confuse heat-seeking missiles. Sharp bursts of machine-gun fire and the deep boom of big tank guns are constant, and muzzle flashes tear through the haze.

title: Sports of The Times; Burke's Devilish Impact
description: IN the frenzy of the final seconds, Sean Burke peered through his mask as Pat LaFontaine swooped in and shot. Rising quickly, the puck thudded into the chest protector of the New Jersey Devils' goaltender as the final buzzer sounded. That save preserved a 6-5 victory over the New York Islanders that put the Devils into tomorrow night's opener of the Patrick Division final in the Stanley Cup playoffs. But when the 21-year-old rookie was asked later if he had heard the buzzer, he smiled.

title: Reagan White House Proves a Memorable Place to Work
description: ONCE it was considered proper for Presidential aides to let their boss get first licks in the memoir department. But no fewer than five Reagan Administration officials have published books and two more are soon to follow, eight months before President Reagan can even begin to reread his diaries. Larry M. Speakes, the former

title: Old Friends Gather In Chamber Series
description: IT should be a happy New York Philharmonic reunion in Salisbury this afternoon, when the Harvey String Quartet, the resident ensemble of the Chamber Music at St. John's series, greets its guest artist, the noted flutist Julius Baker.

title: A Proposal for the Princeton Shuttle
description: NEW JERSEY TRANSIT has predictably been awarded higher fares in response to Governor Kean's holding its subsidy to $530,000 ($193.5 million a year).

title: All the Livelong Day
description: To the Editor:

title: 12 Are Indicted in Tax Fraud
description: A Federal grand jury here has indicted 12 people in what the authorities say was a scheme that allowed nearly 6,000 taxpayers to cut their payments by a total of $88 million.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Health Center Opens in Beijing

title: Reporter's Notebook; Meese Paradox: Success of Trip Contrasts With His Troubles at Home
description: After a week of travels through Latin America with the Attorney General and his 20-member Government delegation, the paradox of Edwin Meese 3d is all the more striking.

title: High Tech Hits the Road
description: DURING the past 10 years, many high-tech gizmos and electronic gadgets have found their way into our homes. It was therefore only a matter of time before much of this gadgetry would find the travel market.

title: ASSASSINATION: UNDIPLOMATIC MIDEAST TOOL
description: For more than 15 years, Palestinian guerrilla groups and the Israeli military and intelligence services have carried out assasinations and counterassasinations in the Middle East and Europe.

title: Annual Benefit: A Spring Coat
description: THE cooler temperatures hanging doggedly around lately are making a lot of women glad they have spring coats, those between-seasons cover-ups that make hailing a cab or catching up on your shopping on a chilly day so much easier to bear.

title: Stopping Along the Way
description: I have been catching up on the movies recently, and as I watch various couples going at ''it'' on the edge of the sink, the floor of the elevator or the back seats of limousines, various thoughts go through my head.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Greenville, Me.; Reviving an Island Resort
description: A GROUP of Maine developers is restoring what is left of Mount Kineo House, a resort on a 322-acre island in Moosehead Lake that was popular in the late 1800's and early 1900's.

title: Patent Office Is Ill-Equipped for Dealing With Rights to Life
description: WHEN Thomas Jefferson wrote the Patent Act in 1793, he didn't think to include animals among the items of ''art, machine, manufacture or composition of matter'' that could be patented. Last week, though, the United

title: DAT's Arrive But No Players
description: PSSST! ANYONE FOR DIGITAL audio cassettes? There may not be any machines to play them on yet (although some models for automobiles will reportedly be available soon, and some gray market home players are said to be for sale, too), but there are already a few (very few) prerecorded tapes to play on them.

title: Her Mind Ran to Lurid Extremes
description: LULU INCOGNITO By Raymond Kennedy. 305 pp. New York: Vintage Contemporaries. Paper, $7.95.

title: THE INSIDE DIRT ON CLEANING RECORDER HEADS
description: CLEANING A VCR HAS been widely regarded as a matter of damned if you do and damned if you don't. If you didn't clean the VCR, dust and accumulated sheddings from the tape would take their toll. If you did, the cleaning action itself would scour the recorder's delicate innards.

title: A Personal Selection of Wildflowers
description: LOOKING back after some 25 years as a wildflower gardener, I remember that my first attempts at woodland gardening were not always successful. Some flowers I planted with great enthusiasm bloomed for only a day or two and were out of flower for the rest of the year. Others I chose proved not to be as vigorous as I had hoped and barely survived.

title: Susan A. Roever Is Married
description: Susan Allison Roever, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas W. Roever of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Andrew Butler Seath, the son of Mrs. Barry Pool of Riverside, Conn., and William Seath of New York. The Rev. Michael A. Drake and the Rev. Richard B. Martin officiated at the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church. The couple are graduates of the University of Richmond. The bride is an account executive with Batem Enterprises, a manufacturer of denim garments in New York. The bridegroom is a high-volume marketing executive with Xerox in New York.

title: Dr. Brophy Wed To Dr. Goldenring
description: Dr. Colleen Marie Brophy and Dr. James Richard Goldenring were married yesterday in Dwight Chapel at Yale University. The Rev. Kate Latimer, a Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: I've Heard The Mermaids Singing Starring Sheila McCarthy, Paule Baillargeon, Ann-Marie McDonald, John Evans, Brenda Kamino, Richard Monette. Directed by Patricia Rozema. 1987. Charter Entertainment. 81 minutes. $79.95. Not rated.

title: The Numbers They Love to Hate
description: THIRTY-FIVE times a month, various Federal departments spew out reams of numbers that purportedly tell how the economy is doing.

title: Downbeat Portrait
description: CHUCK BERRY HAIL! HAIL! ROCK 'N' ROLL Starring Chuck Berry, Keith Richards, Linda Ronstadt, Julian Lennon, Roy Orbison, the Everly Brothers, Jerry Lee Lewis, Bo Diddly, Little Richard, Bruce Springsteen. Directed by Taylor Hackford. 1987. MCA Home Video. 120 minutes. $79.95. Rated PG.

title:
DINING OUT;
Informal Fish Spot in Scarsdale
description: LEAD: LUCKY Scarsdale. Every neighborhood should have a dining spot like Eastchester Fish Gourmet. The place is informal and cheery and, for the most part, serves wonderful fish, a fresh supply always on hand and forthcoming from the adjoining fish shop. Both the shop and the restaurant are owned and operated by Rick

title: PEACE IS NOT ENOUGH
description: 1999 Victory Without War. By Richard Nixon. 336 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: A Season of Low Rates, Stable Prices
description: DESPITE doomsday predictions that initially scared away many home buyers, the most lasting impact of the stock market crash on residential real estate has been a sustained and inviting decline in mortgage interest rates.

title: Peach Bottom
description: To the Editor:

title:
PAPERBACK;
Is This Paranoia, or Am I Nuts?
description: LEAD: THE MUSTACHE By Emmanuel Carrere. Translated by Lanie Goodman. 146 pp. New York: Collier Books/Macmillan Publishing Company. Paper, $7.95.

title: Campus Blacks Feel Racism's Nuances
description: On the campuses of the nation's predominantly white universities, where racial unrest has risen dramatically in recent years, black students say they feel increasingly like outsiders, isolated and unwelcome.

title: Daniel Meyer Fiance Of Audrey Heffernan
description: Audrey Rayelyn Heffernan, an advertising sales representative for Gourmet magazine in New York, and Daniel Harris Meyer, who owns the Union Square Cafe in Manhattan, plan to be married in August.

title: The Inner Landscape
description: MY FATHER'S ABDOMINAL sonogram was taken a few years back for a problem that soon went away.

title: Whining Spreads To Golf Tour
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: BINSTEAD'S SAFARI. By Rachel Ingalls. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $6.95.) Stan Binstead, an academic from New England, travels to London and then to Africa where he plans to do research for a book on ''mythic character and its relation to the society that gives rise to it.'' Stan's dull and defeated wife, Millie, tags along.

title: In Bangladesh, Women Can't Go Home Again
description: Shafia Khatun has made a pioneering journey from rural poverty to a low-paying job in a crowded garment factory, and she may never be able to go home again.

title: NICARAGUAN FOES OPEN PEACE TALKS
description: After years of vowing to destroy each other, leaders of the Sandinista Government and the guerrillas opposing it began peace talks here today.

title: For Anguilla, Tie to London Is Prosperity
description: For six months, the Government of this little British possession in the Caribbean has been trying to find 11 good men or women who would like to become members of the Anguilla Police Force.

title: The Impact of Innovative Firehouse Designs
description: LEAD: FIREHOUSE construction and expansion are booming on Long Island, and with numerous firehouses dating to the early years of the century, the architectural impact of new design is being felt from Great Neck to Westhampton Beach.

title: Michelle Schlanger Weds David L. Kurtz, Executive
description: Michelle J. Schlanger and David L. Kurtz were married last evening at Temple B'nai Abraham in Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Barry Friedman and Cantor Nathaniel Benjamin performed the ceremony.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: CHORAL CONCERT

title: Johnson's Line Raises Devils' Production in Playoffs
description: After being a fourth-line center and a power-play specialist for most of the season, Mark Johnson has raised his play so much in the last four weeks that he has become a key to the success of the Devils.

title: AIRLINE HIJACKERS THREATEN KILLINGS
description: The hijacking of a Kuwaiti jet took a more threatening turn today when the men holding the airliner said they wanted to fly it elsewhere to ''liquidate our account'' with the Kuwaiti Government, which has refused to yield to their demand to free 17 convicted terrorists.

title: Volunteers Monitor Water Pollution
description: LEAD: FOR David Nemazie, a senior at the State University of New York at Purchase, the last year working with Dr. Barbara Dexter, an environmental-science professor, on her RiverWatch project has not only been an unusually rewarding learning experience but has also provided a major focus for his biology studies.

title: Homage to a Pasionate, Witty, Wacky Inspiring Man
description: THE first time I saw Tommy Vezzetti, he was bent over his old Underwood, which was perched precariously on a thick pile of books on the long mahogany bar of the Madison Hotel in Hoboken.

title: The Catskills: Landscapes and Tourism
description: IN 1983, the Hudson River Museum was host to ''In Search of the Picturesque,'' a show about the ways in which the Hudson River School landscapists dealt with the incursion of industry into their wilderness. Its message was that whatever their misgivings about progress, few painters were able to resist its picturesque byproducts -smoking chimneys, cranes, furnaces and the like.

title: Who Should Be Hockey's M.V.P.?
description: With Wayne Gretzky being injured and the Oilers slipping, the race for the m.v.p. became wide open. Steve Yzerman led his Red Wings to first place, but he too was hurt. Sean Burke dominated games the way Ken Dryden and Bernie Parent did, but played in so few games. So it comes down to two players who carried their talentless teams on their backs all year: Mario Lemieux and Denis Savard. Because the Penguins had a better record and stiffer competition, Lemieux should win. KENNETH BRODY Jackson Heights, Queens

title: RUSH HOUR ON THE NAUTILUS
description: SOME THINGS NEAL REED KNOWS about his clients: Carol Rigby can eat a pint of vanilla Haagen-Dazs in one sitting. Joy Toboroff wishes her thighs, which are not at all fat, were thinner. Frank Stella, who bends over when he paints, gets pains in his neck. Paul Kessel worries about losing his flexibility - and his golf swing - as the years advance. Stephen Green takes his squash game very seriously. Nancy Peck, a one-time teen-age swimming star, is thrilled about her newfound fitness, which comes after nearly a decade of putting her career before her body.

title: Urban Newcomers Alter a Farm Area
description: A sign of the times in the fertile Schoharie Valley: the local agricultural college is instituting a new curriculum in the care and maintenance of lawn and garden equipment.

title: Back-Country Hiking In Zion National Park
description: THE Mormon fathers who first explored Zion Canyon, the centerpiece of Zion National Park, gave no hint in their accounts of what lay within, their sober assessment turning more on the canyon's dubious agricultural potential than its spectacle.

title: Wendy G. Olsoff Engaged to Gregg L. Deering, Artist
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Olsoff of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Gail Olsoff, to Gregg Lee Deering, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Deering of Whidbey Island, Wash. The couple plan to marry in September.

title: A Young Actress Goes From Soaps to Stage
description: LEAD: AFTER less than five years in show business, Kimiko Gelman is a bit concerned about being typecast: not as a Eurasian - the young actress has an Okinawan mother and an American father - but as a woman of ill repute.

title: Installing a Dishwasher in 77 Days
description: IF you are tired of consumer complaint stories like the one about the woman who kept being dunned for $00.00 and escaped court action only by sending a check for that amount, then don't read this. But if you want to learn how to take 11 weeks to install a dishwasher, this is for you. David Niven, you will recall, took just three days more to go around the world.

title: Foreign-Studies Grant
description: LEAD: A RECENT grant of $150,000 by the Hitachi Foundation will establish a new three-college consortium to improve international-studies programs at Iona College in New Rochelle, Manhattanville College in Purchase and Marymount College in Tarrytown.

title: Pistons End 30-Year Spell
description: Isiah Thomas scored 20 points tonight as the Detroit Pistons beat the New Jersey Nets, 114-96, and clinched their first division championship since moving to Michigan before the start of the 1957-58 season. The victory, coupled with the Atlanta Hawks' 95-93 loss to the Knicks, gave the Pistons a four-game lead over the Hawks in the Central Division. Atlanta could still tie Detroit, but the Pistons won the season series against the Hawks. The Nets saw their losing streak extended to 13 games. Thomas hit a running jumper with 5 minutes 58 seconds left in the first period to give the Pistons the lead for good, 13-11.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ENDURING WOMEN. Text and photographs by Diane Koos Gentry. (Texas A&M; University Press, Paper, $16.95; Cloth, $29.95.) Popular images of independent women frequently feature an urban, upwardly mobile executive. In ''Enduring Women,'' a book of 10 profiles, Diane Koos Gentry, a photojournalist, reveals a different reality.

title: Film on Richard
description: HIS major-league career came to a sudden end when he suffered a stroke in 1980, but J. R. Richard, the former Houston Astros pitcher, is looking forward to a comeback of sorts, and a resurrection of the glory days when he was one of the leading pitchers.

title: RISEN STAR EDGES FORTY NINER
description: Risen Star, a son of Secretariat who had never raced outside Louisiana, wore down Forty Niner in the final yards to win the $105,600 Lexington Stakes at Keeneland by a head today and thoroughly muddle the outlook for the Kentucky Derby May 7.

title: FACED WITH A SHRINKING SUPPLY OF AUTHENTIC ART AFRICAN DEALERS PEDDLE THE ILLUSION
description: SHADED FROM THE HOT sun, Soro Zana works rapidly, cutting, slicing and chopping a block of cream-colored wood. Under the blows of his adze, an African mask quickly takes shape. Today Mr. Zana, a member of the Senufo tribe, is carving a mask in the style of his rivals, the Baule. He says he does not care -the mask, priced around $30, is destined for the tourist markets of Abidjan, 350 miles south of this Ivory Coast carving center of Korhogo.

title: Land Tax Legislation Expected
description: THE State Legislature is beginning to act on a longstanding proposal to allow six Suffolk County towns to create a special land acquisition fund by taxing real-estate sales.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Raising the Bridge, Lowering the Towers
description: RESPONDING to the complaints of boat owners, Xanadu Properties Ltd. of Hawaii has promised to raise its proposed bridge from 40 feet to 65 feet over the water to help win approval for a billion-dollar, 2,000-unit condominium development on Davids Island, a little more than a half mile offshore from New Rochelle.

title: Who Should Be Hockey's M.V.P.?
description: Mario Lemieux. Besides becoming only the fourth player in history to score 70 or more goals in a season, he kept the Penguins in the playoff race down to the last game. LOUIS MONTESI Jr. Danbury, Conn.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-21 At least 13 Palestinians were killed in clashes with Israeli soldiers in the occupied territories over the assassination in Tunisia of the P.L.O military commander. Khalil al-Wazir had grown up in the Gaza Strip. Page 1 The P.L.O. accused Israel of assassinating its most senior military offical, Khalil al-Wazir, at his home in Tunisia, and of killing two bodyguards and a Tunisian driver. Israel withheld all formal comment. 1 Hijackers threatened a massacre of the hostages they hold on a Kuwaiti jet if Kuwait does not release 17 convicted terrorists. The hijackers said they would ask first for fuel and then fly to an undisclosed location. 1 Resistance by Soviet officials and inertia may have crippled key elements of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's program to reshape Soviet society. Soviet officials warn that many of his policies are not working. 1 Peace talks began in Managua between Nicaraguan Government and guerrilla leaders. Among other things, the contras insist that before they lay down their weapons the army must be free of Sandinista political control. 5 Drug raids in the Bolivian jungles by U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration and Bolivian officials have made it unprofitable for farmers to harvest coca. But few expect the raids to stop the flow of cocaine. 18 The labor of women in Bangladesh is a boon to the struggling nation. About 200,000 women, defying Islamic tradition, now work in the garment industry, which is fueled by American imports. 8 Indian and Vietnamese relations were discussed by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and Vietnam's new Communist Party leader, Nguyen Van Linh, in Ho Chi Minh City. It was their first meeting. 13 A flying clinic for eye specialists teaches up-to-date ophthalmological techniques to doctors and nurses in the third world. Orbis, a program financed largely by the United States, operates out of a DC-8. 21 Billy Graham pays his first visit to China 4 Anguilla looks to London for prosperity 20 NATIONAL 24-36, 46-49 Racism on university campuses is making black students at predominantly white schools feel increasingly like outsiders, isolated and unwelcomed in what they feel is a hostile environment. 1 Developing anti-missile technology has been delayed by budget cuts, grounding of the space shuttle and bureaucratic disputes. The problems encountered by a laser project in New Mexico typify the situation. 36 Plutonium leaks at a dump in Idaho illustrate problems Federal officials face in dealing with wastes from the build-up of nuclear weapons. The situation has developed at 12 other nuclear weapons facilities. 24 Rocky Mountain National Park is already drawing the season's first rock climbers. But winter is slow to leave the high country, and rangers estimate they perform 50 to 85 search and rescue operations a year in the lingering snows. 24 A smoking ban on airline flights will affect about 80 percent of the flights within the United States. The ban, which involves all trips of two hours or less, goes into effect Saturday. 24 Alternative fuels bill advances 26 Fears raised on '90 Census 31 Rural area in the midst of paradox 47 POLITICS 28-32 Problems cities face are an issue for the Democratic Presidential candidates campaiging in New York. But the candidates in Tuesday's primary have suggested few specific solutions or said how much they would cost. 1 Voters in upstate New York make up slightly more than a quarter of the electorate in the primary. According to polls and Democratic leaders, Michael S. Dukakis has built a substantial lead in that part of the state. 28 Voter turnout will be critical in the New York Democratic Presidential primary Tuesday. The substantial lead now held by Michael S. Dukakis, as statewide polls suggest, could dissipate if turnout is low. 30 Sketches of top Democratic campaign staff members 32 REGIONAL 36-44, 51-54 Raises for female faculty members at the University of Connecticut have been approved, and experts say the decision could be a major step toward ending sex discrimination in wages for professors. 36 Nurses who travel are in demand by hospitals across the country. The nationwide nursing shortage has spawned a growing industry of traveling nurses, who typically work three months at one hospital and then move on. 38 The case of the Williamsburg Bridge has become a study of how neglect and poor maintenance can destroy a bridge. The 85-year-old steel structure was closed last week after engineers discovered extensive corrosion. 40 Urban settlers in rural New York are changing the countryside. They demand more municipal services from towns and villages, taxing local budgets, but have also taken an interest in schools and preservation. 40 A trip to Cuba is planned by John Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, after a stop in the Dominican Republic. He is the highest ranking American Roman Catholic to visit Cuba since Fidel Castro came to power. 41 Cigarette ads have little influence on whether people smoke, a witness for 3 tobacco companies testified last week at a civil trial in Newark over the death from lung cancer of a woman who smoked. 44 Plastic library cards replace paper in three boroughs 36 Top-ranking Asian will leave police 51 Cooper Union names a president 53 Near end of yearlong mob trial 53 N.Y.U. receives $2.8 million for new programs 54 For the elderly, 18 summer camps 54 ARTS/ENTERTAINMENT 62-68 OBITUARIES 42 David Margulis Jr., teacher

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: School for Sale - Just Kidding

title: When a Stepfather Loses His 'Children'
description: I REMEMBER my father bringing home wonderful strawberry tarts from work. I was 6 at the time, it's one of the only memories I have of him, because he died in about that same period in my life. But I was lucky. It seemed my neighborhood had lots of men eager to ''step up'' and take on the job of role model.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Office Condominiums; Sales at a Snail's Pace in a Soft Manhattan Market
description: EVER so slowly - with setbacks and skepticism along the way - developers of condominium office projects are convincing companies to buy space in Manhattan rather than lease it.

title: >Nancy Freeman Weds
description: Nancy Jean Freeman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Freeman of Brielle, N.J., was married at the St. Moritz Hotel in New York yesterday to Joel B. Moshin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Moshin of Brooklyn. Justice William D. Friedman of State Supreme Court in Queens officiated. Mrs. Moshin, a graduate of New York University, is a legal secretary at the Manhattan law firm of Spengler Carlson Gubar Brodsky & Frischling. Mr. Moshin, a graduate of City College, is a computer consultant with Howard Systems International.

title: Familiar Faces in New Places Could Field a Strong Team
description: FOR now, they would have to go without a shortstop and a catcher, but a group of players who changed positions this season could otherwise field a highly competitive everyday lineup. Their depth would be especially strong.

title: THRICE-TOLD TALES
description: Ah, how appropriate and timely; kudos for a little good down-home lying. As we sink further each day in a sea of sleaze and misrepresentation at virtually all levels of government, let's hear it for fabrication!

title: Who Should Be Hockey's M.V.P.?
description: Mario Lemieux. If not for his scoring prowess, the Penguins wouldn't amass 20 victories. One man can make a big difference. But a late vote has to go to the Devils' Sean Burke. This young star managed to change a has-been franchise into one of high respectability. HARVEY L. KLATZKO Brooklyn

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: INVENTORS AT WORK: Interviews With 16 Notable American Inventors. By Kenneth A. Brown. (Tempus/Microsoft/ Harper & Row, Paper, $9.95; Cloth, $17.95.) Marvin Camras invented magnetic recording for a cousin who liked to sing in the bathtub. Paul MacCready devised the featherweight Gossamer Condor man-powered plane for a competition because he needed the prize money. Bob Gundlach, who helped perfect xerography (photocopying), likes to create devices that other engineers have decided can't be built. On the other hand, the idea of the laser ''suddenly popped into'' Gordon Gould's head one Saturday night in the fall of 1957. The 15 men and one woman whom Kenneth A. Brown selected range in educational level from high school to Ph.D's; their works run from the pacemaker to the plastic soda bottle. Yet Franklin and Edison would recognize the way these people combine inspiration and practicality, cross conventional disciplines, trust their intuitions and enjoy the occasional moment when the perfect solution comes in ''a flash.'' Under the intelligent questioning of Mr. Brown, who has a degree in geology and has worked as a reporter, they dutifully suggest ways to increase America's declining patenting power, and confess to worrying about ever-increasing hindrances to creativity deriving from the patent law system, the government regulatory apparatus and obtuse corporations. But their hearts are really in their descriptions of their own work, which are all eminently clear, palpably joyful and often have a purely esthetic component.

title: Products Show for Star-Gazers
description: LEAD: TRE close approach of the planet Mars should be one of the main topics of conversation in Windsor Locks on Saturday as hundreds of amateur and professional astronomers gather at the first astronomical products exhibition in the Northeast.

title: Court Asked To Bar Report on Police Acts
description: LEAD: THE Suffolk County District Attorney, Patrick Henry, is seeking a court order to bar publication of an investigative report that is expected to depict misconduct and possible illegalities by county prosecutors and police officers.

title: CD Sonic Blockbusters With Fine Performances
description: BACK IN THE DAYS OF analog recordings and vinyl pressings, an audiophile spectacular stood out from the pack either because it captured a performance with uncommon realism or because the range of timbres and dynamics was so broad that the disk could be used as a measure by which a stereo system might be judged. Digital recording and the compact disk have made it easier to produce this sort of sonic blockbuster, merely by lessening dynamic limitations and eliminating both surface noise and need for the vinyl groove to be easily trackable by a diamond stylus.

title: 7 Die in Clash in Pakistan
description: A clash between local tribesmen and the paramilitary police in northwest Pakistan has left 7 people dead and 17 wounded, reports said today. The official news agency, A.P.P., and the newspaper Frontier Post in Peshawar said the fighting between Kukikhel tribesmen and Pakistan's frontier constabulary occurred Friday near the Khyber Pass. The Frontier Post said the Kukikhel action was a protest over the constabulary's attempt to set up a post in the tribal area, which usually is self-ruled and off limits to the Pakistani police.

title: Women's Salaries Are Raised By University of Connecticut
description: In what experts consider a major step toward ending sex discrimination in wages for professors, the University of Connecticut has agreed to broad salary increases for its female faculty members.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Water Woes: End the Chaos
description: LEAD: JAMES LAROCCA, president of Long Island's largest business association, recently made a thoughtful comment on this page concerning the hundreds of independent local authorities dealing with basic services such as water, garbage and sewage. While the agencies' jurisdictions are limited by political boundaries, their problems are regional and require broad, integrated approaches.

title: Review/Dance; Muller Group Plays 'Hide And Seek'
description: Children's games are often cruel, and adults can be childish game-players. That was made clear in ''Hide and Seek,'' which Lynne Taylor-Corbett created as guest choreographer for Jennifer Muller's company, Jennifer Muller/The Works.

title: 3 Ethnic Groups to Share a Home
description: THE Jewish, black and Italian historical societies in New Haven, each financially strapped, plan to share one home.

title:
GARDENING;
Planning Company for the Early Tulip
description: LEAD: TULIPS can be counted on to provide a splash of color in late April and early May, but what can be planted as companion plants to flower at the same time?

title: POSTINGS: Art Deco in Union City; Exit Sears, Enter Kennedy Center
description: When Sears Roebuck left Kennedy Boulevard in Union City, N.J., for the Newport Center in Jersey City, it was not because the old store was unprofitable. According to Fred Fish, who with Nathan Shmalo bought the 120,000-square-foot building in December for $5 million, Sears was ringing up $30 million a year in sales. He expects Kennedy Center, the shopping plaza the partners are developing in the building, to beat that by $20 million.

title: SMOKING BAN NEAR ON FLIGHTS IN U.S.
description: The no-smoking light will stay on for good starting Saturday on about 80 percent of the airline flights within the United States. The ban, involving virtually all trips scheduled for two hours or less, will affect more Americans than any other single smoking restriction.

title: Long Beach Voters Take the Issues Personally
description: As Democrats in this seaside city consider the Presidential campaign, many of them see the candidates sharply in relation to their own issues and concerns.

title: The Turnout Arithmetic; On Tuesday, Action Could Speak Louder Than Opinion Polls
description: THE outcome of Tuesday's New York primary will be determined in large measure by who shows up to vote.

title: Using Technology Doesn't Mean Getting Seduced by It
description: Go to Madison Square Garden for a concert, and you can expect big-budget theatrics: lasers and full-spectrum lights, ranks of keyboard and guitar electronics, truckloads of stage and sound equipment. But some of the effects I've enjoyed most at recent performances suggest that - just in time - we may be in for a low-tech renaissance. Robyn Hitchcock, for instance, wanted to project the horripilating voice of ''The Man With the Lightbulb Head'' from the stage of the Beacon Theater. He could have plugged in a harmonizer or a fuzzbox, or run his vocals through modulators and filters. Instead, he put an index finger to his not-so-stiff upper lip and wiggled it while he sang - delivering just the kind of burbling distortion (and deadpan humor) he needed.

title: 'Hospitals Are Looking More at Mergers'
description: DENNIS P. MAY is the president of the Connecticut Hospital Association, a trade group that represents the 36 general hospitals in the state.

title: U.S. Soldiers Fight Poverty In Honduras
description: United States Army engineers are completing construction here for both war and peace.

title: Peter K. Gonye Weds Lori Lynne Anderson
description: Lori Lynn Anderson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Anderson of Fresno, Calif., and Peter Kallay Gonye, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Lazlo K. Gonye of Stamford, Conn., and Sarasota, Fla., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Shrine of St. Therese in Fresno. The Rev. Kristof Hites and the Rev. Thomas G. Kleinhans performed the ceremony.

title: Alcoholic Brew
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HUNTINGTON 'JOURNEY' If a little imagination goes a long way, just think of what more than 2,000 imaginations could accomplish. That's how many youngsters in kindergarten to ninth grade in five Huntington Town school districts participated in a yearlong ''Journey'' toward the current Cultural History Museum/Exhibit at the Woodhull School in Huntington. With the help of the local arts council, the students have put together a cultural trip around the world, with stops in China, Africa, India and South America and among Native Americans. Displayed in appropriate museum settings, their creative efforts share the spotlight with bona fide art and artifacts on loan from museums and private collectors. For example, along with such objects as genuine ceremonial statuary and tools, an Aztec temple features student sand paintings.

title: Remember Kurt von Schuschnigg's Courage
description: To the Editor:

title: DATA UPDATE: April 17, 1988
IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: VIETNAM: 1969-1970. A Company Commander's Journal. By Michael Lee Lanning. (Ivy, $3.95.) A good infantry officer must be aggressively courageous, full of initiative, ruthless in pursuit of his mission and lacking in introspection. Oliver North is a prime example of the type, and so is Michael Lee Lanning, who became, at 23, one of the youngest American company commanders in the Vietnam War. His experiences as platoon leader were the subject of ''The Only War We Had,'' published last year; this volume has appeared to complete the story. Mr. Lanning served first in the booby-trapped rice paddies of the Mekong Delta, then in the jungles farther north. His talents were appreciated by both enlisted men and the higher command: he took few casualties while inflicting heavy losses on the enemy. Loving the sense of brotherhood and power that came with leading men in combat, he kept a journal to record the events of what still seems to him to have been the most vital and interesting period of his life. Attention is focused resolutely on surface details, with no introspective pondering of what it all meant. He tells of the joy he felt in taking an enemy's life, his pride in the skill and blood-thirstiness of his men and the contempt he felt for all Vietnamese. Mr. Lanning has not written a work of art, but instead has given one of the most honest and horrifying accounts of a combat soldier's life to come out of the Vietnam War.

title: THIS AMERICAN IN PARIS KEPT TRUE TO NEW YORK
description: WHEN CRITICAL ENTHU-siasm for Abstract Expressionism waned during the 1960's, Joan Mitchell was among the painters whose reputations suffered most. She moved permanently to France in 1968 but pursued the path she had carved out in Manhattan during the early 50's - a path that drew inspiration from the works of de Kooning, Pollock and other members of the New York School.

title: Rental Rejection Annoys Yeshiva
description: LEAD: OFFICIALS of an Orthodox Jewish grammar and high school for boys in Hewlett are perturbed because their requests to rent classrooms in a vacant public school have been refused for the third straight year by the Board of Education.

title: Game of 'Chicken' Kills Boy
description: A 9-year-old boy trying to beat a freight train across railroad tracks Friday afternoon was hit and killed by the train's engine. The boy, Joshua D. Bischoff, and three other children had been playing a game of ''chicken,'' daring one another to cross the tracks on bicycles as the train drew closer, witnesses said.

title: Bridge Troubles Provide A Case Study of Neglect
description: The deteriorating Williamsburg Bridge, which was closed last week because of extensive corrosion, has become a case study in engineering circles of how years of poor maintenance and neglect can destroy a structure as dynamic as a bridge.

title: FOOD FACTS
description: THE AMERICAN DIET IS CHANGING for the more exotic, and an increasing variety of foods is making its way to market, especially in ethnically diverse cities. As we expand our culinary horizons, scientists are discovering how various new foods affect our health. At the same time, they are uncovering some unexpected bonuses and hazards of more familiar edibles. Hot Mushrooms

title: Not All 'Free Trade' Is Free
description: As Congressional debate over the trade bill continues, so does discussion as to whether the remaining provisions are protectionist. Jagdish Bhagwati, Arthur Lehman Professor of Economics at Columbia University, discussed the merits of the bill with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman.

title: Starling Holds Title on Draw
description: Marlon Starling retained his World Boxing Association welterweight title when he and the challenger, Mark Breland, fought to a disputed 12-round draw tonight at the Las Vegas Hilton.

title: Managing Potential Presidents: Sketches of Key Campaign Staff Members
description: Running for President is like running the Presidency in at least one important way: neither task can be done without the help of a substantial staff. The quality, tone and style of a term in the White House depend not only on the President but on the aides who surround the chief executive and White House staffs and cabinets usually draw heavily from the people who surround the candidate who runs successfully for the office. Here are brief biographies of the people who play key roles in the campaigns of the three candidates contesting the Democratic Presidential primary in new York on April 19, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee and the Rev. Jesse Jackson:

title: Headliners; Home From Prison
description: Comdr. Donal M. Billig may be nearly blind in one eye, and his record as a physician may be imperfect. But a military review panel said last week that prosecutors were wrong to portray him as ''a bungling, one-eyed surgeon'' in the 1986 court-martial in which he was convicted of causing the deaths of three patients and was sentenced to four years in prison. In overturning the conviction, the Navy-Marine Corps Court of Military Review said prosecutors had conducted ''a smear campaign'' that resulted in a conviction despite ''a factual insufficiency of evidence.'' Pending the Navy's decision on an appeal, Dr. Billig, the former chief heart surgeon at the Bethesda Navy Hospital, was out of prison, back on active duty and eligible for $120,000 in back pay.

title: AS CATCH CAN
description: PERHAPS NO OTHER FOOD BENEFITS more from simple, unadorned cooking than does fish. At La Cagouille, an unconventional restaurant in Paris's 14th arrondissement, seafood is taken to a new level of simplicity to unveil its subtle flavors and textures.

title: 'La Cage aux Folles' in Darien
description: IT is less than five years old, but one can already become nostalgic over ''La Cage aux Folles,'' the model of a traditional musical that highlights human glitter instead of high-technology trappings.

title: Jury Advised on Recantation in Mob Murder Trial
description: The judge in the trial of three reputed Mafia figures charged with killing a New York City police detective told the jurors yesterday that they had to decide whether to believe the recanted testimony of a prosecution witness.

title: POSTINGS: Park Slope Offices; Walking to Work
description: Howard Pronsky has been blazing trails in Park Slope. First was his garage condominium at 841-45 Union Street, near Seventh Avenue, with car spaces going for up to $39,000. Since 1986, 100 of 145 have sold. Now he is developing a new idea - an office building in a residential community. ''A neighborhood needs more than just homes,'' he said. ''People who live here want to have an office nearby.'' Before he began restoring the 16,000-square-foot building at 435 Ninth Street, at Seventh Avenue, Park Slope could offer office space only in its brownstones.

title: Theatrical Divertisements
description: Small Town to Big City April 17 - Garrison Keillor, that down-home boy from Lake Wobegon, will bring his ''Prairie Home Companion'' to the Church of the Holy Apostles on Ninth Avenue at 28th Street. The evening, which starts at 7, will benefit the Episcopal church's soup kitchen, which feeds 800 each day, and its legal and medical services for the poor. A reception follows Mr. Keillor's home-spun comments and songs. Tickets, $100 or $25 for the performance alone, from 212-279-4200. Briefly Noted: April 17 - The Working Theater will hold its third annual benefit at Sardi's to support its Festival of One-Act Plays. Tickets, $75 for dinner, entertainment, auction and raffle starting at 7, or $100 to include a cocktail party at 5:30, from 212-967-5464. April 18 - The National Corporate Theater Fund, which supports 10 of the nation's top regional theaters, will hold a benefit starting with cocktails at 5:30 and dinner at 6 at the Pierre, followed by a preview performance of the musical ''Chess'' and concluding with champagne and dessert at the ''21'' Club. Tickets, $500 for the evening or $350 for cocktails, dinner and theater, or $150 for performance alone, from 212-393-6252. April 18 - Hors d'oeuvres, cocktails, entertainment and dancing are on the menu at Siberia, a club at 804 Washington Street, just east of the Hudson River near Horatio Street. The evening, starting at 6, will benefit the Shaliko Company, an avant-garde theater group whose current production of ''Doctor Faustus'' is at La Mama Annex. Tickets, $50, from 212-475-6313 or at the door. April 18 - The Manhattan Class Company, which provides a forum for new playwrights, will benefit from the 8 P.M. performance of ''The Phantom of the Opera'' followed by a reception at Sardi's. Tickets, $200 or $150 for performance only, from 212-239-9033. April 19 - Dolly Parton and Kenny Rogers will entertain at a black-tie benefit at the Waldorf-Astoria for the RP Foundation Fighting Blindness, which has headquarters in Baltimore. Cocktails at 6:30, followed by dinner and entertainment. Tickets, $300, $500 and $1,000, from 212-353-8200. April 19 - The Carlota Santana Spanish Dance Arts Company will celebrate its fifth anniversary with a benefit at the Museum of Contemporary Hispanic Art, 584 Broadway, south of Houston Street. Cocktails and performance from 6 to 9 P.M. Tickets, $40, from 212-473-4605. April 20 - King Bhumibol Adulyadej of Thailand is 60 years old and his youngest daughter, Princess Chulabhorn, will hold a benefit celebration at the Grand Hyatt with a black-tie reception at 7 followed by dinner, dancing and entertainment including Thai national dancers. The evening is part of an effort to raise $1 million to establish the King of Thailand Biomedical Research Fellowship at Rockefeller University. Tickets, $500, from 212-463-0684. April 20 - A benefit for the Off-Off Broadway productions of the five-year old New Arts Theater Company will be held from 8 to midnight at Baja, 246-A Columbus Avenue (72d Street). Tickets for snacks, dancing and entertainment, $50, from 212-925-1630 or at the door. April 20 - The annual benefit for the New York Foundation for the Arts will be held at the Lincoln Center Library with an awards dinner that starts with cocktails at 7. Tickets, $275, from 212-233-3900. April 20 - Beethoven's rarely performed Mass in C will be performed at 7:30 by Musica Sacra at Avery Fisher Hall. A black-tie dinner-dance will follow in the hall to benefit the choral group. Tickets, $200, $350 or $500, from 212-874-7887 or 874-6770. April 21 - The Whitney Museum and the New York Academy of Art will benefit from a reception and preview at Sotheby's of the Andy Warhol collection of art from 6 to 9. An 8:30 dinner-dance at the Whitney follows. Tickets, $250 for the preview reception and $350 to include the dinner-dance, from 212-606-7375. April 22 - A traditional Chinese dinner and dancing will highlight a benefit for the Hamilton-Madison House, a Lower East Side settlement. The 6 P.M. party will be at the Silver Palace Restaurant, 50-52 Bowery, just below Canal Street. Tickets, $50, from 212-349-3724 or at the door. April 22 - The 26th annual Leatherneck Ball to benefit the Marine Corps Scholarship Foundation, which will award $500,000 to 400 students this year, will be held at the Sheraton Centre. The foundation has provided $4.4 million in scholarships since its founding in 1962. The dinner-dance (black-tie or military dress) starts with cocktails at 6:30. Tickets $350, from 609-921-3534. April 22 - The Russian Nobility Association will celebrate its 50th anniversary with a dinner-dance at the Waldorf-Astoria to benefit its charitable services to elderly people and needy students. Tickets, $135, from 212-249-2578. April 23 - A black-tie dinner-dance at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria starting at 8:30 will benefit the Weizmann Institute of Science in Israel. Tickets, $150, from 212-752-1300. Benefit for Benefactors April 24 - Before he resumes his Broadway role in ''The World According to Me,'' Jackie Mason will present his show at a benefit at the Beacon Theater for the Foundation to Sustain Righteous Non-Jews and the Riker International Study of Organized Persecution of Children. The foundation is part of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith and provides economic and social support to non-Jews who risked their lives to save Jews during the Holocaust. A cocktail buffet at 5:30 P.M. precedes the 8 P.M. show after which there is a party with Mr. Mason. Tickets, $50 and $100 for the show alone, $175 and $250 for the buffet and show, and $500 to include the party with Mr. Mason, from 212-490-2525 or 212-724-2111.

title:
DINING OUT;
On the Lincoln Highway in Edison
description: LEAD: WHILE there are areas of New Jersey that seem to sport a restaurant on every corner, there are others where restaurants are few and far between. Edison is a good example of a busy town with very few good restaurants, and so the arrival of JQ's in the Clarion Hotel and Towers in August l986 - at that time, the hotel was called Quality

title: Caroline Rhoden Is Engaged
description: Charles H. Price 2d, the United States Ambassador to Britain, and Mrs. Price have announced the engagement of Mrs. Price's daughter Caroline Lee Rhoden to John Gregory McCallister, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Ben D. McCallister of Mission Hills, Kan. A September wedding is planned.

title: Who Will Indict The Indicters?
description: INDICT IS A STRANGE verb; it looks as if it should rhyme with >interdict. The confusion is rooted in the Latin >in- (''against'') and >dictare (''to dictate, order''); to >indict is to speak against, to accuse. We would all be better off to spell it >indite (as in ''to write''), but not even Noah Webster could straighten out English spelling.

title: WARNING: THE WRONG NUTRITIONIST CAN BE DANGEROUS TO YOUR HEALTH
description: SASSAFRAS HERBERT'S WALL sports a handsome certificate, complete with gold seal and red ribbon, declaring her to be a ''professional member'' of the American Association of Nutrition and Dietary Consultants, which calls itself ''a professional association dedicated to maintaining ethical standards in nutritional and dietary consulting.'' Having met all the requirements for membership, Ms. Herbert can be listed in a national directory that the association describes as ''a Who's Who in the world of modern nutrition.''

title: THE GREAT COLLABORATOR
description: A PRETTY RED BARN on the outskirts of a Connecticut village. Inside, the decor is late 20th-century rustic: no trace of hay or horses, but plenty of hand-hewn beams, rough-hewn furniture and high-end electronics, whose video components tap into the global village via a satellite dish on the lawn.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Sheen of Obsession An obsession can be pathological or it can approach the purity of art. Don DeLillo suggests that for novelists, it's a bit of both. This is from ''Anything Can Happen: Interviews With Contemporary American Novelists'' (University of Illinois), edited by Tom LeClair and Larry McCaffery.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Savannah, Ga.; An Amsterdam Of the South
description: JUST 300 yards from one of the nation's largest concentrations of historic homes and buildings, an Australian-owned company is planning a new community - modeled after Amsterdam, with its multitude of canals.

title: DISKS NEW AND OLD SALUTE ARRAU AT 85
description: NOW 85 YEARS OLD, CLAUDIO Arrau has finally begun to slow down. But with few interruptions after his formal debut in 1914 at the age of 11, the pianist maintained a dizzying career for decades. It encompassed roughly 100 concerts annually and several hundred trips to the recording studio.

title: In the Hospital
description: To the Editor: I spent two days in a hospital in Venice. Aside from the misery I felt at having 10 percent of my vacation wasted, my experiences were very positive. Fortunately, my problems were visible so I did not have to describe them, since no one spoke English. The ward was large and very clean with huge windows overlooking a courtyard that ambulatory patients could walk in. Lunch and dinner were served on little tables in the room and included wine. Best of all, the hospital accepted my assurance that I would pay when I returned home. KARIN MILLER New York, N.Y.

title: Texas Air Faces Official Inquiry
description: Texas Air is facing a Government inquiry into its financial condition and its compliance with safety standards. Texas Air, the nation's largest airline company, said there was ''no credible basis'' for challenging it on safety issues. The company also said that it believed political pressure from labor unions had led to the investigation. Unions at the company's Eastern Air Lines unit recently won a court order blocking Texas Air's plan to take the profitable East Coast shuttle operations away from Eastern. The Government contended that Texas Air, which has cash holdings of $850 million, was charging large fees for providing services to its airlines and might be diverting resources from the carriers. Texas Air's other big carrier, Continental, has had heavy losses and recently had to borrow money from Texas Air. Aviation officials stressed that the safety situation was not alarming. During their inspections, officials did ground five Eastern planes.

title: Measure on Alternative Fuels Passed by the Senate
description: The Senate has passed legislation intended to foster use of alternative motor fuels to reduce dependency on foreign petroleum and tap vast American supplies of coal, natural gas and grain.

title: Afghan Hard-Liners Dominate Rally Against Accords
description: Amid chorused shouts of ''death to Geneva,'' ''death to America'' and ''Allah is great,'' about 10,000 Afghan refugees who described themselves as fighters of a holy war rallied today to proclaim their opposition to the Geneva agreement.

title:
MUSIC;
Concert to Reopen The State Theater
description: LEAD: THE newly renovated State Theater in New Brunswick will be reopened officially next Sunday with a concert at 8 P.M. by the Jerusalem Symphony under John Nelson.

title: Cool Jazz, Hot Jambalaya In New Orleans
description: WITH a varied menu of music performed by jazz, rhythm and blues, Cajun, gospel, zydeco, rock-and-roll, African, Latin and Caribbean groups, the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival represents a convergence of cultures that is rare even by American standards.

title: Penguin Stages ''Immigrant''
description: IN 1909, Haskell Harelik immigrated from Russia to Hamilton, Tex. (population: 1,200; no Jews; two banks). There, where it was ''hot and safe, not like Russia,'' he pulled his wheelbarrow filled with bananas. ''A penny a piece'' were virtually all the English words he knew how to speak.

title: Who Should Be Hockey's M.V.P.?
description: Are you kidding? Well, if the V stands for vicious, the m.v.p. should be awarded to the person responsible for setting up those unprofessional fist fights that occur. ABRAHAM HOROWITZ Ocean Beach, N.Y.

title: Mitchell B. Miller Married To Marcia Sann in Jersey
description: Marcia Amy Sann and Mitchell Brent Miller, alumni of Union College and fourth-year medical students at the Albany Medical College, were married last evening at the Fair Lawn (N.J.) Jewish Center. Rabbi Simon Glustrom and Cantor David Rosenzweig officiated.

title: PEOPLE ARE GETTING OUT OF HAND
description: YUPPIES INVADE MY HOUSE AT DINNERTIME A Tale of Brunch, Bombs, and Gentrification in an American City. Edited by Joseph Barry and John Derevlany. Illustrated. 181 pp. Hoboken, N.J.: Big River Publishing. Paper, $5.95.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
From Azure Amulets To Baubles of Brass
description: LEAD: THE decorative arts that can be purchased in Cairo today reflect more successfully than ever the many periods and art forms of Egypt's history. There are representations of Pharaonic Egypt, Coptic or Christian Egypt as of A.D. 63, Islamic Egypt (which saw its artistic zenith during the Fatimid and Ayubid caliphates) and Mameluke Egypt (when a slave class ruled mercilessly but embellished Cairo generously).

title: 'Personal Places': Sequel, Antidote
description: ALTHOUGH not intended as such, ''Personal Places:

title: On Making a Difference, if Not a Revolution; Disastrous Aftereffects
description: To the Editor:

title: 'We're Talking Big-Time Illegal'
description: WHITE HORSE CAFE By Roberta Smoodin. 249 pp. New York: Penguin. Paper, $6.95.

title: Eating Disorders Rise in Adolescents
description: BULIMIA and anorexia nervosa appear to be spreading among girls in their early adolescence as more youngsters become unduly concerned with their weight, appearance and diet, therapists say.

title: Decades Later, Soviet Journal Prints a Rebuttal by Einstein
description: A Soviet journal has published a response by Albert Einstein to an attack on him that the journal printed in 1947.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE GRAYWOLF ANNUAL FOUR: SHORT STORIES BY MEN. Edited by Scott Walker. (Graywolf, $7.50.) This selection of 13 stories is sure to encourage - and depress - those readers given to ruminating on trends in relations between the sexes; the men portrayed here are troubled, restless and muddled, their marriages in various stages of disillusion or dissolution.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article last week on drug-free zones around schools, one of the penalties cited was incorrect. A youth convicted of even a minor offense loses his driver's license for six months and is fined $500.

title: Officials Talk, but the Market And Trade Gap Tell the Story
description: THE economic ministers of the United States and six other industrialized countries gathered here Wednesday to celebrate more than three months of a well-behaved dollar and the rosy hue of their springtime economies. They rededicated themselves to delivering more of the same. But the events of the morning after showed that when ministers want to go one way and the financial markets another, markets are mightier than ministers.

title: Rainer Gross Weds Cynthia Cannell, Vice President of a Literary Agency
description: Cynthia Ann Cannell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter B. Cannell of New York and Point o' Woods, Fire Island, was married yesterday to Rainer Gross, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Heinrich E. Gross of Cologne, West Germany. Judge Robert W. Sweet of the Federal District Court for the Southern District New York performed the ceremony at the New York home of the bride's aunt and uncle, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Eberstadt.

title: 'Dial M': Mystery Still Rings True
description: ''DIAL M FOR MURDER'' is one of those theatrical chestnuts that constantly crop up in the repertory of regional theaters. This thriller by Frederick Knott, now being done by Theater Three in Port Jefferson, made its Broadway debut in 1952. In 1954, Alfred Hitchcock turned it into a movie starring Grace Kelly and Ray Milland, and in 1981 a remake featured Angie Dickinson and Christopher Plummer.

title:
GARDENING;
Planning Company for the Early Tulip
description: LEAD: TULIPS can be counted on to provide a splash of color in late April and early May, but what can be planted as companion plants to flower at the same time?

title: Q and A
description: M.C.I. Rent Increase

title: Pamela J. DiMicco Is the Bride of David S. Keller
description: At St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y., Pamela Jean DiMicco, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. DiMicco of Bedford, was married yesterday to David S. Keller, the son of Richard R. Keller and Dr. Anne Elizabeth Borum Keller of Philadelphia. The Rev. Dr. William E. Foley performed the ceremony.

title: France's Shrinking Communist Presence
description: ANDRE Lajoinie did not sound like someone who was leading the French Communist Party into a debacle of historic dimensions. As 5,000 mostly working-class supporters roared on cue - whenever their presidential candidate raised his voice to a righteous shout - Mr. Lajoinie lambasted the French right and predicted that the Communists would emerge strengthened from the first round of voting next week.

title: DATA BANK: April 17, 1988
Headliners; Home Enrichment
description: The Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, has decided to step down from that national role to concentrate on getting benefits for his home state the old-fashioned way, by appropriating them. The 70-year-old West Virginia Democrat last week confirmed his long-rumored intention to retire from the Senate leadership and seek the chairmanship of the Senate Appropriations Committee, assuming he is re-elected. He said the appropriations post would provide ''that role which at this point in time will be best for West Virginia.'' Asked if that meant he would lavish his state with Federal projects, the Senator replied: ''I will do my best to see that West Virginia receives the share for which it is eligible.''

title: TRACKING VOTES: CANDIDATES STEP UP DRIVE IN TUESDAY'S NEW YORK PRIMARY  Albert Gore Jr.; Discounting Polls, Senator Is Counting On a Surprise
description: His advisers are gloomy. Polls show him a distant third. But Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee insists that New York State Democrats will ''surprise the pundits'' and he will emerge with a formidable vote.

title: Urging Efficiency
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Lenox, Mass.;
Old Campus, New Owners
description: LEAD: APPROPRIATE new uses are being sought for the 69-acre Lenox campus formerly used by The Bible Speaks, an evangelical ministry that vacated the facility last summer after a former member, Elizabeth Dayton Dovydenas, won a lawsuit to reclaim $6.6 million in donations she had made.

title: Pitted Against the Sky
description: HE SAYS: ''THE WAY THE cherry throws itself into the air, it suggests a ship drawing up on shore.'' She says: ''The garden itself is very formalistic. It reminds me of Versailles. Louis XIV was known for the etiquette he enforced in the palace. So the spoon and cherry kind of fit right in, as a parody of table manners.''

title: Springtime in the Rockies: A Growing Sport, a Deadly Risk
description: At Little Twin Owls, a rock formation near the entrance to Rocky Mountain National Park, a group of teen-agers spent one recent afternoon moving spiderlike up an 800-foot cliff on granite warmed by the April sun.

title: LIFE MOVES TOO FAST FOR THE PICTURE
description: MOON TIGER By Penelope Lively. 208 pp. New York: Grove Press. $15.95.

title: THE NEW MARITAL THERAPY
description: We might assume from Mrs. Lear's article that therapeutic models change with the regularity of new car models. As a therapist for the last 30 years, I can confirm that this, in fact, is correct. Marital and family therapies, in particular, have become growth industries, and they employ the same sales gimmicks as any other industry.

title: Amanda Zinsser, An Actress, Wed To James Moffat
