description: At Grace Eipscopal Church in New York, Amanda Zinsser, the daughter of John S. Zinsser Jr. of New York and West Cornwall, Conn., and the late Anne Lowe Roy, was married yesterday to James Matthews Moffat, the son of Mrs. Daniel G. Quigley of Bedford, N.Y., and John Moffat of Cooperstown, N.Y. The Rev. Harold Elliott Barrett performed the ceremony.

title: 2 in Stamford: Jimmy Ernst and Stairways and Chairs
description: IN the two shows now at the Silvermine Gallery in Stamford, there are 47 paintings and works on paper by Jimmy Ernst (1920-1984) and 108 pictures of chairs and stairs by assorted American and European photographers.

title: HIS FIRST CAMPAIGN
description: OUR TIME HAS COME A Delegate's Diary of Jesse Jackson's 1984 Presidential Campaign. By Lucius J. Barker. 233 pp. Chicago: University of Illinois Press. $21.95.

description: AVITABILES, Smithtown's newest Italian restaurant, has an old, familiar address. The gray Victorian house at 64 North

title: Adults Brave the Risks of the Stage
description: ACTING is trusting, surrendering, caring. Acting is listening, believing, feeling moved.

title: FAMILY AND FABLE IN GALILEE
description: ARABESQUES By Anton Shammas. Translated by Vivian Eden. 263 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: Officer Charged in Car Accident
description: An off-duty New York City transit police officer was charged with driving while intoxicated yesterday after an accident in Brooklyn in which a pedestrian was critically injured, the police said.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
The Rock
description: LEAD: THERE will be no more writing on ''the rock,'' if the Katonah Village Improvement Society has its way.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: A READER'S DELIGHT. By Noel Perrin. (University Press of New England, Paper, $9.95; Cloth, $18.) This off-the-beaten-track literary guide describes 40 forgotten masterworks and evaluates their ability to produce delight in the reader. Mr. Perrin, an author himself and professor of English at Dartmouth College, is entranced by a good story and, as indicated by nearly half the choices, a sense of humor is necessary to share his enjoyment.

title: Gateway - to Garbage
description: ''Welcome to Pig City.'' There's no such sign at the entrance to the Van Wyck Expressway at Kennedy International Airport but there might as well be. Instead of an attractive, perhaps even inspiring, gateway to New York City, what travelers find is a display of the disgusting.

title: Library Users in 3 Boroughs Will Be Issued Plastic Cards
description: Plastic library cards, which are supposed to last a lifetime, will begin replacing the traditional renewable paper cards this week at branches of the New York Public Library in Manhattan, the Bronx and on Staten Island.

title: Too Little Money, Too Many Disputes
description: WHEN Robert McNamara was president of the World Bank, he claimed he had the best job in the world. No one is likely to make that claim for the presidency of the World Bank's regional counterpart, the Inter-American Development Bank - at least not now.

title: Cher and Pu Yi: Quite a Couple
description: ''WHERE IS JACK VALEN-ti?'' said Adam. He was growing sleepy and impatient. Monday's night's Oscar telecast was well into its third hour and still the dapper, diminutive president of the Motion Picture Association of America hadn't appeared.

title: EXPLORING THE FORCES OF SLEEP
description: IT'S 2:30 IN THE MORNING, YOU'VE got a crucial interview during the day and you find yourself desperately thrashing in bed. Worry over what you're going to say has given way to panic over whether, given how sleepy you'll surely be, you will be able to speak coherently at all. If this sounds familiar, relax, because the news from the world of science is good. If you care enough about tomorrow's challenge for it to keep you awake, a growing body of research shows, you'll probably rise to the occasion and do just fine.

title: Why Europe Charms Maestros
description: LEAD: ABOUT 10 YEARS AGO, THE conductor Lawrence Foster was called in to replace an ailing colleague in some concerts with the Monte Carlo Orchestra. ''At intermission in the first rehearsal,'' Mr. Foster said recently, ''the manager called me in and said, 'This is going incredibly well. Would you be interested in a job?

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE TALL DARK ALIBI. By Carol Jerina. (Charter/Berkley, $3.95.) This slim, good-natured romp is a textbook example of television's indelible impact on the contemporary novel. Perhaps Ms. Jerina gives the game away when her heroine, a neophyte private eye, says that her work is ''more like 'Magnum' and 'Moonlighting' '' than the rumpled detective story of yesteryear. Young, feisty Jillian Fletcher unwittingly becomes part of a murder case when she bumps into an accused killer. Simultaneously, she comes under the tutelage of Jackson Fury, a rednecked, tight-jeaned, gray-eyed P.I., who agrees to help her bag the real villain. Jackson fruitlessly tries to bed the recalcitrant Jillian, a virgin with a weakness for sexy lingerie (Ms. Jerina seems positively preoccupied with underwear, which provides a lacy leitmotif for the novel). The book includes a complement of the usual suspects, a batch of convenient coincidences and some rather unlikely slip-ups on the part of the 10-year veteran detective, Fury. ''The Tall, Dark Alibi'' smoothly captures the slick, superficial banter of prime-time sleuthing, unfortunately at the expense of strong characterization and narrative. True, the novel's flaws sometimes work in its favor; Ms. Jerina's snappy dialogue keeps the story moving at a breezy clip, and if the main characters were given depth they would be appealing, especially Jillian, whose purposeful stride is interrupted with believable bouts of doubt and vulnerability. Played by the right actors, Jack and Jill might make a pretty entertaining movie of the week - and there's the rub. A book shouldn't depend on its casting.

title:
ART;
Prints from Tokyo at Rutgers Zimmerliz
description: LEAD: A TRIO of interlocking shows is the bill of fare at the Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers. Two are lavish; the third is quirky, but has a certain interest.

title: Corporate Big Brothers Lend a Helping Hand
description: DURING the two years he has been in the Technology Executive Roundtable, a national networking and educational organization for small businesses, Greg Wallace figures he has gotten ''$15,000 to $20,000 worth of free management advice'' he has been able to apply to his small Boston software company.

title: Physician Aides Still Debated
description: LEAD: With a stethoscope protruding from the hip pocket of her white coat, Susan Schwartz moved from bed to bed, examining her elderly patients at the Veterans Administration Medical Center here.

title: Danger Lurking In the Rapids
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MYTHS OF OBSTINACY
description: LEAD: WHITE TRIBE DREAMING Apartheid's Bitter Roots as Witnessed by Eight Generations of an Afrikaner Family. By Marq de Villiers. Illustrated. 420 pp. New York: Viking. $21.95.

title: THE WORLD: Gunfire and a War of Nerves; The United States in Panama: A Troubled Presence
description: ''WE don't shoot at palm trees unless they're shooting at us,'' said a Marine spokesman in Panama, answering a question about why American troops could not find the intruders they said had penetrated the United States-controlled Arraijan fuel depot near Howard Air Base Tuesday night. By the end of the week, no intruders had been found, and a marine was dead, killed accidentally by American fire in a separate incident.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE Morris County Park Commission has an opportunity to trade a baseball field for a mountain, thanks to a landowner who does not want his property overrun by condominiums.

title: CATERING TO THE CARRIAGE TRADE
description: IT WAS ONLY a century ago that Manhattan's Upper East Side still contained patches of abandoned farmland, a tableau that seems particularly odd today, given the area's density and lure. Rows of carriage houses then dominated many of the side streets east of Park Avenue. Built for horses and carriages, and later inhabited by cars and chauffeurs, the structures belonged to New York's well-to-do families who resided farther west in mansions or in some of the earliest apartment houses along Fifth Avenue.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: STARGAZING EVENTS Saturday is International Astronomy Day, and observatories in West Paterson, Cranford and Boonton will present special programs.

title: Raid Fails to Find Fugitive Manila Coup Head
description: Troops raided a hideout of the fugitive leader of August's attempted coup, the military said today.

title:
VIEW FROM: KATONAH HARDWARE;
Mecca for Spring Worshipers
description: LEAD: SPRING! Daffodils, tulips, robins' eggs. Fluffy clouds and sweet-smelling air.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: GOODSPEED AT 25 ''Wonderful Town,'' a Broadway hit in 1953, will open at the Goodspeed Opera House on Wednesday, as the the East Haddam theater celebrates its 25th anniversary.

title: His Death Came Just in Time
description: THE LATE MATTIA PASCAL By Luigi Pirandello. Translated by William Weaver. 262 pp. Hygiene, Colo.: Eridanos Press/Rizzoli International. Paper, $14; Cloth, $23.

title: Why the New Bill Is Not Protectionist
description: THE trade legislation before Congress is being assailed by its critics as protectionist. It has been compared with the Smoot-Hawley Tariff in the 1930's. A Presidential veto is being threatened when the bill gets out of Congress.

title: Gale M. Osborne Wed To Dr. K. J. Bergmann
description: At Temple Emanuel in Gastonia, N.C., Gale Marjorie Osborne, the daughter of Evelyn S. Osborne and Victor Osborne, both of Gastonia, was married last evening to Dr. Kenneth Joseph Bergmann, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Bergmann of Eastchester, N.Y. Rabbi Israel J. Gerber performed the ceremony.

title: A Dollar Should Be Bigger Than a Quarter; Save Susan B.
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Gets a Chance to Make a Difference
description: IT has been difficult all these many years for New Yorkers, who think of themselves as the center of the known world, to swallow the fact that in the process of selecting Presidential nominees their great state has been something of a backwater.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Sea Gate
description: ''WE'RE a summer community that refuses to go home,'' said Lucille Katz, who has lived in the Sea Gate section of Brooklyn for 23 years.

title: August Wedding For Lynne Cohen
description: Dr. and Mrs. Michael H. Cohen of Tarrytown, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lynne Beth Cohen to Michael William Wolitzer, a son of Faith Wolitzer of Woodmere, L.I., and the late D. Lawrence Wolitzer. An August wedding is planned.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Looking for Art
description: LEAD: Do you own a landscape by Owin Parsons? Or a Milne Ramsey still life? How about a small, decorative sculpture by Charles Lewis Hinton?

title: THRICE-TOLD TALES
description: Owen Edwards's ''Thrice-Told Tales'' certainly rings true. If this letter is published, I am sure that in five years I will tell friends I had a short piece published in The Times; in 10 years I will boast of a major article; and I will tell my grandchildren that I was interviewed and written about the week after Russell Baker left.

title: Corrections
description: A graphic last Sunday of the major stock indexes showed an incorrect closing figure for the Dow Jones industrial average of April 8. The Dow closed at 2,090.13.

title: TAKING STOCK: IS AMERICA IN DECLINE?
description: IT IS NOT MORNING IN AMERICA. IT IS LATE IN the afternoon - almost twilight - in New Haven, Conn., and the courtyard of Yale University's Davenport College is empty and cold. Paul Kennedy is late for our meeting. But, considering the past few weeks, it's understandable. Since January, when his Toynbeean best seller, ''The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers,'' was published, Kennedy has been a captive of the world outside the college walls. From Presidential candidates to chief executive officers to editors at major newspapers from Los Angeles to London, the powers that be are scrambling to get Kennedy to explain his book. A scrap of stationery taped to his office door reads:

title: Home Run By Carter Spurs Mets
description: It is much too early to draw conclusions. There are more than five months of a long arduous season ahead, and even in the best of times, Gary Carter has endured his share of foul tips, leaving welts on his body, and hitless nights. In the spring of his 14th season, however, Carter is rejuvenated, feeling like The Kid again, doing what he did again.

title: Review/Jazz; Horvitz's Varied Idioms
description: Wayne Horvitz, a keyboardist, is one of those downtown musicians who juggle a rock band, free-improvising outfits, collaborations with other composers and large-scale works of their own.

title: Scott Thompson Weds Miss Rueppel, a Banker
description: Denise Charlotte Rueppel and Scott Garrett Thompson were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. Thomas D. Bowers. Pamela Mars was the maid of honor and Alfred Maeda was the best man.

title: Former Foster Child Tells Panel of Five Lost Years
description: One ''mother'' struck him and threw him in hot water, the 12-year-old boy recalled. Another spoke only in a language he did not understand. And when it was time to say goodbye after a visit with his real mother, he felt ''like the world was leaving me.''

title: Investigation of Plane Crash Begins in Seattle
description: An eight-member team from the National Transporation Safety Board has been assigned to investigate the the crash landing of a commuter plane Friday at Seattle's airport in which 19 people were injured, officials said today.

title: >Dr. Stacey Rosen Weds
description: At Congregation Beth Shalom in Lawrence, L.I., Dr. Stacey Ellyn Rosen and Dr. Mark Kenneth Silverman, residents in internal medicine at the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, were married last evening by Rabbi Gilbert Klapperman. The bride, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Rosen of Bellmore, L.I., graduated from the Boston University School of Medicine. The bridegroom, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Silverman of Hewlett, L.I., is a graduate of the Tufts University Medical School.

title: Veteran TV Reporter Reflects
description: LEAD: AS I LEAVE CBS NEWS after almost 46 years before the microphones and cameras as a correspondent, broadcasting is at another turn in the road. Perhaps that's why I stayed in it all those years, because I liked the changes, the unexpectedness of each day. There was always some new twist and curve - and there always will be.

title: Rural Area In the Midst Of Paradox
description: Last month residents of northern Berkshire County celebrated after Gov. Micheal S. Dukakis signed a bill authorizing $35 million to convert an abandoned North Adams factory complex into a huge museum of contemporary art.

title: A Big Yawn For Salaries
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Product For Lyme Disease
description: Your article on Lyme disease in Connecticut (''New Offensive on Lyme Disease,'' March 20) was most informative about this growing problem both in Connecticut and, indeed, in some 16 states across the country.

title: A SECRET STASH OF GLASS GOES PUBLIC
description: THE RENAISSANCE AND Baroque glass vessels that Ernesto Wolf collected for more than 40 years are in the princely taste, splashed with myriad colors and frosty engravings. These Venetian, Bohemian, Dutch and German glass goblets, beakers, ewers and bowls were crafted to dazzle and delight European aristocrats - sometimes by their elegant simplicity, more often by their technical virtuosity.

title: Who Should Be Hockey's M.V.P.?
description: This season marked the end of the Gretzky era and the beginning of the Lemieux era. From the Canada Cup in September right through to the final game of the season when he scored his 70th goal, Lemieux has proven that he deserves to win the Hart Trophy. JAMES FITZ-GERALD Princeton Junction, N.J.

title: Searching Split For Its History
description: LEAD: A VISITOR to Split, the Dalmatian capital, will find that the city's museums, of which three are outstanding, offer a comprehensive commentary on the city's compelling historical vicissitudes.

title: Review/Music; Dutoit Conducts a French Program
description: Charles Dutoit's final subscription program of the current New York Philharmonic season at Avery Fisher Hall, heard Friday afternoon, plays to most of his considerable strengths as a conductor.

title: Hundreds in Panama Protest Noriega Regime
description: Hundreds of protesters smashed windows, blocked streets with flaming barricades and clashed with riot police today in a demonstration demanding the removal of the military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The police fired tear gas and birdshot as about 400 demonstrators, mostly members of a women's group, rallied on the north side of the capital. The women, joined later by local residents, set up blazing barricades of trash and tires across streets and hurled rocks at the police. Some windows were shattered by stones. There were no reports of injuries or arrests.

title: Parkways, Once Pretty, Now Pathetic
description: I DRIVE 400 miles a week on a minimum of five Long Island parkways. I've driven that much or a similar amount for almost seven years. What would Long Island say if she could speak?

title: HORNISTS EXPLORE MOZART CONCERTOS
description: IN HIS HORN CONCERTOS, AS in the horn parts of all his works, Mozart wrote, of course, for the only available instrument of his time, the valveless ''natural horn,'' which could produce only overtones of its fundamental note.

title: Naughty Deeds of The Stars
description: BASEBALL CONFIDENTIAL By Bruce Nash and Allan Zullo. 223 pp. New York: Pocket Books. Paper, $6.95.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; What Are The Jets' And Giants' Draft Needs?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: When Favorite Openings Are Undermined

description: Skimming over the landscape in an armed helicopter, United States drug agents and Bolivian police officers point to dozens of fields where coca plants have been left unharvested this spring, a sign of hard times here in the heart of Bolivia's cocaine country.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: THE Prudential Foundation, a nonprofit corporation financed by the Newark-based Prudential Insurance Company of America, has awarded grants totaling nearly $400,000 to New Jersey organizations.

title: The Pilots at Sandy Hook: 294 Years of Taking the Helm
description: WHEN a Navy armada, including the aircraft carrier America and the battleship Iowa, steams up the New Jersey coast this week to join the parade of ships for the Port of New York and New Jersey's first Fleet Week, each vessel will come to a dead halt six miles off this Monmouth County peninsula.

title: For Ballet Theater, The Frill Is Back
description: LEAD: ''DOING 'GAITE PARISIENNE' WITH TO-day's dancers is a little like staging 'West Side Story' in Russia.'' Mikhail Baryshnikov, the artistic director of American Ballet Theater, was commenting recently on some of the challenges involved in mounting anew Leonide Massine's 50-year-old ''Gaite Parisienne,'' a highlight of the company's spring season, which starts this week.

description: Mrs. John D. Penick of Upper Montclair, N.J., has made known the engagement of her daughter Joan Dabney Penick to Peter Somers Cooper, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter N. Cooper of Warwick, Bermuda.

description: WHEN must the archeologists stop excavating so the developer can start?

description: To the Editor:

title:
DANCE;
Ballroom Dancing As a Dazzling Art
description: LEAD: IN THE hands, or rather the feet, of the 10 dancers of the American Ballroom Theater, social dancing attains a dazzling theatricality.

title: WAITZ IS A WINNER AFTER 10 MONTHS OFF
description: Her last race had been 10 months before so naturally, Grete Waitz had questions about her return to competition yesterday, in the 10-mile Trevira Twosome in Central Park. Questions and bad dreams. ''They all had to do with complications around the start,'' she remembered. ''I had no number and no shoe laces. When I woke up, I was glad I still had another chance.''

title:
INVESTING;
Potential Above, Assets Below
description: LEAD: AS stockholders of Pennzoil and Texaco have discovered, an oil company's fortunes are sometimes determined more by what goes on above ground - in a courtroom - than below. That is why Francis X. Curzio likes Canada Southern Petroleum Ltd.

title: Speakes: Product Of the System
description: Everybody seems to be beating up on Larry Speakes for faking statements and attributing them to President Reagan, but Speakes is merely a symbol of a larger problem. In fact, the confession in his ghost-written book that he was putting words in the President's mouth may be the only useful thing he did in the White House.

title: STREETSCAPES: Flatbush Avenue Terminal; The Final Weeks for a Neo-Renaissance Grand Dame?
description: THE battle to save the Flatbush Avenue Terminal, the city's second most impressive rail station after Grand Central, was supposedly lost in 1980 when both the National Register of Historic Places and the Landmarks Preservation Commission declined to designate the 1906 structure.

title: DECENT FOLKS BEHIND BARS
description: CRIMES OF JUSTICE Improving the Police, the Courts, the Prisons. By David C. Anderson. 327 pp. New York: Times Books. $17.95.

title: Young Parents Learn Job Skills
description: EVERY morning at 7 o'clock, a minibus will pick up 19-year-old Vickie Cooper and her 2-year-old boy and take them to a Hempstead center, where he will be cared for while she and 24 other young mothers study.

title: Guterman's Troubles Jolt Client Co-ops
description: AT least 36 New York City co-ops were forced to find new managing agents and sue to recover records and bank balances after the management division of The Hanover Companies, a real estate development company headed by Gerald Guterman, the financially troubled real estate developer-converter, began falling apart along with a number of his other ventures.

title: Is Cable Cornering the Market?
description: EVERY Tuesday night, Sheldon Levin, the owner of a children's store in Birmingham, Ala., watches wrestling matches on ESPN. His wife, Tracy, likes movies on Home Box Office and their 5-year-old daughter is a devotee of Nickelodeon, the children's programming service. The Levin's monthly cable bill is $50. ''But if we go to the movies, it's at least $30,'' Mrs. Levin said.

title: In Separate Gestures, a Mosaic of Intentions
description: THE principal actors in the Palestinian-Israeli conflict often reveal their true feelings and intentions through spontaneous, even subconscious gestures. Sometimes they seem unaware of the implications of what they are doing, or that their acts may unintentionally subvert their goals. In the past two weeks three such gestures have spoken volumes about the real state of the conflict today.

title: Choirboys With Very Big Amps
description: UNFORGETTABLE FIRE Past, Present, and Future -The Definitive Biography of U2. By Eamon Dunphy. Illustrated. 320 pp. New York: Warner Books. $16.95.

title: Help Wanted: Supervisor
description: LEAD: DEVELOPERS are pressing two major lawsuits against town zoning policies; the Town Hall is structurally weak and potentially dangerous; and, on top of everything else, the Supervisor resigned two weeks ago, 90 turbulent days into his first term, blaming extreme divisiveness among the Town Board members.

title: Her Magic Violin
description: MAUD POWELL Pioneer American Violinist. By Karen A. Shaffer and Neva Garner Greenwood. Illustrated. 530 pp. Arlington, Va./Ames, Iowa: Maud Powell Foundation/ Iowa State University Press. $29.95.

title: A Child's View of the Olympics
description: NOW that the Winter Olympics are behind us, I have a chance to revise tactics before the Summer Games begin.

title: Until Music Stops Tomorrow, Candidates Dance to Range of Ethnic Tunes: Albert Gore Jr.; Seeking Ethnic Votes, The Senator Savors Flavors of New York
description: Mayor Koch led an out-of-towner from Tennessee on an ethnic tour of New York yesterday.

title: REAGAN WAS TOLD OF BOGUS QUOTES
description: Larry Speakes, the former White House spokesman, said tonight that he told President Reagan during the Geneva summit meeting in 1985 that he had fabricated a quotation and attributed it to Mr. Reagan.

title: From Walls and Halls, Art Heritage Emerges
description: No one is likely to flunk a course in art appreciation for failing to recognize names like Constantino Brumidi, Lucien Lebaudt, Edward Simmons and Henry Oliver Walker, and yet the legacy of these painters is being cleaned, touched up, chemically stabilized and protected with a loving care not always accorded the works of Leonardo and Michelangelo.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As a son of this land, I ask today that we remember this difficult commonwealth, and ask that everything that later poisoned it, and especially the painful excesses of anti-Semitism, be forgiven us.'' - Lech Walesa at commemoration of Warsaw ghetto uprising. [ A12:3. ]

title: 'Laundered Fish'
description: More than 78,000 pounds of well-traveled - and illegally imported -salmon are being distributed to the needy this week by food banks, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, part of the Commerce Department.

title: P.L.O. Chiefs Meet to Mourn A Comrade and Plot Strategy
description: Stunned Palestine Liberation Organization leaders gathered here today to mourn a comrade and to assess the damage caused by his assassination.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addenda
description: * House Beautiful is increasing its circulation rate to 850,000, from 800,000, as its rates go up the same 6.25 percent with its August issue.

title: Review/Cabaret; Nell Carter comes Back, 11-Piece Band in Tow
description: If the best pop-soul singing carries a steady current of emotional electricity, in the case of Nell Carter the voltage is always turned up to high. The Alabama-born singer whose earthy, wide-open delivery in ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' established her as one of the most explosive latter-day vaudevillians to hit the Broadway stage, left New York not long after her triumph and wound up spending six years playing a maid on a popular television sitcom, ''Gimme a Break.''

title: Sweet but Short Celebration for Capitals
description: Dale Hunter's goal 5 minutes 57 seconds into overtime Saturday night left the Capital Centre a blizzard of white. The crowd of 18,130, some in tank tops, others in tuxedos, but almost all in white per management's request, leaped out of their seats and began to fling an enormous supply of white promotional pom-poms.

title: Dukakis Is Winner of Arizona's Caucuses
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts has defeated Jesse Jackson by a 3-to-2 margin in the first round of Arizona's Democratic Presidential caucuses and has shut out Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee in the race for delegates.

title: Canada Inflation Higher
description: Canada's annual rate of inflation edged slightly higher in March as a decline in food prices helped to offset increases in other areas, the Government agency Statistics Canada reported Friday. The consumer price index, adjusted for seasonal variations, rose five-tenths of 1 percent in March to bring the annual rate to 4.1 percent, up from 4 percent in February.

title: Maryland Bill to Protect Video Viewers' Privacy
description: Privacy for video viewers, which became an issue last year when a Washington publication listed the video-cassette movies rented at a local store by Judge Robert H. Bork, the Supreme Court nominee, would be protected under a bill passed by Maryland's General Assembly.

title: No Edge on Home Ice
description: Although the Devils have won only once in their last 21 visits to the Capital Centre, they are disputing the argument that the home-ice advantage will be the most important factor in their Patrick Division final series with the Washington Capitals.

title: The Footloose Take Joy in a Bridge Too Far Gone
description: The ringing of a church bell in Brooklyn, the clanging of a tugboat on the East River, fragments of a passer-by's conversation: these were among the dominant sounds yesterday on the Williamsburg Bridge.

title: Review/Dance; Rituals From Brazil Reveal a Country's Past
description: Jelon Vieira's Dance Brazil presented a tour through Brazilian culture on Saturday night at the Triplex Theater at Manhattan Community College that was both enjoyable and oddly low keyed. Not everyone performs like Loremil Machado, the wild, firebrand dancer and musician seen here as guest artist. Nor would one want a company of that unvarying intensity. But there were moments when the drum beats were lulling and the smiling dancers almost too gracious.

title: German Publisher Is Up for Grabs
description: In West Germany, where corporate takeovers are few and invariably friendly, the largest publishing empire on the European continent has become the target of what is being viewed as the country's first hostile takeover attempt.

title: Protester Keeps Up Vigil at Carolina Bridge
description: A candidate for the State Senate has chained himself to the only bridge linking Hatteras Island to the mainland and maintained his vigil for a third day today in a call for action to save the structure.

title: Man Who Killed 2, Leading to New Law, Is Held in Prison Attack
description: Willie Bosket Jr., whose five-year prison sentence for the 1978 killings of two people when he was 15 years old led to tougher juvenile criminal laws in New York, attacked a prison guard with a homemade knife Saturday afternoon, a state prison spokesman said.

title: Algerians Say Talks On Hijacked Jetliner Appear Deadlocked
description: Negotiations for the release of the crew and passengers of the Kuwaiti Boeing 747 airliner hijacked 13 days ago seem to have reached an impasse, and Algerian officials expressed exasperation today at the deadlock.

title: Man Shot and 5 Hurt At a Discotheque
description: A 19-year-old man was shot and five other people suffered cuts and bruises early yesterday morning in a fight at a Manhattan discotheque, the police said.

title: A Kit to Turn Tennis Into Child's Play
description: Tennis is still a popular spectator sport, but there has been a noticeable slump during the 1980's in its appeal to recreational players. The United States Tennis Association, the sport's national authority, has taken action to reverse the trend. And so have sports equipment manufacturers.

title: Fishing Dispute Strains Paris-Ottawa Relations
description: France said today that it was recalling its Ambassador to Ottawa after four French politicians and 17 islanders were arrested for fishing illegally in Canadian waters.

title: Auto Racing; Rahal's Mission: To Win 3d Title in Row
description: The defending Indy-car champion, Bobby Rahal, faces a daunting task this year. He has won the PPG Indy Car World Series title the last two years, and the bespectacled 35-year-old driver, who finished second yesterday in the Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach, Calif., is trying for a third consecutive season championship.

title: Mail-Order Official Fined
description: The head of two mail-order companies has agreed to pay a $300,000 civil penalty to settle charges that he violated Federal rules, the Federal Trade Commission announced Friday.

title: Tender Starts For Webb Unit
description: Commonwealth Equity Trust, a real estate investment trust in Sacramento, Calif., has begun a tender offer for more than 50 percent of the outstanding shares of Del E. Webb Investment Properties Inc. of Phoneix.

title: East Timor Endures Harsh Occupation
description: To the Editor:

title: Bigger F.S.L.I.C. Loss Seen
description: An annual audit of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, due to be released soon, will probably show that the losses at the Government fund that insures deposits in the nation's savings institutions almost doubled in 1987 over the year-earlier period, Federal regulators said today.

title: Make Room for Cans
description: We Can is a program that uses New York's container deposit and return law to help homeless people help themselves. Timely assistance from Mayor Koch now guarantees that the program itself won't be homeless.

title: Louise Nevelson, Artist Renowned For Wall Sculptures, Is Dead at 88
description: Louise Nevelson, a pioneer creator of environmental sculpture who became one of the world's best-known women artists, died yesterday evening at her home on Spring Street in Manhattan. She was 88 years old, and had been in poor health for several months.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Charles W. McConnell has joined Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, as a senior vice president, account director, on Dean Witter, Contel and the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Ex-Trooper in Sex Charges
description: A recently retired Michigan state trooper who used to give speeches about child abuse has been charged with sexually assaulting two girls while on the force, the authorities said. Robert L. Beadle, 52 years old, of Traverse City has been charged with criminal sexual conduct, kidnapping and felony use of a firearm. He is accused of abducting and raping at gunpoint two Lapeer girls, an 11-year-old in 1986 and a 13-year-old in 1987.

title: Hospitals Found to Overbill Medicare by $2 Billion a Year
description: Federal investigators have concluded that the nation's hospitals are overcharging the Medicare program about $2 billion a year by admitting patients who do not need hospitalization.

title: With Two Key Losses, Jersey Faces an Ebbing of Its Influence in the House
description: The New Jersey Congressional delegation, long among the most powerful in the House of Representatives, is facing a period of sharply diminished strength because of the imminent retirement of its dean and the death of its second most senior member.

title: Inquiry Faults Office to Help Needy Adults
description: The office of a New York City agency that provides help for indigent adults in Manhattan who cannot care for themselves is in a state of disarray, with widespread mismanagement and caseworkers who are often poorly trained and inexperienced, according to city investigators.

title: CUBAN DISSIDENTS EXPECTED IN MIAMI
description: A group of former political prisoners and their relatives are expected to arrive here from Cuba this week, United States and Roman Catholic Church officials said today, in what the officials hope is the resumption of a long-suspended immigration agreement between the United States and Cuba.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Union County (N.J.) Economic Development Corp. to Vanet Cos.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Like Stickball Players Chasing After a Spaldeen
description: In this city of sharp elbows the final weekend of the New York Presidential primary brought on more jostling than a closing door on the IRT.

title: Meeting von Stade
description: The mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade will be the guest at Lincoln Center Off-Stage, a meet-the-artist program, Thursday evening in the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, at 65th Street. The program is to begin with a wine-and-cheese reception at 5:30 P.M. An open discussion with Miss von Stade will follow, from 6 to 7 P.M. Tickets, at $12, are available through Center Charge, (212) 874-6770.

title: Arming Afghan Guerrillas: A Huge Effort Led by U.S.
description: With help from China and many Moslem nations, the United States led a huge international operation over the last eight years to arm the Afghan guerrillas with the weapons they needed to drive the Soviet Army from their country.

title: World Cup: U.S. Gains
description: A technical inspection group from soccer's world governing body was left with a ''very positive experience'' after its weeklong tour of United States stadiums and related facilities for the 1994 World Cup, a member of the delegation said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Ad World; Account That Could Launch 1,000 Yachts
description: THE General Motors Corporation's all-American response to the Japanese automobile invasion - the Saturn - is not due until the summer of 1990. Its look, price and fuel-efficiency ratings are still, officially, unknown. Yet the car is roiling the agency business from coast to coast.

title: Results Plus
description: Auto Racing Al Unser Jr. Wins in California: Al Unser Jr. ended the Andretti family's hold on the Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach, running away with yesterday's Indy-car race on the seaside road circuit in California. Unser, who will turn 26 tomorrow, picked up his fifth Indy-car victory and his first since the 1986 season finale at Miami. Bobby Rahal, the two-time defending CART-PPG champion, finished second, one lap and 33.482 seconds behind the winner's Chevrolet-powered March. Unser, who came back this year to the team owned by Rick Galles after a three-year stint with Doug Shierson, gave Galles only his second Indy-car victory and his first since Unser won at Portland, Ore., in June 1984. The winner averaged 83.655 miles an hour in the 95-lap, 158.65-mile race. Unser won $91,160. Raul Boesel of Brazil, who replaced Unser on the Shierson team, finished fourth and now leads the season standing after two races, with 22 points. Going into the next event, the Indianapolis 500 on May 29, Unser is tied for second with Mario Andretti, who had won three of the first four Indy-car races in Long Beach, including last year's. (AP) Labonte Prevails: Terry Labonte took advantage of Dale Earnhardt's misfortune yesterday to win the $351,845 First Union 400 Nascar Winston Cup race in North Wilkesboro, N.C. Earnhardt was leading comfortably on the fifth-eighths-mile oval until a right-rear tire went flat with less than 20 laps remaining. Labonte, in a Chevrolet, had been trailing Earnhardt throughout much of the race, but passed the two-time defending Winston Cup points champion and went on to win by 1.49 seconds over Ricky Rudd, who was in a Buick. Earnhardt, also in a Chevrolet, had to settle for third place after leading 265 of the 400 laps. Despite his third-place finish, Earnhardt increased his lead in the season standing, with 1,059 points.(AP) School Basketball Mourning Helps East Win: Alonzo Mourning's 16 points and Billy Owens's 14 rebounds led the East to a 105-99 victory over the West in the McDonald's All-American game yesterday in Albuquerque, N.M. The 11th edition of the game featured some of the nation's best high school players, most headed for major-college powers in the fall. Mourning, the 6-foot-10-inch, 230-pound center from Chesapeake, Va., who will attend Georgetown, hit a pair of late second-half dunks as the East held off a West rally. Owens, a 6-8 forward from Carlisle, Pa., who has signed with Syracuse, added 10 points and shared the game's most valuable player award with Mourning. The West was led by Kentucky-bound Shawn Kemp with 18 points and 9 rebounds. Malik Sealy of Tolentine in the Bronx scored 12 points. Robert Werdann, who played for Archbishop Malloy in Queens, added 11. Sealy and Werdann will attend St. John's next fall. (AP) Soccer Victory for Trinidad and Tobago: Dexter Skeene, who played for Columbia University, scored a second-half goal yesterday as Trinidad and Tobago beat Guyana, 4-0, at Georgetown, Guyana, in the first match of qualifying for soccer's 1990 World Cup. Skeene, an all-American in 1985 during his senior year at Columbia, scored 10 minutes into the second half to make it 3-0. The two teams will meet again May 8 in Port-of-Spain, Trinidad. The team that wins the series by total goals will advance to the second round against Honduras. (AP) Race Walking Null Wins 5-Kilometer Race: Gary Null of the Natural Living racing team won the New York Walkers Club 5-kilometer championship at Central Park yesterday in 24 minutes 25 seconds. Franco Pantoni of the Converse-East Side team was runner-up in 26:01. Susan Travellin of Natural Living took the women's title with a time of 26:01. (AP)

title: INSIDE
description: Iran Reports U.S. Shelling United States warships attacked two Iranian oil platforms in the Persian Gulf, the Iranian news agency reported. Page A9. Hijack Talks at Impasse Algerian mediators say they see no sign of flexibility by the Kuwaiti Government or the hijackers of a Kuwait Airlines jet. Page A9. Agency Cited for Disarray A New York City that helps needy adults is faulted for mismanagement and altering records. Page B1. Striking the Set The seven-week-old writers' strike has left some of television's most popular shows in a lurch, without scripts. Page C22.

title: Israel at 40: Dreams Awash in Realities
description: Forty years after the perilous founding of Israel, the state's pioneer generation finds itself less nostalgic than consumed in dispute about the hazards of wielding power in a watchful, critical world.

title: Sheila Murphy Weds Architect
description: Sheila Murphy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Murphy of Oldwick, N.J., and Michael Maurice Azarian, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Azarian of Andover, Mass., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Brigid in Far Hills, N.J. The Rev. Michael Alliegro performed the ceremony.

title: Treasury Sales Limited to Bills This Week
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills.

title: U.S.-Europe Farm Issue
description: The United States Trade Representa tive, Claytontive, Clayton K. Yeutter, said today that after two days of negotiations, wide gaps remained between the positions of the United States and the European Community on ending farm subsidies.

title: Political Playing Fields
description: Now the turf wars that are endemic in the bureaucracies of the capital have spread to some real turf: the grassy fields around the Washington Monument. Local softball enthusiasts cried foul when the National Park Service released its latest reservation list for playing fields on the monument grounds. They contend that the list favored Congressional and executive branch teams.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 The program to arm Afghans was one of the largest ever mounted by the C.I.A., officials say. It cost more than $2 billion over eight years as Congress pressed for more U.S. support to the guerrillas. Page A1

title: Abrupt End for TV Dramas' Seasons
description: ''L.A. Law,'' ''Thirtysomething,'' ''Moonlighting'' and ''Cheers'' have been caught with their scripts down. Because of a strike by 9,000 Hollywood writers, each of the shows has been forced to interrupt its season abruptly, one or two episodes short.

title: Review/Television; Israel at 40: Violence and a Dream
description: Arguments flare about television coverage of Israel. Violence takes over the evening news: Palestinians throw rocks; soldiers fire weapons; young men are beaten and old women grieve. ''Israel '88: The Dream at 40'' widens the perspective. The one-hour documentary, on Channel 9 at 9 o'clock tonight, is sympathetic to Israel without ever being a tract.

title: Fox Finds Success Is Still Elusive
description: The Fox Broadcasting Company's fledgling fourth network has had a rocky first year.

title: Junk Bond Conferees Put Accent on Quality
description: The junk bond market is surging again as a result of the wave of takeover activity this year, but buyers of the high-yield debt seem to be concentrating on the highest-quality issues.

title: Resort Towns Get Ready for the Summer
description: Along the Jersey Shore, surfers and beachgoers gaze out at the ocean and hope it doesn't bring the hypodermic needles and other refuse that washed up last summer.

title: Bridge
description: Players from Chicago dominated play at the Spring Nationals of the American Bridge Association, which ended in Columbus, Ohio, eight days ago, and one of them was a double winner.

title: Senator Byrd Moves On
description: The smallest of electorates chooses the Senate majority leader, but the colleague they elevate acquires extraordinary national standing. Consider, for example, the careers of Lyndon Johnson, Mike Mansfield and Robert Dole. Consider also the incumbent, Robert Byrd, who has announced that he'll retire as leader at the close of this session.

title: National League; Braves Terminate Nightmare Streak
description: Zane Smith pitched a four-hitter and Damaso Garcia hit his first National League home run as Atlanta ended a record 10-game losing streak with a 3-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers today.

title: Horse Racing; Alysheba Edges Ferdinand by Nose
description: Alysheba edged Ferdinand by a nose in the $530,000 San Bernardino Handicap at Santa Anita today in the third meeting of the two Kentucky Derby champions.

title: Top Americans Skipping Boston
description: ''In some ways, I wish I was younger,'' Bill Rodgers said the other day, marvelling at so many elite runners planning to start the Boston Marathon today. ''In other ways, I'm glad I'm not.''

title: U.S. NAVAL ATTACK REPORTED BY IRAN
description: Iran said United States forces attacked two Iranian oil platforms in the Persian Gulf on Monday.

title: Many Black New Yorkers Believe Campaign Is Tinged With Racism
description: To the distress of many black New Yorkers, the 1988 Presidential primary here has become a painful study in black and white. They see it as a campaign tinged with racism, one in which the Rev. Jesse Jackson is neither forgiven any of his trespasses nor taken with the same seriousness accorded his white foes.

title: Business In a Nation In Turmoil
description: With its sectarian strife, guerrilla insurgency and high unemployment, Northern Ireland scarcely seems a land of economic opportunity. And the grisly murders at two funeral processions that were led by the outlawed Irish Republican Army underscored the province's reputation as a place to avoid.

title: Missile Pact Bars Exotic Arms, Soviet Agrees
description: The Soviet Union has told the United States it agrees that the treaty on medium- and shorter-range missiles bans futuristic weapons, Administration officials said today.

title: Martin Heats Up As Yanks Cool Off
description: The afternoon had come and gone, but Billy Martin was still angered by the events that transpired under overcast skies today at County Stadium. It was as if they gnawed at him.

title: Marathon; 2:06:49 Clocking is World Best
description: Belaney Densimo of Ethiopia ran a world best in the marathon today, covering the 26 miles 385 yards in 2 hours 6 minutes 49 seconds.

title: Aeromexico Files for Bankruptcy
description: Mexico's state airline, Aeromexico, has filed for bankruptcy, after a four-day strike by ground staff that cost the company an estimated $7 million, the Transport and Communications Ministry said today.

title: Bullets Top Celtics
description: Darrell Walker's steal and layup with 1 minutes 23 seconds left in the game sparked the Washington Bullets to a 98-92 victory over the Boston Celtics today.

title: A 21-Year-Old Man Is Slain In a Restaurant in Brooklyn
description: A 21-year-old Brooklyn man was shot to death gangland style in a Chinese takeout restaurant in the Flatlands section last night, the police said.

title: 211 Illegal Aliens Arrested
description: Agents of the Immigration and Naturalization Service have arrested 211 people suspected of being illegal aliens in eight cities in northern and central California. All those apprehended Saturday were men from Mexico, and all but 15 returned voluntarily within hours, an official said.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * China's trade with the six members of the Association of South-East Asian Nations rose to $1.13 billion in the first quarter of this year, from $750 million in the 1987 period, the official New China News Agency said. It said China's exports to Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines and Brunei rose nearly 34 percent, to $566 million, during the first quarter while imports were up nearly 68 percent, to $564 million. The agency said Singapore was China's main regional trade partner with total trade of $468 million.

title: Laura Lee Simons Married To Scott Goldstein on L.I.
description: The marriage of Laura Lee Simons, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay R. Simons of Bellmore, L.I., to Scott Zachary Goldstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Goldstein of Southport, Conn., took place yesterday in Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Myron Fenster performed the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center.

title: Review/Dance; Peggy Spina Company: Determined Tap Dancers
description: In some ways the Peggy Spina Tap Company was just fine Saturday night. Yet in other ways it was all wrong.

title: Polish March Lauds Heroes Of '43 Ghetto
description: Thousands of Poles defied a Government ban today and marched amid opposition banners through the wartime Warsaw ghetto area to commemorate the 1943 uprising there.

title: Horse Racing; Derby Picture is Murkier Than Ever
description: ''Lord only knows,'' Pat Day said after losing the Lexington Stakes at Keeneland Saturday aboard Forty Niner, ''what's going to happen on the first Saturday in May.''

title: Olympic Notebook; Proposal Due on Training Site
description: While George Steinbrenner and the other members of his committee are investigating past problems within the United States Olympic Committee and formulating strategies for the future, another committee is forging ahead with its own plans.

title: Elster's Heroics Win for Mets
description: When he arrived at Shea Stadium yesterday, Kevin Elster figured that redemption probably would have to wait at least another 24 hours. After turning on the lights in the clubhouse, Elster glanced at the early lineup card and saw that Dave Johnson had decided that he should watch the game from a good seat in the the dugout. The manager thought that a little rest and relaxation was what his rookie shortstop needed most.

title: Joseph J. Schwab, Science Professor, 79
description: Joseph J. Schwab, a science professor at the University of Chicago for nearly 40 years, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday at his home in Lancaster, Pa. He was 79 years old.

title: International Air Safety
description: In something of an aerial first, Velichko Velichkov of Bulgaria, Ference Bardosi of Hungary, Stanislaw Koziel of Poland and Stefan Voian of Rumania - all aviation safety experts in their countries - are gathering here today with American and West European counterparts to discuss flight security and new safety technology.

title: Golf; Norman Captures An Inspired Victory
description: Greg Norman, accompanied by a gravely ill teen-ager whose wish was to watch the Australian play, came from four shots back today for his first victory in the United States in two years, a one-shot triumph in the Heritage Classic.

title: New Yrokers & Co.; The Helmsley Palace's Embattled Queen
description: When she knew the cameras were rolling last week, Leona M. Helmsley snapped on her familiar, forced grin and beamed up at her husband, Harry. But as she sat in state court in Manhattan listening to the charges against her, the tears welled up in her eyes.

title: Jackson Is a Friend of Life's Victims
description: In the spring of 1977 when Ed Koch was beginning his first successful campaign for Mayor, I gave him a small fund-raising party. Ed always took nice cognizance of that. He showed up at my wedding; he invited my wife and me to dinner a couple of times at Gracie Mansion, and he was helpful to PEN when we had the 48th International PEN Congress in New York. Koch and I were never that close politically, but I liked him. I still do. It is just that now I cannot forgive him.

title: Nina Nirenberg, Reporter, Marries S. H. Youngstrom
description: Nina Nirenberg, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jesse S. Nirenberg of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stephen H. Youngstrom, a son of Barbara Youngstrom of Corning, N.Y., and the late Harold Youngstrom. Rabbi Emily Korzenik officiated at the Women's Club in White Plains.

title: Taiwan Gold Reserves Up
description: Taiwan's gold reserves hit a record high of nearly 10 million troy ounces in February and there are signs they will continue to rise in the next few months, bankers and economists said.

title: Labor-Jackson Connection In the City Strengthens Both
description: Wherever the Rev. Jesse Jackson campaigns in New York City, he hails the union members in his audience, recognizing the help labor is giving him as it strives to demonstrate its power in city politics - for him in 1988 and for itself in 1989 when the mayoralty and many other offices will be on the ballot.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Chiat/Day Is the Choice f Sutter Home Winery
description: Chiat/Day in San Francisco has become the ad agency for the Sutter Home Winery of St. Helena, Calif.

title: Wide Effect Seen in U.S. Trade Fight
description: A clash between the White House and Congress that could spike 1988 trade legislation endangers major international economic intitiatives of the United States, including a free trade pact with Canada, and could weaken the nation's global posture, analysts warn.

title: Higher-Level Training: Build Up to It Slowly
description: STEVEN SHAPIRO, a Staten Island pediatrician, was running 40 miles a week and feeling a bit bored when a doctor friend called last year and asked if he would be interested in running up the Himalayas in Tibet.

title: Critic's Notebook; Musicians' Quandary: Opera vs. Opportunities
description: ''Talent and artistic imagination are merely preconditions of creativity,'' writes Georgi Dmitriov, a Soviet composer, at the Making Music Together festival in Boston, ''the most important thing being the artist's ethical and moral position.''

title: Whither the 2 Mao Statues?
description: Two giant statues of Mao Zedong have disappeared from Beijing University and students believe they were loaded onto trucks by crane and driven away early today. Vestiges of Mao, who died in 1976 after ruling China since the 1949 revolution, have slowly disappeared from the capital.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., a biotechnology and chemical company, appointed Dallas W. Anderson president of its Davis & Geck unit, a maker of surgical sutures and related products.

title: 42d Street Movie Houses Are Part of a Symbol of Urban Decay
description: To the Editor:

title: Jays Moving Bell
description: Jimy Williams, the Toronto Blue Jays' manager, said today that George Bell would be going back to left field on an everyday basis. Rick Leach and Juan Beniquez will platoon at the designated hitter spot.

title: Quagmires, Revisited
description: Whoever wins in Afghanistan after 115,000 Soviet troops depart, it won't be the experts. It's worth recalling the mood and the predictions when the Russians invaded in 1979 to prevent the toppling of a weak leftist regime in Kabul.

title: Hit-and-Run Driver Kills a Pedestrian
description: A man was killed early yesterday morning by a car that struck him and then sped off, the police said.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Champion on Ice

title: Focusing on Job Security, U.A.W. Opens Talks With Chrysler Today
description: The Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union are to begin bargaining Monday on a new labor contract that could erase the last vestiges of the concessions made by workers almost a decade ago in the company's brush with bankruptcy.

title: Steel Pension Claim Settled
description: The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, the Federal agency that insures pension plans, said Thursday that the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation had agreed to pay $85 million to the agency as a settlement in a pension insurance claim against the bankrupt steelmaker.

title: Metro Matters; New Pit Stops In the Hot Race For President
description: Charlotte Street in the South Bronx is out. Meade Esposito is, too. Borough Park in Brooklyn is in. So are Governors (of New York and Puerto Rico), the Mayor and the Cardinal. The Williamsburg Bridge joined this year's list of campaign hot spots in New York just yesterday.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: With the National Basketball Association regular season winding down, the Phoenix Suns already have lost more than 50 games and the San Antonio Spurs are closing in on that many. Yet one of those teams will earn the eighth and last playoff spot in the Western Conference. Has a 50-game loser ever made the playoffs in the N.B.A.?

title: Jackson: Strong Comparisons
description: No National Basketball Association rookie had ever averaged 10 assists a game. Mark Jackson is averaging 10.6.

title: Health Worker Shortage Is Worsening
description: Hospitals and other medical institutions, which have been struggling with a shortage of nurses for several years, now face a worsening shortage of other health-care professionals, ranging from laboratory technicians to therapists.

title: Alex Kelso Reddin, Consultant, 72
description: Alex Kelso Reddin, a business executive and consultant, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Norwalk, Conn. He was 72 years old.

title: East Timor Endures Harsh Occupation; Reports of Torture
description: To the Editor:

title: Essex Looks to an Outsider To Help Get Itself 'Fired Up'
description: Harry Letaw Jr. is about to do what he likes best - join a small company and try to pep it up.

title: Classic French Novel Is 'Americanized'
description: For four decades, millions of readers have opened the English translation of Albert Camus's classic French novel ''The Stranger,'' and encountered those famous three words:

title: Canadian Leftists Drop Plans to Quit NATO
description: Canada's New Democratic Party, the leftist group that has posed a strong challenge to the centrist Conservative and Liberal parties in public opinion polls during the past year, has indefinitely shelved its plan to pull Canada out of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization if it should win power.

title: Business and the Law; Lawyers Debate Temporary Work
description: A PROMINENT legal ethics panel has expressed reservations about a new trend in the profession that gives small firms more chances to take on big cases: the practice of hiring lawyers for temporary assignments through specialized employment agencies.

title: CONTINENTAL LINE WILL BE INSPECTED FOR PLANE SAFETY
description: The Federal Aviation Administration, which has begun an intensive safety inspection of all aircraft operated by Eastern Airlines, will extend its scrutiny to the fleet of Eastern's sister company, Continental Airlines, the Secretary of Transportation, James Burnley, said yesterday.

title: Hanson Trust Names A New Vice Chairman
description: Hanson Trust P.L.C., the British industrial giant, has named Martin G. Taylor, a longtime Hanson executive, as a vice chairman.

title: Fisk U., Its Money Crisis Resolved, Is Embroiled in Dispute Over Leader
description: Fisk University, the 122-year-old, historically black school rescued from the brink of financial disaster four years ago, is now entangled in a dispute that questions recent activities of some of those credited with saving the university.

title: Workers Cheer Cain's Sale, And the $100,000 Windfalls
description: When she first heard that her employer, the Houston-based Cain Chemical Company, was about to be sold, Barbara Ann Newton feared for her job.

title: Israel's Silence Reinforces Belief Its Commandos Killed P.L.O. Aide
description: The Government said little today to dispel the virtually universal belief, voiced not only by Palestinians but also by the Israeli press and Israelis across the political spectrum, that Israel's secret services carried out the nighttime assassination of the Palestine Liberation Organization's military chief in Tunisia on Saturday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Container Shipper Picks Ogilvy & Mather Direct
description: Ogilvy & Mather Direct, which claims to be the No. 1 direct response agency, has been tapped by Sea-Land Services of Menlo Park, N.J., to promote its container shipping operation. The ad budget is $3.5 million, and the assignment is worldwide.

title: Profitable Renaissance For Children's Books
description: For many years children's book publishing was treated as an industry afterthought, capable of producing some interesting and pleasurable works yet not considered a serious member of the fraternity. But as publishers scramble to develop new markets that will increase profit margins, children's publishing has suddenly acquired a lot more respect.

title: Jennifer B. Kurtz, A Lawyer, Is Wed
description: At the Park East Synagogue in New York, Jennifer Barton Kurtz, the daughter of Margery G. Kurtz of New York and Dr. Anthony D. Kurtz of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday to Aharon Unger, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Robert Unger of Spartanburg, S.C. The bridegroom's father, the leader of Congregation B'nai Israel in Spartanburg, performed the ceremony.

title: 17 Key Bridges With Structural Problems
description: These are the 17 major bridges listed by the New York City Transportation Department as suffering from major structural problems, and the estimated repair costs:

title: Until Music Stops Tomorrow, Candidates Dance to Range of Ethnic Tunes: Michael S. Dukakis; Irish Football, Jewish Parade, Comforting Headline
description: Michael S. Dukakis glided through a series of ethnically and demographically balanced photo opportunities yesterday, two days before a primary that will either confirm his front-runner's status or shatter it.

title: In New York, Ballot Is an Unreliable Score Card
description: In many Congressional districts the ballot in tomorrow's Democratic and Republican Presidential primaries will reflect what might have been, not what is.

title: Dance Theater Scrambles to Finance Soviet Tour
description: Four major Soviet dance troupes have performed in the United States since the joint United States-Soviet cultural exchange program was renewed in 1985. Dance Theater of Harlem, the first American company scheduled to visit the Soviet Union under that program, is to open a four-week tour on May 13 in Moscow.

title: New York City Needs to Find Funds to Repair 600 Bridges
description: More than 600 bridges in New York City face major reconstruction or complete replacement by the end of the century and no one has any real notion where the city will find the billions of dollars needed to correct all that deterioration.

title: Cuomo Says He Will Try to Resolve Dispute in Stalled Budget Talks
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that he would become personally involved in budget negotiations in an attempt to resolve a dispute that has delayed adoption of a new budget for New York State.

title: Pro Football; Jets Are Desperate For a Strong Draft
description: The suddenly old, tired and ineffective Jets will face this Sunday what no National Football League team wants to confront: a critical draft.

title: Pact Could Aid Canada Energy Sales
description: The proposed free trade agreement with Canada could provide an immediate spurt to natural gas sales in this country, by convincing potential gas users that larger reserves are available because neither country could reimpose restrictions, according to spokesmen for American gas producers and pipeline companies.

title: BREACH REPORTED IN U.S. COMPUTERS
description: For almost two years, a West German citizen was able to secretly gain access to more than 30 computers belonging to the United States military and military contractors, according to computer security experts.

title: Republican Wins Race For House in Louisiana
description: A convert from the Democratic Party will apparently become the first Republican Congressman from the Fourth District in 114 years after narrowly winning a special election.

title: Contest Is Tight for New York's Hispanic Vote
description: Despite the unanimous endorsement of the Rev. Jesse Jackson by New York City's elected Hispanic officials, he is struggling with Michael S. Dukakis for the state's Hispanic vote in Tuesday's primary.

title: Mary A. Gruen Is Wed To Robert C. Graubard
description: Mary Abbott Gruen, the daughter of Gerry Schremp of Guttenberg, N.J., and Albert Gruen of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Charles Graubard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Graubard of New York and Greenwich, Conn. Cantor Bernard Dienstag performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: Tennis; McEnroe's Drought Comes to an End
description: John McEnroe, serving strongly and volleying well, trounced favored Stefan Edberg of Sweden, 6-2, 6-2, today in the men's singles final of the Japan Open for his first tournament victory in more than 18 months.

title: Review/Theater; 'Much Ado' at the Equity
description: Without Beatrice and Benedick, ''Much Ado About Nothing,'' would be about nothing much. It has but passing poetry and a barely passable plot. What it does have, surpassingly, is wit, in the form of and at the expense of this talkative couple whose show of mutual distaste is camouflage for ''a mountain of affection.'' When Beatrice and Benedick strike sparks, the play glitters; otherwise, as evidenced at the Equity Library Theater, it is just fitfully entertaining.

title: Gore Can Handle Gorbachev
description: LEAD: The attentions of the next President will perforce be focused on foreign policy: the unstable situation in Central America, the impasse in the Middle East, the tensions with our allies and, perhaps most important, the challenges - which is to say the opportunities and dangers -posed by the ascendancy of Mikhail S.

title: Review/Concert; Messiaen Music Heralds a New Midtown Space
description: The first major musical event at the new Florence Gould Hall on Saturday night tied a variety of aspirations into one neat bundle. The 400-seat space, at 55 East 59th Street, is first of all an advertisement for French culture, hence the presence of Olivier Messiaen in anticipation of his 80th birthday. It is also a venture of the French Institute/Alliance Francaise, an organization sustained by francophilic Americans for over 75 years. Saturday's music was, appropriately, ''Des Canyons aux Etoiles'' a Frenchman's elaborate orchestral hymn to the geological wonder of the American West. It was commissioned by Alice Tully in the early 1970's, played on Saturday by New York musicians (the Orchestra of St. Luke's) and conducted by a young American, Kent Nagano. The piano soloist was Yvonne Loriod, Mr. Messiaen's wife.

title: Kathryn Branson Marries
description: The marriage of Kathryn Elizabeth Ann Branson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Branson of Moorestown, N.J., to Dr. Mark Philip Schwartz, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert A. Schwartz of Edison, N.J., took place yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in Edison. Rabbi Alfred B. Landsberg officiated. The bride is a member of the cardiac rehabilitation staff at the Robert Wood Johnson Lifestyle Institute in Edison. The bridegroom is a member of the emergency medical staff at the Raritan Bay Medical Center in Perth Amboy, N.J.

title: Boxing; Breland Gets Draw But Loses Stature
description: There were no victory parties after the World Boxing Association welterweight title fight Saturday night. Neither the champion, Marlon Starling, nor the challenger, Mark Breland, was in a festive mood after their rematch here ended in a disputed draw.

title: On Your Own: Boating; A Six-Week Plan to Get Your Boat Ready for the Water
description: THE time is right to start preparing your boat for summer. If you begin now and work each weekend, you can be ready to cast off by Memorial Day. With careful planning, you should be able to do most of the job yourself.

title: Michael Jakcson Writes His Story
description: Michael Jackson's first book, ''Moonwalk'' - four years in the making - will go on sale across the United States this week. In it, the 29-year-old entertainer talks about his show business friends, his plastic surgery, his girlfriends and his rise to musical superstardom.

title: Devils Reflect a Coach's Image
description: When Lou Lamoriello started to believe his Devils were on their way to another springtime demise during a January slump, he scoured the hockey horizon for someone who wasn't a defeatist.

title: 2 Texas Banks Report Losses
description: Two major banking companies in Texas that last week disclosed they were considering a merger reported modest losses Friday for the first quarter. Texas American Bancshares

description: At Our Lady, Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church in Marblehead, Mass., Sheila Marie Buckley, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick O. Buckley of Marblehead Neck, Mass., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married yesterday to Daniel Brendon Goggin Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Goggin of Chelmsford and New Seabury, Mass. The Rev. Tomas G. Murphy, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Bioexcell Institute Hires Romann & Tannenholz
description: LEAD: The Bioexcell Institute of New York hopes to become a national franchise chain of hair parlors - not cutters but growers and replacers. To help reach this lofty goal, it has retained the services of Romann & Tannenholz, whose other clients are largely in the food business.

description: For a while there it looked as if Kirschenbaum & Bond had taken on both the Travel Fox and Jump brands of athletic shoes by Hongson. The brands had been handled by Hall & Cederquist.

description: Benjamin W. Krieger has been named chief executive of the Ris Paper Company, succeeding the company's founder. Ris is a privately owned operation in Garden City, L.I., that has quietly grown into a major paper distributor.

That's how the State of Maine sees it - and why the story of Shirley and Bob should warm the heart of even those who salivate over hot, boiled lobster with a little drawn butter on the side, please.

Metaphor, based in Mountain

This summer, Mr. Watkins will attend the Democratic convention in Atlanta as a delegate from Mississippi for the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

Mr. Bricklin, whose 1970's sports-car venture ended in failure, met with only limited success when he introduced the budget-priced Yugoslavian car to the United States.

Market Place;
Slide Tied to Lack Of Real Investors
description: LEAD: THE dust had barely settled after last Thursday's sudden collapse of stock prices when investors and analysts alike began asking, ''What happened?''

description: Ten homes in Belle Harbor, Queens were evacuated for several hours last night after a woman discovered four sticks of dynamite in her garage, the police said.

description: The Little Red Lighthouse under the Great Gray Bridge will be considered tomorrow for official landmark status, as will the giant red signboard over the Pepsi-Cola bottling plant in Queens.

description: The last time the two major political parties in Jamaica confronted each other in a natonal election, something approaching civil war broke out.

title: Review/Theater; In 'The Birthday Party,' Pinter's Daily Terrors
description: ''The Birthday Party,'' revived by the CSC Repertory Theater in a 30th anniversary production, offers testimony both to Harold Pinter's tantalizing theatricality and to the inability of many English critics to apprehend innovation in its time. Kenneth Tynan, for one, dismissed the play as ''a clever fragment grown dropsical with symbolic content.'' After the disastrous opening night reception, it was Harold Hobson who in his review single-handedly rescued the play from oblivion by confronting it on its own mysterious terms as a tale of terror in everyday life.

title: Until Music Stops Tomorrow, Candidates Dance to Range of Ethnic Tunes: Jesse Jackson; A Jewish Leader Provides a Forum For the Candidate
description: ''I'm Jewish, I'm for Israel, I'm for Jesse and I'm not crazy,'' said Martin Markowitz, a State Senator from Brooklyn, as he joined the small coterie of Jewish leaders in New York who support the Rev. Jesse Jackson for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

description: After six years of the foreign debt crisis and four years of democratic government, the Argentine economy today is widely viewed as exhausted, chaotic and out of control.

title: Autolatina Loss in Brazil
description: Autolatina, the largest auto manufac-turer in South America, announced a $223 million loss for its Brazilian operations in 1987. This compares with losses of $78 million in 1986. Autolatina is the holding company for Volkswagen and Ford in Brazil and Argentina. Wolfgang Sauer, the company's president, said that the company's intention was to break even this year. Autolatina employs 54,000 workers in Brazil and has 15 plants in Brazil and Argentina.

title: Sports of The Times; Zola Budd and the Temple
description: ABOUT 10 years ago, a cabinet minister in South Africa said, ''If we go, we will pull the temple down.''

title: Plant-Closing Issue Pressed
description: The Democratic leadership in Congress stepped up its pressure today in the argument with the White House over whether to include in the trade bill a requirement that companies give 60 days' notice when they close plants.

title: Reactions on Budd
description: Zola Budd must wait until Sunday to learn if she will be suspended from international running for at least one year because of contacts with South African sports. And other track and field candidates for the British Olympic team will also be anxious to hear the British Amateur Athletic Board's decision on the Budd case. On Saturday, the board was told by the International Amateur Athletic Federation, the sport's governing body, to bar Budd for at least 12 months or face banishment of British track and field athletes from all international events, including the Olympic Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea. The federation was reacting to warnings that other African nations, in opposition to apartheid, South Africa's official system of racial separation, might boycott the Olympics if Budd was permitted to compete. Budd, who was born in South Africa, has been a British subject since 1984. ''There are 23 other Olympic sports, but of course athletics is the centerpiece,'' Charles Palmer, the chairman of the British Olympic Association, referring to track and field. ''I am not about to impose a decision on the B.A.A.B. I want to give them time to sort their thoughts out.'' John Bryant, Budd's coach, said yesterday that he would seek legal advice for Budd. ''The B.A.A.B. knows how we feel,'' he said. ''They know what they should do: back Zola against this blackmail.'' Also speaking out in support of Budd was Hugh Jones, the British marathon runner. ''She should be backed all the way,'' he said. ''I'm willing to take suspension. If they fail to back Zola, the B.A.A.B. is completely spineless and without principle.''
