title: Persian Gulf: History of the U.S. Combat Role
description: 1987 March 14: U.S. intelligence says Iran has installed antiship missiles near Strait of Hormuz, further threatening oil flow from Persian Gulf. March 19: Pentagon says U.S. warships, led by the carrier Kitty Hawk, have moved into Arabian Sea. March 23: U.S. is reported to offer to protect Kuwaiti vessels in gulf. April 4: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger orders stronger Navy presence in gulf to back up American commitment to continued flow of oil. April 14: Soviet Union announces agreement to lease three tankers to Kuwait; Soviet warships might provide escort. May 2: Iranian marines, looking for Iraq-bound cargo, board 14 foreign ships at Strait of Hormuz. May 11: Iran attacks third Kuwait-bound tanker in eight days and warns Kuwait not to seek American or Soviet protection. May 17: Iraqi missile strikes American guided-missile frigate Stark, killing 37 crew members. Iraq apologizes for pilot blunder. May 19: United States expands role in gulf to provide escorts for 11 Kuwaiti tankers. Carrier Constellation moves into Arabian Sea. May 24: Weinberger calls on Arab gulf states to provide bases and other support for United States military mission in gulf. May 29: Reagan says Administration aim is to prevent Iran and Soviet Union from interrupting oil flow to West. June 16: Pentagon tells Congress that American naval escorts operate under hair-trigger rules; maritime sources say Iran is laying mines. June 18: Pentagon and Congressional leaders agree that Iranian threats must not deter United States from escorting Kuwaiti tankers, though some warn that Navy underestimates danger from mines. July 1: U.S. specialists reportedly find a dozen moored mines in gulf shipping lanes. July 3: Soviet Union condemns U.S. buildup; calls on all foreign warships to leave gulf. July 19: As reflagging of Kuwaiti tankers proceeds, experts from U.S., Kuwait and Saudi Arabia report mine-clearing operation complete. July 21: Two Kuwaiti tankers with American escort head for gulf. July 24: Supertanker Bridgeton, under American escort, hits mine near Iranian island in gulf. July 26: Weinberger says U.S. will bolster its minesweeping units in gulf. Aug. 8: U.S. warships escort reflagged tankers past Iranian bases. U.S. Navy fighter fires two missiles at Iranian plane, but misses. Aug. 10: An American-owned supertanker is damaged by mines. Aug. 15: Mine sinks a tanker tender boat at mouth of gulf, off Oman. Aug. 16: U.S. amphibious assault ship Guadalcanal, with eight minesweeping helicopters, anchors off Bahrain. Aug. 19: Administration orders reactivation of eight mothballed minesweepers. Aug. 24: U.S. destroyer escort fires machine-gun bursts across bows of two small wooden sailboats. Iranian warship nears U.S. force and is warned off. Sept. 21: American helicopter gunship sets suspected mine-laying vessel ablaze. Three Iranians are reported killed and 26 captured in seizure of mine-laying vessel. Oct. 8: United States says three Iranian patrol boats are sunk after firing on American helicopter gunships. Pentagon says Iranian boats may have had Stinger anti-aircraft missiles. Oct. 15: Iranian missile sets fire to American-owned tanker in Kuwaiti waters. Oct. 16: Kuwaiti tanker is hit by missile. Oct. 19: American warships retaliate by shelling two offshore platforms said to serve as bases for Iranian gunboats. Dec. 12: American military rescuers take 28 people off supertanker set afire by Iranian gunboat. 1988 Feb. 17: After reductions in American naval presence, 28 United States warships remain on station in gulf. Minesweeping helicopters are withdrawn and the helicopter carrier Okinawa leaves. March 6: American helicopters are fired on from offshore platform and small boats, but fire is not returned. April 14: American frigate Samuel B. Roberts is seriously damaged by mine blast off Qatar. Ten crewmen are wounded. Washington says Iranians laid new mines. April 18: American forces retaliate with attack on two Iranian oil platforms. Two Iranian frigates fire missiles at U.S. aircraft, and an Iranian guided-missile patrol boat fires on U.S. cruiser Wainwright. Pentagon says Wainwright was unscathed but Iranian frigates suffered heavy damage and patrol boat was sunk.

description: Thousands of workers have been killed and tens of thousands have been injured or medically disabled because of delays by the Reagan Administration in issuing new job health and safety regulations, a Senate committee was told today.

title: New Retail Concepts Seeks an Ad Agency
description: New Retail Concepts, a fairly new company in the fashion field that makes nothing but promotion, is looking for an agency to replace Kirshenbaum & Bond on its $1.5 million advertising account.

title: Oil Prices Go Up Again On Persian Gulf Clashes
description: Crude-oil prices rose again in New York trading yesterday in reaction to a new outbreak of hostilities in the Persian Gulf.

title: Panama Banks Reopen, but Only for Deposits
description: Some of Panama's 130 banks reopened today for the first time since economic sanctions by the United States forced them to close 46 days ago.

title: Koppers Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results for the latest first quarter reflect a $7 million increase in corporate overehead, mainly because of the hostile tender offer by Beazer Plc. The company also said it increased an environmental reserve by $2.5 million, while interest expense rose by $1.5 million.

title: Destiny of Bikini Is Again At the Mercy of Technology
description: THE remote Bikini Atoll once again is the setting for critical tests of the effects of technology's most destructive force. But this time, no atomic bombs are exploding - no mushroom clouds or warships blown out of lagoon waters. The new experiments are as simple and serene as palm trees in the sandy soil, but the results, now as before, will determine the destiny of the Bikinians.

title: Speakes and Meese
description: Larry Speakes has set the Administration he used to work for an admirable precedent - not in those words he wrongly put in Ronald Reagan's mouth but in manfully resigning a lucrative job when he realized his confession had embarrassed his company and perhaps damaged its credibility.

title: Reinforcements for the War on Hunger
description: Since 1983, an emergency Federal program has distributed surplus commodities like cheese and dry milk to the hungry. At times, the operation has been sloppily run - but 15 million poor Americans have eaten better because of it.

title: Grainger, W W Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Valley Capital reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter included $2.3 million in gains on investment transactions. The year-ago period is restated to include the operations of Security Bank of Nevada, which was merged into Valley Capital's Valley Bank of Nevada unit on Dec. 31, 1987.

title: Boatmen's Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $3,058,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Van Brunt's 'Postcard' Evokes Barbados Life
description: The creative people at Van Brunt & Company have cleverly captured the look and feel of an inexpensive fold-out postcard in a television commercial for the Barbados Board of Tourism.

title: Books of The Times; Power in the Museum World
description: The Golden Calves By Louis Auchincloss 213 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $17.95.

title: MEESE CHOICE SEEN TURNING DOWN JOB
description: John C. Shepherd, the choice of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d as his chief deputy, has told Justice Department officials that he expects to turn down the nomination, a department official said tonight.

title: Review/Television; Gang Life in the Barrio
description: The category of ''programming for young audiences'' takes an unusual turn this afternoon at 4 o'clock with a ''CBS Schoolbreak'' presentation. The subject and title: ''Gangs.'' Usually these periodic network specials explore problems that can be handled neatly and then wrapped up with a tidy object lesson. This one, rolling off today's headlines, makes for a far messier package. It's different. More to the point, it's good.

title: Amish Children Inoculated
description: Some Amish communities in northwestern Pennsylvania have dropped their usual opposition to immunizations and sent 125 children to get shots to fight an outbreak of measles.

title: Novel Is on 2 Best-Seller Lists at Once
description: This Sunday, Scott Turow's ''Presumed Innocent,'' a novel about a big city deputy prosecutor who investigates a brutal murder, will be No. 15 on the hard-cover best seller list of The New York Times Book Review. It will also be No. 2 on The Times paperback list.

title: Johnson Controls Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Champagne Drive's Blurry Line
description: A current series of print advertisements for Dom Ruinart Rose Champagne has fooled many readers of eight trend-setting magazines into thinking the ads are part of their editorial content, according to editors at several of the magaazines and people involved in the production of the ads.

title: Rules of Thumb for Would-Be Hitchhikers
description: To the Editor:

title: First Bank System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the decline in income was due to lower net interest income and the implementation of an early retirement program, which was partially offset by a decline in the provision for loan losses and a lower tax provision.

title: Manville Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $9 million from the sale of two real estate joint ventures.

title: Locking Up Data
description: THERE are times when it makes sense to lock up your computer, because the data stored in its hard disk are too secret and valuable to leave unattended. A hard disk is essentially an unlocked file cabinet, and any sneak thief with a rudimentary knowledge of computers and a few floppy disks can make off with the contents without leaving a trace of the crime.

title: Amsouth Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Diebold Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $4,484,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said year-ago earnings are restated for the accounting change.

title: The Primary, Both of Them
description: Beyond voters' obligations to a democratic society, there are two good reasons for New York State's 3.5 million registered Democrats to make the effort to vote in today's Presidential primary.

title: Industry's Operating Rate Slips
description: The operating rate of American industry declined in March for the second consecutive month despite a rebound at automobile plants.

title: Pirelli to Buy Armstrong From Armtek
description: In another sign of a worldwide consolidation in the tire industry, the Armtek Corporation, a tire and industrial products company, said today that it had agreed to sell its Armstrong Tire Company to Pirelli S.p.A., the Italian tire maker, for $190 million.

title: Erie Lackawanna Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are restated.

title: Panama's Crisis Threatening Major Farmers With Extinction
description: This country's large private farmers, who helped make Panama self-sufficient in agriculture more than 15 years ago, are on the brink of financial oblivion as a result of the crisis over the continued rule of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Sprouse: A 60's Spirit in Classic Mode
description: When Stephen Sprouse burst upon the fashion scene in 1983, his clothes were obviously inspired by the architectural Courreges shapes of the 1960's. The spirit of the fall collection Mr. Sprouse showed last Friday is still based in the 60's, but the design inspiration appears to be Halston's classic, ladylike approach.

title: Universal Foods Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Trapeze Artist Dies in Fall
description: A trapeze artist slipped in a solo performance 17 feet above ground and plunged to her death Sunday night in front of 900 spectators, witnesses said. The performer, Belinda Amandis, 31, of Sarasota, who was so proficient she once performed while suspended from a helicopter, was killed instantly at the Circus USA show, the authorities said.

title: Ziegler Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Long Lines but No Unusual Troubles Expected at City Polls
description: The New York City Board of Elections is preparing for a big turnout in the Democratic Presidential primary today, but it is taking no extraordinary measures to handle the vote.

title: E.P.A Plans Survey Of Drinking Water Tainted by Pesticide
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today annnounced that it would conduct a nationwide survey of the extent of drinking water contamination from agricultural pesticides.

title: Di Giorgio Unit
description: The Di Giorgio Corporation, a producer of food products and building materials, agreed to sell its Serv-A-Portion division to Borden Inc. for an undisclosed amount. The sale of Serv-A-Portion, which is the leading United States manufacturer of individual serving portion foods, is the latest step in the company's restructuring and recapitalization program. Earlier steps included the sale of Di Giorgio International B.V., its European juice operation, in March, and the recently concluded public tender offer for 3.5 million shares of its common stock.

title: National Bancshares of Texas reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter loss reflects, in part, a provision of $8.9 million for possible future loan losses. The loan loss provision for a year earlier was $18.6 million, with $20.2 million in loans charged off, resulting in a reserve at the end of the year-ago quarter of $47.9 million.

title: Dr. Morton Berger, 53, Dean at Yeshiva U.
description: Dr. Morton Berger, dean of the Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology at Yeshiva University, died Thursday night in a car accident on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway as he was driving to his home in Albany. He was 53 years old and maintained an apartment in the Bronx.

title: Cincinnati Bell Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Genentech Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. Assails P.L.O. Aide's Killing As 'Act of Political Assassination'
description: The State Department today condemned the killing of a top official of the Palestine Liberation Organization as an ''act of political assassination,'' but said that it had no information about who was responsible.

title: Chase and Continental Earnings Up
description: Two of the nation's major banking companies, the Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Continental Illinois Corporation, yesterday reported increases in first-quarter earnings.

title: Theft Suspect Beaten, Then Slain
description: A 26-year-old Bronx man was beaten by an angry mob, hit in the head with a baseball bat and fatally shot in the chest yesterday when he attempted to steal a car in the Inwood section of Manhattan, the police said.

title: Sears's Net Down 37.7% In Quarter
description: Buffeted by earnings declines in three of its four businesses, Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, yesterday reported a 37.7 percent drop in net income for the first quarter. The businesses adversely affected were merchandising, insurance and real estate, while Sears's financial services group had sharply higher net income.

title: Washington Talk: The Mall; An Empty Space Inspires Battle of the Museums
description: Congressional and museum leaders have become caught up in a seemingly intractable debate over how the United States should recognize the two peoples who suffered most in the growth of the nation: the Indians, who lost their land to the white settlers, and the blacks, who built much of it with their slave labor.

title: Lilly, Eli & Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $3.2 million.

title: Let Nazi Medical Data Remind Us of Evil
description: To the Editor:

title: Pentair Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
What to Do With Social Security Surpluses; Uncorrected Deception
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Looking Ahead at C.I.A.
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has been doing a little anticipatory brushing up on one of its former directors, Vice President Bush. Agency officials say the C.I.A. recently compiled facts about Mr. Bush's tenure at the agency, which he headed for almost a year beginning in 1976.

title: Abitibi-Price Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Shearson Defends Its Kopper Role
description: Peter A. Cohen, the chairman and chief executive of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., defended his company role in Beazers P.L.C.'s takeover bid for the Koppers Company, saying Shearson's role had been ''greatly mischaracterized.'' He said Shearson was merely a financial adviser to Beazer.

title: Better Gauges Devised To Check Test Accuracy
description: THE Government's standards-setting agency is developing chemical yardsticks that could greatly enhance the reliability of laboratory tests that determine how diseases are treated or if a person gets a job.

title: Stocks Mixed as Dow Declines 5.81 Points
description: Stock prices ended narrowly mixed yesterday in nervous, subdued trading.

title: La Jolla Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Television; How Prison Is Different for Women
description: ''Women Behind Bars'' sounds like an exploitation film; it is not. The NBC News report, on Channel 4 at 10 P.M., is tasteful. It finds that women react differently to imprisonment than do men. The news report solves no problems, but it does raise thoughtful questions.

title: Students Find Internal Medicine Less Alluring
description: INTERNAL medicine, which has long attracted many of the brightest medical students, is losing its luster as the central primary care specialty, and top graduates are increasingly choosing other fields.

title: Pfizer Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $53.1 million resulting from the settlement of a patent infringement judgment obtained by one of the company's subsidiaries. Pre- tax income included provision for uninsured product liabilities and restructuring costs which substantially offset this settlement. The year-ago results were restated for an accounting change.

title: Nynex Profit Increases 4%
description: The Nynex Corporation, one of the ''Baby Bells'' born of the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company several years ago, yesterday reported first-quarter net of $311.1 million, or $1.55 a share, up 4 percent from $299.2 million, or $1.47 a share, in the corresponding period a year ago.

title: A Phony Social Security Crisis
description: LEAD: Several newspapers and economic experts have recently discovered what they consider the latest economic catastrophe: The Social Security trust fund is accumulating an enormous surplus, possibly several trillion dollars by early in the next century, and is offsetting a large part of the Federal deficit.

title: Olin Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Louise Nevelson: Flowering
description: Louise Nevelson, who died this week at 88, was a practicing sculptor for 30 years before she made her first sale. Fame didn't arrive until she was in her 50's. Even so, there seems never to have been a moment when she didn't know the worth of her effort. And of all the eulogies there will be for her, there can be none more eloquent, or apt, than the one she gave herself, in an interview in 1981:

title: Baseball; Giants Outlast Reds, 6-3
description: Kevin Mitchell's sacrifice fly drove in the winning run and Will Clark doubled home another run and then scored on Jeffrey Leonard's single in the 12th inning tonight, giving the Giants a 6-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Accounts
description: * Boating magazine to Bruce J. Bloom Advertising and Marketing.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in Weekend last Friday, about performances on college stages, carried incorrect time, day and location provided by Yeshiva University for a performance there by Yoel Sharabi and the Shema Yisrael Orchestra. It will take place at 9:30 P.M. Thursday at the Lamport Auditorium, Amsterdam Avenue and 186th Street.

title: Foster Wheeler Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes about $9,400,000 from the settlement of several pension plans.

title: Capitals Outhustle Devils in Division Final Opener
description: The intensity that earned the Devils their first playoff berth and the subsequent elimination of the Islanders dropped somewhat in the opening game of the Patrick Division final series tonight, and it cost them dearly.

title: Pravda Talks of Ethnic Woes
description: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda said today that the question of redrawing internal Soviet borders deserved further study although rash changes could cause economic disruption.

title: Penn State Will Drop Charges Against 89 Students
description: The president of Pennsylvania State University agreed today to drop charges against 89 students arrested during a sit-in protesting the university's racial policy, but he would not commit new funds for recruiting black students and faculty.

title: Nicor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
What to Do With Social Security Surpluses
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Lose; Aguilera Is Hurt
description: In a long and graceless evening filled with walks, errors and gaffes, the Mets lost a game, a six-game winning streak and maybe Rick Aguilera last night in Shea Stadium.

title: KEY RATES
Britain to Use Nasdaq System
description: The Nasdaq automated quotation system is expected to be authorized today to operate as the first foreign stock exchange in Britain. The step is likely to be seen as a milestone in the globalization of securtities trading.

title: Albany Budget Impasse Laid to Minority Jobs Bill
description: The issue delaying agreement on the New York State budget is a minority jobs bill that would standardize provisions that are already part of some state laws.

title: BFS Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Ex-Texas Bank Officer Will Head Northpark
description: LEAD: Charles H. Pistor, who stepped down Friday as vice chairman of the loss-plagued First Republicbank Corporation, was named yesterday as chairman and chief executive of the much smaller, but profitable, Northpark National Bank in Dallas.

title: Capitals Encounter No True Surprises
description: The nice thing about the Devils, said Scott Stevens, the Washington Capitals defenseman who scored the middle goal in his team's 3-1 victory tonight, is their predictability. But Stevens hastened to add that New Jersey's absence of changeability was in no way an encouraging sign for the Capitals.

title: The Trouble With New Teacher-Transfer Terms
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Orders Wide Curfew in Territories; 2 Are Killed
description: The Israeli Army ordered curfews today on 20 refugee districts and on the city of Nablus and several villages in the occupied territories to block protests over the assassination of the military commander of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Linked Magazines Aim At Doctors and Patients
description: John Nittoli, former publisher of the defunct RX Being Well magazine, is now president of Healthteam Communications in New York, which publishes two magazines - Heart Beat and Doctors' Orders.

title: South Carolina National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Effect of the Attack: No Shift in Iran's Goals
description: Iran's military setbacks in the Persian Gulf today do not change the fundamental strategic equation in the Iran-Iraq war, in the view of military specialists here who are following developments in Iran closely.

title: Anti-Semitism Charges Lead To Delay on Religion Prize
description: The sponsors of the Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion have postponed presentation of the $369,000 award to investigate charges that this year's winner, Dr. Inamullah Khan, supports anti-Semitism.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We determine conclusively, without hesitation or doubt, that the accused is Ivan who was known as ''Ivan the Terrible,' gas chamber operator at the Treblinka death camp.'' - Dov Levin,presiding judge at trial of John Demjanjuk [ A1:2. ]

title: Pennzoil to Buy Auto Filter Maker
description: The Pennzoil Company said today that it had agreed to acquire one of its longstanding suppliers, Facet Enterprises Inc. of Tulsa, Okla., for $32 a share in cash, or a total of $250 million.

title: Teco Energy Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Texas American Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included non- recurring income of $12.4 million.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Hasty Arrangements
description: It is relatively short notice in the business of East-West relations, but when the United States Information Agency heard two weeks ago that a delegation of high-powered Soviet information and cultural officials was prepared to come here almost immediately for meetings with their counterparts, the hosts hopped to it.

title: Centerre Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $4,469,000 from an accounting change.

title: Schroeder Is Expected To Stay With Redskins
description: As pro football's wheelers and dealers prepare for the National Football League's draft Sunday and Monday, two things appear certain regarding quarterbacks. Jay Schroeder seems sure to remain with the Washington Redskins and Kelly Stouffer, or at least the rights to him, seems sure to leave the Phoenix Cardinals.

title: Torrey Unhappy
description: The Islanders, just as downcast as they were when they were eliminated from playoff contention by the Devils on Thursday, assembled yesterday for some housecleaning in their locker room and heard a brief speech by team officials. Bill Torrey, the general manager, called his team's exit from the first round of postseason play the biggest disappointment he had encountered since he assumed control of the franchise. ''We didn't play one good game,'' he said. ''In other seasons, you could pretty well see what went wrong, but that's a different bunch in there now.'' Torrey said he had no plans to dismiss Terry Simpson, who completed his second season with a first-place divisional finish, the team's first in four years. Torrey said he expected to re-sign Tomas Jonsson, and added that he would continue negotiations with Billy Smith, who has been disinclined to accept a one-year contract.

title: Washington Water Power Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
West Mass Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hasbro Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Judge Blocks Plan for Shelter
description: A plan by the New York City Board of Estimate to build a shelter for 100 homeless families in Queens has been invalidated by a State Supreme Court justice. The project is part of Mayor Koch's proposal to place 11 shelters in three of the five boroughs.

title: Pacific First Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $2.1 million on the sale of loans and mortgage- backed securities. c-Included an extraordinary loss of $3,758,000 and a $14 million gain on the sale of loans and mortgage-backed securities. The latest quarter included a $2,516,000 provision for loan losses, compared with a similar loss of $1,891,000 for year-ago period.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Applied Solar Energy Corp., City of Industry, Calif., a maker of photovoltaic devices, said Arthur Douglas Ritchie, executive vice president and chief operating officer, had resigned for personal reasons. A replacement has not yet been named.

title: Sage Broadcasting Buys Physicians Radio
description: The venture capitalists who owned the Physicians Radio Network have sold it to the Sage Broadcasting Corporation. Having traveled across this broad land looking for a buyer, they found one in their own office building in Stamford, Conn.

title: Parents Held in Death Of 1-Month-Old Child
description: A month old girl was found dead in her parent's Morningside Heights apartment yesterday, and her parents were arrested and charged with threatening the welfare of a minor, the police said.

title: In Lieu of Williamsburg: Slow Day for New Ferry
description: Several hundred residents of Brooklyn and Queens took to the wind-whisked waters of the East River to get to work yesterday, riding a fledgling ferryboat service intended to ease congested commuting conditions created by last week's closing of the Williamsburg Bridge.

title: Storage Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $4.2 million from an accounting change.

title: NCR Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Yes, Veto the Trade Bill. But Then? There Are Good Reasons to Oppose It
description: Congress's Democratic leaders have decided on a blunt showdown after three years of wrangling over the foreign trade bill. They plan to send the President a final version with one controversial amendment that he flatly rejects. The truculence on both sides is regrettable. The result may be no trade bill at all, and a deplorable policy vacuum.

title: 'Hot Hands' Phenomenon: A Myth?
description: THE gulf between science and sports may never loom wider than in the case of the hot hands.

title: Bombs Go Off in Frankfurt
description: Bombs exploded early today at the Jewish Community Center and the Saudi Arabian airlines office, damaging both buildings but causing no injuries. The police said the two devices were probably planted by the same people.

title: First Essex Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank converted to stock form of ownership in August 1987.

title: U.S. STRIKES 2 IRANIAN OIL RIGS AND HITS 6 WARSHIPS IN BATTLES OVER MINING SEA LANES IN GULF
description: The United States Navy clashed with Iranian forces across the southern half of the Persian Gulf today, crippling or sinking six armed Iranian vessels. One American attack helicopter was reported missing.

title: Beijing Is Said to Restrict Foreign Travel to Tibet
description: Chinese officials have indicated that they will sharply restrict tourism to Tibet in the wake of last month's riot by Buddhist monks demonstrating for Tibetan independence, according to a United States official who has just returned from the region.

title: Opus to Be Merged With ABC Magazines
description: ABC Publishing has acquired Opus magazine from Historical Times for an undisclosed amount and will merge it into ABC's Musical America magazines. The result will be a magazine whose editorial content will be half reviews of live, mostly musical, performances and articles about personalities, and half reviews of classical recordings. The six issue-a-year magazine will have a circulation of about 31,500 and will be 96 pages an issue, a third larger than its two components.

title: Olympic Invitations
description: Danny Manning of national champion Kansas and David Robinson, the former Navy star, were among 93 players invited yesterday to next month's Olympic basketball trials in Colorado Springs. Invited from Oklahoma, the N.C.A.A. runner-up, were Mookie Blaylock, Stacey King, Dave Sieger and Harvey Grant. Arizona, another Final Four team, had invitations extended to Steve Kerr, Anthony Cook, Sean Elliott and Tom Tolbert. The trials begin on May 18.

title: Congress Split on Disclosure Rule
description: Senate conferees have refused to go along with House Democratic leaders in their efforts to revive a hotly contested provision of the omnibus trade bill, Senator J. James Exon said today. The provision would require disclosure of foreign investments in the United States.

title: First Union Real Estate Equity & Mortgage Investments reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Standard Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said it had fewer shares outstanding in both the latest third quarter and 9-month periods, the result of a 550,000-share stock repurchase program begun in October 1987 and completed during the third quarter. The share earnings for fiscal 1987 have been adjusted for the 5-for-4 stock split declared in August 1987.

title: Thousands Mourn Slain Brooklyn Housing Officer
description: As police officers stood at attention outside a Roman Catholic parish church in Brooklyn and scores of passers-by and friends paused to reflect, Housing Police Officer Anthony O. McLean was praised and remembered yesterday for a lifetime of caring and for a readiness to help others.

title: Review/Concert; A Premiere About China
description: The program Gerard Schwarz and the New York Chamber Symphony offered on Sunday afternoon at the 92d Street Y was packed with gems, but the performance that outshone all around it was the premiere of ''H'un (Lacerations): In Memoriam 1966-1976,'' a searing portrait of the Cultural Revolution in China by Bright Sheng, a 32-year-old composer who grew up in China and completed his training in New York.

title: Reporter's Notebook; As Curtain Begins to Ring Down, Critics Can't Wait to Pan Performance
description: The reviews are in on the New York primary, and the critics are unanimous: This play should close. Which it will, after today's performance.

title: New Budget Raises Fears In Connecticut
description: The beginning of the end of Connecticut's long-running economic boom was forecast by many lawmakers here today as the Senate prepared to give final legislative approval Tuesday to a $6.29 billion state budget.

title: BUSH SAYS ATTACK ON IRAN WAS RIGHT
description: Vice President Bush chose to stay on the campaign trail yesterday despite the United States' military retaliation against Iran, which he defended as a measured response designed to provide a clear message to Teheran.

title: Rollins Environmental Servces reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cleveland Journal; Cuyahoga Freighters Challenged To Coexist
description: Just after midnight not too long ago, as the 600-foot freighter Kinsman Independent was maneuvering through the narrow Cuyahoga River, grinding her way to the mouth at Lake Erie, she became involved in the worst mishap on the waterway in recent years.

title: Riggs National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included net after tax profits of $2.9 million from sales of and recoveries on previously charged-off loans, including loans to Brazil, Ecuador, Chile, the Ivory Coast, and other foreign borrowers.

title: New Vice Chairman Is Named at Citicorp
description: Citicorp yesterday named a new vice chairman, Paul J. Collins, and said he would be its senior banker in Europe and the Middle East. Mr. Collins will report directly to John S. Reed, the chairman.

title: The Scramble to Fix a New York Bridge
description: In New York City, it's hard sometimes to tell the failing bridges without a scorecard.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-15 Iranian and American forces battled in the Persian Gulf. The attacks began when U.S. ships destroyed two Iranian oil platforms as retaliation for the mining that damaged a U.S. ship last week. Page A1 Congressional support for retaliation against Iran is broad. After consultation with the Administration, Congressional leaders said President Reagan would not be pressed to invoke the War Powers Act. A1 Washington condemned the killing of Khalil al-Wazir as a political assassination but said it had no information about who was responsible. The State Department said the U.S. Government was not involved. A1 The Israeli Army imposed curfews on 20 refugee districts in the occupied territories to block any protests over the assassination of Khalil al-Wazir. Soldiers shot and killed two Palestinians in the Gaza Strip. A12 Syria offered to allow the funeral of Khalil al-Wazir, the slain P.L.O. military chief, to take place in Damascus. The offer could improve relations between President Hafez al-Assad and the P.L.O. A12 John Demjanjuk was convicted of war crimes by an Israeli court. The court found that the retired auto worker from Cleveland was a guard at the Treblinka death camp during World War II. A1 The Afghan war's effects in Pakistan are blamed for violence and the flow of drugs. But some consider Pakistan's problems the result of growing poverty and population and the lack of a sense of nationhood. A4 China will restrict tourism to Tibet, in the wake of last month's riots by Buddhist monks, according to a U.S. official who visited Tibet and met with Chinese and Tibetan officials. A5 Debate over social policy in Britain is at a boil as Parliament prepares to vote on a new system of local taxes aimed at bringing the poor, the unemployed and those on welfare onto the tax lists. A6 Panama's farmers face a crisis because they cannot get credit to begin the spring planting. The cash shortage caused by U.S. sanctions against Gen. Manuel Noriega threatens agricultural self-sufficiency. A15 National A18-29 A Federal fund to insure deposits at savings and loan associations had liabilities exceeding assests by $11.6 billion at the end of 1987. A $10.8 billion package Congress passed will not cover losses in the thrift industry. A1 A Presidential panel on airline safety recommended making the Federal Aviation Administration an independent agency to oversee the airline industry, with a new ''safety czar.'' A1 Presentation of a prize for religion will be postponed while the sponsors of the award, the Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion, investigate charges that the recipient, Inamullah Khan, supports anti-Semitism. A18 The parental rights of unwed fathers will be considered by the Supreme Court. It agreed to hear the appeal of a California man who was denied the right to see his daughter after the mother placed the child with a foster family. A22 Bennett says Stanford was intimidated into changing course A18 Chyrsler proposes to tie bonuses of officers to profit-sharing plan A18 Ethics of some Pentagon advisors criticized A24 Politics A26-27 The New York Presidential primary today could decide the nomination for the Democratic Party or leave the race unsettled until after the last primaries, in California and New Jersey on June 7. A1 Albert Gore Jr. campaigned with Mayor Koch, who has endorsed the Senator's Democratic Presidential campaign. Mr. Gore needs 20 percent of the vote here or in Pennsylvania to again receive Federal matching funds. A26 Jesse Jackson talked about hate at a campaign appearance and accused Mayor Koch of being devisive. Mr. Jackson said he had received more death threats in New York than in the other Democratic Presidential primaries. A26 Michael Dukakis was confident on the eve of the New York primary and said he was looking forward to victory. But Mr. Dukakis's aides worried about voter turnout and presented the primary as a close race with Jesse Jackson A26. Washington Talk A28 At Mall, battle of the museums Regional B1-5 Charges of dumping pesticides where they could harm people were brought against a greenhouse operator in upstate New York. Gerardus deWit became the first person indicted under a new state law. B1 Repairs on 32 New York City bridges have closed or partly closed the structures. The serial closings, more frequent now, have become a symptom of neglect in maintenance and repair, according to officials. B1 Weekday commuter ferry service began between Brooklyn and Manhattan to help ease traffic congestion caused by the closing of the Williamsburg Bridge. Turnout was light on the hastily-organized service. B4 Connecticut will draw on reserves in its new budget, which legislators are expected to approve. Some fear that the budget, which does not include new taxes, is the beginning of the end of the state's economic boom. B1 Disagreement on a minority jobs bill is delaying agreement on the New York State budget. Democrats and Republicans disagree on how much business contractors must do with companies owned by minorities and women. B3 Evidence in the trial of Mario Biaggi indicated that he owned stock in the Wedtech Corporation. Prosecutors at the Federal racketeering trial introduced a letter that referred to stock received by Mr. Biaggi. B4 New York Magazine celebrates 20 years B1 Wedding joins two billionaire families B2 New York area not badly hurt by stock plunge B3 Thousands mourn slain Brooklyn housing officer B3 B4

title: BIW Cable Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2.2 million from the sale of a facility. c-Includes a $1.8 million writedown of inventories.

title: Crestar Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Data General Strategy Shift
description: The Data General Corporation, signaling a change in strategy, said today that it would work with Motorola Inc. to develop a computer microprocessor chip set that is built around Motorola's new 88000 ''reduced instruction set computer,'' or RISC, chip.

title: Yanks, Santana Flex Muscles
description: By itself, the game was little more than an exhibition of thundering offensive might: 18 runs, 20 hits, 5 doubles, 3 home runs. But the achievement of Rafael Santana, the unhappy and supposedly unwanted Yankee shortstop, seemed to stand alone tonight.

title: A Toolmaker's Survival Strategy
description: The Kingsbury Machine Tool Corporation has managed to make a profit every year since 1933, even during the stormy downturn of the early 1980's when many rivals gave up tool making or plunged into the red.

title: Sears, Roebuck & Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Suit Involving Cuomo's Son Over Savings-Loan Is Settled
description: A bitter legal battle that pitted Andrew Cuomo, the son of the Governor, and a group of his business associates against the original management of a Florida savings institution has been settled, parties to the settlement announced yesterday.

title: First City Investors Said to Defect
description: An attempt to take control of the troubled First City Bancorporation of Texas has apparently run into a new snag, with serious defections reported from the investor group led by A. Robert Abboud. The deal has also encountered continued resistance from First City's bondholders.

title: Fund to Insure Savings Industry In Critical State
description: The financial condition of the Government fund that insures deposits at the nation's savings and loan associations worsened significantly by the end of 1987, Federal officials disclosed today.

title: Round One of Nicaragua Talks at End
description: Three days of peace talks between contra guerrilla leaders and the Sandinista Government ended today without an agreement.

title: Southern National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Gulf Clash: A Risky Course for U.S.
description: Clashes between American and Iranian forces in the Persian Gulf today have drawn the United States deeper into the Iran-Iraq war, and sent the latest signal of tacit American support for Iraq in the eight-year-old conflict. Although the mood in

title: The Air Is Bitter to Buoyant as Voting Nears: Albert Gore Jr.; From Subway Stop To Seaport, Koch Lends a Voice
description: ''Hi, everybody, it's us! - Al Gore and me!''

title: US HealthCare Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chase Manhattan Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $61 million after-tax gain from the sale of Interactive Data Corp., a $59 million after-tax gain from the sale of a branch office building and a tax credit of $40 million. c-Includes a $9 million after-tax gain from the sales of a factoring subsidiary in the Netherlands and a minority interest in an affiliate in Belgium. The company said latest first quarter results reflect strong performances in foreign exchange trading and trading account activities, as well as increases in fees and commissions, partially offset by a decline in gains from the sales of investment securities. The company also said contributing to the latest first quarter results were a lower provision for possible credit losses and only moderately increased operating expenses. The continuing nonaccrual status of medium- and long-term cross-border outstandings to borrowers in Brazil and Ecuador reduced first quarter 1988 net interest income by $53 million ($32 million after taxes) and reduced first quarter 1987 net interest income by $66 million ($37 million after taxes). The company said its adoption of FAS 91 on Jan. 1 reduced first quarter 1988 net income by $7 million after taxes. In addition, the company said it adopted retroactively, also on Jan. 1, FAS 96, resulting in a $35 million reduction in retained earnings. The effect of adopting this standard was not material to any prior period results or to first quarter 1988 net income.

title: Richard Childs, 78, Former Transit Official
description: Richard Storrs Childs, former deputy administrator for planning and administration for the New York City Department of Transportation, died Saturday at his home in Norfolk, Conn., after a brief illness. He was 78 years old.

title: Mara Lynn Conrad, Dancer, 59
description: Mara Lynn Conrad, a dancer in Broadway musicals, movies and television, died of liver cancer on April 6 in Freeport, the Bahamas. She was 59 years old.

title: Apple Computer Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective May 15, 1987.

title: Meese's Resignation Could Prejudice His Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Citizens Banking CorpO) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Washington Talk: Briefing; 80 Years, Still Blushing
description: The art and architecture of the national capital have their Greek aspects and their Roman aspects, but one thing the two styles have in common in Washington is a general lack of frontal nudity among the statuary.

title: Juilliard Drama School, at 20, Stresses Versatility
description: Over in one corner a wild-eyed drunk pounded someone's face on a table while a few feet away another man snapped the lid of a keyboard on the knuckles of a grimacing pianist. ''This is my laboratory of violence,'' B. H. Barry said, cheery dementia creasing his visage as he extended a welcoming hand. ''We've had about four months of learning how to punch and kick, and now we're starting to put together little scenes.''

title: Science Watch; Gene May Protect Beans From Weevils Science Watch; Update on Icebergs
description: A GENE found in a wild bean plant from Mexico may soon be added to the list of new biological approaches to pest control.

title: Trade Sought By Taiwan
description: Taiwan will treat Europe in the same way it does the United States in an attempt to increase its trade with Europe and diversify its markets, senior Government officials said today.

title: Shareware At Low Cost For Writers
description: SHAREWARE and public domain software were much in evidence at the West Coast Computer Faire in San Francisco 10 days ago.

title: U.S. Inspection At Continental
description: Federal Aviation Administration officials began inspecting Continental Airlines planes today, extending an investigation that had begun last week with Eastern Airlines.

title: Olin Agrees to Buy Subsidiary of Clabir
description: The Olin Corporation said it had tentatively agreed to acquire the General Defense Corporation, a leading manufacturer of heavy ammunition and tactical systems, from the Clabir Corporation in a deal valued at $104 million. Olin said the acquisition would ''establish Olin as a prime systems contractor in large-caliber ammunition.'' The transaction is contingent upon Government approval and General Defense's receipt of a fiscal year 1988 production award under its contract with the Army for 120-millimeter tank ammunition.

title: Medal Re-Awarded
description: The I.A.A.F.'s ruling council voted unanimously yesterday to disregard the sixth and final leap of Giovanni Evangelisti in last year's world track and field championships in Rome, thus stripping the Italian long jumper of his bronze medal and awarding it to Larry Myricks of the United States. Earlier this month, the Italian National Olympic Committee ruled that Evangelisti had been awarded the medal fraudulently when judges marked a distance long enough to win third place before Evangelisti made his jump, then recorded that measurement as the result.

title:
Market Place;
Why the Dow Is Misunderstood
description: LEAD: THE Dow Jones industrial average is one of the most widely watched statistics in the world, with the performance of its 30 stocks considered by many a proxy for the health of the American stock market and a seer for the American economy.

title: Toshiba VCR Price Rise
description: The Toshiba Corporation raised the price of its video cassette recorder exports to the United States by an average 7 percent to reflect part of the yen's rise against the dollar, a company spokesman said today. It is the second price rise this year, after a 3 percent increase in January.

title: Nynex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Supreme Court Roundup; Court to Decide Parental Rights of Unwed Father in Adoption
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the rights of an unwed father to have a relationship with his child can be cut off by the mother's decision to put the child up for adoption.

title: Strickland in Draft
description: Rod Strickland, the junior guard who averaged 20 points a game for DePaul last season, announced yesterday that he was making himself available for the National Basketball Association draft. ''I think it's like any other student in college,'' the 6-foot-3-inch Strickland said, reporting he would pass up his final year of eligibility. ''If they were offered $100,000, $200,000, $300,000, I think they would take it, too.''

title: Jackson Is the Winner In Delaware Voting; Dukakis Is Second
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson won Delaware's Democratic caucuses tonight, with Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts edging the uncommitted ranks for second place.

title: Text of White House Statement on Attack
description: Following is the text of the statement by the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, on the American military action in the Persian Gulf today:

title: Mystics and Science: Hawking's Views
description: ARMY chaplains used to tell their troops that ''there are no atheists in foxholes,'' meaning that the hope for supernatural intercession can powerfully appeal to someone looking into the muzzle of an enemy's gun.

title: Black Africa Exults in Jackson's Powerful Bid
description: ''Win, Jackson, Win!'' read a cover headline on a recent edition of The African Guardian, a news weekly here.

title: Californian to Accept Alzheimer's Prize
description: SCIENTISTS are coming close to understanding the biology of Alzheimer's disease, according to Dr. Robert D. Terry, who today will accept the 1988 Potamkin Prize for research on the disease.

title: British Fetal Implants
description: The first fetal cell implant in Britain caused a stir in political and medical circles today as anti-abortionists condemned what they called the use of embryos as spare parts.

title: Fifth Third Bancorp (Cincinnati, Ohio) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $7,455,000 from an accounting change. Year-ago per share earnings figure is adjusted for a 3-for-2 split paid in October 1987.

title: International Multifoods Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $34,987,000 and $33,330,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: PATTERNS
description: Private Labels Go Public

title: Vietnam Now Behind It, Hollyood Turns to the Civil Rights Struggle
description: Less than a three-hour drive from each other on a Mississippi highway, two movie companies are poking their cameras into the uncomfortable past.

title: Before the Order for Retaliation, A Major Effort to Woo Congress
description: The Administration's decision to retaliate against Iran received unusually broad support on Capitol Hill today, after intensive consultations between President Reagan, his national security advisers and Congressional leaders at the White House over the weekend.

title: Review/Theater; Overcoming Disability, Step by Step
description: The triumph over physical adversity can be a challenging subject for theater, but once a play is past the initial premise, the question remains about the playwright's larger purpose. In ''Fighting Chance,'' at the Long Wharf Theater, N. J. Crisp is interested in depicting the rehabilitation process in an English neurological center. Mr. Crisp, a writer of mystery novels as well as screenplays, is evidently speaking from his own experiences as a former neurological patient.

title: Guiding No. 1: The Man Who Programs NBC
description: Just before the current television season came to a close, Brandon Tartikoff, the chief NBC programmer, was asked to assess the performance of the new shows that made their debut on his schedule last fall. ''I can't sit here and play politician,'' he said, ''and tell you that I was happy with the net results from the fall.''

title: By Design: Combating April's Caprice
description: April has a way of making fashion fools of us. We want to look stylish as well as comfortable, and that can be difficult in the month of April. A few dulcet days seduce us into thinking we can store the heavy stuff and break out our spring togs. Invariably it then turns cold, pours rain, perhaps even freezes.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Why is it that seagulls at the beach always face in the same direction when they are in a group?

title: KaiserTech Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $6.7 million and a tax benefit of $3.4 million. c-Net loss and after income of $1.4 million from discontinued operations. Year-ago results are restated for an accounting change.

title: The Air Is Bitter to Buoyant as Voting Nears: Jesse Jackson; The Candidate Talks About Death Threats And Politics of Hate
description: Tired of turning the other cheek to Mayor Koch's attacks, the Rev. Jesse Jackson put aside the politics of love yesterday and talked about the politics of hate.

title: Grace, W R & Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $17.7 million from the sale of the company's 25 percent interest in Home Quarters Warehouse Inc., and is after a loss of $347,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $27,622,000, which included a gain of $27.4 million on the divestment of Bermans, and tax loss carryforwards of $8,466,000. The share earnings for 1987 has been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 common stock split on Dec. 10, 1987. The company said the sales gain was due in part to the consolidation of National Medical Care in 1988.

title: Business and Health; Bargaining on Fee With a Surgeon
description: PEOPLE will bargain with a stereo salesman or a home remodeler. But haggling over fees with a surgeon is another story. Most patients would dread even the thought of it.

title: TRW Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Irish Bank to Buy First NH
description: The Bank of Ireland, Ireland's second-biggest commercial bank, said today that it had agreed to acquire First NH Banks Inc. of New Hampshire for $370 million.

title: Karachi Journal; By the Sea, a City Bursts With Squalor and Rage
description: ''What problems?'' a senior police official asked a visitor who opened a conversation with a reference to the city's difficulties.

title: Ms. Magazine Adds an Editor
description: Ms. magazine yesterday announced the appointment of Marcia Ann Gillespie as executive editor, a new position.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The state of the F.S.L.I.C. has worsened significantly, reaching a level that all but insures that the $10.8 billion rescue package approved by Congress last year will not be enough to cover losses in the savings and loan industry. Early calculations indicate liabilities exceeded assets by $11.6 billion at the end of 1987. [ Page A1. ] Senate conferees will not agree to a trade-bill provision requiring disclosure of U.S. investments by foreigners, despite House Democratic leaders' plea, Senator J. James Exon said. [ D1. ] The operating rate of American industry fell in March for the second consecutive month, to 82.3 percent of capacity. [ D6. ] COMPANIES Irving Bank received a friendly proposal from Italy's second-largest bank to buy 51 percent of its stock. Shareholders are believed to still favor the Bank of New York's bid. Meanwhile, Irving's takeover defense was set back on two legal fronts. [ D1. ] James E. Olson, A.T.&T.'s chairman, died of cancer at 62. Mr. Olson played a key role in reshaping the telecommunications giant following its breakup. [ D30. ] Robert E. Allen, the president and chief operating officer, is expected to succeed him, representing a change in management style but not in direction. [ D1. ] Sears, Roebuck said earnings fell 37.7 percent, hurt by declines in its merchandising, insurance and real estate groups. [ D1. ] Chase Manhattan and Continental Illinois both reported gains. [ D6. ] Apple Computer's profit more than doubled, exceeding expectations, amid strong sales of its Macintosh computer. [ D5. ] An attempt to take control of First City Bancorporation of Texas has apparently run into a new snag. [ D6. ] Home Shopping Network is suing Drexel Burnham and others, accusing them of manipulating the price of its stock. [ D6. ] The Bank of Ireland has agreed to acquire First NH Banks of New Hampshire for $370 million. [ D6. ] Armtek will sell Armstrong Tire to Pirelli, the Italian tire maker, for $190 million. [ D5. ] Pennzoil will acquire a longtime supplier, Facet Enterprises of Tulsa, for $32 a share in cash, or a total of $250 million. [ D5. ] Chrysler officials pledged to tie executive bonuses to workers' profit-sharing plan as negotiations with the U.A.W. began. [ A18. ] MARKETS Stock prices ended narrowly mixed, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing 5.81 points lower, at 2,008.12. [ D8. ] Treasury prices sagged. Investors were scared off by the rise in oil prices and worries about tightening credit. [ D19. ] Crude-oil prices rose in reaction to Persian Gulf hostilities, with West Texas Intermediate finishing at $18.52, up 15 cents. [ D2. ] Gold futures prices rose on expectations of higher oil prices. [ D22. ] The dollar traded in a narrow range, partly as a result of intervention by the Federal Reserve and other central banks. [ D22. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS A champagne's print ads highlight the ever-blurrier line between advertising and editorial matter in various media. [ D26. ] The people in the Rolling Rock beer spots are obviously not actors, and there is a good reason for it. Advertising. [ D27. ] INTERNATIONAL Some Panama banks reopened on a limited basis for the first time since U.S. economic sanctions were imposed. [ D6. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Negotiating with a surgeon over fees can cut medical costs, a Cornell program has found. Four of five doctors contacted have agreed to lower their price. Business and Health. [ D2. ] The high and low figures for the Dow reported in the press after the market closes are not ''real'' but ''theoretical,'' and traders who understand the difference can benefit. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Volvo Recalls 90,000 Cars
description: Volvo of North America is recalling for free repairs 90,000 1983 and early 1984 model cars because they exceed carbon monoxide and hydrocarbon exhaust requirements, the Environmental Protection Agency said today. The cars involved are 1983 and early 1984 Volvo DL and GL models that have 2.3 liter, 4-cylinder fuel-injected engines. The agency said the company agreed to the recall after E.P.A. officials discovered the problems in routine surveillance.

title: John Reardon, 58, Noted Baritone And Champion of Modern Opera
description: John Reardon, an American baritone noted for his championship of contemporary works at the New York City Opera and the Metropolitan Opera - and of opera itself on the children's television show ''Mister Rogers' Neighborhood'' - died Saturday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 58 years old. He died of pneumonia, according to his agent, Ethel Siegel.

title: One More Question
description: Strange people, Americans. We insist on knowing everything about a Presidential candidate except one little item - what people he would put in posts of power to run the country.

title: York Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Arias Eliminated: Jimmy Arias, a finalist last year, lost in the first round of the Monte Carlo Open yesterday. Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia beat the American, 2-6, 6-4, 6-1. Arias had upset Boris Becker of West Germany last year in the second round and advanced to the final only to lose to Mats Wilander of Sweden. But the one-time teen-age sensation has found it rough this year. He has lost five straight first-round matches this season and is now ranked 50th in the world. Smid is ranked 37th. In other matches yesterday, Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands defeated Eric Jelen of West Germany, 6-1, 6-4; Marian Vajda of Czechoslovakia beat Mark Woodforde of Australia, 6-0, 7-5, and Horst Skoff of Austria beat Jan Gunnarsson of Sweden, 6-0, 6-2. (AP)

title: Merrimack Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Unifi Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
The Air Is Bitter to Buoyant as Voting Nears: Michael S. Dukakis; Buoyed by Polls, Governor Senses 'A Great Victory'
description: After days of nail-biting, some of it authentic and some for effect, Michael S. Dukakis and his aides could barely contain their optimism on the eve of the New York primary.

title: Nacco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cuomo's Speech Fees Exceeded His Salary
description: Governor Cuomo made more money last year from making speeches than he did from making policy, according to tax returns that were made public today.

title: North Fork Bancorporation reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Eurobond Stance By Citicorp Unit
description: Citicorp Investment Banks Ltd. has issued a memorandum to its staff reassuring them that it has no intention of withdrawing from the Eurobond market.

title: U.S. Signs a U.N. Document That Seeks an End to Torture
description: The United States today signed a United Nations document deploring torture. The document, known as the Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment, was adopted by the General Assembly in 1984.

title: Opting Out of Hemline Dilemma
description: With the American fall and winter collections now open, it is clear that pants have made a clean sweep of the world's fashion centers. With almost the same enthusiasm that they showed in adopting midthigh skirts just a year ago, designers everywhere have opted for trousers as an all-purpose style for both day and night.

title: Pilots Say Crash Landing Was Unavoidable
description: The pilots of a small commuter plane that burst into flames before crashing into a passenger ramp at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport Friday told investigators late Sunday that the fire erupted so quickly they had little time to make an emergency landing.

title: Temple-Inland Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
New York Area Not Badly Hurt By Stock Plunge
description: Six months after the stock market plunge, the economy of New York City and its suburbs is proving far more resilient than had been expected by economists, business executives and members of the Koch administration.

title: Mike Tyson's Toughest Opponent
description: FOR a world heavyweight champion, winning the title is always the easy part. It's the money and the fame that create problems. Mike Tyson has unified the world heavyweight title. Now he's trying to unify his life.

title: Oce-van der Grinten NV reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The results are in U.S. dollars with the conversion from Dutch florins at Dfl 1.8955 equals U.S. $1.00.

title: Bond Issuer Is Suing Drexel
description: Home Shopping Network Inc. said yesterday that it was suing Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.; Michael Milkin, senior vice president at Drexel, and certain Drexel clients. It accuses them of manipulating the price of its stock to reap large profits from a convertible bond issue.

title: Speakes Says He Told Reagan Of Bogus Quotes, but Later
description: Larry Speakes, the former White House spokesman, said Sunday night that he told President Reagan during the Geneva summit meeting in 1985 that he had fabricated a quotation and attributed it to Mr. Reagan.

title: In Rite of Spring on Great Lakes, Silver Fish Are Focus of Attention
description: On spring nights, pearls of light from lanterns and campfires sparkle along Chicago's dark sea walls and breakwaters as thousands of people wait for a tiny silvery fish to wander into their nets.

title: The Quest for True Randomness Finally Appears Successful
description: ONE of the strangest quests of modern computer science seems to be reaching its goal: mathematicians believe they have found a process for making perfectly random strings of numbers.

title: Goodbye, Narcissism: A Magazine Party
description: New York magazine last night closed an era of narcissism with an evening of self-celebration, devoted to the magazine's 20th anniversary.

title: Science Watch; Update on Icebergs
description: Icebergs seem to be breaking away from the Antarctic ice shelves in abnormally large numbers, and the Government's iceberg watchers are wondering whether the trend may be a harbinger of climate changes to come.

title: DS Bancor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the decline in net income was substantially due to increased legal and other expenses incurred by the company in the initiation and settlement of litigation between DS Bancor and certain stockholders that reduced net income by 14 cents per share.

title: Penn Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Molex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cancer Researchers Seek a Genetic Strategy
description: A SMALL but growing group of cancer researchers is hoping to develop a radically new form of cancer chemotherapy. Instead of looking for ever better ways to kill cancer cells outright, these scientists are seeking to block the genes that make the cells proliferate wildly.

title: Prize Money Up For du Maurier
description: The du Maurier Classic, one of the four major tournaments on the Ladies Professional Golf Association Tour, has increased its prize money by 25 percent this year.

title: Citizens Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Orioles Need a Sudden Break
description: In the ninth inning of the scoreless game, Baltimore's first two batters, Billy Ripken and Eddie Murray, singled, and the pleading, yearning, faithful - beyond everything else, faithful - crowd of 13,625 sensed that finally the Orioles were going to win a game. But Cal Ripken Jr. hit a fly to right field, Larry Sheets grounded out and Rick Schu hit a fly to center.

title: Careers; Summer Jobs in Right Line Hard to Find
description: FOR a college student, a career-related summer job is ideal, but such a job may be harder to find this year, one expert says.

title: Hibernia Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Candlelight Wedding Joins 2 Billionaire Families
description: It was a power wedding. Laura S. Steinberg and Jonathan M. Tisch were married last night at the Central Synagogue in Manhattan in a candlelight ceremony joining two billionaire families that in one generation have carved a place in New York's world of high finance and society.

title: Louise Nevelson, Sculptor, Is Dead at 88
description: Louise Nevelson, a pioneer creator of environmental sculpture who became one of the world's best-known artists, died Sunday evening at her home on Spring Street in Manhattan. She was 88 years old, and had been in poor health for several months.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Home Section last Thursday about reading lamps misidentified the designer of a steel and aluminium lamp that costs $95 at Dot Zero. He is Shiraz Kassamali.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Touchy, Touchy
description: The inventions of Presidential quotes by the former White House press secretary, Larry Speakes, have touched a sensitive chord among Government press aides worried that such fabrications hurt their credibility.

title: IMC Fertilizer Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company went public in February.

title: Court Urged to Allow Trial on Catholic Church's Tax Status
description: A lawyer for several religious groups and other groups supporting abortion rights urged the Supreme Court today to let them proceed with a Federal suit to force the Government to strip the Roman Catholic Church of its tax-exempt status.

title: Archer Daniels Midland Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AIDS Hits Drug Users in Thailand, Panel Told
description: AIDS has gained a foothold in Thailand, spreading among intravenous drug users in recent months, the Presidential AIDS commission was told here today.

title: Britain's Bitter Debate: Will Welfare State Perish?
description: When Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher declared war on welfare spending, Felicity Godden did not think she would wind up as one of the first casualties or, for that matter, as the butt of jokes in the House of Commons.

title: US Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $8,834,000 from an accounting change.

title: American Electric Power Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Iraq Says It Has Recaptured Strategic Peninsula From Iran
description: Iraq said today that its troops recaptured the strategic Fao Peninsula from Iran this afternoon.

title: Union National Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said first quarter operating income was reduced by $808,000 by costs involved in restructuring and consolidation of functions, and an early retirement program. Amortization of purchase accounting adjustments arising from bank acquisitions reduced income by $502,000 for the first quarter of 1988, compared with a $440,000 reduction in year-ago period.

title: Professor Has Key Role In Utility Default Case
description: For two years Junius Hoffman, an Arizona law professor, has been negotiating with some of the nation's shrewdest lawyers with one goal in mind. A mediator appointed by a Federal court, Mr. Hoffman wants to reach settlements that would prevent the securities fraud lawsuit stemming from the $2.25 billion bond default on two Northwest nuclear plants from going to trial in September.

title: Science Watch; Clue to Brain Cell Movement
description: Sperm cells and brain cells use the same enzyme for movement, a recent study has shown.

title: This Time, Knicks Draw Equal Billing
description: The last two times the Chicago Bulls played the Knicks at Madison Square Garden it was before capacity crowds of 19,591. But many of those fans - if not most - were there to see Michael Jordan, the National Basketball Association's top drawing card.

title: United Carolina Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago results restated for a 2-for-1 stock split last September.

title: Campeau's Plans
description: Robert Campeau, chairman and chief executive of the Campeau Corporation, said at a the headquarters of the Rich's unit of his newly acquired Federated Department Stores Inc. that he would leave the management of the 20-story chain in place, but that he might locate a Bloomingdales in the area.

title: Parishioners Turn In Guns At Request of Denver Priest
description: A Roman Catholic priest who urged parishioners to turn in their handguns and sign pledges to fight violence says he will invite other parishes to join his campaign.

title: RTE Rejects Bid Made by Mark IV
description: The RTE Corporation, a Brookfield-based electrical-products maker, rejected Mark IV Industries Inc.'s takeover offer as highly conditional and not in the best interests of its shareholders. The concern said it was reviewing alternatives to the bid such as a sale, leveraged buyout or recapitalization of the company. It also said it had been contacted by other parties about a possible sale of the company or one or more of its operating units.

title: Topics of The Times; Papp's Peak
description: ''Enthusiasm'' is not among the 884,647 words appearing in the works of Shakespeare, according to the hefty Harvard concordance. Joseph Papp, producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, founded in 1954, has filled the void.

title: Unusual Bonus
description: Mike Gottfried, the University of Pittsburgh football coach, signed a long-term guaranteed contract yesterday that the school's athletic director, Edward Bozik, called unique in college football because it would pay a bonus based on the graduation rate of players. Neither Bozik nor Gottfried would disclose the agreement's length or financial terms. Bozik said it contained a bonus for bowl seasons. The Panthers had records of 5-5-1 and 8-4 in Gottfried's first two seasons and lost to Texas, 34-27, in last season's Bluebonnet Bowl.

title: No Actors In Spots for Rolling Rock
description: AS senior writer on the Rolling Rock beer account at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston, Jerry Cronin set out to do a campaign that would capture the warm, manly feeling a neighborhood tavern can inspire after just the right amount of beer.

title: Federal Signal Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bond Prices Sag in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes sagged further in light trading yesterday. Investors were scared off by a sharp rise in oil prices and worries that the Federal Reserve might be about to tighten credit conditions further.

title: Kraft Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $500,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1.2 million and a gain of $45.2 million from an accounting change.

title: Central Banks Act to Stop Rise of Pound Above $1.90
description: The dollar traded in an extremely narrow range yesterday, partly as the result of coordinated intervention by the Federal Reserve and other central banks to keep the British pound from soaring further.

title: DEMOCRATS VOTING IN CRUCIAL PRIMARY IN NEW YORK TODAY
description: After 44 contests elsewhere and a cantankerous two-week campaign in New York, the state's Democrats vote today in a Presidential primary that will determine the shape of the rest of the campaign.

title: What to Do With Social Security Surpluses; Restore Confidence
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Prosecutors Introduce Letter Tying Biaggi to Wedtech Holdings
description: Prosecutors at the Federal racketeering trial of Representative Mario Biaggi introduced into evidence yesterday a letter that referred to the Congressman and his former law partner ''receiving 112,500 shares of stock.''

title: Hospital Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago first quarter results include operations of the 104 hospitals divested by the company in September 1987.

title: P.L.O. Man's Rites to Be Held in Syria
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria offered today to let the funeral of a slain Palestine Liberation Organization leader be held Wednesday in Damascus, a gesture that could help improve severely strained relations between Syria's leader and the P.L.O.

title: War Powers Act: Years of Conflict Over Constitutionality
description: The War Powers Act, adopted by Congress over President Nixon's veto in 1973, was an outgrowth of the Vietnam War, an effort by lawmakers to assert the constitutional authority of Congress to declare war.

title: KUWAIT CALLED ON TO FREE PRISONERS
description: A man identified as one of the three members of Kuwait's royal family held hostage on the hijacked Kuwaiti jetliner said today that he hoped his Government would yield to the gunmen's demands to end the two-week ordeal.

title: Police Shoot Tear Gas At South Africa Pupils
description: The police fired volleys of tear gas today at schoolchildren campaigning for clemency for six condemned blacks.

title: A Foe of Mitterrand Rallies the Right
description: ''If Mitterrand doesn't get 35 percent,'' predicted Interior Minister Charles Pasqua, ''he's cooked.''

title: Warner-Lambert Company reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hussein of Kenya Wins Boston Race
description: After a grueling 26 miles 385 yards, the 92d Boston Marathon today came down to an old-fashioned 100-yard dash.

title: Milan Bank Makes Bid For Irving
description: In a last-minute effort to stave off an unwanted acquisition by the Bank of New York Corporation, the Irving Bank Corporation yesterday announced a friendly proposal by Italy's second-largest bank to buy 51 percent of Irving's stock.

title: Charles (Honi) Coles Wins 1988 Capezio Dance Award
description: Charles (Honi) Coles, a tap dancer known for rapid, elegant footwork, received the 37th annual Capezio Dance Award yesterday afternoon at the Joyce Theater. Made possible by a grant from the Ballet Makers Dance Foundation, the award honors contributions to American dance. Its recipients are chosen by a panel of dancers, choreographers, critics, teachers and producers.

title: Article 073588 -- No Title
description: The Senate gave final legislative approval today to bills appropriating $13.7 million for a wide range of services for the homeless, including shelter and financial and social aid.

title: Rank Plans to Buy Video Duplicator
description: Rank Organization P.L.C. said it had signed a definitive agreement to buy BHCP Video for $90 million cash, and it will also take on BHCP's $22.8 million debt. BHCP Video is jointly owned by the Bell & Howell Company, Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. and Gulf and Western's Paramount Pictures. The concern is a United States video cassette duplicator with plants in Chicago, Los Angeles and a joint venture in Mexico.

title: A.T.&T. President Expected To Succeed to Chief's Post
description: Robert E. Allen, the president and chief operating officer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, is expected to be named its next chief executive, analysts and industry officials said.

title: Connecticut Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Papal Remains Are Stolen
description: Thieves have stolen the remains of a 13th-century Pope, Celestine V, from a church where they were kept in a glass-lidded coffin, the police said today. Nobody has taken responsibility for the robbery, discovered by a nun who spotted the glass lid propped against a wall at the Basilica of Our Lady of Collemaggio in the town of L'Aquila, east of Rome.

title: Crown Cork & Seal Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Amoskeag Bank Shares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
