description: b-Includes securities gains of $1.4 million in the latest quarter and $1.6 million in the year-ago period. The company said 1987 results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for loan fees.

title: INSIDE
description: New Pesticide Charge A Wayne County greenhouse operator is the first person indicted under a new New York law against dumping pesticides where they can harm people. Page B1. Closest Boston Marathon Ibrahim Hussein of Kenya sprinted to a one-second victory, the closest finish in the 92-year history of the men's race. Rosa Mota of Portugal won for the second straight year. Page B9. Devils Lose Playoff Opener The New Jersey Devils lost to the Washington Capitals, 3-1, in the opener of their four-of-seven-game series in the second round of the hockey playoffs. Page B9.

title: Huntington Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter results reflect the adoption of FASB No. 91. Per share earnings are adjusted to reflect the 10 percent stock dividend distributed July 31, 1987, and for the November 1987, acquisition of United Midwest Bancorp Ltd., accounted for as a pooling-of-interests.

title: First Charge In New Law On Pesticides
description: A greenhouse operator today became the first person indicted under a New York law on criminal charges of deliberately dumping pesticides where they could seriously harm people.

title: Two Critics of Science Revel in the Role
description: Two Government scientists who worked in obscurity for most of their careers have emerged as the nation's leading critics of misconduct and error in science.

title: A Hospital Is Fined $40,000 For Its Treatment of a Patient
description: The Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan has been fined $40,000, largely for its treatment of a former patient who killed two people and stabbed nine others on the Staten Island ferry in 1986. The stabbings occurred two days after the patient, Juan J. Gonzalaez, had been released from the hospital's psychiatric emergency room.

title: Birmingham Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Provident Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,024,000 from an accounting change.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Steuben Has New Form of Expression
description: THERE is a whole new look to Steuben advertising, breaking in the May issues of a few select magazines. The ads are in color after years of black and white. And the objects of Steuben crystal now share the photograph with other items - no longer treated as exhibits in a museum.

title: Super Bowl Score: Giants 39, Broncos 20, Cheaters $85,000
description: Fourteen postal employees and three associates in New York City were accused yesterday of using their post-office know-how to win a 1987 Super Bowl ''Pick the Score'' contest.

title: Republic Bancorporation reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ex-Chief of Phelps Dodge Elected a Times Director
description: George B. Munroe was elected to the board of The New York Times Company yesterday at the annual shareholders meeting.

title: The Right Response to Khomeini
description: Based on what's known, Washington appears to have responded correctly to Iran's renewed mining of Persian Gulf sea lanes. The U.S. naval attack on the Iranian oil platforms seems a proportionate response, and it was Teheran's decision to escalate by firing missiles and downing a U.S. helicopter gunship. Only in retaliation did American forces destroy Iranian ships.

title: Potomac Hospitality
description: Some of the curtains have not yet been hung and a few pieces of furniture are missing, but President and Mrs. Reagan are about to get an advance look at Blair House, the President's newly restored official guest house. The historic mansion, which is actually four contiguous houses with 115 rooms and 30 bathrooms, has been closed for two and a half years while undergoing a federally financed $8.6 million restoration.

title: Road to Seoul Starts in Jersey
description: THE Hudson County training sessions began on a Sunday morning in January and have become a ritual for Pat Petersen. While residents in Jersey City were shoveling snow off the sidewalk or going to church, Petersen was spending his Sundays running toward the Olympics.

title: Transworld Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-percent stock dividend declared on March 1, 1988.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly UNITED NATIONS COMMISSION ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW - 10 A.M. Economic and Social Council UNITED NATIONS CHILDREN'S FUND - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Dennison Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $9,802,000 from the sale of an interest in Hygeia Sciences Inc., and an after- tax charge of $7,123,000 from the sale of two wholly owned subsidiaries.

title: Education; Arrests Dishearten Penn State
description: The arrest of students who staged a sit-in over minority issues has cast uncertainty over Pennsylvania State University's efforts to recruit blacks for next fall, officials say.

title: Afghan Rebel Alliance Leader Outlines His Cause
description: In the crucial period that began just before the conclusion of the Geneva agreement on Afghanistan last week and will span the expected beginning of the Soviet troop withdrawal May 15, the political leadership of the guerrilla movement lies in the hands of the man considered the most redoubtable and ambitious of the leaders of the seven-party alliance based here.

title: Vivigen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $48,600.

title: Vacations To Go reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income and the 9 months included a tax credit of $16,000.

title: We May Be Doing Too Much About Panama; Listen to the Latins
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Manhattan Chowder,' Life in the City
description: New York is what it is; it is what it has always been - a place to build up, tear down and then start over again. Its principal product is wealth, unequally apportioned, passionately pursued and in large part the reason for its existence. ''Metro: Manhattan Chowder,'' on Channel 13 at 10:30 tonight, gets it right. The splendid 90-minute documentary shows New York without tears and in all its historic, eccentric purpose.

title: Jackson Troops Say They Won Future
description: Supporters of the Rev. Jesse Jackson hailed his victory in New York City yesterday as a harbinger of a new coalition that could reshape the city's politics in the 1989 mayoral race.

title: Bridge
description: Players can do very well, up to a point, by simply doing the obvious. Routine bids, plays and defenses are nearly always appropriate.

title: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JVC Festival Making Plans to Mine Jazz History
description: Tribute concerts and returning regulars will be featured at the 1988 JVC Jazz Festival, which is to take place June 24 to July 2. The lineup, announced yesterday by its producer, George Wein, and its sponsor, the JVC Company of America, ranges through jazz history, from concerts dedicated to Louis Armstrong to the Latin-jazz pioneer Machito to contemporary jazz and blues.

title: Union Angered by Pay of Top Chrysler Executives
description: Leaders of the United Automobile Workers reacted angrily today to the disclosure that Lee A. Iacocca and other top executives of the Chrysler Corporation collected more than $100 million in salary, bonus, stock options and other payments last year.

title: Dell Reports I.B.M. Clone
description: The Dell Computer Corporation has become the first company to announce it has developed personal computers based on the International Business Machines Corporation's patented Personal System-2 design.

title: Food for the Occasion
description: To The Living Section:

title: Merck & Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Concert; Pinnock and Old Music in New Context
description: There must be something in the air and soil of England that nourishes an interest in old music - or early music, as it is nowadays known more euphemistically though no more precisely. A steady stream of specialists has been produced, beginning with Arnold Dolmetsch, the pioneering instrument builder, and becoming a flood in recent times with such students of the antique as David Munrow, Denis Stevens, Christopher Hogwood, John Eliot Gardiner and Roger Norrington.

title: Sundstrand Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TGI Friday's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
T. Coraghessan Boyle Wins PEN Award
description: T. Coraghessan Boyle has been named the winner of the eighth annual PEN/Faulkner award for fiction for his novel ''World's End'' (Viking), a historical account of three families in New York's Westchester County over three centuries. The $5,000 award will be presented at a ceremony May 14 at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington.

title: Initial Rate Is Set For Floating Notes
description: The initial rate for a $250 million issue of floating-rate notes due in 1991 and priced last week by Great Western Bank, a unit of the Great Western Financial Corporation, through the First Boston Corporation, were set at 7.14063 percent by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets as agent. The rate will be reset each month at the one-month London interbank offered rate or at three-quarters of a percentage point below the 11th District cost of funds, whichever is lower.

title: Gulf War Not Posing a Serious Threat to Oil Supplies, Traders Say
description: The collective wisdom of the international oil market is that the step-up in the hostilities in the Persian Gulf on Monday does not pose a serious threat to oil supplies, oil traders said yesterday.

title: Profits Up At Makers Of Software
description: Buoyed by surging demand for personal computers, the two leading software producers today reported record revenues and strong earnings growth.

title: Chris-Craft Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after a pre-tax charge of $5,650,000 associated with stock appreciation rights.

title: VF Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Piccadilly Cafeterias reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,007,000 from an accounting change.

title: Wells Fargo & Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a provision for loan losses of $75 million and $80 million for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively; includes net loan charge- offs of $55.3 million and $79.7 million for the same periods, respectively. c-Includes about $20.6 million of losses resulting from sales or swaps of developing country cross-border outstandings that were charged against the allowance for loan losses in the first quarter.

title: Campeau Expects To Have Financing
description: The Campeau Corporation said it expects to have financing in place by the end of the week for its $6.6 billion purchase of Federated Department Stores Inc. Campeau also extended its tender offer for all of Federated's shares until April 28. Without the renewal, Campeau's offer to pay $73.50 a share for all of Federated's stock would have expired on Wednesday.

title: Tornado in Florida Leaves 4 Dead and 15 Injured
description: A tornado blasted through this North Florida town before dawn today, destroying several homes and a college library, and leaving four people dead and 15 injured, officials said.

title: Instruction to Chambers Jury on Manslaughter Was Correct
description: To the Editor:

title: Plain Boys, Fancy Girls
description: In 1898, the name New Yorkers were most likely to call their daughters was Mary - plain as any name can be. After Mary came Catherine, Margaret and Annie - equally plain, equally square. In truth there was little snappy about the next six choices either: Rose, Marie, Esther, Sarah, Frances and Ida.

title: Citicorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: All per share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split declared in October 1987.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Becker Loses in First Match: Marian Vajda of Czechoslovakia beat Boris Becker of West Germany, the two-time Wimbledon champion, 6-3, 5-7, 6-1, in yesterday's second round of the Monte Carlo Open. It was the second straight year that Becker had lost his first match at this tournament, the first major event of the clay court season.

title: First Boston Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jackson Masks Disappointment; Lifts Crowd With Hope for Future
description: When he was asked last night how he felt about losing New York to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the Rev. Jesse Jackson's answer was clipped.

title: Ohio Edison Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pact Reached On Skyscraper Built Too Tall
description: A dispute between New York City and the developer who built a mid-Manhattan skyscraper 11 feet too tall has been tentatively settled, with the developer agreeing to construct rehearsal space, cut down parapets and drop his lawsuit against the city.

title: Warsaw Journal; Hero of the Ghetto, Nemesis of 2 Establishments
description: Marek Edelman is an uncomfortable man. For one thing, there is his history. In 1943, when the tide turned against Hitler's armies, and the decision came to raze the Warsaw ghetto, he was the 22-year-old deputy commander of the desperate Jews who challenged German might by taking up arms.

title: Sports People; Full Confidence
description: Eddie Sutton, the head basketball coach at the University of Kentucky, said yesterday that he has full confidence in the integrity of an assistant coach who, according to a newspaper report, sent a package containing $1,000 to the father of a recruit.

title: Philip Morris Companies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Disappointed, Gore Is Taking Stock
description: Struggling to smile in the face of overwhelming defeat, Senator Albert Gore Jr. said last night that he would consult his advisers over the next 24 hours about the future of his Presidential campaign.

title: Ethyl Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rohm & Haas Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Profits Off at Several Wall St. Firms
description: Several of the leading Wall Street firms yesterday reported generally weaker first-quarter earnings, reflecting the stock market's continued sluggishness since the crash of last October.

title: MiniScribe Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $1,124,000 for the latest first quarter and $468,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Drafting Ollie
description: It had to happen, you said.

title: 6 Hurt in Costa Rica; Blast Origin Disputed
description: Two Americans and four Costa Ricans were hurt here today in an explosion at the United States Cultural Center. A Costa Rican Cabinet minister and the American Embassy disagreed on its cause.

title: Auction Rates Up
description: Interest rates were higher at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. The bank holding company said it had sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.961 percent, up from 6.8198 percent last week. It is the highest rate this year and the sixth consecutive increase in the rates of 91-day paper. Citicorp also sold $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 7.05 percent, up from 6.857 percent a week ago.

title: Fed's Heller Finds Little Price Peril
description: E. Robert Heller, a governor of the Federal Reserve, said today that he saw few signs of the kinds of pressures - rising inflation or a sinking dollar - that would persuade the Fed to raise interest rates.

title: Baby Bells Moving Into the Lab
description: RESEARCHERS at the Nynex Corporation, the parent company of New York Telephone and New England Telephone, are developing a telephone that dials a number at when someone speaks to it. They are also writing software that expands the calling range of cellular radio phones.

title: Iraqi Offensive: Victory Goes Beyond Battlefield
description: Iraq's recapture of the Fao Peninsula is a major military and psychological victory for the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, in the view of Pentagon officials.

title: President of Harvard Urges More Instruction on Ethics
description: American higher education must pay more attention to helping students understand how to lead ''ethical, reflective, fulfilling lives,'' says Derek C. Bok, president of Harvard University.

title: American Savings Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Indiana Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Waltham Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company attributed the decrease in net income primarily to a reduction in gains on sales of securities.

title: When Development Becomes Divisive
description: When Pepsico and the International Business Machines Corporation began building offices in neighboring Somers a few years ago, this rural town at the top of Westchester County started considering ways to ward off developers.

title: Eva Novak Dies at 90; Starred With Tom Mix
description: Eva Novak, an actress who starred as Tom Mix's love interest in 10 of his westerns and did her own stunts as well, died of pneumonia on Sunday at the Motion Picture Country Hospital in Los Angeles. She was 90 years old.

title: First Federal of Western Pennsylvania reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a writeoff of $220,000 for a FSLIC secondary reserve investment.

title: Armstrong Offers 9 3/4% Debentures
description: Armstrong World Industries, a manufacturer of interior furnishing and building products, is offering $125 million of 9 3/4 percent debentures due in 2008 at a price of 99.558 to yield 9.80 percent through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: Champion International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
College Rejections Abound
description: In a spring of turmoil, even many top students have not been accepted by any school. Page B11.

title: Economic Scene; What Makes A City Livable?
description: PITTSBURGH, says the 1987 edition of the Rand McNally Places Rated Almanac, is America's most livable city. Yuba City, Calif., faulted for its unfluoridated water, mediocre schools and paucity of restaurants starred by the Mobil Guide, comes in dead last.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Feb. 15, about the use of libraries by children whose parents cannot find day care, described the visits of two children to a Dallas library incompletely. Katie Morgan, 6 1/2 years old, and her sister Amy, who is 9, are not left alone daily in the library as a substitute for day care; their mother, Kay Morgan, leaves them after school periodically to choose books while she takes a younger daughter elsewhere to avoid disturbing others. Thus it is not correct that Katie might be called a ''latchkey child''; the term was coined in the Depression, when many children who went home alone wore house keys around their necks.

title: United Financial Banking reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the provision for loan losses totaled $77,500; there was no similar amount a year ago.

title: 'Were in Our Own Sight as Grasshoppers'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Banned From Track
description: Bill Green, the hammer thrower from the United States who tested positive for drugs at the Pan American Games last year, and Luis Morales, a sprinter from Puerto Rico, have been banned from international competition for two years, track and field's governing body announced yesterday in London.

title: Lawsuits Over Law Research
description: Over a century ago, Henry Wheaton and Richard Peters fought in a celebrated case for the right to be the reporter of the United States Supreme Court's decisions. Now the modern-day equivalent of the Wheaton-Peters fight is playing itself out in a bitter feud between the two largest computerized research services used by lawyers, judges and academics: Lexis and Westlaw.

title: Roger Rosenblatt Changing Magazines
description: Roger Rosenblatt, a senior writer at Time magazine since 1980, is to leave that magazine on May 1 to write for U.S. News & World Report and The Atlantic.

title: Fugitives Drawing Viewers
description: Real life and television melodrama have combined to give the Fox Broadcasting Company a potential hit program. In its first 10 weeks on the air, ''America's Most Wanted'' has prompted the capture of six fugitives, two of them in New York City.

title: DANES CALL A VOTE ON A NUCLEAR BAN
description: Prime Minister Poul Schluter today called an election for May 10 in which he said voters should ''take a stand'' on Denmark's full partnership in NATO.

title: Introducing Bach, and Others, Behind Bars
description: ''Hold it down!'' barked a guard.

title: Wanted: Writer-Companion To Be a Member of the Family
description: FOR perhaps the first time in his 88 years, Andrew Knickerbocker is lonely. His children are grown and leading their own lives. His oil business has been closed since the last of his wells dried up two years ago. His wife, Hazel, who is 82 years old, is in ill health, often forgetting where she is and what she was saying.

title: Schools in New York Urged To Care For Teachers Better
description: New York City must make extensive changes in the way it hires and treats teachers if it hopes to overcome a teacher shortage, an independent task force has concluded.

title: Israel Deports 8 From West Bank Tied to Violence
description: Israel deported eight more Palestinians to southern Lebanon today, including six from the West Bank village where a teen-age Israeli girl died during a clash between settlers and Palestinians.

title: T. Coraghessan Boyle Wins PEN Award
description: T. Coraghessan Boyle has been named the winner of the eighth annual PEN/Faulkner award for fiction for his novel ''World's End'' (Viking), a historical account of three families in New York's Westchester County over three centuries. The $5,000 award will be presented at a ceremony May 14 at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington.

description: b-Restated to include a cumulative chare of $675,000 from an accounting change.

United Telecommunications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said its portion of the first quarter loss of its US Sprint joint venture with GTE Corp. was $46.1 million, compared with $63.1 million in the year-ago quarter.

title: Grumman to Build Facility in Houston
description: The Grumman Corporation reaffirmed that it would create a production center here, bringing an estimated 1,500 jobs to the Houston area. The company's decision to build the facility had been in doubt since December, when Grumman lost its bid to build a major part of the proposed space station.

title: Panel Suggests Replacement For Dr. Gross
description: A special advisory board has unanimously recommended that Mayor Koch appoint Dr. Charles S. Hirsch, the Suffolk County Medical Examiner, to be the New York City Chief Medical Examiner, city officials said last night.

title: Puritan-Bennett Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Stacey King, Oklahoma's 6-foot-10-inch center, said yesterday that he would remain in school next season instead of trying his luck in the National Basketball Association draft. ''I strongly believe it is very important for me to get my degree,'' said King, who averaged 22 points a game to lead the Sooners. ''I also think it would be selfish on my part to leave my teammates earlier than expected.'' . . . With 2,297 runs batted in during his career, Hank Aaron holds the record for r.b.i.'s. Now Major League Baseball will present the Hank Aaron Award to the r.b.i. leaders in each league at the conclusion of each season. This is the third year for the award, but the first time it has been presented solely by Major League Baseball. . . . Joan Zekala of Rye, N.Y., has been named the United States Tennis Association's director of men's professional tennis. Zekala had been the U.S.T.A.'s national circuits administrator.

title: Freeport to Pay More to Williams
description: Freeport-McMoRan Resource Partners, which bought the Agrico Chemical Company's assets from the Williams Companies of Tulsa, Okla., for $250 million in cash in 1987, said today that, based on Agrico's high earnings, it would pay an additional $250 million.

title: Cornerstone Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $131,649 from the buyback of subordinated debentures.

title: 76ers Retire Dr. J's No. 6
description: The Philadelphia 76ers retired Julius Erving's No. 6 jersey tonight in a lavish ceremony during which basketball's third-leading scorer received gifts and was toasted by Commissioner David Stern for having set the standard.

title: Democrats Warn on Veto
description: Democratic leaders in Congress warned today that Congress might reject legislation putting the United States-Canada free trade agreement into effect if President Reagan vetoed the trade bill.

title: Sotheby's Stock Plan
description: Sotheby's, the renowned auction house, said yesterday that it had restructured its planned initial stock issue and would offer the public only 22 percent of the company. Sotheby's had said before the stock market crash in October that it would sell 29 percent.

title: Professional Women Do Go Home Again
description: CAREN CAMP of Middleburg, Va., a 35-year-old cosmetics executive, was a highly motivated career woman when she left her job in 1986 to concentrate on rearing her infant son. Carolyn Brown, 38, was a high-ranking manager for A.T.&T in Washington when she quit in 1987 to devote more time to her two children.

title: Review/Concert; South African Esprit
description: With South Africa constantly in the news and South African music reaching its largest international audience ever, Monday's concert at Radio City Music Hall promised to be a celebration of black South African culture and spirit. It featured two South African expatriates, the singer Miriam Makeba and the trumpeter Hugh Masekela, along with the cast of the South African musical ''Sarafina!'' But while the performers' political statements drew fervent ovations, poor pacing and the expatriates' choice of internationalized music weakened the concert. A video clip in which Miss Makeba, an underground heroine in South Africa, met the young cast members of ''Sarafina!'' cast for the first time, with tears and songs, had more impact than the live parts of the concert.

title: Monsanto Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: Leftist guerrillas appear to have hardened their tactics in recent days by killing a mayor and two other civilians and warning that they will attack other civilian targets.

The charge is that they spread ''false and defamatory'' information to the press and to former clients.

description: Gathering last night at Georgetown University's Intercultural Center was an unusual collection of wanderers from the American political landscape, commemorating the 20th anniversary of the beginning of Eugene J. McCarthy's maverick Presidential campaign.

description: George C. Riegger, chairman of the Precision Adhesives Corporation of Perth Amboy, N.J., and of Adhesive and Chemical Inc., of Yatesville, Pa., died Sunday at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Little Silver, N.J.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Rule Religious Rights Can't Block Road
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the Government's plan to develop part of a national forest in California that is sacred to three Indian tribes, even though it acknowledged the project ''could have devastating effects on traditional Indian religious practices.'' The vote was 5 to 3.

description: The space agency says it will ask contractors this summer to submit proposals for a $1.2 billion program to design and build an advanced booster rocket for the space shuttle in a plant to be owned by the Government.

title: Morgan Library, in an Expansion, Is Buying a Neighboring Mansion
description: The Pierpont Morgan Library, one of the world's foremost centers for research in literature, art and music, is buying the 45-room brownstone mansion just to the north and will roughly double in size, the library announced yesterday.

description: A man who the police said had just robbed a bank was shot in the head yesterday by a bank guard who chased him into a midtown subway station.

title: Pacific Telesis Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said latest first quarter revenue was reduced to reflect the April 13 California Public Utilities Commission decision on Pacific Bell's latest attrition filing, which the company must file to adjust telephone rates so they reflect current economic conditions. It said the decision reduced Pacific Bell's annual revenue requirement by $64.9 million. Pacific Telesis said that as a result of a C.P.U.C. decision to reduce telephone rates retroactive to March 1986, first quarter 1987 share earnings are restated to 55 cents from 62 cents. Pacific Telesis Group said about 5 cents of the 1987 first quarter reduction was an out-of-period adjustment to reduce 1986 share earnings. In addition, 1987 balances have been restated to reflect the consolidation of majority-owned subsidiaries previously accounted for under the equity method.

title: Late Selling Ends Rally; Dow Falls 8.62, to 1,999.50
description: LEAD: A late selling wave wiped out what had started as a sturdy Wall Street rally yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 1,999.50, off 8.62 points. Earlier in the session, the Dow was ahead by more than 30 points.

description: Intermark Inc. said it had hired Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to explore the possible sale of Pier 1 Imports Inc., which has received several unsolicited takeover inquiries in the last two months. Pier 1, based in Fort Worth, operates 400 stores specializing in imported home furnishings in 37 states.

title: Guatemala Detains 2 Exiles As They Return on Brief Visit
description: Two prominent Guatemalan exiles were arrested and interrogated this week as they returned to their homeland for a planned one-week visit.

description: Vice President Bush recently pressured Labor Department officials to let companies avoid the expense of ventilating toxic gases from workplaces, two Government scientists told the Senate Labor Committee today.

title: AT THE NATION'S TABLE: SEATTLE
description: LEAD: IT'S simple to wax eloquent about fresh and local ingredients as the basis of great cooking when the restaurant is in California. There, one growing season blends with another like faces in a crowd. But move that restaurant to the Pacific Northwest, and all mentions of ''fresh and local'' die down about the time of the first frost, when the basil turns black.

description: State marine biologists plan to salt the waters off the Florida Keys this summer with 10,000 baby queen conchs. The goal is a queen conch population, which dwindled in the Keys because of overharvesting in recent years, large enough to allow private and commercial fishermen to begin harvesting once more.

description: * Apple Canada Inc., Markham, Ontario, a unit of Apple Computer Inc., said it will invest $56 million Canadian ($46 million American) in Quebec in the next three years.

title: L. S. Reiss Dies at 94; Painter of Jewish Life
description: Lionel S. Reiss, a painter known for his interpretations of Jewish life, died last Saturday at his home on Central Park West in Manhattan. He was 94 years old, and had been in poor health since last fall.

Langway Out Indefinitely
description: Rod Langway, the Washington Capitals' captain, the anchor of their defensive corps and the team's only player with Stanley Cup championship experience, will miss the remainder of the team's playoff series with the Devils. The 30-year-old defenseman suffered a gash to the calf of his left leg after he was hit by the skate blade of Pat Verbeek of New Jersey in the third period of the Capitals' 3-1 victory Monday night.

title: JACKSON FAR AHEAD OF GORE, WHO MAY QUIT
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis took a major stride toward the Democratic Presidential nomination yesterday by soundly defeating the Rev. Jesse Jackson in the New York primary and driving Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee into a poor third-place finish.

title: ITT President Quits; Replacement Named
description: Edmund M. Carpenter, the ITT Corporation's president, who was relieved of some operating duties last November in a management shake-up, resigned from the company. ITT said yesterday that DeRoy C. Thomas, 62 years old, had been named both as president and as chief operating officer.

title: Music Noted in Brief; A Duo Piano Recital By Moon and Lee
description: Yong Hi Moon and Dai Uk Lee, pianists on the faculty of Michigan State University who have been playing as a duo for over a decade, gave their first New York recital at Merkin Concert Hall Saturday evening. The first half of the program offered four-hand works of Schubert (the ''Grand Rondeau,'' Op. 107), Mozart (Sonata in F, K. 497) and Byung Dong Paik (''Memorandum on a Line,'' a short piece in fragmented Webernian textures). After intermission came two-piano pieces by Martinu (''Three Czech Dances'') and Ravel (''La Valse'').

title: Review/Dance; Ballet Theater Opens Season With 2 Premieres
description: Another opening, another show. Fortunately, that is not an adage that applies to ballet, which operates within the repertory system. Anyone appraising, for example, American Ballet Theater - which opened Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House - would judge it not by a single program but on its overall artistic profile, its entire season, even the ghosts of seasons past.

title: Meridian Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter is restated to include the results of Delaware Trust Co., acquired in the latest first quarter and accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Marines Dismiss 2 Women
description: Two women have been dismissed from the Marine Corps as a result of a continuing investigation of lesbianism at the Marine Corps Recruit Training Depot. The women, whose names were not disclosed, were given honorable discharges, Maj. Robert McLean, the depot's public affairs officer, said Monday.

title: Hitchcock's 'Suspicion' Is Updated
description: Baffling. That's one word for television's curious habit of tinkering with film classics. In the last several months, we have been treated to mediocre remakes of ''Roman Holiday'' and ''Red River.'' Tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13, ''American Playhouse'' has somehow gotten involved in presenting a new version of ''Suspicion,'' the 1941 Alfred Hitchcock thriller that won an Academy Award for Joan Fontaine and new career opportunities for Cary Grant. Now we get Jane Curtin, Anthony Andrews, on-location shooting in England's Cornwall and, of course, color instead of mere black and white. The result is not dreadful, precisely, merely pointless.

title: Giants Seek Best Athletes
description: The Giants' first-round choice in the National Football League draft next Sunday will be an offensive tackle. Or maybe a running back. And don't rule out a pass-rushing defensive lineman or even a defensive back.

title: Paul L. Freeman Jr., 80, Is Dead; Infantry Commander in Two Wars
description: Gen. Paul Lamar Freeman Jr., an infantry commander in World War II and the Korean War, died of a heart ailment Sunday at Community Hospital in Monterey, Calif. He was 80 years old.

title: France's Main Parties Seek to Exploit Le Pen
description: The issue of anti-immigrant racism has pushed its way to the heart of the French presidential campaign, enhancing the political weight of the extreme-right National Front.

title: Education; Lessons
description: Never mind the myopic drive for success, the contempt for the ''useless'' liberal arts or the widespread belief that knowledge is a commodity bought for the price of high tuition and fees. None of these notions are quite as sobering as the one found in a recent sampling of undergraduates on the Rutgers University campus here. To wit: honesty is a sign of immaturity or, put as a proposition, if the opportunity presents itself, a student would be a fool not to cheat.

title: Hawks Hand Nets 14th Straight Loss
description: The Nets have been the most consistent team recently in the Eastern Conference, where everyone else has been scrambling for playoff positions and playoff spots. And they kept it up tonight as they lost for the 14th consecutive time.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Jayn Rosenfeld Offers A Flute Recital
description: Jayn Rosenfeld plays principal flute in several orchestras in New York and New Jersey, and has been giving recitals here since 1970. Her latest solo outing was Sunday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, where she played an inventive and interesting program, with only two warhorses (sonatas by Bach and Prokofiev) among the novelties. Moreover, in both the new and the familiar works, she played with considerable polish, often producing a tone of uncommon beauty.

Jesse Jackson overwhelmed the New York Democratic Presidential primary, conceded last night that his combative tactics had not helped his choice in the race, Senator Albert Gore Jr. ''There's no sense in rehashing the battle, and I think that the exit polls show that, 2 to 1, people did not like my criticisms of Jackson,'' Mr. Koch said.

For 1986, the company earned $146.4 million, or $2.18 a share.

title: Volvo Recalls 90,000 Cars
description: Volvo of North America is recalling 90,000 1983 and early 1984 model cars for free repairs because they exceed carbon monoxide and hydrocarbon exhaust requirements, the Environmental Protection Agency said Monday. The cars involved are 1983 and early 1984 Volvo DL and GL models that have 2.3 liter, 4-cylinder fuel-injected engines. The agency said the company agreed to the recall after E.P.A. officials discovered the problems in routine surveillance.

description: ''My friends, in Iowa we won the bronze, in New Hampshire we won a gold, and tonight we won the Oscar.'' - Michael S. Dukakis

title: AT THE NATION'S TABLE: SHELBYVILLE, KY.
description: FOR serious country suppers, Kentuckians regularly head for the Claudia Sanders Dinner House in Shelbyville, just off Interstate 64 about 20 miles east of Louisville.

title: Curtice-Burns Foods reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
N.H.L. Playoffs; Oilers Beat Flames In Opener by 3-1
description: Jari Kurri's goal with 6 minutes 37 seconds remaining broke a 1-1 tie and Wayne Gretzky added a breakaway goal to give the Edmonton Oilers a 3-1 victory over the Calgary Flames tonight in the opening game of the Smythe Division finals.

title: We May Be Doing Too Much About Panama
description: To the Editor:

description: b-Includes a gain of $763,000. Per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: A Buoyant Dukakis Offers Conciliation and Criticism
description: Michael S. Dukakis, savoring a resounding victory in New York's Democratic Presidential primary, took his cue from the song last night and declared, ''I love New York.''

title: AT THE NATION'S TABLE: AUSTIN, TEX.
description: IF you are anywhere near Austin next weekend and are very, very hungry, there will be enough food to sate even the heartiest appetite at the third annual Texas Hill Country Food and Wine Festival.

title: Retro-Food: Taste of Nostalgia
description: RETRO-FOOD, the essence of soigne New York of 40 years ago, will be served at the Rainbow Room on Sunday night. Guests at the benefit for Citymeals-on-Wheels, which provides food for the homebound elderly, will dine on dishes of legendary New York restaurants, most of them now closed.

title: Teen-Agers Invade the Kitchen; Not Even Shopping Is Safe
description: ONCE or twice a week, 15-year-old Jenna Bateman of Pittsburgh makes dinner for her family because her parents arrive home from work too late or too tired to cook. ''Sometimes after a long day, I don't feel like doing it either,'' Miss Bateman said. ''But it doesn't usually bother me.''

title: Futures Firms to Merge
description: Three Chicago futures and options firms announced this week that they would merge into LIT America Inc., a subsidiary of LIT Holdings P.L.C. of London. The merger of the three firms - Shatkin Trading Company, the Goldberg Organization and Rialcor-Shatkin - will become effective June 1, with the result that LIT America will then have more than 750 employees and a capitalization of more than $60 million for trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board Options Exchange as well as on the major stock exchanges.

title: Childcraft Bought By Walt Disney
description: The Walt Disney Company said it had acquired the Childcraft Education Corporation from Grolier Inc. for $52 million, a move that will significantly expand Disney's mail-order business. Disney also said it plans to add 10 East Coast stores to its fledgling retail operation, which now operates three stores that are not on amusement-park grounds.

title: Rights Group Criticizes Military in Colombia
description: Amnesty International accused Colombia's armed forces today of conducting a campaign of terror and political murder.

title: Lebanese Held by West Germany Convicted in Beirut Hostage Case
description: One of two Lebanese brothers charged in West Germany with terrorist acts was found guilty today and sentenced to 13 years in prison - more than the prosecution had sought - for taking two Germans hostage in Beirut.

description: The Rev. Al Sharpton said tonight that Tawana Brawley would tell what happened to her during a four-day disappearance , either through a Federal prosecutor or through news organizations, within the next 10 days.

description: Peter Serkin has canceled his piano recital this Sunday at Alice Tully Hall because of tendinitis. Refunds are available at the Alice Tully Hall box office or by mail.

description: Although a number of hard-cover publishers in New York turned thumbs down on ''Fire Arrow,'' the novel by a Connecticut financial consultant about a hijacked American aircraft forced down in Libya, paperback rights to the novel have been acquired at auction by Fawcett Books for $600,000.

description: The New York City program to renovate apartments for the homeless is so mismanaged that completed units are often left with holes in the walls, leaky plumbing and missing gas pipes, according to an audit by the city's Comptroller.

description: Facing tough questions from financial analysts after Monday's report of a 37.7 percent decline in profit, executives of Sears, Roebuck & Company laid out plans today to improve profits at its troubled merchandise group by setting up appliance and home electronics ''superstores.''

title: Accountant Testifies That Biaggi Sought Control of Wedtech Shares
description: A former accountant for Representative Mario Biaggi testified yesterday that the Congressman had sought his advice on how he could receive Wedtech stock and retain some control over it without violating the limit on outside earnings for members of the House of Representatives.

title: China Reinvents Itself
description: Deputy Mayor Zi Quo Rui put it flatly. ''We can't wait any longer, the gap is widening with the coastal zones.'' Kunming, capital of Yunnan province in the southwest just above the border with Vietnam and Laos, is not part of the special zones favored for rapid economic development, and it minds.

title: Record Price for a Jewel
description: A pear-shaped D-flawless diamond weighing 85.91 carats was sold for $9.13 million last night at Sotheby's to an unidentified buyer. It was a record price at auction for a jewel. The previous record, $6.38 million, was paid last October at Christie's for a 64.8-carat D-flawless diamond.

title: Metropolitan Federal Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest third quarter's net is after a $2,450,000 provision for possible loan losses, a $1,850,000 increase over the amount provided in the same quarter a year ago.

title: Toni Frissell, 81, Dies; A Noted Photographer
description: Toni Frissell, a photographer, died of Alzheimer's disease Sunday in the St. James (L.I.) Nursing Home. She was 81 years old and lived in St. James.

title: Germantown Savings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $688,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $897,000. The company converted to a stock savings bank in April 1987.

title: About New York; An Artist at 91: Her First Show Outside the Deli
description: It was all quiet out in Iowa yesterday, according to Atlanta Constance Sampson, who misses New York but isn't ambulatory enough to live here anymore. Ms. Sampson is a 91-year-old artist who just moved back home to Toeterville, thereby raising the town's population to 71. She left her paintings and watercolors behind, however, a lifetime's work, and next month she is to have her first one-woman show here - her first show anywhere, for that matter.

title: CRIME RATE IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Reported felonies by police precinct in 1985 and 1986, and five years of total felonies.

description: Senator Sam Nunn, the chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said today that the Senate might have to attach an amendment to the treaty on intermediate-range arms making it clear that it will also apply to future weapons built with new technology.

description: A Bergen County suburb was denied permission in a preliminary ruling to withdraw its students from a predominantly black and Hispanic high school in a neighboring town, on the ground that the withdrawal would increase segregation and produce a sense of racial isolation and inferiority at the school.

title: Rodney L. Cool, 68, Experimental Physicist

In a meeting this week sponsored by The Stanford Review, a conservative student journal, he called the decision an unenlightened and unfortunate ''capitulation to a campaign of pressure politics and intimidation.''

The Minneapolis investor Irwin Jacobs last month announced plans to take Minstar private for $29 a share and sell its energy and sports products divisions. No deals have yet been made for the sports companies, which make tennis, golf and ski equipment.

description: The House of Representatives today approved a bill renewing Federal education programs over the next five years. The vote was 397 to 1. Senate approval, and signing by President Reagan, are expected swiftly, with both parties planning to use education as a major election-year campaign issue.

title: Study of Chrysler Bonuses Demanded by U.A.W.
description: Reacting to bonuses of $102 million paid to top executives of the Chrysler Corporation, the United Automobile Workers demanded today that executive compensation be included in any study of how to improve the corporation's productivity. And the union's leaders hinted that the bonuses might force them to press for a bigger pay increase for their members.

title: Aftermath of Insanity Plea
description: A study of criminal defendants found not guilty by reason of insanity and turned over to an outpatient program in Los Angeles has found that nearly one-third of them were arrested again, most on charges of violent crimes.

Review/Concert; Gospel Family's Harmonies And Homilies
description: By the third song of its set at the Apollo Theater on Friday night, the pop and gospel group the Winans had the audience on its feet. ''Everybody say 'real,' '' shouted Marvin Winans, the group's extraordinary and charismatic lead singer, to which the audience responded with a gusty, canyon-sized ''real.'' ''Everybody say 'real to me,' '' he continued. ''Real to me,'' the audience sang, gorgeously harmonized, as if it had been hired as a chorus.

title: A Scholar Traces 'Lost' Literature Of Black Women in America
description: In 1772, an 18-year-old slave named Phillis Wheatley faced 18 white men who referred to themselves as ''the most respectable characters in Boston.'' The men - among them John Hancock and the Governor and Lieutenant Governor of Massachusetts -interrogated Miss Wheatley to assure themselves that she had, indeed, written a book of poetry.

title: Joseph Nerenberg, Executive, 76
description: Joseph Nerenberg, founder and retired president of the Webster Wall Paper Company in the Bronx, died Friday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center after a coronary seizure. He was 76 years old and lived in Yonkers and Deerfield Beach, Fla.

The restated 1987 quarter has been reduced by 3 cents a share to reflect an FASB required accounting change at ITT Financial Corp. adopted Jan. 1, 1988. The year-ago quarter also included a charge of $67 million for the prior years' effect of an accounting change at ITT Defense Technology. This charge was reported in December 1987 and is required to be reflected in the first quarter results. ITT said its total revenue for the latest first quarter included insurance and finance revenue of $2.9 billion, compared with $2.6 billion, for the year-ago period.

title: What Jesse Jackson Has Won

He told his supporters: ''We must have healing, we must have hope.'' Then, without bitterness, he congratulated Michael Dukakis for a campaign that was ''credible and decent, with dignity above the fray.''

title: Omaha Council Picks Mayor
description: City Councilman Walt Calinger became the 45th Mayor of Omaha today, succeeding Bernie Simon, who died of cancer last Thursday. The City Council selected the 48-year-old lawyer over Council President Fred Conley, who had contended he would not be chosen because he is black. The vote was 4 to 3. Mr. Calinger was sworn in immediately and pledged to work for increased prosperity while serving the remaining 14 months of a four-year term. Mr. Simon was chosen Mayor by the Council in February 1987 after Mayor Mike Boyle was recalled from office.

title: INSIDE
description: Is Gorbachev Rival Fading?

title: MOZAMBICANS FLED REBELS, U.S. SAYS
description: The State Department issued a report today asserting that hundreds of thousands of civilians fled from Mozambique in the last two years after being subjected to brutality and violence by rebels trying to overthrow the Marxist Government.

title: House Passes an Extension of Amnesty Deadline for Illegal Aliens
description: The House voted narrowly today to extend to Nov. 30 the deadline for illegal aliens to apply for legal status. The current amnesty deadline is May 4.

Metro Datelines; 1 Killed and 5 Injured In Blaze in Brooklyn
description: One woman died and five children were critically injured in a fire last night that swept through the top two floors of a four-story apartment building in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn, officials said.

title: Net Rises 15% at Dun & Bradstreet
description: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, the business information, publishing and marketing services company, said yesterday that its net income rose 15 percent in the first quarter.

description: Iris and B. Gerald Cantor have given grants totaling $3.3 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Jackson's Parting Shot for New York
description: Before he boarded a train this afternoon for the City of Brotherly Love, the Rev. Jesse Jackson offered a few comments about New York, a city of ''division and diversion.''

Vote by Assembly District
Court Upholds Rights of Unions To Use Handbills Urging Boycotts
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that Federal labor law allowed a union to distribute literature at the entrances to a shopping mall urging consumers to boycott the retailers in the mall as long as a nonunion construction contractor was being used by one of them.

Jane Lehman, 55; Active in Philanthropy
description: Jane Bagley Lehman, an investor and businesswoman who was active in philanthropy, died of lung cancer Monday in San Francisco, where she lived. She was 55 years old. Ms. Lehman, a granddaughter of R. J. Reynolds, the tobacco company founder, was born in Greenwich, Conn., and attended the Knox School in Cooperstown, N.Y., and the Carnegie-Mellon Institute. She was the former wife of S. A. Long, the prominent yachtsman, and of Orin Lehman, New York State Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation.

title: Nicholas S. Nicholas, Coffee Wholesaler, 55
description: Nicholas S. Nicholas, a partner in Coffee Associates, a major coffee wholesaler, died of prostate cancer Sunday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Review/Piano; Evening of French Works
description: Frank Daykin, a pianist, played works by Mozart, Schubert, Liszt and a handful of French composers at his debut recital on Saturday evening at Weill Recital Hall, and it was in the French music that he was most fluent. The performance that made the firmest impression was of Ravel's ''Valses Nobles et Sentimentales'' - a decadent twirl around the ballroom, which Mr. Daykin played with vivid but not exaggerated contrasts.

title: Steel Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that during the latest quarter it changed its inventory valuation method from LIFO to FIFO; it also said that if the LIFO method had been used, earnings would have been reduced $479,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter, and $570,000, or 8 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: Micro D Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Koch and Fallout From the Primary
description: This time, Mayor Koch's special brand of belligerence, so familiar to New Yorkers but such a curiosity to the rest of the country, may have hurt not just the Mayor, but also the city he professes to put above all else, in the view of many political leaders.

title: Lucky Holds Talks
description: Lucky Stores Inc., the target of a tender offer of $45 a share, or $1.7 billion, from the American Stores Company, said it had held acquisition talks with other unidentified parties and was also considering a leveraged buyout. Lucky, based in Dublin, Calif., had previously rejected American's offer as inadequate, even when its suitor promised last month to sweeten its bid to $50 a share. In response, Lucky said it was considering a number of unspecified alternatives. Shares of Lucky rose 50 cents, to $53.75, on the New York Stock Exchange today. American's stock fell 87.5 cents, to $58.125, on the Big Board.

title: F.D.I.C. to End Guarantees
description: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that his agency would end guarantees to the creditors and shareholders of the parent holding companies of failed banks.

title: Transportation Dept. Linked To Delays in Air Safety Rules
description: Donald D. Engen, former head of the Federal Aviation Administration, accused the Department of Transportation today of having a plodding rule-making process that he likened to ''a maddening shell and pea game.''

title: STEALTH BOMBER DUE TO FLY IN FALL
description: After a decade of secrecy about the project, the Air Force released a drawing of the Stealth bomber today and said the plane would make its first test flight this fall.

title: Turmoil Is Reported in Iran; Iraqi Air Raids Add to Mood
description: Iran's clashes with American naval forces this week came at a time of turmoil in Iran because of parliamentary elections, disputes over economic policy and sustained Iraqi bombings of Teheran and other cities.

title: Goodrich Stake Held by Goldsmith
description: The British financier Sir James Goldsmith has acquired a stake in the B. F. Goodrich Company but is not interested in a takeover, Goodrich said. Goodrich issued a statement in response to a report published in USA Today that at least one corporate raider, and possibly two, had acquired stakes in Goodrich.

description: LLADRO, one of the world's best-known producers of porcelain figurines, is erecting a museum of porcelain at 43 West 57th Street, to open sometime in September.

title: Review/Dance; Classical Parisians' Modern Offshoot
description: Three years ago, the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C., presented the United States debut of an exceptionally talented group of dancers from the Paris Opera.

title: George Williams, Musical Arranger, 71
description: George Williams, a musician known for his violin arrangements for the Jackie Gleason television show and for a number of major bands, died Sunday. He was 71 years old.

description: The Pirelli family is tightening its grip on its huge Italian-Swiss tire and cables group in a complex restructure that analysts say will almost completely protect it from takeovers.

title: Financing Planned For Utah Housing
description: The Utah Housing Finance Agency is tentatively offering $48 million of single-family mortgage senior bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. More than half of the financing is subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax for certain individuals.

Algeria Says Hijackers Won Deal Apparently Allowing Safe Retreat
description: The gunmen who hijacked a Kuwait Airways jumbo jet were apparently allowed safe passage out of Algeria today under an agreement that freed the 31 remaining hostages and ended a 15-day siege.

title: Parking Update, Overdue
description: Praise the Automobile Club of New York for dropping its opposition to state legislation required to increase parking fines in New York City. The present cap of $50 was set 18 years ago. Since then, inflation has diluted much of the deterrent effect. Parking lots now charge as much as $12 an hour, encouraging many drivers to risk parking in no-standing zones. Those scofflaws inflict disproportionate inconvenience. A single illegally parked car may cause traffic to back up for blocks.

title: Books for Deaf Find a Wider Market
description: One of the nation's youngest university presses publishes fiction for young adults, offers an anthology of short stories by Dickens, Welty and Turgenev featuring characters who are deaf, and this summer will publish a book by a deaf woman in her 60's who recently traveled unaccompanied throughout China.

description: Senior aides to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d who have resigned in recent weeks. Deputy Attorney General: Resigned March 29 Arnold I. Burns leaves Saturday. Boykin Rose Gregory S. Walden Associate Attorney General: Left April 15 Stephen S. Trott took a Federal judgeship in California. Two of his senior staff also left. title: Care and Feeding Of Two Shortstops
description: ONE shortstop isn't even hitting .200 and he's also dropped a pop fly that nearly cost the Mets a game. But as a 23-year-old rookie, Kevin Elster is the Mets' shortstop now and their shortstop of the future. The other shortstop is finally playing again for the Yankees after having been benched and belittled for dropping a double-play toss that was hardly the major mistake in a 17-9 loss. Less than three weeks into the season, it's as if 30-year-old Rafael Santana is already the Yankees' shortstop of the past.

title: Spear, Leeds's Allegheny Push
description: The New York brokerage firm Spear, Leeds & Kellogg said today that it would wage a proxy fight for three seats on the board of directors of Allegheny International Inc. at the company's annual meeting on May 20.

title: NATO Talks Shift to Brussels As Danes Call Vote on A-Arms
description: The Danish Government said today that NATO nuclear planning talks scheduled for next week would be switched from Denmark to Brussels because Denmark has called an early election over the question of allowing nuclear weapons in its ports.

title: Review/Television; Sylvia Plath In Painful Retrospect
description: Public television's ''Voices and Visions,'' the American poetry series presented by the South Carolina ETV Network, reaches its 13th and final essay this week. ''Sylvia Plath'' is being broadcast on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock this evening. Previous programs have ranged from Walt Whitman to Wallace Stevens, from Emily Dickinson to Elizabeth Bishop. The inclusion of Plath has drawn criticism in certain poetry corners. Some contend that her work is less significant than her life. Why not Theodore Roethke instead, it's asked, or Adrienne Rich? Differences of opinion tend to get magnified on tight little islands.

title: Victory's Rarefied Air Is Bracing for Dukakis
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, the eyes-straight-ahead political marathoner, is finally looking around this week and reveling in his position as the Democratic Party's likely nominee.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: SOMETIMES I think you can tell everything about my two children by watching them sleep at night. One lies flat on his back, the quilt tucked neatly under his armpits, his arms at his side, as though he were a child miming perfect sleep for an advertisement for cocoa or pajamas. No matter what time it is, you will find him so.

title: What Mayor Koch Has Lost
description: Blacks and Jews, blacks and Jews: it's as though they were the contenders in Tuesday's New York primary rather than the Democratic Presidential candidates. For the election to be framed that way was wrong, destructively wrong, and a big reason for that was the behavior of Ed Koch. New York's Mayor, who prides himself on speaking fearless truth, made himself sound like someone throwing a tantrum.

title: Norway Skips Oil Talks

He said Norway's policy was not to participate in formal agreements or multilateral talks with OPEC or other oil-producing nations but to assist in stabilizing oil markets through unilateral measures.

title: Review/Concert; Sephardic Music From Alhambra At Weill Hall
description: Sephardic music is a metaphor of Jewish history, being a well-traveled art that has never abandoned its roots. After a thousand years on the Iberian peninsula, Spanish Jews in 1492 were pushed outward in several directions - south to North Africa, east to Turkey and Greece, north to England, even to Poland. The language has survived as Ladino, whose mix of Spanish syntax and added Hebrew make it a kind of warm-weather Yiddish, albeit with a Castilian rather than a German base. The music has bent but not broken to its later surroundings.

description: Children who are kept alive by high-technology machines should have Congressional help in getting the care they need at home when possible, according to a Federal task force.

title: Man Dies in Bronx Stabbing, Apparently in Fight on Drugs
description: An unidentified man was stabbed to death on a street in the South Bronx last night, apparently during a dispute with two other men over drugs, the police said.

title: West Coast Bank Profit
description: The First Interstate Bancorp, rebounding after losses of $556 million last year, said today that its earnings rose 27.3 percent in the first quarter.

title: Municipals Stage Quick Recovery
description: The Supreme Court threw the tax-exempt municipal bond market into momentary confusion yesterday, when it upheld a Federal tax law regarding the need to register state and municipal issues and overruled an 1895 decision that made interest earned on bonds issued by states or localities immune from Federal taxation.

title: American Brands Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,300,000 and $3,900,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively. The company said earnings for the latest first quarter include results of the distilled spirits business of National Distillers & Chemical Corp., acquired May 1987, and ACCO World Corp., acquired August 1987. The quarter also includes results of E-II Holdings Inc. from Feb. 20, 1988. The latest quarter's discontinued operations included income tax benefits of $19 million, mainly resulting from a tax capital loss carryback and income tax expense of $806,000 for the year-ago period.

title: JB's Restaurants Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 13
description: b-Net loss

title: Illinois Tool Works Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day on Tuesday about New Retail Concepts described its president, Neil Cole, incorrectly. He is not the president of Kenneth Cole Shoes; his brother Kenneth runs that company.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MOST homes have either Venetian blinds or roller shades. Despite the advantages of blinds -while preserving privacy, they admit large amounts of light without glare, and add crispness to room design -and the economy of shades, both have drawbacks: They are difficult to clean and sometimes troublesome to adjust.

title: Review/Film; Personal Subject, Personal Picture
description: If you haven't been in a roomful of chatter about relationships lately and are aching for the experience, ''Someone to Love'' may be just the cure. Watching this latest effort of Henry Jaglom, who makes movies that feature his friends and relatives, is the next best thing to being trapped in a 1960's encounter session with people you'd just as soon not encounter.

title: Trion Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split in May 1987.

title: Aims C. McGuinness, Pediatrician, 83
description: Dr. Aims C. McGuinness, a pediatrician and a former professor at the University of Pennsylvania, died of pneumonia Tuesday at the Uihlein Mercy Center in Lake Placid, N.Y. He was 83 years old and had lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: Hill, Holliday Names Five New Executives
description: Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos of Boston and New York has added five executive vice presidents to the six it already had.

title: Baseball Notebook; Ex-Met Hopefuls Shifted by Padres
description: The San Diego Padres' part of the trade that brought Kevin McReynolds to the Mets has taken an interesting twist. Stanley Jefferson, who instantly moved into the Padres' starting outfield a year ago, is back in the minor leagues, and Shawn Abner, who remained in the minors for further seasoning, is in the majors with a chance to replace Jefferson as the Padres' regular center fielder.

title: Liposome Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Personal Health

description: The chief enforcer of the nation's job health and safety laws today vehemently denied a Senate committee chairman's accusation that there had been a ''retreat from safety'' by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration in the Reagan Presidency.

title: How to Protect  [ Copyright ]  In World Markets
description: One bright spot shines out from the otherwise gloomy trade figures released monthly by the Commerce Department. While other economic sectors show steady deficits, the makers of American books, computer software, recordings, movies and other copyrighted materials - that is, intellectual property - generated a $1.5 billion trade surplus last year.

description: The Federal Election Commission fined President Reagan's campaign committee $10,000 for accepting excessive contributions in the 1984 primary election, newly released records show.

Behind the Forecasts of a Close Race: Why Some Are Off the Mark
description: The headlines were dramatic: ''Too Close to Call,'' said the Sunday issue of The Daily News, citing a poll that it said was taken on the eve of the primary. ''Jesse Closes the Gap,'' The New York Post said in a headline Monday, predicting that the performance of Senator Albert Gore Jr. would be the key to the contest. CBS News said Tuesday morning that the Democratic race was too close to make a prediction.

title: Midlantic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Chrysler's Europe Sales
description: The first sedans shipped by the Chrysler Corporation to Europe will go on sale Thursday, and Chrysler's vice chairman, Robert S. Miller, said that if the auto maker sold enough vehicles in Europe it might consider a production venture there, possibly with another auto company. Initial shipments, however, are relatively small. Chrysler plans to send 10,000 to 15,000 Jeeps and 5,000 to 10,000 autos this year to West Germany, Austria, Switzerland, Belgium, Luxembourg, France and the Netherlands, Mr. Miller said. The models that go on sale Thursday include the Chrysler LeBaron coupe and convertible, Chrysler GS turbo sportscar, Chrysler ES family sedan and the Sundance and Shadow small sedans.

title: Signs of Hasty Retreat Seen at Fao
description: Iraqi troops who recaptured the strategic Fao Peninsula from Iran found heavily shelled buildings plastered with pictures of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and anti-Iraqi slogans.

Tiny Hearing Aids Defy Elderly Fingers
description: To the Editor:

Results for the year-ago quarter include $12.4 million, or 23 cents a share, from a number of non-operating transactions, including gains on the sale of U.S. exploration and production properties and the sale to the public of a 57-percent interest in Petrolane Partners L.P.

title: Gerald Arpino Elected Joffrey Artistic Director
description: Gerald Arpino has been named artistic director of the Joffrey Ballet, succeeding Robert Joffrey, who died March 25.

title: Review/Dance; Style of 2 Centuries at Ballet Theater
description: Three role debuts in works presented by American Ballet Theater on Tuesday evening at the Metropolitan Opera House suggested the rich potential of the company today. On the first anniversary of Antony Tudor's death, Leslie Browne, Alessandra Ferri and Ricardo Bustamante brought new light to lead roles in ''Pillar of Fire,'' a signature work by Mr. Tudor. And Amanda McKerrow danced with her characteristic directness and look of truth in ''Les Sylphides.''

title: Metro Matters; Campaign '88 Tired Souls And New Blood
description: Outside Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn, the only hint that an election was taking place Tuesday was the man with the hat. He politely stopped passers-by to give out palm cards promoting the candidacy of Senator Albert Gore Jr. Inside the school, in the Midwood section, Max Sultan was complaining because his polling place had been shifted to the Murrow gymnasium from his apartment house a few blocks away. Mr. Sultan, who will be 81 years old in July, managed to get there. But he was worried about his elderly neighbors.

title: First Empire State Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the 1987 financial statements, except for per share earnings, have been restated to include the accounts of East New York Savings Bank, which was acquired by First Empire in December 1987.
