Delegate Tally
description: Current breakdown of Presidential preference of delegates to national political conventions, compiled by The New York Times. Preferences are based on state laws, party rules, delegates' public statements and projections from early results in caucus states. DEMOCRATS Dukakis 1,048 Jackson 842 Gore 405 Simon 172 Undetermined* 623 Total delegate votes: 4,161 Chosen so far: 3,090 Needed to nominate: 2,081 REPUBLICANS Bush 1,006 Robertson 17 Undetermined* 231 Total delegate votes: 2,277 Chosen so far: 1,254 Needed to nominate: 1,139 * Includes some delegates whose chosen candidate has withdrawn.

title: 2d Rainout for Dodgers
description: The game between the San Diego Padres and Los Angeles Dodgers was rained out tonight. The rainout was the second between the clubs in two nights.

title: Talking Deals; When Targets Tilt Playing Field
description: CORPORATIONS under takeover attack often entice other bidders into the fray either to fetch a higher price or to end up with a new owner more to their liking. Offering to sell a prized division to a new bidder is one form of largesse that has been frowned upon by the courts. But lately more modest inducements, ranging from a peek at a company's books to a promise to pick up expenses, have survived the legal test.

title: Pirates Win, Off to Best Start Since '62
description: Darnell Coles hit a tie-breaking two-run double in the fifth inning and Jose Lind added a two-run single in the sixth as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 8-1, tonight.

title: Ruling on Alcoholic Veterans
description: Federal disability and other benefits may be denied to most veterans disabled by alcoholism. Page A27.

title: An Important Option
description: To The Home Section:

title: D&N Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest quarter net included gains from the sales of securities, loans, mortgage backed certificates and other products of $272,000, compared with $2,085,000 a year-ago.

title: Lawmaker Faults NBC On Projecting Winner
description: The chairman of the House subcommittee on elections said yesterday that NBC's reporting of the Presidential primary election in New York violated the spirit of the network's agreement not to project election winners while voting polls remained open.

title: Metro Datelines; School-Bus Director Says He Took Bribes
description: The school-bus director of Woodbridge pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court to receiving $400,000 in payoffs for favoritism in the awarding of bus contracts. The official, James W. Dickinson, who pleaded guilty last week to related charges in state court, faces 20 years in prison for his plea to extortion charges, an assistant United States attorney, Paul Brickfield, said.

title: Kinark Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Basketball Trials Start for Women
description: The red, white and blue buses stopped in front of the administration building at the Olympic Training Center, the recruits trudging to their first stop in basketball's version of basic training. During the next three days, the Games Committee and Coach Kay Yow will evaluate the 57 women invited here for the Olympic trials, narrowing the field to about 20 after Saturday night's scrimmage.

title: Sybra Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Concert; Guitar and Harpsichord
description: Adam Holzman, a guitarist, and Linda Kobler, a harpsichordist, teamed up on Tuesday evening for a concert at the 92d Street Y that was rather like an old-fashioned salon evening. Only their opening and closing works were duos - four Baroque dances by Le Roux in which the guitar was scarcely audible and a better balanced, beautifully nuanced Ponce sonata. And they were joined by a quintet of Baroque strings for a Vivaldi Concerto (RV 540), which featured a lively dialogue between Mr. Holzman's guitar and Susan Iadone's viola d'amore.

title: Boulevard Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Babies for Export: And Now the Painful Questions
description: The babies, in embroidered pink and blue jumpsuits, wait in the adoption agency, the way station between those who bore them and those who will raise them. They smile at the women who will escort them to new homes half a world away.

title: A Decorating Style to Die For
description: THEY call it post-mortemism. This aptly describes the decorating style on view in ''Beetlejuice,'' the new horror-comedy film that borrows its inspiration, in the words of the production designer Bo Terry, ''from the trendiest architecture money can buy.''

title: Review/Music; Michael Feinstein On Stage
description: Michael Feinstein has moved his fascination with the Broadway musical theater from the cozy intimacy of his customary New York home, the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, to a relatively intimate Broadway theater, the Lyceum, where he will be singing and playing the piano for the next four weeks.

title: Daniel C. Rutledge Jr., Retired U.N. Official, 67
description: Daniel C. Rutledge Jr., a former United Nations official, died Tuesday at the Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 67 years old and lived in Irvington, N.Y.

title: Management Changes At Reynolds Metals
description: The Reynolds Metals Company, completing a management succession that began two years ago, yesterday named its chief executive, William O. Bourke, to the added position of chairman.

title: Promotion Industry Reacts to a Scandal
description: Was the multibillion-dollar sales promotion industry shaken by charges that more than a dozen postal workers cheated The Daily News on a ''Pick the Score'' game keyed to the 1987 Super Bowl's final score?

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the choice of Demoratic superdelegates described Senator Howell T. Heflin's status incorrectly in some editions.

title: Net Revised By Chevron
description: The Chevron Corporation is changing its 1986 profit to a $1.4 billion loss and is raising its 1987 profit to $1.25 billion from $1 billion because of a routine bookkeeping requirement.

title: Shipping and Oilfields Returning to Normal in Gulf
description: Two days after United States and Iranian forces clashed in the Persian Gulf, shipping and oilfield work began to return to normal today. But lingering concerns about renewed conflict were underlined when Iran fired a Soviet-made missile at Kuwait.

title: Diceon Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: The company said year-ago results were restated to include the operations of Symtron Corp. which was acquired on a pooling-of-interest basis in May 1987.

title: TV Notes; Substitute Scriptwriters Filling a Creative Void
description: As the writers' strike against television and movie producers continues through its seventh week, nonunion people have begun taking over some of the scriptwriting for daytime soap operas. And the soaps' creators wait with trepidation - mindful of tales of disaster from their 13-week walkout in 1981.

title: Milton Roy Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was a question of saving human lives, and we cannot talk about bargaining.'' - Hedi Khediri, Algeria's Interior Minister. [ A9:1. ]

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Press Secretaries; Who's Talking? Putting Words in Official Mouths
description: The admission by Larry Speakes, the former White House spokesman, that he fabricated quotations and attributed them to President Reagan has provoked a chorus of indignant criticism, but also a quiet acknowledgement that few rules exist to determine when a politician's words are his own.

title: Young Volunteers Help Tackle Projects in Bronx
description: Elaine Vasquez and Racquel Chambers, with the distinctive apple patch of the City Volunteer Corps on their jackets and clipboards in their arms, stood on Manida Street in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx one morning this week and became involved in a small argument.

title: Jackson Handicapped in Pennsylvania Race
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts is expected to sweep the popular vote in Pennsylvania next Tuesday, the next big date on the primary calendar, and to win a large majority of the 178 Democratic delegates at stake.

title: Response Is Expected To Request by Boesky
description: Federal prosecutors are expected to respond by tomorrow to a request by Ivan F. Boesky that his three-year prison sentence be reduced.

title: Vote by Congressional District
New York: 'Melting Pot' Yielding to 'Boiling Pot'
description: If Tuesday's Democratic Presidential primary was a test of the candidates, it was a test of New York State as well, and the perception around the country in political and other circles is that the state did not distinguish itself.

title: Excerpts From the Court Decision
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision in South Carolina v. Baker, upholding the constitutionality of a Federal law that removed the Federal income tax exemption for interest on state and local bonds issued in non-registered form. Justice William J. Brennan Jr. wrote the majority opinion. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor filed a dissenting opinion: FROM THE OPINION By Justice Brennan

description: Since 1901, when the New York Public Library issued its first borrower's card, the library card has symbolized a passage for millions of New Yorkers into a musty world of paper and glue.

title: Chrysler in Europe

Miller, said that if the auto maker sold enough vehicles in Europe it might consider a production venture there, possibly with another auto company. Initial shipments, however, are relatively small. The models that go on sale Thursday include the Chrysler LeBaron coupe and convertible, Chrysler GS turbo sportscar, Chrysler ES family sedan and the Sundance and Shadow small sedans.

He said the investigation was prompted by an anonymous letter he received last week. The letter accused players of using the banned drugs, and charged members of Columbia's coaching staff of encouraging use of them.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Last summer we had the bricks on the front of our house cleaned and tuck pointed. They are light tan face bricks with a semismooth finish. Since the job was done the brick is dull, with numerous white stains, apparently from the chemicals used in cleaning. Can I restore the brick to its original condition? A.It sounds as if the white stains are from mortar that was smeared around and not thoroughly washed off after the pointing was finished. If so, they can be washed off with a diluted solution of muriatic acid: one part acid to five parts water.

title: Review/Concert; Young American Choruses
description: Midamerica Productions is a musical organization that assembles choirs from far and wide to give hundreds of young singers a chance to visit New York City and sing in its major halls. Monday night, students from high schools in Arkansas, Illinois, Wisconsin, Mississippi, North Dakota and Kansas joined, several hundred strong, to form the chorus for Schubert's Mass in G, Beethoven's Choral Fantasy and short pieces by Haydn, Stanford and Gabrieli. Peter Tiboris, the group's general director, did most of the conducting (Jerry Jordan of the University of Mississippi led the Schubert and the short works), a freelance orchestra gathered under the name Manhattan Philharmonic accompanied, and the 18-year-old pianist Dimitris Sgouros played in the Beethoven, with Mozart's ''Elvira Madigan'' piano concerto (K. 467) thrown in for good measure.

title: No Victors in Algiers
description: Impiously pleading respect for Ramadan, the Moslem holy month, the captors of a Kuwaiti airliner freed 31 hostages yesterday, and were apparently promised safe passage from Algiers. This would not be a good outcome, since it would leave two foul murders unpunished. But the choice of sparing the hijackers or their captives was a dreadful one, not to be second-guessed without humility.

Print and broadcast media too often provide so little substance and so much horse race material that it's hard to judge what the public really wants. But, to their credit, Democrats apparently blocked out the nastiness and charges that swirled around the campaign, voting in Tuesday's New

title: Pitney Bowes Net Up
description: Pitney Bowes Inc. said its first-quarter profit rose 31.5 percent from a year ago on a 13.6 percent increase in revenue. The business equipment and supplies company said on Tuesday that it earned $53.9 million, or 69 cents a share, in the first quarter, compared with $41 million, or 52 cents a share, a year earlier. First-quarter revenue rose to $521.3 million from $458.7 million. In addition to making business equipment and supplies, Pitney Bowes operates a financial services company.

description: Senator Albert Gore Jr., who is expected to announce the end of his active Presidential candidacy today, failed in his quest for the Democratic nomination because he became a prime contender and ceased to be one at almost the same moment in early March.

description: A concert promoter charged with heading a Manhattan prostitution ring was indicted again yesterday on charges of evading state and city income taxes.

title: A Soviet Interview Depicts Yeltsin as Unrepentant
description: In an interview published by a new German-language edition of a Soviet journal, Boris N. Yeltsin declares that he spoke out ''honestly and directly'' in the Central Committee speech last October that led to his ouster from a senior Kremlin post.

title: Two Giants in PC Publishing
description: Since the development of the personal computer, the computer magazine business has undergone waves of consolidations, acquisitions and expansions. Now, analysts report, it has become a two-horse race between the International Data Group, based in Framingham, Mass., and the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company.

title: Esposito's Blessings
description: If Michel Bergeron wants to quit as coach of the Rangers to take the general manager's job in Quebec, Phil Esposito says ''it would be silly to hold him back.'' Esposito, the Ranger general manager, in Montreal to do commentary for ESPN on the Boston-Montreal playoff series, said he would ''seriously talk to my bosses about that'' if Bergeron asked for a release from his contract, adding that the Rangers would insist on compensation. They gave Quebec a first-round draft for Bergeron, who was then the Nordiques' coach, last June. On Tuesday the Nordiques moved Maurice Filion from general manager to club vice president.

title: Stocks Continue Fall, With Dow Off 14.09
description: LEAD: The stock market continued to drift lower in desultory trading yesterday.

description: Most fears in a child's world are only natural for those who are small and helpless in a large and sometimes dangerous place.

title: Tiny Hearing Aids Defy Elderly Fingers
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Knicks in 3-Way Tie: Herb Williams, starting for the injured Wayman Tisdale, scored 20 points last night as the Indiana Pacers rolled to a 116-98 victory over the Hawks in Atlanta and moved into a three-way tie for the Eastern Conference's last two playoff spots. The victory left the Pacers tied with the Bullets, who lost to Milwaukee, and the Knicks, who did not play. All three teams have 37-43 records. The Pacers never trailed, shooting 54.2 percent in the first half as they took a 59-51 lead. John Long scored 13 points in the opening half. The Hawks were frustrated by cold shooting, hitting 43 percent for the game. Dominique Wilkins, who is 30 for 90 from the field in his last three games, was 6 for 26 against the Pacers and finished with 18 points. (AP) Bucks 132, Bullets 94: Terry Cummings had 26 points and 10 rebounds at home as Milwaukee snapped a five-game losing streak. Milwaukee, winning for only the second time in 10 games, never let the Bullets get closer than 36 points in the fourth quarter after finishing the third with a 102-62 lead. The Bullets had won 7 of their previous 10 games. Paul Pressey scored 17 points and had 12 of Milwaukee's season-high 46 assists. John Lucas also scored 17 points for the Bucks. Bernard King and Mark Alarie led Washington with 14 points apiece.(AP) TENNIS Lendl Struggles: Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia, making his first appearance in a tournament in two months, struggled to beat Christian Bergstrom of Sweden, 7-6, 7-5, yesterday in the second round of the Monte Carlo Open. Mats Wilander, seeded second behind Lendl, breezed to victory, beating a fellow Swede, Niclas Kroon, 6-4, 6-2. Lendl has been inactive on the circuit since the last week of February when he lost at the U.S. Pro Indoor in Philadelphia. A stress fracture in a bone under his right big toe forced him to withdraw from three tourneys since.(AP) Navratilova Advances: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova started slowly but overcame her inconsistency with a 6-4, 6-2 victory over Hu Na yesterday in a second-round match of the $250,000 Virginia Slims of Houston. Navratilova broke Hu, of San Diego, in the fifth game of the opening set but was broken in the eighth game with Hu hitting a forehand passing shot at break point. Navratilova broke back in the ninth game and served a love game to end the first set when Hu made three straight errors on service returns. (AP) BOXING McGuigan Wins: Barry McGuigan, swept on by a tide of emotional support, made a successful comeback yesterday, stopping Nicky Perez in the fourth round of a nontitle superfeatherweight bout in London.(AP)

description: The Chemical Bank is making a $257 million public offering of asset-backed securities through its Chemical Bank Grantor Trust. It is the bank's first sale of such securities.

title: Broten, a Quiet One, Makes Some Noise
description: Aaron Broten, who is usually back home in Minnesota weather-watching by this time of year, hid behind his slowly sprouting playoff beard and awaited the inevitable. After scoring only the second hat trick of his seven-season career and contributing the deciding goal in the Devils' recuperative 5-2 victory against the Washington Capitals, Broten realized there was no escaping the limelight.

title: Coleman Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Glass Boxes by A Master
description: Japan had no strong glassmaking tradition, so Kyohei Fujita invented one by translating the splendor of 17th- and 18th-century Japanese lacquerware into glass boxes. His containers, on display at the Heller Gallery, are also reminiscent of Impressionist works brushed with a Midas touch.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Congress can tax interest on state and local government bonds, the Supreme Court ruled. The Court held that the Constitution does not protect state and local governments from Federal taxation of the interest received by holders of their bonds. [ Page A1. ] The municipal bond market was momentarily thrown into confusion by the Supreme Court, but prices later recovered a bit. [ D16. ] The Consumer Price Index climbed 0.5 percent in March, the biggest advance in 14 months, the Labor Department reported. But most economists continued to predict that the Federal Reserve would not need to take severe restraining measures. [ A1. ] Consumer prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose a moderate 0.3 percent in March. [ D5. ] COMPANIES Irving Bank announced several changes in a friendly investment proposal from the Banca Commerciale Italiana of Milan, as efforts to defeat a bid from Bank of New York continued. [ D1. ] A.T.& T. appointed Robert E. Allen as its chairman and chief executive, succeeding James E. Olson, who died Monday. A.T.& T. announced that net income in the first quarter rose 10.6 percent, to $492 million. [ D1. ] BellSouth and Southwestern Bell reported lower earnings, while Bell Atlantic and Ameritech posted gains. [ D4. ] Shearson Lehman Brothers Holdings reported its profits increased 3.8 percent, to $81 million. [ D5. ] G.M.'s three principal units reported combined earnings of $695.5 million, up 12 percent. [ D5. ] American Brands reported a 15 percent increase in earnings and announced plans to sell its Andrew Jergens unit. [ D21. ] Dun & Bradstreet said its income rose 15 percent, to $114 million. [ D21. ] A response is expected tomorrow to Ivan F. Boesky's request that his three-year prison sentence be reduced. [ D2. ] A bailout of First City of Texas was nearly scuttled. [ D2. ] Lord, Einstein, O'Neill & Partners won a $20 million account from Saab. The agency's billings are now about $60 million. [ D1. ] Negotiations to buy J. P. Stevens continued for a second day with no announcement expected until late tomorrow. [ D20. ] Heirs of the late newspaper executive Axel Springer have won control of the West German group named after him. [ D22. ] The publisher of Simon & Schuster has added the title of president of the publishing company, effective immediately. [ D22. ] The founders of the Banana Republic chain resigned, citing ''creative and cultural differences'' with The Gap. [ D22. ] The Wall Street Journal plans to publish a third section. [ D22. ] Gillette's stock fell in heavy trading amid uneasiness about a proxy fight expected at its shareholders' meeting today. [ D4. ] MARKETS The stock market continued to drift lower in desultory trading. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at its low for the day, 1,985.41, down 14.09 points. [ D6. ] Yields on C.D.'s, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mostly up for the recent week. [ D13. ] The dollar firmed slightly against most major currencies in light, lethargic trading. [ D18. ] Crude oil futures prices continued to decline in heavy trading, largely because of contract expirations. [ D18. ] INTERNATIONAL Sweeping trade legislation heads for Congressional votes with a worker-safeguard provision intact that has elicited threats of a veto from the White House. [ D1. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Courts seem to be letting companies under takeover attack entice friendly bidders into the fray with modest inducements, such as a peek at the company's books. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Investors are giving scant attention to first-quarter earnings, even though they were higher than expected. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: Ralphs Grocery
description: The managers of the Ralphs Grocery Company are to become equity participants in the Los Angeles-based supermarket chain under its ownership by the Campeau Corporation, Robert Campeau, the Toronto-based company's chairman, said. Soon after winning a $6.6 billion takeover battle for Federated Department Stores Inc. earlier this month, Mr. Campeau halted an auction for the Federated unit by saying he intended to keep Ralphs. Details about the percentage of Ralphs to be held by managment or the number of employees eligible have yet to be worked out, Gene A. Brown, a Ralphs vice president, said.

title: Rockwell Net Up 24.4%
description: The Rockwell International Corporation, the aerospace, automotive and electronics company, reported today that its second-quarter earnings rose 24.4 percent, but gave most of the credit to a tax adjustment. Rockwell rose to $218.4 million, or 81 cents a share, from $175.6 million, or 62 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1987. Sales totaled $3 billion in the three months ended March 31, down from $3.16 billion for the comparable period in 1987, largely because of a 24 percent decline in sales of B1-B bombers.

title: Review/Dance; A Spanish Archetype
description: Pilar Rioja is a great Spanish dancer and a great dancing actress. Her program Tuesday night at Repertorio Espanol's Gramercy Arts Theater (138 East 27th Street) included refined Escuela Bolero dances and tempestuous flamenco solos. Yet her sensibility resembled that of our century's pioneers of modern dance, who sought to give choreographic form to inner experience. Whereas the specific form Miss Rioja employed was Spanish dance, her themes were universal experiences of joy and sorrow.

title: In a Clown-Care Unit, the Rx Is Laughter
description: SHANE understood where he was going. A 2-year-old boy with downy blond hair and long eyelashes, he had endured months of hospitalization for a brain tumor. Seated in a stroller, with his arm connected to an intravenous pump four times his size, he stared from under his baseball cap down the hospital corridor toward the room where he was about to undergo ultrasound treatment. ''He knows,'' his father said.

title: 'Steamroller and Violin,' Tarkovsky's Earliest
description: ''The Steamroller and the Violin,'' which opens the Andrei Tarkovsky retrospective at Film Forum 2 today, is in a much lighter mood than the works for which the Soviet director is celebrated. Mr. Tarkovsky, who died in 1986, was known for powerful, sometimes violent images and big, sometimes mystical symbols. This very early work, made in 1960 during his final year at the Moscow Film Institute and not shown in New York until now, is a small story told through the eyes of a small boy.

title: Texas Instruments Net Down; Compaq Up
description: Texas Instruments Inc., a major manufacturer of computer chips, today reported a slightly lower net income for the first quarter, while the profits of Compaq Computer Corporation, a rapidly growing computer maker, nearly doubled. The companies said demand surged for their major products.

title: NO PROGRESS CITED IN NEW ARMS TALKS
description: American arms control officials accompanying Secretary of State George P. Shultz completed several rounds of discussions with their Soviet counterparts tonight but made no major headway toward a new strategic arms treaty, American officials said.

title: U.S. Deficit Grew in March
description: The United States budget deficit widened last month but it was still smaller in the first half of the Government's 1988 fiscal year than it was a year earlier, the Treasury Department said today.

title: New President At Texas Bank
description: The First City Bancorporation of Texas said today that Robert D. Richley, head of a rapidly growing bank company in San Diego, had been appointed president and chief operating officer of the Houston-based banking company. Mr. Richley, who is 44 years old, will be responsible for First City's $6.9 billion commercial and consumer lending portfolio.

title: Arrest Made in '79 Slaying of Boy Outside Stadium
description: Almost nine years after a 12-year-old boy was stabbed and killed outside Yankee Stadium by a teen-ager who pulled a basketball from the dying boy's hands and then stole his bicycle, a suspect has been arrested.

title: United Missouri Bancshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Film; In London, Comic Politics and Food
description: ''Excuse me,'' the elegantly dressed woman says to the waiter at Bastard's, the smart London supper club. ''The baby panda, is it fried in honey?''

title: Gore Suspends Presidential Campaign
description: Offering warm tributes to his Democratic Presidential rivals, Senator Albert Gore Jr. today ended his quest for the Democratic nomination.

title: Knicks Ready for the Final 2
description: With a chance to purchase playoff tickets for the first time in four years, Knick fans have responded by buying all but 2,000 of the 19,591 tickets for each game of the opening series. At times Tuesday, the first day of the public sale, it was estimated that more than 400 people were waiting in the ticket lines at Madison Square Garden.

title: Orioles Fall to 0-15 In Loss to Brewers
description: Baltimore continued to struggle today as the Milwaukee Brewers scored six runs in the third inning and beat the Orioles, 7-1. The loss was the Orioles' 15th straight since the beginning of the season, a major league record.

title: Once Ally & Gargano, Now Ally vs. Gargano
description: Ally & Gargano lost the $30 million Saab Scania of North America account because of a disintegration of the relationship between the firm's former chairman, Carl Ally, and his successor, Amil Gargano, numerous associates of the two men say. The Swedish auto maker had hired Mr. Ally to help it in an agency review.

title: Review/Film; Melodies and Politics
description: The definitive reggae performance movie hasn't been made yet. ''Cool Runnings: The Reggae Movie,'' filmed in Jamaica at the 1983 Reggae Sunsplash Festival, is an honorable attempt; the film maker, Robert Mugge, has also made documentaries about such worthy musicians as Al Green, Sonny Rollins and Ruben Blades. But ''Cool Runnings,'' limited by middling performances and some poor technical choices, is for committed fans only.

title: Anchor Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $2 million for the quarter and an extraordinary gain $6.3 million for the 9 months. c-Includes an extrarordinary credit of $1.5 million for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $42.8 million for the 9 months. The company converted from a mutual to stock form on April 1, 1987.

title: A Salute to Magic At Hunter College
description: What's a magician to do when suspended upside-down, with ankles chained and wrists shackled, in a glass tank filled with 200 gallons of water? Escape, of course. Only the feat has to be accomplished in two minutes - just the amount of time needed by Harry Houdini for the same trick 76 years ago.

title: This Gore Campaign, and the Next
description: When the book is written on Albert Gore Jr.'s 1988 Presidential campaign, the subtitle could be ''The Price of Wisdom.'' Now that the Tennessee Senator has suspended his activity, the question is whether he'll be able to apply his hard-won wisdom in some future Presidential race. He ought to; he is, after all, just 40 years old. But first, Al Gore has some mending to do.

title: Stevens Bidders Seem to Progress
description: Two bidding groups collaborating to buy J. P. Stevens & Company, the textile producer, are expected to present their plan today to a special seven-member committee of Stevens's independent directors, headed by E. Virgil Conway, president of the Seamen's Bank for Savings.

title: END TO SUIT DENIED IN SMOKING DEATH
description: A Federal judge refused today to dismiss a suit against three cigarette manufacturers, saying sufficient evidence had already been presented for a jury to reasonably conclude that the companies had conspired to misrepresent and conceal the dangers of smoking.

title: Benefits for U.S. Seen in a Recession
description: A leading Japanese politician said today that the United States may suffer an economic recession later this year but that a small downturn could be good for it.

title: Anchor Savings & Loan Association reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company went public in October 1987.

title: Both Sides Confident At Gillette
description: Hundreds of Gillette Company shareholders turned out for an annual meeting today to vote in a proxy contest that is viewed as a referendum on the company's future.

title: Koppers May Sell Parts of 2 Units
description: The Koppers Company said it had been negotiating with third parties to sell portions of its chemical and construction materials divisions but that no one had emerged who was interested in buying the entire company, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Pittsburgh-based concern is exploring its options in light of the $1.69 billion hostile tender offer from Beazer P.L.C. of Britian. Earlier this month, in documents filed in Federal District Court, Koppers said it had no plans to sell the operations of its chemical division. Beazer has said that it intends to sell the chemical division if its takeover is successful.

title: No Victory Through Surrender
description: On the day before the primary, Jesse Jackson was winding up an appearance before one of New York's more influential audiences - 1,300 business people, academics, social workers and politicians, brought together by the Association for a Better New York.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Shift a Bit on Big Board and Amex
description: Both the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange yesterday reported small changes in their ''short interest'' for the month ended last Friday, April 15.

title: A Change of Heart
description: Beryl W. Sprinkel, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, has decided to stay on the job, probably until the lights go out next January, White House people say.

title: One Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $119,000 for the latest first quarter and $1,259,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: 4 Groups at CBGB

title: No Charges Against Reporter In Inquiry Into Voting Fraud
description: Criminal charges will not be sought against a television reporter who registered five times to vote in the New York Presidential primary Tuesday to dramatize the potential for voting fraud, a spokesman for District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said yesterday.

title: Museums Will Admit You Even for a Nickel
description: To the Editor:

title: Fred Stark, Builder, 83
description: Fred Stark, a builder, died of heart failure April 15 at his home in Holliswood, Queens. He was 83 years old.

title: Tolland Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Researchers List Odds of Getting AIDS in Heterosexual Intercourse
description: The chance of catching the AIDS virus from a single act of heterosexual intercourse with an infected partner is 1 in 500 if no condom is used, according to a report published in the current issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Surgery for Patrick Kennedy
description: Patrick J. Kennedy, the 20-year-old son of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, was operated on today for the removal of a benign growth that had been pressing on his spinal cord, a spokesman for Massachusetts General Hospital said tonight. Mr. Kennedy, the Senator's youngest son, was in satisfactory condition after the operation, which was succesful, the spokesman, Martin Bander, said. Mr. Kennedy is in his sophomore year at Providence College in Rhode Island. Senator Kennedy has two other children, Edward M. Jr. and Kara.

title: Lillian Shapero, 80, Dancer and Teacher
description: Lillian Shapero Rauch, a member of the first Martha Graham Dance Company, died on Tuesday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 80 years old and had had a stroke.

title: Houston Mayor's Image Threatened by Economy
description: As Houston's economy has wilted over the last five years, one thing in town has usually held its value: the political standing of Mayor Kathy Whitmire.

title: Solid Rotation Puts Indians in Orbit
description: The loyal fans, all 6,551 of them, were on their way out of Cleveland Stadium into a persistent rain that was too hard to be categorized as mere drizzle but too soft to interrupt a major league baseball game. Lucky for them. As they skipped down the ramps of the cavernous old stadium Wednesday night, wrapped in sweaters, sweatshirts, quilts, boots, hooded jackets, blankets, gloves and scarves, they knew it was a lovely night on the shores of Lake Erie. The fans could perform a rite rarely experienced here this late, that is, 15 games into the season.

title: Mets Take to Road With Lifted Spirits
description: The Mets flew west yesterday to open an eight-game trip, starting with their first appearance of the year in St. Louis. They weren't hitting much, and they didn't know when Rick Aguilera would return to the pitching staff, but to confront the new problems, they were armed with an old symbol of success: Dwight Gooden, striking out hitters and dominating games again.

title: Highlights of the Trade Bill
description: Plant Closings 60 days' notice of plant closing or long-term layoff by companies employing more than 100 persons. Notice required if layoff affects either one-third of the work force or 500 persons. Unfair Trade Investigation of countries with ''pervasive'' unfair trade practices. Retaliation if their barriers are not eliminated. Trade Relief Industries seriously injured by imports could get some protection if willing to make ''positive adjustment'' to foreign competition. Foreign Corruption Clarifies the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act to specify what kind of knowledge makes American corporate officials liable if their foreign employees or agents are involved in bribery. Worker Assistance Expands programs for workers displaced by imports. Creates a $1 billion retraining program with most of the money going to states. Toshiba Ban Three-year ban on Government purchases from the Toshiba Corporation, parent of Toshiba Machine Corporation, which violated export controls with technology sales to Moscow. Agriculture Loans A marketing loan provision for grains and oilseeds that would be activated in 1990 by a stalemate in trade liberalization talks under GATT auspices. Farmers pay such loans at market rates, thus protecting their income while releasing crops to the market. Securities Dealers Bars foreign companies from serving as primary dealers in U.S. Government securities unless their government lets American companies compete in their nation against domestic firms. Negotiating Authority Grants the President special authority to complete international trade negotiations aimed at increasing markets for banking, insurance and other services, liberalizing investment rules, protecting patents, copyrights and other intellectual property and slashing tariffs as much as 50 percent.

title: Peoples Bancorp of Worceser reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a non-recurring gain of $78,000 from the sale of an investment.

title: Restaurants
description: The Drake Hotel opened its sumptuous restaurant, Lafayette, in July 1986 with the reserve and discretion of a Swiss banker - actually, the hotel is owned by two Swiss companies, Swissair and Nestle S.A. In less than two years, Lafayette has become one of the city's most exhilarating dining rooms under the direction of two French chefs: Louis Outhier, the consultant, who had a Michelin three-star restaurant on the French Riviera, and his startlingly gifted protege, Jean-Georges Vongerichten, who is the full-time chef. Curiously, both remain relatively unknown here outside of professional circles. That should not last long, for the kitchen's performance, paired with the highly civilized service, now merits four stars.

title: Jacobs Considers Bid for Acme Steel
description: An investment group led by the Minneapolis-based corporate raider Irwin L. Jacobs has purchased a 8.3 percent stake in the Acme Steel Company and said it is considering a bid for control of the steelmaker based in Riverdale, Ill.

title: Hijackers of Jet Went to Syria, Arab Aides Say
description: Arab officials said today that the hijackers of the Kuwait Airways plane left Algiers early Wednesday and were flown on a private Algerian jet to Damascus, Syria. The officials said the hijackers were then believed to have traveled overland to Beirut, Lebanon.

title: Allied Security Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Alliant Computer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $116,000 and a gain of $617,000 on the repurchase of debentures. c-Includes a tax credit of $871,000.

title: REview/Film; Exotic U.S. In Bavarian Perspective
description: Imagine an enormous kewpie doll wearing a Bavarian business suit and you have some idea what Marianne Sagebrecht looks like in the opening moments of ''Bagdad Cafe,'' a sequence explaining the circumstances by which this anomalous creature finds herself stranded in the American desert. There is an argument with a similarly dressed husband, and then a suitcase thrown out onto the sand. There is oom-pah music on the radio. There is an immense kewpie doll who looks terribly worried, for good reason.

title: At the Bar
description: On the wall of Mark Senak's office at the Gay Men's Health Crisis legal services department is a poster of a client, a handsome melancholy young man. He appears healthy but for a small sore on his forehead. ''His father disowned him,'' the poster declares. ''His friends deserted him. His boss fired him. His doctor won't even talk to him. He has AIDS, and it's going to take a total stranger like you to help him.''

title: Republic Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Wilmington Trust Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Concert; Musica Sacra Tour of Old and New Choral Works
description: Since he became director of Musica Sacra 20 years ago, Richard Westenburg has carved out a place for himself as New York's most venturesome and most successful purveyor of choral music. Picking up the banner that Robert Shaw dropped when he turned to full-time orchestra conducting in 1967, Mr. Westenburg has been a force for choral good ever since. Although by no means overlooking the Handel and Bach staples, his programs have continued season after season to enlarge the musical outlook of Musica Sacra audiences.

title: Key Flaws in Shultz's Mideast Plan
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz should be commended for his earnest efforts to reinvigorate the Arab-Israeli peace process. Most of the debate about his proposal has focused on the pros and cons of an international peace conference and on the principle of exchanging land for peace. While these are important issues, his plan is fundamentally flawed in two ways that have received too little attention.

title: United Banks of Colorado reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes securities gains and income tax credits totaling $4.6 million.

title: Reagan Questions Moscow on Afghan Intent
description: President Reagan said today that a pledge by the Soviet Union to withdraw its forces from Afghanistan did not guarantee an end to Soviet involvement there, and he cited fears for the security of Pakistan.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Atlantic Financial Federal-West Virginia, Charleston - the state's largest savings and loan association and a unit of Atlantic Financial Federal, Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. - named Patrick A. Bond president.

title: Oilers, Wings Take 2-0 Leads
description: Wayne Gretzky's short-handed goal at 7 minutes 54 seconds of overtime tonight gave the Edmonton Oilers a 5-4 victory over the Calgary Flames and a 2-0 lead in the Smythe Division finals.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Newsweek is raising its ad rates 3.7 percent with the July 4 issue. Subscription rates will rise about 10 percent.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: President Gave Permission For Attack on Iranian Ships
description: Top military commanders obtained President Reagan's personal permission in the middle of Monday's intense fighting in he Persian Gulf to destroy Iranian craft firing on oil platforms and vessels, the Pentagon said today.

title: Indian Head Banks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Film; Haunting Foursome In a Web of Menace
description: Mike Figgis happens to be a fledgling director whose reach is more than matched by his grasp, which is very lucky, since his ''Stormy Monday'' might have amounted to overreaching had it been handled with anything less than Mr. Figgis's absolute assurance. Here is the kind of neo-film noir plot that could easily seem mannered; here is a fragmented story that could easily add up to less than the sum of its parts. Here is an idiosyncratic setting - the waterfront nightclub district of Newcastle, England - that could easily have grown claustrophobic if it had not been filmed with so much feeling and skill.

title: Bass Group Advances Savings and Loan Bid
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it had entered a final round of negotiations to sell the Financial Corporation of America's troubled savings and loan unit to the Robert M. Bass Group of Texas.

title: Health Insurance and Political Hoopla
description: With balloons, songs and a rally designed to exact the full political measure from the moment, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today signed the country's first law to guarantee health insurance to all residents of a state and said the nation should follow Massachusetts's lead.

title: U.S. Aide Urges Private Industry To Help Bridge
description: A Federal transportation official said yesterday that the private sector should help rehabilitate the Williamsburg Bridge because the city had botched its responsibilities and might not be up to the job.

title: Reston Wins Prize Of $15,000 in Journalism
description: James B. Reston, senior columnist of The New York Times whose reporting from Washington over four decades earned him two Pulitzer Prizes, received the first Helen B. Bernstein Award for Excellence in Journalism at a luncheon yesterday in the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue.

title: President and Mrs. Reagan Are Set for Checkups Today
description: President Reagan will travel to Bethesda Naval Hospital on Friday for a ''routine dental checkup,'' while his wife, Nancy, has her first X-ray examination following breast cancer surgery.

title: Railroad Savings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Amax Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes credits of $24 million from tax loss carryforwards. c-Includes an after-tax gain of $140 million from the sale of assets, and a credit of $34 million from tax loss carryforwards.

title: Andover Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MCA in Australian Deal
description: MCA Inc. said today that it had agreed to supply Northern Star Holdings Ltd., parent of Network Ten Australia, with its entire output of television shows and feature films for 10 years. MCA, based in Universal City, Calif., already exports ''Miami Vice,'' ''Magnum P.I.'' and other shows to 50 countries, but previously had sold its programs to all three Australian television networks.

title: SOVIET POLITBURO IS SAID TO DEMOTE THE NO. 2 LEADER
description: The Politburo, meeting in special session this week, approved steps that all but removed Yegor K. Ligachev as the party's No. 2 leader, Soviet officials said today.

title: Halting Steps Toward Modular Housing
description: New York City, desperate for low-cost housing, could produce units by the thousands if it could only turn out prefabricated modular housing. A Staten Island factory that would do so finally approaches reality, but a similar development in the Bronx has bogged down because the developer insisted on employing handymen and elevator operators rather than carpenters and plumbers.

title: Lacroix: Meteor or Constant Star?
description: Christian Lacroix's visit to New York this week proved that he's a bona-fide fashion celebrity. Parties were held in his honor, and people lined up for his autograph. But his visit is more than a social call.

title: Library Is Neutral
description: Curators at the Huntington Library here would neither support nor dispute today Professor Levi's contention that the 14 verses were written by Shakespeare.

title: Veronica Parker Johns, Mystery Writer, 81
description: Veronica Parker Johns, a mystery story writer who lived in Manhattan, died in Lenox Hill Hospital on April 14. She was 81 years old. Miss Johns was a member of the Mystery Writers of America for 42 years. Her novels included ''Hush, Gabriel!,'' ''Shady Doings,'' ''Murder by the Day'' and ''Servant's Problem.'' She was president of the New York Shell Club in 1975 and was the author of ''She Sells Sea Shells.''

title: G.M. Share Is Higher, Profits Disappointing
description: The General Motors Corporation's heavy use of financial incentives helped it to regain some of its lost share of the car and truck market but caused it to earn slightly less in the first quarter than many analysts had expected.

title: Alexander K. Reddin, Executive Recruiter, 72
description: Alexander K. Reddin, a retired executive-recruiting consultant, died of cancer April 14 at his home in Norwalk, Conn. He was 72 years old.

title: SUNY Selects A Chancellor From Within
description: The State University of New York has selected D. Bruce Johnstone, the president of Buffalo State College, to be its new Chancellor, university officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Profits Increase Sharply at Time Inc. and Times Mirror
description: Time Inc. and the Times Mirror Company reported higher first-quarter income yesterday. Both companies said increased profits from their cable operations contributed.

title: TV Sale Set By Murdoch
description: Rupert Murdoch put his Boston television station up for sale today, saying he would have difficulty receiving a Government waiver allowing him to own both the station and a daily newspaper in the city.

title: BancTexas Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that in the latest first quarter there was no added provision for loan losses, while there was a $15 million additional provision in last year's first quarter.

title: California Officials Limit the Harvesting Of Older Redwoods
description: In a surprise decision, state officials have limited harvesting of ancient redwoods in a Northern California forest that has become the focus of an environmental battle.

title: 1,000 Shades of Purple in the Bronx
description: Proudly gazing at a 10-year-old orchid with a mottled lip of lemon yellow and deep purple, Henry Rothman tried to put into words why the judges had bestowed on his plant the Rodney Wilcox Jones Memorial Award for the Best Brassocattleya or Brassolaeliocattleya in the show.

title: HOUSE VOTES 3 TO 1 FOR BILL ON TRADE FOUGHT BY REAGAN
description: Defying a veto threat by President Reagan, the House of Representatives today overwhelmingly passed the most comprehensive trade legislation in 14 years.

title: Refuse Concern To Be Formed
description: Two leading companies in the solid waste management industry, Waste Management Inc. and the Henley Group Inc., said today they had agreed to form a new waste-to-energy company with assets and annual revenues of more than $1 billion.

title: Bahrain Ruler Backs U.S. Gulf Raids
description: Seated in a cavernous meeting hall in his palace, the diminutive, white-robed ruler of Bahrain expressed no qualms about the display this week of American firepower in the Persian Gulf.

title: U.S. Marathoners' Best Isn't Enough
description: In the last five days, nine men have run a marathon in under 2 hours 10 minutes, including one, Belayney Densimo of Ethiopia, who became the first to break 2:07, with a world best time of 2:06:49 last Sunday in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.

title: Review/Film; A Teen-Ager's Suicide
description: Why should popular, talented, good-looking, success-bound David jump into the Pacific Ocean? If the writers of ''Permanent Record'' know, they are not telling. Anyhow, the event creates great distress among David's high school classmates, especially his best pal and musical collaborator, the sexpot whose favors he has been enjoying, and a shy, serious-minded girl who admires him. All are played by young folks dressed in jeans and acting-school mannerisms.

title: Comings and Goings
description: John McEnroe, who returned after a seven-month absence from tournament competition and defeated Stefan Edberg last Sunday to win the Japan Open, will play in a $126,000 tournament in Florence on May 16-22, Before that he will compete in the Tournament of Champions in New York and the Italian Open in Rome. . . . July 30 is the date announced by Chris Evert for her marriage to Andy Mill, a former Olympic downhill skier from Aspen, Colo. It will be held in Boca Raton, Fla. . . . Dave Jennings, who has been a punter with the Giants and the Jets, will provide analysis of New York Knights arena football games on the Madison Square Garden cable network beginning May 9. . . . Bill Gullickson, the pitcher who spurned the Yankees for a season in Japan, won his third game without defeat as the Yomiuri Giants beat the Hiroshima Toyo Carp, 4-2, yesterday. Gullickson pitched a six-hitter.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's 421 money market mutual funds decreased $850.6 million, to $273.93 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 114 institutional funds decreased $2.10 billion, to $73.14 billion. Assets of the 210 general-purpose funds were up $1.01 billion, to $83.24 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds increased $246.1 million, to $117.54 billion.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Security Council Meets at 10:30 A.M. on Tunisian complaint against Israel. Economic and Social Council CHILDREN'S FUND - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Walker Scotch Ads: Image Is All
description: FOR the first time in memory, Johnnie Walker Red will go through the fall and holiday season without advertising support.

title: Support for Lendl
description: The ball in the Congressional court took a strong bounce Ivan Lendl's way yesterday in Washington when a House immigration subcommittee approved without opposition the tennis player's bid to have a customary five-year waiting period for American citizenship waived so that he can participate for the United States team in the Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea.

title: Salomon Earnings Up 16.1% in First Quarter
description: Salomon Inc., the parent of one of Wall Street's largest securities firms, announced yesterday that its first-quarter earnings increased 16.1 percent.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Armtek Corp., New Haven, Conn., a maker of automotive and industrial products, said its board approved the sale would sell of its Armstrong tire subsidiary to the Italian tire maker Pirelli for $190 million.

title: Continental Bank Stake
description: First Chicago agreed today to acquire a large portion of Continental Bank's consumer banking business. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: House Panel Assails Approval of T.V.A. Reactor
description: Members of Congress complained today that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission had approved plans to restart a repaired power reactor at the Tennessee Valley Authority while knowing that safety questions remained unresolved.

title: Review/Dance; Dance: 'Parisienne,' A Ruffled Confection From Ballet Theater
description: THINK of a huge hot fudge sundae topped by a banana split and you get a taste of American Ballet Theater's eagerly awaited revival of ''Gaite Parisienne.''

title: Dukakis Avoids Commitments to Factions In an Unusual Course Toward Nominations
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts has come close to winning the Democratic Presidential nomination without making the commitments on issues or to interest groups that have crippled Democratic Presidential candidates in the past.

title: Skepticism Over Tax-Exempts
description: A tremor initially went through the municipal markets Wednesday when it was learned that the Supreme Court had ruled that Congress has the right, if it chooses, to begin taxing the interest income paid on bonds issued by states and localities.

title: Theodore R. Urban, Upholsterer, 58
description: Theodore R. Urban, an upholsterer who did work for the White House, died of lung cancer Wednesday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 58 years old and lived in Middle Village, Queens.

title: Staley Rebuff To Tate & Lyle
description: Staley Continental Inc.'s board of directors today rejected Tate & Lyle P.L.C.'s $32-a-share bid and urged stockholders not to tender their shares to the British sugar giant.

title: Devils Ready To Play Rough
description: As the Devils become more and more a reflection of their coach, who was a notorious tough guy as a player, getting them mad is probably the last thing you would want to do.

title: Tulane Basketball Back
description: Tulane University announced today that it would reinstitute men's basketball and hoped to resume play in the 1990-1991 season. The university abolished the program three years ago after a point-shaving scandal.

title: Two Who Quit Justice Dept. Meet With Reagan and Bush
description: President Reagan and Vice President Bush met at the White House on Wednesday with two Justice Department officials who recently resigned in protest over the leadership of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, a department official said tonight.

title: Dwight Gooden At the Age of 23
description: A COLLEAGUE stopped me short last week when he said: ''You know who the best interview is in the Met clubhouse? It's Dwight Gooden.'' I thought about the flat voice and the averted eyes of a couple of years ago, but my friend convinced me there was a different Gooden these days.

title: Oiler-Raider Trade
description: In a move to bolster their defense, the Houston Oilers traded their selection in the first round of Sunday's National Football League draft to the Los Angeles Raiders for Sean Jones, a defensive end who led the American Conference with 15 1/2 sacks in 1986.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Criticizes Ethiopia

title: House Unit's Drexel Inquiry
description: Michael Milken, the head of Drexel Burnham Lambert's high-yield ''junk bond'' department, has been subpoenaed to testify next week before a Congressional subcommittee that has been investigating Drexel's practices in the junk bond market.

title: Noriega Reported to Discuss Stepping Down
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega has been holding indirect conversations with opposition groups, apparently to find a formula allowing him to step down with his wealth and his dignity intact, opposition figures and diplomats say.

title: On Stage
description: What Are Those Things?

title: Market Place; Unequal Voting Facing Challenge
description: TWO major publishing and broadcasting companies have moved to strengthen their takeover defenses in the wake of a hostile bid for Media General Inc. that challenges its dual classes of stock, which have different voting rights. Some analysts also believe that executives at other companies in the industry are re-evaluating their anti-takeover arsenal because the low stock prices of media companies have made them ripe takeover targets.

title: Bell Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago per share earnings were not available; the company went public in February 1987.

title: No Slight to Deaf In Oscar Broadcast
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nature of Pilate Remains an Enigma
description: To the Editor:

title: Value Added Tax Is Wrong Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: No. 3 Bank Says Profit Rose 62.7%
description: The BankAmerica Corporation today reported its best quarterly financial results in three years, a further sign that the banking company is on the mend after losing $1.8 billion over that time.

title: Mt Baker Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank said after-tax expenses of $132,321 related to its proposed acquisition by U.S. Bancorp contributed significantly to the decline in earnings.

title: Society for Savings Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $542,000.

title: Obscure Poem, Oxonian Argues, Is Shakespeare's
description: A British professor's contention that he has authenticated a hitherto unpublished poem of 14 short verses as probably having been written by William Shakespeare for a betrothal party has set the stage for a major scholarly dispute.

title: Diner's Journal
description: A Sunday Spot

title: 76ers Defeat Nets And Gain Ground
description: Charles Barkley scored 38 points and grabbed 19 rebounds to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 104-101 victory over the Nets tonight and set up a final weekend decision on the last two playoff spots in the Eastern Conference.

title: Sex and the Marines
description: Marine Corps officers need an attitude adjustment, according to a letter from their Commandant, Gen. Alfred M. Gray, who advised them that regardless of what they might feel, all marines were created equal, whether they are men or women.

title: RHNB Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Slaught's Hitting Is Healthy
description: One day after he absorbed a stinging jolt in a home-plate collision at the Metrodome, Don Slaught was still hurting. His right shoulder - the one that had absorbed most of the force of Gary Gaetti's charging body Tuesday night - was red and not freely movable. The area at the base of his left thumb, where he was hit initially, also bothered him.

title: Dime Savings Bank of New York reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $9,491,000 for the latest quarter and $9,275,000 for the year-earlier period. Year-ago quarter results are restated to reflect FASB No. 91, accounting for non-refundable loan fees and costs. The company said the latest quarter net includes sales of $921.7 million of Dime-originated loans resulting in a pre-tax gain of $18 million. The company also said that in the latest quarter, it recognized a one- time $3.2 million writedown on a previously restructured loan on a Florida hotel property. Because this property is still carried as owned real estate, the writedown is charged to other expenses.

title: Pretoria Suggests a Black Electoral Role
description: President P. W. Botha today raised the possibility of constitutional changes that could pave the way for black participation in the national Government and in the election of the President.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Jerry Schneider has been named publisher and chief operating officer at Careers magazine.

title: NBSC Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Horse Racing Notebook; Wood May Refine Forecasts on Derby
description: For the first time since 1982, the winner of the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct could go to Louisville as the favorite for the Kentucky Derby.

title: The Blase Are Awed by 10,000 Items of Warhol
description: ''Where did he put all this stuff?''

title: Save Theater Interiors
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Policy and Such Public: The Whole Story
description: Some of the most careful writing in the capital is done every morning when the State Department, Pentagon and White House begin preparing their public statements on the previous day's events.

title: Our Towns; From L.I. Sound, A New Nation Asserts Itself
description: ''No man is an Iland,'' John Donne wrote. Not even Dean Kamen, sole owner and resident of this rocky three-acre freckle in Long Island Sound, three miles off Noank, Conn. ''I am an empire!'' he boasts. Mr. Kamen, a 36-year-old bachelor and millionaire inventor who prefers to be called Lord Dumpling, has fulfilled one of life's larger fantasies. For $2.5 million, he has bought an island - complete with mansion, lighthouse and a copy of Stonehenge - and seceded from the world around him, or so he likes to believe.

title: Christopher S. Cahan Is Wed to Vicki Sheff
description: The marriage of Vicki Bunch Sheff, the daughter of Beth Spencer of Memphis and the late Russell Bunch, to Christopher Sykes Cahan, a son of Mary S. Cahan and Dr. William G. Cahan, both of New York, took place yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's father. Justice Alvin Schlesinger of State Supreme Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony.

title: American Express Earnings Fall 15.3% as Revenue Rises
description: The American Express Company reported yesterday that its earnings dropped 15.3 percent in the first quarter while revenues rose 31 percent.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Doremus Sets Up Link With Japanese Agency
description: Doremus & Company, the Omnicom Group's business-to-business and financial agency, has established a relationship with Nihon Keizaisha Advertising of Tokyo. Each will establish an office in the other's headquarters city to service its clients back home.

title: Review/Theater; A 'Macbeth' Starring Plummer and Jackson
description: The destiny of Macbeth becomes clear in the opening scenes of Shakespeare's play, once the witches chart out a grisly future that the hero seems all too willing to embrace. The destiny of ''Macbeth,'' as acted by Christopher Plummer and Glenda Jackson on Broadway, can be guessed even earlier. Open the Playbill, and one finds one of the season's zanier attributions of directorial credit. The production has ''original direction by Kenneth Frankel'' and ''additional direction by Zoe Caldwell.'' Is this what is meant by begging a question? If there was a true director of record for this ''Macbeth'' - a final arbiter of artistic decisions, a brave leader willing to be left holding the bag - he or she seems more elusive than Banquo's ghost.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; B.B.D.O. Is Given Some of the Ragu Ads
description: Also under the Omnicom umbrella, Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn has been selected by Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. to serve as the second agency on its Ragu brand, whose only agency has been Waring & LaRosa, another Omnicom company.

title: Helen Biren, Geology Professor, 81
description: Helen Biren, professor emeritus of geology at Hunter College and Brooklyn College, died of a stroke yesterday at Peninsula Hospital in Far Rockaway, Queens. She was 81 years old and lived in Belle Harbor, Queens.

title: First Federal Savings & Loan (Fort Myers) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dukakis And Jackson
description: The impressive victory of Michael Dukakis in the New York primary has led some Democrats and observers to claim that his nomination for President now is ''inevitable.'' It may be, but voters this year have had a way of reacting against front-runners - for example, Senator Bob Dole and Representative Richard Gephardt after the Iowa caucuses.

title: Cuomo Tells Koch of the Sounds of Silence
description: In 15 minutes yesterday, Governor Cuomo rescued Mayor Koch from the boos of his own constituents, told him to keep quiet and implied that the Mayor's vociferous attacks on the Rev. Jesse Jackson had led the press to paint New York unfairly as a ''hellhole of contention and divisiveness.''

title: Linowitz's Call for Lawyers to Be People Again
description: Sol M. Linowitz celebrated two milestones last weekend, but Mr. Linowitz, a Washington lawyer, former ambassador and international negotiator, was not in a celebratory mood. In Ithaca, N.Y., for Cornell Law School's centennial observance, an event that also marked 50 years since he received his own law degree there, Mr. Linowitz delivered a grim keynote address on the state of American law practice.

title: Duke Requires All Departments To Hire Blacks
description: After two weeks of student and faculty protests, Duke University's Faculty Advisory Council voted today to reverse its position on the recruitment of black faculty members and require each of the university's more than 50 departments to hire one additional black faculty member by 1993.

title: Cup Series Proposal
description: The group managing the defense of the America's Cup for San Diego agreed yesterday to a challenge series in which a British yacht club will compete with New Zealand for the right to face the San Diego Yacht Club's defender.

title: Schroeder Trade Denied
description: The No. 2 quarterback of the Super Bowl champion Washington Redskins has been the No. 1 topic of trade talks during the off season, but yesterday it looked as if Jay Schroeder's days with Washington were far from numbered.

title: Washington Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $528,000 and $800,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $270,000 and $570,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and also includes a $735,000 charge from a prepayment penalty on an advance from the Federal Home Loan Bank.

title: Ex-ITT Official Named Chief of General Signal
description: Edmund M. Carpenter, who resigned earlier this week as president of the ITT Corporation, yesterday was named the chairman and chief executive of the General Signal Corporation.

title: Top Executive Teams Reported Set at Macy
description: R. H. Macy & Company has named top executive teams as part of an internal restructuring, according to industry sources.

title: Review/Film; Basque-Style Romance in 'A Time of Destiny'
description: ''A Time of Destiny,'' opening today at the Gotham, is something of a first and, perhaps, a last.

title: Alaskan Lost in Nepal Climb
description: A 27-year-old American, Christian Liebundgut of Wasilla, Alaska, has disappeared after reaching the summit of Mount Pumori, a 23,494-foot mountain near Mount Everest, the Tourism Ministry said today. Mr. Liebundgut, a carpenter, disappeared April 18 in a snow storm, the ministry said. The three surviving members of the American expedition were expected to return to Katmandu today.

title: 3 Durer Masterpieces Vandalized With Acid
description: A homeless man embittered by cuts in his pension payments seriously damaged three paintings by Albrecht Durer in a museum here today by spraying them with sulfuric acid from a champagne bottle.

title: Textron Net Falls 35.7%
description: Textron Inc. said today that its first-quarter earnings dropped 35.7 percent because of a $20 million arbitrator's award against an insurance subisidiary and early redemption of $130 million in high-interest debt. The aerospace, commercial products and financial services company said it earned $38.7 million, or 43 cents a share, down from $60.2 million, or 72 cents a share, in the first three months of 1987. Revenue for the quarter ended April 2 was slightly changed at $1.82 billion, down from $1.84 billion.

title: Strike Costs Assayed
description: The Association of Motion Picture and Television Producers said today that more than $15 million in salaries and benefits had been lost because of the writers' strike, which is now in its seventh week.

title: Des Allemands Journal; Crab-Trap Crime Wave in Louisiana
description: In this quiet fishing village nestled in bayou country, the anger is epidemic. Somewhere nearby and soon, the fishermen say, there's going to be a murder. ''It's around the corner,'' says Leon Fonseca, his sunburned face darkening. ''It might be tomorrow, the next day or the following week.'' His brother Walter finishes, ''If the law don't get into this, it's going to happen.''

title: No Headline
description: ''I want no part of a stop-Jackson or stop-Dukakis movement. The only man I want to stop is George Bush.'' - Senator Albert Gore Jr. [ A16:1. ]

title: More Gloom At Lord, Geller
description: Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, the WPP Group subsidiary that has suffered a major brain drain, received more distressing news this week.

title: More Erosion in J st e
description: Two of Attorney General Edwin Meese's top appointees and four of their deputies resigned in disgust three weeks ago. Yet no replacements are yet in sight, even as more Department of Justice officials resign. Why? Because Mr. Meese, who should be leading the search for a solution, is himself the paramount problem.

title: Mexican Gang Frees 42 to Get Safe Passage
description: Seven gunmen surrounded in a bank after a foiled robbery freed 42 captives and were allowed to flee with three hostages today after a 24-hour standoff in which five people were killed.

title: Suffolk Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company attributes the change in share earnings and R.O.E. to the proceeds of a secondary offering of 500,000 shares in June 1987. Per share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 5-for-1 split in August 1986 and a 2-for-1 split in May 1987.

title: Review/Art; A Look at a Decade of Elizabeth Murray's Works
description: The Elizabeth Murray exhibition completing its six-stop tour at the Whitney Museum of American Art provides the first concentrated look at one of America's best painters. Her canvases, shaped like commas, palettes or armor, are coated with paint that can suggest fabric, metal or earth. There is no fear of sentiment here. There are few artists with a better sense of the manifold meanings and possibilities of painting. Ms. Murray gives intimate feelings and subjects a monumentality they have rarely had before.

title: Roll-Call Vote in House On Sweeping Trade Bill
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 312 to 107 by which the House passed the trade bill today. A ''yes'' vote was a vote to pass the bill, and a ''no'' vote was a vote to defeat it. Voting ''yes'' were 244 Democrats and 68 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 2 Democrats and 105 Republicans. An ''x'' is a member not voting. The 435-member House has three vacancies. ALABAMA

title: Hodel Wins One
description: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel has taken a fair amount of criticism from conservation groups that contend he has favored the exploitation of Federal lands for energy and other commodities over the preservation of those lands for wildlife and recreation. But the conservation committee of the National Society Daughters of the American Revolution thinks Mr. Hodel is swell.

title: Saxophones and More
description: Tom Guralnick, a saxophonist and composer, is to play music for his Mobile Saxophone and Mute Unit - an assemblage of saxophones, electronics and woodwinds - tomorrow at 9 P.M. at Kraine Gallery, 85 East Fourth Street (254-7706). Admission is $5.

title: Group's Founder Raises Money to Promote Interests of Children
description: It is not your typical political headquarters. A blue stroller graces the entrance, and there is a playpen in the reception area. The silence is often broken by an 11-month-old baby's bid for attention.

title: '68 Passions Replayed at Columbia
description: Mark Rudd, the fiery Columbia rebel of 1968, is now a 40-year-old writer living quietly in Albuquerque, N.M. The university president's office, seized then by rebels, is occupied by Michael I. Sovern, a calm-spoken former arbitrator.

title: Reliably, Donovan Is Back
description: She still stands well above the others on a basketball court, a one-time all-American at Old Dominion who is now regarded as Ole Reliable among the women. Anne Donovan has surprised even herself with her continuing desire to play, especially in light of the sacrifices that she has made to earn a living in basketball.

title: Bush Returns Show Benefit From '87 Tax Law Changes
description: Vice President Bush benefited from the sweeping changes in Federal income tax law last year, returns released by his office today show.

title: Jackson Said, 'Take My Hand'
description: LEAD: You'd have to say it was before the transformation - before he was a major force in Presidential politics, before he had kissed thousands of white babies. It was 9 o'clock on a Sunday morning last August. My brother, Larry, and I were on the eighth floor of the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, a place we had left only rarely in the preceding two weeks.

title: Haikou Journal; The Short March to Capitalism Takes a Great Leap
description: Hainan Island drips into the South China Sea like a dollop of marmalade from a spoon, tingling the entrepreneurial appetites of China's leadership far to the north.

title: Kate Rodina Steichen, Publishing Executive, 79
description: Kate Rodina Steichen, a daughter of Edward Steichen, the photographer, and a niece of Carl Sandburg, died of lymphoma sarcoma Monday at her home in Wilton, Conn. She was 79 years old.

title: Pop/Jazz; Country Without Sequins
description: Country music, gaudy with sequins and sentiment, is often portrayed as monolithically simple, as if it sprang fully grown, free of outside influences, from the South. But country music's past, like the past of America's other historically complex, indigenous forms - jazz, blues and gospel - is a document of social interaction and movement in America. And, above all, it's an accurate document: through it, we can understand the different intertwinings of black, white, urban and rural cultures, and what the friction and empathy between them has produced.

title: Anti-Acne Drug Faulted in Birth Defects
description: Government officials estimate that the popular anti-acne drug Accutane has caused hundreds, perhaps more than 1,000, babies to be born with severe birth defects in the past six years.

title: U.S. Delivers Food to Contras in Honduras
description: An official of the Agency for International Development said today that the United States began delivering food to Nicaraguan rebels in Honduras under a new program this week.

title: Corrections
description: A calendar of exhibits and tours in The Home Section yesterday gave an incorrect schedule for a pottery bazaar at Greenwich House Pottery, 16 Jones Street, near Bleecker Street. It takes place today from 1 to 9 P.M. and tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: First Wisconsin Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes $57.2 million gain on the sale of the headquarters property and additional tax benefits applicable to last year's less developed countries loan loss provisions.

title: Drop That Pistol!
description: It happened in January and, as diplomatic gaffes go, it was not big league, but on Embassy Row people are still talking about the episode of the perverse pistol.

title: ETHIOPIA ASSAILED BY U.S. ON FAMINE
description: The United States denounced Ethiopia today for impeding international efforts to combat famine in its northern provinces, and Administration officials appealed to the Soviet Union to help prevent what President Reagan described as an imminent ''human catastrophe'' in the East African country.

title: Brazil-I.M.F. Accord in June
description: Brazil will sign an agreement with the International Monetary Fund in June to put a series of economic reforms into effect in return for emergency financial assistance, a senior Government official said today.

title: Bridge
description: A player who doubles a game or a slam out of a clear blue sky usually has something in mind. That something is the opening lead if that will be the responsibility of his partner. His intentions are generally clear against a slam, following the Lightner recipe: ''Consider giving me a ruff, if that seems feasible, and try dummy's suit rather than anything more obvious or passive.''

title: Amercian Bionetics reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
BankAmerica Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $20 million tax credit. The company said its adoption of FAS No. 91 during the latest first quarter resulted in a $7 million reduction in net income.

title: 1 Killed and 4 Hurt in Fire
description: One person was killed and four others were critically injured in a fire that swept through a four-story building at 1421 DeKalb Avenue in the Wyckoff Heights section of Brooklyn last night, officials said. Two of the victims were taken to Woodhull Hospital, and two were taken to Wyckoff Hospital. None of the victims was immediately identified. One firefighter and four police officers were treated at the scene for smoke inhalation.

title: Progress Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Castro Indicates He'll Free Hundreds
description: Fidel Castro indicated today to John Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, that he is prepared to free several hundred political prisoners ''quite quickly,'' the Cardinal said.

title: First Jersey Case Is Settled
