description: A former director of the First Jersey National Corporation and her husband today settled Federal civil charges that they traded First Jersey stock while possessing non-public information about merger negotiations with a unit of National Westminster Bank P.L.C. of Britain last summer.

title: Nelson Planning to Start for Giants
description: In the last eight months, Karl Nelson has undergone surgery and radiation treatment for Hodgkin's disease, and shoulder surgery. Now he is spending five hours a day trying to regain his strength so when the Giants open their National Football League season Sept. 5 he will be back at his old job as the starting right tackle on offense.

title: About Real Estate; Manhattan-Style Luxury In Suburban Apartments
description: Luxury apartments of the kind associated with the fashionable neighborhoods of Manhattan are finally arriving in the suburbs.

title: New Look At Orson Welles
description: When Orson Welles died in 1985 at the age of 70, he had spent nearly half a century battling the stigma of a career many viewed as largely unfulfilled. Featured on the cover of Time magazine as the ''Wonder Boy'' of the theater when he was only 23, Welles was first pronounced a has-been at 24, a verdict repeated regularly for the rest of his life despite some remarkable achievements.

title: Hearst Names Publishers At Two of Its Magazines
description: As part of a series of executive changes at the Hearst Corporation's magazines division, Alan Waxenberg has been named publisher of Good Housekeeping after six years as publisher of Redbook.

title: Self Magazine's New Editor
description: Elizabeth Crow is leaving as editor in chief of Parents magazine to take a similar position at Self magazine.

title: Rain, and Records, Fall
description: The twilight-night doubleheader between the San Diego Padres and the Los Angeles Dodgers was rained out tonight, marking the first time in the 26-year history of Dodger Stadium that games had been rained out on three straight days. It was the 15th rainout ever at Dodger Stadium, the sixth involving the Padres. No makeup dates have been announced.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Reached agreement with Jim Mora, head coach, on a five-year contract. COLLEGES N.C.A.A. - Upheld sanctions against Cleveland State University for recruiting violations; sanctions include a three-year probationary period, a two-year ban on postseason play for the men's basketball team, a one-year ban on live television appearances by the team and a number of recruiting restrictions. CORNELL - Named Kim Jordan head women's basketball coach. HOLYOKE - Anounced that Les Poolman, athletic director and head soccer coach, has resigned to become athletic director at Dickinson. ST. LOUIS - Named Jackson Wheeler assistant basketball coach. SOUTH CAROLINA - Named Dr. John T. Moore associate athletic director for internal affairs.

title: Dining Out Guide: Seafood
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants reviewed in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Cafe 58

title: I. A. L. Diamond Is Dead at 67; Won Oscar for 'The Apartment'
description: I. A. L. Diamond, the Hollywood screenwriter and the longtime collaborator of the director Billy Wilder, died of multiple myeloma, a form of cancer, yesterday at his home in Beverly Hills. He was 67 years old. Mr. Diamond, who spent his entire professional life writing movies, was best known for the films he made with Mr. Wilder. These included ''Love in the Afternoon,'' ''Some Like It Hot,'' ''The Apartment,'' ''One, Two, Three,'' ''The Fortune Cookie,'' ''Irma la Douce,'' ''Kiss Me, Stupid,'' ''The Private Life of Sherlock Holmes,'' ''The Front Page,'' ''Fedora,'' ''Avanti'' and ''Buddy, Buddy.''

title: Books of The Times; 'Black Box' Explores the Crash of a Marriage
description: Black Box By Amos Oz Translated by Nicholas de Lange and Mr. Oz. 259 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich; a Helen and Kurt Wolff Book. $19.95.

title: Jakarta Sees Oil Accord
description: Indonesia expects that OPEC will reach agreement with leading producers outside the organization to stabilize oil prices over the long term, the Indonesian Minister of Mines and Energy said today.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Marathon at Parsons

title: Police Say Mother Killed Missing Baby
description: A woman who said Wednesday that her 2-month-old son had been kidnapped from his stroller on a Brooklyn street was charged last night with second-degree murder in his death.

title: Milosz to Read
description: Czeslaw Milosz, the Nobel Prize winning Polish poet, will give a benefit reading at the New York University Club, 123 West 43d Street, tomorrow at 5:30 P.M. Mr. Milosz, who won the Nobel Prize in 1980, will read selections from his poetry in both Polish and English translation. Proceeds from the $100-a-person reading will support the Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences in America, a Manhattan-based scholarly organization dedicated to Polish culture. Reservations: 686-4164.

title: American Express Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes $49 million on deferred income tax benefits recorded to comply with new FASB accounting rules adopted in December 1987.

title: N.Y.U. Law School Acts to Bar Sex Bias
description: A law professor calls only on women students, or calls on them only if they volunteer. Or he says he will not tell certain jokes ''because ladies are present.'' In hypothetical cases cited in class, a woman is always a client and a man is always the lawyer, judge or legislator.

title: Pro-Iran Faction Says It Will Try U.S. Captive
description: A pro-Iranian group that says it is holding a United States Marine officer captive said today that it was putting the marine on trial on charges of spying.

title: Westcorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Frankly, It's a Mistake
description: When last seen, he was leaving Atlanta to ''hunt in old towns and old countries where some of the old times must still linger.'' She was heading for ''a haven in which to plan her campaign'' to get her husband back. That would be Tara, of course.

title: Book Notes;
description: In what is thought to be the largest reprint sale of any book published by a university press, Ballantine Books has agreed to pay $504,000 for ''Battle Cry of Freedom: The Civil War Era'' by James M. McPherson, published by Oxford University Press.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday HAPPY BIRTHDAY, WILL

title: Campaign Trail
description: Western Running Mate?

title: Playwright and Poet At Black Roots Festival
description: The playwright August Wilson and the poet Rita Dove - both winners of Pulitzer Prizes - will be amonth those taking part in the 16th Black Roots Festival on Sunday at 5 P.M. at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street. Mr. Wilson, winner of the Pulitzer Prize for drama for his play ''Fences,'' will read from his newest play, ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone.''

title: Corrections
description: A front-page map on Tuesday illustrating the clashes in the Persian Gulf misidentified Qatar and Bahrain. Qatar is the larger country; it is southeast of Bahrain.

title: Irving Bank Postpones Crucial Vote
description: The Irving Bank Corporation yesterday postponed its shareholder meeting in an attempt to thwart the Bank of New York Company in its proxy fight to take over Irving.

title: Animed Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $775,000 and $127,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: CD That Is Erasable Introduced by Tandy
description: The Tandy Corporation today introduced the THOR-CD, the first erasable, re-usable compact disk system. Using a laser beam, the THOR-CD can digitally record, play back, store and erase either music, video or data on an optical disk.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Palmer Leads U.S. Team: Arnold Palmer birdied the 18th hole from 30 feet yesterday, leading the United States to a sweep of four best-ball team matches and a 16-0 lead after the opening day of competition for the Chrysler Cup in Sarasota, Fla. Palmer's chip shot from behind the green allowed him and Chi Chi Rodriguez to defeat Gary Player and Bob Charles of the international team, 1 up, on the par 72, 6,763-yard course. Billy Casper and Al Geiberger of the United States beat Roberto De Vicenzo and Bruce Devlin by the same score.

title: BankAtlantic FSB reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Economic Scene; When to Worry About Inflation
description: OFFICIALS of the Administration and the Federal Reserve continue to talk reassuringly about the lack of inflationary pressure, but the bond and stock markets continue to worry. This week the markets had fresh reasons for concern: rising oil prices as a result of clashes in the Persian Gulf, and reports that producer prices rose in March by six-tenths of 1 percent and consumer prices by five-tenths of 1 percent - annual rates of 6 to 7 percent.

title: U.S. Issues Show Little Change
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were little changed to slightly lower yesterday in thin, directionless trading.

title: U.S.-ISRAEL ACCORD CODIFIES RELATIONS
description: The United States and Israel signed an agreement today making formal their cooperation on a range of military, economic, political and intelligence matters.

title: Corrections
description: An Associated Press article in some editions yesterday about a Supreme Court ruling on the distribution of union literature at the University of California misstated the background. The Court reversed a decision by a California agency; it did not uphold it.

title: All Vietnam Is Now a Stage; Its Players Are Mostly Angry
description: In a short story much talked about these days in Vietnam, a dying grandmother is knocked to the ground by rough militiamen in a midnight tax raid. They want the rice she has stored in her coffin, her insurance against indignity in death.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9 Yegor K. Ligachev is losing key posts in the Kremlin, according to Soviet officials. They said the Politburo had all but removed Mr. Ligachev as the party's No. 2 leader. Page A1

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Needham Officer Quits To 'Smell the Flowers'
description: For Al Wolfe, president of the domestic operation of DDB Needham Worldwide, 56 years of age seems like the proper time to ''smell the flowers and scratch a bit and to ponder the business that has been my second love all these years, and to think about how I want to spend the rest of my life.''

title: Portsmouth Bank Shares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: No per share earnings available since the company went public in February.

title: American City Business Jourals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Profits Scoreboard
description: Net-Income Income Jan.-Mar. Change 1988 From '87 American Express Co. $266,000,000 -15.3 Colgate-Palmolive Corp. 65,400,000 +16.0 Compaq Computer Corp. 46,800,000 +131.7 Data General Corp. 17,200,000 *- Eaton Corp. 60,300,000 +0.2 GAF Corp. 22,700,000 -45.6 General Motors Corp. 1,092,100,000 +18.4 Henley Group Inc. 103,000,000 *- Holiday Corp. (18,800,000) - Inland Steel Industries 63,600,000 +1.8 MCA Inc. 26,900,000 -6.6 McDonald's Corp. 125,800,000 +17.7 PPG Industries 118,600,000 +36.5 RJR Nabisco Inc. 273,000,000 +24.1 Salomon Inc. 173,000,000 +16.1 Texas Instruments Inc. 85,500,000 -4.9 Textron Inc. 38,700,000 -35.7 Time Inc. 66,000,000 +43.5 Times Mirror Co. 75,100,000 +29.0 Union Carbide Corp. 101,000,000 +53.0 See accompanying notes for special items. ... (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: After 45 Years, Vindication for Scholar
description: For more than four decades, his Ph.D. dissertation remained locked in a steel box, the bitter legacy of an academic future that had died when a faculty committee at the University of Chicago rejected the manuscript.

title: Heritage-NIS Bank for Savngs reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Borden's Lemon Battle
description: The United States food giant Borden Inc. lost another round today in its court battle to enter the British lemon juice market. The Court of Appeal dismissed Borden's appeal against last year's High Court ruling preventing the company from selling Realemon on the ground that consumers would confuse it with Jif, a popular British product manufactured by Reckitt & Colman. Both products contain lemon juice in plastic lemon-shaped squeeze containers.

title: America Is Better Off Than Before Ronald Reagan Took Office
description: To the Editor:

title: Byrd Sees No Need to Hurry Senate Action on Arms Pact
description: The Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, said today that the Senate would not rush its consideration of the treaty on intermediate-range arms simply to accommodate the White House.

title: End the Death Penalty For Crimes by Minors
description: To the Editor:

title: Managers to Buy A Wickes Business
description: The Wickes Companies, the furniture and home-improvement retailer, said it would sell its lumber business to the unit's managers for $320 million, a plan that was derailed earlier this year. Wickes Lumber, based in Vernon Hills, Ill., is one of the nation's largest home-improvement retailers, with 225 outlets nationwide and sales of about $1.1 billion in 1987.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about political polling misstated the Presidential selection process in Michigan. The state conducts caucuses, not a primary election.

title: Helmsleys Plead Not Guilty to Evading U.S. Taxes
description: Harry and Leona Helmsley, whose hotel and real-estate holdings are valued at $5 billion, pleaded not guilty yesterday to Federal charges of income-tax evasion and extortion.

title: Nafco Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary income of $151,000.

title: Ford to Delete a Model
description: The Ford Motor Company plans to eliminate its two-seat Escort EXP model this summer, to allow more production of the Escort, the Escort wagon and the Escort GT. Ford sold 24,427 EXP's last year, out of a total of 392,360 Escorts, it said Wednesday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; The Scott Paper Search Is Down to 3 Agencies
description: The Scott Paper Company, which started a search for a new agency March 1 and has been totally open about its progress since, announced yesterday that it had cut the field to three from five and should have a winner by June 1.

title: At the Movies
description: Alien Love

title: Review/Art; 3 Donald Sultan Shows: Paintings to 'Black Eggs'
description: The art of Donald Sultan is in some ways perfect, and yet it leaves a lot to be desired. This is the paradox that presents itself in three exhibitions that make Mr. Sultan's work abundantly visible in New York right now. A survey of his paintings and charcoal drawings from the 1980's is on view at the Brooklyn Museum, while at the Museum of Modern Art there is a small show devoted to prints of his signatory image of poisoned fecundity, the ''black lemon.'' At the artist's home base, the Blum Helman Gallery, there is a new variation on his dark spheres: ''black egg'' drawings. Walking through these shows, the popular Wendy's commercials of yesteryear come to mind, the question being not so much ''where's the beef?'' as ''where's the juice?'' Where's the passion, the risk - not to mention the occasional loose end?

title: Review/Film; 'White Mischief,' Death of a Rake
description: It's not easy being decadent, though intelligence isn't required. One must have a certain amount of time and money (or credit), an all-consuming self-interest and, whenever possible, an exotic setting in which to misbehave. Good looks, preferably beauty, also help, as well as the constitution of a goat.

title: 13 Named in Extortion Case On Minority Building Pacts
description: Thirteen people, many leaders of community groups seeking construction jobs for minority-group workers, were accused yesterday of schemes to extort payoffs from building projects in Brooklyn and Queens by threatening demonstrations and disruptions.

title: Auctions
description: Nijinski as Erotic Faun

title: Dow Up Just 1.99 in Wild Day
description: Wall Street had another volatile session yesterday, with wide swings in the prices of blue chips - and another chorus from traders and brokers criticizing index-arbitrage-related program trading.

title: First Interstate of Iowa reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $6.5 million litigation reserve because of a lawsuit against the company's Des Moines Bank unit by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. c-Net income

title: Boston to Pay Catholic Order $1.5 Million for Curley Home
description: Mayor Raymond L. Flynn and a Roman Catholic order announced an agreement today under which the city will buy the home of James Michael Curley, the legendary Boston politician, for $1.5 million.

title: Excerpts From Ruling In Suit Over Smoking
description: Following are excerpts from a ruling by Judge H. Lee Sarokin of Federal District Court here on a motion to dismiss a suit seeking damages from three cigarette manufacturers:

title: Man Sues Wife on Abortion Done Without His Knowing
description: A Long Island orthodontist yesterday filed suit against his wife, seeking both a divorce and monetary damages because she had an abortion without his knowledge or consent.

title: 1.2 MILLION IN FINES FOR SEX MESSAGES
description: The Federal Communications Commission voted unanimously today to impose penalties totaling $1.2 million on two California operators for failing to block children's access to sexually explicit telephone messages.

title: TV Weekend; Writers on Strike, Networks Rely on Movies
description: As if the usual schedule rejiggerings aren't enough, the writers' strike has brought the production of weekly series to a halt. One very noticeable result: The networks are falling back heavily these days on television movies, many of them the mediocre sort that in more normal circumstances would stay on the shelf until the summer doldrums. Now we have what looks like year-round doldrums.

title: Alexander & Baldwin Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a credit of $18,269,000 from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes. c-Includes the effect of a change in the method of accounting for voyage revenue and expenses. The company said about $2,400,000 of the latest quarter income is its after-tax share of an accounting adjustment made by Pacific Resources Inc., a Honolulu-based energy company in which Alexander & Baldwin holds a 35 percent interest.

title: Advance Ross Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes income from discontinued operations of $1,354,000.

title: Penalties Upheld for Cleveland State
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today upheld sanctions against Cleveland State University for recruiting violations in its dealings with Manute Bol and two other prospective basketball players from Africa.

title: Rediscovering An Ornate Cast Of Cast-Iron Buildings
description: They are often dwarfed by skyscrapers or rusted from decades of indifference. But the cast-iron buildings of New York, with their ornate facades mimicking the palaces of Italy and France, once stood as conspicuous examples of this city's commercial and architectural aspirations.

title: Review/Film; Seeking the Outrageous In New York
description: Looking for a sampling of entertainments that are not listed in your run-of-the-mill going-out guide? It is available in ''Mondo New York,'' which reaches into the East Village underground to dig up ''performance artists'' who present their bodies to be painted and enclosed in Saran Wrap, bite off the heads of mice, switch genders and rely on obscenities when they require a punchline. In its hunt for the outrageous, the movie also takes us to a cockfight, a purportedly authentic Haitian voodoo ceremony (this time a chicken gets its head bitten off), a simulated sadomasochistic party where the whips are waved to a Yiddish ballad and a dull affair that is supposed to be ''a Chinese slave auction.'' It's 2 A.M. Is this where our children are?

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; WPP Group Acquires Jersey Sales Promoter
description: Britain's WPP Group, whose United States properties include J. Walter Thompson and Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, has acquired Einson Freeman, a sales promotion company in Paramus, N.J.

title: Review/Film; Searching for Mr. Right
description: The difference between something as up-to-the-minute as ''Casual Sex?'' and something as hopelessly retrograde as ''Where the Boys Are'' can be measured in language - clinical language, the kind the Thin Man would never have used to describe foreplay even if he'd had an inclination to describe it at all. So much for the way ideas of sophistication change from generation to generation. Take away the ostentatious candor, though, and ''Casual Sex?'' is ''Where the Boys Are'' all over again, with a plot about giddy young women at a sunny vacation spot, hunting. Their quarry is, for films of this kind, the eternal one: cute guys.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on April 12 about new methods of producing leaner livestock incorrectly characterized the decline in recent decades in the average weight of hogs at the time of slaughter and mislabeled a chemical. Hogs going to market now tend to weigh about 40 pounds less than in the past. Diethylstilbestrol is a synthetic hormone, not a steroid. An accompanying illustration mislabeled beta-agonists, which are chemicals that stimulate hormonal receptors, not hormones themselves.

title: Matthew Blei, Lawyer, 81
description: Matthew Blei, a lawyer and former village justice in Great Neck, L.I., died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Hollywood, Fla. He was 81 years old.

title: Reagan Again Backs Meese, Saying He Should Not Quit
description: President Reagan said today that Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d should not resign. He also said that the Justice Department was operating well despite the recent departure of several senior officials in apparent protest over Mr. Meese's legal troubles.

title: Review/Pop; Songs of Jule Styne, As Sung by Julie Wilson
description: In her fifth year of exploring the works of the great American songwriters, Julie Wilson has arrived at the songs of Jule Styne, and she is back at Michael's Pub (211 East 55th Street), the room in which she started this series in January 1984 with a program of Cole Porter.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Beker Industries, Greenwich, Conn., said a trustee for the Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York had filed a petition seeking to convert its pending reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code to a liquidation proceeding under Chapter 7 of the code. A hearing is set for May 10.

title: Dukakis Nears Financial Goal
description: The Presidential campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts has met such financial success that it expects to reach the $27.6 million spending limit by late next month, the campaign's chief fund-raiser said today.

title: The Once Feared Mitterrand Again? Ho-Hum
description: LEAD: The real significance of the French presidential election is its relative insignificance for the French and the world at large.

title: Dorothy M. Bell, College President, 84
description: Dorothy M. Bell, former president of Bradford College in Massachsetts, died April 8 of pulmonary fibrosis in Oxford, Md., where she lived. She was 84 years old.

title: Review/Concert; Jerusalem Symphony for Anniversary
description: The Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra's concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening was timed happily to coincide with the celebration of the 40th anniversary of the founding of the State of Israel. The event provided a perfect opportunity to put on display a 50-year-old ensemble that has long labored in the shadow of the more celebrated Israel Philharmonic. Founded as an arm of a Hebrew-language radio station, the Jerusalem continues its broadcast activities but has moved into ever-widening musical circles in recent years. Now it is in the midst of an ambitious 20-city American tour.

title:
Patents;
Heart Monitor
description: LEAD: Carl Orlando, president of the Engineering Development Company in Tinton Falls, N.J., was granted patent 4,738,264 this week for a heart and breathing alarm monitor. The monitor is non-invasive. No wires or other devices are attached to the body. The electronic transducer senses vibration of the mattress, generated by the heart and respiratory muscles and the blood flow.

title: Muddy Waters's Imprint on Mississippi
description: Muddy Waters, the pioneer of electric blues, grew up near this small, quiet Mississippi Delta town, on Stovall's Plantation, leaving in May 1943 after the plantation overseer refused his request for a raise from 22 1/2 cents to 25 cents an hour. Thursday night, in Clarksdale's civic auditorium, the members of Z. Z. Top, the popular rock group from Texas, gave Clarksdale's Blues Museum a gleaming white electric guitar made of a cypress log from the cabin where Muddy Waters grew up.

title: Sundstrom Sets Mark as Devils Win Grueling Game
description: Patrik Sundstrom, the reticent Swedish forward of the Devils, found enough time in between fights here tonight to eclipse Wayne Gretzky's playoff record for most points in a game.

title:
Patents;
A Dental Dispenser Of Gum Medication
description: LEAD: A New York dentist was awarded a patent this week for a dispenser that he believes will allow patients to apply liquid medication to their gums at home. Patent 4,738,669, granted to Dr. David G. Vlock, describes a hand-held dispenser with at least three prongs that meet at a pyramid apex to form a cradle for a precise amount of fluid.

title: 2d Youth Is Charged In Fatal Queens Fire
description: The older brother of a 15-year-old boy charged in a fatal fire in South Jamaica, Queens, last week was arrested yesterday and also charged in the death of a 12-year-old fire victim.

title: 'Mob Yuppies' Said to Reshape Organized Crime
description: Young Mafia members and immigrant drug traffickers are changing the face of organized crime in the United States, a New York State official has told Congress.

title: Teen-Ager Wounded In Shooting by Police
description: An undercover police officer shot and critically wounded a Queens teen-ager who was being arrested for allegedly selling crack yesterday, the police said.

title: Smoking in the Skies: The Rules
description: Major provisions of the airline smoking ban, which went into effect today.

title: Hugh S. Knowles, an Inventor, Is Dead at 83
description: Hugh S. Knowles, an acoustical engineer, inventor and manufacturer in the hearing-aid field, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Oak Brook, Ill. He was 83 years old.

title: Intermedics Seeking Buyer
description: The directors of Intermedics Inc., a manufacturer and marketer of cardiac pacemakers and other biomedical products, said they had hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to seek a buyer for the company.

title: DALI IN MOSCOW: SCENE IS SURREAL
description: The lines begin to form at 7 in the morning and by noon the sidewalks outside the Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts are jammed with hundreds of people, standing and reading and knitting and waiting to see a flaming giraffe, a tattooed nude, a matador with an elephant's trunk and a wax figure of the man who created these surreal works - Salvador Dali.

title: CORRECTION
description: The De Gustibus column in The Living Section on April 6 incorrectly described a Connecticut no-smoking law. A restaurant that holds 75 people or more must have a no-smoking area and must post a sign saying the area is available.

title: 2 Killed and 3 Missing in Blasts Destroying 4 Illinois Grain Silos
description: Two explosions ripped through a grain elevator complex on the Des Plaines River today, killing at least two people, injuring three others and leveling four grain silos and an office building, the authorities said.

title: Tricks With Numbers
description: To the Editor:

title: In Loire, a Mouse Too Bored to Roar
description: Julius Ceasar warned his generals not to permit their soldiers to spend too much time at this placid site high above the banks of the Loire because they would grow indolent. A local pun has it that one sleeps deeply in Blois like a ''loir,'' a dormouse in French.

title: Superintendent Held In Slaying of Tenant
description: A 47-year-old Harlem man was shot to death and his 20-year-old son was critically wounded by their building superintendent after a dispute over the use of the building's basement, the police said.

title: 10 Indicted in Alleged Rape
description: A grand jury indicted 10 men Thursday in an alleged kidnapping and gang rape of a woman who told police that bystanders at a cockfight joined in the attack. The 10 were arrested within days of the alleged attack that shocked this South Texas town of 5,000 people. The defendants were charged with offenses including sexual assault and kidnapping. The 19-year-old woman, a mother of two, said she was abducted from a road on March 26 and gang raped over four hours. Some of the men have said she was a willing participant.

title: Bruins' Goaltending Thwarts Canadiens
description: Reggie Lemelin stopped 22 shots in his second consecutive strong performance in goal and the Boston Bruins, seeking their first playoff series victory over Montreal in 45 years, beat the Canadiens, 3-1, tonight to take a 2-1 lead in the Adams Division final.

title: Your Money; Renewed Interest In Time Shares
description: WHILE the October stock market plunge initially scared buyers away from the vacation-home market, the decline in interest rates since then has drawn many of them back. And some of the buying interest is being directed toward time shares.

title: Correction
description: An article on Monday about Israeli reaction to the killing of a Palestinian guerrilla commander misidentified the aircraft hijacked in 1976 to Entebbe, Uganda, and freed in an Israeli raid. It was an Air France plane.

title: Ruling Adds To Pressure On Irving
description: A New York judge delivered another setback yesterday to the Irving Bank Corporation, ruling that it must complete a shareholder vote on a takeover proposal by May 6.

title: Alfred T. Eade, 96, Artist and Author Of Religious Books
description: Dr. Alfred Thompson Eade, an artist and the author of five religious books, died April 7 in Grants Pass, Ore. He was 96 years old. Next month his publisher will re-issue Dr. Eade's first book, published in 1941, for which Dr. Eade recently rendered the original black-and-white illustrations in full color.

title:
Patents;
Circuitry Speeds Math Calculations
description: LEAD: A digital arithmetic combiner, intended to facilitate calculations, was patented this week for the RCA Corporation, now part of the General Electric Company. Patent 4,739,503 describes the invention as including circuitry that enhances processing speed of arithmetic calculations.

title: Forget About Fixing the Williamsburg Bridge
description: LEAD: In the mad scramble to temporarily fix, and ultimately replace, the Williamsburg Bridge, which connects Brooklyn and Manhattan, serious thought should be given to not replacing the bridge at all.

title: Books of The Times; Looking for Literature in the Ring
description: Reading the Fights Edited by Joyce Carol Oates And Daniel Halpern Illustrated. 305 pages. Henry Holt & Company. $17.95.

title: J.P. Stevens Truce May Collapse
description: A three-day truce in the $1.2 billion takeover battle for J. P. Stevens & Company seemed in danger of collapse yesterday, unless a solution can be found to major problems raised by its directors.

title: Argentina Is Likely to Halt Work on Atom Power Plant
description: Faced with an exhausted national treasury and rejections by foreign banks, Argentina is on the verge of halting construction of its third nuclear power plant.

title: U.S. Must Join World In the Rule of Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks' Playoff Chances Suffer Setback
description: The Milwaukee Bucks dealt the Knicks' bid for their first playoff berth in four years a blow by defeating them tonight, 118-109, in the Mecca.

title: Stock Exchange Plan for Halt In Trading Widely Criticized
description: As the stock market went into its chaotic tailspin last Oct. 19, the New York Stock Exchange struggled to keep trading open and preserve a bedrock principle: that the exchange provides a marketplace where investors can always buy or sell stocks at fairly determined prices during operating hours.

title: Damon to Split
description: The Damon Corporation announced it would split itself into two concerns, one devoted to clinical laboratory services and the other to biotechnology. The company has also adopted an anti-takeover plan. Damon was considered a takeover candidate after the American Magnetics Corporation disclosed that it owned 9.9 percent of the company.

title: Dukakis and Jackson on Agreeable Terms in Debate
description: Debating one on one for the first time, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and the Rev. Jesse Jackson demonstrated tonight that the tone of their competition for the Democratic Presidential nomination would be that of a respectful rivalry, not a contentious struggle.

title: Mistrial Ruled In Slaying Of Detective
description: In a tumultuous and emotional scene, the second trial in the slaying of a police detective in Queens ended yesterday in a mistrial for the two remaining defendants after the jury declared itself ''hopelessly deadlocked.''

title: Navajo Accord Allows Couple In California to Keep a Baby
description: A white couple trying to adopt a 9-month-old Navajo baby will be able to keep the baby under an agreement reached today with the child's Indian family, but the couple will not be able to adopt the girl formally.

title: Chrysler to Expand Car Output in Mexico
description: The Chrysler Corporation will increase production of its K-body cars in Mexico after American production is phased out in this country by the end of the current model year, company officials said today. The K-cars, including the Dodge Aries and Plymouth Reliant, were instrumental in the company's financial recovery in the early 1980's.

title: Cuomo Aide Resigns
description: Governor Cuomo's top adviser for social and welfare issues, Ilene Margolin, resigned yesterday, effective May 20. Administration officials said a replacement had not yet been selected. Ms. Margolin, who is 45 years old and is paid $76,400 a year, will become chief operating officer of the Federation Employment and Guidance Service, a private group that works with industry to provide job training for the poor and disabled.

title: Softer Sell in Ads For Beauty Products
description: Time has run out for the cosmetics industry. Fed up with a profusion of therapeutic-sounding claims in labeling and promotion, the Food and Drug Administration has put cosmetics companies on notice, as of today, to watch their language.

title: Record Vehicle Output in Japan
description: Vehicle production rose 5.5 percent in March from a year earlier, to a record 1.21 million, the second consecutive year-to-year gain, an official of the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

title: Dow Venture In Japan
description: The Dow Chemical Company said today that it would form a joint venture in Japan with the the Sumitomo Chemical Company to market and eventually manufacture materials used to make plastics.

title: Young Kennedy Has Surgery
description: Patrick Kennedy, youngest son of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, was reported in ''very satisfactory'' condition today, a day after surgeons removed a non-cancerous tumor from the top of his spine. Mr. Kennedy, 20 years old, a sophomore at Providence College, was admitted to Massachusetts General Hospital Monday after complaining of headaches and back pains. He is expected to make a complete recovery from the surgery, said Jeff Smith, a spokesman for the family.

title: Contras Getting U.S. Arms, Ortega Says
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra charged today that the United States is secretly shipping arms to Nicaraguan guerrillas under the cover of ''humanitarian aid.''

title: Filing on Varo
description: United Scientific Holdings P.L.C., a British military contractor, has filed for permission from Federal antitrust regulators to acquire more than half of Varo Inc.'s 4.4 million shares outstanding. Varco shares closed on the New York Stock Exchange today at $21.75, up $1.375. United Scientific, which announced its intentions in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, holds just under 10 percent of shares of the maker of military electronic equipment based in Garland, Tex. A spokesman for Varo said that the company would have no immediate comment on the S.E.C. filing. United Scientific told the S.E.C. that it had not decided if it would purchase the shares if it received the antitrust clearance.

title: Minneapolis Museum Finds a New Director
description: After a seven-month search, the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, one of the country's leading art museums, has chosen Evan M. Maurer as its director. Mr. Maurer, who is 43 years old, has been director of the University of Michigan Museum of Art since 1981. He replaces Alan Shestack, who left to become director of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts last July.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Lendl to Face Noah: Ivan Lendl, coming back from a two-month layoff, and Yannick Noah advanced to a semifinal meeting with victories yesterday at the Monte Carlo Open in Monaco. Noah survived 3 match points in the second set to beat his fellow Frenchman Henri Leconte, 2-6, 7-6, 6-4. Lendl, the world's No. 1 player, beat the 1986 champion, Joakim Nystrom of Sweden, 7-6, 6-2. In another quarterfinal match, Martin Jaite of Argentina dominated a tired Claudio Pistolesi of Italy, 6-2, 6-0. Jaite will meet Thierry Tulasne of France in the semifinals. Tulasne defeated Andres Gomez of Ecuador by 7-5, 6-1.(AP) Mandsorf Wins: Second-seeded Amos Mansdorf of Israel won his second match of the Bank of Oklahoma Tennis Classic in Tulsa yesterday and Christo Van Rensburg of South Africa earned his first victory in the event. Mansdorf easily defeated Ramesh Krishnan of India, 6-4, 6-3. Van Rensburg had more difficulty with Richey Reneberg of the United States, struggling to a 4-6, 6-4, 6-4 victory. Eight men are competing in the tournament and the two players with the most victories in the two four-man groups will advance to tomorrow's final.(AP) Evert Will Play Garrison: Chris Evert rallied to overpower Gretchen Magers, 2-6, 6-3, 6-0, yesterday in a quarterfinal match of the Virginia Slims of Houston tournament. Zina Garrison, playing in her hometown, defeated Isabel Cueto of West Germany, 7-6, 6-1. Garrison will play Evert in a semifinal match. Martina Navratilova beat Arantxa Sanchez of Spain, 7-6, 6-2, and will play Elly Hakami of the United States in the semifinals. Hakami advanced when Patricia Tarabina of Argentina withdrew with an ankle injury.(AP) Golf Wadkins in Front: Lanny Wadkins shot a seven-under-par 65 and took a one-stroke lead yesterday in the second round of the USF&G Classic in New Orleans. Wadkins has a two-round total of 132, 12 under par. Chip Beck, who scored the first victory of his 10-year career at Los Angeles two months ago, was a stroke back at 133. He was followed by Tom Byrum at 134.(AP) Two Share Lead: Donna White shot her second straight four-under-par 68 yesterday and moved into a tie for the lead with Rosie Jones after two rounds of the USX Golf Classic at the Pasadena Yacht and Country Club in Gulfport, Fla. Jones shot a 69 for a 36-hole total of eight-under-par 136. Kathy Postlewait also shot a 69 and was alone in third at 137. Heather Drew, the first-round leader, struggled to a par 72 and was tied at 138 with Tina Tombs-Purtzer and Vicki Fergon.(AP) Track Bronx Runner First: John Charleston of Kennedy High School in the Bronx won the 3,000-meter run in 9 minutes 12.8 seconds yesterday at the Redmen Invitational meet at St. John's University in Queens. Sean Rice of Bishop Ford in Brooklyn was the gold medalist in the 2,000-meter steeplechase in 6:22.1. Archbishop Molloy of Queens, with a team of Sean Foran, Mike Kane, Stan Lauture and Phil Hemery, captured the 1,600-meter relay in 18:39.4.

title: Brooks Brothers Offer Is Reduced
description: Marks & Spencer P.L.C., the British retailing group, said it was cutting its offer price for Brooks Brothers, the prestigious American retailer that it agreed to buy from Canada's Campeau Corporation in late February.

title: Zenith Income Down by 60%
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation said today that its first-quarter net income fell 60 percent, to $400,000, from $1 million for the comparable period of 1987.

title: Spelling Before Aristotle
description: At Stanford the forces of social uplift and the academic Bourbons have been quarreling about what makes for a good education. More black and female literature in the curriculum? Or hold the line for Aristotle, St. Thomas Aquinas and Shakespeare?

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Girl Scouts Sing a Song Of Protest
description: The demonstrators filed determinedly off a yellow school bus, each carrying a protest sign made with bright crayons. They formed a picket line in front of the Manhattan headquarters of the Girl Scouts of the United States of America and began to clap, stamp their feet, and shout protest songs.

title: Xerox Profit Up by 12.6%
description: The Xerox Corporation, the world's leading producer of copying and duplicating machines, reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1988 rose 12.6 percent on an 11.3 percent increase in revenue.

title: Review/Film; A First Feature, With a Bounty Hunter
description: ''The Blue Iguana,'' which opened yesterday at the Cinema 2 and other theaters, belongs to that genre of first feature most favored by film-school graduates. It's inspired not by life but by other movies. Whatever passion it possesses is the film maker's desire to make movies - any movies - before he has much of anything in mind to make movies about.

title: New York Finds Librarians in Short Supply
description: ''Do you have any books by Ellen Agara Pa?'' a young girl recently asked a children's librarian at the Fordham Library Center in the Bronx.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-7 U.S. warships in the Persian Gulf will be allowed to protect neutral merchant ships under attack according to rules being revised by the Reagan Administration, Pentagon officials told Congress. 1 Passengers freed from a hijacked jet, after returning to Kuwait, said they were searched and confined to narrow seats day and night with their hands bound. They tried to sleep by squeezing beneath the seats. 1 China will not back an arms embargo against Iran after the clashes between American and Iranian naval forces, officials said. The Chinese message was in reply to a request by the Reagan Administration. 1 Israel decided to kill a P.L.O. official because army and intelligence officials believed he was directing the uprising in the occupied territories, according to Israelis with access to Government officials. 6 The funeral for the P.L.O. official, Abu Jihad, was held in Damascus, Syria, to protest an American plan for peace in the Middle East and to slight King Hussein of Jordan, Palestinian leaders said. 6 Mikhail S. Gorbachev criticized President Reagan's approach toward Moscow as becoming confrontational. He told Secretary of State George P. Shultz that this could jeopardize improvements in U.S.-Soviet relations. 1 Yegor K. Ligachev appeared with the Politburo at a ceremony marking Lenin's birth a day after he was said to have been all but removed as the No. 2 Communist Party official and ordered to go on vacation. 1 Afghan refugees are reluctant to return home. Some refugees say they see little difference between the current Government and the Soviet troops, who are to be withdrawn, and they disparage the guerrilla leadership. 4 The French presidential campaign has stirred little excitement in Blois, a town that does not often stray from national political trends. Seven years ago, a slight majority of voters favored Francois Mitterand. 3 Four top executives of a French machine-tool company were arrested and charged earlier this week with selling sophisticated milling machinery to the Soviet military, according to French and American officials. 37 Argentina is likely to halt work on atom power plant 2 Contras getting U.S. arms, Ortega says 3 NATIONAL 8-11, 32 A pilot shortage at Eastern Airlines is disrupting the carrier's schedules and causing it to cancel flights. The shortage may force Eastern to reduce its service on major routes, analysts and airline officials say. 1 The maker of an anti-acne medicine rebutted an estimate by Government scientists that the drug Accutane may have caused up to 1,300 birth defects. Hoffmann-La Roche, Inc., said the estimate was ''flawed.'' 1 Agreement on a halt in stock trading during wild swings is close at hand between the New York Stock Exchange, other exhanges and Government officials. Some experts do not think it would work. 1 Japanese purchases of U.S. timber in the Pacific Northwest have caused a shortage for American lumber mills. Japanese construction firms are willing to pay prices far above American market rates. 8 Confidence in the Attorney General was expressed by President Reagan, who responded ''no'' when asked whether Edwin Meese 3d should resign. He said the Justice Department was operating ''just fine.'' 8 The IRS revoked tax-exempt status of the PTL television ministry and said contributions to the organization were no longer tax deductable. The IRS says PTL owes more than $55 million in taxes. 8 A list of potential trial witnesses in the Iran-contra case includes the major national security officials in the Administration but omits Vice President Bush and President Reagan. The list has 37 possible witnesses. 9 Dispute on rescue settled 8 Nancy Reagan has cancer tests 9 'Mob yuppies' said to reshape organized crime 32 POLITICS 10 Michael Dukakis and Jesse Jackson, debating one on one for the first time in the Democratic Presidential race, agreed on a wide range of domestic and international issues and disagreed only in nuance. 10 The impact of Presidential debates has been less decisive in this year's campaign than in previous races. The debates this weekend between Michael Dukakis and Jesse Jackson bring the total in the 1988 race to about 60. 10 Dukakis's war chest to aid rivals as well 10 REGIONAL 33-35, 54 A mistrial was declared for two men accused of murdering a detective in Queens. The action came after the jury said it was deadlocked. A third defendant was acquitted Wednesday. 33 A shortage of librarians has become particularly acute in New York City's public libraries. Fewer people are going into the profession even as information services are expanding. 33 Skyscraper envy in Hartford is so great that three developers are racing to build the tallest building in New England. One designer increased the height of his building because it was 35 feet too short. 33 Girl Scouts are protesting a decision by the national organization to divide the Hudson County, N.J., council between two others. Officials in Hudson County fear the demise of Scouting there. 33 About 11,000 sailors have landed in Manhattan for Fleet Week, a long weekend organized by a several groups. Eleven ships, including the battleship Iowa and the aircraft carrier America, will be here through Sunday. 35 Approval of an oversized building by the Koch administration in exchange for rehearsal space and minor structural changes has angered civic leaders, who say it contradicts City Hall's own zoning policy. 35 About New York: An artist whose medium is the fish 33 College leaders discuss racial enmity 34 State University student electrocuted in Albany campus pond 34 Bail set for woman in son's death 35

title: USG Bid Extended
description: Desert Partners L.P. extended its $42-a-share tender offer for the USG Corporation until midnight on April 29. The offer was to expire at midnight tonight. In a hearing in Federal District Court here, USG and the investor group failed to agree on the terms for a proposed vote on a preferred share rights plan, a so-called poison pill. Desert Partners said about 12.4 million of USG's 51.5 million outstanding common shares had been tendered.

title: Student, 20, Electrocuted In Albany Campus Pond
description: A 20-year-old sophomore at the State University here was electrocuted Thursday night when he waded into a concrete-bottom drainage pond. An investigation is under way to determine whether the accident involved a fraternity initiation, a spokesman for the university said today.

title: Gordon Merrick, 71, Reporter and Novelist
description: Gordon Merrick, a former journalist and the author of 13 novels, died of lung cancer in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on March 27. He was 71 years old.

title:
Patents;
Device for Reproducing Confidential Documents
description: LEAD: Apparatus for reproducing a confidential document that has a visible image and an invisible image was patented this week for the Eastman Kodak Company in Rochester.

title: Frank L. Harrington, Executive, 86
description: Frank L. Harrington, retired chairman and president of the Paul Revere Life Insurance Company of Worcester, Mass., died Thursday at Worcester Memorial Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Worcester.

title: Public Power Saves
description: To the Editor:

title: Killing Fields of Mozambique
description: Rarely does a State Department document evoke a nightmarish Conrad novel. Alas, there's nothing fictional about a new report describing how 100,000 people have been massacred in Mozambique - mainly by Renamo, a rebel group waging a bush war against Mozambique's left-wing regime. Civilians have been shot, knifed, axed, bayoneted, burnt, starved, beaten, drowned and throttled. Nearly a million have fled into exile. In neighboring Malawi, 1,000 refugees arrive daily ''in poor health, severely malnourished, without belongings and often naked.''

title: Sailor Rescued in Storm
description: An American container ship rescued B. J. Watkins, a solo sailor from Annapolis, Md., early yesterday as her 31-foot trimaran, Heart, foundered in a storm 500 miles north of Bermuda. Watkins, 35 years old, was on her way to Plymouth, England, for the start June 5 of the Carlsberg Single-Handed Trans-Atlantic Race to Newport, R.I.

title: Colts Sign Klecko
description: Two months after the Jets released him, Joe Klecko signed a two-year contract with the Indianapolis Colts yesterday, ignoring advice from the Jets' team doctor to retire from pro football.

title: Coping/With Buying a Used Car
description: The question is one that every automobile shopper has wrestled with: Should I plunk down a large chunk of change for glitter and that new-car smell, or should I scout the used-car ads and take a chance?

title: Nancy Reagan Has Cancer Tests; President Gets a Dental Checkup
description: Nancy Reagan today underwent a routine physical examination and a breast X-ray, neither of which showed any problems, the White House announced.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on the Washington Talk page on April 11, with an article about Representatives who move to the Senate, misattributed a quotation. The quotation, ''It is a more even playing field over here,'' was from Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, not Senator Richard C. Shelby of Alabama.

title: The Mystique of the Orioles
description: Brimming with confidence that they wouldn't lose every one of the 162 games on their schedule, the Baltimore Orioles went out to face the Brewers in Milwaukee Thursday afternoon.

title: I.R.S. Revokes PTL Tax Exemption
description: The Internal Revenue Service revoked the tax-exempt status of the PTL television ministry today and said donations to the financially troubled organization were no longer tax deductible.

title: EXODUS OF PILOTS IS CAUSING EASTERN TO CANCEL FLIGHTS
description: An accelerating exodus of pilots from Eastern Airlines is disrupting the carrier's schedules and causing it to cancel many flights.

title: Doubts Remain on Abortion Pill's Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Recital; Sherrill Milnes Reaches Out
description: Sherrill Milnes, in his recital on Wednesday evening at the 92d Street Y, quickly captured his audience's heart, and if he did so in an extroverted, operatic way - by reaching out to the listeners, rather than by gently luring them in as the best recitalists do - he achieved the desired effect nonetheless. He chose his music intelligently, presenting a stream of dramas in five languages and diverse styles, and leaving an impression of versatility while keeping to works that fall mostly in the middle of the baritone range, where his voice is as robust as ever. He ventured higher rarely, but enough to show that if his top is coarse in forte passages, it can be lovely in a high pianissimo.

title: Hot Fudge, In a Squeeze
description: No-fuss, no-muss hot fudge? It's almost a contradiction in terms, but that's what Smuckers has come up with in a 16- or 22-ounce squeeze bottle made for the microwave oven.

title: Rain Shouldn't Ruin The Wood Memorial
description: The significance of the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct today may be muddied if the meteorological handicappers are right in predicting rain, but it will not be dampened as much as most races would be. The Wood is a rare race in which every leading contender has past performances or a pedigree that suggests he can handle a wet track as well as a dry one.

title: Albany's Squandered Credibility
description: What has New York's Legislature gained from the last three weeks of bitter partisan conflict over the state budget? Nothing but embarrassment, especially for State Senate Republicans. The $28.4 billion spending plan signed by Governor Cuomo is virtually identical to the one on the table when talks collapsed on the eve of April 1, the legal budget deadline. Issues that provoked the impasse remain unresolved.

title: Facts Are Fine; Historical Reasoning Is Finer
description: LEAD: We recently received more alarming news that many high school graduates are ignorant of their own nation's history. This has sent panels and commissions scurrying into session.

title: Review/Dance; Balanchine's Stravinsky, With Feeling
description: Dance companies often take time to settle into new seasons, and it looked as if the American Ballet Theater was doing that in two performances on Thursday at the Metropolitan Opera House. There was certainly nothing wrong with the level of dancing. But a wan air of careful discretion hung over most of the proceedings.

title: U.S. WILL INCREASE ITS GULF DEFENSE OF MERCHANT SHIPS
description: Top Defense Department officials told Congress today that the Reagan Administration had decided to revise the rules for American warships in the Persian Gulf to allow them in unspecified circumstances to protect neutral merchant ships under attack.

title: College Leaders Focus on Enmity Between Races
description: Against a backdrop of increasing tension on college campuses among students of different races, religions, ethnic origins and sexual orientations, 300 college officials, teachers and students met today to examine causes and seek solutions.

title: Housing Officers Seek Friend's Killer
description: As the black and purple bunting hanging over the door of their precinct house in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn flapped in the wind yesterday, more than 50 off-duty housing police officers began distributing the fliers that many hoped would help catch a killer.

title: Icahn Makes New Bid For the Rest of T.W.A.
description: Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor and chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc., yesterday resumed his efforts to take the airline private.

title: Article 632188 -- No Title
description: A judge agreed yesterday to permit the release on bail of a Brooklyn woman accused of drowning her 2-month-old son and then telling the police he had been kidnapped.

title: Yankees Lose in 12th
description: Dave Righetti is showing signs of beginning his annual slump.

title: The Talk of Hartford; A Heated Race to Be New England's Tallest
description: New York City may have its World Trade Center and Chicago its Sears Tower. But here in Hartford, renowned more for its steepled suburbs than its modest downtown skyline, three developers are racing to raise what would become New England's tallest building.

title: About New York; Dancing Salmon: Artist's Medium Is the Fish
description: Fernando Lara came here in 1979 from Mexico City, where he worked as a carpenter, and got a job as a busboy in a Broadway restaurant run by Greeks, who sold out to Indians, who treated Mr. Lara a little shabbily, he felt, so much so that he crossed the street and went to work for an Italian in a fish store, where he has since become a minor celebrity, shuffling seafood toward his own American dream.

title: Guidepost: Home Security Check
description: Few things can ruin a vacation or a weekend trip faster than returning to an apartment or a house that has been burglarized. Locks and alarm systems should always be tested before you leave. If you don't have an alarm, it's a good idea to install one at least a week before you go (professional installation of alarms and locks can cost extra). Have the post office hold mail and cancel newspapers for long trips; neighbors can pick them up during short trips. Here are other tips to help keep your home safe while you are away: Lights: Buy a timer that switches lights on and off. Radios: Leave a radio on, tuned to an all-talk station. Alarms: Even the cheapest is loud enough to make an intruder think twice. Prices start at $40. Doors: Dead bolts are crucial; prices begin at $60.

title: Koch Plans to Honor Art-in-Schools Program
description: The Studio in a School Association, a program in which artists set up working studios in city elementary schools, is to be given the Doris C. Freedman Award by Mayor Koch on Tuesday at Cooper Union. Agnes Gund, who created the program in 1977 and who is a trustee of the Museum of Modern Art, will receive the award on behalf of the association.

title: Bridge; Two Californians stumbled onto a Westchester tournament, and victory.
description: Serious players can usually recall how they came to attend their first tournament. Almost invariably, it was within driving distance of home.

title: Export Boom Dividing Pacific Timber Country
description: This should be boom time at the Garka Timber Mill on the fringe of thick forest lands west of the Cascade Mountains, about 35 miles north of here. More wood is being sold, to both Americans and foreigners, than at any time in recent history. Prices for logs are approaching an all-time high.

title: Reagan Attacks Trade Bill
description: President Reagan accused Congress today of caving in to organized labor on trade legislation, but supporters of the measure said it was his ''wishful thinking'' that a veto would lead to a version he prefers.

title: Option Entry By Japanese
description: Signaling the start of direct Japanese participation in the United States options markets, a representative of Nomura Securities Inc. executed the first options trade by a Japanese securities firm on a United States exchange.

title: Change-Up Pitch
description: Willie Hernandez, Detroit's left-handed relief pitcher who won the American League's Cy Young and Most Valuable Player awards in 1984 when the Tigers captured the pennant and the World Series, has not enjoyed such heroic accomplishments since that rosy year. In 1984, he had a 9-3 record, 32 saves and an earned run average of 1.92. Last season, the same categories produced such numbers as 3-4, 8 and 3.67, plus 50 days on the disabled list and a short stint with Toledo of the International League.

title: William I. Freedman, 89, Founded Customs Firm
description: William I. Freedman, founder of a customs-brokerage firm that transported sets and costumes for international theatrical troupes and opera companies, died of congestive heart failure Thursday at the Courtland Gardens Nursing Home in Stamford, Conn. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan and Miami.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Ex-Hostages Tell of Days Bound and Cramped on Jet
description: ''You are hijacked,'' Capt. Sobhi Youssef said the three men told him after they forced the cockpit door open, brandishing hand grenades.

title: Civic Leaders Fault Pact On Outsized Skyscraper
description: The Koch administration's announcement that it would trade approval of an oversized skyscraper for free rehearsal space and minor structural alterations is under attack by civic leaders and officials, who argue that it contradicts City Hall's own zoning policy.

title: Olongapo Journal; At an Old Port of Call, a New Scourge
description: Amid the garish bars that cater to American servicemen here, a young prostitute with spiky pink hair greets a circle of acquaintances with the reminder, ''Hey, we're dying.''

title: A Movie Tribute for Stalin Generation
description: Sergei Pshenichny is a smug, cynical 38-year-old Moscow psychologist, scornful of the society his father's generation built in the days of Stalin.

title:
Patents;
A Pendulum For Variety Of Purposes
description: LEAD: A New Hampshire engineer, William B. Elmer, has invented an inertial pendulum. Patent 4,738,032, granted to him this week, explains that any body suspended from a fixed support and free to oscillate under the influence of gravity can be considered a pendulum.

title: One Person, More Than One Vote
description: Many New Yorkers find voter registration procedures so daunting that they end up forfeiting their right to vote. Yet an enterprising WCBS-TV reporter, Barbara Nevins, has now demonstrated how easy it is to vote not just once but several times. In the New York primary this week, Ms. Nevins registered five different times under different false addresses. If her experiment raises no real questions about journalistic ethics, it raises large ones about registration procedures.

title: MOSCOW REBUTTING REPORTS OF A RIFT
description: A day after he was reported to have been all but removed from his position as the No. 2 Communist Party official and ordered to go on a long vacation, Yegor K. Ligachev appeared today in his accustomed place alongside his Politburo colleagues at a ceremony marking Lenin's birth.

title: After Gulf Clashes, China Rejects U.S. Call for Iran Arms Embargo
description: China has informed the United States that it will not endorse an international arms embargo against Iran after the clashes this week between American and Iranian naval forces in the Persian Gulf, State Department officials said today.

title: Japan Oil Import Data
description: Japan imported 1.16 billion barrels of crude oil in the fiscal year that ended March 31, a 2.2 percent increase over the previous year, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: Not Frankensteins
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Is Said to Have Killed Abu Jihad to Quell Unrest
description: Israel decided last week to kill a Palestinian guerrilla commander because army and intelligence officials believed he was directing the uprising in the occupied territories, according to Israelis with access to Government officials.

title: CORRECTION
description: A map on April 16 showing a new ferry service between Brooklyn and Manhattan reversed the locations of two bridges in some editions. The Manhattan Bridge is north of the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: BATTLING SATANIC FORCES
description: So what in the name of heaven are Trevor Howard, Hal Holbrook, Ben Cross and Ned Beatty doing in ''The Unholy,'' which was spirited into the Warner and other theaters yesterday? Well, it's like this. Mr. Cross is a young priest who does not know that he enjoys anti-Satanic powers, which ought to come in handy considering that the last two priests in his New Orleans church had their throats torn out by a mysterious force. Mr. Howard is a blind old priest, ''a great scholar of demonology,'' who discovers that Mr. Cross is the Chosen One, destined to do battle with the Unholy One. Mr. Holbrook is an archbishop and Mr. Beatty is a cop.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: Baseball; ORIOLES FALL TO 0-16 IN A BIG WAY (13-1)
description: The Baltimore Orioles lost their 16th straight game, 13-1, tonight after the Kansas City Royals scored nine runs in the first inning.

title: G.M., in Shift, to Trim Size To Match Cut in Sales Share
description: The General Motors Corporation, which has traditionally been the most optimistic of American auto makers, is lowering its sights to cope with the competitive squeeze expected in the early 1990's.

title: 4 in France Arrested in Soviet Sale
description: Four top executives of one of France's largest machine-tool makers were arrested earlier this week and charged with selling tens of millions of dollars' worth of sophisticated milling machinery to the Soviet military.

title: Trimedyne Group Halts Proxy Fight
description: A group of investors in Trimedyne Inc. and some directors in the company said they would not wage a proxy fight for seats on the board of the fiber-optic medical equipment concern.

title: Correction
description: An article last Saturday about prenuptial tests for the AIDS virus reversed the numbers of marriage licenses issued for the first quarters of 1987 and 1988 in Louisiana, a state that requires such tests. The totals were 776 in 1987 and 628 in 1988.

title: Jean Gascon, Director, 67
description: Jean Gascon, a French-Canadian actor and director who was artistic director of the Stratford Festival in Ontario from 1969 to 1974, died Wednesday of heart failure. He was 67 years old.

title: Stocks Up, But Volume Is Slight
description: LEAD: The stock market, buoyed by a surge in blue chips, moved smartly higher yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 27.69 points to close at 2,015.09.

title: DARLING STOPS CARDS
description: Two bats were impounded tonight as the great corked-bat controversy broke out for the first time this season. But in the main performance of the evening, the Mets defeated the Cardinals for the fourth time in a week, driving St. Louis deeper into the cellar of the National League East.

title: James C. Evans, Professor, 87
description: James C. Evans, a retired Defense Department aide and former professor at Howard University, died of Alzheimer's disease April 14 at his home in Washington, D.C. He was 87 years old.

title: Another Mayor Killed By Peruvian Guerrillas
description: Maoist guerrillas killed the Mayor of Peru's second-largest city and his driver today and set fire to an agricultural cooperative, the police said.

title: Representative Melvin Price, 83, Is Dead of Cancer After 22 Terms
description: Representative Melvin Price, an Illinois Democrat who was one of the longest serving members of the House, died of cancer yesterday, hours after entering a Maryland hospital complaining of pain. He was 83 years old.

title: Maker of Drug for Acne Calls Birth-Defect Report 'Invalid'
description: Hoffmann-La Roche Inc. charged today that an estimate by Government scientists that 900 to 1,300 babies have been born with birth defects caused by the popular anti-acne drug Accutane in recent years was ''flawed'' and ''essentially meaningless.''

title: Airline Bumping, and Its Consolations
description: A cavernous room in the American Airlines headquarters building at the Dallas-Fort Worth Airport is one of the places where your best-laid travel plans can come unglued.

title: Melanesia Separatists Kill 3 and Kidnap 26
description: Melanesian separatists stormed a police station today and fled with 26 police hostages after a battle that left 3 French officers dead and 20 people wounded.

title: 35 Rebounds for Oakley
description: Charles Oakley grabbed 35 rebounds for the Bulls tonight, the highest total in the league in nine seasons, but the Cleveland Cavaliers hit enough shots to beat Chicago, 107-103.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Olympic Trials Are a Trying Time
description: There is an art to trying out for a team that many of the women at the Olympic basketball trials have never had to learn. From the time they were high school seniors being recruited by some of the college coaches evaluating talent here, they have been treated like stars, unburdened by the anxiety of making the last cut or wondering how much playing time they would get.

title: Time for the Windfall Tax to Fall
description: Do American oil producers deserve ''windfall'' profits? It was a resentful question when Americans waited two hours in gasoline lines and Saudi princes summered in Monaco. It seems almost quaint now, when OPEC is fighting a losing battle to hold the line at $18 a barrel and many Texas oil producers are bankrupt.

title: A Breakthrough In Cycling Event
description: When residents of this corner of the world look back upon advances of the women's movement in the late 1980's, they may well remember the symbolism of a sunny Friday afternoon when 31 female students at Indiana University rode their Roadmaster bicycles across the starting line in a race they could once only watch.

title: Grand Jury Indicts Man Arrested On Jersey Turnpike With Bombs
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted a Japanese man arrested last week in New Jersey with three powerful homemade bombs, and it will continue to hear evidence about other possible crimes and accomplices in the case, the authorities said.

title: Gorbachev Says Reagan Remarks On Rights Issues Threaten Accords
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev accused President Reagan today of jeopardizing improvements in Soviet-American relations by reverting to a confrontational approach toward Moscow, the press agency Tass said.

title: From Ships to Shore Comes a White-Capped Wave of Visitors
description: Amid bright sunshine and brisk breezes, about 11,000 sailors landed in Manhattan yesterday and took the city with virtually no resistance.

title: INSIDE
description: 4 Arrests in Export Case

title: U S West Gains
description: U S West said it would realize a one-time gain of $89 million this quarter as a result of the sale of 9.7 million shares of a subsidiary, U S West Newvector Group Inc. U S West said it would retain an 81 percent stake in the telecommunications concern, which is engaged primarily in operating cellular telephone systems.

title: Lord Ramsey, 83, Dies in England; Former Archbishop of Canterbury
description: Lord Ramsey, Archbishop of Canterbury from 1961 to 1974, who traveled the world in his passion to heal schisms and reunite the divided Christian churches, died early today, the Church of England said in a statement. He was 83 years old.

title: Afghan Refugees Still Not Ready to Go Home
description: After an exile that for many has lasted nearly a decade, it is evident in the huge mud hut camps of the three million Afghan refugees in Pakistan that it will take more than a diplomatic agreement to persuade them that it is time to prepare to go home.

title: IRAN-CONTRA TRIAL GETS WITNESS LIST
description: The independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra case made public today a list of potential trial witnessess that includes the major national security officials in the Reagan Administration but omits Vice President Bush and President Reagan.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16.

title: Richard Corbin, 76, Former English Teacher
description: Richard Corbin, an English teacher, editor and writer of textbooks, died of heart disease Wednesday at Peekskill (N.Y.) Community Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Peekskill.

title: Dispute on Rescue Settled
description: Civic leaders today ended a battle between movie producers over the rescue of an 18-month-old girl from a well by selecting a Los Angeles production company to retell her story and her rescuers'.

title: Review/Concert; AN ALL-AMERICAN QUARTET
description: The Walter W. Naumburg Foundation doesn't just present its new winners in showcase concerts; it presents its old winners, too. Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall it offered the American String Quartet (a 1974 winner) with the pianist Stephen Hough (who won in 1983) joining in for the Dvorak Quintet in A (Op. 81).

title: Abu Jihad's Burial Site: Slap at Jordan and U.S.
description: Palestinian leaders acknowledged in interviews this week that Middle East diplomacy, and particularly the American peace initiative, was a prime concern in deciding where to bury their slain military commander.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Last year it became known that we would only protect American-flag shipping and would do nothing to intervene to stop an attack on a foreign-flag vessel even if it were attacked right under our noses.

title: U.S. Issues Rise Slightly in Slow Trading
description: The market in Treasury debt issues improved more in tone than in price yesterday in what dealers described as one of the slowest sessions of the year.

title: Hammered Out
description: A women's softball game between the University of Massachusetts and Boston College was called Thursday because of unsafe playing conditions after wild heaves by hammer throwers competing in the Boston College Relays interfered with the game.

title: A Weekly Chart on Markets Starts Today
description: Starting today, The New York Times will publish a comprehensive three-column markets chart every Saturday.

title: Seahawks Sign Stouffer
description: The Seattle Seahawks signed Kelly Stouffer, a quarterback, yesterday and sent three draft picks to the Phoenix Cardinals as compensation after Kenny Easley, a safety, failed a physical exam. The Cardinals received Seattle's first-round and fifth-round picks in the 1989 National Football League draft and Seattle's fifth-round pick in this year's draft, which starts Sunday, said Larry Wilson, Cardinals director of pro personnel. Seattle had acquired this year's pick from Dallas in a trade for offensive lineman Ron Essink, an offensive lineman.

title: KEY RATES
Review/Theater; NEW LIFE FOR 'COCOANUTS' AFTER 60 YEARS
description: The Arena Stage has brought back ''The Cocoanuts'' after an absence of 60 years. The result, as intended, is comic pandemonium - and proof that performers as well as shows can be restored to stage life.

title: Providence Picks Coach
description: Providence College hired Rick Barnes as its head basketball coach yesterday. Barnes had 20 victories in his only season at George Mason University. He replaces Gordon Chiesa, who resigned on March 21.

title: Taiwan Frees 6,000 and Cuts Terms for 16,000 Prisoners
description: The Nationalist Government released about 6,000 prisoners, including 19 political detainees, in a mass amnesty today on the 100th day since the death of President Chiang Ching-kuo.

title: RED RUDENSKY, 89, SAFECRACKER WHO WENT STRAIGHT
description: Morris (Red) Rudensky, a New York-born safecracker who spent 35 years in prisons before he changed his ways and became a security expert for a lock manufacturer, died Thursday at a nursing home in St. Paul, where he had lived for many years. He was 89 years old.

title: Taxi Agency Should Recruit New York Cabbies
description: To the Editor:

title: Ferro's Chief Gets New Post
description: The Ferro Corporation, a Cleveland-based producer of industrial specialty materials, has given its chief executive, Adolph Posnick the added post of chairman, the company announced yesterday.

title: The Election Process; Political Debates and Their Impact on the Race
description: This weekend's pair of debates between Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and the Rev. Jesse Jackson - tonight in Philadelphia, tomorrow near Pittsburgh - brings the total number of such events in the 1988 Presidential campaign to something near 60.

title: Review/Film; In a Comedy of Desperation, The Odyssey of a Romantic
description: ''Love Is a Dog From Hell'' was shown as part of the recent New Directors/New Films festival. Following are excerpts from Walter Goodman's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 18. The film opened yesterday at the Waverly, Avenue of the Americas at Third Street.

title: A New Era in the Air
description: Beginning today, smoking will be prohibited on all domestic flights of less than two hours. Page 8.

title: Durable Goods Orders Were Steady in March
description: Orders to the nation's factories for so-called big ticket items remained strong in March, bolstering analysts' views that the economy is growing at a healthy pace.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Corporate Earnings listing in Business Day yesterday reported the McDonald's Corporation's first-quarter results incorrectly, and the Profit Scoreboard misstated the company's earnings gain. Correct figures appear today in the Corporate Earnings listing, on page 49.

title: Save Us From Those Noxious Corporate Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Next Step for U.S. Soccer Stars
description: If he'd picked up the ball instead of kicking it when he was a child, his college career might have led him into the good life of professional basketball. But when a talented athlete from the United States chooses to play soccer, college usually becomes his last hurrah. He becomes a Ferrari without a road, his engine racing, his career in neutral.

title: Cardinals Trade Herr for Brunansky
description: The St. Louis Cardinals, desperate for home-run power after their worst start in 15 years, traded Tommy Herr to the Minnesota Twins tonight for Tom Brunansky.

title: Delay Is Asked On Boesky Plea
description: Federal prosecutors yesterday declined either to support or to oppose a move by Ivan F. Boesky to have his three-year sentence reduced. Instead they suggested that the judge hearing the case await the outcome of continuing investigations into related cases that have relied on the testimony of Mr. Boesky.

title: Schubert 'Mullerin' Cycle, Peter Schreier's Forte
description: ''Die Schone Mullerin,'' Schubert's song cycle about the eager, heartsick miller lad and the girl he does not win, is so beloved and familiar that it comes as something of a surprise to see how infrequently it has been performed in New York over the last decade. Peter Schreier will be singing it tonight at 8 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. But for whatever reasons, ''Die Winterreise'' - the longer, grimmer companion cycle, which was once reserved for rare occasions - has become the preferred work for public performance. The earlier songs might almost be said to need a word of introduction.
