title: Woman Stabbed in Brooklyn; Nephew Charged in Slaying
description: A 57-year-old Brooklyn woman was fatally stabbed yesterday in her home, and her nephew was charged in the slaying, the police reported.

title: EMBROIDERED ANTS AND SUCH
description: Isabel Canovas's fal accessory collection resembles an etntomologist's fantasy: embroidered and jeweled ants scamper across a classic high-heel pump in hot pink silk, and a purple octagonal handbag is embroidered in a spiderweb patern, complete with caputred flies.

title: Ford Foundation Leads Delayed Philanthropic Response to AIDS
description: In what even philanthropy officials acknowledge is a delayed response to the AIDS epidemic, the Ford Foundation will announce Monday a major effort to finance care for people with the disease and to assist their families.

title: Review/Rock; A Straightforward Brand Of Music, From the Alarm
description: Part of the way through the Alarm's sold-out show at the Beacon Theater on Wednesday night, its lead singer, Mike Peters, risking his clothes if not his life, wandered out into the audience. He said: ''I hate music that makes you feel bad, too fat, too thin, too ugly, too this, too that. I will fight those songs with every ounce of breath in my body.'' A bit disingenuous, maybe, but Mr. Peters lives up to his word: the Alarm rattles neither minds nor bones. It's a friendly, less ponderous and finger-shaking version of U2 and Sting, with a dose of the Rolling Stones to keep things egalitarian - and to draw a larger audience.

title: NEW CELEBRITY ISSUES TO WOO NONCOLLECTORS
description: FAMOUS entertainers are being employed by worldwide postal administrations and their philatelic agencies in their search for new avenues to reach millions of noncollectors. The entertainers are not used as one might expect - in paid commercials or testimonials. Rather, they are being increasingly chosen as subjects for stamp issues.

title: POSTINGS: New Jersey Law; Now Co-ops Need a Deed
description: Buyers of New Jersey cooperative apartments created on or after May 9 must be given a deed along with the bill of sale. The new requirement, the first of its kind in the nation, is contained in the Cooperative Recording Act signed in January and it has both positive and negative implications for buyers.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: New Orleans;
Tower Rising Above a Mall
description: LEAD: FOR the last year, the only construction in this city's business district has been a 600,000-square-foot shopping mall being developed by the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation of Youngstown, Ohio.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Tenafly
description: AMID wildlife displays and pamphlets that are scattered around the office of the Tenafly Nature Center is a remnant of a developer's plans to build high-rise buildings on a wooded, 200-acre property in this borough.

title: 'Sweet Charity' on Stage at Cabaret in Bridgeport
description: ''SWEET CHARITY'' isn't one of the American theater's landmark musicals, but if the current drought in homegrown song and dance shows goes on, this one just might move up a notch or two, as if by default. Whereas some musicals deepen with time and others become dated, the theatrical values of ''Charity'' remain constant; the show seems better only because times are worse.

title: WHEN THE CASE FOR THE DEFENSE IS TOP SECRET
description: When Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and John M. Poindexter were in the White House, they handled some of the most closely held secrets in the Government. They knew the intimate details of this country's covert operations. They learned precisely where and under what circumstances American intelligence can eavesdrop on conversations around the world.

title: Corrections
description: A drawing with the article about cable television on page 1 last Sunday appeared without a credit line. The artist was Brick Mason.

title: Ewing Finds Joy At Bottom of Pile
description: A blue and orange pile of Knickerbockers was quickly growing on the floor of Market Square Arena, and Patrick Ewing had become its involuntary foundation. The happiest moment of Ewing's three years in professional basketball was quickly becoming a painful one.

title: Dara F. Altman Is Married
description: he marriage of Dara Felice Altman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David R. Altman of New York and Long Valley, N.J., and Michael William Lennon, a son of Phyllis A. Lennon and Robert E. Lennon, both of Montclair, N.J., took place last evening at the Cosmopolitan Club in New York. Rabbi Joel Goor performed the ceremony. The bride, who will keep her name professionally, is associate counsel for network operations and corporate development at Home Box Office in New York. The bridegroom is a writer and producer in New York of on-air promotion for television.

title: What Are The Jets' And Giants' Draft Needs?
description: The Giants' two needs are an offensive line and the secondary. The Giants will probably draft Paul Gruber of Wisconsin if he is available. If he is not, my hunch is they will go for size and draft John Elliott of Michigan. For their secondary, look for names like Michael Brim of Virginia Union and Quintin Jones of Pitt.

title: When 'Old Fashioned' Ceases to Be a Virtue
description: THE Campbell kids have been around since 1904, but they had not changed much until a few years ago. With America in the midst of a health and fitness craze, marketing executives at the Campbell Soup Company decided to slim down the pudgy trademark characters.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A SECOND MINTING OF THE ISRAEL 'PEACE MEDAL'
description: LEAD: THE Israel ''Peace Medal'' first appeared in 1974, after the Yom Kippur War. A special new edition has been issued to commemorate the country's 40th anniversary. The issue is sponsored by the Judah L. Magnes Memorial Museum of Berkeley, Calif.

title: A Playwright Honors His Past and His People
description: IN AN ACT OF HOMAGE TO HIS THEATRICAL past and the little-known cultural history of his race, Lonne Elder 3d, best known for his play ''Ceremonies in Dark Old Men'' (1969), has resurrected the life of a renowned 19th-century black actor, Ira Frederick Aldridge, and brought him home at last to America.

title: THE MEN WHO BRING US SPRING
description: From spring to spring, you never know what you'll find in the public gardens at Wave Hill, up in the Bronx. That's because Marco Polo Stufano and John Nally don't know either -and they're in charge.

title: Anne Geary to Wed
description: Dr. Paul Geary Jr. of Orlando, Fla., and Mrs. James Otey McClellan of Hilton Head Island, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Morris Geary to Charles Stephen Joseph, a son of Lieut. Col. Edwin N. Joseph, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Joseph of Herndon, Va. Miss Geary, an associate at the New York law firm of Thacher Proffitt & Wood, and her fiance, an associate at the New York law firm of Golenbock & Barell, both graduated in 1985 from the University of Virginia Law School.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Developers Offering Buyers an Inside Job
description: LEAD: OPERATING on the assumption that buyers of high-priced residential units deserve to have a hand in their design, as they would in single-family custom houses, two developers on the Island are giving purchasers the chance to shape interior spaces to their individual needs.

title: Getting Medical Help When You're Overseas
description: WHEN a vacationer is taken sick or injured overseas, there may not be anyone around who speaks English well enough to grasp what the complaint is and advise on getting help. This sort of emergency is one driving force behind the growth of organizations that give help by phone in many languages 24 hours a day.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE PILOT AND THE PASSENGER: Essays on Literature, Technology, and Culture in the United States. By Leo Marx. (Oxford University, $29.95.) Here is a rarity in these deconstructionist days: literary criticism that is actually about literature. Leo Marx, a professor of American cultural history at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has gathered together a selection of his essays, including one he first published in 1956 about Hawthorne's demonic pastoral ''Ethan Brand.

title: Puerto Vallarta
description: To the Editor: ''Puerto Vallarta Losing a Hotel'' (Travel Advisory, March 13) was of great interest to those of us who knew and loved the hotel years before John Houston filmed ''The Night of the Iguana'' and put the sleepy little fishing town on the tourist map. Your report that the Oceano Hotel has surrendered to condominium builders needs some updating, though.

title: ABASEMENT WAS IRRESISTIBLE
description: BLACK BOX By Amos Oz. Translated by Nicholas de Lange with the author. 259 pp. San Diego: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: Home Video/New Releases; Maugham, With a Twist
description: QUARTET Axon Video 120 minutes. $69.95.

title: HOUSE HUNTING
description: BY COMMON CONSENT, the great Palladian pile known as Chateau Margaux, in the wine commune of the same name, is the architectural masterpiece of the Bordeaux wine region. Built by the architect Louis Combes between 1810 and 1812, and completely refurbished over the last decade by new owners, Margaux is considered one of the great architectural treasures of France.

title: 'M. BUTTERFLY' ON BROADWAY
description: I am flattered by Jeremy Gerard's contention that I am ''one of the principal figures in bringing 'M. Butterfly' to New York,'' but I must correct a misimpression about the play's genesis (''David Hwang: Riding on the Hyphen,'' March 13). It was Gordon Davidson, artistic director of the Mark Taper Forum, who first suggested to the Taper's literary staff that the Boursicot spy scandal might be the source for a play, and the theater's literary manager, Jessica Teich, who suggested that David Hwang would be a good choice to write such a play. As it turned out, David was already at work on what became ''M. Butterfly.''

title: Cervantes Award Given To Carlos Fuentes
description: The Mexican novelist Carlos Fuentes today was awarded Spain's $87,000 Cervantes prize for literature, considered the top honor for Spanish-language writers.

title: Comings and Goings
description: WHEN the 100th anniversary of golf in America is celebrated at the St. Andrews Golf Club in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., on June 20, near the site where the first United States match was played, one of golf's most celebrated players will be there. But it is not known whether the 75-year-old Ben Hogan will play in the Hero-Am, along with Jack Nicklaus, Arnold Palmer, Byron Nelson and Sam Snead, who have agreed to play. . . . Pervis Ellison, the 6-9 junior center at Louisville, has turned down an invitation to try out for the Olympic basketball team because he fears the effects on his troublesome left knee. ''I'm trying to get my knee right,'' said Ellison, who led the Cardinals in scoring with a 17.6 average and 8.3 rebounds.

title: Offense on Film?
description: LIKE an instant replay capturing an infraction, the videotape shot by an Italian tourist Thursday afternoon at a Phoenix shopping center shows Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the Los Angeles Lakers center, straight-arming the camera as he strolled past the cameraman, according to the police in Phoenix.

title: THE VILLAINS WORE RED COATS
description: PATRIOTS The Men Who Started the American Revolution. By A. J. Langguth. Illustrated. 637 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95. TURNING 200 The Bicentennial of the U.S. Constitution. By Jane Nevins. 395 pp. New York: Richardson & Steirman. $21.95.

title: Home Video/New Releases; Elegant and Hip
description: SWING: THE BEST OF THE BIG BANDS Volumes 1 through 4, featuring Jimmy Dorsey, Duke Ellington, Gene Krupa, the Ink Spots, Les Brown, Count Basie and others. Produced by George Paige. 1987. MCA Home Video. 50 minutes. $24.95 each or $79.95 for the set.

title: Gurkhas Kill 2 Communists
description: Gurkha militants kidnapped and beheaded two members of the Communist Party of India (Marxist), the police said today.

title: Trump Everything
description: To the Editor:

title: Housewives and Prom Queens
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE SYCAMORE DRIVE-IN RESTAURANT;
A Living Museum of Hot Rods, Poodle Skirts and Rock 'n'Roll
description: LEAD: IF Dean Lawrence had his way, time would have frozen in the 1950's, when Chuck Berry was singing ''Maybelline'' and fuzzy dice dangled from the rear-view mirror of a hopped-up Ford.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE HOODED figure in the dark windbreaker turned, revealing a woman's face.

title: Late-Inning Scramble Gives Mets a Victory
description: The St. Louis Cardinals huffed and puffed, traded guys, promoted guys, juggled guys, stole home and tried everything else to pull out of the tailspin tonight.

title: BOOKS FROM THE TIMES
description: PITCHERS DO GET LONELY: And Other Sports Stories. By Ira Berkow. (Atheneum, $17.95.) ''For some of us,'' writes the New York Times sports columnist Ira Berkow, ''the struggle to get it right, to do it well and to realize at least a small portion of our dreams never ends. Like sports.'' In this selection of 85 columns that have appeared in The Times since 1981, the author covers the bases - including an interview with Sigmund Freud, who analyzes the Yankees owner George Steinbrenner - and everything else, from basketball to hockey to wrestling.

title: A Mirage, Not an Oasis
description: LA MIRAGE in Cedarhurst is appropriately named. The restaurant is not what it seems to be. Its name is French, its menu Italian, its owner Portuguese, its service laughable and its food mediocre.

title: Review/Pop; Ironic Songs And Tart Lyrics By Jay Leonhart
description: Jay Leonhart, one of the most sought-after standup bass players on the New York pop-jazz scene, has another side to his musical personality. A writer of humorous rhymed verse, he has recorded three albums of original songs that combine his jousting wit with fluid bebop-flavored melodies. These wry songs add up to a grownup pop-jazz oeuvre in the same mode as Dave Frishberg, Blossom Dearie, and early Rupert Holmes. Mr. Leonhart's characteristic attitude is to stand back and describe a subject from an ironic, sometimes jaundiced perspective, sprinkling the lyrics with tart bon mots.

title: Peru Rebels Said to Kill 20
description: Leftist guerrillas dressed as Government soldiers massacred 20 peasants in a remote mountain hamlet to avenge the deaths of three rebels in February, witnesses said today.

title: DATA UPDATE: April 24, 1988
description: NATIONAL HOUSING TRENDS *4*(In thousands of units, seasonally adjusted annual rates) Feb. 88 Feb. 87 Change Starts 1,514 1,809 -16% Completions 1,425 1,745 -18% Sales 628 738 -15% *4*(Source: Census Bureau, U.S. Department of Commerce) *4*MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages) Last Week Previous Week Year Ago New York Conventional (30-yr) 10.45 10.43 10.41 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 7.63 7.61 7.42 New Jersey Conventional (30-yr) 10.27 10.24 10.30 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 7.58 7.57 7.63 Connecticut Conventional (30-yr) 10.36 10.40 10.45 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 7.75 7.73 7.61 Co-ops (N.Y.) Conventional (30-yr) 10.42 10.33 10.63 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 7.82 7.85 7.49 Indexes for Adjustable-Rate Mortgages* 1-yr. Treasury security 6.92 7.01 6.60 National Mortgage Contract Rate 8.84 8.84 8.80 *Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes. (Source: HSH Associates)

title: BELMONT MAKES THE HEART BEAT FASTER
description: From the window of the placing judges booth, a hundred feet above the finish line at Belmont Park, the horses look like canoes as they pass beneath on the post parade to the starting gate - canoes with bright colors at their centers, the silks of the jockeys, the red jackets of the outriders, the green jackets of the pony boys and girls. Some horses seem relaxed, several prance sideways, flicking their heads; one sprints forward as its jockey stands in the stirrups. Beneath the booth, thousands of spectators watch the horses -amateur handicappers ranging from the happy beginners with $40 for the day, more interested in the outing than the betting, to the passionate horse-players who hardly notice the beauty of the track as they search for that last detail that might give them an edge.

title: Risky Business
description: AN EARNEST YOUNG woman on the Donahue show asks a psychiatrist whether she thinks our ''morals'' - meaning sexual morals - are returning to the Golden Age of the 1950's.

title: Chess Grandmasters Say New Era Began With a Tournament
description: The world's leading chess grandmasters declared a new era for their game today after a hard-fought tournament they themselves had helped to organize.

title: Vitamin C Priority
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The nearly flat roof on my ranch house has no provision for ventilation. Roofers have told me the lack of air circulation makes rot a strong possibility. I have been able to look inside this confined roof space but have seen nothing unusual. I am about to have a new roof installed and want to know what to do about this problem, or even if there is a problem. I am thinking about opening vent holes in the soffits and screening these to keep out insects. However, I don't think these will help much because the space between the roof and the ceiling is filled with fiberglass insulation. What do you think?

title: Key Health Role Seen For Veterans Dept.
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending April 10 MANHATTAN Greenwich Village $325,000 303 Mercer Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,500-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; concierge, windowed dining area, sunken-living room; maintenance $820, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Sulzberger-Rolfe) Murray Hill $156,400 136 East 36th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 800-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, high-ceilings, original moldings and details; maintenance $533, 36% tax-deductions (Broker: B.J. Gottesman) Sutton Place $905,000 25 Sutton Place South 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 2,200-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, dining room, large kitchen, East River view; maintenance $1,844, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: M.J. Raynes) West Midtown $345,000 159 West 53d Street (Tower 53) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 900-sq.-ft. postwar condo; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, balcony, Hudson River view; common charge $677, taxes $3,456 Broker: L.B. Kaye Associates) West Midtown $420,000 100 West 57th Street 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 1,700-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, 2 terraces, partial Hudson River view; maintenance $1,350, 31% tax-deductible (Broker: Sotheby's International Realty) West Midtown $850,000 58 West 58th Street 3-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 2,200-sq.-ft postwar condo; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, entry foyer, dining room, terrace; common charge $1,456, taxes $6,792 (Broker: Joffee LaSalle) BRONX Gun Hill Road Area $155,000 2906 Fenton Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, semiattached house; dining room, large kitchen, semifinished basement, 1-car garage, 30- by 50-ft. lot; taxes $1,132 (Broker: J.A.V. Realty) Pelham Parkway Area $80,000 610 Waring Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 800-sq.-ft. postwar condo; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, large kitchen, hardwood floors; common charge $154, taxes $900 (Broker: Tryax Realty) BROOKLYN Brooklyn Heights $255,000 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1,500-sq.-ft. co-op; dining room, maid's room, large living room; maintenance $1,040, 64% tax-deductible (Broker: Meridian Realty) Sunset Park $260,000 4901 Fourth Avenue 4-family, semiattached, brick house; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath, dining area, large kitchen in each unit; 1,800-sq.-ft. of commercial space on the first floor; 23- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,987 (Broker: Shelter Real Estate) QUEENS Jackson Heights $309,000 31-11 84th Street 2-family, semiattached, brick house; 2 bedrooms, dining area in primary unit; 1 bedroom in other; 1 bath, large kitchen in each; finished basement, 220 wiring, 2-car garage, 22- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,025 (Broker: Century 21/Metalios Real Estate) Jamaica Estates $65,000 84-50 169th Street (Gothic) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 700-sq.-ft. co-opin a recently renovated postwar building; entry foyer, dinette, hardwood floors; maintenance $310, 52% tax-deductible (Broker: Kraham Realty) STATEN ISLAND Dongan Hills $260,000 120 Delaware Street 2-family, detached, brick house; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath, large kitchen in each unit; half-bath in finished basement, 60- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,400 (Broker: Otto Vitale Real Estate) Clove Lake Area $245,000 57 Potter Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, detached Cape Cod; entry foyer, dining room, Florida room, large kitchen, attached 1-car garage, 50- by 95-ft. lot; taxes $1,400 (Broker: Century 21/Appleseed Agency)

title: Sex Education Manual Prompts Moral Outrage
description: A federally financed manual outlining a curriculum of sex education for teen-agers has touched off a political firestorm in this conservative state because it describes homosexuality as normal.

title: Fuel-Wise Corvettes: Detroit's Longtime Guzzlers Learn to Sip
description: When the Senate Finance Committee voted last month to double the tax on cars rated as gas guzzlers, the domestic auto industry scarcely lifted an eyebrow. After decades of sending chrome-bedecked, overweight monsters onto the highways, the Big Three have changed their ways.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Chinese Reformers, Soviet Upstarts
description: Western analysts talk of reform, Soviet and Chinese, in one breath. Not the Chinese. They've been at this reform business for a decade. They see the Russians as upstarts with greater problems and more entrenched habits. Indeed, the traveler to China is struck by an economic vitality and consumerism beyond Moscow's dreams. But when it comes to political and cultural relaxation, the Soviet Union's reforms surpass those in China.

title: Civil War Images at the Morris Museum
description: THERE are the war fans for whom the fighting not only is the thing but, also, the more up-to-date, the better.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE LAST PRINCESS. By Cynthia Freeman. (Putnam, $18.95.) In easy-reading, plot-packed style, ''The Last Princess'' takes us from New York to Paris to Israel and a few places in between. It tells the story of Lily Goodhue, who was rejected by her high society parents because she had the poor judgment to be born a girl -and the even poorer taste to be born with red hair.

title: Quartets Play Today: Tokyo and Manhattan
description: GREAT quartets and grand opera, not to mention orchestral galas, are on the schedule as the end of April approaches, and with it, the winding down of the concert season.

title: PICTURES FROM AN EXPLORATION
description: LEAD: THE ART OF CAPTAIN COOK'S VOYAGES By Rudiger Joppien and Bernard Smith. Volume III: The Voyage of the Resolution and Discovery 1776-1780. Illustrated. Text. 233 pp. Descriptive Catalogue of All Known Original Drawings and Paintings of Peoples, Places, Artifacts and Events and Original Engravings Associated With the Voyage.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about a plan to convert a Massachusetts factory into an art museum gave an incorrect location for the factory. It is in North Adams.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Vallejo, Calif.;
2,900 Houses For 900 Acres
description: LEAD: WITH demand for affordable housing remaining strong in the San Francisco region, some builders are taking on complicated projects in an effort to develop the remaining land.

title: ORCHESTRATION
description: PUTTING TOGETHER A MENU IS A DIFFERENT skill entirely from cooking a great dish. The process has often been compared to composing a symphony. A chef who understands the progression of the ''movements'' of a dinner knows how to create anticipation, climaxes and resolution in the way dishes are arranged in sequence.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is a triumph for science, for man and for history.'' - Kanellos Kanellopoulos, after flying from Crete to Santorini. [ 1:3. ]

title: THREE WORLDS OF 57th STREET; The World of Music
description: ALTHOUGH BIG BUSIness deals are cut in financial centers all over the world, the name that comes to mind when we think of stocks and bonds is Wall Street. Theater in midtown Manhattan fans out into a dozen side streets and alleys, but all major activity is nonetheless subsumed under the rubric Broadway. Accurately or not, Fleet Street is shorthand for British newspaper publishing. And so it is in the classical concert world, where the seat of authority is considered to be 57th Street - more precisely, the single West Side block between Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas.

title:
GARDENING;
How to Minimize Pests and Diseases
description: LEAD: DEDICATED gardeners take pride in producing perfect flowers, fruits and vegetables in their garden. In this imperfect world, however, gardeners must do battle with legions of diseases and insect pests that seem bent on cheating them out of success. Plants are disfigured and even killed by these maurauders.

title: 3 Proposed for Federal Bench By D'Amato Are Scrutinized
description: Three candidates for Federal judgeships recommended by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York have come under unusually intense scrutiny in regard to their ethics or qualifications.

title: How One Company Will Cope
description: The Campbell Soup Company has been developing new systems for assembling and interpreting marketing data. It is in the process of automating much of the processing of this data. Anthony Adams, vice president of market research, talked with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about how Campbell Soup will manage its marketing data.

title: OPEC ISN'T THE ONLY CARTEL THAT COULDN'T
description: One of the basic tenets of economics, related to supply and demand, is that producers will always try to control the prices of their products. A second tenet holds that they will almost always fail.

title: Nigerians Hold an Election
description: The Government took a step today toward restoring civilian rule when councilors voted on hand-picked candidates for the Constituent Assembly. The Assembly will debate a new constitution drafted by a Government-appointed committee. The constitution will serve as the charter for Nigeria's political future. President Ibrahim Babangida, a general, has reserved one-fifth of the seats for members appointed by the ruling military council.

title: Miss Findlay Is to Be Wed
description: The engagement of Kimberly Wrede Findlay to Jonathan Bostwick Davis, the son of Dr. E. William Davis Jr. of New York and Old Westbury, L.I., and the late Lillian Bostwick Davis, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mrs. Edward A. Deeds of Charlotte, Vt., and David B. Findlay Jr. of New York and New Canaan, Conn. The couple plan to marry in September.

title: East Brunswick Students In Contest on Constitution
description: LEAD: WHEN the Bicentennial competition on the United States Constitution and Bill of Rights gets under way in Washington tomorrow, 26 East Brunswick High School social-studies students will represent New Jersey.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Fifth Avenue Merchants; Prestige Tenants Battling Tourist-Oriented Stores
description: IN the Rolex Building on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, a shop that sells everything from $4.99 coffee mugs to Persian rugs at ''80% off'' trumpets an ''Inventory Clearance'' sale.

title: HIS, NOW HERS
description: FASHION HAS SOMETHING TO DO WITH IT, BUT there's more to it than that. On the right woman, a man's shirt can be alluring - one reason, experts say, why shirts designed for men routinely find their way into many women's closets. A man-sized shirt masks curves, to be sure, admits Judith Waters, a psychologist who has studied the role clothes play in business and private life.

title: BREAKING THE LAW IN NEW YORK CITY: 7 MILLION PEOPLE, HALF A MILLION FELONIES
description: Killings rose in New York City last year, alarmingly in some areas, and it was small comfort that robberies were down. While robberies declined by 2.4 percent to 78,890, the New York City Police Department reported last week, murders increased by 5.8 percent to 1,691.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: A JOINT legislative hearing earlier this month on how to reduce the production of hazardous wastes gave industry officials and environmental activists a chance to air their differences and, perhaps more significantly, a hint at some areas of agreement.

title: Why Not Maintain Public Land?
description: I was interested in the article on open space on March 13 (''Towns Scrambling to Acquire Open Space''). Leslie N. Corey, of the Nature Conservancy, spoke of the continual drive for more public land, and particularly land on Long Island Sound.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
APARTHEID, BOYCOTTS AND A LONELY RUNNER
description: LEAD: IT'S easy to sympathize with Zola Budd, the barefooted middle-distance runner from South Africa who first made headlines as the wonder teen-ager who challenged world records. In 1984 when she adopted British citizenship and ran in British colors, Budd's youthfulness, lanky stride and record times upset the established hierarchy of female distance runners.

title: Yucatan
description: To the Editor:

title: THE HIGH COST OF THINNESS
description: It is with great concern that I respond to Robin Marantz Henig's article ''The High Cost of Thinness'' (Body and Mind, Feb. 28). The article correctly states that suction lipectomy is the most common form of esthetic surgery performed in the United States today, but the procedure is not designed to be an easy way to make people ''look thinner.'' Suction lipectomy addresses contour deformities that cannot be improved with diet and exercise.

title: POSTINGS: New State Forms; Renewing A Lease
description: Beginning next Sunday, rent-stabilized tenants whose leases are expiring will receive new state-mandated lease-renewal forms. Because landlords must offer a lease renewal between 120 and 150 days before its termination, the first tenants to find the form in the mail will be those whose leases end in September and October. The form is based on one already used for rent-stabilized apartments in Nassau, Westchester and Rockland Counties. Unlike current leases, it details who should be offered a lease renewal and sets a timetable for responses.

title: First-Strike Weapon
description: To the Editor:

title: After 15-Game Slide, Nets Win Amid Some Optimism
description: While the Knicks managed to rise from their ashes to the playoffs this season, the Nets, injury-plagued and demoralized, continued to wallow in the swampland that has characterized the franchise for the last two seasons.

title: Leather Goods With Roman Flair
description: SOME of the most interesting shops in Rome may lie hidden behind old stone walls that almost seem to sag under the weight of centuries of accumulated dirt and grime. With no slick facades or decorative window displays to lure the passer-by inside, these nondescript shopfronts may only attract the adventuresome.

title: IS MANAGUA REDRAWING THE PARTY LINE?
description: Three days of talks between contra guerrilla leaders and the Sandinista Government ended without agreement last week, but the prospects for a peace settlement did not die and the two sides agreed to meet again this week. The cease-fire declared a month ago was holding, and negotiators said they still believe a formula for a final armistice can be reached.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Bloomsburg, Pa.;
Anticipating The Competition
description: LEAD: WHEN the 64-store Columbia Mall opens two miles north of here next fall, its developer hopes to draw shoppers from a population of about 120,000 in rural northeastern Pennsylvania that does not have easy access to a large shopping center.

title: HOW THE U.S. CAST OFF NEUTRALITY IN GULF WAR
description: Although the United States maintains official neutrality in the Iran-Iraq war, the Reagan Administration's gradual tilt toward Iraq is beginning to look like a full-fledged embrace.

title: Review/Blues; Temptation and Infidelity In Neil Young's New Songs
description: Neil Young was playing with the blues when he came to the World last week. He has been writing 12-bar lyrics and listening hard to the guitar work of T-Bone Walker, Wes Montgomery, Elmore James and the Kings (B.B., Freddie and Albert). With the release of his album ''This Note's for You,'' he brought his band, the Blue Notes, including a six-man horn section, to the World for four barely publicized club dates rather than a large New York concert. Tuesday's two sets included new (or unfamiliar) songs exclusively, and Mr. Young wore sunglasses for all but one line of his last encore.

title: George St. Offers 'Rappaport'
description: HAVING been perplexed by one oddity after another, a sex-reversed ''King Lear'' being the oddest of all, and then jolted by ''Tracers,'' a graphic piece about the Vietnam War, George Street Playhouse audiences can now be taken in by ''I'm Not Rappaport,'' a play that appears rigged for safety and endearment.

title: Rite of Spring: Pleas for State Aid
description: ONE OF the new harbingers of spring around the State House is the rally by local officials seeking some help with their mounting fiscal problems.

title: Yucatan
description: To the Editor: My husband and I recently returned from two months in the Yucatan Peninsula and so read Elizabeth Benedict's article on Kailuum with amusement and disbelief.

title: Review/Theater; Feeling Right at Home With the Unspeakable
description: No need to take a hit of anything before you go into Sebastian Stuart's ''Beverly's Yard Sale'' at the Theater for the New City; if this thing, all on its own, doesn't shake your screws loose, mere chemistry won't help you get it. The play, the third part of what Mr. Stuart calls his Saugerties trilogy, pits a degenerate Hudson Valley family, a neighbor, a pack of yard sale scavengers and a screaming hallucination against one another in a game of nitwits.

title: STREETSCAPES: Claremont Stables; An 1892 Survivor of Close Calls With Demolition
description: BUILT in 1892, Claremont Stables at 175 West 89th Street in Manhattan has twice escaped demolition. Now the city, which had condemned the site for housing in 1965, has both offered to sell the building back to the family that has operated it as a riding academy since 1943 and proposed the building for landmark designation.

title: New Caledonia Rebels Demand Halt to Vote
description: Melanesian separatists holding 27 French police officers hostage on the small island of Ouvea demanded today that regional elections scheduled for Sunday in this French Pacific territory be canceled.

title: A Cure for a Company's Identity Crisis
description: CORPORATE logos once tended to be straightforward graphics and identifiable trademark objects and characters - the A.T.&T. bell, for example, or Pegasus, Mobil's winged horse. In the 1970's, however, logos took on a new look: Lettering and symbols became abstract, and logo characters became passe.

title: Uneasy Alliance
description: To the Editor:

title: IN EUROPE: AN EVOLVING TRADITION
description: In Western Europe, with its tradition of strong socialist and union movements, worker-owned cooperatives were forming as long as a century ago.

title:
Recordings;
Latin Hip-Hop Elbows Its Way to the Top
description: LEAD: A NEW GENERATION OF AMERICAN pop is emerging from Hispanic New York. Variously called Latin hip-hop, be-bop and other imprecise tags, dance recordings made by and for Latino youth have elbowed their way up the pop charts. In the last two years, a nationwide radio format has coalesced around these records and their ever-widening audience (initially urban listeners between the ages of 14 and 25).

title: Delhi Lawyers End Strike Over Police Official
description: A bitter 75-day strike by lawyers ended in a new flood of controversy this week, as the authorities bowed to the lawyers and removed one of the highest ranking women in India from her post as deputy commissioner of police in New Delhi.

title: Ads of Candidates Offer a Guide to the Ballot Maze
description: In a barrage of radio advertisements and election-day fliers, the campaign of Michael S. Dukakis is offering Pennsylvania voters a legal, 1980's version of the old aphorism of the Illinois political machine: Vote early, vote often.

title: THE HEALTH-CARE CHAOS
description: Joseph A. Califano Jr.'s article ''The Health-Care Chaos'' (March 20), was a well-balanced dissection of today's health-care cost problems. More importantly, he has provided well thought out, eminently sensible solutions, but the main questions remain. Will Government and the judicial system make the necessary changes and will the medical community be able to establish valid standards for quality care combined with justifiable expense? F. PETER RESCIGNO, M.D. Glen Ridge, N.J.

title: 'We Can Still Save Fiction in America'
description: LEAD: EDITH WHARTON was 38 years old before anyone other than her editors at Charles Scribner's Sons thought her letters worth preserving. By 1900 she had been publishing fiction for nine years, and was the author of a book on house decoration and a well-received volume of short stories. She had been married for 15 uneasy years to Edward Wharton of Boston, and was now living in Newport, R.I., and New York City with annual trips to Europe.

title: Ethics Board Asks Developer to Testify
description: ''WE'RE not dragging our feet,'' said Roland F. Berlingo, a member of the Port Chester Board of Ethics. ''These are legal matters, and they take time.''

title: Family Violence
description: In Rye and in Newport News, Va., ''if you hit a woman, you're going to jail'' or at least to a mandatory therapy program. That message is the focus of the award-winning videotape ''Agents of Change - A Law Enforcement Response to Family Violence,'' now being used to train police departments nationwide. Earlier this month, ''Agents of Change'' beat 1,000 competitors to win second place at the 30th American Film and Video Festival in Manhattan, an event that is considered the largest and most prestigious showcase of non-theatrical films and tapes in the country.

title: POSTINGS: Fishkill Project; The Rush To Dutchess
description: A five-year, $100 million project being built in Fishkill, N.Y., is grounded in microprocessors and home furnishings. The first of six office buildings, a four-story, 120,000-square-foot structure, will be ready for occupancy in June. Its first tenant, with 6,200 square feet, will be the Intel Corporation, the world's largest maker of microprocessors. Meanwhile, early this month, ground was broken for a six-building home furnishing center. The 88,000-square-foot retail plaza will open next spring.

title: Barriers to DAT Recorders Are Breaking Down
description: AUDIOPHILES LIVING along the northern border have lately been crossing into Canada to buy Digital Audio Tape decks. They are readily available there, as they are in Japan and Europe. Among industrial countries, only the United States is still without this latest advance in audio technology. Soon, however, it may no longer be necessary to leave the country in search of DAT recorders.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A Bomb You Can Pat WILLIAM F. GASSER was showing off his nuclear bomb. ''It's certainly the first one on Long Island you can pat,'' he said, as he gave the black cylinder an affectionate stroke. ''But it's not my first nuclear weapon; no, the Nike missile over there, on the trailer, in front of the armored tank; you see it? Yeah, that was my first nuclear weapon. I had it brought here on a flatbed truck, all the way from Texas.''

title: Strawberry Shortcake: Two Versions
description: THE season for locally grown strawberries will not begin for at least another month.

title: THREE WORLDS OF 57th STREET; The World of Shopping
description: MAY I HELP YOU?''

title: MUD-WRESTLING WITH HER PAST
description: WESTERN SWING By Tim Sandlin. 372 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $19.95.

title: Orderly Exodus From Cuba Is Near
description: United States officials said today that they expect 12,000 to 15,000 Cubans to emigrate to the United States by the end of the year in the first major exodus from the country since 1980.

title: Television; Reading Hemingway With One Eye Closed
description: IN HIS KINDER MOMENTS, ERNEST Hemingway regarded biographers as either grave-robbers or morticians. As a grim compliment, he congratulated Arthur Mizener on his 1951 biography of F. Scott Fitzgerald, ''The Far Side of Paradise,'' calling it ''good undertaking.'' It was not an unintentional pun. Mizener, Hemingway said, had done a better job than most members of the profession: ''Almost as good as the job they did on my father's face when he shot himself. One remembers the face better as it actually was. But the undertaker pleases those who come to the funeral.''

title: Review/Theater; Childhood Memories Of a Long-Gone World
description: Larry Cohen's memory play, ''Washington Heights,'' revisits a world that will seem very familiar to anyone who has already savored Neil Simon's ''Brighton Beach Memoirs'' and Woody Allen's ''Radio Days.'' Once again, it is the eve of World War II. Once again, a grown-up character introduces his own childhood memories of New York Jewish family life during a time of economic austerity. Once again, the boy he remembers having been is a bright, funny kid with a hyperactive imagination.

title: Planner's Proposals Miss the Mark
description: On its surface, the interview with David Emilita [ ''A Planner Balances Quantity and Quality,'' March 20 ] would appear to warrant serious thought. Unfortunately, the proposals Mr. Emilita suggests show a lack of understanding of the true forces that affect the residential development community on Long Island today.

title: STEPPING OUT
description: FOR MANY MUSICIANS, NEW YORK ISN'T the center of the world - it's more like a far-flung suburb of Port-au-Prince or Athens, Bogota or Dublin. Ethnic communities here are magnets for the music of the old country and nothing, except perhaps the smell of home cooking, stirs memories and reinforces roots like local music. Now, in the age of jet travel, the world is local. And across New York City are clubs where musicians from all over the world - some internationally known, some well-kept community secrets - can perform as if neither they nor their listeners had ever left home. That makes globe-hopping as easy as stepping through the door of a club, especially on Saturday nights, when places are full and lively and a stranger can get swept up in a crowd where English is rarely spoken. Forget the passports and the airline reservations (but do phone ahead for current information); at these clubs, you can travel by ear. DESERT SONGS

title: Yankees Stumbling After Hot Start
description: What hot start?

title: Of Snobs, Art and Price Tags
description: To the Editor:

title: Devils Sharpen Their Killer Instinct
description: Never had the New Jersey Devils scored so many times in a game. Never had the Washington Capitals, after seven consecutive seasons of playoff appearances, been beaten so soundly.

title: Toward the Extreme
description: Whatever chance there might have been for early negotiations between Israel and its Arab neighbors is now gone. The fragile hopes raised by Secretary of State Shultz have been destroyed by events of the last three weeks.

title: A Nostalgic View of Farming in Stamford
description: LEAD: TO everything there is a season, and in farming there a tool for every season: a tool to till, and to plow, harrow, cultivate, hay, harvest and thresh.

title: A Frenetic Pace Prevails as the Big Night Nears
description: LEAD: IT was just more than a month ago that Peter W. Delaney talked to one of Liza Minnelli's representatives and described the quarters the superstar will use Satur-day night, when she officially opens the newly renovated County Center here with a gala concert to benefit a performing-arts trust.

title: PHYSICIAN FAULTS CANCER DIAGNOSIS
description: The main witness this week for three tobacco companies defending themselves against a suit seeking damages for the death of a 58-year-old woman was a pathologist who testified that the woman had died of a rare type of cancer that is not caused by smoking cigarettes.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Like Father, Like Son

title:
Gardening;
SHAPING RHODODENDRONS AND AZALEAS
description: LEAD: THE marvelous diversity of growth habits and blooming times for azaleas and rhododendrons offers a pruning challenge to even the most experienced gardener. Should a low growing, ground covering azalea like Late Love or Flat Out be pruned in the same manner as a Dexter Rhododendron like Scintillation, which is six feet tall?

title: Kenneth Glover And Miss Dugas Wed in Chicago
description: Lauren Roberta Dugas, an account executive at Burrell Public Relations in Chicago, and Kenneth E. Glover, the deputy manager of the municipal finance division of Drexel Burnham Lambert in New York, were married yesterday in Chicago. The Very Rev. David N. Harris performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Paul and the Redeemer.

title: A Canada Goose That Thought It Was a Chicken
description: WHEN he came he could hardly be recognized as a proud Canada goose.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WAITING FOR NEXT WEEK. By Michele Orwin. (Holt, $17.95.) Lying in her hospital bed, riddled with cancer, Naomi tells her daughter Beth, the narrator of this ably written first novel, ''I just want it to be next week. . . It's what your father and I say to each other whenever we have to do something we don't want to do. We say we wish it was next week. Then it would be over. Sometimes I think we've wished our whole lives away like that.'' It's Christmas time, and Beth, her younger brother Billy, and her older brother and sister, Grim and Sharon, have been summoned by their father, Hersh, to await their mother's death. As the days creep by, Beth leads us from the hospital coffee shop to her parents' Tudor house in affluent suburban New Jersey - and down the splayed path of memory as well. Here she maps out the Asher family politics: Grim, a philosophy professor, and Sharon, a charmless city lawyer, versus the ne'er-do-well younger children, Billy and Beth. Beth never quite makes peace with Naomi, and when her mother finally dies the release that Beth feels is dispiritingly banal. Her coming of age, it turns out, is the novel's main concern - though instead of going on 16, the protagonist here is pushing 40. Unfortunately, Beth and the rest of the book's many characters remain mired in stereotype. Michele Orwin is adept at propelling her tightly knit story along, and she's especially good at capturing the humorous kvetching of Beth's relatives. What ''Waiting for Next Week'' fails to capture, however, is the reader's imagination.

title:
BODY AND MIND;
Cadence of the Heart
description: LEAD: MY STETHOSCOPE, BY NOW, IS AN OLD friend. It is, after all, the one I bought in medical school, 28 years ago, though it has been replaced several times over, part by worn-out part, like atoms of the body. The earpieces slip into my ears tightly, the sounds of the world diminish. I enter the cave-dark, tone-dense hollow of the chest and tune in to the mother heart.

title: TRANSIT NOTES
description: LEAD: AFTER 13 years of steady growth, the total number of vehicle crossings between New Jersey and New York declined slightly last year, with bus, rail and ferry commuting incresing.

title: THE SPORTING LIFE
description: DEEP ENOUGH FOR IVORYBILLS By James Kilgo. Illustrated by the author. 193 pp. North Carolina: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $14.95.

title: 'There Is a Responsibility to Protect Land'
description: NICHOLAS F. BELLANTONI became the new state archaeologist in January and runs a one-man operation at the Connecticut State Museum of Natural History in Storrs.

title: Madeleine D. Willi To Wed Reporter
description: Madeleine Denise Willi and Wayne Ryerson Coffey, a son of Marion Coffey of Ridgefield, Conn., and Frank B. Coffey of Palm Springs, Calif., plan to marry in September, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Willi Jr. of West Redding, Conn., have announced.

title: THE HEALTH-CARE CHAOS
description: One example in Mr. Califano's litany of ''economic errors'' was the excessive cost of Caesarean sections -presumably because physicians did too many.

title: Exterior Paint Problems
description: BLISTERING and peeling are perhaps the two most noticeable signs of deteriorated exterior house paint. Their causes can also be among the most difficult to pinpoint and remedy. However, whether you intend to repaint your house or only make spot repairs, take time to analyze areas of deteriorated paint and eliminate their causes before mending them. If you don't, chances are they will recur, sometimes quickly.

title: Cioppino: Fish Stew From the Pacific
description: SAN FRANCISCO'S cioppino, a chowder composed of the catch of the day, is from that large family of seafood stews that flourish in the restaurants of ports around the world. The name is derived from ciuppin, in the dialect of Genoa, where California's first fishermen came from in the middle of the 19th century.

title: Man, Guilty of Killing Officer, Is Convicted on More Charges
description: A 40-year-old Manhattan man who was convicted Friday of killing a veteran police detective was found guilty yesterday on related charges of assaulting a second officer in the same shootout.

title: Ruth S. Sharp to Wed Robert A. Keilty
description: Mr. and Mrs. George B. Sharp of Katonah, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ruth Sloane Sharp to Robert Allan Keilty, the son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Bruce Keilty of Toronto. A September wedding is planned.

title: Bringing Music of the World to Students
description: Three dozen music teachers studied song sheets with the words in the Akan language of Ghana and music to ''Bantama Kra Kro,'' a Ghanaian stick-game song. Soon, most of the group was vigorously singing, and several members rose to try a Ghanaian dance.

title: Sports of The Times; Hockey Wins but Loses
description: MARK JOHNSON did not mind being overshadowed by Patrik Sundstrom in the Devils' 10-4 victory over the Washington Capitals Friday night.

title: China and Arms Sales
description: China's sale of medium-range missiles to Saudi Arabia touched off a furor, evidently to Beijing's surprise. The official explanations are resentfully defensive.

title: Editors' Note
description: The article ''The Men Who Bring You Spring'' in The World of New York, Part 2 of The Times Magazine today, profiles John Nally, curator of the gardens at Wave Hill in Riverdale. Mr. Nally died after the magazine had gone to press.

title: DUKAKIS DECLINES TO DETAIL PLANS
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts ducked a challenge from the Rev. Jesse Jackson tonight to ''put some money on the table'' to pay for domestic programs.

title: Paris Opera
description: To the Editor: I recently returned from Paris and a visit to the Paris Opera. Some thoughts on the Q & A item of March 13 on ''Phantom of the Opera'' tours: Since viewing some parts of the opera house is very limited, especially on days of performance (you will not see the Chagall ceiling), we found the best thing to do was to buy the cheapest seat ($13) for an evening performance. The 10 days we were there, no operas were being performed, but a guest orchestra was there for two nights. We were up in the heavens, and the seats were very tight - no leg room - but we arrived half an hour before the performance and were able to walk all around. At intermission we viewed the long bar, and at the end of the evening, we were able to walk into the boxes.

title: More Co-op Owners Battling Their Boards
description: KENNETH ROSENBLUM, a Manhattan lawyer, said the difficulties with his co-op board started with a leak in the ceiling of his living room. The problem was not properly corrected, he said, and water seeped into his walls, his furniture mildewed and his floors warped.

title: U.S. IS CONSIDERING COAST GUARD ROLE IN GULF DEFENSES
description: The Pentagon is considering adding Coast Guard vessels to the Navy fleet in the Persian Gulf, Defense Department officials said today.

title: Orioles (0-17) Edged by Royals in 9th
description: The Baltimore Orioles tried a new lineup and they had a new set of managers for most of the game. They wound up with the same old result - a defeat, their 17th straight since the start of the season.

title: WORK AND LOVE: REVOLUTION AND AFTER
description: INTIMATE MATTERS A History of Sexuality in America. By John D'Emilio and Estelle B. Freedman. Illustrated. 428 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $24.95.

title: Antiques; A Bestiary of British Furniture
description: BEHEMOTHIC BRITISH furniture - framed in columns, crowned with pediments and fitted with beastly feet - dominated fashionable interiors throughout England, Scotland and Ireland 150 years ago. Now these massive mahogany library tables, reading chairs, sideboards, bookcases, armoires and folio stands are back in favor on both sides of the Atlantic. They may proliferate if a full-fledged revival is spurred by the exhibition ''Powerful Forms in Furniture,'' opening Friday and remaining through May 21 at Didier Aaron, 32 East 67th Street.

title: Turning a School District Around
description: IN APRIL 1986, the Asbury Park school system was the first in New Jersey to enter Level III monitoring, the last step prior to takeover by the state's Department of Education. Now, Asbury Park expects to be the first urban school district to achieve state certification under current standards.

title: DUKAKIS STRATEGY: GRAB FROM BUSH, BORROW FROM JACKSON
description: A strange calm descended on the campaign trail last week. Not only the Republicans but now also the Democrats seem very close to having their nominee, months before the national conventions. Suddenly, the talk among politicians about endorsements, momentum and delegate counts gave way to some hard thinking about how Michael S. Dukakis and George Bush will compete against each other this fall.

title: Ex-Cameraman Donates One-of-a-Kind Films to Yale
description: LEAD: VICTOR CROMWELL, 68 years old, became a television cameraman when the networks were still in their infancy. Now, with early films of rare and one-of-a-kind shows, he is making sure remnants of those years are not thrown away.

title: Food Banks Report Increase in Donations
description: LEAD: FOOD BANKS in the state are reporting increases in donations. ''I think more people are realizing that instead of throwing food out, they can give it to someone,'' said Ann Donovan, an administrative assistant at the Connecticut Food Bank in New Haven.

title: Rack Up That City On a Hill
description: FIVE DAYS BEFORE New York Gov. Mario Cuomo was to deliver his keynote speech at the 1984 Democratic convention, he called broadcaster Larry King and read it to him over the telephone.

title:
ANTIQUES;
Decoys: A Long Pine Barrens Tradition
description: LEAD: PART of the heritage of life in the Pine Barrens is continuity, and it's a fact of living here with which Gary Giberson is very familiar.

title: FILL-IN FLASH ANXIETY REMEDIED
description: BACK in the Dark Ages of photography, the most anxiety-producing technique known to camera-toting man or woman was called fill-in flash. It was meant to remedy a common problem of outdoor portraiture: too much contrast. Sophisticated photographers knew that just the right amount of light from a flash would eliminate unflattering deep shadows from under their subjects' noses, eyes and chins.

title: The Eternal Resort Off Italy's Shore
description: THE first pleasure palaces were built on Capri 2,000 years ago for Augustus Caesar, who adopted this rugged, semitropical island as his favorite retreat. Emperor Augustus's successor, Tiberius, found it even more to his liking. He lived on Capri for the last 10 years of his reign, dividing his time among 12 villas as he avoided most of the cares and dangers back in Rome.

title: Gene Raymond Jr. Wed to Mary Cole
description: Mary Elizabeth Cole, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Cole of Owings Mills, Md., and Gene Sherwood Raymond Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond of Waldoboro, Me., were married yesterday. The Rev. Philip Roulette performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Garrison, Md.

title: The Motto At This Spa: Easy Does It
description: LESS than a two-hour drive from London, deep in the bemeadowed Suffolk countryside, is Shrubland Hall, a stately mansion from the 1740's that is one of Britain's most splendid health spas. Surrounded by rolling Constable landscape and celebrated Italian gardens on more than 1,200 acres, Shrubland is a place for relaxation, exercise and contemplation.

title: With Too Much Festivity for a Week, State Celebrates Dance Month
description: LEAD: GOVERNOR KEAN added luster to the state's dance community on April 14 when he proclaimed, a bit belatedly, ''New Jersey Dance Month.'' The designation formalizes what has been evident this spring: that dance flourishes in New Jersey's fertile artistic landscape.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Bridgewater $266,000 969 Sevren Place 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 21-year-old ranch; fireplace, 2-car garage, intercom system; taxes $3,079. Franklin Lakes $867,500 228 Seminole Lane 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 24-year-old custom ranch; library, 3 fireplaces, pool; taxes $6,567. Maplewood $220,000 13-15 Kendal Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 42-year-old colonial; screened porch, fireplace, hardwood floors, 1-car garage; taxes $3,893. South River $112,500 27 Florence Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; patio, eat-in kitchen, 2-car detached garage; taxes $1,930. Springfield $196,500 29 Crest Place 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 38-year-old colonial; full basement, screened porch, fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $2,874. Summit $875,000 81 Hobart Avenue 7-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 69-year-old English country house; master bedroom, w/w carpeting, 2-car garage; taxes $7,825. OTHER AREAS Smithtown, L.I. $282,000 12 Andrea Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; dining room, den, center hall, 2-car garage; taxes $4,400. Ossining, N.Y. $220,000 2 Birchbrook Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 33-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, deck, family room, .24-acre, taxes $3,853. North Branford, Conn. $175,000 39 Hummingbird Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 5-year-old ranch; huge family room with bar, 1 acre; taxes $1,408.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The nearly flat roof on my ranch house has no provision for ventilation. Roofers have told me the lack of air circulation makes rot a strong possibility. I have been able to look inside this confined roof space but have seen nothing unusual. I am about to have a new roof installed and want to know what to do about this problem, or even if there is a problem. I am thinking about opening vent holes in the soffits and screening these to keep out insects. However, I don't think these will help much because the space between the roof and the ceiling is filled with fiberglass insulation. What do you think?

title: Review/Recital; Premiere of Gimbel Work
description: Jon Klibonoff, the pianist who performed at Riker's Island and at a homeless shelter under the auspices of the Pro Musicis Foundation last week, was presented by the same organization in a public recital at the Metropolitan Museum on Thursday evening.

title: Review/Pop; Dancing Zairian Rhythms By Les Quatre Etoiles
description: Les Quatre Etoiles (the Four Stars), a seven-piece band from Zaire by way of Paris, brought intricate, effervescent dance music to SOB's on Wednesday. Zairian pop is a cross-cultural delight, an amalgam of traditional rhythms, imported (or repatriated) Afro-Cuban rhumbas and electric guitars used in a purely Congolese style, with skipping, syncopated lines in a quicksilver tone. Zairian pop has swept French-speaking Africa, and it is now reaching Europe and the Americas, lately via the Talking Heads' album ''Naked.'' Like Haitian rock, another French-African-Caribbean hybrid, it rolls along with lilting, tickling, multilayered melodies that are utterly seductive.

title: Social Events; Parties With a Purpose
description: For Creative Solitude

title: Comeback by the Atlanta Papers Isn't All Hurrahs
description: This city's newspapers, The Atlanta Journal and The Atlanta Constitution, have all the ingredients of an editor's dream: a celebrated reputation in need of repairing, owners with money and a hunger for dramatic improvement, a town large enough to support a first-rate paper, and a big story to cover - the evolving South.

title: Breat Cancer: Anguish, Mystery and Hope
description: IT IS TUESDAY, BREAST CANCER DAY AT THE National Institutes of Health clinic in Bethesda, Md. At first glance, the women sitting in this sunny waiting room waiting to be examined look perfectly healthy. There are no obvious wigs - the telltale sign of chemotherapy. But these patients are clearly nervous, flipping through magazines distractedly or staring out through the large plate-glass window at a wooded landscape dotted with N.I.H. buildings. Each has had breast cancer or is considered at risk of developing it, often because of her family history. They come regularly to this sprawling 14-story building for checkups and, if the worst happens, for treatment.

title: Special Today
description: The World of New York/Magazine, Part 2

title: Gas Spill Spurs Code Review
description: LEAD: LIKE the company that owns it, a pipeline central to the distribution of petroleum products on Long Island has long kept a low profile.

title: The RoboAnchor
description: Some weeks ago, NBC announced it was putting into operation television's latest technological marvel, the robotic camera, or robocam. The robocam slides around the studio floor and zooms in for close-ups like any other TV camera, but all by remote control. This means that the three or four cameras aimed at Tom Brokaw are no longer operated by three or four operators, but by one. As with the introduction of any new labor-saving device, the company is happy, the union is worried about losing jobs and Japanese manufacturers are raking in the profits.

title: Elisa Lord Plans to Wed Steven Rothman in May
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Lord of New York and Roslyn Heights, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Elisa Lord, to Steven Rothman, the son of Lucille Rothman of Jericho, L.I., and the late Norman Rothman. The couple plan to marry May 29.

title: Verbatim: Honoring Debts
description: ' The measure would provide for the first time an official acknowledgment of the grave injustice that was done. It would provide token monetary compensation to those who suffered irreparable losses. . . . Its passage will prove that our beloved country is great enough to acknowledge and correct its past mistakes. ' Senator Spark M. Matsunaga, Democrat of Hawaii, supporting a bill the Senate passed last week that would compensate the 60,000 living Americans of Japanese ancestry who were interned during World War II.

title: Headliners; Off the Hot Seat
description: Tumbleweeds do not yet roll past vacant offices at the Justice Department, nor does the wind whistle along empty corridors. But Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d is having difficulty filling the posts from which two top aides and four of their deputies recently resigned in protest against Mr. Meese's continuing legal problems. Last week, John C. Shepherd, the Attorney General's choice as the new No. 2 man in the department, withdrew his name from consideration. In recent weeks, his club memberships have come under attack and there have been reports that a former bookkeeper in his St. Louis law firm said she had had an affair with him, which Mr. Shepherd denied. He said he and his wife were ''not prepared for the pressures'' that resulted from his nomination.

title: Latest Literary Battle: Robinson vs. Ueberroth and Edwards
description: AS if Frank Robinson hasn't received enough attention as manager of the instantly infamous Baltimore Orioles, he now has a book coming out in which he leaps into another struggle: the hiring of black former players as managers and front-office executives.

title: Intriguing Thai Fare in Stamford
description: THE opening of two Thai restaurants in lower Fairfield County within months of each other suggests that a trend may be in the making. A Thai restaurant in Danbury was the pioneer about a year ago.

title: WHEN THE PUTTING GOES BAD
description: At 38, Tom Watson is no longer a golf prodigy (''When the Putting Goes Bad,'' by Peter de Jonge, March 13). However, he may be encouraged to recall that Sam Snead, Ben Hogan and Jack Nicklaus were still winning major titles past the age of 40, and Lee Trevino won his second P.G.A. Championship in 1984, when he was 44, 10 years after his first P.G.A. victory.

title: Noise in the Halls
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.-Iran Gulf Battle: Powerful Lesson in How Naval Warfare Has Changed
description: Although a minor engagement by World War II standards, the Persian Gulf battle last week was the most significant American naval surface action since the Battle of Leyte Gulf in the Philippines in 1944 and underscored the accuracy and destructiveness of modern high-technology weapons.

title: Give Illegal Aliens More Time
description: The 1986 Immigration Reform and Control Act provided amnesty for the estimated 1.4 million to 2 million undocumented aliens who have been in the United States since before 1982. But with the May 4 deadline less than two weeks away, only 1.2 million have applied. Fairness justifies an extension.

title: By 2 Wheels and 4 Through France's South
description: THE airport security guard knew we were bicyclists - our carry-on luggage included helmets and handlebar packs. Even so, the X-rayed contents of an additional knapsack mystified him, and he asked us to open it for a closer look. A nuisance, but forgivable. How many couples, embarking on a cycling vacation in France, equip themselves with a folding car rack?

title: 'Angel Street': Wife And Her Tormentor
description: IN 1939, Patrick Hamilton's thriller ''Gas Light'' opened in London, and in 1941 the same play, about a fiendish husband trying to drive his wife insane, opened in New York under the title ''Angel Street.'' It was later made into a Hollywood movie, again titled ''Gaslight.'' The Arena Players Repertory Company has revived ''Angel Street'' and if you have missed it up to now, you have another opportunity to see it.

title: Kenya's Taxi Vans Are Packed and Perilous
description: A recent cartoon in the Daily Nation newspaper here depicted a reporter interviewing the owner of a taxi company named Kenya Speedsters, Ramshackles, Crammers and Skull Crushers.

title: Indian Village and Museum Being Built in Burlington County
description: LEAD: LIKE other members of the Powhatan-Renape Nation in and around the Burlington County township of Westampton, the Samuels family of Moorestown is working to keep its native-American heritage alive and strong.

title: Arms and Dukakis
description: To the Editor:

title: French Election Tests Mitterrand And 3 Rightists
description: France goes to the polls Sunday for the elimination round of a two-stage presidential election in which President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, and Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, the neo-Gaullist leader, are expected to emerge victorious.

title: A July Wedding For Lucy Pearson
description: Lucy Pearson of Lake Worth, Fla., a daughter of Viscount and Viscountess Cowdray of Cowdray Park, Midhurst, Sussex, England, and Charles Torquil de Montalt Fraser, a son of Maj. and Mrs. Michael Q. Fraser of Nashes Farm, Penshurst, Kent, England, plan to marry in July.

title: Lord Ramsey, 83, Dies in Britain; Former Archbishop of Canterbury
description: Lord Ramsey, a former Archbishop of Canterbury who, during his tenure as Primate of the Church of England, was a thorn in the side of conservatives and a proponent of worldwide Christian ecumenism, died yesterday in Oxford, England. He was 83 years old.

title: New Construction Work to Affect Motorists
description: MOTORISTS can expect delays, beginning this week, on Route 33 in Mercer County, Routes 1 and 9 in Elizabeth, Route 166 in Toms River and on the Duncan Avenue ramp leading from the southbound lanes of the Pulaski Skyway in Jersey City.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: GILOT'S 'JOURNEY' Straight from an acclaimed run at the Picasso Museum in France, ''Francoise Gilot: An Artist's Journey,'' a retrospective of the Frenchwoman's work, begins a tour of American museums in Hempstead today. Why Hempstead? That's where Hofstra University is, and since Ms. Gilot is a special friend of Hofstra - the university has given her an honorary degree, and she's been involved in some of its art programing - the artist has chosen it as the first American site for her exhibition. In turn, the university has made the art show the center of a kind of festival with concerts and lectures accompanying it during its stay through July 1.

title: Rajneesh Haven: A Legacy of Debts
description: SIX years after the Indian guru Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh began to build a ''world commune'' near Antelope, Ore., all that was left was a ghost city.

title: China Strains for Olympic Glory
description: TRAIN HARD, MAKE PROGRESS TO Win Honor for the People - Only 7 Days Until the National Games.''

title: Dana Shaffer Marries Gregg David Hayden
description: Dana Shaffer, a daughter of Mrs. Alvin I. Weinstein of Chicago and Jack A. Shaffer of New York, was married last evening at the Pierre in New York to Gregg David Hayden, a son of Loretta Hayden of Hingham, Mass., and Gerard M. Hayden of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Michael Gelber performed the ceremony.

title: Scandinavia
description: To the Editor: You had an item about Finncheques (Travel Advisory, Feb. 21) to be used for housing in Finland. Last summer, I bought the vouchers, but upon using them in Finland, I had to pay a 50 percent surcharge to occupy a single room. The rooms had a single bed. I was not occupying a double room, on which a surcharge might have been appropriate.

title: THE K.G.B. AND ME
description: Your Moscow bureau chief, Philip Taubman, seems puzzled by the degree of surveillance accorded him by the K.G.B. (''The K.G.B. and Me,'' March 6). As a former intelligence officer, I can assure him that intelligence bureaucracies, regardless of nationality, have one sacred purpose - to expand the T.O. (the table of organization). The more cases you have, the more bodies you can assign to cover them. And the more bodies you supervise, the higher your rank.

title: RIDING THE ROAD OF DANGEROUS CARS
description: REMEMBER how on long drives you used to make a game of spotting out-of-state license plates? Lately, I've been playing a similar time-passing game when I'm driving after dark - counting ''one-eyed'' drivers.

title: N.F.L. Draft '88; ... BUT SO DO THE JETS
description: AS good as he may be -and he will probably be very good - the first player the Jets draft today is unlikely to turn the club into a winner in 1988. But it's a start. Again. The likely starting point, if the clubs ahead of the Jets draft to form, will be the offensive line. The Jets pick eighth. They would probably like to take Paul Gruber of Wisconsin. If the Jets get Gruber, he could produce a ripple effect through the entire offensive line. In theory, the Jets, who permitted 66 sacks last season, could go from having a questionable line to a pretty good line.

title: Homeless: One Man's Odyssey
description: FOR 14 years, Bruce ''Dice''

title: Michael Specter Is Wed To Alessandra Stanley
description: Alessandra Stanley, a correspondent in the Washington bureau of Time magazine, and Michael Specter, a reporter on the national staff of The Washington Post, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Timothy Wadsworth Stanley, in Washington. t Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit performed the ceremony.

title: Growth of Small Airport Eyed
description: EAST HAMPTON pilots and residents agree that no expansion at the town airport is desirable, but an $11 million master plan now under consideration by the Town Board envisions one.

title: Airport Growth: Problems Amid Promise
description: LEAD: LONG ISLAND MACARTHUR AIRPORT, which had its busiest year in 1987 and expects to break that record for passengers this year, is at the center of a controversy in which business leaders want to expand the airport's capacity and residents of the area want just as fervently to prevent any further disruption of their lives.

title: Police Say Thief Told Victim He Had AIDS
description: A Bronx man was arrested Friday night on charges that he had robbed a woman of her jewelry by telling her he had AIDS and holding a hypodermic needle to her neck, the police said.

title: THERE'S MORE TO CHINATOWN
description: It is your original ethnic theme park. I could eat the air, food-promise-crammed. Street life chugs, as thick and rich as arterial blood. Guitar-twang speech, a harmonic convergence of it, is all around. Red and gold, colors of good luck, flare up. And this wild variegation, alongside the jagged Chinese writing, cuts against architectural regularity. Buildings seem to bow down, to billow and sag like cloth dragons. For once, at 5 feet 4 inches, I do not feel short in New York. Chinatown is human-sized.

title: THE HEALTH-CARE CHAOS
description: The ''barely explored world of biotechnology beyond the imagination of Steven Spielberg'' seems to carry a price tag beyond the imagination of King Midas. The prices that are being charged for the new genetically engineered drugs are outrageous. Instead of berating the American Association of Retired Persons for charging its measly $4.50 dispensing fee, Mr. Califano should reserve his ire for Genentech, which is charging $2,000 for a single dose of tissue plasminogen activator for heart-attack victims, or Burroughs-Wellcome for charging AIDS patients $8,000 a year for AZT. ROBERT J. YAES, M.D. Lexington, Ky.

title: Peace Group to Mark Anniversary
description: IN 1958, 55-year-old Dorothy Eldridge, a Nutley microbiologist and mother who regarded nuclear defense as a threat to human and other life, began to publicly oppose nuclear weapons and the arms buildup.

title: For Fugard, Many Roads Lead to This 'Mecca'
description: THE TITLE CHARACTER IN ''Dimetos,'' one of the few Athol Fugard plays that has not yet been performed in the United States, lives on a stark landscape, unidentified by name but a clear approximation of New Bethesda in South Africa. At one point, Dimetos describes a workman in the local quarries as a man who ''assaulted'' rock ''as if nothing short of total obliteration would satisfy him.'' He adds: ''Without that dour tenacity of purpose, survival here wouldn't be possible.'' That tenacity is pervasive in Mr. Fugard's work, from the earliest plays through his most recent, ''A Place With the Pigs.'' It defines Helen Martins, the iconoclastic heroine of ''The Road to Mecca,'' which has arrived in New York four years after its world premiere at the Yale Repertory Theater.

title: INSIDE
description: Shultz Plays Down a Rift

title: Trade Bill Passes First Crucial Vote
description: A trade bill made it through the House. A party-line vote of 312 to 107 approved the measure, which included an intensely disputed item requiring that workers be given 60 days' notice of plant shutdowns or big layoffs. President Reagan, in a stand backed by many business groups, has said he will veto a bill that includes the notice provision. The rest of the bill encompasses the most sweeping trade legislation in 14 years. Among other things, it calls for investigations to uncover ''pervasive'' unfair trade practices and for retaliation against countries that persist in them. The bill would increase benefits to industries and workers whose livelihoods are damaged by imports. Farmers would get increased export subsidies and oil producers would see an end to the windfall profits tax. A Senate vote is expected early this week.

title: THE LATIN PRESENCE
description: MEXAMERICA Two Countries, One Future. By Lester D. Langley. 312 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $19.95. HISPANIC U.S.A. Breaking the Melting Pot. By Thomas Weyr. 241 pp. New York: Cornelia and Michael Bessie/ Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE SECRET IN THE MATCHBOX By Val Willis. Illustrated by John Shelley. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Sean Kelly Is Married To Patricia Anne Todd
description: At the Woodmont Christian Church in Nashville, Patricia Anne Todd, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis B. Todd Jr. of Nashville, was married yesterday to Sean Kelly, the son of Mrs. Charles Kelly of Owen Sound, Ontario, and the late Mr. Kelly. The Rev. Dr. Joseph H. Bragg Jr., the vice president of the Christian Board of Publication in St. Louis, performed the ceremony.
