title: CRIME
description: Tuthill Willow, the private eye in DEATH WORE GLOVES by Ross H. Spencer (Donald I. Fine, $17.95), is approached by a nun who wants him to locate her missing niece, a model. This nun is not your everyday variety of nun. She is in a permanent alcoholic fog, and her language would bring a blush even to men in an army barracks. Willow needs the work. So he takes the case and asks her a few questions:

title: Treat Teachers Like Professionals
description: A RECENT article on teacher participation in the hiring process in the East Williston school district may give the teacher empowerment movement a much needed boost on Long Island.

title: Battle for Loyalty at the Wedtech Trial
description: The chief prosecutor and defense lawyer in the corruption trial of Representative Mario Biaggi fought last week for the memories and loyalties of two accountants.

title: THE HEALTH-CARE CHAOS
description: Joseph Califano states in his article that Americans spent $1,800 a person on health care in 1985. He says that the British spent $600 and yet their health-care system is ''sophisticated and modern'' and that life expectancy is ''at least as high as in the United States. . . .'' This, however, obscures the fact that a British citizen with chronic debilitating pain resulting from, for example, end-stage hip disease, may have to suffer for years waiting for surgery. The British have chosen to allow patients with chronic renal failure, whose life expectancy could be indefinitely prolonged, to languish and die rather than to supply costly dialysis. Would this be acceptable to Mr. Califano and to other Americans as a way to cut medical costs? LAWRENCE S. SCHIFFMAN, M.D. Florence, Mass.

title: If Jazz Quartet's on Stage, Lawyer Can Take a Bow
description: ''I never had any musical talent, and everybody knows I can't sing a thing on key,'' said Paul Chevigny, a 52-year-old civil rights lawyer, law professor and jazz aficionado. ''I was always a guy who went to clubs, nursed a beer and just listened.''

title: No Headline
description: AFTER a four-day cruise out of Stonington recently, Arthur Medeiros returned to port with 4,000 pounds of flatfish, cod, monkfish, squid and skate, about as much as he would have caught in two days as recently as last year.

title: Rediscovering Japanese Life At a Bike's Pace
description: JAPAN. Remembering the old days. I had been there a number of times, the last of them as a fighter pilot direct from the war in Korea. We were given 48 hours in Tokyo every two months or so. I have a vague recollection of having seen the Great Buddha at Kamakura, but far more distinct are images of an indoor waterfall, many lighted levels and 800 evening-gowned hostesses - the allures of a famous nightclub called the Mikado, I think.

title: Manhattan Rabbi Celebrates 25 Years on a Different Path
description: A remark by a Soviet official 22 years ago that ''religion is for old people'' vexed Rabbi Arthur Schneier, then the young leader of the Park East Synagogue, in a broadly political and deeply personal way.

title: BEST SELLERS: APRIL 24, 1988
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 7 THE ICARUS AGENDA, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) A congressman's secret dealings with terrorists may bring him the Presidency - or death. 2 2 25 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 3 1 ROCK STAR, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The glory and anguish of three rock-and- roll performers in tinselly southern California. 4 3 6 TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Dirk Pitt leads a global pursuit of hijackers of an ancient Egyptian literary trove. 5 4 6 INHERITANCE, by Judith Michael. (Poseidon, $18.95.) A woman finds herself enmeshed in the jealousies and conspiracies of a wealthy family on Boston's Beacon Hill. 6 1 LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $18.95.) A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested by ife's changing conditions. 7 5 7 HOT MONEY, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) Which member of a gold arbitrager's family was responsible for the murder of his fifth wife? 8 7 27 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $18.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 9 * 6 3 KING OF THE MURGOS, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $16.95.) Book Two of the fantasy saga that began with ''Guardians of the West.'' 10 8 10 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 11 9 3 THE LAST PRINCESS, by Cynthia Freeman. (Putnam, $18.95.) What ensues when a New York socialite sacrifices a family fortune and a wealthy fiance to marry for love. 12 12 5 S., by John Updike. (Knopf, $17.95.) A New England woman, in search of a new life, joins a religious commune in Arizona. 13 * 14 5 EMPEROR OF THE AIR, by Ethan Canin. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) Nine short stories about a variety of characters and situations. 14 11 22 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Putnam, $19.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts creates nightmares in a Maine village. 15 10 44 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. Nonfiction 1 2 50 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions. 2 1 19 TRUMP: The Art of the Deal, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the entrepreneur. 3 1 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 4 3 12 THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Random House, $24.95.) How economic and military forces affected the fortunes of great nations in the past 500 years. 5 4 3 CITIZEN COHN, by Nicholas von Hoffman. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The life of Roy M. Cohn. 6 1 WASHINGTON GOES TO WAR, by David Brinkley. (Knopf, $18.95.) A social and political portrait of the nation's capital during World War II. 7 5 24 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) How companies can survive. 8 6 8 BATTLE CRY OF FREEDOM, by James M. McPherson. (Oxford University, $30.) A history of the American Civil War era. 9 7 2 THE POWER GAME, by Hedrick Smith. (Random House, $22.50.) How the Federal Government has evolved over the past 15 years. 10 9 14 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Viking, $19.95.) An account of a fast-developing new science. 11 1 WINFIELD, by Dave Winfield with Tom Parker. (Norton, $16.95.) The autobiography of the New York Yankee outfielder. 12 8 11 THE PRIZE PULITZER, by Roxanne Pulitzer with Kathleen Maxa. (Villard, $17.95.) Life in Palm Beach's steamy rich society. 13 12 3 THE TRIAL OF SOCRATES, by I. F. Stone. (Little, Brown, $18.95.) The Greek philosopher's life and death, with an unfavorable assessment of his ideas. 14 14 2 UNDER THE EYE OF THE CLOCK, by Christopher Nolan. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) The autobiography of a young Irishman who has been paralyzed, spastic and speechless since birth. 15 13 9 OSCAR WILDE, by Richard Ellmann. (Knopf, $24.95.) The life of the dramatist, essayist and poet. 16 * 10 4 UNFORGETTABLE FIRE, by Eamon Dunphy. (Warner, $16.95.) The story of the rock band U2. 17 * 11 3 ON THE OUTSIDE LOOKING IN, by Michael Reagan with Joe Hyams. (Zebra, $17.95.) The autobiography of Ronald Reagan's adopted son. Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 42 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 2 3 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 3 3 12 ELIZABETH TAKES OFF, by Elizabeth Taylor. (Putnam, $17.95.) The film star relates her experiences in gaining and losing weight. 4 5 2 BEING A WOMAN, by Toni Grant. (Random House, $17.95.) How to achieve a life balanced between feminism and femininity. 5 4 3 CONTROLLING CHOLESTEROL, by Kenneth H. Cooper. (Bantam, $17.95.) A physician's program to prevent heart disease through exercise and diet. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) ARABESQUES, by Anton Shammas. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) An autobiographical novel about self-discovery and self-definition in the most troubled of times and places, manifold and intertwined in shape but rational and responsive in tone, originally written in Hebrew by a Christian Arab from a small town near Haifa. THE DEATH OF METHUSELAH: And Other Stories, by Isaac Bashevis Singer. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.95.) Stories from the 1970's and 80's by the cunning artificer of Yiddish prose; some concern Manichean clashes between the holy and the demonic; others, carnal and spiritual ambition in the almost ordinary world. MOON TIGER, by Penelope Lively. (Grove, $15.95.) A popular historian, dying, projects her own life on the rest of history in this intelligent novel, winner of Britain's 1987 Booker Prize. THE HOUSEGUEST, by Thomas Berger. (Little, Brown, $16.95.) Alternately benevolent and predatory, a perfect houseguest whom no one invited dominates Mr. Berger's creepy 15th novel. YUPPIES INVADE MY HOUSE AT DINNERTIME, edited by Joseph Barry and John Derevlany. (Big River, Paper, $5.95.) A vivid picture of a town in the throes of gentrification, compiled from letters written to The Hoboken (N.J.) Reporter. COMING FIRST, by Paul Bryers. (Atlantic Monthly, Paper, $7.95.) This saucy British farce exposes its hero, a television director and equal-opportunity victim, to every stereotype of woman in power. SAILING, by Susan Kenney. (Viking, $18.95.) This wise sequel to Ms. Kenney's wrenching ''In Another Country'' brings her heroine, Sara Boyd, up against the fact of her husband's terminal cancer.

title: Understanding the Dream World of Cigarette Ads
description: The magazine advertisement is starkly beautiful: a woman with full, open lips holds a bar of melting ice to her neck, as water streams onto her naked shoulder. Embedded in the ice, in shimmering green letters, is the word ''Salem.''

title: Marathon Running Is Alive And Well
description: REPORTS of the death of distance and marathon running are greatly exaggerated. Long Island has the proud distinction of showing this to be so.

title: Something There Is That Does Not Love a Missile
description: To the Editor:

title: District Spends $345,000 on Plans But Doesn't Build School
description: One week school officials here were preparing building plans for a new school. Six weeks later, they had a nearly complete set of drawings and a bill of $345,000 for a school that would never be built.

title: THRONGS OF ALIENS SEEKING AMNESTY AS DEADLINE NEARS
description: In an atmosphere of hope, confusion and fear, tens of thousands of aliens are scrambling to apply for legal status before the nation's landmark amnesty program is to end in less than two weeks.

title: Report Alleges Human Rights Abuses in Panama
description: Panama's military-dominated Government has engaged in a widespread pattern of human rights abuses, including the beating and jailing of protesters and the mistreatment of prisoners, according to a report by a human rights group. The report was released today.

title: Seeking Victory Without Fear
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Dr. Leona Chen Weds K. A. Eng
description: Dr. Leona Liyuan Chen and Kevin Arthur Eng were married yesterday at Tavern on the Green in New York by Justice Richard L. Price of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: IN SEARCH OF FRAGRANT SPACES
description: LEAD: Rose gardens spilling over with floribundas, damasks and hybrid teas, tulip beds like miniature Hollands, carpets of daffodils and banks of azaleas -New York gardens.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Ocean County Draws Adult Complexes
description: LEAD: SINCE the Garden State Parkway was cut through the area more than three decades ago, Ocean County's wide-open spaces have steadily disappeared. At almost every turn are houses, retail strips and small office centers.

title: TREASURE HUNTS
description: Visiting the city's auction houses can be as enjoyable and educational as perusing works in a museum or art gallery. In some ways even better. There aren't any admission fees. Art and objects can be viewed at close proximity and experts are on hand to discuss them and to answer questions. Shoppers with a hankering to try on a giant diamond brooch, inspect the inner workings of a clock or open every drawer of a desk may do so, in most houses. And the auction rooms are located conveniently close to each other, so it is easy to take in several in a single outing.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE UNARMED PROPHET:

title: City Hall Notes; Little Support From Within for Koch's Candidate
description: Mayor Koch was nothing if not honest last week when he said he had endorsed Senator Albert Gore Jr. for President against the advice of almost all his closest advisers. In fact, the Mayor's preference was shared by only a handful of the top officials in his administration.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: GRAHAM LA BELLA whisked his automated wheelchair ahead of the visitor into an art room of the Human Resources School with a deftness that made it look almost like fun. He did a U-turn and brought himself up to the table where he, a visitor, his teacher and a center official were going to talk about Graham's favorite subject, if not passion: art.

title: How 1984 voters feel now
OLYMPIC PROFILE: MARY DECKER SLANEY; HARD TIMES BEHIND HER SLANEY RENEWS THE QUEST
description: ON Aug. 4 she turns 30, and the mere idea of such antiquity drew a laugh and a slap of the forehead in mock disbelief. ''I know, I know,'' Mary Decker Slaney said. ''But they say distance runners don't peak until their mid-30's. Do I believe it? Yeah. Of course I believe it.''

title: Home Video/New Releases
description: Three O'Clock High Starring Casey Siemaszko, Richard Tyson, Anne Ryan, Stacey Glick, Jonathan Wise, Jeffrey Tambor, John P. Ryan. Directed by Phil Joanou. 1987. MCA Home Video. 90 minutes. $79.95. Rated PG-13. Some strong language.

title: Review/Concert; Philharmonic Assays Persichetti's Fourth
description: James DePreist, music director of the Oregon Symphony, began two weeks of subscription concerts with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall Thursday night; he will also lead the orchestra in a special program tomorrow night at the Apollo Theater in Harlem.

title: A NEW ERA: SENATE SEEKS A LEADER FOR THE 1990's
description: The decision by Senator Robert C. Byrd to relinquish his post as Democratic leader in January may mean not only a changing of the guard but also the passing of an era. The choice will be up to the West Virginian's fellow Democrats, who if they retain control of the Senate in November will pick the man to lead a troubled legislative body into the 1990's. Elected leader in 1977, Mr. Byrd had been pressed to step aside by those who find his meticulous attention to parliamentary detail ill suited to the politics of the television age. Younger senators complain of the quality of their life, of long hours consumed in procedural and partisan dispute rather than policy debate. Three senators - Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii, J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana and George J. Mitchell of Maine -seek the leadership. They discussed their agendas with Susan Rasky, chief Congressional correspondent for The New York Times. Excerpts follow. Inouye: A Call for Comity

title: State Plans to End Japanese Pine Sales
description: DECORATIVE Japanese black pines, which for 30 to 40 years have lined many Long Island state parks, parkways and coastal areas, have recently been dying in rapidly growing numbers, and the State Tree Nursery has finally decided to stop producing and selling them.

title: Russian Denies Signing Letter
description: Andrei Voznesensky, the Russian poet, denied last night a report that he was among 38 prominent Soviet writers and editors who signed a letter to the Communist Party newspaper Pravda.

title: Sports of The Times; Yankees' Version of The Natural Is 3-0
description: SITTING at his Yankee Stadium locker, the 22-year-old rookie was staring at the front page of the new issue of Baseball America, a weekly newspaper. Above a color photo of himself in a windup were the words: ''New York's New Star'' and below, ''Will Al Leiter Live Up to His Advance Billing?''

title: Elyse Applebaum Engaged to Wed M. A. Newhouse
description: The engagement of Elyse Sue Applebaum to Michael Andrew Newhouse, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Newhouse of New York, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Donald I. Applebaum of Iselin, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: Introducing the First PS/2 Clones
description: THE Dell Computer Corporation of Austin, Tex., last week became the first major company to show a working copy of an I.B.M. Personal System/2 computer, introducing two machines that incorporate the high-speed Micro Channel architecture used in I.B.M.'s PS/2 Models 60 and 80. A few days later the giant Tandy Corporation of Fort Worth introduced its own Micro Channel machine, driven by the 80386 microprocessor chip. The Tandy appears to take aim at the Model 80 (perhaps matching the desktop PS/2 Model 70 that I.B.M. is expected to introduce in June).

title: Clifford L. Abbey And Clare Luce Are Wed on L.I.
description: Clare Middleton Luce, the daughter of Margarget H. Howe of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Peter P. Luce of Boulder, Colo., was married yesterday to Clifford Louis Abbey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Vance Abbey of Sweet Home, Ore. The Rev. Dr. James I. McCord, the chancellor of the Center of Theological Inquiry at Princeton University and a former president of the Princeton Theological Seminary, performed the ceremony at the home of Henry Luce 3d, the bride's uncle, in Mill Neck, L.I.

title: THREE WORLDS OF 57th STREET; The World of Art
description: IN THE MATTER OF 57th Street, I find myself agreeing with the art critic who spoke of it as perhaps the longest street in the country - so far does it stretch in our imaginations, and so widely is its example followed. Many other streets in Manhattan have art galleries, and some of them are very good indeed (others are awful, which is a story for another day), but 57th Street has a character all its own.

title: Review/Guitar; Artist Bridges Two Styles
description: The guitar is a common denominator between popular and concert music, so, appropriately, Douglas Niedt's evening at Weill Recital Hall on Friday went back and forth between the two. At one pole in his program were familiar items by Tarrega, Turina and Villa-Lobos. At the other were placed arrangements of Paul Desmond and Dave Brubeck, with Richard Rogers's ''Lover'' and ''Laura'' by David Raksin alongside them. The common ground between these extremes - and perhaps the evening's most engaging music -were the Latin American items by Zaldivar, Morel and Ovalle. Here the rough flavors of the street and the refinements of the concert hall mingled easily.

title: PRIVATE TERMS WINS
description: Private Terms ran his record to 7 for 7 by scoring a 1 1/2-length victory over Seeking the Gold and Cherokee Colony in the $599,000 Wood Memorial Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. The race considerably brightened the outlook for the Kentucky Derby May 7, because the first five Wood finishers finished just four lengths apart in a very quick race, and all ran well enough to earn a trip to Churchill Downs.

title: Kean Presses Plans to Promote Foreign Trade
description: LEAD: WITH Congress still debating a trade bill and New Jersey businesses eager to keep their new momentum, the Kean administration is moving ahead with plans to expand the role of its Division of International Trade. The proposals, if approved by the Legislature, would double the division's budget and include a major higher-education center.

title: The Plot's The Thing - Again
description: A LEGEND IS A TWISTED FACT THAT HAS SURVIVED more than a generation. Having burrowed into the general consciousness, it is well on the way to becoming irrefutable myth. No one is ever going to prove, for instance, that Helen's face launched only 500 ships, or that there was an honest man in Athens but Diogenes just didn't find him. It is also too late, I suppose, to persuade compilers of program notes that Bach did not compose ''Bist du bei mir'' but simply copied G. H. Stolzel's song into a book that he put together for the use of his wife, Anna Magdalena. Just the other day, at Alice Tully Hall, Bach once again received undue credit, though it is not as if his reputation needed a boost.

title: Sarah R. Houghton to Marry Mark Grayson in December
description: Sarah Richardson Houghton, a daughter of Representative Amory Houghton Jr. of Corning, N.Y., and Washington, and Ruth Houghton of New York, plans to be married in December to Mark William Grayson, a son of Thomas D. Grayson of Fairfax, Va., and Suzanne M. Rowins of Hancock, Calif.

title: MAGICAL MYSTERY TOURIST
description: LETTERS FROM EGYPT A Journey on the Nile 1849-1850. By Florence Nightingale. Edited by Anthony Sattin. Illustrated. 223 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $22.50.

title: Foreign Ensembles to Visit
description: THE week in music is crowded with performances by Connecticut artists and orchestras, but since three renowned ensembles from abroad are visiting us as well, let's begin our previews with a welcome to I Musici of Rome, the Choir of St. Paul's Cathedral in London and the Jerusalem Symphony of Israel.

title: Financial Aid And Private Colleges
description: The article ''Concern Growing on College Costs'' on March 20 contained a number of inaccuracies with regard to the cost of attending a private college. My observations are based on more than 20 years of administrative experience at three private colleges in Connecticut.

title: Locusts Head South, Threaten New Africa Famine
description: The desperately poor countries just south of the Sahara will face a resurgence of famine next year as vast swarms of locusts now infesting northern Africa move south and ravage their crops, officials at the headquarters of the Food and Agriculture Organization here say.

title: NEW YORK, PARIS, LONDON, TOKYO, BERLIN, ATLANTA! ATLANTA?
description: It was April 14, the day the Soviet Union and the United States signed the Afghanistan withdrawal agreement in Geneva. In Moscow, a new trade agreement between the Soviet Union and Atlanta-based RJR Nabisco Inc. was being announced. Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry, might have been expected at either event, and in fact was scheduled to appear at both.

title:
MUSIC;
Hollybush Updates 'Tosca' for Festival
description: LEAD: THE sixth annual Hollybush Festival will open Saturday at Glassboro State College, presenting opera - including an updated ''Tosca'' - symphony, ballet and visual arts. It will run through May 19.

title: Who Will Win the Kentucky Derby?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Finding a Bicycle Trip Built for You
description: MORE and more Americans are discovering the pleasurable pace of two-wheeled travel: swift enough to satisfy the urge to ''get somewhere,'' slow enough to let you appreciate the country in the process.

title: Keeping Corporations Accountable
description: ALICE TEPPER MARLIN has spent half her lifetime exhorting corporate giants to meet what she considers their social responsibility.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
At a Reunion, Agonies Revisited
description: LEAD: IN everyone's life there's a Janice Plotkin.

title: Editor of the Letters Tests Limits
description: The tiny office is submerged in stacks of readers' letters, one day's worth of mail piled precariously on the desks and spilling onto the floor. The small staff of Ogonyok, the brash weekly magazine, is inundated by an outpouring of newly voiced passions from the Soviet people.

title: Art or Not? Anyway, Now It's Mine
description: I CAN'T blame the wine at the opening - I'd only had one small plastic glassful, and it was white and cheap. But something had loosened my inhibitions and purse strings, and now I'm a Collector, a graduate to uppercase.

title: Another Feather For Massimino
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Tick Research Is Threatened
description: LEAD: THE Smithsonian Institution, which houses many of the nation's great art treasures, is also curator of one of the world's more unusual collections, a million tick specimens.

title: A Car Phone That Links People and Their Desires
description: Heaven knows, it's hard to keep up. On your last trip to Paris, you dropped into Chichen Itza for a custom-made pigskin briefcase, only to arrive back at work and find some 26-year-old with a new $2,500 alligator model he snapped up in San Francisco while his Ferrari was being serviced.

title: Uncertain Legacy?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE HIGH COST OF THINNESS
description: Congratulations to Robin Marantz Henig on her coverage of the popular liposuction surgery. It would be interesting to study the statistics concerning the gender of these patients. How many men, I wonder, are so inclined to run serious health risks and pay outrageous sums of money for a narrower appearance? Those who died in the search for a beautiful body are victims, not only of their own vanity, but of the culture that dictates, primarily to women, that which is beautiful, acceptable and attractive, and that which is not. JANICE KOCH Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE SECRET OF INNER STRENGTH: My Story. By Chuck Norris with Joe Hyams. (Little, Brown, $16.95.) On the evidence of this autobiography and self-help guide by the karate champion turned movie star Chuck Norris, it can safely be said that Mr. Norris's writing is just about as good as his acting. In a brisk, superficial, occasionally entertaining book (written with Joe Hyams, a Hollywood biographer), Mr.

title: THE STAGES OF MARTY'S FESTIVAL
description: His signature garnet rosebud blooming in his lapel, Martin E. Segal -Marty to anyone who has known him more than five minutes - is presiding over the weekly staff meeting of the First New York International Festival of the Arts, of which he is founder and chairman. The monthlong, citywide celebration of the performing arts opens on June 11, just two years after the 71-year-old Segal resigned as chairman of Lincoln Center to carry out the grand design he has nurtured for more than a decade.

title: Headliners; On the Record
description: ''Moonwalk,'' the autobiography of Michael Jackson, began dancing out of the bookstores last week. For $15.95 a copy, readers became privy to the kind of tidbits that most entertainers toss off for free in interviews, which the reclusive Mr. Jackson does not give. The 29-year-old superstar concedes, for instance, that he has had his face remodeled, but not as much as many have speculated:

title: Mixability
description: To the Editor:

title: Indian Fishing Dispute Upsets North Woods' Quiet
description: With white-tailed deer prancing along the forested shores of Big St. Germain Lake under a moonlit sky, this North Woods region seemed posed for a portrait of splendor and tranquillity. But a National Guard helicopter whirred overhead. Police officers stood by in riot gear. And an ambulance waited near the shore, just in case.

title: Now, Dear Moscow Editor, About the Socialist Plague . . .
description: Before the era of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, readers' letters were regarded as fit to print in the Soviet press only if they made a point that the authorities wanted to make, and they were severely edited for that purpose.

title: THE HEALTH-CARE CHAOS
description: Joseph Califano's article raised many issues concerning the rise in health-care costs, but fundamental to the discussion is his call for a cultural shift in patient attitudes and expectations. He is saying, in effect, we must begin to make choices.

title: ARMY RADIO MAKER IS FOCUS OF INQUIRY
description: A criminal investigation is being pursued into whether the manufacturer of the Army's main combat radio, E-Systems Inc., repeatedly covered up defects in thousands of the radios by falsifying test results, according to documents obtained from the Pentagon.

title: Robin Comiteau Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joel T. Comiteau of West Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Alise Comiteau, to Patrick Joseph Tully, a son of Mary C. Tully of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., and Michael J. Tully of Garrison, N.Y. A June wedding is planned by Ms. Comiteau, an associate at Adams & Rinehart, a financial public relations firm, and Mr. Tully, an institutional broker at Mabon, Nugent & Company, both in New York.

title:
Music;
American Music's Vitality
description: LEAD: FOR MUCH OF THE NATION'S history, Americans have battled a cultural inferiority complex. All too often, composers have been taken seriously only if they studied in Europe, or at least imitated European styles. And such a phenomenon is hardly restricted to the past, for even composers as popular as Philip Glass and Steve Reich had to receive a European stamp of approval before they were accepted at home.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE SKY PEOPLE. By John Emery. (Soho/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) Into the world of Melville and Conrad, the poet and screenwriter John Emery has put a cast of jaundiced Australians, disgruntled tribesmen and fascistic Germans. The action unfolds in New Guinea in 1937. Out of necessity rather than altruism, the colonists have made peace with their subjects.

title: Review/Opera; Fairies, Lovers and Rustics Abound in Juilliard 'Midsummer Night's Dream'
description: Shakespeare is bustin' out all over New York these days, but it's hard to imagine the Bard better served -and the composer Benjamin Britten, as well - than at the Juilliard American Opera Center's current production of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.''

title:
GARDENING;
How to Minimize Pests and Diseases
description: LEAD: DEDICATED gardeners take pride in producing perfect flowers, fruits and vegetables in their garden. In this imperfect world, however, gardeners must do battle with legions of diseases and insect pests that seem bent on cheating them out of success. Plants are disfigured and even killed by these maurauders.

title: Tick Research Is Threatened
description: LEAD: THE Smithsonian Institution, which houses many of the nation's great art treasures, is also curator of one of the world's more unusual collections, a million tick specimens.

title: Going Solo Into White Water
description: LEAD: IT has often been suggested by white-knuckled passengers in my sports car that I must have a pronounced death wish. Maybe, but it had never occurred to me to indulge it by rafting until some friends invited me to join them on a trip down Oregon's Rogue River. Rafting, a cottage industry in the Northwest, is a generic term for any means of navigating the tumultuous rapids, euphemistically described as white water, that break the even flow of the rivers tumbling into the Pacific along the western coast of the United

title: CORRUPTION CASES RISE IN ARGENTINA
description: Several months ago, as a federal judge was inspecting a beach club believed to be the site of various misdeeds, someone stepped out of the crowd of spectators and handed an envelope to one of the judge's assistants.

title:
INVESTING;
A Solid Military Supplier
description: LEAD: WHEN Iranian missiles bore in on American warships last week, they missed, thanks in part to chaff. This metalized-glass-fiber product, when fired into the air, presents a confusing picture to an incoming missile's radar that may deflect its aim.

title: Reagan Predicts Victory on Veto of Trade Bill
description: President Reagan, who has steadfastly opposed the comprehensive trade bill that is scheduled for a vote in the Senate Tuesday, predicted today that his veto will be sustained.

title: Runners Aiming For Gold, Cash
description: America's elite marathoners have received their share of criticism the last few days. Nine runners from six other countries have covered the 26-mile 385-yard distance in less than 2 hours 10 minutes, and not once in the last five years has an American run it that fast.

title: New Haven Holding On To 'Elm City' Nickname
description: NEW HAVEN may be on its way to living up to its nickname the Elm City, thanks to the planting of 100 of the once plentiful trees this week.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs; Oilers Win to Take Three-Game Lead
description: Charlie Huddy and Glenn Anderson scored second-period goals tonight to lead the Edmonton Oilers to a 4-2 victory over the Calgary Flames and a commanding 3-0 lead in the Smythe Division final.

title: Propping Up the S.&L.'s
description: Troubles in the savings and loan industry continue to multiply. Hundreds of savings and loan associations, mostly in the oil belt, are insolvent. The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, whose job it is to bail out depositors if these associations go under, is also insolvent. What will it cost to fix the F.S.L.I.C. and the problem thrift institutions? Fredrick D. Wolf Assistant Comptroller General, General Accounting Office.

title: THE HEALTH-CARE CHAOS
description: Documenting and eliminating waste in the health-care system will be a difficult task. It is not even clear that waste can be defined adequately. Is it wasteful for Medicare to spend a large proportion of its funds on acute care of the elderly who are in their last year of life while access to prenatal care for women on Medicaid is severely limited? Is it wasteful to pay for organ transplants while thousands of children do not have access to adequate primary care or vaccinations? Mr. Califano's statement that computers make the job simple reflects naivete about the complexity of the task at hand. Judging and quantifying complicated clinical information is not something that can be performed over the weekend on an I.B.M. PC Junior.

title: Tips on Maintaining Co-ops and Condos
description: The following recommendations for maintaining cooperatives and condominiums were made by Dick Koral, director of the Apartment House Institute, a branch of the City University of New York.

title: Yucatan
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Roughing It in Style in Mexico'' by Elizabeth Benedict (Travel, March 6): For those who are not ready to spend an entire vacation in a thatch-roof palapa in the Yucatan Peninsula, a limited experience in one is possible.

title: Congressional Report Casts Doubt On Feasibility of Anti-Missile Plan
description: The feasibility of an anti-missile defense system based in space remains in doubt because of serious unresolved technical problems in the five-year old Strategic Defense Initiative program, according to a study by a Congressional research office.

title: Settling the Score
description: AN ORCHESTRAL PERFORMANCE IS the result of hours of rehearsal preceded by a month or a lifetime of preparation.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Celebrating Change And Tradition
description: ''WE WERE stuck on many a muddy road, searching out self-taught craftsmen who had taken to the woods,'' recalled Betty Turino, director of the America House Gallery in Tenafly.

title: Jill Buttenwieser Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Jill Ann Buttenwieser to Richard Perry Schloss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Schloss of New York and Holmdel, N.J., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence B. Buttenwieser of New York and North Salem, N.Y.

title: Shultz Plays Down Gorbachev Criticism of Reagan
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz today sought to minimize the significance of charges by the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, that President Reagan is jeopardizing improvements in Soviet-American relations.

title: 'Chess' Seeks To Shed Its Checkered Past
description: TIM RICE, THE LYRICIST AND mastermind behind ''Chess,'' has a nickname for the spectacle that will be unveiled this Thursday at the Imperial Theater. He calls the $6 million show, which originated as a record album in 1984 and has had one of the longest, most troubled histories of any musical to reach Broadway, ''Chess II.''

title: Japanese Farmers Hold Angry Rally Against U.S. Trade Demands
description: Farmers smashed and burned an American car, set fire to boxes of American oranges and burned a United States flag today in a rally to protest American demands that Japan end restrictions on imported beef and oranges.

title: After Taking the Oath of Secrecy, It's Magic on a Smaller Scale
description: ONSTAGE at parties, weddings and special events, the magician Sandini -otherwise known as Michael J. Piacente of Yonkers - is a master of the dramatic effect. Doves materialize at his command, and the straps and clasps of straitjackets mysteriously give way.

title: Nynex Research Center Opens in Harrison
description: LEAD: ''E.T.,'' Stephen Spielberg's popular movie alien, might have had a better chance to ''phone home'' had he had access to the Nynex Corporation's new Science and Technology Center, which opened last week in Harrison.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: QE2, Needing New Propellers, Cancels Trips

title: What the Poor Are Entitled To
description: Who's entitled to a helping hand from Washington? Liberals raised in the glow of the New Deal have long assumed that the best way to protect the poor was to guarantee benefits for all. The Democratic candidates echo this view.

title: Pop View; Out of Tune With the Times?
description: DOES LOVE OF MUSIC have a window of opportunity?

title: TALKING: Dockominiums; Navigating The Resale Market
description: DOCKOMINIUMS have been around the New York coastal region for about four years - enough time to gain acceptance in boating circles and to build a track record for gauging how this kind of investment behaves over the longer term.

title: New Jersey Guide
description: TRIBUTE TO RESISTANCE Pierre Sauvage, among the 5,000 Jews smuggled out of the French village of Le Chambon-sur-Lignon during the Nazi occupation, has made a film, ''Weapons of the Spirit,'' a tribute to the residents of that major way station in the Resistance's underground railway.

title:
INVESTING;
A Top Fund Manager's Formula
description: LEAD: EVEN though the stocks of small-capitalized companies have been beating the blue chips by an enormous margin since December, Neil T. Eigen of Integrated Resources Asset Management is not convinced that small stocks are the next market leaders.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The nearly flat roof on my ranch house has no provision for ventilation. Roofers have told me the lack of air circulation makes rot a strong possibility. I have been able to look inside this confined roof space but have seen nothing unusual. I am about to have a new roof installed and want to know what to do about this problem, or even if there is a problem. I am thinking about opening vent holes in the soffits and screening these to keep out insects. However, I don't think these will help much because the space between the roof and the ceiling is filled with fiberglass insulation. What do you think?

title: A Town Pays a Price for Indifference
description: NESTLED in the rolling hills of southwestern Connecticut, the town of Southbury fans out like the wings of a butterfly along the banks of the Pomperaug River. The setting is peaceful and bucolic. Sprawling red barns dot the landscape and silos soar up among the white, New England church spires that seem to touch the sky.

title: Including Labor in the Division of Capital
description: ''If we want this private property system of ours to succeed,'' Senator Russell B. Long of Louisiana warned a few years ago, ''we simply must insure that as many Americans as possible have an opportunity to earn an ownership stake.''

title: Faulty Cable Linked to Electrocution Death
description: A faulty underground cable was responsible for the electrocution death of a student wading in a campus pond this week, officials of the State University of New York said today.

title: Pancho Villa's Right-Hand Man
description: To the Editor:

title: Budd Is Resolute
description: BECAUSE she appeared at a cross-country meet in her native South Africa, Zola Budd faces an international ban, and the British Amateur Athletic Board, for which she competes, faces a dilemma at a hearing in London today. If Budd is not banned by the board, the British team could be banned from international competition for 12 months and miss the Olympics.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Japanese Arrival in Mt. Kisco
description: LEAD: TO the delight of residents of northern Westchester, Japanese restaurants have been moving, albeit all too slowly, to higher, sushi-starved latitudes. Mount Kisco is the locale of the newcomer Toku, a restaurant and sushi bar.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Riff for Typewriter Not all modern novelists are minimalists -certainly not Leon Forrest, who mixes gospel, jazz and mandarin rhythms in ''There Is a Tree More Ancient Than Eden'' (Another Chicago Press).

title: Car Bomb Kills 60 In North Lebanon; 125 Are Wounded
description: A car bomb exploded in a crowded vegetable market in Tripoli in northern Lebanon today, killing 60 people and wounding 125.

title: FOCUS: Chattanooga; A New Look Plus Jobs on The River
description: LIKE many urban areas, this sprawling city in southeastern Tennessee is developing condominiums, shops and parks on its waterfront.

title:
NORTHEST NOTEBOOK: Bloomsburg, Pa.;
Dissipating a Mall's Shadow
description: LEAD: WHEN the 64-store Columbia Mall opens two miles north of here next fall, its developer hopes to draw shoppers from a population of about 120,000 in rural northeastern Pennsylvania that does not have easy access to a large shopping center.

title: COAST TO COAST ON 57th STREET
description: ''And that,'' said my cicerone, ''is Dan Rather's chair, the chair Mr. Rather sits in for ''The CBS Evening News With Dan Rather.''

title: Legislative Campaign Spending Must Be Controlled
description: IN THE early 1970's, New York radio and television reporters occasionally amused themselves, and perhaps their listening and viewing addiences, by translating New Jersey political news into sporting terms.

title: Muslim Patrols Fight Capital Drug Trade
description: To some who live here, what happened this week at the Mayfair Mansions housing project at first seemed a shocking exercise in vigilante justice.

title: New Haven Symphony Picks a New Conductor
description: AFTER a two-and-a-half year search involving 275 candidates, the New Haven Symphony has named Michael Palmer to succeed Murry Sidlin as music director.

title: Homeless Projects: Setbacks and Optimism
description: THREE months ago, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke and a nonprofit agency headed by Andrew M. Cuomo, the Governor's son, announced plans to build four housing projects for the homeless under an arrangement that they said they hoped would neutralize any local criticism.

title: Mavin Martin Weds Robert H. Johnson, an Editor
description: Calvary Episcopal Church in Louisville, Ky., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Mary Vincent Hamilton Martin, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Boyce Ficklen Martin Jr. of Louisville, to Robert Harle Johnson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Johnson of Morristown, Tenn. The Rev. Robin Jennings performed the ceremony.

title: Traditions At Parade Of Sikhs
description: As the rain fell on a large model of the Golden Temple, the central shrine of the Sikhs in India, crowds of turbaned marchers stepped off yesterday for the first-ever Sikh Day Parade.

title: N.F.L. Draft '88; Giants Want A Tackle . . .
description: THE Giants' first-round choice in today's National Football League draft will probably be an offensive tackle or a running back.

title: IN LATIN AMERICA, NORIEGA IS A PRINCIPLE
description: Seen more as a whim of American power than as a new commitment to democracy in the hemisphere, the Reagan Administration's campaign to unseat Panama's military leader has been received with a mixture of resentment and resignation by the rest of Latin America. No one is willing to recognize Washington's right to meddle in the domestic affairs of countries of the region, but no one seems able to stop it from happening.

title: Clash in Chicago Over City Seal
description: IT WAS described last year as a hot issue in Chicago: Was the 150-year-old municipal seal - which graces everything from city stationery to dump trucks - racist?

title: Three More Bodies Are Found In Rubble of Grain Elevator
description: Workers pulled three bodies today from the rubble of a grain elevator complex that was leveled by two explosions Friday, the police said, raising the death toll to five.

title: Television; The Shot Heard Round the World is Fired Anew
description: BACK AROUND 1950, HOWARD Fast spent three months in prison for refusing to give the House Un-American Activities Committee the names of contributors to an organization deemed subversive by the Attorney General. Although he had already published extensively, including the popular novels ''Freedom Road'' and ''Citizen Tom Paine,'' Mr. Fast found himself blacklisted for much of the ensuing decade. He publicly severed his ties with the Communist Party in 1957, though, unlike others who had followed the light that failed, he did not embrace any conservative movement. He later described himself as ''politically an iconoclast, a radical, in formal terms, an absolute pacifist.''

title: Driven Away From Baseball
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article in The Times Magazine on April 10 about Abel Aganbegyan, Mikhail Gorbachev's economic adviser, misstated the price set by the Russians for a metric ton of oil for military use. The price is 21 rubles, which, at the official rate of $1.67 per ruble, is the equivalent of $35.

title: Puerto Vallarta
description: To the Editor: In ''What's Doing in Puerto Vallarta'' (Travel, Feb. 14) reference was made to a sewage treatment plant whose ''excess sewage often overflows into the bay'' without warning. That is but one of the hazards of a vacation in this resort.

title: EXPERIENCE WINS, BUT NOT TOTALLY, OVER YOUTH
description: IT might be expected that experience would triumph over youth in match play, and that is what happened generally in the preliminary world championship candidates matches in Saint John, New Brunswick. Yet in the seven contests the more mature players did not achieve a shutout but had to yield two victories to younger adversaries.

title: Pianist Comes Home
description: THE pianist William Wolfram stretched out his long legs under a luncheon table and sighed with relief. A sleepless cross-country night flight was several days behind him and he was beginning to unwind during a brief hiatus in his performance schedule.

title: Schoolgirl Has No Illusions
description: The shorts are baggy, which is to be expected of those issued for Olympic trials. She wears low-cut black sneakers, an old-fashioned look in the era of Air Jordan. She has a pale complexion and her medium-length blonde hair is cropped short in front, to keep it out of her eyes. In the gymnasiums and playgrounds of Indianapolis, her appearance and passion for basketball has earned Vicki Hall the nickname Lady Bird, the female version of Indiana's favorite son, who plays for the Boston Celtics.

title: The Milliners' Tale
description: ''THE BRITISH ARE GREAT AT THINGS LIKE breakfast and Rolls-Royces,'' says David Shilling. ''And hatmaking.'' Not surprisingly, Shilling is a British hatmaker. ''Designer, actually,'' he says. In business for 11 years, he's been something of a brash, millinery presence since 1965, when, at the age of 12, he designed an enormous hat of black and white tulle for his mother to wear to the races at Royal Ascot. She has returned to the scene annually in a David Shilling original. ''By now she's known as 'the Ascot Mascot,' '' Shilling says. In general, his clients, ''are from all over the world and from all walks of life,'' though he allows that some of them are among ''the most beautiful and wealthiest women in the world.''

title: French Seem to Fail In Talks in Lebanon On Freeing Hostages
description: A French delegation seeking to negotiate the freedom of three French hostages kidnapped by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslems returned home today after its mission apparently ended in failure.

title: County Chamber Celebrating Its 75th
description: BEFORE there was a republic, there was a Chamber of Commerce. The chamber of commerce movement in America dates to 1768, when the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, representing the businessmen of New York City, was founded. Since then various types of chambers of commerce - neighborhood, city, regional, state and national - have been organized, including the County Chamber of Commerce in Westchester, which celebrates its 75th birthday this year.

title: Headmaster Retires From Browning
description: When Charles W. Cook was named headmaster of the Browning School in 1952, he was the youngest person in New York City holding such a post.

title: When Mud Season Arrives, Life Bogs Down
description: While most states struggle along with just four seasons, Vermont enjoys six: spring, summer, fall, winter, more winter and mud.

title: Sydney's Quirky Village, Paddington
description: SYDNEY'S neighborhood of Paddington has always celebrated bohemia in Down Under style. Its 400 acres of sturdy Victorian terrace houses are festooned with a quirky overlay of lighthearted colonial, wrought-iron balconies and gray-green eucalyptus trees. And, like Greenwich Village in New York or the French Quarter in New Orleans, Paddington preserves a village ambiance with local institutions and colorful personalities that confound the bulldozer of progress. In Paddington this translates into a very Australian disrespect for authority or even prudence.

title: Let Shadow Cabinets Join in the Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Jennifer Freeman To Marry in June
description: Jennifer Beth Freeman and Walker Stevenson, a son of James Stevenson of Guilford, Conn., and the late Jane Walker Stevenson, plan to marry in June, the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. John M. Freeman of Ruxton, Md., have announced.

title: Penn Crew Wins Cup
description: Penn's heavyweight varsity crew posted its first victory of the season to retain the Blackwell Cup, defeating Yale and Columbia on the Harlem River yesterday. Penn, without a victory in its previous two regattas, withstood a strong challenge from Yale to win in the fast, current-aided time of 5 minutes 34 seconds.

title: A DELIGHTFUL ANENOME FROM GREECE
description: FINISH pruning overgrown forsythia; cut thick old branches to near ground level to rejuvenate shrubs. Last call to start melon seed indoors. Use dormant sprays to control insect eggs on twigs and branches. Keep seeded lawn bare patches moist to hasten germination. Anemones

title: Our Muscle-Bound Navy
description: THE NOISY RESIGNATION of Navy Secretary James H. Webb Jr., on Feb. 22, throws into sharp relief the growing controversy over the expensive naval buildup launched by the Reagan Administration. With its stated objective of deploying a ''600-ship'' Navy by 1989, the buildup represents, in the words of former Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, the Reagan Administration's ''most significant force expansion.'' Under the leadership of Weinberger and Webb's hard-sell predecessor, John F. Lehman Jr., the Navy has come to enjoy the biggest budget of any of the military services.

title: Defying Curfew, Palestinians Hold Protests
description: Israeli troops maintained a curfew today on 400,000 Arabs in the occupied territories during a ''Day of Anger'' ordered by Palestinian leaders. But some protests took place, and in one of them an Israeli police officer shot and killed a Palestinian man who reportedly attacked the officer with an ax.

title: About the Arts/NEW YORK; At Yale, Images of Pope: A Classical Poet With Tragedy At His Very Core
description: ALEXANDER POPE WAS born 300 years next month, on May 21, 1688. A hundred years later, when he had already been in his grave for 44 years, he was still a dominant literary force, his immense reputation seemingly secure. But the tide was about to turn, and 100 years further on, the prevailing view was that he had scarcely been a poet at all. A classic, yes - every educated person could quote at least a few of his lines; but in Matthew Arnold's phrase, ''a classic of our prose.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CLOUDS OF SECRECY: The Army's Germ Warfare Tests Over Populated Areas. By Leonard A. Cole. (Rowman & Littlefield, $21.50.) From slow-moving ships offshore, the United States Army blanketed San Francisco with over 700 trillion organisms of a supposedly benign strain of bacteria in 1950 as part of its secret ''vulnerability testing'' program of biological warfare techniques.

title: HE HAD A BETTER IDEA
description: THE SUICIDAL CORPORATION By Paul H. Weaver. 270 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE OFFICE OF EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES;
A World of Ambulances and Seconds
description: LEAD: NO sirens wail in Ted Tully's office in the basement of Cedarwood Hall at the County Medical Center here. He starts no intravenous lines, applies no splints, brings no heart-attack victims back from the edge of death.

title: The Monte Carlo Orchestra Plays Roussel and Dukas
description: It is not particularly the fault of Lawrence Foster and his Monte Carlo Philharmonic Orchestra that their Carnegie Hall concert Sunday afternoon prompted thoughts less about the specifics of the program at hand than about the international symphonic scene. The playing was good: very good indeed in the hushed, well-sustained slow movement of Dukas's Symphony in C; more than adequate everywhere else. The character of the shifting sections in Roussel's ''Bacchus et Ariane'' (the second suite) was reflected to a reasonable degree. Enjoyable energy was marshaled for the endings of both works.

title: What Are The Jets' And Giants' Draft Needs?
description: What the Giants need is a blue-chip player regardless of their needs to fill holes at offensive tackle and in the defensive backfield. With the 10th overall pick on the first round they have an excellent chance to obtain such a player. MICHAEL GIVANT Jamaica, Queens

title: THE MIGHTY FATHER
description: LEAD: FREUD A Life for Our Time. By Peter Gay. Illustrated. 810 pp. New York: W. W. Norton. $25.

title: Smoking Becomes 'Deviant Behavior'
description: It was cause for a libel award when a Chicago television commentator said in 1981 that the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation was trying to snare teen-agers with advertisements relating smoking to drugs, alcohol and sex. The idea, the commentator had said, was to present cigarettes as ''an illicit pleasure.''

title: Six Artists Explore 'A Sense of Space'
description: IN its current brochure, the Rye Arts Center celebrates its reopening in a newly renovated house at 51 Milton Road. It also lists the available courses, which include fine arts, photography, crafts, music and drama - not to mention such specialties as knitting, and painting ''for those who think they can't.''

title: Winning Scholars Head for Big Test
description: LEAD: ASK ANY high school student what he or she likes least about school and chances are that taking tests would top the list. Yet more than 800 students in New Jersey voluntarily took 10 challenging tests for fun.

title: Giving the Proper Credit for Child Care
description: WORKING mothers get a lot of credit. (And a lot of blame, but that's a different discussion.) Not that we don't deserve it: whatever the ages of our children, whatever the nature of the work, whatever the reasons behind a mother's decision to leave her child for part or most of the day, it's never easy.

title: AVIATION ACE: Ernest H. Boullioun; Roaring Out of Retirement
description: THE sign on the door says ''Boullioun Aviation Services/Sumishin Leasing.'' Inside are brand-new quarters - so new the furniture is still arriving. And behind the desk in the executive office, surrounded by model planes and framed by a sweeping view of Lake Washington, sits Ernest H. ''Tex'' Boullioun, retired president of the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company.

title: VDT Bill Splits Labor and Business
description: LONG ISLAND business leaders seem unanimously against it.

title: House Panel Reports Abuse and Conflicts At a Federal Agency
description: Officials of a Federal agency that was created to sell property from insolvent savings institutions traveled in high style and awarded no-bid contracts to former business associates, all while receiving six-figure salaries and bonuses, the House Banking Committee has charged.

title: Improvements: Cease and Desist
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''When the special interests on both sides are unhappy, I know we did something right.'' - Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, on the trade bill.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Harley-Davidson Inc. misidentified the motorcycle ridden by Marlon Brando in ''The Wild One.'' It was a Triumph.

title: Pirates Rally in the 8th To Defeat the Cubs, 5-4
description: Mike LaValliere's two-run single in the eighth inning gave Pittsburgh a 5-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs today. It was the Pirates' 10th victory in their last 12 games.

title: Storytellers Enthrall Students with Yarns and Stir Creativity
description: LEAD: IT was an eerie tale about a hitchhiking ghost who still haunted the dimly lighted street where she had died years before, and it was being told by a professional storyteller to a group of junior high school students.

title: What Are The Jets' And Giants' Draft Needs?
description: The Jets should draft a new coach. PHIL LANE Montclair, N.J.

title:
DINING OUT;
Fancy French Fare in Fairfield
description: LEAD: NOW YOU see them and now you don't.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: APRIL 24, 1988
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 7 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 2 1 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. Warner, $4.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 3 4 THE LADIES OF MISSALONGHI, by Colleen McCullough. (Avon, $3.95.) An Australian town where men dominate but women rule. 4 5 WATCHERS, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $4.95.) Two creatures emerge from a secret laboratory. 5 5 BOLT, by Dick Francis. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A star jockey contends with an arms-selling intrigue. 6 7 OVER THE EDGE, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) A psychologist-detective solves a string of vicious murders. 7 4 VOWS, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Jove, $4.50.) A feisty young woman in a 19th-century Wyoming town. 8 3 OUT OF PHAZE, by Piers Anthony. (Ace, $3.95.) Volume Four of a fantasy series. 9 * 12 DESTINY, by Sally Beauman. (Bantam, $4.95.) A couple's 30-year romance. 10 21 THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Bantam, $4.95.) Complex family relationships in South Carolina's low country and New York City. 11 2 SOMETHING WONDERFUL, by Judith McNaught. (Pocket, $3.95.) A country girl's dazzling life in Georgian London. 12 * 3 TIME FOR YESTERDAY, by A. C. Crispin. (Pocket, $3.95.) A new ''Star Trek'' novel. 13 7 TEXASVILLE, by Larry McMurtry. (Pocket, $4.95.) A sequel to ''The Last Picture Show.'' 14 * 2 STINGER, by Robert R. McCammon. (Pocket, $4.95.) A Texas town besieged by an evil force. 15 3 THE UNBEARABLE LIGHTNESS OF BEING, by Milan Kundera. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) A story of two Czechoslovak couples. 16 * 1 PATTERN CRIMES, by William Bayer. (Signet/ NAL, $4.95.) Tracking down the perpetrator of three murders in Jerusalem. 17 * 3 NO DEALS, MR. BOND, by John Gardner. (Charter, $4.50.) James Bond returns to solve a case of amazingly similar ritual killings. The actress's memories and opinions. 4 9 THE FATAL SHORE, by Robert Hughes. (Vintage, $10.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author says, and we must confront them to grow. 6 3 CLOSE PURSUIT, by Carsten Stroud. (Bantam, $4.50.) A week in the life of Eddie Kennedy, member of a New York City homicide squad. 7 77 WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Beryl Markham. (North Point, $12.50.) Hay. (Hay House, $10.) A counselor's prescription for regaining one's confidence and self-esteem. 3 * 46 CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $6.95.) Cartoons. 4 * 13 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1988 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. 5 * 82 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin Norwood. (Pocket, $4.95.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 6 * 48 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) Latest edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 retail outlets, including newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets and bookstores. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets acrossthe United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Express Bus Service to Stamford Proposed
description: A bus company based in Milford has joined with a nonprofit Stamford organization to propose an express commuter-bus service to Stamford, the workday destination of 50,000 commuters.

title: A CITY IN GREEN
description: Henry Adams in his ''Education'' wrote that the contrast of the seasons gave life itsrelative values; he associated winter with town (Boston) and summer with country (Quincy). ''Town was winter confinement, school, rule, straight gloomy streets, piled with six feet of snow in the middle.'' It was ''restraint, law, unity.'' But Quincy, only seven miles away, was ''liberty, diversity, outlawry, the endless delight of mere sense impressions given by nature for nothing, and breathed by boys without knowing it.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: WIND STAR: The Building of a Sailship. By Joseph Novitski. (Macmillan, $19.95.) Joseph Novitski, a sailor and an author, has tackled a fascinating subject with intelligence and skill, documenting the conception, design and construction of Wind Star, a brand-new passenger sailing ship. The entrepreneur Karl Andren's dream was challenging: Wind Star had to provide 150 passengers on a diesel-electric motor sailer with competitive cruising luxury.

title: A. Atwater Kent Jr.; Investor, 79
description: A. Atwater Kent Jr., son of the radio manufacturer, died of leukemia April 16 at St. Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 79 years old and lived in Palm Beach; Newtown Square, Pa.; and Northeast Harbor, Me.

title: Moratorium on Higher-Life-Form Patents
description: To the Editor:

title: Debunking An Old Myth
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE WRONG SIDE OF KATYDID, ILL.
description: LEAD: MARTHA CALHOUN By Richard Babcock. 310 pp. New York: Random House. $15.95.

title: Daedalus Flies From Myth Into Reality
description: Like a giant dragonfly out of myth, a fragile ultralight plane with a Greek cycling champion at its pedal controls skimmed 74 miles over a choppy Aegean Sea yesterday to establish three new world records for human-powered flight.

title: MISCONCEPTIONS MADE EASY
description: FRUIT OF THE MONTH By Abby Frucht. 167 pp. Iowa City: University of Iowa Press. $15.95. SNAP By Abby Frucht. 339 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $17.95.

title:
ART;
Abstracts of Urban and Rural Landscapes in New Haven
description: LEAD: ''THE LANDSCAPE,'' a northeastern states competition juried by the noted landscape painter Wolf Kahn at the Creative Arts Workshop in New Haven, is a complement to the portrait competition juried by the figurative painter Phillip Pearlstein last year.

title: PICNICS TO GO
description: Despite the constraints of the urban landscape, New Yorkers love a picnic. We jump at the chance to eat outdoors - at sporting events, concerts and shows in the parks, or a garden outing. And stocking the picnic basket is now almost as easy as buying hot dogs from an umbrella cart. Restaurants, carry-out shops and caterers have organized picnic menus, complete three- or four-course meals, assembled and ready to go.

title: Dance View
description: EVERY SO OFTEN A NOTABLE young choreographic talent creeps up on the ballet world, diligently producing imaginative, even excellent work that is perhaps more appreciated abroad than at home. Along the way, he or she develops what looks like a confirmed signature, and yet the evidence is that, like any true creative spirit, this choreographer is still in a stage of continuing development.

title: Jackson Nudging Democrats to Left
description: Others have fallen by the side of the campaign trail, but the Rev. Jesse Jackson runs on in a campaign that is increasingly aimed at moving the party and its likely nominee, Michael S. Dukakis, to the left.

title: Winning Makes Devils Easy to Love
description: With rueful smiles, the group has come to call itself the Original 13. They first met one evening in 1982. For the most part, they were young and idealistic, although admittedly somewhat apprehensive about the future of their union. In time, a constitution was drafted and bylaws were adopted.

title: Polly Roberts Married To Rexford Hall Swain
description: Mary Jaques Roberts and Rexford Hall Swain were married yesterday at the Myopia Hunt Club in Hamilton, Mass. Judge George N. Hurd Jr. of State Superior Court officiated.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about Jesse Jackson's campaign in Buffalo incorrectly reported the site of a rally. It was at the Kleinhans Music Hall.

title: Does Albany's Fight to a Draw On Budget Portend Summer Standoffs?
description: After a long and largely fruitless battle, New York state legislators last week approved a $28.4 billion budget that was essentially the same as the one they had been on the verge of passing before the deadline three weeks earlier. The only difference was that after 20 days of debate, the Legislature had given up trying to reach agreements on the issues that had been holding them up.

title: Japan Talks Trade While America Sleeps
description: RECENTLY the United States Government triumphantly announced that it had solved a major trade dispute with Japan. After years of negotiations, an accord was reached under which American construction companies will be allowed to bid on designated public works projects in Japan.

title: THE HEALTH-CARE CHAOS
description: I would like to suggest that a system like ours, which relies so heavily on highly trained physicians, will never be cost effective, nor will it meet the demands of our neediest citizens.

title: Reflections on a Stagestruck Life
description: LEAD: IN a career that spanned more than 60 years, Maria Gambarelli did it all: starred as the premiere danseuse of the Metropolitan Opera; headlined the bills that opened the Capital and Roxy Theaters and Radio City Music Hall in New York; made movies with Gary Cooper and Gene Raymond; sang on one of the first weekly radio shows; toured the major concert halls of the world, several times dancing before royalty in command performances, and, after she stopped dancing at the age of 54, even appeared in television commercials.

title: In Spring, Let There Be Polka Dots!
description: IT'S often the little things in fashion that can make a big difference. Take navy-and-white polka dots, for instance, as a lot of people are. This spring dots are leaving their imprint in a number of ways, some of them quite subtle.

title: Defending School Aid for L.I.
description: LEAD: HOW much is Long Island property worth and what should it mean for aid to public schools? Governor Cuomo, a Democrat, and the leadership of the State Assembly and State Senate could not seem to agree.

title: Hartford Series on Iran Aims at Misconceptions
description: A program focusing on Iran will run in Hartford this week, and its organizers hope that it will dispel many incorrect stereotypes among Americans.

title:
ART;
More Than Meets the Eye: Levels of Space and Form
description: LEAD: DESPITE the fame achieved by art-world superstars whose work commands high prices, most artists rely on alternative employment to keep the wolf from the door. Some teach; others do carpentry, house painting or any number of other jobs to support themselves and their families while they pursue the work they consider their primary occupation regardless of its lack of financial reward.

title: What Are The Jets' And Giants' Draft Needs?
description: As a Jets season-ticket holder, I am tired of going to games and seeing Ken O'Brien sprawled out, so I suggest that they draft Paul Gruber, Dave Cadigan or Gerald Perry to protect him.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Lendl and Jaite in Final: Ivan Lendl and Martin Jaite advanced to the final of the $492,500 Monte Carlo Open in Monaco with victories over two Frenchmen yesterday. Lendl, the world's No. 1 player since 1985, is returning to the circuit after a two-month layoff. He gained his first final of the year with a 4-6, 7-6, 6-3 victory over fourth-seeded Yannick Noah. Jaite, an Argentine who was seeded seventh, beat Thierry Tulasne, 6-4, 6-2. Lendl was sidelined in February with a stress fracture in his right foot.(AP) Navratilova-Evert Final: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova won a battle of second-set service breaks with Elly Hakami of Tiburon, Calif., yesterday for a 6-1, 6-3 victory in the semifinals of the $250,000 Virginia Slims of Houston tournament. In today's final, Navratilova will play second-seeded Chris Evert, who defeated fourth-seeded Zina Garrison, 7-5, 6-2. (AP) Connors Coasts: Jimmy Connors needed just an hour to beat Mel Purcell, 6-3, 6-3, yesterday and advance to today's final in the Bank of Oklahoma Classic in Tulsa. Scott Davis earned his second victory in the round-robin tournament by defeating Robert Seguso, 6-2, 7-6.(AP) Soccer Liverpool Clinches Title: Liverpool clinched the English League First Division title yesterday, beating Tottenham Hotspur, 1-0. Peter Beardsley scored the only goal of the First Division match, in the 31st minute. The victory enabled Liverpool, which had led the standing since mid-November, to gain its 17th title and its ninth in the last 13 years. Liverpool has 84 points in 36 games, and the runner-up, Manchester United, which was idle yesterday, has 69 in 36.(AP) Golf Beck Moves in Front: Chip Beck shot a bogey-free 65 yesterday and took a three-stroke lead over Lanny Wadkins after the third round of the $750,000 USF&G Classic in New Orleans. Beck came from one shot off the pace with his seven-under-par round. He was at 18-under 198. Wadkins shot a 69. Greg Ladehoff shot a four-under 68 and moved into third place at 204. (AP) United States in Lead: Al Geiberger and Gene Littler birdied the last two holes to win their match by one stroke yesterday and help the United States maintain its lead over an international team in the Chrysler Cup. The U.S. squad will take a 40-20 lead into today's conclusion of the four-day Senior PGA Tour event at the Tournament Players Club at Prestancia, Sarasota, Fla.(AP) Jones Ahead by a Stroke: Rose Jones shot a three-under-par 69 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead in the $225,000 USX Classic at the Pasadena Yacht and Country Club in Gulfport, Fla. (AP) Boxing Title to Brown: Simon Brown of Jamaica stopped Tyrone Trice of the United States in the 14th round last night to win the vacant International Boxing Federation welterweight title in Berck, France, yesterday. The victory was Brown's 25th in 26 fights. Trice's record is 27-2.(AP) Track and Field 2 Take 2 Golds Each: Vincenzo Insingo of Monsignor Farrell of Staten Island and Nikki Inglis of Bishop Ford of Brooklyn were double gold-medal winners yesterday in the Redmen Invitational high school meet at St. John's. Insingo won the shot-put at 56 feet, then threw the discus 165 feet 6 inches. Inglis won the women's 100-meter high hurdles in 16.7 seconds and the 400-meter intermediate hurdles in 1:15.2. 2 Firsts for Clinton Senior: Ron Guialdo, a DeWitt Clinton senior, captured two first places yesterday at the 10th annual Mobil Big Apple Relays for public high schools at Midwood Field, Brooklyn. Guialdo teamed with Gary Wright to win the 800-meter intermediate hurdles in a meet record time of 1 minute 51.7 seconds. He later finished first in the 110-meter high hurdles in 15.6 seconds. Tilden had three winners in the girls' division. The Brooklyn school won the sprint medley in 4:18.2, the 1,600-meter relay in 3:56.9 and the team shot-put at 69-6 1/2. Gymnastics Soviet Women Dominate: Svetlana Boguinskaya, the all-round champion, led a near sweep by the Soviet Union yesterday in the women's gymnastics competition with the United States at the McDonald's Challenge meet in Phoenix. Six of the top seven finishers in the women's all-round event were Soviet athletes, with Boguinskaya and Olga Strazheva, both 15 years old, leading the way. Sabrina Mar of the United States tied the former world champion, Oksana Omelianchik, for third place. (AP)

title: Ms. Reiner to Wed Geoffrey Greener
description: Melissa Jill Reiner and Geoffrey Stephen Greener, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Greener of Hollywood, Fla., plan to marry in August, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Reiner of New York and Middletown, N.J., have announced.

title: John S. Radosta, 74, Sportswriter And an Editor at Times, Is Dead
description: John S. Radosta, who spent 38 years with The New York Times as a photo editor and reporter, died of lung cancer yesterday at the Cabrini Hospice in Manhattan. Mr. Radosta, who retired from The Times in 1983, was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Blazing New Trails for Hiking the Wilds of Suffolk
description: LEAD: Armed with an ironwood walking stick in his left hand and a pair of gardening purners in his right hand, Kim Darrow of Dix Hills led six trailblazers through patches of heavy brush and woods ona recent Sunday.

title:
GARDENING;
How to Minimize Pests and Diseases
description: LEAD: DEDICATED gardeners take pride in producing perfect flowers, fruits and vegetables in their garden. In this imperfect world, however, gardeners must do battle with legions of diseases and insect pests that seem bent on cheating them out of success. Plants are disfigured and even killed by these maurauders.

title: Charges of Misconduct Denied in Mob Trial
description: A prosecutor has ridiculed defense arguments that the Government ''framed'' defendants in the Manhattan trial of Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno and 10 others charged with racketeering.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Texas Developer Thinks Big on Rentals
description: A TEXAS development company is providing something that is in great demand but short supply in Connecticut - sensibly priced apartments for rent. The company, Trammell Crow of Dallas, the nation's largest developer with assets of $13 billion, recently set up a regional office in New Canaan from which it is directing the construction of about 3,000 apartments, some already built and occupied, some under way and others on the drawing board.

title: Norwalk Police Officers Like the Classroom Beat
description: WHEN Norwalk Police Officer Carleton Giles walks into a high school classroom he's not looking for trouble and he's not visiting -he's there to teach.

title: WORK AND LOVE: REVOLUTION AND AFTER
description: LEAD: IN THE AGE OF THE SMART MACHINE The Future of Work and Power. By Shoshana Zuboff. Illustrated. 468 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: Watch Out for the Market Data Glut
description: CAN too much of a good thing be bad? Absolutely - as marketing executives are finding out. The amount of data available to them is increasing at a pace that will defy their capacity to assimilate it. And over the next decade, the data directed at a typical brand manager at a packaged goods company could jump from several hundred thousand new numbers a month to billions a day.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: DEAF DANCERS Changing attitudes toward deaf performers are opening new doors for deaf dancers. A two-year-old group called The American Dance Theater of the Deaf will perform ballet, jazz, modern dance and dance containing sign language at 7:30 P.M. Saturday in the Performing Arts Center of Lehman College in the Bronx. The company has performed in Manhattan at Alice Tully Hall in Lincoln Center.

title: Katharine O'Brien to Wed R. L. Rohn
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donal Clare O'Brien Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Katharine Louise O'Brien to Robert Lawrence Rohn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Wesley Rohn of Naples, Fla., and Litchfield, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: What Are The Jets' And Giants' Draft Needs?
description: Who is going to block Dexter Manley? The Giants need another Brad Benson. Without him the Giants don't have a chance. The Jets need a whole new team. They need running backs, an offensive line, defensive line and a quarterback. O'Brien can't play a whole season. BARRY BERKO Brooklyn

Isaac, Not Abraham
