description: Mr. and Mrs. James Francis McDonnell Jr. of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and Southampton, L.I., have announced that their daughter Amy Frances McDonnell is to be married May 21 to Edwin Robeson MacKethan 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. MacKethan 3d of Grosse Pointe.

title: R. H. Swindell 3d Is Wed in Jersey To Miss O'Herron
description: The wedding of Elizabeth Coughlin O'Herron, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. O'Herron of Westfield, N.J., and Peru, Vt., to Robert Haldane Swindell 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Swindell Jr. of Baltimore and Damariscotta, Me., took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. James in Basking Ridge, N.J. Msgr. William J. Capik performed the ceremony.

title: KOREAN ELECTION: ECHO OF DECEMBER
description: At 1:10 P.M. today, six local candidates for South Korea's National Assembly began to debate on the wind-swept soccer field of Kaepo Elementary School, in a middle-class Seoul neighborhood.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: Homelessness: A Need For 'Community' And Basic Comforts
description: TRAFFIC on the highway had slowed to a halt. My friend and I had hoped a quick trip into Manhattan would break the monotony of another gray, cold winter day. As I sat humming to the radio, a flash of light caught my eye from the opposite side of the road.

title: What Are The Jets' And Giants' Draft Needs?
description: The Jets need three linebackers, four defensive linemen, two tackles, a coach, a club president, and miracles.

GARDENING;
How to Minimize Pests and Diseases
description: LEAD: DEDICATED gardeners take pride in producing perfect flowers, fruits and vegetables in their garden. In this imperfect world, however, gardeners must do battle with legions of diseases and insect pests that seem bent on cheating them out of success. Plants are disfigured and even killed by these maurauders.

title: THE HIGH COST OF THINNESS
description: Ms. Henig's assertion that liposuction surgery ''most often requires an overnight hospital stay,'' is not supported by my own experience nor that of many other plastic surgeons. The statement that liposuction ''is far more traumatic than traditional body sculpting'' is false. Ms. Henig's comment that patient activity is limited for six weeks is not true. Almost all patients return to work in one week or less following surgery, and sports activities are limited for three weeks.

title: KNICKS EDGE INTO PLAYOFFS
description: The Knicks are going to the playoffs for the first time in four seasons. They qualified for the Eastern Conference's eighth and final berth tonight by defeating the Indiana Pacers, 88-86, at the Market Square Arena.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: STORIES: Five Acre Virgin and The Travelling Entertainer. By Elizabeth Jolley. (Viking, $17.95.) Reading Elizabeth Jolley is a bit like listening to your favorite grandmother, the one who is wise and funny and a little bit demented, the one who keeps track of all the cousins and can see all of human nature in a family reunion or a day at the beach. As with any good grandmother, Ms. Jolley's sympathies are always with the underdog - the lonely immigrant, the plain girl, the cleaning woman, the old man in the nursing home - and her wonderful characters often reappear, slightly altered, at different times and in different stories. Manipulated by clever landladies and selfish relatives, they nevertheless manage to survive and occasionally triumph. Ms. Jolley, an Australian, is perhaps best known in this country for a series of recent comic novels, including ''Miss Peabody's Inheritance'' and ''Foxybaby.'' ''Stories,'' a new volume of 21 tales, comprises her first two short-story collections (''Five Acre Virgin'' and ''The Travelling Entertainer''). They too are essentially comic, although there is an underlying sadness in them: things often turn out badly, particularly children. Australia puts in a major appearance; not the country but the very land itself - fertile, consoling and reliable in a way that people seldom are. A large part of Ms. Jolley's charm is her style, which is conversational, a bit faux naive, but as sharp and clear as a primitive painting. What is not grandmotherly is the precise literary intelligence and masterly technique Ms. Jolley brings to her work; she is an artist of the first order.

title: Of Snobs, Art and Price Tags

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 20 about subliminal messages misstated the annual sales of self-help subliminal tapes. The estimated figure is 2.5 million tapes.

title: Review/Music; PIANO VIRTUOSITY THAT CROSSES BOUNDARIES
description: Muhal Richard Abrams generally devotes his New York concerts to his work as a composer and jazz-ensemble leader. But on Wednesday at the Alternative Museum, he played solo piano improvisations that reaffirmed his category-crossing virtuosity.

title: Guerrillas Shell Ethiopian Port
description: Eritrean guerrillas shelled Ethiopia's largest port and its only oil refinery, diplomats and the official Government news agency said this weekend. Five people were reported killed and 15 wounded.

title: Takeover With a Twist
description: WHEN executives of the Koppers Corporation peer out their windows, they see a towering near-empty headquarters building, abandoned after the Gulf Oil Corporation was bought by the Chevron Corporation three years ago.

title: PERSPECTIVES: The M.C.I. Allowance; Attacking a Rental Upgrading Incentive
description: ''THE only way you can maintain rental property is to get the major capital improvement allowance,'' said Joseph Pistilli, whose Astoria-based company, the Pistilli Group, owns and manages older buildings in Queens and Brooklyn. ''It would be economic suicide if it were revoked.''

title: Reagan Disproves A Lame-Duck Myth
description: Some good news. In several important areas, the Administration is dispelling the myth that a President, especially a lame duck, cannot make foreign policy progress in an election year. Moreover, by offering President Reagan explicit or implicit support in those areas, the Democrats may be contributing to a selective bipartisanship that could serve the nation very well in the years ahead.

title: FROM RUSSIA WITH HOPE
description: SHORES OF REFUGE A Hundred Years of Jewish Emigration. By Ronald Sanders. Illustrated. 673 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $27.95.

title:
NORTHEST NOTEBOOK: Gaithersburg, Md.;
A Town Grows On Technology
description: LEAD: TRAMMELL Crow Company has begun leasing at its Chase Grove community, the residential component of Washingtonian Center, a 212-acre mixed-use development here. Eventually, it will offer 784 garden and mid-rise apartments.

title: CHANGING TIDES
description: On a mild afternoon I watch pretty little single-masted sailboat beat its way around the foot of Manhattan Island. Against the background of skyscraping towers, it looks absurdly delicate as it glides along, close to the wind. Between Governors Island and the Jersey piers a half-dozen more sailboats are racing over the gray water. On this particular Sunday, they appear to have the Upper Bay to themselves. Throughout its white-capped expanse, they're nearly the only craft afloat. The harbor is a stern prospect and on it the sailboats look not only delicate but also frivolous, like tourists on a silent battlefield. One might imagine that things had come full circle, from the doughty little sailing ships of Hudson and Verrazano to these, their lively descendents.

title: Recordings; Wanted: Lg. Space, Grt. Acoustics
description: WHEN ASKED WHERE HE would go to record a massive classical work - Mahler's ''Symphony of a Thousand,'' for instance, or a Wagner opera - provided he had to remain in New York City, the veteran producer Max Wilcox refused to play along. He laughed and replied, ''To London.'' Finally he said, all too seriously, ''There's only one place to go: the Manhattan Center,'' referring to the venerable building on 34th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.

title: For Dukakis Campaign, the Money Keeps Rolling In
description: When critics make much of the millions of dollars fueling his Presidential campaign, Michael S. Dukakis gets uncharacteristically ruffled. At least once, the normally deliberate Governor of Massachusetts is said to have snapped at his advisers, ''I don't want to be known as Governor Buckakis.'' But he finds that reputation hard to escape. Campaign aides say that his message and his leadership skills propelled Mr. Dukakis to front-runner status in the Democratic race. And that, they say, is reflected in his campaign's fund-raising success.

title: Oxford Versus Thatcher's England
description: ''OXFORD!'' CRIED THE CONDUCTOR. ''Oxford is next.'' I peered through the dirty window, hoping for a glimpse of the fabled spires, but all I saw were giant cranes looming against the sky. Down by the station, Oxford could have been any provincial English city in the midst of a boom. There was construction everywhere: car parks, concrete office blocks, a new shopping mall on Queen Street. The sidewalks were crowded with shoppers, the streets jammed with traffic. This is the face of England now: prosperous and ugly.

title: Giving Lean Beef A Better Image
description: THE best beef you can buy is fatty, according to grading established by the Federal Department of Agriculture. And that, health organizations have been saying for years, is not the best for your health.

title: Emelin's Many Facets
description: MENTION a season at Mamaroneck's Emelin Theater for the Performing Arts and what comes to mind? It could be the foreign films (on seven Fridays), the chamber music recitals (five Saturdays) or the prominent lecturers (four Wednesdays). Or perhaps ''Super Stuff for Kids,'' which includes 14 different shows on weekend mornings and afternoons.

title: The Crisis of Confidence in Options
description: IN recent days, a huge banner has been hanging on a wall near the trading pits of the Chicago Board Options Exchange. Marking the 15th anniversary Tuesday of the opening of the C.B.O.E., the world's biggest options market, the banner proclaims that ''The Best Is Yet to Come.'' But with the industry still reeling from the effects of Black Monday, the slogan may leave investors and professionals around the country wondering just when that might be.

title: Snacks Are Used to Promote Causes
description: PRINTED on the bright blue bag are facts about the earth, a picture of the earth and a plea to speak up on environmental issues. Inside the bag are cheese-flavored pasta chips, the latest product from Hampton Hill, a company with a conscience.

title: Teams Put Character At Top of Their Checklists
description: NATIONAL Football League teams still want to know how fast a player runs a 40-yard sprint, but their 53d draft of college players, starting at noon today at the Marriott Marquis in New York, will reflect an increase in research of athletes' character.

title: THE HEALTH-CARE CHAOS
description: Joseph Califano's article implied that the support of the American Association of Retired Persons for the prescription-drug benefit under Medicare's proposed catastrophic-health-insurance legislation is due to the ''substantial windfall'' for A.A.R.P.'s mail-service pharmacy. This is simply not true.

title: Dr. Garcia Plans A June Wedding
description: The engagement of Dr. Roxann Garcia, the daughter of Anita Garcia of Rutherford, N.J., and South Cairo, N.Y., and the late Anthony J. Garcia, to Dr. Miklos P. Salgo has been announced by the future bride's mother. Her fiance is the son of Nicolas M. Salgo of New York and Washington and Marika Salgo of New York and Naples, Fla.

title: What Are The Jets' And Giants' Draft Needs?
description: I've given up this kind of speculation after years of wondering why George Young drafted linebackers when we had so many good ones (L. T., Carl Banks, Gary Reasons, Pepper Johnson). Or why he chose a free safety (Terry Kinard) when we had other needs or a tight end (Mark Bavaro). It's been proven to me that the needs for both teams are the best players available. THOMAS P. DOHENY Langhorne, Pa.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE WORLD: Ambassador Grunwald's View; Kurt Waldheim and Austria's Embarrassment
description: Henry A. Grunwald, a Jew who was born in Vienna, fled Austria after the Nazis took power in 1940. He retired last year as editor in chief of Time Inc. and was appointed Ambassador to Austria by President Reagan. Following are excerpts of a speech he gave this month at the University of Minnesota on Austrian attitudes toward Jews and Austrian President Kurt Waldheim's World War II activities.

title: Peach Bottom
description: To the Editor:

title: Licensing for Fun and Profit - and Free Exposure
description: TWO decades ago Andy Warhol turned a soup can into a work of art, but corporate logos and trademarks were not valued in their own right by the public until about three years ago. Today consumers can't get enough Coca-Cola T-shirts and Spuds MacKenzie dolls, and corporations are turning to licensing specialists to supply the demand.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE MARTYR. By Jurgen Petschull. Translated by Stephen G. Cappellari. (Mercury House, $18.95.) On the jacket of ''The Martyr'' there is a description, meant to promote the book, that unintentionally reveals what's wrong with it: ''Reality is so deftly interwoven with fiction that it is a challenge to distinguish where one stops and the other begins.'' Jurgen Petschull, a West German journalist, has produced one of those ambitious but difficult to pull off capers that used to be called New Journalism. Or was it New Fiction? Not that it matters, since this particular hybrid isn't satisfying as either journalism or fiction. ''The Martyr'' is based on the 1985 hijacking of a TWA jet to Beirut during which an American military man was murdered by Arab terrorists. Mr. Petschull has fictionalized the principal characters in this drama: the chief terrorist, the air crew, the American agents who, in this version, succeed in capturing their foe. The terrorist is conveniently given a great motive: a misguided volley from the U.S.S. New Jersey had killed his wife and child, who were visiting Beirut. But for all that, he's still a cardboard character: he murders a young American, but we get no hint of what he's thinking as he does so. Ronald Reagan also appears in full command, asking calm, incisive questions - odd characterization, at best, when Mr. Petschull could have learned from the newspapers that this was a time when White House aides were in the basement making deals with Iranians to free hostages. Given all this, it's not surprising that the fictionalized ending of Mr. Petschull's stiffly translated book is predictable and implausible. And if, as the book says, the author believes Bandar Abbas to be an Iranian harbor on the Indian Ocean, I wouldn't hire him for an operation moving a bale of feathers or a handful of microdots - or anything else.

title: A GREAT DEAL OFFERS OCCASIONS FOR BRILLIANCE
description: FEW players appreciate the vast organization that underlies a major tournament. In the recent Spring Nationals in Buffalo, for example, there were 40 directors, 50 caddies and a bunch of assorted officials and journalists.

title: Q&A
description: Costa Rica Question:We have enjoyed the Yucatan and Belize for the great snorkeling and wonder if Costa Rica has anything comparable. - R. R., Corning, N.Y. Answer:It is unlikely that travelers who have been to the Yucatan and Belize will be impressed by the snorkeling in Costa Rica. However, it does have some snorkeling spots, and the best, according to CanoAndes Expeditions, a tour company that specializes in Central and South America, is at Cahuita National Park, which is about 25 miles south of Limon on the Caribbean coast. The reef off Cahuita Point offers excellent snorkeling, particularly in the less rainy season from December through May.

title: Of Snobs, Art and Price Tags
description: To the Editor:

title: Reservoir From Which Memories Flow
description: THE onetime residents of a secluded river valley in Massachusetts cannot go home again because the four little towns in which they lived are no longer there.

title: Correction
description: In last week's Chess column, Black's 35th move should have read N-B3.

title: Correction
description: A map last Sunday with an article about the Adams-Morgan neighborhood in Washington misidentified the street that forms the neighborhood's eastern boundary. It is 16th Street.

title: Is Anybody Listening?
description: To the Editor:

title: Women Film Directors Make a Strong Comeback
description: THIS MONTH, AN UN-precedented number of films directed by women have opened in New York.

title: Robert Allen Is on the Line
description: ''THIS is a bitterwsweet moment for me,'' said Robert E. Allen, addressing shareholders after being named chairman of the American Telephone & Telegraph Company last week. Mr. Allen, 53 years old, got the job after the sudden death of James E. Olson, who succumbed to cancer at the age of 62.

title: CHINATOWN MARKETPLACE
description: THERE ARE TIMES WHEN the atmosphere of Chinatown is strongly reminiscent of the sights, the smells and the sounds of Hong Kong marketplaces -especially on weekends, when Asians from other parts of the metropolitan area crowd these narrow streets to do their week's shopping. Chinatown offers great bargains as well as items that are unavailable elsewhere, such as fragrant fresh lemon grass, pale jade-colored bitter melons, chrysanthemum leaves, lichees and kumquats, water chestnuts, lotus root and fresh banana leaves for wrapping preparations of sticky rice.

title: Film; Where the Action Was
description: IT IS AN EXERCISE IN ARCHEOLOGY, the act of viewing the films that Andy Warhol made in the 1960's. It summons up more than the ghosts of cinematheques, lofts, college auditoriums and other vaguely remembered spaces. For those who saw these films way back when, it is a ride on a time machine to revisit the land of 60's dreams and nightmares.

title: 'Candidate' Runs Again And Wins
description: JOHN FRANKENHEIMER'S ''MANCHURIAN CANDIDATE'' is arguably the most chilling piece of cold war paranoia ever committed to film, yet by now it has developed a kind of innocence. There was so much that we had the good luck not to know in 1962, when the film was made; so much that, unluckily, we know now. A lone assassin, perhaps under the influence of a foreign government, can indeed shoot an American political leader. For that matter, so can a deranged housewife or a disgruntled movie fan. And the power of mind-control techniques, such an exotic part of this story, has been demonstrated by religious cults from Rajneeshpuram, Ore., to Jonestown.

title: POSTINGS: Norwalk Market; Condominium, Yes; Office Building, No
description: The changing face of Clocktower Square, a planned office and apartment complex near downtown Norwalk, Conn., is a sign of the times for Fairfield County. While construction of a 61-unit condominium will begin in June, continuing an urban revival aided by a strong residential market, plans for a 55,000-square-foot office building have been shelved for now. Thomas P. Markunas, the project manager, said the developers, NPA Properties and three limited partners, had decided not to proceed with the speculative office building because of the county's high office vacancy rate, which stood at 20.1 percent in March. ''That's not the kind of market that we want to build into at this point,'' Mr. Markunas said.

title: Review/Recital; A PIANIST OF CONTRASTS
description: As if to underscore that she is not only a purveyor of music new and obscure, Ursula Oppens began her recital at the 92d Street Y on Thursday evening with an early Mozart sonata, closed it with a set of works by Chopin and played Schubert's ''Wanderer'' Fantasy in between. But Ms. Oppens did not leave it at that, tucking Hanns Eisler's First Piano Sonata between the Mozart and Schubert and following intermission with Carla Bley's ''Romantic Notions'' in its premiere.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CROSSING OPEN GROUND. By Barry Lopez. (Scribners, $17.95.) One of the sights that awaited Cortes when he entered the Aztec capital, Tenochtitlan, in 1519 was the city's aviaries, which housed thousands of herons and egrets, condors and hawks, flycatchers, hummingbirds and parrots. Nineteen months later, Cortes returned with an army and laid siege to the city.

title: About Cars; SPEED AND SPACE FOR A GRAND PRICE
description: THE gas-station guy took my order to fill 'er up, and then he said something I haven't heard in a long time. He said, ''Can I check the oil?''

title:
NORTHEST NOTEBOOK: Westfield, Mass.;
Builders Bet On Downtown
description: LEAD: TWO developers, gambling that this city's downtown can be revitalized, plan to build a $4.5 million condominium project that would be the first privately financed housing downtown in a generation.

title: NOTHING SCARES HER LIKE MEN
description: LEAD: POOR DEAR CHARLOTTE By Anabel Donald. 256 pp. San Francisco: Mercury House. $16.95.

title: PRAGMATISTS LEAD IN BUSH ECONOMICS
description: After a primary campaign in which his economic proposals consisted mainly of support for President Reagan's programs, Vice President Bush has gathered around him advisers who are helping him prepare proposals that imply a more moderate, pragmatic agenda.

title: Of Snobs, Art and Price Tags
description: To the Editor:

title: Freelance Writers Find Familiarity Breeds Contentment
description: LEAD: THEY don't write flashy best sellers. Their faces don't show up in glamorous book-jacket photographs or on television talk shows.

title: A FAD ACCOMPLI
description: TEN YEARS AGO, FEW PEOPLE knew about Biedermeier furniture.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SEATTLE
description: In Seattle this is the year of the drought. This is a mixed blessing for Northwesterners, to whom too much sun is as objectionable as someone who wears the same shirt every day. A favorite quote, attributed to John Steinbeck and displayed in offices and homes all over town, goes like this, ''I lived in a place with a nice climate once and it bored the hell out of me.''

title: Transplants: Long Lists, Few Organs
description: LEAD: MARY ANN FIG of Norwich is a widow at the age of 30. Her 29-year-old husband, David, died after three months on a waiting list for a heart transplant. ''David really thought last Father's Day that a heart was going to come through,'' Mrs. Fig said. ''He died nine days later.''

title: U.S. BRACES FOR A TRICKY TRANSITION IN AFGHANISTAN
description: After meeting with leaders of the Afghan rebels five months ago, President Reagan declared, ''The people of Afghanistan speak with one voice in their opposition to the Soviet invasion and occupation of their homeland.''

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Chappaqua, N.Y. $410,000 2 Rose Lane 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 33-year-old split-level; deck, workshop, 1.1 acre; taxes $6,475. Mount Kisco, N.Y. $265,000 182 Dunster Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 48-year-old frame two-story; cathedral ceiling, deck, .75-acre; taxes $2,141. Yorktown Heights, N.Y. $208,000 3616 Edge Hill Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 20-year-old frame ranch; eat-in kitchen, accessory apartment, 100- by 165-foot lot; taxes $5,620. North Branford, Conn. $175,000 39 Hummingbird Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 5-year-old ranch; huge family room with bar, 1 acre; taxes $1,408. Bridgeport, Conn. $151,900 207 Lawrence Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 3-year-old, semidetached Tudor; country kitchen, deck; taxes $1,895. Brookfield, Conn. $362,500 12 Cawdor Burn 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old contemporary; marble fireplace in master bedroom, large deck, 1.9 acres; taxes $4,095. OTHER AREAS North Bellport, L.I. $115,000 211 Atlantic Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 32-year-old ranch; den, eat-in kitchen, finished basement; taxes $1,600. Plainview, L.I. $215,000 66 Marilyn Boulevard 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old split level; eat-in kitchen, den, 2-car garage; taxes $3,800. South River, N.J. $112,500 27 Florence Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; patio, eat-in kitchen, 2-car detached garage; taxes $1,930.

title: Richard Neel, an Art Dealer, Is Married To Constance M. Hoguet, an Educator
description: Constance Middleton Hoguet, the daughter of Robert L. Hoguet of New York and the late Constance R. Hoguet, was married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany in New York to Richard Neel, a son of the late Alice Neel of New York. The Rev. Ernest E. Hunt 3d performed the ceremony.

title: Art; So, Mate, You Want to Know What's New in Australian Art?
description: CONTRARY TO IMPRESSIONS OF Australia conjured up by the tourist campaigns, Australian culture is a mixed palette of artistic visions and gritty urban scenes. Of any neighborhood in Australia, St. Kilda, situated on one of Melbourne's sunny downtown beaches, is the one with the greatest number of artistic associations, embodying all the contradictions of Australian urban life. The district, the closest thing to an Australian bohemia, is noted for its mix of punk-rockers and tourists, prostitutes and drug abusers, as well as Australia's largest Jewish population. From the ''Angry Penguins'' art movement of the late 1930's and 40's to the New Wave art scene of the early 80's, it has also supported a variety of artistic factions. In the words of the painter Jenny Watson, ''this is our East Village.'' But the sense of real conflict, as well as the infusions of big money that characterized New York's East Village art scene until very recently, is missing here. Like the Australian art world as a whole, St. Kilda's artists have a sense of identity and pride, but little idea of where to go with it.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: OUT OF THE WHIRLPOOL. By Alan Sillitoe. Illustrated by Peter Farmer. (Harper & Row, $11.95.) Peter Granby, age 18, a dropout, doomed to fetch and carry in a furniture factory in Nottingham, England. Mother dead of cancer, father long gone off with a ''fancy woman.'' There seems little in the lad's future, but his needs are few and his wants modest.

title: Man's Heart Transplanted Without Prior Consent
description: The heart of a man found unconscious on a sidewalk was transplanted six hours after the man died Wednesday, still unidentified. The case has caused debate among medical ethicists, one of whom said Friday that the transplant was ''incredible'' because no permission had been given for the heart to be donated.

title: SUMMER IN THE PARK WITH GEORGE
description: WINFIELD A Player's Life. By Dave Winfield with Tom Parker. Illustrated. 314 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95.

title: Architecture View; A Novel Design And Its Rescue From Near Disaster
description: ONE OF THE MOST EXTRAORDINARY stories in contemporary American architecture is that of the John Hancock Tower in Boston, a glass slab that for years was known less for its architecture than for the fact that while it was under construction its windows kept tumbling out onto the street. They did not all fall out, but so many of them cracked, broke and were replaced with a temporary sheet of plywood that it was common to hear Bostonians call the tower the U.S. Plywood Building. Eventually all 10,344 original panes of glass in the 60-story building were replaced with a different kind of glass, and in 1976 the building finally opened, five years behind schedule.

title: Governor Gets Bills to Help The Homeless
description: TWO BILLS that would provide $13.65 million for emergency assistance programs to ease the problems of homelessness are awaiting Governor Kean's signature following their unanimous approval by the State Senate last week.

title: Pleasing the Teen-Ager Who Buys the T-shirt
description: YOU can't judge a company by its trademark, but customers do anyway - and for that reason, among others, companies spend millions of dollars each year making sure their trademarks convey the intended message. From commercial characters as lively as Cap'n Crunch to dignified corporate logos, trademarks shape the identity of a company and its brands. And today an entire industry of corporate identity consultants, taking in more than $100 million annually by most estimates, is eager to help the shaping process.

title: U.S. Presses Nicaraguan Children's Aid
description: The United States is preparing to announce which relief organizations will administer millions of dollars in aid to injured Nicaraguan children despite continuing doubt about how the aid will be delivered.

title: THE HEALTH-CARE CHAOS
description: Joseph Califano's article summarized accurately the health-care dilemma. There is no simple solution, but it appears that medical-school training is beginning to stress conservative management and appropriate ordering of diagnostic tests.

title: Racism on Campuses Discussed at Conference
description: LEAD: COLLEGE students, administrators and faculty members from throughout the Northeast gathered in a classroom at Yale University last weekend, and took stock of race relations on their campuses. Many found them to be troubling.

title: Bidders Throng Warhol Auction
description: Andy Warhol's sort of people swarmed through Sotheby's yesterday, spending money or trying to, on his Art Deco and Art Nouveau possessions at the first day of the 10-day auction of 10,000 items from his collection.

title: Route Approved For Electric Cable
description: LEAD: A PLAN to run cable carrying inexpensive electricity to Long Island along state-owned parkways in the county rather than beneath local streets has hit an apparent dead end.

title: Talks With Sabonis
description: AFTER months of talks, permission was granted for Arvidas Sabonis to have his injured Achilles' tendon examined in the United States last week, and that gave the 7-foot-2-inch Soviet basketball star a chance to speak over the weekend with the Portland Trail Blazers, the National Basketball Association team that drafted him on the first round in 1986.

title: Top Players At Each Position
description: OFFENSE Quarterbacks Kerwin Bell, Florida Chris Chandler, Washington Don McPherson, Syracuse Running Backs Lorenzo White, Michigan State John Stephens, NW Louisiana State Gaston Green, U.C.L.A. Fullbacks Craig Heyward, Pittsburgh Brad Muster, Stanford Elbert Woods, Nevada-Las Vegas Wide Receivers Tim Brown, Notre Dame Michael Irvin, Miami Sterling Sharpe, South Carolina Tight Ends Keith Jackson, Oklahoma Pat Carter, Florida State Ferrell Edmunds, Maryland Centers Chuck Lanza, Notre Dame Matt Wilson, Texas A&M Rodney Lossow, Wisconsin Guards Randall McDaniel, Arizona State Glen Derby, Wisconsin Todd Kalis, Arizona State Tackles Paul Gruber, Wisconsin Dave Cadigan, Southern Cal Eric Moore, Indiana Kickers Chip Lohmiller, Minnesota Marty Zendejas, Nevada-Reno Gary Gussman, Miami-Ohio DEFENSE Tackles Michael Perry, Clemson Al Noga, Hawaii Pierce Holt, Angelo State Ends Neil Smith, Nebraska Dan Stubbs, Miami Aaron Jones, Eastern Kentucky Linebackers Aundray Bruce, Auburn Vincent Brown, Mississippi Valley St. Ken Harvey, California Safeties Bennie Blades, Miami Anthony Newman, Oregon Kevin Porter, Auburn Cornerbacks Rickey Dixon, Oklahoma Eric Allen, Arizona State Terry McDaniel, Tennessee Punters Greg Montgomery, Michigan State Barry Helton, Colorado Doug Robinson, Stanford

title: Where Spies Went to Be Seen
description: In the 19th century, whenever East met West in the Orient, it happened in a hotel. The spacious establishments, with their plush public rooms and shady verandas, occupied a special place in the closed societies of the East. Not only did they offer the European traveler an introduction to the exotic Orient amid the security of Western-style comforts, they served as neutral territory where local officials could entertain colonial interlopers. In these outposts of Western civilization, they were social hubs, places of fashion and intrigue where diplomats, politicians, journalists and spies could rub shoulders and be seen. Some of the mystique of these elegant Old World hostelries has been recaptured in a lavish volume, GRAND ORIENTAL HOTELS (Vendome, $60). Though it is principally a picture book - there are over 250 pages of period photographs, as well as copies of hotel menus, postcards, maps and note paper -three brief, well-written essays provide a lively introduction to the illustrations. These engaging, anecdotal pieces are the work of Martin Meade, a lecturer at the Ecole Speciale d'Architecture in Paris; Joseph Fitchett, a correspondent for The International Herald Tribune; and Anthony Lawrence, formerly the Far East correspondent for the BBC. The graphic artist Marc Walter and the picture researcher Catherine Donzel (who also collaborated on ''Grand Hotels'') have produced an unusually beautiful book. It celebrates the romantic symbols of a bygone colonial era while at the same time underscoring the cultural hubris these ''opulent tourist palaces'' came to represent.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: FUNNY SAUCE, by Delia Ephron. (Penguin, $3.95.) With all the messy entanglements caused by divorce, remarriage and joint custody, the humorist Delia Ephron writes, the term ''extended family'' now often applies to a mismatched group of mostly unrelated people who are forced to tolerate one another's existence. ''It's a pleasure to report that 'Funny Sauce' won't lead to heartburn, despite the acid wit that's one of its ingredients - only to chortles and nods of recognition,'' Cyra McFadden said here in 1986. Penguin has also published a paperback edition of Ms. Ephron's book HOW TO EAT LIKE A CHILD: And Other Lessons in Not Being a Grown-up ($3.95), a collection of humor pieces illustrated by Edward Koren. PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $4.95.) When a deputy prosecutor investigates the murder of the beautiful colleague he loved, he finds the case ensnared in ambiguous political connections. ''This sordid, big-city murder story has the delicious closed quality of the classic country-house mystery, in which anybody from the butler to the visiting Russian cousin might have committed the crime,'' our reviewer, Anne Rice, said last year. ''From page 1, the book consciously transcends the murder-mystery genre, combining whodunit suspense with an elegant style and philosophical voice.'' The same publisher has reissued Mr. Turow's ONE L ($4.50), an account of his first year at Harvard Law School. The book ''is compelling in its vivid portrayal of the high-tension competitiveness [ and ] group madness it seems to induce,'' P. M. Stern said here in 1977. ''It is important because it offers an inside look at what law students do and don't learn and who they are and are not equipped to represent when they graduate.'' THAT NIGHT, by Alice McDermott. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.95.) When the mother of a pregnant Long Island teen-ager refuses to let her see her hoodlum boyfriend, a war breaks out in suburbia. Last year, our reviewer, David Leavitt, found the story pleasantly surprising. ''What distinguishes this novel from the mass of literature that takes on the barely middle-class suburban experience is the almost baroque richness of [ Alice ] McDermott's sentences, the intellectual complexity of her moral vision and the explicit emotion of her voice. 'That Night' gloriously rejects the notion that this betrayed and bankrupt world can be rendered only in the spare, impersonal prose that has become the standard of so much contemporary fiction.'' IN THE SHADOW OF THE POORHOUSE: A Social History of Welfare in America, by Michael B. Katz. (Basic, $11.95.) One of the problems with this country's welfare system, Michael B. Katz writes, is that too many political leaders like to believe that people can always find jobs if they really want to - a position that impedes the formation of what the author declares should be a coherent welfare policy. In 1986, Ann Grimes said here that this history ''lends perspective to a domestic debate that has raged fitfully in America for nearly two centuries.'' FALSE ENTRY, by Hortense Calisher. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $9.95.) The son of a London seamstress grows up in the South, where his search for an identity becomes all the more confused when he masquerades as a witness at a Ku Klux Klan murder trial. In 1961, our reviewer, A. S. Morris, said Hortense Calisher's first novel is a ''brave and major book, with many of its scenes drawn to the measure of a masterpiece.'' The same publisher is reprinting THE NEW YORKERS ($10.95), Ms. Calisher's novel about a judge who must shield his daughter, Ruth (who also appears in ''False Entry''), from the fact that she killed her mother after finding her in the company of another man. BLACK KNIGHT, WHITE KNIGHT, by Gloria Vanderbilt. (Fawcett, $4.50.) When the second volume of Gloria Vanderbilt's autobiography was published last year, Nora Johnson said here that ''it's hard to feel sorry for the young and beautiful heiress. . . . Ms. Vanderbilt's theme of a child seeking love from an unloving parent and then, somehow, marrying reflections of that parent has been told before. But her painful awareness of this hidden force results in a unique, very personal and haunting tale.'' TRUANTS, by Ron Carlson. (Norton, $7.95.) Two young runaways and a lonely old man meet in the desert and form a family, which, while it lasts, is better than the ones they have left behind. Ron Carlson ''presents all of this in an affecting manner, with a very decent heart and a tart tongue,'' Barry Yourgrau said here in 1981. ''He practices a kind of wit that is at once tender, canny and vivid, capable of burnishing a passing moment with a quick touch.'' THE FABULOUS LUNTS: A Biography of Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, by Jared Brown. (Atheneum, $14.95.) After meeting in 1919 and marrying two years later, the actors Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne appeared together on stage more than 100 times. ''Like most great artists, the Lunts aimed for an art that was seamless,'' Margaret Croyden said in The Book Review in 1986. Jared Brown's ''impressive, definitive biography . . . reveals the meticulous craftsmanship underlying all their performances.'' TIME CAPSULE, by Mitch Berman. (Ballantine, $3.95.) In the aftermath of atomic destruction, a saxophonist befriends an engineer, and they spend a nuclear winter together. ''Mitch Berman's prose is risky and phonic, emanating from the horn of jazz,'' Fanny Howe said here last year. ''He has humor and is thorough, beyond the call of duty, in transcribing nuclear destruction.''

title: City Ballet Moves to an American Beat
description: LEAD: A BAREFOOT DAVID PARSONS, WHO HAS never partnered a ballerina, steadies New York City Ballet principal Merrill Ashley as she rises on pointe in an arabesque during a rehearsal of Peter Martins's ''Barber Violin Concerto.'' The work is the first by Mr. Martins to blend modern and classical ballet dancers.

title: U.S. Suspends Search for 28 Ship Crewmen
description: The United States Coast Guard suspended a 14,000-square-mile search today for 28 crewmen missing from a Greek-owned tanker that broke up and burned in the North Atlantic earlier this week.

title: Yonkers Sewer Moratorium Is Extended
description: THE ban on new public sewer connections to the giant Yonkers treatment plant will continue at least another six months, officials of the State Department of Environmental Conservation said last week. Continuing the moratorium will effectively eliminate the building season in much of the county.

title: Jews Voted Against Jackson for Views, Not Color
description: To the Editor:

title: BREAKING AWAY FROM LENIN
description: THE GORBACHEV PHENOMENON A Historical Interpretation. By Moshe Lewin. 176 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $16.95. RUSSIA AND THE WEST Gorbachev and the Politics of Reform. By Jerry Hough. 301 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: A Chance to Pile Up a Few Dollars More
description: Below are answers to some recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column.

title: Headliners; Under Discussion
description: Clearly, Fidel Castro and John Cardinal O'Connor had a lot to talk about. Cardinal O'Connor, who last week became the first American cardinal to visit Cuba since Mr. Castro's forces overthrew the Batista Government nearly 30 years ago, met with the Cuban President into the wee hours one morning for what the prelate described as discussions of church-state relations. Cuban Catholics had invited the New York archbishop to visit for a celebration of the 200th anniversary of the birth of the Rev. Felix Varela, a priest who opposed Spanish colonial rule. He said his three-hour meeting with Mr. Castro was ''very rational and very amiable.'' The Cardinal said his visit was aimed at demonstrating the church's unity and its desire for ''peace with justice.''

title: Owl in Colorado
description: A hungry and emaciated snowy owl, found sitting along Route 9W in Milton, N.Y., last November and cared for at the Wildcare Raptor Rehabilitation Sanctuary in Harrison, is now flying wide circles in a large flight cage in Colorado.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'REGINA' REVIVED ''Regina,'' Marc Blitzstein's operatic version of Lillian Hellman's play ''The Little Foxes,'' opens at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven on May 6, with previews this Friday through May 5.

title: Hispanic Advisers Outline Concerns
description: LEAD: AS the Westchester County Hispanic Advisory Board wraps up its final report, those involved with the Hispanic community say the dominant issues include a lack of political influence and economic development, as well as inadequate education, housing and health care.

title: From a Safe Haven, Charting a Course through Past and Future
description: ''THE LAST SPRING,'' by Grieg, ended just as I came to a stop only yards from the water on the north shore of Gardiners Bay. My mood was anything but elegiac. I switched off the radio, deepening the silence of the empty beach (it was early April), and admired the view that had been an almost unchanging part of my summertime life since boyhood.

title: Honor Lassalle Marries Mark McIntyre
description: The marriage of Honor Lassalle, a writer and photographer, to Mark P. McIntyre, the environment writer at Newsday, took place yesterday at the Puck Building in New York. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee, the rector of St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., performed the ceremony.

title: 'Great' Corruption Case in Miami Turns Out to Be Much Less
description: In February 1986, when a Hialeah real estate developer was arrested, state prosecutors named him a ''great corrupter'' and said he was the central figure in one of the biggest political scandals in Dade County history.

title: New Stamps, New Shmamps!
description: AS someone who remembers the days of the penny postcard and the 3-cent letter, and who also remembers when 25 cents could send me to the movies for an entire afternoon, or send me on five uneventful subway rides, I am shocked - no, horrified -to learn that this once princely sum of money now sends no more than a skinny little letter on a trip through the mail.

title: JUNIOR BIRDMEN GROW UP
description: FLIGHTS OF PASSAGE Reflections of a World War II Aviator. By Samuel Hynes. 270 pp. Annapolis, Md.: Frederic C. Beil/The Naval Institute Press. $16.95.

title: 'Twice as Less' Once More
description: To the Editor:

title: T. E. Cronin Wed To Alanna Gibson
description: The marriage of Alanna Christina Gibson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Gibson of New York and Bogota, Colombia, to Timothy Edward Cronin, the son of Donald E. Cronin of Hillsdale and Bay Head, N.J., and the late Alice Fischer Cronin, took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: As recently as the early 1960's, new science fiction meant short fiction. Except for an occasional novel marketed as something else, new s.f. appeared mostly in monthly magazines where the longest stories were chopped into three or four parts for serialization. Only when paperback books displaced magazines as the principal outlet for new science fiction did the novel replace the short story as the genre's standard narrative form. But evolution is not necessarily progress. A short story can compel our attention if it does no more than tell us what happened, but, with rare exceptions, long stories must also provide convincing characters for something to happen to. Despite its vaunted ability to imagine new worlds and furnish them with all manner of living creatures, science fiction is notably deficient in novels of character.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Headsets in Theater
description: LEAD: A SYSTEM to help the hearing impaired has been installed at the Performing Arts Center of the State University of New York in Purchase. The system - consisting of headsets that pick up sound waves from a series of infrared light emitters placed on the walls - made its debut last weekend at ''Five by Tenn,'' a retrospective of Tennessee Williams's short plays performed by the Acting Company, a professional Manhattan-based group.

title: Miss Woolworth To Wed in August
description: Frederick Woolworth of New York and Winthrop, Me., has made known the engagement of his daughter Priscilla Woolworth to Cassian Elwes, a son of Mrs. Elliott Kastner of London and the late Dominic Elwes. An August wedding is planned.

title: A Treasure Trove Worthy of a Pulitzer
description: ONCE UPON A TIME, THERE were collectors who did not follow fashion, never resold or traded what they had bought, preferred the difficult and the taxing to the easy and ingratiating and never, ever, used the word ''I'' when discussing the art that they owned. The very notion of ownership made them feel uneasy, and quite often they gave it to a museum in their lifetime. To flirt with one institution after another as to which would get it when they were dead would have seemed loathsome to them, though it is common form among pseudo-collectors in our own day.

title: Gatting Teachers Involved
description: WHEN the state's Department of Education issued its Level III monitoring report on the Asbury Park school system, it unfairly and inaccurately labeled the school district a failure.

title: Ernest Yenke Is Wed To Katharine Conrod
description: St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Katharine Jane Conrod, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Franklin Conrod of Chappaqua, N.Y., to Ernest Kenneth Yenke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard William Yenke of Boca Raton, Fla. The Rev. Charles Kavanagh performed the ceremony.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The nearly flat roof on my ranch house has no provision for ventilation. Roofers have told me the lack of air circulation makes rot a strong possibility. I have been able to look inside this confined roof space but have seen nothing unusual. I am about to have a new roof installed and want to know what to do about this problem, or even if there is a problem. I am thinking about opening vent holes in the soffits and screening these to keep out insects. However, I don't think these will help much because the space between the roof and the ceiling is filled with fiberglass insulation. What do you think?

title: Mob Suspect Held in Slaying on Manhattan Street
description: A man killed another on Friday afternoon as the two strolled down a busy street in the East Village, and the police believe the suspect is an organized-crime figure who testified against two associates in a 1978 murder trial.

title: A Helping Hand in Buying a First Home
description: AS home ownership continues to decline among young adults, a growing number of states, municipalities and private employers are developing programs intended to help first-time home buyers over a relatively new hurdle: the difficulty of accumulating down payment and closing costs and meeting tightened mortgage-qualifying rules.

title: Catharine Eddy White Marries John O'Rourke
description: At the Central Presbyterian Church in Manhattan yesterday, Catharine Eddy White, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip C. White of Washington and Lakeside, Mich., was married to John Joseph O'Rourke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. O'Rourke of Beaver Falls, Pa. The Rev. John David Burton performed the ceremony.

title: No Headline
description: Kurt Vonnegut usually has several of what he describes as ''conscience books'' around the house. This does not mean that Mr. Vonnegut routinely delves into how to be a better person or atone for sins. Not at all. Conscience books are those that he believes he should read, as opposed to those that he freely chooses to read.

title: NO MORE SITTING ON DADDY'S LAP
description: LEAD: THE PERFECT FAMILY By Sharon Daley. 310 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $18.95.

title: Lombardozzi Wants Trade
description: Steve Lombardozzi, the Twins' second baseman, said he has asked the team to trade him because of the acquisition of another second baseman, Tom Herr, from the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE MEDIA BUSINESS SCI Holdings has agreed to sell the stock of its company to Tele-Communications and Comcast for $1.55 billion in cash. The price is also subject to certain adjustments and apparently includes the company's debt. Tele-Communications and Comcast said that they would form a new company to buy SCI, formerly Storer Communications. [ Page D1. ] A new television series offers a Solomonic solution to the problem studios have had with hourlong shows: after initial showings of the series ''Law and Order'' on network, each show can be sliced in half for syndication as two half-hour shows. [ D10. ] IDG Communications is betting PC World USSR will succeed with Soviet readers. The new computer magazine is a venture with Soviet partners. [ D10. ] U.S. newspapers have begun shifting to lightweight newsprint and saving on paper, labor and mailing, while preserving a print quality that advertisers and readers demand. [ D10. ] An established author without a big seller faces a hurdle comparable to that of getting a first novel published. Publishing. [ D10. ] Free copies of Global Business magazine will be mailed this week by the British publisher Robert Maxwell to about 50,000 decision makers in the U.S. and 10 other countries. Advertising. [ D11. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT The Soviet economy grew at a rate of only one-half of 1 percent last year, as the Soviet Union cut back its imports from the West and failed to increase standards of living for its consumers, despite the economic policies of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, according to an analysis by two U.S. intelligence agencies. [ D1. ] A Texas Railroad Commission member plans to urge OPEC members meeting in Vienna this week to adopt production limits with non-OPEC nations to keep prices above $18 a barrel. [ D3. ] Mexico's airline industry appears set for an overhaul after the Government's decision to allow a state-owned airline to declare bankruptcy. [ D8. ] Four Asian nations are beginning to crack the Japanese market with inexpensive, quality electronic and consumer goods. [ D8. ] COMPANIES J. P. Stevens has accepted a $1.2 billion takeover offer from West Point-Pepperell, Wall Street sources said. The offer, amounting to $68.50 a share, splits the assets of the huge textile company at least three ways. [ D1. ] G.M. plans to phase out its purchases of Firestone tires within two years, the auto maker announced over the weekend. [ D6. ] THE ECONOMY The U.S. will have moderately higher inflation and the general price level could rise 5 percent or more a year into the early 1990's, but there will be no return to disruptive levels, analysts say. [ D1. ] Orders for American-made machine tools fell 14.6 percent in March from the previous month, to $254.4 million, according to a report by the industry's trade association. [ D2. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS John S. R. Shad was named Business Statesman of the Year last week by the Harvard Business School Club of Greater New York, and 74 top industry executives and 1,200 other guests showed up at the New York Hilton to honor him. New Yorkers & Co. [ D1. ] Few taxpayers with above-average incomes received tax cuts in the first year of the new tax law, accountants say. And there were other surprises as well. Tax Watch. [ D2. ] Wall Street is more pessimistic, but that indicates a rally is likely, technical analysts contend. Market Place. [ D6. ] Interest rates will probably stabilize at close to their current levels for a few weeks. But most analysts assert that yields will rise later in the quarter. Credit Markets. [ D7. ]

title: A Novelist's Nightmare: 'Publish And Perish'
description: WHEN the literary agent Lois Wallace conducted an auction last year for ''Privileged Lives,'' she told publishers she was submitting the novel under a pseudonym. But not until Delacorte Press won the auction with a six-figure bid did it learn that ''Robert deForest'' was really Edward Stewart, the author of nine books. More to the point, Mr. Stewart was the author of nine books that, despite generally favorable reviews, had not made much money.

title: TV Notes; People-Metering for Commercials
description: You're watching television, a commercial comes on and you leave for the kitchen to get a snack. A box on the television set knows you're gone; a message on the screen asks who is there.

title: G.M. Plans to Phase Out Its Purchases of Firestone Tires
description: The General Motors Corporation, in a move to reduce the number of companies from which it purchases tires in North America, announced over the weekend that it would phase out its purchases of Firestone tires within the next two years.

title: 'STAR WARS' RUNS INTO NEW CRITICISM
description: Even early versions of the Reagan Administration's ''Star Wars'' missile defense system, ones that use rockets instead of lasers, are vulnerable to equipment and computer software failures that would make them unworkable, according to a report by a Congressional research agency.

title: Dukakis Stumps on Message of Hope
description: Past aging coal tipples and rusting mills, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis whistle-stopped through Western Pennsylvania today with a promise of economic development. His oratory was more focused on the Republicans than on the Rev. Jesse Jackson, his opponent in Tuesday's Democratic Presidential primary here.

title: P. T. Cirenza Wed To Lisa S. Gitkin
description: Lisa Sue Gitkin, an associate at Booz Allen & Hamilton in New York, and Peter Timothy Cirenza, an associate in mortgage securities at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York, were married yesterday. Rabbi Frederic Dworkin and the Rev. Roland Ghirlando, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Mayfair Farms in West Orange, N.J.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Too many students do not graduate from our high schools, and too many of those who do graduate have been poorly educated. Our students know too little, and their command of essential skills is too slight.'' - Education Secretary, William J. Bennett. [ A1:2. ]

title: Short Period of Rate Stability Seen
description: After rising steadily since early March, interest rates are likely to stabilize at close to their current levels for the next few weeks. But most credit market analysts assert that the pause will be temporary, and that yields will rise further later in the quarter.

title: Japan Increases Imports From 4 Asian Countries
description: In a major department store in downtown Tokyo, shoppers gathered recently around a small display of electronic products. A miniature radio with headphones made in Hong Kong was selling for less than $30 and a portable television set from South Korea for about $93.75.

title: Mitterrand Far Ahead in Round 1; Chirac Is Second as Le Pen Gains
description: President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, handily outdistanced Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, the neo-Gaullist leader, in the first round of France's presidential election today.

title: Olympic Notebook; Maneuvers Start For Future Games
description: Atlanta or Minneapolis-St. Paul will be chosen this week as the United States bid city for the 1996 Summer Olympics. But the victory, by vote during the United States Olympic Committee House of Delegates meeting in Washington, may be hollow.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: What's the closest Dave Winfield of the Yankees ever came to winning the league's most valuable player award?

title: Review/Rock; A Bar Band's Forward Motion And Edginess
description: There's an element of wildness and unpredictability to a good performance by a bar band: that it's going to get louder and louder until windows shatter; that the lead singer, in a fit of abandon, might just throw himself into the audience. Terrance Simien and the Mallet Playboys, a young group from rural southwest Louisiana, had that sense of edginess at the Lone Star on Thursday night. Earl Sally, their virtuoso rub board player, moved up to audience members and unleashed barrages of clattering rhythms; Mr. Simien, accordion folding and unfolding, leaped around the stage as if he were possessed.

title: Market Place; Seeing Pessimism As a Bullish Sign
description: LAST week, the mood on Wall Street began approaching the levels of pessimism and confusion that dominated the stock market after the crash. ''The sentiment appears to be more extreme than in December,'' said Richard Eakle, founder of Eakle Associates Inc., an advisory firm in Fair Haven, N.J.

title: For Montand at 66, The Passions Burn, The Memories Endure
description: He is 66 years old now, and he is still, as he has always been, a man of passion - passion for politics, passion for women, passion for singing, passion for movies, passion for life. He is Yves Montand, whom a French critic once described as ''the heart and hands of our time.''

title: Youth Killed on Line to See Movie on Gangs
description: A young man was shot to death today in a gang-related scuffle as he stood in line for the movie ''Colors,'' the police said.

title: Review/Theater; Black Actor in 19th-Century England
description: Ira Aldridge was apparently the first black actor to play Othello, and that was only one of his many accomplishments. In the mid-19th century, Aldridge had a following on the English stage comparable to that of Edmund Kean, and he carried that reputation across Europe and Russia. Published reports on Aldridge have been contradictory, beginning with the date of his birth, but one thing is certain. He had an astonishing career in the English theater, one that has not been equaled by any other American classical actor.

title: Review/Theater; A Tough Woman In Thrall
description: Late in ''Emily,'' his new comedy at the Manhattan Theater Club, the writer Stephen Metcalfe pays homage to an undying, totemic television image of the 1970's. As the play's heroine, a New York stockbroker played by Lisa Banes, arrives in Minnesota for a visit, she tosses her hat in the air - just as Mary Tyler Moore did each week in the role of the Minneapolis career woman Mary Richards, during the opening credits of her long-running ''Mary Tyler Moore Show.'' Fans of that series will recall that its theme song promised a bright future for the smart, ambitious, single, quasi feminist Mary. ''You're going to make it after all!'' went the lyric, as Mary jubilantly tossed her hat.

title: Pennsylvania Politics: Some Anomalies
description: Pennsylvania, which holds its primary elections on Tuesday, is a political oddity.

title: Schools Lag Despite a 5-Year Effort, Bennett Says
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett says in a new report that the overall performance of American schools remains ''unacceptably low,'' even though a five-year campaign to improve schools has raised academic standards and led to modest increases in student achievement.

title: Da Lat Journal; Among the Faded Snapshots, a Middle Class Dies
description: Duong Quang Trong is missing in action. His name appears on no list, because in Vietnam there are no comprehensive records of the casualties of war. They are too numerous to count, and there are more urgent tasks.

title: Machine-Tool Orders Down 14.6% in March
description: Orders for American-made machine tools fell 14.6 percent in March from the previous month, to $254.40 million, according to a report scheduled to be released today by the industry's trade association.

title: With Inmates at Record High, Sentence Policy Is Reassessed
description: Officials around the country are cautiously reassessing the sentencing practices that have left more than a half million inmates in Federal and state prisons after more than a decade of the most explosive growth in the prison population in the nation's history.

title: America's Game
description: It's official. Baseball was the nation's leading spectator sport last year. It was followed by horse racing, which, in turn, eclipsed football, basketball, and, by one reckoning, even automobile racing.

title: Kimberly A. Gallas Is Wed To G. J. Veras, a Producer
description: At Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church in New Rochelle, N.Y., Kimberly Anne Gallas, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Gallas of Brecksville, Ohio, was married yesterday to George James Veras, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James G. Veras of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Peter Kyriakos performed the ceremony.

title: Cindy Jo Still Wed to Niles A. Howard
description: At the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, Cindy Jo Still, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy L. Still of Chattanooga, Tenn., and Washington, Iowa, was married yesterday to Niles Ainsworth Howard, a son of Mary Jo Howard of Clinton, N.C., and the late Leon E. Howard. The Rev. Charles A. Amstein performed the ceremony.

title: Stationary Version of Skiing
description: The ski season may be winding down, but that doesn't mean you have to let your leg muscles turn to mush. Scientific Sports Systems, a firm based in Port of Redwood City, Calif., manufacturers a stationary exerciser designed to duplicate the lateral rhythm needed in downhill skiing. The United States Olympic ski team trained on the device, the Skier's Edge, last winter. The company introduced it to the mass market in February.

title: In China, the Family Farm Is Far From Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: Ojeda Leaves Early And Mets Lose, 5-4
description: The Mets, flushed with early success this season, got two reminders of the frailty of success today: Their pitchers are still prone to injuries, and the St. Louis Cardinals are still alive and running.

title: Consultation Is Pledged on Gulf Role
description: Two top Pentagon officials said today that the Reagan Administration would consult further with Congress and other nations before expanding the American military role in the Persian Gulf.

title: South Africa Reported To Jail Fewer Children
description: Domestic and international pressure has led to a decline in the number of children under detention in South Africa, according to a commission of inquiry into the situation.

title: Love of Guns, and Applause for Goetz
description: It was the day of the gun.

title: Parolee in Rape Case To Be Released Today
description: A man who raped and mutilated a teen-age girl nine years ago will finish his parole Monday, but the emotions generated by his crime show no sign of abating.

title: Blue Jays' Blunders Lead to Yankee Victory, 5-3
description: Not that the Yankees were struggling enough to start worrying, but they had lost four out of seven and as Claudell Washington said: ''We've been dragging a little bit lately. We haven't been swinging the bat well.''

title: Sleeper Issue for the '88 Campaign: Child Care
description: WASHINGTON

title: Israelis Reopen the West Bank and Gaza
description: The Israeli authorities reopened the West Bank and Gaza Strip today for the first time in a week and ended 24-hour curfews that had kept about 400,000 Palestinians shut in their homes.

title: Rising Price For Gasoline
description: The average price of a gallon of gasoline in the United States jumped 2.67 cents, to 98.84 cents, in the past two weeks, and prices could continue rising as summer nears, an oil industry analyst said today.

title: Shultz Carefully Asks Soviet Religious Liberty
description: Throughout his two days of travel outside Moscow, Secretary of State George P. Shultz delivered a carefully worded call for religious freedom in the Soviet Union.

title: Drug Problem Is Too Big for Any City to Handle All by Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: Harlem: The 'Haves' Struggle
description: Eight years ago, shunning the warnings of well-meaning friends, Randy Daniels, a young black television correspondent, moved with his family into a brownstone on Sugar Hill, one of the grand neighborhoods of Harlem past.

title: Review/Recital; Schubert, Rendered Vocally and Pianistically
description: Peter Schreier and Norman Shetler gave ''Die Schone Mullerin'' at the Metropolitan Museum on Saturday night as it can be given only by artists who know it from the inside, though at least one listener was left somewhat perplexed by what they seem to have found there.

title: Special Programs Hampered at Justice Dept.
description: Justice Department officials say that while much of the department's work goes on as before, the recent departure of nearly a dozen top aides to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d means there is no one left to champion several important legal initiatives sought by the Administration.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; Harvard's $275 Prix Fixe For Money-Minded Alumni
description: John S. R. Shad must have been proud.

title: Corrections
description: A report on Wednesday in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day misidentified one of Carl J. Heger's new posts at Batus Inc. He has become senior vice president, chief financial officerand a member of both the board and the executive committee.

title: Philharmonic at Apollo: Taking the A Train
description: When the New York Philharmonic gave its first concert, 146 years ago, its home was the Apollo Rooms, on Broadway near Canal Street. Tonight, the orchestra will be making a debut at another Apollo - the legendary theater on 125th Street in Harlem, long a hot spot for jazz, rhythm and blues, early rock-and-roll, soul and gospel, and now a refurbished community cultural center with plans to present a broad array of the arts.

title: Juror Explains The 2d Mistrial In Slaying Case
description: A Queens minister who served on the jury that deadlocked on charges that two reputed Mafia figures murdered a police detective says the defendants ''never will be convicted'' because the prosecution case has serious problems.

title: Lawyer Guilty In Note Scheme
description: A French lawyer has been convicted in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on charges of trying to sell worthless Indonesian promissory notes to an undercover New York City detective, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, said.

title: Tokyo Stock Prices at High
description: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange were higher at midday on continued momentum from Saturday's surge here, with broadly based buying pushing the Nikkei index to a new peak.

title: 2 Cable TV Companies To Buy SCI
description: In an unexpected move, SCI Holdings, the owner of the cable systems of the former Storer Communications, announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell the company to two of the nation's largest cable operators in a deal for $1.55 billion in cash and apparently the assumption of the company's debt.

title: N.A.B. Elections
description: At a meeting yesterday of its board of directors held in Hawaii, the Newspaper Advertising Bureau elected as its new chairman Bob Marbut, chairman and chief executive of Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. of San Antonio. Mr. Marbut succeeds Frank A. Daniels Jr. publisher of The News and Observer and The Raleigh Times in Raleigh, N.C. Walter Mattson, president of The New York Times Company, was elected vice chairman. John Giuggio, vice chairman of The Boston Globe, was elected treasurer, and James Hoge, president and publisher of The New York Daily News, was re-elected secretary and assistant treasurer.

title: At Universal, Two Programs for Price of One
description: In a production room on the Universal Studios lot, a producer named Dick Wolfe is finishing the first episode of a new television series he hopes to sell to CBS. Mr. Wolfe's crime-and-punishment program, called ''Law and Order,'' is more than just another prime-time fantasy; it is a textbook example of the new economics of television.

title: A Restive Island Tribe Adds to Noriega's Woes
description: As if Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega didn't have enough problems, the San Blas Kuna, one of the country's indigenous Indian populations, are in revolt.

title: To the Court: Retain the Special Prosecutor Law
description: LEAD: The Supreme Court today will hear a constitutional challenge to the Ethics in Government Act, which established the office of independent prosecutor. At issue is January's decision by the Circuit Court of Appeals in Washington that the act unconstitutionally interferes with the President's powers.

title: Jets Take Bruising Blocker
description: Dave Cadigan, the top ''decleater'' since Southern California began keeping records of punishing blocks, became the Jets' first draft pick yesterday.

title: Laid Back Golfers
description: The very best golfers get to join the Professional Golfers Association or the Ladies Professional Golfers Association, but the way Max Colclasure sees it, until he came along the only thing lousy golfers got was high-blood pressure.

title: Texan to Urge Limits In Non-OPEC Output
description: Frustrated by the oil industry's battered condition in Texas, the first Republican ever appointed to the Texas Railroad Commission plans to urge OPEC members in Vienna this week to adopt production limits with non-OPEC nations to keep prices above $18 a barrel.

title: Voznesensky Denies Signing Pravda Letter
description: Andrei Voznesensky, the Russian poet, has denied that he was among 38 prominent Soviet writers and editors who signed a letter to the Communist Party newspaper Pravda. The letter defended Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policy of perestroika, the term used to describe Mr. Gorbachev's efforts to restructure the Soviet economy and to reduce rigidity in the Soviet system.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Sweetening the Senate
description: The only lobbyists permitted on the Senate floor are former members, and they normally confine their activities to the cloakrooms. But one lobby has been making its influence felt directly on the floor for years, providing the members with something of value under daily observation by Senate officials and the press, without a breath of scandal.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 24, 1988: MONDAY Acme United Corp Walt Disney Airborne Freight Interstate Securities Allied-Signal Inc Kennametal Inc Armstrong World Indus Koppers Co Boeing Co Lubrizol Corp Cenvill Investors Phila Electric Co Consol Freightways Springs Industries TUESDAY Ball Corp McDonald & Co Invstmnts Bausch & Lomb Mohasco Corp Boise Cascade Corp Norwest Corp CalFed Inc O'Sullivan Corp Certain-teed Corp Phillips Petroleum Cilcorp Inc PSC New Mexico Cincinnati Milacron Reebok Intl Ltd EDO Corp Rollins Inc Fedders Corp Rubbermaid Inc Glenfed Inc Santa Fe So Pacific Hexcel Corp Southwestern Public Svc Kentucky Utilities USX Corp Kerr Glass Mfg Warner-Lambert Landmark Svgs Assn Whirlpool Corp WEDNESDAY AMP Inc McGraw-Hill Amer Electric Power Myers Industries Anheuser-Busch NCNB Corp Baker Hughes Oneida Ltd Battle Mountain Gold Pacific Scientific Champion Spark Plug Panhandle Eastern Corp Clorox Co Potomac Electric Power Columbia S&L Scana Corp Dennison Mfg Sealed Power Corp Du Pont Co Sherwin-Williams Energen Corp SmithKline Beckman Fleming Cos Standex Intl Hercules Inc TW Services Inc Houghton Mifflin Teledyne Inc Inland Steel Indus Union Carbide Kollmorgen Corp Wendy's Intl Lukens Inc West Point-Pepperell THURSDAY Anadarko Petroleum Nalco Chem Avemco Corp Oakite Products Avery International Olin Corp Corning Glass Works Owens & Minor Delta Air Lines Pennzoil Co Dexter Corp Pfizer Inc Duke Power Philips Indus Empire District Electric Quaker State Corp General Instrument Quantum Chemical Corp Iowa-III G&E RLC Corp Johnson & Johnson Sara Lee Corp Key Corp Sonat Inc Lawter Intl Veeco Instruments Mead Corp Wicor Inc Morton Thiokol-Inc FRIDAY Amer President Cos Mobil Corp Browne & Sharpe Mfg Oakwood Homes Corp Equifax Inc Rollins Environmental Kimberly-Clark Sizeler Property Invstrs Kysor Industrial Univar Corp McDonnell Douglas

title: Outdoors: Care Is Needed to Avoid Lyme Disease
description: LYME disease, a tick-transmitted malady that can result in severe and prolonged arthritic symptoms and neurological and heart disorders, is spreading rapidly in southern New England, New York and New Jersey.

title: 2 in Honeywell Protest
description: Two activists protesting Honeywell Inc.'s involvement in military activities tried to place the company's president under citizens' arrest Thursday at the company's annual meeting. Instead, the two women were ushered out of the meeting by security guards. The two had spoken before the incident in support of a shareholder resolution that urged the company to move into nonmilitary businesses. The resolution was defeated by 95.7 percent of Honeywell's shareholders. Since the Vietnam War, Honeywell has frequently been the target of protests against its involvement in military contracts.

title: Washington Talk: Military Careers; Air Force and Marines Battle 'Ticket-Punchers'
description: The Air Force and the Marine Corps have declared war on what a civilian critic calls ''milicrats,'' or military bureaucrats, and those who are called ''ticket-punchers'' in the armed forces. The generic term is ''careerists.'' These are military officers who are more concerned with their promotions than with the performance of their current duties. They seek assignments that will make them visible to senior officers, or settle into comfortable jobs that open the way to lucrative civilian jobs.

title: Cherokee Colony Goes Lame
description: Cherokee Colony, whose future looked bright after a strong third-place finish Saturday in the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct, went lame less than an hour after the race and will not run in the Kentucky Derby on May 7.

title: Bruins Take 3-1 Lead
description: Reggie Lemelin earned the second post-season shutout of his career with 22 saves tonight as the Boston Bruins defeated Montreal, 2-0, to move one victory from beating the Canadiens in a playoff series for the first time in 45 years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a reunion of civil rights workers from the 60's gave an incorrect location for John Chatfield's work as an organizer with the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee. He worked in southwest Georgia.

title: In Amazon Jungle, a Gold Rush Like None Before
description: The men of Padeiro pay for a gun, a drink or a plane ride in gold, pure gold dust, like fresh produce just drawn from the soil.

title: Study Finds Soviet Output Is Stagnant
description: Despite the ambitious economic program of the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet Union last year experienced almost no economic growth, cut back its imports from the West and failed to increase standards of living for its consumers, an analysis by two United States intelligence agencies concluded.

title: Review/Ballet; In San Francisco, a Tomasson 'Swan Lake'
description: Helgi Tomasson's completely new production of ''Swan Lake'' - one of the most beautifully designed in recent years, now puts the San Francisco Ballet on the international dance map.

title: Stevens Said to Have Accepted Offer
description: J. P. Stevens & Company, one of the nation's biggest textile producers, has accepted a $1.2 billion takeover offer from West Point-Pepperell Inc., a major competitor, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: When TV News Gives Its Word
description: Should the television networks keep their promises to Congress? Of course, and when they don't, Congress and the public have a right to feel wronged.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; One Last Ambassador?
description: The White House is looking covetously at the United States ambassador's post in New Delhi. Ambassador John Gunther Dean, a veteran Foreign Service officer who has served three years during a period of thorny but improving relations with India, has been informed that he should be prepared to leave soon.

title: Review/Dance; Ballet Theater, in a Sassy 'Gaite Parisienne'
description: The clashing colors of Christian Lacroix's costumes for American Ballet Theater's revival of ''Gaite Parisienne'' give this delightful comedy a bright, sassy - even garish - new look. It could be argued that they emphasize the characters' vulgarity more than previous productions have. Yet Leonide Massine's choreography has retained its energy, and when the ballet was performed Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House delighted dancegoers clapped rhythmically along during the cancan.

title:
ROWING;
Navy Women's Eight Gains Sweep
description: LEAD: The women's crew from the Naval Academy withstood a strong closing challenge from Columbia to win the varsity eight-oared event and complete a sweep of four races yesterday on a blustery Harlem River course.

title: Laura Hershaft Wed To Adam E. Saltman
description: Laura Beth Hershaft, a doctoral candidate in microbiology at Columbia University, and Adam Evan Saltman, who is studying in a joint program at Columbia for a Ph.D. degree in pharmacology and an M.D. degree, were married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in Yonkers. Rabbi Abraham Klausner officiated.

title: Review/Television; Connie Chung Reports On Everyday Pressures
description: ''Stressed to Kill'' examines stress and says it is no fun. At worst it can kill you; at best, it leads to bad manners. The NBC News report, on Channel 4 at 10 o'clock tonight, is a voyage in pop medicine, pop psychology and pop culture. It is also quite neatly done.

title: Pirates Top Cubs For 3-Game Sweep
description: Darnell Coles hit a tie-breaking single and Rafael Belliard followed with a run-scoring triple in the fourth inning as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Chicago Cubs, 4-2, today to sweep their three-game series.

title: Columbia's Rebels Retake Campus for a 20th Reunion
description: Mark Naison finished coaching his son's Little League team and then, rushing into the past, went straight to the anniversary of the 1968 Columbia student strike. Mr. Naison, a onetime member of Students for a Democratic Society, is now a history professor at Fordham University. He teaches a course on the 1960's.

title: Afghan Asks Improved U.S. Ties
description: President Najibullah of Afghanistan said today that his Communist Government wants better relations with the United States, but that Washington must stop providing military aid to Pakistan if it wants the Soviet Union to stop arming his forces.

title: Bell Collectors Work to Strike Right Note With Public
description: They are a small group, and they sometimes suffer from an identity crisis. ''When we say we're bell collectors, people say, 'Bill collectors? Bell Telephone?'
