'' said Byron Ward of Mount Holly, N.J., a member of the American Bell Association International who has been buying bells for 20 years. ''They can't visualize that we collect bells as such.''

title: Review/Concert; Minnesota Orchestra
description: The Minnesota Orchestra offered us an evening of extremes at Carnegie Hall Saturday night. It would be hard to conceive another program with such a range of extravagance and subtlety or of good taste and bad. The three 20th-century pieces surrounding calmer pockets of Handel and Mozart also made a nice comparative study between 18th-century ears and our own.

title: INSIDE
description: Devils-Capitals Series Tied The Washington Capitals defeated the New Jersey Devils, 4-1, to tie their hockey playoff series at two games each. SportsMonday, page C1. Higher Inflation Expected The general price level in the U.S. could rise 5 percent or more a year into the 1990's, many economists and business executives say. Page D1.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Banco de Bilbao S.A., Madrid, named Howard S. Freeman treasurer of its New York branch.

title: The First Round
description: Comments by The Associated Press. NO. TEAM PLAYER POSITION SCHOOL 1 Atlanta Aundray Bruce Linebacker Auburn Has already signed a five-year, $4.1 million contract. 2 Kansas City Neil Smith Def. End Nebraska Had 65 tackles and 7 1/2 sacks last year. 3 Detroit Bennie Blades Free Safety Miami Highest a DB has been picked since 1963. Had 19 interceptions for his career. 4 Tampa Bay Paul Gruber Off. Tackle Wisconsin Can play anywhere on line. A 293-pounder who runs a 4.8 40-yard dash. 5 Cincinnati Rickey Dixon Free Safety Oklahoma Eight interceptions last year to tie school record; will be shifted to cornerback. 6 L.A. Raiders Tim Brown Wide Receiver Notre Dame Career leader at N.D. with 2,493 receiving yards and 1,613 kickoff-return yards. 7 Green Bay Sterling Sharpe Wide Receiver South Carolina Holds Gamecock records with 163 receptions, 2,444 yards and 17 TD's. 8 Jets Dave Cadigan Off. Tackle Southern Cal 16th U.S.C. lineman to go in first round since 1968. 9 L.A. Raiders Terry McDaniel Def. Back Tennessee Entered Tennessee as wide receiver. Four-year sprinter on track team. 10 Giants Eric Moore Off. Tackle Indiana 292-pounder was named the outstanding lineman for the Hoosiers in 1987. 11 Dallas Michael Irvin Wide Receiver Miami Caught at least one pass in 33 regular-season games, including 22 for TD's. 12 Phoenix Ken Harvey Linebacker California Made 200 tackles in two seasons at Cal; has 37 1/2-inch vertical leap. 13 Philadelphia Keith Jackson Tight End Oklahoma Tough blocker with excellent speed (4.67 in the 40). 14 L.A. Rams Gaston Green Running Back U.C.L.A. Most prolific runner in Bruin history with 3,731 yards on 708 carries. 15 San Diego Anthony Miller Wide Receiver Tennessee Missed most of 1987 with a knee injury. 16 Miami Eric Kumerow Linebacker Ohio State Had not been projected as first-rounder. Reminds scouts of Ted Hendricks. 17 New England John Stephens Running Back N.W. Louisiana First small-college player picked. A bruising 217-pounder who runs a 4.38 40. 18 Pittsburgh Aaron Jones Def. Tackle E. Kentucky Future may be at defensive end; had 264 career tackles. 19 Minnesota Randall McDaniel Off. Guard Arizona State Won Morris Trophy last year as top offensive lineman in Pac-10. 20 L.A. Rams Aaron Cox Wide Receiver Arizona State He had 38 receptions for 760 yards last year. 21 Cleveland Clifford Charlton Linebacker Florida Led the S.E.C. with 23 tackles for a loss last year and had 70 tackles over all. 22 Houston Lorenzo White Running Back Michigan State Finished as best runner in Spartan history with 4,887 yards. 23 Chicago Brad Muster Running Back Stanford Can play halfback or fullback; turns the corner well and is a dangerous receiver. 24 New Orleans Craig Heyward Running Back Pittsburgh Gave up senior season to enter the draft; rushed for 1,791 yards last year. 25 L.A. Raiders Scott Davis Def. End Illinois A 6-7, 268-pound pass-rusher who led Illini with 10 sacks; runs the 40 in 4.7. 26 Denver Ted Gregory Nose Tackle Syracuse Missed several games last year with knee injury and had 57 tackles. 27 Chicago Wendell Davis Wide Receiver Louisiana State Caught 80 passes for 1,244 yards last season, both school records.

title: Capitals Defeat Devils, 4-1
description: The Capitals resorted to their strength, skating rather than fighting, and the strategy brought them success as they evened the Patrick Division final series at two games apiece tonight with a 4-1 victory over the Devils.

title: Farm Bank Issue Among Sales This Week
description: Treasury financings this week include today's regular auction of three-month and six-month bills and Wednesday's auction of two-year notes, which are sold every month.

title: The Strategy Behind Global Business
description: ABOUT 20,000 American decision makers in business, government and especially communications will be receiving Global Business magazine in the mail this week, while 30,000 copies will be distributed to the same groups in 10 other countries.

title: Review/Television; Stacy Keach as Ernest Hemingway
description: A lavish, six-hour film biography, ''Hemingway,'' begins unfolding on Channel 11 at 8 this evening (the second half will be broadcast next Monday). Starring Stacy Keach, this is a thoroughly serious and generally intelligent effort to capture the essence of the man and the writer, relying primarily on ''Collected Letters 1917-1961'' and Carlos Baker's ''Hemingway: a Life Story.''

title: Bush Delegate Majority Is Expected Tomorrow
description: Vice President Bush is poised to receive enough delegates to clinch the Republican Presidential nomination in the Pennsylvania primary Tuesday, but his campaign is not planning much ado.

title: Conover Is Winner of U.S. Trial
description: The United States men's Olympic marathon team was determined today on a chilly, windy afternoon during which 108 racers competed for three spots on the team going to Seoul, South Korea, and $95,000 in prize money.

title: Papers Move to Lighter Newsprint
description: The nation's newspapers have begun moving toward the use of lightweight newsprint, according to some industry experts.

title: A. J. Isserman, a Labor Lawyer, Dies at 88
description: Abraham J. Isserman, a longtime labor lawyer and a member of the defense team during the cold war conspiracy trial of the top leadership of the American Communist Party, died Friday in a Manhattan nursing home after a series of strokes. He was 88 years old.

title: Video Chains May Merge
description: The Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation and the Major Video Corporation said they have been discussing a possible merger.

title: Review/Concert; The Laurentian Quartet
description: The most magical moment of the Laurentian String Quartet's concert, on Saturday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, came at the point in the Shostakovich Eighth Quartet where the world-weary opening slow movement suddenly becomes an allegro molto. The players did not merely shift gears; they rocked into the fast movement with an intense, savage energy and an almost orchestral heft, as if an emotional dam had suddenly burst. The score winds down again, but the Laurentians maintained a soul-stirring drive to the end.

title: Goalie Tries Again, Succeeds
description: Just as everything seemed to be going so well for the hitherto beleaguered Capitals, Clint Malarchuk watched the goaltender Pete Peeters collapse to the ice tonight after being struck in the forehead by a wrist shot from John MacLean.

title: Katherine Ann Freygang Marries Donald K. Flagg
description: Katherine Ann Freygang, a graphic designer, and Donald Kerr Flagg, an architect, were married yesterday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden by the Rev. Bernard Poppe, an Episcopal priest.

title: Leslie Reed Married To Matthew J. Ferro
description: Leslie Allison Reed, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Reed of Dix Hills, L.I., and Matthew Jonathan Ferro, a son of Daniel E. Ferro of New York and the late Beth Hollinger Ferro, were married yesterday at Temple Shaaray Tefila in New York. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum officiated.

title: Mexico's Air Travel In Turmoil
description: The Mexican Government's decision to allow a state-owned airline to declare bankruptcy may bring a sweeping overhaul of the country's inefficient and highly regulated air transport system, Government officials and airline analysts say.

title: Nancy Glimcher Is Wed To Dr. Brian Kushman
description: Nancy Blair Glimcher, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Melvin J. Glimcher of Chestnut Hill and Menemsha, Mass., and Dr. Brian S. Kushman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving A. Kushman of Miami Beach, were married yesterday. Rabbi Gary Glickstein performed the ceremony at the Biltmore Hotel in Miami Beach.

title: Key Official Replaced At Doyle Graf Mabley
description: About the time Friday morning that Thomas Mabley, executive vice president and United States creative director, was learning that he no longer worked for Doyle Graf Mabley a press release was being prepared in which William S. Doyle, president of the agency, said, ''Tom, who joined us after a highly successful stint at Lord, Geller, has wanted to get back into a larger agency setting.''

title: Dr. Kay Haedicke Weds in Westport
description: Dr. Kay Ann Haedicke, a fellow in hematology and oncology at the Yale University School of Medicine, and Dr. Roger Lowlicht, an oral and maxillo-facial surgeon in North Haven, Conn., were married yesterday at the Inn at Longshore in Westport, Conn. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey and the Rev. Peter Kuritz, a Lutheran minister, officiated.

title: Lawyer for Pirelli to Head Its U.S. Holding Company
description: Robert M. Kaufman's term is coming to an end next month as president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, but the free time that he had anticipated may be consumed by his new duties as chairman of the Pirelli Enterprises Corporation, the American holding company for the Italian tire maker.

title: Orthodox Jewish Psychotherapists Face Conflicts
description: If science and religion may sometimes seem to conflict, the relationship between Orthodox Jewry and psychotherapy - largely seen as the creation of Sigmund Freud, the apostate Jew -has a special poignancy.

title: Marjorie Snyder Wed
description: Marjorie Snyder, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Snyder of Cranbury, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Wold, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Wold of Marlboro, N.J. Rabbi David Gelfand performed the ceremony at the Scanticon-Princeton hotel in Princeton, N.J. The bride is a community relations assistant at the State University College at Purchase, N.Y. Dr. Wold is a resident in radiology at New York Medical College in Valhalla, N.Y.

title: Revlon Job to Y.&R.
description: Revlon has named Young & Rubicam as agency of record for all network television buying, and assigned it the Flex line of hair care products. The TV assignment had been at Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, and Flex had been in house. This is Y.&R.'s first Revlon assignment and the first beauty product since it lost Oil of Olay earlier this decade.

title: Toll in Lebanese Explosion Is 66; Moslem Leaders Blame Christians
description: Relief workers continued to search for survivors of a car bomb explosion in the northern Lebanese city of Tripoli today as the number of dead rose to 66, the police said.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * West German banks have agreed to reduce the working week of their 390,000 employees by an hour, to 39 hours, according to representatives of two unions. Employees will also receive a 3.4 percent pay raise. In exchange, the unions have agreed to allow more flexible working hours for bank employees.

title: RIDING THE CYCLIST'S PATH TO BETTER HEALTH AND HEART RATE
description: FOR most people, there is a golden memory of the time a father, an older sibling or a friend's parent trotted alongside, a hand on the seat or handlebars, steadying us as we wobbled about learning to ride a bicycle. The moment of triumph - no adult help, no training wheels, real freedom - is one of life's singular pleasures.

title: ACID RAIN IS CALLED PERIL FOR SEA LIFE ON ATLANTIC COAST
description: Acid rain, already recognized as a serious threat to fresh-water organisms, is also contributing far more to the degradation of marine life in Atlantic coastal waters than previously recognized, according to a new report.

title: Britain Team Ban Deferred in Budd Row
description: A decision on whether to ban Zola Budd, a South African-born runner, was deferred today as the threat of Britain's entire track and field team being banned from world athletics appeared to evaporate.

title: Conquering the Ups and Downs of Running Hills
description: SPRING is here and the hills are alive with the sounds of runners' footsteps.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Beck Finishes 26 Under: Chip Beck, three shots in front at the start of play, birdied four of his first six holes and shot an 8-under-par 64 yesterday at the Lakewood Country Club to win the U.S.F.&G. Classic in New Orleans by seven strokes. Beck, who scored the first victory of his 10-year PGA Tour career in Los Angeles earlier this season, won with a 262 total, 26 under par. He broke the course and tournament record of 267 set by Lee Trevino in 1974.

title: Honduras Says Sandinistas Destroyed a Village, Killing 2
description: Nicaraguan troops destroyed a village in a remote part of eastern Honduras, killing two Hondurans and wounding 17 in a ''perverse and cowardly'' incursion on April 13, the Honduran military said today.

title: I.R.S. Closes Loophole That Added Revenue
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Two Grand National Team events reached a climax in the New York metropolitan area over the weekend.

title: Canada Losing Patience With U.S. on Acid Rain
description: In the view of many Canadians no prime minister in the country's 128-year history has been as consistently pro-American as Brian Mulroney, the Conservative from Quebec who has pledged his political survival on a repudiation of the wariness that has traditionally characterized Canada's attitude toward the United States.

title: Victor Holt Jr., 79, Ex-Goodyear President
description: Victor Holt Jr., a former president of the Goodyear Tire Company, died at his home Friday of Parkinson's disease. He was 79 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Expansion Plan for CNN
description: The Cable News Network, the 24-hour cable television operation owned by Turner Broadcasting System Inc., plans to expand its broadcasts to South America.

title: A Magazine Reflects a Shift in the British Left
description: The magazine has more than tripled its circulation during the 1980's, the era of the ''enterprise culture'' in Britain under the free-market policies of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Its standing is such that leading journalists from The Economist and The Financial Times write for the magazine without payment, and it is read with respect by many of the intellectual torchbearers of Thatcherism.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
CMS Enterprises Picks A 32-Year-Old President
description: LEAD: Eric O. Fornell made the social leap from the blue-collar neighborhoods of northeast Detroit to the promenades of nearby Grosse Pointe by a roundabout path through Oxford and Wall Street.

title: Divestment Is Opposed
description: A vast majority of the chief executives of 120 of the biggest United States companies oppose the divestment of business interests in South Africa, according to a Northwestern University survey.

title: Cuing In
description: Under the hanging light fixture, she chalked her pink cue, crouched to line up her shot and then declared to the official, ''Six ball in the cross-corner pocket.'' Click. Plunk. Jennifer Schmidt, from Jersey City, and a 22-year-old senior at William Paterson College in Wayne, N.J., was competing over the weekend in the women's division in the Association of College Unions International pocket billiards tournament.

title: Lendl Outlasts Jaite
description: Ivan Lendl, the world's top-ranked tennis player, came back from a two-month layoff to win the Monte Carlo Open today, defeating Martin Jaite of Argentina, 5-7, 6-4, 7-5, 6-3, in a match that lasted almost four hours.

title: Rivals See Koch Weakened, But Not Easy to Beat at Polls
description: As Mayor Koch's rivals and critics look ahead to challenging him next year, they are also beginning to look back to the last time they tried to defeat him, and their conclusion is this: It won't be easy.

title: Tax Watch; Some Surprises For the Affluent
description: IT will be some time before the Internal Revenue Service is able to provide even a preliminary analysis of how taxpayers actually fared in their first encounter with the Tax Reform Act of 1986. But in reviewing client returns, accountants spotted several trends, some of which ran counter to earlier expectations.

title: Review/Recital; Emanuel Ax Plays Chopin
description: Emanuel Ax performs so often in New York, either as soloist or teamed in recital with the cellist Yo Yo Ma, that it is all too easy to take his considerable gifts at the keyboard for granted. Among them are a remarkably fluent technique, the most shimmering and velvety of tones, and a wonderfully natural way with rubato. To hear the pianist perform the familiar Chopin Polonaise-Fantaisie as he did on Friday evening in Carnegie Hall is to hear these qualities on display. This was playing of rare intelligence, intimacy and a quiet, steady grace.

title: Decade of the Child: a Modest Start
description: Governor Cuomo, in his State of the State address this year, argued that New York's economic survival may depend upon guaranteeing its poor children a fair chance. He declared the next 10 years ''The Decade of the Child.'' If the fiscal 1989 budget is any guide, the decade is off to a modest start.

title: Pacific Telesis Names New Chief Executive
description: The Pacific Telesis Group, the California-based Bell System holding company, has announced the election of Sam Ginn as chairman and chief executive. Mr. Ginn had been vice chairman of the group, as well as president and chief executive of the Pactel Corporation, which controls the diversified businesses of Pacific Telesis.

title: Washington Leads Way in Housing for the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada to Press on Acid Rain
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada, in a visit to Washington this week, is expected to press for American action on acid rain. Page A10.

title: Japanese-U.S. Venture
description: The Kawasaki Steel Corporation has agreed to work with SDA Systems Inc., a United States software concern, in using computer-aided design technology to develop large-scale integrated circuits, a Kawasaki spokesman said Friday. SDA, a San Jose, Calif., producer of computer-aided design programs, will provide its software to Kawasaki Steel at preferential prices under the agreement, he said.

title: PC Magazine to Gamble on Soviet
description: For a $300 million company, $250,000 is hardly a big gamble.

title: Knicks Bask in Unlikely Role
description: As Trent Tucker was leaving La Guardia Airport yesterday morning after the flight from Indianapolis, an elderly woman passenger said to the Knicks' guard: ''I wish you win all your games.''

title: Maritime Trade Stance by U.S.
description: The United States will continue to seek fairer maritime trade practices in Far Eastern and Asian countries, a senior United States Transportation Department official said.

title: Giants Beef Up The Line
description: This year's National Football League draft was especially rich in highly-rated offensive tackles ranging from 6 feet 4 inches to 6 feet 7 inches and from 276 pounds to 305 pounds. George Young, the Giants' general manager and a 300-pounder himself, called it the Dance of the Elephants.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: R.F.K. Remembered, 20 Years Later
description: Bennett Kayser was a college student on June 5, 1968. He was among campaign workers hoping to see Senator Robert F. Kennedy, who was to be mortally wounded in the Ambassador Hotel just after winning the California Democratic primary.

title: Jordan's 46 Points Lift Bulls
description: Michael Jordan, the National Basketball Association's leading scorer for the second consecutive season, had 46 points today as the Chicago Bulls held off the Boston Celtics, 115-108, in the regular-season finale for the teams.

title: Kenya to Receive Funds
description: The World Bank is to lend Kenya $122 million for industrial development and West Germany will make a grant of 152 million marks, or $91 million, to finance development projects, George Saitoti, the Finance Minister, said. Mr. Saitoti made the announcement Saturday as he returned from a trip to the United States and West Germany. Economists said Kenya had been negotiating an industrial-sector support loan with the World Bank for some time. In 1986, the Washington-based lending institution lent Kenya $60 million to modernize its agricultural sector.

title: Corporate Takeovers Favor Shareholders
description: To the Editor:

title: Bills on Jobs for Welfare Mothers: Limited Impact in New York
description: Federal legislation intended to help single mothers get off welfare rolls and into jobs will provide some new funds but is unlikely to produce dramatic changes in New York City welfare programs, city and state officials say.

title: Backer to Acquire Stake in Korean Agency
description: Backer Spielvogel Bates has reached an agreement to acquire a minority position in Diamond Advertising of Seoul, becoming the first American agency to own a piece of the R.O.K.

title: Oslo Extends Its Oil Curb
description: Norway said Friday that it would extend until the end of the year its voluntary 7.5 percent cutback in the planned growth of petroleum production.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday G.N.P. First Quarter Corporate Profits Fourth Quarter (Rev) Wednesday Personal Income March Thursday None Friday New-Home Sales March Prices of New Homes March Leading Indicators March Farm Prices April

title: Warhol Cookie Jars Sell for $247,830
description: Andy Warhol loved cookie jars. So do hundreds of others among the 10,000 who filled Sotheby's galleries yesterday as if it were Bloomingdale's at Christmas time. They came from Florida and Paris and Halifax, Nova Scotia, to browse and bid at the auction of the Pop artist's collection of 175 pottery jars, including pigs, mice, goats, sheep, Humpty Dumpty and a plump panda.

title: Technology Centers Named
description: Industries trying to capitalize on superconducting technology will get help from three Federal research centers under a program announced by the Energy Department.

title: Wicks Moves One Step Closer to Seoul
description: They stood in the center of the gymnasium late Saturday night, 50 anxious young women, all with lumps in their throats the size of a basketball. One by one, Kay Yow, the Olympic coach, called the names of the lucky 21 who survived the first round of cuts that moved them a step closer to Seoul, South Korea, and the Summer Olympics.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Helping the Hunters
description: The debate over the rights of animals versus the rights of hunters has a new venue, the Capitol, where some members of the Senate and House have introduced legislation on behalf of the hunters.

title: A Nightmare For the Arabs And for Israel
description: LEAD: An independent Palestinian state would pose well-known dangers to Israel and the United States, but a close look shows that if such a state ever came into existence the biggest losers would be the Arabs. The citizens of this state would suffer human rights abuses, and Arab states in the neighborhood would be threatened by a whole range of new dangers.

title: Irene Rich, Silent-Screen Actress And Radio Personality, Dies at 96
description: Irene Rich, the urbane star of scores of silent films of the 1920's and a popular radio personality of the 30's, died of heart failure Friday at her home in Hope Ranch, Calif., outside Santa Barbara. She was 96 years old.

title: News Summary
description: International A2-10 Chernobyl still has problems two years after an explosion and fire. The nuclear power station is riddled with negligence, and managers have ignored safety regulations, the Soviet newspaper Pravda charged. Page A1 Soviet economic change has failed so far to produce much growth or raise living standards, despite the ambitious programs of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, according to a U.S. intelligence analysis. D1 A careful call for religious freedom in the Soviet Union was delivered by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who attended a Mass at the Georgian Orthodox Cathedral in Tbilisi before leaving for Brussels. A7 Anti-missile systems using rockets instead of lasers are vulnerable to equipment and computer software failures that would make them unworkable, according to a Congressional research agency. A8 President Mitterrand took the lead over Prime Minister Jacques Chirac in the elimination round of France's presidential elections and appeared to be the front-runner in a run-off vote against Mr. Chirac on May 8. A1 Yasir Arafat arrived in Damascus in an a effort to achieve a reconcilliation with Syria after a five-year rift. The P.L.O. chairman is expected to meet President Hafez al-Assad for talks on the Middle East. A1 Israel reopened the West Bank and Gaza Strip for the first time in a week and ended the 24-hour curfews. Army officials said the steps were rewards for ''relative calm'' in the occupied territories. A3 A gold rush in Brazil's jungles has drawn at least 500,000 people into the country's wild interior, where, with primitive tools, they have made Brazil the world's fifth-largest gold producer. A10 South Vietnam's middle class all but disappeared after the war ended in 1975. While many Southeast Asians have risen to higher income levels in the last decade, many in Vietnam have sunk to the peasantry. A4 Prime Minister Brian Mulroney will push Washington for more cooperation on the problem of acid rain when the Canadian leader meets President Reagan and addresses a joint meeting of Congress on Wednesday. A10 Toll in Lebanese explosion is 66; Moslems blame Christians A2 Consultation is pledged on gulf role A3 A restive island tribe adds to Noriega's woes A6 National A14-19, B6-7 An explosion and fire aboard the sub-marine U.S.S. Bonefish yesterday left 18 sailors injured, three in serious condition, and 3 of the 92-member crew missing, according to the Navy. A1 Acid rain's effects on the Atlantic coastal waters is greater than previously recognized, according to a report, and contributed to large, temporary die-offs of marine life along the northeastern coast. A1 Overcrowding in the nation's prisons is forcing officials to reassess sentencing practices. But despite the costs of building new prisons, a widespread fear of crime makes a dramatic shift in policies unlikely. A1 Academic performance remains low in American primary and secondary schools, according to Secretary of Education William J. Bennett, despite movements over the last five years to raise standards. A1 Resignations of top Justice officials have left no one at the Department to push several important legal initiatives sought by the Reagan Administration but have not affected day-to-day operations, officials say. A16 A $1.2 billion takeover offer for J. P. Stevens & Company, among the biggest textile producers in the country, has been accepted from West Point-Pepperell Inc., a major competitor. D1 Years Later, 'R.F.K. Remembered' A14 Politics B6 Pennsylvania has voted contrary to national political trends, voting more Democratic than the rest of the nation in Presidential elections since 1952. But Republicans have done better in statewide races. B6 Vice President Bush is on the verge of winning enough delegates to secure the Republican Presidential nomination in Tuesday's Pennsylvania primary, a week earlier than had been expected. B6 Dukakis stumps on message of hope B6 Jackson challenges Dukakis's plans for domestic projects B6 Washington Talk A18 Air force and Marines battle 'ticket-punchers' Regional B1-5 Mayor Koch's political opponents acknowledge that it will not be easy to take advantage of his weaknesses as they look ahead to challenging him in the Democratic mayoral primary that is 17 months away. A1 A middle-class migration to Harlem has taken place over the past decade as a small but growing number of well-educated blacks has moved there, hoping, in part, to spark a renaissance. B1 Graduates of the 1968 student strike at Columbia University returned for a reunion, and 20 years after occupying five buildings on the Morningside Heights campus, many still proclaim their political involvement. B1 Problems in the prosecution's case will prevent the conviction of two men accused of murdering a New York City police detective, predicted a Queens minister who served on the jury that deadlocked in the case. B2 Public services in New York City are not equal to what the public pays, according to a report by a citizens group. It rated refuse collection excellent, street cleaning poor and other services passable. B3 Legislation to help single mothers move off welfare and find jobs, now in Congress, will provide some new funds but is unlikely to produce dramatic changes in New York City's welfare programs, officials say. B3 Metro Matters: Long Island grappling with growth B1 Orthodox Jewish psychotherapists and their conflicts B2 Love of guns and applause for Goetz B3

title: ARAFAT IS IN SYRIA FOR FENCE MENDING
description: Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, arrived unexpectedly in Damascus today in an effort to seal a reconciliation with Syria after five years of fierce rivalry.

title: Placid Seeks to Sell Asset
description: The Placid Oil Company, which is owned by the Hunt brothers, has asked a United States Bankruptcy Court judge for permission to sell part of its Green Canyon offshore oil project to pay for cost overruns.

title: Metro Matters; L.I. Grappling With Growth, Fears and Goals
description: The Indians who greeted Henry Hudson referred to it as ''the long island.'' After determining how long and that it was, indeed, an island, Adrian Block named it T Lange Eilandt.

title: 'Maturation of Fanship'
description: IT'S a sports crowd unlike any other. But it's not that big a crowd. Even with a few more yesterday than in recent years, it added up to only 700 or so. There's not even an admission charge. Just show up early enough and take a number, like you do in a bakery. As early as 3:15 yesterday morning, with the sidewalks of Times Square winding down after another Saturday night, the first of this year's National Football League draftniks arrived in the Marriott Marquis lobby. And now, under the eight crystal chandeliers of the Broadway Ballroom, most of the draftniks were hushed as the Jets pondered their first-round choice. But some draftniks were in full uniform. And in full cry. ''Irvin, Irvin, Irvin,'' several were chanting. ''Irvin, Irvin, Irvin.'' One of those draftniks was wearing a green Jets sweatshirt, another a blue-and-red-trimmed white Giants jersey with 56 on the back. Together, they were pleading for the Jets, who have made several forgettable choices in recent years, to take Michael Irvin, a wide receiver from the University of Miami. But when the chanting stopped, another voice was heard. ''Don't even think about it,'' that voice yelled. At the lectern minutes later, Commissioner Pete Rozelle announced, ''The New York Jets have selected David Cadigan, tackle, Southern California.'' Many of the draftniks applauded, but some booed, including those who had been chanting for Irvin. Then they erupted in another chant. ''Joe must go,'' they yelled. ''Joe must go.'' This, of course, was a revival of the lyrics that serenaded Coach Joe Walton late in the Jets' 6-9 season that dropped them into the American Conference East dungeon last year.

title: San Francisco Journal; Asian Children Play Amid Despair
description: At 3 o'clock in the afternoon, the school buses arrive in the Tenderloin district, disgorging a cargo of scampering, shrieking children who immediately transform these tawdry streets into a gentler neighborhood.

title: Moderately Higher Inflation Forecast
description: The United States appears to be entering a period of moderately higher inflation in which the general price level could rise 5 percent or more a year into the early 1990's, many economists and business executives maintain.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the South African novelist Alan Paton on April 13 misstated his birthdate. He was born Jan. 11, 1903.

title: Guess Who Lost Again? Orioles Fall, 3-1
description: The Baltimore Orioles sunk to 0-18 today and stumbled closer to the worst losing streak in history as the Kansas City Royals beat them, 3-1, behind Bret Saberhagen's six-hitter.

title: Agency Seeks Assurances Over Bridge
description: Some time in the next 10 days a BMT subway train is expected to clack across the Williamsburg Bridge for the first time since the structure was closed two weeks ago for public safety. For the riders, it will largely be a matter of trust that the bridge is once again safe.

title: 3 Missing and 18 Injured in Fire Aboard a U.S. Diesel Submarine
description: An explosion and fire today aboard the diesel submarine U.S.S. Bonefish injured 18 sailors, three of them seriously, and left three crew members missing, the Navy reported.

title: Krone Hurt In a Spill
description: Julie Krone, the leading female jockey in racing history, will be sidelined indefinitely after suffering an injury to her left arm in a spill at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Top-Secret, and Vulnerable
description: Concern is mounting among Government and private security experts that the computers storing the nation's secrets are vulnerable to penetration.

title: Books of The Times; Canine Consciousness and the Call of Hollywood
description: The White German Shepherd By Vicki Hearne 205 pages. The Atlantic Monthly Press. $16.95.

title: Jackson Challenges Dukakis Over Funds For Programs in U.S.
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts ducked a challenge from the Rev. Jesse Jackson Saturday night to ''put some money on the table'' to pay for domestic programs.

title: 6 City Services Rated by Panel: 5 Are Passable
description: New York City's refuse collection is ''excellent,'' its street cleaning ''poor'' and other services - police, fire, correction and waste disposal - merely warrant a ''passing'' grade, according to a report released yesterday by the private Citizens Budget Commission.

title: Slimmer Bureaucracy, Safer Skies
description: Is flying safe? No doubt about it, the President's Aviation Safety Commission says reassuringly in its new report. But air safety could deteriorate unless regulators are given the bureaucratic incentives and financial resources to keep up with the rapidly changing needs of the air traffic system.

title: Would-Be Stars Live on the Edge
description: Pat Petersen, the 28-year-old from Lake Ronkonkoma, L.I., was supposed to have gotten his ticket to the Seoul Olympics today. But he lost his chance for that glory between miles 10 and 11 of the Olympic Marathon Trial when he got a side stitch.

title: Cuomo Urged to Create Linear Park Panel
description: A citizens committee yesterday recommended the appointment of a Governor's council to create a linear park along the Hudson River stretching 150 miles from the New York City border to Troy - a Hudson River Greenway.

title: 8 Policemen Wounded in New Caledonia Vote
description: Melanesian separatists wounded eight French policemen today in an attempt to disrupt elections in this French Pacific island territory.

title: Lots of Surprises After First Pick
description: He clutched the red and white Atlanta Falcons jersey that had a huge No. 93 on it and grinned as cameras clicked and onlookers gushed. For Aundray Bruce, the first college player selected in the National Football League draft yesterday, no surprise meant the best gift of all.

title: Wrong Victim
description: A woman killed a man by running over his head with her car, the police said, adding that she then told them she had mistaken the man for her boyfriend, with whom she had quarreled. The woman, Donna Faye Williams, 31 years old, was charged Friday with first-degree murder in the death of Joel Robinson, 28. Ms. Williams told the police she had mistaken Mr. Robinson for Louis Teague, 31.

title: Imagine a Palestinian State
description: LEAD: Under a Palestinian state in the West Bank and Gaza, which surely will be democratic and secular, Palestinian Arabs and Israeli Jews will be bonded in a political order not yet experienced in the Middle East.

title: 'Pigtown' at Brandeis U. Protests Food Policy
description: A group of Brandeis University students who say that the serving of pork and shellfish in campus dining halls is an affront to Judaism staged a protest today in which they erected a cluster of shanties and called it ''pigtown.''

title: What the Elderly Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Stewart Named Publisher at Scribner's
description: Robert Stewart has been named publisher of Charles Scribner's Sons, a part of the Macmillan Publishing Company. He will also retain the title of editor in chief.

title: CHERNOBYL PLANT BEING MISMANAGED, PRAVDA CHARGES
description: Two years after it was the scene of the world's worst nuclear accident, the Chernobyl power station is riddled with negligence and nepotism, Pravda charged today.

title: 2 Jai Alai Frontons Closed By Connecticut Amid Strike
description: Jai alai frontons in Hartford and Bridgeport, in the 11th day of a players' strike, were shut down today by the Connecticut Division of Special Revenue after complaints of strikers harassing fans and replacement players.

title: Reviews/Music; Polonaises in Pianist's Debut
description: David Nish's piano program at Weill Recital Hall on Sunday offered occasions of such promise that it was difficult to reconcile them with the afternoon's less successful moments. Mr. Nish, who won his debut here through an Artists International audition, began and ended with polonaises - the first by Beethoven, the other by Chopin. In both, he understood very well how to make dance rhythms cede and surge.

title: Immobile Phones
description: For the desperately upwardly mobile who really can't afford it, there's hope in the trendy town of Los Altos, Calif. A company called Faux Systems has created the Cellular Phoney, an inexpensive fake car phone that looks like the real thing. The company's motto: ''It's not what you own; it's what people think you own.'' Faux Systems has already sold 45,000 of the phones (at $16, including fake antennas), and after a story about the Phoney in The Times last week, the firm's real phones started ringing off the hook.

title: 'Medical Michelangelo' Nears Finish Of Comprehensive Anatomical Atlas
description: DR. Frank H. Netter, an artist who has probably contributed more to medical education than most of the world's anatomy professors taken together, celebrated his 82d birthday yesterday. But he will be back at work today on the medical illustrations that have made him famous.

title: Giants and Jets Set To Pound Away; Parcells Likes Size on Line
description: The Giants completed the National Football League draft today by taking nine more players, including one more big offensive lineman and a record-breaking quarterback.

title: Giants and Jets Set To Pound Away; Walton Hopes For Quick Help
description: When the second day of the National Football League draft ended yesterday, the Jets had three offensive lineman and four defensive backs among their 12 picks. There wasn't one glamour player in the lot, except a running back from Eastern Michigan, Gary Patton, who was taken on the seventh round.

title: Canada to Act On Japanese
description: The Canadian Government is expected to give its approval this week to applications by three of Japan's largest securities firms to establish operations in Canada.

title: U.S. Extends Embargo On Nicaraguan Trade
description: Declaring the Sandinista Government a continued threat to national security, President Reagan today extended for a fourth year a United States trade embargo against Nicaragua.

title: Prison Wardens' Power To Censor Is Considered
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to consider giving Federal prison officials broader power to restrict the access of prisoners to publications the officials do not want them to read.

title: Chess
description: The 13th Lugano International Open Tournament in Switzerland illustrated the drawback of Swiss-system competition - the tendency to produce multiple winners. In Lugano there were seven: the grandmasters Lubomir Ftacnik of Czechoslovakia, Eugenio Torre of the Philippines, Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland, Lev Psakhis of the Soviet Union, and Kevin Spraggett of Canada and the international masters David Norwood of Britain and Klaus Bischoff of West Germany.

title: Leo Frenkel, 92, Dies; Insurance Executive
description: Leo S. Frenkel, a former honorary chairman of Frenkel & Company, an insurance brokerage firm in Manhattan, died of heart failure Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 92 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Careers; Customized Financial Training
description: TWO emigrants from Wall Street, Peter Mathias, 36 years old, and Jeffrey Hansen, 30, have developed techniques for providing customized training to financial services companies, which traditionally train their younger staff members in-house. One of their first assignments will be for Citicorp's North American Investment Bank.

title: U.S.-Soviet Dialogue On Global Warming
description: Scientists in the United States and the Soviet Union, linked through desk top computers, have begun a conference on what the two nations can do to cope with an expected global warming caused by the ''greenhouse effect.''

title: INSIDE
description: Saudis to Join Atom Pact Riyadh will join the treaty limiting the spread of nuclear weapons, the Saudi press agency said. No details or signing date were given. Page A10. Navy Submarine Burns Explosions and fire on a 30-year-old Navy submarine in the Atlantic injured 23 men aboard. Rescue workers are searching for three crew members still missing. Page A14. An African Success Story A trip to Abidjan, the capital of the Ivory Coast, can be an unsettling experience, one that defies Westerners' expectations about Africa. Page A6. Lasers on the Battlefield Lasers on the modern battlefield are almost as dangerous to friend as to foe, prompting new defensive measures. Science Times, page C1. Scarlett Sequel Is Sold Warner Books last night bid $4.94 million at auction for rights to the sequel to ''Gone With the Wind.'' Page C17.

title: Campaigning For Assembly Ends in Korea
description: An 18-day campaign for legislative elections ended tonight with the Government party widely forecast to win a majority ranging from safe to resounding.

title: Final Payments for Japanese Internees
description: Congress is about to pass a bill offering token payments and apologies to Japanese-Americans interned during World War II. But President Reagan is said to be uncertain about signing it. Not to do so would interrupt justice for all. This legislation responds to the needs of the victims, and to the nation's need to make amends.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; John Emmerling Hires a New President
description: John Emmerling Inc. has been without a president since James R. Guthrie left last November to become executive vice president of the Magazine Publishers of America.

title: Jordan River Project Could Help Peace Bloom
description: To the Editor:

title: Legal Perversion
description: Managers of the Legal Services Corporation are supposed to get money from Congress to pay lawyers who represent the poor. But President Reagan's appointees perversely hired high-priced Washington law firms for advice - on how to reduce the agency's appropriation.

title: Beazer Cites Tally Of Koppers Shares
description: The British building group Beazer P.L.C. said that it had been offered more than half the shares of the Koppers Company, the Pittsburgh-based construction materials concern, under a hostile takeover offer of $1.7 billion. But a United States District Court order is keeping Beazer from acquiring the shares, a company spokesman said.

title: Lasers for the Battlefield Raise Concern for Eyesight
description: LASERS, which have become nearly as common as guns in modern armies, are making battlefields so dangerous for friends as well as foes that arms makers are racing to devise new shields against them.

title: France at Crossroads; Le Pen Vote Shatters Unity of Right And Threatens Nation's Social Peace
description: The first round of balloting in France's two-stage presidential election Sunday did more than designate President Francois Mitterrand as the odds-on favorite for victory in two weeks. It signaled, in the apt metaphor of Jean-Marie Le Pen, the exultant leader of the ultra-right National Front, ''a political earthquake.''

title: 2 Players Ineligible
description: The N.C.A.A. has ruled that two former Memphis State players who admitted dealing with an agent have lost their eligibility to play college basketball.

title: Talking Business: with Morosky of Federated; A Retail Empire Takes Shape
description: On Friday the Campeau Corporation, the Canadian developer, will take control of Federated Department Stores Inc., the largest operator of department stores in the United States. The completion of the $6.6 billion takeover concludes an 11-week battle in which Campeau bested R.H. Macy & Company. Campeau agreed to allow Macy to buy two Federated divisions, Bullocks-Bullock's Wilshire and I. Magnin, for withdrawing from the fight.

title: Knick-Celtic Rivalry Goes Beyond the Court
description: A playoff pairing between teams with the best and worst records in their conference - such as the Western matchup between the Los Angeles Lakers and the San Antonio Spurs - is usually considered a yawner. But this year the Eastern Conference pairs the Knicks and the Celtics.

title: U.S. Preparing to Relax Some Panama Sanctions
description: Expressing misgivings about the sweeping American sanctions imposed on the economy of Panama, an Administration official said today that the curbs would be relaxed ''within a week or so.''

title: New Art Show Sent By Soviet
description: An exhibition of 90 early 20th-century Russian and Soviet paintings is to open July 12 at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, the Smithsonian Institution announced today.

title: Jordan River Project Could Help Peace Bloom; Land Day Bitterness
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Video Retailers Agree to Merge
description: The Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation has agreed to acquire the Major Video Corporation in a stock transaction valued at about $56 million. The merger would combine the nation's top two video retailers.

title: Mother in Baby Drowning Released on Bail
description: The Brooklyn woman who said she drowned her infant son to stop his colick-induced crying was released yesterday afternoon from Rikers Island, a spokeswoman for the Correction Department said.

title: Partylock at Elaine's: 25 Years of First Names
description: The first names came out last night for Elaine. Unthinkable that they would have stayed home when the East Side celebrity saloon that bears Elaine Kaufman's first name was celebrating its 25th anniversary.

title: Ivory Coast: African Success Story Built on Rich Farms and Stable Politics
description: For a first-time visitor, a trip to this West African capital can be an unsettling experience, one that defies Westerners' expectations about Africa.

title: Students Will Manage $5 Million
description: In a test of whether amateurs can beat professionals at investing, Ohio State University said yesterday that it would take $5 million of its $245 million endowment and entrust it to undergraduate business students.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Pugh and Vilas Win: Jim Pugh of the United States and Guillermo Vilas of Argentina easily won first-round matches in the Grand Prix tournament in Hamburg yesterday. Pugh beat Alexander Mronz of West Germany, 6-1, 6-1. Vilas beat Francesco Cancelotti of Italy, 6-3, 6-2. (AP) 2 Seeded Players Lose: Fourth-seeded Jay Berger routed unseeded Gary Muller of South Africa 6-1, 6-1, in the first round of the United States Men's Clay Court Championships. Two seeded players lost. Milan Srejber of Czechoslovakia beat sixth-seeded Luiz Mattar of Brazil, 6-2, 6-2, and Marty Davis of Harbor Bay Isle, Calif., beat eighth-seeded Kelly Evernden of New Zealand, 6-7, 6-3, 7-6. The first tie-breaker score was 3-7; the second was 7-4.(AP) GOLF Cadet Is Top Medalist: Tom Ertner of Army shot 71-74 for a three-over-par 145 to gain medalist honors in the Metropolitan Golf Association Intercollegiate championship. St. John's earned the team title for the eighth time with a total of 452.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on April 13 about a West German court's decision to refer the case of Mohammed Hamadei to a juvenile court misstated the reason. The court said Mr. Hamadei was less than 21 years old when the 1985 hijacking of a Trans World Airlines plane was being planned; it did not say he was under 21 when the hijacking was carried out.

title: Mid-April Vehicle Sales Rose by 1.9%
description: Mid-April sales of new American-made cars and light trucks rose 1.9 percent from the comparable period last year, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: L.I. Authority Raises Offer To Buy Lilco
description: The Long Island Power Authority today increased by $137 million its $7.45 billion bid to buy the Long Island Lighting Company, voting to raise its offer for Lilco's common shares to $10 from $8.75.

title: Home Resales Up in March
description: Sales of existing homes, spurred by lower mortgage rates, edged up 2.5 percent in March, the National Association of Realtors said today.

title: Flooding Endangers Nile Delta, Expert Says
description: Over the next century, sinking land and rising seas will flood Egyptian lands where more than a million people now live, according to a researcher at the Smithsonian Institution.

title: Jordan River Project Could Help Peace Bloom; The Big Giveback
description: To the Editor:

title: Token of Gratitude
description: Although Steve Yzerman of the Detroit Red Wings is recovering from torn ligaments in his knee and is not expected to be ready to resume play for two or three more weeks, he got a pleasant surprise recently. When he got off a private jet hired by Mike Ilitch, owner of the Red Wings, to take him to a hospital in Madison, Wis., he was greeted by a messenger, who handed him an envelope from Ilitch. ''I didn't think anything of it until I got into the car,'' he said. ''Then I opened it up. Wow.'' In the envelope was a bonus of $50,000 for scoring 50 goals. Yzerman was hurt on March 1 in the game during which he scored goal No. 50.(AP)

title: Quantum Fighting Kansas City Action
description: The Quantum Fund N.V., a fund controlled by the New York money manager George Soros, has filed a lawsuit contending that Kansas City Southern Industries' repurchase of 11.3 percent of its stock from the New York investor Howard Kaskel was ''a waste of corporate assets.'' The lawsuit, filed in Delaware state court on April 12, seeks to block the repurchase. It was disclosed by Kansas City Southern in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: Appeal of 9 Companies On Asbestos Is Barred
description: The Supreme Court refused today to hear an appeal by nine former manufacturers of products containing asbestos that complained that they had improperly been denied a chance to show they did not know of potential hazards of their products decades ago.

title: Pitcher Suspended
description: Mitch Williams, a relief pitcher for the Rangers, was suspended for two games by the American League yesterday for his part in a brawl between Texas and the Boston Red Sox.

title: Japanese Bond Purchases Top Sales by $3.63 Billion
description: Japanese purchases of foreign bonds exceeded sales by $3.63 billion in March, compared with $9.48 billion in February, the Japan Securities Dealers Association said today.

title: Bridge
description: A foursome led by Alan Sontag of Manhattan and including Jim Cayne, also of Manhattan, and Matthew and Pamela Granovetter, both of Jamaica, Queens, scored a solid victory Sunday in the district Grand National Team championship and will advance to the national playoffs in Salt Lake City in July.

title: Review/Television; 'China Beach,' Women at War
description: ABC is testing still another limited series. ''China Beach'' is being introduced tonight at 9 as a television movie. Actually it's a two-hour pilot, introducing the key characters who, beginning tomorrow at 10 P.M., will strive mightily in several one-hour episodes to grab the ultimate ring on the television carousel: a contract for a full-fledged weekly series in the new fall season. ''China Beach'' is a good candidate for making it. When it's bad, it's incredibly embarrassing. But then when it's good, it's terrifically on target.

title: OPEC and Non-Members Will Meet Today on Prices
description: Major oil producers from inside and outside the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet in Vienna on Tuesday to try to fashion an agreement on controlling production and bolstering the price of oil.

title: Meese's Rough Ride
description: Edwin Meese 3d, the well traveled Attorney General, had an interrupted journey yesterday. He was traveling in the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Sabreliner from Washington toward Detroit when, at an altitude of about 32,000 feet, the aircraft's windshield cracked. The plane ''went into a pretty steep dive to make sure the windshield would not implode,'' said Pat Korten, a Justice Department spokesman. The plane made an emergency landing at Pittsburgh, where Mr. Meese boarded a commercial aircraft and continued his journey.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Joseph Mollo, 79, a Brooklyn Chiropractor
description: Dr. Joseph Mollo, a pharmacist and chiropractor, died from complications after a leg amputation Sunday at Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 79 years old and lived in the Bay Ridge section.

title: Yeutter Assails Japan Quotas
description: The Reagan Administration's top trade official accused Japan today of failing to make a serious effort to meet United States demands that Tokyo lift quotas on beef and citrus imports.

title: Fun List: Boccie to Rodeo
description: First there were the White Pages. Then the Yellow Pages. Now, the Green Pages have landed.

title: Review/Theater; Ignoring the Holocaust, in Congress's Own Words
description: Some subjects, the Holocaust prominent among them, are so inherently powerful that they almost defy dramatization. After the photographs of ovens and bodies, the testimony of survivors, the Eichmann trial, Anne Frank's diary, Eli Wiesel's books, the movie ''Shoah'' and so much more, what can the playwright do to stir us afresh?

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Catalyst Thermal Energy Corp., an operator of steam systems, elected Jay F. Kilkenny chief executive and John E. Donahue president and chief operating officer.

title: Brooklyn's Medical Examiner Beaten and Robbed on Street
description: Dr. Beverly Leffers, the acting Chief Medical Examiner of Brooklyn, was robbed last night by a man who struck her twice in the head with a pistol, forcing her to release her purse, the police said.

title: Profit Scoreboard
description: $ M,03,35,20,15 Net Income Percent Jan.-Mar. Change 1988 From '87 Allegheny Ludlum Corp. $20,400,000 +70.0 American Petrofina Inc. 30,400,000 +53.5 Amoco Corp. 469,000,000 +80.4 Asarco Inc. 46,200,000 *- Boeing Co. 136,000,000 +15.3 Browning-Ferris Industries 50,300,000 +33.8 Charter Medical Corp. 11,400,000 -19.7 Enserch Corp. 33,800,000 +50.2 Exxon Corp. 1,455,000,000 +36.0 Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. 95,300,000 -66.5 Hershey Foods Corp. 36,900,000 +12.2 Kroger Co. 40,300,000 -58.6 Lubrizol Corp. 23,800,000 -8.5 Masco Corp. 79,600,000 +43.4 Mobil Corp. 505,000,000 +100.4 Occidental Petroleum Corp. 113,000,000 +16.5 Sara Lee Corp. 77,000,000 +23.8 ServiceMaster L.P. 15,700,000 +8.3 USG Corp. 39,800,000 -53.2 See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Jail for Grape Sampling
description: A shopper landed in jail Saturday after an off-duty policeman spotted him popping grapes in his mouth as he walked through a supermarket produce section. ''They're taking me for eating grapes!'' yelled the shopper, Arthur Culberth, as he was taken in handcuffs from a Winn-Dixie grocery store in the Liberty City section of Miami. Mr. Culberth, 55 years old, was charged with theft and resisting arrest. He was released after spending a night in jail.

title: Market Place; Bank-Led Funds Beat the Market
description: COMMON stock funds administered by banks, as a group, slightly outperformed the stock market in the first quarter, according to CDA Investment Technologies Inc., a Rockville, Md., financial concern that tracks the performance of professional money managers at banks, insurance companies, mutual funds and private firms.

title: Review/Music; Trio From Texas Offers Novelties And War Horses
description: Academia Musica, a trio based in Texas, balanced novelties and war horses in its Weill Recital Hall concert on Sunday afternoon. The players - Clive Amor, violinist; William Lipman, clarinetist, and Louis Lowenstein, cellist - approached their labors with energy and commitment to their labors, but they have a great deal of work before them in matters of interpretive subtlety and overall polish.

title: Some Shuttle Fares Cut
description: Both Eastern Air Lines Inc. and Pan American World Airways are offering one-way fares of $54 on the New York-to-Washington shuttle, compared with a regular fare of $89, but the reduced-price tickets are not easy to get and are limited in number.

title: Fill In the East River
description: LEAD: With the forced closing of the Williamsburg Bridge, cable anchors corroding on the Manhattan Bridge, steel beams rotting on the Queensboro Bridge and the concrete deck deteriorating on the Washington Bridge (linking Harlem's West 184th Street to the Bronx), it may soon prove impossible to reach Manhattan except by boat.

title: Kuwait Journal; All Hail the Sabahs for Their Gritty Hostage Stand
description: The Sabah house was ablaze with festive lights. As guests streamed in, the beat of Bedouin music floated above the sprawling home into the warm midnight air.

title: The Heat of War Welds A Bond That Endures Across Aisles and Years
description: While the Senate was voting last week on the bill to offer apologies and compensation to the Americans of Japanese ancestry who were held in internment camps in World War II, Representative Norman Y. Mineta walked over from the House side of the Capitol and into the Senate chamber to shake hands with Senator Alan K. Simpson.

title: Cache of Spear Points
description: ARCHEOLOGISTS working in the state of Washington have now excavated the largest cache of the rare Clovis spear points. Clovis stone points, which are at least 11,000 years old, are the earliest undiputed evidence of humans in the Americas. They were first discovered near Clovis, N.M., but have since been uncovered at sites throughout North America.

title: Capital Cities/ABC Net Nearly Triples in Period
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. reported yesterday that its first-quarter earnings had almost tripled as a strong performance by its cable and television station operations had offset weak results at the ABC Television Network.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Chadbourne's Anarchy
description: Eugene Chadbourne commandeered the small stage at the Knitting Factory on Friday night by putting up a large sign of his name and littering the stage with a few guitars, a banjo, a saw, some music stands and a contraption he calls a porthole, a clear plastic half-bubble wrapped with rubber bands and amplified with a microphone.

title: Elf Aquitaine Buys RTZ's Operations
description: The French state oil company, Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, will expand its stake in Britain's North Sea oilfields by purchasing the oil and gas business of the British mining company the RTZ Corporation. RTZ said it had sold its oil and gas business for $:308 million, or about $579 million.

title: Director of Woods Hole Lab to Resign
description: Dr. John H. Steele, who for the past decade has headed the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution in Woods Hole, Mass., will resign next year, he announced Friday.

title: N.F.L.'s No-Frills Draft Ends
description: The glamour has gone out of the National Football League draft, at least for this year.

title: Jackson Strains to Clarify Position on Terrorist Talks
description: The more the Rev. Jesse Jackson tried to explain his position on negotiating with terrorists today, the more tangled up he got.

title: Copper in Sea Urchins
description: Soft tissue from sea urchins 800 feet from a copper ore ship that sank off California last year has been found to contain 100 times as much copper as normal, raising new questions about contaminants that enter food chains of the sea.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The crimes he committed cannot be forgiven either in the letter of the law or in the hearts of men.'' - Judge Zvi Tal, sentencing John Demjanjuk to death. [ A1:3. ]

title: Aguilera Will Not Require Surgery
description: The Mets, who lost seven starting pitchers last season and who cringe at the thought, got good news yesterday on two of their casualties of this season: Bob Ojeda expects to pitch Saturday in his regular turn, and Rick Aguilera will not undergo surgery and may return to the staff in two or three weeks.

title: Pilots Rate the Safety of Airports
description: Commercial pilots responding to a newspaper survey on airport safety rated Los Angeles International Airport the most dangerous in the nation and Dallas-Fort Worth the safest, but they cautioned that was hard to judge safety because individual workers could make all the difference.

title: Cole-Haan to Nike For $80 Million
description: Nike Inc., based in Beaverton, Ore., agreed to acquire Cole-Haan, a manufacturer of dress and casual shoes, from Cole-Haan Limited Partnership, a private company. The purchase price is about $80 million, plus the repayment of $15 million in debt.

title: Bush's Welcome of Rizzo Support Stirs a Debate
description: When Vice President Bush appeared in a South Philadelphia union hall recently, he emphatically espoused one campaign message that seemed to contradict another.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: Mitterrand Calls for Voiding Of New Caledonia's Ballots
description: President Francois Mitterrand called today for Sunday's first ballot for the French presidential election in the South Pacific territory of New Caledonia to be declared null.

title: Clark Seeks Stadium Hit
description: When the Yankees play the Kansas City Royals at Yankee Stadium tonight, Jack Clark will try to end his ''0-for-New York'' slump.

title: Krone Recovering
description: Julie Krone, who is fourth in the riding standings in the current Aqueduct meeting, escaped the serious injuries first suspected after she fell from her mount Sunday in the fourth race. According to her agent, Larry Cooper, Krone, the winningest female jockey in the history of racing, sustained no broken bones. She is expected to be sidelined for 7 to 10 days. . . . Cherokee Colony, who finished third in last Saturday's Wood Memorial at Aqueduct, suffered a bucked left shin, which will keep him out of action until the fall according to his trainer, John Campo. ''He's fine,'' said Campo, who added that X-rays showed no serious injury.

title: Patterns
description: Columbus's Appeal

title: We the People Should Pay for Our Landmarks
description: To the Editor:

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Two St. Louis Bankers Are Rivals No Longer
description: LEAD: After competing for 30 years in downtown St. Louis as leaders of the city's second- and third-largest banks, Donald E. Lasater and Clarence C. Barksdale will soon be reporting to work for the same bank holding company.

title: Boeing's Net Rises 15.3%
description: The Boeing Company today reported higher earnings in the first quarter despite lower sales. The company attributed the improved profits primarily to lower research and development costs in its core businesses of commercial aircraft, aerospace and computing. These factors were partly offset by increased costs in its de Havilland commuter aircraft division as well as significant performance problems on several military aircraft programs.

title: Murder Misconceived
description: The Government of Israel has not denied, and tends to confirm by its silence, that it ordered the murder of Khalil al-Wazir, also known as Abu Jihad. This order, efficiently carried out by Israeli gunmen, violated Israel's established policy not to assassinate leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization. It violated also the decent behavior demanded of a democratic and law-abiding government.

title: City Ballet Offering Music in Abundance At 3-Week Festival
description: The New York City Ballet is known for its music festivals. But the American Music Festival, which opens the company's 88th season tonight at the New York State Theater, is one of extraordinary ambition. It focuses not on one composer but on 40, with ballets by 18 choreographers, performances by guest musicians and art by leading American painters.

title: Lautenberg Opens Drive for Re-election
description: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg announced his bid for a second term today, pointedly ignoring the Republican who is seeking to oppose him in the United States Senate race and saying he would let his record speak for itself.

title: Hefty Playoffs For Lower Teams
description: HOW can the N.B.A. be serious about calling this the playoffs when the teams that finished 17th, 18th, 19th, 20th, 21st, 22d and 23d don't make it?

title: Robert J. Logan, Engineer, 43
description: Robert John Logan, president and chief operating officer of Syska & Hennessy, engineering consultant, died of meningitis virus Friday at New York Hospital, the chairman of the firm, John F. Hennessy, said. Mr. Logan, a native of Havana, was 43 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Mutual Fund Rule Delayed
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it was delaying by two months the effective date of a rule designed to make it easier for investors to shop for mutual funds.

title: Hans Brenaa, 77, Dies; Bournonville Specialist
description: Hans Brenaa, a former member of the Royal Danish Ballet and an internationally known specialist on August Bournonville, died of cancer of the liver and spine on April 14 in Bispebjerg Hospital in Copenhagen. He was 77 years old.

title: This Censored World
description: American newspapers and TV news shows carry firsthand accounts of all the important news of the world - except.

title: Macy Prepares for Takeover
description: A top management team from R. H. Macy & Company plans to spend several days in Los Angeles to prepare for the company's acquisition next week of the Bullock's/Bullocks Wilshire stores.

title: Renewal of Devils' Work Ethic Sought
description: Jim Schoenfeld, the coach of the Devils, gave his team a simple reminder today about who they are and how they have got as far as they have this year.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some copies on Saturday on an article about reconciliation efforts between the Palestine Liberation Organization and Syria misidentified the Palestinian guerrilla leader who was buried in Damascus last week. He was Abu Jihad, not Abu Nidal.

title: Farmers Group Ends Talks
description: Facing a $4.5 billion takeover offer from B.A.T Industries P.L.C., Farmers Group Inc. said today that it had ended talks about a possible leveraged buyout and was continuing to explore possible alternatives. The move is a sign that the

title: Honda Unit in U.S. Deal
description: The Honda Lock Manufacturing Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Honda Motor Company, will form a 50-50 joint venture with All-Lock Inc. of the United States next month, a Honda Lock spokesman said today. The new company, Honda All Lock Manufacturing Inc., will be in Selma, Ala., and will produce 400,000 sets of car keys a year for Honda's American car manufacturing units.

title: METHODISTS FOCUS ON HOMOSEXUALITY
description: Is homosexual behavior incompatible with Christian teaching and thus a bar to church leadership? This is the No. 1 issue facing the highest policy-making body of the United Methodist Church, according to surveys of the delegates to the church's General Conference opening today in St. Louis.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Heavy-Metal Press
description: The threat of nuclear war now has its own theme music: speed-metal rock. All three bands at the sold-out speed-metal concert Friday at the Beacon - Megadeth (whose album ''So Far, So Good . . . So What!'' reached the Top 30), Warlock and Sanctuary - had at least one song about an atomic World War III, and others about death and universal despair.

title: Whimsy Yields to a Sleek Simplicity
description: The show stoppers in the New York fall collections that have just ended were far from the giddy, ruffled, pouffed, exuberant designs that dominated the runways as recently as last season. Fashion has grown up, and so have the clothes. Sleek, sophisticated and simple are the operative words today, but that does not mean the clothes are much easier to wear than the midthigh bouffant confections that captured the applause six months ago. Today's eye-catchers follow the body's lines snugly, without a millimeter to spare. They offer no surcease from the diet-exercise regime many women felt they should consider when contemplating fluffy miniskirts.

title: KEY RATES
Q&A
description: Q.Do fish sleep? A.Yes, experts say, but they don't sleep the way mammals do.

title: Newspaper Publishers Note Gains
description: Though it has been a rough year at some of the nation's dailies, members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association were mostly celebrating the industry's considerable prosperity as they began their annual convention today.

title: A Town Grows, and So Do Tax Battles
description: April is budget time, and the mood is sour. Indignation over ever-growing taxes is rising, especially among older people who arrived long before the condominiums and subdivisions that increasingly dot the farmland here.

title: New York Budget Chief Joining Financial Firm
description: Governor Cuomo's budget director is resigning to become a senior vice president of a financial-services company, Cuomo administration officials said today.

title: Henry B. Martin, 82, Book Collector, Dies
description: Henry Bradley Martin a book collec-tor and a grandson of Henry Phipps, died Saturday at his home in Key Biscayne, Fla., after a brief illness. He was 82 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: Dow Up by 22.21; Trading Remains Light
description: A modest demand for oil stocks and some other blue chips was sufficient yesterday to move the market moderately higher, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose by 22.21 points, to 2,037.30. Volume, however, remained relatively light.

title: U.S. Continues Pre-Summit Sparring With Soviet
description: The verbal skirmishing in preparation for next month's summit meeting in Moscow continued today as the White House accused Mikhail S. Gorbachev of making ''needlessly inflammatory'' comments to Secretary of State George P. Shultz last week.

title: Our Towns; Subsidized Units And Slow Death Of Stereotypes
description: For the last eight years, the weed-strewn field across from Norman Borra's Mobil station has been empty. It has stayed empty because this hamlet and the rest of Huntington Township has opposed the construction of 162 apartments for poor people there. Apartments and poor people would ruin the neighborhood, residents say.

title: 3-Month Battle for J.P. Stevens Ends
description: The three-month takeover battle for J. P. Stevens & Company closed yesterday with an agreement that will end one of the nation's oldest corporate dynasties.

title: U.S. Agents Accuse 15 Of Illegal Duck Hunting
description: Federal agents arrested 4 men yesterday on charges of illegal duck hunting on Long Island and cited 10 others for violations. An arrest warrant has been issued for a fifth man.

title: Union Oil Offering
description: A $250 million offering of five-year notes from the Union Oil Company of California, a subsidiary of the Unocal Corporation, was priced yesterday through a syndicate led by investment bankers from Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The 9 percent notes, which mature on May 15, 1993, were priced at 99,604, to yield 9.10 percent, or 85 basis points over the prevailing yield on Treasury securities of comparable maturity. The notes are noncallable for life, and are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB by the S.&P. Principal and interest payments on the issue are guaranteed by Unocal.

title: ARIZONA DEFEATS BAN ON ABORTIONS
description: The Arizona House of Representatives yesterday rejected, by one vote, a bill that would have banned abortion in the state.

title: Polish Workers Strike and Win a Raise
description: Several hundred transport workers in the northern city of Bydgoszcz negotiated a 63 percent pay increase today after staging a wildcat strike that disrupted the city's municipal transport for more than 12 hours.

title: Nucorp Case Acquittals
description: A jury in San Diego yesterday found the defendants not guilty in a securities fraud case involving Nucorp Energy Inc.

title: Jordan River Project Could Help Peace Bloom; No Soviet Shift
description: To the Editor:

title: Maneuvering On Trade Bill Intensifies
description: Administration officials asserted today that the Senate would not pass trade legislation with enough votes to override a veto. But the Democratic leadership continued to hunt for support, putting pressure on oil-state Republicans.

title: Danes Divided on Nuclear Resolution
description: What seemed at first just another of Denmark's regular domestic squabbles over military policy - this one over visiting allied warships - has swollen into a major political confrontation with ramifications for the entire North Atlantic alliance.

title: The Dilemma: Save a Fish or a Wetland?
description: A FESTERING water dispute here is forcing environmentalists to choose between saving an endangered fish and preserving one of the country's most vital rest stops for migrating shorebirds.

title: Natural Chemicals Now Called Major Cause Of Disease
description: FREE radicals, highly reactive chemicals believed to have given rise to life on earth, are now increasingly regarded as primary forces of destruction and death in nearly all living things.

title: Unclear Outlook for Marathon
description: The three marathoners who qualified for the men's Olympic team Sunday over the New Jersey Waterfront Marathon course have raised hopes, if not expectations, that the United States might make a more impressive showing in the Seoul Games later this year than the 1984 team did in Los Angeles.

title: A.T.&T. and Olivetti: Strained Relationship
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that Vittorio Cassoni would step down as head of the company's computer division and return to Olivetti of Italy, which had lent the executive to A.T.&T. to turn around sagging personal computer sales.

title: NEW SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-13 News analysis: Jean-Marie Le Pen, by his strong showing in the first round of France's Presidential election, may have helped President Mitterrand reorient French politics around the moderate Socialist Party. Page A1 John Demjanjuk is to be hanged, an Israeli court ordered. The court had found that he tortured and killed thousands of Jews as a Nazi death camp guard. His lawyer said an appeal was planned. A1 An Afghan leader offered refugees a demilitarized zone through which they could return home from Pakistan as Soviet troops withdraw. Najibullah said the zone would be created if Pakistan and the Afghan guerrillas agree. A1 U.S. continues pre-summit sparring with Soviet A8 Denmark's ban on nuclear weapons and a debate over a requirement that the Government tell visitng warships of the policy has turned a domestic political dispute into a major political confrontation. A8 Polish transport workers struck in Bydgoszcz and negotiated a pay increase after disrupting transport for more than 12 hours. It was the most visible labor action in Poland since 1982, opposition leaders said. A3 Kuwait is celebrating the liberation of passengers from the hijacked jet. The hijacking has galvanized Ku-waitis into a show of solidarity and national pride at having overcome a challenge from outsiders. A4 Seoul's ruling party expects to win a majority in legislative elections because of the election system's structure and a divided opposition, not because of support for South Korea's President, Roh Tae Woo. A3 A split among the Nicaraguan rebels threatened the movement in the last week. Rebel leaders have patched differences for negotiations with the Sanidinistas, but officials say that unity is delicate. A13 The Ivory Coast defies expectations that Westerners hold about Africa. The country's relative prosperity can be attributed to agricultural productivity, an open immigration policy and continuity of leadership. A6 Saudis will join treaty on nuclear arms A10 Arafat meets Syrian President A10 Security Council condemns killing of P.L.O. chief. A10 NATIONAL A14-24, B6-7 The Supreme Court voted to rehear a pending case, over bitter dissent, as a way of reconsidering a decision that expanded the rights of minorities to sue private parties for racial descrimination. A1 Control of the stock market would not be shifted to a superagency or the Federal Reserve Board under proposals being worked out by a Presidential committee on the market crash, an Administration official said. A1 Competition with private companies may make government agencies more efficient than turning them over to the private sector, officials with experience in ''privatizing'' services have found. A1 The Navy sent rescue workers to search for three missing men in the hull of a diesel-powered submarine that caught fire Sunday in the Altantic Ocean. Twenty-three men aboard the submarine Bonefish were injured. A14 The community college in Roxbury, a poor section of Boston, dedicated a new $40 million campus, which has become a source of pride for Roxbury Community College and a sign of better times for the neighborhood.
