A14 News analysis: Extending amnesty for illegal aliens has produced debate in Congress that reflects assessments of the program's effectiveness and the tensions that made amnesty such an explosive issue. A14 Abortion ban defeated in Arizona A14 Radiation benefit bill for veterans gains A19 Educators assail Education Secretary as too negative. A23 Churches fight 'clergy malpractice' ruling B7 Methodists to discuss homosexuality, B7 POLITICS B6 People in western Pennsylvania say they have heard the same promises repeated about reviving industrial decay. Even as they prepare to vote in Tuesday's primary, they say they no longer expect much from government. A1 The Rev. Jesse Jackson's explanation of his position on negotiating with terrorists has become more confused as the Democratic Presidential candidate has tried to clarify various statements he has made. B6 Vice President Bush's strategy of appealing to conservative Democratic voters by campaigning with former Mayor Frank Rizzo of Philadelphia may confict with his attempts to woo minority voters. B6 WASHINGTON TALK A22 Friendship forged in war endures in Congress REGIONAL B1-4 A bid to buy Lilco rose $137 million as the Long Island Power Authority voted to increase its $7.45 billion offer for the utility's common shares to $10 from $8.75. Lilco had no comment on the offer. B1 Budget time in Raritan Township, a farming town developers are turning into a suburb, has become increasingly contentious as the Township Committee has raised property taxes to meet growing demands for services. B1 Club life for people under 21 is developing as owners have begun to cater to people who cannot drink legally. Some clubs have set aside special rooms for underage guests. Others have set aside particular nights. B1 Senator Frank Lautenberg will run for a second term. The New Jersey Democrat faces opposition from two candiates in the June 7 primary. He said he expected to debate a Republican candidate, Pete Dawkins. B2 Connecticut closed jai alai frontons in Hartford and Bridgeport after the state received complaints that striking players were harassing fans and replacement players. The strike was in its 11th day. B2 A crackdown on illegal duck hunting conducted by Federal agents on Long Island led to the arrests of four men and citations against 10 others, including a bank president and an assistant school principal. B3 Parks Dept. issues Green Pages B4 Bill to tighten campaign disclosure laws is passed in Albany B4 Students talk about drugs B4

title: Review/Concert; A Program of Music New to New Yorkers
description: The American Composers Orchestra continued to act out on Sunday what passes through the consciences of other performing groups in this country but usually keeps on going. The afternoon event at Carnegie Hall was once again a careful and considered look at music new to New York audiences and important to this country. Yet none of these four performances seemed a duty - each piece well chosen and well played.

title: Maker of Faulty Baby Swings Offering Free Replacements
description: The manufacturer of baby swings that could collapse is offering free replacements, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today.

title: A Strategy to Oust Panama's Leader
description: After weeks of stand-off in Panama, Americans deserve answers to some basic questions about our policy there. What are the prospects that unrelenting pressure will force Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega out of power? What are the costs and risks associated with this policy? What are the options to economic and military threats?

title: Warner Books Wins Rights to 'Wind'
description: Warner Books last night bid $4.94 million at auction for the right to publish the sequel to ''Gone With the Wind.''

title: DEMJANJUK GIVEN DEATH SENTENCE FOR NAZI KILLINGS
description: John Demjanjuk was sentenced to death today by the Israeli court that found him to be the brutal Nazi death camp guard known as Ivan the Terrible.

title: Pennant Fever, Then Relapse
description: The St. Louis Cardinals have had two experiences with the repeater syndrome, so it comes as no surprise to them. The Minnesota Twins, on the other hand, are encountering it for the first time.

title: Contras Reported to Avert a Split, Narrowly, on Eve of Talks
description: A power struggle and differences over negotiations with the Sandinistas nearly split the Nicaraguan rebel movement in the last week, pitting senior military commanders against some political leaders of the movement, according to several rebel and American officials.

title: I.B.M. Says It May Sell MCI Stake
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would probably sell its 16 percent stake in the MCI Communications Corporation over the next several years, a move that analysts said reflected a strengthened and more independent MCI.

title: Red Sox Win, 5-1
description: Bruce Hurst pitched a six-hitter and struck out eight tonight as Boston beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 5-1, for the Red Sox's sixth straight victory.

title: Ex-Crewman Acquitted in 8 Boat Killings in 1982
description: A man who formerly served as a crewman on a fishing boat has been acquitted in the killings in 1982 of eight people aboard the boat.

title: Public Services Found Better If Private Agencies Compete
description: One of the most promoted economic ideas of the 1980's holds that private companies can provide public services more efficiently than government.

title: By Design: Spring Hemline Census
description: This has been a great month for fashion observing. The showings of fall collections drew crowds of style-conscious spectators and the spring social season started to swing. Despite the snappish weather a great many women have begun to appear in their new spring clothes. Finally it has been possible to judge the response to the hemline hoopla, better known as, ''Is up out and down back in?''

title: Private Access to F.B.I. Records Is Proposed
description: A pioneer in the private security guard business has proposed giving employers in his industry access to the Federal Bureau of Investigation's computerized file of citizens' criminal records.

title: Frank Forester Jr., 72, Retired Banker, Dies
description: Frank Forester Jr., a retired banker, died of intestinal cancer Saturday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 72 years old and lived in Plandome, L.I.

title: Army Is Preparing 30-Year Plan For Modernization at Modest Cost
description: Evidently acknowledging political and fiscal reality, the Army is drafting an extensive plan to take that service well into the 21st century with much more modest budget growth than in recent history.

title: A Mental Autopsy on the Shakespearean Corpus
description: As the Thane of Cawdor's wife once observed while sleepwalking, ''Who would have thought the old man to have had so much blood in him?''

title: Trade-Show Pioneer To Buy Sands Hotel
description: Sheldon G. Adelson, the computer trade-show pioneer, said today that he would enter the gaming business by buying the Sands Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, Nev., for $110 million from the West Coast financier Kirk Kerkorian.

title: Danes Divided on Nuclear Resolution; Shultz Urges Reversal
description: Secretary of State Shultz called on Denmark today to reverse its Parliament's decision to bar nuclear-armed ships from its ports.

title: Boeing Gets Order For 30 Jetliners
description: The Boeing Company has received a $1.4 billion order for 30 jetliners from the International Leisure Group, the parent company of Air Europe Ltd. of Britain. The order consists of 22 of the company's 757-200's and eight of its 737-400's. The 757's, powered by the RB211-535E4 engines of Rolls-Royce P.L.C., will be delivered beginning in 1989. Each plane can seat up to 185 passengers.

title: 5 Posts Filled at Justice Dept.
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d temporarily filled five vacant posts in the Justice Department today, a spokesman said.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs; Oilers Beat Flames, 6-4, to Sweep Series
description: The Edmonton Oilers built a four-goal lead into the second period, then held off Calgary with the help of Glenn Anderson's clinching goal for a 6-4 victory tonight to sweep their Stanley Cup playoff series.

title: Roxbury Journal; For the Inner City, a Beacon of Light
description: Roxbury can barely contain its pride. It took 15 turbulent, often bitter years, but this battered inner-city neighborhood finally has a campus for its community college.

title: No Liquor but Still Exotic: A Night Life for the Young
description: Disco, funk and rap engulfed the dance floor. Spotlights swirled and darted to the beat. And soda and ''near beer'' flowed at the packed bar of Studio 54.

title: 46 Salvadoran Troops Killed Over Weekend
description: Leftist guerrillas, carrying out a vow to intensify their struggle, inflicted heavy losses on Salvadoran Government troops over the weekend, killing at least 46 soldiers in a series of attacks, the authorities said today.

title: Corrections
description: An Executive Changes listing in Business Day on April 18 misidentified the company that promoted Joseph Isenstein and Thomas W. McIntyre to senior vice presidents. It is the Bertelsmann Music Group.

title: TLC Group Studies Beatrice Units' Sale
description: The TLC Group, a New York investment company controlled by the financier Reginald F. Lewis, said that it was exploring the sale of three European operations of the Beatrice International Company. The group has retained Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to explore the sale of the Beatrice International Bottling Group, based in the Netherlands and Belgium, and two British operations - Beatrice Poultry and the Callard & Bowser Group, which makes confectionery products.

title: Timing of Chicago Election Depends on Vacancy Ruling
description: The city Board of Elections voted today to hold a special mayoral election next year if the city clerk declares a vacancy in the Mayor's office.

title: Robertson Assessed $28,000 in Court Costs
description: Pat Robertson, the Republican Presidential contender, has been ordered to pay $28,000 of court costs incurred by a former Congressman he had sued for questioning his Korean War record, lawyers said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions yesterday about a Time magazine poll on a hypothetical Presidential contest between Vice President Bush and Gov.

title: LINE FORMS AT U.S.C.
description: When the Jets took Dave Cadigan on the first round, he became the 16th offensive lineman from Southern Cal since 1968 to go in the top round. The others: $ Year Player N.F.L. team 1968 Ron Yary Minnesota 1968 Mike Taylor Pittsburgh 1970 Sid Smith Kansas City 1971 Marv Montgomery Denver 1974 Steve Riley Minnesota 1973 Pete Adams Cleveland 1977 Marvin Powell Jets 1980 Anthony Munoz Cincinnati 1980 Brad Budde Kansas City 1981 Keith Van Horne Atlanta 1982 Roy Foster Miami 1983 Bruce Matthews Houston 1983 Don Mosebar Raiders 1985 Ken Ruettgers Green Bay 1986 James FitzPatrick San Diego 1988 Dave Cadigan Jets

title: Irving Seeks More Talks
description: The Irving Bank Corporation said yesterday that its board had told its management and financial advisers to negotiate with the Bank of New York Company and with Banca Commerciale Italiana to get the best terms possible in the bidding for Irving. But Bank of

title: Reagan Group Is Likely to Back Broad Proposals on Stock Crash
description: The White House Working Group on the market crash is likely to produce a set of proposals that will closely track the broad recommendations made in January by the Brady commission, with one key exception, an Administration official said today.

title: A Sweet Homecoming
description: More than 200,000 pages of documents from the life and career of Duke Ellington, one of Washington's greatest native sons, are coming home today - as an acquisition of the Smithsonian Institution's Museum of American history.

title: Technology Aids Vaccination Effort
description: AT the Kofar Nassarawa vaccination center here, the temperature was approaching 100 degrees, but an electric fan stood still and a refrigerator was abandoned in a corner. Despite the lack of electric power to cool the precious vaccines, volunteers toiled through a recent morning, immunizing 531 babies in five hours.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Tobacco Co., a unit of American Brands Inc., Old Greenwich, Conn., agreed to sell its pipe tobacco brands and related assets to Pinkerton Tobacco Co., Owensboro, Ky. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Steel City Tires of Politics and Promises
description: As people here look to Tuesday's Presidential primary, they say they no longer expect much from their Government. They point to the closed steel works of Western Pennsylvania brooding on the bank of the Monongahela, visible in the clear air, no longer obscured by the acrid smoke of prosperity.

title: Herbert Lebovici, Maritime Lawyer, 75
description: Herbert Lebovici, a maritime lawyer who specialized in labor-management problems, died March 8 at the Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J., from complications after surgery. He was 75 years old and lived in Hillsdale, N.J.

title: 3 Boys Avert Accident As Driver of Bus Dies
description: Three junior high school boys brought their school bus to a safe stop today after the driver suffered a fatal heart attack at the wheel, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Frank A. Tomaino, Florist, 85
description: Frank A. Tomaino, the founder of Rhinelander Florist who sold flowers to the Rockefellers, Astors and Whitneys, died of emphysema and cancer Thursday at the St. Francis Gardens Nursing Home in Albuquerque, N.M. He was 85 years old. Mr. Tomaino, who was born in Deal, N.J., spent his childhood in Calabria, returning to the United States as a gardener for Huntington Hartford. He opened Rhinelander Florist in the Rhinelander Mansion, at 72d Street and Madison Avenue in Manhattan, in 1936.

title: Music Noted in Brief
description: The Alaria Chamber Ensemble's program at Weill Recital Hall Friday night began with bright premises, which rarely worked out. What a nice idea to put Christoph Graupner's Trio Sonata in C (here played by bassoon, bass clarinet and continuo) next to the group's own arrangements of Bach choral preludes. Graupner was a rival for the Leipzig church post that Bach was to immortalize and lost the job only because his current employer would not release him.

title: Lanny Ross, Star of Radio Series In 1930's and 1940's, Dies at 82
description: Lanny Ross, a singer, actor and radio personality, died of heart failure at Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Peru-Colombia Drug Drive
description: President Alan Garcia of Peru and President Virgilio Barco Sanchez of Colombia called today on drug-consuming nations to toughen the fight against narcotics traffic. The call was in the form of a joint statement signed Sunday and made public today.

title: Soviet Says Output Is Up
description: Soviet industrial production increased by 5 percent in the first three months of 1988 as reforms requiring many factories and companies to operate on a self-sustaining basis went into effect, Moscow radio said today.

title: Educators Call Bennett Too Negative
description: Education experts said yesterday that a report by Education Secretary William J. Bennett had jeopardized the continuing effort to improve the nation's schools because he had undervalued gains in graduation requirements, student test scores and teacher salaries.

title: Books of The Times; Saving Grace (and Much More) of 'Hypochondria'
description: Hypochondria Woeful Imaginations By Susan Baur 252 pages. University of California Press. $19.95.

title: Corrections
description: The Eating Well column in The Living Section last Wednesday misstated the amounts of two components of beef sirloin. Three and a half ounces contain 9 milligrams of fat and 89 milligrams of cholesterol

title: Resigning Would Help Meese Before a Jury
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council UNICEF EXECUTIVE BOARD - PROGRAM COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Scholars Doubt Poem Is Shakespeare
description: After a weekend of dispute over a British professor's claim that he had discovered a new poem of 14 verses written by William Shakespeare in 1606, scholarly opinion here has quickly massed behind the consensus that the poem is neither new nor by the Bard.

title: Reviews/Music; Sonata and Suite for Viola
description: Lenore Weinstock's viola recital at Merkin Concert Hall last Tuesday evening found its expressive stride in some of the wistful dances in Ralph Vaughan Williams's Suite for Viola and Piano. A tone evocative of melancholy and an unhurried, far-away feeling to the rhythm matched the music nicely. Elsewhere in the wide-ranging program (Bach, Brahms, Tibor Serly and Karen Campbell), Miss Weinstock's technically adroit playing was hampered by a certain reticence of expression that registered as vaguely apologetic. She played well, but seemed reluctant to assert a strong view of how the pieces should go.

title: U.N. Council Votes To Condemn Killing Of Top P.L.O. Aide
description: The Security Council adopted a resolution today condemning the assassination of a top Palestine Liberation Organization official in Tunis and noting that Tunisia has accused Israel of the murder.

title: Ethiopian and Somali Forces Withdrawn Under Agreement
description: Ethiopian and Somali armies have completed a disengagement of forces along their border in accordance with the peace agreement signed by the two former enemies earlier this month, Ethiopia said today.

title: COURT, 5-4, VOTES TO RESTUDY RIGHTS IN MINORITY SUITS
description: In an extraordinary action, the Supreme Court decided today to reconsider the rights of minorities to sue private parties for racial discrimination under a post-Civil War statute.

title: 'Tattinger's': TV Produced in East
description: An elegant restaurant has been built on a pier at West 23d Street, but it will serve the public only on television. It is a set for ''Tattinger's,'' a weekly dramatic series starring Stephen Collins and Blythe Danner, scheduled to make its debut on NBC next fall, if the writers' strike ends by then.

title: Time for Amnesty?; Congress' Debate on Extending Plan For Aliens Rehashes Original Issues
description: On the surface, the Congressional debate over extending the nation's amnesty program for illegal aliens is a simple question of time: whether to give aliens an extra seven months to apply for legal status.

title: Notes and Bonds Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in extremely thin trading yesterday, as market participants chose to ignore a signal from the Federal Reserve that it does not intend to tighten monetary policy in the immediate future.

title: French Jobless Rate Slips
description: France's unemployment rate fell in March to its lowest level in 18 months, Labor Ministry figures released today showed. The ministry put the percentage of the work force without jobs in March at 10.3 percent, compared with 10.5 percent in February and 11.1 percent a year ago.

title: New York City Has Done Exceedingly Well in State School Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Enterprising Women
description: Let's hear it for the women - the 3.7 million who own a quarter of the nation's businesses - a Congressional panel has decided. Today, the House Committee on Small Business will begin hearings on women-owned enterprises. Among the witnesses will be Gillian Rudd, president of the 3,500-member National Asociation of Women Business Owners and head of a communications consulting company, and Polly Bergen, the actress, who heads a women's accessories company.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; J.W.T. USA Chairman Named Chief Executive
description: Burton J. Manning, the bearded copywriter who is chairman and chief executive of J. Walter Thompson Worldwide, announced yesterday that James B. Patterson, the bearded copywriter who is chairman of J.W.T. USA, had been promoted to chief executive as well.

title: 2 High-Power Portables
description: ZENITH Data Systems has just introduced a new family of portable personal computers. The Supersport and Turbosport machines replace the popular Z-181 and Z-183 models and add new levels of power. The Supersport 286, scheduled for delivery late next month, has performance specifications that may make it the fastest portable that is based on the 80286 chip. The Turbosport 386, which will be available in June, is a battery-powered machine based on the powerful 80386 chip.

title: Consolidated Papers Appointment
description: Patrick F. Brennan was named president and chief operating officer yesterday of Consolidated Papers Inc., a paper company based in Wisconsin Rapids, Wis., that has $800 million in sales.

title: Replaying the Civil War
description: AT the other end of the spectrum from computer games in which you blast human or alien war machines into oblivion are thoughtful reconstructions of historic battles. One of the most painstaking, even fussy, examples is Decisive Battles of the American Civil War.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Cumberland Music
description: The Cumberland Plateau of Kentucky and Tennessee is one of the richest sources of the Appalachian Mountain music, often known as old-time, that predates bluegrass. Composed for fiddle, banjo and voice (sometimes unaccompanied), this regional music whose sound is as plain as the environment in which it was made is a disappearing oral tradition. Spare, droning and Celtic in its origins, it also reflects the contact of American settlers with African-Americans by taking cognizance in its dour, tight-lipped way of the blues.

title: U.S. Rig Count Up a Bit
description: The number of working domestic oil and gas rigs rose by four, to a total of 908 last week, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today, The rig count, the widely watched industry index of drilling activity, totaled 765 a year ago.

title: Fred Jordan, Minister to Poor, 79
description: The Rev. Fred Jordan, founder of the international nondenominational missions that bear his name, died of heart failure Sunday. He was 79 years old.

title: Chemical Bank Cutback
description: The Chemical Bank, part of the Chemical New York Corporation, plans to transfer its Zurich activities to Geneva this fall to save back-office costs, the bank said. About 40 of the 170 people employed by the bank's Zurich branch and a subsidiary, Chemical Bank (Suisse) S.A., are expected to be laid off. But a spokeswoman said it was not clear what would happen to the private banking operation in Zurich, which might not move to Geneva.

title: Profits Rise At 5 Big Oil Companies
description: Five major oil companies yesterday reported higher first-quarter profits, mostly because of increased earnings from chemical operations and improved margins in their oil refining and marketing businesses.

title: 13 Drown in Kenyan Floods
description: Thirteen people drowned in flooding in Kenya over the weekend and heavy rains made roads impassable in many parts of the country, police reports said today.

title: On Trade: Wrong From the Start
description: The foreign trade bill that Congress expects to complete this week had a bad beginning, a tormented middle and a dismal end. President Reagan properly promises a veto, but the fault is as much his as Congress's. The pending bill is worse than none at all.

title: Ancient Animal Hair Found in Caribbean Amber
description: A SCIENTIST at the University of California has found the oldest evidence of land mammals on Caribbean islands, a tuft of animal hair preserved in amber. The 40-million-year-old hair came complete with an infestation of parasites the size of fleas.

title: Rescuers Sent to Fire-Swept Submarine
description: The Navy today sent rescue workers to search for three missing men in the hull of a diesel-powered submarine that caught fire Sunday evening in the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Comings and Goings
description: John Tudor, who has been out with a sore shoulder, was activated yesterday and will make his first start of the season Tuesday night when the St. Louis Cardinals play in San Diego. . . . Willie deWit, the Canadian heavyweight boxer, has decided to retire. . . . Bill Sharman, the Los Angeles Lakers' president, announced his retirement yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Melitta Ads Offer 'Coffee Perfection'
description: MELITTA Region North America, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., is the United States marketer of West German-made premium drip coffee makers, filters and a coffee, which it considers a rare, and perhaps unique, combination.

title: Detroit Papers' Petition
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese said today that he expected to issue a ruling soon on a request to grant a joint operating agreement to The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press. The News, owned by the Gannett Company and The Free Press, owned by Knight-Ridder Inc., have both said they are losing money and cannot continue to publish without the operating agreement. ''It is my hope we would reach a decision in the very near future,'' Mr. Meese told the Economic Club of Detroit.

title: 1,500 Religious Groups Helping To Fight 'Clergy Malpractice'
description: Joined by 1,577 churches and religious organizations, a fundamentalist church is appealing a ruling that it can be held liable for the suicide of a 24-year-old church member. It says the ruling violates the First Amendment's affirmation of freedom of religion.

title: Group Heads At Marriott
description: The Marriott Corporation yesterday announced a reorganization into two principal operating groups -lodging and service - effective Sunday.

title: William Frankel, Editor, 68
description: William Frankel, an editor who retired from Time-Life Books in 1983, died Thursday after a stroke at Capitol Hill Hospital in Washington. He was 68 years old and lived in Alexandria, Va.

title: Iran-Contra Prosecutor, in Switch, Takes Stand and Defends Method
description: In an unusual reversal of roles, the independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair took the witness stand today in Federal District Court and denied allegations that his investigation had been tainted by Congressional testimony from Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and others.

title: Bill on Campaign Laws Voted in Legislature
description: The State Legislature acted today to tighten the state's campaign disclosure laws by requiring that political committees reveal all payments made from funds that are supposed to be used for day-to-day operating expenses.

title: Curb Pardon Powers
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; 2 New Choreographers
description: Louisa Laurie and Diane Vivona offered an evening of punchy, brainy dance on Friday at the Westbeth Theater Center. It was also remarkably self-assured for choreographers of such relative newness, for program notes suggested that Ms. Laurie has not created dance before and Ms. Vivona's experience has been limited. At this point, however, the two have chosen a small vocabulary to work with and a fairly unambitious territory to explore.

title: Arafat Meets With Syrian President
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria and Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, held talks here today aimed at ending their violent five-year dispute.

title: A Commodity Trader Fares Poorly in Funds
description: Richard J. Dennis, a daring and usually successful Chicago commodities trader, had no trouble drumming up public interest when he teamed with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. last year to sell two commodity funds to the public. Within months, the funds, which are known as limited partnerships, boasted $115 million in combined assets.

title: Review/Rock; Jerry Harrison Grafting Funk, Art and Fervor
description: Jerry Harrison, the keyboardist and guitarist from the group Talking Heads, put on a show Friday night at the World that never quite defined its purpose. At times, he and his band tried to reproduce the chilly fervor of Talking Heads, from their 1984 ''Stop Making Sense'' period - several of Mr. Harrison's band members were in that incarnation of the band. Like that band, Mr. Harrison adds a self-conscious artyness and vocal angularity to 70's funk; it's an odd synthesis that, when it works, can be culturally provocative; when it fails, it seems like artless grafting, a student's experiment. At other times, Mr. Harrison seemed as if he were struggling to find an identity.

title: Afghan Leader Offers a Pullback; Envoys Say He Is Being Defeated
description: Afghanistan's leader, Najibullah, offered today to create a demilitarized zone through which Afghan refugees could return home from Pakistan as Soviet troops withdraw.

title: Senate Backs Aid to Veterans Exposed to Atomic Radiation
description: The Senate approved today a bill granting new benefits to 250,000 American veterans who were exposed to radiation in the nuclear attacks on Japan in 1945 and in postwar nuclear tests.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Saatchi & Saatchi Buys A Research Company
description: Saatchi & Saatchi has struck again in the research field. The successfully acquired company is the National Research Group of Los Angeles, which specializes in movie marketing research.

title: Massachusetts' Bold Health Experiment
description: Massachusetts last week ventured where no state had gone before: It guaranteed health insurance for every resident. This ambitious initiative was the brainchild of Gov. Michael Dukakis, who hopes it will commend him to voters in his quest for the Presidency.

title: SAUDIS WILL JOIN TREATY ON A-ARMS
description: Saudi Arabia said tonight that it would become a party to the treaty limiting the spread of nuclear arms, according to a Saudi press agency report released here.

title: A Blend of Student Voices on Drugs
description: When it comes to drugs, New York City high school students confess they often don't know what to think.

title: Theme for Today, Class: Role Models and How to Succeed
description: Wendell Niles, a graphic artist who founded his own company, was telling a group of seventh graders from Harlem recently that there were all kinds of jobs for them.

title: Control Data Net Rises 7%
description: As a result of strong orders for computer disk drives, the Control Data Corporation's earnings in the first quarter rose 7 percent, to $7.7 million, or 18 cents a share, from $7.2 million, or 17 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. Its revenues rose 10 percent, to $902.2 million, from $821.7 million.

title: Return of Children to Deaf Mother Is Ordered
description: A state judge has overruled city foster-care workers and for the second time in five months has ordered New York City to return two children to the care of their deaf mother.

title: Cavalier Star Out
description: Ron Harper, who would have been guarding Michael Jordan, will probably miss the Cleveland Cavaliers' opening playoff game in Chicago against the Bulls tomorrow night, Coach Lenny Wilkens of Cleveland said yesterday.

title: Obituary; Ralph McCallister, 82, A Former Educator
description: Ralph McCallister, a former educator and director of programs and education at the Chautauqua Institution, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 82 years old.

title: Uniroyal Goodrich Goes To Wyse Advertising
description: The Uniroyal brand tires from the Uniroyal Goodrich joint venture have been assigned to Wyse Advertising of Cleveland. Leading National Advertisers could find only $405,000 in ad spending for the Uniroyal brand last year.

title: U.N. Sets No Blame in Gulf War Gas Attack
description: After weeks of investigation in Iran and Iraq, a United Nations expert declined today to state which country used chemical weapons in attacks that wounded thousands of civilians last month.

title: Japan's New Goal: U.S. Companies
description: First they tried their hand at United States Treasury securities. Then they dabbled in New York skyscrapers. Now the next stage of Japanese investment in America has arrived - the acquisition of United States companies.

title: Profit Soars at Washington Post Co.
description: The Washington Post Company said today that its first-quarter profit soared nearly sevenfold from a year earlier, mainly because of a huge gain on the sale of its cellular telephone operations in Florida.

title: Nuclear Safety Accord Is Signed With Soviet
description: The United States and the Soviet Union today marked the second anniversary of the Soviet nuclear-reactor disaster at Chernobyl by signing an agreement to exchange technical and safety data on civilian nuclear-power reactors.

title: Justices Are Urged to Nullify Independent Prosecutor Law
description: Challenging the constitutionality of the law on independent prosecutors, Solicitor General Charles Fried argued today before the Supreme Court that the proper mechanism for checking abuse by the executive branch was ''the long, deep shadow of Congress's power of impeachment.''

title: Cronkite Weighing Other Offers
description: As CBS News prepares for the political conventions and the Presidential election, it is faced with the awkward possibility of seeing Walter Cronkite, the longtime CBS anchor and for generations the face of CBS News, broadcasting for a competing organization.

title: Growth Rate of Economy at 2.3% In Quarter as Spending Rebounds
description: The economy grew at a 2.3 percent annual rate in the first three months of the year as spending by business and consumers rebounded from a sluggish fall pace, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Books of The Times; William Boyd's Reverberations With Rousseau
description: The New Confessions By William Boyd 476 pages. William Morrow & Company.

title: Addendum
description: * The Electric Company magazine is changing its name to Kid City with the September issue.

title: Board Faults Thruway Unit On Collapse
description: The National Transportation Safety Board today cited inadequate maintenance as the major ''probable cause'' of the collapse last year of the Schoharie Creek bridge on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in which 10 motorists were killed. It blamed the New York State Thruway Authority for failing to buttress the bridge's piers.

title: P.& G. Profits Increase 40%
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said today that its profit in the third fiscal quarter jumped 40 percent over the corresponding period last year, largely because of a lower Federal income tax rate.

title: People
description: * Richard H. Anderson, Diana F. Kramer and Frederick P. Massin, have been promoted to executive vice presidents of Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton.

title: Tarlow to Handle Jontue Fragrance
description: The recently born Tarlow Advertising, which already had a couple of assignments from Revlon, has been given Jontue Fragrance. The agency will handle Jontue on a full-service basis except for the network televison buying. All of the client's network television buying is now the responsibility of Young & Rubicam.

title: Iranians' Words of Praise for Their Forces
description: While American commanders are praising the performance of United States forces in the Persian Gulf last week, Iranian commanders are putting forth a stream of praise for their own. Following are excerpts from a Teheran television broadcast monitored on April 21. The speakers were Commodore Mohammad Hoseyn Malekzadegan, commander of the Iranian Navy, and Hoseyn Alai, commander of the Iranian Revolutionary Guards Corps Navy.

title: Eating Well
description: LEGUMES and grains have only recently lost their lowly status, earning respect for their contributions to healthful eating. In 1967 Ancel and Margaret Keys remarked on this problem in their book ''The Benevolent Bean'' (Doubleday):

title: Campaign Trail
description: Jackson's Way Station

title: INSIDE
description: Oil Cutbacks Proposed Seven oil-producing nations have offered to reduce exports by 5 percent if OPEC will join them in steps to bolster the price of oil. Page D1. Saudis Break Ties With Iran Saudi Arabia said it was breaking relations with Iran and gave Iranian diplomats a week to leave. Page A10. Why Schoharie Bridge Fell A Federal report blamed inadequate maintenance for the collapse, and warned that thousands of other bridges are in danger. Page B1. Leading Educator Dies Frederick Douglass Patterson, founder of the United Negro College Fund, is dead at 86. Page B8 Limits on Acne Drug Urged Distribution of the acne drug Accutane should be restricted to make it more difficult for young women to obtain, a panel recommends. Page A17. Jagger Wins Plagiarism Suit A Federal jury said Mick Jagger did not steal his hit ''Just Another Night'' from another musician. Page C22.

title: Smith International Names New Chairman
description: Robert Sutherland, one of two executives who supervise the United States investments of Sir Ronald Brierly, the corporate raider from New Zealand, has been named chairman of Smith International Inc.

title: Milken Faces Panel Today On Drexel
description: On the eve of two days of hearings into the trading activities of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and one of its leading executives, Michael Milken, a Congressional subcommittee finds itself bitterly divided over the propriety of letting the public hear the testimony.

title: Connecticut Housing Agency Makes $100 Million Offering
description: The Connecticut Housing Finance Authority priced a $100 million bond offering yesterday.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; From Pell to Stafford
description: First there were Pell grants; now come Stafford loans.

title: A Principal, Despite Praise, Is to Resign
description: Even as the United States Secretary of Education was calling Eileen Petruzillo an exemplary principal who had ''transformed'' Park West High School in the Clinton Section of Manhattan, Mrs. Petruzillo announced yesterday that she was leaving the New York City school system to become principal at Greenwich High School in Connecticut.

title: U.S. BARS PROPOSAL TO LIMIT ACID RAIN
description: On the eve of a visit by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, the Administration has rejected a proposal that the United States limit the flow of nitrogen oxide pollution across the border to Canada, Administration officials said today.

title: Earnings Rise Buoys Tandem
description: Shares of Tandem Computers Inc. rose sharply today in heavy trading as the company reported earnings exceeding most analysts' estimates. Although Tandem's earnings rose only slightly, the results followed a disappointing quarter and relieved concerns that its performance would be weak for the rest of the year, the analysts said.

title: Accounts
description: * Starch INRA Hooper, the advertising research firm, to Cox & Greenwald.

title: Twins Sign Easler
description: The Minnesota Twins have signed their outfielder-designated hitter, Mike Easler, to a minor-league contract. Easler, 37 years old, will report to Portland. He became a free agent after being released by the Yankees in spring training. His career batting average over 14 seasons with six teams is .293.

title: Dow Overcomes Selling Spurt to Rise 8.79
description: Overcoming a violent five-minute burst of selling, the stock market managed to close yesterday with a modest gain.

title: Food Notes
description: Exclusively Rhubarb

title: Frederick D. Patterson, Founder Of Negro College Fund, Dies at 86
description: Frederick Douglass Patterson, founder of the United Negro College Fund and president emeritus of the Tuskegee Institute in Alabama, died yesterday after suffering a heart attack at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 86 years old. Under his leadership, the college fund became the largest independent source of money for the nation's private, historically black colleges and universities, providing for student scholarships, staff salaries, library resources, laboratories and new teaching programs.

title: Bank Services for Poor Expected
description: Any bill emerging from Congress this year to break down the walls between commercial and investment banking is likely to contain provisions requiring commercial banks and savings institutions to provide more services to the poor and elderly.

title: Consumer Magazines Lure Bondlow Back
description: With elation, William F. Bondlow Jr. has announced his return to consumer magazines. He started work yesterday as publisher of Home magazine at Knapp Communications, after spending the last year as publisher of Interior Design, a trade publication.

title: Eagles Release Clarke
description: When Ken Clarke, a defensive tackle, was released yesterday by Philadelphia, it left just three players from the 1980 National Conference championship team on the Eagles' roster. Clarke, 32 years old, fell victim to the club's youth movement, the team president, Harry Gamble, said. Clarke joined the Eagles as a free agent in 1978 and played in 147 straight games, first as nose tackle from 1978 to 1985, then as defensive tackle. He started in 83 consecutive games between opening day in 1982 and the 14th week of the 1987 season.

title: Gooden Improves To 5-0
description: Despite the growing sense of pity concerning Baltimore's macabre first month of the season, there is at least one team grateful for the plight of the Orioles. Baltimore's struggle has, after all, allowed the Atlanta Braves to lose with numbing regularity in virtual and welcome anonymity.

title: Net Up 21.4% At Interpublic
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies reported that its net income was up 21.4 percent in the first quarter. Interpublic is the first of the publicly held American advertising companies to announce its results.

title: Israel Withdraws Credentials of 2 Journalists
description: The Israeli Government today withdrew the press credentials of two foreign correspondents, from The Washington Post and NBC News, as punishment for reports that had not been submitted to a military censor.

title: Transportation Aide Named
description: President Reagan plans to nominate Wendy Monson DeMocker, a Government press secretary and former aide to Senator Dave Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, as an Assistant Secretary of Transportation, the White House announced today.

title: South Africa Issues Warning It Will Close Liberal Weekly
description: The Government has given the country's independent liberal weekly newspaper, The Weekly Mail, a final warning that it intends to close it for three months.

title: Doctor Seized in Christie Photo Theft
description: A New Haven physician was arrested in Manhattan yesterday and charged with the theft of a photograph on exhibition at Christie's Park Avenue auction house and with attempting to bribe the arresting officers.

title: Desert Partners
description: Desert Partners L.P. disclosed in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it needs the approval of Merrill Lynch & Company and Elders Investment Ltd. of Australia before it can sweeten its $42-a-share hostile tender offer for the USG Corporation. Desert Partners' latest offer, valued at $2.2 billion, has been rejected by the USG board as inadequate.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Indicators chart and the main stock market article in Business Day yesterday carried an erroneous figure supplied by The Associated Press for Monday's change in the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: Ex-Mayor of Syracuse Seeks Shorter Sentence
description: Former Mayor Lee Alexander, who has served less than two weeks of a 10-year prison sentence, will ask a Federal appeals court to reduce his term, according to his lawyer.

title: A.M.A. Files Motion For U.S. to Regulate Smokeless Cigarettes
description: The American Medical Association has asked the Food and Drug Administration to regulate the virtually smokeless cigarettes introduced last fall by the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company and to review their ingredients and safety before they go on the market.

title: St. Louis Journal; Stadium Plans Turn to Soybean Seed
description: In a painstaking effort to keep professional football in St. Louis, officials here planned a domed stadium with 70,000 seats and a movable ceiling along the Missouri River.

title: Wine Talk
description: IF cabernet sauvignon is the Cary Grant of grapes, then merlot is the Gig Young: handsome, likable, No. 1 in any other company, but rarely playing the lead. In most of the big productions - Lafite, Mouton and Mondavi, among others - cabernet is the star, with merlot in a supporting role.

title: Strike-Time Passer Tries Indoor Game
description: Jim Crocicchia, who has been looking for honest work since graduating from college almost a year ago, calls it ''a great summer job.'' At $1,000 a game, he will be the quarterback for the New York Knights, a new team in the Arena Football League that begins a 12-game season on Saturday night in Los Angeles and will play its first game at Madison Square Garden on May 9.

title: Smithsonian Acquires Duke Ellington Trove Of Scores and Papers
description: The Smithsonian Institution announced today the acquisition of a huge trove of papers, memorabilia and orchestral manuscripts of the music of Duke Ellington.

title: Korean Voters Strip Ruling Party Of Majority in National Assembly
description: South Korea's ruling party suffered an unprecedented loss of its legislative majority today against an opposition that registered strong gains despite bitter divisions.

title: Oil Nations Offer Cuts To OPEC
description: Oil producers outside the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have offered to reduce their exports of oil by about 5 percent in an effort to persuade OPEC members to join them in steps to bolster the price of oil.

title: Factory Jobs in 4-Year Drop
description: The number of Americans in manufacturing jobs has fallen since 1982, the Census Bureau said today. Over all, employment in manufacturing fell by 731,900 between 1982 and 1986, a decline of 4 percent, to 17,086,200, according to preliminary statistics from the 1986 Annual Survey of Manufactures.

title: Cartier to Acquire 2 Watch Concerns
description: Cartier S.A. said it would acquire a controlling interest in the Swiss watchmakers Piaget S.A. and Baume & Mercier S.A. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but Cartier's chairman, Alain Perrin, said the acquisition should help to increase Cartier's sales to $840 million this year.

title: Health Service Needs at Rikers I. Are Growing
description: To the Editor:

title: Five Are Killed As Two Houses Burn in Yonkers
description: A woman and four children died today in a fire that raced through two adjoining frame buildings in the downtown Nodine Hill area.

title: About New York; And He Can Get His Oil Changed At Any Grocer's
description: Louis Wichinsky was telling the story of his life while driving around the city in a 1980 Volkswagen Rabbit pickup truck that he had adapted to run on vegetable oil, a fuel that gave off fumes that made Mr. Wichinsky smell like a french fry. ''Anybody that goes along with an inventor is a virtual nut,'' he was saying as the odors one associates with short-order cooking swirled roundabout his creation. Accelerating to 50 miles an hour down the West Side Highway, the car coughed out the distinct aroma of doughnuts.

title: Colson Resigns
description: In an emotional news conference, Gary Colson resigned yesterday as head basketball coach at the University of New Mexico, ending an eight-year tenure during which he guided the program back from a major scandal. In his prepared statement, Colson cited ''a basic difference of opinion regarding his ability to lead the U.N.M. basketball program to the next level of success.'' Colson did not elaborate, but it is known Colson had met privately this week with Athletic Director John Koenig to discuss Colson's contract, which had two years remaining. He coached the Lobos to 146 victories and 106 losses, including 22-14 this season and five straight National Invitation Tournaments.

title: Of Corsets and Things Meant for Her Majesty And Ladies of Her Ilk
description: JUNE S. KENTON, corsetiere to Queen Elizabeth II, has arrived from London for a fortnight of fittings in New York, a metropolis teeming with women wearing the wrong brassieres. They should not be faulted, however, as roughly 75 percent of the world's bras do not really fit their wearers. This is an industry estimate that Mrs. Kenton has vowed to change.

title: Ward Assails Koch For Jackson Attacks And Urges Apology
description: New York City's Police Commissioner, Benjamin Ward, angrily criticized his boss, Mayor Koch, yesterday and said the Mayor should apologize for the attacks he made on the Rev. Jesse Jackson before the New York Presidential primary election.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., a manufacturer of aerospace, electronic and automotive materials, named Andrew B. Samet, the associate general counsel, to the additional posts of vice president and secretary.

title: Dukakis Wins Pennsylvania Race And Tightens Grip on Nomination
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts tightened his grip on the Democratic Presidential nomination today by trouncing the Rev. Jesse Jackson in the Pennsylvania primary.

title: Two Leave Ayer Board
description: Robert P. Zabel, 59, and George R. Eversman, 60, both of whom plan to retire this summer from N. W. Ayer, have resigned from its board. They will not be replaced, and the board now has 10 members. Mr. Zabel, a former president of Ayer, is chairman of the Midwest division in Chicago. He has been with the agency 36 years. Mr. Eversman, an alumnus of J. Walter Thompson, is an executive vice president and executive account director.

title: Big Hair Do
description: The telephone just rang and I picked it up and - this is no joke - a machine said, ''Hello, I'm from the Hair Loss Council.'' Before it could say another word, I hung up, as I always do when machines try to start phone conversations.

title: Veterans Shelter: Crack and Wine Are the Enemy Now
description: When Capt. Ronald Foreman of the Salvation Army opened New York City's first shelter for homeless veterans last fall, he saw it as an opportunity to help hundreds of men down on their luck make their way back into the mainstream.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Nystrom and Perez-Roldan Win: Joakim Nystrom of Sweden and Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina won second-round matches yesterday in a Grand Prix tournament in Hamburg, West Germany. Nystrom defeated Thierry Champion of France by 6-0, 6-2 on the Hamburg clay court in sunny but cool weather. Perez-Roldan beat Michael Westphal of West Germany by the same score. Other players moving into the third round include Hansjoerg Schwaier of West Germany, who defeated Jim Pugh of the United States, 6-3, 3-6, 6-2, and Ricki Osterthun of West Germany, who downed Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands, 7-5, 6-0. In other second-round matches, Tom Nijssen of the Netherlands beat Jan Gunnarsson of Sweden, 6-3, 5-7, 6-4, and Claudio Mezzadri of Switzerland overcame Alberto Tous of Spain, 3-6, 7-6, 6-4. (AP) Savchenko Advances: Larisa Savchenko of the Soviet Union, seeded fifth, lost the first set but came back to defeat Robin White of the United States, 1-6, 6-1, 6-4, in the first round of the Toray Pan Pacific Open in Fujisawa, Japan. Dianne Balestrat of Australia upset Catarina Lindqvist of Sweden, the sixth-seeded player, 6-3, 1-6, 6-0, and Peanut Harper of the United States beat Elizabeth Smylie of Australia, 7-6, 6-2.(AP) Agassi Beats Brown: Top-seeded Andre Agassi downed Jimmy Brown, and Diego Perez of Spain upset David Pate, seeded third, in first-round play in the 78th annual United States Men's Clay Court championships at Isle of Palms, S.C. Agassi, ranked No. 18 in the world, was a 6-1, 6-4 winner, and Perez won, 6-3, 6-1. In another match, Jimmy Arias, seeded seventh, advanced to the second round of a tournament for the first time this year, defeating Dan Cassidy, 6-2, 6-2.(AP) BOXING Mitchell Retains Title: Brian Mitchell of South Africa, the World Boxing Association junior lightweight champion, retained his title last night with a split decision over Jose Rivera of Puerto Rico in a bout in Madrid. Mitchell improved his record to 34-1-2. Rivera fell to 17-2-1.(AP)

title: Resettlement in Vietnam: A Hard Life
description: The village looks like the set for a Western: a single street of wooden storefronts on a dusty rise against distant mountains. The air is clear under a bright blue sky. The people are homesteaders, pioneers from Vietnam's overpopulated capital, Hanoi. Nam Ban and its sister settlement, Tan Ha, about 25 miles to the southwest, are still commonly known as Hanoi Moi - New Hanoi.

title: Steel Strike Widens Polish Labor Unrest
description: Labor unrest erupted in Poland for a second day today when the big Lenin steelworks near Cracow was struck by workers demanding higher pay and workers at a second major steel and heavy machinery works declared a strike alert.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: First City to Convert 33 Units Into Branches
description: The First City Bancorporation of Texas will move soon to convert 33 of its 59 subsidiary banks into branches, a step that would leave First City ''much more efficient,'' A. Robert Abboud, chairman and chief executive, said in an interview today.

title: KEY RATES
Aguascalientes Journal; In the Footsteps of Cardenas, Cardenas Campaigns
description: Loudspeakers had trumpeted his arrival, and as Cuauhtemoc Cardenas strode through the streets looking for votes, a crowd quickly formed and surged around him. As beaming parents pressed their small children to him, grizzled peasants in sandals and straw hats, some moved to tears, shouted, ''Long live the son of the patriot general!''

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Sequa Corporation, formerly the Sun Chemical Corporation, offered $150 million worth of 10 1/2 percent 10-year notes through a syndicate led by Drexel Burnham Lambert yesterday. The notes, which mature on

title: Pilots Rate the Safety of Airports; Dallas Ranks Best
description: Pilots responding to a newspaper survey rated New York's LaGuardia Airport as the third most dangerous in the country, but they cautioned that is hard to judge safety because individual workers can make all the difference.

title: Market Place; Clamor for Zenith To Sell a Division
description: AS losses have mounted at the Zenith Electronics Corporation's consumer electronics division, investors have begun putting pressure on the last major American manufacturer of televisions to sell its troubled unit.

title: A Japanese View of World War II Is Attacked
description: A Cabinet minister's declaration last week that Japan was not an aggressor in World War II has brought expressions of outrage from Japan's Asian neighbors.

title: For the Hardy, a San Francisco Swim
description: LEAD: THE last place a reasonable person would want to be at 6:30 A.M. is in San Francisco Bay.

title: Senate Panel Votes to Subpoena North Diaries in Drug Inquiry
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 16 to 1 today to subpoena the private working diaries of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North in its continuing investigation of international drug smuggling.

title: Disparity in College Courses on Vietnam
description: College courses on the Vietnam War have exploded in the last few years, now numbering in the hundreds, reflecting widespread interest by young Americans about the war, according to experts at a major conference here on teaching about Vietnam.

title: A Taste of Spring, In Tender Greenery
description: THE weatherman can say what he wants, but the calendar says spring is here. With it comes the prospect of the whole gamut of tender young seasonal vegetables that the French, with culinary exactitude, call ''primeurs,'' or firstlings.

title: Soviet Rations Sugar in Move to Foil Moonshiners
description: In an assault on the prospering moonshine industry that has grown up during Mikhail S. Gorbachev's anti-alcohol campaign, the Soviet authorities have begun to impose sugar rationing in parts of the country.

title: Orioles' Losing Streak at 19
description: The Baltimore Orioles fell to 0-19 tonight and are one game from tying the longest losing streak in American League history. The Orioles lost to the Minnesota Twins, 4-2, on two home runs by Kent Hrbek and another by Randy Bush.

title: Review/Television; The Met Opera's 'Ariadneauf Naxos'
description: Tonight at 8:30 on Channel 13, ''The Metropolitan Opera Presents'' (formerly ''Live From the Met'') concludes its season with ''Ariadne auf Naxos.'' Produced by Samuel J. Paul, the series has been at its best this year with a mix of unusually telegenic productions. The two previous presentations were ''Turandot,'' approached with unbridled lavishness by Franco Zeffirelli, and a handsome, well-acted rendering of ''The Tales of Hoffmann.''

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Celebrating the Finns
description: President Reagan is scheduled to visit Finland for three days at the end of next month. But before that he will receive Finland's Prime Minister Harri Holkeri here.

title: Devils Defeat Capitals, 3-1
description: An insatiable appetite for hard work, effective forechecking and the ability to kill penalties are the qualities that have brought sudden success to the Devils this spring.

title: A Changing World for Secretaries
description: Charles Miller will not be treating his secretary to lunch this week. About a year ago, Mr. Miller, president of a small computer company in Los Angeles, bought a system that, by automatically answering telephone calls, eliminated the job.

title: North's Diaries Are Sought
description: A Senate panel subpoenaed the private working diaries of Oliver L. North in its investigation of international drug trafficking. Page A18.

title: Saving Greenmarkets
description: To The Living Section:

title: CMP Publications Plans Long Island Monthly
description: The latest attempt to establish a Long Island ''city magazine'' is being made by a successful Manhasset publishing company with considerable experience in the trade field.

title: With Race in Ohio, Jackson Shifts Focus Abroad
description: Returning to the international arena, where he has had some flashy successes, the Rev. Jesse Jackson flew to Washington today and descended on Capitol Hill and the State Department to take up the issue of South Africa. Later he traveled to Ohio, the next primary state in the campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Belo Earnings Decline 59.3%
description: The A. H. Belo Corporation said its earnings had declined by 59.3 percent in the first quarter from the corresponding period last year because of higher operating costs and weak advertising demand.

title: Bordeaux, '85: A Very Good Year, Indeed
description: LIKE patrician debutantes in deep red gowns who are regally presented at a coming-out party, the Bordeaux wines of 1985, one of the standout vintages of the decade, were introduced in New York City at a black-tie dinner at the Four Seasons on Sunday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a recipe for duck confit in The Living Section last Wednesday with an article about the Coyote Cafe in Santa Fe, N.M., omitted a footnote. The note should have said:

title: Ex-Controller of Philadelphia Wins Democratic Senate Bid
description: Former City Controller Joseph Vignola won Pennsylvania's Democratic Senatorial primary today, setting up a contest with the Republican incumbent, John Heinz.

title: What Koch Said About Jackson and Why
description: To the Editor:

title: New Cooking Surface: Light Anodized Aluminum
description: GREAT advances have been made in recent years in the technology of pots and pans, with the development of new alloys and designs that increase efficiency and longevity. Much of this progress has come at a stiff price, however: quality cookware is costly. A heavy-duty copper or stainless steel saute pan can easily cost $75, and a basic set of pots and pans can cost hundreds of dollars.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: IT has been a slow process, but Americans seem finally to be adopting a vegetable that is, to my mind, one of the finest greens now available in this country. I have noticed that it is available in increasing quantities in my relatively small community on Eastern Long Island.

title: Big Stake By WCRS In Europe
description: BRITAIN'S WCRS Group, with worldwide billings of $1.63 billion and several properties in the United States, has reached an agreement to acquire half of SGGMD, Europe's largest media-buying group, for $121.2 million. The deal comes as a media revolution is building on the Continent.

title: Carolyn Franklin, 43, Singer and Songwriter
description: Carolyn Ann Franklin, a singer and songwriter, died of cancer on Monday. She was 43 years old.

title: Who Can Beat Koch in '89?
description: LEAD: New York City's political center of gravity shifted when the Rev.

title: Treasury Prices Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were little changed in light trading yesterday, as market participants grappled with a report on the nation's economic growth and rising fears about a possible rise in oil prices.

title: Review/Theater; 'Lucky Stiff,' a Musical From a Crime Novel
description: Only two weeks after Broadway delivered us ''Mail,'' a musical whose opening song paraphrases Stephen Sondheim's ''Company,'' Off Broadway has rolled out ''Lucky Stiff,'' a musical whose opening ensemble number recalls Mr. Sondheim's ''Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum.'' The song, titled ''Something Funny's Going On,'' promises the audience at Playwrights Horizons comedy tonight -and comedy, even if derivative, is a much-needed antidote to the gloom and gargantuan extravagance of so much of our current musical theater. ''Lucky Stiff,'' a farcical adaptation of a crime novel by Michael Butterworth, offers no metaphors, no portentous themes, no melancholy relationships. It does have $6 million in stolen loot, a henpecked optometrist, a plethora of offstage dogs and a happy ending, of course.

title: Meese Is Seeking to Require Drug Testing in All Arrests
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d told the nation's mayors today that he would like to see that ''every person arrested is subjected to a urine test'' to detect drug use.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Justice Dept. in Compromise On Ban of Undetectable Guns
description: The Reagan Administration and law-enforcement groups agreed today on compromise legislation to ban undetectable plastic pistols, using an approach that has been staunchly opposed by the National Rifle Association and its legislative supporters.

title: Sequel to Auction of 'Gone With the Wind' Sequel
description: Every book auction is a gamble, and Monday's $4.94 million winning bid by Warner Books for the sequel to ''Gone With the Wind'' is proof that the stakes are often high.

title: Brother of Bush Urges Committeeman to Leave
description: In an early display of post-primary political muscle by Vice President Bush, his brother, Jonathan, yesterday called on Richard M. Rosenbaum to step down as the state's Republican national committeeman.

title: Mall Murder: Security Guard's Secret Criminal Past
description: A security guard charged with killing a teen-ager in the Brooklyn shopping mall he patrolled had served 18 months in prison for armed robbery. But because a state agency was required to keep his criminal record secret, the company that hired him never learned of his conviction.

title: Lacrosse Notebook; Johns Hopkins Still Going Strong in Its 100th Year
description: The 100th anniversary of Johns Hopkins's first lacrosse victory was celebrated with another triumph on Saturday as a crowd of 10,050 squeezed into Homewood Field in North Baltimore for the Homecoming Day contest against Maryland.

title: Indictment of Businessman Links Racketeering and Waste Disposal
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted a Rhode Island businessman on racketeering charges related to alleged violations of Federal hazardous waste laws by his company, the Justice Department said.

title: Ethiopia On the Brink
description: LEAD: Last week, President Reagan appealed to Mikhail S. Gorbachev to intervene in Ethiopia before the famine there is taken to an even grimmer level by a ''scorched earth'' policy imposed by the Moscow-backed Government. The recent expulsion of foreign relief workers from areas where both civil war and famine are escalating can only mean, Mr.

title: Dining With Babies
description: To The Living Section:

title: Economic Scene; Executive Pay: Is It Too High?
description: DID Jim Manzi really deserve the $26.3 million he was paid as chairman of the Lotus Corporation in 1987? How about Waste Management's Phillip Rooney, who received $14.3 million?

title: Singapore Tourism Up
description: Singapore had 3.68 million tourists last year, 15.3 percent more than in 1986, the Singapore Tourist Promotion Board said today. In its latest bulletin, the board said that tourist spending for the year also increased by 21.3 percent, to about $2.35 billion.

title: BUSH, PENNSYLVANIA VICTOR, NOW HAS ENOUGH DELEGATES TO CAPTURE THE NOMINATION
description: Vice President Bush clinched the Republican Presidential nomination with an overwhelming victory Tuesday in the Pennsylvania primary.

title: What's Needed to Oust Noriega
description: After two months of Yanqui economic pressure, Panama's drug-dealing dictator, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, stubbornly holds on to power. The sanctions have had an effect, however: they have brought suffering to Panamanians, threatened their country's economic future and aroused Latin American sensitivity to Yankee intrusion.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Congressional Penchant For Experimental Efforts
description: The $8.3 billion education bill that Congress passed last week calls for largely experimental programs that could cost up to $400 million in all and are aimed at tackling challenges from adult illiteracy to the education of gifted and talented children.

title: 'Joe Turner' Not Closing
description: ''Joe Turner's Come and gone'' is continuing regular performances at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, Elliot Martin, a producer of the August Wilson drama, said Monday. A closing notice that had been posted last week because of poor attendance was taken down Sunday after business at the box office surged over the weekend.

title: A Few Books Lawyers Still Have to Consult
description: To the Editor:

title: About Education
description: The nation's business schools have become self-satisfied, complacent and unresponsive to changing domestic and international conditions. They lack a ''forceful push for systematic curriculum change'' even though the business community is dissatisfied with much that is being taught.

title: Student Is Charged in Death of Fraternity Pledge In Jersey
description: A Rider College student has been charged with aggravated manslaughter in a drinking-related car crash during a fraternity ritual that led to the death of another student, the authorities said.

title: Nestle Bids $3.95 Billion for Rowntree
description: Nestle S.A., the Swiss-based consumer products giant, today announced a $3.95 billion bid for Rowntree P.L.C., but the board of the British confectioner, which is best known for its Kit Kat bar, rejected the offer.

title: Hospital to Lose U.S. Payments For Health Care
description: Parsons Hospital, a 100-bed institution in Flushing, Queens, will be cut off from Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement in June, according to Federal officials.

title: New York Bureaucracy Is Not User Friendly
description: To the Editor:

title: NTC Head Paved Way For J. P. Stevens Deal
description: Thomas C. Foley smoothed the way for a compromise between rival parties that led to an agreement over the weekend on the sale of J. P. Stevens & Company, the big textile producer.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: 4 Hurt in Air Compressor Explosion at Manhattan Construction Site
description: Three pedestrians and a construction worker were injured yesterday when an air compressor hose exploded at a construction site on the Avenue of the Americas, hurling debris into the street and starting a small fire.

title: 35 Pages That Shook the U.S. Education World
description: ''A Nation at Risk,'' the report whose fifth anniversary was observed here today in a ceremony in the East Room of the White House, already ranks as one of the most significant documents in the history of American public education.

title: Review/Ballet; First 'Sleeping Beauty' Of Ballet Theater Season
description: ''The Sleeping Beauty'' is surely the grandest choreographic spectacle of the 19th century. With its curses, spells and struggles between good and evil, it's also a good story. And, though the pace is leisurely, it's a story well told, thanks to the choreographic variety of the dances that Marius Petipa created in 1890. For a production of this ballet to come alive, the cast must both dance well and take the story seriously.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Increase 3.4% on Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered for the most active over-the-counter securities edged up by 4.7 million shares, or 3.4 percent, in the month ended April 14.

title: Knight Is Criticized Over Rape Remark
description: Bob Knight's analogy between handling stress and being raped, expressed during a documentary on national television Monday night, drew strong criticism yesterday from the president of Indiana University and from the university women's affairs office.

title: Everyman's Guide to Life as a Paraplegic
description: A VENTURESOME editor in Colorado has published a book with a casual but thorough approach to a topic most people tend to resist thinking about at all: life as a paraplegic.

title: U.S. LOSES RULING IN WORLD COURT ON P.L.O. MISSION
description: The World Court ruled unanimously today that the United States must submit to international arbitration in its attempt to close the Palestine Liberation Organization observer mission to the United Nations.

title: Arms Talks: The Pace Is Slow, for Now
description: In the recent talks in Moscow, the United States and the Soviet Union made just enough progress to suggest that the negotiations on a new strategic arms treaty are gradually moving forward. But the two sides did not accomplish enough to insure a good chance of completing a pact this year.

title: Bank of New York Shareholders Vote
description: The Bank of New York Company said yesterday that it had won shareholders approval to issue an unlimited number of new shares as part of its takeover bid for Irving Bank Corporation of 1.575 shares of common stock and $15 in cash for all of Irving's shares.

title: Caption; Lobsterman Hunts His Crustacean Prey Off the Connecticut Shore
description: Robert Vissa, above, baiting one of his 600 lobster traps as he headed out into Long Island Sound past the Riverside Yacht Club in Greenwich. Below, Mr. Vissa hauls traps into boat where the lobsters are banded, right, before being sold to wholesalers. (NYT/Steve Zavatski)

title: Profits Rise At 3 Big Oil Companies
description: Texaco Inc., the Phillips Petroleum Corporation and the Chevron Corporation all reported much stronger profits in the first quarter yesterday, bolstered by chemicals and refining and marketing operations.

title: F.D.A. Panel Calls for Curbs on Acne Drug Linked to Birth Defects
description: An expert advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration recommended today that distribution of Accutane, an acne drug linked to birth defects, be restricted so that it would be more difficult for young women to obtain.

title: Who's Hiding the Money?
description: All over America today, parents are ripping apart their sons' mail, attacking music cassettes with hammer and screwdriver. This is it, the big break, no more cheap cars, no more clipping coupons.

title: DUKAKIS IS VICTOR IN UTAH CONTEST
description: Michael S. Dukakis swept to an easy victory over the Rev. Jesse Jackson in the Utah Presidential caucuses Monday night, collecting a large majority of the state's 23 Democratic delegates.

title: Dole Accuses Press and TV of Failing to Focus on Campaign Issues
description: Senator Bob Dole, an unsuccessful candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination this year, took the Senate floor today to criticize coverage of all the campaigns by television and the press, particularly The New York Times.

title: Solid Outlook For Britain
description: With consumer demand strong, British business confidence is booming, the Confederation of British Industries said today.

title: Hollywood Welcomes Back Older Audience
description: The director of ''Broadcast News'' called it ''the return of language to film.'' The writer of ''Chinatown'' said, ''Studios are more responsive to stories that involve grown-ups, and when you can write about grown-ups you feel better.'' And the producer of ''Fatal Attraction'' said, ''If you say you want to do a picture about a marriage, today the executives let you finish your sentence.''

title: 60's Find a Place in 80's Classrooms
description: With surprising scholarly detachment, Boston College's History 101 class recently analyzed two documents of the 1960's: the lyrics of Janis Joplin's recording of ''Bobby McGee'' and of Steppenwolf's ''Born to be Wild.''

title: AIDS Crisis Spurs Shift In Program for Addicts
description: Since its founding 19 years ago, Spectrum House has treated drug addicts by stressing a message of hope.

title: Lessons
description: Long after the fire of reform goes out, Richard Mitchell will still be writing ''meditations on foolish language,'' about the nonsense of college presidents, grade school teachers, principals, educational policy makers and the like.

title: New Life for an Old Idea
description: Traditional electric motors can spin a shaft at speeds up to 10,000 revolutions a minute. At higher speeds, the motor rotors, which include the metal shaft and an assembly of laminations, wire windings or magnets, are torn apart by centrifugal force. The problem plagues both rotors for induction-type motors and synchronous motors, above left, and is particularly troublesome for high-power motors. REM Technologies, a new company started in Albany by several former General Electric employees, has developed an electric motor with a solid rotor that has no windings or laminations and is capable of reaching 50,000 r.p.m., the burst strength of the steel rotor itself, designers said.

title: Digress Out Of Derby
description: Digress, who would have been among the favorites in the Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland Thursday, was not entered for the race this morning and will miss the Kentucky Derby on May 7, his owner said today. ''We shipped him up from

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Abraham W. Zucker, Bond Dealer, 76
description: Abraham W. Zucker, a municipal bond dealer, died of colon cancer Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76 years old and for many years had lived in Ossining, N.Y.

title: Thwarted Builder Takes Case to the Public in Ads
description: To Richard M. Griffith, his latest advertising campaign is an experiment in ''Athenian democracy.'' To Mayor Raymond J. O'Grady, it is ''a crap shoot with the people of the township.''

title: Saudis Break Diplomatic Ties With Iran, Citing Mecca Riots and Gulf Raids
description: Saudi Arabia said today that it was breaking diplomatic relations with Iran and it asked all Iranian diplomats to leave the kingdom within a week.

title: Casting a Shadow Over Civil Rights
description: At the very least, the freedom that Congress is empowered to secure under the 13th Amendment includes the freedom to buy whatever a white man can buy, the right to live wherever a white man can live. If Congress cannot say that being a free man means this much, then the 13th Amendment made a promise the Nation cannot keep.

title: Open-Hearth Cooking: Why All the Fuss Over Hot Ashes?
description: OPEN-HEARTH cooking has made a surprising comeback since the Bicentennial 12 years ago, and it may develop into one of the more unusual trends in American cookery over the next 10 years.

title: Seagram Has China Pact
description: The Seagram Company hopes its entry into the vast Chinese market under a joint-venture agreement will generate $1 billion (American) in revenues within 10 years, its president of international operations said today.

title: Saturn to Continue Firestone Supplies
description: The General Motors Corporation's Saturn subsidiary said it would retain the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company as its sole supplier of tires for the planned Saturn compact auto even though G.M. has said it will drop Firestone as a supplier for its existing models. The Saturn automobile, which will be built in Spring Hill, Tenn., is set for introduction in 1990. On Sunday, G.M. said it would sharply curtail its Firestone business and end its relationship with the supplier in two years.

title: N.B.A. and Union in Accord
description: After more than a year of stalled negotiations and legal clashes, the National Basketball Association and the players' union yesterday announced an unexpected agreement on a new six-year contract. Both sides said that the accord would virtually assure increased prosperity for the teams and the players.

title: ISRAEL ARMY FOILS RAID BY GUERRILLAS
description: Two Israeli soldiers and three Palestinian guerrillas were killed in a shooting battle today when an Israeli patrol came upon the guerrillas infiltrating from Lebanon, the army said.

title: Top Jersey Court Overturns Bail in Child Molester Case
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court today revoked the $1 million bail granted by an appeals court to Margaret Kelly Michaels, the former day-care worker convicted of molesting pre-schoolers.

title: Publishers Are Urged To Spur Minority Hiring
description: For the first time in its history, the American Newspaper Publishers Association today made work force diversity a centerpiece on the program of its annual convention.

title: Human Tests Announced for New AIDS Vaccine
description: An experimental AIDS vaccine developed in the United States will be tested in Britain beginning this summer. The tests will involve volunteers already infected with the AIDS virus.

title: Possible Penalty
description: Dick Beaty, a Nascar official, will meet with a driver, Kyle Petty, today to discuss a possible penalty following an incident in which Petty was accused of swerving his car in the direction of inspectors during last Sunday's race at Martinsville, Va.

title: Byrd Warns Trade Veto Could Hurt Canada Pact
description: The Senate Democratic leadership warned President Reagan today that a veto of the omnibus trade bill could jeopardize the free-trade accord with Canada that is awaiting Congressional approval.
