Mike Donald birdied three holes on the front nine and played steadily on the back side for a 67.(AP) BOXING Dokes Knocks Out Pritchard: Michael Dokes won the Continental Americas heavyweight title last night when he knocked out James Pritchard at 2 minutes 32 seconds of the seventh round of a scheduled 12-round bout at the Felt Forum. For Dokes, a former world heavyweight champion, it was his fourth straight victory in a comeback that began last December after a 33-month absence from the ring. With the victory, Dokes's record goes to 33-1-2 with 20 knockouts. Pritchard is 18-2-1 with 14 knockouts.

title: Kim Dae Jung on the Rebound: Taking Off the Gloves
description: Kim Dae Jung, who appeared to be in political decline in the aftermath of the presidential election earlier this year, emerged from this week's National Assembly election as South Korea's strongest opposition figure.

title: Main Line Journal Diversity Finally Invades a Corridor of Old Suburban Wealth
description: If anyone ever personified the storied Main Line, it was Katharine Hepburn as Tracy Lord in the film ''The Philadelphia Story.''

title: U.S.-Japan Pact in Doubt
description: The United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said today that he was pessimistic about the chances for a quick settlement of a dispute with Japan over United States beef and citrus exports.

title: Outdoor Flower Sale
description: An outdoor flower sale to benefit the East Village Visiting Neighbors is planned tomorrow from noon to 5 P.M at St. Mark's-in-the-Bowery Church, Second Avenue at East 10th Street. On sale will be fresh cut flowers and house plants, as well as silk flowers. The East Village Visiting Neighbors is an eight-year-old organization that provides assistance to elderly residents in the area. Information: 477-6582.

title: Blast Rocks Jet Over Hawaii; 59 Injured and One Missing
description: At least 59 people were injured, three critically, and one person was reported missing today in a midair explosion aboard an Aloha Airlines Boeing 737 carrying 95 people from Hilo to Honolulu, the authorities said.

title: Bank Bidder Is Tendered 54% of Irving
description: The Bank of New York Company said yesterday that it had received about 54 percent of the shares of the Irving Bank Corporation, which it is seeking to acquire. Analysts called this another sign that the eight-month hostile takeover battle may be drawing to a close in the Bank of New York's favor.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Books of The Times; The Images and Beliefs That Underlie Fear of Nuclear Power
description: Nuclear Fear A History of Images By Spencer R. Weart 535 pages. Harvard University Press. $29.50.

title: Compromise Sought on Trade Bill
description: With President Reagan reiterating that he will veto the sweeping trade legislation that Congress has produced, Administration officials have suggested the Democrats return to a compromise bill they walked away from two weeks ago.

title: Afghan Islamic Parties: 7 in Search of a Leader
description: The Afghan guerrilla alliance is entering a crucial period when, with the Soviet army withdrawing, it may have a chance to seize and govern the country though it is not a unified liberation movement under a generally accepted leadership.

title: Housing Inquiry Leads to 8 New Indictments
description: Five more housing supervisors and three more contractors were indicted yesterday in a continuing investigation of bribery and kickbacks in the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney.

title: NATO Agrees to Keep Atom Arms Into 90's
description: The defense ministers of the NATO countries agreed today that Western Europe would still have nuclear weapons in some form in the 1990's.

title: KEY U.S. SHIFT SEEN TO JOB PROTECTION FROM FREE TRADE
description: While President Reagan and Congress have not come to terms on a new trade law, they have agreed on an important shift in policy - one that protects American industries and workers more than it values free trade.

title: Fuel-Price Strikes in Nigeria
description: Bank employees in Lagos went on strike today to protest higher fuel prices, helping to raise tensions between trade unions and Nigeria's military Government. National newspapers said illegal strikes over fuel prices were still spreading in northern Nigeria. They reported 14 union leaders were arrested, and nurses and midwives were threatening a walkout at state-run hospitals across the country. Lagos banks were closed by the strike.

title: The Law; Coming of Age of the Environmental Lawyer
description: Those who still think of an environmental lawyer as a long-haired youth in sandals with bald eagles for clients should look at the firm of Latham & Watkins here. About 40 of the 450 lawyers in its six offices practice environmental law, making the firm a major player in the game nationally.

title: Kuhn and Carter
description: The duo of Steve Kuhn, pianist and Ron Carter, bassist, will perform tonight and tomorrow at Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440). Music begins at 9:45; there is a $5 cover and an $8 minimum.

title: Chamber Music
description: The violinist Cho-Liang Lin will play a chamber music concert with Li Jian, pianist, and Bion Tsang, cellist, on Sunday at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. Their program is to include Beethoven's ''Archduke'' Trio, Kodaly's Duo for Violin and Cello and a Fantasia for Violin and Piano by Xia Liang, a young Chinese composer. Tickets are $15. Information: 362-1911.

title: 20th-Century Sculpture At the Met Museum
description: A new display of 20th-century sculpture will mark the reopening on Sunday of the Iris and B. Gerald Cantor Roof Garden at the Metropolitan Mueum of Art. The garden, which was first opened last year, has been closed for the winter.

title: The Artist's Eye: Dorothea Rockburne; A New-World Painter Views the Masterpieces of Old-World Innovators
description: FOR Dorothea Rockburne, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a special place. She worked there part time for several years after arriving in New York in the mid-1950's, tagging objects for the Egyptian department and helping out in the finance office. She studied the collections of Greek and Egyptian sculpture and Italian painting.

title: Review/Film; 'Powaqqatsi,' Cataloguing Existences
description: There are two kinds of dirt to be found in ''Powaqqatsi'': good dirt and bad. The former is the glistening mud that coats sinewy peasant laborers, outlining the contours of their lean bodies, caking their untroubled faces and their unencumbered feet. The latter is urban grime, part of the blight that afflicts these same simple souls when they fall under modern civilization's long shadow.

title: KEY RATES
Mass Starvation Feared as Ethiopia Curtails Aid
description: The Government of Ethiopia has so severely restricted emergency relief operations in the country's north, a region ravaged by both drought and war, that as many as two million people are out of reach of any known system of food distribution, aid officials and Western diplomats say.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is not our position to stop cooperating with the Soviet Union, especially when the situation is not settled yet.'' - President Najibullah of Afghanistan. [ A1:1 ]

title: To Mop Up Military Gravy
description: No waste in government is more obvious than keeping military bases open only to benefit a particular congressman's or senator's constituents. At last, leading members of Congress have come up with a sensible, nonpolitical antidote. They propose a bipartisan commission that would select bases to be closed, saving up to $5 billion a year.

title: Review/Art; Linking Politics, Repression and Business
description: With dogged intensity, Hans Haacke unravels the pacts binding money to art. Mr. Haacke's latest exhibition at the John Weber Gallery, appropriately entitled ''Business: As Usual,'' finds him once again uncovering and laying bare the discomfiting activities of multinational corporations, lauded publicly for their cultural patronage but quietly carrying out profitable associations with repressive regimes. It remains a bracing message, even if one that Mr. Haacke has served up many times before.

title: On Stage
description: 809 and 35 Miles Off Broadway

title: C. Sterling Bunnell, Banker, 86
description: C. Sterling Bunnell, a former executive of the First National City Bank and former director of Citibank, died of heart failure Saturday at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Cornwall, Conn.

title: Auctions
description: Postwar Works

title: N. W>. Ayer to Open Dallas Office for Penney
description: In order to better serve its client J. C. Penney, the giant retail chain that has moved its headquarters to Dallas, N. W. Ayer will open a full-service office there on June 1. It will be staffed largely by indigenous personnel.

title: Seizure of Assets Presses Drug Suspects
description: In seizing the apartment leases of two suspected drug dealers in New York City Wednesday, Federal authorities broke new legal ground in their fight against illicit drug trafficking by tenants of public housing projects.

title: Campaign Trail
description: The Dixon Solution

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anchor Savings Bank, Hewlett, L.I., will buy Residential Funding Corp. from Salomon Inc., which said the sale would generate proceeds of about $60 million with a pretax gain of about $13 million.

title: Sports People; Coach for Rhode Island
description: Al Skinner, a former college teammate of Rick Pitino at the University of Massachusetts and a former guard with the Nets, was appointed head basketball coach yesterday at the University of Rhode Island, where he had been an assistant coach for four years. Skinner, 36 years old, succeeds Tom Penders, who resigned to move to the University of Texas. Skinner was signed to a three-year contract for an undisclosed salary, Edward Eddy, the school president, who has been criticized for not doing enough to keep Penders at Rhode Island, said the university had committed $250,000 of the prize money earned in the recent National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament to improve the school's basketball facilities. Skinner was an All East selection while playing in the early 1970's at the University of Massachusetts with Pitino, now the coach of the Knicks., As a pro he played with the Nets, the Detroit Pistons and the Philadelphia 76ers. (AP)

title: Hapchon Journal; A Different Hiroshima Story: The Bitter Koreans
description: Chung Ki Jang has spent most of his life as a footnote to history.

title: Review/Film; 'Da' Adaptation, With Barnard Hughes
description: Ten years after Broadway gave Barnard Hughes a Tony Award for his rich, funny, affecting performance in Hugh Leonard's Irish comedy, ''Da,'' movie audiences finally have the chance to see that performance in the screen adaptation opening today at the Paris theater.

title: Celebrating the Bard With Free Park Events
description: A week after Shakespeare's 424th birthday and the Broadway opening of ''Macbeth,'' the Bard is to be celebrated with free performances in Central Park tomorrow from noon to 4 P.M. by more than 15 of the city's Shakespeare companies. Three stages along Literary Walk, between East 66th and 72d Streets, are to be filled with excerpts of various Shakespeare plays by the Riverside, Kings County and Parks Shakespeare companies. In addition, there are to be songs, sonnets and Renaissance music; take-offs on Shakespeare; puppet plays and performances by young Shakespeareans - winners of the National Youth Shakespeare Competition and students at La Guardia High School.

title: Wesray-Carter
description: The William Carter Company, a maker of infants' and children's wear, said it had reached a definitive agreement to be acquired by Wesray Capital, a private investment group, for $70 a share in cash. Carter has about 1.7 million common shares outstanding, said Jim Haymes, senior vice president of finance. Carter had an earlier offer of $54 a share from Crescott Castle Partners. One of Wesray's co-founders is William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary. The group has had impressive returns from a number of companies that it has taken private in leveraged buyouts and then has sold assets or eventually sold shares to the public again.

title: Norwest Financial Notes Yield 9.037%
description: The Norwest Financial Corporation offered $100 million of 9 percent five-year notes yesterday through a syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Wave Hill Trio
description: The Wave Hill Trio (Marian Hahn, pianist; Sung-Ju Lee, violinist, and Roberta Cooper, cellist) is to give the world premiere of Gerald Cohen's Trio at Wave Hill's Armor Hall, 249th Street and Independence Avenue, the Bronx, on Sunday afternoon at 3 o'clock. Also on the program are the Beethoven Trio in E flat (Op. 1, No. 1), and the Brahms Piano Quartet in A (Op. 26), with Paul Neubauer, violist. Tickets are $7. Information: 549-3200.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * CBS Records Division, the U.S. record company of CBS Records Inc., a subsidiary of Sony Corp. of Tokyo, named Tommy Mottola president.

title: Canadian Pacific Sells Certificates
description: Canadian Pacific Ltd. offered $100 million of 10-year equipment trust certificates yesterday. The 9.45 percent notes, which mature on May 1, 1998, are noncallable for seven years. They were priced at 99 7/8 to yield 9.47 percent, or 60 basis points over the current yield on Treasury securities of similar maturity.

title: Afghan Ruler Says Soviet Advisers Will Remain After Troop Pullout
description: President Najibullah of Afghanistan said today that Soviet military advisers would remain behind to help the Afghan armed forces after a Soviet troop withdrawal.

title: Gillette Alters Bylaws In Coniston Dispute
description: The Gillette Company has amended its bylaws in an effort to limit the power of candidates backed by Coniston Partners in the event the nominees succeed in gaining seats on the board, the company said yesterday.

title: CHINA ISSUES DRAFT OF HONG KONG LAW
description: China today issued a draft of a constitution for Hong Kong that would grant considerable autonomy in economic, trade, cultural and political affairs for 50 years after British rule ends in 1997.

title: Harcourt Says Loss Widened
description: Burdened by the heavy debt it assumed two years ago when it initiated a recapitalization plan to fight off a takeover attempt, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. yesterday reported a net loss of $35.5 million for the first quarter, nearly four times its loss of $9.4 million a year earlier.

title: Turning on 'a Faucet' For Pentax's IQZoom
description: Things are going swimmingly for Pentax. Sales are up worldwide on its SF1 35-millimeter camera as the result of the top rating it got in the February Consumer Reports.

title: Will Bush, Dukakis Be Able to Govern?
description: LEAD: This seems to be the year when nobody is required to say what he would do as President. It should be pointed out to Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis that noncommittal campaigns that emphasize management skills tend to produce weak presidencies.

title: Jobs Cut in Merger
description: About 750 employees will be cut from the combined staffs of Mercantile Bancorp Inc. and Centerre Bancorp after a merger of the bank holding companies, Donald E. Lasater, Mercantile's chairman, said. The cuts will occur through attrition to the extent possible, Mr. Lasater told the annual shareholders meeting. The two banking companies last week agreed to merge in a stock swap and estimated annual cost savings of about $40 million. The new company will be called Mercantile Centerre Inc.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Bullet That Killed Sergeant Came From an Officer's Gun, Police Say
description: Reversing their initial account, New York City police officials said yesterday that the bullet that killed a police sergeant during a drug raid in upper Manhattan on Wednesday came from another policeman's gun, not from the gun fired by a pregnant woman in the apartment.

title: Officials of 44 Wall St. Settle
description: Two senior officers and two outside directors of the 44 Wall Street Fund today settled Federal civil charges that they violated their fiduciary duties to the mutual fund's shareholders. They were barred from further association with any investment company.

title: Thor E. Wood, 55; Led Library Center On Performing Arts
description: Thor E. Wood, chief of the Performing Arts Research Center of the New York Public Library, died of complications from AIDS yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 55 years old.

title: Washington Talk: The White House; At Monday Luncheons, Issues Are on the Menu
description: There are some subjects around the White House in the waning months of Ronald Reagan's Presidency about which his aides avoid comment: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d is one, and the issues briefing luncheon, held each Monday afternoon in the Cabinet Room, is another.

title: China to Offer Food Subsidies to Urban Residents
description: China's urban residents will be given cash food subsidies to supplement stagnant wages and offset increasing food prices, the official New China News Agency reported today.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Appointment in Cannes

title: Panama Arrests Several Opposition Members
description: The Panamanian military regime has arrested several members of the opposition even as a special American envoy was reportedly in Panama to try to negotiate the resignation of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, opposition figures said today.

title: S.E.C. Fights Delaware Regulation
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has taken the position that Delaware's recently enacted takeover law is unconstitutional.

title: Capitals Rout Devils and Send Series to a 7th Game
description: In a series in which playing on the road has been the best motivator for both teams, the Washington Capitals, the visiting team, evened their Patrick Division championship series against the Devils at 3-3 with a 7-2 victory tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: B-E-E, as in 'a Rewarding Pastime for Juvenile Inmates'
description: During the spelling bee at Spofford Juvenile Center yesterday, the teachers tried to use the words in sentences that made them more meaningful to the contestants.

title: Life at Eastern Airlines: A Lost Sense of 'Family'
description: For many of Eastern Airline's 33,000 employees, working for a company at the edge of financial ruin had become a way of life. For more than a decade they watched as it limped along in a seemingly indefinite state of fragmentation, more or less at war with itself.

title: Ex-Executive Says Wedtech Sought Connection to Bush
description: A former Wedtech executive testified yesterday that the South Bronx company hired a Princeton, N.J., management consultant ''because of his contact'' with Vice President Bush.

title: This Slogan Won't Help the Market
description: When investor panic creates a stock market crisis, why not stop trading for a few hours and give calmer heads a chance to prevail? That's the beguiling logic behind the New York Stock Exchange's proposal for a ''circuit breaker,'' an automatic halt in trading when market averages shoot up or down by some specified amount.

title: Big Board Seeks Data On Program Trading
description: The New York Stock Exchange has issued one requirement and is considering others that would enhance the exchange's ability to regulate trading by member firms.

title: Flexi-Van Tender
description: The FLX Acquisition Company, owned by the Flexi-Van Corporation's chairman and chief executive, David H. Murdock, said that it had received 3,594,295 shares of Flexi-Van in response to its tender offer for all shares at $38.50 a piece. The tender, which expired April 27, gave Murdock 97.3 percent of Flexi-Van.

title: The Right Fight on Mental Health
description: Pressed by Mayor Koch, New York State mental health officials are finally addressing the overcrowding that has turned emergency rooms in New York City's municipal hospitals into snake pits of despair. Patients - some handcuffed to wheelchairs, others strapped to stretchers - remain in emergency rooms three days or more, awaiting psychiatric beds that don't exist.

title: CHARLES AND DEVLIN LEADERS IN LEGENDS
description: The old-timers of golf have played through so many weather problems in their careers that a two-and-a-half-hour delay for passing thunderstorms today didn't upset the team from down under: Bob Charles, the southpaw from New Zealand, and Bruce Devlin of Australia.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the extradition case of a former Argentine military officer in San Francisco misstated the judge's reasoning in dropping some charges. Four counts of murder against the defendant, Carlos Guillermo Suarez-Mason, were ruled out as grounds for extradition because of lack of proof, and 24 counts of unlawful detention were dropped because the five-year statute of limitations had run out.

title: Start of Gotti Trial Delayed
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday granted prosecutors a week's delay in the start of the second racketeering and drug-trafficking trial of Gene Gotti and two other defendants. Assistant United States Attorney Robert P. LaRusso sought the postponement after Judge John M. McLaughlin of Federal District Court in Brooklyn denied his motion to introduce into evidence portions of dozens of tapes of conversations containing references to the Gambino organized-crime family and what Mr. LaRusso said was the defendants' participation in that enterprise.

title: Valery Legasov, 51, Chernobyl Investigator
description: Valery A. Legasov, a physical chemist who headed the commission that investigated the Chernobyl nuclear power accident, died on Wednesday, Soviet media announced today. He was 51 years old.

title: Promises, Promises on Acid Rain
description: On the issue of acid rain - the term commonly given to rain or snow that carries destructive chemical compounds - Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney deserves an award for saintly patience.

title: Art; A Chance to Gorge on Gauguin
description: Anyone who doubts that ours is a golden age of exhibitions should go forthwith to the National Gallery of Art, where ''The Art of Paul Gauguin'' opens to the public on Sunday and can be seen through July 31.

title: Field for the Derby Thins Out a Bit
description: The Kentucky Derby next Saturday appears unlikely to draw a full field of 20, following 8 defections today from the race.

title: Candelaria Lifts Yankees' Spirits
description: The Yankees received bad news in the early afternoon, but John Candelaria made them forget it, at least for a while, last night at the Stadium.

title: Lord Brockway, 99, Politician and Pacifist
description: Lord Brockway, a veteran socialist, pacifist, political writer and prison inmate who campaigned for Indian independence and championed African nationalism, died Thursday, his family reported. He was 99 years old.

title: Mark C. Feer, 59; Served as Director Of Investment Firms
description: Mark Cecil Iselin Feer, an investment banker, died of complications of intestinal cancer Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 59 years old.

title: Official Blames Shortage of Staff For Delay in Testing AIDS Drugs
description: A top Federal health official said today that human clinical trials of several promising AIDS drugs had been delayed for as much as a year because of insufficient staff to guide each drug through the testing process.

title: Correction
description: A headline on March 15 about the arrest of a drug suspect in Manhattan incorrectly described the United States arrival of the suspect, Kon Yu-leung. While Mr. Kon was born in China, he was not lured from there, and the authorities have not provided information on where he had been.

title: Asthma Death, Too, Stalks the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Birds, Parks, River and Other Pleasures of Washington Heights
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Money; Power of Attorney Fills Many Needs
description: WHEN Richard and Lee Allan returned to their Manhattan apartment last Sunday evening, they found a disturbing message on their telephone-answering machine: a resident at the hospice of St. Vincent's Hospital, where Mrs. Allan works, had taken a turn for the worse. Could Mr. Allan, a professor at Brooklyn Law School, quickly draw up a power of attorney permitting a third party to withdraw cash from the man's bank account?

title: McDonald's in Moscow: A 'Bolshoi Mak'
description: The prospect of golden arches on Gorky Street moved a step closer today when the McDonald's Corporation agreed to help put two all-beef patties, special sauce, lettuce, cheese, pickles and onions on a Soviet bun.

title: Refugee Finds Home With Georgia Family
description: Since being released from detention by the immigration authorities on Feb. 29, Felix Brena-Toledo has lived with sponsors in a suburb barely 20 miles from the Atlanta Federal Penitentiary, where he had remained off and on for five of his eight years in the United States.

title: Familian Bought
description: The British builder Wolseley P.L.C. acquired Familian Northwest Inc., the largest distributor of plumbing products in the northwestern United States, for $56 million in cash. Oregon-based Familian has 38 locations. In 1987, it had a pretax profit of almost $13 million and had assets of $26.9 million.

title: PLASTIC WRAPPING BANNED IN SUFFOLK
description: The Suffolk County Executive today signed legislation that will ban plastic grocery bags and many plastic food containers in the county beginning in July 1989.

title: METS WIN BUT CONE DOESN'T
description: David Cone did everything he thought his new assignment as a middle reliever required: he gave the lead to the short man. But then he got a glimpse of a Cincinnati long ball and realized there was one more thing to be asked of him: diplomacy.

title: Robert Johnson, 40, Hostel Group Director
description: Robert B. Johnson, executive director of American Youth Hostels, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Arlington, Va., according to Elliot Winick, a spokesman for the organization. He was 40 years old and suffered from colon cancer.

title: Release of Cubans Stepped Up In 5 Months Since U.S. Riots
description: In the five months since protest riots occurred at two Federal penitentiaries, the Government has released 1,153 Cuban detainees, 10 times more than were freed the previous five months. The majority have been released to live with family sponsors, and others have been sent to halfway houses as a step to freedom.

title: Devils Like Road Advantage in Game 7
description: In the last month, the Devils and the Capitals have survived in games they desperately needed to win. On Saturday night, one of them will not survive.

title: Judge Upholds USG's 'Poison Pill'
description: A Federal judge has ruled that the USG Corporation can use a ''poison pill'' strategy in defending itself against Desert Partners L.P.'s hostile $1.6 billion takeover bid. United States District Judge James F. Holderman refused to grant a preliminary injunction sought by Desert Partners against the use of the defensive tactic.

title: 50 YEARS OF NURTURING EXCELLENCE IN SCIENCE
description: In a third-floor laboratory at the Bronx High School of Science, 14 small-scale industrial robots, which look a little like old-fashioned movie projectors, are arrayed around the benches.

title: Why to Legalize Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Halt the Interior Dept.'s Land Giveaway
description: LEAD: The Federal Government is preparing to sell more than a quarter million acres of Western land at a per acre price that wouldn't buy a hamburger and french fries.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Agassi Advances to Semifinals: Top-seeded Andre Agassi and former champion Jimmy Arias advanced yesterday to the semifinals of the United States men's clay court championships in Isle of Palms, S.C. Agassi celebrated his 18th birthday by beating Richey Reneberg, 6-1, 6-3. Arias, seeded seventh, beat second-seeded Aaron Krickstein, 6-0, 6-2. Jim Courier, 17, beat Horacio de la Pena of Argentina, 6-3, 7-6, and Lawson Duncan defeated fourth-seeded Jay Berger, 6-0,3-0.(AP) Becker and Leconte Advance: Top-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany and Henri Leconte of France advanced yesterday to the semifinals of the $602,500 German Open tournament in Hamburg, West Germany. Becker breezed by Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina, 6-1, 6-3, and Leconte defeated Joakim Nystrom of Sweden, 6-4, 6-2. In other matches yesterday, second-seeded Kent Carlsson of Sweden easily defeated Claudio Mezzadri of Switzerland, 6-0, 6-3, and Jordi Arrese of Spain eliminated Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, 6-4, 6-4. (AP) Shriver Defeats Harper: Top-seeded Pam Shriver used a strong serve and superior reach yesterday to defeat a fellow American, Peanut Harper, 6-1, 7-5, in the quarterfinals of the Toray Pan Pacific Open tournament in Tokyo. Fifth-seeded Larisa Savchenko of the Soviet Union upset Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union, 7-6, 7-5, and will meet Shriver in the semifinals today. Second-seeded Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria posted a 6-4, 6-2 victory over Anne Minter of Australia. Maleeva will meet third-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, who defeated Etsuko Inoue of Japan, 6-4, 7-5.(AP) Golf Donald and Sutton Share Lead: Mike Donald and Hal Sutton, completing their rounds before heavy rain curtailed play in the second round, shared the lead in the $700,000 Independent Insurance Agent Open yesterday. Only 45 golfers completed their rounds before PGA Tour officials halted play because of rain and lightning on The Woodlands Country Club's Tournament Players Course in The Woodlands, Tex. About one-third of the field, including first-round leaders Greg Norman and Raymond Floyd, were unable to tee off before play was halted. Donald shot a three-under-par 69 for a 36-hole total of eight-under-par 136. Sutton, one shot off the first-day lead with a 66, shot a 70 in the second round.(AP)

title:
PATENTS;
Inventors Hall of Fame Is Seeking Nominations
description: LEAD: Nominations to the National Inventors Hall of Fame are being sought, said Sidney B. Williams Jr., a patent attorney who is president of the foundation that oversees the hall.

title: Fahnhorst Ends Career
description: Keith Fahnhorst, an offensive tackle for the San Francisco 49ers for 13 seasons, has decided to retire from pro football because of a neck injury that caused him to miss nine games last season. Fahnhorst, a 273-pound, 6-foot-6-inch lineman from the University of Minnesota who led the 49ers in seniority, said he planned to move to Minneapolis to work as a stockbroker or to assist his agent.

title: Administrator Is Sought for Building in Disrepair
description: New York City housing officials said yesterday that they would seek a court appointment of an administrator to run a 113-unit apartment building in Brooklyn where a landlord served a term of house arrest for refusing to make repairs.

title: Holmes a Court Sells Most of Bell Group
description: The financier Robert Holmes a Court, whose fortune shrank from billions to millions in October's market crash, today sold most of his stake in the Bell Group Ltd., which has interests in a variety of industries.

title: Justice Dept. Preparing to Deport 14 Cubans Held in U.S. Prisons
description: The Justice Department announced today that it was preparing to deport 14 Cuban detainees, the first such action since Cuban inmates took over two Federal prisons in uprisings last November.

title: Contact Lens Merger Fought
description: Federal antitrust regulators said today that they would fight a planned merger of two of the nation's largest soft-contact-lens companies.

title: Correction
description: An article on Thursday about Polish labor unrest misstated a demand by striking steelworkers. They were asking for reinstatement of at least four workers dismissed over membership in the banned trade union Solidarity; they did not ask for reinstatement of the union itself.

title: Corning in Accord For Revere Ware
description: Corning Glass Works, the maker of cookware and dinnerware, signed a definitive agreement to buy Revere Ware Inc., the second-largest manufacturer of range-top cookware. Corning said the acquisition would be made in cash, but a spokesman, Eugene Saunders, would not confirm that the price was $120 million, as sources had reported.

title: About New York; What Is a Stoop? Brooklyn by Bus For 15 Tourists
description: Every Thursday and Sunday morning, from April through October, a bus leaves the Gray Line terminal on Eighth Avenue, threads its way downtown to Canal, crosses the Manhattan Bridge and spends the next six hours in Brooklyn. The people who take this bus are usually international tourists with some sort of immigrant connection to the borough, according to John Kriskiewicz, who guides the tour with wit and an occasional swipe at Manhattan. True enough, this past Thursday, there were passengers from Finland, Germany, New Zealand, Norway and Sweden, as well as California and Georgia.

title: Labor Unrest in Nigeria
description: Labor Minister Abubakar Umar met with leaders of 22 unions today as labor unrest spread across Nigeria following a rise in the price of gasoline, the Lagos radio reported. Many Lagos banks remained closed for the second day, officials said, and others operated with skeleton crews because most workers were on strike. Planes were grounded throughout the country when air traffic controllers joined the strike.

title: Juilliard Receives Grant
description: A grant of $1.5 million has been given to the Juilliard School from the Dorothy Richard Starling Foundation to be used for a $2 million endowment to establish a permanent chair in violin studies at the school. Dorothy DeLay, who teaches violin at the school, is to be the first holder of the chair, called the Dorothy Richard Starling Chair in Violin Studies. A number of former students of Miss Delay, including Itzhak Perlman and Cho-Liang Lin, are to be responsible for raising the additional $500,000 for the endowment.

title: Needlessly Harsh on Student Loans
description: Despite a Government crackdown, student loan defaults remain a fiscal drain and a political outrage. They will continue to be until Congress and the Administration find a solution that fairly recognizes the obligations of student borrowers as well as colleges that depend on the borrowed money.

title: Amdahl Offering A New Computer
description: The Amdahl Corporation next week will announce its most powerful mainframe computer ever, surpassing all other machines compatible with the mainframe computers of the International Business Machines Corporation, analysts say. Amdahl would not comment about the announcement, which it has scheduled for Tuesday. The Sunnyvale, Calif., company, 46 percent of which is owned by Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan, is also expected to announce new products for storing computer information, analysts said.

title: GAUGE OF ECONOMY SHOWS STRONG RISE FOR SECOND MONTH
description: The Government's main economic-forecasting gauge posted its second straight hefty advance in March, for the strongest two-month performance in more than a year.

title: Famous Amos Cookies Sold
description: The Baer family of Denver said today that it had acquired the Famous Amos Chocolate Chip Cookie Corporation for undisclosed terms. Wally Amos, the former Hollywood agent who opened his first cookie store in 1975, will remain a significant shareholder and director.

title: Malaysia in Cocoa Talks
description: Malaysia will consider joining the International Cocoa Organization after talks were held between a cocoa organization delegation and Malaysia's Minister of Primary Industries, Lim Keng Yaik, the organization said today.

title: Gibbons Green's Deal With Lucky
description: Lucky Stores Inc. disclosed that it would pay the New York investment firm Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen Ltd. $20 million as a ''breakup fee'' if Lucky Stores canceled the $2.4 billion merger agreement between the two parties in favor of a higher bid.

title: Stocks End Mixed After Late Buying
description: LEAD: The stock market was mixed yesterday, thanks to a late surge of buying at the close that trimmed earlier losses.

title: A Solution Finds Its Problem: How to Tell if Dinner Is Done
description: At the 3M company in suburban St. Paul, the scientists who invented sandpaper, Scotch tape, Post-it notes, translucent orthodontic braces and 50,000 other products now want to help you cook dinner.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't think that the situation in Poland is dramatic, but I am not hiding the fact that strikes are under way.''

title: Henry B. Laidlaw, 75; Led a Brokerage Firm
description: Henry Bell Laidlaw, the former president of Laidlaw & Company, a Manhattan brokerage firm, died of heart failure Thursday at the Muhlenberg Medical Center in Plainfield, N.J. He was 75 years old and lived in Plainfield.

title: Federated's Chief Resigns
description: Howard Goldfeder, chairman and chief executive of Federated Department Stores Inc., announced his resignation yesterday and his retirement on completion of the acquisition of Federated by the Campeau Corporation.

title: RULING MAY FREE SOME N.F.L. PLAYERS
description: Although a ruling issued Thursday by the National Labor Relations Board's general counsel appeared to favor National Football League players, the players and the owners agree that their dispute over free agency will have to be settled in court.

title: Death Is Linked to Ex-Nurse
description: A fourth former patient at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip died by poisoning from the drug Pavulon, authorities said today. Prosecutors said they would seek additional charges against the former nurse, Richard Angelo, 25, of Lindenhurst, who has been accused of murdering one of the patients by injecting the drug.

title: Still a Long Leap From Theory to Invention
description: To the Editor:

title: New Caledonia Gunmen Kill Settler Acquitted of Murder
description: Gunmen killed a farmer today who was acquitted of killing a separatist leader in 1984. He was the first European settler to be killed in this French Pacific territory since a wave of separatist unrest began a week ago.

title: Cecil Taylor
description: Cecil Taylor, a pianist, will lead his five-piece unit at 9 o'clock and 11:30 tonight at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Tickets are $15 in advance, $18 at the door.

title: M.T.A. and Union Reach Accord
description: The union representing New York City's 35,000 subway and bus workers reached a tentative agreement yesterday with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority on a new contract providing wage increases of 17 percent over three years, the authority announced.

title: Opera Films to Show Off Gould Hall
description: Two years ago, when the French Institute/Alliance Francaise's Florence Gould Hall was still being built, the institute's director, Jean Vallier, began mapping out plans for the hall's opening. His goal was to show, in just under a month's programming, that the 400-seat hall at 55 East 59th Street could be used for theater, music, dance and one of the institute's longtime specialties, film.

title: Dance; A Ballet by Bonnefoux With a Wuorinen Score
description: The American Music Festival at the New York City Ballet continues apace with Thursday night's premiere at the New York State Theater consisting of Jean-Pierre Bonnefoux's ''Five,'' to a commissioned score by Charles Wuorinen. The composer was the guest conductor in the pit and Fred Sherry the formidable guest cellist.

title: China Business Program Is Set
description: The Columbia Business School is cooperating with the University of International Business and Economics in Beijing to establish an executive program on joint-ventures management in China.

title: Books of The Times; The Many Ways People Fail to Communicate
description: What Is It Then Between Us? By Ehud Havazelet 177 pages. Charles Scribner's Sons. $15.95.

title: A Quick Spin in the Fast Lane
description: Even if you can't afford to buy the car of your dreams, you may still be able to drive it. At least for a day.

title: CUBA VS. U.S. ON BOARDWALK
description: Their drills were punctuated with enthusiastic shouts of ''U.S.A., Eighty-Eight.'' They skipped rope with music playing loudly in the background, prompting Ken Adams, the Olympic boxing coach, to display some of the fancier footwork seen outside a ring. In the mile-high environment of Colorado Springs last week there was a heady feeling among the boxers on the American national team, optimism that drowned out any thoughts of defeat.

title: The Good the Adolescent Family Life Act Does
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan, U.S. Still Talking
description: United States and Japanese negotiators made little progress today in their talks over liberalizing Japanese quotas on beef and citrus imports, but will try again Monday, a United States official said.

title: Delegate Count
description: Current breakdown of Presidential preference of delegates to national political conventions, compiled by The New York Times. Preferences are based on state laws, party rules, delegates' public statements and projections from early results in caucus states.

title: Duke Power Gets Nuclear Plant Job
description: The Duke Power Company has tentatively agreed to operate the troubled Rancho Seco nuclear plant in California, company officials said. The deal is dependent on approval by Sacramento voters to restart the troubled plant, idled since an emergency shutdown in December 1985, said Bill Lee, Duke's chairman and chief executive at the company's annual meeting here on Thursday.

title: Humphery Signs
description: The number of unsigned veteran Jets defensive backs fell to five yesterday when the club signed Bobby Humphery. In addition, the club acquired six other free agents, five of whom started for their teams during the strike last season.

title: Atlanta Is Chosen To Bid for Games
description: The United States Olympic Committee's executive board voted today to approve Atlanta as the United States city to bid for the 1996 Summer Olympic Games.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: TV Show Questions British Killings
description: The British Foreign Secretary has failed to block the broadcast of a witness's account that two Irish terrorist suspects killed in Gibraltar were shot as they raised their hands in surrender to British troops.

title: Rev. Leo Cullum, 86, Professor of Theology
description: The Rev. Leo A. Cullum, a professor of theology and rector at San Jose Seminary in the Philippines, died of cardiac arrest Sunday at Lourdes Hospital in Manila. He was 86 years old and lived in Manila.

title: Austria Remembers and Aids Nazism's Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: A Professor Takes On a Takeover
description: How many Yale professors does it take to change a light bulb company? The answer, as it turns out, is one: William P. Lyons, an adjunct professor at Yale's business and law schools who engineered the takeover of the Duro-Test Corporation.

title: Zonnebloem Journal; Apartheid's Wasteland of Lost Souls
description: More than two decades after South Africa declared the vibrant multiracial ghetto of District 6 a whites-only area, an ambitious corporate plan to redevelop it for all races is dividing those who once lived here.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-6 Labor unrest in Poland spread to steel mills near Warsaw and Cracow as talks with Government-sponsored labor unions at one mill collapsed. Arrests of Solidarity supporters and other dissidents were reported. Page 1 Mikhail Gorbachev urged tolerance of religion in the Soviet Union during a meeting with leaders of the Russian Orthodox Church. The reception was reported at the start of the main Soviet television news program. 1 Big Macs will be sold in Moscow under an agreement between McDonald's and Soviet officials to open 20 restaurants, staffed by Soviet workers and managers, and a food-processing plant to service them. 1 Soviet military aid to Ethiopia may decide the fate of Ethiopians facing famine, diplomats say. Washington has asked Moscow to persuade Ethiopia to end military tactics that prevent food deliveries. 5 Talks on southern Africa will be held between South Africa, Angola, Cuba and the United States. Officials will discuss withdawal of Cuban troops from Angola and terms for the independence of South-West Africa. 4 The French presidential candidates, President Francois Mitterrand and Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, debated rancorously on television for more than two hours. They face each other in the election May 8. 3 Witnesses' accounts of the killing of three Irish terrorist suspects in Gibraltar were broadcast on British television despite an appeal by the British Foreign Secretary to delay the program. 3 American forces in the Persian Gulf were ordered by President Reagan to broaden their protection of commercial vessels. Navy warships will now be allowed to defend neutral ships under attack by Iranian forces. 3 Peace talks in Nicaragua continued as police officers clashed with striking construction workers. The current round of talks between the Government and contra leaders has apparently produced little progress. 4 Panamanian opposition wary of U.S. bargaining with Noriega 4 U.S. backs off report on Panamanian military leader 4 American and Soviet scientists test plan to verify arms ban 6 NATIONAL/7-11, 32 An economic-forecasting gauge posted its second straight hefty advance in March, the strongest two-month performance in more than a year. The index of leading indicators rose eight-tenths of 1 percent. 1 Delays in testing AIDS drugs have been caused almost exclusively by the lack of personnel to guide each drug through the testing process, a Federal health official testified at a Congressional hearing. 1 Releases of Cuban detainees from two Federal prisons in the five months since riots there increased tenfold over the previous five months. The accelerated review of cases has been criticized. 1 U.S. to deport 14 Cuban detainees 9 Cuban refugee finds home with Georgia family 9 Efforts to encourage illegal aliens to apply for amnesty under the new immigration law were not aggressive enough, says Alan C. Nelson, the Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization. 10 Sabotage was being discounted by Government investigators looking into the severe fuselage rupture that caused a jetliner to crash-land in Hawaii. One person was apparently killed and 60 were injured. 7 Passengers of crippled jet praise pilot 7 Bowen rejects optimistic drug stance 7 Praying for church and state 10 Prosecution rests in Colombian's cocaine case 11 Ethics panel criticizes Durenberger 32 Politics 8 Patriotism and economic strength were stressed by Michael Dukakis in a campaign speech in Ohio, where the Democratic Presidential candidate said he would campaign on the issues of jobs and industrial growth. 8 The grasp on foreign affairs of Michael Dukakis was criticized by Jesse Jackson, who derided the Democratic Presidential front-runner for not outlining a more ambitious plan to end apartheid in South Africa. 8 The Democratic National Committee has collected campaign money for the eventual Presidential nominee more agressively than in 1984. But it has had to compete with Presidential and Congressional candidates for money. 8 Bush to retaliate if Democrats press ethics issue 8 REGIONAL/33-36 A ban on plastic grocery bags and many food containers in Suffolk County beginning in July 1989 was signed by the County Executive. Plastics industry representatives are considering a legal challenge. 1 A bid for a hostile takeover of Lilco was approved in a vote by the Long Island Power Authority, which said it would begin to solicit support for the attempt after Federal approval of its proxy material. 35 The initial incorrect police report of how a New York City police sergeant died in a drug raid was caused, in part, by confusion over what actually had happened and pressure on the police to produce a full account. 33 Checks of the Williamsburg Bridge to see how much of its steel remains are about 85 percent complete. About 100 spots have been found that required inspectors to notify state and city officials. 33 The Bronx High School of Science celebrates its 50th anniversary at a dinner-dance in Manhattan tonight. Founded to motivate bright students, particularly in the sciences, the school has kept that purpose. 33 A city shelter will screen veterans under a plan announced by Mayor Koch to exclude drug addicts and alcoholics who refuse to undergo treatment. The shelter is the city's first for homeless veterans. 34 Victim's family makes 2 requests of Koch 34 Former mob captain testifies before Senate subcommittee 34 Moyhihan says he voted for Dukakis in primary 36

title: How Punch Lines Bolster the Bottom Line
description: The ''Humor in the Workplace'' seminar did not kick off with a joke, a gag or even a rim-shot line like, ''Now take my memo - please.'' Instead, Dr. Barbara Mackoff asked a question of the 37 managers and employees seated somberly before her:

title: Koch Offers New Plan To Aid Veterans' Shelter
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that the first homeless shelter for veterans in the city would be redesigned to screen out drug addicts and alcoholics who refuse to join treatment programs.

title:
Patents;
A System To Locate Vehicles
description: LEAD: A VEHICLE-LOCATION system was patented this week for the Hughes Aircraft Company, a Los Angeles-based division of the General Motors Corporation's GM Hughes Electronics subsidiary.

title: KNICKS ARE OUTDONE ON DEFENSE
description: The Knicks talked defense before tonight's game, but the Celtics played it, and that was the difference as Boston overwhelmed New York, 112-92, in the opening game of their National Basketball Association playoff series.

title: Strikers at Colt Industries Win a Ruling on Jobless Pay
description: A state review board ruled today that hundreds of striking Colt workers are victims of a two-year-old lockout and are entitled to millions of dollars in unemployment benefits.

title: Economics and Patriotism: A Revised Dukakis Theme
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today pronounced his Democratic Presidential campaign ''a battle for the economic future of America,'' and promised to wage his fight against the Republicans on Democratic hallowed ground: jobs and industrial growth.

title: DUKAKIS WAS MOYNIHAN'S CHOICE IN PRIMARY
description: Throughout the New York State Democratic primary campaign earlier this month, the spotlight was on the roles played by Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch. Far from the glare was New York's senior Senator, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who refrained from endorsing a candidate and who, even after the polling, declined to name his favorite.

title: Nascar Sued
description: Tim Richmond, a Nascar driver, filed a lawsuit against the racing body and five of its officials in United States District Court in Charlotte, N.C.

title: New-Home Sales Up by 4% in March
description: New-home sales increased in March for the second consecutive month, continuing to recover from the weakness that followed October's stock market plunge.

title: Lakers Cruise in Opener
description: James Worthy scored 22 points and Kurt Rambis had 19 tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers opened the playoffs with a 122-110 victory over the San Antonio Spurs.

title: Campaign Finance; Democrats Improving Over '84 Fund Raising
description: The Democratic National Committee has been far more aggressive this year than in 1984 in collecting campaign money for the party's eventual Presidential nominee.

title: U.S. Expands Protection in Gulf To Any Neutral Vessels Attacked
description: President Reagan ordered American forces today to broaden their protection of commercial vessels in the Persian Gulf, Administration officials said.

title: Michael Grumley; Author, 46
description: Michael Grumley, an artist and author, died of complications from AIDS on Thursday at New York University Hospital. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Unchanged
description: The prices that farmers received for raw products in April were unchanged from March, on average, for the second consecutive month but were still 4 percent above a year ago.

title: KEY RATES
Jackson Prods Dukakis Over Policies on Africa
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today intensified his criticism of Michael S. Dukakis, striking where the Democratic Presidential front-runner has the least experience: foreign policy.

title: The Post to Add an Edition Starting Monday
description: The New York Post, will publish a new edition beginning Monday with 100,000 additional copies geared primarily toward the morning commuter in an effort to expand its circulation in the suburbs.

title: Mexico in '87: Mixed Result
description: After declining sharply in 1986 in large part because of falling world oil prices, Mexico's troubled economy grew modestly last year but its chronic inflation also rose, the nation's central bank reported this week.

title: Bradley Ailing
description: Pat Bradley, one of the most successful players on the women's golf tour, will be out until at least June while receiving treatment for hyperthyroidism, the L.P.G.A. announced. Bradley is not expected to compete again until the Rochester International June 9-12.

title: G.M. Recalls 26,000 Cars
description: The General Motors Corporation announced it was recalling nearly 26,000 cars to correct several possible problems, including an automatic transmission cable that could cause shift levers to display the wrong gear. Included in the recall were about 17,500 Buick Regals and about 8,400 Pontiac Grand Prix models, G.M. said Thursday. Both are 1988 models. Owners were being notified to take the cars to dealers, who will make repairs free.

title: L.I. Youth Is Convicted In Girlfriend's Slaying
description: A teen-ager tried for murder in the strangulation of his girlfriend was convicted of a lesser charge of criminally negligent homicide today after claiming she was killed accidentally during a sex act using a rope.

title: 13 Minutes Aboard Jet After Blast
description: There was a blast, the tearing of metal, then for 13 long minutes wind and debris whipped through a jetliner passenger cabin ripped open like a pop-top can. Yet the passengers aboard Aloha Airlines Flight 243 remained calm. Remarkably calm, some say.

title: Bomb Discounted as Cause Of Hawaii Plane Explosion
description: Sabotage has been discounted for now as the cause of a 20-foot rupture in the fuselage of an Aloha Airlines jet that apparently swept a flight attendant to her death in Hawaii on Thursday.

title: Faded Jersey Movie Palace Edges Closer to Restoration
description: The Loew's Jersey Theater is living on borrowed time. But it is living.

title: Victim's Family Makes 2 Requests
description: A lawyer for the family of a New Jersey woman shot to death in East Harlem by police officers who mistakenly thought she was reaching for a gun said yesterday that the family wanted an expression of sympathy and a financial settlement from New York City.

title: Reagan May Offer Support To Vice President Next Week
description: Aides to Vice President Bush said today that President Reagan might endorse Mr. Bush next Tuesday, but the President's spokesman said a decision had yet to be made.

title: Oil Group's Ecuador Pact
description: A United States-Dutch consortium has signed a contract with the Government to explore for and produce oil in Ecuador's eastern Amazon River basin, the Government said.

title: Workers Killed in Van Crash
description: A van plunged off a steep embankment on a winding, rain-slickened road in the Mount Hood National Forest late Thursday, killing one forest worker and injuring 13 others, the authorities said.

title: Senate Ethics Panel Criticizes Durenberger on Talk
description: The Senate Select Committee on Ethics today criticized Senator Dave Durenberger for publicly discussing American espionage in Israel, but it decided not to take any other action against him.

title: Majority At OPEC Backs Cuts
description: A majority of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed early today to reduce its production of oil. But the oil ministers of Saudi Arabia and its allies said they needed to consult with their governments before they could decide whether to support the cutbacks.

title: Private Groups Are Said to Lag on Alien Amnesty
description: The Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization said today that he was disappointed that religious groups and other private organizations had not brought more illegal aliens to the Government to seek amnesty.

title: COLORADO'S BANKING CHIEF IS FORCED TO RESIGN HIS POST
description: Gov. Roy Romer forced State Banking Commissioner Richard B. Doby to resign today after an audit found ''numerous management deficiencies'' in the state's Division of Banking.

title: Birds of a Feather
description: BIRD-AWARENESS was sweeping the country.

title: The Primary, a la Koch
description: Mayor Koch is now saying that voters in New York's Democratic Presidential primary really agreed with him, even though his choice came in a distant third.

title: U.S. Backs Off Report of Deal To Ease Noriega From Power
description: Senior Administration officials said today that the United States and Panama still had to work out many details of a plan to ease Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from power.

title: Taiwan Cool to China Tie
description: Taiwan has ruled out importing coal from China or officially allowing Taiwan businessmen to invest in the mainland, an economic official said today. Dr. Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, told a news conference in Tokyo on Thursday that China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, wanted to export coal to Taiwan and South Korea.

title: MANAGUA STRIKERS CLASH WITH POLICE
description: As talks between Government officials and contra leaders continued today, police officers clashed with striking construction workers in a confrontation that reflected growing labor tensions here.

title: U.S. Disputes Afghan On Soviet Adviser Issue
description: The United States today disputed the assertion of the Afghan President, Najibullah, that Soviet military advisers can stay in his country under the terms of a settlement signed in Geneva this month.

title: Student Volunteers, Academic Credit
description: LEAD: Despite the enticements of our competitive, consumerist culture, a growing number of high school, undergraduate and graduate students are finding time to do local volunteer work. We applaud such evidence of idealism put into daily or weekly practice in what amounts to a national service program. As one Middle Western college dean said, it is ''exactly the kind of constructive extra-curricular activity this school values.

title: U.S. Issues Unchanged in Light Trading
description: After opening weak, prices of Treasury securities closed essentially unchanged in very light trading yesterday.

title: Police Cite Tumult in Error On Report of Officer's Death
description: A tangled combination of factors, some easy to explain and some not, resulted in the erroneous report of how a New York City police sergeant died in a drug raid on a Manhattan apartment, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Soviet Arms Aid Is Seen as Pivotal to Ethiopia
description: Western diplomats and relief officials say the result of Ethiopia's civil war and the fate of as many as two million hungry people depend largely on how much military support Moscow is willing to commit to this country.

title: DEVISING AN EFFECTIVE SYSTEM NOW CAN PREVENT NIGHTMARES AND SAVE MIDNIGHT OIL NEXT APRIL 15
description: You've just filed your tax return, and you'd like to have an easier time next year. One way is to set up a better personal record-keeping system this year.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Crystal Brands Inc., a manufacturer of sportswear and costume jewelry, said its board had approved the acquisition of Trifari Krussman & Fishel Inc., the jewelry unit of Hallmark Cards Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Testimony of a Top Bush Aide Conflicts With North's Notes
description: Donald P. Gregg, a senior aide to Vice President Bush, testified under oath today that he had no knowledge of the White House-directed efforts to supply the rebels fighting in Nicaragua until August 1986.

title: Theater; De Sade's Kinswomen, as Portrayed by Mishima
description: In ''Mme. de Sade,'' Yukio Mishima set himself the difficult task of writing a play about the Marquis de Sade in which de Sade does not appear. Instead, he is seen through the eyes of six women, three of them real and three of them fictional. They include his wife and his mother-in-law, who converse at length, comparing disparate notes on their respective attitudes toward the absent, imprisoned de Sade.

title: Television; And Once Again It's the 'Dirty Dozen,' as a Series
description: If you're in the market for a formula, ''The Dirty Dozen'' surely commands a moment of attention. It all began in 1967 with an enormously successful movie about a gang of murderers, rapists and other assorted felons who were given a chance to redeem themselves on the battlefields of World War II. Television's NBC and MGM/UA got into the act with two sequels: ''The Deadly Mission'' (1986) and, in what appeared to be the coup de grace, ''The Final Mission'' (1988).

title: TALKS WITH OFFICIAL UNIONS FAIL
description: Labor unrest was reported to have spread to two more steel mills in southeastern Poland today as talks with Government-approved labor unions at the big Lenin steel mill near here collapsed.

title: IT'S OVER! HONEST! THEY WIN!
description: Ronald Reagan's telephone calls can now switch from sympathetic to congratulatory. Bob Rivers, the Baltimore disk jockey who had broadcast through loss after loss, can rest. The Baltimore Orioles ended their American League record 21-game losing streak tonight with a 9-0 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

title: Study Urges a Rethinking Of Ethnic Images on TV
description: Ethnic and racial images on television have a powerful impact on the way adolescents perceive ethnicity and race in the real world, a recently released study of high school students has concluded. As a result, the study asserts, television networks ought to re-examine their ethnic characters and content and to incorporate more variety into their programming.

title: Have a Second Opinion
description: George Bush, Michael Dukakis and the Baltimore Orioles are all in the same pickle. The season for all three having ended before it really began, what do they do now to keep their publics awake?

title: Evangelicals Rally to Pray for Church
description: More than 100,000 evangelical Christians gathered on the Mall today to pray in repentance for what the rally's leaders said were the sins of the church and the country.

title: McSorley Suspended
description: Marty McSorley of the Edmonton Oilers was suspended for three games by the National Hockey League and will miss the start of the Campbell Conference championship series with the Detroit Red Wings. McSorley drew the suspension because of a game misconduct penalty he incurred for spearing Mike Bullard of the Calgary Flames last Saturday night in the third game of the Smythe Division final.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14.

title: Prosecutors Rest Their Case In Colombian's Cocaine Trial
description: Defense attorneys, after listening to 22 weeks of Government testimony and 115 witnesses, will begin presenting their case Monday in the cocaine smuggling trial of Carlos Lehder Rivas.

title: Thai Cabinet Resigns Over U.S. Coprights
description: Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda dissolved his Cabinet and Parliament today and called new elections in a dispute over legislation to protect United States copyrights.

title: Sanford C. Miller; Lawyer, 59
description: Sanford C. Miller, a lawyer, died of cancer Wednesday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 59 years old and lived in Ridgewood.

title: Bridge; The loss of one player left a struggling group of five in the Grand Nationals
description: In major events some experts choose to play four-handed, testing stamina but avoiding the problem of the six-member team: who is to be on the bench. The five-member team is the worst of all worlds, requiring at least one player to play with more than one partner.

title: Map Update
description: Where can you go to find old New York? Until recently, one answer might be the information kiosk on the little traffic island in Times Square. Here, 14-year-old maps directed visitors to restaurants that had closed, stores that had moved and tourist attractions that had failed to attract.

title: The Boston Pops
description: John Williams is to conduct the Boston Pops in a program that includes four of his own works, as well as selections from Andrew Lloyd Webber's ''Phantom of the Opera'' and works by Samuel Barber, Peter Maxwell Davies and Cole Porter, at Carnegie Hall at 8 o'clock tonight. Nancy Crutcher Tunnicliffe is to be the bagpipe soloist in Mr. Davies's ''Orkney Wedding, With Sunrise,'' and Tamara Smirnova-Sajfar will be violin soloist in selections from ''Fiddler on the Roof.'' Tickets are $15 to $27.50. Information: 247-7800.

title: Passengers Laud Pilot of Crippled Jet
description: Passengers today praised an Aloha Airlines pilot who safely landed a jetliner Thursday about 15 minutes after a large chunk of the forward cabin blew off.

title: Robert Van Pelt; Federal Judge, 90
description: Robert Van Pelt a senior Federal district judge, died Wednesday. He was 90.

title: GOOD GIFT FOR MOM: TIME
description: Confectioners, florists and greeting-card makers predict that Mom is in for more hearts and flowers than usual this Mother's Day, May 8.

title: Sunglasses That Work
description: Sunglasses purchased for a few dollars on the street may be decorative, but they may not filter out punishing ultraviolet rays. Good sunglasses are optically ground and polished like prescription lenses. Prices vary greatly - from $20 to $100 or more - and may depend more on the store and the frame than on the quality of the lenses. To test sunglasses, hold them up and look through them at a vertical or horizontal line, like a column or a curb, and move them up and down. If what you're looking at seems to move a lot, the lenses are not very good. Glasses with the Polaroid trademark cut reflected glare from shiny nonmetallic surfaces, like sand, water or glass. Glasses should let you distinguish red and green. Here are some recommendations on which glasses work where: Tint Design Protection Street Various light To Keep out Grit, ''Cosmetic lenses tints are fine consider wrap- absorb 5%-10% of arounds light Driving Gray to Look side to light-adjusting very dark side to be sure lenses won't darken views are unob- fully because of structed windshield Beach Dark Cover as much General-purpose as possible lenses absorb 40%- 80% of light; special-purpose, 90% (Dr. Robert Rosenberg, chairman, department of vision sciences, State University College of Optometry, Manhattan)

title: Irving Sells Swiss Holding To Help Italian Tender Offer
description: The Irving Bank Corporation yesterday announced the sale, for $390 million, of its 39 percent interest in a Swiss bank. The proceeds will help finance a friendly tender offer for Irving by Banca Commerciale Italiana.

title: Method to Verify Arms Ban Is Tested by U.S. and Soviet
description: Soviet and American scientists conducted an experiment in Nevada today that they hoped would show the possibility of policing a ban on all but the smallest tests of nuclear weapons.

title: Gorbachev Sees Church Leaders, Vows Tolerance
description: In a highly unusual Kremlin meeting with the hierarchy of the Russian Orthodox Church, Mikhail S. Gorbachev called today for a more tolerant attitude toward religion in the interest of national unity.

title: Four Nations to Discuss Withdrawal of Outside Forces From Angola
description: Officials from South Africa, Angola, Cuba and the United States will meet next week in London to discuss the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola, the Reagan Administration announced today.

title: Feld at the City Ballet: A Man of Both Worlds
description: It was 1954 when Eliot Feld, one of two boys at the School of American Ballet, was called into service to play the little prince in the New York City Ballet's first production of ''The Nutcracker.'' Tonight, the prince returns to the City Ballet - as the creator of ''The Unanswered Question,'' a new ballet set to music by Charles Ives and commissioned for City Ballet's American Music Festival.

title: Concert; A Mozart-Mahler Evening With Ozawa and the Boston
description: If Seiji Ozawa's direction of the Boston Symphony were not so notoriously inconsistent, one might have suspected that he conducted two orchestras of very different calibers on Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall - a commonplace one before the intermission, and a more finely polished one afterward.

title: Engineers Bash Away at Bridge To Get to the Bottom of its Rust
description: Rasool S. Attar stands in the cherry-picker, his upturned face concealed by safety glasses, aspiration mask and hard hat, and does his best to smash a hole through the bottom of the Williamsburg Bridge.

title: Mitterrand and Chirac in Frosty Debate
description: French television viewers watched President Francois Mitterrand and Prime Minister Jacques Chirac put a rancorous end to two taut years of power-sharing as they debated each other for more than two hours.

title: Sacrifice Fly in 10th Lifts Red Sox, 6-5
description: Dwight Evans hit a sacrifice fly with one out and the bases loaded in the 10th inning tonight to give the Boston Red Sox a 6-5 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: The Hudson River Sunset, Unblocked
description: LEAD: Even though Westway is long dead, New York City's civic good guys seem intent on retaining the park that was part of its design and incorporating it into the entire West Side waterfront south of 42d Street. After all, they say, why not extend Riverside Park to Battery Park City?

title: Theater; A Tale of Two Sisters In a Fearsome Forest
description: ''The Love Talker,'' Deborah Pryor's tale of witchery in the mountains of Virginia, is overgrown with apparitions and vegetation. First presented last year at the Humana New Play Festival at the Actors Theater of Louisville, it is now playing in a somewhat expanded, though still brief, version at the Hudson Guild Theater - and leaves approximately the same impression as it did before. As a ghost story told at fireside or, perhaps, as a folk ballad, it might have had the desired mysterious effect. As a play, however, it is an entangled exercise in mysticism.

title: Martha K. Piper, Head Of Winthrop College
description: Martha Kime Piper, 56 years old, president of Winthrop College, died Sunday at Presbyterian Hospital in Charlotte, N.C. She had been suffering from colon cancer for a year.

title: Eastern Fare Cuts to Be Matched
description: The nation's major airlines said yesterday that they would match the reductions in discount fares announced Thursday by Eastern Airlines.

title: ARMS PACT DEBATE IS TENTATIVELY SET
description: The Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, said today that he was prepared to bring the new Soviet-American arms treaty to the Senate floor on May 11, provided the Administration could resolve four outstanding issues. Among them is a newly aired dispute with the Soviet Union over verification.

title: Work to Be Done
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Aide Is Pessimistic on Drugs
description: Dr. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Services, has told President Reagan and fellow Cabinet officers that he can no longer adhere to the Administration's optimistic accounts of the war on drugs.

title: ARKANSAS WINS
description: Joe Falcon, the nation's leading collegiate distance runner, anchored the University of Arkansas to its fifth victory in the last six years in the distance medley relay at the Penn Relays today.

title: Basketball Winner, and Loser
description: Over the years, Bob Knight, the Indiana University basketball coach, has become a legend as much for his crude behavior as for his successful teams. So a display of insensitivity in a recent television interview perhaps should come as no surprise. Mr. Knight was asked to describe how he handles stress. He responded with an analogy: ''I think that if rape is inevitable, relax and enjoy it.''

title: Irving Kolodin, Music Critic, Dies; Historian of Met Opera Was
description: Irving Kolodin, an American music critic and historian of the Metropolitan Opera, died yesterday in a Manhattan nursing home. He was 80 years old and had suffered a stroke a year ago.

title: Suchard Increases Rowntree Stake
description: The Swiss chocolate manufacturer Jacobs Suchard A.G. has snapped up still more shares in the British candy maker Rowntree P.L.C., which has already received an unsolicited takeover offer from the Swiss foods giant Nestle S.A. Suchard now owns more than 20 percent of Rowntree, its broker, S. G. Warburg Securities, said.

title: Noriega Foes Are Wary of U.S. Deal
description: Panamanian opposition leaders reacted with caution today to reports that the Reagan Administration was pursuing negotiations to remove Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from power.

title: Music; Chamber Works Of Elliott Carter And Saint-Saens
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center regularly presents programs that are something of a repertorial hodgepodge, and Tuesday evening's concert at Alice Tully Hall was no exception. Saint-Saens' Sonata for Oboe and Piano in D Major (Op. 166) and Arensky's Trio in D minor (Op. 32) framed the event's two most intriguing and persuasively rendered offerings - Elliott Carter's Eight Etudes for Woodwind Quartet and Schumann's ''Liederkreis.''

title:
PATENTS;
An Aid to Golfers
description: LEAD: Luther G. Simjian of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., who has 217 patents, will be granted another on May 10 for a device to aid golfers in practicing putting. Patent 4,743,027 will be assigned to Command Automation Inc., a company Mr. Simjian owns. The invention includes a mechanism that distorts the putting mat to provide more of a challenge.

title:
PATENTS;
Toy Robot Developed
description: LEAD: A toy robot was patented this week for Marvin Glass & Associates, Chicago. The human-shaped robot carries tiny vehicles that fit in its head, torso or limbs. Patent 4,740,187 was obtained by Russell G. Rasmussen and Harry Disko. The robot has been manufactured by a licensee under the trade name Matchbox.

title: Film; The Princess and the Carny
description: ''Two Moon Junction'' is a breast-and-buttock show for the soft-porn set. On display at the National and other theaters is April, a Southern princess (Sherilyn Fenn) whose terrific sex urge compels her to take up with Perry, a carny (Richard Tyson). What these repellent people have in common are their great chests and abundant hair. ''You excite me so much I can't help myself,'' says Perry. ''This has never happened to me before,'' says April.

title: Avon President Resigns
description: Avon Products Inc. said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, John S. Chamberlin, had resigned for personal reasons.

title: Correction
description: An obituary of Christina Paolozzi Bellin yesterday gave an incorrect time for the funeral. It will take place today at 12:30 P.M. (not 3 P.M.) in St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, at 71st Street.

title: Renault Subsidy Fought
description: The West German Economics Minister, Martin Bangemann, has complained to the European Community commission about its approval of a large subsidy by the French Government to the state-owned car company Renault. In a letter to Peter Sutherland, the European commissioner for competition, Mr. Bangemann said the commission had underestimated the consequences of the aid for fair competition. He said Renault would have had to retire from several of its activities had it not received this help. The Economics Ministry said the aid to Renault totaled 20 billion French francs (about $3.5 billion).

title: Broadus Mitchell, 95, Professor, Historian and Hamilton Authority
description: Dr. Broadus Mitchell, an educator, historian and biographer of Alexander Hamilton, died Thursday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 95 years old and lived in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Wendell, Mass.

title: Inside
description: Offer on Missile Pact Senator Robert C. Byrd said he could bring the arms treaty to the Senate floor May 11 if the Administration resolved a dispute on verification and three other issues. Page 6. Soviet Role in Ethiopia Cited Western officials link the outcome of the civil war and the threat of starvation in Ethiopia to how much military aid Moscow gives the country. Page 5. Break Up the Orioles Baltimore shut down the White Sox, 9-0. Their first victory of the season put an end to a 21-game streak that set an American League record for most consecutive losses. Page 51. Oil Producers Optimistic An OPEC majority has agreed to reduce output, while the governments of Saudi Arabia and its allies reconsider the plan. Page 37. Gauguin Show Opens in Washington ''Tahitian Pastorals,'' on loan from the Hermitage in Leningrad, is among the 300 works at the National Gallery of Art through July. page 13)

title: Bush Vows to Retaliate if Democratic Hopefuls Press 'Sleaze' Issue
description: Vice President Bush said today that he had some ''cannon fodder'' to use if the two Democratic Presidential contenders accused Republicans of conflicts of interest or other unethical activities.

title: Panel to Seek Hostile Takeover of Lilco
description: Four days after increasing its offer to buy the Long Island Lighting Company, a state power authority voted today to wage a proxy battle for control of the utility.

title: Joel Webber, 33, Dies; Rock Record Executive
description: Joel Webber, vice president for artists and repertory at Island Records, died Thursday at his home in New York after a heart attack associated with Marfan's syndrome, a congenital disease primarily of tall people. He was 33 years old.

title:
PATENTS;
Device Helps Control Bubbles in Test Liquids
description: LEAD: Two staff scientists at the National Institutes of Health were granted a patent this week for a device that helps keep bubbles from hindering the testing of liquids. Stephen B. Leighton and G. Maret Maxwell got patent 4,740,709, assigning it to the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: MOB ROLE IN NEW YORK CONSTRUCTION DEPICTED
description: Organized crime controls 75 percent of the construction industry in New York City through its control over the concrete industry and construction unions, an admitted mob captain told Senators today.

title: Edberg Is Seeded No. 1
description: Although he was seeded No. 1 yesterday, Stefan Edberg of Sweden will not necessarily be favored to win the Eagle Tournament of Champions, which begins Monday at Forest Hills. Edberg, whose first match will be against one of the qualifiers competing this weekend, is a serve-and-volleyer whose game is not especially suited for the Har-Tru synthetic clay surface.

title: Correction
description: An article on Tuesday about a crackdown on illegal duck hunting on Long Island, with a list of people cited or charged, supplied by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, included a name erroneously. John Kanas of Mattituck, L.I., was not cited and should not have been listed.

title: Feldstein Sees Lower Dollar
description: The United States dollar is likely to continue to drop in value against the Japanese yen and the German mark so the United States can attract foreign investment to finance large deficits, the economist Martin S. Feldstein said Thursday night.

title: Alvan Adams Retires
description: Alvan Adams broke into the National Basketball Association impressively as a high-post center with the Phoenix Suns during the 1975-76 season. But in the 12 seasons after leading the Suns to the N.B.A. championship round against Boston and being named the Rookie of the Year, the 6-foot-9-inch center from the University of Oklahoma was never able to equal his first season totals in five categories: 1,519 points, 512 rebounds, 450 assists, 121 steals or 116 shots blocked.

title: 'I Am a Jelly-Filled Doughnut'
description: Putting words into a President's mouth, or attributing fabricated quotes, as former White House spokesman Larry Speakes admitted he did for President Reagan, may on occasion be preferable to having a President utter clever words dreamed up by his speech writers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy
